# 古书隐楼藏书

**The Jade Garden Altar Sutra**
*Expounded by Wang Changyue, the Seventh Generation Successor of the Dragon Gate Lineage of the Complete Perfection Tradition, a High Daoist of the Great Qing; Compiled by Precept Disciple Shi Shouping of the Eighth Generation; Collated by Min Yide, Eleventh Generation Descendant*

**Volume One**

**I. The True Words of the Mind-Dharma**
In the second year of the Kangxi reign, the cyclical year *guimao* (1663), on an auspicious day in the tenth month, Master Kunyang expounded the precepts at the Jade Garden in Jinling. Addressing Master Ningzhen Shao Shoushan and Master Fuyao Zhan Shouchun, he said:

"From my youth, I aspired to the Dao, seeing through the insubstantiality of floating life and the impermanence of illusory realms. To escape the wheel of rebirth, one must early cultivate the supreme Dao. Yet though Mount Kongtong lies near, Master Guangcheng would not deign to meet me; though Penglai is not distant, how could a mortal’s body ever reach it? One must resolutely depart from defilement, sweep away all dust, purge the heart’s chamber, and purify the will—grinding away ingrained habits until worldly thoughts turn to ash, scouring the desirous self until deluded roots are severed.

All conditions cease at once, each step taken within the discipline of precepts and stillness; all thoughts dissolve into emptiness, each layer perceived through wisdom. If you can break free, you may attain samādhi; if you see through, you may endure. Thus, I raise my brows and wield the blade to sever attachments; I stride forth and board the vessel to ferry across the world. A turn of the body brings liberation from rebirth; a shift in thought transcends the snares of the net.

With compassion unceasing, as the ancients said, one first delivers oneself, then others; with mercy ever-present, I vow to deliver myself, then all beings. I recall my early years of seeking truth and visiting Daoist masters—once I journeyed to Wangwu Mountain and encountered an enlightened teacher. Above, I received the boundless grace of the Three Treasures and heard the sacred Dharma; below, I relied on my own strength to endure austerities and cultivate the body. I took refuge in the peerless Dharma King and practiced the wondrous Dao of the Great Vehicle.

Now, in this flourishing age of peace and prosperity—a rarity across ten thousand kalpas, a sight scarce in a thousand lifetimes—how dare I not propagate the Three Treasures to repay the Four Graces! Let me fulfill even a droplet of my vow and offer the light of my humble heart. Thus, undeterred by my presumptuous transgressions, I open the altar to expound the precepts; unshaken by scorn and slander, I teach and discourse on the scriptures. This is not for the sake of seeking fame through good deeds, but to dispel delusion and refute heresy.

Heaven’s law brooks no embellishment; the supreme Dao resides in plain speech. I now impart the ancestral teachings of the Seventh Generation of the Dragon Gate, sharing them with all present. Humbly recording the unvarnished words of the Jade Garden, may they universally benefit beings in the heavens and the world. I dare not indulge in empty rhetoric; why not speak plainly? Today, I transmit this to you, rightly guiding the deluded and clarifying the true Dharma. As for those of superior capacity—keen-eyed adepts of the highest vehicle—this poor Daoist stands humbly before you, eager to receive your compassionate instruction and verify what I have heard. Such is my wish."

The two disciples, having heard this teaching, bowed and withdrew, standing in order to the east and west. Then Precept Disciple Shi Shouping of Guangling prostrated himself and intoned:

"The Dharma is no-Dharma, for the mind has it;
The mind is no-mind, for the Dharma is empty.
The mind manifests the Dharma King, the mind manifests form;
The Dharma returns to the mind’s master, the Dharma returns to emptiness.
To understand the fixed Dharma is not the perfect sign,
One must realize the ordinary mind is the sage’s mind.
Mind-Dharma, Dharma-mind, mind-Dharma-Dharma,
The Dharma-mind’s liberation is the knowing friend."

**II. Taking Refuge in the Three Treasures**
The Three Treasures are the Dao, the Scriptures, and the Masters. The Dao is originally empty, formless and nameless; without the scriptures, it cannot be made manifest. The Dao resides within the scriptures, profound and subtle; without a master, one cannot grasp its principles. Those who fail to take refuge in the Three Treasures will surely sink into heterodox paths, lost in confusion and delusion.

All who cultivate truth and study the Dao, with sincere devotion, must regard this as a rare and precious encounter. First, take refuge in the peerless Treasure of the Dao, vowing that all beings may eternally attend the Heavenly Worthy and forever escape the wheel of rebirth. Second, take refuge in the peerless Treasure of the Scriptures, vowing that all beings may, in every life, hear the true Dharma. Third, take refuge in the peerless Treasure of the Master, vowing that all beings may study the supreme vehicle and avoid false views.

These Three Refuges are the first step on the ascending path by which the sages of old guided people into the Dao, the foremost gateway to entering virtue. Whether attaining immortality, the Dao, sagehood, or worthiness, none do not begin with these Three Refuges. Why? Because the great matter of life and death, of nature and destiny, is subtle and secret, difficult to see or hear. The supreme, liberating Dharma of the Great Vehicle—without a true master’s compassionate guidance to awaken the spiritual faculty, how could one suddenly awaken to the orthodox lineage of the Great Vehicle, gradually enter the wondrous Dao of emptiness, and avoid falling into false views or straying into side doors?

Thus, those who have yet to understand the Dao first take refuge in the scriptures. Those who have yet to understand the scriptures first take refuge in the master. If one can take refuge in the Treasure of the Master, then the Treasure of the Scriptures may be heard where once it was unheard. If one can hear the Treasure of the Scriptures, then the Treasure of the Dao may be seen where once it was unseen. What was once invisible and inaudible may suddenly become thoroughly clear—all through the power of taking refuge in the Treasure of the Master. Naturally, one comprehends the true texts, gains insight into the correct Dharma, transcends birth and death, and avoids the wheel of rebirth.

Yet the Three Refuges of which I speak must be the true Three Treasures. Why? Let all here present—"

Nowadays, the Three Refuges are treated as mere routine—morning and evening, one bows before sacred images and recites the words by rote, yet never truly penetrates the essence of refuge, never asks: *For what purpose do I take refuge?* Thus, one remains sunk in delusion and heterodox teachings, unable to escape the wheel of rebirth. How then can one comprehend the Great Dao and transcend birth and death?

The true Three Treasures are these: In taking refuge with *intent*, one stills the arising and ceasing of thoughts, and the Treasure of the Dao may be realized. In taking refuge with the *mind*, one removes all obstructions to awareness, and the Treasure of the Scriptures may be awakened to. In taking refuge with the *body*, one ensures the eyes see nothing, the ears hear nothing, the nose smells nothing, the tongue tastes nothing, the hands do not move in vain, the feet do not wander astray—free from defilement and lust, one practices ascetic discipline, exhausting sinew and bone, starving flesh and skin, subduing the limbs, and relinquishing the form. Then the Treasure of the Master may be truly felt.

Only when one moves the master’s compassion to transmit the scriptures and impart the Dao must one first take refuge in one’s own body, mind, and intent as the true Three Treasures. If the ears and eyes of this body cannot forget seeing and hearing, one is either deluded by form or attached to sound. As long as sound and form remain, the body is not true—how then can it move the master? But if one holds the body upright, nurtures the spiritual root in the mind, and unites intent with the unchanging truth, then thought after thought abides in emptiness, profoundly still and serene—this is called taking refuge in the Three Treasures. When the body is free from lust, the Treasure of the Master may be felt; when the mind is not obscured, the Treasure of the Scriptures may be awakened to; when intent is undivided, the Treasure of the Dao may be realized.

A steadfast body preserves essence and strengthens the form; a luminous mind purifies qi and sharpens wisdom; a sincere intent gathers spirit and reveals nature. When essence and qi are full, spirit and intelligence transform—mysterious and unfathomable—all arising from taking refuge in the Three Treasures of one’s own body, mind, and intent. From these, the Dao, the scriptures, and the master emerge.

Now, how does one take refuge in body, mind, and intent? All of you, listen with single-minded attention, for I shall now explain the method of taking refuge in the Three Treasures of body, mind, and intent, that you may shatter darkness and dispel doubt.

All of you! This body is formed from the union of father’s essence and mother’s blood, its temperament, countenance, and limbs all grown within the womb. A mass of filth, a sack of the four elements—eyes seeing, ears hearing, feet moving, hands swaying, mouth speaking, tongue tasting—nothing enduring or inherently good. Those who use it well become immortals, buddhas, sages, and worthies; those who misuse it become demons, monsters, ghosts, and beasts. A single turn upward ascends to heaven; a single turn downward descends to hell. Those who receive blessings treat it as an external thing; those who receive suffering make it their foundation.

Moreover, all of you who have left the household life and seek to transcend birth and death must take refuge in this body—only then is it secure. Otherwise, the six senses turn outward, the three poisons arise within, and the ten thousand calamities, thousand disasters, nine demons, and ten hardships all stem from the body. How then can one cultivate and enter the Dao?

If you wish to take refuge, there is but one method to subdue this body: uphold the precepts and restrain the unruly form. Let the four great deportments—walking, standing, sitting, lying—be governed with dignity. Let the ears not hear sound, the eyes not see form; let your bearing be majestic, your appearance serene, your demeanor compassionate, so that all who see you rejoice and feel reverence. When the precepts harness the wild body and transform it into a vessel of Dharma, then the Treasure of the Master may be taken refuge in.

All of you! This first method has now been made clear. Next, you must take refuge in the mind. All of you! This mind is not the same as this body.

The perilous and unfathomable transformations are like wind blowing over the sea—its waters vast and deep, the wind’s force surging fiercely, waves and tides churning violently, rising and falling unpredictably, shifting and turning without reliance. Since beginningless kalpas, this has been called "no day of deliverance" and "the boundless sea of suffering."

If you now wish to take refuge in this mind, you must recognize that this mind is but a mass of blood and flesh, no enduring or inherently good thing. It delights in sounds and pleasures, unafraid of transgressing the law or incurring punishment; it craves fine food and wealth, heedless of losing life itself. It sinks into the realms of hungry ghosts and beasts without fear, submits to knife mountains and charcoal fires without alarm; it drifts through plagues and pestilence without hesitation, conjures falling stars and crumbling mountains without avoidance. All manner of calamitous causes arise from this mind’s beckoning. The six thieves serve as its vanguard, the seven emotions as its generals.

If you seek to cultivate the Way yet do not first take refuge in this mind, how can you subdue demons and tame monsters, dispel obstacles and expel evil, penetrate the primordial mechanism, attain the true Dharma, delve deeply into the宗旨, and ascend directly to the supreme vehicle? Yet to restrain this mind, you must abide by the precepts, enter samādhi with a tranquil mind, rein in the steed and wield the whip, turn back the wind and extinguish the flames. When the fire of ignorance arises in this mind, quell it with the water of forbearance. Transform raging flames into the wind of wisdom, transmute ignorance into great insight. Shift evil causes into good fruits, dissolve grievances into joy. Sweep away sounds and forms as mere dust, turn indolence into reverence. Let no delusion or filth arise, no discrimination between right and wrong, no conflict between departure and stay, no vacillation between rise and fall, no shifting between gain and loss. Naturally, the qi settles and the mind becomes still; the mind still, the qi settles. Then the Treasure of the Sūtras may be taken refuge in.

All of you! Once the power of samādhi has tamed this wild, fleshy mind, the waves grow calm and the wind stills, the moon rises over placid waters, the pearl radiates its light, wisdom penetrates the sūtras’ store, and insight comprehends their teachings. Next, you must take refuge in this intent. This intent is even harder to restrain than the mind. The mind seeks rectitude, while intent lies in sincerity. Sincerity means meticulous care. In samādhi, within stillness, all is vividly clear, not a hair’s breadth concealed, undivided and unceasing, movement and stillness as one, light shining universally.

Thus, until you take refuge in intent, you must guard against the mind in samādhi and stillness. It may stealthily seize control, its mechanisms shifting and deceitful; its illusions branching and divergent, now coming, now going. It devises myriad paths, vanishing and arising in an instant; its waves churn in cunning forms, like dragon or tiger. It cannot be grasped—now shadow, now wind; though you may seize it, no form is visible. A crossbow’s trigger looses a thousand *jun* in silence; a single drop steers a ten-thousand-*hu* boat, scheming with boundless calculations. Its spiritual powers are unfathomable—stealing the sun and swapping the sky, its stratagems without limit.

Once you take refuge in intent, it dissolves like ice melting or tiles crumbling, and all things return to spring. You may then enter sagehood and attain the real, ascend as an immortal and realize the Dao. In the world, you may transform and guide others, bringing order to the state and peace to the people, harmonious seasons and abundant harvests, loyalty, filial piety, integrity, and chastity. The Three Bonds and Five Constants arise from sincere intent; the Nine Schools and Three Teachings emerge from sincere intent. Between sincerity and insincerity lie fortune and misfortune, calamity and blessing, good and ill, prosperity and adversity—all hinge upon this intent as the cause of life and death, the karmic retribution of saṃsāra.

All of you! Without taking refuge in this intent, this mind will never find peace. If you seek peace, take refuge in this intent. The light of wisdom will naturally shine brightly, and awakening will clarify all things. Before this thought arises, it is limpid and clear; the moment it stirs, it becomes either evil or good. Do not obscure the radiant light—its mechanism turns on the pivot, stars follow the Dipper’s course. When this intent is sincere, you may wield the power over life and death; when it is not, who holds the handle of saṃsāra?

All of you! Within your own mind lies the Treasure of Intent—a single thought of true purity can reach the heavens above and move the netherworld below. Ghosts and spirits pale before this intent; sun and moon lose their light; creation forfeits its power; yin and yang lose their balance; demons and monsters flee its presence; the rise and fall of beings depend upon it. Within the Three Realms, intent reigns supreme. Let it loose, and it exists; gather it in, and it vanishes. Free and unbounded, nothing lies beyond this intent.

Above, it ascends to the Primordial Breath as ancestral qi; in the middle, it returns to the Numinous Treasure as Brahmanic qi; below, it relies on the Most High as true qi. Stretching forth, it becomes vast qi; congealing, it becomes primordial qi; compassionate and benevolent, it becomes yang qi; sorrowful and wrathful, it becomes yin qi; greedy, wrathful, restless, and violent, it becomes blood qi; lewd, murderous, thieving, and deluded, it becomes evil qi; clinging and obstructed, it becomes demonic qi; cruel, dark, and ignorant, it becomes monstrous qi; oppressive and vengeful, it becomes resentful qi.

All these arise because you, all of you, do not take refuge in the Treasure of the Master with your bodies, indulging in fierceness and strength; do not take refuge in the Treasure of the Sūtras with your minds, mired in confusion and darkness; do not take refuge in the Treasure of the Dao with your intent, entangled in endless complications. Partiality and insincerity lead to losing the center; losing the center, wisdom’s light does not arise, samādhi’s power is not firm, precepts are not strictly observed, spirit does not congeal, qi does not gather, essence does not transform. Thus, the body cannot be cultivated, the mind cannot be stilled, and intent cannot be made sincere.

All of you! I now clearly expound the great Dao, pointing directly to the human mind. If you do not swiftly subdue body, mind, and intent, transforming them into the true body of the Three Treasures, and escape saṃsāra, then one by one take refuge in the world’s awakened ones, the forerunners who knew the Dao, the sūtra-teachers of the Three Treasures—you will have squandered the fine karmic conditions of leaving the household life.

If any among you can rely on the three great Dharma gates of precepts, samādhi, and wisdom, practice with unwavering faith, without wavering or regret, know that such a person will surely attain the Dao. But if there is the slightest deviation, an inability to adhere, or personal negligence, know that such a person bears deep transgressions and meager blessings, cannot comprehend the Dao, and will not be tolerated by the gods—how then could they hear the supreme, most true, pure, and liberated Dao?

Should you encounter such individuals, take care not to rebuke them in anger. Instead, cultivate compassion, employ tactful means, and skillfully guide them onto the Way—this is what it means to take refuge in the Three Treasures.

Thereupon, the precept-disciples bowed their heads in reverence and took refuge, reciting these verses:

The great Dao is clear and empty, beyond all naming;
Through subtle, wondrous sūtras, it is set into script.
Were it not for the master’s exposition of the primal principle,
How could the muddled and deluded ever come to clarity?

Clarity unbroken is called Perfection;
Attaining the true origin, one transcends life and death.
The forerunners who knew, with earnest compassion,
Guide the boundless worthy and good to the gate.

III. Repentance of Transgressions (with appended repentance and vow text)

Disciples!
Having taken refuge in the Three Treasures, you must now uphold and cultivate the wondrous practices.

The Most High has said: Misfortune and blessing have no fixed gate; they are summoned by one’s own actions. The retribution of good and evil follows like a shadow after form. Thus, heaven and earth possess spirits that oversee transgressions, and according to the severity of one’s offenses, they diminish one’s allotted lifespan. The transgressions, great and small, number in the hundreds. Those who seek long life must first avoid them.

Transgressions refer to faults and errors. Nowadays, those who cultivate the Way often obscure their innate knowing, deceive their original nature, see only the faults of others, and remain unaware of their own. This very unawareness of one’s own faults already deepens the sin and weighs down the karma. How can one who deceives heart and self ever enter the Dao? Therefore, repentance is necessary.

Repentance means reverently facing the sacred and true, daring not to conceal past wrongs, and solemnly vowing never to repeat former misdeeds. Only thus can one advance.

I shall now, without hesitation, expose the worldly deceit of heart and self, making it plain for all to see. Disciples, listen closely, and you will understand.

Now, what are the deeds of deceiving heart and self?
One’s mouth speaks in lofty, expansive terms, while the heart covets wealth and property;
Outwardly, one maintains appearances, but inwardly schemes and plots;
One receives precepts but does not observe them, urges others yet fears no censure;
Outwardly a Daoist, secretly consorting with the unruly;
Words spoken in the hall are untrusted, yet in public affairs, one constantly conceals faults;
Hearing the Dao but not practicing it, knowing the Dharma yet willfully violating it;
Using cunning to deceive the foolish, seizing advantages as a matter of course;
Habitually stirring ignorance, often acting stubbornly;
Taking non-being for being, being for non-being;
Treating the false as true, the true as false;
Calling a deer a horse, selling dogs as sheep;
In the dark, betraying conscience; in broad daylight, playing tricks;
Plotting in secret, hiding daggers behind smiles.

Such manifold perverse actions, each one a departure from the Way—there is none that one does not know oneself. Those who do not know are fools, the deluded, the confused, the reckless. But those who know yet willfully transgress are the treacherous, the wicked, the perverse, the petty. Are these not deceivers of heart and self? Their transgressions far exceed those of the foolish and deluded.

Why is this so?
The foolish, lacking wisdom, err unknowingly. Their harm is limited to themselves and cannot extend to others; if they harm others, they will ultimately be harmed in return. Only the treacherous, with their cunning and malice, harm others to benefit themselves while deceiving their own hearts, striving to ensure that heaven and earth remain unaware of their schemes, and ghosts and spirits oblivious to their evil.

They weave intricate deceptions, yet always conceal their actions;
They plot in secret, yet cunningly patch over their faults;
They set snares for others, yet others do not perceive where the traps are laid;
They push others into wells, yet none can fathom who dug them.

Such people exist in great numbers in the world. Yet they have no place in the practice of cultivation.

Before taking refuge in the Three Jewels, if one harbored such a mind, now that the precepts have been received, one must transform and reform, swiftly seeking repentance.

In recent times, the primordial wind has waned, precepts and disciplines have slackened, the Dao’s transformation has declined, and the teachings of the Yellow Crowns have been lost. Repeatedly instructed by the feathered and flowing-robed, many violate the rules and breach the precepts.

I now spare no effort in earnest admonition, exhorting and urging all. Not only should the sins of karmic transmigration through kalpas be repented, the sins of parents through many lives be repented, and the sins of present parents and nine ancestors and seven progenitors be repented—even the sins of one’s own past must be swiftly swept clean in the secret chamber of the mind.

All unrighteous deluded thoughts, every trace of errant念, must be repented for past wrongs and regretted for former transgressions, only then can one achieve the fruits of the Dao. Otherwise, like covering one’s ears to steal a bell, how can liberation be attained? The Great Dao is far indeed.

I now compose a repentance and vow text for all to recite morning and evening.

**Repentance and Vow Text**

We, the assembly of disciples, since receiving the precepts until now, have merely indulged in the empty name of precept-holding, failing to uphold them in truth. Robes and crowns are falsely assumed, rules and alms bowls are hollowly transmitted. We neither advance diligently in the initial truth nor avoid falling into the depths of transgression and fault. Lacking wisdom in the heart, we fail to earnestly seek guidance from enlightened masters; our nature, stirred by ignorance, often struggles to endure humiliation among our kind. With narrow minds, we cannot embrace compassion; with biased and deviant thoughts, we commit many offenses. Failing to perceive true awakening, we mistake illusion for reality; not examining causes, we take thieves for sons. We regard the virtuous as wicked, inverting right and wrong; we mistake gentlemen for petty men, confusing truth and falsehood. Some mislead donors in karmic causes, pocketing alms for private gain; some recite scriptures with erroneous words, oblivious to their meaning. Some are stirred by lust at the sight of beauty; some doubt and boast upon hearing sacred words. Such corrupt conduct forever binds us to the mundane.

If we do not renew ourselves from now on, as the day wanes and the path ends, we shall inevitably sink like stones to the ocean’s depths. If we continue recklessly, when the bell tolls and the clepsydra runs dry, we shall only then know the sword trees and blade mountains.

Therefore, with the offerings of heart-incense, heart-lamp, and heart-water, we exhaust the sincerity of taking refuge in body, mind, and life. Moment by moment, we gaze toward the cinnabar heavens to plead for mercy; morning and evening, we look up to the golden palace to offer our devotion. With the reverence of fasting and bathing, we spare no toil. Turning around, we bow repeatedly to the compassion of our masters, setting up offerings and imploring: May Heaven forgive!

From now on, may we eradicate all evil and forever become good and virtuous people; from this day forward, may we rouse ourselves to serve the true and painstakingly uphold the initial precepts. Should we violate these precepts again, may we suffer heavenly punishment in life and fall into Fengdu in death; if we defy the former statutes, may we endure extreme punishment in the yang world and be buried in the Avīci hell in the yin realm.

Yet after repentance, may sins vanish and blessings arise, disasters dissolve and calamities be released, ice melt on the ground of awakening, and the moon of understanding shine forth. May the dark chamber regain its light, the sun of wisdom illuminate the black night; may the sprout of goodness grow, sweet dew drip upon withered branches. May the primordial net be restored with benevolence, and the Dharma rain abundantly bestow reviving grace. May our black records be erased and our names inscribed in the azure registers. Through diligent cultivation of great samādhi, may our true bodies be preserved. May the eight consciousnesses be relinquished, the hundred obstacles and thousand demons disperse like clouds; may the three lives be thoroughly understood, and the nine ancestors and seven progenitors ascend to the rosy clouds. May the divine wind spread far, and the myriad qi flourish. May the ancestral teachings be perpetually revived, and the lineage’s threads flow unbroken to the ancestral seat. May our conduct and concealment be auspicious, ending the winds and waves of the world beyond; may our seclusion and emergence be peaceful, enjoying the sun and moon within the gourd. Again, we vow for masters and disciples, fellow students, family and clan, all beings on earth, and all benefactors under heaven—may each person’s mind-ground be illuminated, and their nature-sky radiant. May the times be harmonious and the years abundant, the nation prosperous and the people at peace. May weapons be laid down, and water and fire balanced. May the imperial domain be secure, and the emperor’s reign enduring. May the sage-emperor live ten thousand years, and his ministers be virtuous. May all people share sincerity, and all lands delight in the Dao. Together with all beings, may we return to purity and stillness.

May the sacred compassion deign to bestow salvation.

**The above Repentance and Vow Text is to be recited devoutly morning and evening.** One must face the Dharma-body and the Emperor of Heaven with every thought sincere, every heart contrite, reciting each sentence clearly and each word with repentant hesitation, advancing with courage and diligence. Whether in life or death, hardship or hunger, all must be relinquished. Only by embracing precepts and samādhi can one have a future.

*Green Garden Altar Sutra, Volume One*
*4. Removing Obstacles*

For those who cultivate the Way, if obstacles remain unsevered, the mind becomes obstructed and benighted; if hindrances are not dispelled, one grows dull and dim. The essence of the heart is originally one with heaven and sun, yet deluded emotions resemble floating clouds. When mist veils the azure sky, how can the bright sun shine forth? When passions delude the numinous apertures, how can the true mechanism attain perfect penetration? Is this not the gravest malady of the cultivator?

Now I reveal the root of this malady: among Daoist obstacles, there are two kinds—one called *li-zhang* (obstacles of principle), the other *shi-zhang* (obstacles of phenomena). Without clarity in phenomena, truth and falsehood cannot be distinguished; without clarity in principle, right and wrong cannot be discerned. If one clings to principle while discussing phenomena, rigid and pedantic, this becomes an obstacle of principle to the heart. If one acts in ways that harm principle, perverse and wayward, this becomes a thief to one’s nature—an obstacle of phenomena. Whether in principle or phenomena, any attachment whatsoever constitutes an obstacle.

Now I shall expound upon these two characters, *zhang-ai* (obstacles). All the thousands of scriptures and myriad canons are the teachings of those who awakened first, intending that later generations practice goodness, learn virtue, awaken to the Dao, and cultivate truth. Yet beings do not practice goodness but instead commit evil; they do not learn virtue but instead learn wickedness; they do not cultivate truth but instead engage in pretense; they do not awaken to the Dao but instead corrupt the teachings—this is called the *shi-zhang* (obstacle of phenomena) obscuring the original heart.

There are also those who have left the household life, practicing goodness and clinging to goodness, learning virtue and clinging to virtue, cultivating truth and taking it as real, awakening to the Dao yet attaching to forms and chasing traces. All this stems from an inability to liberate themselves from what they deem good—this is called the *li-zhang* (obstacle of principle) obscuring the original heart.

Yet even those with these two obstacles—of principle and phenomena—are still a class of superior cultivators. There is another class of practitioners whose hearts remain unenlightened, whose celestial mechanism has not turned. Everywhere they go, obstacles arise. When they see those of us who have ascended, expounding sutras and teaching precepts, they outwardly praise but inwardly stir ignorance, generating obstructive thoughts and igniting deluded impulses.

Disciples, if this obstructive heart is not eradicated, how can one escape the sea of suffering? Though the boat and raft, sail and oar are clearly at hand—enabling one to cross—yet one cannot cross, dares not cross. What is the reason? Know this: this obstructive heart is like a sudden surge of dark clouds, billowing forth, threatening wind and rain, inevitably bringing perilous waves and treacherous swells. Thus, one dares not cross, cannot cross.

Disciples, the sea of suffering is incomparable; to turn back is to reach the shore. The obstacles of the cultivator resemble black clouds rising on all sides, shrouding the heavens in deception. Yet once severed, the waves grow still and the winds calm, allowing one to cross the sea of suffering in peace and ease.

Have you not heard what is said in the *Highest Emperor’s Original Deeds Sutra*? “Only because beings’ obstacles are heavy do they fail to behold the compassionate countenance of the Supreme Emperor.” It also states: “All such obstacles—each of you must sever them.” Thus, the *August Sutra* begins by proclaiming the severance of obstacles.

The method for severing obstacles lies in generating great wisdom: do not arouse doubt, do not arouse greed or anger, do not arouse lust, do not arouse jealousy, do not arouse killing or harm, do not arouse mundane emotions, do not arouse mundane thoughts, do not arouse dullness or filth, do not arouse sound or form, do not arouse right or wrong, do not arouse love or hatred, do not arouse discrimination, do not arouse arrogance, do not arouse attachment. Concentrate the spirit and settle the thoughts; regulate and subdue the myriad spirits. Let the heart be as vast as the great void, inwardly and outwardly pure. Embrace all without exclusion, receive all without rejection. Do not allow external deviance to disturb the supreme Dao, dragging one from the true source, corrupting the numinous root, and stealing the supreme treasure. Thus, for ten thousand kalpas, one remains forever mired in the mundane, ensnared in the worldly net. Myriad demons assail, and for hundreds of thousands of kalpas, one does not hear the wondrous Dharma. Ghosts and spirits execute punishment, passing from life to death.

Therefore, each of you must resolve with wholehearted sincerity to guard the true source, lest it be lost. As previously stated, sever each of these—these are all clauses of obstacles. If not severed, the six senses become defiled, the three karmas entangled, and purity cannot be attained. Without purity, how can one behold the compassionate countenance of the Supreme Emperor? How can the seventeen great lights of illumination and the thirty kinds of virtue and power arise? Thus, the light and virtue of the Supreme Emperor, the sacred teachers of all buddhas, and the lords of the ten thousand heavens—all the wondrous canons of three volumes and five ranks—are perfected through the severance of obstacles.

Disciples, the obstacles in the world are manifold. The *August Sutra* merely points out the main events and categories, allowing you to grasp the general outline and understand the gateway to heavenly principle. You must realize that the subtle obstacles in the world are countless, myriad in form. With every thought and movement, they are too numerous to enumerate.

For instance, when reading scriptures and reciting canons, if the profound and subtle meanings remain obscure and one’s own wisdom is limited, unable to comprehend, one should recognize that the apertures of the heart are not yet awakened, and the light of wisdom is dim. Yet if one is unwilling to humble oneself and inquire of the wise, this is dullness and filth. Even after inquiring, if doubt arises—fearing the other’s words may not be true—and one asks another, only to find their answers differ, the heart grows vexed. With a thousand paths and ten thousand teachings, is this not an obstacle?

Or when companions read scriptures together, if another is more familiar while one is not, and vexation arises—is this not an obstacle? Conversely, if one is more familiar while the companion lags, and joy arises—is this not an obstacle? Or if one possesses talent while another is dull, and deceit arises—is this not an obstacle? Or upon seeing others do good—whether through almsgiving or meritorious deeds—if they are rich while one is poor, jealousy arises; if one is rich while they are lacking, arrogance arises. Is this not an obstacle?

Or when reading scriptures, if one suddenly gains insight, faintly comprehending the principle, and clings to it as truth, expounding it to others—yet if another is more enlightened and one’s heart refuses to submit—is this not an obstacle?

Or when cultivating through seated meditation, should one chance upon a wondrous state and boast of it—is this not an obstacle? Or when hearing profound principles, clinging to them in the mind, knowing only one aspect without adaptability—is this not an obstacle? Or when fellow Dao companions gather to receive the master’s teaching, and the master says another is bright while one is dull, yet instead of self-reproach, one envies the other’s advancement—is this not an obstacle?

As for hoarding wealth and possessions, refusing to part with even a single coin at death; all attachments to love, craving, and indulgence—unbroken, unremoved—whether fondness for zithers or books, for chess or paintings, every kind of fixation—all are obstacles. Or there are those who regard talismanic arts as divine and wondrous; others who dismiss them as inferior, contrived methods. If they delight while one resents, or one favors while they despise—all are obstacles.

Disciples, since you seek liberation from the world and wish to escape the cycle of rebirth, you must cultivate the work of transcendence and bear the Dao’s vocation of transcendence. These obstacles are but veils that clog the gate of spirit, demonic mists that delude the nature of awakening—how then can you attain liberation? If you are willing to sever each of these tangled hindrances, cutting away their roots entirely, dispelling distracting thoughts, and making the breast as vast and boundless as the great void, then the heart will flow freely, infinitely luminous, and wisdom will arise of itself, the celestial nature shining clear. Within it, the myriad wondrous functions—mechanisms of life and death, coming and going, the unity of heaven and humanity—will unfold naturally, beyond what knowledge can grasp!

Ah!

Obstacles, obstacles! They lie solely in whether the multitude can sever them or not. Thereupon the preceptor of the precepts expounded the Dharma, saying: "From the first bestowal of the celestial mandate, the luminous decree is no empty thing. The mirror of the spirit’s terrace shines so clear that not even the finest filament can be concealed. Once the breast is suddenly swept clean and vast, the eye’s vision instantly becomes limpid and bright."

V. Abandoning and Severing the Bonds of Love
All of you, you have now seen how obstacles bring harm. Yet the harm of the bonds of love is even more dire than that of obstacles. How so? The mind of obstacles arises only when encountering circumstances, and vanishes once the circumstances pass—its harm comes and goes in an instant. But the two words "bonds of love" are karmic roots planted from beginningless kalpas down to this present life. Thus the sages, immortals, and buddhas have all exhorted sentient beings not to cling to appearances, not to be bound by attachments, not to indulge in craving. The scriptures of the Three Teachings all urge later generations of the world not to be ensnared by the bonds of love. These bonds of love are the progenitor of all demons, the root of all harm. Repeated kalpas of delusion, countless lives of downfall—all stem from the bonds of love. Failure to attain the Way of liberation, failure to comprehend the principle of true emptiness—all stem from the bonds of love. In life, one incurs the penalties of the law; in death, one sinks into hell—all stem from the bonds of love. Drowning in floods, perishing in fires, slaughter by bandits, death by the sword—all stem from the bonds of love. The ruin of clans and the extinction of heirs, the breaking of precepts and the violation of rules—all stem from the bonds of love. Nine generations suffer calamity, ancestral sacrifices decline—all stem from the bonds of love. Birth, aging, sickness, death; the perversity of nature and mind; the frailty of the body; the stagnation of the Dao and its methods—all stem from the bonds of love. The six senses are impure, the six thieves run rampant, the six consciousnesses discriminate, the six paths revolve in rebirth—all stem from the bonds of love. Within heaven and earth, amid the five phases, the flourishing and withering of the myriad things, the arising and ceasing of the ten thousand kinds—all stem from the bonds of love.

If you wish to leave the world, to transcend birth and death, yet do not seek to sever and abandon these bonds, to cut off love and forsake attachment, and still hope to be lucid and clear, pure and undefiled, free and liberated—such a thing has never existed. Let me first speak of the bonds of love among the laity in the world: between ruler and minister, father and child, husband and wife, elder and younger brothers, friends. The ancient sages have already spoken of the five relationships, the five restraints, the five perversions, and how to bring forth all that is harmonious and fitting, loving kin and honoring the worthy, each according to its proper measure. Within this innate luminous essence, they established distinctions and cultivated refinement, each rectifying its nature and destiny, thereby preserving the great harmony of the cosmos. The primordial qi, vast and undifferentiated, requires no further severing of the bonds of love—it is purely the natural, tranquil, liberated Way. But let us set that aside for now and speak only of those who have left the household life—today’s assembly of benefactors here in this garden. You must thoroughly purge all extraneous bonds of love. As for all that is properly within your sphere and might be deemed lovable, you must not love it. Like bonds that have an end, you must examine each one clearly and restrain it with discipline, cutting it off in the past.

All of you, the delusion of the bonds of love—you are utterly unaware of it. How so? Whatever the mind delights in and clings to is called the bonds of love: all things, great or small, refined or coarse; all people, kin or stranger, near or far...

All matters of internal and external, right and wrong, true and false;
All teachings of the Three Teachings—Confucianism, Buddhism, and Daoism—of sages and worthies;
All principles within scriptures, texts, and classical records;
All marvels of heaven and earth, yin and yang, creation and transformation;
All arts of the divine, primordial, illusory, and fantastical;
All paths of Qingwei, Lingbao, Quanzhen, and the Dao—
Even the grotto-heavens and blessed abodes, the celestial palaces and sacred realms;
Even the seven treasures, eight rarities, River Chart, and tortoise omens.

As for one’s own body and mind, the five viscera and six bowels, teeth and tongue, essence and qi, mountains and rivers, the great earth, grasses and trees, birds and beasts, insects and worms—whatever the thought covets, the mind dwells upon, the heart imagines, the spirit fixates on, the emotions cling to, the nature delights in, the mouth desires, the body enjoys, or the dreams wander through—all are bonds of love. If even a single thought lingers, it becomes an entanglement, preventing the attainment of the pure, tranquil, liberated Way, and one remains forever a deluded, suffering being.

Assembly, when deluded, the bonds of love arise; when awakened, the bonds of love vanish. You must be ever vigilant, moment by moment, bearing this truth. If even the slightest attachment to any beloved thing arises in the heart, you must sever it at once, allowing no further conditions to take root. Those who love sleep should sit; those who love sitting should walk; those who love abiding should let the spirit roam freely; those who love nothingness should let the numinous nature become empty. With not a thread clinging, no bonds arise. The awakened one’s heart radiates light, unshaken by circumstances, unmoved by things, undisturbed by affairs. In time, the wondrous, causeless state arises, and the primordial aperture opens.

If today you do not eliminate these bonds, nor sever them tomorrow, if you relinquish them yet fail to cut them off entirely, you remain entangled as before. Then your robe and alms bowl, your meditation cushion, become nets; your straw sandals and bamboo staff, become ropes; sacred mountains and blessed realms, become prisons; fellow disciples and companions, turn into enemies. Even oral instructions and true mantras transform into arsenic and poison; the Dao-heart and original nature become mere karmic rewards and asura realms. How can one not be cautious? How can one not feel anguish? How can one not bear to sever and cut them off entirely?

Long ago, there was a Daoist who sat in meditation for so long that his spirit manifested. He saw a radiant light above his crown, resplendent in five colors, like rosy clouds or brocade. Within that light, mountains and rivers, the great earth, and all things were visible. The Daoist rejoiced in his heart, believing he had attained the great, unobstructed light of the Supreme Emperor. Day and night, he sat upright, contemplating the light, but it never reappeared. Failing to recognize the illusory nature of this vision, he fixated his mind on it, forgetting all other thoughts, thinking only of the light. As he persisted in this contemplation, he grew dull and witless, his body like earth or wood. Others believed he had entered the supreme Dao.

After six years of such sitting and concentration, his spirit congealed and his form altered, yet he remained unaware. One day, his breath grew coarse and labored. His companions kept watch, hoping he would emerge from stillness so they might seek the Dao. Among them, only one practitioner recognized that he had fallen into delusion. At midnight, the meditator suddenly flung his hands outward as if taking flight. The others lit lamps, candles, and incense, making offerings and bowing in reverence. Then, with a final gasp, a moth flew from his mouth and perished in the flame. The practitioner retrieved it and addressed the assembly: “This is the body of the Daoist who fixated on the light. His bond of love for the light made him no different from this moth. As the bond deepened, his form transformed, and he entered another realm. If the bonds of love are not severed, all meet the same fate. How lamentable! How essential it is to cut them off!”

Assembly, whatever the heart loves is a bond; bonds arise from love, and love follows bonds. Bonds and love entwine endlessly, never reaching clarity. Fathers become sons, ancestors become grandchildren, men become women, faces and forms change, names and identities shift. Deluded ordinary beings mistake these for reality—how terrifying, how pitiable!

Assembly, take heed. Six: strict observance of precepts.

The practitioner who has severed love and cast off bonds, sincerely seeking liberation from the world to end the cycle of birth and death—if the bonds of love are not extinguished and desires arise anew, then this heart remains entangled, once more ensnared in the net and trapped in the pitfall, never to attain liberation. One must devise preventive measures before signs appear. Otherwise, past efforts will be wasted in vain, and future demonic obstacles will be inescapable. Thus, one should follow the ancient sages and saints, gathering the mind within the precepts.

This word "precepts" is the vajra that subdues demons, capable of suppressing evil spirits; it is the talisman that protects life, capable of increasing blessings and longevity; it is the ladder to ascend to heaven, capable of paying homage to the Three Pure Ones and transcending the mundane to enter sagehood; it is the lamp that illuminates the path, capable of dispelling the six desires and shattering darkness to remove delusion; it is the immortal boat and precious raft, capable of ferrying sentient beings across the sea of suffering; it is the compassionate pole and bridge, capable of delivering sentient beings from the river of love. Truly, it is the safeguard of the cultivator and the guiding principle for advancing on the Dao.

There is no other gate for immortals and sages; all enter through the precepts. There is no other path for saints and worthies; all proceed from precept observance. It is indeed the grand thoroughfare for immortals and perfected beings, the central gate and proper path for the wise and virtuous.

Assembly, since the karmic causes planted in past lives have led you in this life to hear the Dharma of precepts, this is the greatest of fortunes. Yet if you do not uphold the precepts with discipline, diligence, and rigor, then this greatest of fortunes will transform into the greatest of transgressions.

These precepts are the prohibitions of the Yuandu Heaven, the rules and regulations established by the Most High Lord of the Primordial Treasure. The Celestial Bureau of Lady Qing constantly inspects them; divine soldiers guard them, and heavenly generals patrol them. Those who honor and uphold them receive merit recorded in the cinnabar ledgers. Those who violate and defy them have their transgressions inscribed in the black books.

Even the slightest infraction is not overlooked, nor the smallest deviation missed.

Those who now receive the precepts are, in truth, the ignorant. What does it mean to be ignorant? Simply that they have not grasped the principle. If one truly understood this principle, one would uphold the precepts with utmost rigor and never transgress. To violate the rules—is this not ignorance?

Therefore, all who have taken the precepts must earnestly contemplate the meaning of *precept*. What is a precept? It is a prohibition, a restraint. What does it restrain? And why did you initially receive it? If you came for the Dharma of precepts, you should uphold it day by day. If you do not uphold it daily, why receive the precepts at all? Such an attitude reveals you did not come for the precepts themselves, but rather for the empty reputation of being a Daoist monk, seeking only the robe and alms-bowl. Otherwise, why would you not observe the pure regulations?

I must earnestly reflect: since the Seven Perfected Ones propagated the teachings, the Dao has declined. The precepts and their dignified observances have not been manifest in the world for four hundred years. This is because no one within the teaching has arisen to shoulder the responsibility. Thus, the heavenly lamp that illuminates the Way has not been trimmed, leaving those who cultivate in darkness, struggling to proceed. The staff that supports the body has been cast aside, and its handle lost. No wonder heterodox teachings and deviant sects have spread throughout the world, while the pure, liberated, upright, and luminous Dao has fallen silent and unheard.

Now, by good fortune, the Dao’s destiny is unfolding in this flourishing age. Above, the Emperor’s blessings ensure peace under heaven; below, many officials and worthy patrons serve as protectors of the teaching.

Moreover, there are benefactors who offer alms—robes, headscarves, caps, and alms bowls—all prepared and ready. Such opportunities are rare in a thousand lifetimes, seldom encountered across ages. This is the karmic affinity you have chanced upon in this life.

Having received the precepts, you must now diligently pursue the meaning of *jie* (戒). What is *jie*? Alas, those who take the precepts vary in wisdom and folly. The foolish may begin with good intentions, but once the precepts are received, they obscure their initial resolve, failing to uphold the discipline. How lamentable—this original aspiration is abandoned, and the precept robe and cap are cast into the vast ocean. Some pawn or sell them, others alter them into ordinary clothing or patch them into sleeves. They profane the celestial spirits and defile the sacred precincts. The pure alms bowl is repurposed as an incense burner, a vessel for coins or rice. They break fasts, violate precepts, drink wine, consume meat—nothing is beyond them. Their wisdom is extinguished, and their immortal root severed.

There are living cases to prove this, clear and undeniable. Once, a precept-disciple violated his vows, defiled the precept scriptures, sold his robe, and discarded his bowl. He suddenly died, and many ghostly underlings seized him with chains. In the netherworld, he saw a majestic tribunal, flanked by rows of ghostly attendants binding many souls—all former companions who had broken their precepts. Startled, he asked, *"Why are you here?"* They replied, *"We do not know why, but one by one, we all ended up here."*

Above the gate hung a plaque inscribed with three characters: *Kao Dui Si* (考对司, the Bureau of Examination and Verification). He asked a ghostly attendant, *"What is the Bureau of Examination and Verification?"* The ghost replied, *"This is a newly established celestial court, with two branches, solely responsible for the precepts of monks and Daoists. When someone in the mortal realm resolves to receive precepts, the local earth god and kitchen god record their name in the register. The day of their ordination, their merits and transgressions, their adherence or violation of precepts—whether they betray the Dao or their master, defile the discipline, sell their robe, desecrate their bowl, slander the precept-master, deceive benefactors, indulge in greed or lust—all is meticulously recorded and reported monthly to the relevant bureaus for examination. Only after passing through this bureau may one proceed to other courts. Those who receive precepts but cultivate virtue with unwavering devotion need not appear here. But for those like you, who disregard the precepts, you must first be examined and struck from the register before your allotted lifespan ends. Without passing through this bureau, no other court will issue a summons."*

Listen well, all of you: the one who died returned to life after half a day and night, recounting this case. When you judge others’ faults, you are sharp and discerning, yet when it comes to your own, you remain blind. Day by day, month by month, you excuse yourself, accumulating boundless transgressions while concealing them—this is called deceiving your own heart.

Those who have received the precepts must examine their every thought, word, and deed, day and night. Cultivate the good, abandon the evil, and never justify or indulge yourself. If you err and fail to reflect, immediately repent before the sacred immortals, weeping in remorse. Study the precept scriptures diligently, seek enlightened masters, and pursue profound learning. Revere your masters as parents, your fellow disciples as elder brothers, cherish the Dao as a wife, and treasure the scriptures as jade. Hold the precepts in your heart as firmly as you hold an object in your hand—for the moment you release it, it is lost; the moment you relax your vigilance, the precepts are broken.

The laws of the mortal realm punish transgressors with penalties; the celestial Dao’s statutes, the *Nü Qing* precepts, mete out karmic retribution. Do not assume the netherworld is unseen—life and death reside in your heart. Do not think the precept spirits are hidden—every thought, every action, is known to them.

The four characters *jie xing jing yan* (戒行精严) embody this: subduing the heart to align with the Dao is *jie* (precept); endurance and perseverance are *xing* (conduct); purity without admixture is *jing* (precision); flawless adherence is *yan* (strictness). Unwavering from beginning to end is *chi jie* (upholding precepts); steadfastness in hardship is *shou jie* (guarding precepts).

Yet among you who have received the precepts, how many recall even the Ten Precepts? This is precept in name only—why bother? But if there is even one word of Dharma, let it give all of you the resolve to uphold it.

The celestial sovereign above governs all with a heart that cherishes life, vast in compassion and mercy, delivering and liberating sentient beings. If one who has transgressed the precepts repents from this moment on, revealing a sincere heart, and once more upholds the regulations with strictness and precision, never daring to repeat the offense—such earnest remorse and repentance will move the heart of Heaven to pity, pardoning the transgression and restoring one to the original state.

Now I shall tell you another tale of karmic cause and effect: one who broke the precepts yet later upheld them. A precept-keeper once said that after receiving the precepts, he suddenly encountered demonic tribulations, breaking fasts and violating the precepts, committing every kind of transgression. One night, he dreamed of the netherworld, witnessing the proceedings of its courts. There, he saw many ghostly clerks lighting gauze lanterns and setting up incense tables. After a short while, King Yama emerged from the main gate, his majesty akin to that of an earthly emperor. A judge announced, "The celestial envoy has arrived—quickly prepare the incense table to receive the decree," no different from how officials in the mortal realm receive imperial edicts.

The envoy was a celestial officer, wearing a golden lotus crown, draped in a five-colored cloud crane cloak, and holding a yellow scroll. He entered, while the ghosts were barred from following. The dreaming Daoist also wished to enter. A ghostly guard shouted, "What wandering soul are you, daring to approach this solemn hall?" Another ghost remarked, "He looks like a Daoist." The first ghost replied, "The decree from the other day instructed that those who cultivate the Way and uphold the precepts, upon the end of their lives, are permitted to enter in full attire. Those with radiant light may pass through the main gate; those with lesser light, the eastern side gate; those without light shall have their Daoist names revoked, bound in shackles at the western side gate, and await trial by roster. You, Daoist, have no light at all—only a mass of black qi, no different from us. Impersonating a Daoist, be gone at once!" He brandished an iron rod. The precept-keeper awoke with a start, remembering the dream vividly.

The precept-keeper immediately rose from his narrow bed, hastily washed his face, took up pure fire to light incense, and was filled with dread. Grieving and repentant, he vowed to mend his ways and strictly uphold the precepts.

One day, he dreamed again of wandering through the underworld, returning to the same place as before. The ghostly guards wielding iron rods and chains knelt and asked, "Where does the immortal master wish to go?" The precept-keeper replied, "I was merely passing through and dared not disturb the King. I shall take my leave now." The ghost said, "The King has a rule: all immortal masters of radiant virtue who pass by must first enter the tea hall, take a seat, and have their names recorded for verification." The precept-keeper answered, "I have no official business here; I shall not stay." As he turned to leave, he suddenly found himself outside the realm. Upon waking, he recounted the dream to the assembly.

In his first journey, he was beaten and scolded by ghosts; in the second, they knelt to receive him and inquired after his name. The difference lay solely in the advance or retreat of his own heart—had he not repented of his past faults, he would have remained as before. Behold the workings of the Dao in the unseen and visible realms! How can one not stand in awe?

O assembly! Time passes swiftly; let your heart and nature shine brightly. Do not wait until impermanence arrives, forcing you to wander in the underworld’s darkness, where Ox-Head offers no kindness and Horse-Face shows no mercy. If you have faults, correct them swiftly; all depends on the purity of your precepts. Among the ten thousand methods and thousand gates of practice, cultivating the mind is the supreme vehicle. In the boundless sea without shore, follow the precepts and let wisdom’s light guide you.

**7. Enduring Humiliation to Subdue the Mind**

For those who cultivate the Way, the greatest affliction—the hardest to remove and rectify—is the character for *wrath*. Whether clinging to the illusion of self or the illusion of others, wrath encompasses the six desires, seven emotions, and the myriad transgressions that arise from it. When wrath stirs, it is called the fire of ignorance. Among the three poisons, wrath is foremost.

If wrath is not resolved, it burns oneself within; if wrathful words are spoken, they burn others without. It scorches the subtle gate of spirit, reducing the Dharma-body to ashes. The six viscera cannot remain at peace, nor can the five organs find harmony. When the ear hears another’s insult, wrath-fire arises from the liver, and like wildfire meeting a gale, the ear’s faculty of hearing is suddenly sealed, as if shutters had closed its apertures. When the eye sees another’s disrespect, wrath-fire arises from the kidneys, and like wildfire meeting a gale, the eye’s faculty of sight is suddenly obscured, as if a door had blocked its path. Unaware, the mouth speaks wrathful words, and from the heart surges the fire of resentment; from the gallbladder rises the venomous scheme of harm. Above, one fears neither the gods of heaven and earth; in the middle, one fears neither life nor death; in the unseen, one fears neither the cauldrons of boiling oil nor the forests of swords; in the world of men, one fears neither execution, exile, nor military conscription. With the tongue’s faculty of speech, one creates a thousand kinds of karmic offenses.

Why do the ear, eye, mouth, and tongue suffer such torment? It is because this heart of flesh cannot be subdued, relying on a mere breath of qi to wield power and authority. Yet when the moment of reflection arrives, it is as cold and insipid as ice.

O assembly! All beings in the world are formed from blood and qi, and this root of wrath has been planted since the beginningless kalpas. Thus, when circumstances align with the heart, joy arises; when they do not, joy turns to enmity. When conditions oppose the heart, wrath is born—this is the root of endless rebirth.

You have left the household life to escape the cycle of birth and death, yet if the root of wrath is not severed, the poisonous dragon will assail the celestial root. You seek liberation from the snares of the world because the weight of your nature and life is profound; if the root of wrath is not extinguished, qi will fill the lunar palace. Nature is fundamentally good, but wrath transforms it into a poisonous dragon—beware the fire of wrath, for when it blazes, it burns the body. Life is inherently enduring, but wrath turns it into a ferocious tiger—constantly generating toxic qi, hastening the loss of one’s true essence. Ignorance of birth and death stems from failing to treasure one’s nature and life; the failure to establish nature and life stems from the strength of fire. Thus, the six senses cannot be gathered, the four limbs tremble and weaken, the five organs cannot function, and the pores emit the flying flames of wrath, causing a hundred harms, injuring heaven and shortening life.

O assembly! To sever the root of wrath, first subdue evil thoughts. What are evil thoughts? The inability to endure humiliation is an evil thought. If this thought lingers for a day, one remains an evil person for that day. How can an evil person enter the Dao?

The great sage Confucius said, *"Teach with gentleness and forbearance; do not retaliate against the unprincipled."* If the heart cannot endure, the thought persists for a day, and one remains an evil person for that day. How can such a one enter the Way?

O assembly! Those who cannot endure humiliation have hearts that cannot be subdued, like poisonous dragons or ferocious tigers. They only know how to humiliate others, not how to bear their own humiliation. They crave dominance and victory, seizing pleasure before others, wielding power and authority, speaking harshly and sternly. They play the hero, act the champion, seize profit and fame, boast of their merits and power, bully the weak, and disdain the elderly. Though they may sometimes act with warm hearts for the sake of others, they do not realize that while they may save people, they may also kill them.

Beings are deluded and do not awaken; when have they ever considered deeply or planned far ahead? Heaven’s way is retributive, and enmities remain unresolved—all because the root of wrath is not severed. Wrath inevitably seeks to humiliate others, unwilling to endure humiliation oneself. Yet there is a vast difference between being humiliated by others and humiliating others.

O assembly! The character for *humiliation* encompasses a vast range. For example, if one seduces another’s wife or concubine, one disregards the humiliation of her husband, children, grandchildren, ancestors, and entire clan. Yet when another seduces one’s own wife or concubine, wrath arises, and great evil is conceived. One thinks, *"This person has seduced my wife or concubine—how can I preserve my dignity? If others hear of it, not only will I be shamed, but the merits of my parents and ancestors, the reputation of my descendants, and the standing of my entire clan will be defiled and ruined. How can I let this pass?"*

Should one take up blade or cudgel, flare with rage, and suddenly conceive murderous intent—never once considering, *"He humiliates me, and so I react thus. But if I were to humiliate him, how would he respond?"*

If in this life one’s wife or daughter is violated, there must be a karmic cause from a past life. In a former existence, one violated another’s wife or daughter; in this life, one’s own wife or daughter is violated. This is the inevitable cause and effect among men.

All of you, heed these words: never allow the mind of lust to arise. I speak plainly to this assembly: the lives of all these people exist because of lust. If the mind of lust is not eradicated, the root of birth and death remains unsevered. It is through lust that the physical form arises; to cast off the physical form, one must wash away desire. When desire is extinguished, within this perishable body, the Dharma-body is born—only then can one escape the cycle of birth and death.

These are my true words; do not dismiss them as idle talk.

Recently, there was a lay disciple who, though ordinarily firm in his devotion to the Way, suddenly set out to beg for alms and provisions. Passing by a rice shop, he held out his alms bowl.

The shop’s owner, a devotee of the Way, was overjoyed. He invited the precept-observer into the central hall, where he bowed, offered alms, and placed a mace of silver fragments into the alms bowl. As the precept-observer was leaving the hall, he suddenly encountered the owner’s wife passing beneath the veranda. She could not withdraw in time, and after a mutual glance, the precept-observer expressed his thanks for the alms and departed. That night, as he sat in meditation, his thoughts drifted to the wife, picturing her face. He rose, knelt before the incense, and repented before lying down. Then, in a dream, he saw himself die, enter a womb, grow to adulthood, marry a woman of striking beauty, and live in marital harmony. One day, while walking outside, he saw a Daoist begging for alms. His heart rejoiced, and he invited the Daoist home, where he offered alms and made merit. He called his wife to meet the guest and bowed to her. Turning back, he saw the Daoist beckon to his wife, and suddenly, unbearable rage surged within him. He rushed into the kitchen, seized a vegetable cleaver, and charged at the Daoist to strike him down. Tripping over his own feet, he awoke—his heart still seething with anger—to find it was all a dream, his body drenched in sweat. Reflecting on the Daoist’s face, he realized it was the shop owner who had offered alms; the wife in the dream was the woman he had encountered beneath the veranda.

All of you, this precept-observer, though diligent in his early practice and steadfast in his precepts, lacked firm concentration. Thus, his daytime sight gave rise to nighttime thoughts, and his deluded mind, deeply entangled in illusion, manifested in his dream. Another practitioner, however, observed the precepts with unwavering resolve. He never spoke falsely, his thoughts never strayed, and when humiliated, he harbored no resentment. Struck, he did not strike back; cursed, he did not curse in return. He reflected only on his own faults, never blaming others. One day, while carrying a load on the road, he encountered a donkey rushing toward him. He stepped aside to let it pass, but the donkey suddenly butted him, knocking him to the ground. The donkey then bit his clothes, tearing them, before running off. That night, as the practitioner sat in meditation, he entered a state of hazy concentration. Suddenly, a man in white appeared and thanked him, saying, “I was the donkey that collided with you on the road. In a past life, we were bound by karmic enmity, but now the grievance is resolved, and we are both liberated. I have escaped the realm of suffering and will be reborn among humans. I have come to inform you: on a certain day next month, seek me at a certain place to perform rites for my deliverance.” With that, he vanished. The practitioner saw and heard all this clearly—it was neither dream nor waking. He rose and resumed his meditation as usual. When the appointed day arrived, he went to the designated place, where a family seemed overjoyed, as if celebrating a joyous occasion. Inquiring with neighbors, he learned that a child had been born to the household the previous night. The practitioner was deeply alarmed. He memorized the name and vowed to first deliver himself, then others.

All of you, you may have planted the roots of enmity in past lives, and now, in this life, they are being resolved. Precept-observers, you must rouse your own resolve: endure humiliation, release resentment, bear hardship, embrace suffering, forget shame, accept loss, reconcile grievances, and submit to karmic conditions. Subdue this mind of yours. Wield the blade of precepts to slay the fire of ignorance at every moment; clothe yourself in the robe of endurance at all times. When others strike or curse you, when they slander or shame you, none of it can shatter even a single precept in your heart. Even when falsely implicated, subjected to the law’s punishments, or struck by lightning from a clear sky; when burned by fire or thunder, drowned in floods, robbed by bandits, seized by wolves or tigers, afflicted by disease or snakebite, oppressed by demons or haunted by ghosts, tormented by spirits or harmed by malevolent forces; when worldly desires twist words to ruin your reputation, when enemies hurl curses to harm your kin, or when you cannot escape mutilation—your body broken, your limbs severed—all these are the fixed karmic consequences of past causes, the inescapable fate you must face. You can only accept them with equanimity, aligning with the will of Heaven, repaying old debts, and settling past karma. Never harbor resentment or defiance, lest you violate the precepts. Instead, reflect: when others humiliate me, it is because I once humiliated them; when they trouble me, it is because I once troubled them. All the calamities, misfortunes, harms, and disasters you encounter are the results of your past actions—you reap what you have sown. From the moment you receive the precepts, all evil karma dissolves with your resolve. Naturally, the six desires will not arise, the three poisons will vanish, body and mind will be light and healthy, your temperament will be calm and harmonious, suffering will cease, and enmities will be resolved.

All of you, from the beginningless past to this very day, awaken your innate goodness. For all grievances, debts, and obligations, willingly accept and repay them one by one. Sacrifice yourself for the benefit of others—only then can you attain liberation. From this point forward, you will forever abide in purity, returning to the original integrity of the Great Void, the primordial chaos. Preserve your spirit in silence, and you will refine a perfect Dharma-body. Otherwise, if you refuse to repay past-life debts and reject present humiliations, the retribution in future lives will not spare you. How, then, can this body achieve liberation? How can this mind attain emptiness? How can this Way be cultivated? If you cannot even endure these few words now, how will you ever reach the end of birth and death and attain pristine purity?

All of you, endurance extinguishes the fire of ignorance, and naturally, the five viscera become cool. Endurance generates the waters of the Flower Pool, and naturally, the six bowels are harmonized. Endurance fulfills the desires of others, and naturally, grievances dissolve into peace. Endurance expands your capacity, and naturally, your heart becomes vast. In truth, when others insult me, I do not take it as an insult—their shame returns to them.

When I insult others, they receive my insult and will surely repay me with insult in return. If I can endure, my heart-qi becomes harmonious, the liver’s fire does not flare, and it transforms into the Azure Flower that relieves suffering. If I can endure, my heart-spirit becomes kind, the heart’s fire does not blaze, and it transforms into the Southern Dipper that dispels calamity. If I can endure, the lungs and armpits generate fluid, universally moistening the stomach, and it transforms into the Jade Pool’s sweet dew. If I can endure, kidney essence is not depleted, the upper and lower origins are freed from distress, and it transforms into the Dark Warrior’s numinous spring. If I can endure, the spleen’s earth does not parch, the body becomes light and at ease, and it transforms into white snow and yellow sprouts. If I can endure, the Dharma-body remains unblemished, the Dao-qi connects with the spirit, and the adorned wondrous form manifests before me.

To endure in the realm of state brings benefit to the court. To endure in the household brings benefit to kin. To endure in the body brings benefit to vitality. To endure in the heart brings benefit to life and nature. To endure in teaching brings benefit to the Dharma-family. Such are the benefits of endurance.

If one cannot endure, the heart is not empty, the spirit is not numinous, the qi is not robust, the capacity is not vast, the chest is not open, aspirations are not grand, merit is not complete, conduct is not fulfilled, perception is not penetrating, thought is not profound, wisdom is small, blessings and virtue are shallow, and the root is weak. The Way is not clearly understood, its practice is obstructed, one is despised by others, invites jealousy, incurs aversion, provokes vexation, is treated with contempt, suffers ghostly reproach in seclusion, startles in dreams, is rebuked by spirits in waking life, and afflicted with scabies, madness, and rashes. The roots of karmic grievances from many kalpas remain unextinguished, and the retribution in future lives grows deeper. The sea of suffering ceaselessly churns waves—how can one stir up waves from nothing?

All of you, have you not heard? Virtue is the root, and only with forbearance does virtue become great. Heaven is impartial, aiding only those with virtue. Among you, the wise and foolish differ. Some lose virtue for wealth, some for lust, some for temper. Though the external circumstances vary—whether insult comes from wealth, lust, or temper—the experience of insult is the same.

The sage said: “A moment’s anger makes one forget body and kin.” And again: “When angry, think of the consequences.” Master Zeng said: “When the heart harbors anger, it loses its rightness.” How weighty is the precept of endurance! How poisonous is the harm of wrath!

Thus, the true patriarchs took the restraint of anger as the gateway, forgetting anger as the Way, endurance as the slaying of the heart, and forgetting insult as the fulfillment of vows. The *Sutra of Salvation* by the Most High Lord of Heaven says: “The fiery haze becomes clear autumn, the sword-forest blooms as fragrant groves. Transcending the three realms’ trials, one ascends to the Heaven of Primordial Beginning.”

All of you, awaken swiftly and heed my verse:

*"Swiftly dissolve the self-and-other divide,
Hasten to awaken to the cause of birth and death.
Endure insult to quell the fire of wrath,
And the Dharma-body appears in emptiness.
The seven emotions perish with each thought,
The ancients praised the hundredfold endurance.
Willingly bear the weight of karmic sins,
Only then is one beyond the kalpa’s reach.

Myriad karmic obstacles are past-life bonds,
Debts owed and repaid are all the same.
The foolish, when slighted, ignite in wrath—
A swirling mass of black karmic debt.
In cultivation, never seek advantage,
For if I gain, others will not comply.
Through kalpas adrift, grievances unresolved,
The Pure Hall teems with strife.

Strife finds no foothold where heaven is vast,
Immortals and asuras differ thus.
The Cool and Blessed Land thrives on forbearance,
Repaying insult-debts completes the Dao’s work.
This mortal frame walks the Dao’s path—
Why refuse to bear another’s slight?
Raging fury sets the body aflame,
The homeless true one suffers hungry ghost’s fate."*

Eight: Purify Body and Mind.

All assembled, having taken the precepts and sought refuge, you must now single-mindedly seek liberation from the world, transcending birth and death. Yet those lofty ones who transcend birth and death and leave the world possess the supreme, deathless, birthless Dao of the highest vehicle. This Dao is the turning of the worldly dharma into the body—fundamentally, there is no dharma. Worldly dharma and transcendent dharma differ only in the mind; what is employed reverses or follows, yet in truth they are but one dharma, and this dharma is not merely the reversal of what follows.

When reversal is applied within what follows, the myriad dharmas return to the absence of dharma, and even spirits and gods cannot fathom its mechanism. When following is applied within reversal, one dharma scatters into the myriad dharmas, and yin and yang do not escape its calculations. This is not a matter of employing the mind as an instrument or using intention to deliberate. Rather, it is the luminous wisdom of inherent principle—originally thus, not some other transcendent dharma.

Yet who is it that transcends the world? Ultimately, one must send this person beyond the world to the realm outside it—only then is it true transcendence. But this, too, is not so. Now, I urge this person to take the body beyond the world. Yet the vastness of heaven and earth, the expanse of the world—where can one call "beyond the world"? All assembled, listen closely: "beyond the world" lies outside worldly dharma.

See through worldly dharma as unreal, illusory emotions as false. All conditioned deeds and powers are but dreamlands; every thing is without substance, every affair unreal. Only by purifying this mind can one transcend the world. All assembled, how can this mind transcend the world?
