Consider this: heaven’s cycles of cloud and clear cannot transcend; earth’s collapses and landslides cannot transcend; the waxing and waning of sun and moon cannot transcend; the distant fall of stars cannot transcend; wind, clouds, thunder, rain, frost, snow, mist, and dew—each bound by its limits—cannot transcend; mountains crumbling, stones splitting, waters drying, springs depleting, grasses withering, trees rotting, metals smelting, jade shattering—cannot transcend; humans’ birth and death cannot transcend; things’ growth and decay cannot transcend; emotions’ thickness and thinness cannot transcend; qi’s inhalation and exhalation cannot transcend; the mind’s movement and stillness cannot transcend; essence’s leakage cannot transcend; spirit’s dullness and dispersion cannot transcend; power’s rise and decline cannot transcend; profit’s gains and losses cannot transcend. All conditioned things are bound to formation, abiding, dissolution, and emptiness—birth, aging, sickness, and death—how could they ever transcend?

All assembled, you must awaken to the transcendent dharma within worldly dharma. This dharma of transcendence does not lie in many words but in the return of this mind alone. Once you know that heaven and earth, the myriad things, human emotions, and worldly affairs are not the dharma of transcendence, you realize that they are all within the confines of the world’s snare. If you can awaken in your mind to this single point—seeing that heaven and earth, the myriad things, worldly dharma, and human emotions are all impermanent, all illusory—what then is the true spirit?

This true spirit is formless and imageless, odorless and soundless. Spoken of as within, it does not merely reside within; spoken of as without, it does not come from without. It is possessed by every person, inherent in every thing—this is the Dharma King capable of transcending the world. All assembled, this Dharma King of true spirit pervades the cosmos, past and present, existing in all things at all times—no small matter indeed. In Buddhism, it is called the wondrously luminous true mind; in Confucianism, the luminous virtue of utmost goodness; in Daoism, the perfectly luminous Dao Mother or the primordial qi. The many other names cannot be fully enumerated.

Where is this knower of heaven and earth, the myriad things, human emotions, and worldly dharma to be sought? It is found in the *Great Learning*’s "illuminate its luminous virtue, rest in utmost goodness." This luminous virtue of utmost goodness dwells within formation, abiding, dissolution, and emptiness—birth, aging, sickness, and death—within body and mind, yet possesses the true spirit of no-formation, no-abiding, no-dissolution, no-emptiness, no-birth, no-aging, no-sickness, no-death. From ancient times to the present, it abides undimmed. It penetrates heaven and earth, emerges from darkness and enters the unseen. It is unborn and unchanging, neither more nor less, without lack or excess, without coming or going. It moves yin and yang yet is not obstructed by them; it governs spirits and gods yet is not hindered by them. It employs the myriad things yet is not misled by them; it transforms human emotions yet is not moved by them. It responds to worldly dharma yet is not drowned by it. It transcends the world yet abides within it. It roams the three realms freely, unbound; it commands the myriad spirits, its transformations profound and unfathomable. Above heaven and below earth, it alone is supreme, without equal.

Yet this true spirit, though possessed by all, is rarely understood. The myriad dharmas, the thousand gates, the three vehicles, the entire canon—all emerge from it. Its subtleties, its mysteries—awakened to, it is right before you; deluded, it sinks to the ocean’s depths. All assembled, know that the practice of transcending the world does not exceed the two words "body" and "mind." The body is provisional, the mind is real; the mind is provisional, nature is real. You must awaken to cultivating the real through the provisional. The external is provisional, the internal is real; the external is form, the internal is emptiness. Without relying on the provisional, conditioned form-body, the internal, unconditioned Dharma-body cannot be cultivated. Without the body of birth, aging, sickness, and death, the internal, serene, and perfect mind cannot be realized. Without the mind’s lively and responsive nature, the vast and boundless true nature cannot be attained.

Yet this nature comes from the Mandate of Heaven. At the beginning of life, it is unstained, one in substance with the great void, one in measure with the great void.

Empty and hollow, utterly devoid of all.
Whole and undivided, nothing it does not contain.

Disciples, if you now seek liberation from the world, first each of you must purify body and mind.
What is the practice of purifying body and mind?
The body is formed of blood and qi, and blood and qi are not indestructible things—they are the root of birth and death, the source of calamity and misfortune.
They burden my mind, they ravage my nature.
Lust and desire for pleasure arise only for the sake of this body.
Striving for fame and profit arises only for the sake of this body’s enjoyment.
Violating laws and incurring punishment, inviting disaster and illness—all begin with this body.
The Most High said: “People have troubles because they have a body; if I had no body, what troubles would there be?”
The ancients said: “If one is not burdened by form, before one’s eyes is the Great Heavenly Immortal.”
Thus, this body is no small source of misfortune.
Now you must see through this skin-bag as a provisional thing, composed of earth, water, fire, and wind.
If one does not speak of thorough cultivation but only urges filial piety, you may say the body—skin, hair, flesh—is received from parents and must not be harmed.
Father’s essence and mother’s blood, the five agents in harmony, endowed with the finest qi of Heaven and Earth, perfected by the divine workings of yin and yang.
The head is round, modeling Heaven; the feet are square, modeling Earth.
Standing between Heaven and Earth, ranked among the Three Powers, among the ten thousand things, humans are foremost.
Above, they may match Heaven and Earth; in the hidden, they may assist ghosts and spirits.
Through learning, they may aspire to sagehood; through cultivation, they may become immortals or buddhas.
How could one regard this most noble and richly endowed body as foul and filthy as dung and dirt?
This is only to urge disciples not to sink into delusion with the worldly tide.
Do not seek comfort for the physical form; only seek the true nature’s return to its original constancy.
Let the will and qi govern yin and yang; let form and spirit adorn the Dharma-realm.
If the Dharma-body remains leaky, form and spirit cannot both be wondrous, nor can they merge with the Dao in truth.

Disciples, now I explain the practice of purity to you.
To purify this body, first cast aside worldly things, sever worldly attachments, and distance yourself from all mundane ways.
Embrace simplicity and delight in tranquility; forsake rich flavors and leave behind clamor.
Take refuge in the Three Jewels, steadfastly uphold the One Truth.
Cultivate a peaceful temperament; keep hands and feet dignified and composed.
Eyes and ears must not stray; thoughts must not scatter.
The mind must not cling to deliberation; the mouth must not raise its voice in clamor.
Gather the spirit-light of the two eyes to inwardly illumine the unwavering mind-terrace.
Return the essence of the two ears to inwardly listen, ever hearing the celestial sounds.
Speak sparingly, remain silent—return to the natural, unmoving state.
Aim for no regrets, let thoughts not drift; let the spirit be free of restlessness, the celestial mechanism clear and smooth, the profound principle perfectly realized.
Refrain from meat and strong flavors, silently dissolving the karmic retribution of many lives’ killing.
Observe the precepts with the body, secretly uphold the four great dignities.
Feet do not wander aimlessly—lest the mind grow anxious.
Hands do not move recklessly—lest the mind grow restless.
When sitting, be upright and centered, not leaning or slouching.
When lying down, remain alert, avoiding excessive drowsiness.
When eating, consume plain and mild flavors, that the five viscera may be clear and harmonious.
When speaking, be cautious and unhurried, that the voice may be gentle and smooth.
This is called the coarse practice of bodily purity.

As for the subtle work, you must delve into the meaning of “purity” and “stillness.”
The concern is not that you will fail to attain the Dao if you earnestly investigate and practice, but that you will not penetrate deeply enough to embody it.
Disciples, a mind without dual thoughts is called pure; thoughts without confusion are called still.
A mind not attached to forms is called pure; thoughts not lingering are called still.
Thought after thought perfectly luminous is called pure; luminosity without obstruction is called still.
Not a speck of dust clings—this is called pure; all worries are empty—this is called still.
The myriad things cannot escape its form—this is called pure; ghosts and spirits cannot fathom its mechanism—this is called still.
The mind like flowing water is called pure; the nature like the bright moon is called still.
Sins from beginningless time extinguished—this is called pure; causes from countless kalpas before fully exhausted—this is called still.
Inwardly observing the mind, the mind is no-mind—this is called pure; outwardly observing things, things are no-things—this is called still.
Realizing the Three Truths—this is called pure; seeing only emptiness—this is called still.
Observing emptiness as empty—this is called pure; emptiness itself empty—this is called still.
The emptied is gone, the emptying of the empty is also gone—this is called pure.
Abiding in serene constancy, stillness without stillness—this is called still.
Truly constant in responding to things—this is called pure; constantly responding, constantly still—this is called still.
Luminous and unwavering—this is called pure; entering the gate of myriad wonders—this is called still.
Transcending the Three Realms—this is called pure; liberated from the Five Agents—this is called still.
Shattering the void—this is called pure; pulverizing the void—this is called still.
Light embracing all heavens—this is called pure; universally ferrying sentient beings—this is called still.

Disciples, I have briefly outlined the essentials for your instruction.
The sages of the Three Teachings, the vast canon of scriptures;
the ten thousand dharmas and thousand gates, the wondrous functions of the heavens;
the thirty-six thousand kinds of Dao, the eighty-four thousand Dharma-gates;
the numberless bodhisattvas like the sands of the Ganges, the countless golden immortals—
none can surpass the wondrous Dharma of purity, stillness, samādhi, and non-action.

Disciples, the supreme, unsurpassed, great vehicle, the highest and most true wondrous Dao—
the generation of heavens, earth, humans, and beings—all arise from purity and stillness.
The Most High said: “If people can always be pure and still, Heaven and Earth all return to them.”
And again: “Purity and stillness set the world aright.”
Thus, swiftly seek awakening through purifying body and mind.

Disciples, from this day forward, you must cast aside all the metaphors you once clung to—lead and mercury, dragon and tiger, yin and yang, firing and refinement.
Only follow the gate of purity: extinguish deluded thoughts, still perverse notions.
Proceed steadily and securely along the great Middle Way.
This will not lead you astray.
It is called “delaying but not erring; when there is a path, do not board the boat.”

If I speak falsehoods to deceive you, may I fall into hell.

At that time, the Vinaya Master again spoke in verse:
*"A scattered mind is not still,
A dust-laden body is not pure.
Without purity, how can one see the nature?
Without stillness, how can there be no emotion?
Inwardly illumine—the body is but illusion,
Turn the light around—the heart too is empty.
Within emptiness, the spirit sees itself;
Samādhi and prajñā are the true teaching.
Sun and moon must be observed,
The ordinary must be embodied in practice.
Moving against the Dipper’s handle,
Purity aligns with Heaven’s heart."*

**9. Seeking a Master to Inquire of the Dao**
Since ancient times, sages, immortals, and buddhas—all who realized fruition and attained truth—did so without a master. Thus, masters transmit to masters, mouth to mouth, heart to heart. The principle within is one, universally penetrating. Like milk and water blending, like glue and lacquer uniting, like qi seeking like qi, like sound resonating with sound, like water and sky merging as one, like lamps illuminating one another—only then can the way of master and disciple be fully realized.

Disciples, I see that many in the world seek masters to inquire of the Dao, yet most err slightly. They bear the name of master-disciple transmission but lack its true substance. Therefore, today I spare not my words nor fear slander, to explain the principle of seeking a master and inquiring of the Dao. You must bear this in mind, so that in the future, when you first become another’s disciple, you may uphold this propriety. Then, when you later become a master, your disciples will follow ancient models and emulate your conduct. To honor the master is to revere the Dao.

Disciples, the world is full of blind fools who do not know their own minds, swayed by external things. Though they possess the thought of the Dao, they do not discern the gate of right and wrong; though they possess the heart of the Dao, they do not know the method of cultivation. Hearing the saying, *“Nature is realized through self-awakening; life is transmitted through a master,”* they follow it blindly. They may encounter some wandering Daoist—robed in tattered rags, sandals on his feet, a palm-leaf fan in hand, a rush mat slung over his shoulder—passing through towns, sitting by the roadside with a begging bowl, or strolling leisurely along the way. He takes lodging in temples and monasteries, discoursing on elixir formulas, his tongue like a reed organ. What is the mysterious pass? The tailbone’s sea of qi? How to ascend to the Mud-Pill Palace or descend to the Bubbling Spring point? How to guard the center and lift the qi, establish the furnace and cauldron? How to prolong life and ward off illness through massage and daoyin? The Six-Syllable Formula, the Eight Brocades, the *Awakening to Reality*, the *Triple Concordance*—along with the metaphors in alchemical classics: lead and mercury, dragon and tiger, silver and cinnabar, husband and wife, sun and moon, hexagrams and lines, tortoise and snake, warming and nurturing, bathing and forming the embryo, entering the chamber to sit in meditation, emerging as the yin spirit or yang spirit. Endless are the thirty-six hundred heterodox paths, the eighty-four thousand demonic methods. Who could count them all?

Good people, these benighted fools lack wisdom in their hearts—how could they discern truth from falsehood, or recognize orthodoxy from heresy? Yet they readily heed such Daoist practitioners. Even more detestable is another breed: those deceitful charlatans who prattle of crucibles and vessels, or swindlers who refine "straw silver." They lure others with sensuality, ensnare them with wealth. Not only are their methods entirely fraudulent—even if such arts were genuine, how could ordinary mortals transmute gold, or lechers prolong life?

Thus, those who prate of crucibles and vessels, upon seeing beauty, stir desire; facing temptation, their thoughts roil. Their souls scatter, their spirits waver, true mercury flows downward, primordial qi collapses, and their most precious treasure is lost. Many end stricken with consumptive illness, failing to extend their lives—indeed, they sever their very liferoot. How hateful, how lamentable!

As for the swindlers who burn "straw silver," they spin tales of cinnabar and ore, spinning lies upon lies—warming, nurturing, and "opening the elixir," their deceptions and ploys endless. The greedy and foolish often ruin their families. Compared to the aforementioned Daoists, their karmic offenses are manifold.

I dare not speak further, lest I invite slander. But those who have received the precepts must now heed my counsel on seeking a master and inquiring into the Dao.

People,

This august and celestial Dao of the Highest Heaven—dim and indistinct, profound and obscure; vast and boundless, lofty and supreme; most mysterious and hidden, most secluded and subtle. It is so great that nothing lies beyond it, so small that nothing lies within it. It can weave the heavens and warp the earth, emerge from darkness and enter the unseen. Now present, now absent—entering water yet unsoaked, entering fire yet unburned. Without past or future, it gives birth to heaven and earth; it moves the sun and moon, nurtures the ten thousand things; it gives rise to sages and worthies, immortals and buddhas. From the crawling and conscious to insects, grasses, and trees—none lack it, nowhere is it absent. In daily use and common practice, all is the wondrous Dao.

Yet because the common folk use it daily yet do not know it, and lesser minds remain deluded and unenlightened, the One True is lost in an instant, and the myriad kalpas remain unilluminated. Before parents gave birth, the true spirit knows no beginning; after essence and spirit depart, this body knows no end. Trapped in the cycle of inversion, they suffer the torments of birth and death.

Thus I point to the source and root, urging all to seek a true master and swiftly hear the supreme Dao. Yet true masters are rare to meet, and worthy disciples hard to encounter. If a disciple lacks the true mind to transcend the world, obstacles cloud their wisdom-nature. Even if they meet a true master, spirits prevent them from seeing, veiling their wisdom-nature. Even if they see, they cannot recognize the master’s truth. If a master lacks the universal mind to save the world, even if they meet a worthy disciple, spirits also prevent them from seeing, veiling their Dharma-eye. Even if they see, there is no karmic affinity, and many opportunities are missed face-to-face.

People, when a master seeks a disciple, it is like rolling a mustard seed to thread a needle; when a disciple seeks a master, it is like grasping the moon from water. True masters are hard to find, worthy disciples hard to seek—not in wealth or treasure, but in the sincerity of a single thought.

Have you ever seen a master of the Dao recklessly transmit to the unworthy? Have you ever seen a seeker of the Way carelessly bow to a master? Since masters do not recklessly transmit, they hold the supreme Dao close while seeking worthy disciples. Since disciples do not carelessly bow, they possess keen insight and remain vigilant.

If one refuses to lightly seek a master or recklessly follow the Way, their mind is free of obstacles, their resolve set beyond the dust. With broad vision and expansive heart, when they meet a master of the Dao, they naturally see clearly beyond appearances. They can speak of it, discern it deeply—even a word or half a phrase strikes like a mustard seed threading a needle, fitting perfectly.

If a master does not recklessly accept disciples or lightly transmit teachings, when they meet such a discerning disciple, how could they not gladly respond, engage in lofty discourse, and reveal the wondrous secrets, the subtle celestial mechanisms, the profound and mysterious truths? How could they not transmit the Dao heart-to-heart and orally bestow the celestial chapters?

People, true masters are not few, and disciples are many. How do I say true masters are not few? Consider: your six senses all receive true masters. For example, if your ear hears good words and you sincerely accept them, your ear-root becomes the introductory master, and the good words become the transmitting master. The other five senses are the same.

People, there is no fixed master in learning—only the Dao is the master. Whenever you hear good words, attend to them in silent reverence, as if sweet dew bathes the heart or ambrosia pours upon the crown. Hold these words in mind, grateful that this person dispels your ignorance with compassion and skillful means. May they swiftly realize the mysterious workings and attain the supreme Dao—is this not the master-disciple relationship?

If your eye sees scriptures, the texts of the Three Teachings, true words, or secret formulas, and your heart awakens, you should bow in reverence and praise. Such texts become the transmitting master, and the eye-root becomes the introductory master.

People, in seeking a master and inquiring into the Dao, do not cling to one method or rely on a single path. Only when you recognize the true and believe it utterly will master and disciple naturally meet. Yet the master’s compassionate vessel and Dharma-bridge are not of one kind.

Mencius said: *"Teaching has many methods—some transform like timely rain, some cultivate virtue, some develop talent, some answer questions, some privately instruct, and even those who refuse to teach are still teaching."* Thus, some meet and instantly rejoice, bonding at first sight; some remain strangers even after a lifetime; some bow in reverence to transmit; some swear oaths and offer alms before transmission.

Reverence is the foundation of propriety, but reverence without substance is not true reverence. The key lies in observing the disciple’s sincerity, steadfast conduct, and respect for the master and the Dao. Thus, some test repeatedly before transmitting, like Master Yunfang’s ten trials of Lü Dongbin. Some humble themselves before meeting, like Liu Xuande’s three visits to the thatched cottage. Some follow a master for years without wavering; some, knowing another’s sincerity, deliberately impose hardships.

This transmission of the Dao and reception of teachings—how could it be trivial or easily obtained? Thus, some never speak of it to three people, nor transmit where six ears may hear. For the supreme teachings cannot be given to those of middling or lesser capacity, just as middling teachings cannot be given to those of superior wisdom. Teaching must be tailored to the person.

As in Confucius’ school, when Ran You asked whether to act upon hearing something, the Master said: *"Act upon it."* When Zilu asked the same, the Master said: *"With father and elder brother still living, how could you act upon it?"*

For Ran You was retiring, so the Master urged him forward; Zilu was overbearing, so the Master held him back—this is why the same teaching could not be heard by both. Thus, when Gongxi Hua heard both answers, he was left perplexed.

Many among Confucius’ disciples asked about benevolence, yet the Master’s replies varied each time. So it is: when one person is wholeheartedly devoted while another merely listens in passing, the devoted one may be taught, but the casual listener may not. Hence the saying: *"Do not take what is hard-won and treat it as commonplace."*

Among the multitudes to whom the Dao is transmitted, the wise grasp it with ease, while the dull struggle to practice it. If one proclaims it loudly and reveals its mysteries outright, those with the heart to receive it may record it, yet those with the heart but without the karmic affinity will hear it as wind passing the ear—no more than idle chatter.

Disciples, when Śākyamuni Buddha held up a flower before the assembly and said, *"I possess the wondrous luminous true nature, the sublime mind of nirvana, the treasury of the true Dharma-eye—can any of you perceive it?"* Only Mahākāśyapa broke into a subtle smile.

Disciples, Mahākāśyapa and Śākyamuni—one openly built plank roads, the other secretly crossed the hidden pass. Before the great assembly, they transmitted the esoteric Dao in silence, heart to heart, mouth to mouth. Yet none among those disciples knew what was being passed or what was being received.

So too did the great sage Confucius, standing before the assembled worthies and disciples, address Zengzi: *"Shen, my Way is bound together by one thread."* Zengzi replied, *"Yes."* Though many disciples were present, did not the sage transmit the Dao before them all, while Zengzi alone grasped it among the crowd? Those who do not recognize their own minds meet the teaching yet do not truly meet it—they remain ignorant of what is transmitted or bestowed. But Zengzi, deeply attuned to his own nature, naturally aligned with the sage’s mind.

Long ago, the Yellow Emperor journeyed to Mount Kongtong to seek the Dao from Guangchengzi. Though he pleaded repeatedly, Guangchengzi remained silent. The Emperor withdrew, purified himself, and secluded for three months. Returning, he approached from the lower position, advancing on his knees with utmost humility and reverence. Only then, when asked about the essence of the supreme Dao, did Guangchengzi reply:

*"The essence of the supreme Dao is profound and obscure;
its ultimate state is dim and silent.
See nothing, hear nothing—embrace the spirit in stillness,
and the body will naturally align.
Be still, be pure; do not weary your form,
do not disturb your essence,
do not let your thoughts and worries scatter.
Then you may attain longevity.
Guard your externals, close your internals—
excessive cleverness leads to ruin.
I abide in the One and dwell in harmony,
thus for twelve hundred years I have not aged."*

These were the only words he spoke to the Yellow Emperor. Whether you follow them or not is your choice.

This is called "each fulfilling their Dao."

Disciples, within my Daoist gate lie the *Nanhua*’s many subtle truths and the *Chongxu* and *Wenshi*’s countless sacred words. Add to these the Three Caverns and Four Supplements, the thirty-six marvels—how vast the scriptures! Who among you can sweep clean your ears to reverently hear the wondrous teachings of the sacred texts? Who can open wide your eyes to transcend and awaken to the great Dao beyond words? Without awakening, the heart remains unillumined; even if you encounter a sagely master, you will not recognize them.

Disciples, before seeking a master, first seek within yourself. Before inquiring of the Dao, first inquire of your own heart. If you do not follow the precepts in conduct, it will be nearly impossible to find a master who will affirm your Dao. The key lies in cultivating humility and meekness: first carve away all pride and arrogance, soften your manner, and yield with deference. Sever every thought of slander and jealousy. When meeting others, never boast of your abilities—fear only that someone may surpass you. If you encounter a clear-eyed master or a lofty-minded adept, and their single phrase or half-sentence cuts to the core, how will you break free? Like snow melting to reveal the corpse beneath, you cannot escape the discerning eye.

I now exhort you all: seeking a master and inquiring of the Dao is not a matter of carelessly kowtowing a few times before a teacher, nor of merely calling them "Master" with your lips. Today, those who slight their masters and disdain the Dao are everywhere. Disciples, you must urgently turn inward, reflect, and before the successive patriarchs of old, repent your disrespect and arrogance. Transform your old habits and revere the Dharma-treasures. If your heart is truly sincere and earnest, and you keep your eyes open in your search for a master, then Heaven will not fail you—the immortals and perfected ones will come unbidden, without regard to distance or delay.

Hear my gatha:
To seek a master, first master yourself;
to inquire of the Dao, your heart must be sincere.
Only with sincerity can you awaken to the Dao;
with earnest devotion, you will meet good causes.
A meeting so rare it spans ten thousand kalpas,
arriving only after a thousand lifetimes.
If you can fathom my words,
you will suddenly awaken to the unborn root.

From the *Jade Garden Altar Sutra*, Scroll the Middle.

Tenth: Equal Holding of Samādhi and Wisdom

Disciples, those who have received the Initial Perfection Precepts and wish to advance to the Middle Ultimate must first fulfill the subtle and wondrous practices of the ten Initial Perfection Precepts in secret and with diligence before proceeding to receive the three hundred great precepts of the Middle Ultimate.

Disciples, what distinguishes the Middle Ultimate Precepts from the Initial Perfection Precepts? One precept encompasses all precepts; one truth encompasses all truths.

Why, then, after the Initial Perfection, do we have the Middle Ultimate, and after the Middle Ultimate, the Heavenly Immortal Precepts? What is the reason for this progression?

Disciples, this principle is clear and evident. Let me draw it from the emptiness of space to explain to you.

Great assembly, the ten Initial Perfection Precepts you have received are meant to restrain your physical form, to ride the wind and break the waves, forbidding reckless movement or erratic behavior. The three hundred great precepts of the Middle Ultimate are meant to subdue your stubborn mind, forbidding wild thoughts or scattered intentions. The wondrous precepts of the Heavenly Immortal are meant to liberate your true intent, forbidding attachment or entanglement.

Disciples, the ten Initial Perfection Precepts are coarse; the three hundred Middle Ultimate Precepts are refined. The Initial Perfection Precepts govern the six external senses, while the Middle Ultimate Precepts sweep away the six internal defilements. The Heavenly Immortal Precepts enable the three bodies to attain liberation, the eight consciousnesses to dissolve, and the nine demons and ten trials to dare not encroach.

Disciples, the Initial Perfection Precepts are given because you have awakened to past wrongs, deeply reflected on former transgressions, and recognized that human life in this world is fleeting, with impermanence looming over birth and death. Since you have left the household life to become Daoists, you are called "Perfected Ones." Reflect carefully: from the day you left the household life until now, when have you ever truly perfected anything? Year after year, you have idly passed the days, growing old just like the common folk. From dawn to dusk, you wade through rivers and climb mountains, rushing south and north. Though you may have paid homage to several famous mountains, seeing more rocks and trees than the common folk, in the end, you suffer just as they do—trading and traveling, buying and selling. Eating wind and sleeping in water, what purpose does it serve? When have you ever encountered immortals? Those who transmit oral instructions are merely common folk, carrying burdens up and down, with mundane eyes and mortal frames. They recite alchemical classics by rote, clinging stubbornly to trivial details, swallowing stones that cannot be digested, utterly unaware of their flavor. Thus, you differ not at all from the common folk; how can you transcend the worldly and rise above the ordinary?

Today, having received the Initial Perfection Precepts, the heart that recognizes past errors still retains its original face. Why not transform your usual false heart into a true heart, your usual false intentions into true intentions, your usual false visage into a true visage? Reveal your true heart and extend your repentance. From this day of receiving the precepts, you shall be called a disciple of the Initial Perfection. These Initial Perfection Precepts govern the four great dignified postures and adorn the physical form, but they have no bearing on the Dharma-body and are unrelated to samādhi and wisdom. Knowing your restlessness, we use the ten precepts to subdue your body. If you can uphold and practice these precepts, your body will become tranquil and settled, allowing you to advance to the Middle Ultimate Precepts.

Disciples, the Middle Ultimate Precepts pertain to the practice of samādhi, differing from the Initial Perfection Precepts. The Initial Perfection is characterized by the word "precept," the Middle Ultimate by "samādhi," and the Heavenly Immortal Precepts by "wisdom." When the Heavenly Worthy took pity on sentient beings, he established these precepts, samādhi, and wisdom as the means to subdue body, mind, and intent—this is the wondrous treasure of the Golden Elixir, the method for transcending the worldly and rising above the ordinary. Beyond these three—precepts, samādhi, and wisdom—there is no other method. Though there are eighty-four thousand dharmas externally, none can escape these two words: samādhi and wisdom. Whether it be divine elixirs, golden liquid restoration, ascending to heaven in broad daylight, lifting one’s dwelling to soar, divine transformations, emptying the corpse, instantaneous transformation, or entering a womb to seize a new form—all these immortal arts remain steadfast within the radiance of samādhi and wisdom. They are like a bright mirror in the courtyard, where every entry and exit is clearly reflected, all contained within samādhi and wisdom, unable to transcend them.

Disciples, the "middle" in Middle Ultimate refers to the celestial pivot of the Dipper Mother, the unshakable center; the "ultimate" refers to the Southern Ultimate governing birth and the Northern Ultimate governing death, the great mechanism of life and death entirely dependent on the silent movement of the Dipper’s handle. The Middle Ultimate wields the authority of heaven and earth, grasping the handle of life and death. This "middle" is neither inside nor outside, neither left nor right, neither front nor back, neither biased nor partial, neither excessive nor deficient—it is the "middle" of "holding to the mean to achieve harmony," the "middle" of "when words and numbers are exhausted, it is better to abide in the center," the "middle" of the noble one who walks the central path, the "middle" of standing alone without leaning. The Mystic Pearl, the grain of millet, the Pearl of Śākyamuni, the relic, the Great Ultimate of the Golden Elixir—these many alternative names all ultimately refer to this wondrous, luminous, and unobscured true nature.

Disciples, what is the equal holding of samādhi and wisdom? Disciples, this spark of numinous awareness has been entangled by the three karmic actions you have committed since beginningless time, stained by the six defilements, obscured by the seven emotions, invaded by the six desires, and fumigated by the three poisons, while the ten demons forcibly dominate. They have secretly stolen your numinous awareness, leaving you neither daring to die nor daring to live. You cannot observe the Dao of heaven nor grasp the movements of heaven.

Disciples, this spark of numinous awareness is a Dharma-treasure; it should only be reversed, not followed in its ordinary course.

If one follows the ordinary course, one drifts with external things, stirred by circumstances, summoning demons and gathering monstrosities, inviting harm and encountering misfortune, entering and exiting the cycle of rebirth, wandering through the four modes of birth and six paths of existence, adrift and submerged. But if one has received the Supreme Precepts, one must reverse the course. Reversal means not being turned by any thing, not being swayed by any circumstance; demons, monsters, disasters, and misfortunes dare not approach. The cycle of rebirth can be escaped, and wandering can be transcended.

Now, what is meant by "following the ordinary course"? In worldly matters, it is bearing sons and raising daughters, taking wives and purchasing concubines, fathering children and grandchildren, pursuing fame and wealth, expanding households and managing properties, buying fields and acquiring land, wearing fine silks and embroidered robes, indulging in lust and pleasure, killing living beings and harming lives, filling one’s belly with delicacies—all these merely serve the convenience and enjoyment of the physical body. Yet this physical body is originally composed of earth, water, fire, and wind, a temporary vessel formed of skin and flesh. Through the father’s essence and mother’s blood, united in lustful union, qi and blood coalesce, spirit and consciousness invest, and life takes root in the womb. All arises from the illusory transformation of the two qi, yet in the end, it is impermanent, ultimately returning to dust. Only these two matters—merit and transgression—do not concern the physical body; rather, it is the Dharma-body that suffers.

Alas! Disciples, those of you who do not believe this claim that the Dharma-body originally resides within the physical body. Once the physical body dies, the Dharma-body is already empty. When a person dies, their numinous qi disperses and returns to emptiness. How then can one speak of heaven and hell, hungry ghosts and animals, or the Dharma-body receiving retribution?

Now, let me ask you this: when a person dies and their qi scatters into emptiness, why do families set out offerings during the four seasons and eight festivals for their deceased parents? If one claims that after death, this stream of numinous qi is not taken by the underworld authorities for judgment, and that the good and evil, kindness and malice, debts owed, schemes, killings, thefts, and all manner of karmic entanglements of one’s former life no longer concern this stream of qi, then it would not return to partake of the sacrifices offered by descendants in the world. If it does not come to enjoy these sacrifices, then the ancient *Rites of Zhou* and other texts should not have falsely recorded so many sacrificial texts, vessels, rituals, and ceremonies. The great sage Confucius should not have said, "Serve the dead as if they were living, serve the departed as if they were present," or "Sacrifice as if they are present, sacrifice to the spirits as if the spirits are present." "With purity and solemnity, receive the sacrifices, and the spirits will be present above, to the left and right." The *Book of Songs* says, "The spirits come in thought, unfathomable in their reach; King Wen is above, radiant in heaven." Disciples, since these sayings of "as if they are present above" and "King Wen is above" have been passed down, our hearts have already established the sincerity of the spirits’ arrival. If our hearts have already established this sincerity, then the great sages of old like the Duke of Zhou and Confucius must have deeply understood the nature of spirits and ghosts before creating these sacrificial texts, vessels, rituals, and ceremonies to instruct countless generations for all time. How could the sages have spoken deceptive words or fabricated falsehoods?

Moreover, consider those scholar-officials who receive posthumous titles and ranks: if the stream of numinous qi after death scatters and becomes insensate, then the honors of posthumous enfeoffment would be excessive. Who would enjoy the golden seals and purple patents or ascend to heavenly favor? If receiving blessings implies the existence of spirits and ghosts, while suffering punishment implies their absence, then it is the human heart that lacks clarity, and the numinous awareness that remains unenlightened.

There are also those cunning, murderous fools who only know greed for wine, lust, and wealth, deluded by material gain. They have not examined the karmic roots of what comes after death, recognizing only the present blood and qi. They stubbornly recite a few lines of poetry: *"Do not ponder the endless matters after death; just drain this cup of wine in life."* They never recite those other two lines: *"When the body perishes, nothing is taken away; only karma follows one into the dark."*

Disciples, karma has three kinds. The first is unwholesome karma—all entangling, unbroken, unending, and unresolved actions, with causes and effects, fruits and retributions. Those who do not believe in spirits and ghosts, do not revere heaven and earth, do not fear the law, are disloyal to the sovereign, unfilial to parents, corrupt the Three Bonds, ruin the Five Constants, slander sages and worthies, kill, steal, engage in sexual misconduct, act cruelly and viciously, behave recklessly and falsely, instill fear in their households, and bully their villages—after such people die, they fall into hell, transmigrating through its chambers, enduring endless suffering. Later, they are reborn in the world as animals. After exhausting their animal retribution, they return as humans, but with incomplete faculties, dull-witted and confused, unaware of human affairs, despised and loathed by all, their lives degraded and wretched, their bodies reduced to servitude. They become beggars, their bodies covered in sores, infested with lice and filth, clothed in rags, starving, unable to fill their mouths, suffering cold and hunger without recourse, enduring myriad pains. They die in the wilderness, their flesh eaten by ants and dragged away by dogs. Their solitary souls, adrift, sink once more into hell.

The second is wholesome karma—those who are intelligent and upright, honest and impartial, bringing joy to their six relations and peace to their villages, respecting parents, revering the divine, honoring heaven and earth, serving the sovereign, venerating teachers and elders, cherishing friends, cultivating virtue and transforming desires, not being greedy with wealth, not lusting after beauty, maintaining the Five Constants, and conducting all affairs with care. Even those monks in the mountains and old Daoists in the caves who embrace simplicity, endure humiliation, and though their samādhi is not yet firm and their Dao-practice not yet complete—after such people die, they are reborn as humans, becoming high officials or esteemed teachers, or enjoying ready-made wealth and honor, or attaining both fortune and longevity, living in ease and splendor, their lives filled with joy.

The third karma is the pure karma, with aspirations set upon sages and worthies, and wishes directed toward immortals and buddhas. The mind abides in good thoughts, the mouth speaks good words, and the body performs good deeds. One associates with good people, treads upon good earth, and holds good objects in hand. Solemn and dignified, the body does not move recklessly, the mind does not wander idly. One strives for a pure heart, strives for a still heart. With long and deep cultivation, the original spirit becomes profoundly settled, dwelling constantly within the Crimson Chamber, in the Yellow Court, in the Golden Gates and Jade Halls. All entanglements suddenly cease, all thoughts become empty, and only the true spirit is perceived. Form is forgotten, things are forgotten, realms are forgotten, and mechanisms are forgotten—this is called *ding* (samādhi). This is no small matter; it is the luminous and unobscured realm of the Three Purities, transcending the thirty-six heavens above and penetrating the seventy-two earths below. One roams freely beyond the Three Realms and revolves within the Five Phases.

Within this state of *ding*, it is dim and profound, silent and obscure. Heaven and earth revolve and return to primordial chaos, merging into a single *qi*. It is neither heaven above, nor earth below, nor human in between. It cannot be spoken, cannot be described, cannot be conceived. Suddenly, a divine radiance shines forth, and a wheel of wisdom-nature surges forth. The clear is divided into heaven, the turbid into earth, and the harmonious *qi* within the principle becomes the Dharma-body. Wisdom pervades the Three Realms, illuminating the Great Mystery. No being can escape its discernment, no affair is unknown in its coming and going. There is not the slightest hindrance, not the thinnest obstruction, not a speck of dust or filth.

All heavenly dragons, ghosts, spirits, demons, and monsters submit in reverence. Yama, upon seeing it, dare not raise his voice; Ox-Head and Nightmare, fists raised, bow in submission. The ledger of life holds no name, the register of death bears no entry—one may thus attain longevity in the world. By expounding the Dharma and delivering beings, one may ascend in spirit and transform. Ultimately, one enters the realm of purity and emptiness, ascends to pay homage to the Beginningless, and forever escapes the cycle of rebirth.

All of you, the pivotal celestial mechanism of transcendence lies solely in the movement and stillness of the true heart. Profound stillness is called the power of *ding*; true *ding* is called the radiance of wisdom. If the deluded mind is not first put to death, how can one stabilize the spirit and settle the *qi*? If one cannot abide in constant purity and stillness, how can one enter *ding*? If one cannot enter *ding*, how can one attain wisdom?

All of you, when the heart is empty, the spirit is settled; when the spirit is settled, radiance is born. If there is *ding* without wisdom, it is called the yin-spirit overcoming the yang-spirit. One must give rise to wisdom within *ding*. Wisdom is the Dharma-body; *ding* is the Buddha-nature.

All of you, *ding* is the home, precepts are the path, and wisdom is the living person. All things, all realms, and all affairs in the world are but guests. If *ding* and wisdom mutually give rise to one another, entering the gate of manifold wonders, then the spiritual powers and wisdom of the true master are fully nurtured, and radiant light manifests. One can respond to all things and affairs without being bound by them; one can transform all worldly realms without being deluded by them; one can escape the cycles of yin and yang, life and death.

All of you, first you must understand the two paths of sin and blessing, the retribution of cause and effect. Follow the precepts and practice them one by one, not daring to deviate in the slightest. After long contemplation and realization, clarity and understanding will naturally arise. Only then should one enter stillness and engage in meditative observation. Within *ding*, the original nature becomes perfectly luminous, the radiance of wisdom shines brightly, and the spirit and *qi* suddenly awaken. Then, mountains, rivers, and the great earth do not extend beyond one’s body; the life and death of the myriad beings do not extend beyond a single thought. From the true master’s numinous clarity, there is a handle that prevents entry into the cycle of rebirth.

This work of the "middle" cannot be substituted by father or son, nor can it be known by gods or ghosts. Each of you must personally attend to it and practice it. All of you, I erect the ladder to heaven—who knows who will ascend it? I pole the raft of the Dao—who knows who will board it?

Hear this poor Daoist’s gāthā:
*"The River of Love stretches boundless—none cross its tide,
The Sea of Suffering yawns wide—few bridges span its side.
Hasten, all, to hold the Three Hundred Precepts tight,
For in idle moments, *ding* and wisdom rise above the waves’ might."*

**11. Cultivating the Dao in Secret Practice**
All of you, since you have vowed to cultivate the true, and wish to become perfect Daoists, you must first clearly distinguish between the real and the false, discerning them thoroughly before applying effort. Only by strenuously transforming the false into the true do you fulfill the duty of a cultivator.

All of you, listen as I speak of the false, so that you may cultivate the true.

All of you, this body of yours is entirely false—it is but an impermanent phantom. The six roots will ultimately decay, the six consciousnesses will ultimately dissolve into emptiness. Though the breath in your throat serves a thousand uses, in a single moment of impermanence, all things cease.

All of you, have you not seen those born into the world—
nine feet tall, their waists ten spans wide;
faces like the full moon, lips as if stained with cinnabar;

Eyes like black lacquer, skin soft as fine lard;
Visage imposing, bearing majestic and stern;
Eloquent of speech, rich in wisdom and stratagems;
A thousand skills at hand, ten thousand schemes in mind;
Keen of intellect and learned, strong of limb and martial;
High officials and fierce generals, artisans and men of talent;
Engaged in trade and commerce, seizing profit and contending for fame;
Greedy for glory to rise in rank, amassing wealth to build their houses.
In painted halls, twelve golden hairpins play and sing;
On jade steps, three thousand bejeweled slippers come and go in obsequious attendance.
Gold and silver surpass the Northern Dipper, treasures rival Mount Tai’s southern peaks.
Feasting on delicacies in brocade robes, each bite a hundred rare flavors;
Consorting with the bold and chivalrous, everywhere met with elaborate courtesies.
When a wife reaches middle age, she is cast aside for the new;
Concubines gather in throngs, heedless of spirit’s withering and essence’s exhaustion.
Wealth and property abound, fertile fields of ten thousand *qing* lay the foundation;
Children precocious, yet a first-rank official’s post still seems too small.
Day and night without rest, infatuated with flowers and enamored of beauty;
Greed unceasing, body wearied and mind taxed.

Amidst summer damp, wind, and cold, the six pulses of yin and yang fall into discord;
Through ceaseless toil and pursuit, the three *hun* souls scatter and take flight.
A hundred ailments assail, bringing birth, aging, sickness, and suffering;
A thousand calamities cling fast, with weariness and transgression unshaken.
Ginseng and poria are taken in vain, heaven and earth invoked to no avail;
A thousand pains and sorrows defy description—one morning, the qi severs, and the soul descends to the netherworld.
Once so stately in appearance, before the body turns on the bed, others already cover their noses;
Once so awe-inspiring in presence, the moment the eyes close, the face turns upward to the sky.
The four limbs are gathered into wood, the likeness preserved only on paper;
Children do not die in one’s stead, nor do wives and concubines follow in death.
The corpse is not yet cold, yet the living have already conceived new schemes;
Brothers divide wealth and seize property, while wives and concubines hide treasures and fine garments.
Those with sons begin plotting how to pass the days;
Those without heirs at once consider remarrying.
At the gate, carriages and horses of guests grow sparse—common wisdom says, *"When a man lives, his favor lives with him"*;
In the household, servants begin to steal, for as the saying goes, *"When power wanes, even slaves betray."*
Who tends to the crumbling walls and collapsed beams? Who notices the family’s decline?
Wives turn wanton, sons prove unfilial—each looks only to their own future.
When has the dead ever returned to life? Who has ever gone and come back again?

Born with empty fists, one departs with bare hands.
The physical form returns to earth, the name dissolves into emptiness;
The two paths of good and evil clearly bear their retribution.
All of you, observe these illusory forms of the material world—are they not false?
Yet while they are false, the one spark of true spirit within—seeking wealth and honor, desiring wives and concubines, cherishing sons and grandsons, indulging in glory and riches—is undeniably real.
See where this true spirit goes: clearly, it journeys into the unseen.
If it is bound in the unseen, can it still cling to wives, concubines, beloved children, wealth, and glory?

All of you, the two causes of good and evil, the two retributions of sin and blessing, the two fruits of suffering and joy—these truly follow like shadows.
If the Dharma-body suffers torment, can even a thread escape?
Thus, you must regard the physical form as light and the Dharma-body as weighty, using the false to cultivate the true, preserving the true and discarding the false, to seek liberation from the sea of suffering.
Yet without this physical form, there is no place to cultivate, and the solitary Dharma-spirit, unable to govern itself, falls into the six paths of rebirth—then the labor is in vain.

Since we have received human form and entered the Dao’s gate, we must escape the cycle of rebirth while the light of our eyes has not yet dimmed, advancing diligently in true cultivation.
How to cultivate? All of you, sweep clean the six sense-gates and their dust, harmonize the five viscera and their qi, and let the master abide constantly in the spirit-terrace, so that demonic thieves cannot invade.
Practice many good deeds to eradicate the roots of sin.

Yet within the method of true cultivation, there are two paths—true and false, with effort and without.
The *Vajracchedikā Sūtra* says: *"All conditioned things are like dreams, illusions, bubbles, shadows, like dew and like lightning."*
The *Scripture of Purity* says: *"Living beings fail to attain the true Dao because of deluded thoughts."*
From these scriptures, we know that the path of effort is not the best.

Alas, there is one school that manipulates essence and moves qi, extends life and replenishes vitality, reverses aging and restores youth, seeking immortality—all by clinging to form in cultivation.
Others ascend lead and descend mercury, forge cauldrons and burn thatch, ingest elixirs, swallow talismans, and consume qi.
These are all attempts to use the false to cultivate the true, mere conditioned methods—how can they reveal the nature, establish destiny, and escape rebirth?
To transcend life and death, this is not the way.

All of you, in using the false to cultivate the true, you must investigate the great matter of life and death and truly understand the authentic path.
Where does this path lie? In the mind’s compliance or defiance alone.
Comply, and it follows others; defy, and it follows the self.
This physical form—whether cultivated or not—must die. Even if one lives a thousand years, it will return to earth. Why, then, does it come?

All of you, what has form must decay; what has a beginning must end; what is created must transform; what gathers must disperse; what comes must go; what is accomplished must fail; what is strong must age.
Since this body is born, it must die.
The method of transcending life and death I speak of does not concern this body—it merely borrows it as a dwelling to cultivate the heavenly destiny of the Dharma-body.

Outsiders, not understanding this principle, take it as real, cling to form, and seek to make this fleshly body imperishable and deathless—is this not laughable?
The method of transcending life and death I speak of lies only within the true mind of this body, in the thoughts it moves and the deeds it performs.
When deluded thoughts do not stir, the Dharma-body arises;
When the Dharma-body is still, the heavenly mechanism moves;
When the heavenly mechanism moves, the true light appears.
Yet because this true light cannot be perfected, we rely on this physical form to perform many good deeds.

Good deeds, too, have truth and falsehood: clinging to form makes them false; not clinging to form makes them true.
Observe the Tathāgata: He gives without clinging to form, accumulates merit without clinging to form, expounds the Dharma without clinging to form, cultivates the Dao without clinging to form, emerges into the world without clinging to form—thus He emerges into the world.
Emerging into the world, He transcends life and death.

The *Scripture of Purity* says: *"The highest virtue does not claim virtue."*
This means not grasping. If one boasts of merit after doing good, claims virtue after practicing kindness, or asserts attainment after meditation and contemplation—even if true, this clinging to form means one is not liberated. How can one escape life and death? One may live a few more years and gain some blessings, but when blessings are exhausted, one still cannot transcend rebirth.

All of you, I urge you to follow the words of the Most High, which are never wrong: *"Set the body aside, and it endures; place the self last, and it comes first."* Only then can one die yet not perish.
All of you, set this body aside—do not obsess over refining essence and moving qi, coveting the ascent and descent of essence, the unblocking of orifices, the flow of blood and meridians, the prolongation of life, or the cure of illness.
If you become attached to these pursuits, you will only strengthen the physical form, seeking fleeting joy and freedom, while neglecting your true nature, failing to tend to it day and night.
Then, one day, when the little ghosts catch you unawares, where will your Dharma-body drift in the waves? Your physical form will be consigned to the mud, and in the end, all will be empty.

I ask all of you to practice diligently in secret. Do not focus solely on cultivating the physical form—turn instead to the true matter of life and death, and cultivate the Dharma-body.
If you can quietly practice the work of subduing the mind and enduring hardship, and early see your nature, how can you worry that your destiny will not be established?

All of you, let me remind you: the physical form is but a house, while the Dharma-body is the master who dwells within. If the master possesses treasure, how can the house not be well-ordered? But if the master falls ill, or invites misfortune, or summons calamity, and is taken away—who then will dwell in that well-ordered house?

All of you, let me raise this matter one level higher to awaken your understanding. The physical form is a rented house, not one you have bought. When the master departs, it returns to dust, and the four elements—earth, water, fire, and wind—are each restored to their source. If you can quietly cultivate a true Dharma-body free from attachment to form, how can you worry that the physical form will not find a good place to rest?

All of you, I have a few humble verses—listen as I recite them:

The physical form is but the Dharma-body’s house;
When the inner is bright, the outer naturally shines.
If only the master cultivates blessings and wisdom,
How can the house fail to radiate splendor?

To attain perfection, first dispel the false;
The true Dharma must cast aside false delusions.
Do not boast, do not cling to form—
Cultivate both nature and life to transcend impermanence.

Silent endurance is the paramita of forbearance;
True non-action is the highest reality.
Only by quieting the mind and seeking liberation
Can the illusory body be set down and the true body revealed.

Clinging to life and fearing death, you will still die;
Attaching to form in cultivation, how can you attain truth?
The Tathagata severed body and limbs,
The Jade Emperor once endured humiliation.

Forgetting the self, he perished through three thousand kalpas;
Abandoning the kingdom, he retreated to the mountains for eight hundred years.
Yet the Daoist clings to this skin-bag of illusion—
Through ten thousand kalpas and a thousand lives, how can he escape the dust?

Cease your striving, spare your spirit in vain;
All that has form must ultimately return to yin.
If you lose the true nature of Suchness,
You will drift endlessly in the苦海, with no place to seek refuge.

Alas! Pity those who cling to illusion within illusion,
Layer upon layer of falsehood—
In vain they study the Perfect Truth, yet fail to grasp reality.
Birth, aging, sickness, demons, the sorrow of death—
When the hour comes, how are they different from worldly people?

In vain they don the yellow crown and feathered robes,
Yet never comprehend the mechanism of life and death.
They wander the ends of the earth in search of clothing and food,
Only for karmic retribution to claim them, turning them to mud.

If you do not understand that sin and blessing are fundamentally empty,
The wheel of birth and death will never cease.
If you have not awakened to the truth that the false and real reside within you,
Who then will reveal the light of wisdom?

All of you, reflect deeply: the impermanence of life and death is swift. The secret practices I speak of number three hundred, comprising the Three Hundred Subtle Precepts of the Supreme Ultimate. Cultivating the body refines its posture; cultivating the mind dissolves deluded thoughts. Applied inwardly, it makes one sagely; applied outwardly, it makes one kingly. It enables transcendence of the world and attainment of the fruit of pure emptiness, allowing one to deliver others from suffering and end the cycle of birth and death.

The most crucial element is secrecy. Without secrecy, one cannot attain perfection; without perfection, the mind remains unclear; and if the mind is unclear, the nature cannot be seen.

All of you, what does "secret" mean? The sages used it to purify the mind and retreat into concealment. Secrecy is the utmost vigilance. Utmost precision is hidden in obscurity—this is the ultimate secrecy.

All of you, those who wish to receive the Supreme Ultimate Precepts must first observe the first hundred precepts, which are the great divine mantra for purifying the body. By upholding this mantra with reverence, the body’s restlessness must be entirely dispelled, transforming it into stillness. Frivolity must be cast aside, replaced by steadiness. In the four great deportments—walking, sitting, standing, and lying—one must walk the middle path, sit without leaning to one side, stand upright without leaning against walls or pillars, or propping oneself on tables. When lying down, one must curl the body to the side, never sprawling on the back with loud snoring. Even the slightest sound of breath must be regulated, cultivating an appearance of reverence and propriety—this is called "external adornment."

The second hundred precepts are the great divine mantra for purifying the mind. By contemplating them with precision and aligning with the Dao, one must delve deeply and awaken secretly, ensuring every thought returns to truth, every action accords with the Dao, and not a single word is neglected. One must contemplate again and again, awaken again and again, observing things from afar and reflecting on the body up close, until the mind’s wildness, disorder, and perversity are entirely eradicated. Only then will the true mind settle in tranquility.

Then, from the two hundredth to the three hundredth precept, one enters the great divine mantra for purifying the intent. Not a single thread must be leaked. Within it lie the subtle mechanisms of ebb and flow, the principles of interaction, hidden in the mysterious capital’s treasury—subtle, wondrous, ineffable, beyond thought or description. It can only be grasped through spiritual insight, not transmitted in words. Herein lies the supreme, most honored, non-actional wondrous Dao.

All of you, this is the secret practice of cultivating the true. Listen carefully to my next words and remember them well: the supreme Dao abhors disclosure.

All of you, the purpose of cultivating the true is to transcend birth and death—how could this be a trivial matter? If the heavenly mechanism is not kept secret, it will be leaked to the unworthy. Thus, when Master Zhang Ziyang of the Purple Yang transmitted it to the unworthy three times, he suffered heavenly punishment three times. It must not be disclosed. How much more so for those who seek to transcend the cycle of rebirth, leap beyond the world, and become an indestructible true person? Would this not incur the envy of heaven and earth, the wrath of ghosts and spirits, the resentment of yin and yang, and the workings of creation? Moreover, this reversal of fate and inversion of conduct sets you at odds with worldly laws like fire and ice.

You must be meticulous and vigilant. Otherwise, your six relations will turn against you, your nine clans will become enemies, your spouse will grow indifferent, and your friends will lose faith—all because you failed to arouse courageous resolve, leading to a wavering of the Daoist heart.

**Twelve: Repaying Kindness and Dispelling Calamities**

All of you, since you have left the household life to seek transcendence, you must repent and eliminate the karmic debts accumulated over a thousand lifetimes, the deep-seated grievances of past generations. Only by extinguishing them from this moment onward, never to arise again, can you clear the suffering of repayment and retribution.

This discourse still speaks of the conduct of inferior retribution—those who flee from karmic debts, the cowardly and life-clinging, the petty and incapable. Such persons remain benighted in heart, their innate nature yet unmanifest. They live only for the present, heedless of future lives. Now, let me recount to you one such case of heterodox practice.

There was once a Daoist who left the household life midway through his journey, wandering in search of truth. He met several companions, and together they vowed to build a hermitage on Mount Lao in Shandong to cultivate the Dao. Later, due to war, they descended the mountain and settled in the foothills of Mount Wangwu in Henan, where they lived alone in meditation. Though six in number and dwelling together, each harbored different aspirations and pursued distinct practices. After a year, three departed, leaving only three who renewed their vows to seek transcendence.

Later, one of the three entered *samadhi* and passed away. The remaining two grew even more resolute. Then another entered *samadhi* and departed, leaving only one to cultivate in solitude. During meditation, he entered a deep trance, and his spirit wandered to Mount Tiantai, where he unexpectedly encountered the friend who had passed later. Overjoyed, the departed one said:

"By fortunate karmic connection, I must tell you this: you should revise the vow you made years ago. When I first vowed to cultivate, I sought to repent and eliminate karmic debts to attain liberation. Yet when my allotted worldly years ended, I arrived at the outer gates of the Three Heavens, where the examining officials proclaimed: *'This one’s karmic roots remain; their fate is inescapable. Their name is absent from the celestial register, their place unassigned in the Cinnabar Terrace. They may not proceed further but must report to the Three Primordials’ Assembly Hall in Mount Yuntai to receive office.'* Immediately, a mighty wind and vast *qi* obscured the heavenly gates, and I found myself in the Palace of the Three Officials.

The Three Great Emperors consulted their ledgers and said: *'You, with your inferior aspirations and heterodox practices, dared to seek liberation. Out of compassion for your ignorance, we appoint you provisionally as the mountain spirit of the Tongbo Palace on Mount Tiantai. When a vacancy arises in the underworld bureaucracy, you may be formally installed.'* I pleaded for further instruction to continue my cultivation in the unseen realm. The Three Great Emperors, their faces kind, replied:

*'When you sat in meditation, your thoughts were not purified, your mind not emptied. You failed to see through the emptiness of the physical form and the reality of the numinous nature, nor did you awaken to the non-emptiness within emptiness. You knew only to repent the karmic debts of a thousand lives and eliminate the deep-seated grievances of past generations, believing that after leaving the household life, karmic transgressions and debts would never arise again. Yet you never deeply investigated how to extinguish grievances within the numinous nature or how to repent karmic debts. How could the karmic debts accumulated over countless kalpas and the grievances forged across lifetimes be dismissed with mere words or thoughts, as if swept away by the wind? You must enter the gate with great resolve, study the supreme vehicle of the great root and great capacity, and embrace universal salvation.

The great vehicle of supreme capacity extinguishes the mundane heart, rendering heaven and earth empty and illusory forms as ash. Yet even then, one’s deep-seated karmic grievances may remain unresolved. How can debts of wealth and life be so lightly dismissed? Thus, the ancient Buddha King Ali severed his own limbs to repay past debts, leaving no trace behind, and thereby attained the fruit of Sakyamuni. The Sixth Patriarch washed away his deep-seated grievances, bearing even the slightest residue, and thus attained the great mirror of the Western Heaven.

Now, your aspirations are petty, your roots weak. Unwilling to repay karmic debts, you seek only to escape suffering. You cling too tightly to the physical form, fearing the arrival of karmic adversaries, dreading punishment, beatings, death, and pain. Your sole desire is for the physical form to enjoy perpetual bliss—this selfish fear of repayment is the mark of inferior roots, the hallmark of the lesser vehicle.

If the root of grievance is not emptied, it will resurface in future kalpas. If the cause of karmic debt remains, you will encounter it again in future lives. Though you call yourself one who has left the household life, you are in truth only fleeing suffering. Unable to escape it, you remain entangled kalpa after kalpa, generation after generation, all because your initial vow was weak and your aspirations narrow.

This life of leaving the household life is called cultivating merit, not cultivating the Dao. You were fated to reenter the wheel of rebirth and transmigrate for vast blessings. Yet because you once recited the *Divine Dharma Treasure* a hundred times and chanted the *Maitreya Sacred Name* for three years with sincere devotion, you were appointed to the rank of Orthodox Unity Perfected One. You are now due for formal investiture as an official in the underworld bureaucracy. Moreover, as you performed scripture recitations for patrons in life without error and distributed the alms you received, you merit promotion by one rank. Your name is recorded for selection as deputy mountain spirit of a grotto-heaven. Go swiftly to assume your duties, and continue your unseen cultivation without negligence.'*

At this, I suddenly awakened, regretting my narrow aspirations. Only then did I understand that small causes yield small fruits, while great vows bring great rewards. Now, it is too late for remorse. I came to your realm of pure spiritual awakening to tell you this, but as I am bound by my office, I dare not leave my mountain’s bounds. My friend, you have arrived at the perfect moment—go and renew your vow. Spare no effort in repaying all karmic debts, whether to friends or foes, and never retreat. Only then can your fruit be great. If even the slightest fear or hesitation lingers, you will fail the test of escape, and even if you succeed, your fruition will remain small."

With that, he vanished. Emerging from meditation, the Daoist at last understood that he had been a lesser vehicle heterodox, one who merely sought personal perfection—and in the end, he would remain but a mountain ghost.

In haste, he burned down his thatched hut, shouldered his rush cushion, gourd, and staff, and began anew to cultivate the ground of his mind. He endured every humiliation, bore every hardship, and practiced every discipline. He drove out stray thoughts and tempered body and mind. He vowed that for those with whom he had entanglements, he would face blades and axes without flinching, still embracing their resolution; for those to whom he owed karmic debts, he would brave water and fire, repaying them in full through the kalpas. He regarded this flesh-and-blood body as finite, while the life of his nature’s heaven he preserved in purity. Unencumbered and unobstructed, undisturbed and unshaken, he stood bare and radiant, round and complete, utterly naked—coming and going with perfect freedom. He desired no blessings even when fortune came, nor shunned suffering when it arrived. With this single resolve, he passed many more years.

Then, one day in deep meditation, he saw a Daoist approach to pay respects and bow in homage. Looking closely, it was the same friend who had first appeared to him in transformation. His appearance remained unchanged, but his face bore shame, and he dared not lift his gaze. Asked the reason for his coming, he explained that he had followed a deviant teaching from his master, failing to grasp the central principle. He had long focused his spirit and qi on visualizing the cinnabar field, and through years of deep practice, had become a corpse-guarding ghost. His light extended only a foot or so, illuminating only his own bodily form and shell, while beyond his body all remained dark, nothing visible. Now, because this Daoist had entered deep meditation and his light had grown, it had drawn in this long-deceased friend, bringing him into his meditative realm. After a short while, he vanished again.

This encounter deepened the surviving Daoist’s understanding of the principle of nature. He realized that life resides within nature: with each increment of comprehension, light increases; with each increase of light, wisdom grows; with each growth of wisdom, virtue and power expand; and with each expansion of virtue and power, the fruit of attainment rises higher. Then he emerged from meditation.

This Daoist, having swept clean his six senses, dissolved his eight consciousnesses, emptied his five aggregates, and severed his seven emotions, was now fully prepared to take refuge in the Eternally Pure and Tranquil Great Heavenly Worthy. Yet, by the fate of his mortal form—bestowed by his parents, nurtured by heaven and earth—his allotted span of qi and destiny had reached its end. The next day, he descended the mountain and addressed the external protectors of the various halls: "I must now take leave of you all and return home." The assembly asked, "Why must you depart so hastily?" The Daoist replied, "I have repaid my three karmic debts, yet four great debts of gratitude remain unfulfilled. Thus, I must be reborn to settle this one final thought." With these words, he clasped his hands, turned to bow toward the empty sky, and in that very posture, sat in transformation and passed away.

Disciples, listen well: the paths of Dao may differ in correctness, and the vows may vary in magnitude. These three individuals, when we observe their turning back, reveal ranks of attainment that are by no means the same. Disciples, those with great aspirations become great beings; those with small aspirations remain small. For if the aspiration is not great, the heart cannot be vast. If the heart is not vast, the capacity cannot be broad, the vow cannot be universal, the understanding shallow, the vision narrow—then the qi one cultivates cannot be vast and boundless. If qi is not vast and boundless, it merely fills this illusory sack of skin, unable to pervade the Great Void, to stand between heaven and earth, to penetrate sun and moon, or to permeate the ten thousand kinds. How then can this be called the Great and Perfect Dao?

Disciples, we are born under heaven’s covering and earth’s bearing, illumined by the sun and moon, reared by our parents, and instructed by ruler and teacher—these are the Four Gratitudes, profound and boundless, impossible to fully repay. Yet we still fall back into the suffering of the colored body and the five aggregates, still unable to transcend, and our dual cultivation of merit and wisdom remains impermanent. Disciples, now that you have taken refuge under the Three Treasures, why have you not yet transcended suffering? Why does your merit and wisdom not endure? It is because karmic debts are the roots of love between husband and wife, parent and child, and merit and wisdom are the sea of desires for wealth and honor. As the ancient sages said: "The river of love has waves a thousand feet deep; the sea of desire has billows ten thousand layers high." Only when the waters dry and the waves subside, when the source of nature is perfectly clear, can you awaken.

You must realize that all beings—past and present—share this same source of nature. Whether born from womb, egg, moisture, or transformation, all possess awareness. Recognizing that self and others share this same source is to repay heaven. With boundless compassion, enduring filth and humiliation, embracing all life without cease—whether flying, swimming, moving, or growing—this is to repay earth. When the ground of nature is luminous and the sky of nature is vast and bright, you meet those lost in darkness and, with true words, guide them, breaking through their delusion. You encounter those drowning in ignorance and, by expounding the Dharma, lift them from their obstacles—this is to repay the sun and moon.

Diligently follow your teacher’s instructions, strictly adhere to the laws of the land, and reverently uphold the king’s decrees. Do not transgress your station, violate virtue, or stray from the natural order. Uphold the pure regulations and observe the scriptural teachings. Pray for the emperor’s longevity and the stability of the realm. Pass these teachings to future generations and propagate the true Dao—this is to repay ruler and teacher.

The body is received from one’s parents; do not defile hair or skin. Dissolve the selfishness between self and others, repent and relieve the suffering of the departed. For the toil of past parents, pray to resolve the karmic knots of many lives. For the hardships of present kin, repay their afflictions and transgressions. Devote this entire colored body to unceasing filial piety. If you do not deliver your parents, you yourself cannot ascend to truth. Reverence all people’s parents as you would your own, and cherish all children as you would your own—so that the seven ancestors may ascend and the three generations rise high—this is to repay your parents.

Disciples, if your heart holds even the slightest obstruction, how can you behold the Three Pure Ones, the Jade Emperor, the Three Officials, the Four Saints, the Five Elders, or the Seven Perfected? How can you repay heaven, earth, sun, moon, ruler, teacher, or parents? Now, you constantly divide self and others, habitually give rise to ignorance. Your heart is narrow—unable to endure even one matter. Your capacity is shallow—unable to contain even one person. You do not examine origins, misjudge right and wrong. You rejoice in honor and rage at humiliation. Your aspirations lack steadfastness, your thoughts lack clarity. Your heart lacks tolerance, your body indulges in laziness. You dismiss small faults as insignificant, yet cling to minor strengths with pride. How then can you repay heaven, earth, ruler, teacher, or ancestors?

Disciples, to repay the gratitude of heaven and earth, you must understand the Way of heaven and earth, embody the heart of heaven and earth, penetrate the principles of heaven and earth, and realize the virtue of heaven and earth. Do not deceive even in darkness; sever all false passions. Let wisdom’s light shine universally, and truly embrace all defilements. In loss, accept loss without a trace of self; in suffering, endure suffering without the slightest deceit. Cultivate with steadfast effort, and your realm will shine with clarity. When virtue is weighty and the Dao is lofty, even ghosts and spirits revere you. When spirit is clear and wisdom arises, things transform and people return to the Way. Above, you may move the throne of the Emperor; below, you may command thunder and lightning. In drought, pray for rain to nourish the people; in flood, pray for clear skies to dispel the waters’ calamity. Demons and goblins flee, and evil spirits vanish. Above, pray for the eternal stability of the nation and the boundless longevity of the sage; below, pray for the land’s songs of joy and the people’s prosperity.
