This is how one propagates the ancestral teachings and revives the practice of the Dao.

Moreover, consider how our parents endured ten months of pregnancy and three years of nursing, bearing countless hardships—gratitude so deep it cannot be measured. As we grow, they hope for our support in old age, a glorious family line, and a proper burial. The ruler, too, rises early and retires late, with the Six Ministries and Nine Chief Ministers managing governance, eliminating evil, nurturing the good, suppressing wrongdoing, and honoring virtue.

Masters, by startling the deaf and enlightening the blind, they emulate earth following heaven, ensuring the Three Bonds are made clear and the Five Constants fully realized. They distinguish good from evil, the human from the beast—how shallow, then, could their virtue be?

Yet you, while at home, fail to honor and support your parents; in office, you cannot serve the state with wisdom. Your clothing relies on the alms of a thousand households; your food depends on the toil of ten thousand farmers. Adrift on the waves, you follow the current, passing your days in confusion. Idle and parasitic, you mutter ceaselessly, neglecting the cultivation of the Dao and disregarding the precepts and commandments. Your every action violates the rules; your spirit is dull, your mind scattered. When you ascend the altar to pray for the nation, the gods and spirits do not descend. When you drive out evil and purify pestilence, disasters and epidemics do not heal. Talismans lose their efficacy; prayers and exorcisms are in vain. The basest among you, when met with darkness or floods, curse the wind and rail against the rain, resenting heaven and blaming earth. You wander recklessly, defy your kin, break the law, and rage at others.

Disciples, observe the oxen, horses, donkeys, and mules, the swine, sheep, dogs, and pigs—all possess the five senses and six apertures, the yin and yang, male and female, awareness and intelligence. Yet today, you differ from them only by this: you can speak.

At that moment, the Precept Master again expounded in verse:

Cultivate both concentration and wisdom, refine the precepts,
Heaven and hell become self-evident.
Unburdened by even a thread, radiance remains ever pure,
All entanglements dissolve, the heart grows clear.
The mandate of heaven is not easily received,
To transcend life and death requires a sincere heart.
Deviant paths and strange arts branch in many directions—
I urge all to awaken to true integrity.
The Four Graces remain unrepayed, the heart feels shame;
The Three Karmas persist, the Dao is not achieved.
To repay the Four Graces, first uphold the precepts;
To dissolve the Three Karmas, cultivate the true.
Upholding precepts naturally leads to walking the true path,
Cultivating the true ultimately awakens to the floating life.
Once the floating life is seen through and impermanence is grasped,
The Three Karmas are empty, and the Four Graces are repaid.
To leave the world and renounce the household, seeking to transcend the dust,
Yet clinging to greed, anger, and delusion—how can truth be realized?
Only when worldly passions are exhausted does the heart grow pure;
Only when the celestial nature shines is the Dao near.
See through the illusory body—what is real?
Pierce the nature of things—what endures?
Not a thread clings, the three minds are extinguished,
The Ten Precepts fully observed, one walks in freedom.

**13. Resolving the Will and Making Vows**

Disciples, since ancient times, sages, immortals, and buddhas have seen through worldly affairs, recognizing all conditioned things and every form as empty and illusory. They sought to transcend the world, to awaken to life and death, to retreat deep into the mountains, to forget the body and risk life itself in pursuit of the supreme Dao.

Disciples, you know only the names of sages, immortals, and buddhas, but not their true essence. You all possess the desire to become sages, immortals, and buddhas, yet you have not established their resolve. You all wish to attain the fruits of sages, immortals, and buddhas, yet you do not cultivate their causes. You all aspire to reach the station of sages, immortals, and buddhas, yet you do not generate their vow-power. Thus, you can speak of the path but cannot walk it—your mouths are clear, but your hearts remain obscured.

The Dao is not understood because one has not encountered a true master of the Dao. The Dao is not practiced because one has not found a true practitioner of the Dao. Those called *daoshi*—how many truly grasp the subtleties of the Daoist? Those named *Quanzhen*—who among them embodies the reality of the Complete Truth? No wonder the teachings decline and the ancestral path withers.

Today, having taken refuge in the Three Treasures and received the precepts, you may be said to have encountered a true master of the Dao. But you must follow my true words and practice the deeds of sages, immortals, and buddhas—only then are you called a practitioner of the Dao.

Disciples, before attaining the Dao, sages, immortals, and buddhas were no different from you—ordinary beings, no extra eyes or hands. Yet they were able to establish their resolve, seeking the method to transcend the world and understand the mechanism of life and death. This resolve elevated them a hundredfold above ordinary people, vast and boundless. Though their bodies remained those of ordinary beings, their minds already embodied the sacred.

The sage does not merely speak of transcending the world; they truly hold it in their hearts and act accordingly. Thus, they are called possessors of great heroic power, bearers of great compassion. The great person, the teacher of heaven and humanity—all arise from an extraordinary resolve. Their actions are not small. With thunderous might, the sword of wisdom slung over their shoulder, their brows raised like flashing lightning; with awe-inspiring presence, the blade of precepts at their neck, their eyes blazing like rolling thunder. The hearts of heretics grow cold, and they flee afar; the courage of evil winds trembles, and all wish to take refuge. Ascending the nine-petaled lotus throne, they rise straight to the Dharma King’s seat. Their words resound with clarity, heard as the pure Dharma-sound, pouring the nectar of wisdom upon all gods and humans. Their bodies emanate the sacred fragrance of *qi*, and all who see them attain liberation, rivers of ghee flowing for countless beings.

After attaining the Dao, their great resolve fulfilled, they make great vows, free from the notions of self, others, beings, or lifespan. They do not wish to liberate themselves alone but only to liberate others. With the method of self-liberation, they universally liberate all beings, yet without the mind of self-liberation, they do not demand it of others. They take the hearts of the people as their own heart. The people—another name for beings; beings—of the same kind as oneself. With the method of one’s kind, they save those of the same kind. Without liberating beings, they do not wish to attain the Dao.

The *Qingjing Jing* states: “Though called attaining the Dao, there is nothing attained. To transform beings is called attaining the Dao. Those who awaken to this may transmit the sacred path.”

Disciples, sages, immortals, and buddhas are no different from ordinary people.

The difference lies solely in the two words: public and private. The sage is only impartial and upright, acting for others, not for self; the ordinary person is only biased, deceptive, and selfish, acting for self, not for others. The sage is only clear, bright, deep, and tranquil; the ordinary person is only turbid, dark, superficial, and restless. The sage only employs firmness inwardly to discipline the body and gentleness outwardly to win over others; the ordinary person only employs softness inwardly to indulge the self and firmness outwardly to reproach others. The sage is ever fearful of his own faults; the ordinary person only blames the faults of others. Where the sage takes on tasks, he is ever meticulous; where the ordinary person shoulders perilous affairs, he is careless and overconfident. The sage, before death has come, first discerns the mechanism of what follows death; the ordinary person, with death before his eyes, still only schemes for survival. The sage seeks the Dharma of transcending the world, tempering the heart with worldly Dharma. As a child, he fulfills filial piety; as a subject, he fulfills loyalty. The ordinary person not only knows nothing of the Dharma of transcending the world, but even of worldly Dharma he knows nothing—how then would he know loyalty to his lord or filial piety to his parents? Pitiable are these deluded and unawakened beings, who neither know worldly Dharma nor the Dharma of transcending the world. Day after day, they live in drunken stupor and dreamlike death, drifting through life and squandering it, born in the morning and dead by evening, clinging to life and fearing death, blindly living and blindly dying. They bury their single spark of true numinous principle within a foul skin-bag, drifting for ten thousand kalpas, ignorant of their inversion, turning back and forth, changing faces and altering heads, endlessly revolving in samsara—when will they ever emerge?

Disciples, having already received the precepts, you have already emerged. Having emerged, you may escape suffering. Escaping suffering, you may transcend the world.

Disciples, to escape suffering, first endure suffering. Without enduring suffering, one cannot escape suffering. You must follow the true words of sages, immortals, and buddhas, not chase their empty names. You must establish the resolve of sages, immortals, and buddhas, not merely speak their words. You must cultivate the causes of sages, immortals, and buddhas, not merely hope for their fruits. You must plant the roots of sages, immortals, and buddhas, and naturally their rewards will come. You must accumulate the virtues of sages, immortals, and buddhas, and naturally attain their Dao. You must enact the deeds of sages, immortals, and buddhas, and naturally realize their station. If one’s actions do not match one’s words, if one’s words exceed one’s deeds, one is but an ordinary person making no progress. How could one who vainly aspires to the Dao of sages, immortals, and buddhas be such a spiritless person?

Disciples! You must establish great resolve and make great vows, only then can you transcend the world.

Thus I speak these verses:

Listen with devoted heart, disciples, to what I say,
Resolve can cast off birth and death.
First endure suffering to discipline body and mind,
When suffering ends, sweetness comes, and death revives.

Set your heart’s resolve to rise above the dust,
Worldly passions reversed, transcendence comes near.
Grasping the Dipper’s handle, stand firm and towering,
Unmoving in true emptiness, on the white jade terrace.

Do not wish for action and become an external path,
Do not wish for inaction and stray into heterodox teachings.
Neither non-being nor being—wish for harmony,
Neither existence nor non-existence—cultivate awakened illumination.

Resolve not to turn with circumstances,
In perilous situations, the heart remains unshaken.
Able to turn circumstances with the mind’s Dharma,
Wisdom’s sky opens, light pervades all.

Resolve not to be moved by worldly things,
If moved by them, apply true mechanism.
Once authority is lost to demonic hands,
Revolving is left to them—too late for regret.

Resolve not to be hindered by affairs or principles,
Clinging and attachment bind one to appearances.
Principles clear, affairs penetrated, hindrances dissolve,
Liberation in true emptiness dispels illusory delusion.

Resolve not to follow the ear in hearing sounds,
Inwardly listen with the ear’s root to the true source.
Guard against the ear’s leakage, lest true nature be lost,
Endure insults, first seal the ears from hearing.

Resolve not to follow the eye in seeing forms,
Contain the light, inwardly illuminate with empty whiteness.
Guard against the eyes’ leakage, lest primordial spirit scatter,
When the eyes see nothing, the heart’s master is unified.

Resolve not to follow the mouth in uttering words,
Accord with the Dao, speak sparingly, return to spontaneity.
Speaking the Dharma without words completes the teaching,
No speech, no words—qi naturally flows.

Resolve not to follow the tongue in tasting flavors,
Killing beings to harm life offends gods and ghosts.
Golden nectar, jade liquid, sweet springs fragrant,
Divine water, copious and refreshing, drips with ambrosia.

Resolve not to follow the nose in smelling scents,
The human heart stirs, true constancy is broken.
Since liberating from celestial fragrances,
Each offers heart’s incense to the heavens above.

Resolve not to follow the body in reckless movement,
Ever maintain dignity, abandon laziness.
Disrespect and defilement ruin the numinous root,
The Dao-body is solemn, reverent in its seat.

Resolve not to follow the heart in opposing things,
Anger and wrath arise without cause.
Subdue the heart, follow principle in action,
Harmonious qi flows, the spirit is joyful.

Resolve not to follow the will in changing,
Sincerity and constancy are ever in mind.
The heart without dual thoughts, the will without other,
Vigilance in solitude, sincerity preserved, return to one vow.

Resolve not to follow love’s entanglements,
Love’s bonds are ropes and chains.
You must uproot love’s roots entirely,
Sever all sprouts, board the Dharma-boat.

Resolve not to follow reckless and inferior companions,
Inferior friends and wild companions lack enduring hearts.
They weaken the resolve for the Dao, lose true heart,
How can one walk with those who ruin the teaching?

Resolve not to be misled by blind teachers,
The six roots and six dusts—let the heart not dwell.
Not relying on any Dharma, see the true mechanism,
External paths and side doors cannot ferry the body across.

First receive the initial true precepts,
Upholding the ten precepts, the heart remains uncorrupted.
Subdue the heart, guard the precepts, not losing the true,
The four great dignities are diligently maintained without slack.

Advance to receive the middle ultimate precepts,
Secret practices and subtle merits—observe self-mastery.
The physical body liberated, become the Dharma-body,
Realize the three bodies, transcend beyond kalpas.

Resolve to repay kindness with earnest heart,
The four great debts of gratitude must be settled.

To repay profound kindness with body and life,
Filial sons and loyal ministers delight heaven and earth.
Resolve to cultivate the true by first casting off falsity,
Dare not feign deafness or mimic dumbness.
With true heart and sincere intent, never deceive,
The slightest pretense—mere donkeys and cattle.

Resolve to sever killing, stealing, and lust,
Wine, sensuality, wealth, and anger—greed, delusion, and wrath.
The six desires, seven emotions, and three poisonous karmas,
Forever cut off, lest they delude the heart anew.

Resolve not to cultivate the lesser or middle vehicles,
Lest one depart not from karmic retribution, which must end.
The Great Vehicle’s pure and liberated Way,
The Most Supreme Vehicle’s vow shall be fulfilled.

Resolve to endure hard cultivation without retreat,
Erasing a thousand transgressions and ten thousand sins.
Innate luminosity, wisdom, and boundless fortune,
Vast virtue towering—heaven and earth’s station.

Resolve to take refuge in precepts, concentration, and wisdom,
The unsurpassed Dharma-gate without obstruction.
Unobstructed, unobscured, great radiance,
Stainless, undefiled, without fear.
Unborn, undying—transcendent Dharma,
Neither ceasing nor increasing, without counterpart.
Formless, non-action, without rank or measure,
Without limit, without reverence, without supreme nobility.

Transcending the three realms, attaining the Three Clarities,
Brahma-qi pervading, ascending the jeweled throne.
Resolve to take refuge in the Primordial Honored One,
Mirroring the heart of the Dao, scriptures, and master’s treasure.
This heart vows to transcend kalpas of dust,
Realizing body and mind, escaping the wheel of rebirth.

With steadfast heart, we vow:
From this day forth, resolve to cast off falsehood.
Vow to offer body and life to the void,
Contemplating true suchness—emptiness, illusion, and delusion.
Vow to study the Most Supreme Vehicle,
Vowing the heart clings not to any form.
The six roots purified, the six dusts empty,
Reverently upholding the imperial scriptures, first severing obstacles.

Vow to dissolve emotional consciousness, awakening to the true source,
Lest the supreme treasure be swayed by demons.
Vow to equalize heart and life with emptiness,
Lest nature and life drift and wander.
Vow to illumine birth and death, transcending the world,
The Dharma-realm vast, the Dharma-body great.
The Dharma-body perfected, the Dharma-realm empty,
The true emptiness of the Dharma-realm—vast and unobstructed.

Vow to liberate oneself from birth and death,
Self-liberation and liberating others—without duality.
Only vow to universally liberate all beings,
All sentient beings as oneself.
Vow the heart remains steadfast to attain perfection,
Vowing to grasp the true mechanism, reversing fate.
Though blades sever the body, the body does not flinch,
Though fire and flood ravage, the heart does not soften.

The three disasters, eight difficulties, and five sufferings,
Only vow to bear them, never resisting.
Though vow’s power be exhausted, resolve remains unbroken,
All heavenly demons cannot obstruct.
Though the nine and hundred-six kalpas’ tribulations be inescapable,
Though body perish and form decay, the vow does not abandon.
Though stones rot and seas dry, the heart does not fail,
The adamantine resolve of concentration and wisdom stands firm.

Even if consigned to the Avīci hell,
Karmic retribution shall not be shunned, no retreat.
Vow to endure the causes of self-created evil karma,
Patiently bearing hardship until fulfillment.
Vow to illumine the nature of beginningless delusion,
Vowing to enter the untainted, ever-serene samādhi.
Vow to offer liver and gall to aid the three wretched realms,
Vowing to enter the unobstructed great mirror of clarity.

Vow to extend compassion to save all beings,
Vowing to transform into a skilled physician, healing worldly ills.
Vow to steer the compassionate vessel across the sea of suffering,
Vowing to ferry beings beyond illusion.
Heaven and earth, the myriad things—all true,
The Primordial Ancestral Qi, all spirits.
Sages, immortals, buddhas—all sincere,
Universally exhorting all beings,
Together following liberation, transcending the mundane.

“Disciples, those who have resolved with苦志 and made great vows—
today, each instruction is given, every step enjoined.
You, the lofty disciples who propagate the Dao,
The immortals who elucidate the lineage,
The divine youths who continue the Dao’s pulse,
The Daoists who shatter the celestial barrier.
The Ten Continents and Three Isles—
all have heard, all have understood.
Each reflect deeply,
hastening to set a resolute vow for cultivation—
truly, this is most auspicious.

Hark!
If this body is not liberated in this life,
In what life shall this body be liberated?”

Time flies like an arrow, sun and moon shuttle like a loom—since you first left the household life until now, you have dallied away the years, frittered away the seasons. Your hair is frosted, your skin wrinkled, your teeth loosening, your sinews stiffening, your flesh slackening. Alas! When the bones soften, one cannot walk far; when the blood is depleted, one cannot bear heavy burdens. When essence withers and the kidneys fail, the eyes grow dim; when spirit flags and the heart runs wild, the single soul cannot settle. When the hun fades and the po swells, the ears droop in listening; when the stomach is strong but the spleen weak, one’s appetite wanes.

Disciples, know that this body is originally illusory—no matter how sturdy, it will one day die; only the timing differs. Like this: ears deaf, eyes dim, tongue parched, mouth dry, teeth falling, jaws trembling, waist aching, back bent, hair white, temples scorched, sinews hardened, hands and feet numb, resolve weakened, heart cooled, thoughts chilled—all are invitations sent by King Yama, courteously awaiting your early arrival. Do not cling to the soft-heartedness of old women, the petty trade of tofu vendors, the shallow views of children, the delusion of beasts, fixating only on the present while neglecting the next life. If today, at this very hour, ghosts come to summon you, you may endure it, but you must still go. Can you, as Daoists who have left the household life and cast off the mundane, truly evade or escape this? Why not see through it clearly and attain liberation early? Take one step in vigilance, let go at once, and only then will you be a true man of courage, an extraordinary hero. Stand firm in resolve, possess skill, and cultivate to transcend the world. Otherwise, with a timid spirit and a feeble countenance, the four great elements—wind, fire, earth, and water—each rush to their own ends, while the faculties of sight and hearing scatter in all directions. Muttering and murmuring, drifting and floating, rising and falling, you sink into hell.

Ah! Disciples, to cultivate without resolve is like a puppet show—when the gongs and drums end, where will you go? Only with resolve can one transcend the world; without it, all is ten thousandfold harder. Only by standing firm in resolve and cultivating the true Dao can one attain great spiritual power with ease.

**Fourteen: Verification and Proof**
Disciples, if you wish to cultivate the wondrous Dao of purity, non-action, and spontaneity, you must first possess resolve and act with spontaneity. If you can act spontaneously, the Dao of naturalness will naturally be within you. But if you cannot act spontaneously, how can you attain naturalness? If you cannot even complete worldly affairs, how can you be spontaneous?

The immortal masters say: “To cultivate the Dao of immortality, first cultivate the human Dao. If the human Dao is not cultivated, the immortal Dao remains distant.” The Confucian school says: “First bring order to your household, then you may govern the state.” Ordering the household is the human Dao; governing the state is the immortal Dao. If you cannot govern your household, how can you govern the state? The Buddhist school says: “Exhaust the mundane heart, for there is no separate sacred understanding.” This mundane heart is the principle of the Three Bonds and Five Constants. If you can fully embody this, the human Dao is complete, and cultivating immortality becomes easy. Even if you do not become a sage, immortal, or buddha, it will still be within reach.

How, then, does one advance in the cultivation of the immortal Dao? Disciples, since entering the Mystery Gate, learning to be Daoists, bowing to masters and receiving transmissions, you have gone to sit in meditation and quiet the mind, believing you have already exhausted the human Dao of the mundane world and that the immortal Dao is within reach. Yet you have not even fully embodied the reverence due to your masters, and the oral transmissions you received remain indistinct, yet you rush to act without foundation. As soon as you begin, you seek verification. After sitting for two or three days and seeing no signs, you abandon it. Then you seek another master, receive a few words, and sit again. This fleeting heart of seeking the Dao does not last even two or three days before you crave verification, unable even to steady your thoughts. With such a deluded mind and shallow wisdom, your meager cultivation is in vain. Though you ponder endlessly, your spirit cannot settle, and it all amounts to a dream. After sitting for twenty or thirty years, you remain an ordinary person, unaware even at the moment of death. What a pity—to waste time, squander the years, grasping at the moon in water, plucking flowers in a mirror, thinking it easy. Where is the principle of ready-made immortals? How pitiful, deceived by blind masters and misled by heterodox teachings—I will say no more.

I only urge you to repeatedly contemplate the chapter on strict observance of precepts and the resolve to repay kindness. First correct your thoughts, eliminate afflictions and ignorance, single-mindedly turn toward the Dao, take refuge in the Three Treasures, recite the true scriptures, and practice in accordance with the precepts. Sit in the Ten Directions Hall for a hundred days, maintaining dignified appearance, steady demeanor, unconfused in all matters, and upright in body. Then, when moving to perform prostrations, invoke the true masters, vow not to pursue the lesser or middle vehicles, and with sincere devotion, take refuge and aspire to hear the wondrous Dao of the supreme, most true, great vehicle—pure, liberated, and spontaneous—fully awakening to birth and death, forever escaping the cycle of rebirth. Only then may you receive the Ten Precepts of Initial Realization.

Disciples, only thus: the Dao prioritizes the transformation of temperament. After hearing the Dao, you may then ascend the meditation cushion, still the mind, cease thoughts, forget emotions, and apply effort to the mind-ground, completely casting aside worldly affairs. Thoroughly contemplate and penetrate the Three Hundred Great Precepts of the Central Ultimate, fully understanding them, and only then will you know that the great matter of karmic conditions lies within the body, not outside the mind.

In the secret realm, penetrate the truth with utmost clarity, perfect the wondrous practices, and verify the emptiness of spontaneity—advancing yet further beyond the hundred-foot pole. Do not distort the crooked into the straight, nor force arguments from ignorance. Once you recognize the place of enlightenment as your own Dao-ground, or acquire a small hermitage and take in one or two disciples, you may grow complacent and arrogant, no longer holding the precepts, concentration, and wisdom in your heart. You fail to emulate the discipline of the precept masters, their dignified demeanor and strict observance, nor do you harmonize with fellow disciples. Illiterate and half-witted, your own transformation incomplete, you falsely exalt yourself, claiming to others, *"Our practice is of the supreme vehicle."* Waving a fan inscribed with cryptic alchemical verses, carrying a pouch stuffed with a few alchemical scriptures, you fill gourds with countless herbs, deceiving the laity for their silver—calling it *"secret transmission from an immortal"* or *"elixir formulas from the Eastern Sea."* With the silver earned, you buy wine and meat. Your mouth spews reckless words, yet you grasp nothing of pulse diagnosis or yin-yang principles, casually picking up a few formulas to falsely claim merit. All day, you prattle on about heaven and earth, rushing east and west in search of clothing and food.

You corrupt the supreme teachings of the Most High, tarnishing the reputation of the Perfect Truth. O law-breakers, precept-violators—seeds of sin! When your evil fills to the brim, heaven’s courts shall mete out punishment, and you shall forever sink into hell. How lamentable! How grievous!

There are others who, upon entering the Daoist gate, harbor petty ambitions and narrow aspirations. They seek only seated meditation for ease, unwilling to subdue the heart or master the qi, to sever attachments or cut off emotions. Clinging to mud and water, they remain entangled in form and fixated on thoughts. They obsess over the effects of their practice, circulating qi and moving essence, yet their mysterious apertures grow dim, mistaking the thief for their own child, lost in delusion for ages. Refusing to humbly seek verification, to observe, inquire, and reflect, their illusions deepen until they become irredeemable. Many thus harm their bodies and lives, falling into the cycle of rebirth.

They take the boundless Great Dao and reduce it to a lump of flesh and blood, mistaking the conscious spirit for the primordial spirit, allowing it to lead them astray. How can they ever transcend life and death? Disciples, heed my words: sweep away all these heterodox paths, deviant methods, and misguided branches without delay. Cast them aside boldly. Temper body, heart, and intent within the mandate of heaven and the nature of being. Do not crave immediate results; seek only insight through the heart. With resolve, press forward on this path—even if it be a wall of bronze or iron, you must break through. Naturally, there will come a day of liberation, when the fruit ripens and the stem falls, and the heart suddenly awakens, penetrating heaven and earth.

If your blessings are meager and your karmic conditions shallow, you must accumulate virtue and merit, advancing with courage and diligence. Should you fail to awaken in this life, you will in the next; if not in the next, then in a thousand or ten thousand lives—yet you will inevitably awaken. Set this vow, and your resolve for enlightenment shall endure across kalpas, making you a sage of great compassion and vast aspiration, destined to attain the Dao.

Yet worldly fortune is easily cultivated, while spiritual fortune is hard won. If you aspire to tread the path of transcendence, follow the true Dao, not the external paths of visualization, refinement, and the pursuit of physical immortality. Those are but ghosts guarding mountains for millennia, clinging to corpses. The boundless, serene, and true Dao seeks no quick results, no immediate gains, nor does it fixate on three or nine years—its essence lies in perceiving one’s nature. Effects manifest daily, transforming moment by moment: the mouth moistens with fragrant saliva, the limbs grow firm, the head assumes a spherical aura, the heavenly gate opens in the brain, fire steams within the abdomen, and the bones resonate throughout the body. Yet these are but middling or lesser practices—each step must return to the Dao’s essence.

For the Dao is fundamentally empty, its body fundamentally nonexistent, hence its name: the Limitless. If one’s practice loses its proper direction and mistakes transient gains for true attainment, it becomes a heterodox path. Thus, a hair’s breadth of error leads to a thousand miles of deviation. Those who cling to names and forms, who recklessly set up furnaces and tripods, who at the hour of *zi* ascend lead and at *wu* descend mercury, who advance the yang fire and retreat the yin tally, who practice according to hexagrams and seek verification by the hour—those who do not recognize the return to the Dao’s essence follow only the lesser paths.

The wondrous Dao of serene non-action, of natural return, differs entirely from these. Consider the *Huangjing*: when one first resolves to transcend the mundane, this initial aspiration is like the Jade Maiden releasing fragrance. As soon as the heart’s incense is lit, the four kinds of birth and six paths of existence who catch its scent are universally liberated. This release of fragrance is the practice; this perception of fragrance is its effect. Or when the Jade Emperor radiates light, all heavens, all earths, and the boundless worlds are drawn into its brilliance, like infinite mirrors reflecting one another—this is the effect.

Severing obstacles is the practice; the seventeen lights and thirty kinds of merit are the effects. The *Merit Chapter* and *Karmic Response Chapter* are the karmic effects for those who recite the sutras. If you were once frivolous and restless, your mouth never still, spouting reckless words, your hands never idle, always in haste—

Your feet never still, merely wandering blindly; seated, you never steady, only slouching askew; in sleep, you never rest, your body tossing endlessly. Your eyes dart about—now east, now west—your movements a gust of wind, no semblance of the Daoist’s demeanor. Like an ox yet unbridled, a horse without reins, you stray from the straight and central path.

Now, having received the precepts, you don robes and sashes, carry alms bowls, and wear sandals, your body adorned in the guise of a perfected one. Following others’ ways, heeding words and observing forms, you transform your former coarse and hasty manner into one of composure and ritual propriety—this is the practice of upholding the precepts. Transmuting your temperament, assuming the countenance of the Dao, you inspire reverence at first glance—this is the outward sign of upholding the precepts.

If you can maintain sublime conduct, refine your thoughts to align with the Dao, seeking only to illumine the heart and perceive your nature, without chasing effects, fretting only over the insufficiency of practice rather than the delay of its results, then when the great season ripens, enlightenment will come in a single stroke.

But if your practice is not steadfast, your mind divided between two or three intentions, interrupted by doubt, then if the heart is not true, the spirit will not be efficacious; if the thought is not pure, the qi will not gather. With spirit wandering and qi floating, the heart’s devotion lacking, from where could effects arise?

Now that you harbor great resolve to escape the wheel of rebirth, first expand your capacity, focus on the practice, and set effects aside—then it will be wondrous. It is like a skilled physician administering medicine, whose chief concern is harmony; an inferior physician, seeking quick results, disregards the root, chasing immediate effects. Though the near-term effect may appear, the primordial qi is ultimately harmed, the original source never restored. Chronic afflictions multiply, and the patient, unaware, regrets it too late.

Disciples, if you truly practice day and night according to the precepts, following the rituals and upholding the rules, ever vigilant, constantly refining, how could there be no effect? Yet even if your breast feels open and your vision clear, you must still subdue your will and humble your heart, drawing near to the virtuous to seek confirmation from the wise.

Never cling to the self and forget others, nor cling to others and forget the self. With no duality in the heart, the four illusions dissolve, and the effects of virtue and fortune will naturally follow.

Disciples, the cultivation of the Dao depends entirely on a single heart. When the heart is true and devotion earnest, the Dao becomes intimate. If thoughts cease and the heart is empty and still, where in practice will efficacy not arise?

The heart must be cold, thoughts must turn to ash—from cold ash, a mighty spark bursts forth. True fire and qi can illuminate all things, like the sun radiating brilliance in the sky. Uphold the precepts and practice diligently, and in samadhi, the effects of wisdom’s light will be known. Within, a grain of millet contains heaven and earth; to speak of it to others is but folly.

Listen closely to these teachings, disciples. With a careless heart and restless qi, how can one become immortal? Swiftly follow the precepts to cultivate merit and conduct, with firm resolve and unwavering heart, severing wayward thoughts. Practice in seclusion, deep in the mountains, closing the temple gates, your heart unruffled. With the four illusions dissolved and the heart stilled, the Dao flows freely.

Now I reveal this celestial mechanism to you: the manifestation of merit lies solely in the heart’s devotion. Diligence in practice and austerity yield abundant efficacy, moment by moment, profound and deep. Within the heart’s stillness, reflect alone; let no one know even half. Do not cling to the mind’s inner realm—only then is it the moment of great awakening.

The deluded cat guarding its den stirs ignorance; vain thoughts gestate, birthing the sacred infant. When will the Metal Lord ride the azure tiger? Where does the Wood Mother mount the white dragon? Atop the crown, the three flowers blaze radiantly; within the body, the five qi surge powerfully. Pitiable are those who do not recognize the true message, their spirit’s terrace blocked, their nature unopened.

I tell you, do not disparage the precepts as inferior—they are the foundation for entering the Dao through non-action. Like a raft poled through waves to cross the sea, like a ladder raised in emptiness to ascend the heavens. Do not boast of your own arrogance, nor slander others to judge right and wrong. If you refuse to accept this, it is your choice—why create obstacles to sow doubt in others?

Only when your lips praise and your heart rejoices are you one who promotes the mysterious and protects the teachings. If you generate slander, you will incur heavenly retribution, for karmic consequences are ever true.

Hark! Why forgo being a good person? Why refrain from speaking good words? Why abandon the great Dao to pursue cleverness and blunder? Without cultivating precepts and samadhi, how can you inherit the Supreme’s robe and bowl? Without dual cultivation of merit and wisdom, how can you attain liberation of body and mind? Without understanding the principles, how can you unravel the mechanism? Without removing obstacles and ignorance, how can your heart’s capacity expand?

Many transgressions are worse than few; reckless speech is worse than silence. The supreme Dao differs from heterodox paths—do not lightly chatter and wag your tongue. Everywhere, oral instructions are sold for coin, and the weight of karmic fortune is clear. If you remain deluded and unenlightened, you will face death without life. Reborn as swine or sheep, your karmic retribution will be slaughter at the hands of others. You cannot escape the unseen and seen realms of heaven and earth, nor the scrutiny of the Five Offerings and Three Primordials. Know that the sun and moon, yin and yang, are not muddled darkness. Naturally, the deluded will be exposed—disciples, be aware and do not slander what is right.

With boundless compassion, I urge you: take refuge early in the Three Thousand Great Precepts. With no obstacles in the heart, right and wrong dissolve; in sitting, lying, walking, and practice, all paths open. From this day forth, the flames of karmic fire turn to empty illusion, and the dawn’s light reports the dharma hall aglow.

Within precepts, samadhi, and wisdom, liberation is born. Uphold the precepts with sincere resolve, and you will transcend and attain. If you doubt that the precepts are deceptive transmissions, heaven will despise you and condemn you to have your tongue torn out. When disciples awaken without doubt, floating clouds vanish like wind-scattered mist. Beyond the kalpas, you will wander freely and at ease, suddenly severing the tangled vines.

Follow the rituals to revere the Heavenly Worthy, your mouth not raising its voice, your head not tilting. Within and without, a single spirit, unwavering—though in a mortal body, the Dao is already accomplished.

The Dao’s accomplishment is neither easy nor difficult—whether one upholds or neglects the precepts lies within the heart. From life to death, from death to life, all arises from precepts and samadhi. Once you take refuge, do not treat the precepts as stubborn folly.

**Fifteen: Preserving Life and Prolonging Existence**
Disciples, when I previously took the seat, I repeatedly exhorted you to rouse courage, to vow with great resolve, and to seek early clarity on life and death. You must not diminish your aspirations, nor follow the Two Vehicles’ path of clinging to life and fearing death.

Yet today I speak again of the mind’s method for preserving life and prolonging existence—does this not make me double-tongued, uttering reckless words to delude sentient beings?

Disciples, the mind’s method for preserving life and prolonging existence that I speak of is not attachment to the physical form, nor mere talk of essence and qi, urging you to preserve post-heavenly lifespan or extend this transient existence.

What I now call *preserving life* refers to the mandate of Heaven as one’s nature—guarding the life bestowed by Heaven, abiding in simplicity while awaiting its fulfillment. This is what is meant by *the mandate of Heaven as one’s nature*, the *wisdom-life* of the Buddhist school, the *original destiny-star* of the Daoist gate.

This *life* is the longevity that does not perish in death. As the *Vajracchedikā* says: *"How can one attain long life? Through the indestructible vajra-body."* Moreover, the mandate of Heaven is non-dual; cultivate body and mind to await its fulfillment. To exhaust principle and fulfill one’s nature to reach the mandate—this is the essential principle of establishing life.

What I call *prolonging* is not the removal of illness to extend years, nor immortality in the flesh. Rather, it is the true nature that remains unbroken through ten thousand kalpas, the dharmakāya that abides eternally since time immemorial, the form and image that nurtures all beings—this is no ordinary body.

If you point to the skin-bag and cultivate it, you may live a few more years, but death will only come later; this is not the true Dao.

What I now indicate by *preserving life through cultivation* is to equalize oneself with Heaven and Earth and align with the myriad things. Though Heaven and Earth undergo change and movement, my original nature knows no change or movement. Though the myriad things have their ends and limits, my Dao-body knows no end or limit. Though Heaven, Earth, and the myriad things all follow the cycles of kalpas, epochs, and ages, my luminous true constancy, my empty and numinous awareness, transcends all forms, free from destruction, decay, or transformation.

This is the *life* to be preserved, the *existence* to be prolonged—what is called the ceaselessly flowing Heavenly principle, the true and constant Dao of unending generation.

This passage reveals words of the heart only out of utmost necessity. If one with clear eyes awakens fully to the profound seat of dharma-teaching, where silence reigns without sound, then one already knows the message within.

The great Dao is boundless, encompassing Heaven and Earth, leaving nothing behind, present at all times, inherent in all things, all-encompassing. In daily life, every moment is the Dao: what the eyes see, the ears hear, in walking, standing, sitting, lying, eating, resting, advancing, retreating, dressing, dining, in cold and heat, in clear and cloudy skies—everywhere is the Dao.

Yet how is it that you remain obscured by things and constrained by qi, unaware in daily use? Within emptiness, the luminous response is ever-present, yet before echoes and shadows, you wander step by step in confusion.

Now, relying on the patriarchs of the Three Teachings, moved by the compassionate heart of universal salvation and the vow to benefit all beings, I cannot but speak at length to you, disciples.

Thus, I universally proclaim to all beings: there is no second method. If there were two, it would not be the true path of the Great Vehicle’s perfect awakening.

This single spark of numinous awareness within you is another name for *wisdom-life*; originally, it is one thing. This *wisdom-life* is but a provisional name for the Dao-body, all arising from the same source. Only because they emerge together yet differ do they contain the Three while manifesting as One.

This *wisdom-life* appears at every moment, yet you do not see its form; it hides at every instant, yet you do not know its whereabouts. It expounds the dharma daily, yet you do not hear its voice.

Are you not like fools searching for fire by the light of a lamp, or riding an ox to seek the ox? Disciples, why must I teach you to preserve it? I fear you do not recognize this *wisdom-life* as the sacred treasure. I know well that you, at every turn, resist and defy it—you are neither seasoned practitioners who see the nature nor elder Daoists who grasp the intent. Even when you perceive it, you cannot employ it. And when you do employ it, you cannot employ it fully. The moment this *wisdom-life* departs, it is as if the Primordial Heavenly Worthy has left the Dharma-throne, the Yellow Emperor lost the Mystic Pearl, Iron-Face Patriarch mislaid his staff, or Master Zhang Guo of Penetrating Mystery his blue donkey. Then, though you may have a mouth, you cannot speak; though you grope for your nose, it is but empty air. Though you have a heart, there is no aperture; you lack subtlety and vanish into darkness.

Now, I thus ascend to fulfill the sacred heart of the Primordial One’s teaching and reverently embody the great virtue of Patriarch Qiu’s love for life, awakening you with this ambrosia. Hasten to investigate and realize the wondrous principle of preserving life and prolonging existence. Have you not heard the *Supreme Pervasive Numinous Treasure Sutra of Wondrous Methods for Eliminating Disasters and Protecting Life*? Disciples, if you can turn and awaken to this sutra, you will continue the *wisdom-life* endlessly, living on without cease.

If you merely recite the sutra by rote, it is called "offering devotion," not "turning and awakening." Those who offer devotion recite and then forget, unable to savor its depth. Does the sutra not say: "All you sentient beings, since beginningless time, your minds have been enslaved by form, your thoughts swept away by circumstances. Only clinging to love and delusion without respite, you drift upon the River of Desire, sink into the Sea of Craving, grasping at illusory forms as if real, oblivious to your original face. The Dao is originally formless, yet you cling to it as form; the Dao is not empty, yet you grasp it as emptiness. Deluded by the interplay of emptiness and form, you invert existence and nonexistence, ultimately unable to awaken. How then can you escape the path of birth and death, leap beyond the karma of rebirth?"

If one knows emptiness yet is not bound by emptiness, knows form yet is not bound by form, does not cling to the view of emptiness, and is free from all doubts and leaks, then such a person can purify the six senses and sever all obstructions. This is the essential teaching of my school, expounded and transmitted through this sutra named *Protecting Life*, so that by relying on the Dharma, all beings may be universally ferried across, the teaching spread throughout the world, and its recitation circulated. Those who recite and transmit it will have flying heavenly kings, vajra warriors to break evil, Dharma-protecting spirit youths, deliverance-perfected ones, golden-eyed fierce beasts—countless millions—guarding this sutra, enabling all to depart from these defilements.

O great assembly! How can this bodily form know emptiness yet not emptiness, know form yet not form, discern the Dharma of non-emptiness, penetrate without obstruction, and enter the gate of myriad wonders? Therefore, I first explain the sutra’s wondrous truth to protect the *wisdom-life* of the great assembly.

The ancestral masters, in their compassion, fear that you, disciples, will mistake this bodily form for the true body. You must abide in non-emptiness within emptiness, non-form within form, non-existence within existence, non-emptiness within emptiness. Do not be manipulated by this illusory, blood-and-flesh body, tossed about without respite, deluded as to the true teaching, and losing the treasure of wisdom. Thus, this sutra urges each of you to protect the spiritual root, nurture the original source—when the root is firm, the Dao arises.

The noble person delights in Heaven, thus preserving life; whether short-lived or long-lived, they are not two—this is prolonging existence. The noble person serves Heaven, thus the *wisdom-life* endures. When the *wisdom-life* endures, you live on without cease, transforming and nurturing, realizing the indestructible vajra body and attaining the true, eternal, leakless Dharma-body.

O great assembly! The scriptures of the Three Caverns and Four Palaces, the five thousand and three hundred true texts—all point to prolonging existence and preserving life, enabling one to transcend kalpas and rise above the dust. Clinging to appearances is not preserving life; true emptiness is prolonging existence. *Wisdom-nature* does not depart from *wisdom-life*; *wisdom-light* is the *wisdom-lamp*. If you wish the *wisdom-light* to shine constantly, the *wisdom-life* must abide long. When it abides without departing from stillness and concentration, the lamp’s light naturally remains bright. Awakening to the true suchness, the lamp shines constantly, naturally illuminating and delivering all beings. The light is truly without light to behold; the brightness is truly without brightness to name. It is merely the original presence within life, provisionally called "light" and "brightness." In the world of form and emptiness, birth and death, emptiness and form preserve life and prolong existence. Prolonging existence is transcending beyond kalpas; transcending kalpas, what death is there? What name?

Sentient beings, only because they are deluded regarding wisdom, drift and sink through kalpas without end. When the *wisdom-lamp* and *wisdom-light* universally illuminate, swiftly awaken to the causes of discipline. Let us take up the wondrous method of preserving and prolonging—silently and emptily, I point it out to you all.

Disciples, disciples! The sutra says: "If you cannot see it when using it, then life can be preserved; if you cannot use it when seeing it, then existence can be prolonged. Only by extinguishing the moving mind and not extinguishing the illuminating mind can existence be prolonged; only by extinguishing the abiding mind and concentrating the empty mind can life be preserved." If you can prolong existence, the *wisdom-life* is unbroken, and the great elixir is accomplished. If you can preserve life, there is no birth to realize, and the great cinnabar is achieved.

Only when life is not constant does the Dao favor those who are good and abandon those who are not. Receiving life from Heaven, one must attend to Heaven’s bright mandate. Though Zhou was an ancient state, its mandate was ever renewed. All this is the true principle of preserving and prolonging—this is called the great Dao of establishing life.

Disciples, if you can awaken to this point, you have fully attained this wonder. Now, I do not begrudge the supreme treasure; I empty my bag and overturn my sack, directly revealing the mystery. Here are four verses for the great assembly to contemplate deeply:

Life short or long, originally there is life;
Born and dying, fundamentally there is no birth.
Prolonging and preserving require no esoteric method—
The method returns to the non-method, the city of the Dharma King.

*Blue Garden Altar Sutra, Scroll the Lower*
*Sixteen: Expounding the Teaching and Propagating the Dao*

Disciples, what this poor Daoist expounded yesterday from the high seat speaks of the Dao-body as non-action and the Dharma-body as reality itself. Yet you must understand that the Dao-body does not lie beyond the ordinary body, and the Dharma-body resides within the physical form. The physical form is firm and solid, adorned by the merit of external, conditioned action; the Dharma-body is pure and still, adorned by the merit of internal, unconditioned action. When both inner and outer are doubly purified, and both are awakened to, then the spirit is liberated—attaining the supreme, unsurpassable, indestructible true emptiness, the great radiance, the great perfection, the invincible. All spirits pay homage, thunder and lightning are commanded, the Three Realms are upheld, and the Five Emperors receive and welcome. All this is not achieved through the cultivation of conditioned merit.

Disciples, secure your essence and nurture your qi, and qi will abide while essence congeals. Still the fire and return the wind, and essence transforms into qi, steaming the four great elements and harmonizing the myriad spirits. When the true fire burns without smoke, qi becomes clear; when the spirit-water does not leak, the spirit becomes still. When qi is clear, it transforms into spirit; when the spirit is still, it merges with emptiness. When emptiness reaches its extreme and stillness is profound, the primordial true returns, and the ninefold return and sevenfold reversal restore life to its root. Restoring the root establishes life and preserves the true nature; when the true nature is preserved, the Dao-body manifests, and when the Dao-body manifests, the Dharma-body appears.

Disciples, this is the Dao-body cultivated within conditioned action as unconditioned, the Dharma-body cultivated within non-use as use. The physical form has a lifespan; the Dharma-body has a wisdom-life. Lifespan is determined by Heaven, not by oneself, thus the physical form undergoes the cycles of rebirth and death, the revolutions of kalpas. Wisdom-life is determined by oneself, not by Heaven, thus the Dharma-body wields sovereign power, liberated and unimpeded. Disciples, the lifespan of the physical form is limited, and its fixed karma is inescapable—when Heaven decrees death, one cannot but die. The wisdom-life of the Dharma-body is infinite, its spiritual powers vast, eternally realizing non-birth, and only then is long life attained.

Disciples, even if the physical form endures for ten thousand years, it is merely called a demon, not the Dao. The Dharma-body comes and goes yet remains constant—hear the Dao in the morning, and you may die by evening. This is the true teaching of the utmost sage. The Dharma-body dies yet does not perish, thus it is called long life. The physical form dies and dies again, thus it is impermanent. Disciples, if you awaken to the Dharma-body, you can transform even those of short, impermanent lives into long life. If you cling to the physical form as reality, you cause even those of boundless long life to fall into the cycle of rebirth.

The essential secret in a single phrase: see through the physical form, and all cares vanish. Cultivate with true sincerity, unstained by even a speck of dust. Do not let the Dharma-body be enshrouded by the physical form; instead, see through the physical form and liberate the Dharma-body. Is this not the great turning of the Dharma-wheel, the flourishing of the Dao’s work? What I now expound—*Expounding the Teaching and Propagating the Dao*—relies entirely on the constant turning of the Dharma-wheel. To restore the ancestral Dao to its former glory, if I do not clarify the Dharma-body for all beings, who will come to protect and uphold it?

As the saying goes: *The teaching, if not propagated, obscures the Dao; the Dao, if obscured, cannot be practiced; if the practice cannot proceed, the Dao cannot flourish.* The utmost sage has declared: *"It is people who propagate the Dao, not the Dao that propagates people."* You must each recognize those who propagate the Dao, practice the methods that propagate the Dao, and expound the mechanisms that clarify the Dao. Then how can the lineage of the Dao not thrive, and the ancestral tradition not decline?

In my youth, I studied little, my reading was not extensive, and I was unversed in the teachings of Confucianism and Buddhism. Foolishly, I sought out Daoist learning, wandering beyond the world for decades, determined to fathom its source. What I sought was the seeking of my own innate knowledge; what I inquired into was the inquiry into my original wisdom-nature. After long inner seeking, innate knowledge alone revealed itself upon the cinnabar terrace; after deep inner inquiry, wisdom-nature gave birth to clarity in the empty chamber. With an inner host, why fear receiving guests or responding to visitors? With a true origin within, I now wish to expound the teaching and propagate the Dao.

Disciples, I am not skilled in literature and feel ashamed before the jade scrolls of the Three Caverns. I have read few alchemical classics and have no access to the precious secrets of the immortals. My nature is indolent, fond of leisure and stillness. I have long cultivated the wisdom-life, deeply entered the realm of the subtle and imperceptible, cast aside all affairs, and embraced only the true origin. Where would I find the time to read Confucian texts or study alchemical classics? Thus, even now, I am unlearned in letters, clumsy in speech, and blunt in expression. Yet I speak these utmost true words, these most secret and profound mysteries, in coarse and common language, revealing some of the unspoken secrets for you to hear.

However, the Dao is fundamentally wordless—why expound it? The sutras are originally unlearned—why open a hall? The teaching is fundamentally non-action—why trouble oneself with much ado? This Dao is everyone’s share; one cannot be separated from it for even a moment. Whether in the world or beyond it, one can awaken and inquire—why must one leave the world, seek teachers, or find companions? It is only because of this one matter of birth and death, unresolved in the heart, that one races east and west, from the ends of the sea to the corners of the sky, seeking a method to restore life to its root.

Fortunately, the Jade Purity, Highest Purity, and Great Purity have transmitted the sutras, expounded the teaching, established the tradition, opened altars, propagated the lineage, and passed it down to the present. Even the Confucian masters—Master Zhou, the two Cheng masters, Master Zhang, and Master Zhu—received the secrets of the sacred scriptures and elucidated the essentials of the mind’s method. Then there are the *Vajracchedikā Sūtra*, the *Śūraṅgama Sūtra*, and the *Heart Sūtra*—the true principles of Buddhism, the profound mysteries of stilling the body and shedding desire. The Three Teachings share a single path in the matter of nature and life, all with the compassionate intention to deliver beings from suffering and save lives.

Now, I have been humbly listed among the disciples of Master Qiu, following the example to propagate the Dharma-treasures, receive and transmit, and expound the teaching.

Disciples, I am but an ordinary mortal, possessing no divine powers—only the work of everyday practice, teaching others to awaken, and nothing more than guiding those within the Daoist gate who uphold precepts and observe discipline. Unlike those who peddle secrets for alms, idle their days away, eat without labor, and clothe themselves without toil—how could such as these ever comprehend the matter of life and death? Thus, I rouse my own spirit with resolve, for the sake of universal deliverance. Above, I revive the teaching’s appearance; below, I benefit all living beings. This is fundamentally for the sake of sentient beings, not for myself.

Our Dragon Gate lineage began with Ancestor Qiu of the Yuan dynasty, who propagated the mysteries and spread transformation. Now, four hundred years later, lofty masters are rarely encountered, and determined seekers are hard to find. In this declining age of the Dao, I unexpectedly spent thirty years devoutly upholding precepts, observing discipline, and following the rules—visiting masters, seeking truth. Heaven aligned with my aspirations: I met my teacher at Wangwu, received the Dharma at the Nine Palaces, and for over twenty years, the Dao’s fortune has unfolded. By the grace of the imperial court, I have encountered this flourishing era, where officials and gentry embrace goodness, scholars and merchants delight in giving. Fellow cultivators, bound by karmic affinity, have met this opportune time. Thus, I established an altar and administered precepts in the capital. Through eight cycles of cold and heat, the wind stirred a thousand truths. Those of the feathered and secular realms, bound by affinity, have all taken refuge in precepts and samādhi, directly entering the wondrous Dao of pure emptiness.

This poor Daoist relies solely on this spark of spiritual insight, silently and sincerely moving with true sincerity, moving Heaven’s grace to grant a true encounter. Presumptuously ascending the Dharma seat, I merely play the role of a precept-master. As for grandly propagating the mysteries of the Daoist gate and widely establishing Daoist altars—this is the deepest aspiration of this poor Daoist.

Disciples, do not heed those slanderous and skeptical words, stubbornly clinging to your meditation cushions, sealing your throats and gritting your teeth, feigning the appearance of the Dao—only to mislead yourselves in the end. Such people claim to abide in constant response and stillness. Response to what? They speak of great compassion and great vows. What do they vow? To deliver sentient beings—deliver them from what? If they cannot even tend to their own nature and life, how can they tend to others’?

Listen well:
The precepts and scriptures emerge from the Daoist Canon,
Transmitting precepts by the rules is no falsehood.
Only to propagate the teaching and deliver sentient beings—
I wish you deluded disciples would cease your slander.
I urge you, fellow cultivators, to open your hearts and broaden your capacity,
Endure humiliation and cultivate truth to expand the teaching’s appearance.
Cultivate both samādhi and wisdom to deepen blessings and virtue,
Universally deliver sentient beings from the ocean of suffering.
Those who receive precepts must first sever obstacles—
Once obstacles are removed, radiance shines brightly.
Why worry that wisdom-nature lacks brilliance?
Fear only that its light will blaze ten thousandfold.
Conceal its flame to preserve life, and wisdom will grow long;
Abiding nowhere, you extend life and depart from illusory appearances.
Embrace purity, nurture simplicity, and learn non-action—
The wisdom-life will lengthen and return to vastness.
If you cling stubbornly to the physical body,
Not knowing who attains immortality when the body dies,
And refuse to deliver others, seeking only self-liberation—
How could immortal masters ever deliver us?

Ready-made robes, carefree meals—
Who provides each mouthful, each garment?
How can the kindness of Ancestors Mi and Qiu ever be repaid?
A single drop of water, a vast wave—
The cries of the Avīci hell echo.
Deceiving others with offerings for ease and comfort,
Warm clothes and full bellies—yet never thirsting.
With cunning words and flowery speech, claiming the Dao is already attained,
Promising to ascend and carry you away.
Outer protectors, hearing such words, offer even more diligently,
Foolishly hoping for gold from water.
How many ordinary people can awaken on their own?
In what year, what month, will they ascend?
Those who awaken through wisdom harbor no jealousy.
In stillness, they practice non-action and first deliver themselves.
In activity, they propagate the Dao and deliver fellow beings.
Ten thousand words, a thousand sayings—all point to one awakening.
This one awakening, the cause of universal deliverance—
Universal deliverance requires a sincere and steadfast heart.
The Dao flourishes, the teaching spreads, the ancestral wind soars,
Liberation in true emptiness harmonizes the nature of the mind.

---

**Seventeen: Delivering Sentient Beings**

Disciples, the propagation of the teaching and the flourishing of the Dao that I speak of are not for myself, nor even for the sake of the teaching itself. They are solely for embodying the Dao and emulating Heaven, to deliver sentient beings.

In ancient times, the sages of the Three Teachings—had they not acted for the sake of sentient beings, why would they have established teachings, transmitted scriptures, proclaimed altars, revealed truths, and bent their compassionate hearts to offer expedient means?

Disciples, the Confucian gate was founded by the Most Sage Former Teacher, whose virtue matched the Great Ultimate and whose Dao perfected the Great Accomplishment. Free from rigidity and dogmatism, self and others—he edited the *Book of Documents*, established music, expounded the *Yi*, and upheld the rites. Everywhere, he practiced the transformative influence of the *Spring and Autumn*; in every place, he propagated the scriptures of filial piety and righteousness. The Dao was transmitted to Zengzi and Mencius, bearing the weight of a single shoulder. He became the teacher of Confucians for ten thousand generations and the founder of education for all people. Had Zengzi and Mencius not received transmission in the Zhou dynasty, and had the Cheng brothers and Master Zhu not elucidated the lineage in the Song, how could this be so today?

The Buddhist gate originated with the Tathāgata Śākyamuni Buddha of the Western Land. He practiced austerities in the Snow Mountains, abandoned his kingdom and left his family, subdued body and mind, and perfected merit and conduct. The five aggregates were empty, the six senses purified. He manifested wondrous forms and transformed the ten directions. During the reign of Emperor Ming of Han, a golden figure appeared in a dream. The White Horse carried west the *Vajracchedikā Prajñāpāramitā Sūtra* in 5,048 scrolls. The teaching flowed into the eastern lands, and the name Tathāgata spread. The Dharma was transmitted to the Sixth Patriarch, venerating the golden immortals of Brahman temples, the supreme compassion of the Mahāyāna. Had our Buddha not transmitted the scriptures, how could golden bodies and arhats be universally revered today?

The Dao was established by the Three Pure Ones—vast and boundless, towering and unfathomable. The scriptures are wondrous and profound, transmitted from sage to sage. Manifesting bodies to expound the Dharma, they polished their minds through kalpas. They delivered beings from the sea of suffering and saved the world through the ages. This is the transmission of the Three Officials, the establishment of altars by the Five Poles.

Ancestor Lü of Pure Yang, master of the Three Teachings, issued the commands of the Five Thunders. Everywhere, he revealed traces; in every place, he opened the mysteries. Great compassion, great benevolence, great kindness, great filial piety—he forgot fame and profit, leaving behind the fragrance of incense. He transmitted to our Ancestor Qiu, who diligently cultivated the Dao and preserved benevolence, receiving the *Cinnabar Scripture* at the Phoenix Tower. He founded the lineage and transmitted precepts, reviving the pure discipline of Dragon Gate. Through a thousand hardships and ten thousand sufferings, he vowed to deliver sentient beings.

Revered as the Longspring Perfected Lord, repeatedly exalted as the Illustrious Heavenly Venerable of Radiant Response, he illumines all dharma realms, bestowing vast grace equally upon all. Through meritorious deeds and the establishment of virtue, manifesting manifold divine powers—all for the deliverance of sentient beings, that all may together attain the Great Dao.

Disciples, those who would deliver others must first, with utmost earnestness, deliver themselves. Only then may they deliver others. That the teachings now falter and the mysteries of the ancestral gate lie concealed is precisely because this great malady has not been eradicated.

Why has the Great Dao not flourished? Why have the teachings declined and grown feeble? Disciples, it is due to the root of the great transgression within our Complete Perfection tradition—these eight words: *"unable to deliver oneself, yet seeking only to deliver others"*—which have corrupted the very form of the Complete Perfection teaching.

Disciples, if you expound the teachings yet cannot first follow and uphold them yourselves, how can you persuade others to do so? Who would believe you?

How is it that Complete Perfection fails to deliver the self? Disciples! To deliver sentient beings is to deliver the sentient beings within oneself. And what are these sentient beings within? Disciples, they are the杂念妄想—deluded thoughts and wayward imaginings—within one’s own original mind.

Within the belly of a Complete Perfection adept dwell eighty-four thousand deluded thoughts and wayward imaginings—eighty-four thousand sentient beings. In the course of a single day, within the twelve double-hours, though the body sits upon the meditation cushion, the mind roams the world. One deluded thought just extinguished, another arises. The seven emotions surge unceasingly; the six desires cling and detain. The three poisons entangle; the eight consciousnesses invert. Like floating clouds obscuring the sun, drifting east and west; like raging waves driven by wind, surging west and east. From dawn to dusk, when has the mind ever known a moment’s stillness? Through months and years, when has a single thought ever settled? Not only while seated on the cushion—even while walking the road, or in dreams—when has the deluded mind ever been cast aside, the right mindfulness upheld?

If the mind does not rest, the body is not delivered. If thoughts are not unified, the Dao remains obscured. Thus, within the Complete Perfection gate, one must still thoughts and quiet the mind, only then can the celestial mind manifest and the radiance of wisdom dawn.

O assembly! If Complete Perfection adepts are thus, then they may be called fellow cultivators. Therefore, one must first deliver oneself before proceeding to deliver others. How, then, does one deliver oneself?

Through **fierce resolve**, **courageous vigor**, **unflagging diligence**, **relinquishment and renunciation**, **generosity and offering**, **luminous clarity**, **humility and modesty**, **liberation and detachment**, and **natural spontaneity**.

Disciples, you must concentrate your will without distraction, gather your spirit, and settle your thoughts. Fellow cultivators of karmic affinity, lend your whole hearts to listen as I expound these nine essentials of the Dao, one by one.

Hark! What is **fierce resolve**? The Dao of transcendence fundamentally opposes the ways of the world; their directions differ, their shapes clash. To cultivate the Dharma-body, one must first see through the illusory appearances of the world and the phantom imaginings of the physical form. Sever the bonds of affection for children, spouse, and family; cut off the craving for fame, wealth, fine food, and splendid attire. With a single mind, leap free from the snares of delusion; purify your resolve and do not stray from the numinous treasure. This is fierce resolve—called the *Vajra Pestle* or the *Demon-Slaying Platform*.

What is **courageous vigor**? Indecision and hesitation allow wandering thoughts to come and go; the handle slips from grasp, and clarity is obscured. The mind does not resemble the autumn moon, bright and ever-luminous; the spirit does not ascend the morning clouds, resplendent in reflection. Procrastination and sloth, drifting with the waves; carelessness and distraction, fickle as the hour. Unable to achieve a single morning of expansive clarity, or a single instant of limpid vision. Apply effort to the mind, utterly forsake the mundane; endure hardship in the Dao, vanquish demonic forces. As for the swift and impermanent matter of birth and death, do not remain benighted. Pierce through iron walls and bronze ramparts; awaken to the reality of heaven and hell. Disciples, after fierce resolve, one must add courageous vigor.

What is **unflagging diligence**? Fierce resolve severs karmic ties and establishes the mind in life’s mandate. Courageous vigor subdues distraction and wandering, steadies the spirit, and calms the mind. But what of unflagging diligence? The seeker investigates birth and death: before this body came into being, where were you? After this body perishes, where will you go? In the world, heaven and earth, the ten thousand things, and daily life—all are the Dao. What the eye sees, what the ear hears—nothing lies outside the Dao, nothing escapes its bounds. Things have beginnings and ends, which are the birth and death of things; affairs have starts and finishes, which are the arising and ceasing of affairs. If one applies the mind to inquiry, with苦志精搜, and can fathom the beginnings and ends of things, then one can fathom the birth and death of the body. If one can fathom the starts and finishes of affairs, then one can fathom the arising and ceasing of the mind.

From the ten thousand things, from the ten thousand affairs, examine each minutely, comprehend each truly. From one thing to all things, from one affair to all affairs—none fail to reveal the mechanism of birth and death, the principle of arising and ceasing. When beginnings and ends, birth and death, arising and ceasing all become a single, unbroken effort, only then does one draw near the Dao. Thereafter, with profound absorption in the Great Dao, pursue the subtle and hidden, penetrate the obscure and mysterious, intuit the celestial mind, and secretly fathom the ancestral intent. Enable this single spark of numinous awareness to penetrate the source and flow, respond to the ten thousand things without confusion, and govern the ten thousand affairs without perplexity.

If one refuses unflagging diligence, indulging in sloth and negligence, one abandons oneself and willingly becomes a lowly ghost, devoid of the aspiration for true cultivation. Even if one sits in meditation for a hundred years or prolongs life for a thousand, ultimately impermanence prevails, and one still falls into the wheel of rebirth.

What is **relinquishment and renunciation**? It is to relinquish former vulgarity and renounce heterodox paths, thenceforth advancing with single-minded sincerity.

This single spark of numinous awareness, unobscured and true, is called the primordial and supreme treasure. Though it undergoes a thousand transformations and ten thousand changes, it has no fixed form. When encountering things or meeting affairs, its application differs each time, its response never the same. Wherever one turns, its shadow appears; at every moment, its traces elude. Following its wondrous and numinous mechanism, one penetrates layer upon layer, yet still finds it difficult to reach the summit or exhaust the profound. The more it moves, the more it emerges; drawn upon without end, employed without exhaustion. Those who awaken attain it of themselves; those who remain deluded remain far removed.

For I fear that once you have awakened to one or two parts of this principle, you may cling to it and seek further awakening, rather than abandoning it to awaken anew—this would be impermanence. You must employ the constant and unchanging numinous mechanism to transform those impermanent and ever-changing affairs. Then, with principle clarified and nature revealed, you may relinquish the old and embrace the new, drilling deeper layer by layer, ascending step by step toward the highest. If you do not stand alone and transcendent, how can you thoroughly comprehend the profound mechanism, illuminate life and death, rise beyond the world, and sever the roots of doubt across ten thousand kalpas?

What is **almsgiving**? It is to take the awakened mechanism of yesterday and the wondrous principles of the past—all that has been awakened to and attained—and either bestow them upon sentient beings or conceal them within a grain of millet. They must not be retained, lest they muddy my numinous terrace. As it is said: the mind of the past cannot be grasped, the mind of the future cannot be grasped, and even the mind of the present cannot be grasped. Yet within this ungraspable, seek out the wondrousness of self-attainment, and the light of wisdom will become perfect.

To give alms of wealth is called cultivating blessings; to give alms of the Dharma is called cultivating wisdom. The giving of wealth has an end, but my expounding of the Dharma is inexhaustible. The giving of wealth can aid others in worldly matters, nourish the physical body with clothing and food, and adorn external appearances. Yet when wealth is exhausted, one remains empty-handed. My giving of the Dharma, however, can be practiced in both worldly and transcendent matters. Moreover, the giving of the Dharma can open the deluded apertures of others and uplift their numinous roots.

Yet the wealth given in almsgiving is not the wealth of the world. When ordinary people nurture life, save others, relieve emergencies, aid the distressed, ward off disasters, and avert calamities; when they bring prosperity to the nation and peace to the people; when they govern the movements of water and fire, dispel misfortune, and resolve crises; when they act as agents of heaven to transform all under heaven, command yin and yang, and penetrate heaven and earth with boundless and immeasurable wondrous power—this is true wealth, the very talent of the youth Sudhana, disciple of the Great Being Avalokiteśvara of the Southern Seas. Ah! Do you know that to seek the treasures of heaven, one must use the wealth of the world? This worldly wealth is not the vulgar wealth of the world, but the Dharma-wealth of self-cultivation and liberating others, called the *spiritual treasure*, which can evoke the treasures of heaven. In daily practice, it is the giving of the Dharma. Those who can awaken to this are the primordial sages of wisdom across ten thousand kalpas.

What is **loftiness and clarity**? One who can bestow the wondrous Dharma to liberate sentient beings must possess true loftiness and clarity, with wisdom that is thoroughly penetrating. All things between heaven and earth possess this numinous nature. If I take the Dharma as the Dharma, this is clinging to the Dharma. To cling to the Dharma as the Dharma is a dead Dharma, not a living one, and indicates a lack of loftiness and clarity. Thus, if I teach others using the Dharma I myself employ, applying rigid principles to respond to things, this is a dead Dharma and a dull mechanism—like fixing the oar in place or tuning the zither with glue. One must not insist that one’s own Dharma is correct and others’ Dharmas are wrong. With uprightness and luminosity, one should guide others in accordance with the time, act in response to the moment, and expound with flexibility.

If one applies square methods to round situations, one cannot turn freely. To enlighten the foolish with wisdom is not fitting. One must discern the foolish and speak to them in the language of the foolish, so that they may understand and gradually awaken. If one addresses the wise as if they were foolish, this is also unfitting. One must be attuned to both self and others, refined and common alike, harmonious and fluid. The wise see it as wisdom, the benevolent see it as benevolence; blockages are cleared, disturbances are settled, doubts are resolved, the dull become astute, the deaf hear, and the blind see. Only then can one be called lofty and clear, worthy of leading the work of salvation.

What is **humility**? When true cultivation reaches this point, one encounters those of discerning eyes—vast in wisdom, empty in heart—and all external things, all worldly affairs, become utterly empty. Above, one shakes the gates of heaven; below, one sways the axis of earth. Transcending the human world, the spirit enters the formless.

Where then is there still a sentient being before one’s eyes? From ancient times to the present, the Two Vehicles’ bodhisattvas and the lesser immortals of the lower teachings have all contracted this affliction—so deeply ingrained that none have awakened to it. Thus they are called the lesser vehicle’s inferior roots, the side doors and external teachings, the heterodox paths and demonic arts.

If this be so, how could one presume to fix the boundless Dao or grasp the unfathomable transformations of spirit? How could one, a finite being, dare to exalt oneself?
