Have you not heard that the Most High dares not take precedence in the world, nor claim priority in blessings, nor boast of achievements, nor display the Way? Advancement takes retreat as its foundation; loftiness takes humility as its base. By placing the self last, one preserves it; by yielding, one leads. While others vie to be first, I alone withdraw. Supreme virtue does not assert virtue; the noble person does not contend. Seeing yet unseen, one neither exalts nor esteems nor imposes the self. The more one gives to others, the more one possesses; the more one benefits others, the more one gains. I know not its name—perforce I call it the Dao.

Thus, the higher one’s attainment, the more one practices humility and withdrawal. Through modesty and gentleness, one preserves the Way of profundity. On the one hand, one universally extends kindness and wisdom; on the other, one conserves radiance. A state’s sharpest instruments must not be shown to others—if I do not seek to subdue others, they will naturally submit. At this stage, the principle of liberation cannot remain unknown.

What is liberation? Disciples, those who cling fail to comprehend the Dao and virtue. Unfettered and unentangled by dharmas, naked and unburdened by things, perfectly round and adapting teachings to circumstances, radiantly luminous and delivering beings across kalpas—one enters the gate of all wonders and becomes the mother of sentient beings. Compassion loves beings yet is not defined by love; goodness aids others yet is not defined by aid. The sublime Dharma delivers beings yet is not defined by deliverance; the supreme Dao transcends the world yet is not defined by transcendence. Having transcended the world, one can also enter it; having escaped suffering, one can also endure it. Above, one may ascend beyond heaven yet not regard celestial palaces as realms of joy; below, one may universally save hell-beings yet not view hell as a place of torment. Encountering suffering, one rescues beings from it; encountering joy, one shares it with all. In joy, one points out the suffering of beings; in adversity, one reveals their joy. In heaven, one delivers dragons, spirits, and gods, enabling them to hear the true awakening and attain transcendental immortality. On earth, one delivers sin-laden departed souls, allowing the lost to see the light and be reborn in the human realm. In the world, one delivers all good men and faithful women, universally cultivating the ordinary and everyday—effortless integrity, loyalty, trustworthiness, fairness, and the great Way of virtue. One does not teach scholars, farmers, artisans, or merchants to enter lesser teachings, manipulate spirits, fall into demonic paths, or wage the wars of asuras.

Within this liberation, one must attain the natural function—this is the Dao of spontaneity.

What is the natural? Disciples, this wondrous spontaneity is what the *Heart Sutra* calls “Avalokiteśvara Bodhisattva”—the one who observes the sounds of the world, attaining the marvel of spontaneity, the self-existing and self-liberated Guanyin. This is the bodhisattva within one’s own heart, the Guanyin of the Southern Sea. It is the wondrous form of the pure emptiness of the other shore, the principle of formless spontaneity—able to perceive the true sound’s wondrous form. Without a true teacher’s guidance, could one awaken to the wondrous form of true emptiness?

Ah, disciples! Form is precisely emptiness, emptiness precisely form; neither emptiness nor form, the Dao is not real. The true emptiness’s wondrous form is the everlasting Dao; neither empty nor formed, its wonders are infinite. It is one body with the void, and the void is no different from it. It enters metal and stone without obstruction, water and fire without harm.

Disciples, delve deeply into the nine essentials of the Dao, firmly uphold the humble meditation cushion, awaken to all wondrous forms, align with spontaneity, and the three teachings will be realized. Perfectly delivering beings, your merit will be immeasurable, your virtue subduing spirits and demons, evil forces bound and malevolent entities disempowered. What fear is there that the world will not believe and take refuge?

Just so:
Universal deliverance’s merit, a heart of beneficence,
Diligently cultivate the self before saving others.
A sincere aspiration for the everlasting Dao,
Naturally, bodhisattvas protect my path.
The ninefold wondrous canon transcends the mundane,
A piece of perfect truth, deeply refined.
Disseminating subtle words of true marvel,
Dual cultivation of nature and life, undaunted by toil.
With discerning insight, expound the Dharma often;
With humility and gentleness, never boast of ability.
Abandon external appearances, forget self and other,
The true thusness of heaven’s heart, the great Dao in motion.
Carefree and liberated, expounding the profound,
The supreme true emptiness, the mysterious Dao.
Water and fire unharmed, the three lineages united,
Merit perfected, conduct fulfilled, stepping into the clouds.

**18. The Radiance of Wisdom**

Disciples, having received the three hundred great precepts of the Middle Realm, you must uphold secret conduct and subtle decorum—this is not like the initial precepts of earlier days. These precepts are refined and profound; the effort must be applied within your own heart. In every arising thought, maintain sincerity and reverence, silently reflecting, examining, and rousing yourself to utmost integrity. Sweep the mind’s thoughts clean—spotless as the azure sky and bright moon, without a trace of cloud; pure as crystal and lapis lazuli, without the slightest flaw; vast as an unblemished mirror, without a speck of dust; luminous as a night-shining pearl, without a thread of darkness. Only when perfectly steady and radiantly bright can one proceed to discuss the radiance of wisdom. This true emptiness’s wondrous form originally arises from precepts and concentration.

Only through enduring humiliation to sever obstructions, through rigorous discipline in precepts, through relentless self-mastery and tempering—coupled with the aid of dharma and elixirs—can one attain this state. If one merely observes precepts yet lacks the resolve to uphold them, if one’s practice is subtle and exacting yet self-deceptive and self-concealing, it remains utterly unattainable.

Why is this so?
Ah, disciples, laxity in practice becomes a leaky cause—how then can one realize the fruit of the unconditioned? This wisdom-radiance, these four characters, belong to the superior vehicle of keen faculties. Thus, those of inferior capacity and dull roots, unable to awaken, must instead focus their will undividedly, concentrate spirit within the qi-cavern, cultivate the ancestral qi, nurture the primordial, attain utmost emptiness, and guard stillness with unwavering devotion. When singular and unbroken, the spirit conceals itself boundlessly; when pushed to its limit, it becomes the Great Ultimate. Naturally, wisdom’s radiance arises, the first yang returns, and one beholds the original face.

To know the conditions of ghosts and spirits, to penetrate the pivot of creation—this is called *zhi* (wisdom).
To assist heaven and earth in transformation, to parallel the sun and moon in illumination, to harmonize with the alternating seasons—this is called *hui* (insight).
To universally manifest the Dharma-body, to encompass the Dharma-realm without straying beyond awakened awareness, to wholly return within luminous clarity—this is called *guang* (radiance).
To pervade all things without form, to perceive all affairs before their signs arise, to traverse empty space without trace, to surpass sun and moon without shadow—this is called *ming* (luminosity).

If precepts are not observed with precision, one cannot attain profound stability. Without profound stability, wisdom does not arise. Without wisdom, radiance does not manifest.

The *Jade Pivot Precious Sutra* in one scroll directly reveals the original nature and points to the human heart. The nature’s truth is made manifest, the celestial mechanism fully unveiled, enabling beings to recite the sutra and awaken to the Dao. Yet alas, the deluded are many, the awakened few. The mouth recites in vain while the heart fails to uphold; the heart may be sincere, yet the strength cannot turn it. What a pity—betraying the sagely intent, vainly pointing to the Dharma-treasure.

Now I cannot but expound the sutra’s wondrous meaning on its behalf, revealing the true mechanism to guide you, disciples, into sudden awakening. Each of you must reverently and attentively listen.

The sutra states: *"Long ago, fifteen thousand kalpas past, my heart encountered this Dao, and I ascended to the rank of Upper Perfected. My intent refined this merit, and I wielded the power of great transformation."*
It further says: *"With a pure and still heart, one makes vast vows; with the power of wisdom, one subdues all demons."*
And: *"You, gods and humans, desire to hear the supreme Dao. The supreme Dao is profound and distant—it lies not elsewhere. Since you wish to hear, know that the one who does not hear is the true hearer. Without hearing, without seeing—this is the true Dao. Even hearing and seeing must be dissolved; only you remain. Yet you yourself are not a thing—how much less the Dao? To hear without hearing—what Dao is there to discuss?"*
And: *"The Dao is entered through sincerity, guarded through silence, and employed through softness. Using sincerity appears foolish; using silence appears inarticulate; using softness appears clumsy. Only thus can one forget form, forget self, forget even forgetting. Those who enter the Dao know when to stop; those who guard the Dao know caution; those who employ the Dao know subtlety. Knowing subtlety, wisdom’s radiance arises; knowing caution, sagely wisdom is complete; knowing when to stop, profound stability is secure. With profound stability secure, sagely wisdom is complete; with sagely wisdom complete, wisdom’s radiance arises; with wisdom’s radiance arisen, one becomes one with the Dao. This is called true forgetting. Only in forgetting yet not forgetting, in forgetting what cannot be forgotten—this is the supreme Dao. The Dao pervades heaven and earth, yet heaven and earth do not know it; whether sentient or insentient, it is singular and without duality."*
And: *"Those who attain awakening ascend to the immortal’s throne."*
And: *"The foolish may become wise, the turbid may become clear—only fate commands it. Foolishness is dim, turbidity is dark—these too are shifts in the endowment of wind and earth. Heaven and earth move by their mechanism, causing people not to know—this is called spontaneity. If one knows that they do not know, this too is called spontaneity. The wonder of spontaneity, though wondrous in knowing, is wondrous precisely in not knowing. Yet regarding the Dao, there has never been foolishness or turbidity."*
And: *"All that has been proclaimed—when a superior person receives the sutra, they must cut gold and place coin, swearing an oath to heaven before transmitting it."*

Disciples, this is the true, mysterious, and secret essence of the *Jade Pivot Sutra*—the unsurpassed, inconceivable, supreme, and wondrous Dharma-treasure of pure liberation. You merely recite the sutra daily yet have never grasped its wondrous import. If, when reciting and revering it, you awaken to its secret subtleties, then sagely wisdom will be complete and wisdom’s radiance will arise.

The supreme Dao is profound and cannot be seen or heard. Had the Heavenly Worthy not, fifteen thousand kalpas ago, opened the pure and still heart and made vast vows to deliver all future beings to the wondrous ultimate, it would be said: the Dao’s root is emptiness and nothingness—no sound to be heard, no form to be seen. Since no sound can be heard, one must forget the ears; since no form can be seen, one must forget the eyes. When ears and eyes are forgotten, hearing and seeing are also dissolved. For ears and eyes, being formed and colored, lead the six senses; hearing and seeing, clinging to appearances and thoughts, are the very source of the six senses—how could they accord with the Dao?

If one can purify the six sense-fields and sweep away the six consciousnesses, then one does not listen with the ears but with the heart, does not see with the eyes but with the spirit. Thus, one hears without listening, sees without looking. Without hearing, without seeing—this is accord with the Dao.

The *Red Writ Cavern Classic* states: *"Forget the eyes, and radiance overflows boundlessly; forget the ears, and the mind’s awareness abides in profound depth. When both mechanisms are forgotten, one enters the gate of all wonders. Seeing yet not seeing the self, hearing yet not hearing—transcending all extremes, this is called the wondrous Dao."*

The *Nanhua Sutra* states: *"Qi settles in the ears, the heart settles in resonance."* Thus, the *Jade Pivot Classic* says: *"Forget form, forget the self—this is the mechanism of entering the Dao."* One enters through sincerity, and this sincerity is precepts. One guards through silence, and this silence is samadhi. One acts through softness, and this softness is wisdom. To employ sincerity as if foolish is to uphold precepts and subdue body and mind. To employ silence as if inarticulate is to enter samadhi and forget the ears and eyes. To employ softness as if clumsy is to conceal wisdom in secrecy.

It further states: *"If you seek within your own corporeal form to hear and see, you will never see, never hear."* The *Vajracchedikā Sūtra* says: *"One who seeks me through form or sound walks the deviant path and cannot see the Tathāgata."* Those who wish to enter the Dao must only receive precepts, enter samadhi, and secretly cultivate wisdom. When delusion is transformed into clarity, one hears without hearing and sees without seeing.

Thus, those who enter the Dao know cessation—this is the practice of upholding precepts to still thoughts; know reverence—this is the practice of vigilance in solitude and diligent progress; know subtlety—this is the practice of transcending sagacity and relinquishing cunning. Stillness of thought cannot be achieved without precepts; vigilance in solitude cannot be achieved without samadhi; subtlety cannot be known without wisdom. If one can uphold precepts, enter samadhi, and cultivate wisdom, then body and mind will be profoundly settled, sagely wisdom will be wholly perfected, and the radiance of wisdom will universally illumine. When the radiance of wisdom shines through, one merges with the Dao—this is called true forgetting. This true forgetting is not the vacuous stillness of sitting in meditation; it is true emptiness. Within this true emptiness, there is the wondrous form of purple gold—emptiness that is not empty, the marvelous fruit within the void. If one does not fall into vacuous emptiness but abides in emptiness that is not empty, the essential marvel will naturally manifest. Only when one forgets that which is to be forgotten does the utmost true and wondrous Dao emerge.

It is also said: Fools and the wise differ, and thus purity and turbidity diverge. Though these arise from varying endowments of wind and soil, all are the workings of creation’s mechanism, the natural movement of qi and the principle of destiny, predetermined by heaven. Yet fools remain fools, and the wise remain wise—how could heaven be blamed for their folly or wisdom? Only by arousing a mind of purity and establishing vast vows—vows to transcend the world and deliver beings, to hear the Dao and attain self-liberation—can one proceed. Those who attain self-liberation take refuge in the Three Jewels, receive precepts, enter samadhi, and cultivate wisdom to radiate light. Then the foolish may become wise, and the turbid may become pure. If one cannot uphold precepts, enter samadhi, or penetrate wisdom, then no light will shine, and the pure may become turbid, the wise may become foolish. The *Vajracchedikā Sūtra* says: *"The Dharma I teach has no fixed Dharma."* This is what it means.

The wisdom and radiance spoken of here illumine the Great Mystery, shining upon the Dharma realm—how could they lie beyond the *Jade Pivot Treasure Classic*? The Jade Pivot is the true mechanism. Those who wish to turn the sutras must first turn the true mechanism and secretly cultivate merit and wisdom. Yet if the radiance remains concealed, one cannot open or perceive it. How then could one discern the forms of ghosts and spirits, grasp the pivot of creation, participate in heaven and earth’s transformation, direct the movements of sun and moon, gather the Dharma realm within a mustard seed, or stabilize all things at their unmanifest beginning? How could one be called a master of the wondrous Dao or ascend to the realm of celestial immortals?

Truly:
*"Perceiving the treasury of radiance,
One hears the root of the utmost Dao.
Without cultivating precepts and samadhi,
How could wisdom’s light run deep?
Clinging to form is not true form;
Only in forgetting hearing does one truly hear.
Hearing, contemplation, and cultivation lead to the marvelous—
Naturally, the sound of the ocean tide."*

**19. The Wondrous Function of Supernormal Powers**

Disciples, the path of wisdom and radiance spoken of above is expressed in the *Jade Pivot Classic* merely through the forgetting of hearing and seeing. In the absence of hearing and seeing, the wondrous function is fully expounded, and supernormal powers manifest.

Disciples, the *Yinfu Jing* states: *"The deaf see clearly, the blind see and hear."* The ancient immortals said: *"In stillness, one does not hear thunder; in deep vision, one does not see Mount Tai."* The *Doctrine of the Mean* says: *"The virtue of ghosts and spirits is most abundant! They are seen yet not seen, heard yet not heard."* The *Nanhua Sutra* says: *"See nothing, hear nothing, embrace the spirit in stillness."* The *Cantong Qi* says: *"The three treasures—ears, eyes, and mouth—must be closed and not opened. The true person hides in the deep abyss, floating and wandering within the compass."*

All the wondrous words in the scriptures cannot be fully recounted. The Bodhisattva Avalokiteśvara, through hearing, contemplation, and cultivation, entered samādhi. The ear is the aperture through which essence leaks—not the essence of postnatal floating desires, but the qi of primordial Taiyi containing true reality, the essence of the true origin’s response. If one listens inwardly and seals one’s hearing, essence will not scatter, and wisdom will arise. The eye is the aperture through which spirit leaks—not the spirit of postnatal deliberation, but the innate knowing of the wondrous form’s numinous awareness, the original spirit of the primordial undifferentiated mist. If one gazes inwardly and returns one’s clarity, the spirit will not wander outward, and wisdom will arise.

By upholding precepts and entering samadhi, wisdom is born. When wisdom is born, water and fire interact. When water and fire interact, Kan and Li unite. When Kan and Li unite, heaven and earth are at peace. When heaven and earth are at peace, metal and wood harmonize. When metal and wood harmonize, hun and po converge. When hun and po converge, essence and qi transform. When essence and qi transform, supernormal powers manifest. When supernormal powers manifest, radiance shines forth. When radiance shines forth, merit is perfected. When merit is perfected, the Dharma body is accomplished. When the Dharma body is accomplished, the Dao’s essence is revealed. When the Dao’s essence is revealed, the wondrous function operates.

When the wondrous function operates, all beings are delivered. When all beings are delivered, the power of vows is fulfilled. When the power of vows is fulfilled, the great task is complete. When the great task is complete, the position is realized and the fruit is attained.

There is but this One Vehicle; the other two are not true. From beginning to end, it does not depart from the word *sincerity*. As the *Doctrine of the Mean* says, "Without sincerity, there is nothing." That "nothing" is the "dimly visible, indistinct" in which there is something; the "profound, obscure" in which there is essence. That essence is most true, and within it there is *faith*. Faith is sincerity—this is what the *Book of Changes* means by "essence and qi become things," and what the *Great Learning* means by "things are investigated." The essence is the "refined essence" of the *Book of Documents*. The "center" is the "center" of *its center*. The *Lotus Sutra* says, "There is a treasure hidden in the mountain of form; the sage uses it to wash the heart and then retreats to conceal it in secrecy"—all these refer to this very thing. First conceal it, then reveal it.

An ancient song says:
*"If this heart holds not a single thing,
Before your eyes is Fu Xi’s time."*
Why then seek supernormal powers or wondrous function?
Why pursue wisdom or radiance?

These supernormal powers and wondrous functions are the true person who upholds the precepts and the Dao, manifesting to teach and deliver beings, gathering the illusory to return to the real—this is the wondrous function. Thus, within the radiance of great wisdom, arms of golden wisdom are extended to rescue all beings, lifting them from suffering and affliction into purity and stillness. They can grant short-lived beings long life, transform calamity and suffering into peace and joy, bring about the clear governance of lands, and extend life to preserve destiny. They make beings pure and upright, dispelling demons and evil; they drive away the violent and rebellious, annihilate demons and monsters, so that beings become compassionate and refrain from killing or harming life.

They can protect beings from the constraints of kalpas, dissolving karmic knots and resolving grievances. They can shatter the darkness of beings and reveal radiance. They can cure the hundred diseases and universally dispel chronic illnesses. They can turn foolishness into wisdom, return to correctness and abandon evil. They can reduce desires and purify the heart, gathering emotions to return to nature. They can bring about unobstructed liberation, transcending the mundane to enter sagehood. They can accumulate blessings and dispel calamities, generating auspiciousness and eradicating transgressions. They can enable beings to leave the world and accomplish the Dao, departing from suffering to ascend to truth. They can allow beings to cultivate the supreme vehicle, ascend to heaven, universally guide all beings, spiritually roam the eight directions, and transcend the celestial palaces.

May all beings in their ordinary forms become Dharma Kings—even to the point of being unfathomable—this is called *supernormal power*. Not leaking its mechanism is called *wondrous function*. Thus, the supernormal powers of the gate of precepts, samadhi, and wisdom are the *non-supernormal supernormal*, transforming the six consciousnesses into the six penetrations—penetrating heaven, penetrating earth, penetrating spirits, penetrating ghosts, penetrating humans, penetrating things—this is called *supernormal power*. This wondrous existence, the wondrousness of non-wondrousness, moves a single mechanism to manifest in myriad forms and transformations. Transforming heavenly demons, earthly malevolent stars, myriad ghosts, evil people, and monstrous beings—this is called *wondrous function*.

Within the gate of precepts and samadhi, entering stillness, samadhi and wisdom generate radiance—this is the auspicious sign of the primordial unity of qi, perfectly luminous. Above, it connects to the celestial palaces, paying homage to the ancestral qi above the Three Clarities. Below, it connects to the earthly prisons, absolving sinful souls at the bottom of the Nine Springs. When the Dharma is expounded, heavenly spirits are subdued; the Five Emperors attend the court, myriad spirits stand guard, ranks arrayed in solemn order, desiring to hear the true Dharma and refine the spirit to return to emptiness. Having attained liberation, with a heart of compassion and pity, they relieve the suffering of the cold and the hidden. Thus, Yama praises, Earth Treasury illuminates, ghostly judges comply, and the underworld is subdued. Sin is absolved, rebirth is granted, the true Dharma is heard, the ghostly register is cast off, and all are transformed into the Land of Ultimate Bliss.

Thus, from self-deliverance to delivering others, great vows are made: may all beings universally hear the supreme Dao, and may the medicine of the Dharma universally save all beings. Even the dull and the moving, the endowed with spirit, all receive liberation. Earth, wood, tiles, and stones all attain resonance. All things and emotions are thoroughly penetrated. Supernormal powers operate in the unknowing and unaware, and heaven, earth, and the myriad things are within this body. Wondrous function arises naturally, and mountains, rivers, and stars all return to the Dharma. Heavenly demons all bow in reverence, lowering their heads in welcome. Earthly malevolent stars all transform into kindness and harmony, their hearts filled with awe and submission. Fierce and malevolent ghosts, upon transformation, ascend and forever renounce blood offerings. Asuras and external paths take refuge in the Dharma and return to correctness. Wars cease forever, wrongs are righted, and grievances dissolve. Through virtue, not force, evil people all become good; through sincerity, not artifice, the perverse all become upright.

Reversing the handle of the Dipper to move yin and yang, spirits and ghosts cannot fathom it. Inverting the mechanism of transformation to transcend the world, heaven and earth do not perceive it. Universally manifesting spirit and luminosity, the Dharma body is indestructible, yet no form is observable. Broadly proclaiming the supreme One Vehicle wondrous Dharma, yet no sound is audible. Empty space is my Dharma realm; I am the Dharma body of empty space. Vast and boundless, one with heaven; upright and great, one in heart with immortals and buddhas.

Master Cheng said: *"Release it, and it pervades the six directions; withdraw it, and it retreats into concealment."* This is precisely what is meant. The parents of all beings, the Dharma masters of the Daoist gate—are they not the supernormal powers of purity and liberation, the wondrous function of non-action and spontaneity?

Disciples, do not cling to appearances, and wisdom will be vast and great. Follow the natural course, and wondrous function will be boundless. It lies only in the ordinary and everyday, never neglecting even in haste or urgency—these are but the two words *Dao* and *virtue*. Why then abandon precepts to study talismanic arts, discard jade to covet worthless stones, contenting oneself as a fool and not learning the supreme vehicle of the Dao?

Alas! Disciples entering the mysterious gate should seek the supreme vehicle. Every person contains a wondrous aperture; each one is radiant and luminous.

Amidst manifold obstructions, they regard precepts as empty formalities.
Though they hold them often, their practice is intermittent; their meditation, shallow and unsteady.
When meditative power deepens and precepts are earnestly upheld,
let neither forced effort nor forgetfulness be the rule.
In every one of the twelve double-hours, hold fast without cease;
through three years or five, let no lapse or transgression occur.
When meditation is forgotten and precepts become second nature, spiritual communion arises of itself—
and when the spirit communes, wondrous function is true.

Wielding spiritual communion, attaining wondrous function—
disciples must rely on sincere, unrelenting progress.
If one clings foolishly to appearances in seeking,
the ghostly den becomes their livelihood, not the true path.
External paths and heterodox schools cling to form;
attachment to emptiness or to form is no true cultivation.
Neither cling to emptiness nor to form—
in samādhi, formless; in response, communion.
In function, numinous clarity—spirit distinguishes itself.
How many Daoists lose the central work!

I do not speak idly now—
hark! I reveal the celestial mechanism!
When spiritual communion manifests and wondrous function shines forth,
one becomes the great Dharma-king, coiling through earth and spanning heaven.
Not departing from the ever-quiet true and constant Dao,
demonic teachings submit, and evil transforms into goodness.
Rebellion, in a single dawn, becomes filial piety;
the stubborn and fierce all turn gentle and kind.
Wisdom like a mirror, insight like a spirit—
a single luminous terrace, radiant and bright.
The six supernormal powers interpenetrate without trace;
the great earth and mountains and rivers are all gold.

Disciples, do not slacken in upholding precepts—
this is the heavenly ladder, step by step ascending.
The spirit is unfathomable, the wondrous immeasurable;
yet they do not depart from precepts, samādhi, and the true and constant function.
Within the gate of Suchness lies a celestial aperture;
in the chamber of Non-Duality, sacred fragrance issues forth.
Disciples, cultivate sincerely and do not abandon yourselves—
since ancient times, the great Dao-field of immortals and sages.

---

**20. Awakening to Life and Death**

Disciples, from ancient times to the present, sages, immortals, and buddhas
have acted only for the great matter of causation—
nine years facing the wall, solely to press forward in seeking life and death,
to transcend the world and subdue the mind.
Have you not heard? Like sparks from struck stone or lightning’s flash,
like fallen blossoms or flowing water—
when impermanence arrives, not even a moment can be retained.
Sin and merit follow the body; in the wheel of rebirth, one receives retribution.
Before words are finished, the breath in the throat ceases;
before speech is complete, the tongue retracts, unable to sound.
Naked and alone, where can one find refuge?
Dark and boundless, who can establish their destiny?
With great fortune, one returns to the human world;
with evil karma, one falls into Fengdu.
When blessings are exhausted, one re-enters the wheel;
when karmic retribution ends, one is reborn as an animal.
For ten thousand kalpas, karmic entanglements are hard to escape;
for a thousand lives, sinful karma cannot be worn away.
Life after life, sunk in delusion—
drunk in life, dreaming in death.
Mutual retribution, wearing horns and fur.
To speak of it is grievous and lamentable;
to recount it is pitiable and terrifying.

If one does not firmly resolve, clenching one’s innate conscience,
uprooting the earth and overturning the heavens—
awakening to what life after death is like;
sacrificing the heart and risking life,
seeing through the myriad foolish delusions of past lives—
then, should one encounter a man of resolute determination,
let his brows bristle straight, the demon-slaying sword grasped in hand.
Truly a great man—let his vast qi expand,
the blade of rectitude slashing at the heart’s deceptions.
One must see through to the time before parents gave birth—
where was one’s destiny established? From what profound transformation did one arise?
After death, where will one find refuge?
Awakening to the three bodies—past, future, and present.
Pursuing the three lifetimes as if they were yesterday,
the coming dawn as if it were this very morning.
Thus, one dissolves the ten thousand cares,
leaving only that single point of numinous light.
Sweeping clean all conditions, preserving only that spark of wisdom.
Entering the mysterious pass—when one aperture opens, a hundred open;
perceiving the true source—then the three times are clear, and the three realms are transcended.
Liberated, the five phases are unobstructed;
in emptiness, the four great elements return to void.
Entering the gate of myriad wonders, ascending the ground of the Three Treasures—
coming and going freely, transforming without limit.
Gently turning the celestial mechanism,
even spirits cannot fathom its wonder.
Majestically wielding the Dipper’s handle in reverse,
yin and yang cannot constrain its power.
Carefree in the vastness of Brahmā’s qi,
attaining the position of pure emptiness and boundlessness.
Forever departing the dust and kalpas,
transcending the cage of the world.
The great matter of the Perfected Realized One is accomplished;
the causal conditions of self-liberation are fulfilled.
This realm of true emptiness—
all arises from the steadfast practice of samādhi,
advancing step by step along the great path.
Without cultivating right and wrong, one swiftly arrives.
This wondrous dharma-body of existence—
all is obtained through the aperture of wisdom,
practicing each subtle work in sequence.
How could one not awaken and attain gradual completion?

Disciples!
The Dao is transmitted by sages, but cultivation depends on oneself;
virtue is accumulated by the person, but discernment comes from heaven.
Have you not heard? Heaven divides creation from the One;
humans establish order from the heart.
Each must strive, hastening in practice—
urgently pressing forward.
Those who have not awakened do not lose the good cause;
those who awaken fully return to the azure heavens.
Even those who have not awakened do not fall into hell.

Disciples!
It is like knocking on a door with a golden brick—
if the door does not open, the golden brick remains.
Upholding precepts and cultivating the Dao—
if the Dao is not awakened, the precepts and practice remain.
One will certainly not sink into the netherworld;
ultimately, one will be reborn in the world of light.
Former causes are not obscured, and the fruit is naturally attained.
With but a slight turn, one still holds the handle in hand.

Disciples!
Awakening to life and death—do not seek outside yourself.
Only when life and death are awakened to does one know the true origin within the heart.
All my words now are no substitute for any method.
If you embody this in your heart and act accordingly,
you will find that principle for yourself.
Investigating life within death, awakening to death within life—
this mechanism of life and death turns on the person’s own effort.
It is up to you, not up to me.
Seeking stillness within movement, finding movement within stillness—
the subtleties of movement and stillness
depend entirely on the inner illumination of innate knowledge.
The heart can be questioned, but the teacher cannot.
Remember my words well—they will not lead you astray.
If you do not follow what I say, you will ultimately err and delay.

This dim lamp of mine lights the way for countless lost travelers.
This raft of mine ferries suffering beings across—passengers fill the Ganges.
Disciples, cast aside doubt—once you recognize the truth, walk onward through the night.

Then, in the silent garden, a chant arose:
*"Where is the homeland before birth? To which realm do we return after death?
Now is the time to awaken to the Dharma-body—do not pass through the prime of life empty-handed.
Death and life, life and death—intertwine them,
for the great matter of cause and condition brooks no delay.
Before death, first embody death—
the mechanism of life is found by probing within death.
Not in water, not on mountains—
why seek in the northwest or southeast?
Look, and you will see it lies not beyond this body,
only within this small square inch of the heart.
Precepts, concentration, wisdom—enter the mysterious gate,
and do not let your efforts scatter in duality.
With single-minded focus on awakening to life and death,
even iron walls and bronze ramparts cannot withstand you.
Truly bitter, truly arduous—
like a boat navigating shallow shoals.
But should the river tide rise and the wind turn fair,
in an instant you will fly past the Nine Dragons’ Bay.
Recognize the truth, and walk through the night—
seek your staff, and you will find none exists.
Alone on the empty path of cultivation,
thirstless, hungerless, with the longevity of heaven and earth."*

21. The Merit Comes to Completion.

Oh disciples! Vast as the empty sky, within this gate of precepts and concentration lies the ladder to heaven; boundless as the sea of suffering, within this radiance of wisdom lies the vessel to cross it. If you do not stride forward with resolve, how can you traverse ninety thousand miles? If you do not stand firm with spine upright, how can you hear the true Dharma through a hundred thousand kalpas?

Should your practice lack density or your will falter, how can merit be perfected or virtue fulfilled? Disciples, let not a single thought leak from your mind, and the primordial qi within your body will naturally suffuse and harmonize. When virtue subdues gods and spirits, only then can you escape the retribution of rebirth; when the Dao flows through heaven and earth, only then can you emerge from the path of life and death.

Ascend the shore of the Dao, and with a turn of the body, you return home; plunge into the profound and subtle, and in an instant, you recover your original face. Disciples, who among you abides in deathlessness? Who has witnessed eternal life? Deathlessness is no mortal form; eternal life is not bound to physical substance. Where now is Pengzu? Where does Yanzi endure through ten thousand kalpas? Deathlessness is my Dharma-body; eternal life is my primordial qi.

Even the Tathāgata had his time of quiescent extinction, entering the realm of nirvana; even Laozi had his day of ascension, transcending the Great Scarlet Heaven. Where the Dao abides, there the person abides; where the Dharma exists, there the body exists. To die yet not forget is longevity—through a thousand myriad kalpas, the indestructible nameless name; to live yet not possess is form—through a hundred generations, the unmarred formless form.

Countless as the sands of the Ganges, the sages and worthies—each and every one emerged from this mysterious gate; innumerable beyond reckoning, the immortals and buddhas—each and every one traversed this great path. How clear and bright is the celestial thoroughfare, yet deluded beings doubt and disbelieve; how pure and still is the Buddha-land, yet worldly beings cling to obstacles hard to remove.

It is only that blessings are meager and sins profound—though they have eyes, they are no better than the blind. Many, burdened by deep karmic debts, though living, are already counted among the dead. Moving as corpses in flesh, they differ from beasts only in speech; sleeping by day and night, they are less than plants, lacking even their upright stems and spreading branches.

When the tally of days is spent and ghosts come to summon, what care is given if you are a perfected Daoist? When the record of sins is examined without a single error, you are still judged a man of no virtue, an evildoer. Disciples! All must die—yet strive to die well, pure and clean, untrammeled in coming and going. All must disperse—yet strive to disperse wondrously, lucid and free, transforming with effortless mastery.

Before turning away, bid farewell to all; when the hour arrives, let go and depart.

Naked as a newborn babe, from the crown of the head radiate a myriad streams of luminous qi and auspicious light. Perfect and round, the wondrous form ascends in flight, midair adorned with colored clouds and soaring white cranes. Amidst such celestial splendor, the primordial spirit returns to pure emptiness; within this single expanse of auspicious radiance, the true bones are enshrined in the grotto-heaven. The great man’s work is complete! He leaves behind an immortal name among men and bequeaths a scripture of Daoist teachings to the world. Thus, for a thousand hundred years to come, it shall be known that such a one existed. This is what is meant by "death yet not perishing—this is longevity."

Should his Way endure through ten thousand亿 kalpas, he becomes a body of Great Perfection, Great Merit, and Great Blessing.

Disciples! Life and destiny lie within yourselves—none can inform you of them. If you do not cultivate yourself, none can cultivate in your stead. The arising and ceasing of thoughts—none can grasp them for you. Deluded thoughts and selfish desires—none can sweep them away for you. Deeply entangled in love and attachment—none can relinquish them for you. The Dharmakāya is formless—none can recognize it for you. Precepts and monastic rules—none can practice them for you. Afflictions and ignorance—none can extinguish them for you. Habits of worldly dust—none can dissolve them for you. Myriad obstructions—none can remove them for you. Sacred words and wondrous Dharma—none can adhere to them for you. Karmic consequences of sin and merit—none can believe in them for you. Worldly thoughts and mundane attitudes—none can forget them for you. Aspirations clinging to form—none can empty them for you. Heterodox paths and external teachings—none can discern them for you. Illusory fabrications of conditioned existence—none can penetrate them for you. Every affair and every thing—none can respond to them for you. Every state and every realm—none can transcend them for you. A perfected one or a luminous master—none can seek them for you. The vast and empty Great Dao—none can enter it for you. In this very life, disciples—none can liberate you. The initial vow and its power—none can fulfill them for you.

Why is this so? It is only because, O disciples, your pride and arrogance render you unteachable. Kind words and gentle admonitions cannot reach you. Doubt and disbelief cannot awaken you. Heavy karmic debts and deep sins cannot be uprooted for you. Anger, slander, and defamation cannot be restrained for you. Flattery and obsequious praise cannot sway you. Fierce temper and violent rage cannot be opposed in you. Cunning schemes and treacherous calculations cannot be abandoned for you. Sincere counsel and bitter exhortations cannot penetrate you. Confusion, delusion, and madness cannot be shattered for you. Blindness and lack of insight cannot be enlightened for you. Recklessness and impropriety cannot be curbed for you. Sickness and suffering cannot be healed for you. Karmic misfortune and calamities cannot be pardoned for you. Fate and kalpas cannot spare you. Cyclic rebirth and retribution cannot release you. Royal law and infernal punishment cannot exempt you. Knife mountains and sword trees cannot spare you. The compassionate vessel and wisdom raft cannot ferry you across. The golden elixir and wondrous treasure cannot be bestowed upon you. Though there be celestial mechanisms, they cannot turn you. Though there be divine powers, they cannot liberate you.

Disciples! Only when you truly resolve with bitter determination, uphold the precepts without transgression, seek samādhi within samādhi, and maintain unwavering sincerity—only then is this a true turning of the heart toward the Dao.

Disciples, when the heart turns toward the Dao, repentance naturally washes clean. When one takes refuge in the Great Dao, entanglements can be severed. The celestial vault of heaven’s mystery—pure emptiness can be neared. The darkness of hell’s underworld—light naturally dawns. Great disasters and cataclysmic kalpas—cyclic rebirth can be escaped. The impermanence of life and death—the handle stands firm. The boundless Great Dao—heart after heart naturally aligns. The supreme Dharmakāya—clear and complete, it is naturally realized. Limitless blessings—naturally, they are received with ease. Countless beings—one by one, they can be liberated. Vast vows and great aspirations—profoundly, they are naturally fulfilled. Enduring as heaven and earth—longevity can be attained alike.

Only with a luminous heart—obstructions naturally dissolve. Only with sincerity—metal and stone naturally yield. Only with humility—not even the finest dust can cling. Only with constancy—not even the ten thousand demons can seize. Only with a kind heart—enmity and evil naturally transform. Only with a true heart—demonic forces cannot provoke. Only with a clear heart—the sages and worthies can be equaled, and all is naturally comprehended. Only with an enlightened heart—the immortals and buddhas can be realized, and all is naturally awakened. Only with an empty heart—wondrous principles can be perceived, and one naturally delves deeply. Only with a settled heart—wondrous forms can be recognized, and wisdom naturally unfolds. Only with an illuminated heart—true emptiness can be attained, and all is naturally silently harmonized. Only with a steadfast heart—life and death can be understood, and all is naturally dissolved. Only with an impartial heart—King Yama can be met, and one is naturally free of sin. Only with a just heart—ghosts and spirits can be faced, and one is naturally free of deceit. Only with an upright heart—demons and monsters can be subdued, and one is naturally radiant. Only with a sincere heart—evil demons can be awed, and one is naturally endowed with great wisdom. Only with a giving heart—heavenly deities can be approached, and one is naturally imbued with great vow-power. Only with a compassionate heart—the ignorant and stubborn can be transformed, and one naturally bestows universal shade. Only with a majestic heart—fierce evils can be subdued, and one is naturally fearless. Only with a forbearing heart—nothing can be discarded, and one is naturally magnanimous. Only with an empty heart—formlessness can be preserved, and one naturally ascends to awakened illumination. Only with a forgetful heart—formlessness can be distinguished, and one is naturally free of self and others. Only with a patient heart—no being is unknowable, and one naturally liberates all beings. Only with a non-abiding heart—no realm can be clung to, and one is naturally fluid and complete.

Only with a mind of perfect penetration—none of the Three Realms can confine it, and one is naturally free from all entanglements. Only with a mind of beneficent salvation—no kalpa is impassable. Only with a mind of purity and stillness—boundlessness can be dwelt in, and one is naturally perfected in great wholeness.

Disciples, I have now finished expounding the Dharma; the Dao-field is complete. Yet I think of you: father and son ascend the mountain, the father cannot transmit to the son, the son cannot take the father’s place. Those who cultivate the Way together know their own warmth and cold, advance and retreat on their own.

Thus, in teaching the Dharma there is not a single fixed method—it is merely prescribing medicine according to the illness, dispensing remedies according to the symptoms. When the illness is cured and the symptoms dispelled, there is no further need for prescriptions or medicine. It is like crossing a river by boat: once ashore, one should not think of the boat again. It is like threading a needle to sew clothes: when the sewing is done, there is no need to seek needle and thread further. Do not draw legs on a snake or pull up grass to search for a snake.

Only let each of you press forward with effort, holding fast to the precepts in earnest. Forget the precepts within the precepts, add discipline beyond discipline. When the work is deep and the firing time is ripe, you will naturally receive the ancestral masters’ uplifting and guidance to true communion. Never be without resolve, leaning on the master or relying on fellow cultivators, clinging to names and forms, blindly following others’ footsteps day and night.

You must also steady your mind, free from doubt, wholeheartedly and unwaveringly, even unto death without regret. When the firing time is complete, how can it be said that Heaven does not reward the earnest?

The great Dao is still and unmoving; when one is moved by it, penetration follows.

Disciples, if you can resolve with a fervent heart, advance without hesitation, and pursue without turning back, you may be called lofty in aspiration—truly seeds of the Dao-gate. Our Patriarch Qiu left behind a silent gatha, rarely shown to others. Today, for your sake, I recount it; listen closely.

Gatha says:
"Impermanence of life and death must be self-realized—
When you die, none will care for you but yourself.
Do not rely on others for your own salvation,
Even immortals must cross the bridge alone.

Not only the six dusts and six senses,
But not clinging to any dharma, the mind abides in constancy.
The constant abides in the inconstant, the inconstant in the constant—
Know the causes without delusion, for causes are innumerable.

At the causal ground, investigate and realize the emptiness of self-nature;
At the fruition stage, who perceives emptiness to abide in?
From this moment, resolve the mechanism of life and death,
And henceforth strike your name from the ledger of rebirth.

If one follows the precepts and seeks practice,
Heavenly spirits will silently take note.
The Longmen heart-teachings are originally without form,
Yet I speak plainly, expounding this scroll in earnest.

Do not cling to dharmas but sweep them all away,
Only then will the truth of these gatha-words be seen.
Ponder my words deeply to discourse on the Dharma-body—
The empty sky itself is a treasury of many jewels.

When moved, thoughts arise endlessly,
Yet the Dao conceals itself within the body, prolonging blessings.
The heart-teaching merges with the Dao, the Dao is the heart;
The Dao-heart, unending, stretches across the long bridge."

Twenty-Second: Penetrating the Primal Mechanism

Disciples, this single spark of luminous clarity—this is your original true self, the primal life-spirit. Is it so easily seen? From ancient times to the present, sages, immortals, buddhas, patriarchs, and hosts of perfected beings have faced walls in nine-year retreats, sat in meditation for six-year cycles, endured the trials of three threes and seven sevens, and toiled in earnest inquiry. They traversed sacred mountains, wandered blessed lands, sought masters, visited friends, questioned the Dao, listened to sutras, practiced asceticism, and accumulated virtue through almsgiving. All their cultivation was but for this one great matter of life and death—the root cause of their existence. Unaware of whence they came, ignorant of whither they go, they drift and drown, unable to escape the wheel of rebirth. Thus, they vowed oaths and established merit through practice.

Some, seeking liberation, took the path of extinguishing thoughts and forgetting emotions, sitting in meditation for three or five years, wearing through countless meditation cushions. Yet when had a single thought truly ceased, or a moment’s emotion truly vanished? This was but the return of duality to unity.

Others pursued the refinement of lead and mercury as their path to liberation, practicing the firing process from *zhun* to *meng*, retreating and advancing the fire, adding and withdrawing the符. Yet when had they ever witnessed the sevenfold return of jade liquid or the ninefold restoration of golden elixir? They grasped at the thief only to let him slip away.

Some engaged in visualization and contemplation, silently paying homage to the Celestial Emperor in the Three Heavens. Others refined and delivered souls, liberating the departed from the Nine Hells. Some summoned spirits and generals, wearing talismans to command the title of "Perfected One." Others directed qi to open the gates, circulating essence and qi to claim mastery of the wondrous Dao. Some chanted scriptures and performed devout prostrations. Others prepared elixirs to heal sickness and cure ailments. Some refined and consumed alchemical substances in hopes of ascending to immortality. Others emulated yin and yang, engaging in the arts of absorption. Some practiced breath control in crucibles, using spirit to guide true lead and prolong life. Others adjusted the fire and added cinnabar in furnaces, refining *maogen* to accumulate merit through almsgiving. Some, their bodies withered and broken, clung to the Way of the Golden Elixir, awaiting transmission to the fortunate. Others, their karmic conditions shallow, performed deeds most arduous, only to let go at the precipice.

All these deluded practices, straying from true nature, are but side doors.

Disciples, to extinguish thoughts and forget emotions, you must first penetrate where thoughts arise and whence emotions come. Only when you firmly grasp, securely seize, truly recognize, and clearly point to them can you then proceed to extinguish and forget. Yet I ask you: what is it that grasps, seizes, recognizes, points, acts, extinguishes thoughts, and forgets emotions? No matter how you extinguish thoughts and forget emotions, no matter how many cushions you wear through, thoughts remain thoughts, and emotions remain emotions.

Assembly, to extinguish thoughts with thoughts is like placing a head upon a head. To forget emotions with emotions is to grasp the thief only to release him. Far better to forget even the method of forgetting, to extinguish even the method of extinguishing, to forget both mechanisms and enter the gate of manifold wonders. Only then is it the supreme principle.

Disciples, when I use a method to extinguish thoughts, I do not realize that the method itself is but another thought. When I use a method to forget emotions, I do not realize that the method itself is but another seed of emotion. Assembly, extinguishing thoughts is not as good as thoughts extinguished; forgetting emotions is not as good as emotions forgotten. This is what is meant by "seeking others is not as good as seeking oneself."

Disciples, those who refine lead and mercury, adjust the fire, or emulate the hexagrams and lines have pierced and shattered the Supreme Ultimate Chaos. They mistake false names for true application, take metaphors for actual practice, and recklessly discuss the Three Fields, blindly guessing at essence and qi. They turn the mechanisms of the seven emotions and the nine orifices into the pivotal workings of seven and nine, interpreting "return" and "restoration" as seven or nine times, seven or nine cycles, seven or nine segments, seven or nine years, or seven or nine transformations. This diagram, that illustration—upright spine, Mud Pill Palace, Tailbone Gate, Cinnabar Field, Crimson Chamber, Yellow Court, Flowery Pond—water ascending, fire descending, warming and bathing, sealing and securing. Today it is the union of *kan* and *li*, tomorrow the hexagram *Earth over Heaven*, the next day the merging of hun and po. This year, the same infant; next year, the same infant. After nine years, still an old sinner unaware of death.

Unaware of their own errors, they shake their heads, count on their fingers, and prattle to outsiders: "On such-and-such a day, I formed the sacred embryo. My warming and firing were flawless, my bathing timing precise. Why, after ten months, has the infant still not been born? Is it that my blessings are meager and my sins profound, that the gods and spirits refuse to bring it to fruition?" They clutch their bellies, their faces aged, their eyes searching, tears falling in vain.

You know these foolish, benighted souls, ignorant of their own minds, unclear about their own nature, lost in the darkness of karmic obstructions. What principle do they understand? You know these people—though they aspire upward, they are deluded, unaware of the mechanism of ascent.

The essence and qi within your bodies are the original, primordial qi and essence, an unchanging treasure that neither increases nor decreases. If you manipulate it, you will not see it grow; if you leave it be, you will not see it diminish. This luminous, unobscured true origin is the primordial spirit. Since it is called the primordial spirit, why speak of it as an infant? Your sins from countless kalpas past remain unexpiated, your obstructions undispelled, your mind’s source uncleansed, your nature’s root dull. Instead of early repenting your transgressions, transforming your temperament, seeking a master, and awakening to the Dao, you turn this useful true heart to useless false endeavors, squandering this limited time in pursuit of a shadowy infant—what for?

Disciples, that within yourselves which knows good and knows evil, knows right and knows wrong, knows deviance and knows uprightness, knows arising and knows ceasing, knows self and knows other, knows true and knows false—this is the infant. Yet this infant originally knows neither good nor evil, neither right nor wrong, neither deviance nor uprightness, neither arising nor ceasing, neither self nor other, neither true nor false. This infant does not cling to appearances; it is through encountering circumstances that the mind arises, through the mind that wisdom arises, through wisdom that knowledge arises. Through good it knows evil, through right it knows wrong, through uprightness it knows deviance, through arising it knows ceasing, through self it knows other, through the true it knows the false. Originally without the mark of self, yet not the mark of emptiness, it is merely this point of awareness moving in the world to respond to all things. If we speak of the Supreme Ultimate and Primordial Chaos, then even this knowing can be called non-knowing. Yet this knowing is *liangzhi* (innate knowledge); in the Buddhist tradition it is called *kalyāṇa-mitra* (good spiritual friend), while in the Daoist tradition it is named the infant primordial spirit. In sum, disciples, it is this single point of luminous, unobscured nature-essence.

You have only seen Daoists enter the chamber to sit in meditation, speaking of "conceiving the embryo," and after ten months in seclusion, have you ever seen any Daoist manifest the infant in radiant form? Such people, before entering the chamber, know nothing of the conditions of heaven and earth, ghosts and spirits, yin and yang, nor of human fortune and misfortune, future auspices and inauspices, the day of their birth or the hour of their death. After emerging from the chamber, they remain as ignorant as before. Unclear about their own life and death, unable to liberate themselves, how can they liberate others? With their own life and death unresolved, fortunes and misfortunes unprognosticated, gains and losses undiscerned, they remain subject to ghosts and spirits, bound by heaven and earth, living like ordinary people in toil and suffering, dying like common folk in burial and decay. Is this not a futile endeavor?

Disciples, first die to the mind before entering the chamber; first sever the bonds of attachment before sitting in meditation. When lustful thoughts have long ceased, the kidneys are full and true lead ascends. When anger has long subsided, the heart is empty and true mercury descends. When diet is regulated and timely, the spleen is strong and mercury and lead are sealed and stabilized. When emotions are stilled, the lungs are moistened; when the nature is settled, the liver flourishes; when kidney water is abundant, the eyes shine and the pupils are dark as lacquer. When the fire of the heart is extinguished, the mouth is filled with sweet saliva; when the *hun* is clear, the liver qi flows smoothly and the sinews and bones are light; when the *po* is at peace, the lung fluids flow and the hair and beard turn black. When the spleen is robust and the stomach harmonized, the tongue and throat are refreshed and the voice resonant. When the orifices are open and the blood flourishes, the ears are keen; when qi is abundant and spirit complete, the eyes are bright. When the five viscera are balanced, all illnesses retreat; when the five flavors are bland, the upright qi arises. By practicing *daoyin* in accordance with the four seasons and eight solar terms, wind, cold, summerheat, and dampness cannot invade. By restraining the six desires and seven emotions, taming the nature and subduing the mind, demons and evil spirits cannot encroach. By seeking the great Dao, the good heart appears and the true nature is illuminated; by awakening to *tathātā* (suchness), the physical body is emptied and the Dharma-body is revealed. Only after liberating oneself can one liberate others—yet this is still the liberation of oneself.

Disciples, only at this stage have you truly taken the first step through the great gate. Then, entering the chamber to sit in stillness, above you may communicate with heaven, below you may penetrate the earth; the conditions of ghosts and spirits, the pivot of heaven and earth—opening and closing occur within a single breath, creation and transformation lie beyond the palm of your hand. All this comes from discipline and concentration. Thus, when entering the chamber, you are of the ordinary womb-born body; when emerging, you are of the sacred Dharma-body. Having realized the great Dao, your vision is elevated, and you see through all conditions as illusory and false. With the staff of wisdom, your mind is vast, encompassing heaven and earth within the void.

Before the human mind stirs, I already know; before events arise, I foresee. Only then does one attain the six penetrations, with boundless wisdom, all heavenly demons prostrating in submission and secretly protecting you. Heretics from the ten directions submit in reverence and fear. Within a mustard seed, Mount Sumeru is contained unawares; within a grain of millet, the ten-directional worlds are hidden unknowingly. When expanded, the great earth and mountains and rivers are at my leisure; when concealed, a mote of dust or a grain of rice is at my disposal.

Disciples, this supreme, non-doing, perfectly real and wondrous Dao depends first on investigating subtle principles and awakening to the celestial mechanism. Therefore, you must set aside all those unprofitable pursuits—blind cultivation and aimless sitting, refining lead and mercury, contemplative visualization, salvific rituals for the deceased, assuming ranks and receiving registers, circulating qi and waving fans, chanting scriptures and reciting invocations, compounding elixirs and burning talismans, ingesting medicines and gathering herbs, yin-yang furnaces and crucibles—and cast them all aside. Instead, with utmost sincerity, face heaven and vow with resolute heart: from this day forward and into the future, may I swiftly comprehend the mechanism of life and death, past and future, escape the suffering of cyclic rebirth, depart from all extremes, and hear the wondrous Dao.

Ah! This phrase "depart from all extremes" is spoken directly to you—it is the great expedient gate to investigating subtle principles and awakening to the celestial mechanism.

Disciples! What are these "various extremes"? They are blind cultivation and aimless sitting, refining lead and mercury—all those side doors. What is an "extreme"? These side doors are neither central nor upright. Consider a table: all these side doors lie at its edges, unable to enter the center. Even if they reach the center, they do not leave the table. Only by departing from the table does one enter the vast emptiness of the Dao. Failing to leave the table, one remains with things, not the Dao—is this not an extreme? "Extreme" means periphery, deviance, boundary, shore. Peripheral is not central; deviant is not upright.

Where there is an earthly realm, there can be no vastness; where there are banks and shores, there can be no boundless expanse. Clinging stubbornly to this sack of flesh, mistaking it for a thousand-year-old cypress or an everlasting pine—such fixation strangles the true master within. Abandoning the lamp to seek fire, clinging to the false and discarding the real—is this not toppling to one side? Even if one succeeds, one remains but a self-liberated being, having never seen one’s true nature. Though one may attain a fruition, when the retribution is exhausted, one re-enters the cycle of rebirth, unable to transcend the Three Realms. What benefit does this bring to sentient beings?

Disciples, to become immortals, buddhas, sages, or worthies lies entirely in forsaking the self to follow others, in vowing to deliver all beings. Yet these meditators cannot even liberate themselves—how can they liberate others? They are but self-liberated beings. When have they ever awakened to the great Dao or delivered countless beings? Falling into peripheral cultivation is truly pitiable!

The True Lord spoke in verse, revealing the true mechanism, teaching the multitude to relinquish the mind of self-benefit and to depart from one-sided methods. Thus, side doors return to the central path, and heterodox teachings revert to the true Dharma. The limited earthly realm is opened to become unobstructed and unhindered. The vast world is unfolded to span heaven and earth. The bounded channels are widened to become boundless and shore-less. The unfathomable Dharma-body is extended to become without self or other.

As the sutra says, “Seen yet not perceived as ‘I,’ heard yet not perceived as ‘I,’ departing from all extremes—this is called the wondrous Dao.”

Disciples, the gateway to investigation and awakening begins with opening the ground of the mind. From whence does life arise? To where does death return? Draw near to enlightened and accomplished teachers, to wise and sincere companions. Cultivate a heart of goodness and inquire meticulously.

In life, one is like a cup of tea, confined by form, its water already flavored. Poured into the vast Eastern Ocean, it disperses into towering waves. If one seeks one’s original source, the tea’s flavor remains. If one claims it is water, there is still form and appearance. Yet within this ocean, one’s original source abides—what, then, is one’s original source? Inquire carefully, investigate thoroughly, until seeing yields no sight, hearing yields no sound. With accumulated merit over time, the breast naturally becomes vast and open, the eye’s light instantly clear. One sees one’s original face, the luminous celestial mechanism, and this single speck of true nature appears. Only then does one realize the great Dao has never failed anyone!

Disciples, sages, worthies, immortals, and buddhas attained the Dao and ascended to heaven long ago. To perceive the hearts of sages, worthies, immortals, and buddhas, first comprehend their principles. By comprehending their principles, one awakens to their methods. By practicing their methods, one performs their deeds. By performing their deeds, one embodies their form.

Disciples, where do the hearts of sages, worthies, immortals, and buddhas reside? They reside within each person’s square-inch terrace of the mind. Where do their principles reside? They reside before each person’s eyes. Where do their methods reside? They reside within the classics and histories. The deeds of sages, worthies, immortals, and buddhas do not lie beyond worldly Dharma—they lie within it. The bodies of sages, worthies, immortals, and buddhas reside within their own hearts.

If one knows the hearts of sages, worthies, immortals, and buddhas within the square inch of the mind, one can comprehend their principles. By comprehending their principles, one can awaken to their methods. By awakening to their methods, one can perform their deeds. By comprehending their principles, the true Dao abides. By awakening to their methods, all conditions are realized. By performing their deeds, merit is established, the celestial mechanism ceaseless, enduring through ten thousand kalpas.

Know that such a person, possessing the spiritual penetrations and wisdom of sages, worthies, immortals, and buddhas, has already attained their essence—this is the body of sages, worthies, immortals, and buddhas.

Disciples, where does investigation begin? First, receive the Initial Real Precepts to subdue body and mind, so that the square inch of the mind remains unconfused—then one can perceive the hearts of sages, worthies, immortals, and buddhas. Next, receive the Middle Ultimate Precepts to open the numinous pass, so that the mysterious barrier becomes thoroughly clear—then one can comprehend the principles of sages, worthies, immortals, and buddhas. Then, receive the Heavenly Immortal Precepts to delve into wondrous meanings, so that wisdom becomes all-pervading—then one can penetrate the Dao of sages, worthies, immortals, and buddhas.

Thereafter, one becomes unobstructed and liberated—able to be round or square, large or small, to move or stop, to advance or retreat, to live or die, to bend or stretch, to exit or enter, to be a sage or worthy, an immortal or buddha; to traverse the four births, the six paths, the heavenly palaces, or the hells. Adapting teachings to circumstances, delivering beings across kalpas, transformations unfathomable, manifesting bodies to expound the Dharma. Like an infinite bright mirror reflecting all forms and shadows, mutually containing one another—then one can perform the deeds of sages, worthies, immortals, and buddhas, embody their forms, and realize their fruition.

Disciples, at this stage, one has investigated subtle principles and awakened to the celestial mechanism.

Of old, the Yellow Emperor lost his dark pearl in the Red Waters and sent Li Zhu to seek it. Li Zhu could not find it. He then sent Qi Gou to seek it. Qi Gou could not find it. Finally, he sent Wang Xiang, and Wang Xiang found it.

That Li Zhu, adorned in vermilion splendor, represents the postnatal fleshly heart of man—thus he could not find it, likening those who today rely on peripheral views. That Qi Gou, who cherishes purity, cleanses mouth and body, and depends on fasting—his mind, though purified, also could not find it. As for Wang Xiang—how was he able to find it?

Disciples! "Wang" means "none," and "xiang" means "form and appearance." "Wangxiang" thus signifies "formless and imageless." Hence it is not called a luminous pearl, but a dark pearl. Even the most sagely former master Confucius said: "That which is above form is called the Dao; that which is below form is called the vessel." The Most High Ancestor Laozi spoke of "inwardly observing the heart—when the heart is without its heart; outwardly observing form—when form is without its form." Disciples, the supreme principle is the true suchness. Sages and worthies, immortals and buddhas—all abide in non-attachment to forms in their cultivation. If one cultivates by clinging to forms, even the Yellow Emperor, employing wisdom and maintaining purity, would be seeking the dark pearl through effort and abstinence.

Disciples! The Yellow Emperor lost the dark pearl and found it through Wangxiang; ordinary people investigate wondrous principles and find them through non-mind. Assembly, I have revealed the celestial mechanism in full and illuminated the mind-seal. You must examine yourselves carefully, guard closely, and take heed—for once the dark pearl in the Red Waters is lost, who knows where it may be recovered!

Thereupon, he admonished his disciples, who bowed in reverence and listened to the gatha:

Ten thousand scrolls of immortal scriptures cannot exhaust it,
One direct pointing reveals all without remainder.
I urge you: do not pursue manifold methods—
The Dao resides in the heart, not in books.

Clinging to forms in inquiry breeds scattered thoughts,
Intentional sitting in meditation breeds demons.
Many stray paths men insist on treading,
Yet none heed the true Way—what can be done?

The true person is without form, without shape,
A single celestial mechanism laid bare everywhere.
Do not grope blindly before your eyes—
Abandon not the true path for side doors.

At that time, Master Kunkun Yangzi, together with the entire assembly, having completed the dedication, charged disciple Shi Shouping to compile the text into a volume and present it to the precept-master for instruction to later learners. The precept-master said: "There is no need. You need only transmit it from person to person. After one hundred seventy years have passed, it shall be established as *The Platform Sutra of the Azure Garden*."

Recorded by Master Xiyun of Mount Qiyun, *Inquiry and Verification on Cultivating the True*.

**Preface**

The Way of the Fuxi sovereign is distant, its meaning profound. The six hundred scrolls of the *Fire Records* were composed to guide men in avoiding worldly entanglements. In the Eastern Han, the Perfected Wei Boyang emerged, distilling the essence of the *Book of Changes* and composing the *Triplex Unity*. Xu and others later annotated it, and thus the alchemical teachings of the Yellow and Laozi were made manifest. Since the Han and Jin dynasties, men have grasped its coarse aspects while neglecting its subtleties, branching into peripheral arts—calamities that persist to this day.

On Mount Qiyun dwells Master Wuyuan, surnamed Liu, named Yiming. Entering the Dao through Confucianism, he has perused countless texts for decades, exhausting principle and fulfilling nature. Through profound realization, he penetrated the Three *Changes*, composing thirteen volumes of works, four of which concern the *Changes*. These include *The Essential Compendium of the Dao and Its Virtue*, *Direct Pointers to Realization*, *The Original Meaning of the Journey to the West* in four volumes, *The Compass*, *The Collected Understandings*, and *The Three Guiding Books* in one volume. Though their names are known, their contents remain unseen.

This spring, in the first month, a scholar from Xin’an named Bao Lanpu, styled Ganting, with the Daoist name Yangyong, long devoted to the study of the mysterious, received books from Kong Zhaopu. Having grasped the principles of gathering, refining, and perfecting the Elixir, his practice has borne fruit for some time. As I once encountered a perfected one, he humbled himself to serve me for nearly six years. On this day, he presented me with Master Wuyuan’s complete *Inquiry and Verification on Cultivating the True* for my examination. Only then did I engage in repeated study and reflection.

The book was printed by Precept-Master Cui Jiaojiao Chun of the Changchun Abbey in Hubei, who funded the carving of one part of Master Wuyuan’s complete works—two volumes in total. The upper volume contains Precept-Master Cui’s preface, which states that the earlier sections of the work are concise in language yet comprehensive in meaning, aiming to guide learners first to recognize the true path, lest they be misled by heretical doctrines and stray into heterodox byways, thereby endangering the great matter of life and destiny. Thus, the plainer the words, the more manifest the Dao. Even those with but a rudimentary education may follow its traces to enter, progressing from shallow to deep—making it an essential text for beginners.

Precept-Master Cui, recognizing this, vowed to first carve this book and later the rest of the master’s works, thereby fulfilling his aspiration. In safeguarding the Dao and transmitting the lineage, his merit and virtue surpass even those of Master Wuyuan. Without Cui’s carving, how could this work be widely disseminated? In days to come, those who obtain this book and thereby enter the orthodox tradition will owe their deliverance to their teacher, while Cui shall be their guide. Whoever fails to reverently study this text is surely a deluded person.

It must be understood that this book’s completion stems from having read ten thousand volumes. Without decades of arduous study, the works such as the *Three Changes* could never have been composed. Yet even in this book, the functional secrets of the Mysterious Pass remain inadequately revealed. Without these, how can one enter the great union and great harmony of emptiness? How can one encounter the undying person of the Kun direction? Without this, the entire work is rendered useless!

Moved by the compassionate hearts of both author and carver—a rare encounter across the ages—and as I have gained some insight, while Bao Ganting’s inquiries were earnest, I dared not keep this knowledge to myself. Thus, I have selected teachings from my masters and appended them to the dialogues where the meaning was incomplete. Neither commentary nor critique, these additions seek the master’s approval above and the verification of future readers below.

As the book neared completion, I was suddenly visited in a vision by the venerable Master Wuyuan, who altered one of my responses. Though not the original text, the revision came from the hand of one of his disciples. All that I have written has received his confirmation. Thus, the book may be retitled *Inquiry and Verification on Cultivating the True by a Certain Disciple*. With these words, he vanished. The lamplight dimmed, and I awoke—it had been but a dream. Yet the fragrance lingered, neither orchid nor musk. I recorded this beneath the original response, neither affirming it as real nor dismissing it as illusion. The Three Powers are of a single qi; through the ages, all hearts are one. I am Master Wuyuan, and Master Wuyuan is I—what difference is there?

Upon completion, I append these notes to the preface to inform Scholar Bao. Let him read this book with care, lest he repeat past errors. This text is the supreme treasure of our lineage—let it be studied as the works of Wei of the Eastern Han were. Should he obtain any of the commentaries on the *Three Changes*, I would be most grateful to see them.

Respectfully inscribed in the second month of spring, the ninth year of the Daoguang reign, by Min Yide of Mount Jingai, disciple of Wuxing.

---

**Original Preface**

When Master Tang Jieting of Jincheng came to Wuchang, he presented me with the works of Elder Pusuxuan, including *The Essential Compendium of the Dao and Its Virtue*, which he left at the abbey as a guide for those devoted to cultivating the true. Among them was a book titled *Inquiry and Verification*, which I read repeatedly, delighting in its earlier sections. Concise in language yet comprehensive in meaning, it aims to guide learners first to recognize the true path, lest they be misled by heretical doctrines and stray into heterodox byways, thereby endangering the great matter of life and destiny. Thus, the plainer the words, the more manifest the Dao. Even those with but a rudimentary education may follow its traces to enter, progressing from shallow to deep—making it an essential text for beginners. Is not this a great act of compassion?

Yet the master’s collected works are vast, and reprinting them is no easy task. Scholar Qin Yaopu, moved by noble intent, donated funds to ensure their wide circulation.

Thus, to cap the pagoda and widely sow the fruits of merit is truly this humble monk’s private aspiration and devout prayer. The catalogue of works is appended below, with their outlines meticulously arranged and prefaced to the volumes.

*Preface by Daoist Monk Cui Jiaochun Puranzi of Changchun Abbey, Third Month of the Sixteenth Year of Jiaqing.*

*Preface by Wuyuanzi*

The *Book of Changes* states: "The interplay of yin and yang is called the Dao." It also says: "Exhausting principle and fulfilling one’s nature to reach destiny." Principle is the Dao, and the Dao is principle. The Dao of yin and yang is the Dao of nature and destiny. This principle, this Dao, positions heaven and earth and nurtures the myriad things—so vast it has no exterior, so minute it has no interior. It precedes heaven yet heaven does not contravene it; it follows heaven yet accords with heaven’s timing. Most subtle and profound, most refined and fine. Those who comprehend it become sages, immortals, or buddhas; those who stray from it become humans, creatures, or ghosts.

Yet without the oral instructions of a master, a thousand analogies and a hundred metaphors—rendering the formless from the formed, the insubstantial from the concrete—may reveal branches or expose roots, making thorough inquiry exceedingly difficult.
