Moreover, later generations’ heterodox byways and crooked paths have distorted the sagely Dao, disordered the immortal scriptures, each propounding their own doctrines, each asserting their own truths. They take the metaphorical language of the true classics literally, burying the ancients’ original intent. Some drift into inner alchemy for women, others err into furnace fires; some cling to the physical body, others fixate on emptiness. Heretical sayings and deceptive words circulate throughout the world. Even if one or two aspirants exist, their eyes bristle with thorns, their ears ring with clamor—brilliance rendered useless, resolve left wavering. Once ensnared in the net, they struggle to escape for a lifetime. This is the origin of my *Inquiry and Verification*.

What is difficult to discern? The difficulty lies in distinguishing the seemingly true from the false, the apparently real from the counterfeit. The difficulty lies in deciphering the ancients’ veiled words and symbolic forms. Within it, the celestial Dao, sagely practices, the sources of nature and destiny, the right and wrong of medicinal herbs and fire—all are meticulously clarified. After completing the work, I feared its threads might scatter and its phrases grow verbose, leaving readers unable to grasp its coherence. Thus, I appended twenty-six entries titled *Later Verifications on Cultivating the True*, distilling its essence and dividing it into topics. The language is plain, the meaning evident; the text concise, the principle clear. Metaphors are set aside for substance, branches pruned to expose the root—so that fellow cultivators may see and instantly comprehend. As for the principles of yin and yang, nature and destiny, one may plumb their depths and investigate their subtleties, attaining profound mastery without difficulty.

Alas! Did I delight in disputation?

I acted out of necessity.

On the third day of the third lunar month in the third year of the Jiaqing reign (wuyin), Liu Yiming, the Plain Man of Dwelling Cloud Mountain and Awakened Primordial Master, wrote this preface in the Chamber of Ease.

**Postscript by Awakened Primordial Master**

Zhuangzi said: *"The great Dao is beyond naming; great disputation speaks not."* For the Dao is originally nameless—what is there to name? The Dao is originally formless—what is there to say? If naming is impossible, and speaking is impossible, how much less possible is disputation?

Yet in the world, there are those who name the Dao, and those who speak of it. Once naming begins, right and wrong intermingle, and the Dao is no longer true. Once speaking begins, orthodoxy and heterodoxy contend, and the Dao becomes false. Naming the Dao falsely is not naming the Dao but slandering it; speaking of the Dao falsely is not speaking of the Dao but burying it. To slander or bury the Dao blocks the gate of true cultivation and obstructs the path of practice—this is the greatest harm. Thus, I could not but argue forcefully to expose the falsity of such naming, nor could I but argue meticulously to refute the deception of such speech. By refuting false names, the Dao that cannot be named becomes gradually clear to the seeker. By refuting deceptive words, the Dao that cannot be spoken becomes effortlessly grasped in silent understanding. What is difficult to awaken to, I make self-evident; what is difficult to comprehend, I make self-apparent—this is the intent behind my persistent disputation.

Yet if I have already argued, can it be said there are no words? If words exist, can it be said there are no names? If names and words exist, yet I still dispute false names and deceptive speech—is this not contradictory?

Others name, and I name; others speak, and I speak. How can one know whether their naming is true or mine is false? How can one know whether my naming is true or theirs is false? How can one know whether their words are deceptive or mine are genuine? How can one know whether my words are deceptive or theirs are genuine? Who is true and who is false, who is genuine and who is not—this is for those who neither name nor speak of the Dao to see and know for themselves. Why should I dispute further?

**Second Postscript by Awakened Primordial Master**

*Collated Evidence for the First Compilation of Disputations on Cultivating the True*
By Master Liu Yiming of Tongcheng
Collated by Min Yide, later disciple of the Golden Canopy

On the mid-autumn night of the renyin year of the Qianlong reign, the moon bright and stars sparse, Awakened Primordial Master sat in silence atop Dwelling Cloud Peak. His spirit entered the dim and boundless realm; his form returned to the void and stillness.

*In this state, the mystery is penetrated, the gate opens to reveal the mountain—how vivid and free! Here, the True Child and the Living Child leap forth in radiant clarity. Let the seeker not dismiss this as mere preface.*

His disciples gathered around. As midnight approached, one disciple ventured to ask: *"Master, unmoving and soundless, without scent or trace—have you attained the Dao? Have you forgotten the self?"* Three times he asked, and three times received no answer.

Here the text does not recount mere preface—it merely borrows this moment to illustrate the subtle function of the Dao! The "Master" here is not to be taken as the Awakened Primordial Master himself; rather, consider it from the perspective of the disciples gathered around, and the meaning of this "Master" becomes clear. The essence lies in "unmoving and soundless, without scent or trace," for only thus can one progress from awakening to forgetting. As for the disciple who spoke at midnight, his question had substance. The "disciple" is no empty title—his movement brought forth speech at the gate! Thus, three questions met with three silences, for the answer lay within. This is a vivid depiction of yang stirring within stillness, an image of the supreme mystery. Two thousand five hundred call him "Master." The Master remains unmoving, without sound or scent—yet one beholds him. Who is this "one"? The Awakened Primordial Master within the disciple. Know this: the disciple’s inquiry arises from within the gate. His mouth bears three aspects: heaven, earth, and humanity. Three in one is attainment; one in three is loss. Hence, three questions and three silences. The word "answer" holds profound mystery. If it does not return to the One, the answer loses its foundation—how could it suffice? Thus I say: three questions and three silences, for the answer lies within. Let the seeker reflect deeply upon this.

Another disciple then asked: *"Master, you utter not a word—does this mean you are like rotten wood, uncarvable, or a wall of dung, unadornable? Are we unworthy of your teaching?"* The Awakened Primordial Master gazed intently for a long while before replying calmly: *"This is not for you to comprehend."* (Here, the question and answer serve to illuminate profound meaning; henceforth, the same principle applies—no need for external inquiry. This subtle intent urges disciples to reflect inwardly in stillness. Thus, after a long gaze, he still declares, *"This is not for you to know."*)

The disciple pressed further: *"May I ask why?"*
The Awakened Primordial Master replied: *"I take heaven and earth as a travelers’ inn, the sun and moon as passing guests, the ten thousand things as drifting threads, worldly affairs as dreams and illusions, human sentiments as bandits and foes, wealth and honor as floating clouds, the physical form as shackles, the four elements as withered wood, the six senses as hollow openings, body and mind as ashes and dust—what is there to move? What sound or scent could there be?"*

Here the Master reveals only why one may remain unshaken and how one attains the absence of sound or scent—yet this itself marks the first step in unlocking the Mysterious Pass. Though Wuyuan longed to make it plain, the world remained sunk in delusion, and sharp blows would have found no purchase. Thus he began by urging the disciple to lay down body and mind, hinting at the wondrous use of refining the real through the false—this lies precisely in treating the six senses as hollow openings. For when all is seen through, the will becomes one-pointed. At that moment, I enter the numinous realm of the formless by passing through the apertures of the six thieves!

Alas, why do seekers fail to awaken? This is the universal malady; the method is but to guide them to proceed.

The disciple asked: *"By your words, is there then nothing at all?"*
Wuyuan replied: *"How could there be nothing?"*
The disciple asked: *"What, then, is there?"*
Wuyuan said: *"Only the knowledge that the Dao exists!"*
The disciple asked: *"Is the Dao, then, without action?"*
Wuyuan replied: *"How could it be without action? The Dao has substance and function, advance and retreat, reversal and compliance, urgency and slowness, cessation and fulfillment, beginning and end, priority and sequence, gradations and layers, transformations and variations—great works and great uses of every kind. How could it be without action?"*

The disciple said: *"I have entered the Dao for many years, studied countless alchemical classics, and sought guidance from many teachers, yet I know nothing. I beg you, Master, in your compassion, to open my ignorance even slightly."*
Wuyuan said: *"The Dao is what heaven and earth conceal, what spirits and gods envy—it cannot be discussed lightly. Without purification, one must not presume to listen."*

The disciple bowed and withdrew, performing the Six Purifications:
1. **Body Purification**: The four elements ungrasped.
2. **Mind Purification**: All thoughts stilled.
3. **Eye Purification**: Turning the light inward in reflection.
4. **Ear Purification**: No sounds entering.
5. **Nose Purification**: No scents reaching.
6. **Tongue Purification**: No judgments stirring.

When the Six Purifications were complete, he approached again and said: *"I have purified myself! May I now ask about the Dao?"*
Wuyuan said: *"Not yet. There remains one purification unfulfilled. How dare you ask?"*
The disciple said: *"Beyond the Six Purifications, what other purification is there? I beg you, Master, to clarify."*
Wuyuan said: *"There is still the purification of the heart’s realm. This realm is fouler than the six senses. The six senses are external thieves—they come and go. The heart’s realm is the internal thief, where the consciousness of the discriminating mind resides, the seed of endless rebirth. If this realm is not purified, the Six Purifications are of no benefit."*

The disciple withdrew in great alarm.

*(Do not say the Six Purifications are of no benefit—they are merely acts of deliberate effort. When purification reaches the heart, arising naturally, it may be called true purification. If each of the Six Purifications arises naturally, it may be named Heart Purification.)*

Thereupon, he swept away all entanglements, detached from all extremes, and responded without abiding while giving rise to the mind. In an instant, it was as if frozen ice dissolved, leaving no residue. Again, he knelt in reverence and asked:

*"By your compassion, Master, I have purified without purification, no purification to purify;
Purifying without purifying, not purifying yet purifying;
Not purifying—who purifies? Who purifies the purification?
The purifier does not purify, not purifying is purification;
Knowing purification is not purification, purification has nothing to purify;
If one seeks true purification, purification does not see purification;
Since purification is no purification, why force purification?"*

Wuyuan said: *"You know purification! You have purified! You may now inquire about the Dao, you may now hear the Dao."*

*(At this stage of practice, the essence of the Dao is fully manifest—one touch and enlightenment dawns. If one were to recognize this state and proceed, all dualities would dissolve, both self and dharma forgotten, entering the boundless realm of nothingness. Body and mind would merge with the transformations of creation. If one were to maintain this state for forty-nine days without losing it, when the time arrives, responding to the moment with a single touch, one would naturally realize it in the body, and the six supernatural powers would be complete. How could the primordial be obscured, or the immortal embryo fail to form and perfect? Such guidance could swiftly elevate one to the highest wisdom and virtue. Yet he merely acknowledged knowing and having purified, allowing inquiry and hearing of the Dao—without directly pointing it out, without urging progress, or testing before the seat with timely blows. Thus the opportunity was lost—how lamentable! This was a disciple of the highest caliber, capable of self-motivation and diligent progress, separated from innate knowledge by but a thread. Had I encountered such a one, I would have seized the moment, riding their momentum with skillful guidance, surely achieving extraordinary results. Even if obstacles arose, the Mysterious Pass would naturally and permanently open. Gathering, nurturing, liberation, and all such practices could then be taught in response to questions. The essential method is to remain unattached, aware yet without clinging. Did Master Wuyuan not understand this? Perhaps this dialogue was merely to illustrate the supreme Dao—it is unlikely such a high disciple ever appeared, or if they did, they would not have missed the opportunity thus.)*

The disciple asked: *"What is the Dao?"*
The Master replied: *"The Dao is the primordial ancestral qi that gives birth to all things. Invisible, inaudible, intangible, it encompasses heaven and earth, nurtures the ten thousand things, vast beyond all bounds, minute beyond all measure. In Confucianism, it is called the Supreme Ultimate; in Daoism, the Golden Elixir; in Buddhism, Perfect Awakening. It has no name—we merely call it the Dao."*

To conceive of it is to miss it; to discuss it is to lose it. Without form or image, neither form nor emptiness, neither being nor non-being—if one clings to the appearances of form, emptiness, being, or non-being, one has already strayed from the Dao.”

*(This answer fully reveals the fundamental nature of the Dao, making clear the great path of the Golden Elixir, so that scholars may know what to pursue. Its essential teaching lies in non-attachment: to be aware yet without clinging—this is the key.)*

The disciple asked: “If the Dao is without form or image, merely a unified qi, why does the *Book of Changes* say, ‘The alternation of yin and yang is called the Dao’?”

The Master replied: “‘The alternation of yin and yang is called the Dao’ refers to the Dao in its function; ‘without form or image’ refers to the Dao in its essence. Before the Supreme Ultimate divides, the Dao encompasses yin and yang; after the Supreme Ultimate divides, yin and yang give rise to the Dao. Without yin and yang, the qi of the Dao would not manifest. Only through the ceaseless interplay of yin and yang does the qi of the Dao endure, remaining uncorrupted through ten thousand kalpas. In the primordial state, it is the Dao; in the postnatal state, it is yin and yang. The Dao is the root of yin and yang; yin and yang are the expression of the Dao. Thus, the Supreme Ultimate divides into yin and yang, and yin and yang unite to form the Supreme Ultimate—one becomes two, two returns to one.”

The disciple asked: “When the Supreme Ultimate divides into yin and yang, does this not create two yin-yang pairs? Why then do the ancients speak of two layers of heaven and earth, and four yin-yang configurations?”

The Master replied: “The two layers of heaven and earth refer to the primordial and the postnatal. The four yin-yang configurations refer to the primordial and postnatal yin and yang. Primordial yin and yang are spoken of in terms of qi; postnatal yin and yang are spoken of in terms of substance. Primordial yin and yang are the yin and yang inherent within the Supreme Ultimate; postnatal yin and yang are the yin and yang generated from the Supreme Ultimate. The great path of the Golden Elixir takes the qi, not the substance, returning from the postnatal to the primordial—hence it is called the primordial great Dao.”

The disciple asked: “If primordial and postnatal yin and yang each have their boundaries, how can one speak of returning from the postnatal to the primordial?”

The Master replied: “Once the primordial is broken, postnatal yin and yang arise; yet within the movement and stillness of postnatal yin and yang, the primordial is again generated. The perfected person, within the postnatal, gathers this newly generated primordial qi, reverses its flow, and returns to the origin, restoring the fullness of the Supreme Ultimate’s body—this is called the Returned Elixir.”

The disciple asked: “If yin and yang are already divided into primordial and postnatal, why is there also a distinction between inner and outer yin and yang?”

The Master replied: “Inner yin and yang are the postnatal yin and yang, born of the physical form. Outer yin and yang are the primordial yin and yang, emerging from the emptiness of space. The yin and yang of the physical form follow the natural course, generated by heaven and earth. The yin and yang of emptiness reverse their flow, generating heaven and earth. The terms ‘inner’ and ‘outer’ refer to their function.”

The disciple asked: “If yin and yang have inner and outer aspects, do the Five Phases also have inner and outer?”

The Master replied: “The Five Phases arise from yin and yang; if yin and yang have inner and outer, how could the Five Phases not? Consider the ten heavenly stems and twelve earthly branches—each of the Five Phases is divided in two. Taking the heavenly stems: *bing* is yang fire, *ding* is yin fire; *jia* is yang wood, *yi* is yin wood; *geng* is yang metal, *xin* is yin metal; *ren* is yang water, *gui* is yin water; *wu* is yang earth, *ji* is yin earth. Taking the earthly branches: *hai* water is yang, *zi* water is yin; *yin* wood is yang, *mao* wood is yin; *si* fire is yang, *wu* fire is yin; *shen* metal is yang, *you* metal is yin; *chen* and *xu* earth are yang, *chou* and *wei* earth are yin. Yang is outer, belonging to the primordial; yin is inner, belonging to the postnatal. This is how primordial and postnatal are distinguished, and how inner and outer medicines are differentiated.”

The disciple asked: “Inner medicine completes nature, outer medicine completes life—thus cultivating nature and life each has its proper timing. The *Book of Changes* says, ‘Before heaven, do not oppose it; after heaven, follow its timing.’ This suggests that reverse practice and natural flow are unrelated. Why then does the *Mirror of Entering the Medicine* say, ‘Primordial qi, postnatal qi—those who attain it are ever as if drunk’?”

The Master replied: “The patriarchs, in their compassion, have spoken plainly—you simply fail to awaken. Completing nature with inner medicine is ‘after heaven, follow its timing’; completing life with outer medicine is ‘before heaven, do not oppose it.’ Using the reverse path, one takes preemptive action to seize creation and form the elixir. Following timing means using the natural course, the celestial fire phase, to harmonize the Five Phases and release the elixir. These two stages of practice are what is meant by ‘dual cultivation of nature and life’; cultivating inner and outer together is ‘using both reverse and natural flow.’”

The disciple asked: “Nature belongs to yin, life to yang—are these the yin and yang divided from the Supreme Ultimate?”

The Master replied: “This requires distinction. Nature has both the nature of temperament and the nature of heaven’s endowment. Life has both the life of predetermined fate and the life of Dao-qi. The nature of temperament and the life of predetermined fate are the postnatal, embodied nature and life. The nature of heaven’s endowment and the life of Dao-qi are the primordial, formless nature and life. Cultivating postnatal nature and life follows creation; cultivating primordial nature and life reverses creation. The great practitioner borrows the postnatal to return to the primordial, cultivates the primordial to transform the postnatal, merging them into one—nature and life congeal, and this is called the elixir’s completion. Nature and life are the embodiment of yin and yang;”

Yin and yang are the function of nature and life. Yet they are distinguished by truth and falsity, by primacy and posteriority—only through precise discernment and clear recognition can this be understood!”

Someone asked: “If nature and life must rely on yin and yang to congeal, then where there is yin there cannot be absence of yang, and where there is yang there cannot be absence of yin. Why then is there the saying, ‘When the host of yin is wholly stripped away, the elixir ripens’? In the end, is yin used or not used?”

The Master replied: “What is used is true yin and true yang; what is not used is false yin and false yang. True yin and true yang belong to the primordial; false yin and false yang belong to the postnatal. The primordial fulfills the Dao; the postnatal corrupts the Dao.”

Someone asked: “What is true yin and true yang? What is false yin and false yang?”

The Master replied: “Yin within yang is true yin; yang within yin is true yang—these are the yin and yang that are used, what the ancient scriptures call ‘yin and yang attaining their kind.’ Hyperactive yang without yin is false yang; solitary yin without yang is false yin—these are the yin and yang that are not used, what the ancient scriptures call ‘solitary yin, widowed yang.’”

(Alas that this passage reveals the character *lei* “kind” without fully disclosing its depth! For this subtle meaning was guarded by the ancient sages, and thus only what the alchemical classics had already revealed is cited here. Yet since this meaning is not thoroughly exposed, later scholars remain entangled in thorns. Therefore, I have elucidated it in *The Orthodox Exegesis of the Classic of Yin Conformity*—but alas, there are few who respond in kind, few who understand. Sigh!)

The alchemical classics state, “With those of the same kind, effort is easily applied; without the proper seed, skill avails not”—these two lines contain the entire method! To savor this word *lei* “kind” is to seek the same kind within the primordial. Heaven and earth generate humanity, and among the boundless dragons and tigers, those that align with the stars and tides are likewise innumerable, ready to be met and gathered—yet all depends on whether one sees or does not see. This Dao is known only to our Northern School. As for the term *zhong* “seed,” its meaning is even more refined! Without fully grasping the seed’s function, one risks the mockery of “boiling water and fire in vain.” Let those who read this passage take care not to skim past it lightly. Yet this method of gathering is not merely a matter of loosening robes or untying sashes! Within the vast expanse of Yin and E, a hundred *li* away, without meeting or prior arrangement, they are drawn together as iron to a magnet, as if seated side by side. Only when the Mysterious Pass is opened does one’s practice remain free from delusion or illusion.

Someone asked, “The union of yin and yang is the natural Dao of heaven and earth—why then are there solitary and widowed states?”
I have already answered: “When yin and yang unite, they are true yin and yang; when they do not, they are false. The distinction between true and false lies solely in whether they unite or not.”

Someone asked, “If the union of yin and yang is the natural Dao, then it arises spontaneously—why is cultivation necessary?”
I answered: “In the postnatal realm, yin and yang sometimes unite and sometimes do not. The sage’s primordial learning reverses the flow within the natural order, ensuring perpetual union without dispersion. Thus, humans can overcome heaven and are no longer bound by yin and yang.”

[Note here: This answer should follow the secret method of Ma Danyang’s *Returning to the Origin*—avoiding deviation by deeply planting the seed and nurturing it without fail, awaiting the proper time. When human timing aligns with celestial timing, it is called “heaven and human acting in concert,” and one may then employ illusion to draw forth the mysterious. Within this process, reversals occur that even spirits cannot fathom. Without a moment of primordial chaos, attainment will not be complete; without placing body and mind beyond their limits, one risks dangers like “flying away” or “scattering.” Ancestor Zhong handled this with perfect equanimity, while Ancestor Lü gained it three times and lost it three times. The key lies in the two words *qing* “clarity” and *he* “harmony”—through their regulation and balance, one achieves an eternal spring, and human determination triumphs over heaven. Is this not the so-called primordial learning? For in every matter and at every step, one must precede heaven, ensuring that when the time arrives, one does not fall behind. Beware of wild speculation that leads astray. Though Wu Yuanzi has touched upon this, he has not laid it bare. Fearing that later scholars will still struggle amid thorns, I have therefore expounded and supplemented it here.]

Someone asked, “Does the union of yin and yang occur internally or externally?”
I answered: “Yes. Postnatal yin and yang are internal, while primordial yin and yang are external. The internal arises naturally; the external requires effort.”

[If we speak of postnatal union, it is entirely a matter of reversal, yet the answer calls it “natural”; primordial union is entirely effortless, yet the answer calls it “effort.” Is this merely distinguishing between the internal and external of the two colored bodies? Or does it refer to the internal and external of the two illusory Dharma-bodies in their qi-based resonance? From the perspective of the two illusions: the yang illusion contains primordial yin, and the yin illusion contains primordial yang. If one follows the primordial, reversal is required—hence “effort”; if one follows the postnatal, one enters the natural flow—hence “natural.” Such an answer is overly broad and does not reflect Wu Yuanzi’s original intent. It should be understood in terms of the qi-based resonance of the illusory Dharma-bodies, where true subtlety lies. According to alchemical methods: that which has form and image is called postnatal and internal; that which is without sound or scent is called primordial and external. When the two illusions meet, spirit congeals and qi coalesces—this arises naturally. When pent-up energy bursts outward, reaching the void’s edge—this too arises naturally. Then, as the Supreme Ultimate responds, the primordial surges forth, filling the two illusions. The wondrous state within is beyond description. Ancestor Lü’s three gains and three losses occurred precisely at this moment! One must proceed step by step in harmony to achieve perfect stability. This is the true meaning of Wu Yuanzi’s “effort”—scholars must not take it lightly.]

Someone asked, “If yin and yang are external, do they have no relation to my body? Are they in heaven and earth, or in another household?”
I answered: “Fools, not understanding the meaning of ‘external,’ either inhale the qi of clouds and mist or gather the impure blood of women’s red lead and plum blossoms, abandoning the correct path to commit countless transgressions. They do not realize that ‘external’ encompasses heaven and earth, meaning it does not belong to me. At the beginning of life, it was originally my own, but when the primordial unity was broken, the false took over, and the true retreated, growing ever more distant and estranged until it had no connection to me—thus it became external. This secret is difficult to recognize without a true teacher.”

[Note: This refutation is correct.]

Yet this secret matter must be sought from its own kind. Whether called "internal" or "external" is but a matter of present perspective—fundamentally, it is one and the same. Where, then, do yin and yang, internal and external, truly reside?

Proceeding from the foundation of the primordial, all things—heaven and earth, sun and moon, clouds and mist, red lead and plum blossoms—are but transient forms; their *qi* is still *qi*. How could this *qi* be of an "external" kind? The ancient sages offered subtle guidance, each with its marvelous application, yet these are not for beginners to grasp, nor for those bound by rigid attachment.

Only by never straying from the primordial, by tracing back to what precedes even the primordial, does the Mysterious Pass open in all eight directions. Whatever one touches or encounters is of the primordial—like a vast gauze canopy of finest silk, where every object is precious, and all is luminously revealed. One need only possess the thousand hands and thousand eyes to gather them at will. All that was lost is fully contained herein.

Yet without a true teacher to open the Mysterious Aperture before you and bestow the Dharmakāya of thousand hands and thousand eyes behind you, how could one recognize it? Master Wuyuan guarded this secret closely, and so I set it forth here to complete the record.

Someone asked, “If the primordial is estranged from me, then my body must be purely yin, and I cannot cultivate by clinging to this form. Why, then, does the *Yijing* speak of ‘returning without going far to cultivate the self’?”

I answered: “The Great Dao does not depart from this body, nor does it cling to it. To seek it externally is to pursue what is not of one’s own kind—this is to enter the deviant path. To seek it within a purely yin self is to be bound to the postnatal—this is attachment to the later heaven. Yet there is a method that can restore what is absent and reclaim what has departed, which is why it is called ‘returning to the origin and reverting to the root.’”

[This response, as noted, has been elaborated in the previous commentary; what the earlier remarks describe is precisely the unique method referred to in this answer.]

Scholars may savor these words deeply, for when sincerely practiced, none shall fail to verify their truth. To investigate this unique method, one must begin with the secret of settling the heart-mind. Once this secret is thoroughly mastered, proceed then to follow the oral instructions transmitted by Patriarch Ma, adding only the word "constancy."

Someone asked: “If it is neither within the body nor outside it, where precisely does this primordial substance reside?”

I answered: “It resides in the Mysterious Pass. What is called the Mysterious Pass is the place untouched by the Four Great Elements—neither existent nor nonexistent, neither form nor emptiness, neither inside nor outside. It is also named the Gate of the Mysterious Female, the Abode of Life and Death, the Orifice of Yin and Yang, the Gate of Life and Death, the Cavern of Chaos, the Altar of Dragon and Tiger, the Orifice of Tortoise and Serpent, the Realm of Vagueness, the Land of Obscurity, the Portal of Inhalation and Exhalation, the Gate of Wu and Ji, and many other designations—all referring to the Orifice of the Mysterious Pass. Within the body, it is not the heart, liver, spleen, lungs, or kidneys; not the eyes, ears, nose, tongue, body, or intent; not the three hundred and sixty bones and joints; not the eighty-four thousand pores. Since ancient times, immortals and perfected beings have refused to speak of it plainly, which has led to many deviant schools that vainly speculate and privately conjecture, seeking it only among the bodily forms and images—how grievously mistaken!

Now I shall point it out to you: know that this orifice lies where the Six Desires do not reach, where the Five Phases do not penetrate. Vague and indistinct, within it there is an orifice; obscure and profound, within it there is a gate that opens and closes of itself. Call to it, and it responds; tap it, and it awakens. Bright and clear, it is ever-present and complete. If deluded, it seems a thousand miles away; if enlightened, it is right before you. Alas! To spiritually illuminate it depends on the individual—without decades of exhaustive inquiry into principle, one cannot perceive it.”

[This answer reveals that the Master arrived at this stage through inquiry into principle, appearing to have grasped it yet not truly attained it. I, however, have seen it as described! The Master’s error lay in reading books and pursuing principle. Those who recognize that practice begins with emptiness and stillness will know my words are not mistaken. The great flaw in this passage lies in the phrases “call to it” and “tap it,” and in later attributing its perception to exhaustive inquiry. This stage can only be entered through the two words *emptiness* and *stillness*. When practice reaches its utmost, all mysterious states must be observed without attachment. As the ancient sages said: “Without thought, without concern, one suddenly penetrates the mysterious state, as if returning to one’s homeland—never to be astonished.” Regard existence and nonexistence, movement and stillness, reality and emptiness, form and formlessness—see them as if not seeing, perceive them as if not perceiving. Whether the pass opens or not, do not investigate. The slightest fixation will fall into illusory delusion outside the orifice—beware!

If one can guard this secret in stillness, with no thought arising, one may suddenly awaken as from a dream. Vast and boundless, obscure and unfathomable—this is what the ancient sages called the initial state of the spirit entering the orifice. Then, the mechanism suddenly vanishes—what the ancients called “the spirit attaining primordial chaos.” Suddenly, one perceives all things clearly, yet the center remains still—what the ancients called “the living primordial movement of the Mysterious Orifice itself.” This movement corresponds to the initial mysterious state of the *huo zi* (living child) at the *zheng xu wei* (true void and non-being) stage.

At this time, one must stand as if atop a ten-thousand-foot peak, the eye’s reach limitless, profound and lofty—what the ancients named the mysterious state of the *zheng zi* (true child) within the orifice. Then, life and death interact, transformations endless, responses manifold. Yet one remains still, the mind unmoved—what the ancients called the *huo wu* (living noon) within the orifice. At this stage, the method lies in advancing and withdrawing, withdrawing to return to the prenatal, preventing yin from overwhelming yang and thus preserving harmony. This also encompasses the method of bathing—here lies the true person, true resonance, true response!

For this Mysterious Orifice directly shares the breath of creation. If emptiness is not absolute, if stillness is not profound, there is no principle by which it can open. The ancients said that within this realm, heaven and earth, the Five Phases, the Three Powers, and the cycles of generation and extinction all arise. Great cultivators invariably lay their foundation here. The six kinds of immortal retinues—celestial, aquatic, terrestrial, human, divine, and demonic—all emerge from this, as detailed in the *Ten Principles of the Correct Path for Female Cultivation* by the Queen Mother of the West. The means of attaining it lies in the resonance of mechanism and response.]

Someone asked: “If the Mysterious Pass is neither within the body nor outside it, yet is called the Orifice of Yin and Yang, does the body itself not contain yin and yang?”

I answered: “Humans receive the qi of heaven and earth’s yin and yang and the Five Phases to form their bodies, which inherently contain the qi of yin and yang and the Five Phases. The numinous aspect of yin is the *po* (corporeal soul), and the numinous aspect of yang is the *hun* (ethereal soul). The *hun* and *po* reside in the body like people in a house. The Mysterious Pass is the gate through which the *hun* and *po* enter and exit. Yet this gate has no form or image; it opens and closes in emptiness, and the *hun* and *po* also enter and exit in emptiness. Because it is in emptiness, it is neither within the body nor outside it—even the body’s every movement and stillness occurs in emptiness. Thus, reflect for yourself: How does this body walk? How does it stand? How does it sit, how does it lie? How does it speak? How does it remain silent? How does it bend? How does it stretch?”

All such movements—walking, standing, sitting, lying, speaking, silence, bending, stretching—emerge from the Mysterious Pass. Where, then, does this subtle mechanism truly reside? If one can truly know it, one perceives the gate of yin and yang and may thereby preserve one’s nature and life.”

[This Mysterious Aperture cannot be grasped by conjecture, for it is no ordinary aperture—it is the very boundary between the Prior-Heaven and Posterior-Heaven. Yet according to the alchemical classics, where the thought stirs is the Mysterious Female (*xuan pin*); thus this Mysterious Aperture must lie before the spine and behind the palace, in emptiness awaiting. With sufficient cultivation, it will naturally manifest. This teaching was received from the world-abiding immortals, the Perfected Ones Huang and Li, and having personally witnessed its numinous efficacy, I dare not keep it private, but humbly append it here.]

Someone asked: “Since yin and yang reside within the body, the cultivation of nature and life depends on oneself and cannot be borrowed from another. Why then did the ancients say, ‘Do not take this body to be the Dao; you must recognize the other family’s deathless method’?”

The answer: “This refers to the Posterior-Heaven! From the moment of birth, nature and life were one household, yin and yang a single qi. As one grows, reaching the age of sixteen, the yang qi becomes full, and a single yin stealthily arises. Thereupon Qian and Kun unite: Qian, empty, becomes Li, and Kun, full, becomes Kan. Within Li is stored nature; within Kan is stored life. Kan has sunken its true essence, like a tiger fleeing to dwell in the west—life no longer belongs to me, and what I possess is purely yin. If one clings to this body in cultivation, one merely refines the Posterior-Heaven’s essence and qi—how could one attain the fully realized pure yang body? Thus one must seek the other family’s deathless method, that is, the single yang essence sunken within Kan. Because Kan has sunken it, it is not mine to possess, hence it is called ‘the other family’—not some other family outside the body. To fixate on anything outside the body is to slander the sagely Dao and will consign one to the hell of tongue-pulling. As Yuanzi of the *Supervising Vessel* said, ‘A single yang essence is hidden in the mountain of form, not in the heart or kidneys, but in the Mysterious Pass’s single aperture’—this is the meaning.”

[This answer still pertains to the initial steps of consolidating the foundation in the earthly immortal tradition. Yet if the Mysterious Pass does not open, all efforts will be in vain. My late teacher, Master Taixu, said: “Yuanzi of the *Supervising Vessel*, though a scholar of broad learning who received true transmission, was overly secretive. Saying ‘not in the heart or kidneys, but in the Mysterious Pass’s single aperture’ was already not entirely concealed, yet his lack of full disclosure only misled others.” Such was my teacher’s critique. Now, considering Master Wuyuan’s answer here, was he not also misled by Chen’s doctrine?]

Chen’s doctrine was expounded with intent, and only our Southern School’s Niwan Patriarch Chen saw through it. The Patriarch lamented this, hence his claim that Ancestor Zhang of Ziyang’s cultivation was not universally applied. If even Ancestor Zhang of Ziyang, a sage, was misled by Chen’s doctrine, how much less should we wonder at Zhao of Yuandu’s errors!

I have examined Zhao’s writings, which record an *Unobstructed Buddha Assembly* and state: *“Without true transmission, how can one know the method of gathering?”* Thus, Zhao must have heard the true oral instructions for gathering, yet like Master Wuyuan, he feared divine retribution and so revealed only this much. Still, saying *“not in the heart or kidneys, but in the Mysterious Pass’s single aperture”* was already an implicit hint at the method.

For later learners whose primordial qi is depleted and foundation broken, only deep plowing and planting the seed will suffice to provisionally hook into the profound. Without deep plowing and planting, there is no way to return to the root and restore the primordial. To deep plow, one begins with the Three Observations; when the Three Observations are mastered, this is planting the seed.

What is the seed? It is the *same kind*. Recognizing the same kind and being skilled in gathering, one may yet rely on the embryo’s formation and perfection—how could this merely secure the foundation? Yet without being shown the beginning and end, none will avoid falling into heterodox teachings.

I have heard Master Taixu say that the harm of heterodox teachings lies in failing to break through the pass, in not recognizing the same kind. The direct pointing to break through the pass is nothing other than placing this body and mind before the prior Heaven, reaching the state of effortless spontaneity. Without laboring at cultivation, the Mysterious Pass will open, appear, and admit of itself. One must only know to avoid attachment to form or thought, and to avoid missing it when it arises.

When the initial glimpse of the pass appears, if a single thought stirs, the Mysterious Pass vanishes at once. Its wondrous state shifts with every thought, leaving no stable ground. The secret lies in placing one’s spirit and intent in a state of unknowing, reaching the point where ten thousand concerns do not arise and the single numinous spark is also extinguished—this is the state of profound chaos, the position of having deeply entered the aperture of the Mysterious Pass.

Suddenly, a thought stirs; in stillness, one observes and senses a spontaneous resonance like breath responding to breath, a sound arising without striking—this is the sign of the first yang stirring. One must maintain absolute stillness, yet avoid the flaw of rigid fixation. The secret is to follow the movement and penetrate inward—this is the moment when the Mysterious Pass opens wide. If one errs by rigid fixation, the ancients called it “stiffness within and without.”

At this stage, the environment will transform like spring or summer, with warm sun and gentle wind, bright flowers and deep willows. If one remains truly blind and deaf, the six gates tightly sealed, the single aperture unopened, this is missing the moment. If one chases after distractions and inverts reality, losing one’s original nature, this is following external things and thus self-deception. The secret is to expand one’s true primordial qi, merging with the primordial qi of the environment, while inwardly preserving a composed intent, empty and still. One will then sense an ineffable, profound moistening within. External phenomena may be manifold, but one merely listens—this is the wondrous state of *“cultivation at high noon, when all paths open.”*

The secret is to proceed with the retreat of yin, yet this is nothing more than inwardly gathering intent, allowing one’s primordial qi to return to the cave as if clouds to the valley, where only mist swirls in the empty gorge. Suddenly, harmony shifts to solemnity—this is the wondrous state of the *shen-you* hours. In prolonged stillness, the scene manifests the image of winter—this pertains to the first line of the *Kan* hexagram. The learner must not stop here.

The secret is to gather the spirit at the lower extreme; when cultivation fills the entire body with harmony, one may cease with ease—this is the initial step in the method of the Mysterious Pass. After a hundred days of such practice, one may then discuss advancing further. As for planting the seed and other secrets, those with strength may prepare the primordial seed in advance; those without may dwell in stillness amid the marketplace.

Above all, nothing surpasses forming an *Unobstructed Buddha Assembly*. Whether one plans, conceals, or completes it, each path has its supreme and ultimate function. What has been described thus far only completes the first step of deep plowing—what the ancients called the foundation of *xing*-learning and *ming*-learning. This is the great Dao that Master Wuyuan kept secret and never disclosed. Fearing that later learners might stray onto wrong paths and remain unredeemed for life, I have here supplemented the account.

Yet these are the oral instructions sworn in mountain covenants and sea vows by the ancient sages and perfected ones, transmitted at midnight and never before committed to paper. Learners who encounter them must not treat them lightly. The crux lies entirely in the step of deep plowing. If deep plowing is shallow, the harvest will be meager; if deep plowing is thorough, the harvest will fill the granary—this is the ultimate principle. Do not deceive yourself.

What is planting the seed? It is constructing a living dragon and tiger within the cinnabar chamber to attract the true primordial qi. For men, it is attracting the *kun*-primordial; for women, the *qian*-primordial. When the two primordial qi interact in the void, something must be born. Using my own medium, I draw it inward, uniting them as husband and wife—this is the way to immortality and longevity.

Only by expanding my boundaries and inwardly resonating with the Three Primordials, employing the true fire within the provisional to strip yin and retain yang, refining day and night until all becomes one, awaiting the right moment for activation—only then, when the *Kun*-Mother responds, will the true unity of the human primordial descend to pair with my center. When true meets true and virtue merges, the true fire will naturally blaze. Refining the living millet pearl, one guides it with intent to fall into the Central Yellow Ultimate, where it spins like a pearl, enveloped in rosy clouds. Stored as if a woman with child, this is forming the embryo.

The method is to preserve it in emptiness and stillness, nurturing it daily with warmth. Through such cultivation, when oneness is not one and twoness is not two, this is the method for attaining the celestial immortal. Such was my teacher Master Taixu’s profound discourse. This is the true function of what Master Wuyuan called *“attaining the body of pure yang completion.”* Yet if one follows his instructions, it remains merely the interaction of illusory qi and the birth of the primordial—it does not yet constitute the body of pure yang completion.

The method of fire timing has not yet been fully revealed, so I shall now expound and supplement it.

**Question:** "Are *xing* (nature) and *ming* (life) attributed to *kan* (Water) and *li* (Fire), with the heart as *li* and the kidneys as *kan*?"
**Answer:** "Those are the *kan* and *li* of the postnatal illusory body, not the *kan* and *li* of the prenatal Dharma-body. The *kan* and *li* of the Dharma-body are such that *li* removes its yang to become *li*, while *kan* submerges its true essence to become *kan*. When *li* removes its yang, what remains must be yin. When *kan* submerges its true essence, what it conceals must be yang. *Li* is the solar soul, an image of radiant brightness, yet outwardly masculine and inwardly feminine—its soul contains a spirit. *Kan* is the lunar spirit, an image of obscurity, yet outwardly dark and inwardly luminous—its spirit contains a soul. Within this central yin and central yang lies the balanced body of *qian* (Heaven) and *kun* (Earth), forming true yin and true yang, the root of *xing* and *ming*. The Dao of the Elixir gathers these two qi, uniting them to become true, transcending the mundane and entering the sacred. How could this compare to the postnatal, tangible *kan* and *li*?"

**Question:** "If *kan* and *li* are true yin and true yang, then in 'taking from *kan* to fill *li*,' what yang is taken, and what yin is filled?"
**Answer:** "This refers to returning from the postnatal to the prenatal. The yin to be filled is the yin of our own house—postnatal matter, false yin. It is the sevenfold cinnabar within *li*: the bodily fluids of saliva, tears, essence, spittle, qi, blood, and marrow. These seven numinous substances cannot be retained for long. The yang within *kan* is the matter of another house—prenatal true yang. Taking this true yang from *kan* to fill the false yin within *li* is like a cat catching a mouse: using the prenatal to transform the postnatal, employing true yang to subdue false yin. One must not mistake false yin for true yin. False yin is born of heaven and earth, while true yin gives birth to heaven and earth—how could they be confused?"

**Question:** "Can the actual manifestations of true yin-yang and false yin-yang be explained?"
**Answer:** "True yin-yang is like a husband and wife united by a matchmaker. False yin-yang is like a man and woman engaging in illicit union. When illicit unions are exposed, harm befalls *xing* and *ming*—not only are they unbeneficial, but they cause injury. A union arranged by a matchmaker is open and upright, bearing sons and grandsons—who can break it? Who can ruin it? Thus, the true accomplishes the work, while the false destroys it. This is why the perfected do not use the false but take the true."

**Question:** "In harmonizing yin and yang, the Yellow Dame serves as the matchmaker. Where does the Yellow Dame reside?"
**Answer:** "In the Central Earth. The *Yijing* states, *'The yellow center penetrates principle.'* The Central Earth harmonizes yin and yang, unites the Four Images, and gathers the Five Phases. Without this earth, how could yin and yang harmonize? How could the Four Images unite? How could the Five Phases gather? It is the trust of yin-yang, the Four Images, and the Five Phases. Thus, in the four seasons of spring, summer, autumn, and winter, each has eighteen days ruled by earth—this is to establish its trust."

**Question:** "Does earth have distinctions of true and false, prenatal and postnatal?"
**Answer:** "How could it not? Consider the eighteen days of earth’s rule in each season. This earth is formless, belonging to the prenatal—it is the *qi* of earth. The earth of the great land is tangible, belonging to the postnatal—it is the substance of earth. *Qi* is true, substance is false. Not only is earth’s truth and falsity like this, but so too are the Four Images and Five Phases."

**Question:** "If false earth is not used, how does the false earth of the great land give birth to things?"
**Answer:** "The true borrows the false to enact its function, while the false borrows the true to take form. Without the false, the true does not manifest; without the true, the false does not appear. The false resides within the true, and the true resides within the false. The Great Dao’s return from the postnatal to the prenatal follows this principle."

**Question:** "*If *kan* and *li* return without *wu* and *ji*, though they contain the Four Images, the Elixir will not form.* Are these *wu* and *ji* the alternate names for true and false?"
**Answer:** "These *wu* and *ji* are what I call the prenatal earth, not the postnatal. Prenatal *wu* and *ji* exist, as do postnatal *wu* and *ji*. From the prenatal perspective, *li* contains *ji*, and *kan* contains *wu*. *Wu* is the earth of movement within stillness, belonging to yang. *Ji* is the earth of stillness within movement, belonging to yin. What is called *'occupying the position of the Central Palace'* is the still earth. What is called *'summoning the prenatal'* is the moving earth. Possessing these two earths to unite *kan* and *li* causes water and fire to mutually assist, forming the Elixir—this is the reverse path. From the postnatal perspective, the yin within *li* is false yin, an unbalanced yin, bright externally yet dark internally, an unquiet *ji* earth. The yang within *kan* is false yang, an unbalanced yang, with upright qi obstructed and deviant qi manifest—it is a delusively moving *wu* earth. Possessing these two earths harms *xing* and *ming*, causing water and fire to fail in mutual assistance and the Dao to be ruined. With such distinctions, how can they be discussed indiscriminately?"

"Someone asked: 'Are the prenatal *wu* and *ji* earths used together or separately?'

The master replied: 'In terms of the Returned Elixir, one employs the inner *ji* earth to summon the outer *wu* earth, seeking others through oneself to gather the medicine. In terms of the Great Elixir, one employs the outer *wu* earth to approach the inner *ji* earth, returning emotion to nature to form the embryo—this is their separate use.

When gathering the medicine, if the inner *ji* earth does not initiate, the outer *wu* earth will not harmonize; if the outer *wu* earth does not move, the inner *ji* earth will not respond. Only when inner and outer mutually assist does the medicine spontaneously arise from emptiness.

When forming the embryo, if the inner *ji* earth does not welcome, the outer *wu* earth cannot approach; if the outer *wu* earth does not move, the inner *ji* earth cannot act. Only when movement and stillness become one does the embryo naturally coalesce—this is their joint use.'

Someone asked: 'How does one distinguish the principles of the Returned Elixir and the Great Elixir?'

The master replied: 'The Returned Elixir returns to one’s original state, transforming the postnatal back into the prenatal. The Great Elixir cultivates one’s original state, generating substantial form from formlessness.

After a person’s yang reaches its extreme and generates yin, day by day, yin erodes yang, and the prenatal *qi* dissipates, greatly diminishing its measure. The *return* involves using methods to pursue and gather it, gradually collecting and restoring its original measure—like something lost that is recovered, or departed that returns. This is the Returned Elixir.

Yet though the original measure may be complete, without refinement by fire, it cannot generate form from the formless or substance from the insubstantial. Thus, after the Returned Elixir is achieved, one must reinstall the furnace and reestablish the crucible; lead is cast into mercury, and mercury nurtures lead. Using the natural true fire, one refines it into genuineness, transforming it into an indestructible substance—coeternal with heaven and earth, rivaling the sun and moon in brilliance—only then is the original state fully attained. Otherwise, if the Returned Elixir is achieved but the Great Elixir is not cultivated, though the original state exists, it will not be firm, and there will inevitably come a time when what was gained is lost again.'

[The final step of the Returned Elixir, in its common yet wondrous application, is an essential stage in the Dao of the Elixir. Its profound principles diverge in their tendencies and cannot be discussed indiscriminately. Yet all are termed *reinstalling the furnace and reestablishing the crucible*. The terms *crucible* and *furnace* are metaphorical. Master Wuyuan’s teachings follow methods established since the Han and Tang dynasties, not yet tracing back to the Supreme Heart-Mind School, hence the notion of reinstalling and reestablishing. Some follow the tale of Pei Hang, others emulate the hidden wonders of Ancestor Xue—all are essential paths to fully realizing the wondrous practice.

Only in our Supreme Heart-Mind School is the foundation laid in the prenatal: the Returned Elixir resides here, and the Great Elixir also resides here—this is the non-dual Dharma gate. It is most refined, most subtle, most profound, most mysterious, yet also most balanced, most ordinary, most shallow, most near. Embodied and practiced, within it lies vastness like the great sea, wondrousness like the sands of the Ganges.

The practitioner need only cultivate a thousand hands and a thousand eyes, refining and constructing a boundless, infinite Dharma treasury. Within this treasury lies a great jewel of gold-absorbing stone, which I select and appropriate. This jewel is born from the Limitless, without form or image, without sound or scent. The ancient sages could not name it, merely noting that from the insubstantial it generates substance, yet it is not quite a stone—hence the forced name *jewel*. How could it be lodestone? A person’s true unity closely resembles it.

As for the thousand hands and thousand eyes, and the boundless, infinite Dharma treasury, these are refined from the single effort of overcoming the self. My late master, the Venerable Taixu, expounded thus. In essence, the method is nothing more than releasing the myriad conditions, focusing the mind on *kun*, and initiating the practice—thus, thus. I dare not be selfish, and humbly add this to supplement what Master Wuyuan did not teach.]

Someone asked: 'Are the Returned Elixir and the Great Elixir equivalent to the inner and outer medicines?'

The master replied: 'There are several interpretations. In terms of the beginning and end of the Elixir Dao, the art of extending life is the outer medicine, and the Dao of completing nature is the inner medicine. Without the outer medicine, one cannot shed the illusory body; without the inner medicine, one cannot shed the Dharma body. The outer medicine forms the embryo, while the inner medicine liberates it.

In terms of the Returned Elixir, *kan* is the outer medicine, and *li* is the inner medicine. In terms of the Great Elixir, true lead is the outer medicine, and true mercury is the inner medicine. The ancients’ words each have their referents; one must not cling to the letter or fixate on images.'

Someone asked: 'True lead resides in *kan*, true mercury in *li*. Once the Returned Elixir is formed, lead and mercury unite. Why then does the Great Elixir again involve lead and mercury? Are there not four leads and mercuries?'

The master replied: 'In the Returned Elixir, the lead within *kan* and the mercury within *li* are the prenatal lead and mercury concealed within the postnatal. Extracting these lead and mercury is called the Returned Elixir, also termed the Golden Elixir, the true seed, or true lead. It touches one’s own yin mercury like a lodestone attracting iron. This mercury is the sevenfold cinnabar within *li*. When mercury receives the *qi* of lead, it instantly dries. Later, using the natural true fire within the already-dead true mercury, one nurtures it for ten months, applying the method of withdrawal and addition. The *qi* of lead flies away in flakes, leaving only a single essence of numinous cinnabar. Pure yang without yin, the Dharma body is complete.'

Someone asked: 'The Golden Elixir is formed by the union of lead and mercury. If one says mercury restrains lead, yet also says that after ten months of nurturing, lead flies away and mercury dries—is this not contradictory?'

The master replied: 'This celestial mechanism has confused countless learners through the ages. Among thousands, who truly understands it?'"

The numinous cinnabar is a primordial, supremely yang substance. Yet when yang reaches its extreme, yin arises, and the primordial enters the postnatal—truth becomes mingled with falsehood. Without the true lead from another source to restrain it, this numinous cinnabar will never truly belong to oneself. For within true lead lies the primordial true unity of *qi*; when this lead-*qi* touches one’s numinous mercury, the mercury naturally ceases to flee. Once the mercury is dead, if the lead-*qi* is not fully withdrawn, the numinous cinnabar will not congeal. Why? Though lead is a primordial *qi*, it emerges from the postnatal realm—outwardly yin yet inwardly yang—carrying residual yin within. Only when this yin is entirely drawn out can it become firm, upright, and centered, revealing a grain-like precious pearl, luminous within and without, penetrating heaven and earth. When released, it fills the six directions; when gathered, it retreats into secrecy. As *Awakening to Reality* states:

*One must use lead, yet not common lead—*
*Once true lead is used, it too is cast aside.*
*This is the true esoteric art of using lead—*
*To use lead yet not use it is the sincere word.*

From this, one may grasp the meaning of using lead. If lead is so, then mercury may be understood likewise. If lead and mercury are thus, then the four images, five phases, heaven and earth, and all beings are no different. This is the principle of using *qi* rather than form. Here, one advances further still—it is the great Dao of using the primordial and not the postnatal. This is what is meant by knowing the wondrous meaning of return and reversal. Practitioners should embody and enact it.

The scriptures say:
*Refine essence to transform it into* qi*,*
*Refine* qi *to transform it into spirit,*
*Refine spirit to return to emptiness,*
*Refine emptiness to merge with the Dao,*
*Refine the Dao to unite with spontaneity.*

Such is the sequence of return and reversal. When return reaches this point, one may master life and death. If the work does not attain this, one will inevitably encounter demons and retreat, regressing to fate’s decree—how lamentable! The crux of its function begins with exhausting the self. Never has one who has not exhausted the self been able to fully realize nature and fulfill destiny. Such was the teaching left by my master, the Great Void Elder.

Someone asked: "Do the Reverted Elixir and the Great Elixir differ, and do their fire phases also differ?"
The master replied: "They differ. The fire phase of the Reverted Elixir lies in the *living midnight hour*, while that of the Great Elixir lies in the *true midnight hour*. The *living midnight hour* is not confined to the fixed division of midnight and noon. The *true midnight hour* is the single hour in which the elixir is completed. The fixed division of midnight and noon means that in every moment, there is the mechanism of yin waning and yang waxing—advancing yang at midnight and withdrawing yin at noon. As *The Mirror of Ingredients* says:

*Within a day, the twelve hours—*
*Wherever the mind reaches, there it may be done.*

This refers to gauging the waxing and waning of yin and yang with intent, which is precisely the *living midnight hour* of gathering the medicine without fixed timing. As for the elixir being completed in a single hour, this hour aligns one’s virtue with heaven and earth, one’s brightness with the sun and moon, one’s sequence with the four seasons, and one’s fortune with spirits and gods. It is difficult to attain yet easy to lose, tied to life and death, bound to nature and destiny. The perfected one, in this single hour, exerts great effort and sets the great mechanism in motion. The numbers of heaven and earth are exhausted; the numbers of the myriad things are exhausted. The dragon is driven to the tiger, and the tiger is harnessed to the dragon. Entering the yellow chamber, they congeal into the supreme treasure. This is the *true midnight hour* of elixir formation and harmonization."

Someone asked: "How does one recognize the arrival of the *living midnight hour* and the *true midnight hour*?"
The master replied: "How does one act without knowing? Taking the *living midnight hour* as an example: primordial true yang is obscured by the postnatal and cannot manifest on its own. Even if it occasionally arises, it is mixed with human desire and is lost as soon as it appears. Why? Because one mistakes the false for the true."

At this moment when the primordial first flickers forth, the perfected one employs the method to pursue and gather it, gradually drawing it in and collecting it. Once the medicine has accumulated sufficiently, it is warmed and nurtured until qi is full and spirit complete. When the *true midnight hour* arrives, the great medicine arises. With but a brief effort, it is gathered and ingested, merging with one’s true mercury to restore the primordial unity of qi—this is the convergence with the great workings of creation.

After ingesting the elixir, for seven days one abides in primordial chaos, dying and reviving, transmuting the postnatal hexagrams and trigrams to reveal the root-sprout of the primordial. Thus one passes from effortful practice into effortlessness.”

[This passage reveals a method originating after the Qin and Han dynasties, hence its various elaborations. The practice is intricate and arduous; though effects may appear swiftly, only one in ten thousand attains completion. Its flaw lies in failing to establish a foundation prior to the primordial. Examining its method, it emphasizes deliberate action and application. The primordial qi is never truly encountered, and its so-called "primordial chaos" is merely yang submerged in yin, requiring seven days for yang to emerge. Yet some achieve transient spiritual transformations and illusory manifestations, which the world, unaware, reveres and venerates. In truth, none of this accords with the great Dao. Our tradition warns against it; though our virtue is meager, we dare not endorse such practices.

Our master, the Venerable Tai Xu, also discussed this method, noting that whether in solitary or dual cultivation, external assistance is required. For solitary practice, one enters samadhi and instructs an attendant to prepare a high-quality hand-bell, striking it near the ear. When the resonance nearly fades, it is struck again. Those in shallow samadhi awaken at once; those in deep samadhi may require three, five, or seven strikes, but all will awaken. If the body shifts position, however, only two or three in ten will awaken. Even if they do, strange ailments arise—dual cultivation fares no better. If one fails to awaken, the attendant must direct their spirit to focus on the practitioner or even align their mouth and nose closely to rouse them. Should they remain oblivious, dual cultivators die together, and solitary practitioners die alone.

Our late master recounted: “Once, while traveling past Dongting Lake, I passed a grass hut where the Venerable Jing had taken residence. For years, Jing had regularly convened unrestricted Buddhist assemblies. That day, before I entered, an elderly woman emerged in evident distress. Soon after, a child ran out calling for Mother, overjoyed.”]

The elderly woman, upon inquiry, replied, “Qing Gu has awakened!” She then turned back. Intrigued, I followed them inside. Before I could ask, Qing Gu had already descended the steps and, seeing me, exclaimed with great joy, “It is indeed you, it is indeed you!” She led me into the room. Qing said, “To the east sat so-and-so, to the west sat so-and-so, to the left of the north seat sat so-and-so, and to the right was your disciple. When my spirit departed, I saw you standing motionless beside the hut and thus awakened. I suspected it was a dream—yet it was truly you.” She then recounted how the entire hall had entered meditation together, leading to this transformation.

Upon hearing this, I carefully assessed that no one in the hall was in mortal danger. I took the hand-bell and struck it in sequence—those to the east and west all revived, but the one to Qing’s left remained unresponsive even after seven strikes. I then instructed Qing to sit steadily on the right while directing her spirit to focus intently on the still form. After the time it takes to carve an inch, the left-seated one also awakened. All prostrated themselves and kowtowed, saying, “We had just entered the land of mist, unable to distinguish east from west. Suddenly, the wind of the bell’s roar reached us, and our minds settled slightly—only then did we awaken.”

The monk to Qing’s left was her cousin from Tonglu, the sixteen-year-old disciple of the hut’s master, Venerable Jing. The monk said, “I was blinded by the mist and mistakenly entered an icy pit, my body stiff and immobile. The bell’s resonant sound only deepened the mist’s grip, until a warm qi suddenly pierced my body and heart, reviving my spirit. Then I heard you calling me and awoke as if from a dream.”

I told them, “This is called *entering samadhi*. From now on, if this happens again, be careful not to shift your sleeping position. Simply use the bell to summon them, and none will fail to awaken. If you are the first to awaken in a shared samadhi, do not descend your seat—wait until all have revived before doing so. This collective entry into samadhi is a rare occurrence across the ages. Alas, their primordial chaos has not yet refined into clarity; if they can reach the harmony of spring, they may once more behold the stars and moon, the thousand-fathom blue waters, and lotus-lined shores—only to re-enter chaos and awaken. Then they will not be far from the Dao!

Yet now, Venerable Jing has also fallen into this state, and the hut is without a master. Dare I cling to scripture and neglect expedience? Still, the clouds above have already shielded them, and the Buddhas and heavens will surely bestow their grace. This is why I stood motionless beside the hut—Qing Gu, take heed and encourage the others.”

This principle of our late master was recorded by Master Qiaoyun in *The Golden Canopy Diary*. It serves as a mirror for those who cultivate the truth, and thus I have appended it here.

Someone asked, “The Way of the Golden Elixir, once attained, is eternally secure. Why then does it entail the peril of death and revival?”

I answered, “The hour of *zheng zishi* is the moment for connecting life. When true lead merges with mercury, lead and mercury fuse, all pulses cease, and every thought stills—one enters the aperture of primordial chaos. A single lapse of care, and the Great Elixir leaks away. This moment is the critical juncture: life is connected here, and life may also be harmed here. Thus the ancients said, ‘In the chaos of seven days, one dies and revives—all depends on companions to regulate water and fire.’”

Someone asked, “The signs of elixir formation lie within oneself. How can companions regulate water and fire?”

I answered, “This is not the water and fire of external companions, but the internal water and fire of companions—those of like mind and intent who can harmonize yin and yang to augment one’s strength. As it is said, ‘First, I am host and they are guests; then, I am guest and they are host. When we meet and our natures align, self and other merge, and lead and mercury congeal.’ One water, one fire—within the crucible, they refine and boil themselves. One dragon, one tiger—within the cave of creation, they devour and consume each other. Spirit congeals, qi gathers, and the infant takes form. Without the merit of companions, how could this be achieved? Yet such companions are most difficult to find.

Alas! Mortals seek the treasures of heaven, but in their search, they must use the wealth of the world. If one is stingy in conduct and miserly in giving, even ten thousand immortals will refuse to come.”

Here follows the translation:

---

As the response indicates, this refers to the inner companion who unites tiger and dragon in harmonious union—hence the term "those of like mind and intent." Yet this is not mere mud and water, but rather the collaborative workings of qi, spirit, and virtue. What is obtained is one celestial treasure after another. Though called a treasure, it is no treasure at all—not the mere "stop-crying" object described by the Holy Maiden, which is but a yellow leaf, not true gold. Master Wu Yuan seems not to have experienced this firsthand, and thus, following the ancients who attained emptiness and felt celestial treasures descend, he speaks of the infant taking form. Later students must ponder this carefully.

If the companion is indeed one who plants the seed, with no loosening of garments or unbinding of sashes, then the one dragon and one tiger, both in pure and tranquil qi and spirit, will penetrate emptiness together. Within the purity of the void, they devour and consume each other. Beneath them, I but expand the *yinqie* (the receptive vessel), remaining empty and awaiting. When the seed-dragon and seed-tiger, through their spiritual union, generate an entity, it will naturally descend into my valley. I need only double my stillness and emptiness, and it will spontaneously merge with my mercury. Only guard against the arising of stray thoughts, and no other mishap will occur. After the work is complete, I will feel an immediate and profound peace within!

Should I be blessed by heavenly fate, and at the moment of seed-union, the sacred Father and Mother of Heaven unite in the void, there will surely appear a celestial treasure, radiant as the sun and moon conjoined in the empty sky. At that time, I must expand the *yinqie* to its fullest, and my true yin, accumulated like the dark garden of Xuanpu, will be fathomless and boundless. Then, with intention, I may ascend to receive the treasure, as a needle finds its mark in a mustard seed—without any mishap.

If, however, my *yinqie* is not yet fully prepared and my true yin is scant, I may only stealthily partake of its lingering shade, my body warmed as if basking in sunlight. Should I overreach and rashly intend to ascend, there will surely be a conflagration like flames engulfing Mount Kunlun, where jade and stone alike are reduced to ash. Even with a companion of true understanding, we would both be turned to cinders!

The "celestial treasure" spoken of by the ancients refers precisely to this. The "worldly wealth" refers to the *yinqie* and true yin. For this celestial treasure burns hotter than a fireball, and without true yin to match it, if it follows one’s mortal form, the physical body will instantly be reduced to ash—there is no remedy for this.

As for the treasure Master Wu Yuan obtained—though it arises from the union of living dragon and tiger, and comes of its own accord—one must still examine oneself. If one’s cultivation of nature is incomplete and one’s cultivation of life is unprepared, extraordinary dangers may arise. Only with a companion of true understanding, silently aiding and protecting, can one attain peace. For when the treasure returns to the Northern Sea, the greatest danger is the scorching fire of the Southern Sun—this fire is the fire of desire.

At that time, there will inevitably be extraordinary pleasures. If I am not a virgin in purity—or even if I am, but my knowledge has awakened early, and I have heard of such things, for the ways of the world are thus, and true purity is no longer true—once my body experiences such pleasure, it is difficult to avoid slipping into the sea of passion. This is the greatest peril, and one must guard against it strictly.

Master Wu Yuan has also considered this, hence his earlier warning against carelessness. When this occurs, the student must swiftly gather body and mind into the realm of "nothing whatsoever," and fix the emotions between the spine and the heart—that is, following the *gen* (Mountain) trigram’s back. Yet even then, there remains the risk of relapse. This is where an external protector of true understanding is needed, to remain vigilant within. All three must observe this together, using the striking of a chime as the signal.

The ancients left a disciplinary method, which states: Invoke the black *sha* (killing energy) at the *yongquan* (Bubbling Spring) point, ascend to unite with the *mingmen* (Gate of Life) at the *haidi* (Sea Bottom), then reverse course from the North Pole of the Sea, rising along the back to the brain, gathering in the void. From the void, it descends forward, and one will feel the fire descending from the face to the chest, accompanied by an inner gust of *xun* (Wind) energy. Suddenly, the great earth appears in its primordial chaos, only to return to the clarity of heaven and the tranquility of earth. Then one may quietly guard the mysterious aperture, practicing the first line of the *qian* (Heaven) trigram, with four inhalations and six exhalations, and stop—this is called "assisted regulation."

This means that within the companion’s body, one performs the inner circulation, ascending and then externally infusing one’s own body—all while employing the ritual chime to achieve the unity of the four. As for the absurd fabrications of the world regarding such sacred companions—those who are noble as emperors, wealthy as lords of all under heaven, whose virtue rivals the Four Companions and whose merit equals Yi and Zhou—without karmic affinity, one will never encounter them. The perfected ones, moved by compassion, devised the method of "deep plowing and seed-planting," employing the wondrous technique of "hooking the mysterious." This is not a love of the strange, but because such sacred companions are purely a matter of heavenly fate. Without them, attaining the Dao is difficult indeed! How many of the ancients ever encountered them? Master Wu Yuan revealed this but did not complete it, nor did he elaborate fully—hence this supplementary account.

---

Someone asked: “The first precept for cultivators is to avoid stinginess with wealth. You say, ‘One must use worldly wealth,’ yet also say, ‘If one is stingy, immortals will not come.’ In the end, should one use wealth or not?”

The answer: “Use it, yet do not use it. Wealth is what people cherish. Using wealth makes it easy to win the hearts of others and to purchase the true treasures of heaven, so that both heaven and humanity are within one’s grasp. Without wealth, to seek true treasures is to demand and force—heaven will not comply, nor will people submit. Even if one is only slightly stingy, how can immortals come? This is why worldly wealth must be used.

Yet wealth easily corrupts virtue and harms one’s nature and life. If one clings to wealth, one is deceived by it, and one’s actions are dictated by it. Thus, virtue must come before wealth, with virtue as the root and wealth as the branch—this is why worldly wealth is not to be used.

However, this worldly wealth includes both the virtuous wealth of the world and the ordinary wealth of the world—one must distinguish between them.”

Someone asked: “If wealth suffices to win the hearts of others and to buy the true treasures of heaven, does this not resemble the alchemical work of the crucible and furnace?”

The Master replied: “The person here refers to one of the Kun direction—no mere mortal woman. The treasure is of heaven, not of earthly minerals. The person of the Kun direction is one who does not die, the immortal summoned by worldly wealth. The treasure of heaven contains within it a singular treasure, the true treasure sought in the world. To suspect it of being woman or mineral is to slander the sacred Dao, to belong to those who have only just begun as human beings.”

Someone asked: “Does this use of worldly wealth then refer to Dharma wealth?”

The Master replied: “Wealth is wealth, Dharma is Dharma—two distinct things, not one. This is the teaching of dual use of Dharma and wealth. Dharma refers to the work of cultivation and refinement. Wealth refers to the offerings of sincere prayer. Without Dharma, there is only emptiness and unreality, and the true treasure of others will not reveal itself. Without wealth, the firing time will be off, and one’s own vessel will not be proper. Dharma and wealth—neither can be lacking. Thus it is called Dharma-wealth: Dharma contains wealth, wealth contains Dharma. This is not the gold, silver, or money of the world.”
