Someone asked: “If wealth is not gold or silver, why did Baopuzi, after hearing the Dao for twenty years, have no household savings and thus could not proceed? Shangyangzi said, ‘The poor worry they have no wealth; those with wealth worry they have no companions.’ Zhang Sanfeng said, ‘Golden flowers bloom bright, but without money, cultivation is difficult.’ What do these mean?”

The Master replied: “This is a hidden mechanism—without a teacher, one cannot know it, nor should one rashly guess. The Dao of cultivating truth has two paths: one is the path of superior virtue, the work of preserving wholeness through the Dao; the other is the path of inferior virtue, the work of extending life through technique. Those of superior virtue, whose pure yang has not been broken, preserve wholeness through the Dao. They perform effortless work without wealth and can complete their nature. When nature is complete, life is also complete. Those of inferior virtue, who have lost their primordial state, are like the poor who have no wealth. They must borrow wealth from others, extend life through technique, and practice the path of effort to complete their life. Only when life is complete can they begin to cultivate their nature.

Baopuzi heard the Dao for twenty years—he heard the work of preserving wholeness through the Dao. That he ‘could not proceed’ was due to lacking the accumulation of Dharma-wealth, unable to extend life through technique, not because he lacked gold or silver. If gold and silver were truly required, Baopuzi came from a noble and official family—why would he have no savings? Or take Ma Danyang, who possessed wealth across half a province—why did he abandon his family and live in poverty? Why did Liu Haichan abandon his prime minister’s position to wander rivers and lakes? Why did Scholar Luo give up riches and honor to embrace simplicity? The ancient sages and worthies all did likewise. Would they abandon their own present silver and money only to seek the hard-to-find wealth of others? Clearly, there is another principle at work—this is no ordinary worldly wealth.”

Such is wealth—so too may one understand the person!

With wealth spanning half a province and the rank of minister or chancellor, what could one not obtain? Even Qin Shihuang and Han Wudi—could the tripods of five thousand and forty-eight, or the treasures of nine thousand and ninety myriad, have been difficult for them to possess? As *The Rhapsody of the Palace of Epang* declares, “Powdered faces and painted brows—there were those unseen for thirty-six years.” Herein lies the awakening!

Those who seek to cultivate this Dao find the Mysterious Pass unopened, the true primordial essence unrecovered, while the *yinqie* daily collapses, the flowing pearls scatter in all directions, and nothing remains. Know this: the Mysterious Pass, that single aperture, externally encompasses the Three Powers, internally fills the Four Great Elements—it has no inside or outside, no place where it is not, for it is simply one qi. How could it be open or closed? It is only obstructed and sealed by external things.

If one can place body and mind before the prior heavens, the Three Powers and the self are originally one thing. Within this, the true primordial essence has never known gain or loss. What is lost is like the treasures of the inner treasury moved to an outer vault. If I but still my inner treasury, every single thing returns as if merely on loan.

The distinction between higher virtue and lower virtue refers only to the present. If one awakens to the self and stills one’s inner treasury, step by step never straying from the path of return—practicing the refinement of essence back into qi, qi back into spirit, spirit back into emptiness, emptiness back into the Dao, and the Dao back into spontaneity—then one’s inner treasury becomes the supreme Dharma-treasury. The three times and Three Powers return to a single grain of millet, and what distinction remains between higher virtue and lower virtue? Where then is the difference between completing nature and completing life?

This is the secret of return in the Supreme Mind’s tradition. Master Wuyuan never revealed it. Thus, I have set it forth and supplemented it.

The Master’s reference to "the world" signifies this very body of ours; what he calls "wealth" is the wealth of this body—namely, essence, qi, and spirit. What he terms "good" is the primordial; what he terms "ordinary" is the acquired. The primordial perfects the Dao, while the acquired corrupts it—thus, they must not remain unexamined. Though the Master revealed this teaching, he did not expound it fully, fearing divine retribution.

Yet I hold that the obscuration of the Great Dao stems ultimately from the failure of past sages to extend their intent universally. The world speaks of Ancestor Zhang Ziyang, whose transmission fell to unworthy successors three times, incurring three heavenly punishments. I say the cause of these three punishments lay in his reclusive seclusion, which allowed the licentious to cite his authority as proof, so that the writings he bequeathed gravely misled the world. Ancestor Chen Cuixu perceived this, hence his criticism of "non-universality." Master Zhang Qiongguan’s eulogy for Ancestor Xiang also contained subtle reproach—this too was a critique of his reclusion.

Truly, Heaven and Earth delight in those who uphold the Dao; to compose writings that endure through the ages to deliver the predestined is as if ordained by Heaven. Cuixu declared, *"I shall deliver all beings in the world."* And again, *"Could Heaven fail to be Heaven?"* If this be so, what then is there to fear in revealing the profound mysteries of the Dao?

Herein lies the supplementary account:

Someone asked, *"If it is not worldly wealth, then the notion of external protection is likewise absurd. Why then did Apricot Grove entrust the Dao to Daoguang, charging him, ‘Hasten to a bustling metropolis and rely upon the wealthy and powerful’?"*

I replied, *"Worldly wealth has its true and false forms; how could external protection lack inner and outer dimensions? The inner external protection is the Golden Duke, through which the Dharma-body is perfected. The outer external protection is the worldly external protection, through which the illusory body is preserved. This body, not yet freed from the mundane world, remains subject to calamities. External protection safeguards my nature and life, aiding my attainment of the Dao. To dwell in a bustling metropolis is to cultivate the ways of the world. For this Dao readily invites slander; by blending with the俗 and harmonizing one’s light in such places, one remains unrecognized and may thus engage in secret cultivation and refinement. Huineng concealed himself among hunters in Sihui. Daoguang returned to lay life to fulfill his great task—both followed this same principle."*

Here follows the translation:

---

[As for Patriarch Xue’s concealment in bustling metropolises by relying on the immensely wealthy and powerful, Patriarch Shi instructed him thus, further stating: "This was because he had already received the secret transmission of the *Supreme Heart Transmission*. For bustling metropolises are the great treasuries of Elixir materials. Among the immensely wealthy and powerful households, what is stored is even more refined and proximate. The Patriarch, dwelling therein, expanded his *yinqie* (defensive barriers), penetrated the Mysterious Pass, and in morning and evening audiences, not only did his Dharma-body daily solidify, but celestial treasures must naturally bestow themselves. Assuming a false name and blending with the俗 was but a temporary expedient. Ultimately, changing garments and altering appearance—how could this be due to following worldly fashions in venerating the Dao? Having inwardly engaged with the Mysterious, one naturally dons the robes of the Dao, as the saying goes: ‘Speaking the words of Yao, wearing the robes of Yao.’ To say this was to avoid slander is still a mundane sentiment, not the Patriarch’s intent. To say it was the same path as the Sixth Patriarch is correct, yet their circumstances were not identical. The Sixth Patriarch’s Chan study had already attained the state of no-abiding and nothing-to-be-done, so he did not necessarily have to conceal himself among the masses. Moreover, given the jealousy of those in the same robes, living among hunters sufficed as illusory protection. Furthermore, his midnight transmission was an unobstructed one, and dwelling among hunters provided ample protection for the Dharma. The Dharma here refers to the Dharma-body, and the illusory to the illusory form. Employing the illusory to hook the Mysterious is also a matter of great significance. With these two principles, his concealment was thus. Patriarch Xue’s concealment among the masses was solely to attract the one talent, and beyond this, there was no need for such measures. My teacher, the True Immortal of Jizu, once spoke of this, and I have thus supplemented and recorded it for joint reference.]

Someone asked: “Cultivating the Dao is a radiant and upright affair—why does it readily invite slander?”
The answer: “This Dao differs from the worldly Dao. The worldly Dao values fame, profit, love, and affection, while the Dao of cultivation regards them as insignificant. The worldly Dao takes cleverness and quick-wittedness as true, while the Dao of cultivation recognizes them as false. The rich are not benevolent, and the benevolent are not rich—these two are opposed. Thus, the Way of the Immortals is what worldly people are unwilling to pursue; they either deem it foolish or consider it heretical. Great cultivators, outwardly rounded and inwardly square, blend with the俗 and harmonize their light precisely for this reason!”

Someone asked: “Those who cultivate the Dao originally seek to sever worldly ties and leave the dust, with all conditions stilled. Now, to blend with the俗 and harmonize one’s light—does this not risk contamination by worldly dust?”
The answer: “Emptiness, quiescence, and non-action are matters for after obtaining the Elixir. If one practices non-action before obtaining the Elixir, how can the transformations of creation be seized? How can birth and death be transcended? Blending with the俗 and harmonizing one’s light are precisely for seizing the transformations of creation and transcending birth and death! Though one dwells in the俗, one is in truth detached from the俗; though one dwells in the dust, one is in truth beyond the dust. Only after the Great Elixir congeals can one attain emptiness and quiescence without striving for them, and only then can one sever worldly ties and leave the dust. One should not engage with worldly affairs but instead undertake nine years of wall-facing practice to seek liberation.”

[Respectful note: The final sentence of this answer reveals that the master has not yet thoroughly penetrated the *Supreme Heart Tradition*. Otherwise, within the above answer, he would have clearly revealed the reasons for harmonizing one’s light and blending with the俗, thereby allowing seekers to grasp the profound subtleties of true cultivation. Learners of the world would no longer cling to outdated methods, rendering wall-facing unnecessary—would this not be the great prajñā vessel? Alas, why has the master not fully penetrated this? Though he has bequeathed the great method of deep plowing and planting seeds, his strength was insufficient to practice it, and circumstances made it unfeasible. Consider our Patriarch Xue: after the Primordial was broken and the True lost, the Dharma could only be provisionally concealed in bustling metropolises, where the Mysterious Pass was opened wide, its light radiating to gather the scattered Primordial Ones of the world, refining and repairing the *yinqie*. Relying further on immensely wealthy and powerful households, he reverently performed rituals to reach the celestial treasures of the Supreme Heavens, congealing his Sacred Infant and accomplishing this great task. Thereafter, the solitary was no longer alone, and the dual was no mere dual—what concern remained for subsequent matters such as nurturing, nursing, transformation, and pulverization? This secret was not divulged, and the Great Dao remained obscure. Even if the embryo congealed and the embryo emerged, without nine years of wall-facing, pulverizing the empty space would be exceedingly difficult, for the Elixir thus congealed contained falsity within the true! The flaw lay in seeking quick results without attaining the true faith in the state of absolute nothingness. *The True Words of the Dao’s Song* laments that this arduous labor was wasted on the infant, forsaking the broad path to tread the narrow, bird-like trails. Even if one’s practice succeeds, one remains in the state of an ordinary being, and the nine years of nurturing are ultimately inferior to the Sacred Infant’s rank. The *Supreme Heart Tradition* and the Great Dao’s Elixir method advance step by step, refining each stage. This refining means that with each step, the study of life returns to the natural. In its ultimate efficacy, it is to merge with the vast and profound, refining and preserving the semblance of the millet-like pearl—such was the ancient sages’ method. For example, a field of one *mu* yields only about a *shi* of rice, yet the stalks amount to ten loads; after removing the husks and chaff, there remains about a *shi*. Scholars must know that if the sifting is even slightly coarse, how can the field’s rice be edible? Such is the nature of circumstances.]

Thus, the ancient sages in this Dao invariably began with refining the heart, thereby enabling each step to return to the primordial, advancing until reaching the state of "emptiness beyond emptiness" and "stillness beyond stillness," where the primordial Heaven then manifests. When such emptiness and stillness attain spontaneity, the Mysterious Pass opens. Once the Pass opens, one may draw from inexhaustible sources, and the celestial treasures are thereby obtained. In this manner of coalescence, it can gather to form shape or disperse to become qi, rendering the practice of "facing the wall" unnecessary.

Someone asked: "Does the nine-year 'facing the wall' practice necessarily entail nine years of seated meditation?"
The answer: "No. The term 'nine years' signifies the principle of the 'nine returns.' 'Facing the wall' does not mean sitting rigidly; rather, it denotes an undivided focus, a concentration of spirit, aiming to eliminate even the slightest impurity—like a towering cliff standing before one, where nothing is perceived, and all dharmas return to emptiness. This is the method of quietly nurturing the Sacred Infant’s embryonic transformation, not the side practice of seated meditation to still thoughts, nor 'facing the wall' to preserve spirit, nor taking nine years as nine cycles."

[This practice, performed after the return and coalescence of the Elixir, may seem secure, yet few in antiquity expended the immense effort without faltering midway. The *Supreme Heart Tradition* is far more subtle, as it thoroughly fathoms nature to thoroughly fathom life. The ultimate secret within the secrets: thorough penetration of the One and concentration on the One, accumulating the small to form the great—this aligns with the alchemical adage of "one grain upon another grain." The late master, Tai Xu, said: "Plowing deeply, sowing seeds, reaping the harvest, threshing the grain, and exchanging it for silver—this is not yet refined. One must exchange white for yellow, yellow for pearls, and store them in the inner treasury. Through such transformation, the outer treasury becomes empty, thus averting the calamity of thieves. This is the subtle function of exchanging the coarse for the refined." This is the supreme secret of turning being into non-being and returning the illusory to the real. Practicing thus day by day, month by month, year by year, truly accords with the principle of daily and monthly reckoning.

Yet few can adhere to this, accumulating without transmutation, leading to the storage of both refined and coarse together, an excess that cannot be contained. Externally, it invites thieves; internally, it breeds decay—silver turns into sparrows and clams, coins into green flies.]

These are all failures to comprehend the wondrous principle of returning to the primordial! The perfected ones of antiquity proceeded step by step toward emptiness, attaining the utmost spontaneity—thus aligning with the profound concealment of the sagacious merchant. Though their comings and goings were free and unconstrained, they would exchange millions in wealth for something so refined it could not even be grasped in the hand. Hence they could gird themselves with a hundred thousand strings of cash and ride a crane to Yangzhou—desiring release, they were instantly released; desiring transformation, they were instantly transformed. Such is the state of shattering the void to atoms; why labor nine years facing a wall?

Someone asked: "Is this 'infant' the same as the infant of the infant and the maiden?"

The reply: "There is a distinction. The infant of the infant and the maiden is the yang within Kan, the primordial qi stored within the postnatal. The infant of the sacred embryo, however, is the primordial qi itself, emerging from the formless to unite with true mercury and take shape—this is what is called the yang spirit."

Asked: "May we hear of the differing functions of the yang spirit and the yin spirit?"

Replied: "The yin spirit is the postnatal spirit of consciousness, what the *Yinfu Jing* calls 'spirit as spirit.' The yang spirit is the primordial spirit of origin, what the *Yinfu Jing* calls 'non-spirit as spirit.' Spirit as spirit follows the cycle of birth and death—alive, it abides; dead, it departs, becoming the root of karmic rebirth across ten thousand kalpas. Non-spirit as spirit reverses creation, coalescing from the void, unobstructed by birth and death, transcendent and solitary—this is the true seed of immortality and Buddhahood.

The great cultivator refines the primordial and transforms the postnatal, dissolving the karmic roots of rebirth across kalpas to reveal the indestructible vajra spirit of the primordial. They endure as long as heaven and earth, rivaling the sun and moon in brilliance. As for the middle and lower vehicles, ignorant of the primordial, they focus solely on the self, quietly guarding the spirit of consciousness. Should a glimmer of wild wisdom arise, they deem it enlightenment. Yet when the four great elements return to emptiness, the yin spirit, left without support, must seek another dwelling—this is what is meant by 'the root of birth and death through countless kalpas, which the deluded call the original person.'"

[Note in caution: The Buddhist vehicle does not originally regard the spirit of consciousness as the true mind. Later Chan practitioners, misunderstanding the Buddha’s intent, took luminous awareness as mind and cognition as truth—how could this align with Bodhidharma’s teaching of "mind as Buddha"? *The True Words of Singing the Dao* focuses on refining the mind precisely because the mind is the Dao, yet it is occupied by the spirit of consciousness. Thus, one must apply effort to extinguish this consciousness. When consciousness dies, the mind of the Dao appears. The mind of consciousness is the seed of rebirth; the mind of the Dao is the indestructible vajra spirit. The *Vajracchedikā*, *Surangama*, *Avataṃsaka*, and *Śūraṅgama* sutras—when have they ever taken consciousness as real?

To refine the mind while missing the point is the error of later Buddhist students. Yet these later students do not refine the mind at all—they merely follow and guard consciousness, thus falling into delusion, violating the *Śūraṅgama*’s warning that "pure emotion leads to descent." Falling into the trap of following consciousness is entirely at odds with *The True Words of Singing the Dao*’s teaching on refining the mind. To "refine" the mind means to kill consciousness, so that the mind may live! When the mind is unoccupied by consciousness, why would it need refining to become luminous?

Scholars must read with a discerning eye, and every point will align with the teaching. What Wu Yuanzi describes as the learning of the middle and lower vehicles is the practice of following and guarding consciousness, not the practice of extinguishing or killing consciousness. Reflect carefully, and the distinction is self-evident. If scholars read without discernment, they will surely mistake *The True Words of Singing the Dao* as unworthy of practice. Thus, I record these few words as a warning and a wake-up call for later students.

For to follow and guard consciousness is the way of the middle and lower vehicles, while to extinguish and kill consciousness is the path of the supreme vehicle. Though both pertain to the study of the mind, one leads to sagehood, the other to demonhood—scholars, take heed!]

Asked: "What is the origin of the primordial spirit and the spirit of consciousness?"

Replied: "The primordial spirit is the essence of the two fives, born within the chaos of the primordial flood. Neither form nor emptiness, without shape or image, it is formed by the coalescence of the qi of heaven and earth’s yin and yang. At the very beginning of a person’s life, when father and mother’s essence and blood unite in profound darkness, a wisp of creative, misty qi enters the womb. From formlessness, form arises; from imagelessness, images take shape—five senses, hundred bones, four limbs, five viscera—all unfolding spontaneously, without design. Even the parents know not how this comes to be. Within the womb, the primordial spirit of numinous qi is already present, the primordial spirit concealed within it—this is the origin of the primordial spirit.

The spirit of consciousness, however, is the postnatal yin spirit, indestructible across ten thousand kalpas, ceaseless in the cycle of rebirth. Only when the infant emerges from the womb does it enter the apertures, merging with the primordial spirit to become one—this is the origin of the spirit of consciousness."

Asked: "Since the spirit of consciousness merges with the primordial spirit, refining the former is the same as refining the latter. Why then is refining the spirit of consciousness called cultivating one’s own yin?"

Replied: "There is an explanation. At the beginning of life, the spirit of consciousness originally merges with the primordial spirit. But by the age of sixteen, the pure yang body is broken, and the two separate. The primordial qi scatters, the postnatal qi arises, and the spirit of consciousness takes control while the primordial spirit retreats into hiding. Over time, the spirit of consciousness reigns entirely, and the primordial spirit vanishes without a trace. Who, then, sustains life without dying?

If one clings to the self in cultivation, one merely refines this spirit of consciousness. Even if one attains the ability to know past and future, when the house collapses, one must move elsewhere—ultimately, all falls into emptiness and annihilation."

Asked: "Once the primordial scatters, the postnatal takes control..."

"Where does one find the primordial to restore it?"

The master replied: "Though the primordial is obscured by the postnatal, it is not entirely extinguished within it. The ancient immortals said, 'As long as a single thread of yang qi remains, one does not die.' Begin precisely where this undying thread persists—from non-being guard being. What difficulty is there in returning to the root and restoring the original?"

The disciple asked: "The postnatal is a thing of form and image—why call it 'non-being'? The primordial is formless and imageless—why call it 'being'?"

The master replied: "The postnatal, with its forms and images, is a turbid yin thing—possessing the false but not the true, hence 'non-being.' The primordial, formless and imageless, is pure essence—possessing the true without the false, hence 'being.' The alchemical method of 'drawing from Kan to fill Li' is precisely using being to fill non-being."

The disciple asked: "If the primordial is formless and imageless, how can one draw from Kan to fill Li?"

The master replied: "Though qi has no form, its principle is fully present—only that people do not recognize it! If one truly knows, one can shape the insubstantial with the substantial, give form to the formless. Within heaven and earth, the yellow sprout grows, filling the cosmos; the golden flower blooms. Through methodical refinement and gathering, one gradually gathers and tempers it. Once the water is purified and the gold is born, one restores it in due time—what difficulty remains?"

*(The disciple fails to inquire deeply into the true and false, instead questioning the meaning of 'drawing.' The method of drawing from Kan to fill Li is the very essence of returning to the root and restoring the original. Had the disciple pursued the inquiry into being and non-being within Kan and Li to verify truth and falsehood, a great gate would have opened, and a broad path would have appeared. Instead, by fixating on the method of application rather than the nature of the substance, all subsequent inquiries remain trapped in technique. Thus, the true countenance of the primordial remains obscured. If the primordial’s face is unclear, how can one enter the mysterious pass? If the mysterious pass does not open, how can one bear the great union and great encounter? From where, then, does the primordial return? To where does the true essence restore itself?)*

When water is purified, metal is born—this is indeed a matter of timing; yet the root of truth and falsehood remains utterly obscure. How, then, can one discern their true and false countenances? The alchemical methods of past and present have long been difficult to clarify, for the malady lies in abandoning the root to pursue the branches. Within the *Daoist Canon*, there exists the *Scripture of Primordial Dao and Virtue*, whose entirety elucidates the essence of the Dao—yet none have known to study and contemplate it. This scripture’s meaning runs profound, and fortunately, Master Li of Xizhai has provided annotations. I intend to further expound upon it through embodied commentary, yet how many will truly savor its depths? If one were to obtain and reflect upon it, the sequence of before and after would become clear, and truth and falsehood would be distinguished. I intend to employ it as the touchstone in the furnace of discernment.

Alas, my learning is shallow and my talent meager, and my years now verge upon decline. The immortals who abide in this world remain beyond my reach to meet again. When True Master Shen Taixu was still alive, I regrettably never encountered his writings. With doubts unresolved and difficulties unaddressed, I long to annotate and embody its principles for contemplation—yet dare not presume.

---

**Question:** The alchemical path speaks of *fire times* and *effortful practice*. Why then is it said to be "not difficult"?
**Answer:** "Not difficult" refers to the moment of obtaining the medicine. What is truly difficult lies in the subtleties of the *fire times*. Thus, the *Awakening to Reality* states:
*"Though you recognize cinnabar and black lead,
Without the fire times, all is in vain.
It all depends on the power of cultivation—
A hair’s breadth amiss, and the elixir fails to form."*
If the *fire times* are precise and the effort exquisitely refined, it is indeed not difficult.

*(The subtleties of the fire times manifest in ineffable states when the moment arrives. If one grasps the meaning of harmony, not a hair’s breadth will err. But if one remains ignorant of the foundational secret of establishing oneself in the primordial, one will often miss the opportunity even when it stands before them. If the root of the Great Dao remains unclear and the arising of the medicine goes unrecognized, then even if one knows the fire times, one merely engages in empty practice. My heart laments this, and so I speak of it here.)*

---

**Question:** If it is said that the medicine is obtained in a single moment, then the *fire times* and effortful practice seem unnecessary. Why then speak of their exquisite refinement?
**Answer:** "In a single moment" refers to the effect of obtaining the medicine. The *fire times*, however, pertain to the work of cultivation. Returning the elixir is easiest; refining the self is hardest. The sages condense years into months, months into days, and days into hours. Within this single hour, they mobilize their spiritual power, gather the medicine into the crucible, and coalesce the three-hundred-day embryo in an instant—this is the easiest part. Yet if the refinement of the self is not diligent and the *fire times* not meticulous, then when lead arrives, mercury fails to greet it; when Kan comes, Li does not receive it; when the other arrives, I am not prepared—inevitably, one misses the opportunity face-to-face, gaining only to lose again.

*(Know that refining the self is refining the heart. No method surpasses the* Singing the Dao’s True Words*. That this text serves as the compass of alchemical scriptures is precisely because it contains these essentials of self-refinement. If one thoroughly contemplates this book and integrates it with insight, the path to celestial immortality is complete. Such was the legacy of my late master, the Venerable Taixu.)*

"How does one know when the other arrives and I am prepared?"
"Without knowing, how can one be prepared? The *Most High* says:
*Vague, oh—elusive, oh—within it there is something;
Dim, oh—obscure, oh—within it there is essence.
Its essence is most true, within it there is certainty.*

This *something* is no ordinary thing—it is the medicinal substance.
This *essence* is no turbid essence—it is true essence.
This *true* is no common truth—it is celestial truth.
This *certainty* is no ordinary certainty—it is real certainty.
When this certainty arrives, the tiger roars and wind arises; the dragon chants and clouds gather.
The great cultivator, at this moment, drives the dragon to the tiger, unites the tiger with the dragon, gathers them into the *Yellow Court’s earthen crucible*, and binds them to form the elixir.
This celestial mechanism lies near at hand for those who awaken to it; for those who remain deluded, it is a thousand miles away."

*(Note: This "vague-elusive, dim-obscure," the wind arising and clouds gathering—all are wondrous states within the process. Yet if the *Mysterious Pass* does not open, these wondrous states will not appear; if the refinement of the self is incomplete, the aperture opens but one remains unaware. If one does not place body and mind prior to the *prior-heaven*, one does not even know what refinement is. To place body and mind prior to the *prior-heaven*, begin with the Six Fasts. After completing the Six Fasts, proceed to fast the heart. During this fasting of the heart, the work naturally advances—without movement or stillness, without direction or place—one attains the true realm of the natural and wondrous state. The *Pass* stands open, like a bright gauze veil in empty space, every pore perpetually open, yet stillness remains as before, and the gauze veil dissolves. Before one’s eyes, one is already within it—utterly without exit or entrance, where is there inside or outside? When the work reaches this point, layer upon layer of wondrous states manifest without concealment. I merely abide in *not-having having*, *not-being without*—only reflecting inwardly, where the inner is as the outer. By solely concentrating on emptiness and stillness, this is what is meant by the *function of the wondrous function*—never erring in its midst. Thus spoke my late master, the Venerable Taixu, and this suffices as a supplement to the answer, hence I record it here.)*

"How is the *Yellow Court’s earthen crucible* the same as the *Central Palace’s Yellow Court Cavity*?"
"This is the true earth that gathers the Five Phases and harmonizes the Four Images—formless and imageless—unlike the tangible, locatable *Yellow Court* within the body. Specifically in the Dao of the elixir, the *Yellow Court* transcends existence and non-existence, unbound by direction or place.
From the perspective of *gathering the medicine*, it is called the *Yellow Matron*;
from the perspective of *refining the medicine*, it is called the *earthen crucible*;
from the perspective of *forming the embryo*, it is called the *Yellow Court*.
The *Yellow Matron* harmonizes yin and yang.
The *earthen crucible* smelts lead and mercury.
The *Yellow Court* quietly nourishes the *Valley Spirit*.
If one mistakes the *post-heaven Yellow Court Cavity* for the true, how can it harmonize yin and yang, refine lead and mercury, or nourish the *Valley Spirit*?
Lu Ziye said: *‘True earth has no position; true intention has no form.’* Does this not refer to the *Yellow Court’s earthen crucible*?"

"If this earth has no position and true intention has no form, does the congealing of the sacred embryo also lack position?"
"‘No position’ refers to the moment of gathering the medicine. When forming the embryo, yin and yang unite, and earth resides within. The *Yellow Center* penetrates principle, rightfully occupying the body—all merging into a single qi. The *Elixir Root* takes form: though without position, it truly has position. Yet this position is not the position of clinging to emptiness or grasping at appearances. It remains formless, though distinguished by movement and stillness."

"Earth is inherently still—why now speak of movement? Does this not verge on the artificial?"
"This is no ordinary movement or stillness of earth, but the movement and stillness of *prior-heaven true earth*.
Movement pertains to yang—it is the *outer Yellow Matron*;
stillness pertains to yin—it is the *inner Yellow Matron*.
The *outer Yellow Matron* facilitates the harmony of the two families, hence it moves without position;
the *inner Yellow Matron* transmits the passage of the moment, hence it is still with position.
Movement gathers the medicine.
Stillness refines the medicine.
Without movement, how can the *prior-heaven qi* be summoned?
Without stillness, how can the *prior-heaven qi* congeal into the embryo?
This is the distinction between inner and outer, the division of movement and stillness."

"Does the function of earth have inner and outer aspects? Does the function of the Four Images also have inner and outer aspects?"
"Four Images with earth make Five Phases.
The *outer Five Phases* gather the *prior-heaven* to complete destiny.
The *inner Five Phases* perfect the *post-heaven* to complete nature.
Completing both inner and outer is the Dao of dual cultivation of nature and destiny."

"Nature pertains to the inner, destiny to the outer—does this mean the body has no destiny?"
"Heaven uses yin and yang, the Five Phases, to transform and generate the myriad things. Qi forms the body, and principle is also inherent. Qi is destiny; principle is nature. Qi does not depart from principle; principle does not depart from qi. Thus nature does not depart from destiny; destiny does not depart from nature—how can there be nature without destiny?"

"If the body already has destiny, then cultivating the body fulfills destiny—why seek elsewhere?"
"Destiny belongs to the *prior-heaven*; nature to the *post-heaven*. Since the *prior-heaven qi* has scattered, destiny is deficient. If one clings to cultivating the self alone, what is cultivated is empty nature; if one clings to cultivating the body alone, what is cultivated is turbid substance. Even if one preserves the present qi without loss, how can one retrieve the already-lost qi and restore it? One must employ the *immortal method of the other*—this is how one summons the lost measure of qi!"

"The *prior-heaven qi* is formless and imageless—once lost, it is gone! How can it be summoned back?"

The Master replied: "The secret transmitted orally and imparted mind-to-mind by the Patriarchs resides precisely here—this is the Dao passed down once in ten thousand kalpas. Where a thing is lost, there it must be retrieved. The *prior-heaven qi* was lost through the advent of the *one yin* in *Gu* (Encountering); now it must be summoned back at the very point where the *one yin* in *Gu* arises. Thus, the thing is present, requiring no external search—it may be obtained as readily as reaching out one’s hand. As the *Book of Changes* states, ‘Return is not distant when one cultivates the self’—this is the meaning. Nevertheless, to summon the *prior-heaven*, nothing is more vital than finding the right person. Without such a person, the *prior-heaven* cannot be restored. As Zi Ye said:

*The medicine emerges from the southwest, the *Kun* position—*
*To seek the *Kun* position, how could one depart from the person?*
*Clearly spoken, you must remember,*
*Lest you meet yet fail to recognize truly.*

Without the oral transmission of an enlightened teacher, how could one easily discern this medicine, this person?"

The *prior-heaven qi* is the true yin and true yang of the *prior-heaven* *Taiji*, the qi generated by their union. In Heaven, it is called *Qian*’s origin; on Earth, *Kun*’s origin; in humanity, the true origin, also called the human origin. The qi of the Three Powers is called *origin*; the principle they receive is called *oneness*. *Origin* is destiny; *oneness* is nature. Destiny is the self; nature is the other. Originally one thing, one kind, one family, they are forcibly named differently only because each has its own embodied locus—hence the terms *origin* and *oneness*, *principle* and *qi*, *nature* and *destiny*, *self* and *other*, *yin* and *yang*, *dragon* and *tiger*, and so on. In truth, they are but one Dao. Yet later learners, clinging to names and debating forms, have splintered into myriad fixed views, their minds and eyes obscured, and heterodox teachings have spread. Even the worthy cannot but be confused, for the root of this error lies in the *Celestial Statutes*’ provision on ‘reckless transmission bringing calamity.’ The ancient perfected ones, without exception, trusted the ancients, and thus their writings often concealed truths, inadvertently providing heterodox teachers with evidence. My teacher, Master Taixu, took pity on this and recorded a passage from the oral transmission of the Vinaya School:

"Venerable Lü Jing was attending Master Qiu Changchun in the *Yanbo Hall* one night when the Master explained the saying, ‘Lost through the person, sought through the person.’ He said: ‘This is the oral secret transmitted by our Patriarch, Emperor Zhengyang. These two instances of *person* must not be conflated. The first *person* refers to human affairs; the second, to the human origin. It means that the *prior-heaven qi*, scattered through human affairs, cannot be recovered. Only by seeking the origin in the *Taiji* can the origin be restored without fail. Know that the three origins in the world all root in the *Taiji*. In Heaven, it is the celestial origin; on Earth, the terrestrial origin; in humanity, the human origin. If the human origin is lost yet not sought within the self, how can it be restored? Thus it is said: *Lost through the person, sought through the person.* Moreover, there is a subtle technique called *placing the seed*, devised by earlier sages. One must place one’s body and mind prior to the *prior-heaven*, whereby not only is the origin restored, but oneness follows. I then await it in emptiness, congealing it in stillness—this is the profound function of the two phrases.’

The Vinaya Master asked: ‘Then why is there the saying about the *Kun* direction and the undying person?’ The Master replied: ‘The origin resides in *Kun*, which nurtures the myriad things, upon which the Three Powers depend—hence it is called the Gate of Life. This means the origin dwells in *Kun*, for *Kun* occupies the southwest, and *Kun* possesses the virtue of nurturing and completing. *Kun* is also called the Human Gate because humanity is the chief of the myriad things—hence the name Human Gate. It is called *undying* because while things arise and perish, the origin neither arises nor perishes, and *Kun* too relies on it for stability. The earlier sages, recognizing that it harbors the origin of life, thus named it the *undying method*. Furthermore, since things receive life by dwelling in *Kun*, and humanity is also a thing, it is called the *undying person of the Kun direction*. Here, *person* does not mean immortal or Buddha, but refers to the human origin—it must not be mistaken for an ordinary person. If one comprehends this and awaits it in emptiness and stillness, the *prior-heaven* origin will be instantly restored. Once restored, the origin congeals of itself—what need is there for a furnace? What need for a crucible? Moreover, the furnace and crucible are metaphors of the ancient sages. The world, failing to understand, has spawned all manner of heterodox interpretations.’"

This is recorded in the *Pillow Secrets of the Vinaya School*. I note that the Master’s answer here—"*nothing is more vital than finding the right person*"—and his statement that "*qi* was lost through the advent of the *one yin* in *Gu* and must be summoned back at the very point where the *one yin* in *Gu* arises"—these are more than sufficient to serve as evidence for heterodox teachers. Thus, I have recorded my teacher’s transmission to supplement what this answer lacks. Moreover, is the loss of the human origin solely due to union with yin? Buddhist scriptures record losses through "emitting essence with the hand"; the *Treatise on Abstaining from Lust* speaks of losses through "external fondness for *Longyang*"; medical texts describe losses through "nocturnal emission." To say "one must seek restoration at the point of loss" and "the originally lost thing is present and easily restored"—if, as I have described, one seeks the original thing in its original place, there would be no way to recover it. Only as my teacher explained—it comes from the *Taiji* and returns to the *Taiji*—thus, if I seek restoration, I must welcome it from the *Taiji*. This principle is utterly correct and true. However, in the Master’s answer, "*Lost from where it was lost, sought from where it was lost*," the word *person* was mistakenly rendered as *where* by later disciples of the Vinaya School—a critical error. Readers must examine this carefully. Since the Master titled his book *Disputations and Difficulties*, these two characters cannot go unexamined. Let the reader discern this.

In the autumn of the *renzi* year of the Qianlong reign, I sought the utmost Dao from the earth-dwelling immortal Huang Shouzhong. At the time, the immortal was over five hundred years old, having been born in the Song dynasty. He entered China during the early Yuan and was a Yuezhi person. In the twelfth year of the Shunzhi reign, he received the Three Great Precepts from the eminent scholar Master Kunyang Wang. He said: "Where does one obtain human nature and destiny, and where does one seek what has been lost? Without the mind-to-mind transmission, how can one return?"

Yet human nature and destiny possess a sequence of prior and posterior. The prior-heaven nature and destiny disperse and return to the Wuji. The posterior-heaven nature and destiny disperse and return to Heaven and Earth. Though Heaven and Earth are vast, they are but the posterior of the Wuji. The formless nature and destiny of the human body derive from the Wuji. The posterior-heaven nature and destiny of the human body take shape from father and mother—these are the Three Treasures of form. Thus, when lost, they revert to Earth and Heaven, as the saying goes: "The *hun* ascends to Heaven, the *po* descends to Earth."

The perfected ones of antiquity, having lost both prior and posterior, sought their reunion in the Wuji as one, for the Wuji encompasses the qi of both prior and posterior. The method of seeking in quiescence lies in emptying and stilling this colored body, in deep stillness of this dharma-body. Thus, one summons without summoning, gathers without gathering, coalesces without coalescing—only following its spontaneity. For in spontaneity, qi fuses the Three Powers. Though the Three Powers are three, their qi is one—fundamentally without going or coming, without being or non-being, without movement or stillness, without birth or extinction. It cannot be named, yet by force of naming, it is called the Taiji.

Men say the Wuji gives birth to the Taiji, but in truth, from the Taiji arises the bounded and the boundless. Thus is it called the Taiji. If so, then Wuji and Taiji share the relation of ancestor and descendant, concealing within them the wondrous function of overcoming to give life—this is the alchemical work of return and reversion.

I heard this also from my former Vinaya master. There is yet deeper plowing and planting, the illusory hooking of mysteries, the great enactment of great function.

This is no mere oath sworn by sea or mountain—none dare transmit it by word alone. Yet it is achieved through nothing beyond the single method of "silent seeking." The immortals who abide in the world, the patriarchs who uphold the precepts, and the profound discourses all proceed thus. Yet this supreme Dao of the Golden Elixir is preserved and practiced only within our Vinaya tradition. Though the external schools and sects possess libraries stacked to the rafters, none match the mind-to-mind transmission of Vinaya masters Shen and Huang—it is merely *as if* they do. Not that it has never been heard, but rather that none dare divulge it.

Someone asked: "Life and nature are my own life and nature; cultivation depends on oneself, and no other can take one’s place. Now you speak of ‘not departing from the person’—does this mean seeking from another?"

I answered: "This person is no outsider, but the deathless one—none other than the original True Person. The ancient immortals said: ‘If you wish for a person not to die, you must seek the deathless person.’ This is called the Golden Duke. The Golden Duke was originally a thing of my own household, yet it wandered astray into another’s home and, deluded, did not return. What remains in my household is pure yin alone. If one clings to this solitary yin in cultivation, how can it avail? Thus one must summon back the Golden Duke. Only when it is paired with my Wooden Mother can the medicine be born and the elixir congealed."

[Note to the answer: Master Wuyuan has spoken plainly here.]

Yet without reflecting further upon these additional elucidations, the principle remains profoundly elusive. When it is said "the deathless person," again "the original True Person," and further, "the Golden Duke was originally a thing of my own household, yet wandered astray into another’s home—it must be summoned back to avail," how perfectly clear! This speaks of the primordial qi having departed into the realm of Non-Ultimate, hence the need to call it back. Should one cling to the notion of "self" and "other" as corporeal forms, doubts will arise on all sides.

I find Master Wuyuan’s answer—"paired with my Wooden Mother"—still lacking in precision. According to the oral transmission of the Perfected Huang, when one’s primordial nature strays, not only does the Golden Duke flee, but the Wooden Mother must also depart in full. What remains in the body—one’s heart-mind and spirit—are but the handmaids and concubines of the Golden Duke. The proper method is to summon back the Golden Duke, welcome home the Wooden Mother, and restore the household’s prosperity—only then does it accord with the profound meaning.

For when a deluded thought arises, the spirit scatters, the qi disperses, and essence inevitably leaks—there has never been a case where qi disperses yet the spirit does not flee or essence does not leak. Thus, both the primordial nature and life-force are no longer at home. What remains in the household is merely the acquired nature and life-force, hence it is called "pure yin." Therefore, I say one must summon back the Golden Duke and welcome home the Wooden Mother, so that metal and wood unite, and the Way of ceaseless generation is complete. If the Wooden Mother does not return, the calamity of fanning flames will not cease, and the Golden Duke can never rest in peace.

Master Wuyuan omitted this crucial point, leaving a gap in the canon, which I have thus supplemented.

---

**Question:** "How is the Golden Duke summoned back?"

**Answer:** "Summoning it is quite simple; the difficulty lies only in failing to recognize it. If one truly recognizes it, a single call brings it instantly—like an echo in an empty valley, it cannot but respond. The Golden Duke departed because I grew distant and neglected it. Now, knowing it as the savior of life, one cherishes and loves it, and it returns home at once, without the slightest effort."

[One must understand: the Golden Duke’s departure was due to usurping ministers seizing power, seductive consorts fanning flames, and the Wooden Mother’s full retreat, leaving the Golden Duke shrouded in dust and shame. The secret lies in expelling the treacherous ministers, welcoming back the Wooden Mother, and purifying the palace’s governance—only then can the royal business be restored, and the Golden Duke will surely grace us with its presence. That it requires "no effort" is the Way of dual cultivation of nature and life. In practice, it is nothing more than quieting the heart-mind, settling the qi, and attaining profound emptiness and stillness, reaching the utmost sincerity to arrive at spontaneity. Then, the governance of this palace and the court will be cleansed and solemn, the Golden Duke will come of its own accord, and the Wooden Mother will return naturally. Should even the slightest discriminating thought arise, future calamities will follow.

Master Wuyuan’s answer did not touch upon this, for he missed the initial step of welcoming back the Wooden Mother and instead fell into the trap of recognition, which does not fully align with the Great Dao of the Golden Elixir. Thus, I have respectfully supplemented this to enlighten the wise.]

---

**Question:** "Once the Golden Duke is summoned back, can one immediately receive life?"

**Answer:** "Not yet. The Golden Duke’s return is but the true seed arriving in hand. From this point, one must apply solid effort and cultivate in a timely manner. When the yellow sprout emerges, warm and nurture it until it ripens, then ingest and consume it—only then can life be grasped."

[I once heard of the world-abiding immortal Zhang Pengtou—Zhang being his adopted surname, the son of the Ming loyalist Qu Shisi—who came to Jin’gai during the Jiaqing era, appearing as a man of thirty. I had long heard of his name! Thus, I inquired of him regarding the lineages of the Yin-Yang school, seeking to determine which was the authentic one.]

The immortal replied, "Your master, Grand Void Elder, must have already instructed you—why do you ask me?"

I knelt and pleaded, "Indeed. My master said there are those who attain it from the Great Void, those who attain it from bustling metropolises, those who attain it from the alchemical chamber, those who attain it from altars and oratories, and even those who attain it from the alchemical seat—yet none of these are heterodox paths."

The immortal said, "Those who attain it from the Great Void take the Great Void as their Dharma-body and the Three Powers as their medicinal substances—this is the supreme vehicle of the highest order. Those who attain it from bustling metropolises take the Six Directions as their Dharma-body and living tigers and dragons, the materials of qi-transformation, as their medicinal substances. Those who attain it from the alchemical chamber take the Dharma-body as their crucible and enclosure, also using dragons and tigers as seed and medium, thereby attracting the substance born of the union of Yin and Yang in the Supreme Ultimate, drawing it with intention into the Yellow Court as the foundation of the elixir. Those who attain it from altars and oratories take the alchemical chamber as their crucible and enclosure, and the Dharma-body as the mysterious aperture. They refine tigers and dragons with method, congeal spirit in the alchemical chamber, and draw it into the mysterious aperture to produce the True One. Some retain the One to pair with the primordial, making it their seed; others use tigers and dragons as mediums to unite Yin and Yang of the Supreme Ultimate, congealing spirit in the alchemical chamber, from which tigers and dragons also generate. They retain the one born of the union of the Supreme Ultimate and return the primordial One generated by tigers and dragons. The One is returned to the dragon, the primordial to the tiger, each silently returning to its place and abiding—all belong to the supreme vehicle. Below this, there are still the middle and lower vehicles, which your master did not speak of.

Follow my instructions and practice: empty your heart, still your spirit, forget your qi. If your worldly wealth is abundant, your attainment will surely be rich. If you wish to pursue this, cultivate virtue first—great virtue brings great fortune. Heaven reveals this wondrous Dao to deliver one and thereby aid the myriad. If your aspiration is merely long life, Heaven may not necessarily look upon you with favor. Proceed according to your own capacity."

I then bowed and received his teaching. On that day, clouds of five colors wove a canopy, dispersing only after some time. The immortal master pointed and instructed, "Young one, take heed! Today’s affair has already moved the celestial spirits to witness it. Why not record it in writing to await the proper time for transmitting it to the world?"

I now append this to the answers above, moved by my master’s grace and daring not to keep it for myself. I only hope that those of aspiration will quiet their minds, embody this in practice, and find great fortune in it.

I asked, "In the Way of grasping life, is there a principle of inherent nature?"

The answer came, "If one cannot cultivate inherent nature, how can one establish life? For nature is the abode of life, and life is the dwelling of nature—nature and life are originally one family. How can one not cultivate nature?"

I asked, "If nature and life are one family, then completing life should complete nature. Why then is there a saying that after cultivating life, one must still cultivate nature?"

The answer came, "The nature cultivated while cultivating life is the nature endowed by Heaven. The nature cultivated after cultivating life is the nature of emptiness and nothingness. The nature endowed by Heaven comes from Yin and Yang; the nature of emptiness and nothingness comes from the Supreme Ultimate. They cannot be regarded in the same way."

I asked, "In cultivating the nature of emptiness and nothingness, is there a regimen of fire and timing?"

The answer came, "The principle of cultivating nature is to preserve the Dao in its entirety, embracing the One and practicing non-action. Though called non-action, it involves the work of guarding against danger and considering peril—it is not the doctrine of complete quiescence and annihilation. Thus, one may return to the realm of True Suchness and wondrous enlightenment."

[The principle of cultivating nature depends solely on sharpness or dullness—there is originally no regimen of fire and timing to speak of. If others advance by one, you advance by a hundred; if others advance by ten, you advance by a thousand. Without clarity and thoroughness, there is no end to the principle.]

Great clarity and thorough enlightenment—how could one dare the slightest negligence? For destiny has its limits, while the nature knows no bounds. If even limits do not exist, how could there be a regimen of fire and timing?

To cite the Buddhist sutras as proof: Avalokiteśvara’s luminous perception illuminates the great chiliocosm as if gazing at the lines upon his palm. The Buddha of the Lotus Edge (Padmaśrī) perceives the three-thousandfold great chiliocosm just as clearly. The radiance of their natures may be called supreme! Yet when compared to Vairocana Tathāgata, they are but a single petal upon his thousand-petaled lotus throne—thus, the Buddha of the Lotus Edge still lacks nine hundred and ninety-nine petals. From this, one may awaken to the truth that the nature has no bounds. How, then, could there be a regimen of fire and timing to speak of?

I asked, "When one returns to the realm of True Suchness and wondrous enlightenment, has one reached the ultimate end of the Dao?"

The answer came, "Not yet. Only when the void itself is shattered is the matter truly settled. If one takes the void as the goal, the void still remains—this cannot be called the ultimate end."

[This "ultimate end" refers to the nearness of destiny’s principles. But in terms of the Dao, neither destiny nor nature has any limit. As the Buddhist sutras attest, the four great continents may be concealed within a grain of millet, and a mustard seed may contain them all. Spoken in dispersion: the number of worlds is as countless as the sands of the Ganges, and each grain of sand holds within it billions upon billions of Ganges’ sands. Both the number of worlds and the Dao itself are without end! Thus, the dedicated cultivator refines without cease. To speak of limits is to render one’s accumulated virtue and merit utterly insignificant.]

I asked, "Having heard of cultivating destiny before nature, why is there also the teaching of cultivating nature before destiny?"

The answer came, "This refers to gradual refinement after sudden awakening. For humans receive qi in varying degrees of purity, and the roots of their natures differ in sharpness. Those whose qi is pure and whose nature-root is keen, upon encountering a master’s instruction, suddenly awaken to perfect comprehension—they recognize their original face before birth. Steadfast and sure, they never abandon the work of gradual refinement, preserving this very face. This is what is meant by cultivating destiny through nature.

As for those whose qi is turbid and whose nature-root is dull, even with a master’s instruction, they cannot immediately see through to the truth. Thus, they must proceed from gradual to sudden, from effort to ease. This is what is meant by cultivating nature through destiny."

I asked, "Is the Dao of cultivating destiny the work of gradual refinement?"

The answer came, "The primordial qi dissipates gradually. To restore it, one must also proceed gradually. As *Awakening to Reality* states: *It all depends on the power of cultivation—even a hair’s difference will fail to produce the elixir.* And an ancient immortal said: *Without shared words, they are no kin; without sufficient effort, nothing attains perfection.* Both speak of the work of gradual refinement."

"Asked: *'True fire has no fixed timing, and the great elixir is not measured by weight. If one obtains the true oral instructions and cultivates single-mindedly, how could there be error?'*

Answered: *'True fire has no fixed timing' means it does not rigidly adhere to the hours of zi and wu; 'the great elixir is not measured by weight' means that without sufficient effort, nothing attains perfection. Without fixed timing for zi and wu, one advances or retreats, adapting to the moment—no set schedule can determine it. Without sufficient effort, nothing attains perfection: one gathers and refines, nurturing qi and preserving spirit—no weight or measure can limit it. Yet the great Dao of the golden elixir is most subtle and minute, with layers of auspicious and inauspicious moments, of fullness and restraint, of youth and age, of urgency and slowness. One cannot but proceed with utmost caution.*

Asked: *'May I hear the principles of auspicious and inauspicious moments, of fullness and restraint, of youth and age, of urgency and slowness?'*

Answered: *Returning to the primordial is auspicious; following the acquired is inauspicious. When the elixir has ripened, that is fullness—where the firing process is complete, one should stop. When the elixir’s qi has just arisen, it is young; when the elixir’s qi has passed, it is old. Before obtaining the elixir, one should act with urgency; after obtaining it, one should proceed with slowness. One who understands this may restore the elixir, form the embryo, and wield reversal and compliance—all will be as desired.*

Asked: *'The Dao of the primordial is the reverse Dao—why speak of compliance?'*

Answered: *Reversal is how one steals the primordial qi to return to yang. Compliance is how one completes the work of the acquired to retreat from yin. Returning yang and penetrating yin, one follows the primordial without opposing Heaven, and follows the acquired in accord with Heaven’s timing.*

Asked: *'The primordial qi is also born of Heaven and Earth—why does Heaven not oppose me?'*

Answered: *Though qi is born of Heaven and Earth, the perfected person can establish the self before Heaven and Earth, awaiting its arising to immediately gather it, so that Heaven and Earth remain unaware. Thus, the top line of the *Bo* hexagram in the *Book of Changes* says: *'The great fruit is not eaten.'* It preserves that one yang, halting its advance to serve as the root of return—this is what is called the study of the primordial.*

Asked: *'Bo means yin stripping away yang—how can one return to yang through Bo?'*

Answered: *Bo is the transformative work of Heaven and Earth proceeding in compliance, leaving one yang without advancing. The sage’s transformative work proceeds in reversal: through Bo to return to Fu, within the acquired to restore the primordial, employing the six lines without being employed by them. This is to borrow yin to rescue yang! Its mechanism of theft is unknown and unseen by all under Heaven.*

Asked: *'The Dao exists between Heaven and Earth, radiant and upright—why speak of theft?'*

Answered: *Heaven bestows upon humans their allotted qi and years—yet it is but a temporary loan. If borrowed too long, repayment is demanded. Thus, Heaven and Earth, taking advantage of human unawareness, secretly steal their qi—when it is exhausted, death follows. The perfected person, deeply understanding the workings of transformation, does not wait for qi to be spent but, seizing Heaven and Earth’s unawareness, reverses the theft to steal their qi, prolonging life and enhancing vitality. If one does not steal but openly takes, Heaven and Earth will become aware; even if one reverses and controls them, and by good fortune succeeds, one has already lost the true and obtained the false.*"

"Thus it is said: what can be seen cannot be used, and what can be used cannot be seen. Only by placing oneself prior to Heaven does Heaven and Earth fall within one’s artifice, and nothing remains beyond one’s use."

[This response, though not original, still clings to the mundane interpretation of the word "stealing." If we follow the *Three Sovereigns’ Esoteric Exegesis of Characters*, its meaning becomes far more refined. The term "stealing" (盗) derives from "objects placed beside a vessel" (物次于皿). "次" means "to store," like a nation’s treasury or a household’s granary. In Heaven, it is the Wuji; in the body, it is the Mysterious Cavity. The perfected person conceals its name, hence calling it "stealing." Interpreting the character thus seems more stable and apt.

As for Heaven and Earth’s bestowal of qi upon humans—qi has no sound or form, emerging naturally. When a person dies, qi returns; it reverts to its origin, and Heaven and Earth reclaim it, all by natural course. There is no intent to take or demand; to say "Heaven and Earth take advantage of human unawareness to seize it" is a flawed phrasing, lingering in the rhetorical habits of the *Masters’ Texts* school.

Moreover, from the perspective of the Dao, the Three Powers are not merely one family but a single qi, without exit or entry, without taking or giving. To speak of gain or loss is merely human conjecture. The perfected person sees it thus: the Three Powers are one with me, the Six Directions are one with my heart, and every thing and being is stored within the Wuji. There is no gain or loss, no taking or discarding, no coarse or refined, and no division between inner and outer treasuries.

Yet what is stored has its place, and the steward of storage has its office. Taking and giving are the same: it is like drawing gold from the treasury, a painting from the hall, a horse from the stable, a robe from the chest, tools from the shed, grain from the granary, food from the kitchen, or firewood from the yard. Each has its keeper, and whether one takes or gives, it is but a matter of will—no need for commands or gestures.

If one returns to the state prior to Heaven in this way, what difficulty remains? Herein lies the intent of "desiring benevolence and attaining it." The trouble is that scholars do not fully exhaust their own minds! What stinginess, what greed, what seizure, what demand could there be? To say "Heaven and Earth are unaware" may seem so, but to claim they "fall within one’s artifice" is a grave error. To reduce the great Dao of returning to the transformations of creation to a mere "artifice" is to remain trapped in the methods of the *Masters’ Texts* school.

Furthermore, the term "awareness" (觉) is the essential principle of all cultivation practices. When cultivation reaches completion, it is nothing more than perfect awareness. When one places oneself prior to the prior Heaven, silently awaiting the moment of qi’s emergence, it is precisely when the initial form of qi—known as the Yellow Sprout—becomes usable. This is not a matter of exploiting Heaven and Earth’s unawareness to carry out theft.

When a person’s desires scatter and primordial qi flees, the Creator gathers it back into the Wuji—this is the Creator’s love for the Dao, akin to leaves returning to their roots. If one knows to return and seek self-restoration, it is as natural as eating when hungry or drinking when thirsty before one’s parents—no need to calculate or take. Such is the principle.

Once mixed with the methods of the *Masters’ Texts* school, the majestic teachings of the classics devolve into cunning and deceit. A hair’s breadth of error leads to a thousand miles of deviation—how can one not be cautious in phrasing?]

Asked: *"Humans are born bearing the qi of Heaven and Earth’s yin and yang and the Five Phases—thus, we are but one thing among many in the world. How can we surpass Heaven? How can Heaven fall within our artifice?"*

Answered: *"The sage surpasses Heaven because they possess the Dao that encompasses Heaven and Earth. To encompass Heaven and Earth is to operate inversely beyond them, thus ensuring that my fate is determined by me, not by Heaven."*

[This explanation has its basis, yet the reason for "being able to surpass" remains insufficiently revealed—it is but a provisional account. Scholars must understand that the emergence of the Three Powers stems from the Supreme Ultimate. The Two Great Forces and humanity alike receive the same Dao. The Two Great Forces take non-intent as their essence, while humans employ intent as their function.

Originally, the transformations of creation entrust non-intent to the Two Great Forces and intent to humans because we dwell between them. Thus, the reversal of creation, the rise and fall of worldly fortunes—Heaven and Earth merely oversee their completion. This rise and fall follows the natural flow of qi. When the world waxes and wanes, the course of fortune loses its way. The power over fortune’s course lies with humanity, not the Two Great Forces.

If one models oneself on the Dao, and the Dao models itself on spontaneity, one can calmly observe the arrival of qi’s mechanisms: where it is deficient, replenish it; where it is excessive, reduce it. Whether the qi is firm or yielding, strong or weak, warm or cool, dry or moist, stagnant or unrestrained—whatever mechanism arrives, one ensures it attains harmony without bias. Then, life and death are timely, advance and retreat are fitting. Applying this to ordering fortune, fortune prospers; applying it to refining the elixir, the elixir coalesces. This fulfills the duty entrusted to humanity by the Dao.

Heaven and Earth rely on this to maintain their positions; the myriad things rely on it to flourish. Because this principle exists, humans are also called a "power," standing alongside the Two Great Forces as one of the Three. If cultivators grasp this principle, they will embody the Dao with every thought, allowing no trace of selfishness, emulating the ancient sages without belittling themselves or betraying their hearts.

With this intent, the Creator entrusts governance of the world to humanity—not for the sake of the individual, but because it is the Supreme Ultimate’s own possession, now stored within us. Hence, it is said: "Humanity is the heart of Heaven and Earth."

The rise and fall of worldly fortunes are determined by humanity; Heaven and Earth have no part in it. Since humanity bears this duty, when even a single person remains unsaved, it is as if they are flogged in the marketplace—this is the Confucians’ charge. To ferry all beings across is the task of Buddhism and Daoism. Truly, this is our duty and responsibility.]

The Master’s response pertains to the expedient teachings of the postcelestial realm, not to the canonical scriptures—this distinction must not go unexamined. Moreover, though humans dwell within the Six Directions, minute as a grain of millet in the vast ocean, by virtue of possessing this heart and bearing this duty, the sages of antiquity undertook it without the slightest hesitation. They truly saw that this heart is the primordial unity within the primordial qi of Heaven and Earth—vast beyond all bounds, minute beyond all measure. In the Dao, it is called the *Dao-heart*; in Buddhism, the *Buddha-heart*; in Confucianism, the *Heavenly Heart*. It is not the fleshy organ of the heart, which merely generates blood. As for the "Heaven" in the saying "human determination overcomes Heaven," this refers to the postcelestial, not the precelestial. When it is said that the Dao proceeds in reverse, it does not mean opposing the Dao itself, but reversing course to return to the origin. This aligns with the *Zuozhuan*’s use of *ni* ("to meet" or "reverse") in "to meet the bride"—yet if one misapplies the term *shu* (technique) to the operation of the Dao, it may mislead later generations, hence this clarification.

Someone asked: "May we hear of the Way by which human effort overcomes Heaven?"

The Master replied: "The Dao is the precelestial qi of emptiness and nothingness, the root of generating Heaven, Earth, and the myriad things. The sage’s work plants its foot in emptiness and nothingness, and thus Heaven does not oppose them. Observe the people of the world: some are fated to be orphaned, widowed, short-lived, or impoverished. Yet if they perform a great virtue or establish a great deed, the orphaned or widowed may instead have many descendants, the short-lived may attain longevity, and the impoverished may gain wealth and honor. If virtue alone can thus overcome Heaven, how much less surprising is it that the Dao overcomes Heaven?"

The answer given is correct, yet it does not fully elucidate the Way by which human effort overcomes Heaven. Why not clearly expound the sage’s work of planting its foot in emptiness?

This qi arises from the Great Ultimate, fundamentally without egress or ingress—how could it have coming or going? It responds only to human stimulus. The qi itself harbors no intent, yet its circulation waxes and wanes; the stimulus bears a bias of dominance, not the qi’s fault.

The perfected person knows this and establishes their person in nothingness, examining their mind in emptiness. While the worldly person’s stimulus is unfathomable, Heaven’s qi must respond, manifesting at the verge of emptiness. The perfected person, at the moment of incipient signs, discerns whether to generate or destroy, for there are always portents—through tranquil scrutiny, they surely grasp them. Thus they reverse the course at the first sign, either welcoming or restraining, without expending effort.

The world does not understand this, yet our Dao silently preserves it whole. It is like a person in quiet introspection: when a thought arises, they must perceive it. At the moment of incipient signs, whether to heed or disregard, all is subject to their own mastery—why wait until the thought has taken form to suppress it?

The body is qi; when thought stirs, qi responds as swiftly as an echo. Extending this to Heaven and humanity, the speed of stimulus and response is likewise. To respond and reverse is called overcoming. Where is there any grand exertion or great application? The Master did not expound this, hence this supplementation.

"Someone asked, 'In cultivating the Dao, should one also accumulate virtue?'

The answer: 'How could one not accumulate virtue? The Dao cannot be without virtue, just as yang cannot be without yin. Virtue pertains to others; the Dao pertains to oneself. Those who study the Dao—if they do not first accumulate virtue—will be detested by spirits and ghosts, constantly plagued by inner demons that obstruct their faculties, preventing deep progress. Those who cultivate the Dao—if they do not first plant virtue—will displease Heaven and Earth, and at every turn, external demons will block their path, hindering advancement. Whether studying or cultivating the Dao, establishing virtue comes first. Thus, misfortune transforms into fortune, peril turns to safety, and enlightenment is assured. For the Dao has limits, but virtue is boundless. Since ancient times, immortals and perfected beings, even after attaining the Dao, continue to accumulate merit and refine their conduct in the mundane world, awaiting the fulfillment of three thousand merits and the completion of eight hundred deeds before receiving Heaven’s decree.

As the *Wuzhen Pian* states:
*Without cultivating practice and amassing hidden virtue,*
*At every move, hordes of demons create obstacles.*

How could virtue not be cultivated?'"

"〔The answer given is correct. Those who can practice the *Three Numinous Teachings on Healing the World* as expounded by Master Lü, following its methods for healing the world, may achieve this in their very bodies—without spending a single coin or exerting the slightest effort—thus attaining the verified state of harmonizing Heaven and Earth. Though once a hidden treasure of the Vinaya school, it has now been printed to preserve and benefit the world. Those devoted to the Great Dao may thus be free from the concerns warned of in the *Wuzhen Pian*, gaining profound benefits for both body and world. Yet the master has not mentioned this—perhaps he has not yet heard of it.〕

Someone asked: 'A true cultivator is as poor as can be, relying entirely on alms for clothing and food. How can they have silver or coin to accumulate virtue?'

The answer: 'Accumulating virtue does not necessarily require silver or coin. Virtue without silver or coin is even greater than that with them. For those who have left the household life, the two words "expedient means" are most essential. For example: enduring hardship for the sake of benefiting others; speaking truthfully; not deceiving almsgivers; dispensing medicine or offering tea; repairing bridges and mending roads; guiding others to do good. Whatever slightly benefits others, do it; whatever slightly harms others, do not. All such actions are the accumulation of virtue and the establishment of conduct. Practicing thus, one forges karmic ties with others, and heavenly blessings become attainable—not only benefiting others but also oneself.' 〔The answer is most apt.〕"

"Those of superior virtue and inferior virtue alike must first uphold conduct. After three years of such practice, past karmic debts may be redeemed, and only then may one engage in healing the world—great merit may then be attained."

Someone asked: "Does exclusive devotion to accumulating virtue hinder the work of cultivating the Dao?"

The answer: "How could it hinder? Externally, one accumulates virtue; internally, one cultivates the Dao. Virtue assists the Dao, and the Dao perfects virtue. Dao and virtue advance together, inner and outer harmoniously aiding one another—this is the solid, grounded endeavor of sages and worthies. It is not like the middle and lower vehicles, which cling to emptiness and non-action, mistaking the mind for the Dao in their hollow learning."

〔Privately I observe: The great Dao of healing the world is precisely the practice of healing the world through one’s own body. This is the solid, grounded learning of the sage, the supreme Dao, not mere dharma-power. Its effects are tangible and real: the body is at peace, and the world is well-ordered. But one must first open the mysterious pass before proceeding. For what is undertaken here concerns nothing beyond *xing* and *ming*, yet yields the dual fruition of virtue and merit—this is the highest vehicle of the elixir path. Those resolved upon the great Dao may undertake it.

In its operation: the head is Heaven, the Crimson Palace is the capital, and the belly of Earth is the marketplace. The essential secret within the secret: with intention, welcome the true *qi* of the Limitless, descending to infuse the abdomen and heart, penetrating the spine to reach the back. The aim is to attain a heart at peace and *qi* at ease, with harmony filling the entire body. Do not count the months and years; practice thrice daily, and the effects will manifest without inquiry.

This teaching is the supreme Mahāyāna learning of the heart, corresponding to the great Dao of the *Doctrine of the Mean*. By maintaining clarity, one welcomes the *qi* of *Qian*; by maintaining harmony, one welcomes the *qi* of *Kun*. Through these two *qi*, one attains central harmony. This is the practical learning of embodying virtue within the Dao.〕

Someone asked: "Confucians preserve the heart and nurture *xing*; Daoists refine the heart and cultivate *xing*; Buddhists illuminate the heart and perceive *xing*. The sages of the Three Teachings all establish their teachings on heart and *xing*. Yet now you say, ‘The heart is not the Dao’—I truly do not understand."

The answer: "The Dao is the Dao; heart and *xing* are heart and *xing*. It is not that heart and *xing* are the Dao. What is called preserving the heart and nurturing *xing* is for the purpose of practicing the Dao. Refining the heart and cultivating *xing* is to prevent harm to the Dao. Illuminating the heart and perceiving *xing* is to perfect the Dao. Thus, one employs heart and *xing* to cultivate the Dao, but cultivating heart and *xing* is not itself the Dao. Moreover, if one speaks of preserving, nurturing, refining, cultivating, hearing, or seeing, it is not mere emptiness and non-action! If one truly empties the heart to become the Dao, then the heart would be the Dao. Refining the heart would grant longevity; nurturing the heart would confer immortality—why then seek teachers, visit friends, or inquire after true secrets?"

Someone asked: "If the heart is not the Dao, does that mean one should let the heart roam freely?"

The answer: "The heart is the root of birth and death, the very thing that harms the Dao.
