For the practitioner, the first step is to cut this thing down and eradicate its roots, only then can one advance unimpeded without obstruction. The sage said: ‘The human heart is perilous; the Dao-heart is subtle.’ How greatly the heart harms people!"

〔This means that only when the heart dies does the spirit live—here it refers to the discriminating mind. What follows pertains to the Dao-heart.〕

Someone asked: "Is the Dao-heart not a heart?"

The answer: "The Dao-heart is the heart of Heaven and Earth. It is a heart yet not a heart—empty and vast, containing all principles yet untouched by any thing. It is the spirit distilled from the Five Agents, called true *yang*, true lead, true seed, Black Tiger, Metal Duke, true essence, numinous brightness, gold within water, *yang* within *Kan*, the immortal recipe of the other house, the Third Son of the Nine, the Youth of Numinous Clarity, and many other names. In sum, it is called the Dao-heart. This heart has no form or appearance, no sound or scent; it is rarely encountered by people. Even if one encounters it, without true recognition, it slips away before one’s eyes."

The sage, through methodical refinement, gathers from the void the Nine Returns and Seven Reversions, transcending the mundane to attain sagehood. In Confucianism, this is the Way of the *Doctrine of the Mean*; in Buddhism, the One Vehicle; in Daoism, the Way of the Golden Elixir. Later generations of monks and Daoists, unaware that the sages share a single great Way, falsely claim that Buddhist and Daoist principles differ from Confucianism—how foolish they are!

Someone asked: "If the Way of the Golden Elixir and the One Vehicle are the same as the *Doctrine of the Mean*, why did Confucius rarely speak of *ming* (destiny/fate)?"

The answer: "To 'rarely speak' does not mean he never spoke of it—only that he did not speak of it lightly. The principles of *ming* are profound, containing the mechanism to seize creation and reverse life and death. To speak of them would startle and confuse people. Yet the *Great Learning* and *Doctrine of the Mean* both concern the study of body, heart, nature, and *ming*, and within them lie moments where the celestial mechanism is fully revealed—only people fail to recognize it themselves! As for his praises of the *Ten Wings* of the *Book of Changes*, they are nothing but the study of exhausting principle, fulfilling nature, and attaining *ming*. Later generations, not understanding the great principle, contend over sectarian teachings and slander one another. How would they know that the gate of Daoist and Buddhist meaning is the gate of all wonders—and also the gate of non-duality?"

Someone asked: "Since Confucius did speak of *ming*..."

"Why was the firing process not transmitted alongside the rest?" He answered: "To elucidate the hexagrams and lines *is* to transmit the firing process. The principles of fortune and misfortune, regret and humiliation—these are the concrete practices of drawing out and adding, advancing and retreating. Within them, the celestial mechanism is fully revealed; it is for people to comprehend it themselves!"

Someone asked: "Yan Hui stood foremost among the virtuous disciples in the Sage’s school. Hearing one point, he understood ten; though he appeared foolish in never opposing the Master’s Way, he was more than capable of expounding it—Confucius deeply praised him. He should have been able to master *ming*; why then did he die young?"

He answered: "Whether one masters *ming* or not is distinguished by principle, not by examining the illusory form. One who has not attained the Dao, though living, is as if dead. One who has attained the Dao, though dead, is as if living. For what dies is the illusory form, while what does not die is the Dao. Yan Hui grasped Confucius’ Dao, dwelling where others could not bear the hardship yet finding joy within it. Having gained even one good, he would grasp it firmly and never lose it—thus he had already obtained the primordial True Unity of *qi*, returning to the root and recovering *ming*, no longer bound by yin and yang. Having reached the Sage’s station, he no longer cherished this illusory form and could die at will. Observe his words during the crisis at Kuang, when he told Confucius: ‘While you live, how could Hui dare to die?’—this is sufficient to see that life and death are self-determined, not heaven-determined.

As for Confucius’ statement that ‘unfortunately, he died young,’ this was meant to encourage all his disciples by invoking Yan Hui. If he had truly died young, how could one who had attained the Dao die prematurely? How could one who could prevent a premature death teach others to die young? The meaning is clear—how could it be mistaken?"

A question was posed: "After attaining the Dao, one’s lifespan aligns with heaven—why then did Yan Hui die at thirty-two?" The answer: "Once the Dao is realized, there exists a body beyond the body—this is called the true body, also known as the yang spirit. The yang spirit is the indestructible vajra-body of truth. When the Dao reaches the point where the yang spirit manifests, the illusory form appears but a heap of dung—how could one cling to it? The sages and worthies temporarily retain the illusory body only to cultivate the true body. Once the true body is established, the illusory form serves no purpose—why not discard it?"

Another asked: "Confucius lived over seventy years before his natural end—does this mean his attainment of the Dao was slower than Yan Hui’s?" The answer: "Confucius’ heart was set on saving the world. He sought to propagate the Dao across the land and awaken the people. When he obtained the unicorn during the western hunt, he knew the Dao could not be realized in his time, yet he could not bear to see the great Way vanish from the world. Thus, he edited the *Book of Songs* and *Book of Documents*, established the *Rites* and *Music*, annotated the *Zhouyi*, and composed the *Spring and Autumn Annals*—opening the ears of later generations and fulfilling his salvific vow. Once his aspirations were complete, he departed this world. Yan Hui, having attained the Dao, already had Confucius preceding him in saving the world—there was no need for further effort, so he was free to shed his form and depart early."

[Life and death are mastered freely, yet neither Confucius nor Yan Hui chose to exercise this power—such is attested in the classics. How could the master not have seen this? It must be that he spoke with purpose. From a proper perspective, during the crisis at Kuang, Confucius trusted in heaven, and Yan Hui did the same—thus they feared neither death nor life. As for the matter of "dying young," this rightly shows Confucius and Yan Hui’s compliance with fate, not daring to defy heaven with self-determination. Hence, Confucius mourned. If one says, "While the master lives, how could Hui dare to die?"—does this mean one may die when the father lives? This precisely demonstrates Yan Hui’s non-defiance of fate, unrelated to the presence or absence of illusory methods. The three teachings’ core principle is to establish destiny, and thereby accept it—hence, they remain unwavering whether life is long or short, cultivating the self while awaiting fate. The master must have understood this, yet his answer here suggests a deeper intent. Moreover, in the earlier response, he stated: "The illusory has life and death, but the Dao has no life and death." Later learners may grasp this truth. Yet those who cultivate or study the Dao today do so with private motives—what more can be said? The world’s admiration lies entirely in the questions below, all rooted in the twin maladies of clinging to life and craving the marvelous. After the master’s subsequent answer, I fear those who hear it and withdraw will number far more than five thousand—how lamentable!]

Another asked: "If the illusory body cannot attain the Dao, why do legends speak of the Yellow Emperor ascending to heaven on a dragon at Mount Dinghu, or Master Xu’s entire household flying upward?" The answer: "Such events are real, but not as commonly understood. The great Dao of the Golden Elixir involves drawing from *kan* to fill *li*, returning *kun* to *qian*. After the Dao is realized, all yin is exhausted, transforming into a *qian*-body that shatters the void to become a celestial immortal of the Great Luo Heaven. This is what is meant by ‘riding the dragon to heaven’—not that the fleshly body mounts a dragon and departs. As for the tale of ‘lifting the household and flying upward,’ it signifies that when one person attains the Dao, nine generations of ancestors ascend to heaven. Alternatively, those of great merit and conduct may receive an imperial decree from the Jade Emperor, allowing their entire family to relocate to the celestial realm of bliss or to grotto-heavens and blessed lands, escaping afflictions and enjoying heavenly emoluments. The world, not understanding this, assumes they flew away as immortals. Yet consider: immortals are achieved through cultivation—without practice or realization, how could one become immortal? This clarifies the meaning of ‘lifting the household and flying upward.’ Some fools even believe houses and dwellings are physically lifted away. But ask: if immortals dwell in the boundless void, how could the void bear the weight of earthen and wooden structures? Moreover, immortals encompass heaven and earth—what could they not obtain, that they would still cherish these mundane materials? Alas! Even the illusory body is discarded—why cling to earth and wood? Why not reflect deeply?"

I once inquired of this matter with Master Taixu. The master replied: "This Dao is most true and real, not at all illusory. To ultimately attain ascension in broad daylight is to refine the illusory into the real. First, one transforms the red into the white; then, the white into qi; next, qi into primordial qi. Further refinement returns it to the void, merging with the Dao, naturally reverting to the primordial. Yet this is not a matter of one day practicing this and the next that—it is a method accomplished within a single two-hour period, counted by days, months, and years. When the Dao is perfected and the moment of ascension arrives, the body is wholly composed of primordial qi, and the garments and shoes one wears are likewise transformed by qi. Thus, one walks and stands at midday without casting a shadow.

I once encountered Master Niquan three times to inquire of this. He replied: ‘You still fail to grasp that the return to the primordial is no illusion.’ As I pondered, he took my kerchief with one hand and lifted my hat with the other, bidding me look down. I saw only the shadow of the kerchief—nothing beyond it. Startled, I then saw him place the hat upon my head while donning the kerchief himself. Again, I saw only the shadow of my kerchief, while my head cast no shadow of the hat. He smiled and said: ‘Now you understand! Yet true attainment begins with steadfast practice, only then can one return to the void. If even a grain of sand remains unrefined, its shadow lingers!’

When I later asked about the meaning of ‘lifting the household,’ he answered: ‘There are two paths: one of method, one of Dao—method is illusory, Dao is real. I have examined the records of those who lifted their households and ascended throughout history—over seventy instances. Yet only the Yellow Emperor, Huan Xuan, and Tao Hongjing achieved this through the Dao. Others, like Laozi, the Prince of Huainan, and Master Jingyang, employed methods to manifest the Dao, though in truth they merely relocated to islands in the sea to further cultivate and return to the void. Whether they truly attained the Dao remains unknown. These are cases where the physical body ascended with the household. As for the Yellow Emperor, Huan Xuan, and Tao Hongjing, they ascended bodily in full. The rest—over eight hundred in number—shed their mortal forms. Yet none could ascend without the endorsement of the Three Officials and a jade edict from the heavens. Can one then claim ascension is mere illusion? Can one say immortality is an ordinary attainment?’

My master recounted this, and I now supplement it to affirm that not a single record in the registers is untrue. My master further stated: ‘The sacred art of lifting the household begins with egg-guard practice. The method of egg-guard: take heaven and earth as the Dharma-body, with the great qi spiraling, encompassing the earth below and the clouds above. Gradually contracting from afar, one practices without cease. Once the qi of the *gang* converges, it forms a protective shield around the body, impervious to wind and clouds—its efficacy is manifest! Progressing further, the gate opens, and serpents and beasts cannot enter—one’s practice advances still! With unceasing cultivation, awaiting the right moment to relocate becomes effortless. Yet within three thousand years, only Wei Boyang, the Ancestor of Alchemy, and Xu Sun, the Ancestor of Far Wandering, have mastered this. My teacher, Master Li Niquan, deemed the Dao not immediately essential to himself, so I dared not practice it.’

He also said: ‘The ascension of households by the ancients was done out of necessity. The Prince of Huainan and Master Jingyang exemplify this. The Prince of Huainan’s three clans ascended through the power of the Eight Immortals. Master Jingyang accumulated merit through alchemy, and his disciples followed him. When he incurred heavenly retribution and sought to mitigate it through his art, he tested them by transforming a singing girl into charcoal. Of over eight hundred followers, only Yu Zhen, Yin Zhen, and eight others upheld the three precepts. Thus, the Longyu isle was elevated, while seven hundred and ninety-one were left behind, giving rise to the *Prophecy of Longsha*. Precepts must be observed—let this be a warning from past examples.’

My master recounted this not without purpose, and so I append it here."

Someone asked, “If the illusory body is of no use, why then do some practitioners, after death and at the time of burial, leave behind an empty coffin—or find within it a bamboo staff or clothing and shoes? Does this not mean they have taken their illusory body with them?”

The master replied, “This cannot be judged by a single standard. Some, having attained the Dao, shed their illusory body, and their dharmakāya manifests in a certain place. After decades of accumulating merit and perfecting conduct, their work complete and their virtue fulfilled, they ascend to pay homage to the Jade Emperor, concealing the celestial mechanism and departing as if in death. The unenlightened, seeing nothing in the coffin, assume the fleshly body has become immortal. Others, though their Dao is not yet complete, evade calamity by employing the art of illusion, substituting a staff or clothing for their body, while their true form flees far away, leaving no trace—this, too, is not the attainment of immortality through the fleshly body. As the Most High said, ‘The reason I have great afflictions is because I possess a body; if I were without a body, what afflictions would I have?’ Thus, shedding the illusory body is merely to cast off affliction.”

Someone asked, “Yet there are those who remain in the world without shedding the illusory body—why is this?”

The master replied, “This, too, cannot be generalized. Some, having attained the Dao but lacking sufficient merit, remain in their form to accumulate further virtue. Others have completed their *ming* (destiny/lifespan) but not their *xing* (nature), and thus cannot shed the illusory body, remaining in the world. If one has perfected both *xing* and *ming*, fulfilled all merit, yet clings to the illusory body and refuses to relinquish it, this is called a ‘home-clinging ghost’—a state that immortals do not delight in.”

[Note: A home-clinging ghost must be a stubborn immortal who fails to comprehend the study of *xing*. Not only is their *xing* unresolved, but their *ming* is not the *ming* of heavenly mandate; rather, it relies on the *shen* of consciousness to solidify the illusory body. To speak of resolving *xing* and *ming* in such terms is mere worldly discourse. If, however, one’s aspiration is to achieve the supreme vehicle, they do not cling to form but refine it, ultimately dissolving even the subtlest illusory traces—this is the state of ‘complete reception and complete return.’ The ancients attained this, and thus cannot be dismissed as home-clinging ghosts. This distinction must not be overlooked.]

Someone asked, “If one has completed *ming* but not *xing*, they remain burdened by the illusory body. Why not resolve *xing* first and transcend?”

The master replied, “It depends on what one has received from their teacher. If their understanding is thorough from beginning to end, after completing *ming*, they will also complete *xing*, shedding the illusory body and manifesting the dharmakāya—this is inevitable. But if one only knows the principles of *ming* and not those of *xing*, they may become an earthbound immortal, living long but unable to shed the illusory body. If they recognize there is still something higher, seek a teacher, and grasp the final step—moving from *youwei* (effortful practice) to *wuwei* (effortless attainment)—they will no longer be burdened by the illusory body. With a body beyond the body, form and spirit both perfected, they unite with the Dao.”

Someone asked, “The *wuwei* Dao is the work of those with complete upper virtue. Why then do those of lower virtue, who merely extend their lifespan, also practice the *wuwei* Dao?”

The master replied, “Those of upper virtue have an unblemished original nature and an unobstructed spiritual aperture. With the true oral transmission, they resolve everything at once and directly cross to the other shore. Thus, in practicing the *wuwei* Dao, the affairs of *youwei* are already contained within it—*xing* is resolved, and *ming* is also preserved. Those of lower virtue, however, have already suffered primordial depletion, and a hundred illnesses arise. Even with a teacher’s transmission, they cannot achieve immediate purity. They must progress gradually, from effort to ease, and only after completing *ming* do they converge with those of upper virtue, at which point they may practice *wuwei*. This does not mean those of upper virtue practice only *wuwei*, nor that those of lower virtue practice only *youwei*. At the ultimate stage of the Dao, neither *you* nor *wu* are established—heaven and earth dissolve into emptiness. Not only is *youwei* unnecessary, but even *wuwei* is no longer needed. The terms *youwei* and *wuwei* are merely discussed in the context of where one begins practice. Not only do those of upper and lower virtue differ in their starting points, but even men and women begin differently in their cultivation.”

Someone asked, “How do the starting points differ for men and women?”

The master replied, “For men, the essential practice is refining *qi*. For women, it is refining form. Refining *qi* means subduing it, and subduing *qi* requires returning it. When *qi* returns, emptiness reaches its extreme and stillness its depth, rooting and restoring *ming*—thus the White Tiger descends. Refining form means concealing it, and concealing form requires its dissolution. When form dissolves, the Four Great Elements enter emptiness, the limbs decay, and the Red Channel is severed. When the White Tiger descends in men, they revert to a youthful body, and the post-heaven essence no longer leaks—this allows the elixir to form and lifespan to extend. When the Red Channel is severed in women, they transform into a male body, and the impure yin blood no longer descends—this allows them to escape death and enter life. Thus, men’s cultivation is called ‘Taiyang Refines *Qi*,’ while women’s cultivation is called ‘Taiyin Refines Form.’”

Someone asked, “Do women who refine form not subdue *qi*?”

The master replied, “Women are yin by nature, so their *qi* is easily subdued. However, the Red Channel is most harmful to the Dao, and this is where their focus lies—thus, they begin by applying effort where it is most needed. Once the Red Channel is severed, *qi* naturally becomes docile. Unlike men, who are yang by nature and whose *qi* is difficult to subdue—what might take a man three years to tame, a woman can achieve in one. If a woman is truly a hero among her kind, receives her teacher’s oral transmission, and practices the Taiyin Refining Form method, she may attain the Dao in three to five years—a path even more effortless than that of men. Yet such heroic women are exceedingly rare.”

Such heroic women are rare indeed—those whose fortitude and resolve exceed a man’s a hundredfold are the only ones who can succeed. Those whose strength merely equals a man’s will never accomplish it.”

Someone asked, “The Great Dao makes no distinction between men and women. Why, then, are there differences between them?”

The master replied, “The Dao is the same, but its application differs. For their natures are distinct, and their forms are not alike. Thus, though the Way of *xing* and *ming* is one, the methods of practice and their effects vary greatly.”

Someone asked, “How is the Red Channel severed?”

The master replied, “The Red Channel arises from the body’s postnatal yin *qi*. When yin *qi* stirs, impure blood flows. To transform the blood, first refine the *qi*. Once *qi* is transformed, the blood returns upward, entering the breasts, turning from red to white. Circulating throughout the body, it banishes the affliction of raging desire-fire. When desire-fire is extinguished, true fire emerges. From then on, all proceeds steadily and smoothly, and preserving life and completing the elixir is no longer difficult.”

Someone asked, “When the golden elixir is accomplished and one swallows and ingests it, does a woman transform into a man and the old become youthful—is this true?”

The master replied, “This speaks of principle, not of physical form. After a woman attains the Dao, she sheds all yin and becomes a body of pure yang, the same as a man who has attained the Dao—hence the saying, ‘a woman transforms into a man.’ After an elder attains the Dao, they return to the prenatal state, becoming a body of pure yang, the same as a child’s perfection—hence the saying, ‘the old become youthful.’ This does not mean their appearance changes.”

Someone asked, “If the Dao has no concern with illusory appearances, why then are those with incomplete six senses not taught the Dao?”

The master replied, “Those with incomplete six senses are called the disabled and infirm—useless people. The Dao is what heaven and earth hold most precious; it steals from yin and yang and seizes the workings of creation—this is the work of great sages. How could the disabled and infirm accomplish such earth-shaking, heaven-shaking deeds? They cannot do so not because they do not wish to, but because their form is limited and their qi obstructed. If the great Dao were entrusted to them, it would be like placing a valuable treasure in a useless place, and heaven’s punishment would surely follow—thus, it dare not be taught. If one with incomplete six senses truly performs great deeds and cultivates great conduct, then one may point them toward the lesser vehicle of nature and principle, guiding them to cultivate the path of coming and going. As for the great Dao of the golden elixir, it must never be taught. This secret is known only to those who have heard the great Dao!”

Someone asked, “Are there not those with complete six senses who do not attain the principle of destiny, but only complete their nature—do they truly not know of the principle of destiny?”

The master replied, “The principle of destiny is the Dao of the nine returns, seven reversions, and the great return of golden liquid elixir—a transmission that occurs but once in ten thousand kalpas. If one is not a true man of resolute will, bearing the steadfastness of vajra and the disposition of a sage, they cannot attain it. Even a true master dare not transmit it; if forced to do so, spirits and gods will obstruct it in secret. This is because such a person is not a vessel capable of bearing the Dao—transmitting it to the unworthy would be to leak heaven’s mechanism. As for the Dao of nature and principle, which guards the center and embraces the One, even those of middling or lower capacity, or those of virtuous conduct, may be guided to complete their elixir. For the principle of nature is the innate mechanism of heaven, without any notion of stealing from creation, and thus of no great consequence. Nevertheless, it must not be recklessly transmitted to the unworthy. Generally, among learners, those of superior wisdom are few, while those of middling or lower capacity are many. Thus, the patriarchs use the principle of nature to guide the middling, and the principle of destiny to guide the superior—teaching is established according to the person! There are also masters who transmit only the principle of nature, knowing nothing of destiny. Likewise, there are learners who attain only the principle of nature, knowing nothing of destiny—these cannot be discussed as one and the same.”

Someone asked, “If the great Dao of the golden elixir is transmitted but once in ten thousand kalpas, will it not nearly vanish from the world?”

The master replied, “The phrase ‘once in ten thousand kalpas’ expresses its utmost reverence and preciousness, not that it is lightly transmitted. Thus, after attaining the Dao in ancient times, if no worthy recipient was found, the adept would remain in the world for hundreds of years, blending with the mundane, until the right person appeared before departing. For example, Zhènyáng transmitted to Chúnyáng, Chúnyáng to Hǎichán and Chóngyáng—each took hundreds of years to find the right person. How cautious the ancients were—it is clear they did not recklessly transmit! When Zǐyáng transmitted to the unworthy three times, he suffered heavenly punishment three times—this is further proof that it must not be recklessly transmitted.”

[After the two patriarchs Zhōng and Lǚ completed nature and destiny but failed to find a successor, they remained in bodily form in the world. Our tradition understands the reason for their lingering presence. The Chan school, not knowing this, mocks them as “corpse-clinging ghosts.” Thus, what the noble one does is surely not understood by the multitude. This may be appended to the discourse on *liúxíng* (lingering in form) for further clarification.]

“Someone asked: ‘Is the great Way of the Golden Elixir transmitted only to those of superior wisdom? Are those of middling and lesser capacity necessarily excluded?’

The master replied: ‘There are those among them who attain it—it depends entirely on how one studies. If one plants both feet firmly on the ground, takes the great matter as one’s own, ascends from low to high, and progresses from shallow to deep, exerting ever greater effort over time, then bitterness will give way to sweetness. A true person, upon seeing such sincerity, will surely rejoice and offer guidance. But if one’s roots and conduct are inherently shallow and one lacks great aspiration, how can one ever hear of the great Way of the Golden Elixir?’

Someone asked: ‘Is there a method to studying the Dao?’

The master replied: ‘Success or failure in cultivation is entirely determined by the quality of one’s learning. Where one does not reach, there one remains deluded; what one does not know, that becomes difficult. Though one relies on an enlightened teacher for transmission, one must still achieve personal realization. Before one has heard the Dao, one must conduct oneself as one devoted to nature and destiny. To be devoted to nature and destiny means to be unburdened by wine, sex, wealth, or temper; to cast aside greed, anger, delusion, and attachment entirely; to have no other concern apart from the Dao; to approach those of the Way with a sincere and wholehearted reverence, as if honoring heaven, earth, and the gods, without the slightest deceit. One must further cultivate resolute aspiration and accumulate virtue through ceaseless effort, never resting until the principles become clear. Even if one spends an entire lifetime without attaining the Dao, one will have no regrets. With such a mindset, sages will subtly guide one, and true teachers will gladly offer instruction.

Yet today, people do not study the Dao with sincerity. Even when they encounter an enlightened master, they refuse to humble themselves. If they do lower their heads, after a few days they demand the Dao at once. At the slightest dissatisfaction, they assume they lack affinity and promptly depart. Throughout their lives, they fail to accumulate virtue or cultivate conduct, instead fixating on clothing and food, entangling themselves in worldly affairs. They vie for superiority, indulge in greed, anger, delusion, and attachment—nothing is absent. Should they chance upon some minor technique from a side school, they treasure it as if it were a priceless jewel, growing complacent and self-satisfied. Even when a superior master stands before them, they remain convinced of their own attainment and refuse to seek correction. With such deceit in their hearts, how can they ever attain the true Dao?

The perfected person, from the moment they emerge, is already different from others. They possess both aspiration and the ability to learn, combining sincerity with intelligence. They refuse to waste time or squander their future. Thus, after the light of the Dao illuminates their mind and they perceive their nature, they recognize there is still more beyond. They must then seek out an enlightened teacher, and in time, receive the transmission of the Apricot Grove, thereby completing the great Way. Patriarch Lü failed to complete the returning elixir three times, but upon obtaining Master Cui’s *Mirror for Absorbing the Medicine*, his great elixir was finally achieved. Both these masters remained humble and thus reaped the benefits of receptivity.

Yet later students, arrogant and self-important, claim sagely wisdom for themselves and refuse to work earnestly for nature and destiny. Instead, they engage in empty posturing, yet still vainly long for immortality. Rather than seeking blessings, they invite misfortune—how foolish they are!’

[Note: The master recounts how Patriarch Lü’s returning elixir was completed only after obtaining Master Cui’s *Mirror for Absorbing the Medicine*. Profound indeed! Profound indeed!]”

"One may speak of this to those who understand, but it is difficult to discuss with the vulgar. If one merely treats this as a *gong’an* to be read superficially, poring over the text without grasping its essence, one will scarcely avoid drowning in water or plunging into fire—self-inflicted ruin. Even if one grasps the essence yet lacks humility, or remains arrogant and self-important, one will still miss the mark face-to-face, lamenting like one who returns empty-handed from a mountain of treasure. The fault lies in refusing to work earnestly for nature and destiny, indulging instead in empty posturing.

This ‘empty posturing’ refers to the ‘head of the One within the Limitless’ in my Dao—the primal origin of the Three Powers and the Eight Lords. Suspended atop Mount Sumeru, what lies beneath its peak is known to be gathered as medicine, placed behind the mirror, and refined to emerge before it. Thus, one neither errs by attachment nor falls into emptiness; to swallow it is to ingest it, and this is called attainment, this is called completion. This is the *gong’an* of Patriarch Lü’s refinement of Master Cui’s *Mirror for Absorbing the Medicine*, through which his elixir was finally achieved.

I recall my master, the Elder of Great Emptiness, once expounded a profound discourse, affirming such arcane meaning. Yet he also spoke of a deeper mystery: when the Mysterious Pass stands open, but worldly wealth is exhausted, even if this treasure is obtained, without the proper means to match it, one may still face the peril of drowning in water or plunging into fire.

Thus, I append this response to corroborate Master Wu Yuan’s answer, for it is not without oral transmission. The subsequent reply, however, dares not reveal all openly."

A question arises: "Patriarch Lü’s three attempts at returning the elixir were unsuccessful—could it be that what he obtained was not genuine?"

The answer: "Patriarch Lü’s Dao was transmitted from the Perfected One of True Yang; it was utterly authentic—how could the return be false? The matter lies in having returned it only to lose it again. In the practice of refining the Golden Elixir, one must know the maturity of the medicine when gathering it, know moderation when refining it, know fortune and misfortune when congealing the elixir, know withdrawal and supplementation when nurturing it, and know the proper timing when releasing it. Moreover, there are distinctions between true and false medicines, between abundance and scarcity in measure, and between reversal and compliance in application. These are all matters of extreme subtlety—if one errs by even a hair’s breadth, the deviation spans a thousand miles. Patriarch Lü’s three unsuccessful attempts at returning the elixir must have involved some imperceptible flaw in the firing process, some detail unseen, causing him to miss it at the very moment of attainment and thus lose what had been gained.

Therefore, those who study the Dao must thoroughly comprehend the entire process from beginning to end, penetrate the subtle and fathom the wondrous, harbor no doubts whatsoever, and only then may they proceed. Only thus can they stand before the furnace without error."

Here follows the translation:

---

[Commentary: Considering all the above, given that Patriarch Lü was a sage, he must have penetrated the subtle and fathomed the wondrous—how could he have erred in the firing’s fine details? It must be that in the earlier transmitted methods, he lacked Master Cui’s *Mirror of Entering the Medicine*. Without this mirror, the primordial fails to coalesce within, and the acquired cannot thereby be transformed. This is merely toying with emptiness. Without true yin to aid it, true water and true fire do not meet, the substance does not transform—how then could it gather and abide for oneself? This was Patriarch Lü’s loss.

Having obtained the text, one grasps its meaning from its title and employs it in refinement, thereby achieving the elixir. Patriarch Lü, who began with purity and stillness, upon receiving Master Cui’s *Mirror of Entering the Medicine*, used it to refine emptiness, and emptiness naturally returned to wholeness—yet he did not stray from the purist principle. Profound! Most profound! The marvel of the title’s meaning is thus. Master Wuyuan understood this but dared not expound it to disciples; he merely hinted at it here with the phrase “harbor no doubts whatsoever,” speaking thus to those of kindred understanding. The great Dao is not lightly disclosed—such is its nature.]

Someone asked, “If one thoroughly comprehends the entire process from beginning to end and proceeds with cultivation, can one then attain the Dao?”

The master replied, “A great craftsman teaches others the compass and square but cannot impart skill. What the teacher transmits is no more than pointing out the true medicine and true fire, the great passes and great apertures. As for the subtlety of their application, the urgency or slowness of their practice, and the swiftness or delay of their fruition—these depend on the disciple’s strength of effort, the keenness or dullness of their resolve, and the sharpness or bluntness of their innate nature. Thus, the methods of practicing the great Dao comprise three approaches—upper, middle, and lower—each to be undertaken according to one’s capacity.”

Someone asked, “What are these three methods?”

The master replied, “The upper method is the method of spontaneity. The middle method is the method of expedience. The lower method is the method of grinding and polishing.

The method of spontaneity is sudden awakening and perfect penetration—one realization settles all. Bare and unadorned, radiant and luminous, round and complete, it is present whether walking, standing, sitting, or lying down. Like a clear mirror or still water, nothing is not reflected, and nothing can deceive it. Proceeding with ease in the central Way, one acts in tranquility—thus heaven and humanity unite in activation.

The method of expedience is returning from the acquired to the primordial, proceeding counter to the Dao within the flow of the Dao. One transforms the false with the true and preserves the true by means of the false. Adapting to circumstances and responding to conditions, one acts with advantage, with inner and outer mutually sustaining.”

The method of grinding and polishing is for those of dull nature and limited understanding. They must apply effort to the mind-ground, wholly abandoning worldly affairs. They harden their resolve, exhaust their sinews and bones, starve their bodies, enduring a thousand refinements and a hundred temperings. They firmly hold to what is good, suffering what others cannot suffer, enduring what others cannot endure. If others achieve it with one effort, they must do so with a hundred; if others achieve it with ten, they must do so with a thousand. Through every hardship and affliction, they forge ahead with relentless effort—until suddenly their original face is revealed. From there, they proceed with steadfast and solid practice, ultimately aligning with the same path as the upper and middle methods. This is forced progress, seeking the Way through one’s own effort.

These three methods are all secret teachings passed down orally by the immortals and perfected ones of old, instructing people to proceed according to their capacity. Those who cannot practice the upper method may follow the middle; those who cannot follow the middle may practice the lower. All ultimately aim to fully realize both nature and life. Beyond these three, there are no other methods.

---

The five grades of immortals do not follow the same Way.

The Way of the Heavenly Immortals is the refinement of the Nine Returns and Seven Reversions into the Golden Elixir, fully realizing both life and nature, achieving a body indestructible as vajra, with a hundred billion transformation bodies, manifesting and vanishing beyond measure. This is the Way transmitted once in ten thousand kalpas.

The Way of the Earthly Immortals is returning from the acquired to the primordial, reverting to nothingness and returning to the root, restoring life, gathering spirit and qi, preserving form and abiding in the world, attaining longevity without death.

The Way of the Ranked Immortals is receiving the talismans of the Three Jia, refining the wondrous methods of the Three Caverns of Highest Clarity, soaring through clouds and mist, evading the three disasters and eight difficulties, coming and going without obstruction. This is the Way of the Southern Palace’s protective body.

The Way of the Ghostly Immortals is cultivating the emptiness of true nature, foreseeing past and future, exiting through the yin spirit in corpse liberation, avoiding evil destinies. This is the Way of preserving the horn with the Dao.

The Way of the Human Immortals is subduing body and mind, nurturing essence and qi, dwelling in the world without suffering. This is the Way of cultivating the acquired.

Among these five grades of immortals, only the Earthly Immortal, by advancing one step further and practicing the Way of non-action, may ascend to the rank of Heavenly Immortal. The others are all subject to kalpic cycles. To attain the rank of Heavenly Immortal, many layers of obstacles remain. Without the transmutation of the Golden Elixir’s Way, success is nearly impossible.

---

The Dao is the undifferentiated qi of primordial chaos, what is called the Supreme Ultimate. The Elixir is round and complete, lively and vibrant, symbolizing the Supreme Ultimate. The Elixir is the Dao, and the Dao is the Elixir—their names differ, but their principle is one.

Gold is a substance that endures through ancient and modern times without decay, co-eternal with heaven and earth. It is chosen for its utmost firmness. Nine is the complete number of metal; seven is the complete number of fire, both belonging to yang. "Reversion" means returning to a state of pure yang without yin.

The Dao is fundamentally non-action, yet its methods involve action. Because it is non-action, the transformations of yin and yang cannot be without deficiency.

The sage employs methods of cultivation, refining with metal and fire, thereby restoring what is deficient to wholeness and ensuring that what is whole endures without loss. This returns it to the Supreme Ultimate, to the Ultimateless, and to the state of soundlessness and scentlessness, the realm of profound stillness. Heaven and earth may decay, but this does not—hence it is called the Great Return Elixir of Ninefold Reversion and Sevenfold Refinement.

As for the term "Elixir," it is so named because it is refined through fire. Someone asked, "In cultivating this Great Elixir, is it better to practice in activity or in stillness?" The answer: "The Dao permeates waking and sleeping, reaches the hidden and the manifest—it is not bound by activity or stillness. For the great cultivator, lively and vibrant, outwardly rounded and inwardly square, why not dwell in the marketplace or serve at court?"

Someone asked, "In the marketplace or at court, one cannot avoid human affairs and worldly matters—how can one focus wholeheartedly on the Dao?" The answer: "Precisely in the marketplace or at court is where one exerts great function and activates great opportunity—this is the highest method of practice. For the Golden Elixir exists within humanity and is sought within the marketplace and court. The ancients, in bustling cities, relied on those of influence to accomplish this—this is the very point!"

Someone asked, "The Dao is in the void, yet also in humanity, in the marketplace and court—why is this?" The answer: "Because it is in the void, the common people use it daily without knowing. If they knew, then in walking, standing, sitting, and lying down, all would be the Dao. Humanity is the perfect place for cultivation, and the marketplace and court are the best places for action. How could it be that only by dwelling in stillness, with all dharmas empty, is the Dao level?"

[Dwelling in the marketplace or serving at court, the great cultivator conceals great function. Yet dwelling in the marketplace is for virtue, while serving at court is for action. Virtue without action is not virtue; virtue with action completes the Dao. Master Wuyuan spoke of this, but there is another application within—perhaps not as I once heard. What I heard was this: virtue is the supreme great virtue, and action is the ultimateless great action. It requires no expenditure, no effort, and is practiced standing. Amidst the crowd, without distinction or difference, people cannot conceive of it. From dawn to dusk, whether in the marketplace or not, one enters profound stillness; whether at court or not, one encompasses the six directions. At times, virtue and action complement each other, fulfilling wishes together; at times, one cultivates virtue alone until it is sufficient, then cultivates action; at times, one cultivates action alone until it is accomplished, then fulfills the wish. The ancient sages practiced this, and its wondrous actions are not beyond the *Three Ni’s Salvation of the World*, while its spiritual affairs follow the Yellow Emperor’s *Yinfu Jing* and Wenchang’s *Yinzhi Wen*. The essential method of entry comes from the *Qingjing Miaojing*. Others may not know, but one must act with wholehearted devotion. This is what I heard from the True Man of Jizu, who called it the constant Dao of the Vinaya school in this world.]

Someone asked, "If walking, standing, sitting, and lying down are all the Dao, why is there the practice of refining sleep?" The answer: "Refining sleep is for beginners. When ordinary people sleep, the spirit enters the yin cavern, and qi scatters to the four limbs. In dreams, they encounter inversions, cauldrons, and pitfalls—nothing they do not fall into. What is accumulated by day is not equal to what is depleted by night. Therefore, one must subdue the demon of sleep, keeping the heart-spirit in its chamber, clear qi ascending and turbid qi descending, so that the practice of the Dao may proceed without obstruction. The ancient immortals said, ‘Sleeping for an hour is dying for an hour. Sleeping for a day is dying for a day.’ If one has daily progress and goes a thousand days without sleep, the task is accomplished. It is also said, ‘One year without sleep, the Lower Elixir coalesces; two years without sleep, the Middle Elixir coalesces; three years without sleep, the Upper Elixir coalesces.’ This is a precise statement. But if the empty chamber generates brightness and the spirit’s illumination is constant, then even in sleep one remains awake—there is no harm in sleeping. The *Cantong Qi* says, ‘In sleep, the spirit embraces; in waking, one observes its presence or absence.’ This is not sleep causing harm. Until one reaches this state, one must not sleep. The predecessors, Zhang Weng of Guoqing Temple in Shu and Zhang Weng the Sleeping Immortal of Huangzhong, both initially refined sleep and later slept endlessly—this is the proof of refining sleep."

Someone asked, "Are there three Elixirs—the Upper, Middle, and Lower?"

“Answer: It is fundamentally one Elixir. Speaking in divisions: the Lower Elixir refines essence into qi; the Middle Elixir refines qi into spirit; the Upper Elixir refines spirit to return to emptiness. The three Elixirs are named according to their stages. When one reaches the stage of returning to emptiness, essence, qi, and spirit merge into one qi—this is the Great Return Elixir of Golden Liquor. The scriptures’ teachings on the Three Fields and Three Passes express this same meaning.”

[In elixir practice, one does not refine essence today, qi tomorrow, and spirit the day after—these three methods are present within a single moment. Just as in a single elixir manual, though the stages from beginning to end are many, one does not proceed one stage today and another tomorrow; rather, all stages are traversed in a single moment without omission. Thus one avoids the danger of imbalance. Yet those whose passes remain unopened cannot achieve this. The passes include the three anterior and three posterior ones; opening them regulates the Conception and Governor Vessels. The three anterior passes regulate the Conception Vessel; the three posterior passes regulate the Governor Vessel. Only when the Conception Vessel is open can the Governor Vessel be regulated. This is the principle, though in practice it is not so. Rather, one should regulate them through immediate inhalation and exhalation.

Inhalation begins at the Yin Heel Point in the Sea Bottom, ascending from this point in reverse through the tailbone and spine, crossing the occiput to reach the crown, and entering the Celestial Valley. The crown is Kunlun—this is the human head. The Celestial Valley is within the human brain, the Upper Field. From the brain, it descends through the nose to the upper lip, where it meets the Conception Vessel at the Flowery Pond. The Pond is beneath the tongue; the philtrum is the Flowery Pond—this is the established method for regulating the Governor Vessel.

Exhalation begins at the Flowery Pond, descending through the Jade Pillar—the Jade Pillar is the human throat—continuing downward through the Crimson Palace. The Crimson Palace is the chest, the hall of the breast. From here it reaches the Central Yellow, the Middle Field. From there it descends to the abdomen, resting deep behind the navel at the Sea of Qi, the Lower Field. From here it reaches the Yin Heel Point, located before the anus and behind the scrotum, where the Conception and Governor Vessels intersect—this is the established method for regulating the Conception Vessel.

In all cases, one guides qi with intention, aligning thought with the Dao—this is the essential method for beginners to open the passes. As Ancestor Lü said, ‘When the three threes are open, half the work is done; spiritually opening them seals the Xun wind.’ The Xun wind is the breath through the nose. When the heart is utterly still and the breath becomes so subtle it seems closed, this is the method of Embryonic Breathing. Achieving Embryonic Breathing is the spiritual work following the opening of the three threes—it is not a separate spiritual practice.

Beginners should first open the passes by following inhalation and exhalation with intention. Once the passes are open and the Three Fields are unobstructed, as practice deepens into extreme emptiness and profound stillness, even Embryonic Breathing dissolves—this is true cessation of breath. ‘Cessation’ means stopping. When practice reaches true cessation, breath also ceases, all meridians stop, the six bowels and five viscera attain perfect peace, and the primordial qi is gathered from this stage.

Students should understand that ‘stopping’ and ‘cessation’ describe an extreme subtlety—one does not perceive its beginning or end. This is the very qi circulating throughout the body. All the minute stages of elixir practice are contained within this single moment, circulating without omission. The great function of elixir practice, said to seize all of creation’s transformations, must not be taken lightly. Practicing thus daily and yearly without interruption, one will surely attain the rank of Heavenly Immortal—how much more so those of lesser attainment?

The essentials lie in two transformations, one return, and two unions. Now, step by step, returning again and again, daily progress may seem insufficient, but monthly progress will be more than enough. The *Book of Changes* says, ‘Returning is not far,’ and also, ‘If one does not constantly maintain virtue, disgrace may follow.’ The practice is lively and fluid—it depends on the individual.

Someone asked, “Are essence, qi, and spirit postnatal or prenatal?”
Answer: “They are prenatal. The *Heart Seal Scripture* says, ‘The three superior medicines are spirit, qi, and essence; dimly, faintly, obscurely, profoundly; seen but not visible, heard but not audible.’”

"From nonbeing guard being, and in an instant it is accomplished." How could this be regarded as a postnatal, tangible thing? Thus, the great practitioner refines the prenatal original essence, and the essence of intercourse will naturally not leak; refines the prenatal original qi, and the qi of breath will naturally harmonize; refines the prenatal spirit, and the spirit of thought will naturally settle into stillness. The prenatal is perfected, and the postnatal is transformed. Scholars must strive in cultivation to witness its efficacy. Otherwise, even the postnatal cannot be preserved—how much less the prenatal?"

Someone asked, "If it is said to be accomplished in an instant, why then speak of refining essence into qi, refining qi into spirit, and refining spirit to return to emptiness?"
Answer: "Accomplished in an instant refers to the effect of obtaining the medicine. Refining essence, refining qi, and refining spirit are the gradual work of cultivation and the subtlety of the firing process."

Someone asked, "The three superior medicines all belong to the prenatal—is the Golden Elixir formed from these three?"
Answer: "Though the three medicines belong to the prenatal, they are formless and imageless, still belonging to yin, and cannot congeal the sacred embryo. Only when transformed by the prenatal True One qi of emptiness and nonbeing can they generate form from the formless and substance from the insubstantial, and the three medicines become purely yang!"

Someone asked, "If form is generated from the formless and substance from the insubstantial, does the sacred embryo then have an appearance?"
Answer: "It is a dharma-form, not a material form. Dharma-form is form that is no-form. This qi congeals from emptiness and nonbeing and is also called the yang spirit. When this spirit gathers, it takes form; when it scatters, it becomes qi. It enters water without drowning, enters fire without burning; tigers and rhinoceroses cannot harm it, blades cannot touch it."

"Free in coming and going without obstruction, unlike the body of material form, which is a great affliction."

Someone asked, "There are those who exit as yin spirits—what is this?"
Answer: "This is the Jade Fluid Returning Elixir, which completes the nature of True Suchness. When the nature of True Suchness is completed, the will remains undivided, and thus congeals into spirit. Over time, when stillness reaches its utmost, the spirit departs, traversing a thousand miles in an instant, knowing the future from the past—yet this is merely a ghost immortal! It has no shadow, no form. If one wishes to take form, one must undergo rebirth, seeking out the wise in the next life to cultivate the Great Elixir of Golden Fluid and thereby attain it. Thus, the great practitioner, having completed the Jade Fluid Returning Elixir, proceeds to refine the Great Elixir of Golden Fluid, aspiring to reach the state of pure yang without yin and nothing more."

[Our late master, Tai Xu Weng, once said: "When the path of the ghost immortal is achieved but the material body has not yet been transcended, one may know of the supreme Mahayana and seek the Great Elixir of Golden Fluid. There is still a swift method: one must empty and still the body and mind, dull one’s awareness, block one’s hearing and seeing, cut off one’s thoughts and concerns—just like an infant before it can crawl—single-mindedly and sincerely welcoming the True One of the Limitless. Then this Great Elixir of Golden Fluid will naturally be swiftly obtained. It will be as if awakening from a dream: one stirs the natural true fire, neither martial nor civil, refining and nurturing. One day, when yin is transformed into pure yang, the celestial immortal may be learned. However, one must beforehand place existence and nonexistence, life and death, beyond concern—meeting fright without fear, meeting joy without delight. Beyond profound stillness, all is viewed as dream, illusion, bubble, shadow. Only then can the True One remain constant, and the postnatal be transformed by the primordial.

This transformation depends on the True One bestowed by the Limitless. This bestowed One is the mother of the Golden Fluid, capable of transforming the yin of the body. The yin of the body is the Three Treasures within us: in the body, it is prenatal; at its utmost, it is postnatal—yet still a yin substance. Only by relying on the One can it be transformed. At this stage, the discerning power within the body must inevitably diminish; do not grow lazy because of this. Initially, one may feel unable to sustain it, but gradually one returns to the original state, then enters profound peace. The four limbs grow stronger, the spirit and complexion become radiant, and the eyes emit light. If one then aligns with the Celestial Stem and reflects the True One within oneself, one’s own True One is born anew each day. With sincere and unbroken practice, how could one merely recover the primordial unity? Worldly wealth will also overflow. When the time comes and the Great Return Elixir descends, there will be no danger of sinking into water or entering fire."]

He also said: "If the ghost immortal achieves the Dao without adding further practices, when the kalpa arrives and the four great elements are no longer one’s own, with no place to abide and no desire to transmigrate, how can one open a new path?"

Our late master left this discourse, which I have carefully recorded and appended to this answer to supplement what Wu Yuan Zi did not address. Scholars may use it for reference.

Someone asked, "Are those who enter wombs, seize bodies, or return to old dwellings this kind of yin spirit?"
Answer: "They are not the yin spirit of True Suchness, but the primordial spirit. Because they have not completed the destiny, they remain yin! As for those who enter wombs or seize bodies, they merely manipulate the consciousness, guarding the seed of samsara. They have no connection to the Great Dao, thus passing from one existence to another without end. What sets them apart from ordinary people is only their ability to choose their dwelling place and avoid rebirth as non-human beings! As for illuminating the mind and seeing nature, entering samadhi and exiting as spirit—how could they achieve this?"

Someone asked, "If one has completed nature but not destiny, will one be deluded in the next life?"
Answer: "Some will be deluded, some will not. Those who are not deluded will naturally understand the principles of nature upon rebirth and seek the Great Elixir to complete the Great Dao. Those who are deluded lose their former path and must be guided by an enlightened person to awaken to past causes. For example, the Ming dynasty top scholar, the Perfected Luo—if his father had not reminded him, he would have nearly forgotten! Though deluded, he still had residual roots, so a single reminder awakened him. Without residual roots, even a reminder would not awaken.

Not only those who have completed nature are like this, but even those with aspiration who study the Dao their entire lives without meeting an enlightened teacher will carry residual roots into their next life. As soon as they emerge, they will naturally know of this great matter and remain in the Dao, researching and striving in every possible way, single-mindedly cultivating the Dao without love for glory or wealth—these are all people with residual roots. Without residual roots, even if they are orphaned, widowed, impoverished, or face a hundred hardships, they would rather die in distress than enter this path."

Someone asked, "Those who cultivate nature must return to the human world to complete the Great Dao. Those who cultivate destiny live as long as heaven and earth—surely they do not return?"
Answer: "Some do return. The arts of extending life are not attainable by those who are not true great men, nor practicable by those who are not naturally endowed with supreme wisdom. Even if one attains them, one must also have deep accumulated virtue from ancestors, great merit and conduct of one’s own, and countless heavenly conditions converging to proceed without obstruction, step by step, to complete this great matter. If one’s ancestors lacked virtue, or one’s own residual roots were shallow, even if one advances boldly, one may be limited by unfinished affairs when one’s allotted time expires..."

"Or one may be hindered when one’s merit is just being put to use, and demonic obstructions arrive prematurely. Often there are those who possess the method but lack the resources, or have the Dao but lack the strength, and die while still embracing the Way—such cases are many. Yet though they have not completed the Dao, their comings and goings are clearly distinct from those of ordinary people. Some die after achieving half their work, others before reaching the halfway point. Those who die after half their work is done will surely be born with innate knowledge in their next life. Those who die before reaching the halfway point will surely be devoted to the Dao in their next life. Therefore, those who study the Dao must recognize whether they possess residual roots; they must not abandon themselves in despair, for to lose the human form once is to suffer for ten thousand kalpas."

Someone asked, "Those born with innate knowledge—can they cultivate and uphold the Dao without seeking a teacher?"

Answer: "Though they possess innate understanding, there are still points of confusion. Without encountering a master of superior wisdom to guide them, they too cannot attain the Dao. If they meet such guidance, they will suddenly awaken to perfect comprehension, resolving all matters at once. Once they begin their practice, none will fail to complete the Dao. I have encountered two such born-with-knowledge individuals: one was Master Gu of Jiangsu, the other Master Wang of Longxi. Master Gu was deluded by his official career, Master Wang by the pursuit of profit. Though they knew the Way, they did not value life and destiny, and this was the cause of their confusion. Such men as these must surely have lacked great ancestral virtue and personal merit, which is why they remain entangled, unable to escape the net. Who knows what their next life will bring—how lamentable! Later learners, should you not accumulate virtue early?"

The disciple asked, "Does this disciple also possess past-life roots?"

The master replied, "If you had no past-life roots, how could you have heard the name of the Great Dao? How could you have heard its teachings? Whether you possess past-life roots or not, you yourself do not know. I have a few words for you—you will know for yourself."

Then he spoke a gatha:
"In a past life, your surname was Yuan,
In this life, your surname is Lu.
Yuan Chengde was your name then,
Lu Wogu is your name now.
This is the cause and effect of past and present—
Examine your steps carefully.
The meaning is quite clear:
Awaken early, if you must awaken."

At these words, the disciple suddenly awakened. He knelt and offered a song:
"I have awakened to my past and future selves—
Others are myself, and I am others.
Breaking through the chaos to enter the numinous cave,
I see the original, single truth.
This single truth is like dew or lightning,
Without head, tail, or face.
Supporting heaven and earth, yet beyond thought—
In the indistinct and boundless, transformation occurs.
Fortunate to have the kind teacher’s subtle guidance,
I now recognize this ancient treasure.
The true countenance is right before my eyes—
Why seek merit elsewhere?"

In the exchange between master and disciple, they unknowingly saw the eastern sky brighten and the earth suffused with light. The assembled disciples dispersed to attend to their duties, while Wu Yuanzi strolled alone in the Pavilion of Purified Heart.

*Posthumous Compilation of Discourses on Cultivating Truth by Wu Yuanzi of Mount Qiyun*
*Annotated by Liu Yiming of Tongcheng*
*Collated by Min Yide, Disciple of the Golden Canopy*
*On the Three Treasures of Primordial Qi, Essence, and Spirit*

Purple Clarity Elder states:
That essence is not the essence of intercourse—
it is the saliva in the Jade Emperor’s mouth.
That qi is not the qi of breath—
know instead it is the mist of Grand Simplicity.
That spirit is not the spirit of thought—
it may stand shoulder-to-shoulder with the Primordial Beginning.
These are what are called primordial essence, primordial qi, and primordial spirit.
Essence, qi, and spirit are called "primordial" because they are the original things.
Before this body existed, these things already were;
only after these things existed did formless give rise to form,
and the insubstantial give rise to substance—
they come from the time before father and mother united.
At the moment of union,
the father’s essence has not yet been released,
the mother’s blood has not yet enclosed,
yet when emotions align and intentions merge,
within that profound obscurity there is something—
barriers secretly permeate, blending into one,
steaming and swirling without dispersion.
Then, as essence is discharged and blood receives,
essence and blood fuse,
enveloping this single point of truth,
transforming and taking form,
already containing essence, qi, and spirit within.
Though named as three, they are in truth one.
One conveys the meaning of undifferentiated origin;
three refers to the division of numinous power.
One is the substance, three are the functions.
The undifferentiated substance is pure and unadulterated as essence,
flowing through blood and vessels as qi,
empty and numinous in activity as spirit.
Three yet one, one yet three.
The so-called "three grades of superior medicine" are the functions;
the so-called "complete and perfectly realized" is the substance.
One cannot speak only of three, nor only of one.
Many learners do not understand that three are one and one is three;
some cling to the undifferentiated origin and fall into attachment to emptiness;
others refine the three grades of medicine and become fixated on form.
Attachment to emptiness or form both miss the wondrous principle of returning to the origin.
Returning to the origin means returning to primordial essence, primordial qi, and primordial spirit.
If one wishes to cultivate the Dao, one must first know that these three things lie hidden within the undifferentiated origin.
Separated from the undifferentiated origin, they are no longer the original substance of precelestial essence, qi, and spirit;
losing this original substance, they are no longer the primordial things.
The *Heart Seal Scripture* says:
The three grades of superior medicine—
spirit, qi, and essence—
dimly indistinct, profoundly obscure,
seen yet unseen, heard yet unheard...

From nonbeing to being, it is accomplished in an instant.
Called "dimly indistinct," called "profoundly obscure," called "being and nonbeing"—
these reveal it as a formless thing.
Only this primordial essence,
like a pearl, like dew,
pure and unadulterated,
nourishes the hundred bones;
primordial qi,
like mist, like smoke,
permeates the hundred channels;
primordial spirit,
most numinous, most sagely,
governs all affairs.
To know this is to prolong years and extend life, to attain ageless longevity.
If the cultivator can recognize these three medicines, then the cultivation of the Dao may be hoped for.

[If the cultivator can from the undifferentiated origin bodily realize the Three Treasures,
then no error will arise.
Moreover, the compassionate instruction of "nourishing" and the like
reveals the meaning of "nonbeing yet not nonbeing,"
as clear as the lines on one’s palm,
sufficient for realization.
Having attained it, guard it,
and one will not fall into attachment to emptiness.
If one can comprehend the secret of "from nonbeing,"
one will not fall into fixation on form.
The essential words of the ancient sages
depend entirely on spiritual apprehension;
to hear and not understand is enough to lead one astray.
If, after reading this, one still clings to form or emptiness,
I can do nothing more.]

Postcelestial essence, qi, and spirit
Postcelestial essence is the essence of intercourse.
Postcelestial qi is the qi of breathing.
Postcelestial spirit is the spirit of thought.
These three things have form and appearance,
things that arise after the body’s birth.
When male and female unite,
essence and blood merge,
forming the embryo.
Within the womb, there is only primordial qi,
and no qi of breathing.
When the ten months of gestation are complete,
the child emerges from the womb,
and at the moment of birth, with a cry,
takes in the tangible qi of heaven and earth,
which enters the cinnabar field and merges with primordial qi.
From this point, qi moves in and out through the mouth and nose,
externally connecting with the qi of heaven and earth to become breath—
this is the root of breathing qi.
Postcelestial spirit also arises at this time,
this spirit being the consciousness that transmigrates through kalpas.
It arrives first at birth,
departs first at death;
whether one becomes human or beast, it is this;
whether one does good or evil, it is this;
whether one is born or dies, it is this;
moving from this to that,
shifting from old to new,
there is nothing that is not this.

At the very moment of birth, when the infant cries out upon touching the earth, this is when the spirit enters its aperture—hence a newborn who does not cry will not live, for the spirit has not entered its aperture. At the time of birth, spirit and qi govern each other, forming the root of the postcelestial and giving rise to the illusory body. As for the essence of intercourse, it is entirely a product of later existence. While in the womb, this essence does not exist; even at birth, the body has no such essence. Only upon reaching the age of sixteen, when primordial yang qi is full, does it necessarily overflow and, having reached its extreme, return. When yang reaches its peak, yin arises; as yin arises, yang wanes. Yin qi takes charge, and yang qi retreats. The formless yin then generates the tangible yin. The aperture in the kidneys opens, true water diminishes, and the fire of desire stealthily arises. At the slightest provocation, this fire flames upward, steaming the entire body, stirring the blood and vessels of the hundred bones, and boiling the fluids of the five viscera and six bowels. All surges upward to gather at the Baihui acupoint atop the head—this point being where the hundred vessels converge. From here, the qi and blood descend along the spine, passing through the Shenshu acupoints, where they first transform into a white substance before traversing the coccyx and reaching the yin aperture, where they are finally discharged. This essence did not exist at birth, nor did it exist after birth—it is merely a transformation of qi and blood! The kidney aperture is but the gate through which essence exits; how could essence ever reside in the kidneys? The so-called essence of intercourse arises only through union and sensation; without union or sensation, there is no essence. Even nocturnal emissions occur due to sensation; if they happen without sensation, it is because the kidneys are weak and the blood vessels unstable, with perverse fire driving the essence out. This is the origin of the essence of intercourse.

When yang reaches its peak and generates yin, not only does essence arise from this, but the spirit of thought and the qi of breathing also become volatile. Scholars must recognize that these three—essence, spirit, and breath—are all products of existence after birth, not things that existed before birth. If one relies on these postbirth elements to preserve life, prolong years, and transcend yin and yang, is it possible? Scholars should ponder this thrice.

[It is noted that the ancients cherished these three aspects of the body, for if they could be returned, the three could revert to the One, and the later would no longer be later. In essence, the method lies in nothingness.]

**The True Qi of Prenatal Unity**
Yuanduzi said: The prenatal qi comes from the realm of emptiness. *The Awakening to Reality* states: "The Dao, from emptiness, generates the One qi; from this One qi, yin and yang are produced." Daoguang said: "There is a thing prior to heaven and earth, nameless, originally quiescent and silent. It can be the master of all phenomena, yet does not wither with the four seasons." All these speak of prenatal qi as the ancestral qi of living things, arising from emptiness, the master of all phenomena, and the origin of heaven and earth. It is formless and imageless, soundless and odorless—unseen to the eye, unheard by the ear, and untouchable by the hand. Yet though formless, it can generate form; though imageless, it can generate images.

In terms of its spirit, it is the spirit beyond spirits; in terms of its qi, it is the true qi of unity; in terms of its essence, it is the true essence of unity, also called the true seed, the golden elixir, or the immortal formula of another house. It cannot be compared to postcelestial breathing qi, the spirit of thought, or the essence of intercourse, nor is it the same as primordial essence, primordial qi, or primordial spirit. For primordial essence, primordial qi, and primordial spirit, when in the postcelestial, are yang, but when returned to the prenatal, they become yin. Unlike the true qi of prenatal unity, which remains indestructible through ten thousand kalpas, transcends all beings, and stands alone in honor—unbound by life and death, unconstrained by existence or nonexistence—it is the root of postcelestial essence, qi, and spirit, and the sovereign of prenatal essence, qi, and spirit. It is the most yang of things, the treasure of heaven, yet few recognize it.

This thing is neither inside nor outside, neither within the five aggregates nor the eight consciousnesses, neither in the five viscera nor the six bowels, neither at the gates of the six senses nor in the hundred bone apertures. It resides solely in the mysterious pass, the one aperture. If sought with intention, one clings to form; if guarded without intention, one clings to emptiness. It cannot be grasped by thought nor discussed in words. It is inherently present, yet when yang reaches its peak and generates yin, it flees to another house and is no longer ours. The perfected person employs methods to pursue and gather it, substantiating the insubstantial and giving form to the formless. Stirred, it takes shape and comes from the midst of emptiness.

Gathering and cultivating it, one refines it into an elixir with yin tally and yang fire, coalescing into a single grain as large as a millet seed to be swallowed and ingested. This ignites the primordial treasure, bringing forth existence from non-existence; it transforms the acquired substances, turning yin into yang. The Three Corpses and Five Thieves vanish without a trace; the eighty-four thousand hair spirits all transform into dharma protectors. Thus it is said: "A single grain of golden elixir swallowed into the belly—only then does one know that my life is not ruled by heaven."

Deluded people do not recognize this primordial True Unity of qi as the ancestral qi that gives birth to all things, the primal qi before the separation of the Great Vagueness, the numinous root at the dawn of chaos. Some mistake the original qi for the primordial True Unity of qi; others take the qi of breathing in the cinnabar field as the primordial True Unity of qi; still others regard embracing unity and guarding the center as preserving the primordial True Unity of qi; or viewing emptiness and stilling thoughts as observing the primordial True Unity of qi. Then there are those hell-bound seeds who refine the five metals and eight minerals, or gather red lead and plum blossom essence, believing these to be the ingestion of the primordial True Unity of qi. How can such myriad divergent paths speak of the primordial True Unity of qi?

The primordial True Unity of qi is the primordial ancestral qi that gives birth to heaven, earth, and all beings. Vast beyond all bounds, minute beyond all measure; in movement and stillness it remains undivided, yin and yang blended as one. In the primordial, it gives rise to yin and yang; in the acquired, it conceals itself within yin and yang. It is the true Unity, not a false one. To embrace and guard the true Unity—how could the true Unity be embraced and guarded? If it could be embraced and guarded, it would not be the true Unity; what is embraced and guarded must be a false unity. To observe and still the true Unity—how could the true Unity be observed and stilled? If it could be observed and stilled, that unity would not be true; what is observed and stilled must be a false unity.

As for the thousand gates and ten thousand doors of the various heterodox paths, all mistake the thief for the son, abandon the correct to follow the perverse, and do not know what the true Unity of qi truly is. No wonder they reach old age without accomplishment and fall into emptiness and ruin!

When Wu Yuan first encountered the old man of Kan Valley, he was shown the great Dao of cultivation, with all matters made clear. Only the phrase "the primordial qi comes from the midst of emptiness" remained obscure to him, eluding his grasp for thirteen years. He pored over the elixir classics but never grasped its essence. Later, he met the Immortal Liu Zhangren, who pierced the source and flow, cracking open the iron pellet. In an instant, all became luminously clear in his heart. Only then did he truly know that the emptiness of true emptiness is the true Unity—true Unity is true Unity. It is not possessed by me, nor obtained from another; it cannot be described in images or depicted in diagrams. One joins with it through intention and meets it with spirit. Released, it pervades the six directions; gathered, it retreats into secrecy. It penetrates heaven and earth, making sages and worthies, immortals and buddhas—all emerge from this. If one knows this primordial True Unity of qi, the great foundation is established, and all else is but secondary.

Thus the ancient immortals said, "Obtain the One, and all things are complete." Having gained the method and cultivating it, every step is the Dao. As the ancient immortals said: "Everywhere the green willows can tether a horse; every household’s gate opens to Chang’an."

To seek the true Unity, one must sincerely practice and naturally attain it. Without deep cultivation, there is no principle by which one may fortuitously obtain it. What Wu Yuanzi discusses here is the primordial great Dao, purely concerned with returning to the origin. If one does not place this body and mind prior to the primordial, the mysterious pass will not open. Thus, following the methods Wu Yuan revealed, without cultivating the natural, the primordial will not manifest, and what is obtained will not be true. If one can embrace, guard, observe, and still, beginning the work prior to the primordial and deeply cultivating the natural state, then one’s entire spirit will have verified the One. Seeking the One through the One is as easy as turning a hand. How could there be the flaw of mistaking the false for the true?

According to what I have heard and what is shown here, the essential cautions are against the two paths of "red lead and plum blossom essence" and "the five metals and eight minerals." The ancient sages practiced these methods solely as catalytic agents, for they possess profound and wondrous functions in drawing forth the mysterious. If used for ingestion, they are utterly contrary to the methods of the immortals and must be vigorously refuted. Beyond these two paths, every other gate can lead to verification of the fruit, but all must proceed from the principle of non-being.

In the sequence of proceeding from non-being, one must follow the inner, outer, and distant observations. Cultivating until there is no emptiness to be emptied, no stillness to be stilled, one then advances to seek the sagely Dao, shattering the void. Then one becomes non-dual and non-identical with the primordial True Unity of the void. This is the way to obtain the primordial True Unity. What I have received from the Primordial Void Master and verified with the True Man of Jizu Mountain is set forth here to supplement what Master Wu Yuan did not expound.

**True and False Body and Mind**

People today all speak of body and mind, knowing only the illusory body and mind, unaware of the true body and mind. Abandoning the true to follow the false, no wonder their allotted lifespan is not exhausted, yet body and mind are prematurely burdened, their form appearing alive while their soul enters the ghostly cavern!

Why is this? The illusory body is the fleshly body; the illusory mind is the human mind. The eyes, ears, nose, tongue, mouth, and intention all arise from the illusory body. Joy, anger, sorrow, happiness, love, aversion, and desire all arise from the human mind. At the gates of the six senses, every aspect is sufficient to destroy life.
