The seven emotions and delusive thoughts, each and every one, can lead to death. At the slightest bump or collision, they erupt. How many escape without harm to life and destiny?

If one takes the illusory body and mind as real, this is to take the thief as the son and the slave as the master. When heaven does not grant more years, where will the body be? Where will the mind be? There is no doubt they are but illusory things.

As for the true and authentic body, it is the Dharmakāya. The true and authentic mind is the celestial mind. Yin and yang, the Five Agents—all arise from the Dharmakāya. The Infant, the Maiden, Wood-Mother, Metal-Elder, Yellow Dame, coral, giant clam, crystal, jasper, and gold—all are born of the celestial mind. The five natures and causes are all seeds of the Dao. The five supreme treasures are all resources for refining the elixir. Gather them, cultivate them, and one may raise the dead, restore life, reverse aging, and return to youth.

Yet most do not recognize this Dharmakāya and celestial mind. Thus, the Dharmakāya lies buried while the illusory body acts; the celestial mind retreats while the human mind rules. For this reason, life after life, death after death, the wheel of rebirth turns endlessly without cease.

This Dharmakāya upholds heaven above and earth below, without head or tail, without back or front, standing centered and unswayed. Speak of its hardness, and it shatters empty space; speak of its softness, and the ten thousand transformations all cease. Speak of its firmness, and it enters water without drowning, enters fire without burning, passes through metal and stone unimpeded—tiger’s spells cannot harm it, blades and weapons cannot touch it. Here life abides.

This celestial mind is neither defiled nor pure, utterly empty yet numinous, still and unmoving, yet responsive when stirred. Speak of its stillness, and it is without sound or scent; speak of its movement, and it is supremely divine and wondrous. Speak of its form, and it is like a crescent moon, like an upturned bowl, like a grain of millet—neither form nor emptiness, yet both form and emptiness; neither being nor non-being, yet both being and non-being. Here the nature abides.

Know this body and mind, and cultivate life and nature—then completing life and nature becomes as easy as turning one’s palm. Thus the ancients said: “These two words, body and mind, lie hidden in ten thousand volumes of alchemical scriptures.” If the illusory body and human mind were so clear and bright that even the foolish could understand, why would ten thousand alchemical texts conceal them? The reason for concealment must lie in secrets too profound to speak. How could one regard them as mere illusory body and mind?

Alas! Are body and mind so easily known? Without decades of exhaustive effort to fathom principle, the Dharmakāya is not easily seen, the celestial mind not easily understood. Without knowing body and mind, how can one cultivate life and nature? Scholars, take heed.

[This true body and true mind are possessed by all. The deluded lose them; the awakened recover them. The ancients transmitted methods of pursuit and gathering—some restored them through the body itself, others used means to guide their return. The key to recovery lies in the fact that the true and illusory arise from one source, differing only in sequence. The One is the essence; the Origin is the function. To follow function is to fall behind; to follow essence is to return to the origin. Scholars, grasp this, and the distinction between essence and function becomes clear. The so-called secrets too profound to speak refer to the wondrous workings of deep cultivation, planting the seed, borrowing the false to return to the true, and the arts of gathering and pursuit. Yet where do these lie, if not within body and mind? One must discern the true and illusory within them, and the path will have its guide, every step aligning with the Dao.]

**On the True and Illusory Nature of Life and Destiny**
The *Book of Changes* says: “Exhaust principle and fulfill nature, to reach destiny.” The ancient immortals said: “To cultivate nature without cultivating life is like a spirit in darkness for ten thousand kalpas, far from sagehood. To cultivate life without cultivating nature is like possessing family wealth without control.” Both speak of the dual cultivation of nature and life.

Yet nature has the principle of nature, and life has the principle of life—without exhausting principle, one cannot know them. Nature has the nature endowed by heaven and the nature of qi and disposition. Life has the life of heavenly decree and the life of Dao-qi. The nature endowed by heaven is innate knowledge and innate ability, possessing all principles and responding to all affairs. The nature of qi and disposition varies with the purity, turbidity, uprightness, or perversity of the qi one receives—hence the differences between worthy and foolish, wise and unworthy. The life of heavenly decree varies in length—premature death or longevity, poverty or wealth, success or failure. The life of Dao-qi is strong, pure, and unified, transcending life and death, enduring through kalpas, unopposed by heaven and earth, unbound by yin and yang.

The nature endowed by heaven is true; the nature of qi and disposition is illusory. The life of Dao-qi is true; the life of heavenly decree is illusory. The true is a thing of prior heaven; the illusory is a thing of later heaven. Prior heaven lies beyond yin and yang; later heaven lies within yin and yang. This difference between true and illusory makes nature and life distinct. Those who cultivate the Dao must know how to cultivate the nature endowed by heaven to transform the nature of qi and disposition, and cultivate the life of Dao-qi to turn the life of heavenly decree. Then the Dao of nature and life is attained.

Moreover, nature is born of the mind. The mind is the abode of spirit; when the mind is clear, the spirit is pure, and when the spirit is pure, nature is settled. Thus the transformation of nature depends on the mind. Life is a single knock on the human mind—knock, and it must respond; respond, and qi stirs; when qi stirs, life takes root. The person is the body, so the transformation of life depends on the body.

Life belongs to another’s domain; nature belongs to one’s own. First seek the method of immortality from another’s domain to establish life, then seek the original thing in one’s own domain to complete nature. Body and mind are not two; nature and life are one family. Thus both nature and life are completed.

The heterodox schools do not know what life is. Some take the qi of later heaven as life, others take the turbid essence in the kidneys as life, still others take orders as life. They do not know what nature is. Some take numinous awareness as nature, others take dull emptiness or extinction as nature, still others take the qi and disposition one receives as nature. These are all cases of speaking of life without knowing its crux, speaking of nature without knowing its source.

What is nature? “Not knowing, not perceiving, following the decree of the Emperor”—this is nature.

Round and perfect, radiant and luminous,
pure and bare, naked and unadorned—this is nature.
When Qian meets Xun, observe the Moon Grotto;
the Moon Grotto is nature.
Observe its wonder through non-desire;
the wonder is nature.

What is life?
The union of male and female essences,
through which the ten thousand things transform and arise—this is life.
The thing within the indistinct and vague,
the essence within the profound and obscure—this is life.
When earth meets thunder, behold the Heavenly Root;
the Heavenly Root is life.
Observe its crux through desire;
the crux is life.

Only when this nature and life are fully fathomed
does one truly know nature and life.
Only when this nature and life are known
can one cultivate nature and life.

Alas!
Those who know are already few,
how much rarer are those who cultivate?
Why do scholars not discern this early?
*(Here, all of nature and life has been laid bare in full!
Truly, without decades of arduous effort, one cannot fully comprehend it.)*

**Precelestial and Postcelestial Yin-Yang**

Precelestial yin-yang is being and non-being.
Postcelestial yin-yang is heart and kidney.
Being and non-being are yin-yang without form;
heart and kidney are yin-yang with image.

Being is the one yang within Kan,
true yang, wondrous being.
Non-being is the one yin within Li,
true yin, true emptiness.
That yang is called "true" makes clear it is no false yang.
That yin is called "true" makes clear it is no false yin.
Where there is true yin and true yang,
there must also be false yin and false yang.

True yin-yang emerges from the precelestial,
operating within the Supreme Ultimate.
False yin-yang arises from the postcelestial,
stored within the body.
False yin-yang exists while the body exists,
perishes when the body perishes, and is destructible.
True yin-yang emerges from the formless,
operates in the imageless, and is indestructible.

For heart and kidney yin-yang
are transformations of the essence and blood from parental union,
possessing qi and substance,
thus existing and ceasing with the body.
As for precelestial yin-yang,
they issue from the Dharma-body,
born of the single qi of emptiness and non-being,
possessing qi but no substance,
thus enduring as long as heaven and earth.
This is the distinction between precelestial and postcelestial.

Yet though precelestial yin-yang are born in the precelestial,
once the body exists, they are stored within the postcelestial,
thus belonging to Kan and Li.
Kan is outwardly yin yet inwardly yang;
its outer yin is postcelestial yin,
its inner yang is precelestial yang.
Li is outwardly yang yet inwardly yin;
its outer yang is postcelestial yang,
its inner yin is precelestial yin.
This is another distinction between precelestial and postcelestial.

Moreover, postcelestial yin-yang operate only within the body,
following the course of creation.
At the zi hour, one yang arises,
a single yang-qi in the kidneys ascends to circulate blood by day.
At the wu hour, one yin arises,
a single yin-qi in the heart descends to circulate blood by night,
yin and yang revolving in alternation.
Since the precelestial is buried and the postcelestial takes charge,
excessive thought harms the spirit,
indulgence in desire depletes essence;
spirit and essence decline,
qi is silently consumed,
and when qi is exhausted, death follows.

As for precelestial yin-yang,
they operate in the void,
reversing the course of creation.
When the living zi hour arrives,
the one yang within Kan returns,
and one advances the yang fire to generate and nurture.
When the living wu hour arrives,
the one yin within Li unites,
and one retreats the yin tally to warm and nourish the Dharma-body.
When the Dharma-body is accomplished,
the ten months of qi are fulfilled,
and one emerges from the sacred embryo as an immortal.
This is yet another distinction between precelestial and postcelestial.

Alas!

Within the postcelestial body, one cannot yet realize nature and fulfill destiny. How much more grievous, then, is the sin of those who take male and female as yin and yang and practice deviant arts? If scholars can truly distinguish between precelestial and postcelestial yin-yang, they should urgently seek a true master for verification—only then may they achieve attainment. If one fails to recognize the true and false of yin-yang, harboring vain hopes that a word or half a phrase could usurp the workings of creation and transcend the mortal to enter sagehood, how could such a thing be possible? Should scholars not reflect deeply upon this?

[This discernment is most refined; scholars should take it as their foundation, for it is the path to advancing in the Dao. If one can extend this understanding into sincere practice, great efficacy will follow. It is not like the side doors, which mistakenly regard near and far applications as rooted in the tangible and the imaginal.

Master Wuyuan said that the profound cannot be grasped in a word or half a phrase—precisely because there is great profundity in this! Yet if one truly establishes their footing in the prior-to-precelestial, they will naturally find resources at every turn.

The late Master Taixu said that cultivation reaching the state of no-self naturally illuminates the unity of the Three Powers, where individual distinctions dissolve into fusion and transformation. The utmost ancients could take the Three Powers as the Dharma-body, take being and non-being as yin and yang, and take the True One as the Wuji. Being and non-being do not move toward movement; movement and stillness do not abide in stillness. Serene and quiescent, beginning and end are as one—this is the Heavenly Heart as my own. If the ancients’ utmost could achieve this, and scholars emulate them, progressing from the temporary to the constant, from effort to ease, is this not wondrous? Such were my master’s sublime teachings. This can supplement what Master Wuyuan’s discourse did not reach, and so I record it here as verification.]

**Internal and External Five Phases**
When the Five Phases converge, the Golden Elixir forms; when the Golden Elixir wanes, the Five Phases disperse—this is an inevitable principle. Yet yin and yang are two, so the Five Phases cannot be one. Why? There are internal Five Phases and external Five Phases; there are the internal and external Five Phases of Heaven and those of Earth.

The Five Phases of Heaven are its movements; the Five Phases of Earth are its qi. The Five Phases of Heaven are the ten celestial stems: *jia*, *yi*, *bing*, *ding*, *wu*, *ji*, *geng*, *xin*, *ren*, *gui*. The Five Phases of Earth are the twelve earthly branches: *zi*, *chou*, *yin*, *mao*, *chen*, *si*, *wu*, *wei*, *shen*, *you*, *xu*, *hai*.

*Jia*, *bing*, *geng*, *ren*, *wu* are yang and external; *yi*, *ding*, *xin*, *gui*, *ji* are yin and internal. *Yin*, *shen*, *si*, *hai*, *chen*, *xu* are yang and external; *zi*, *wu*, *mao*, *you*, *chou*, *wei* are yin and internal.

Yet the Five Phases are but one—why then are there four? Precisely because the Five Phases are born of the two qi of yin and yang. The Dao of Heaven is established as yin and yang; the Dao of Earth is established as softness and hardness. The Five Phases of Heaven are transformed by Heaven’s yin and yang, where metal, wood, water, fire, and earth each possess the qi of yin and yang. *Jia*, *bing*, *geng*, *ren*, *wu* contain yang qi; *yi*, *ding*, *xin*, *gui*, *ji* contain yin qi—these are Heaven’s yin-yang Five Phases.

The Five Phases of Earth are transformed by Earth’s hardness and softness, where metal, wood, water, fire, and earth each possess the qi of hardness and softness. *Yin*, *shen*, *si*, *hai*, *chen*, *xu* contain hard qi; *zi*, *wu*, *mao*, *you*, *chou*, *wei* contain soft qi—these are Earth’s yin-yang Five Phases.

The Five Phases of Heaven govern movement, yet within movement there is stillness; this stillness within movement is *yi*, *ding*, *xin*, *gui*, *ji*. The Five Phases of Earth govern stillness, yet within stillness there is movement; this movement within stillness is *yin*, *shen*, *si*, *hai*, *chen*, *xu*.

Viewed in terms of Heaven and Earth as a whole, Heaven’s Five Phases belong to the external, and Earth’s Five Phases belong to the internal. Viewed in terms of Heaven and Earth as separate forms: among Heaven’s stems, *jia*, *bing*, *geng*, *ren*, *wu* are external, and *yi*, *ding*, *xin*, *gui*, *ji* are internal; among Earth’s branches, *yin*, *shen*, *si*, *hai*, *chen*, *xu* are external, and *zi*, *wu*, *mao*, *you*, *chou*, *wei* are internal. These are the principles of the four Five Phases, their internal and external, yin and yang.

The human body is likewise: there are the Five Phases of the celestial stems and the Five Phases of the earthly branches. The Five Phases of the celestial stems are: original nature, original emotion, original spirit, original essence, original qi as yin; benevolence, righteousness, propriety, wisdom, and trust as yang. The Five Phases of the earthly branches are: wandering soul, ghostly corporeal soul, consciousness, turbid essence, and deluded thought as yin; joy, anger, sorrow, happiness, and desire as yang.

As for the yang of the heart, liver, spleen, lungs, and kidneys, and the yin of the stomach, gallbladder, triple burner, bladder, and large and small intestines—these are turbid substances of the postcelestial, with form and image, and do not belong to the four Five Phases! Only these four Five Phases, when the Dharma-body and illusory body are considered together, employ the Five Phases of the celestial stems to move the Five Phases of the earthly branches. When the Dharma-body and illusory body are considered separately: the Dharma-body perfects nature, emotion, spirit, essence, and qi through benevolence, righteousness, propriety, wisdom, and trust; the illusory body contains joy, anger, sorrow, happiness, and desire within spirit, soul, corporeal soul, and thought.

These are the distinctions of the internal and external Five Phases of Heaven, Earth, and humanity.

The Five Phases have the Dao of mutual generation: metal generates water, water generates wood, wood generates fire, fire generates earth, earth generates metal. They also have the Dao of mutual restraint: metal restrains wood, wood restrains earth, earth restrains water, water restrains fire, fire restrains metal. Moreover, there is the Dao of restraint within generation and generation within restraint. Restraint within generation is the postcelestial’s sequential movement; generation within restraint is the precelestial’s reverse operation. If scholars can truly know generation and restraint, discern reversal and sequence, then the principles of the Five Phases will be perfectly clear.

[These refined principles should be thoroughly pondered in leisure and embodied in practice, each one awakened to clarity in mind and eye. Practice repeatedly, and with deep embodiment, even in busy moments one may act without confusion; when forgetting arises, one will naturally not stray. Scholars must not err through self-deception, for a miss by a hair’s breadth leads to an error of a thousand miles.]

Since our birth, we have turned our backs on the Dao and strayed from the true, losing control of expansion and contraction, deviating from rule and measure—far from the inner state of an infant. At the outset of cultivation, one must place the body in emptiness and establish the mind in stillness, neither aiding nor forgetting. In such profound stillness, without place or time, this is what is meant by "extinguish only the moving mind, not the illuminating mind." When one reaches the point where emptiness is not empty and stillness is not still, then one may focus the body and mind to perceive within. What appears internally will all emerge from the precelestial, yet one must still regard each manifestation with tranquil observation. Over time, the visions will grow ever more pure, and only then may one proceed to maintain them, judiciously adding or removing without error.

The foundation lies in first thoroughly pondering this discourse, advancing step by step in practice, embodying each stage, guarding against distraction and attachment, not allowing perceptions to disturb the mind, and setting aside concerns of efficacy. Forgetting time and days in steadfast practice—this is the essential instruction. When all illnesses of the body are wholly dispelled, one will naturally proceed step by step within the rule, attaining the wondrous effect of every drop returning to the source. Scholars must not dismiss this as mere idle talk of old monks. No matter how surpassing one’s wisdom may be—beyond Yan or Min—without true practice, one cannot enter the gate.

Thus spoke the late Master Taixu. I, Yuanzi, moved by his compassionate intent, have recorded his teachings to share with fellow cultivators.

**Internal and External Medicines**
Medicines are internal and external; practice unfolds in two stages. For those who cultivate the Dao, ignorance of the two medicines—internal and external—is like a blind man walking or a deaf man listening, never attaining success.

What are internal and external? The internal medicine is what one already possesses; the external medicine is what arises from another. What one possesses is *ling mercury*; what arises from another is *true lead*. *Ling mercury* is not quicksilver, nor is *true lead* black tin—both are celestial treasures, not the impure substances of the world.

Now, *ling mercury* is the *alchemical maiden*, the wife who governs within. *True lead* is the *infant boy*, the husband who governs without. Though *ling mercury* is a celestial treasure, its nature is restless; when it sees fire, it flees. Without *true lead* to restrain it, it will wander without trace, inevitably mingling the false with the true, breeding harm within grace—like a woman without a husband, unable to preserve her integrity. Thus, *true lead* is used to restrain *true mercury*; when lead and mercury unite, husband and wife are joined, and when fire is applied, it brings benefit rather than loss.

This *ling mercury* is already present within oneself, requiring no external search. As for *true lead*, after the yang reaches its extreme and yin arises, it departs to another’s domain, no longer belonging to oneself. One must first seek this substance, bring it into one’s own domain, and unite it with *true mercury*, thereby avoiding the misfortune of yin and yang falling out of harmony. Since lead belongs to another and mercury to oneself, there is the distinction of internal and external, self and other.

The alchemical classics speak of the *Seven Returns*—this refers to returning the original nature of *true mercury*—and the *Nine Reversions*—this refers to reverting the original nature of *true lead*. The designation of "another’s domain" does not imply a literal other household; rather, before *true lead* arrives, it is external to oneself, and once it arrives, it becomes internal. The terms "external" and "other" are used only in reference to its state before arrival, not as a fixed separate domain.

The distinction of internal and external arises from this. Originally, at the moment of receiving qi in the womb, lead and mercury were a single qi, without separation of internal and external or division of self and other. Only when the round reaches its limit and begins to wane do lead and mercury part into two places, giving rise to the distinctions of self and other, internal and external.

Yet this lead and mercury have two meanings, which must be understood. During the refinement of the *Returned Elixir*, one takes *black lead* to restrain *red mercury*; when lead and mercury unite, the *Returned Elixir* is formed. This is one distinction of internal and external medicines. Once the *Returned Elixir* is completed, it is also called *true lead*. Ingesting this *true lead* to refine one’s own *yin mercury* dries it in an instant. Then, using the dried mercury to nurture *true lead*, the *Great Elixir* is formed. This is another distinction of internal and external medicines.

If scholars can grasp these two layers of internal and external medicines, the matters of the *Returned Elixir* and the *Great Elixir* will become perfectly clear.

[The discussion of internal and external, self and other, is here made exceedingly clear—scholars will know what to pursue! Moreover, the compassionate instruction on the two layers of internal and external medicines is especially rare. From this, the subsequent stages may be traced. How compassionate! How compassionate!]

The emergence of this text may yet revive the fortunes of the Daoist lineage—how many scholars will recognize its value and delve deeply into its study?

Alas! What Master Wuyuan has revealed pertains only to the *Lesser Return*, while the secret of the *Greater Return* lies precisely in placing body and mind prior to the *Prior Heaven*, drawing them to the primordial unity of the Three Powers, and merging them with the original unity of the self. Its essential function rests entirely on the two characters "from nothingness." For it is from *Wuji* that the One first appears—yet this is not the "nothingness" revered by later followers of Śākya. Rather, it is the utmost *having* that does not cling to having, thereby attaining the utmost *nothingness*. When obtained and ingested, this nothingness is called the Mother of the Myriad Things, the root of the Three Powers. To attain this singular nothingness is to achieve the *Greater Return*. Thus did my late master, the Venerable Taixu, expound in his profound discourse, which I record here to supplement what this treatise has not fully disclosed.

**The Greater and Lesser Returned Elixirs**
As the *Awakening to Reality* states: "The resplendent Golden Elixir is completed in a single day." Yet an ancient scripture says: "The Returned Elixir is formed in an instant, but its nurturing requires ten months." Alas! How could the Way of the Returned Elixir be easily understood?

For there is the *Lesser Returned Elixir* and the *Greater Returned Elixir*. The *Lesser Returned Elixir* is called the *Golden Elixir*, while the *Greater Returned Elixir* is named the *Seven-Return, Nine-Return Golden Liquor Great Elixir*. The *Lesser Returned Elixir* entails returning from the *Posterior Heaven* to the *Prior Heaven*: using *lead* to restrain *mercury*, water to temper fire, the *Golden Duke* to pair with the *Vermilion Maiden*, the *Black Tiger* to harness the *Red Dragon*, the *Black Tortoise* to swallow the *Vermilion Sparrow*; employing the other to refine the self, reclaiming the self’s lost property and restoring its original truth. This is the Way of the Returned Elixir, hence its name, also called the *Golden Elixir*. As the scripture says, "When metal returns to its original nature, it may then be called the Returned Elixir"—this refers to the *Lesser Returned Elixir*. The term "lesser" signifies merely restoring what was lost, recovering the original state of former years, like replenishing what was deficient or reclaiming what had departed. Though this elixir is returned, it has not yet undergone the firing process; if one is careless even for a moment, there remains the risk of losing what was gained. Thus it is called the *Lesser Return*.

Proceeding further with the work above, one must reinstall the furnace and reestablish the crucible, nurturing this Returned Elixir with warmth and care until utmost emptiness and profound stillness are achieved, and *zhen* gives rise to *yuan*. Again, one moves the *yin tally* and *yang fire*, gradually withdrawing and adding, proceeding from nothingness to being, from the subtle to the manifest. After ten months, the embryo is complete, the melon ripens and its stem falls away, and the *Dharma-body* emerges—this is called the *Great Elixir*. As for constructing a new heaven and earth, reinstalling the furnace and crucible, where the child begets grandchildren and grandchildren branch forth, becoming a *Perfected One of the Ten Poles and Great Luo*—this lies beyond the scope of the Greater and Lesser Returned Elixirs.

People today fail to distinguish between the Greater and Lesser Returned Elixirs, yet speak glibly of the Way of the Golden Elixir, vainly hoping that a word or half-phrase from a master will suffice for success. How foolish! Other heterodox and external paths are not even worth discussing. Even among those who have attained genuine insight, some know how to refine the self but not how to gather the medicine; others know how to gather the medicine but not how to install the furnace and crucible; still others know how to install the furnace and crucible but not the method of harmonizing them. There are also those who know only the *Lesser Returned Elixir* but not the *Greater Returned Elixir*, abandoning the work halfway.

Alas! The beginning is with effort, the end is without effort. If one knows the beginning but not the end, attaining the Great Dao will be difficult. Scholars must trace the origin and pursue the consummation, ensuring not a shred of doubt remains before proceeding.

[The discussion here emphasizes the installation of the furnace and crucible, as the ancient sages did. In my humble view, without sufficient worldly resources, even the beginning is difficult—how much more so the end? Thus the Most High, in compassion, opened the door of "establishing the provisional and illusory" to transmit to the Vinaya lineage: first consolidating the *yuan* to stabilize the Dharma, then welcoming the One to form the Elixir. How majestic! How free! Compared to what Master Wuyuan has expounded, this is truly the most wondrous.]

Yet if worldly resources remain insufficient, few indeed escape the fate of sinking into ruin. How much less can one hope for a fortunate encounter without prior cultivation! Thus I have set forth what I have heard to supplement what this discourse has left incomplete. Yet in tracing the origin and pursuing the consummation, one inevitably invites slander; to ensure scholars remain without doubt is simply unattainable.

**On Applying Auspicious and Inauspicious Signs**
As *Wuzhen* states:
*"Fortune and misfortune lie interdependent, ever following one another like shadow and echo. If one can reverse the mechanism of life and death, disaster transforms into blessing in the turn of a palm."*
And again:
*"One must turn the door of death into the door of life—never cling to the gate of life as the gate of death. Only when one comprehends the reversal of the killing mechanism does one realize that harm conceals grace."*

For the Dao of the Golden Elixir, one must first discern the principles of auspicious and inauspicious signs before proceeding or retreating with the times, wielding them at will. Otherwise, ignorant of fortune and misfortune, unable to distinguish right from wrong, one acts recklessly—fire arises from wood, and calamity erupts as surely as conquest follows. Not only will this bring no benefit, but harm will ensue.

**What constitutes auspicious and inauspicious signs?**
*Regarding medicinal substances:*
Auspicious when just arising; inauspicious when past their prime.
Auspicious in the southwest; inauspicious in the northeast.
Auspicious without the *shen*; inauspicious with the *shi-shen*.
Auspicious with *yuan*-essence and *yuan*-qi; inauspicious with postnatal essence and qi.
Auspicious with the true body; inauspicious with the illusory body.
Auspicious with celestial nature; inauspicious with qi-nature.
Auspicious with the Dao-heart; inauspicious with the human heart.

*Regarding gathering and refinement:*
Auspicious when water and fire harmonize; inauspicious when they fail to do so.
Auspicious when metal and wood unite; inauspicious when they remain apart.
Auspicious when the prior Heaven transforms the posterior; inauspicious when the posterior Heaven plunders the prior.
Auspicious when urgency, slowness, and speed align with the moment; inauspicious when gentle simmering or fierce refining exceeds measure.
Auspicious when excess is reduced and deficiency replenished; inauspicious when the correct is abandoned for the perverse.
Auspicious when life is sought within killing; inauspicious when killing lurks within life.

*Regarding the Returned Elixir:*
Auspicious when self and other coexist; inauspicious when self exists without the other.
Auspicious when emotion returns to nature; inauspicious when nature follows emotion.
Auspicious when *yi* arises from accumulated righteousness; inauspicious when *yi* is seized by force.
Auspicious when dragon and tiger do not harm the person; inauspicious when spirit and qi scatter in chaos.
Auspicious when the yang of the other household arrives; inauspicious when the yin of one’s own household congeals.
Auspicious when self-stripping leads to renewal; inauspicious when self-splitting leads to corruption.
Auspicious when *kan* arrives and *li* receives it; inauspicious when it arrives and I am unprepared.
Auspicious when lead restrains mercury; inauspicious when yin consumes yang.
Auspicious when the medicine is sufficient for warm nurturing; inauspicious when fullness is maintained without cessation.

*Regarding the Great Elixir:*
Auspicious when tortoise and snake coil together; inauspicious when dragon and tiger contend.
Auspicious when the Elixir coalesces in an instant; inauspicious when chaos persists for seven days.
Auspicious with a companion of like mind; inauspicious with external demonic intrusions.
Auspicious when danger is guarded against and risks considered; inauspicious when water chills or fire blazes.
Auspicious when sealing is firm and closure secure; inauspicious when errors go unnoticed.
Auspicious when the embryo is complete and transformation occurs; inauspicious when it is forced out prematurely.

All the above pertain to the principles of auspicious and inauspicious signs in both inner and outer Elixirs. One must thoroughly understand each point and scrutinize every detail before proceeding. Further, there is the "hard-won fruit of *Bo*," the "calamity of *Fu*," the "life-disorder of *Tai*," the "joy after *Pi*," the "soundless *Guai*," the "concealed elegance of *Gou*," the "final chaos of *Jiji*," and the "radiant auspiciousness of *Weiji*." Within misfortune lies fortune, and within fortune lies misfortune; fortune and misfortune are unfixed, and transformations are ceaseless. If one’s understanding is not true, one’s actions will be misguided—an error by a hair’s breadth leads to a loss of a thousand miles. Yet if one penetrates the workings of auspicious and inauspicious signs, attaining true knowledge and clear insight, advancing or retreating, hastening or slowing, diminishing or augmenting—all will follow the heart’s intent, and every step will be effective.

*[The discussion here is most precise; scholars must take heed. Yet there exists an exceedingly simple and wondrous method: if one can maintain clarity and harmony in every thought, one will naturally ascend to the Supreme Vehicle. For what Master Wuyuan expounds still belongs to the methods of earthly immortals—what Master Qiongguan called "a path so intricate and difficult that success is rare." What I have described, however, is the method of celestial immortals: "taking the body as lead, the heart as mercury, stillness as water, and wisdom as fire." In refining the fire-times, one relies solely on the central and the harmonious—no hexagrams, no weights or measures. Master Wuyuan did not expound this, hence I have supplemented it thus. If scholars can further establish their foundation prior to the prior Heaven and govern body and mind with the two characters "clarity" and "harmony," they will naturally attain the state of central harmony, entirely free from flaws. Thus spoke my late teacher, Master Taixu.]*

**On Anterior and Posterior Furnace and Crucible**
As *Wuzhen* states:
*"First take Qian and Kun as the crucible and vessel, then gather the crow and hare to refine the medicine. Once these two are driven into the Yellow Path, how can the Golden Elixir fail to form?"*
And again:
*"Within the crescent-moon furnace, the jade bud blooms; in the cinnabar crucible, mercury lies level."*
From this, we know that furnace and crucible are the first steps in cultivation. Without them, where would the medicine be gathered? Where would the Elixir be refined?

Yet the furnace and crucible are not external vessels of bronze, iron, clay, or earth, nor are they the furnaces and crucibles of alchemical women. They are the great creative furnace of the Dao, the majestic radiant crucible. The ancients took *Qian* as the crucible and *Kun* as the furnace, drawing on the meanings of *Qian*’s yang vigor and *Kun*’s yin compliance. The *Qian*-crucible and *Kun*-furnace embody this yang vigor and yin compliance. The so-called "crescent-moon furnace" and "cinnabar crucible" also express this principle of yin and yang, vigor and compliance. The term "crescent moon" signifies the generation of yang within yin, while "cinnabar" signifies the presence of yin within yang. Only when yang is vigorous and yin compliant, with yin aiding yang and yang aiding yin, does one possess the true furnace and crucible of Daoist cultivation.

If one abandons the four characters of "vigorous yang and compliant yin" to seek the furnace and crucible elsewhere, this is to walk the deviant path rather than the true Way!

Yet the furnace and crucible also have distinctions: there is the furnace and crucible of *huandan* (Returning Elixir), and there is the furnace and crucible of *dadan* (Great Elixir). For *huandan*, *Qian* and *Kun* serve as the furnace and crucible, while the crow and hare are the medicinal substances. For *dadan*, emptiness and nonbeing serve as the furnace and crucible, while the singular *qi* is the medicinal substance. Such is the distinction between *huandan* and *dadan*.

However, within *huandan* there is further differentiation—the furnace and crucible of *Kan* and *Li*—which must be discerned early. For this furnace and crucible is of the utmost importance; without knowing it, even with the *Qian* and *Kun* furnace and crucible, the Golden Elixir cannot readily coalesce. Why is this? The crescent-moon furnace is where true fire is generated, and the cinnabar crucible is where true water is generated. Knowing this furnace and crucible, one harmonizes water with fire, uniting water and fire in the same chamber. The primordial *qi* then arises naturally from emptiness and nonbeing, spontaneously coalescing into the supreme treasure. Once this treasure is formed, it re-enters the furnace and crucible of emptiness and nonbeing, where the movement of natural true fire gives rise to form from the formless and substance from the insubstantial. When spirit is complete and the body perfected, the sacred embryo emerges, and even the furnace and crucible of emptiness and nonbeing are no longer needed.

As for the single step beyond, there is yet another furnace and crucible, which cannot be sought through words.

Alas! Furnaces are originally without furnace, crucibles are originally without crucible. The two words "body" and "mind"—the whole world remains deluded about them.

---

The ancients said: "True fire has no fixed timing, and the great medicine is not measured in ounces." *Wuzhen pian* states: "Even if one recognizes cinnabar and black lead, without knowing the fire timing, it is all in vain. It all depends on the power of cultivation; the slightest deviation will fail to produce the Elixir." These are all spoken in regard to fire timing.

Later generations, not understanding the intent behind the ancients' words, either cling to the phrase "true fire has no fixed timing" and fall into quiescent extinction or forgetful dissolution, or they fixate on the line "without knowing the fire timing, it is all in vain" and either doubt the hours of *zi*, *wu*, *mao*, and *you*, or become confused by the years, months, days, and hours of gathering. Some, perplexed by the apparent contradictions in the words, do not delve deeply.

Alas! The ancients' words each have their profound purpose; though their expressions differ, their meaning is the same. When they say "true fire has no fixed timing," they mean that true fire has no unchanging moment—when yang arises, one advances yang; when yin arises, one retreats yin. This is not to say that fire is constantly moving without timing.

When they say "without knowing the fire timing, it is all in vain," they mean that in applying fire, there must be a definite timing. One refines the self and awaits the moment: when yang arises, it is the time to advance fire; when yin arises, it is the time to retreat yin. This is not to speak of rigid, fixed timings.

"Having no fixed timing" and "knowing the timing" are one and the same mechanism. Thus, *Ruyao jing* says: "Within a single day, in the twelve hours, wherever the intent reaches, all can be done." This means that within the twelve hours, there are moments when yin arrives and yang arrives. One anticipates their arrival: when yang comes, advance yang; when yin comes, retreat yin. Whether yin arrives or yang arrives, all are opportune times. The meaning is clear—what need is there for further elaboration?

Yet fire timings are not uniform: there is the inner fire timing and the outer fire timing; the fire timing for gathering the medicine, for refining the medicine, for uniting the Elixir, for coalescing the Elixir; the fire timing for warming and nurturing, for shedding the Elixir, for ingesting the Elixir; the fire timing for forming the embryo, for shedding the embryo; the fire timing for cultivating nature, for cultivating life, for gentle refinement, for fierce tempering. Though the fire timings are many, one must know their precise measures—when to stop, when to proceed, when it is ripe or tender—and apply them accordingly, ensuring not the slightest deviation.

Alas! The moon’s fullness depends on oral transmission; the timing’s subtlety lies in heart-to-heart instruction. How easily can the wonders of fire timing be known?

People today, unaware of the utmost subtlety and refinement of fire timing, cling to the ancients' phrase "a single word or half a phrase can penetrate the mystery" and claim that nothing can be said, nothing can be transmitted. Little do they realize that the wonder of a single word or half a phrase lies in the true master’s whispered revelation, pointing out a secret celestial mechanism—not in the verbal transmission of fire timing.

In the world, even a single art or skill involves countless principles—how much more so the great matter of life and destiny? How could it be comprehended in a single word or half a phrase? Let the seeker reflect deeply on this!

[These instructions are exceedingly subtle, truly the method of the earthly immortals. From what I have heard, the essence lies in knowing the timing and recognizing the signs. When timing is known and signs are recognized, advance and retreat align with measure, responding to both the literary and martial aspects of the process without error. The maintenance and regulation within this practice rest solely with the seeker. Extinguish movement but not awareness; the mechanism manifests of itself. Respond to the moment with appropriate measures, guiding it toward harmony. Let no thought prevail excessively; swiftness lies in the instant of turning, requiring no effort. Yet if one does not abide in utter stillness and profound tranquility, drifting into reckless confusion and stupor, the time will pass unnoticed, the mechanism will remain unperceived—this is truly harmful.

If one can focus the will on quiescence, settle the mind in emptiness, and maintain awareness without deliberate observation, preserving the singular spirit, how could timing ever be missed or the mechanism obscured? Should one neglect this essential method and seek elsewhere, even if one were to master the intricacies of hexagrams and lines, the multitude of formulas and rules would only lead to disorder and distraction, making it impossible to avoid even the slightest deviation.

Thus, in the orthodox tradition of the Most High, all else is swept away, and the essence is found in attaining emptiness and oneness, while harmony—both centered and pure—serves as its function. The Southern School’s Patriarchs Chen and Bai once received confirmation from the Venerable Ancestors Zhong and Lü of the Vinaya tradition. Hence, Chen criticized *The Awakening to Reality* for its limited scope of intention, and in his eulogy for the portrait of Master Ziyang, he subtly remarked, “It still carries the scent of lead and mercury.”

Nevertheless, one must thoroughly ponder the discourse, step by step and stage by stage, grasping its profound meaning. With a settled mind, contemplate it again and again. Then the essence within will be perfectly clear, leaving nothing obscured.]

Moreover, when emptiness reaches its utmost and stillness becomes profound, the singular spirit remains in illumination—then, when the time arrives, one must awaken, and when the mechanism manifests, one must know. How, then, could the fire-tending and timing fail to meet the standard and conform to the rule?

The cardinal principle of the Vinaya tradition lies solely in returning to the primordial and attaining centered harmony, nothing more than preserving the mind-to-mind transmission. As for the claim that a single word or half a phrase constitutes the secret whispered by a true master into the disciple’s ear—this may well provoke suspicion among later learners, leading them astray into heterodox paths. Scholars should examine this carefully, for it is hardly a sound argument. In my humble view, even the Confucian tradition’s “all-pervading unity” reduces to but a single phrase. This is because, when learning nears completion, a single moment of profound realization arises—this, too, is the highest truth. Even if whispered into the ear, it is only because the disciple sits solemnly before the master, their mechanism and principle obstructed, manifesting in their countenance. The master, perceiving this, offers guidance in a low voice, for a loud voice would startle them. Where is there any intent to conceal? Scholars must not misunderstand.

This is a text of great consequence, and thus I dare not refrain from elucidating it.

**“The Other House” and “My House”**
*The Awakening to Reality* states:
*Cease crafty pretense as effort—*
*Recognize the other house’s deathless method.*
It further says:
*Such supreme treasure exists in every house,*
*Yet fools fail to grasp it in full.*

These passages point to the source from which the primordial medicine arises. Later generations, unaware of the ancients’ secret teachings, encounter phrases like “the other house” and “every house” and conjecture them to refer to women, descending into the debased arts of chamber alchemy. Those who, with callous hearts, engage in a hundredfold transgressions, sinking into the realm of beasts, are too numerous to count. How could they know that the primordial qi emerges from the formless void—how could it be sought in the tangible and the manifest?

Man receives the primordial qi, borrowing the essence and blood of ordinary parents to take form, and thus the human body inherently possesses this primordial qi. Yet this qi waxes day and night, and when yang reaches its peak, yin inevitably follows. The yang of the Qian palace flows into the Kun palace, whereupon Qian becomes empty as Li, and Kun becomes full as Kan. Li means the yang has departed; Kan means the true has sunken. When yang is trapped in yin, it no longer belongs to me—hence, “the other house.” *The Awakening to Reality* says:
*To know where the medicine is produced,*
*Look only to the southwest as its native land.*
The southwest is the Kun direction, where yin reaches its extreme and yang is born. Zi Ye says:
*The medicine emerges in the southwest, the Kun position—*
*To seek the Kun position, how could it depart from man?*
*I clearly explain—remember this well,*
*Lest you meet it yet fail to recognize it truly.*

This person is called the “deathless one,” or the “true person.” An ancient immortal said: *If you wish man not to die, you must seek the deathless one.* This “deathless one” is the “deathless method of the other house.” “My house” refers to my true yang having departed, so Li is mine; “the other house” refers to my true yang trapped by yin, so Kan is the other. The distinction between Kan and Li gives rise to the names “other” and “self.” These names exist only while yang has yet to return. If yang does return, then the other is me, and I am the other—there is only one, with no duality. *The Yellow Crane Rhapsody* says: *Imitate the birth of male and female, but only to activate the celestial mechanism.* The terms “imitate” and “activate” apply worldly methods to reveal Daoist principles—they do not mean that male and female are the “other” and “self” within the Dao. Later generations, unaware of the ancients’ subtle intent in their wording, take “the other house” to mean an external other, engaging in bestial acts, corrupting the teachings. They will be fortunate to be reborn as humans in their next life—how could they aspire to immortality?

In the alchemical classics, whenever “other” and “self” are mentioned, they refer to yin and yang; whenever “host” and “guest” are mentioned, they refer to operation; whenever “inversion” is mentioned, they refer to attraction and gathering; whenever “being” and “non-being” are mentioned, they refer to movement and stillness; whenever “dragon” and “tiger” are mentioned, they refer to nature and emotion; whenever “lead” and “mercury” are mentioned, they refer to floating and sinking. In essence, all these are nothing more than the two words “yin” and “yang.” In the end, they are nothing more than the two words “nature” and “life”—yet in truth, they are nothing more than the two words “body” and “mind.”

Those sinful wretches in the world, ignorant of the sagely Dao, take women as “the other house,” the first menstrual blood as the supreme treasure, and plum blossoms as the elixir of immortality. This is not cultivating the sagely Dao—it is slandering it. They are destined for the hell of torn-out tongues!

Alas! That which exists in every house yet does not belong to one’s own house—its use is invisible. If one seeks it, the great essentials are method and resources. It must be sought in the divine land of the Red Continent, for what is seen cannot be used. What is used cannot be seen; if it does not exist within one’s own body, how could another possess it? If it is not found within, what can be sought without? This secret—unless one is profoundly versed in yin and yang, deeply understands the workings of creation, and recognizes the primordial true unity of qi—how could one know it?

[Wu Yuanzhi’s instruction shatters ten thousand layers of darkness, rendering no small service to the study of the mysterious. Yet regarding the “method” in “deathless method,” it remains bound to the character for “person,” failing to point precisely. Wu Yuan was a believer in the ancients, and his error stemmed from the ancients’ excessive secrecy—what they called “intention not universal, revealed yet not revealed,” misleading later learners. This is why my ancestor Zhang suffered three heavenly punishments, though the world mistakenly attributes it to reckless revelation, and thus he was rebuked by the Perfected One abiding on Cock’s Foot Mountain. A Daoist said: *“The ‘deathless person’s method’ in *The Awakening to Reality* corresponds to Bodhidharma’s ‘divine land of the Red Continent’ and the ‘Great Red Heavenly Palace’ in the *Daoist Canon*. Zi Ye’s ‘how could it depart from man’ refers to the ‘people of the Great Red Heaven’—hence, the true person.”*]

"Now, this Heavenly Palace is the original position of the human primordial *qi*. When the human primordial *qi* is depleted and one seeks to restore it, one must naturally seek it within this palace. For this palace, in terms of the body, is located no farther than the heart and abdomen—thus, what the texts describe and what Bodhidharma sought all align perfectly.

Furthermore, in theoretical terms, humans bear *qian* (Heaven) upon their backs and tread upon *kun* (Earth). The direction of *kun*: in the *xiantian* (precelestial) arrangement, *kun* lies due north; in the *houtian* (postcelestial) arrangement, *kun* lies in the southwest. The ancients regarded the human primordial *qi* as relying upon *kun*, hence the saying: *'The people of the southwest are the deathless ones.'*

Moreover, according to the *Falu* (Dharma Registers), *qian* is the Gate of Heaven, *gen* the Door of Earth, *xun* the Path of Ghosts, and *kun* the Gate of Humans—can the learner not awaken to this? This teaching originates from the Vinaya School and is cited here to supplement what has not yet been revealed in this discourse.

The *Zhenzheng Shoujing* (*Awakening to Reality*) states: *'The White Tiger’s* Shoujing *is the supreme treasure.'* It also says: *'When lead encounters* gui *(the tenth celestial stem), it must be swiftly gathered.'* These all refer to the *Shoujing* as the *qi* of the primordial True One.

The White Tiger pertains to the west, belonging to *dui* metal. *Shou* (首) signifies the ancestral *qi* of the *xiantian*. *Jing* (经) denotes the constant Way."

The ancestral *qi* of the *xiantian* is concealed within *kan*, trapped by yin *qi* and unable to emerge on its own. The youngest maiden of *dui* possesses the true earth of *kun*’s palace, acting in place of the mother to arouse the yang within *kan*, returning it to *kun* and manifesting as the *Shoujing*—this is the crescent moon of the third day, also called the Heart of Heaven and Earth, the *qi* of the *xiantian*, or true lead. As it lies beneath accumulated yin, stillness reaches its extreme and gives rise to movement, and yang *qi* begins its return, becoming the constant path through which the ancestral *qi* of the *xiantian* flows—hence it is called *Shoujing*. The term *Shoujing* refers to its essence, while "lead encountering *gui* and being swiftly gathered" refers to its function.

Now, lead is *ren* water. *Ren* water is clear, while *gui* water is turbid. When *ren* water first arises, it is like dew or a pearl—difficult to obtain and easy to lose. The moment it appears, one must act swiftly. If there is the slightest delay, *gui* water will arise, and once *gui* water appears, *ren* water will conceal itself, falling into the *houtian* and becoming unusable. To gather *ren* water is to gather the true *Shoujing*. This *jing* arises in the *xiantian* and abides in the *houtian*; it gives birth to heaven, earth, and all beings. Following it leads to death, reversing it leads to life. Immortality lies here, and so does mortality. Originally, immortals and mortals were no different, but when yang reaches its extreme, yin arises, and the central yang of *qian* flees to *kun*’s palace. The emptiness within *qian* becomes *li*, while the fullness within *kun* becomes *kan*. The *xiantian* *qian* and *kun* transform into the *houtian* *kan* and *li*, and the true *jing* thus conceals itself.

The great cultivator, through methodical pursuit, gathers this true *jing* within a single *shichen*, refining it into the elixir, called the Golden Elixir. Ingesting it restores youth and grants immortality. Thus, the Golden Elixir is none other than the *Shoujing*—before refinement, it is called *Shoujing*; after refinement, it is called the Golden Elixir. The Golden Elixir and the *Shoujing* are one and the same, not two distinct things.

Later generations, deluded and failing to grasp the profound intent of the ancestral masters, mistakenly assume the *Shoujing* refers to the first menstruation of a fourteen-year-old girl. Alas! The *Shoujing* is the *Shoujing*—it is not the supremely pure and immaculate *jing* of sages and worthies, but rather the utterly turbid and filthy *jing* of ordinary mortals. The character *jing* (经) means "path," and a path is the Way. The character *dao* (道) is composed of *shou* (首, "head"), *chi* (彳, "movement"), and *zhi* (止, "stillness"). *Chi* and *zhi* represent the *qi* of movement and stillness. The "head" of *qi*—is this not the *Shoujing*? Thus, the Way is the *Shoujing*, and the *Shoujing* is the Way.

This *Shoujing* is formless and imageless, soundless and odorless. To describe it is to miss it; to discuss it is to lose it. It cannot be depicted in diagrams; it can only be spiritually apprehended—how could it be the turbid blood of menstruation? As for the theory of the five thousand and forty-eight *huangdao* days, this refers to the secret of yin reaching its extreme and giving birth to yang, the return of the *xiantian*—it is not fixed at fourteen years. Fourteen years amount to five thousand and forty days; where do the remaining eight days reside?

Now, five is the generative number of earth, and one thousand and ten are its completion numbers. Four is the generative number of metal. Earth belongs to *kun*, and metal to *dui*. From *dui* to *kun*, yin reaches its extreme and gives birth to yang. In the southwest, one gains companions, and the moon appears in the *geng* direction—is this not the *Shoujing*? The eight days refer to the first quarter moon in *dui*, when metal and water are in balance, yin and yang harmonize, and the *qi* resides at the center of the *huangdao*—this is yin giving birth to yang, the *qi* of yang flowing and returning to the central path. Is this not the five thousand and forty-eight *huangdao* days?

Moreover, eight days exceed seven by one. Heaven and earth return in seven days. When yin reaches its extreme and yang arises, the seventh day marks the return, and the eighth day marks the flow, with the increase returning to the central path—this precisely aligns with the theory of the five thousand and forty-eight *huangdao* days. The eight days also represent the union of three and five. When three and five unite, yang *qi* becomes pure, a single *qi* pervading all, standing centered and unbiased, like the full moon on the fifteenth day, radiant and complete, traversing the center of heaven and earth—this, too, accords with the theory of the five thousand and forty-eight *huangdao* days.

The seventh day marks the return, the eighth day the first quarter, and the union of three and five—all signify stillness reaching its extreme and giving rise to movement, the *qi* of yang beginning its flow at the "head." The ancestral masters’ words are profound and of great significance—how could they be carelessly misconstrued as the first menstruation of a fourteen-year-old girl? As for the first menstruation of a fourteen-year-old girl, this is yang reaching its extreme and giving birth to yin, not yin reaching its extreme and giving birth to yang. Blood belongs to yin; when menstrual blood flows, it is the manifestation of yin arising. How could one mistakenly identify this utterly turbid substance as the supremely pure *qi* of the *xiantian*?

The *Awakening to Reality* states: *"To mend broken bamboo, one must use bamboo; to hatch a chick, one must use an egg."* The *Triple Concordance* says: *"Work is easily done with like kind; without the proper seed, skill is in vain."*

For when one’s *xiantian* is damaged, one must use one’s own *xiantian* to replenish it—only then is it the true seed of like kind. When one’s nature and life are unstable, one must still rely on one’s own nature and life to restore them—only then is it the true seed of like kind. If one abandons one’s own original substance and seeks another’s, how can that be the true seed of like kind?

Each person possesses their own nature and life. Another’s nature and life cannot be given to me, just as my nature and life cannot be given to another—this principle is self-evident without need for debate. If a man could attain the Dao by obtaining a woman’s first menstruation, why then could a woman not achieve immortality by obtaining a man’s essence? If a man cultivates the Dao by using a woman, then a woman cultivating the Dao must likewise use a man! This principle, too, is self-evident without need for debate.

I urge fellow cultivators to swiftly fill the pit of delusion, urgently open both eyes, distinguish between the perverse and the upright, discern right from wrong, accumulate virtue and establish conduct—thereby securing a lasting foundation. How much better than toiling in the city of confusion or seeking a luminous pearl in a vat of black lacquer!

How exhilarating this refutation! Like an elder magistrate rendering a verdict, not a single word can be altered.

Hang this upon the gates of every kingdom—who would dare utter even a single word of dissent? This very essay alone is destined to elevate its author to the leadership of the immortals. Yet, alas, in matters concerning the true seed of one’s own kind, his vision remains narrow, his instruction limited. One suspects he has not received the full transmission of the great work from a true master!

For humans stand alongside heaven and earth as the Three Powers, all born of the primordial True One. If one’s own kind is allowed to decline, the Three Powers remain a single qi—one in three, three in one. Even if the yang of this body becomes exhausted and deficient, the ancient sages taught: “When bamboo is broken, mend it with bamboo.” If one does not seek restoration from the source that generates the Three Powers, where else could recovery be found? This principle shines clearly: one must never abandon the True One in thought after thought. Seek the One with the One, as the mind commands the body; once the One descends and fills, what difficulty remains in mending the break?

Yet people, in their ignorance, persist in following the current and chasing the branches, unaware of returning to the root and restoring the origin—thus allowing yin to grow while yang wanes. Since Master Wu Yuan has grasped the wondrous meaning of return, why does he not expand his wisdom and power, morning and night, becoming a model for the world? Let him first test it in his own body: when bodily yin is exhausted, bodily yang becomes pure. If others achieve it in one, strive a hundredfold; if others achieve it in ten, strive a thousandfold. Progress from effort to ease, from ease to attainment. Do not seek small gains, nor desire hasty results. Advance from moments to hours, from hours to days, from days to months, from months to years—what need is there to seek other methods?

Mountains, rivers, and the great earth are none other than the cauldron; all creatures that move and possess spirit are none other than the medicine.

How to gather? How to congeal? How to refine and temper? Warm it, nurture it, perfect it, release it—until pulverizing the void is achieved. Master Wu Yuan has heard these instructions in full! To act as a model for the world—is this not joyous indeed? Do not say your virtue and conduct are yet unremarkable, for the *Three Nuns’ Medical Writings for Saving the World* remain, offering teachings that may be practiced in parallel without contradiction.

Alas! Even one as self-cultivated as Master Wu Yuan has attained such heights in learning and practice. Though the cosmos is vast, how many possess a heart-virtue like his? Among the earthbound immortals of the Qianlong and Jiaqing eras, how many remained? Yet Master Wu Yuan never once encountered them.

Not understanding is no understanding—let this serve as a humble admonition.

**Taming and Refining the Nine Cauldrons**
The *Cantong Qi* states: *"Only the sages of old, embracing the primordial and holding fast to the true, tamed and refined the nine cauldrons, concealing their traces in obscurity."* An ancient immortal also said: *"To subdue qi, one must not merely ingest qi; to ingest qi, one must first subdue qi. Ingesting qi does not grant longevity—longevity requires subduing qi."* These are the essential words of the alchemical classics, yet later generations fail to grasp their meaning.

Those who practice external alchemy use nine cauldrons to refine elixirs; those who cultivate inner elixirs employ nine women to gather qi. Alas! How could the principle of the nine cauldrons refer merely to iron vessels or female crucibles? To mistake it as such is to transform the ancestral masters’ heavenly ladder for crossing the world into a passport to Fengdu—how tragic, how lamentable!

What is meant by "taming and ingesting"? It is to subdue the primordial qi, filling the abdomen—not the consumption of metals, minerals, herbs, or plants. What is meant by the "nine cauldrons"? It signifies the nine transformations of the golden elixir, the state of pure yang without yin—not the furnace fires of nine vessels or the inner alchemy of nine women.

The primordial qi is invisible to the eye, inaudible to the ear, and intangible to the touch. Like dew, like lightning, it comes without trace and departs without shadow—hard to obtain, easy to lose. The perfected one refines the substantial into the insubstantial, transforms the tangible into the intangible. Gathering years into months, months into days, days into hours...

At this very moment, one seizes the primordial qi of three thousand six hundred years and reverses the seventy-two seasonal nodes at their crucial junctures. Subduing this single point of precelestial true yang, one draws it into the furnace of creation, where it congeals into the sacred embryo—this is called "taming and ingesting." After the embryo is formed, one employs the natural true fire to smelt away all residual yin, revealing the original face of the primordial yang. Thus is forged the indestructible substance of diamond—this is called the "Great Elixir of Nine Transformations," or "taming and refining the nine cauldrons." This is the work of the Dharma-body, accomplished from within the formless, free from any marks of male or female, untainted by the vessel of temperament or flesh.

Thus did the ancient immortals say: *"Cauldrons are originally without cauldron; medicines are originally without medicine."* What is called "furnace and cauldron, medicine and substance" is but a borrowed image of smelting and refining, a metaphor for the method of cultivating the golden elixir—it is not that a literal furnace or cauldron exists. The golden elixir is the Supreme Ultimate. Within the Supreme Ultimate resides the One Qi: when it moves, yang is born; when it rests, yin is born. Extreme motion must return to stillness; extreme stillness must return to motion. Extreme yang must give way to yin; extreme yin must give way to yang. Yin and yang are mutually rooted. The Four Images, Five Phases, Eight Trigrams, Heavenly Stems and Earthly Branches, and the myriad phenomena all arise from this! This is the Dao of creation’s natural course.

If one wishes to fulfill one’s nature and attain destiny, one must seize creation, reverse life and death, invert the Five Phases, and overturn the mechanisms of qi, returning to the undifferentiated One Qi and completing the original form of the Supreme Ultimate. How could a tangible furnace or cauldron refine such a thing? The so-called "smelting and refining of the golden elixir" is precisely the aim of completing the Supreme Ultimate. The Supreme Ultimate is a perfect sphere. When perfection reaches its limit, it must wane—hence the need for cultivation to preserve it. The Supreme Ultimate is originally without flaw, but through the interplay of yin and yang, it becomes flawed. To preserve the Supreme Ultimate, one must first harmonize yin and yang. When yin and yang merge, the One Qi circulates, restoring the original undifferentiated form of the Supreme Ultimate—this is called "gathering the medicine and refining the elixir." Because the medicine must be blended, the vessel for its blending is called the "cauldron." Because the medicine must be refined, the instrument of its refinement is called the "furnace." Because the refined substance becomes true and enduring, it is named the "golden elixir." Yet in truth, "cauldron," "furnace," and "golden elixir" are all provisional names and borrowed images, revealing only the ebb and flow of transformation. If even names and images are nonexistent, how much less could there be the filthy practices of "female cauldrons" and "furnace stoves"?

Alas! Since attaining the secret of longevity,
Year after year, I seek a kindred spirit upon the sea.
Who among you is a true listener?
Ponder deeply these wild words and search within.

---

The Mysterious Pass

The scriptures say: *"There are three thousand six hundred gates to the Dao, and each person clings to their own sprout of a root."* Yet if one wishes to know this subtle Mysterious Pass, it lies beyond those three thousand six hundred gates. This pass is the most profound and wondrous threshold: here life and death are divided, here sage and mortal part ways. It is the secret transmitted from master to disciple through the ages, not something to be guessed at or fathomed by ordinary means.

Later students, failing to meet a true teacher, have mistaken it for the nostrils, the space between the eyebrows, the fontanel, the Baihui point, the throat, the Jiaji spine, the coccyx, the heart’s aperture, the Yellow Court, the Cinnabar Field, the Primordial Pass, or the Sea of Qi—yet none of these is the Mysterious Pass. The Mysterious Pass is without form or image; how could it have a fixed location? It is neither form nor emptiness; how could it occupy a place? If one were to fix it to a place or location, it would become a thing of form and image, and thus could no longer be called the Mysterious Pass.

This pass is neither attached to nor separate from the illusory body. It is not attached to the illusory body because it is not any tangible thing. It is not separate from the illusory body because it cannot be sought outside the body. Since it is neither within nor without the body, there must exist something that is neither internal nor external—here lies the celestial mechanism! Thus the ancients dared not commit it to writing, yet neither could they keep it entirely secret. They referred to it by many names: the Gate of Life and Death, the Mysterious Female, the Altar of Dragon and Tiger, the Aperture of Tortoise and Snake, the Gate of Wu and Ji, the Pass of Life and Death, the Gate of Punishment and Virtue, the Door of Yin and Yang, the Gate of Myriad Wonders, the Palace of the Inaudible and Invisible, the Land of Immortals and Buddhas, the Aperture of Nature and Destiny, the Chamber of the Original Spirit, the Cavern of Emptiness, the Realm of Thunderous Silence, and countless other designations—all to illuminate this single aperture.

Master Ziyang said: *"This aperture is no ordinary aperture; it is formed by the union of Heaven and Earth. It is called the Cavity of Spirit and Qi, within which resides the essence of Kan and Li."* These words reveal the great celestial mechanism, yet how is it that people cannot recognize it?

Now, I, Wu Yuanzi, spare not even my lips to vividly transmit the spirit of the ancestral masters, revealing what has never been revealed and disclosing what has never been disclosed. Through spiritual resonance and intuitive alignment, I declare to my fellow cultivators: This aperture resembles Penglai Island—small without yet vast within, fathomless in depth, neither round nor square, where black and white merge, and the hidden and manifest interpenetrate.

Its gate stands five *zhang* high and four *chi* wide, with two doors—one open, one closed. To the left coils the Azure Dragon; to the right crouches the White Tiger. Above soars the Vermilion Bird; below rests the Dark Warrior. Vague and indistinct, profound and obscure, within dwells the True Person, named Valley Spirit, styled the Long-Lived One. By day he consumes millet porridge; by night he drinks the wine of primordial chaos. At times he sings in pure harmony; at times he seals his lips tight. With one exhalation, the aperture’s gate opens; with one inhalation, it closes. Thus the *Daodejing* says: *"The Valley Spirit does not die—this is called the Mysterious Female. The gate of the Mysterious Female is called the Root of Heaven and Earth."* It is the aperture through which Heaven, Earth, and humanity are born, the homeland where sages, buddhas, and immortals are made. Here the furnace is established and the cauldron set; here the medicine is gathered and refined. Here the elixir is formed; here the elixir is released. Here the willed and the effortless converge; here all practice begins and ends. Yet this aperture lies beyond the four great elements, within the realm of stillness and emptiness. Seek it with intent, and it cannot be found; seek it without intent, and it remains elusive. Those who cultivate must first pursue this single aperture, attaining true knowledge and clear vision before venturing to grasp the celestial treasure. Without knowing this aperture, no matter how diligently one labors or how bitterly one toils, all effort will be in vain. Should scholars not exert themselves to the utmost, devoting their hearts to fathoming this principle?

[Now, a cautious note: Measured against the teachings of true masters, Wu Yuanzi’s insights, though gleaned from texts, lack the verification of an authentic teacher. His error lies in relying on written descriptions to "attain true knowledge and clear vision," a poison deeply ingrained. The Three Corpses within seize the opportunity to weave illusions—phantasms of towering gates, shifting dimensions, opening and closing doors, colors, and sounds. Self-taught and self-deluded, he mistakes these visions for validation, drawing from books to justify his claims. Trusting in his "true knowledge," he proceeds to act, unaware he has already entered the thorny labyrinth of the Rakshasa’s cave. Had he encountered a true master who shouted, commanding him to place his mind before the primordial, in stillness beyond stillness, preserving only awareness, he would not have fallen into lifeless extinction. When phenomena—being and non-being, boundless and formless, real and illusory—arise and vanish within, one must meet them with the mechanism of *qi*. Thus, whatever appears or recedes naturally returns, while one remains anchored in the profound serenity of the mysterious scene. Should one not emerge from samadhi, all processes—gathering, refining, forming, and releasing the elixir, warming and nurturing—unfold spontaneously, requiring only subtle maintenance to prevent imbalance. This is the work that follows the opening of the Mysterious Pass, entered through the secret of "no-thought within thought." Before its opening, one must simply place body and mind before the primordial, progressing from effort to ease, allowing it to manifest without forced pursuit. The "pursuit" spoken of by the ancients refers to returning to the primordial, without conceptualization. Any trace of conceptualization in ordinary times will inevitably give rise to illusory visions during practice. Wu Yuanzi’s affliction stems precisely from his habitual reliance on textual interpretations. Thus, his account should not be followed uncritically.

Know this: when we speak of a "pass" or an "aperture," we refer only to a stage of practice, not to any tangible structure. A "pass" implies obstruction; an "aperture" implies passage and receptivity. If scholars establish their foundation before the primordial and deeply embody spontaneity, the mysterious conditions before them *are* the conditions within the aperture—why labor to pursue them? My late teacher, Master Taixu, taught thus, as did the Perfected Ones: Zhang the Disheveled, Li the Mud-Pill, Huang of Chicken Foot Mountain, and Li the Barefoot. All affirmed that the Mysterious Pass opens without fixed location, and its visions have no fixed form. Were it to open in a fixed place with fixed visions, it could not be called the Mysterious Pass. For this pass encompasses countless eons before and after, its profound principles and realms finer than dust, yet nothing is omitted. It responds to touch as swiftly as an echo. Whether one enters depends on the moment of contact; a misstep before or after seals the way. Thus, the ancients’ essential method of cultivation begins with utter emptiness and profound stillness, discerning the arising of movement and stillness. If one stirs falsely, the pass responds falsely—this bears great consequence. How could the mechanism be rashly activated?

The ancients regarded this pass and aperture as encompassing all principles and containing all realms. Yet if practitioners have not purified themselves, or if their purity has not attained spontaneity, they will find it impossible to enter the true realm of the Mysterious Pass. Reflecting on this, I sigh with sorrow: Had Wu Yuanzi heard these teachings earlier, it would have made all the difference—whether one enters the Dao or achieves it hinges entirely on this aperture. How could I not supplement his account?

With this, my narration concludes. I drift into slumber, unaware of my surroundings. At first, stars and moon hung in the sky; then distant mountains appeared like a painting, and a post station nestled by the flowing stream.

Ascending to gaze, I beheld a vast expanse of tranquil waves, the moon mirrored at the lake’s heart, and a skiff cutting swiftly through the water. I called out: "Ferry?" Thrice I asked, yet received no answer. Sensing the intent, I removed my sandals and boarded. The boatman said: "Now it is right!" Once aboard, I saw it was no mere skiff but a great vessel. Waves surged violently, yet the ship, though vast, did not capsize. When the waters stilled, we had already reached the shore.

By then, I had placed myself in the realm of *wu-he-you*—the land of nothing-whatever—so the raging waves did not startle me, nor did the calm waters bring joy. The boatman regarded me with approval. Thus we disembarked, my sandals still upon my feet. I did not think myself extraordinary, yet the boatman nodded deeply and said: "So it is—you truly know the affairs of the Mysterious Pass." With these words, the shore was no longer a shore but a pure abode.

Behind it rose sheer cliffs, and below lay a pool. A youth entered from outside, announcing: "A guest has come." The one who came forth to greet me was none other than Master Wu Yuan, bareheaded in a blue hemp robe, leading a company of four or five: two Daoist priests, three elders, and a white-robed attendant. They ascended the slope along a bamboo path. Upon seeing me, Wu Yuan bowed deeply, his courtesy most reverent. I returned his bow.

Upon rising, I awoke to nothing heard or seen—the night watch had already struck three! This is the wondrous principle of responsive resonance, though I know not who the boatman truly was. Thus I record this to ponder further.

**Celestial Guidance and the Workings of the Dipper**
The *Cantong Qi* states: *"Following the Dipper to its Shaking Radiance, grasping the balance to fix the primal order."*
Zhang Sanfeng says: *"Revolving the Dipper’s handle and pivot-star, refining a crucible of true sun and moon, sweeping away the three thousand six hundred paths."*

The Dao of cultivating truth requires understanding the workings of the Celestial Guidance (Tian’gang), for only then can one reverse the course of creation, invert heaven and earth, and manipulate yin and yang without being manipulated by them.

The Celestial Guidance is the seventh star of the Northern Dipper, also called the Breaker of Armies, the Shaking Radiance, or the Pivot-Star. It is the chief minister of the North Pole, wielding the scale of life and death, grasping the handle of creation and transformation. It governs the Five Phases, propels the Four Seasons, generates the myriad things, leads the constellations, and serves as the pivot of cosmic qi. Its duty is weightiest, its merit greatest.

Humans, born of heaven and earth’s upright qi, also possess this Celestial Guidance’s qi, which governs life and death and holds the reins of destiny—its function no different from the Dipper’s Guidance above. Those who know this live; those who remain ignorant perish. Yet this Guidance Star has both precelestial and postcelestial aspects, which must not be confused.
