The postcelestial Guidance Star circulates daily through the twelve meridians, harmonizing the blood and vessels of the entire body. Those who refine the Guidance qi merge human and celestial Guidance, unifying inner and outer qi to repel the hundred evils. Yet in seeking the external, they lose the internal, becoming hollow and insubstantial—benefiting none while harming themselves first.

As for the precelestial Guidance Star, it is intimately bound to the original master, united as ruler and minister, advancing in harmony without conflict. But once the primordial yang is broken, the precelestial enters the postcelestial, turning its back on the master to seek glory, allying with external foes. At first, it guards one’s life and destiny; later, it harms them—like a tiger fleeing to the west, utterly estranged. Why? The Guidance Star’s seat brings misfortune; its point brings fortune. If it does not point to me but to another, then vital qi resides with the other, while killing qi remains with me. Unceasing slaughter will topple my life and destiny!

Great cultivators seeking the deathless elixir of others do so precisely to capture the vital qi to which the Guidance Star points. The method of capturing qi never departs from the Guidance Star. If the Guidance Star sits in my domain, vital qi resides in another’s; if it sits in another’s domain, vital qi resides in mine. Thus, one must shift the Guidance Star to sit in another’s domain to achieve creation.

The method of shifting the Guidance is not difficult—simply twist the other’s heel, and they will turn back, returning home to recognize their origin. This celestial mechanism is neither bound to form nor sound, nor does it dwell in emptiness. It is not something one possesses, nor is it sought outside the self. It is already complete, radiantly clear.

The world encounters it yet fails to recognize it, often letting it slip away before their very eyes. This is what is meant by: *"The position before Pojun—the vow never to transmit to others."* Yet "not transmitting to others" does not mean it is truly withheld; rather, one fears passing it to the unworthy, for even spirits and gods would not tolerate such a transgression.

This matter is the rarest under heaven. Those who attain it master life and death at will, their nature and destiny free—neither heaven nor earth can enslave them, nor yin and yang constrain them. Only those of utmost loyalty and filial piety can bear its weight; only those of supreme worthiness and virtue can uphold it. The noble who obtain it remain steadfast in adversity, while the base who gain it treat life lightly. It is not something that any heterodox path or external doctrine can fathom, even in part.

Alas! Those who awaken ascend instantly to sagehood; those who remain deluded sink into eternal perdition. The golden toad, the jade crow—recognize the true, and you become a master. Yet why do so many fail to recognize the Guidance Star?

*(This discourse should be revered as a treasure by seekers, for it is the profound and hidden Dao of celestial spirits. Master Wuyuan’s compassion in revealing it thus moves me beyond measure. To know it and practice it with sincerity is to extinguish the Three Worms. I have heard of this for forty-nine years, yet dared not disclose it—fearing divine retribution!)*

Once, when Ancestor Lü achieved the Reverted Elixir thrice yet lost it thrice, it was because he had not obtained this single secret. Only after receiving Master Cui’s *Mirror for Absorbing the Medicine* and further verifying it with Ancestor Zhong did he dare employ the esoteric transmission of the Guidance Star. The Precept School preserves it through generations as the *Supreme Mind-to-Mind Transmission of the Most High*. Those who attain this secret align unknowingly with the ancients. Yet all the world’s learners know only "turning the light inward"—how could they know this is the very secret of twisting the Guidance Star? As the saying goes: *"The people may be made to follow, but not to understand."* Henceforth, scholars at last have a compass! Not only may the Reverted Elixir be congealed, but the self may thereby be perfected.

The late Master Tai Xu once said: *"In the study of the Mysterious, every step is free of demonic obstruction—all depends on the secret of twisting the Guidance Star."* To obtain and embody it is precisely the "turning the light inward" of reflective illumination. The Master has revealed it, and thus I secretly rejoice for all learners.

**Life and Death, Punishment and Virtue**
The *Scripture of Unconscious Unison* states:
*"When Heaven unleashes its killing mechanism, stars shift and constellations alter. When Earth unleashes its killing mechanism, dragons and serpents rise from the land. When Man unleashes his killing mechanism, Heaven and Earth are overturned."*

The *Scripture of Dao and Virtue* says: *"Weapons are instruments of ill omen, not the tools of the noble—used only when unavoidable."* Yet while killing harms life, it may also defend it; while punishment harms virtue, it may also perfect it. The key lies in spiritual illumination—it rests with the individual.

From the moment of birth, one inherits the nature of qi and disposition, receives the essence and blood of parents, accumulates the dust of karmic consciousness across kalpas, and gathers the filth of lifelong habits. Thus, the entire body, above and below, is swirling with yin qi—only a single spark of yang qi lies hidden in the mountain of form, concealed and unseen. This is what the ancients meant by: *"The four great elements of the body are all yin—what thing is the yang essence?"*

Though the body is yin, if it has not yet engaged with the postnatal, the prenatal still governs, and no harm arises. The profoundly wise guard against danger and peril at this stage, fortifying true yang so it is not invaded by postnatal yin qi. Thus, they transcend directly to the other shore, and the methods of punishment and killing become unnecessary. As the saying goes: *"Laws exist to eliminate abuses; where no abuses exist, laws need not be applied."* This is why punishment and killing are not employed.

Yet when the prenatal lies dormant and the postnatal takes charge, yin qi surges forth, and the entire body becomes diseased. Some afflictions have already manifested, others have not; some take root across kalpas, others in the present life; some arise from Heaven, others from man. A hundred strange forms, ten thousand demonic obstructions—all emerge in myriad ways.

Should there be no methods to restrain yin and support yang, nor arts to transform the perverse and return to the correct, then yin qi will grow day by day, waxing ever stronger, until it consumes all yang, toppling life itself—this is where punishment and killing must be applied. Punishment and virtue, life and killing: these four depend upon one another. For punishment perfects virtue, and virtue employs punishment; killing defends life, and life rescues from killing. If one resorts only to punishment without virtue, or killing without life, then punishment and killing become excessively harsh, inevitably injuring harmonious qi. If one relies solely on virtue without punishment, or life without killing, then life and virtue lack authority, allowing perverse influences to steal in. Only when life and killing are both employed, punishment and virtue both enacted, can unforeseen calamities and unpredictable anxieties be averted. Punishment and killing serve to transform yin qi; life and virtue serve to preserve yang qi. When yang qi flourishes, yin qi naturally recedes; when yin qi dissipates, yang qi naturally consolidates. How could the interplay of life, killing, punishment, and virtue be of minor benefit?

For the practitioner who comprehends the pivot of punishment and virtue, who grasps the application of life and killing, then punishes with virtue, gives life through killing; within punishment lies virtue, within killing lies life. Punishment is used to safeguard virtue, killing to support life. Responding to adversity with compliance, adjusting pace and progression—nothing is fixed, yet nothing is impossible.

*(The principles of punishment, virtue, life, and killing, upon which the alchemical processes of refining, warming, and nurturing depend to achieve success, have already been expounded in detail. Yet how one comes to know and practice them remains to be addressed. For there exists a secret to attaining such knowledge and mastery! What is this secret? It lies in the four methods of wielding, sustaining, illuminating, and attending. When these four methods are meticulously observed, the subtlest signs become perceptible, and one is not deluded by the transformations of qi. Then punishment and virtue, life and killing are aptly applied, and the Dao of the Elixir is perfected. This is the great linchpin of the study of destiny. Yet without a pure cultivation of inherent nature, few will not find it thorny.)*

**Superior and Inferior Virtue**
The ancient scriptures state: *"Superior virtue acts without contrivance, and thus has no need for contrivance. Inferior virtue acts with contrivance, and thus has contrivances."* They also say: *"Those of superior virtue preserve their form through the Dao; those of inferior virtue prolong their lives through techniques."* Both speak of superior and inferior virtue, distinguishing between their bodily endowments and the methods they employ.

Those of superior virtue possess a complete and intact body, replete with virtue, their primordial yang unharmed. "Unharmed" refers to the primordial yang before Heaven, not the unbroken body after Heaven. When primordial yang is fully intact, it is pure and perfectly refined, a singular, undifferentiated qi, the Five Phases gathered, the Four Images harmonized—every precious treasure, every fine rarity, is wholly present. Without methods to preserve it, yang will inevitably reach its zenith and generate yin, and fullness will turn to deficiency. Those who recognize this urgently seek the oral instructions of an enlightened teacher. Without waiting for yin to arise, they employ the method of preserving the horn through the Dao, circulating the natural true fire to refine away all yin qi within the body. They use the Six Qi yet are not used by them, accomplishing the work of the postnatal. When yin is exhausted and yang is pure, they attain immortality and do not die.

As for those of inferior virtue, after yang reaches its peak and yin arises, the prenatal scatters, the Five Phases separate, the Four Images fall out of harmony, and all manner of treasures are lost. If one attempts to cultivate them through the non-doing of the Dao, it is like boiling an empty cauldron without seeds—what can be achieved? One must instead steal from yin and yang, seize the workings of creation, and within the postnatal return to the prenatal. Only then can the lost treasures of former times be restored from nothingness, return from absence, and the complete inheritance be reclaimed. Once the original treasures are recovered, the foundation of life is secured. A separate cauldron and furnace are established, the Dao of non-doing is practiced, the sacred embryo is nurtured, and after ten months, when qi is full, the Dharma-body emerges—thus converging with the path of those of superior virtue.

Later generations, not understanding what constitutes superior or inferior virtue, have erroneously claimed that those who leak essence are of inferior virtue, while those whose essence is intact are of superior virtue—how grievously mistaken! The essence of sexual intercourse is a postnatal substance, the grossest of the gross—how can it serve as a criterion? As for the notion of losing one’s virginity at sixteen, it refers to the principle that *"at sixteen, one catty is reached, yang reaches its peak and generates yin, and after yin arises, essence is produced."* This is a determination based on yin and yang, not on age. If judged by age alone, some experience the flow of essence at sixteen, others before sixteen, and still others after sixteen—what then is to be said? Thus, superior and inferior virtue are not to be discerned in the postnatal but distinguished within the prenatal. When the prenatal is whole, one is of superior virtue; when the prenatal is deficient, one is of inferior virtue—this is the definitive judgment.

There are those who, not comprehending the great Dao, claim that *"destiny is weighty, nature is light,"* or that *"nature is weighty, destiny is light"*—both are incorrect. Nature and destiny must be cultivated together, and the work proceeds in two stages. Those of superior virtue do not wait to cultivate destiny before cultivating nature; when nature is perfected, destiny is also perfected. Those of inferior virtue must first cultivate destiny before cultivating nature; having perfected destiny, they must then perfect nature. Perfecting destiny is a doing; perfecting nature is a non-doing. The Dao of doing and non-doing is established for the practice of those of superior and inferior virtue. Yet upon the completion of the great Dao, not only is doing unnecessary—even non-doing is no longer needed. As for the supreme attainment, it possesses a wondrous function beyond the categories of doing and non-doing.

If a practitioner does not understand the distinction between superior and inferior virtue yet seeks the essence of doing and non-doing, how can they truly know doing or non-doing? Without knowing true doing or true non-doing, not only can nature not be preserved—destiny cannot be secured either. The reason for nature and destiny lies entirely in the distinction between superior and inferior virtue.

Should scholars not delve deeply into this? The discourse here is exceedingly precise, rarely expounded by ancients—without bodily practice and decades of exhaustive inquiry, one cannot grasp its subtleties.

I humbly observe that whether one’s essence leaks or remains sealed determines the ease or difficulty of cultivation. When the time arrives and yang arises, and the work reaches the stage of union, if a virgin youth encounters this, they will feel a pervasive tingling throughout the body, with qi mechanism ascending. For those who have previously leaked, the qi mechanism readily descends. When ascending, it either transforms into essence or refines into qi, thus remaining secure. But if it descends, thoughts stir mundane inclinations, and it will rush straight to the jade stem—great danger indeed. This is the utmost truth, and one must swiftly restrain and guide it, allowing it to penetrate the tailbone and ascend, thereby preventing leakage. Yet the human mind is ever-active, and qi is supremely responsive; at this stage, if the true virgin merely hears or knows of this union, the thought will naturally turn to the stem, and qi will immediately rush downward. In my youthful practice, I leaked three to five times. This aligns with Wu Yuanzhi’s teaching that the primordial is injured at the moment of hearing and knowing—though the essence has not leaked, the aperture has opened. Once the work reaches this point and thoughts arise, the transformation occurs instantly, for this is the natural principle of the celestial mechanism’s sequential flow. Nowadays, not one or two in ten virgin youths understand this practice. Thus, even in their cultivation, they should be instructed that when yang arises, they must immediately direct it backward and upward, sealing the *gen* position without fail. Then yang will remain in the crucible, not reaching the male root, blocking its exit—this is the crucial technique. If one unfortunately leaks once, ensuring it does not recur is exceedingly difficult.

From the age of nine, I entered the Dao, yet by eleven, I suffered a great leakage. Later, nearly weakened and unable to continue, I preserved my life—how could one not fear this? I append this caution to share with fellow seekers, for I have further insights unclarified in ancient and modern alchemical texts.

My late master, Tai Xu, said: I heard from the sagely master Ni Wan that the distinction between superior and inferior virtue originates from Laozi, yet the *Cantong Qi*’s usage differs from that in ancient alchemical classics. The ancient texts’ distinction lies in "non-being" and "being," aligning with the higher and lower vehicles. The *Cantong Qi*’s distinction lies in "non-doing" and "doing," corresponding to different stages and functions. The ancient texts’ usage closely resembles the *Qingjing Miaojing*. The old commentaries on the *Cantong Qi* sometimes apply it to temperament, sometimes to cultivation. My master, the Er Wu Elder of Song Mountain, said the *Cantong Qi* only discusses the Dao of the elixir, while its oral instructions—such as "superior virtue, inferior virtue," "upper opening, lower opening"—pertain to the body’s regions, differing from the *Daodejing*’s meaning.

Now, examining Wu Yuanzhi’s discourse, it seems to align with the *Cantong Qi*’s traditional interpretations, all of which are correct. Later learners should integrate and compare them—hence I record this here.

The *Wuwei* and *Youwei*
The *Wuzhen Pian* states:
*"At first, with doing, few perceive its trace;
Only when non-doing comes do all recognize its grace.
Yet if one sees non-doing as the subtlest art,
How can they know that doing forms the root and heart?"*
This is the method of the entire process of cultivating the truth.

Later practitioners, unaware of what "doing" entails, have proposed various interpretations: some speak of circulating *qi* at *zi* and *wu* hours; some of revolving the river chariot; some of the union of heart and kidneys; some of the meeting of the *Ren* and *Du* vessels; some of gathering *qi* behind the brain; some of *qi* surging through the crown; some of regulating the breath; some of refining the essence of intercourse; some of flying golden crystals from behind the elbow; some of shaking the bones to stir the marrow; some of swallowing the essence of sun and moon; some of ingesting the *qi* of clouds and mist; some of firing the furnace to refine minerals; some of controlling women to extract inner elixirs; some of refining the *qi* of the celestial stem; some of gathering the essence of the five viscera—such methods number over a thousand. Though their paths diverge, their attachment to form remains the same. To regard these as the *Dao* of "doing" is to stray far indeed!

The various methods thus refuted, though not the great Dao, remain practicable—yet to call them "far astray" is due precisely to their being "doing." From what I have heard, "internal furnace-firing and controlling women," though ancient techniques, are utterly forbidden for those with delicate viscera, who must never ingest minerals; nor can those whose physical form has not transcended to a body beyond the body derive benefit from controlling women. Beyond these two schools, even if the transmitted instructions are not authentic, one must still refrain from testing them on oneself. Thus did my late master warn. Wuwuzhi rejects them all, and rightly so, for caution’s sake.

Yet what of "non-doing"? Some guard the Yellow Court; some contemplate the fontanel; some fix their gaze upon the tip of the nose; some observe the Hall of Light; some concentrate below the navel; some focus on the spine’s midpoint; some contemplate emptiness; some observe the heart-mind; some halt all thoughts; some forget the form; some silently pay homage to the Celestial Emperor; some mirror the form to congeal the spirit; some envision the spirit departing its sheath. Such methods number over a thousand. Though their mental focus differs, their attachment to emptiness remains the same. To regard these as the Dao of "non-doing" is gravely mistaken!

Of the methods described, save for "mirroring the form" and "envisioning the spirit departing its sheath"—which must not be practiced—the rest may serve as stepping stones toward the Dao, provided one does not cling to them as the great Dao itself. Thus did my late master teach.

Attachment to emptiness or to form—both are but schemes devised upon this stinking skin-bag, mental exertions expended upon this sack of filth. How could such know the sagely Dao, which clings neither to emptiness nor to form, yet abides in that which is neither empty nor material?

The refutation stands. Yet if one understands these as provisional means to return to the real, then one treads the true path of cultivation. The learner must awaken to this, lest the author’s compassionate intent be in vain.

By "doing," we do not mean forced action. Rather, since the primordial endowment lies buried within, and the nature and life-force are not secure, without the method of grafting and the Dao of return, how can one prolong life and fulfill the great Dao? "Doing" seeks to reclaim what has departed and restore what was originally possessed—this is the art of stealing from yin and yang, seizing the workings of creation, and reversing the course of life and death. It precedes heaven without violating it, follows heaven while conforming to its seasons; neither ghosts nor spirits can fathom it, nor divination rods nor tortoise shells foretell it. How then could ordinary people perceive it? Being imperceptible, it cannot be any of the form-clinging practices.

The argument is sound. Yet one must first know that if the three barriers and nine orifices remain blocked, and the blood and qi obstructed, one will be too occupied with curing illness to undertake the distant work of grafting. The various methods bequeathed by the ancient sages were precisely laid out as preparations for cultivating this great Dao. If pursued for any other purpose, they become mere schemes devised upon this stinking skin-bag. How could they not be refuted?

By "non-doing," we do not mean the state of withered wood or cold ashes. Rather, when the true seed has not yet been obtained, one must employ provisional methods to gather it. Once obtained, the original endowment returns, and one must swiftly secure and seal it, bathing and nurturing it with care, guarding against danger and risk, to preserve this original endowment and prevent the calamity of regaining only to lose it again.

The argument is most apt. Yet one must know that the loss of the true seed stems from inner disturbance.

Once the provisional methods have gathered the true seed, should one not swiftly apply such practices as stilling thoughts and contemplating emptiness? Moreover, internal observation, external observation, and distant observation all derive from the *Wondrous Scripture of Clarity and Quiescence*. As Lü Zu himself declared: "The Dao teaches people first to still their thoughts; if thoughts do not cease, all effort is in vain." How then can such expedients as stilling thoughts and contemplating emptiness be refuted? Yet Wu Yuanzi rejects them—precisely because he rejects those who mistake withered extinction for the Dao.

When one attains a body beyond the body and vast spiritual penetrations, with utter sincerity foreknowing all, who would not recognize this? At first, one seeks what belongs to others; in the end, one preserves what belongs to oneself—this is the interplay of doing and non-doing. The subtle principle of knowing the beginning as the beginning and the end as the end—how could those who cling to forms or fixate on emptiness ever fathom its depths?

If a student encounters an enlightened teacher, they should first seek the Way of doing, then the Way of non-doing, and further, the Way beyond both doing and non-doing. Only then can the work of cultivating the true be thoroughly awakened, avoiding the pitfall of beginning without end or abandoning the path halfway. Students must exert themselves diligently.

Upon reaching this point in the discourse, students may understand why such practices warrant rejection. Those who engage in them know only this and remain ignorant of that; thus, their clinging and attachment are rightly condemned. Wu Yuanzi, deeply versed in the great Way of the Golden Elixir, would never impart it all at once. He would first transmit such teachings as the circulation of principle and qi to open the barriers, then follow with methods for pursuing, gathering, and returning to the origin. Once the numinous essence is restored, one must by necessity cease thoughts. Engaging in contemplation of emptiness and guiding the celestial stems to return the light ensures that what is restored is not lost. The profound meaning of secure sealing lies therein—not in clinging to existence or emptiness, which cannot achieve this. Without refutation, there can be no awakening; this is the earnest intent behind establishing such distinctions. Should students not take this to heart?

*Zi, Wu, Mao, You*

The ancient scriptures state: *"No need to seek zi and wu at the horizon—within the body, a yang naturally arises."* They also say: *"Winter solstice is not fixed at zi; mao and you are but empty comparisons."* Thus, zi, wu, mao, and you have no fixed time, no fixed direction. What are called zi, wu, mao, and you are but provisional names assigned by principle. For when a single yang arises, it is called zi; when a single yin arises, it is called wu. When yang unites with yin, it is called mao; when yin unites with yang, it is called you. In time, they mark the waxing and waning of yin and yang; in space, they signify the central equilibrium of yin and yang. Therefore, it is by yin and yang that zi, wu, mao, and you are determined—not by zi, wu, mao, and you that yin and yang are fixed.

When yang qi first stirs, one must swiftly advance the yang fire, lest the yang qi dissipate—hence the saying: *"At the zi hour, advance the yang fire."* When yin qi first stirs, one must swiftly withdraw the yin tally, lest the yin qi grow unchecked—hence the saying: *"At the wu hour, withdraw the yin tally."* Advancing yang to the point of central equilibrium, the yang qi becomes harmonious. At this juncture, one should rest, tempering it with yin to avoid the peril of excessive rigidity—hence the saying: *"At the mao hour, one should bathe."* When yin recedes to the point of central equilibrium, the yin qi becomes compliant. Here, one should pause, tempering it with yang to avoid the fault of excessive softness—hence the saying: *"At the you hour, one should bathe."* As Zhang Sanfeng said: *"When encountering zi and wu, focus solely on the fire-times; when meeting mao and you, bathe the golden elixir."* This is precisely the meaning.

Later generations of heterodox and external schools, failing to receive the true transmission, all fixate on the zi, wu, mao, and you of the external world. Some guard the kidneys at the zi hour, stabilize the mind at wu, or sit in stillness at mao and you. Others nurture yang at the winter solstice, suppress yin at the summer solstice, or practice non-action during the mao and you months. Alas! These are the zi, wu, mao, and you of Heaven—what do they have to do with me? Heaven has its own times, and I have mine. Born with the upright qi of Heaven and Earth, the human body embodies the transformations of Heaven and Earth, possessing its own yin and yang—why seek yin and yang from Heaven and Earth? If one seeks yin and yang from Heaven and Earth, one obtains only the postcelestial, formed and conditioned yin and yang. How can this restore my precelestial supreme yang qi or transcend the postcelestial yin and yang? Postcelestial yin and yang follow the course of creation, subject to birth and death. If one clings to the postcelestial in cultivation, one remains within the forging of the Five Phases. When the four great elements disperse, the solitary spirit may struggle to endure, and one must seek another dwelling elsewhere.

Yet zi, wu, mao, and you cannot be sought within the body, nor outside it. They must be sought in the realm of emptiness and non-being to find their true locus. For when yang arises, it is not the stirring of the body, nor the mind, nor the kidneys, nor the movements of the eyes, ears, nose, or tongue—it is the gestation of *zhen* within *kun*, the manifestation of the precelestial within the postcelestial. When yin arises, it is not the dullness of spirit, nor the turbidity of qi, nor the emission of essence, nor the engagement with forms, sounds, scents, flavors, or tactile objects—it is the concealment of *xun* beneath *qian*, the sudden advent of the postcelestial within the precelestial. When yang advances to return to the central path, the precelestial is half restored. When yin recedes to return to the central path, the postcelestial is half dissolved. Advancing the yang fire and withdrawing the yin tally, yin and yang balance each other, neither excessive nor deficient, both realms preserved. Herein lies the Way of Heaven and Earth’s utmost centrality and uprightness, as well as the sagely Way of holding to the One and maintaining the center.

If scholars can thoroughly investigate this point, the subtleties of cultivating the true mystery will become clear. Yet how many mistake these four times, failing to delve deeply into their essence?

How compassionate is this teaching! It lays bare the profound secrets of embodied practice, committing them to wood and paper. What the ancient sages dared not reveal, Wu Yuanzi has now disclosed. Later learners should burn incense and bow in reverence, giving thanks to Heaven and Earth. They should straighten their robes and prostrate toward the void, offering solemn gratitude again and again, acknowledging the fortune of those who behold this text. Alas!

The *Yinfu Jing* speaks of the "celestial and human forces converging" in the living zi and wu—has this been disclosed in the myriad alchemical scriptures? Our Lü Zong’s transmission of the Heavenly Immortal Precepts has always been passed mouth-to-ear, yet Wu Yuanzi has now committed it to wood and paper. Since its publication, this is truly Heaven’s bestowal, the turning of the Daoist lineage’s destiny! How could one who obtains this secret dare treat it with arrogance or neglect?

The *Celestial Precepts* states: "Arrogance and neglect toward the true formula sever one’s spiritual root and block the mysterious aperture. To transmit without warning brings calamity upon nine generations." How could this be taken lightly?

My master, the Venerable Taixu, said: "If the master speaks and the disciple does not heed, the master bears no fault." Let the receiver take heed—beware of careless irreverence. As this book rarely reveals what has been concealed, I dare not withhold this warning from fellow seekers.

---

**Life and Death, Being and Non-Being**
The *Book of Changes* says: "In the southwest, one gains companions; in the northeast, one loses them." The *Yinfu Jing* states: "Life is the root of death; death is the root of life." Both speak of the root of life and death, the aperture of being and non-being. Yet most learners mistake the presence of breath for life and its absence for death. Alas! To regard this as the essence of life and death is gravely mistaken.

They do not realize that while human life and death are inseparable from breath, their root does not lie in breath. From birth, one inwardly harbors the prenatal essence, qi, and spirit to nourish the Dharma-body, while outwardly receiving the postnatal essence, qi, and spirit to sustain the illusory body. By the age of sixteen, the postnatal assumes control, the prenatal retreats, and following the course of creation, yang qi gradually wanes while yin qi waxes—thus the root of life and death is established.

Day by day, year by year, yin qi flourishes as yang qi declines; the upright cannot overcome the perverse. In a single day, one undergoes a thousand births and ten thousand deaths. Suddenly, yang qi is exhausted, yin qi prevails—who then does not return to the great transformation?

As for infants who die before engaging the postnatal, this is merely due to insufficient prenatal endowment, where yang qi fails to arise and dissipates over time. Only the great cultivators, understanding the pivot of life and death and the aperture of being and non-being, reverse the course of creation at the moment of receiving qi in the womb. They seize the aperture of yin and yang, bolstering yang qi to grow while suppressing yin qi to dissolve. They enable yang qi to live eternally and yin qi to die perpetually. This is what is meant by "seeking life within death" and "generating being from non-being."

The ancient immortals said: "The consciousness dies and revives; the original spirit revives and dies." The *Wuzhen Pian* states: "One must turn the door of death into the door of life—do not cling to the gate of life as the gate of death." This gate of life and door of death reside not in the eyes, ears, nose, tongue, body, or mind; not in the spirit, soul, ethereal soul, corporeal soul, qi, or blood; not in the five viscera or six bowels; not in the hundred vessels or three fields. They lie beyond the four elements, in the vast emptiness of the great void—luminous, manifest, and complete. Yet people, unwilling to humble their hearts, are distracted by worldly affairs, entangled by love and attachment, deluded by wealth and sensuality. Thus, they fail to recognize it when it appears before them, passing by the treasure in vain.

If one is truly of this path, recognizing this gate and door and steadying their steps, returning to the origin at the source of their birth and reverting to the root at the point of their death—within darkness, white is born; within the masculine, the feminine is embraced—what difficulty remains in attaining eternal life?

Yet what is called "life" is the birth of the true body; "death" is the death of the illusory body. If the illusory body does not die, the true body cannot be liberated; if the true body is not born, the illusory body does not die. Life and death do not coexist; the true and the illusory do not share the same path. This is unlike the heterodox schools, which mistake the life and death of the illusory body for the real, and the life and death of the true body for the false; which regard the prenatal qi of emptiness and non-being as false, and the postnatal breath as real.

Those who wish to transcend life and death must first exhaust its principles. Once the principles of life and death are understood, one can attain eternal life, and ultimately, neither life nor death. To cultivate the Dao to the point of neither life nor death is to fully resolve life and death. This is what Zhuangzi meant by "gathering the spirit to attain long life, forgetting the spirit to attain non-being."

When one’s understanding of life and death reaches this point, life and death are equalized, being and non-being dissolve, and the great Dao may be achieved.

---

**Discussing the Dao to this extent—how many in the world truly grasp it? It is not that they do not know, but that they are unwilling to speak. My master, the Venerable Taixu, if he did not discuss it, would remain silent; if he did, he would exhaust the matter. Fearing misguidance of later learners, he dared not remain reticent.**

---

**Prior and Posterior Kan and Li**
The scriptures say: "There is something wondrously strange—heart and kidneys were never Kan and Li." This secret may be spoken to those who understand, but it is difficult to convey to those who do not.

For the prior-heavenly workings of creation are formless and imageless, neither attached to being nor fallen into non-being. Formless yet able to generate form, imageless yet able to generate image—how could heart and kidneys be Kan and Li?

Heart and kidneys are postnatal, tangible, and visible entities. Not only are they not prior-heavenly Kan and Li, but they are not even postnatal Kan and Li—they are merely the dregs of postnatal Kan and Li.

The true Kan and Li, in terms of water and fire, are Kan as water and Li as fire. Yet within water lies true yang, and within fire lies true yin—true yin and true yang are the upright and compliant qi of Qian and Kun. Thus, it is said: Kan and Li are the continuation of Qian and Kun.

Originally, yin and yang were one qi. Due to the division of the prior-heavenly Taiji, yin and yang emerged. Once yin and yang arose, Qian and Kun interacted; the yang within Qian flowed into the palace of Kun...

The yin within Kun enters the palace of Qian. Qian, being empty, becomes Li; Kun, being full, forms Kan. Thus, the prior-heavenly Qian and Kun transform into the postnatal Kan and Li.

Li is so named because it has lost its yang. Kan is so named because it has sunken its true essence. The Li trigram has yang on the outside and yin within—its yang having lost its substance, the outer yang must be false. The Kan trigram has yin on the outside and yang within—its yin having sunken its true essence, the outer yin must be false. Yang is no longer pure, yin is no longer true—such are the postnatal Kan and Li.

Yet though the outer yin and yang are not true, the yin concealed within yang is true yin, and the yang concealed within yin is true yang. True yin is hidden within false yang, true yang is hidden within false yin—these are the prior-heavenly Kan and Li concealed within the postnatal. Neither prior-heavenly nor postnatal Kan and Li have anything to do with heart and kidneys.

Later scholars not only fail to understand the prior-heavenly but also misunderstand the postnatal, mistaking heart and kidneys for true Kan and Li, or even taking male and female as Kan and Li—how grievously mistaken! The Kan and Li within a person are like the sun and moon in the heavens. The sun and moon in the sky move in cycles, governing the four seasons and nurturing all things. The Kan and Li within a person, in their movement and stillness, harmonize spirit and qi, sustaining life and nature.

The sun and moon in the heavens have no fixed position—how could the Kan and Li within a person be confined to a single location? Yet once a person enters the postnatal realm and follows the course of creation, the false takes precedence while the true remains hidden. The prior-heavenly is obscured by the postnatal, unable to emerge on its own. Thus, there is birth and death, and one cannot attain immortality.

Only the great cultivators, who truly understand prior-heavenly Kan and Li and also recognize postnatal Kan and Li, can return to the prior-heavenly within the postnatal and walk the immortal path amid the common way. They draw the prior-heavenly true yang qi from Kan to fill Li, and take the prior-heavenly true yin qi from Li to return to Kan. In this way, the postnatal yin and yang of Kan and Li are thoroughly transformed and restored to their true nature, once again becoming the union of Qian and Kun, the oneness of yin and yang, the completion of the Taiji.

*"Prior-heavenly qi, postnatal qi—those who attain it are ever as if drunk."*

The ancient immortals said: *"A speck of yang essence is secretly hidden in the mountain of form—not in the heart or kidneys, but within the mysterious pass of the One Aperture."* Thus, it is clear that the heart and kidneys, lacking yang essence, are not true Kan and Li.

As for the great Dao of the prior-heavenly, there is yet another secret Kan and Li—one that borrows yin to conceal yang and borrows yang to withdraw yin—beyond the categories of prior-heavenly and postnatal.

Alas! To comprehend this profoundly depends on the individual. How can Kan and Li be easily understood?

---

**Refining the Self and Laying the Foundation**

Master Lü said: *"The sevenfold returning elixir lies within a person, but one must first refine the self and await the proper time."* Master Ziyang said: *"If one wishes to complete the ninefold transformation, one must first refine the self and hold fast to the heart."* The *Cantong Qi* states: *"Begin with rectitude, and the end will be well-ordered; establish Qian, but do not yet act."*

Thus, to cultivate the great Way of the Golden Elixir, one cannot do so without refining the self and laying the foundation. Yet refining the self and laying the foundation are not two separate matters—they are one and the same principle. Laying the foundation is not apart from refining the self; refining the self is within the process of laying the foundation. It is not that one refines the self first and then lays the foundation afterward, nor that one lays the foundation first and then refines the self later.

Refining the self refers to the work of practice. Laying the foundation refers to consolidating qi. When the refinement of the self is perfected, the returning elixir may be attained. When the foundation is firmly laid, the chamber of spirit is secure. How could refining the self and laying the foundation be minor matters?

Master Lü achieved the returning elixir three times because his refinement of the self was not yet perfected. Master Ziqing’s midnight encounter with wind and thunder occurred because his foundation was not yet firm. These two masters were luminaries among immortals and leaders within the teaching—if even their practice was not yet flawless, how much more so for others?

What does it mean to refine the self and lay the foundation? The self refers to selfish desires, to the existence of an "I" and a "self." The foundation refers to solid ground, to the root and origin. The reason people fail to attain the Dao is because they are bound by the "I" and the "self." Once there is an "I" and a "self," selfish thoughts fill the heart, and one cannot stand firmly on solid ground. A thousand demons and a hundred obstacles block the numinous chamber; every step is hindered, every matter is muddled. The six thieves multiply, the seven emotions form factions, the good heart is lost, the true nature is harmed, the original destiny is shaken, the spirit is dull, and the qi is turbid. Everywhere, there is nothing but deluded thoughts and perverse intentions. How then can one cultivate virtue and practice the Dao to achieve the great Way? Is it possible? No!

The ancestral masters teach that one must first refine the self and lay the foundation so that one may work on solid ground, ascending from the humble to the lofty, progressing from the shallow to the profound—employing gradual, step-by-step effort.

Since birth, a person’s illusory body carries the qi of the parents’ essence and blood, concealing the yin of the karmic consciousness accumulated over countless kalpas, and further receiving the qi of the postnatal five phases. Inside and out, it is purely yin, with only a single speck of yang essence hidden and unseen. The upright cannot overcome the perverse, and the perverse obscures the upright. If one does not refine and expel the inner and outer yin qi, how can the yang essence return? Thus, the work of refining the self and laying the foundation cannot be neglected.

Let us clarify the essentials of refining the self and laying the foundation:

Restraining anger and suppressing desires—this is refining the self.
A heart turned to ashes and a will grown cold—this is refining the self.
Forgetting emotions and cutting off thoughts—this is refining the self.
Unmoved by wealth and nobility, unshaken by poverty and lowliness—this is refining the self.
Neither coveting fame nor clinging to sensual pleasures—this is refining the self.
Sacrificing oneself for others, humbly seeking instruction—this is refining the self.
Practicing all virtues and refraining from all evils—this is refining the self.

Unwavering in resolve, advancing with courage and vigor—this is refining the self.
A steadfast heart, unwavering even unto death—this is refining the self.
Securing the yin essence, preserving spirit and qi—this is laying the foundation.
Releasing the entire body, dissolving self and others into emptiness—this is laying the foundation.
Embracing heaven and earth as one’s heart, embodying the ten thousand things—this is laying the foundation.
Unseen yet never deceitful, in darkness without flaw—this is laying the foundation.
Unafraid of tiger’s roar, unyielding to power and might—this is laying the foundation.
Indifferent to life and death, untroubled by illness—this is laying the foundation.

Refining the self and laying the foundation are inseparable: to refine the self is to lay the foundation; to lay the foundation is to refine the self. In truth, refining the self and laying the foundation are one and the same. If one can refine the self and lay the foundation, when the work is complete, the Returned Elixir may be formed, the Great Elixir may be cultivated. Alas!

When laying the foundation, the bellows and key are required; when refining the self, true lead is still needed. Is refining the self and laying the foundation an easy matter?

[This is the profound principle of attaining the Dao. Scholars must inscribe it in their hearts, never ceasing, whether moving or still, sitting or lying down—reciting each word silently at every moment to uphold it. Carefully ponder: *"For laying the foundation, use bellows and key; for refining the self, seek true lead."* How compassionate this teaching!

In my humble view, if the Mysterious Pass remains unopened, true practice cannot be grasped. Though celestial lead may accumulate like a mountain, without the key and bellows, it cannot be obtained. Without the bellows, one’s efforts are in vain; with the key, the harvest is gathered. To complete the foundation of the Great Dao, the work lies solely in vigilant solitude.]

**Inner and Outer Companions**

The *Scripture* states: *"For seven days, chaos dies and revives—all depends on companions to regulate water and fire."* It also says: *"Entrust your heart to a knowing one, guard and tend carefully, attending to the furnace’s fire and timing."*

In pursuing the Great Dao, one must have responsive companions; only then can progress be made. If companions are unsuitable or absent, a lone yin cannot act—every move invites misfortune. How can one then steal yin and yang to seize the workings of creation?

When two share one heart, their strength can sever metal. When three unite in purpose, they may still avert danger. Companions are the reliance of life and destiny, the support of virtue and the Dao—those who cultivate the truth must never part from them.

Yet companions differ: there are inner companions and outer companions.

Outer companions are kindred spirits and fellow cultivators, bound in life and death, aiding each other through hardship. They encourage virtue and correct wrongdoing, harmonizing in heart and intent, mutually benefiting one another to cultivate the Great Dao together.

Inner companions reside in the southwest, in the direction of Kun—a person of immortality. They bear the qi of unyielding strength, possess a body of upright integrity, and hold the talent for decisive action. They wield the power of life and death, grasping the handle of existence itself.

They expel evil and uphold the upright, reward goodness and punish wickedness; transform misfortune into blessing, turn calamity into fortune. Inner demons cannot arise, outer demons dare not invade—thus do they guard life, destiny, and the workings of creation. In spirit, they are divine officials; in the stars, they are the Celestial Stem; in direction, they are Venus.

Great cultivators take them as companions, uniting in heart and intent. Entrusting them with life, life may be preserved; committing to them the workings of creation, creation may be reversed. They open the Gate of Heaven and close the Door of Earth, leave the Human Gate ajar and block the Ghost Road. Employing the mechanism of destruction to seek the mechanism of life, they invert yin and yang with absolute certainty.

Thus, while outer companions may sometimes be dispensable, inner companions are never to be lacking. Should the inner companion be lost even once, one’s nature becomes disordered and destiny unsteady, the heart deluded and the spirit clouded. The primordial is lost, and the acquired arises; one passes from life into death, beset by demonic obstructions on all sides, with no limit to their incursions.

Therefore, in the practice of the Dao, forming a companion of like heart is the foremost step. Yet such a companion is most difficult to recognize. In its essence, it is formless and imageless, soundless and colorless, without back or front. When it transforms for ill, it becomes a yaksha; when it transforms for good, it becomes bodhi. Its changes are boundless, its appearances and disappearances unfathomable. Most people overlook it even when face to face, unwilling to acknowledge it in earnest. Thus, day by day, it grows more distant, more estranged, cut off from oneself. If, by chance, one finds a kindred spirit and binds them as a companion of like heart—never parting for even a moment in walking, standing, sitting, or lying down—and further gains outer companions to mutually encourage one another, with inner and outer working in concert, both the minor elixir and the great elixir may be accomplished.

Yet while inner companions are indeed difficult to secure, outer companions are no easier to come by. Unless one possesses great merit, great conduct, great fortune, and great karmic affinity, both cannot be attained. For those devoted to the cultivation of truth, it is better to lose an outer companion than to lack an inner one. The inner companion is what completes the Dharma-body; the outer companion is what protects the illusory body. The Dharma-body is of grave importance; the illusory body, of lesser weight.

Master Changchun said: "When ill, let them bear the illness; when dying, let them face death. Even at the final moment, hold fast to the Dao and perish." Does this not speak to the lightness of the illusory body and the weight of the Dharma-body? Should cultivators not take heed?

What has been discussed here is the most profound secret of the Daoist tradition. In elucidating the inner companion, it distinguishes between two methods—one of emptiness, one of substance—both established for obtaining the celestial treasure. One saying speaks of receiving it from the direction of Kun; another, of finding it through a kindred spirit. That which comes from Kun arrives from the empty void, yet without a medium or seed, how can it be summoned? Thus, this medium or seed may itself be considered the inner companion.

However, according to what I have heard, outer companions—those kindred spirits and fellow cultivators—are in truth one’s kin. The ancients employed them as intermediaries to attract the formless, imageless supreme treasure, making it the master of the great elixir, nurturing and transforming the true primordial essence. Thus, they are also called outer companions. Yet in the cases of the four great ancient immortals—Ding, Xu, Pei, and Li—their spouses were their inner companions! And so, they further established outer companions to protect them.

The applications within this practice are threefold:
First, worldly wealth must be abundant.
Second, self-restraint must be flawless.
Third, one must seek outer protectors.

The use of the qing and the fish serves to distinguish between self and other, employing a method of resonance and harmony. In general, the qing is used to attend to yang, and the fish to attend to yin. When they interact and transform, the fish and the qing are employed neither too soon nor too late, neither too swiftly nor too slowly, with the utmost harmony as the guiding principle. This can be grasped intuitively but cannot be conveyed in words.

According to Master Wuyuan’s analysis, though seemingly precise and detailed, there remains confusion, and much is left unaddressed. It seems he grasped only the name but never heard the full teaching. Reflecting on what he described, it appears he understood the kindred spirit as a means to awaken to the Kun direction in seeking the treasure. Hence his statement that outer companions may be dispensed with.

Originally, the method for seeking the treasure from Kun involved placing the seed and setting the medium, with the entire firing process relying entirely on the outer companion’s accurate reporting. My late master, Master Taixu, said: "The things summoned by ordinary people are either *yuan* or *yi*. *Yuan* may be turbid or clear; *yi* may come first or last. The clear *yuan* is still; the turbid *yuan* is restless. Tracing their origins, the clear comes first, the turbid comes after. To distinguish between first and last depends entirely on oneself. The outer companion has no part in this—the crux lies entirely in one’s own cultivation. Only when worldly wealth is abundant and one’s cultivation is perfected can one discern first from last. Only when worldly wealth is abundant can one directly receive without hindrance. As for whether the firing process is appropriate, though it may be self-directed, the ancients feared errors and thus established the method of entrusting it to an outer protector, for matters of life, death, gain, and loss are at stake!

The ancients transmitted this orally, yet Master Wuyuan did not emphasize this point. Thus, he must not have fully grasped the method of summoning from the empty void. As for kindred spirits in the mundane world—how truly difficult they are to find! Even the First Emperor of Qin and Emperor Wu of Han, though they ruled as Sons of Heaven and possessed all under heaven, could not obtain them."

The Venerable Bodhidharma, a prince of the King of Central India—a land not small—yet journeyed afar to the red continent of Zhendan to attain his realization. The Venerable Qianzhang dwelled in the world for twelve hundred years before passing away unmet. Such encounters are not merely the result of extraordinary karmic conditions from past lives aligning with the right time; their convergence is as rare as seeking a pearl by crossing the vast sea. To abandon the Kun direction is to seek the unseekable, yet one still hopes to chance upon such kindred spirits in the boundless mundane world. I can only attribute this to the longevity of Qianzhang and the blessed virtue of Bodhidharma. Thus, regarding the matter of kindred spirits and companions in the dust, I record this solely for those in future generations with profound karmic affinity to follow in their steps—neither daring to obstruct nor to urge.

Scholars must understand that the Kun direction is what the Daoist tradition calls the "Great Red Heavenly Palace" and the Buddhist tradition terms the "Divine Continent of the Red County." The common claim that the Divine Continent of the Red County refers to Bianliang is an unfounded conjecture, not to be relied upon. My true teacher, the Yellow Perfected One of Jizu, taught that it belongs to the Wuji within the Taiji. The Wuji has no fixed position, yet the primordial has fixed names: Heavenly Origin, Earthly Origin, and Human Origin. We dwell amidst the Three Powers; when form perishes, it returns to earth, and spirit ascends to heaven—this is merely the workings of the postcelestial, for it is bound by form and appearance.

Yet the life we attain is not this postcelestial form and spirit. When the primordial unity of the precelestial is exhausted, each returns to its kind—hence the saying that form returns to earth and spirit ascends to heaven. If so, when our primordial unity is depleted, we must seek its restoration in the Human Origin. The Human Origin is humanity’s precelestial state, abiding within the Wuji. The ancients named this primordial unity the "Kun-direction human" because humanity stands by relying on Kun. This Human Origin—when spoken of as existent, it exists; when spoken of as nonexistent, it is nonexistent. Movement and stillness, emptiness and fullness, life and death are likewise. If one can regard existence as if it were not, nonexistence as if it were not, and in movement and stillness, speech and silence, maintain such equanimity, one has already merged with the original substance of the precelestial. From there, with single-minded resolve, seek its restoration and fulfillment, and one will swiftly attain it, as if echoing a response. Naturally, it will flow and infuse within—this is the wondrous method of exhausting one’s will in the human Dao, fulfilling one’s aspirations and achieving perfection. Thus did my true teacher transmit it orally—exhaust the heart and fathom the principle.

The *Book of Changes* states: "Trace back to the origin and return to the end, thus one knows the discourse on life and death." Mencius said: "To order the beginning is the task of wisdom; to order the end is the task of sageliness." For the great Dao of sages and worthies has a beginning and an end, a root and a branch. Only by knowing its beginning, illuminating its end, investigating its root, and exhausting its branch can one proceed from start to finish, attain thorough enlightenment, and move forward with benefit. If even one matter remains unclear, that matter will be obscured; if knowledge is not true, practice will not flow. Scholars must first exhaust the principle, and only then can they practice it—both the extension of knowledge and the force of practice are indispensable, neither can be lacking.

What principle is this? It is the Dao of Heaven and Earth’s creation and transformation. The Dao of creation and transformation has substance and function, a beginning and an end. Within it, yin and yang alternate in operation, waxing and waning interchange, and transformations are endless. Yet its most essential point lies entirely in *qi*; this *qi* is never apart from emptiness and nothingness. This pivotal point is neither void nor form, neither existent nor nonexistent; it cannot be sought with intention, nor can it be attained without intention; it is difficult to depict, difficult to portray, difficult to contemplate, difficult to discuss.

To follow it is to give rise to humanity and all beings; to reverse it is to become immortal or Buddha. Within it, nature and life are entrusted; from it, life and death emerge. Those who awaken ascend instantly to sagehood; those who remain deluded sink into eternal perdition for ten thousand kalpas. To "exhaust principle" is to exhaust this very principle. Only by thoroughly penetrating this principle can one practice it. Yet this principle involves timing, effort, adaptation, pace, urgency, restraint, concealment and revelation, square and round, fullness and deficiency, cessation and sufficiency—myriad functions in all. First, one must clarify the Dao; next, one must grasp its methods. Only when Dao and method are both applied, when nature and life are both cultivated, does one attain the supreme vehicle of the Way, the Way of solid grounding. This grounded Way demands gradual progression, step by step—one must not skip stages in pursuit of attainment.

What is gradual progression? The first step is to accumulate virtue and establish conduct; the second, to refine the self and lay the foundation; the third, to govern mercury with lead; the fourth, to unite lead and mercury; the fifth, to nurture and return the elixir; the sixth, to generate the great medicine; the seventh, to ingest the golden elixir; the eighth, to coalesce the sacred embryo; the ninth, to nourish lead with mercury; the tenth, to withdraw lead and replenish mercury; the eleventh, to guard against peril and contemplate danger; the twelfth, to cease firing when the embryo is complete; the thirteenth, to face the wall for nine years; the fourteenth, to shed the embryo and release the spirit; the fifteenth, to nurse the infant; the sixteenth, to relocate the furnace and crucible; the seventeenth, to attain unfathomable spiritual transformation; the eighteenth, to shatter the void. These are all essential steps in the cultivation of the Dao, the full capacity of sagely achievement.

If one can discern these stages with clarity, penetrate them thoroughly, persist from beginning to end without slackening, then nature and life may be resolved. Yet most learners in the world mistake the false for the true, refuse to devote themselves to exhausting principle, and slight the matter of nature and life. Before entering the gate, they seek to ascend the hall; before fulfilling human affairs, they aspire to immortality. They contribute no effort themselves yet demand true treasures from others. At the slightest setback or hardship, they retreat, abandoning the path midway, attributing failure to lack of karmic affinity. With such conduct, how can they draw near the gate of the sages?

The learning of the sages is the study of exhausting principle, fulfilling nature, and attaining life’s destiny. Its principles are subtle, its meanings profound—beyond the divination of milfoil and tortoise, beyond the ken of ghosts and spirits. It cannot be grasped in a word or half a phrase. Without decades of relentless effort to exhaust principle, one cannot fathom even a fraction of it. Without accumulating virtue, establishing conduct, and advancing with unyielding courage and single-minded resolve, one cannot move a true teacher to respond.

If a true seeker takes nature and life as the great matter, toiling day and night without respite, delving deeply into the subtle and discerning the incipient, then at times, when bitterness gives way to sweetness and fortune’s affinity suddenly arrives, all past doubts—headless and tailless—melt away like ice or shatter like tiles. Only then does one realize that one’s lifelong striving was not misdirected.

Alas, most learners today do not reflect on what the matter of nature and life truly is, nor do they inquire into what the Dao of nature and life entails. They muddle through learning and cultivation, vainly hoping to ascend to heaven in a single step or become a sage overnight. No wonder they are misled by blind or false teachers, spending their lives in the ghostly den.

Consider this: even a single skill or craft in the world requires meticulous, prolonged study before mastery. How much more so this great matter of life and death, the rarest endeavor under heaven—how could it be easily known?

In former days, my immortal teacher Liu, while studying in Shu, traveled between Baishi and Guiqing for over a decade without attaining ultimate realization. Later, in Hannan, he took the Daoist of Honggou as his teacher, his resolve growing firmer, his practice more arduous. For eight or nine years, he still found no point of understanding. Only after journeying to Gansu’s Gaolan Adgan Town did he encounter my venerable master. Their karmic affinity aligned, and at last, he grasped the great Dao.

Teacher Liu was sincere in his pursuit of the Dao, his merit and conduct extraordinary. Yet even he wandered the rivers and lakes for over thirty years before catching the fragrant breeze of truth. How foolish are those deluded souls who expect to learn in the morning and succeed by evening, or study yesterday and attain today!

I urge fellow seekers to establish an indestructible resolve and cultivate an enduring heart.

Dispel delusive thoughts and prioritize the matter of one’s nature and life. Exhaust the principles of creation and transformation, and commit with utter devotion. Peel away layer by layer, advancing one layer at a time, until you reach the very marrow of the Dao. Only then will you see that the dust and sand of the vast earth are all treasures. Walk with unwavering faith, and every step is the Dao. Attain great awakening, penetrate past and future, and press forward without hesitation—how could one’s nature and life remain unfulfilled, or the great Dao unachieved?

The study of knowledge demands the full exertion of the heart to fathom principle, naturally returning to the origin and reverting to the end—this is the learning of advancing both knowledge and practice. Knowledge resides in the heart, while practice belongs to the body. When knowledge and practice advance in unison, body and heart become undivided—this is what it means to stand on solid ground. From the very first step, if one truly embodies the return to the original state, the mysterious pass will open of itself. Once the mysterious pass opens, the great path of the Golden Elixir is restored, free from delusion. The key to opening it lies in the first step of self-mastery. The method of self-mastery begins with purifying the heart and eliminating delusion. From there, commit with utter devotion, peeling away layer by layer. After shedding each layer, you will reach the marrow of the Dao and realize that truth and delusion are originally without form—delusion arises from delusive thoughts, and truth arises from true thoughts. The manifestation of truth and delusion depends on the movement of thought. Thus, the ancients took the point where thought stirs as the Mysterious Female, for yang is called "mysterious" and yin "female." The great path of the Golden Elixir is the practice of returning to pure yang. Yet when yang reaches its extreme, yin arises—it is impossible for there to be no yin within. The ancients’ practice was simply to return everything to truth. Thus, daily renewal and return merge into the One. This One is indescribable; we forcefully call it the "aperture." Therefore, what is meant by "entering the aperture" is learning to return to the One, preventing yang from scattering and yin from overflowing.

Each day of life is a day of return—how can learning have a limit? Thus, the ancient immortals said, "From the Primordial Heavenly Worthy at the beginning of creation to the present, there is no moment without gathering, no moment without refining." This means the Primordial Heavenly Worthy is constantly engaged in the work of return, and thus knows no suffering of birth, aging, sickness, or death.

Upon careful examination of the *Discourses on the Difficulties of Cultivating Truth*, it expounds in countless instances what the ancient sages wished to express but left unsaid. Only the section on the mysterious pass, where the author omitted his own account, remains incomplete. Scholars must understand that within the apertures of the body, there exist both true and illusory qi—this is what the *Book of Changes* means by "the Dao consists of one yin and one yang." What the Daoist tradition values lies in resonance. True resonance elicits true response; illusory resonance elicits illusory response. Resonance and response follow their kind—this is the principle.

Thus, both the self and others possess true and illusory qi. The ancients practiced emptiness and stillness with the aim of self-mastery to preserve truth. The true source of the ultimate Dao does not lie in the concealment or revelation of qi’s mechanism, but in its unfathomable concealment and revelation. When the heart does not waver and thought does not stir, truth is preserved. With true resonance comes true response, and the mysterious pass opens. When truth opens, what is revealed and concealed is also true. Since concealment and revelation are true, the gathering, refining, and return are without delusion, and the effects achieved are also true.

This mysterious pass, this single aperture, encompasses past and future. Within it, truth and delusion each respond according to their kind. As resonance arises, so does response—no spirit or deity can obstruct it for even a moment. Grasping this essential subtlety, the ancients regarded self-mastery as the first step in achieving mastery of the mysterious learning. Master Wuyuan’s decision to use this discourse as the keystone of the entire work deeply reflects the intent of the ancients in writing. Scholars should not dismiss the entire book because of a single omission. Master Wuyuan’s oversight is but one lapse in a thousand considerations of the wise. My effort to supplement it is but one insight in a thousand considerations of the foolish. Compared to Master Wuyuan, my learning is as a minor shaman to a great one! These are my true words, written to share with fellow seekers.

**Postscript**
The transmission of the ultimate Dao in the world has been obscured by the many veiled expressions in alchemical texts, their origin traced to a single word: "secrecy." Yet what is meant by "secrecy" is merely the principle that "one knows the warmth or chill for oneself." Scholars must understand that humans, earth, and heaven emerge from the same Dao. Humans know to follow the cycle of return, fulfilling the mandate of their birth, and thus become filial children who fully receive and fully return. In principle, how could a child who serves their parents incur heavenly punishment?

Moreover, it is said that earth and heaven are without intent, their intent residing in humanity. Thus, humans bear the duty of mending heaven and healing the world. Writing alchemical texts, transmitting true methods, and guiding others in cultivating truth are akin to teaching filial piety and loyalty. Could such acts invite punishment? Is there such a decree in the celestial statutes?

Yet within this path lie the most perilous and treacherous mechanisms. Scholars must know that heaven has asuras, earth has rakshasas, humanity has the virtuous and the wicked, and the body has corpse-demons. If cultivation is impure, the corpse-demons within will resonate, and the later mechanism of the primordial will respond swiftly, like an echo or shadow. Summon them, and they come; oppose their tendencies, and great disaster strikes immediately. The unknowing may believe they are punished for following the Dao, unaware that it stems from their own lack of self-mastery.

If one knows to keep every thought untainted, placing body and heart before the primordial, the corpse-demons will vanish of themselves, and the primordial spirit will stand alone. With primordial resonance comes primordial response, with one comes one—no barrier, no obstruction, breath flowing freely. Pain and itch are naturally felt, like eyelashes protecting the eyes. Without need for summoning, heavenly spirits respond immediately. What fear is there of asuras, rakshasas, or the virtuous and wicked?

The problem lies in people not knowing how to eliminate their own corpse-demons. Furthermore, this ultimate Dao was received by the Two Great Ones and entrusted to humanity. Those who receive it pass it on, mutually illuminating its truths—this cannot be called leakage.

Yet the supreme Dao is subtle and profound, formless and imageless, soundless and odorless. The perfected ones know it, and wishing to transmit it, must employ the tangible to express the intangible, the substantial to manifest the insubstantial. Thus arise myriad analogies, each drawn from the moment’s opportunity—how could there be any concealment? It is like the Western teaching of pointing to the moon to discuss nature: how clear and evident! Yet students mistake the finger for the moon. Nearby stands a bronze basin, struck to demonstrate its roundness and wholeness. Unaware, the students retreat and reflect, saying: "Nature has no fixed form—it may be straight or round, and it has sound, a resonant hum with lingering overtones, truly stirring to the heart and mind." Thus they convince themselves they have penetrated the Buddha-nature and proceed to teach others in turn.

Alas! Is this the fault of the teacher’s instruction, or the student’s misapprehension? The loss of the supreme Dao stems precisely from such misapprehension. Hence some hear and laugh outright—this is why Master Wuyuan felt compelled to compose the *Later Discourses*!

Yet even those who grasp the finger or the basin remain in error. I have seen this in the *Discourse on the Mysterious Pass*: the claim that it is "five measures high and four wide" arises from a misreading of the *Five Thousand and Forty Characters*. How could they know that the Mysterious Pass is the Mysterious Female, the Mysterious Female is body and heart, body and heart are emptiness and fullness, emptiness and fullness are yin and yang, yin and yang are Kan and Li, Kan and Li are Earth and Heaven? "Water flows within the earth"—this speaks of water and earth as one. The Classic states: "Heaven generates the One as water; Earth completes it as the Six." This opening embodies both generation and completion. The opening is the body, the body is the pass, the mysterious is Heaven, Heaven is the One, the One is the heart. Thus it is said: "The heart embraces the ten thousand things," and "The heart embraces Heaven and Earth."

Probing its profound meaning, the great Way of the Golden Elixir is nothing but the learning of the heart. Released, it pervades the six directions; gathered, it retreats into secrecy. This too is the alternation of emptiness and fullness, of being and non-being. Being and non-being mutually give rise, emptiness and fullness mutually define—only then does the True One appear. This is what is meant by "non-establishment of being and non-being, non-abiding of emptiness and fullness"—the esoteric essence of cultivating the Real.

This essence transcends Heaven and Earth, surpasses the Five Phases. Thus it can position and nurture Heaven and Earth, create and transform the Three Powers. The heart is the heart of the Dao—beyond naming, yet by necessity called the Mysterious Opening. Once subject to conceptualization, it is no longer the true state of mystery, and one can never enter it through seeking. This is the great key to the entire work, which must be made clear. Thus I record it at the outset of the *Later Discourses*.

*Respectfully inscribed by Min Yide, later disciple of the Golden Canopy.*

---

The *Orthodox Exegesis of the Mysterious Explanation of the Yin Fu Jing* was compiled by Min Yide of Gui’an, with collation and revision by Qu Zeng of Wujin.

The *Mysterious Explanation of the Yin Fu Jing* was written by Fan Yizhong. Though titled *Mysterious Explanation*, its meaning deviates from the true Way, leading to no small error. Thus I expound the original meaning of the Classic to correct it.

I, Yide, also deeply fear the penalty for idle talk. Yet among the dozens of commentaries on the *Yin Fu Jing*, each offers profound insights—how dare I lightly criticize or claim to possess the definitive interpretation? Still, none have fully satisfied my heart.

My late teacher, Master Taixu, left behind the *Three-One Sound Talisman* by the Mud-Pill Recluse Li. Its postscript states: "The *Yin Fu Jing* is the transmitted text of Kongtong, yet without oral transmission, its heart cannot be grasped. I once received instruction from the Two-Five Daoist, and though his explanation was close at hand, I felt uneasy that the great Dao could be so easily encompassed. After years of repeated inquiry, the Mud-Pill Teacher arrived from afar and said to me: 'What I once heard was indeed the ancient immortals’ interpretation of the text, where the key lies in comprehensive understanding. Abandon the traces to seek the mysterious, and you will attain it. Recently, I heard of Zimu’s *Revelations of the Yin Fu Jing*, but his discussion of the mind’s operation is not universal.

The true lineage of the *Yin Fu Jing* was transmitted by the Supreme Lord to the Western Regions, then brought east by Bodhidharma to China—this is the special transmission outside the teachings of the world, the wondrous principle of "the mind is Buddha, form is emptiness." Our sect’s founder, Master Changchun, embodied and practiced it. His Way was transmitted from Fire Dragon, who received it from Ancestor Wang Chongyang. In his later years, Ancestor Wang heard of it and used it to verify his understanding with Ancestor Lü Chunyang. Ancestor Lü said: "The profound meaning of this Classic lies in observing Heaven and wielding Heaven, adapting to circumstances and making choices, acting in accord with the times. Its esoteric essence resides in the section on the sun and moon. Yin and yang differ in form, their foundations distinct, each with its wondrous function—this is the meaning of the section on the foolish person. It opens new vistas, revealing clarity at every turn, all flowing back to the source—this is the meaning of the section on the person. Ultimately, the transmission of the heart lies in the character *bu* (not). The ultimate secret within the secret is in the final section of the Classic, where all is sought in the midst of the supremely empty and non-polar. The entry point lies in stillness; its attainment in harmony lies in the character *sha* (kill, pronounced in the departing tone). One must further investigate the 'wondrous vessel' in the final section to achieve the ultimate perfection of embryonic nurturing and sagehood, for therein lies the wondrous completion. You may first contemplate the character *dao* (steal) in the text. *Dao* means 'object placed in a vessel.' This character *dao* is already the 'wondrous vessel,' with the two characters serving as a guide. Yet *dao* still has traces, and what is placed is only the primordial. The sages speak of it as nurturing the colored body, for within the primordial there is the One. It may also be called nurturing nature—this is why I first direct you to contemplate *dao*. As for the 'wondrous vessel' as an object, it is indescribable. Seek its traces and you will not find it; forget form and it appears. The sages, with the Dao not beyond the body, use it for thorough refinement, refining to form the divine abode.'"

When in motion, kites soar and fish leap; when at rest, the myriad sounds fall silent. As the White Elder’s true primordial essence daily returns to the One, the self no longer exists, and the divine abode becomes serene. Yet the *yinin-e* (鄞鄂) remains unrefined. Thereupon, gather essence and concentrate spirit, empty the position to congeal the true One, expand it to fill the body, and merge it with the Three Powers. Await the dissolution of form into emptiness, holding steadfast until the time arrives—then the primordial of the Three Powers must unite within. Abundant as if by inherent transformation, ceaselessly generating and regenerating, left to nature’s course, purified again and again, the primordial of the Three Powers coalesces into a single precious pearl. Vague and indistinct, it hangs before me, and the *yinin-e* is complete.

Thereafter, the pearl and I suddenly merge, and I perceive only boundless radiance. Here, the true One of the Three Powers and my own true One unite as non-dual—this is called the embryo forming within the vessel, which is the wondrous vessel itself. The wondrous vessel’s use is vast indeed! Yet to exhaust its initial work, one must begin with refining the self. Only when the work of self-refinement is mature may one proceed to the wondrous vessel.

Though the scripture reveals but the latter stages, this principle is inherent in the nature of all beings, sages and commoners, men and women alike. The world’s exclusive focus on men is mistaken. Its true application, however, lies in the moment when heaven and humanity jointly manifest. Thus it is said: without oral transmission, it is difficult to grasp with the heart. Such is the general outline of this scripture.

Readers of this text must keep their mind’s eye clear. While the separation and combination of characters may seem profound, one must comprehend and penetrate them, maintaining balance and adaptability. The method has no fixed form, yet it does not transcend the four words: *growth and decline, life and death*. There are instances where dual approaches proceed simultaneously—innumerable and ubiquitous—neither to be neglected nor over-interpreted. A single misstep from the true intent leads one astray into the three branches, beyond all remedy.
