Listen, I tell you: the steps in pursuing this Dao are but three. First, from being enter non-being; then, within non-being recognize being; finally, gather being back into non-being. This is the meaning of *retiring to concealment*—nothing more than following nature. For there is that which acts without deliberate action.

The Great Dao of Heavenly Immortality is fully contained in this scripture. To practice the Dao without this text—where else could one turn? Taking this scripture as the foundation, its great application can heal the world; its lesser use allows the fulfillment of three thousand deeds and the perfection of eight hundred merits, thereby attaining fruition.

Master Wang bowed and received it. This discourse was expounded by Master Wang and recorded by Master Qiu, never committed to writing but transmitted down to me. Recently, I have heard that well-intentioned scholars have misconstrued its true meaning, their words veering into yin-yang heterodoxy—these are texts that bring calamity to the world. Thus, I set forth the profound principles anew for the sake of the age. Bear this in mind.

Elder Tai Xu bowed and received it, inscribing these words after the *Three-One Sound Talisman*. This book, in essence, complements the *Yin Fu Jing*, having been treasured for forty springtimes. Recently, my disciple Shi Zhaolin discovered the *Profound Explanation of the Yin Fu Jing* on his desk and brought it to me. Upon reading it, I could not help but sigh thrice. The author, a certain Fan Yibin of Shenyang, compiled it based on what he had heard. His intentions were admirable, but his sources were incomplete, and thus his explanations were incorrect. His language, steeped in heterodoxy and corroborated by the common character-splitting techniques, aligns precisely with what the Perfected One of Muddy Pellet called "texts that bring calamity to the world." Yet it is now being included in the Daoist Canon. Surely our ancestors and masters foresaw this, which is why they proclaimed the profound principles eighty years ago—to rescue later generations from confusion. Clearly, the Great Dao shall not remain forever obscured.

Having received this transmission from my masters, how could I dare evade the penalty for concealing the profound? Thus, I have carefully appended this to the right of Fan’s commentary, naming the book *Orthodox Explanation of the Profound Meaning of the Yin Fu Jing*. My aim is to transmit the masters’ teachings and illuminate the true Dao, though I am aware that my words may be verbose and not entirely in keeping with the style of annotations. I ask readers to forgive this.

A further note by Yi De: The *Explanations of the Yin Fu Jing* included in the *Daoist Canon Compendium* contains the *Collected Explanations of the Ten Perfected Ones*. The Ten Perfected Ones are: Master Red Pine, Perfected Zhang Zifang, Perfected Ge Xuan of the Left Palace of the Supreme Ultimate, Perfected Xu Xun of West Mountain, Imperial Lord Zhongli of Zhengyang, Imperial Lord Lü of Pure Yang, Perfected Shi Jianwu of Huayang, Perfected Cui Zhiyi, Imperial Lord Liu Haichan of Minggong, and Perfected Cao Daochong of Xuan Ying and Pure Emptiness—all of whom relied on planchette divination for their explanations. Additionally, there are the annotations by Master Zhang Guo of the Tang, the commentary by Wang Daoyuan of the Yuan, and the revisions by Gao Shiming of the Ming—all likewise derived from planchette writing. Other versions include the commentary by Shen Yafu, the commentary by Cangyai, and the ode by Yuanyangzi—all planchette texts. Moreover, there exist ancient annotated editions of merit, such as the preface by Zhang Hongyang, the rare edition by Chen Tuan, the commentary by Li Quan, and the commentary by Zhu Xi. None of these were included in the *Compendium*; to select texts, one must possess a discerning eye.

Fan’s Explanation of the *Yin Fu Jing*:
*Yin* refers to the Great Yin, the moon. *Fu* refers to the conjunction of the Great Yin and the Great Yang, occurring twelve times a year, with twelve new moons and twelve full moons—this period of conjunction and fulfillment is called the *fu* (symbol). Since the Great Yin borrows the sun’s light and contains true fire within, it is also called the *fire symbol*. *Jing* (scripture) refers to the lunar phases having five or six numerical divisions, like the tides of the sea, never failing their appointed times. Previous interpretations, such as the obscure explanations of *yin* and the divisions of *yin*, are all mistaken. This is a clear exposition: the Great Yin is manifest, and within the Great Yin lies the true fire of the Great Yang. By relying on the symbol to "steal" it, one attains the profound model for cultivating the Dao. These three characters contain the secret essence of the entire text.

A Certain Attainment states: This interpretation is most apt and direct, free from fragmentation. If scholars grasp this interpretation and return to the correct path, they will avoid the pitfall of straying into emptiness. Yet if they cling rigidly to this interpretation and seek only by its traces, they will lazily enter side doors, thereby trifling with their very lives.

**First Section**
To observe the Dao of Heaven and grasp the movements of Heaven—this is all there is to it.
Master Fan says: The term *Dao* signifies the meaning of "lower intercourse," as in the initial work where the flow descends from the head—is this not the character *Dao*? Yet the work of the Dao is accomplished by one person alone, whereas here it speaks of *Heaven*, which refers to pure Yang. This pure Yang cannot truly be achieved by one person alone; it requires two, and the character for "two" is *yin*. When two unite and return to one place, is this not the character *Heaven*? As for the character *observe*, it contains a subtle meaning: placing two mouths above the character for "excellent" (佳) must imply the mechanism of seeing with the eyes, hence the character *observe* subtly conveys this meaning. The opening and closing of Yin and Yang are like Heaven’s emptiness and stillness, naturally manifesting their mutual illumination. One must emulate Heaven’s reverse movement, grasp the center, and traverse the transition, thereby obtaining a single pellet as the pivot of creation. When the human body applies this practice, the secret of the *yin* symbol lies herein. These two lines serve as the guiding principle of the entire scripture, introducing what follows.

A Certain Attainment states: Master Fan did not receive the true transmission; he merely clung to the method of dissecting characters, thereby slandering the sages and misleading the masses. Even if his knowledge had some basis, it remains a side door. This passage is the overarching introduction to the entire scripture, and a straightforward interpretation should focus on *observing Heaven* and *grasping Heaven*. Thus, the character *Heaven* is the essence, while *observe* and *grasp* are its functions. Hence, it speaks of *Dao* and *movement*. The character *Dao* need not be dissected. To dissect *Dao* belongs to the lowest grade of the Yin-Yang school, unworthy of consideration. This method originated with foreign monks and was transmitted into China after the Han dynasty by blue-eyed barbarian monks. Their books exist in the world but are disdained by our tradition. The correct interpretation of *Dao* is straightforward, as is that of *Heaven*. Only the character *observe*, when dissected, reveals a profound principle, though not in the conventional manner. The character *grasp*, when dissected, also holds meaning. The method of cultivation must begin with the standard form of *observe*, applying effort to emptiness and stillness, where wondrous meanings and responses emerge endlessly, truly profound and secret. I urge scholars to integrate and contemplate this: the most upright interpretation lies herein, for this passage already possesses the marvel of dual perspectives working in tandem. If one understands how to dissect *observe* correctly, the profound meaning will naturally appear, and every aspect will be the Dao.

Heaven has five thieves; those who perceive them prosper.
The five thieves reside in the heart and are enacted in Heaven.
The cosmos lies within one’s grasp, and the myriad transformations arise within the body.
Master Fan says: The Heaven of two persons possesses the five burdens of eyes, ears, nose, tongue, and body. Recognizing these five as one’s own burdens is to perceive them, yet in practice, one does not depart from the use of these five thieves. The key is for one’s heart to recognize the five thieves and employ them to burden others, ensuring they do not become one’s own burdens. Applying the five thieves to the Heaven of two persons is like using straw dogs: one holds Yin and Yang in hand, causing the five thieves to harass and burden others. Only by responding to the myriad changes with agility can the myriad transformations truly arise within one’s own body.

A Certain Attainment states: Master Fan’s interpretation is utterly perverse. He assumes the sacred scripture was written exclusively for men, revealing his selfish perspective—a mere play of spiritual cleverness, which Master Fan fails to consider. Those who pursue deviant paths to attainment will surely be struck by lightning, die and be reborn as snakes or foxes, or even sink into the ranks of geckos, becoming ingredients for bedroom aphrodisiacs. Such is the inevitable karmic retribution. How could he know that this passage expounds the sage’s discipline of self-cultivation, elucidating the essence of the *observe* and *grasp* characters from the previous section? When the five phases are upright, they become the five virtues; when perverse, they become the five thieves—this hinges on the word *perceive*. Partial dominance turns them into five thieves, but if the heart can discern them and follow Heaven’s enactment, one may wield control in hand and generate the myriad transformations within the body. Both men and women receive the mean of Heaven and Earth at birth, each rectifying their nature and destiny—how could the Dao of Heaven involve harming one to benefit another? Carefully following the scripture’s intent, the five phases’ function contains both virtue and punishment; restraining excess and employing the mean, the source of the myriad transformations is not thievery. This universally instructs both men and women in self-cultivation—such is the Great Dao.

Heavenly nature is humanity;
The human heart is mechanism.
Establishing the Dao of Heaven is to stabilize humanity.
Master Fan says: The Heaven of two persons is inherently small, naturally possessing the five thieves. When the mechanism of these five thieves arises, it invariably originates from the human heart. The heart recognizes this mechanism and borrows the eyes to observe, hence it is called *mechanism-heart*. Those who understand this quiet the mechanism-heart within and employ it in the Heaven of two persons to establish the foundation of the Dao. This foundation of the Dao does not depart from the "Six-One Lead" of the prior Heaven, where the characters "Six-One" guide humanity to stabilize it. Thus, heart and nature, Heaven and humanity, are essential to the Dao. There is no distance of a foot, nor the slightest confusion.

A Certain Attainment states: The main thrust of this interpretation is already mistaken—what more need be said?

Having obscured this passage’s essential meaning and failing to recognize the true Unity, their deluded theories flood the mind, thus splitting the character *li* 立 ("to establish") into "Six-One." They do not understand that this passage speaks of humanity receiving Heavenly nature, where the human heart is the pivot of all transformations. The sutra’s intent is to instruct people to fulfill their nature in order to establish destiny—precisely because fulfilling nature is the foundation of the Dao! How could the trivial "Six-One Lead" suffice as this foundation? Mistaking "Six-One" for the true Unity, they know not that "Six-One" is the primordial origin—confusing the subject for the ruler.

This passage addresses nature; the following speaks of destiny. Yet preserving destiny lies in nature, so one must fulfill nature to lay the foundation. Simply following the principle and interpreting it directly unifies the text’s upper and lower sections—why dissect the character *li*? "When Heaven unleashes its killing mechanism, stars shift and constellations alter; when Earth unleashes its killing mechanism, dragons and serpents rise from the land; when humanity unleashes its killing mechanism, Heaven and Earth reverse; when Heaven and humanity jointly unleash it, the foundation of the myriad transformations is secured."

Master Fan states: The yang mechanism, manifest in the radiant brilliance of stars, descends from Heaven; the yin mechanism, revealed in the rising and writhing of dragons and serpents, emerges from Earth. This is spoken of separately. Yet when considered together, Earth’s ascending qi naturally responds to Heaven’s descending qi, just as Heaven’s radiant brilliance arises from Earth’s ascending qi. When humanity perceives the signs of Heaven and Earth’s mutual resonance, reversing yin and yang to invert this qi, it all depends on the indivisible union of two as one. With a single exhalation, they seize the true Unity’s qi from Heaven and Earth, wresting the mystery of yin-yang’s creative transformations. This is precisely the wondrous function of "non-arising arising" and "non-transforming transformation," turning separation into the creative. All this serves to stabilize one’s root-origin through the already stabilized other. The line "when Heaven and humanity jointly unleash it" is the entire sutra’s secret.

A Certain Attainment states: This passage embodies the most profound and vast principle—how lamentable that Master Fan misinterprets it with heterodox theories, like a fool recounting dreams. For this passage establishes destiny, yet its focus lies entirely in the work of nature. As the saying goes: "Though winds and waves arise, I never set sail." It speaks of observing the subtle movements in stillness—after rain, the sky clears; clouds part and the sun appears. Seizing the moment to guide it, the myriad transformations arise spontaneously—how could human effort intervene? Interpreting it directly by principle may lead to realization.

The term "killing" harbors the principle of transformation. Within the five phases’ generative qi, none does not lie dormant in the qi of death. For instance, metal generates water, water generates wood—thus metal is wood’s ancestral qi, yet wood is imprisoned and dies when encountering metal. This is the generative qi concealed within the qi of death. Here lies the mechanism of contraction and expansion mutually rooted in one another. Without the killing mechanism, there would be extension without withdrawal, and the Dao would reach its limit.

Stars and constellations, dragons and serpents—these are the visible traces of yin-yang’s waxing and waning, alternating succession. Heaven and Earth’s reversal embodies the principle of yin-yang inversion. The mechanism of transformation arises from reversal: arising is compliance; killing is reversal. Reversal completes compliance, and thus the foundation of the myriad transformations is secured. The first six lines collectively describe the marvel of the Three Powers’ mutual resonance; the latter two lines reveal the infinite subtleties of the elixir path. The key lies in the initial moment of natural mechanism’s arising, adjusting it with perfect timing—neither excessive nor deficient, neither early nor late, with no room for a hair’s breadth. Without the utmost emptiness and profound stillness, one cannot begin. Master Fan is correct in calling this the sutra’s secret. Yet by mistaking the yang of Kan for the true Unity and rigidly splitting the character *he* 合 ("to unite") into "two persons with one mouth," he becomes an advocate for the Three Peaks School—how greatly does this deviate from the sutra’s intent!

Another interpretation reads the character *sha* 杀 ("to kill") in the falling tone, aligning with the *Yijing*’s hexagram *Qian* 谦 ("Modesty"). The natures and feelings of the Three Powers all despise fullness and favor modesty. Yet this meaning applies to the techniques employed *after* the mechanism arises, serving as the transitional method between activation and response—also an essential aspect of the elixir path.

The character *ding* 定 ("to stabilize") in this passage also contains the subtle meanings of both "stabilizing" and "determining." Such functions merely prepare the ground for attaining the true Unity. Once the true Unity is obtained, the foundation is established. Yet it cannot be acquired through cleverness. If one remains ignorant, they will fail to kill when killing is required, fail to stabilize when stabilization is needed, and fail to unite when union is sought. A hair’s breadth of error leads to a thousand miles of deviation—this is the great pivotal point of this passage.

Nature may be clever or clumsy, and can be subdued and concealed. The nine orifices’ deviations lie in the three essentials, which can be activated or stilled.

Master Fan states: The true Unity’s qi arises from the small, yet without effort, it cannot be drawn; without hands, it cannot be lifted. Its proper use depends entirely on the heart’s generation. If governed by nature, cleverness becomes clumsiness. If not governed by nature, what seems clumsy is truly vast. Cleverness retreats and conceals, its secrecy becoming correctness—this is the function of seeming clumsiness yet being truly skillful. Seizing the true yang within true yin, concealing it in secrecy, ascending and descending through the front and back, circulating through the Ren and Du channels without stagnation—this is how one achieves enduring longevity, for long life requires the sublimation of qi.

Ordinary people, unaware of the subtleties of sublimation and concealment, fail to guard the nine orifices’ deviations, thus losing their lives. Among the nine orifices, the most spiritually potent are the three essentials: ears, eyes, and mouth. These three operate within activity and stillness, as the *Daodejing* states: "To contract, first expand; to weaken, first strengthen; to abolish, first exalt; to seize, first give." Yet the three are contained within the One, and the One contains the three. Though specifically referring to these three, they ultimately do not depart from the Western Woman as the essential—hidden within, this is the crucial point of sagely work.

A Certain Attainment states: This "nature" refers to the nature of qi and disposition, embodying the meaning of subduing and concealing without movement.

The unskilled are shackled by the burdens of yin turbidity; the skilled, too, are enslaved by the entanglements of affairs and responses. Both must subdue and conceal without movement. With time, great wisdom may arise—then skill is no boast, and clumsiness no harm.

This passage follows from the preceding "foundation," speaking of how people, whether gifted or dull, may avoid being led astray by the deviations of the nine orifices if they know to subdue and conceal without action. Forgetting skill and transforming clumsiness lies in guarding the three essentials. One must move yet not move—what is called "stillness in stillness, stillness in motion." This is the meaning of stillness giving rise to wisdom, revealing the secret of nurturing one’s nature.

Master Fan, drowned in heterodox teachings, fails to grasp the essentials of nature and life. What does he mean by "hooking and propping with the hand"? Nature may be awakened but not grasped; life may be seen but not seized—both are utterly empty, without substance. Nature and life exist within emptiness and quiescence, "living dragons and tigers," as the ancient classics say. Yet he would hook and prop them from the ordinary body of the Western Woman—could this refer only to *gui* water?

The alchemical texts state: "What is seen cannot be used; what is used cannot be seen." Master Fan should know this—how could he utter such layman’s words? Moreover, the *kan* within *kun* still pertains to true *yuan*—what does it have to do with nature? How does he regard nature?

This passage is directed at those who falter in practicing the preceding section, as is the next. Here, the focus is on sublimation and concealment; the next follows from its closing line. Ultimately, the crux lies in illuminating the heart—only with a clear heart can one discern the moment.

Fire arises from wood, and disaster erupts in destruction; treachery arises in the state, and when the time moves, collapse is inevitable. To know this and cultivate is to be a sage.

Master Fan says: The first two lines speak of those lacking steadfastness in precepts and concentration, driven by the discriminating mind to recklessly act, losing their true nature and turning into dead corruption, like fire consuming wood. The middle two lines are double-edged: they may be read as above, or as referring to the three women as treachery. When movement arises within them, I respond to that movement to ensure collapse—at the moment of heaven and human merging, I employ my natural killing mechanism, returning the postnatal to the prenatal. To know and practice this reckless cultivation is to be a sage of the highest work.

Yet this "sage" refers to the *kan* mouth and *li* mouth—precisely the intermingling of *kan* and *li*, obtaining the true *qi* of the One, returning to rule the central earth. Do not overlook this "sage"!

A Certain Attainment states: Master Fan’s commentary is grossly mistaken and must not be followed. Not only is his explanation of "know" erroneous, but his interpretation of "sage" also contradicts the character’s meaning. The proper form of "sage" derives from *ren*, not *wang*. This book takes "know" as the essence and "cultivate" as its function, continuing from the preceding section’s closing line. The passage’s essence lies in the single word "know," for only with essence can there be function—without knowing, how can one cultivate? Cultivation occurs at the moment of movement and stillness, before manifestation. Only by knowing the moment can one act. Thus, the passage’s weight rests on "know." One may follow the text’s plain meaning without seeking hidden secrets in the strokes.

Its main point lies in the unfolding of the Five Phases—one must not indulge without restraint, as the preceding text warns, for it demonstrates the meaning of the "killing" character. The first two lines speak of life concealing killing; the middle two, of not harboring what is perilous; the final two, of the subtlety of knowing and cultivating. A plain reading shows that excess in life stirs the mechanism of killing—what harms me lies within, not without. Fire is the *qi* born within wood, yet when fire erupts, wood is destroyed. Treachery is born within the state, yet when treachery moves, the state collapses. These are disasters that cannot be forestalled. Once the mechanism is set in motion, it is too late. What is this mechanism? Excess in life without restraint becomes disaster and treachery—the sage warns against it. Governing the world and cultivating the self share the same principle; this is the original meaning of the classic. Master Fan’s explanation is utterly perverse and convoluted, yet he calls it "sagely work"—this is slander against the sage.

As for dissecting the "know" character into "arrow" and "mouth," there are the Three August Ones’ Jade Secrets for verification. Master Fan’s interpretation relies on recent oral transmissions, unaware that the Jade Secrets are supremely dignified and majestic. Even in bustling thoroughfares and grand halls, the arrow-mouth has its use—how could it be limited to not loosening garments or unbinding sashes? Even if we do not face each other, near and far are not obstructed: "Mountains, rivers, and the great earth are all crucibles; all living beings are medicinal substances." One must empty one’s form and still one’s thoughts, preserving only the One *qi*, boundless and infinite. The Six Directions and Three Powers are like a grain of millet. Within me, radiance shines inwardly, responding and emerging like an arrow—suddenly, the sagely sun and sagely moon appear, golden light illuminating, five-colored clouds and rosy mists floating in the void, swift as a whirlwind, without hindrance.

Then the sun and moon unite, suspended in my golden court, gradually drawing nearer and shrinking to the size of a bean, like a crystal lamp before the Buddha. Within it, the vast is contained, and the minute is embraced—this is the "mouth." At this time, without a single thought arising, something first comes from emptiness, and I sense within a myriad of harmonious flavors, to be experienced but not described. The Three Sages call this the arrival of true *yuan*, though it is not yet the true One. The true One comes suddenly, silent and formless, only felt as utter tranquility within, steadfast as bedrock, beyond all description. True *yuan* and true One strike the target like an arrow—this is the "arrow."

Here the text speaks of what Buddhists call *muni ālaya*. Now, this "mouth" is what our Daoist tradition terms the "Mysterious Aperture"—the wondrous vessel at the end of the scripture. With a single fist, it is shattered, and one reaches the Buddhists’ "other shore" or the Confucians’ "Ultimate Non-Being."

In ancient times, when the Tathāgata expounded the Dharma, five thousand disciples gathered in that land. In the radiance of serene concentration, they saw a light enter the Buddha’s breast. The Buddha seemed to awaken from a deep trance, giving rise to the account of the five thousand who withdrew. This was because the disciples mistakenly believed the Buddha had grown weary and left. Such is one proof of the "arrow-mouth."

Master Fan had not heard of this. As for the character *gu* (故) in the scripture, one need not interpret it through the method of character dissection. Even if one were to dissect it, there would still be a proper meaning. When the text speaks of the mechanism of literary embellishment, one should return to antiquity—this is Laozi’s principle of roaming the mind in the primordial state of things. How could it be verified by the practices of the Three Peaks School?

The above several hundred characters reveal the Great Dao of Heavenly Immortality in full. Originally, they should not have been written here, but because the "arrow-mouth" has been exposed, if not laid bare in its entirety, the profound meaning of this "knowing" (*zhi*) would not be manifest. It is not that one only employs *zhi* when cultivation reaches this stage. According to the scripture’s meaning, it naturally arises in the lines "Heaven and human unite in spontaneous emergence." Let the reader discern this carefully.

**Middle Section**

Heaven generates, Heaven destroys—such is the principle of the Dao. Master Fan says: "Heaven generating" is the forward movement of the Constant Dao; "Heaven destroying" is the reverse movement of the Returning Dao. Now, with a body that naturally moves forward in the Constant Dao, one practices the profound reversal of the Returning Dao’s natural inversion. Thus, it is called "Heaven generates, Heaven destroys." Only by fully applying this wondrous principle of inversion and subversion can one speak of the Great Dao of attaining sagehood and ascending to transcendence.

Master Yide says: This passage continues the principles and logical sequence of the previous section, "Heaven releases the mechanism of destruction." Without the mechanism of destruction in the Five Phases, the four seasons would operate chaotically, devoid of cyclical order. Within destruction lies generation; generation is concealed within destruction. Thus, there is an inherent pattern, an unending succession.

Heaven and Earth are the thieves of the myriad things; the myriad things are the thieves of humans; humans are the thieves of the myriad things. When these three thieveries are in harmony, the Three Powers are at peace.

Master Fan says: The flourishing and withering of the myriad things follow the revolutions of Heaven and Earth, hence Heaven and Earth are the thieves of the myriad things. Humans, unable to preserve their true nature, are plundered by the myriad things, hence the myriad things are the thieves of humans. If humans can firmly guard and not lose their essence, seizing the true *qi* of the myriad things, then humans become the thieves of the myriad things. Three instances of thievery form one line; nine instances complete the *qian* hexagram. The sequence within this process merely employs the human "mouth" to harmonize what is fitting, so that the three lines are as secure as a woman attaining safety.

Master Yide says: The old interpretation—"Heaven and Earth are what the myriad things steal; the myriad things are what humans steal; humans are what the myriad things steal"—is the most straightforward. Respectfully noting: The scripture’s meaning, continuing from above, expounds the profound principle of this section’s first passage, using the Three Powers as metaphors for the three *dantian*. When employed appropriately, without violating nature, each finds its proper place, as if settled in peace. Such is the Dao of the Three Powers. The meaning of "thief" is explained above.

Master Taixu says: The wondrous vessel in the lower section is possessed by all things, enabling mutual thievery. To fully grasp the subtlety of this word, oral transmission is necessary. Yet, it is nothing other than appearing foolish, clumsy, and empty. Then, the essence and function of this word are complete, capable of receiving whatever comes, like a dwelling that accommodates all. When the vessel can contain, things find peace. The crux lies in harmony. Yet Master Fan claims one attains peace through the feminine—how strange!

What is meant by "fitting and peaceful" is that the three *dantian* should all be abundantly filled. The filling of the third *dantian* involves a particular substance, and the process of gradual fulfillment follows a sequence: when essence is full, *qi* is full; when *qi* is full, spirit is full; when spirit is full, essence is sufficient—this, too, follows a Dao.

Such is the profound meaning of this passage. This is the secret of settling the Three Powers in peace, the significance of which appears in the following section. Thus it is said: Eat in its season, and the hundred bones are ordered; move its mechanism, and the myriad transformations are at peace.

Master Fan says: The word *gu* (故) connects to the preceding "peace" (*an*), placing a "ten" (*shi*) over the "mouth" (*kou*) to return the true One within. This is the function of "thus it is said." "Eating" means consuming the Great Medicine—this is what is meant by "those who attain it are constantly as if drunk." Yet, one must await its timely arrival. That time arrives only when the mechanism manifests its dynamic sign. When the sign of the mechanism’s movement appears, it is precisely the time to consume it—this is "humans as the thieves of the myriad things." Once one consumes this hare’s marrow and crow’s essence, the bones throughout the body are all permeated and ordered. The turbid *yin* is expelled, transforming into pure *yang*—this is the result of daily practice in withdrawing the *yin* tally and advancing the *yang* fire in circulation. With ten thousand cycles of refining essence, *qi*, and spirit, one meal brings peace through transformation. How could this myriad-fold peace be attained apart from the feminine?

Master Yide says: Only by not missing the season can one eat in its season; only by not obstructing the mechanism can one move its mechanism. The two characters *gu yue* (故曰) conceal a wondrous meaning, also seen in the Jade Formulae of the Three Sovereigns. The formula lies in returning and not flowing back to the primordial beginning—this is the meaning of "restoring life." The formula for attaining oneness lies solely in the character *yue* (曰).

This *yue* contains the intention of releasing ten thousand entanglements, withdrawing the self from the mundane world into one’s own center, boundless in its vastness. The *qi*-mechanism flows freely, like clouds and mist, then suddenly all sounds cease, and inner and outer settle into peace. Concentrating the intention, one feels only a gentle, serene stillness—this is what the Three Sages call the return of the true One. Such is the mysterious image of the *yue* character, the "image without image."

If one clings to form, what is obtained must be false. Only by entering through emptiness and nothingness do both the *yue*-moment and the *yue*-mechanism align with the Dao. The methods described by Master Fan originally belonged to the oral instructions of ancient immortals, who used external teachings to convey inner cultivation. Yet when he claims, "How can one attain peace apart from the feminine?" he falls into heterodox doctrine.

A private examination reveals: the ancient character *zhi* (知, "to know"), the character *gu* (故, "therefore"), the character *yue* (曰, "to say"), the character *yu* (虞, "Yu"), the character *sheng* (圣, "sage"), and others—all emphasize the recognition of the right moment. Yet Master Fan only knew how to rigidly apply one moment, unaware that every moment could be used. For the moment has both dynamic and fixed aspects; it is not only *zi* and *wu* that possess dynamic and fixed qualities—from *zi* to *hai*, each has its own dynamic and fixed nature.

The true One and true primordial *qi* reside nowhere beyond the body, yet they are not confined to the body. Generally, at the onset of practice, one discerns the prevailing circumstances to determine the moment—this method is most dynamic and most efficacious. Speaking of the body alone, the moment has its fixed and dynamic aspects; speaking of the Three Powers and Six Harmonies, the moment likewise has its fixed and dynamic aspects. Thus, in their mutual resonance, the fixed responds to the fixed, the dynamic to the dynamic, with no gap between them. Herein lies the mechanism within the moment: when the moment arrives, the mechanism stirs; when the mechanism stirs, transformation unfolds. This is the wondrous principle of spontaneity, the great Dao of spontaneity. Master Fan merely sat in a well, gazing at the sky.

People know the numinousness of the numinous, yet do not understand the numinousness of the non-numinous. Master Fan says: "The numinous is yang. The numinousness of the numinous is the yang within yang—this is what is meant by 'the mystery within the mystery.'" Yet this true yang is concealed within true yin, and to obtain this true yang is to attain it in an instant, as Lü Zu said of the "mouth-to-mouth" numinous function. Consider: if the character *zhi* (知) is split in half, does it not form the two characters *shi kou* (矢口, "instant utterance")? Thus, it is called knowing the numinousness of the numinous.

Yet in this application, there is nothing but the ordinary and the plain, without the slightest affectation or contrivance—appearing as non-action yet truly action, within action yet truly non-action. Thus, it is called knowing the numinousness of the non-numinous. One must understand: to obtain this yang *qi* is to do so with the marvelous vessel, employing the method of the non-numinous numinous. When this yang *qi* arrives, it is precisely the primordial *qi* from before one’s parents’ birth.

A note says: These two *zhi* characters—Master Fan did not receive the true transmission and strayed into heterodoxy, for he never heard of the wondrous meaning of mutual resonance within emptiness and nothingness. The upper sentence refers to the true primordial *qi* born of the union of self and other, *qi* and spirit, within emptiness and nothingness. The lower sentence speaks of the true primordial *qi* of the Three Powers ascending and flourishing above, resonating with and condensing one’s own *qi* and spirit as they rise to meet it—thus, within emptiness and nothingness, they merge to generate the true One.

A careful examination of the scriptural meaning reveals: the thing born of the mutual resonance and union of self and other is nothing more than true primordial *qi*, and thus it is called the numinousness of the numinous—it is not truly precious. Only when one obtains the thing born of the mutual resonance of one’s own *qi* and spirit with the descending primordial *qi* of the Two Great Ones, merging within emptiness and nothingness, does it become the true One. To obtain and possess it is to form the embryo of sagehood and perfection—this is the supreme treasure. Spirit unites with spirit, hence it is called the numinousness of the numinous. Yet the One born within this union is the ultimate emptiness, beyond the category of the numinous—thus, it is called the non-numinous numinous. The emphasis of the passage lies in the lower sentence, hence the distinction between knowing and not knowing.

The sun and moon have their numbers, their greatness and smallness are fixed—sagehood arises from this, and the numinous emerges from this. Master Fan says: "The sun, as a yang body, belongs to *li* and is the lesser yin; the moon, as a luminous body, belongs to *kan* and is the greater yang. Each has its number: the sun’s number must reach sixteen, the moon’s number must reach five thousand and forty-eight days." To speak of the sun and moon’s movements is incorrect. As for the "three before and three after," this refers to the pairing of *jia* and *geng*, the union of *ding* and *ren*.

For example, in the first line of the *qian* hexagram: first, take *jia* and count backward three positions to *gui*, then pair it with *ren* after *gui*; next, take *geng* and count forward three positions to *ren*, which is also the *ren* before *gui* when counting backward three positions from *jia*; finally, take *jia* again and count backward three positions to *gui*, then pair it with *ren* after *gui*. This is precisely the method of "three before and three after" between the first and last quarters. Three such pairings form the first line of the *qian* hexagram; nine pairings form its three lines, reaching the state of pure yang. Only when the numbers of the sun and moon are complete can one employ this sage-making practice, gathering the Five Phases at the central palace, whence the spirit-person is born and emerges. The birth of the spirit-person does not come from the sun and moon merely shining together—this is the non-numinous numinous.

The "three before and three after," the first and last quarters, the references to *jia*, *geng*, *ding*, and *ren*—these are the fire talismans. When the numbers of the sun and moon are complete, the numbers of the fire talismans are complete. The moment of revelation is precisely the numinousness of the numinous. As Lü Zu said, "Pointing afar to the sun and moon at the edge of the sky," and again, "The moon in the sky above, the tide in the sea below," and as Cui Xifan said, "The heavens respond to the stars, the earth responds to the tides"—all derive from this interpretation. This is truly the great Dao of sagehood through the *Yinfu Jing*, the esoteric meaning transmitted across millennia.

A note says: Calculating the sun and moon through *geng* and *jia*, speaking of greatness and smallness in terms of yin and yang—this is indeed the principle of the *Yijing*, and Master Fan’s explanation is correct. A careful examination reveals that this passage elucidates the meaning of the earlier phrase "people know," and it is truly the one essential oral instruction transmitted since antiquity. Yet the scripture speaks of it as something "people know." In the time of the Yellow Emperor, many practiced the Dao, and this kind of scriptural meaning was known to all—hence it is said, "People know the numinousness of the numinous." Master Fan failed to realize this, treating this passage as an untransmitted secret, and thus regarding it as the non-numinous numinous—he had never heard of the highest-level practice of the *Yinfu Jing*.

This passage still adheres to the dynamics of the Two Schools of yin and yang—timely movement when qi is full, the subtlety of balanced stimulus and response, the fire-phasing of even penetration and even resonance. Yet it has not yet spoken of the cultivation that universally resonates and responds across the Six Harmonies and Three Powers, the merging and intermingling that gives rise to life. Even so, sagely attainment arises here, and numinous clarity emerges here. The late master, Elder Tai Xu, thus held that this passage merely elaborates the opening line of the preceding text. As for the highest-level practice of the highest vehicle, it takes its stand before heaven and earth existed, before father and mother were born—thus it operates without reliance on yin and yang, the Five Phases, years, months, days, or hours. Once the moment of activation arrives, emotions are regulated and returned to their original nature, forming a single precious pearl that is drawn into the wondrous vessel. Through daily accumulation and monthly refinement, it ultimately unites with the true singularity of the Three Powers, becoming one without duality—thus the sagely embryo is formed. In this way, the Three Powers dissolve, yet I alone endure forever. This is the arcane cultivation method of the Three Sovereigns’ era, a secret not even known to the people of the Yellow Emperor’s time. The latter half of the preceding passage refers precisely to this, hence the phrase "people do not know." This is the hundred-foot-pole technique, a method that allows one to turn left or right and find the source, the wondrous Dao by which all under heaven returns to benevolence. What I have heard from my late master is as follows.

Yet my late master also said that the profound principle of this passage is the foundation of establishing oneself. If this passage is forgotten, there is no way to advance in the highest-level practice of the highest vehicle. How could this passage ever be momentarily neglected? As for its "stealing mechanism," none in the world can see it, none can know it. The noble person who obtains it strengthens their person; the petty person who obtains it treats life lightly. Master Fan said: "To steal is the Dao; the Dao is to steal." The sagely function operates by observing the mechanism and applying the "stealing" to the heavens of two persons. Thus, the true yang of the upper spoonful cannot be seen with the eyes, while the true yang of the lower spoonful can only be obtained through the arrow-mouth. The noble person, knowing the inch of yang in two persons, must employ the method of the "cross-shaped large and small mouths" to return it, thereby strengthening their person and enduring forever. The petty person, unable to maintain self-discipline, relies on talent and forgets action, drifting into heterodoxy and losing their life without awareness—hence it is said they treat life lightly. This illustrates the auspicious and inauspicious outcomes of deviance and uprightness.

I say: The "its" in this passage refers to the Dao spoken of in the preceding section. "To steal" means to secretly take and conceal. "Mechanism" refers to the mechanism activated between self and other. If not concealed, it scatters—hence the value of knowing how to steal. Since none can see it and none can know it, it is called "stealing." Yet it is essential to maintain an all-embracing mind, lest one aspect dominate. This contains both the meanings of "taking" and "giving." To know this is to be a noble person; to be ignorant of it is to be a petty person. Herein lies the Mandate of Heaven. Those who observe and grasp Heaven—how can they neglect the stealing mechanism? Aligning with Heaven strengthens the person; harboring selfishness in stealing only leads to treating life lightly. What is obtained? It is the attainment of this Dao of taking and giving.

Upon careful examination, this passage still pertains to the Dao of preliminary testing, hence this warning. Master Fan failed to see this, so his interpretation fell into the category of treating life lightly—it cannot be followed.

---

The next section:
The deaf excel in seeing; the blind excel in hearing.
Cut off profit from its single source, and the use of the army is tenfold.
Return three times day and night, and the use of the army is ten thousandfold.

Master Fan said: This refers to the moment in practice when one encounters the use of the beautiful mouth—one must be like the deaf who excel in seeing, the blind who excel in hearing. The two excellences illustrate the meaning of "focus," and also imply using the mouth while the heart is without a mouth. One must know that in the practice of stealing, nothing can be taken without the mouth. The profit from the single source of the silk’s color and true unity is most crucial in the use of the mouth’s single source. First, one applies the ears and eyes to the mechanism; only upon obtaining the mechanism does one use the mouth. Once the mouth is used, it is through the cross-shaped method that one obtains it. If one truly returns to the source three times through the cross-shaped method, it is as perilous as deploying an army. This is precisely planting the lotus in fire—truly yielding ten thousandfold gains. It is the ceaseless use of ears, eyes, and mouth from dawn to dusk to achieve the profit of the stealing mechanism, thereby initiating the use of the mechanism in the following text.

The word "fold" has another wondrous meaning, which I dare not commit to writing—please do not overlook it.

I say: The upper and middle sections speak of the principles as they ought to be, and the advantages and disadvantages therein are also mentioned. The lower section discusses the method of practice, wherein principles are encountered. By selecting, rejecting, reducing, and augmenting within it, the method is complete. To unify and embody it lies in focus, in utmost stillness and extreme emptiness where there is no self or other, allowing naturalness to take its course, viewing existence and non-existence as one through the qi mechanism. Within this, there is constant tranquility—if one forgets this tranquility, one can then operate in constant response and constant stillness.

Upon careful examination, the first two lines of this passage convey the meaning of "focus," the third line the meaning of "oneness." The eyes excel in seeing, the ears excel in hearing; the deaf and blind can cut off their distractions, thus unifying the source. The fourth line gathers the meaning of "augmentation," which is verified in the phrase "return three times"—the meaning of "constancy." "Army" refers to the multitude; the *Yijing*’s hexagram *Shi* (Army) speaks of amassing the masses—this is precisely the great Dao of finding the source and returning to benevolence amidst a multitude of people. "Returning three times day and night" refers to the thirty-six hours. Thirty-six is the extreme of yin numbers.

If one can focus with constancy, then yin is fully transformed into yang, and the thirty-six palaces are all spring. "Tenfold" and "ten-thousandfold" are approximate terms. To focus is to be able to employ the multitude; to be constant is to be ever more capable of multiplying that employment. The character *bei* (倍, "fold") disassembled reveals the workings of yin and yang at the gate of heaven and earth—this must be considered in conjunction with the character *shi* (十, "ten"). The character *wan* (萬, "ten thousand") disassembled consists of *cao* (艹) and *yu* (禺): *cao* pertains to the qi of *kun* (坤), and *yu* to the yin category. This follows Master Fan’s method of interpretation. Yet in terms of principle, employing the character *bei* yields a superior application to that which Master Fan revered. Nevertheless, in orthodox teaching, the Dao is not cultivated in isolation. If a practitioner follows the true lineage of this scripture, even in solitary cultivation within a chamber, the vast emptiness will respond to the true unity and true origin, and the harvest of qi will be inexhaustible—indeed, tenfold or ten-thousandfold. The orthodox meaning of this scripture does not lie in the dissection of characters.

This passage concerns the establishment of destiny, yet its words and intent reside in the realm of nature, for destiny is perfected within nature. Let the scholar examine this closely, and they will know what to pursue.

The heart is born of things and dies by things; the mechanism lies in the eye. Master Fan said: When the heart is led by the mechanism of things, it becomes a tool of those things—though born, it hastens its own death. When the heart is not led by the mechanism of things, it employs things as its own tools—though seemingly dead, it attains true life. This is precisely what is meant by "neither dying nor living, neither living nor dying." Yet the path of life and death is discerned by observing the mechanism through the eye, which serves as the bridge to the Dao.

Master Yide said: Drawn by things, the emotions stir—this is being born of things. Enslaved by things, the spirit is depleted; depletion leads to ruin—this is dying by things. Though the heart is born and dies through things, in truth, it has no birth or death. If, when born of things, one can awaken and reflect, then the mechanism of death is absent. That mechanism is seen only by the eye. The eye is the celestial eye, located between the brows—not the two physical eyes—where the true unity abides. When the eye gazes upon the mechanism, its threads are myriad and its transformations unfathomable. Yet if the eye can perceive the beginning and recognize the thread, or see the thread and identify the beginning, then the mechanism cannot escape. Great indeed is the function of the eye! Thus it is said, "The heart is born of things and dies by things," and again, "The mechanism lies in the eye." This teaches that one must rely on the true unity as the master. Whether it is employed or not depends on the heart, hence the value of a luminous heart. A luminous heart can perceive nature, so the study of the Dao begins and ends with clarifying the ground of the heart.

This character *mu* (目, "eye") is the central pivot of the earlier *guan* (觀, "observation"). The sages’ use of the eye aims to clarify the heart—its intent lies beyond the words. Quietly pondering the preceding and following passages, the meaning becomes self-evident.

Heaven bestows no favor, yet great favor arises; in swift thunder and fierce wind, all things stir. Supreme joy is the surplus of nature; supreme stillness is the restraint of nature. The most private of all things, when employed, becomes the most public.

Master Fan said: When two do not separate, free from the constraints of mundane emotions, and wholly without the common Dao’s compliance with life, this is "no favor." When the time arrives and the mechanism appears, the great medicine is born. At this moment, one must distinguish *ren* (壬) and *gui* (癸), allowing *geng* (庚) and *jia* (甲) to merge, swallowing them into the abdomen to return to the *qian* (乾) body and attain longevity—is this not great favor? Yet the merging of metal and wood occurs in but a moment of fierce wind, and with a sudden thunderclap, all things stir, instantly breaking free from madness to reveal the celestial truth. This depends entirely on the spirit’s single strike. Thus Lü Dongbin’s words, "Within the thunder’s roar, one finds the root," serve as evidence.

Yet the small earth of *yi* (厶) that is born, when struck, yields a thread of white metal from *dui* (兑), which, though small, can fill the six directions. The small earth of *yi* (厶) that is born is originally pure and still, receiving a drop of verdant yang to congeal without contention. Though its restraint is slight, the function of the two and the *yi* earth is inherently a private, unseen act. Yet with a single shock from the great emptiness, returning to truth, it manifests its use within the *yi* earth of self and others—thus it is also called public. These four "supremes" all return to the principle of abiding in the center and guarding the center.

Master Yide said: Supreme joy is the movement of nature; its surplus spills outward. Supreme stillness is the stability of nature; its restraint is inward. The movement of thunder and rain fills and overflows, hence the response of abundance. Swift thunder and fierce wind must change, thus cautioning against excess and dissipation. "All things stir"—this is the public use. Only the cultivator of the Dao benefits from wind and thunder, uniquely receiving heaven’s private favor. Such is the profound principle of this passage.

The influence of sound is greatest in wind and thunder. This passage continues the meaning of "skillful listening" from above, just as the previous passage continued the meaning of "skillful seeing." These two passages speak of the subtlety of seeing and hearing. Responding to the mechanism without attachment leads to the following passage’s function of controlling the *qin* (禽).

Master Fan’s explanation may be selectively adopted, yet it should be grasped in spirit and practiced within emptiness and stillness. If one clings to the traces, it is no longer the great Dao.

The control of the *qin* lies in *qi*. Master Fan said: This speaks solely of *qi*, revealing the marvel of heaven and humanity acting in unison. It employs *qi* rather than form, as in the crane’s union through sound. The principle of employing *qi* does not refer to the *qi* within the body. Without the effort to control it, *qi* will not come, and the *ren* and *du* meridians will remain blocked, the paths of ascent and descent obstructed. Even if obtained, it will be lost, for there will be no place to gather, subdue, or store it. For *qi* is yang: humanity gains life through yang and dies through its loss. Half become immortals, half become ghosts.

Those who practice this art are precisely engaged in dispelling the yin to augment the yang. Yet when the spirit is already bewildered by profusion and splendor, and *qi* further depleted by love and desire, without this marvel of mutual activation and mutual resonance through *qi*, how could one return to the original source?

Yide remarked: Master Fan’s passage here is truly worthy of the term "profound understanding," leaving nothing to be desired. It is regrettable, however, that in the preceding section, the character *guan* (觀) was not analyzed according to the *Hongwu Zhengyun*, leading to a misinterpretation that reads it as "adhering to the body," resulting in the erroneous phrase "using two mouths above the *zhui* flower." Had the character *zhui* (隹) been properly dissected, the rationale behind this sentence in this passage would have been immediately apparent. For *zhui* (pronounced *zhui*) denotes a nimble bird, swift to respond to stimuli—hence the addition of the "see" (見) radical on the right. This signifies observing the nature of the *zhui* and employing *qi* to control it, ensuring the bird remains unaware. When the time arrives and the mechanism is in place, the two *qi* manifest, and the bird, driven by desire, forgets all resistance and merges naturally.

Such is the meaning of *guan*: its function lies in the single word *qi*. What *qi* is this? It is the primordial *qi* within *Kun*. For this bird is a creature of *Li*, containing the true essence and flowing pearls—its nature is keenly sensitive. As the *Cantong Qi* states: "The pearl of the Great Yang ever seeks to abandon man; swiftly seizing its radiant essence, it turns and follows in accord." What is the Golden Flower? It is the primordial *qi* of *Kun*. When the time arrives, the marrow of *Kan* ascends, becoming the marrow of the hare. *Kan* and *Li* unite, transforming into a white fluid that congeals into utmost solidity. Once congealed, it does not disperse—this is what is meant by "control." Such is its effect, the marvel of natural operation.

To uncover the secret of its attainment lies in the midst of primordial undifferentiation. The *Yijing* states: "Supreme is the primal *qi* of *Kun*; the myriad things rely upon it for life, for it follows and upholds heaven." This is the essence of this passage, which Master Fan did not fully perceive.

Life is the root of death; death is the root of life. Favor arises from harm, and harm arises from favor. Master Fan said: Death is the operation of the constant Dao; life is the achievement of the reverse Dao. The constant Dao gives birth to man, but when the heart is deluded by emotions and desires, essence, *qi*, and spirit are lost, inevitably leading to death—hence life is called the root of death. The reverse Dao gives birth to the body when the heart dies to emotions and desires. Then essence, *qi*, and spirit are preserved, inevitably leading to life—hence death is called the root of life. This is what Master Ziyang meant by "merely turn the door of death into the door of life; do not take the gate of life as the gate of death."

In sum, employing the hidden store of the reverse Dao, one learns the way of death before the body dies, thereby attaining complete life. It is like the dragon and serpent rising from the land, nourished by the surging of *qi* and blood; or thunder roaring and wind sweeping, dependent on the moment when the moon’s reflection appears upon the alchemical platform. Thus favor arises from harm. When treachery festers within a state, it foreshadows the inevitable collapse of plunder; when leaves flourish and flowers bloom, it is the response of yin’s exhaustion and yang’s return. Thus harm arises from favor. The latter two lines refer to the timing of the firing process. This firing process and the interplay of punishment and virtue should be considered together.

Yide remarked: The five phases give rise to and cause the death of one another, so favor and harm likewise lie in mutual dependence. This passage offers a straightforward explanation, serving as an introduction to what follows and continuing the meaning of "control" from above. The key lies in discerning the movement of *qi*, preventing excess or imbalance, and reversing control in response to the moment—then success is assured. This is the function of "harm giving rise to favor, death giving rise to life."

The next passage reveals the wondrous principle of how to begin applying the method. The firing process depends on timing, thus one must carefully observe the sequence and interplay of *qi*; the gathering depends on the object, thus one must regulate the imbalance of yin and yang within the body. Its application is profoundly mysterious, its mechanism profoundly elusive, yet it does not transcend what is stated in this passage.

The essence of this passage is that only one who fully realizes their nature can fulfill their destiny. From this point onward, the text focuses entirely on the principles of destiny, though nature still presides over them. Master Fan’s explanation here also contains insights worth adopting.

The foolish regard the patterns of heaven and earth as sagely, while I regard the patterns of time and things as wise. Master Fan said: The *yu* is a macaque. When the *qi* and numerical cycles of the *yu*’s heaven and earth are fully abundant, radiant patterns naturally emerge, signaling the union of *Kan* and *Li* and their entry into the center to form earth. This is the meaning of observing heaven and examining earth—not the vulgar study of celestial stars and terrestrial veins, but rather the profound model of the numerical cycles of the sun and moon, their fixed measures of great and small, and the heavenly and human forces acting in unison. It is the way to seize spiritual power and alter destiny, all contained herein.

Thus, to call the patterns of heaven and earth sagely is the view of the foolish. I, however, employ the numerical cycles of the sun and moon, their fixed measures of great and small, and the moment when the mechanism appears, using the spirit that is not spirit to ensure that the mechanism of theft manifests the radiant patterns of timely refinement, uniting the sagely with the wise. Moreover, amid the bewildering allure of external things, I silently direct the *qi* mechanism of those who regard the patterns of heaven and earth as sagely, enabling me to attain wisdom through the principles of things.

At this time, these patterns are the most intimate and proximate to us, present from morning to night in the most ordinary places. They are the crucial pivot between the sagely and the mundane. We must not mistake them—please consider this carefully.

Yide remarked: That which manifests externally is called *pattern*; that which flows internally is called *principle*. The sagely and the wise both understand and penetrate them. To speak of celestial patterns as stars and constellations, or terrestrial principles as mountains and rivers, is merely to be versed in astronomical and geomantic phenomena—these are the traces of heaven and earth, not the Dao of heaven and earth. *Time* encompasses both heaven and humanity. Heaven has its fixed times, and the human body has its dynamic moments; their transitions and manifestations all possess distinct patterns and orderly principles. In practice, one must not err in this.

The function of *time* is vast indeed! The term *thing* is a designation for what stands before me—it refers to humanity. The traces and images manifest below flourish as human culture. The spirit and *qi* issuing above each follow their own patterns, resonating in harmony without confusion—the function of things is likewise boundless!

Those who aspire to the Dao invariably seek it afar in heaven and earth. Yet *time* and *things* are what people overlook, unaware that the great Dao resides precisely within them. The circulation of *qi*-mechanisms throughout heaven and earth may be calculated and matched to what the eye perceives; the ebb and flow of resonance within *time* and *things* is silently embodied in what the eye cannot see—this is the essence of the *Yinfu* [Scripture]. The principle of direct interpretation is thus.

This passage reveals the core teachings of two schools, each rectifying the great matter of *nature and life*, possessing the wondrous principle of dual cultivation advancing in tandem. The "foolish words of the foolish" refer to the heart of the woman. As the *Zuozhuan* states: "The woman is a yang entity, her nature inherently tranquil." One should begin with the application of the heart, thus it is fitting to merge and penetrate the patterns of one’s own body and heaven-and-earth, resonating with the true unity born of emptiness, thereby forming the sagely embryo.

As for me, I employ *non-mind* as function. Thus, when the patterns of *time* and *things* are fully realized and the mechanism manifests, I remain utterly empty and still—the mechanism naturally comes to accord. Enveloping it with true intention, the sagely embryo is then formed. For Yu was originally without mind, his mechanism easily responsive; I am fundamentally replete within, and without emptiness, nothing can be received. Such is the principle.

The true essence of the *Yinfu* places Yu and me in different positions, each with *qi*-mechanisms outwardly expressed, yet neither departing from its own body. Therein lies the mystery of "appearing yet not appearing." The three powers share one origin, filling the six directions. In their respective practices, each attains the realm of emptiness and nothingness. The three treasures of the three powers find their abode in non-being. Non-being encounters non-being, merging without division. Within this, each possesses yin and yang; their union in emptiness gives rise to transformation. If one sought to describe its wonder, even all the bamboo of Mount Nan could not exhaust it.

When emptiness is further refined into stillness, the interplay of the ten thousand transformations flows unimpeded, and what is generated must be full. If one does not miss the proper time and emptily receives the thing, then mutual attainment arises—within each of us, jade accumulates into mountains, gold spreads into earth. This is precisely the function of the earlier passage, "Heaven triggers the mechanism of killing," and its foundation is laid here.

The sage universally saves both men and women, hence the following section on practice opens a new dimension. Its secret is profoundly subtle, yet its application is exceedingly simple and near. However, from ancient times to the present, few who read this scripture have been able to grasp it, for they lack oral transmission.

Yide, having silently embodied the master’s intent, has here laid bare the profound teaching in its entirety. May those who encounter it take heed and strive together.

People deceive the sage with foolishness; I deceive the sage without foolishness. People await the sage with the extraordinary; I await the sage without the extraordinary. Like sinking wood into fire, one invites destruction.

Master Fan says: "Foolishness" means being ignorant and unaware, in a state of dull confusion. This refers to the requirement that one be like the foolish. "Deception" means fearing that others will perceive one’s actions, and is spoken as an analogy for the central palace within me. "Sage" refers to what is unlike the common Dao, hence the phrase "deceiving the sage with foolishness."

I, however, hold the cosmos in hand, the ten thousand transformations born of the body, the union of *kan* and *li*, the convergence of metal and wood, the arising of sagely achievement, the emergence of spirit and illumination—all is the natural, non-doing Dao. Thus, I do not deceive the sage with foolishness. This is the secret meaning of the three words "foolishness, deception, sage."

Yide says: Master Fan’s misinterpretation of the scripture stems entirely from his assumption that it was written for men, and further from his rigid adherence to the analysis of characters, lacking oral transmission and relying solely on private conjecture. Moreover, he mistakenly took *yuan* as "one," thus exhausting his thoughts only to fall into heterodox paths. It is better to interpret the text directly according to its words, and its meaning will naturally become clear.

"Deception" means *to measure*. "Sage" means *penetrating illumination*. "Foolishness" refers to being settled and still like a fool, though in truth not foolish. "Extraordinary" refers to actions of spiritual marvel. The sagely Dao is natural and does not lie in the extraordinary. Forced and contrived actions lead only to self-destruction. The meaning of this passage is precisely to introduce the following term "natural."

Though it may seem simple and near, its profound teaching runs deep. In the time of the Yellow Emperor, the Dao was spoken of without mention of the elixir. Later generations introduced various teachings, yet all can be encompassed in the two words *body* and *mind*.

This passage emerges from the preceding one, opening a new dimension—it contains the wondrous function of embracing the myriad within the one, the great Dao of mutual completion between self and other. Yet it does not arise from contrivance. Hence, the following passage highlights the word "natural."

It speaks of stillness as the entry point, and through utmost stillness and emptiness, the marvelous vessel is put to true use, ultimately shattering emptiness itself to achieve completion. The scripture guards its secrets and does not fully disclose them. The profound meaning of this passage must be understood through the oral transmission of Ancestor Lü’s seal.

If the previous passage spoke of the method of entry—constantly and silently contemplating the patterns of *time* and *things*—then within the lesser and greater cycles of the sun and moon lies the function of spirit and illumination. This passage on practice, however, sweeps aside the lesser and greater cycles of the sun and moon, the patterns of *time* and *things*, and all such functions with a single stroke. It embraces the three as one, wearing the high and treading the profound, merging all into one body. The living beings of movement and stillness all become companions of the Dao.

Within one’s inherent nature lies a perfect and all-encompassing sphere, suspended like a pellet. Yet when advancing fire or retreating tally, the body perches atop this sphere to observe the firing times—this is the work of expanding and refining the *yinqie* (the inner crucible). Once the firing times are complete, the body penetrates into the sphere, where it congeals and nurtures, thereby resting the primordial spirit and also stilling the *yinqie* with quietude.

At this moment, the ears and eyes perceive nothing, the outer semblance appears foolish—yet one does not realize that great wisdom, which seems foolish, is the very means to enter sagehood. Heaven and earth undergo reversals, the inner image appears wondrous—yet one does not realize that the harmonious union of Qian and Kun, which seems unremarkable, is the very act of sage-making.

The preceding section’s work refers to the true essence scattered across the Three Powers, employed to expand and refine one’s *yinqie*—this is merely an auxiliary to one’s true unity, bearing no relation to the precelestial true unity. It is akin to the Buddhist practice of accumulating śarīra (relics) and the like. The wondrous mechanism of the latter section, however, is another name for true unity, whose function is vast—all is the supreme principle of spontaneity. If the latter section is not aligned with spontaneity, one falls into heterodox paths, sinking into fire or drowning in water. Such is the intent of the sacred scripture.

The Dao of spontaneity is still, thus heaven, earth, and the myriad things are born. The Dao of heaven and earth is gradual, thus yin and yang prevail. Yin and yang contend with one another, and transformations proceed in harmony. Master Fan says: The stillness of the Dao of spontaneity is the undifferentiated body of the precelestial Great Ultimate. When stillness reaches its extreme, movement arises, giving birth to heaven and earth. The Great Ridgepole and the Two Modes interact, further generating the myriad things—this clarifies the spontaneous nurturing of the precelestial in response to the times. As for the Dao of yin and yang and heaven and earth, the mechanism of *qi* flows and circulates ceaselessly, gradually permeating and saturating until the appointed time arrives. Yin and yang contend, and their interplay unfolds. We then propel and agitate them, ensuring transformations proceed in harmony, allowing beings to fulfill their lives—this elucidates the manifestations of the postcelestial *qi* mechanism in accord with the times.

To act in harmony with heaven is to know the moment when heaven and humanity jointly arise—the time of movement, the time of consuming the hour, the times of the lesser and greater cycles of the sun and moon. These various times are the wellspring of firing times.

Master Yide says: *Jin* (浸) means mutual permeation and infusion. Within yin there is yang, and within yang there is yin—hence the phrase "yin and yang prevail." Master Fan’s explanation in this section accords well with the wonders of the Dao. Yet one must know that when there is something, one applies effort; when there is nothing, and even when there is nothing yet it is as if there were still something—upside down, topsy-turvy, the profound meaning within can be grasped intuitively but not spoken. In all cases, the ultimate emptiness and profound stillness serve as the foundation.

When emptiness is extreme, there are no obstructions, and one is not hindered by the postcelestial. Moreover, one can use the Dao to smelt and refine, returning to emptiness. Only after emptiness can there be stillness; stillness brings inner clarity. When the mechanism arrives, one is necessarily aware, avoiding dullness. Actions are timely, free from the flaw of missing the moment. This is the time when the mechanism manifests—sometimes precelestial, sometimes postcelestial, sometimes to be embraced, sometimes to be relinquished. One should advance and add fire; one should retreat and withdraw the tally. Though this is spontaneous, it must rely on the movement of intent. Such movement has its restraints and releases, its softness and hardness, its slowness and urgency, its penetration and concealment. Transformations arise from this, and sagehood is achieved through this.

Master Taixu said: The sage transmits the medicine but not the fire—not that the fire is not transmitted, but that the firing times arise according to the moment and proceed in response to the mechanism. To follow a fixed pattern is impossible. The superior elixir method is transmitted heart-to-heart; the middle elixir method requires oral instruction; the inferior elixir method must be transmitted through writing, for its methods are cumbersome.

The *Yinfu Jing* is written in cloud-seal script, each character over a *zhang* in size. The Yellow Emperor received it at the Heavenly Altar of Kongtong. Even with his sagacity, he still relied on question and answer to understand it. The version revered in the world is likely the text personally transmitted by the Yellow Emperor. Though it has fallen into written form, its profound intent lies in heart-to-heart transmission. To embody it with a tranquil mind is the highest of the highest teachings—this is revealed in the opening line of this section.

Laozi also said: Humans emulate earth, earth emulates heaven, heaven emulates the Dao, and the Dao emulates spontaneity. The opening line of this section already reveals the Yellow Emperor’s guiding principle: it instructs one to stand firm in the state before parents were born, before heaven and earth existed, where the workings of creation left no trace. To know how to enter from spontaneity is to return every drop to the source, to align every aspect with the Dao.

It further says: The preceding section encompassed and swept away all things—the lesser and greater cycles of the sun and moon, the patterns of *time* and *things*. Yet within the transformations of yin and yang in this section lies the meaning of knowing the times—this is most worthy of comprehension. The intent of the preceding section is to warn against clinging to traces; the intent of this text is to warn against neglecting the mechanism. What my teacher, Master Niwan, referred to as requiring oral transmission pertains precisely to such subtle and essential meanings.

Master Yide respectfully notes: In this section, the character *cui* (摧) appears in both ancient and modern editions as *tui* (推). Following the *Yijing*’s phrase "hard and soft propel each other," this *cui* should indeed be *tui*. However, the Hidden Master Yun of the Taiwei Vinaya Monastery possessed dharma objects secretly bestowed by the National Preceptor, the eminent scholar Wang Kunyang. Among the robes, alms bowls, scrolls, ruyi scepters, staffs, and other items passed down by the Perfected Ones through the generations since Ancestor Qiu, there was a copy of the *Kongtong Dialogues*. It bore the imperial inscription and seal of Emperor Taizong of Song, identifying it as a treasured edition of Chen Tuan, and included a verse on transmission in the hand of Ancestor Wang Chongyang. This was an ancient edition predating the Song and Yuan dynasties, and it used *cui*. Thus, this edition’s *cui* must have a basis and is not a scribal error. According to the *Yijing*’s "dragons battle in the wilds, their blood dark yellow," there is the meaning of mutual *cui*. Therefore, Master Yide still follows Master Fan’s use of *cui*.

In the preceding section, the phrase "knowing and cultivating it," other editions uniformly render as "cultivating and refining," yet only the Lü edition from the Vinaya Monastery writes "cultivating it," a more archaic grammatical form. This is because Master Fan’s received text must have originated from the Vinaya tradition, and thus the entire scripture—its sections, passages, and sentences—follows the Fan edition, not others’ chapter divisions or headings. Let the reader examine this carefully.

Thus, the sage knows the Dao of Nature cannot be violated and therefore regulates it. The Dao of utmost quiescence transcends the reckoning of vinaya and calendrics. Therein lies the marvelous vessel, from which the myriad things are born. The eight trigrams and the sexagenary cycle, the divine mechanism and the hidden workings of spirits, the art of yin and yang overcoming one another—all manifestly advance toward the image.

Master Fan states: The Dao of Nature is the practice of embryonic breathing in the three fields. Yet this embryonic breathing is not what the vulgar call "focusing on the cinnabar field" or "forcibly drawing the river chariot." Rather, it first effects the intercourse of Heaven and Earth, then conducts the salvation of Kan and Li, and finally operates the marvel of returning to the center. This is the learning of the form within the mother’s womb, enabling the Conception and Governor Vessels to open and flow, ascending and descending to nourish generation and transformation. None but employ the reversed character for "ten mouths" to obtain the descent of yang qi, hence the designation "thus."

All prior attainments of sagehood and transcendence proceed from this, establishing the practice of non-action and immobility, the most proper and unchanging method. Yet this cannot be aligned with the calculations of vinaya or calendrics. Thus arises the use of the marvelous vessel. This vessel is truly the source of the Dao, the root of qi, the foundation of the myriad transformations, and the progenitor of the *Yin Fu Jing*. The sage relies on it as the starting point for applying effort. Through this vessel, killing and stealing are established; through this vessel, the numinousness of stealing that is not numinous becomes numinous; through this vessel, efficacy is attained. The circulation of the eight trigrams, the sexagenary cycle, Water and Metal—none do not reverse their course through this vessel. The union of Heaven and humanity, the welcoming of spirits and the concealment of ghosts—none do not rely on the function of this vessel. This vessel is the art of yin and yang overcoming one another. Once applied, it necessarily obtains the yang of the "knife and spatula," hence the luminous image. Yet this vessel is discussed in the final chapter, further instructing people to employ this marvelous vessel at the end.

Now, this marvelous vessel is mistakenly identified by people as the Mysterious Female, the furnace and cauldron, the cinnabar field, the Supreme Ultimate, and so on—all incorrect. Even the *Cantong Qi*’s lines—"three and five in a circle, one inch divided, four and eight in the mouth, two-inch lips, twelve inches long, thickness uniform"—refer to the form of this marvelous vessel. Within this "vessel" character lies the secret of "mouth" corresponding to "mouth," aperture to aperture. The "advance" character denotes the application of this marvelous vessel. When the practice reaches the use of the marvelous vessel, nothing is left undone once one attainment is achieved.
