Alas! The sacred scripture lies before you, the wondrous formula resides in your heart, the workings of creation are readily apparent—how can you willingly abandon yourself and fail to urgently attend to this? Strive, strive!

Yide says: This explanation of the "vessel" character does not cohere with the preceding and following text and is not the correct interpretation. Citing the *Cantong Qi* to describe the form of the marvelous vessel is to be mired in the heterodox theories of commentators—even more inadmissible. Only Yang Daoren’s annotation of the "three and five in a circle" and other lines with the *River Chart* and *Luo Writing* is most precise. If one were to annotate the "vessel" character with the *River Chart* and *Luo Writing*, it would nearly approach the Dao.

That which is above form is called the Dao; that which is below form is called the vessel. The vessel is the image of the Dao. Regarding this "vessel" character, it should be viewed as the "Dao" character and understood in terms of the "measure" character. Ordinary vessels have form and substance, yet this vessel has no form or substance; ordinary vessels have size, yet this vessel has no size; ordinary vessels have interior and exterior, yet this vessel has no interior or exterior; ordinary vessels have limits and concealment, yet this vessel has no limits or concealment. Hence it is called the "marvelous vessel." As it encompasses Heaven and Earth and subtly completes the myriad things, it is named "vessel." In truth, it is that by which Heaven and Earth are born and from which the myriad things emerge. Thus it is said: "from which the myriad things are born." In terms of its function, it is called "vessel"; in terms of its essence, it is called "Dao"—the Dao of Nature.

The Dao of Nature is quiescent; calendrics can measure the movement of the posterior heaven but cannot align with the quiescence of the anterior heaven. The eight trigrams and the sexagenary cycle are numbers within movement. That which governs within the eight trigrams and the sexagenary cycle is this quiescent marvelous vessel, possessing the functions of divine mechanism and hidden workings. In the anterior heaven, it leaves no trace that can be named; in the human body, it is called the Mysterious Aperture, yet no trace is visible. This is what both self and others receive from the anterior heaven—the foundation of the myriad things’ lives, the place to which the myriad things return. It is the source from which the myriad transformations arise and the wellspring from which sagely practices proceed. Cultivating the body based on this vessel orders the hundred bones; governing others based on this vessel pacifies the myriad transformations.

The sage knows that Heaven and Earth possess the Dao of Nature, and regulating vessels cannot align with it. Thus there is the marvelous vessel of Nature, from which the myriad things are born. Thereupon, the sage bases this vessel to regulate the configurations of yin and yang, probing the origin of the myriad things’ birth, and only then do the myriad transformations arise within the body. Internally applied to the self, externally applied to the world—all possess the marvelous functions of divine mechanism and hidden workings. The divine is the extension of yang qi, hence called "mechanism"; the ghostly is the return of yin qi, hence called "concealment." When yin and yang overcome one another and attain equilibrium, the myriad things are born. This vessel, though formless, luminously manifests form—this is the ultimate practice of observing the heavenly Dao and grasping the heavenly workings.

Master Fan, with his private cleverness, slanders the great Dao. If he preserves my explanation, perhaps heterodox theories will cease.

**Preface to the *Four Hundred Words on the Golden Elixir* with Commentary**
*Commentary by Min Yide, descendant of the Longmen lineage of the Northern School*

The Great Elixir of Seven Returns and Nine Reversions of Golden Liquor: seven pertains to the number of fire (fire as metaphor for the spirit within the body), nine to the number of metal (metal as metaphor for the qi within the body). Refining metal with fire (the spirit returns, and the qi within the body naturally reverts), returning to the root and restoring the origin (the spirit returns to its original nature, qi restores its primordial mandate; spirit and qi merge as one, nature and life intermingle)—this is called the Golden Elixir. (This passage breaks open the topic with utmost clarity; the following text elaborates step by step, rendering it even more precise.)

Dividing body and mind into the upper and lower arcs, distinguishing spirit and qi as the winter and summer solstices, and harmonizing form and spirit with the *Kan* and *Li* trigrams—these three passages outline the guiding principles of the elixir method.

The wood of the eastern *hun*, the metal of the western *po*, the fire of the southern spirit, the water of the northern essence, and the intent at the center—these gather the Five Agents. (This passage identifies the medicinal ingredients for compounding the elixir.)

Containing the light of the eyes, congealing the resonance of the ears, regulating the breath of the nose, sealing the qi of the tongue—this is the harmonization and union of the Four Images. (This passage instructs one on how to gather the medicinal ingredients through practice.)

When the eyes do not see, the *hun* abides in the liver; when the ears do not hear, the essence abides in the kidneys; when the tongue does not speak, the spirit abides in the heart; when the nose does not smell, the *po* abides in the lungs; when the four limbs do not move, the intent abides in the spleen—this is called the Five Qi Assembling at the Origin.

Refining essence into qi, refining qi into spirit, refining spirit into emptiness—this is called the Three Flowers Gathering at the Crown.

When the *hun* abides in the liver and does not leak through the eyes, the *po* abides in the lungs and does not leak through the nose, the spirit abides in the heart and does not leak through the mouth, the essence abides in the kidneys and does not leak through the ears, and the intent abides in the spleen and does not leak through the pores of the four limbs—this is called "without leakage." (The above four passages all discuss the gathering of medicinal ingredients, ensuring their fullness and preventing leakage.)

Spirit, essence, *hun*, *po*, and intent intermingle and merge, transforming into a single qi, invisible and inaudible, also called "without form"—thus it is called "emptiness and nothingness."

Refining essence means refining primordial essence, not the essence of licentiousness (the essence aroused by licentiousness is leaking essence, not primordial essence). Refining qi means refining primordial qi, not the qi of mouth-and-nose breathing (the qi of mouth-and-nose breathing is leaking qi, not primordial qi). Refining spirit means refining primordial spirit, not the spirit of heart-mind thoughts and deliberations (the spirit of heart-mind thoughts and deliberations is leaking spirit, not primordial spirit). Thus, this spirit, qi, and essence (when thoughts cease for long, the spirit does not leak and returns to the origin; when anger is curbed for long, qi does not leak and returns to the origin; when desires are restrained for long, essence does not leak and returns to the origin—these are primordial essence, primordial qi, and primordial spirit) share the same root as heaven and earth and the same body as the myriad things. To obtain them is life; to lose them is death.

Refining them with the yang fire transforms them into yang qi; nurturing them with the yin tally transforms them into yin essence (when desires are habitually restrained for long, true water naturally ascends; when anger is habitually curbed for long, true fire naturally descends). Thus it is said: "When seen, they cannot be used; when used, they cannot be seen." (These two passages describe the method of refining the medicinal ingredients to merge them.)

The body is the dwelling of the heart-mind; the heart-mind is the master of the body. The heart-mind’s wildness is like a dragon; the body’s ferocity is like a tiger. Within the body, there is a speck of true yang qi (when desires are restrained for long, true water ascends, and the flame of precelestial qi emerges); within the heart-mind, there is a speck of true yin essence (when anger is curbed for long, true fire descends, and the flow of taiji essence emerges)—thus they are called the Two Things. (This passage identifies the wondrous substances that enable the elixir’s formation.)

The heart-mind pertains to *Qian*, the body to *Kun*—thus they are called the cauldron and vessel of *Qian* and *Kun*. Yang qi pertains to *Li*, yin essence to *Kan*—thus they are called the medicine of the Crow and Rabbit.

Embracing the One and guarding the center, refining the primordial and nurturing the plain—thus it is called "gathering the precelestial primordial qi" (when body and heart-mind merge, the spirit naturally congeals in emptiness—this is the method of gathering the elixir’s beginning).

Morning in *Zhun*, evening in *Meng*; noon in *Wu*, midnight in *Zi*—thus it is called "circulating the fire times of the celestial cycle" (when thoughts do not arise, the fire does not flare; when intent does not scatter, the fire does not cool—thus one must employ the method of natural quiescence).

Wood fluid flourishes in *Mao*, metal essence flourishes in *You*—thus one must bathe (calming thoughts to nurture the fire, true qi naturally steams and rises).

The *Zhen* male drinks western wine, the *Dui* female plucks northern flowers; the *Xun* wind stirs the six yang, the *Kun* earth stores the seven numbers (when nature is quiescent, emotions are at ease; when the heart-mind moves, the spirit wearies—reducing daily for learning, increasing daily for the Dao)—thus one must withdraw and add. (The above six passages all demonstrate the method of harmonizing the fire times.)

At the beginning of gathering the medicine, one moves the bellows and key of *Qian* and *Kun* (who moves them? How are they moved? Where does one begin? This cannot be known through knowledge—only by seeking the Valley Spirit can one know). One takes the knife and measure of *Kan* and *Li* (who can take them? How are they taken? Where does one start? This cannot be contended through force—one must rely on the formless net).

At first, it is like clouds filling a thousand mountains; next, it is like the moon containing ten thousand waters. Naturally, it is like the union of tortoise and snake, the pacing of horse and ox.

The dragon contends for the *hun*, the tiger contends for the *po*; the crow battles essence, the rabbit battles spirit. Within the indistinct and vague, true lead appears; within the distant and obscure, true mercury exists. With the Yellow Dame as matchmaker, guard the Central Palace.

When lead encounters fire, it flies; when mercury encounters fire, it flees. Thus, one harmonizes them with the oil of nothingness and stabilizes them with the nameless uncut jade.

Lead returns to the *Kun* Palace, mercury returns to the *Qian* position; true earth merges, containing light in silence.

When fire’s measure waxes excessive, it parches; when water’s weight grows overmuch, it floods. The parching of fire (its fault arises from thought’s arising), the flooding of water (its fault arises from intent’s scattering)—these cannot but be harmonized. Thus there are the measures of weight and balance (this section expounds the subtleties of refining metal with fire, all by way of metaphor, not actual scenes. It is but the recollection of one who has traversed the path, recalling the visions of early practice. In truth, at that time, thought does not arise, intent does not scatter; naturally, spirit congeals and qi gathers. Placing oneself in nothingness—this is harmony. One must not cling to images or adhere to words, weighing and measuring, and so bring ruin upon oneself).

At this stage of refinement, wind stirs in the Mud Pill Palace, the moon shines in the Crimson Palace, fire blazes in the Cinnabar Field, and waves settle in the Valley Sea. The spine moves like a turning wheel, the four limbs stand firm as mountain stone, the pores feel as though just risen from bathing, the bones and channels rest as in deep slumber. Spirit and essence unite like lovers in joy, hun and po linger like mother and child in affection. This is the true realm, not metaphor (this section speaks only of its effects, with no deliberate action).

Refined by measure (the measure is set forth below; the scholar follows the stream to know the source, working within effortless effort), it gathers without scattering. Refined by weight and balance (the weights and balances are recorded in *Awakening to Reality*; the scholar abandons delusion to strengthen the true, working within useful non-use), it solidifies ever more firmly. The hun is stored, the po extinguished; essence congeals, spirit coagulates. With a single intent of harmonious balance, the skin and flesh become radiant and clear. Day by day, hour by hour, it gradually congeals and gathers. From no-substance, substance is born; the sacred embryo is formed (this section reaffirms the essential principle of harmony).

A year has twelve months, a month thirty days, a day one hundred ke, a month totals three thousand ke, ten months total thirty thousand ke. In movement and stillness, ceaselessly and subtly abide (these eight characters are the measure). Once the fetal qi has congealed, the infant manifests form (the formless form), the Mysterious Pearl takes shape (the imageless image), the Great One contains the true (whole and undivided). Within these thirty thousand ke, one may seize the tally of thirty thousand years in heaven. Why? Each ke of effort corresponds to a year’s seasonal cycle (this is the natural measure, not to be sought by private calculation). Thus, thirty thousand ke can seize the tally of thirty thousand years.

A year’s twelve months total thirty-six thousand ke. Even the dullest and most foolish, if they practice this, will immediately ascend to the realm of the sacred (this is true speech: if one attains its nurturance, nothing fails to grow). Yet how is it that the common people, in their daily use (these two characters are key), remain unaware? The primordial essence is lost, the primordial qi exhausted, the primordial spirit departed (if one loses its nurturance, nothing fails to dissipate).

Thus, in each of the thirty thousand ke, ke by ke, harmony must be maintained (it is simply that thought does not arise, intent does not scatter). If even a single ke deviates, the medicinal materials are consumed, the fire-times deficient (if intent scatters, the medicine is immediately lost; if thought arises, the medicine is immediately spent. Those who suffer this fault do so because their usual efforts to restrain anger and curb desire have been insufficient). Hence it is said, “A hair’s breadth of deviation, and the elixir is not made.” One must work ke by ke (simply abiding ceaselessly and subtly in movement and stillness), and this work is not laborious (in activity, focus unifies, and intent does not scatter; in stillness, the mechanism gathers, and thought does not arise—this is what is meant by “ceaselessly and subtly abide, working without strain”). The true qi congeals (intent does not scatter, so qi is able to congeal), the primordial spirit expands (thought does not arise, so spirit is able to expand).

Internally, one refines the elixir of thirty thousand ke in a year; externally, one seizes the tally of thirty thousand years. In greatness, one forms the embryo of thirteen thousand five hundred breaths in a day; in smallness, one circulates the qi of eighty-four thousand li in twelve hours. Thus it is said: Seize the single yang of heaven and earth, gather the dual wheels of the sun and moon. Circulate true water in the lead furnace (through discipline, one attains concentration; spirit and qi become full), move true fire in the mercury tripod (through concentration, wisdom is born; spirit and intelligence become complete).

When lead encounters mercury (the body enters the heart), it is called the Flowery Pond; when mercury enters lead (the heart dwells in the body), it is called the Spirit Water. One must not cling to non-action (from being, one enters non-being), nor act with deliberate effort (from non-being, being is born). One must not fixate on visualization (fixating on visualization remains outside the aperture; only by forgetting what is visualized does one enter the aperture), nor attach to holding and guarding (attaching to holding and guarding is to exit the aperture; through holding, one rests, naturally within the aperture). One must not sit dryly like dead ashes, nor practice blindly without insight (to sit with the body not dwelling in the spirit chamber is to sit dryly like dead ashes; to practice without knowing how to apply the method is blind practice without insight—both are harmful without benefit, and must be utterly avoided).

One must fear not recognizing the source of the medicinal materials (the source of the medicinal materials is indicated from the fifth to the tenth sections above), and fear not knowing the measures of the fire-times (from the eleventh section to this point, the measures are explained in detail. Yet to know where to begin, one must await the explanation below). One must know the single aperture within the body, called the Mysterious Female. This aperture is neither heart nor kidney, neither mouth nor nose, neither spleen nor stomach, neither the valley passage nor the bladder, neither the Cinnabar Field nor the Mud Pill Palace. If one knows this single aperture, then the Winter Solstice is here! The medicinal materials are here! The fire-times are here! The bathing is also here!

The formation of the elixir also lies here! The liberation of the body also lies here! This single aperture has no boundaries, no interior or exterior—it is the root of spirit and qi, the valley of emptiness and nothingness. One must seek it within the body and not seek it elsewhere.

This aperture cannot be conjectured by private speculation (conjecture is merely a thought. The Great Dao teaches one to forget thoughts—how could private speculation be permissible?). Yet since conjecture is forbidden, and seeking elsewhere is also forbidden, it is said that it must be transmitted heart-to-heart and received mouth-to-ear, thereby showing the scholar that it must be realized through inner attainment. Those of superior wisdom, whose celestial nature is inherently settled, may upon reading this immediately enter. Those of middling wisdom, who must progress gradually, may still fear seeking shortcuts without guidance.

Now, in reverence for the compassionate intent of Ancestor Zhang, I shall universally point out for learners the correct path to enter this aperture within the body: it is none other than the method of stopping thoughts. To stop thoughts, one must first restrain anger and suppress desires, cutting away all杂念 to retain only the proper thought. Though the proper thought is retained, one must not allow it to cling to subsidiary thoughts that stealthily grow.

Presently, this thought suddenly ceases, and before the next thought arises—this is precisely the wondrous moment when all concerns vanish. Receiving a single phrase from the teacher, one can then grasp it with the heart. Yet if one can, at the instant when the preceding thought has ceased and the succeeding thought has not yet arisen, suddenly awaken with a single decisive awareness, this is no less than heart-transmission, and one may fully attain it oneself—what need is there for oral instruction?

One must only awaken in that instant and not startle oneself. Not startling oneself leads to stability in abiding; stability in abiding deepens the medicinal materials within the body, and the so-called measures are then drawn from all sides, their source ever-present. The Winter Solstice, medicinal materials, fire-times, and all else mentioned above truly lie here. If one were to conjecture with private speculation, would this not be like heading south while aiming for the north? How could it be permissible?

Should one fail to do so, all becomes delusion.

Herein I compose *Four Hundred Words on the Golden Elixir*, which encompasses the root of creation and transformation, penetrates the marrow of yin and yang, enabling those who refine the Elixir to trace the stream and know its source (to seek meaning through the text), to abandon delusion and follow truth (to awaken to reality through the provisional), and not to mistake the branch for the root (for nature and life are the root, while spirit and qi are the branch. This passage instructs readers not to cling to words or fixate on images; the following text further clarifies the reality of emptiness and the actual).

The Golden Elixir arises from non-being to being, nurturing the infant to completion—how could one cling to words or fixate on images and drown in byways and winding paths? Yet the Golden Elixir’s arising from non-being must not be mistaken for mere vacuity. Know that this emptiness is true emptiness, where non-being is not without being—this is true emptiness and non-being (when all thoughts vanish in the moment, one attains it directly, naturally grasping it with heart and spirit, possessing inconceivable subtlety).

Now, by way of *letting the horse go naturally* (these five characters are another essential oral formula for Elixir refinement), I expound these few words—may you (referring to Hainan Baizi) savor them deeply.

Preface by Zhang Boduan of Ziyang.

Alas!

Why was this preface written? Long ago, Ancestor Zhang Ziyang, having perfected the Great Elixir, sought to perpetuate the Dao in the world, yet feared that revealing its mechanisms might incur heavenly retribution. Thus, he composed *Awakening to Reality*, employing metaphors and analogies to convey its teachings—intending that learners might grasp the real through the provisional, as if receiving mind-to-mind transmission or oral instruction. Unforeseen was the fact that his frequent references to lead and mercury left the form and spirit of the work obscure. Readers, failing to comprehend his intent, clung to the text and strayed into winding byways. Even those of heterodox schools cited his words as proof, and worst of all, his own descendant, Hainan Baizi, misconstrued his meaning, failing thrice in three attempts at refinement. He even sought to condemn the book outright, lamenting that his predecessor had not spoken further.

Moved by the world’s misunderstanding, Ancestor Zhang composed *Four Hundred Words on the Golden Elixir*, using the phrase *"letting the horse go naturally"* to convey its essence to Hainan. Still fearing that the mere mention of lead and mercury would cause readers to avert their gaze, he clarified his intent in this very preface. Only then did Baizi succeed in compounding the medicine of the two eights and gestating the three-hundred-day embryo. Yet he, too, pitied the world’s people—so few awakened to truth, so many mired in images—and in his leisure, transcribed his master’s *Treatise on Dispelling Doubts in Immortal Cultivation*, carving it into wood to transmit it to the world. He dared not conceal Ancestor Zhang’s failure to make his intent universally accessible.

Daoist elixir scriptures like *Awakening to Reality* are indeed sublime! Yet even Baizi, endowed with heaven’s gifts, read it without grasping its crux, misinterpreting it and nearly failing in his practice. Had he not encountered these *Four Hundred Words* and this preface, there would have been no remedy for his errors. Today’s people, possessing virtue and wisdom far inferior to Baizi’s, may read these texts and still find no foothold for practice.

In the autumn of the *xinmao* year, I, Yide, presented to my disciple Yanglinzi a copy of Peng’s annotated commentary on *Four Hundred Words on the Golden Elixir*, which I had collated and published for our school. This year, in the first month, I respectfully retrieved and republished *Awakening to Reality Unveiled*, a work annotated by the Northern Lineage’s True Man Zhu Yunyang, to clarify Ancestor Zhang’s true intent. Now, I have carefully translated and annotated this preface section by section. For the passage on the Mysterious Female, I have appended my own experiential guidance as follows.

May those as foolish and unworthy as I once was follow this regimen to advance in practice. May those as wise as Baizi read the original text and grasp its secrets, then proceed to study *Awakening to Reality Unveiled* as their standard and measure. Would this not be without obstruction? Baizi was of the sudden-enlightenment lineage, while I am a gradual-cultivation disciple—though our paths differ, their destination is one. As Ancestor Zhang said, *"Even the dullest and most ignorant, if they practice this, will immediately ascend to sagehood."* These are true words.

I wish for all learners under heaven and in future generations to progress step by step, ascending together to sagehood, never betraying the compassionate intent of Ancestor Zhang’s preface—to remedy the shortcomings of *Awakening to Reality*. Respectfully annotated and postscripted by Min Yide, descendant of the Northern Lineage, on the second day of the second month in the fifteenth year of Daoguang.

**Commentary on the Four Hundred Characters of the Golden Elixir**
*Annotations by Peng Haogu, Hermit of Xiling Yihao*
*Exegesis by Min Yanglin, Disciple of the Longmen Lineage*

True earth seizes true lead,
True lead restrains true mercury.
Lead and mercury return to true earth—
Body and mind still, unmoving.

**[Annotation]**
At the inception of human life, Heaven’s One generates the Water of Kan (the Kidneys), whose sinking heaviness resembles lead. The Kidneys generate *qi*, and within this *qi* lies the one-point essence of True Unity—this is true lead. Earth’s Two generates the Fire of Li (the Heart), whose soaring volatility resembles mercury. The Heart generates fluid, and within this fluid lies the one-point *qi* of Right Yang—this is true mercury. Within Kan resides Wu Earth; within Li resides Ji Earth. Water is fundamentally yin, yet within yin dwells true yang; fire is fundamentally yang, yet within yang dwells true yin—this is true earth. Yin intermingles with yang, yang intermingles with yin, all depending on true earth. True lead is the *qi* within the body; true mercury is the spirit within the mind; true earth is the intent within body and mind. If one can mobilize this true intent, causing mercury to ever welcome lead and lead to ever restrain mercury, so that lead and mercury return to true earth, then spirit and *qi* merge completely, nature and emotion unite, and body and mind become still and unmoving. Though said to be unmoving, within this thusness there is clarity; within this darkness, there is illumination. The deluded mind is extinguished, yet the illuminating mind remains undimmed; the fleshly body seems dead, yet the Dharma-body endures—this is no descent into dull emptiness or withered desiccation.

**[Exegesis]**
By directing intent to dwell in the body and gather the mind, the Five Phases converge, the Four Symbols harmonize, and from this, the Five *Qi* ascend to the origin, gradually revealing the Three Flowers crowning the summit—how direct and unobstructed! There is no complexity or difficulty, only the primacy of sincere intent.

From emptiness, white snow is born;
From stillness, the yellow sprout emerges.

The jade crucible’s fire glows warm,
The golden tripod sends forth purple mist.

**[Annotation]**
In emptiness and stillness lies the work of gathering the medicine. The white snow and yellow sprout are the signs of the elixir arising within the body. Yet there is a distinction: white snow returns to emptiness, yellow sprout to stillness. White snow arises from the void; yellow sprout must be nurtured by fire, for fire gives birth to earth. When the time of the *Gou* hexagram arrives, Heaven joins with Earth, and from emptiness, white snow naturally forms. When the time of the *Fu* hexagram arrives, Earth joins with Heaven, and from stillness, the yellow sprout naturally emerges. Just as between Heaven and Earth, when yang reaches its extreme and turns to yin, white snow descends from the sky; when yin reaches its extreme and turns to yang, the yellow sprout grows from the earth. The jade crucible is the Yellow Court; the fire is spirit, and by spirit, one guides *qi*, with fire abiding within the jade crucible. "Glows warm" describes the state of tending the fire. The tripod is the *Qian* position, the original palace of spirit. Black transforms into red as purple; fire ascends as mist—mist and fire are not two things. The jade crucible’s fire glows warm as the spirit of the *Qian* palace illumines the *Kun* palace within. When purple mist flies above the tripod, *Kun* receives the fire of *Qian*, manifesting externally in the *Kun* palace as a soaring image.

**[Exegesis]**
When the mind dwells long in the body, the body first yields to the governance of the mind.

The lotus of the Flower Pool blooms,
The golden waves of divine water grow still.
Deep in the night, the moon shines bright,
Heaven and Earth become a single mirror.

**[Annotation]**
Master Ziyang’s preface states: "When lead is seen in mercury, it is called the Flower Pool; when mercury enters lead, it is called divine water." From this, we see that the Flower Pool is the root of life, and divine water is the root of nature. To merge nature and life, first let mercury enter lead, then let lead restrain mercury. The true essence of the *Kan* palace, bearing the upright yang *qi*, ascends—its appearance like the blooming of a lotus. The upright yang *qi* of the *Li* palace follows the true essence downward, settling like the stillness of golden waves. When the hour of *zi* approaches, water clears and metal whitens, and the *qi* of nature and life merge completely. Thus it is said that Heaven and Earth become a single mirror—this lies solely in uniting nature with life and concentrating spirit into the *qi*-cavern. The ancients said, "There is no other method in elixir refinement but to guide divine water into the Flower Pool—all matters are resolved in this," precisely expressing this meaning.

**[Exegesis]**
When mind and body unite as one, purely in accord with Heavenly Principle, the natural movement begins, and the moment to set to work arrives.

Cinnabar refines yang *qi*,
Quicksilver cooks metal essence.
Metal essence and yang *qi*—
Cinnabar and quicksilver.

**[Annotation]**
Cinnabar is the upright yang *qi* within fluid; quicksilver is the true essence within *qi*. To replenish the yin of the *Li* palace, one gathers the true essence from within the fluid. Metal essence and yang *qi*, when refined with yang fire, become like cinnabar; when nurtured with yin tally, they become like quicksilver—yet they are not two things.

**[Exegesis]**
At the moment of setting to work, refine and cook intensely. Still, there is no other method but to govern the body with the mind and nurture the mind with the body, awaiting the transformation.

The sun’s soul is the jade hare’s marrow,
The moon’s spirit is the golden crow’s pith.
Gather them into the tripod,
And they transform into a pool of water.

**[Annotation]**
The sun’s wood-fire is the sun’s soul; the soul stores spirit, and within yang there is yin—this yin is the moon’s spirit. The sun cannot generate its light without the moon, hence it is called the jade hare’s marrow, for marrow arises from essence. The moon’s metal-water is the moon’s spirit; the spirit stores essence, and within yin there is yang—this yang is the sun’s soul. The moon cannot complete its form without the sun, hence it is called the golden crow’s pith, for pith arises from spirit. Just as cinnabar is the essence within the sun, which, when stirred by the moon’s radiance, gives birth to true mercury; and quicksilver is the radiance within the moon, which, when stirred by the sun’s essence, gives birth to true lead. The great cultivator, the superior adept, transforms spirit into *qi* and *qi* into essence; the middling adept preserves essence to retain *qi* and *qi* to retain spirit. When spirit and essence blend and harmonize within the precious tripod, sweet dew descends as a pool of water.

**[Exegesis]**
Through mutual nurturing and fusion, body and mind begin to transform—only then may one observe the mysterious aperture.

Medicine arises in the mysterious aperture,
Fire-timing ignites the yang crucible.
When dragon and tiger meet,
The precious tripod gives birth to the mysterious pearl.

**[Annotation]**
The mysterious aperture is the mysterious female—mysterious as yang, female as yin—together called the mysterious aperture. The lower field of the human body is the crucible, the dwelling of spirit; fire arises here, hence it is called the yang crucible, and above the crucible is the tripod. When stillness reaches its extreme and movement begins, the medicine naturally arises—this is the time for gathering. After obtaining the medicine, if there is no fire-timing to refine it, the medicine scatters, and how could the mysterious pearl be born? One must turn the pivot at the top of the gate and seize the pearl beneath the black dragon’s chin. Medicine is fire, fire is medicine; when medicine and fire unite, dragon and tiger meet, and the embryo suspended in the precious tripod naturally gives birth to the millet-like mysterious pearl. Yet the medicine must first arise in the mysterious aperture before the yang crucible can emit fire. If the moment has not arrived and one forces growth, though the external fire moves, the internal tally does not respond—this only burns one’s own body. Generally, when spirit and *qi* harmonize, the mysterious aperture naturally appears; once the mysterious aperture appears, the fire-timing becomes known; once the fire-timing is known, dragon and tiger naturally merge; once dragon and tiger merge, the mysterious pearl naturally forms. Its subtlety lies in the space between movement and stillness, not erring by even a hair’s breadth.

**[Exegesis]**
When body and mind are pure and undivided, the symbolic transformation becomes clear—yet one must maintain single-minded focus, for vigilance in solitude is of utmost importance. The first five sections emphasize the work of stillness; here, one adds reverence as the guiding principle. Is not the work of maintaining reverence and preserving sincerity found in this? This aperture is no ordinary aperture—it is formed by the union of *Qian* and *Kun*.

The aperture is named the "Cavity of Spirit and Qi," within which lies the essence of *Kan* and *Li*.

**[Annotation]**
This aperture is the same as the aforementioned mysterious aperture. As it belongs neither to being nor non-being, nor is confined to form or dimension, transcending beyond body and mind, emerging between the indistinct and imperceptible, it is thus called no ordinary aperture. The upper part of the human body is *Qian*, and the lower part is *Kun*. The middle line of *Qian* seeks *Kun* to form *Kan*, which resides in the position of *Kun* and is occupied by qi. The middle line of *Kun* seeks *Qian* to form *Li*, which lodges in the position of *Qian* and is occupied by qi. Spirit is the mercury within the heart, and qi is the lead within the body. The heart is the chamber of spirit, and the body is the repository of qi, hence it is named the "Cavity of Spirit and Qi." Within the body lies a single point of true yang qi, which pertains to *Li*; within the heart lies a single point of true yin essence, which pertains to *Kan*—thus it is said that within it lies the essence of *Kan* and *Li*.

**[Exegesis]**
When body and mind are perfectly merged, and through stillness the aperture is perceived, one is no longer a mere physical being of flesh. From this point onward, one must guard body and mind with utmost caution, never straying nor relinquishing. The essential principle lies solely in sincerity of intention and strict mastery over desire. A single point of cinnabar is red; four pounds of lead are black. When lead and mercury conjoin to form a pearl, it gleams with a radiant purple-golden hue.

**[Annotation]**
The single point of true yin essence within the heart is called "wood mercury." Wood corresponds to the number three, yet it contains within it the true yang qi as one, hence "a single point." Wood generates fire, and fire is red, thus "a single point of red." The single point of true yang qi within the body is called "metal lead." Metal corresponds to the number four, hence "four pounds." Lead is black, and metal and water share the same palace, thus "four pounds of black." First, the red enters the black; then, the black is refined into red. When red and black intermingle, they coalesce into a millet-grain pearl within the precious crucible, glowing with a luminous purple hue. Red and black intermingle to produce the color purple, hence "purple-golden hue." However, lead and mercury are not fixed substances, nor are red and black fixed colors; "a single point" and "four pounds" are not fixed quantities. Those who grasp the meaning will understand for themselves.

**[Exegesis]**
This still pertains to the work of merging body and mind, maintaining reverence and preserving sincerity. Through sincere accumulation over time, the great Dao will naturally congeal! Only then will the heart be fully satisfied, and one may employ the principle of natural tranquility. The garden’s scenery is resplendent, as spring deepens amidst wind and rain. Plowing and hoeing require no effort, for the entire earth turns to gold.

**[Annotation]**
The "garden" refers to the true earth within the body, and the "scenery" refers to the manifestations of medicinal substances within. When the time arrives for the return of the first yang, one merely stirs the *Xun* wind to blow upon the *Kun* earth, thereby drawing the spirit-water to moisten the Flowery Pond. By the time the three yangs intermingle in harmony, the effort of gathering is minimal—simply neither forgetting nor forcing, and the golden sprout will naturally burst forth from the earth. It is called "gold" because it signifies the formation of the golden elixir.

**[Exegesis]**
The qi generated from the accumulation of righteousness is vast and unyielding; it must be nurtured directly without harm. True lead is born in *Kan*, yet its function lies in the palace of *Li*. Through black transforming into red, a single cauldron’s cloud-like qi thickens.

**[Annotation]**
The kidneys generate qi, and within qi lies the true one water, which is true lead. The true one water is the correct yang qi of the *Li* palace, which, when seen in its liquid form, coalesces with qi. One gathers the true one water from within qi, not the correct yang qi from within liquid, so that mother and child may meet and gaze fondly upon one another. Only then can metal, hidden in water, ascend. For the spirit to govern qi is the essential secret transmitted through the ages—thus it is said that its function lies in the *Li* palace, its substance in *Kan* but its function in *Li*. Once lead emerges through fire, water transforms from black to red. The medicine is fire itself; when it arises from the path of the Three Passes, ascending to the Ninefold Heaven, it surges forth spontaneously, billows upward, gathers in condensation, and thickens like clouds, rising into the cauldron.

**[Exegesis]**
This continues from the previous section, particularly emphasizing the function of the merged body and mind, which arises entirely from the heart’s governance of the body—this is the power of stillness. True mercury is produced in *Li*, yet its function lies in *Kan*. The maiden passes through the southern garden, holding a jade olive in her hand.

**[Annotation]**
Though mercury is produced in the *Li* palace, without the correct qi of the north to subdue it, it constantly seeks to depart, and one cannot gather or congeal it—thus it is said that its function lies in *Kan*. The maiden is mercury, and the southern garden is *Li*. When the mercury in *Li* encounters the lead in *Kan*, lead and mercury unite, and mercury abandons the *Li* palace to descend together into the *Kan* position—hence "passes through the southern garden." Once it passes through the southern garden, mercury becomes snow! "Jade" symbolizes its white color, and "olive" symbolizes its neither square nor round form.

**[Exegesis]**
This again highlights the function of the merged body and mind, arising entirely from the body’s nurturing of the heart—this is the utmost reverence. *Zhen* and *Dui* are neither east nor west; *Kan* and *Li* are not merely north. The Dipper’s handle revolves through the celestial cycle, and one must comprehend its gathering and convergence.

**[Annotation]**
*Zhen* is east, *Dui* is west, *Li* is south, and *Kan* is north—these are the directional positions of the eight trigrams. The celestial Dao revolves without ceasing, and the Dipper’s handle shifts each month to point in a different direction, ensuring the seasons of yin and yang and cold and heat do not deviate from their appointed times. The human body is a microcosm of heaven and earth. From the Mysterious Valley ascending to the Mud Pill Palace, then descending the Double Towers to return to the Northern Sea, this is called the "celestial cycle." Its revolving mechanism is also governed by the Dipper’s handle. A year has twelve months, a month thirty days, totaling three hundred sixty days; a day has one hundred *ke*, making a year thirty-six thousand *ke*. A single day’s work can seize the qi of thirty-six thousand *ke*. This means that the cultivator of the elixir revolves the celestial cycle’s fire-timing within a single day, exchanging a day for a year and twelve hours for twelve months, gathering years into days and months into hours. One merely follows the Dipper’s handle in its revolutions, and the directions of east, west, south, and north need not be mentioned.

Should the Dipper’s handle err by even a single degree, the seasons would fall into disorder—beware, beware! If the fire-timing is misapplied, winter solstice will not fall at *zi*. As for the method of "bathing," it corresponds to the emptiness of *mao* and *you* hours.

Fire, as an element, burns too fiercely if excessive and cools if insufficient; the key lies in harmonious moderation, hence the term "fire-timing." Each hour comprises six *hou*. The *hou* are the nodal points of our body. What hour is there to speak of? When our body reaches the utmost stillness and stirs, in the moon this is the winter solstice, in the day this is the *zi* hour. Seizing this moment and moving in unison with it—there lies the fire-timing!

Generally, the ascent of one *yang* marks *zi*, the descent of one *yin* marks *wu*; *yang* ascending and *yin* descending mark *mao*, *yin* ascending and *yang* descending mark *you*. Thus, "not carving time to divide *zi* and *wu*" does not necessarily mean taking the winter solstice as *zi*, the summer solstice as *wu*, or the months of the Hare and Rooster as *mao* and *you*. In external alchemy, adding fire is *zi*, withdrawing fire is *wu*, neither increasing nor decreasing fire is "bathing." It is not bound by *zi* and *wu*, nor by *mao* and *you*.

These two passages collectively speak of the unified functioning of body and mind, relying solely on the one true intention to govern them. It is the power of stillness, the utmost of reverence—indeed, the utmost of sincerity without cease.

The Perfected One further expounds these eighty characters not merely to impart the handle of practice to the learner, but also to sweep away all the ocular obstructions of those who cling to texts and images in the alchemical scriptures.

The liver of the crow and the marrow of the hare—
Seized and brought together in one place.
Grain by grain,
From the subtle to the manifest.

Man receives from Heaven and Earth the primordial *qi* of three hundred eighty-four *zhu*, weighing one *jin* in total. Eight *liang* are the essence of the sun, hence called "crow’s liver," which is the liquid of Wood; eight *liang* are the essence of the moon, hence called "hare’s marrow," which is the essence of Metal. Metal and Wood are separated, so *wu* and *ji* Earth serve as the matchmaker. Through the refining of fire, one grain is produced each day, like a millet seed, weighing one *zhu* and eight *li*. From the subtle to the manifest, accumulating *zhu* into *liang*, in thirty days it weighs thirty-eight *zhu* and four *si*; in three hundred days, three hundred eighty-four *zhu*, round and one *cun* in diameter, weighing one *jin*.

This passage clearly states that one need only unite body and mind, with no other method of practice—simply nurturing directly without harm, from the subtle to the manifest. By vigilantly guarding solitude to the point where the heart expands and the body becomes at ease, one’s *qi* will fill the space between Heaven and Earth.

Chaos envelops the Void,
The Void encompasses the Three Realms.
Yet when one seeks its root,
It is but a grain of millet.

Where there is a world, there are the Three Powers; where there are the Three Powers, there is the Void; where there is the Void, there is Chaos. Before the existence of Heaven and Earth, there was only the undifferentiated Chaos. Chaos envelops the Void, the Void encompasses the Three Realms. Yet when one traces the origin of the *qi* received at the inception of our body, it is no more than a grain as small as a millet seed. This is the root of human life, which the cultivator of the elixir must know.

Thus it is said:
If one seeks the secret of longevity,
One must search for the root of Creation.

Chaos is the body, the Void is the mind, and the One is sincerity. The body envelops the mind, the mind encompasses the body—what brings this about is the one true intention. True intention is the pivot of Creation in Heaven and Earth, the master of life and transformation in the human body. Though it acts, it does not hinder knowing; the true adept’s practice attains such grandeur.

Heaven and Earth exchange true liquid,
Sun and Moon contain true essence.
Comprehending the foundation of *kan* and *li*,
The Three Realms return to one body.

When the liquid of the heart descends and the *qi* of the kidneys ascends, the combined liquid and *qi* are called "liquid"—this is Heaven and Earth exchanging true liquid. The *hun* is the essence of the crow, the *po* is the marrow of the hare; together they are called "essence"—this is the Sun and Moon containing true essence.

*Kan* belongs to *yin*, yet within *kan* lies *wu* Earth, which is *yang*—thus *yang* is the foundation of *kan*. *Li* belongs to *yang*, yet within *li* lies *ji* Earth, which is *yin*—thus *yin* is the foundation of *li*. Comprehending that the foundation of *wu* Earth in *kan* begins with *yang*, and the foundation of *ji* Earth in *li* begins with *yin*, then the Heaven and Earth within the body, the Sun and Moon within the body, are all governed by true Earth in their functioning, and the Three Realms return to one body.

*Kan* is the body, *li* is the mind, and the foundation of *kan* and *li* is intention. In the precelestial state, *kan* resides in the West as *po*; in the postcelestial state, it moves to the North, where *po* has already flowed into essence. Now, uniting pre- and postcelestial states, merging essence and *po* into one family—this is the body. In the precelestial state, *li* resides in the East as *hun*; in the postcelestial state, it moves to the South, where *hun* has already manifested as spirit. Now, uniting pre- and postcelestial states, merging spirit and *hun* into one family—this is the mind. Only Earth, residing at the center, harmonizes the Four Symbols and is truly the foundation of pre- and postcelestial *kan* and *li*. It does not change with the pre- and postcelestial states—this is intention. Only the superior adept employs intention to dwell in the body and gather the mind, so that body, mind, and intention merge into one, unwavering and unceasing, nurturing and refining into the true. Attaining such grandeur as to generate beings—is this not having all things complete within oneself, the Three Realms returning to one body? This is the ultimate achievement of the Dao of the elixir, the full realization of the sage’s capacity.

These next four passages reaffirm the practice of congealing essence and binding spirit; they do not represent a further stage. Beware of suspecting the establishment of another crucible and furnace, lest you be led astray by heterodox teachings.

The dragon comes from the Eastern Sea,
The tiger rises from the Western Mountains.
The two beasts battle in one field,
Transforming into the marrow of Heaven and Earth.

The true *yang* *qi* within the heart is the dragon. Wood generates fire, and *zhen* belongs to Wood—thus the dragon comes from the Eastern Sea.

The true *yin* essence within the kidneys is the tiger. Metal generates water, and *dui* belongs to Metal—thus the tiger rises from the Western Mountains. If the dragon’s roar summons clouds to descend and the tiger’s howl stirs winds to ascend, the two beasts meet and battle before the Yellow Chamber. Then the dragon swallows the tiger’s marrow, the tiger devours the dragon’s essence, wind and clouds celebrate their union, blending into one to become the marrow of Heaven and Earth.

[Exegesis] This retroactively describes the initial stage of practice, when body and mind first achieve a state of primordial congealment—there is no actual battle. The term "battle" signifies that in returning from the postnatal to the prenatal, one must engage in a struggle between Heaven and humanity. If Heaven prevails over humanity, the demons of emotion are extinguished; if humanity prevails over Heaven, the obstructions of principle dissolve. Only then do Heaven and humanity merge, and body and mind achieve complete transformation.

According to the preface of *Ziyang’s* original text: "The heart’s wildness is like a dragon, the body’s ferocity like a tiger." This passage speaks of the dragon coming from the Eastern Sea—this is the *hun* of the heart’s domain—and the tiger rising from the Western Mountains—this is the *po* of the body’s domain. In truth, these are the "one point of true *yang* *qi* within the body" and the "one point of true *yin* essence within the heart" mentioned in the preface, referred to as "the two things," which are these two beasts. The preface further states: "The heart belongs to *qian*, the body to *kun*." This passage’s "battle" corresponds to Chen Niwan’s "taming body and mind in open combat." The phrase "transforming into the marrow of Heaven and Earth" corresponds to "Heaven and Earth, sun and moon, soft as silk."

Master Peng, having forgotten the original positions of the prenatal *kan* and *li*, hastily sought images in the postnatal, thus introducing terms like heart, kidneys, *zhen*, and *dui*, which deviate from the original intent. The annotations should follow the preface as corrected here.

Golden flowers bloom with mercury leaves,
Jade stems grow lead branches.
*Kan* and *li* never rest,
How long do *qian* and *kun* endure?

[Annotation] The golden flower is true lead, which borrows mercury to form the embryo; the jade stem is true mercury, which borrows lead to take shape. In the human body, mercury is spirit, and lead is essence. "Golden flowers bloom with mercury leaves" describes the faint, indistinct generation of spirit within water. "Jade stems grow lead branches" describes the profound, obscure generation of essence within fire. Those who grasp the method sit until golden flowers manifest and jade stems sprout, at which point the branches and leaves of lead and mercury flourish. At this time, one should properly gather the medicine and advance the fire, causing *kan* and *li* to circulate between east and west, *qian* and *kun* to revolve above and below, in an endless cycle of ascent and descent. There must be no momentary pause.

Before obtaining the medicine, one must recognize the blooming of mercury leaves and the growth of lead branches. After obtaining the medicine, one must understand the subtleties of circulation and the proper timing of ascent and descent to achieve completion from beginning to end, thereby perfecting the sacred embryo. If *qian* and *kun*, *kan* and *li* do not circulate throughout the ten months, the crucible and medicine may be momentarily gained but soon lost. How can the golden flowers be preserved from withering? How can the jade stems be kept from wilting?

[Exegesis] This passage emphasizes that the entire process hinges on the true intention’s presiding presence, ensuring the constant fusion of body and mind without the slightest interruption. Only by embodying the great strength of *qian*’s Dao in the heart and the great compliance of *kun*’s Dao in the body can natural, ceaseless circulation be achieved, ultimately restoring *kan* and *li* to *qian* and *kun*. There is no need to elaborate on *zhen*, *dui*, *gen*, or *xun*, lest they obstruct the mind’s eye. The next passage clarifies the method of extraction and replenishment.

Bathing guards against danger,
Withdrawal and addition require careful maintenance.
In all thirty thousand moments,
A deviation of a hair’s breadth may cause loss.

[Annotation] A year has twelve months, totaling thirty-six thousand moments, condensed into a single day. Within these twelve months, fire is applied for ten months: when *yang* arises, the medicine is gathered from the Zi Palace and made to ascend in reverse, called "withdrawing lead"; when *yin* arises, the fire is withdrawn at the Wu position and made to descend in sequence, called "adding mercury." The remaining two months—Mao and You—strengthen water to stabilize metal and apply fire to restrain water. Only the water phase is practiced, not the fire phase, termed "bathing." In the Mao month, life contains destruction; in the You month, destruction contains life. This guards against the danger of excessive dryness from fire.

Excluding the two months and six thousand moments, only ten months and thirty thousand moments remain, hence "in all thirty thousand moments." If there is even a hair’s breadth of deviation in these thirty thousand moments of effort, *yin* and *yang* will be misaligned. Only by guarding against danger and maintaining careful discipline, focusing the mind entirely on the cycle, manifesting with activity and concealing with stillness, can the infant be nurtured over a full year to become a transcendent immortal.

[Exegesis] Only through reverence and sincerity can one’s being remain undivided. If one applies this method, a full month suffices. Thus, it is said, "in all thirty thousand moments." The fear of deviation lies solely in the need for absolute unity without distraction, ensuring no pause in the thirty thousand moments—not in any other potential error. As the *Yijing* states: "If one does not constantly maintain virtue, disgrace may follow." This is the fear.

When husband and wife unite,
In the bridal chamber, clouds and rain arise.
After one year, a child is born,
Each one able to ride a crane.

[Annotation] Husband and wife are the true *yin* and true *yang* within the body. With true earth as the matchmaker, true *yin* and true *yang* unite as husband and wife. In the bridal chamber, they join, clouds rise, and rain falls. Within a year—ten months of gestation and two months of bathing—the embryo is complete, and the *qi* is full. A baby is born, riding a crane out of the Niwan Palace. Nine years produce nine children, hence "each one." Though there are a thousand, ten thousand, or countless transformations, they are all one body—there are not truly nine. The infant is a child; the union of Hai and Zi forms the character *hai* (孩), which is the key to initiating the embryo’s formation.

[Exposition]
The husband is *qian* (Heaven), and the wife is *kun* (Earth); the bridal chamber is no ordinary aperture. This elucidates the great purport of the seventh section, summarizing how body and mind attain intent—seizing, restraining, and blending them into unity—to stand as a peer to Heaven and Earth. All is the work of utmost sincerity. It may be likened to husband and wife, who, through a matchmaker, marry and unite to bear a child. Yet here, the child is born from no ordinary aperture, producing no ordinary infant, for all depends on *reversal*. Such is the way of immortals, unlike the worldly path where husband and wife follow the natural course to conceive a child.

Let us further illustrate: true earth is intent, like the matchmaker; true lead is the body, like the husband; true mercury is the heart, like the wife. When the matchmaker unites husband and wife to form a household, it is like raising intent to blend body and mind, coalescing into the supreme Dao. Is this so or not? I dare present this for the Master’s judgment.

*Preface to the Essential Teachings of the Golden Flower*
The Dao lies before us; the body naturally attains it—why seek it beyond oneself? The human body is a fusion of the Three Powers (Heaven, Earth, and Humanity), endowed by Creation with vast potential. Yet people possess it daily without awareness. The sages, moved by compassion, revealed it within the body. The Dao resides in the body, its mechanism in the eyes—hence the teachings of *The Essential Teachings of the Golden Flower*. Why do scholars’ practices fail to align with its principles? Because they do not distinguish between substance and function.

Thus, the title was expanded with the words "Great One," yet practice still did not accord with the method. The error lay in exerting effort on function while failing to glimpse substance through it. Though one exhausts the bamboo of Mount Nan, the nature of substance remains obscured. Only after adding the four characters "Primordial Vacuity" did substance become fully manifest.

The Daoist Patriarch, the August Emperor of Trustworthy Protection, moved by the aspiration to universally deliver all beings, harbored the great vow to heal the world. Comprehending the profound meaning of the ten characters—*Primordial Vacuity, Great One, Essential Teachings of the Golden Flower*—he composed a work in thirteen chapters as a foundation for later scholars to heal the world. Through this, the text was completed, and the teachings were transmitted. Such was the profound intent of the Heavenly Worthy.

The late Master Tai Xu said: I heard from the earth-dwelling immortal, Master Li of Niwan, that when the August Emperor of Trustworthy Protection first attained the Dao-fruit, his four great elements had already dissolved. Before he could heal the world, he composed three poems titled *The Essential Teachings of the Supreme Doctrine*. During the Song and Yuan dynasties, these were already printed and circulated. The second chapter of this work is the *Xiaoyao Jue* (Carefree Formula) contained herein.

This book emerged in the *wuchen* year of the Kangxi era (1688) and was expounded at the Dragon Ridge Mountain Lodge of Golden Canopy Mountain. It was truly the work of eminent masters such as Tao Jing’an, Huang Yinzhen, Sheng Qingya, Zhu Jiuxuan, Min Xuesuo, Tao Shi’an, and Xie Ningsu—all talents for healing the world. Thus, they were entrusted with this great Dao, not merely to preach for those seeking self-cultivation alone.

The divine person Yin Pengtou also produced a work at Liaoyang Hall titled *The Eastern Florescence Orthodox Pulse: The Supreme Ultimate’s Opening and Closing Verification of the Daoist Immortal Canon*, which complements this book. Cultivating one’s nature and life is the foundation for healing the world; engaging in healing the world is the profound work of nature and life. As shown in the *Returning Light’s Verification Chapter* of this book, one must not undertake this with a shallow root or limited capacity—one must aspire to deliver all beings. In the *Circulation of the Heavens Chapter*, the revolutions of the body cause all things in Heaven and Earth to revolve with it. Within a square inch, the smallest becomes the greatest. This is the Dao of uniting inner and outer, where body and world are one—its essential teaching is already luminously clear. All is but to emulate the Most High’s compassion for life, hoping to fulfill this lifetime without betraying its years, months, and days, thereby perfecting the great Dao and delivering all beings.

Those who achieve minor accomplishments—today the dragon and tiger, tomorrow *kan* and *li*—remain self-satisfied, narrowly focused. Even if they attain fruition and ascend as citizens of the realm without rank, benefiting only their own family and seven generations, what value would the Emperor on High see in them?

The late Master’s compilation and transmission of this work reflect the compassionate intent of the Daoist Patriarch, the August Emperor of Trustworthy Protection. The perfected ones—Tao, Huang, Sheng, and Zhu—received this book and passed it to later scholars, their great vow being the same. However, as this book was transmitted, its authenticity was lost. Even the printed edition in the *Daoist Canon Compendium* attests to this. Therefore, I have now undertaken its correction.

May the aspirants of the great thousand worlds obtain this book along with the *Opening and Closing Canon*, practicing them in unity. Then, humanity can magnify the Dao, and the great thousand worlds will be most fortunate. This is the preface.

Respectfully inscribed in the fourth month of the *xinmao* year of the Daoguang era (1831), by Min Yide of Golden Canopy Mountain, the eleventh-generation disciple of the Dragon Gate lineage, with reverent hands.

*Essential Teachings of the Golden Flower of Primordial Vacuity and the Great One*
Compiled by Minister Jiang Yuanting
Corrected by Min Yide of Golden Canopy Mountain

[This book originated in the *wuchen* year of the Kangxi era (1688) from the Dragon Ridge Mountain Lodge of Golden Canopy Mountain in Wuxing. The late master Tao Shi’an had it printed. During the Jiaqing era, Minister Jiang Yuanting mistakenly obtained a corrupted version and included it in the *Daoist Canon Compendium*. Later, he acquired the original version from the mountain in Zhejiang, intending to reprint it. However, the printing blocks were in the capital, and by the time he retrieved them, the minister had already departed for the north, where he passed away in the capital. The matter was thus left unfinished. Though this was an unresolved affair, my heart could not forget it. Recently, while traveling in Moling, I encountered a transcribed copy in circulation. Though it did not entirely match Tao’s version, it contained one or two additional sections compared to Jiang’s edition, seemingly derived from Tao’s original. Each version had its own additions and omissions, with differing interpretations. Here, I have uniformly corrected it according to Tao’s version.]

**Chapter One: The Heart of Heaven**
The Patriarch said: The Heart of Heaven is the heart shared by the Three Powers, known in the alchemical texts as the Mysterious Aperture.

All possess it—sages awaken to it, while the foolish and deluded seal it shut. Awakened, one attains long life; sealed, one meets an early end. To attribute this to fate is the view of the common man. No one does not wish to seek life, yet none does not pursue death—how could this stem from any other intention? The six roots draw one outward, the six dusts disturb one within; in the fleeting span of youth, one turns in an instant to decay and ruin. The perfected ones, moved by compassion, bestow the supreme Dao. Though their teachings are earnest, listeners remain distant and indifferent—why is this? It is because they fail to grasp the substance and function of the Great Dao, instead mutually harming one another. Seeking life in this way is like heading south while driving north. How could they know that the Great Dao takes emptiness and nothingness as its substance, and concealment and manifestation as its function? Thus, one must neither cling to being nor to non-being, that the qi-mechanism may flow unimpeded.

In our practice, we must take the Great One as the root and Golden Flower as the branch, so that root and branch support one another, and long life without death is attained. This Dao has been transmitted heart-to-heart by immortals and perfected ones since ancient times, passed on so that each receives what is given. From the Supreme Venerable’s manifestation, it was transmitted to Donghua, and thence to the Northern and Southern Schools. The Dao itself is not hidden, yet its heart-to-heart transmission is most secret—not because it is deliberately concealed, but because without heart imparting to heart, it cannot be received. Though oral transmission is wondrous, comprehension remains uneven—how much more so with written instruction! Thus, the supreme Dao of the Supreme Venerable values heart-to-heart transmission, where enlightenment dawns suddenly in the midst of obscurity. The master cannot force transmission upon the disciple, nor can the disciple force reception from the master. Only when true faith is pure and unadulterated, when the moment arrives and spirit merges, does clarity suddenly emerge—whether through a shared glance and smile, or tears of realization. Entering the Dao and awakening to it share this commonality. Some enter first and then awaken, while others awaken first and then enter; yet none do so without wholehearted devotion and unwavering faith. Without unity, the mind scatters; without faith, it floats. Scattered, the light does not gather; floating, the light does not congeal. If one cannot see one’s own heart, how can one merge with the heart transmitted by the Supreme Venerable?

Thus, Confucians esteem introspection, Daoists esteem inner observation, and the *Sutra in Forty-Two Chapters* also states: "Set the mind upon one point, and what cannot be accomplished?" For the supreme Dao of the Supreme Venerable is nothing other than the full realization of the one heart. What is this full realization? It is emptiness, stillness, and freedom from杂念. Such is the wondrous essence of the teaching; its wondrous function lies solely in setting the mind upon one point. Inner observation is precisely the method of setting the mind upon one point—it is the secret of heart-to-heart transmission. It can be understood in the heart, and it can be orally transmitted; not only can it be orally transmitted, but it can also be conveyed in writing. Yet when practice reaches its stages, when the heart is empty and all leaks are exhausted, only then does one suddenly penetrate the wondrous principle of the mysterious. This cannot be conveyed by writing, nor even by speech. Truly empty, truly still, truly pure, truly nothing—one radiant pearl, heart-to-heart transmission, most secret indeed. Yet after awakening and entry, it becomes utterly manifest. There is no other reason: the Heart of Heaven has been fully opened.

Those who seek the Dao today are like travelers crossing a vast expanse of water without shore or boundary. Once they reach the other side, the raft should be discarded, as in the parable. But for those who do not know the way, how can the raft not be shown? As I have presumptuously taken on the role of guiding master, I must first make the raft clear. Now, the aperture of the Heart of Heaven is neither within nor outside the body; it cannot be opened through groping but only awaited through silent preservation. To recognize this preservation, one must understand that form is precisely emptiness, and emptiness precisely form—the alchemical texts speak of "it is so, yet not so; not so, yet still so." Only then is it thusness, and once opened, it remains open forever. The method lies in the two words: "preserve sincerity."

Disciples, in the wondrous application of preserving sincerity, there is a swift and secret technique: when all entanglements are released, employ the *Brahman* ∴ character (that is, the *Yi* character. In Brahmanic script, *Yi* is written as ∴, referring to the sun, moon, and celestial stem, which in the human body correspond to the left eye, right eye, and brow center. Primordial divine beings all possess a third eye, as do Doumu and Leizu. When one cultivates refinement, the brow center opens, and the eye that opens is called the Heavenly Eye). Focus the dot within the character at the brow center, the left dot at the left eye, and the right dot at the right eye. Thus, the spiritual light of the two eyes naturally converges at the brow center. The brow center is the Heavenly Eye, the gateway where the three lights gather, enter, and exit (the place where sun and moon unite, as the alchemical texts say). When one uses the three eyes as in the *Yi* character of Brahman, gently directing the intent as if polishing a mirror, the three lights instantly gather at the brow center, radiant as the sun appearing before one. Then, guide them to the space between the back of the heart and the front of the Pass (the Pass refers to the Double Pass). This is the place—the very gate of the Mysterious Female. Guide the light with intent, and it will immediately arrive; yet do not forget the two-word mystery of "as if." The Heart of Heaven will surely open of itself. Further wondrous applications will be explained in detail later. What must be cautioned against is being led astray by *yuan* (for *yuan* refers to transformations of the qi-mechanism, none of which are true and mysterious states; if led by them, one falls into demonic realms).

Disciples, follow this path—there is no other way to advance, only to focus purely upon it. The *Śūraṅgama Sūtra* states: "Pure thought ascends, and one is born in heaven." Heaven is not the azure vault above but refers to being born in the Qian Palace within the body. With time, one naturally attains a heaven beyond the body. For the body is the realm, and the One is the sovereign; light is the sovereign’s heart and intent. Just as when the sovereign issues an edict, all within the realm respond—so too, when one turns the light inward, the qi of the entire body ascends to pay homage, like the myriad states presenting jade and silk to the sagely king who establishes the capital and sets the axis.

Just as when ruler and ministers unite in purpose, all officials and subjects naturally heed the command, each attending to their duties—so too, disciples, must you focus solely upon turning the light inward: this is the supreme and wondrous truth. With long and steadfast turning, this light congeals and naturally forms the Dharma-body. Expand and fill it, and what our tradition calls the *Yin’e*, or what the Western teachings term the *Dharma-king’s city*, is realized. When the sovereign gains such aid, essence and qi grow daily, and spirit flourishes ever more; one day, body and mind dissolve and merge—how could it be merely heaven beyond heaven, body beyond body?

Thus, the Golden Flower is the Golden Elixir; the transformations of spirit and illumination are each guided by the heart. Though the subtleties of this method admit not the slightest error, they are utterly dynamic—requiring both keen discernment and profound stillness. Without extraordinary discernment, one cannot practice it; without extraordinary stillness, one cannot preserve it.

*(This passage is a thunderous awakening for the world—no student of the Way can do without this rousing call. Yet the version transmitted by Jiang omitted this section, for he had not embodied and practiced it himself. There is no other reason but that his faith was not truly steadfast.)*

**Chapter Two: Original Spirit and Discerning Spirit**

The Patriarch said: Heaven and earth regard man as but an ephemeral mayfly; the Great Dao regards heaven and earth as mere bubbles and shadows. Only the original spirit and true nature transcend the eons and rise above them. Their essence and qi, however, perish and decay along with heaven and earth. Yet with the original spirit present, there is the Limitless. From it, heaven is born, and earth is born. If the practitioner can but safeguard the original spirit, they transcend life beyond yin and yang, beyond the Three Realms—this is possible only through seeing one’s nature, what is called the original face.

*(This phrase “only through seeing one’s nature” is a thunderous awakening—it must not be omitted. Yet the transcribed version deleted it; here it is restored. The Patriarch’s intent is this: among those who walk the Great Dao, some practice yet cannot enter, some attain yet cannot preserve—all because they have not seen the true nature of their original substance, leaving room for doubt. Great obstacles follow, and thus they neither enter nor preserve. To claim preservation without true seeing is merely to preserve what one has heard. If one truly sees, there is nothing that cannot be preserved. Thus, the sagely intent of the Patriarch lies heavily on the side of seeing one’s nature. This chapter’s four-character admonition is a thunderous awakening, continuing from the previous chapter.)*

When a person enters the womb, the original spirit resides in the square inch of the heart, while the discerning spirit dwells in the lower heart. The lower heart of flesh and blood is shaped like a large peach, covered by the lungs and assisted by the liver, with the large and small intestines supporting it. If one goes a single day without eating, the heart grows greatly uneasy—startled by sudden noises, it leaps; angered, it feels stifled; witnessing death, it grieves; beholding beauty, it is dazzled. Yet has the slightest movement ever stirred above, in the square inch?

*(Is the square inch incapable of movement?)*
The true intention within the square inch—how could it move? When it moves, it is not wondrous; yet it is most wondrous. For ordinary people, it moves only at death—this is not wondrous. The most wondrous is when the light has congealed into the Dharma-body and gradually becomes spiritually responsive, desiring to move. This is the secret untransmitted for ages.

*(Careful note: This secret untransmitted for ages is not merely the congealing of light into the Dharma-body. For instance, that the original spirit resides in the square inch while the discerning spirit dwells in the lower heart—ancient sages never pointed these out together. Later learners thus mistakenly took the discerning heart as the heart, applying effort to it, falling into contrivance, and thereby stoking the fire. For this fleshy heart is the abode of the discerning spirit, belonging to yin fire, and should only be made empty, still, and reduced to nothing. The original spirit, being true nature, originates from Qian, and also pertains to fire—celestial fire. Thus, the Patriarch explicitly marked both together.)*

The lower discerning heart is like a powerful warlord or fierce general, bullying the solitary Celestial Monarch and seizing control of governance from afar. Over time, the great blade is inverted. Now, if one directs the light to illuminate the original palace, it is as if a wise sovereign has the aid of Yi and Zhou. Daily turning the light inward is like loyal ministers assisting in governance. With internal affairs thus ordered, all traitorous villains naturally lay down their weapons and beg for mercy.

In the Dao of the Elixir, essence-water, spirit-fire, and intention-earth are the supreme treasures. What is essence-water? It is the primordial True One’s qi. Spirit-fire is light itself, and intention-earth is the Celestial Heart of the Central Palace. Spirit-fire is employed, intention-earth is the substance, and essence-water is the foundation.

Ordinary people generate their bodies through intention, yet the body is not merely the seven-foot frame. Within the body resides the po-soul, which operates through the discerning spirit, while the discerning spirit arises from the po-soul. The po is yin, the substance of the discerning spirit. If the discerning spirit is not severed, then life after life, the po’s transformations and changes of dwelling never cease. Only the hun-soul is where the spirit is stored. By day, the hun lodges in the eyes; by night, it rests in the liver. Lodged in the eyes, it sees; resting in the liver, it dreams. Dreaming is the spirit’s wandering—through the nine heavens and nine earths, traversed in an instant. Upon waking, it is obscurely confined by form, and thus confined by the po.

Therefore, turning the light inward is the means to refine the hun, preserve the spirit, restrain the po, and sever the discerning spirit. The ancient method of transcending the world—refining away yin dregs to return to pure Qian—is nothing other than dissolving the po and completing the hun. Turning the light inward is the secret to dissolving yin and restraining the po. Without the work of returning to Qian, there is only the secret of turning the light. Light is Qian; turning it is returning it. Simply abiding by this method, essence naturally becomes full, spirit-fire arises, intention-earth solidifies, and the sacred embryo may be formed.

The dung beetle rolls its ball, and within the ball, white life is born—this is the wondrous work of spirit’s concentration. If even a dung ball can generate an embryo and hatch a new form, then in the resting place of our Celestial Heart, where spirit is directed, how could a body not be born?

*(Examining this method, its entry point lies in turning the light to gather in the Celestial Pond—from the outer palace of the Muddy Pellet, suspended at the Celestial Eye like the sun. With intention, one guides it from the Crimson Palace, storing the illumination in the Central Yellow, penetrating the Mysterious Orifice to reach the Spirit Chamber. Then, the Celestial Monarch descends the discerning spirit to the lower field. At this time, there must be fluids to protect the discerning spirit and the spirit as they undergo refinement. This is the work following the gathering of light in the Muddy Pellet. The greatest taboos are restlessness, distraction, and dullness. The method requires emptying all thoughts, leaving not a single disturbance. When the Celestial Heart opens, the light will naturally and gently enter. At that moment, not only do the hundred apertures of the body each radiate light, but the great earth, heaven’s origin, the Three Powers, and the Three Treasures may all be serenely and intuitively felt. Thus, at this time, I do not actively gather them—their wondrousness is boundless. The Patriarch did not explicitly teach this, fearing that learners’ foundations might not yet be firm, their worldly resources not yet sufficient. Moreover, there is a subtle meaning concealed beyond his words, which cannot go unmentioned.)*

The Spirit Chamber adjoins the Crimson Palace, and in that realm of the Crimson Palace, the sole endeavor is non-action and non-striving. In such stillness of substance and illumination, the Crimson Palace becomes cool, and the consciousness-spirit, now restrained, naturally follows the spirit downward into the Lower Field, there to undergo refinement and tempering without resistance.
