Its subtlety lies in a single thought of emptiness and stillness, whereupon the Six Thieves and Six Roots find no foothold. Such was the profound intent of the Patriarch—this is the application of effort within effortless practice, akin to the Confucian principle of "letting things follow their course without making them known."

These wondrous words were received by Master Qiaoyun from the immortal Zhang Pengtou, who dwelt among mortals. The immortal, originally surnamed Qu, was the son of Qu Shisi, the loyal martyr and Duke of Loyalty and Propriety of the former Ming. Even the Heavenly Immortal Guan revered him as a teacher. In the forty-third year of the Qianlong reign, he wandered to Jin Gai, at which time Master Qiaoyun had not yet taken refuge under Master Taixu. Four years later, when Master Taixu arrived, he instructed that this discourse be annotated beneath this chapter, and thus it is recounted here.

Once the single numinous true nature descends into the Qian Palace, it divides into hun and po. The hun resides in the Celestial Heart—yang, the light and pure qi—derived from the Great Void and sharing the same form as the Primordial Beginning. The po is yin, the heavy and turbid qi, attached to the mundane body of form. The hun seeks life, while the po longs for death. All desires for beauty and stirring of qi are the doings of the po, which is the consciousness-spirit. After death, it enjoys blood offerings; in life, it suffers greatly, for yin returns to yin—like attracts like. When the adept refines away the yin po, they become purely yang.

**Chapter Three: Returning the Light to Guard the Center**
The Patriarch said: From whence did the term "returning the light" arise? It originated with Master Wenshi (that is, Guan Yinzi). When the light is returned, the qi of heaven and earth, yin and yang, all congeal—this is what is meant by "refined contemplation," "pure qi," and "pure thought." At first, practicing this method feels like having something yet nothing; with time and accomplishment, a body arises outside the body—nothing gives birth to something. After a hundred days of dedicated practice, the light becomes true, and only then is it the divine fire. After a hundred days, the light naturally gathers, and a single point of true yang suddenly generates the Millet Pearl. Like a husband and wife conceiving a child, one must then remain still and await it—the return of the light is the fire-tending.

*(The benefits and wonders of returning the light are detailed in the main text, and the method for gathering the returned light is also complete. Yet there remains a profound and wondrous technique of "taking by first giving," which may be extended and applied. The technique lies in emitting light to draw it forth. The marvelous use of emitting light lies in knowing how to expand the qi mechanism. To expand the qi mechanism, one must know how to let qi penetrate the Nine Heavens. To ascend, one must first know how to descend. The work of descending begins with gathering the light of the eyes in the Qian Palace. When the light is sufficient, it descends to the Central and Lower Fields, then pierces through the Gate of Life, rising to the crown. The higher it penetrates, the vaster it appears. When the awareness becomes vast, one still returns to the practice of returning the light—this is an untransmitted secret.)*

Within the primordial transformation, yang light serves as the sovereign. In form, it is the sun; in humans, it is the eyes. Nothing leaks the spirit-awareness more readily than this. Thus, the Dao of Golden Flower employs the method of reversal. Returning the light is not merely returning the essence of one’s body but directly returning the true qi of creation. It is not merely dispelling momentary delusions but directly emptying the wheel of rebirth across kalpas. Therefore, one breath corresponds to a year in the human realm, and one breath corresponds to a hundred years in the long night of the Nine Paths.

Since the first cry at birth (pronounced *huo*), ordinary people follow circumstances and live in accord with them, never once looking back in reversal until old age. When the yang qi declines and perishes, it is the realm of the Nine Darks. Thus, the *Śūraṅgama Sūtra* states: "Pure thought ascends; pure emotion descends." Learners, with little thought and much emotion, sink into the lower paths. Only through earnest observation of breath and stillness does one attain true awakening—this is the use of the reversal method. The *Yinfu Jing* says: "The mechanism lies in the eyes." The *Huangdi Suwen* states: "The essence of the human body all ascends and gathers in the empty orifices." With this single insight, longevity lies here, and transcendence also lies here. This practice permeates the work of the Three Teachings.

The light is neither within the body nor outside it. Mountains, rivers, sun, moon, and the great earth—none are apart from this light, so it is not confined within the body. Intelligence, wisdom, and all movements are also none other than this light, so it is also outside the body. The radiance of heaven and earth fills the great thousandfold world; the radiance of a single body likewise pervades heaven and earth. Thus, when one returns the light, all—heaven, earth, mountains, and rivers—returns with it.

The essence of a person ascends and gathers in the eyes—this is the great pivot of the human body. Consider this, disciples: if one does not sit in stillness for a single day, where will this flowing light come to rest? But if one can sit in stillness for a single moment, the myriad kalpas of empty existence are thereby penetrated. All methods return to stillness—truly inconceivable. This is the wondrous truth.

Yet in practice, one proceeds from shallow to deep, from coarse to fine, with unbroken continuity as the key. The work remains the same from beginning to end, though the warmth and coolness within are known only to oneself. The goal is to reach the vastness of heaven, the boundlessness of the sea, where the myriad methods are as they are—only then has one grasped it.

The transmission from sage to sage never departs from reflection. Confucius spoke of "extending knowledge," the Buddha of "observing the mind," and Laozi of "inner observation"—all refer to this method. Yet though everyone can speak of "returning the light," few grasp it, for they do not understand the meaning of these two words. "Return" means turning the mind of self-awareness back to the unmanifested origin of form and spirit—seeking within one’s six-foot frame the body that existed before heaven and earth were born. Today, people merely sit idly for an hour or two, reflecting on their selfish concerns, and call it "returning the light." How could they ever reach the end?

The dual patriarchs of Buddhism and Daoism taught disciples to gaze at the tip of the nose—not to fix attention upon the nasal point, nor to direct the eyes to the nose while the mind focuses on the central yellow. Where the eyes go, the mind follows; how could one ascend and descend at once, or shift between high and low in an instant? These are but mistaking the finger for the moon. What then is the true method? The phrase "tip of the nose" is most subtle: it merely borrows the nose as a reference point for the eyes. The aim is not the nose itself. If the eyes are opened too wide, they see only what is distant and miss the nose; if they are closed too tightly, they see nothing at all. Excessive openness leads to outward scattering and distraction; excessive closure leads to inward dissipation and dullness. Only when the eyelids are lowered to the proper degree—just enough to glimpse the tip of the nose—does one find the correct alignment. This is the point where the light naturally enters without effort, whether one directs it or not.

[The *Heavenly Heart Chapter* speaks of "guiding intention to the space before the posterior gate of the heart," which describes the full practice of "returning the light" for those already advanced in cultivation. Here, the instruction to avoid "focusing the mind on the central yellow" is meant for beginners, teaching them to gather the light in one place rather than dividing attention between two. Once the light has penetrated, the tip of the nose becomes the finger pointing to the moon of the central yellow. Gazing at the tip of the nose serves as a guide for the eyes, preventing them from straying outward or collapsing inward. Lowering the eyelids to the proper degree is the key. Yet the intention does not rest on the nose but on the Celestial Eye. The light is gathered here first, and once concentrated, it must then be directed downward into the central yellow. The central yellow resides at the exact center of the human body, between heaven and earth—what the *Book of Changes* calls the "yellow center," what Buddhism terms the "conditioned center," and what our tradition names the "Gate of the Mysterious Female." This is the mysterious aperture from which heaven, earth, humanity, and all things are born, the foundation of cultivating truth and attaining the Dao. For beginners, how could they directly focus here? Thus, they must first use the tip of the nose as a reference to gather the light at the Celestial Eye. The Celestial Eye is the convergence point of the three lights, while the root of the nose is the "gate of nature," connecting upward to the Mud Pill Palace, downward to the space behind the navel, and centrally to the central yellow. The light must be concentrated here before being directed downward—this is an unchanging method of practice. However, one must avoid excessive effort and premature advancement. Naturally, the light will gather in the central yellow as the ultimate achievement.]

When gazing at the tip of the nose, do so only at the very beginning of stillness: raise the eyes once to establish the reference point, then let it go. Like a mason using a plumb line, he hangs it once at the start and then works accordingly, without constantly staring at the line. *Śamatha-vipaśyanā* is the Buddha’s teaching and is not secret. With the eyes carefully observing the tip of the nose, sit upright and settle the mind on the conditioned center. The Daoist term is "central yellow," the Buddhist term is "conditioned center"—they are one and the same. There is no need to speak of "within the head"; simply focus the attention on the level space between the two eyes, and the light will naturally penetrate without needing to fix a single thought on the central yellow. These few words encompass the essential teaching; the rest—entering stillness, exiting stillness, and what follows—can be verified in the *Śamatha-vipaśyanā* texts.

The term "conditioned center" is most profound. The center is omnipresent, pervading the great thousand worlds; it merely points to the mechanism of creation as an entryway. Using this as a starting point does not imply fixation—this single word is alive, subtle, and wondrous. *Śamatha* and *vipaśyanā* are originally inseparable, equivalent to concentration and wisdom. Whenever a thought arises, do not remain in dull sitting; instead, investigate where this thought arises, from where it originates, and where it ceases. Examine it repeatedly until it cannot be grasped. This is seeing the arising of the thought—do not then seek its source, for as the saying goes, "Seeking the mind, it cannot be found; I have pacified your mind for you." This is correct observation; the opposite is called deviant observation. If the thought cannot be found, simply continue with unbroken continuity: cease and then follow with observation, observe and then follow with cessation. This is the dual cultivation of concentration and wisdom, the method of "returning the light." "Return" is cessation, "light" is observation. Cessation without observation is returning without light; observation without cessation is light without returning. Take heed.

[The original *Śamatha-vipaśyanā* text includes this method of investigation, for those who have not yet seen the mind’s essence and do not truly believe in its original emptiness, original purity, and original stillness. Thus, there is this step-by-step investigation, culminating in the realization that it cannot be found—this is "I have pacified your mind for you." This phrase is a method of pointing directly within the present moment. For those who have already seen their nature, a single glance dispels delusion, and there is no need for investigation. Delusion vanishes upon examination, without the need for seeking. However, this can only be taught to those who have already seen their nature. For those who have not, they must be guided to realize it through investigation, and then have it directly pointed out to firmly establish the root of faith and sever the root of doubt. Thereafter, proceed with unbroken continuity, simply admonishing: do not move, do not follow. Let delusion surge like the sky and earth, yet your essence remains untouched. All these delusions are like floating clouds dotting the vast emptiness—what harm can they do? These delusions are merely movements of qi, and there is no principle by which they can be completely eradicated. The moment one arises with the thought of sweeping them away, that very thought is delusion, and its arising is attachment. As the ancient worthies said, "Driving away afflictions only adds more thoughts; pursuing true suchness is itself deviant." Our tradition simply admonishes: do not move. Movement leads to either chasing or following—how could it merely disturb the nature? This section’s ancestral intent lies in knowing cessation, hence the method of step-by-step investigation.]

We proceed in this practice by simply applying unwavering faith and action, single-mindedly returning from delusion to truth. Returning from delusion to truth is nothing other than the character "return"—turning the light back upon itself requires no external guidance. Once the essential principle of the quiescent body is attained, one should maintain illumination whether in stillness or in motion. Yet this "illumination" must be like the sun of spring or the moon of autumn—only then is it fitting.

**Chapter Four: Turning the Light Back and Regulating the Breath**
The Patriarch said: The essential principle is simply to proceed with a pure heart, without seeking verification, for verification will arise of itself.

Generally, the ailments of beginners are entirely encompassed by two: torpor and distraction. To remedy these, there is no better method than entrusting the mind to the breath. The breath is one’s own mind. When the mind stirs, qi immediately arises, for qi is the transformation of the mind. Our thoughts move with such swiftness that in the space of a breath, a deluded thought arises, and with each inhalation and exhalation, it responds. Thus, the inner breath and the outer breath are like sound and echo—each day, there are tens of thousands of breaths, and tens of thousands of deluded thoughts. When the spirit’s clarity is exhausted, one becomes like withered wood or dead ash.

Yet if one wishes to be without thoughts, one cannot be without thoughts; if one wishes to be without breath, one cannot be without breath. It is better to transform the ailment into medicine: the interdependence of mind and breath is the way. Therefore, turning the light back is combined with regulating the breath, a method that relies entirely on the light of the ears. There is the light of the eyes and the light of the ears. The light of the eyes is the mutual illumination of the external sun and moon; the light of the ears is the mutual refinement of the internal sun and moon. Yet essence is merely where light congeals—both emerge from the same source but have different names. Thus, wisdom and clarity are but a single spiritual light.

When sitting, after lowering the eyelids, set a standard and then release it. Yet if one releases it entirely, one may fail to maintain it, so instead, focus the mind on listening to the breath. The breath’s ingress and egress should not be audible to the ears; one listens only for its soundlessness. If there is sound, it is coarse and does not enter subtlety. One must patiently, gently, and softly refine it, becoming ever more subtle, ever more still. Over time, the subtle breath suddenly ceases—this is the arising of true breath, and the essence of the mind can then be recognized. For when the mind is subtle, the breath is subtle; when the mind is unified, qi moves. When the breath is subtle, the mind is subtle; when qi is unified, the mind moves. To stabilize the mind, one must first cultivate qi, for the mind has no direct point of entry, so one relies on qi as its initial sign—this is what is meant by "guarding the pure qi."

[Regulating the breath with the light of the ears is a secret method. Yet for those who are deaf, unable to hear the coarseness or subtlety of the breath, what is to be done? One should instead rely on awareness, for qi is transformed by the mind. The mind is formless, and its coarseness or subtlety is not easily perceived. Qi, though insubstantial, still leaves traces that can be sensed. If the trace is coarse, calm the mind; when the mind is still, the trace naturally refines, becoming ever more subtle. When the trace reaches nothingness, the breath has become true breath. Compared to using the light of the ears, this method achieves regulation more swiftly. Thus, the ancients said that regulating the mind is more wondrous than regulating the breath. For the elderly or deaf, apart from this method of awareness, this stage of practice will forever remain elusive. Moreover, awareness is the essence of nature, while traces are the end of life—this also embodies the mutual care of nature and life. Master Taixu once explained this to Gao Hai, and I now record it to supplement what the Patriarch did not address.]

You do not understand the word "movement." Movement is spoken of in terms of being pulled by a thread—it is another name for being tugged. If it can be made to gallop, why can it not be made to rest in pure stillness? This is how the great sages, observing the interplay of mind and qi, established expedient means to benefit later generations. The alchemical texts say: "The hen can hatch eggs by constantly listening"—this is the essential secret. The hen’s warmth enables the egg to hatch, but warmth alone can only warm the shell; it cannot enter within. Thus, the mind draws qi inward. In listening, the mind is wholly focused—where the mind enters, qi enters, and with the warmth of qi, life is born. Even when the hen occasionally leaves the nest, she remains in a posture of listening, her spirit undivided. Where the spirit is undivided, the warmth of qi persists day and night, and the spirit is enlivened. The spirit is enlivened because the mind has first died. If one can "die" the mind, the original spirit is enlivened. "Dying" the mind does not mean withering it but making it single and undivided. As the Buddha said: "Place the mind in one place, and nothing will be unattainable." The mind tends to wander, so refine it with qi; qi tends toward coarseness, so subtlety it with the mind. In this way, how could the mind not become settled?

Generally, the two ailments of torpor and distraction can be resolved only by practicing stillness daily without interruption, naturally leading to great rest. When not in still sitting, even if there is distraction, one may not be aware of it. Yet once one is aware of distraction, this awareness is the very opportunity to dispel it. The difference between torpor one is unaware of and torpor one is aware of is as vast as a thousand miles! Unaware torpor is true torpor; aware torpor is not entirely torpor, for clarity resides within. Distraction is the scattering of spirit; torpor is the lack of clarity in spirit. Distraction is easy to cure, but torpor is difficult to heal. It is like illness: pain and itching can be treated with medicine, but torpor is the numbness of paralysis. The scattered can be gathered, the chaotic can be ordered, but torpor is dull and dark. Distraction still has direction, but torpor is entirely the work of the corporeal soul. Distraction still has the ethereal soul present, but torpor is ruled by pure yin. When one feels drowsy during still sitting, this is torpor.

To dispel torpor, one need only regulate the breath. The breath here refers to the inhalation and exhalation through the mouth and nose—though not the true breath, the true breath’s movement is lodged within it. In sitting, one must settle the mind and unify the qi. How to settle the mind? By focusing on the breath. The breath’s coming and going is known only to the mind itself; it must not be heard by the ears. If unheard, it becomes fine; if fine, it becomes clear. If heard, the qi grows coarse; if coarse, it becomes turbid; if turbid, torpor arises and sleep follows—this is the natural principle.

Yet when the mind is applied to the breath, one must also master the subtlety of it: it is the use of non-use, requiring only a faint awareness and attentive listening. What is awareness? It is the eye’s light turned inward. The eyes see inwardly, not outwardly; when not outwardly directed, their alertness is inward seeing—though not truly inward seeing. What is listening? It is the ear’s light turned inward. The ears hear inwardly, not outwardly; when not outwardly directed, their alertness is inward hearing—though not truly inward hearing. To listen is to hear the soundless; to see is to perceive the formless. If the eyes do not gaze outward and the ears do not listen outward, the spirit may turn inward in distraction. Only through inward seeing and inward hearing can one neither stray outward nor drift inward, and thus remain free from torpor in the center. This is what is meant by the sun and moon exchanging essence and light.

When torpor and drowsiness arise, rise and walk about until the spirit clears, then sit again. In the early morning, when time permits, sitting for the duration of an incense stick is ideal. After noon, worldly affairs multiply and torpor easily sets in, yet one need not rigidly adhere to the length of an incense stick. As long as all conditions are set aside and one sits in stillness for a time, over time one will find the entry point and no longer fall into torpor or sleep.

**Chapter Five: Errors in Turning the Light Inward**
The Patriarch said: As your practice gradually matures, many wrong paths lie before the withered tree crag. It is essential to explain them in detail. The subtleties here can only be known when the body arrives; now I may speak of them.

Our tradition differs from Chan practice, for it proceeds step by step with verification. Let me first describe the points of divergence, then the verifications. When about to engage in the essential practice, prepare beforehand: do not overtax the mind, but allow it to be lively and free, so that the qi harmonizes and the mind settles. Only then enter stillness. In stillness, one must grasp the opportunity and the key—do not sit in a state of emptiness (what is called "indeterminate void"). Amidst the release of all conditions, remain alert and self-possessed. Yet do not strive to grasp it (excessive earnestness often leads to this; not that earnestness is inappropriate, but the true subtlety lies in the realm of "as if present, as if absent," and may be attained through intention or non-intention). Amidst alert clarity, remain at ease in release.

One must also not fall into the skandha realm—the skandha realm being where the five aggregates’ demonic forces take hold. Some enter samadhi with an excess of withered-wood, dead-ash stillness and little of the great earth’s vernal vitality. This is falling into the yin realm: the qi grows cold, the breath sinks, and many signs of chill and decay appear. Over time, one becomes like wood or stone. Nor should one be carried away by the myriad conditions. Upon entering stillness, if myriad thoughts suddenly arise, unable to be dismissed, and following them feels agreeable, this is the master becoming enslaved. Over time, one falls into the realm of desire. The higher rebirth is as a human; the lower, among the fox spirits. Those dwelling in famous mountains may enjoy wind and moon, flowers and fruit, jade trees and divine grasses for three to five hundred years, even thousands, yet when their retribution ends, they are reborn among the various destinies. These are all wrong paths.

Once the wrong paths are known, one may seek verification.

**Chapter Six: Verification of Turning the Light Inward**
The Patriarch said: There are many verifications, which cannot be undertaken by those of shallow roots or limited capacity. One must aspire to deliver all beings. They cannot be undertaken with a careless or arrogant mind; one must treat these words with reverence.

In stillness, a continuous, unbroken state arises, with joy and ease like intoxication or bathing—this is the body suffused with yang harmony, the golden flower just beginning to bloom. Then all things grow still, the bright moon high in the sky, and one perceives the entire world as a realm of light—this is the opening of the mind’s essence, the golden flower in full bloom. Then the body becomes full and solid, unafraid of wind or frost; what others find dull, I encounter with heightened spirit. Golden halls rise, white jade terraces appear; worldly things that rot, when breathed upon with true qi, instantly revive. Red blood becomes milk, the seven-foot fleshly form is nothing but gold and treasure—this is the great congealing of the golden flower.

The first stage corresponds to the *Sutra of Contemplation*: "The sun sets into the great water, the image of the row of trees." The sun setting symbolizes establishing the foundation from chaos, the Wuji. The highest good is like water, clear and flawless—this is the Supreme Ultimate’s governance, the sovereign emerging from Zhen. Zhen is wood, hence the image of the row of trees. Seven rows of trees correspond to the seven apertures filled with light. (The northwest Qian direction, shifted one place, becomes Kan; the sun setting into the great water is the image of Qian and Kan. Kan is the north, the Zi direction; at the winter solstice, thunder lies within the earth, rumbling faintly, until Zhen, when yang emerges above the earth—this is the image of the row of trees; the rest may be inferred by analogy.)

The second stage builds upon this: the great earth becomes ice, a lapis lazuli jeweled land, and light gradually congeals. Thus the lotus terrace appears, followed by the Buddha’s manifestation. Once the golden nature appears, what is it if not the Buddha? The Buddha is the great awakened golden immortal. These are the major stages of verification.

*(Here the text records the transmission of a secret formula. As the planchette pen was about to write, it suddenly halted at the dark of the moon. Suddenly, a great brightness appeared—not sun, not moon—yet not even the finest detail was hidden. A wondrous fragrance filled the air, and faint celestial music was heard in the void. After a long while, the planchette began to dance, and the judgment read: "This is Vairocana Tathagata.")*

Our Supreme Patriarch of the lineage once declared: Alas, in kalpas beyond measure past, I had attained the station of the Lord of Immeasurable Life. Far to the west, one hundred eight thousand *li* beyond the Western Continent of Uttarakuru, lies the land called the Realm of Immeasurable Life. There, I gathered with fellow aspirants—fifteen thousand in number—embodying awakening in this very body and world, extinguishing all within the Treasury of Light. The dharma-realm was like lapis lazuli, and the earth, trees, and all things were congealed from the seven treasures. There were no men or women; beings were born from lotuses. All that flies, burrows, moves, or grows was in perfect harmony, and life too was immeasurable. The present Land of Amitābha Buddha is none other than the former Realm of Immeasurable Life.

Now, at Dragon Peak, I expound the teachings of the *Primordial Void, Supreme Oneness, and Golden Flower*—all to cultivate and verify this very path, that the Eastern Land may be transformed into the Land of Ultimate Bliss. Excellent indeed! Excellent indeed! The proclamation of this vast vow has met with cosmic resonance; the signs of its unfolding are already manifest, for the radiance of inherent nature knows no bounds. Today, we have been graced by the descent of the ancestral nature-light, and boundless blessings have been bestowed. This ancestral nature is none other than Vairocana Tathāgata.

The Patriarch Qiu Changchun also descended to the altar and instructed: *"The Vajracchedikā Sūtra* states: 'The Tathāgata is one who comes from nowhere and goes nowhere; thus is he called the Tathāgata.' When the mind abides, phenomena appear; when thought recedes, they vanish. Yet this appearing and vanishing are but traces—there is no arising or ceasing in truth." At that time, all the perfected ones gathered, each offering verses of praise, though they cannot all be recounted here. Such was the essence of their teaching.

This was an assembly of realized beings convened once in eighty thousand kalpas—an encounter unforeseen at Dragon Peak. Those who read this text must take heed: do not abandon yourselves. Recorded with reverence by the descendant Tai Ding.

*(This was originally inscribed by the earlier sage Shi’an. The present edition, transmitted by a descendant of the Middle Lineage, has suppressed this passage while appropriating the text to disparage the Northern Lineage. The same omission appears in the transcribed copies; thus, it is here restored.)*

Three verifiable signs may now be examined:
First, when one sits in meditation and the spirit enters the valley, voices of people speaking—though distant as a *li*—are heard with perfect clarity, each word resonating like an echo within the valley. Yet while others hear, one does not hear oneself. This confirms the spirit’s presence within the valley, a sign verifiable at any time.

Second, in stillness, the eyes radiate a luminous glow, filling all before one with whiteness, as if enveloped in clouds. Upon opening the eyes, the body cannot be found, for the empty chamber has given birth to light, and inner and outer are pervaded with brightness—an auspicious stillness indeed.

Third, in stillness, the physical body becomes supple and yielding, like silk or jade. Though seated, one feels as if unable to remain, rising effortlessly upward. This is the spirit returning to the celestial crown; with time, ascension may be awaited.

These three are signs verifiable in the present. Yet their manifestations are inexhaustible, varying with each practitioner’s capacity, as the *Mohe Zhiguan* describes in its account of "the arising of wholesome roots." This matter is like one who drinks water and knows its warmth or coolness for oneself—only when you trust it completely is it true.

The primordial qi resides within present verification; seek it there. Once this qi is attained, the elixir forms instantly—this is the single grain of true millet. Grain upon grain accumulates, from the subtle to the manifest.

There is the primordial of the moment—a single grain—and the primordial of the whole—a single grain extending to the immeasurable. Each grain possesses its own power, and herein lies the foremost principle: one’s vow must be vast.

*(In the Jiang edition and its copies, "vast vow" was mistakenly altered to "boldness," a critical error. For "vast vow" arises from one’s capacity: those of great vow are of great capacity, not mere self-liberated individuals. Moreover, the preceding practices involve no extraordinary feats—why would boldness be required?)*

---

**Chapter Seven: The Living Method of Turning the Light Around**

The Patriarch said: Proceed with turning the light around step by step; do not neglect your proper duties. The ancients said: "When matters arise, respond and let them pass; when things appear, recognize and let them pass." Address affairs with right mindfulness, and the light will not be swayed by phenomena. In the midst of circumstances, turn it back. This is the turning of the light without fixed form, moment to moment.

In daily life, if one can reflect inwardly at every instant, free from the slightest trace of self or other, this is turning the light around in every place—the first wondrous function. At dawn, it is most excellent to settle all concerns and sit in stillness for one or two hours. In all dealings with affairs and people, employ only the method of reflection, ensuring no interruption even for a moment. Practicing thus for three or four months, the immortals of heaven will surely come to verify your attainment.

---

**Chapter Eight: The Carefree Formula**

The Patriarch said:
The Jade Clarity left behind the carefree formula:
Four words—*concentrate the spirit and enter the qi-cavern.*
In the sixth month, behold white snow flying;
At the third watch, witness the sun’s radiant wheel.
In water, the wind of Xun stirs;
In heaven, one roams and returns to partake of Kun’s virtue.
Yet there is one phrase within the profound—
The land of *wuheyou* is the true dwelling.

This single regulated verse encompasses all profundities. The essence of the Great Dao lies in the four characters: *non-doing yet doing.* Only through non-doing does one avoid attachment to form and location; only through non-doing yet doing does one avoid falling into inert emptiness or dead vacuity.

All functioning revolves around the center, yet the pivot lies entirely in the two eyes. The two eyes are the handle of the Dipper, revolving creation and turning the wheel of yin and yang. The great medicine is but the gold within water from beginning to end (that is, the lead of the watery realm).

The earlier discussion of turning the light around was for beginners, using the external to govern the internal—assisting the guest to attain mastery. This is for those of middling and lesser capacity, cultivating the lower two passes to penetrate the upper pass.

Now, as the threads become clearer and the mechanism more familiar, Heaven does not withhold the Dao—it directly reveals the supreme teaching. Disciples, guard this well! Guard this well! Strive on! Strive on!

Turning the light around is but a general term. With each layer of progress, the radiance of the light grows more splendid, and the method of turning becomes ever more wondrous.

Previously, one governed the internal from the external; now, one resides at the center to command the external. Previously, one assisted the guest to attain mastery; now, one serves the master to offer tribute—how completely reversed the circumstances have become!

When the practitioner wishes to enter stillness, first regulate and harmonize body and mind, resting in ease and tranquility, releasing all entanglements, utterly unattached. Only when the Heavenly Heart is rightly positioned at the center should the eyes gently lower their lids, as if receiving a sacred decree to summon a great minister—who would dare not come?

Next, with the two eyes, inwardly illuminate the Kan palace. Where the radiance reaches, true yang emerges to respond. Kan, outwardly yang but inwardly yin, is the body of Qian. When one yin enters within to become master, it follows things to generate the mind, flowing outward in sequence. Now, turning the light around to inwardly illuminate, one does not follow things to generate the mind; yin qi halts, and as the radiance pours forth in illumination, it becomes pure yang.

Like attracts like, so the yang of Kan ascends—not the yang of Kan itself, but the yang of Qian responding to the yang of Qian. When the two substances meet, they intertwine inseparably, vibrantly active, now coming, now going, now floating, now sinking. Within one’s original palace, it seems as boundless as the great void, the entire body light and wondrous, as if about to ascend—this is what is called "clouds filling a thousand mountains."

Next, when coming and going leave no trace, floating and sinking become indistinguishable, the pulse stills and qi halts—this is true union, what is called "the moon containing ten thousand waters." If, in this profound obscurity, the Heavenly Heart suddenly stirs, this is the return of the first yang, the living midnight.

Yet the subtleties of this process require careful explanation.

[Here follows the profound discourse of Master Wang Kunyang.]

In the autumn of the *wuchen* year of the Kangxi reign, the Master traveled south from the north and took residence at Zongyang Palace in Hangzhou. Jing’an, the Recluse of Hidden Reality, came to pay his respects and presented this book. The Master received it with solemn reverence, bowed, and read it, saying: "Herein lies the heart-transmission of the Most High. This is the method of practice for attaining perfection in the world, and its transformative efficacy for the world is also contained within—it must not be viewed as pertaining solely to the individual. Its great purport is subtly revealed in the two phrases *wielding the transformations of creation*. Though not a single word speaks of universal salvation, within the meticulous inner workings of this chapter lies the method for refining the entire world. It does not speak of the world, yet the world is contained within it. Only when one practices to this chapter can true verification be attained. Disciples, do not be disheartened, nor be complacent—great practice still awaits its time." Thereupon, he commanded his disciple to record this, and it was later appended to the printed edition for the benefit of future learners. Taiding respectfully notes: *According to my examination of the Jiang edition, this annotation is not included, nor is it found in the transcribed copy. The Master’s words on practice awaiting its time are indeed trustworthy.*

---

Ordinarily, when people hear or see, their ears and eyes follow external things and move accordingly; when the things depart, so too does the movement. In such activity and stillness, one is entirely of the common folk, while the Heavenly Lord within instead becomes enslaved to them—this is to dwell constantly with ghosts. Now, if every movement and stillness is shared with others, then one becomes a true person, the Heavenly Lord within the body. When others move, move with them—this is the Heavenly Root. When others are still, be still with them—this is the Moon Grotto. Without beginning, movement and stillness are also without beginning; in rest and activity, above and below, one likewise moves and rests, rises and falls with them—this is what is called *the Heavenly Root and Moon Grotto, idly coming and going*.

When the Heavenly Heart is serene, if one moves contrary to its timing, the movement is too tender; if one moves only after the Heavenly Heart has stirred, the movement is too old. When the Heavenly Heart stirs, immediately direct true intention upward to the Qian Palace, guiding with the divine light gazing at the crown—this is movement that responds to the time. Once the Heavenly Lord ascends to the Qian Palace, it roams and soars freely. If suddenly it desires stillness, swiftly draw it with true intention into the Yellow Court, the eyes’ light gazing into the central Yellow Spirit Chamber. Then, the desire for stillness vanishes without a single thought arising. The one who gazes inward suddenly forgets the act of gazing. At that moment, body and mind undergo a great release, all conditions vanish without trace, and even the cauldron and furnace of one’s own spirit chamber seem nowhere to be found. Seeking one’s own body, it is utterly unattainable—this is the time when Heaven enters Earth, when the myriad wonders return to the root, and it is precisely the moment of *congealing spirit into the qi cave*.

In one *return of the light*, initially the scattered seeks to gather, the six senses cease functioning—this is *nurturing the original source, adding oil to extend life*. Then, the gathered naturally drifts in ease, without expending the slightest effort—this is *settling the spirit in the ancestral aperture, gathering the primordial*. Finally, echoes and reflections vanish entirely, and profound stillness prevails—this is *hibernating in the qi cave, the myriad wonders returning to the root*. Within one stage lie three stages, and within one stage lie nine stages; their elaboration awaits a later day.

Now, speaking of one stage containing three stages: when nurturing begins and initial stillness arises, both gathering and hibernation are also forms of nurturing. In the end, all nurturing becomes hibernation. The middle layer can be inferred by analogy—what is unchanging is precisely where distinctions arise. This is the *formless aperture*, where a thousand places and ten thousand places are one place. What is unchanging in time is where temporal divisions arise—this is the *timeless moment*, an instant spanning kalpas and eons.

---

*Respectfully note: The formless aperture is the mysterious aperture. The mysterious aperture has no location, yet the Three Powers are entirely within it. What is large or small, far or near, person or thing, body or world—where are the boundaries? The timeless moment is the living time. Living time has no fixed moment, yet all ages are contained within it. What are the Upper and Lower Yuan, spring and summer, autumn and winter, midnight and noon, the hours of the day—how can they be grasped? Yet to open the mysterious aperture, one must do so at the living midnight and living noon, when movement reaches its extreme and stillness arises, or stillness reaches its extreme and movement arises. The aperture’s essence is attained precisely here.*

*What is living midnight? When the myriad things are silent, a single mechanism stirs at its time, yet without direction—this is it. What is living noon? When all paths open, a single moment is utterly still, yet without destination—this is it. The aperture is never closed for an instant; when the mechanism is still, it appears; when the mechanism is disturbed, it vanishes. When it appears, one awakens; when it vanishes, one is deluded. Awakening follows the true; delusion leads to confusion. To activate the mysterious aperture, there is no method of movement—only abiding in stillness. Thus, the wise merely rest the spirit in emptiness and void, observing the movements and stillness of the qi mechanism with contained light. One need not deliberately still the mind within it, and so one attains effortless mastery in all situations. The marvelous secret of the return of the light is precisely this. Following this secret, one may attain living midnight or living noon, while fixed midnight or fixed noon may be attained or lost, all depending on the heart. The heart is the source of the mechanism—this is the essential principle of *rectifying the root and purifying the source*.*

*Midnight and noon refer to movement and stillness, yin and yang, which are distinguished here. Yet within them lie sequence, purity and turbidity, maturity and tenderness—all contained within one stage of nine stages. The explanation is intricate, for the five kinds of immortal lineages arise from this, and it cannot be grasped in a single word. Thus, the Master said it awaits later elaboration.*

---

Generally, the heart cannot move unless it is utterly still; any movement that is not stillness is false movement, not the movement of the original substance. Thus it is said: *Moved by things, it moves—this is the desire of nature.* If it moves not in response to things, then it is the movement of Heaven and Earth.

To contrast Heaven’s movement with Heaven’s nature is to fall into the error of introducing the word "desire." Desire arises only where there is an object—this is thought that has strayed beyond its proper place, movement that has already moved. When not a single thought arises, true thought is born. This is *zhenyi* (true intent). Within the great stillness of *jiran* (utter quiescence), the celestial mechanism suddenly stirs—is this not movement without thought? To act without acting is precisely this meaning.

The first two lines of the poem encapsulate the entire workings of the Golden Flower. The next two lines convey the mutual embodiment of the sun and moon: the sixth month is the fire of *Li*, and the flying white snow is the true yin within *Li*, about to return to *Kun*. The third watch is the water of *Kan*, and the solar orb is the single yang within *Kan*, about to blaze forth and return to *Qian*. The extraction of *Kan* to fill *Li* occurs within this process.

The following two lines describe the function of the Dipper’s handle, the complete mechanism of ascent and descent. Is not the water within it *Kan*? The eyes are the wind of *Xun*; the gaze enters the palace of *Kan*, drawing forth the essence of the great yang. The heavens above are the palace of *Qian*; to wander and return, feeding on the virtue of *Kun*, is the spirit entering *qi*, Heaven entering Earth—this is the nurturing of fire.

The final two lines point to the supreme secret within secrets, the secret that cannot be departed from from beginning to end, what is called "washing the heart and cleansing the thoughts as if bathing." The sagely learning begins with knowing where to halt and ends with halting at perfection; it begins in *wuji* (the Ultimateless) and returns to *wuji*. Buddhism takes "giving rise to the mind without abiding" as the great essential teaching of the entire treasury. Our Dao completes the full work of nature and destiny with the two words "attaining emptiness."

In sum, the three teachings are but a single phrase: the divine elixir for transcending death and preserving life. What is this divine elixir? It is simply having no mind in all circumstances. The most esoteric aspect of our Dao is "bathing." The entire work of this text can be resolved in the two words "emptying the heart." Now, with a single word, I have revealed it—this spares you decades of seeking.

You disciples fail to understand that within one stage lie three stages. I use the Buddhist three contemplations—of emptiness, provisional existence, and the middle—to illustrate. The three contemplations begin with emptiness: seeing all things as empty. Next is provisional existence: though knowing their emptiness, one does not destroy the myriad things but establishes all affairs within emptiness. Having neither destroyed the myriad things nor become attached to them, this is the contemplation of the middle.

When cultivating the contemplation of emptiness, one also knows that the myriad things cannot be destroyed and yet does not become attached—this is the integration of all three contemplations. Yet ultimately, it is seeing emptiness that is most effective. In cultivating the contemplation of emptiness, emptiness is indeed empty, provisional existence is also empty, and the middle is also empty. In cultivating the contemplation of provisional existence, one relies more on the power of provisional existence: provisional existence is indeed provisional, emptiness is also provisional, and the middle is also provisional. When practicing the middle way, one also contemplates emptiness, yet it is not called emptiness but the middle. One also practices the contemplation of provisional existence, yet it is not called provisional existence but the middle. As for the middle itself, it need not be spoken of.

Though I sometimes speak solely of *Li* and at other times include *Kan*, I have never altered a single word. When I open my mouth to say, "The pivot lies entirely in the two eyes," the pivot refers to function—the use of this to revolve the workings of creation, not that creation is confined to this alone. The six roots and seven apertures are all treasuries of radiance; how could I take only the two eyes and disregard the rest? Using the yang of *Kan* still requires the illumination of *Li* to gather it—this makes it clear.

Master Zhu (Yunyu, whose taboo name was Yuanyu, of the Northern Lineage) once said, "The blind are unsuited for cultivating the Dao, but the deaf are not." How does this differ from my words? It merely highlights the primary and secondary, the weight and lightness.

The sun and moon are originally one thing. The true essence contained within the sun is the true essence of the moon. The moon’s cavern is not in the moon but in the sun—this is what is meant by "the cavern of the moon." Otherwise, it would suffice to speak only of the moon. The true yang gathered within the moon is the true light of the sun. The sun’s light is actually within the moon—this is what is meant by "the root of Heaven." Otherwise, it would suffice to speak only of Heaven.

The sun and moon, when separated, are but halves; only when united do they form a complete whole. Like a husband and wife, living alone does not make a household; only when there is both husband and wife is a family complete. Yet things are poor analogies for the Dao. A husband and wife, when separated, remain two people, but the sun and moon, when separated, do not form a complete whole. Understanding this, the ears and eyes are the same.

I say that the blind have no ears and the deaf have no eyes. Seen thus, what is meant by one thing or two things? What is meant by the six roots? The six roots are one root. What is meant by the seven apertures? The seven apertures are one aperture. My words merely reveal their interconnectedness, so that duality is not perceived. You disciples cling to their separateness, constantly shifting your perspective.

**Chapter Nine: Establishing the Foundation for a Hundred Days**
The Patriarch said: As the *Xinyin Jing* states, "Returning the wind and blending it, the work of a hundred days becomes efficacious." In sum, establishing the foundation for a hundred days is what produces true light. As you are now, your light is merely the light of the eyes—it is not the fire of spirit, not the light of nature, not the torch of wisdom and insight. After a hundred days of returning, *jing* and *qi* will naturally be sufficient, true yang will naturally arise, and true fire will naturally exist within water. Proceeding with this, union will occur naturally, the embryo will form naturally, and I will remain in the state of "not knowing, not perceiving," while the infant is spontaneously completed.

If there is the slightest deliberate effort, it is heterodox practice. Establishing the foundation for a hundred days is not a matter of a hundred days. Establishing the foundation in a day is not a matter of a day. Establishing the foundation in a single breath is not a matter of inhalation and exhalation. This breath is the heart itself; the heart as breath is *yuanshen* (original spirit), *yuanqi* (original qi), and *yuanjing* (original essence). Ascent and descent, separation and union—all arise from the heart. Existence and nonexistence, emptiness and fullness—all reside within thought. A single breath, a single lifetime of holding fast—how could it be limited to a hundred days? Yet a hundred days is also a single breath.

The hundred days depend solely on gaining power. If one gains power during the day, one reaps the benefit at night; if one gains power at night, one reaps the benefit during the day. The hundred days of foundation-laying are the jade decree of the highest truth. The words of the perfected ones invariably resonate with the human body. The words of a true teacher invariably resonate with the disciple. This is the mystery

As it remains steadfast like a pivot, it is called the Dipper Pivot. Moreover, this book originates from the Longqiao Mountain Studio, and common editions cannot be relied upon. Clearly, there exists in the capital a Tao edition that could have been consulted—why did Minister Jiang not adopt it? He must have been misled by Monk Wang.

My heart is likewise. The heart is the Dipper Pivot, and qi is the host of stars. The qi within my body, flowing through the four limbs and hundred bones, is originally interconnected—no excessive effort is required. In this state, refine the spirit of consciousness and sever delusive perceptions; then the medicine arises. The medicine is not a tangible substance—it is this radiance of nature, the primordial true qi. Yet it can only be perceived after great stillness, and there is no method of "gathering"; those who speak of gathering are gravely mistaken. Once this vision endures, the mind-ground becomes luminous, naturally emptying all leaks and liberating one from the sea of dust. If one fixates today on dragon and tiger, tomorrow on water and fire, it will all become mere delusion.

As I once received from the oral instructions of the Fire Dragon Perfected: "Thus it is. I know not how the alchemical texts describe it otherwise." Each day completes one celestial revolution; each moment completes one celestial revolution. Where Kan and Li intersect, there is a revolution. My union is the turning of Heaven itself. Unable to rest, there are times of union and times of disunion. Yet Heaven’s turning never ceases for even a moment. If one truly achieves the harmonious union of yin and yang, the great earth becomes warm with yang, and the central palace of my being assumes its rightful place—all things flourish at once. This is the "bathing method" of the alchemical classics. How could it be anything but the Great Celestial Revolution?

(Shi’an remarks: "There is meaning within these words—do not take them lightly.")

Here the firing times truly differ in magnitude, yet in the end, no distinction of great or small remains. (Shi’an remarks: "We may awaken to this—how lamentable to settle for the lesser!")

When skill matures into spontaneity, one no longer knows what Kan and Li are, what Heaven and Earth are, which is union and which is one revolution or two, or where to seek the distinction between great and small. In sum, the revolving of the body is difficult to make real. If unreal, even the vastest appears small; if real, a single revolution carries Heaven, Earth, and the ten thousand things with it—within the square inch of the heart, the smallest becomes the greatest.

Thus the firing times of the Golden Elixir must return entirely to spontaneity. Without spontaneity, Heaven remains Heaven, Earth remains Earth, and the ten thousand things remain as they are. If one forces them to unite, they will never unite. Consider a time of severe drought when yin and yang are disharmonious. Though Qian and Kun complete their revolutions each day, one still perceives much that is unnatural. Yet if I can revolve and harmonize yin and yang, adjusting them to spontaneity, clouds gather and rain falls, grasses and trees luxuriate, rivers flow freely, and even discord dissolves in an instant—this is the Great Celestial Revolution.

(There must be this thunderous awakening. If unreal, it is delusion—a hair’s breadth becomes ten million miles.)

To govern the body is to attain the True—governing the world lies therein.

In stillness, embody it: the Ancestor verifies inner work through celestial timing. How profound! How profound!

**Question:** The marvel of the *living midnight* lies in recognizing the *true midnight*—does this not cling to form?
**Answer:** It does not cling to form. Without pointing to the *true midnight*, how can one recognize the *living midnight*? Once the *living midnight* is recognized, the *true midnight* is surely present—are they one or two? Neither true nor living, yet all depends on seeing with true clarity. When true, nothing is not right; nothing is not alive. If perception is not true, what is right? What is alive? What is true?

For example, the *living midnight* may be perceived at all times. Yet when the *true midnight* arrives, with will and qi clear and bright, the *living midnight* becomes even more manifest. If one has not yet grasped the living, then first verify it at the right moment—when the right appears, the living becomes wondrously subtle.

---

**Chapter Thirteen: Song of Exhortation to the World**

The Ancestor says:
I burn with the cinnabar heart to deliver the world,
Spare no tender care nor spare my tongue.
The World-Honored One, too, for great causes,
Directly pointed to birth and death—how lamentable!
The Old Lord also feared for this body of mine,
Transmitting the Valley Spirit, unknown to men.
Now I briefly speak the path to seek the True:
The *Huangzhong* penetrates principle, bearing the *Great Change*.
Right position dwelling in the body is the Mysterious Pass;
Between *zi* and *wu*, one may settle the breath.
Light returns to the ancestral aperture, the ten thousand spirits at peace;
Medicine arises in the rivers and plains, one qi emerges.
Piercing the curtain, transformation shines with golden light—
A wheel of red sun, ever radiant.
People mistakenly take the essence of *Kan* and *Li*,
Moving heart and kidney, creating separation.
How can man and Heaven unite in mind?
When Heaven accords, the Dao naturally harmonizes.
Lay down the ten thousand conditions, stir not a hair—
This is the precelestial True and Boundless.
The Great Void, serene, its signs concealed,
At the gate of life and nature, forget consciousness.
When consciousness is forgotten, the original True appears—
Water clear, the pearl revealed, the Mystery unfathomable.
Obstructions of beginningless vexations suddenly empty,
The Jade Capital descends the Nine Dragons’ Register.
Now ascending the Milky Way to the Heavenly Palace,
Grasping wind and thunder, driving the thunderbolt.
Concentrating spirit and settling breath is the initial mechanism;
Retreating to the secret ground is constant quiescence.

My former verses for Zhang Zhennu contain the essential teaching:
*After midnight, before noon*—not the time;
*Kan* and *Li*—merely the ears.
"Settling the breath" means each breath returning to the Central Yellow.
"Sitting" means the heart unmoving.
"The spine" is not the wheel on the back,
But the straight path piercing the Jade Capital.
"The double passes"—here lies the unspeakable.
Avoid forgetting and guarding spirit;
Cherish emptiness, quiescence, and nothingness.
What is guarded? Guard this meaning.
Fluids thus transform, blood thus forms.
Thereafter, return to the precelestial;
Qi thus returns to spirit, spirit thus returns to emptiness,
Emptiness thus unites with the Dao, the Dao thus perfects the will,
The will thus fulfills the vow—
The secrets cannot all be told; this is the place.
*(These thirteen phrases are found only in the ancestral altar’s legacy register.)*

As for "the earth-thunder shaking the mountain peak"—true qi is born;
"Yellow sprouts emerging from the soil"—true medicine is born.
*(This phrase, too, is found only in the ancestral altar’s legacy register.)*
These two small passages encompass the great path of cultivation.
Understand this, and you will not be deluded by others’ words.

Long ago, the Master and Yanzi ascended the summit of Mount Tai,
Gazing toward the White Horse Gate of Wu.
Yanzi saw it as a bolt of silk—
Exerting his eyes too much, his spirit-light scattered,
Thus he died young.
Can one not strive to return the light?

Returning the light lies in pure-hearted practice,
Simply awaiting true breath to congeal and illumine the Central Palace.
In time, it will naturally penetrate the numinous and master transformation.
All rests on the foundation of a still heart and settled qi;
The effect is a heart forgotten and qi congealed;
When qi and breath empty the heart, the Elixir is formed;
When heart and qi merge as one, it is nurtured;
When the heart is illuminated and nature is seen, the Dao is attained.

You disciples must each strive to practice.
To waste this time is lamentable—
Seven Disciples, exert yourselves!

A single day without practice makes one a ghost for that day; a single breath in practice makes one a true immortal for that breath. The foundation of assisting in creation and transformation lies herein—Seven Disciples, exert yourselves!

*Preface to the Record of Master Lü’s Teachings on the Three Ni’s Medical Governance of the World*

Writing serves to convey the Dao. I have long heard of this secret text in the world. Recalling my youth, I had the fortune to attend Master Dongli in Mount Tongbai. The Master, revered by heaven and humanity, was already over one hundred and ten years old, bearing the surname Gao. The Governor of Zhejiang and Fujian, Lord Gao, was of the same clan; while inspecting the frontier, he passed through the mountain and inquired of the Master regarding the *Teachings on the Three Ni’s Medical Governance of the World*. The Master replied: “I once saw it in the inner writings of Master Wang Yangming’s bamboo basket, transcribed and disseminated by his disciple Wang Longxi—it is the great Dao by which Fuxi and the Yellow Emperor governed the world with their own bodies. I have also heard of it from the world-abiding immortal Li Niuwan. My disciple Shen Yibing encountered him thrice, and once asked Li about the two characters ‘Three Ni.’ Li replied: ‘This Dao was transmitted from Fuxi and the Yellow Emperor. The Three Great Sages—Confucius, Śākyamuni, and Qingni—expounded it to establish teachings. The followers of each school recorded their entry points, compiling them into a single volume, variously titled *Teachings*, *Mind-to-Mind Transmission*, *Methods of Practice*, or *Functions of Practice*. Now, they have scattered and been lost.’” Such was what I once heard from Master Gao.

On the twenty-sixth day of the tenth month in the bingwu year of the Qianlong reign, my great master, the Venerable Tai Xu, departed this world. Two days prior, he had entrusted me with a book, charging me to keep it secret. At the time, I was still careless and failed to guard it well. A friend took it to Jinning, and after long borrowing, it was never returned—it was none other than the *Three Ni’s Medical Governance Practice Methods* of the Patriarch Lü.

In the jiyou year, when the Zhejiang Education Commissioner, Master Zhu Shijun, inspected Huzhou, I paid my respects at the Youwen Hall. Only then did I learn that he possessed this book as a treasured heirloom, though he never showed it to others, suspecting it might be incomplete. Hearing that the version in the Jin’gai collection was complete, he entrusted me, as one honest and trustworthy, to seek and retrieve it. I returned empty-handed. He then showed me his own copy, a handwritten transcription from the Ming dynasty, bearing a postscript by the Earl of Chengyi. I intended to make a copy, but just then, he was preparing to inspect another prefecture, and in haste, the matter was left unfinished.

Four years later, during my official travels, I passed through Jizu Mountain and visited the world-abiding immortal, the Jizu Daoist, at the Dragon Tree Study. The immortal’s surname was Huang, given name Shouzhong, a native of the Western Regions’ Yue Zhi, who entered China during the Yuan dynasty. Having long resided on Jizu Mountain, he earned his sobriquet. In the sixteenth year of the Shunzhi reign, he journeyed to the capital and sought the Three Great Precepts of the Supreme from Precept Master Wang of Kunyang. Initially, he had no name, calling himself *Yetapova*, meaning “Dao-seeking scholar” in the Chinese tongue. The Precept Master, noting his long sojourn in China, bestowed upon him the Chinese name Huang Shouzhong. To this day, the people of Yunnan universally address him as the Perfected Huang. Though he has lived over five hundred years, his appearance is that of a man of sixty, his eyes bright and piercing, his voice resonant as a great bell. Few books lay upon his desk—aside from the *Buddha’s Discourse on the Dhāraṇī of Upholding the World*, only the *Three Ni’s Medical Governance Teachings*, which I verified as the very text shown by Dong Li, the divine discourse of the Venerable Tai Xu. I begged him not to lend it but to allow me to transcribe it. He smiled and said, “No. Return home and seek it with sincerity. If you find the two fine versions and compile them yourself, now is not yet the time. Wait a while.”

I then asked, “I once received the *Patriarch Lü’s Three Ni’s Medical Governance Practice Methods* from my great master, the Venerable Tai Xu, but before I could study it, a friend took it away. What do you make of this book?”

He replied, “I once possessed it as well. It is an excellent volume. You will surely obtain it again one day.”

I asked further, “Have you ever practiced this teaching?”

He said, “The time! The time!”

I pressed, “If even a sage like Confucius did not use this Dao to govern the world, why is that?”

He answered, “The sage establishes the ultimate standard for humanity, enacting this Dao for ten thousand generations. The Master’s Way is vast—it does not belong to a single era. Moreover, when the Zhou dynasty established its capital at Jiaru, the divination foretold seven hundred years. By the end of the Spring and Autumn period, that span had run its course. How could one know that the divine power of assisting and sustaining was not at work, propping up the declining fate and extending the mandate from Heaven?”

I said, “If the Master had used this Dao to save the world, his time would surely have seen great order.”

He replied, “In the Spring and Autumn period, the sea of karmic retribution was deep, and the cycle of slaughter was about to begin. Heaven did not yet wish to pacify the world. The qi of wanton destruction leads to depletion; the qi of excess and dissipation brings floods; the qi of grievance and oppression causes severe drought; the qi of perversity and rebellion leads to warfare. When wayward qi lingers long and fails to disperse, the primordial qi becomes obstructed and blocked. A sage without official position can nurture the inherent goodness in human hearts but cannot eradicate the entrenched evils of the world. When the Way of the teacher is established, good people multiply, and with many good people, the world’s fate can be sustained. As for those who stir up trouble themselves, Heaven will gather and destroy them—this is not something a common scholar can remedy.”

I asked, “Then is this Dao also limited?”

He said, “A skilled physician must first eliminate the illness before the primordial qi can flow freely. Have you not heard the words of Laozi? ‘The Dao is great, Heaven is great, Earth is great, and the king is also great.’ The king is also great—he is the refuge of all beings within the four seas, wielding the power to turn the heavens and shift the earth. When the Dao unites with power, then the instruments of war, punishment, ritual, and music can reform old customs and renew them. Power is sufficient to remove the illness and establish peace. But with the Dao alone and no power, how can one bring peace and comfort to the wicked and the degenerate?

The world’s illnesses are of two kinds: those caused by human action and those ordained by Heaven’s fate. Illnesses of human origin arise from perverse qi, what is called ‘self-made calamity from which there is no escape.’ Only those with power can heal them. Illnesses of Heaven’s fate can be averted by harmonious qi, what is called ‘Heaven-made calamity that can still be remedied.’ Only those with the Dao can heal them. Yet Heaven’s fate also shifts with human affairs. If perverse qi is dispelled before it arises, Heaven’s fate will respond accordingly. When Heaven’s fate flows freely, the primordial qi flows freely; when the primordial qi flows freely, the great transformation flows freely. Then this Dao will flow freely without end.

For the noble person in high position, it is like leveling the earth to become heaven, leaving nothing unattended. For the noble person in low position, it is like establishing and elevating others, also accomplishing much for all things. To govern the world with the Dao is not to abandon the Dao because of the world. Moreover, in an age of ascending peace, when the realm is well-ordered and at rest, with a great sage as its ruler, the Dao unites with power. Within the borders of the land, there are no obstinate people or corrupt officials to brew disasters and block the flow of qi. Then this Dao circulates freely, and even a humble scholar can perform the work of positioning Heaven and Earth and nurturing the ten thousand things, assisting in ways unseen and unheard.

As for the generation and completion of the Five Phases and the hundred things, if there are occasional minor calamities or minor kalpas, practicing this Dao to remedy them will align with the benevolent heart of the sovereign above and relieve the suffering of the people below. Will there not be an immediate response, like an echo answering a sound?”

“Such was my instruction from the Yellow Perfected.

In the year *guichou*, I traveled to the Eastern Mountain of Lake Dongting and rested at the home of the Zhu family. Zhu was a descendant of the Nine Returns Elder, a senior figure of our mountain, and a grandson of his line. Fond of profound learning, he brought forth two volumes from his collection. One was a book once treasured by the Grand Councilor Wenzheng, also a transcribed copy, though lacking colophons from eminent hands. The other was hand-copied by Master Shi’an the Vinaya Master in his Dragon Ridge Mountain Lodge, compiled under the title *Hidden Perfection of the Yellow Patriarch*. Its meaning was even more lucid—likely the ‘detailed and excellent edition’ referred to by the Perfected One of Chicken Foot Mountain. I begged to borrow and take them home, though at the time I had not yet grasped their profound principles and rashly resolved to practice only after mastering the Dao.

It was not until the fifth year of Daoguang that I received from my teacher, the Great Void Elder, the transmission of the *Esoteric Formula for Healing the World* once bestowed upon him. Later, I was blessed by the descent of the Patriarch Lü upon the sand, where he expounded in ten thousand words, and the profound principles became clear. Only then did I regret that the esoteric formula transmitted by my teacher had been taken to Jinning by a friend and has yet to return. Fortunately, the Perfected One of Chicken Foot Mountain declared that true attainment must come from within. Thus, I meticulously transcribed the revelations from the sand, gathered what I had heard and witnessed, and compiled them with annotations. To supplement this, I drew from the teachings of the Confucian and Buddhist traditions, citing scriptural passages where appropriate. As I had not yet studied the *Sutra of Upholding the World*, I appended seven brief reflections of my own, copying them into a single volume. Here, I have detailed the origins and transmission of this text to dispel doubts arising from lack of evidence, intending to share it with those of like mind.

Once the manuscript was complete, someone asked: ‘Is this Dao only to be practiced by those with a heart for saving the world? Could those who act out of private motives also practice it?’

Startled, I rose to my feet and said: ‘What are you saying! Acting with self-interest is a betrayal of the Dao—it must not be practiced. The Patriarch Lü once descended to the altar and warned: “In the function of the Two Qi, yang is virtue, yin is punishment. When moved by self-interest, one falls into yin. Impartiality and compassion are virtue; perversity and violence are punishment. If one’s heart is not set on benefiting others and saving people, yet seeks to guide the qi of Heaven and Earth with one’s own, the qi of punishment will be summoned in an instant. Heavenly demons will respond, heavenly spirits will strike, and the disaster will come swiftly—self-inflicted destruction, doomed for kalpas without reprieve, with no chance for regret.” Such is the clear teaching of the Patriarch.’

Thus, for those who study the Dao, rectifying the heart is the foremost principle. Let this serve as a mirror for those who would treat this book with frivolity.

Respectfully inscribed on the full moon of the fourth month in the year *wuzǐ* of Daoguang by Min Yide, Eleventh-Generation Successor of the Dragon Gate Orthodox Lineage.

**Original Preface**
In the beginning of the Great Origin, the Dao was established in Oneness.”

Firm yet unsupported, unshakable yet unattached. Without duality or division, without inside or outside, still yet not still, moving yet not moving. Before hardness and softness, vigor and compliance are distinguished, it is the source from which the utmost hardness, softness, vigor, and compliance arise. The Great Mother of all life, the origin of the Great Dao—this is called the True One.

The True One is the primordial essence, lively and unrestrained, its arising unstoppable. When it arises, it flows; when it flows, it becomes yang. Its return becomes yin. This arising and returning is the beginning of qi. Yang, being clear, ascends; yin, being turbid, descends. This clarity and turbidity is the beginning of form. Thus, the True One is the origin of Heaven and Earth, embodying the ten thousand things yet emptying them—this is the Limitless.

Only through nothingness is there no obstruction, and thus utmost spirit and clarity. Only through nothingness is there no entanglement or hindrance, and thus the capacity to contract and extend. Humans and all beings receive its principle of spirit and clarity as their nature, and its qi of contraction and extension as their destiny. The ten thousand things exist within nature and destiny, and nature and destiny exist within the True One. Beyond nature and destiny, there is no Dao; beyond nature and destiny, there is no teaching. The Three Teachings all emerge from the One.

Confucianism fulfills nature to establish destiny; Buddhism perceives nature to liberate destiny; Daoism completes nature to restore destiny. Confucianism penetrates the One; Buddhism returns to the One; Daoism attains the One. Yet at the pinnacle of their transformative power, none is distant or unattainable, flowing throughout the four great continents without cessation.

The Dao of Confucianism reaches the point of positioning Heaven and Earth and nurturing the ten thousand things, transforming wherever it passes and spiritually abiding wherever it remains. The Dao of Buddhism reaches the point of non-abiding generosity, with blessings and virtues filling the four directions, above and below, beyond all measure. The Dao of Daoism reaches the point where the ten thousand things act without refusal, give life without possession, work without claiming, and accomplish without dwelling.

Their fundamental purpose is to govern through non-action and benefit the world—how could this entail abandoning the self to engage with the world? Since the beginning of life, self and others share this one nature, this one destiny, and thus this one Dao. Though forms are separate, qi connects; when qi connects, nature and destiny reach their utmost. All that Heaven covers and Earth bears is connected through the breath of this one qi. When the Dao is within me, I am its master.

In its beginning, it possesses nothing; in its end, it omits nothing. Yet in its wondrous workings with the ten thousand things, it still possesses nothing. What Dao is this? It is the Dao of the True One. Perfecting oneself and perfecting things are both matters within the Dao. Only when the ten thousand things each rectify their nature and destiny is the full measure of the Dao realized. To leave the world and stand alone cannot be called the Dao—this is the origin of the teaching of *healing the world*.

The root canon of this teaching, *Healing the World*, has golden tablets and jade scrolls stored in the heavenly treasury, rarely seen in the world. This book in its entirety also includes expositions on Confucian, Buddhist, and *healing-the-world* teachings. The Great Preceptor Master Kunyang Wang heard from extraordinary persons that “Confucianism was destroyed in the Qin, Buddhism in the Jin, and they cannot be seen in the world today.” What circulates in the world now are merely the initial principles of the Daoist tradition for *healing the world*.

When Ancestor Lü remained in the world, he heard this teaching and expounded the meaning of the root canon, transmitting it to his dharma heirs. This is a commentary on the canon, not the canon’s text itself, and thus its language is plain and easily understood, though it does not yet address the profound subtleties and stages of practice within the canon. It merely sets forth the sequential steps for entering the Daoist tradition of *healing the world*!

Its essentials, along with those of the Confucian and Buddhist traditions, though differing in path, converge in the One. Thus, this book bears the name of the *Three Nis*. After Ancestor Lü ascended to the rank of Golden Immortal, he personally verified it with the Three Nis. These Three Nis, as celestial spirits, proclaimed the great Dao of assisting Heaven and Earth and praising transformation and nurturance, enabling those with aspiration for this Dao to hear, transmit, and follow it, so that generation after generation may enter the realm of benevolence and longevity.

Let those who read this book beware of treating it with frivolity! This book has long been preserved in the mountain’s collection, though it is unknown who took it away. When Ancestor Lü descended to the altar, he expounded its meaning in even greater detail, and so it is respectfully transcribed here, with a few words prefaced.

Respectfully inscribed on the first day of the first month in the year *jiǎchén* of Kangxi by Tao Taiding, Ninth-Generation Successor of the Dragon Gate Orthodox Lineage, at the Dragon Peak Mountain Chamber of Golden Canopy.

**Exposition on the Three Nis’ Teachings of Healing the World by Ancestor Lü**
Inscribed by Huang Shouzhong, Eighth-Generation Disciple of the Dragon Gate
Compiled by Tao Taiding, Ninth-Generation Disciple of the Dragon Gate
Annotated by Min Yide, Eleventh-Generation Successor
Collated by Shen Yang Yigong, Twelfth-Generation Disciple

Ancestor Lü was a fourth-generation dharma heir of Guan Yinzi of the Supreme Lord’s lineage. A descendant of the Tang imperial house, his original name was Li Qiong, courtesy name Boyu. To avoid the persecution of Empress Wu, he and his wife née Jin concealed themselves in the deep valleys of Mount Song, changing their surname to Lü, with the given name Yan and courtesy name Dongbin. After his wife’s passing, he took the sobriquet Pure Yang. A disciple of Ancestor Zhongli, he was later enfeoffed by Emperor Shizong of the Yuan as the Warning and Transforming, Trustworthy and Protective Lord.

The Three Nis are Confucius, the Tathāgata, and Laozi. The *Heart Seal Scripture* states: “The Green Ni attains the center; Zhongni [Confucius] embodies timely centeredness; Śākyamuni embodies emptiness. The Three Nis teach one another; Wen Ni assists in governance. The Three Nis transmit perfectly; Wen Ni praises this. Vastly spreading education, they aid the source of life and transformation.” This is the text of the primordial proclamation to Wen Ni.

The canon further states: “The Perfected One of Pure Yang, known as Wen Ni, holds the office of teaching and transformation.
