Thus, he was commanded to disseminate the Dao of the Three Nis to the world, secretly blessing the people below.” Ancestor Lü’s unification of Confucianism, Buddhism, and Daoism to propagate the teaching was mandated by Heaven, and thus his precious proclamation also honors him as the Teacher of the Three Teachings.

*The Teachings of Healing the World* encapsulate the profound essence of the Three Sages, nurturing the ten thousand things and reaching the heights of Heaven.

Since the dawn of creation, no Way in the world has surpassed this. Ancestor Lü expounded it to initiate the transformative teaching of boundless kalpas, embracing, protecting, benefiting, and bringing peace. Though the principles he set forth for beginning practice belong to the Mystery Gate, they ultimately do not depart from the foundational state of stillness and tranquility. Stillness and tranquility are the common gateway through which the Three Teachings enter; only the Daoist school’s methods are relatively simple and easy to understand, and thus he selected them to instruct others. As for fully realizing one’s nature, knowing destiny, and extending one’s merit to Heaven and Earth, the Three Nis share the same Way, all encompassed herein. Ancestor Lü committed this to writing and transmitted it to his disciples. Successive patriarchs treasured it, concealing it in the Dragon Ridge Mountain Chamber on Plum Island—a retreat once belonging to the Perfected Master of the Yellow Concealment Precepts. Its site remains today, approximately two *li* from Cloud Nest, on the eastern slope of Golden Canopy Peak.

The original preface to this work was composed by Precept Master Tao Shian, while its title was bestowed by the Perfected Master of Concealment. Entitled *Ancestor Lü’s Exposition on the Three Nis’ Teachings of Healing the World*, it clarifies that this book preserves the essence of the Three Sages’ original canon, with Ancestor Lü expounding its meaning to teach others.

**First Step in Teaching: Great Strength**

Drawing upon the *Yi*’s imagery to elucidate each step’s methods of practice, this is not to be taken entirely as discourse on hexagram qi or temporal sequences.

**“Great Strength profits from steadfastness.”**
“Great” is rectitude: within, *qian*; without, *zhen*. *Qian* is Heaven, the head; *zhen* is arousal—thus practice begins here.

**“The Thearch emerges from *zhen*.”**
The Thearch is Taiyi, the true ruler of Unity. *Zhen* and *xun* transform to reveal the “many white eyes”: when the gaze is directed toward the brain, it turns upward, hence the whiteness—meaning one should focus on the *qian* palace. *Zhen* is the movement of yang; intent is the heart’s issuance, the stirring of yang qi.

As if to say: first close the eyes, gather the spirit of the eyes, and direct it toward the brain in a single focus. The *Kuizhong* text concurs.

The phrase “as if to say” makes clear that this is not from the original canon. For the original canon is terse and profound, difficult to comprehend; Ancestor Lü expounds its meaning as if to say, “It is thus, it is thus.”

Precept Master Tao’s version omits the words “as if to say,” includes “slightly” before the next clause, adds “boundary” after “brain,” and renders “a single focus” as “preserve and guard.”

Ancestor Lü states: “What is preserved is the True Unity; what is guarded is the True Origin. True Unity is nature; True Origin is qi. The brain is the sea of marrow, and also the capital prefecture of celestial nature—just as above there is the Jade Clarity’s sublime realm, a realm of utmost purity, dwelling above the stars and moon, the Heaven of Great Nothingness. To know preservation and guarding is to naturally comprehend the Dao.”

Continuing from the brain’s center, direct it upward toward the crown. The Kuizhong manuscript reads the same. In Precept Master Tao’s version, “center” is rendered as “boundary,” the next clause includes “at the gate above,” and “direct it” becomes “a single focus.”

Ancestor Lü states: “The brain is the Jade Clarity Palace of the human body, where the Primordial Beginning dwells. The crown is called the fontanel gate, the acupoint named Hundred Meetings, the gathering place of the Three Origins, and the point where the True Unity of the Three Heavens above converges. Directing it toward the crown establishes resonance with the True Unity, causing the True Origin to converge and pour in, whereupon one may perceive red and yellow star-like specks descending like rain as verification.”

For the True Unity is formless; what becomes visible is the True Origin. The True Origin is the qi generated by the True Unity.

*Yi de* annotation: The *Rites* states: “It originates from the Great One, divides to become Heaven and Earth, revolves to become yin and yang, transforms into the four seasons, and arrays into ghosts and spirits. Its descent is called destiny, and its office is in Heaven.” The Great One is the True Unity, the governor of Heaven. The head is the celestial gate of the human body, and thus one must receive the *gan* at the head. The *Book of Changes* says “the origin of *gan*,” and “emerging foremost among the myriad things”—*gan* is Heaven and the head. The *Yu Shi Yi Yi* states: “*Gan* is nature,” the nature endowed by Heaven’s mandate. “Directing” with the eyes and mind is what the *Book of Shang* calls “gazing upon the bright mandate of Heaven,” and Master Zhu says, “constantly keeping one’s gaze upon it.” The *Buddhist Canon* speaks of the “Great Buddha’s Crown Dhāraṇī,” describing wisdom-light like the sun at the Buddha’s crown. It also says, “This is the Tathāgata’s invisible crown, the non-active mind-Buddha,” and “rubbing the crown to awaken understanding,” signifying that the light of human nature resides in the crown. When the Confucian and Buddhist methods of saving the world are examined through the classics, they align with the principles of this text as if sharing the same compass and square.

This is the first step of practice. The Kuizhong manuscript reads the same. In Precept Master Tao’s version, each step includes the words “method and practice.”

Ancestor Lü states: “Method is the rule; practice is the application.”

“First, close the eyes”—the eyes are the emissaries of the heart, commanding qi and spirit. The *Dharma Record* says: “The eye-spirit in Heaven becomes the two marshals Gou and Bi.” In the human body, when walking, it flows to the two Yongquan points; when seated, it flows to the two kidneys at the waist. “Closing” embodies the meaning of concentration. “Slightly” conveys the sense of “having as if not having.” Intent is the command of the heart-spirit; only when the command is issued does action follow, like an emperor’s edict. “Directing upward” implies piercing through the crown. This is how one directs and receives the origin of the True Unity to protect the body and the world.

Second step: expounding the method. *Guai*...

"Inner *gān* and outer *duì*. *The Uncollected Images* states: '*Gān* is spirit; *duì* is communication,' meaning the communication of spirit with qi. This conveys the principle of drawing the *gān* qi downward to establish connection. *Guài* means 'to decide,' where the firm decides the yielding—thus the Dao of the noble person grows while the Dao of the petty person wanes, the petty person being yin. The *quē* gate descends to connect with the abdomen, and the abdomen is yin. Drawing the *gān* yang downward to infuse it is how one decides yin.

This proceeds from *Bǎihuì*, descending to roam through *Quēpén*. The *Kuìzhōng* text concurs. Tao’s version reads: 'Continuing at the brain’s border, descending toward the chest hall.' *Bǎihuì* is an acupoint, located at the crown of the head. *Quēpén* is also an acupoint, situated in the chest.

Lü Zu states: 'Though intent is not mentioned here, it is implied within.' The word 'descend' signifies the principle of drawing and guiding the primordial unity downward. The meaning becomes self-evident in the following passage.

*Gān*: 'Primordial, prosperous, beneficial, and steadfast.' Primordial is the beginning; prosperous is unimpeded flow; beneficial is harmony; steadfast is correctness. 'Primordial' refers to the *Yi*’s generation of *fù* at the origin, delving into the profound to seek and guide—all things rely on this beginning. 'Prosperous' is yang communicating with yin. Each rectifies its nature and destiny to achieve benefit and steadfastness. Above the heart is yang; the abdomen is yin. The chest is the boundary where yang first communicates with yin, from which the profound mysteries of the world arise. One must not be agitated or disturbed. *Gān* contains hidden *kūn*, governing movement with stillness—this is how the body attains leisurely delight. The virtues of *gān* are firmness, strength, centrality, correctness, purity, and essence. These seven virtues enable one to awaken to the emptiness of form and appearance, utterly unattached.

Roaming through *Quēpén*, the body attains leisurely delight. The *Kuìzhōng* text concurs. Tao’s version reads: 'Abiding in the chest hall, utterly unattached.'

Yide notes: The *Yi* says, 'Clarity and brightness reside in the body'; the *Heart Sutra* says, 'The five aggregates are all empty'—these express the same Dao.

Lü Zu states: 'First, guard against impatience; second, guard against confusion; third, guard against recklessness. One must recognize that within this, there is fundamentally nothing—what person or self, what inner or outer? Radiant and unobstructed, penetrating heaven and earth, every single thing reveals its dynamic mechanism as it arises. Yet this revelation is not the essence of the heart. When it appears, do not examine it; when it recedes, do not pursue it—like floating clouds dotting the vast sky, passing and gone. What one should welcome is to preserve clarity to the fullest and harmoniously receive the three and five.'

This step is what the *Cāntóngqì* calls 'superior virtue.' Virtue is achieved through purity, emptiness, tranquility, and indifference—unstained by even a speck of dust. Gain and loss, being and non-being must not cling in the slightest; only then is the method attained. This is the second step in beginning practice.

Lü Zu states: 'In this step, myriad phenomena may arise. If one clings even slightly or is disturbed, the ruler of the mind becomes afflicted—this not only brings no benefit but causes no small harm. Moreover, the next step will have no place to begin. Beware!'

Yide privately observes: If one can embody the words 'roam' and 'leisure,' the meaning will naturally be grasped, and one’s practice will align with the ancestral teachings.

Third step: expounding the method.
*Gòu*..."

Within, it is Xùn; without, it is Qián. The *Tuan* says: "Gòu means encounter—softness encounters hardness." Yin is soft. "When hardness encounters central correctness, it greatly prevails throughout the world," meaning hardness overcomes softness. The fifth line is centrally correct, thus hardness encounters central correctness. Yin begins to arise, so it is fitting to restrain and illuminate. Gòu and Fù are mutually connected: in Fù, dragons and snakes all hibernate; in Gòu, the myriad things flourish—this is the principle of yin and yang mutually concealing one another.

The *Xiàng* says: "Heaven and earth encounter each other, and the species of things all become manifest," hence the myriad paths open as one. "Beneath heaven is wind," and no path remains obstructed. The cyclical phase reaches true noon, and the key lies solely in diligent illumination. The *Kuìzhōngshū* concurs. The Tao edition adds the words "after this" at the beginning of the first line, and the second line reads "the myriad paths open as one."

This speaks of the flourishing of the mid-Yuan phase, abundant and rich, with nothing lacking—yet one must fear the sun’s decline after noon and the moon’s waning after fullness, thus requiring the function of restraint and illumination. True noon corresponds in the world to the mid-Yuan, in the body to the heart, and in the stages of practice to the "living noon hour"—the moment when the first trace of yin arises, where restraint and illumination are fitting.

Dùn: within, it is Gèn; without, it is Qián.

The *Xiang* says: "Beneath heaven there is a mountain—*Dùn*. The noble one thereby distances petty persons, not through aversion but through solemnity."

The noble one refers to *Qián*; *Qián* is distant and solemn. At *wèi* (the eighth earthly branch), its position is already remote—remote yet solemn, this is the Way of rectifying the root and purifying the source. With yang rightfully positioned while yin gradually grows, there arises the image of partiality. Once *wèi* reaches its proper alignment, the root is rectified and the source purified.

The *Kuìzhōngshū* concurs. The Tao edition reads "若" (*ruò*, "if") for "已" (*yǐ*, "already"), and the following line as "便有偏颇" ("then partiality arises"), for this is the consequence of the people forgetting goodness. When the world has long been at peace, the people grow complacent in ease. Complacency in ease leads to forgetting goodness; forgetting goodness allows the seeds of evil to lie hidden—this is the natural course of events. One should embody the meaning of "rectifying the root and purifying the source" to find a starting point.

In my humble opinion: the method lies in welcoming the One to transform it, not merely in receiving the *kūn*-origin.

---

**Pǐ**
Within is *Kūn*, without is *Qián*.

The *Tuan* says: "Heaven and earth do not interact, and the myriad things do not communicate; within are petty persons, without are noble ones"—thus, outwardly strong but inwardly hollow. "Greatness departs, smallness arrives," so one must focus on nurturing and cultivation. This is the time when heaven and earth are closed off.

Once entering *shēn*-proper (the ninth earthly branch), nurturing and cultivation alone suffice.

The *Kuìzhōngshū* concurs. The Tao edition adds after "申正" (*shēn*-proper): "outwardly strong but inwardly hollow, thus matters require nurturing and cultivation," the meaning of which aligns with this text. For at *shēn*-proper, the phase corresponds to the beginning of the lower *Yuán*, when the people, long accustomed to ease, know no striving or diligence, lack foresight, indulge in frivolous customs, and value form over substance—hence "outwardly strong." Yet the people’s vitality is already depleted, and the hundred resources gradually exhausted—hence "inwardly hollow." Should calamity strike, they would rush headlong into peril, only hastening their ruin—truly lamentable. Those devoted to this Way must take nurturing and cultivation as their task, thereby anticipating and preventing disaster.

---

**Guān**
Within is *Kūn*, without is *Xùn*.

The *Xiang* says: "Wind moves over the earth—*Guān*. The former kings thereby toured the regions, observed the people, and established teachings."

*Guān* governs the transformation of the people, and thus must bring forth renewal. When the five positions remain unchanged, it is called "*A Great Vision Above*." Being near the *qián* line, it thus welcomes *qián*. The Tao edition states "forming the worthy kalpa," for within the *yǒu* hexagram lie *jiǎn* and *míngyí*, marking the hardships of the era. If one encounters *yǒu*-proper, the method lies solely in bringing forth renewal. The *Kuìzhōng* text concurs, while the Tao edition reads beneath "*yǒu*-proper": "the method lies in welcoming *qián* to form the worthy kalpa"—its meaning complementary to this text.

*Yǒu*-proper marks the middle phase of the lower *Yuán*, when old stains and corrupt customs prevail. One welcomes the *qián* energy to sweep them clean, enabling the people to renew themselves. Yet obstinacy and slander may still arise together. If the people renew themselves, then when the kalpa’s hardships arrive, great disasters are transformed into small ones—this is what is called the "worthy kalpa." Compared to the ravages of war and fire, is this not vastly preferable? Master Lǚ surely harbored profound intent here.

What is the "worthy kalpa"? It refers to famine, pestilence, epidemics, and deluges.

---
*Bō*
Inner *kūn*, outer *gèn*.
This is the *xū* hexagram.

The *Qiánzáodù* states: "When yin inflicts harm, its course corresponds to the ninth month’s season. Yang *qi* wanes and dissipates, yet yin ultimately cannot exhaust yang—petty men cannot decisively overcome noble ones." It is called *bō*, meaning merely "not at peace."

The *Tuan* says: "Unfavorable to have somewhere to go—petty men grow." *Kūn*...

Six lines all yin.
This is the *hài* hexagram.
Its hexagram virtue is yielding compliance, beneficial perseverance; its hexagram *qi* is extinguished and concealed in *guǐ*, an image of utmost obscurity—yang wholly vanishes.
Thus it bears the oracle of "treading frost, solid ice arrives."

*Xū* and *hài* form *bō* and *kūn*.
Here it is said, "The method lies only in *zhūn* and *méng* to await *fù*," setting aside the hexagram of the present time to speak of "applying the time’s use"—meaning at this moment one should only rest and nurture.
For *xū* and *hài* correspond to the body’s lowest extremity and the world’s lower epoch within the lower cycle; whether inwardly or outwardly, all should rest and nurture.
When the cycle reaches *xū* and *hài*, the method lies only in *zhūn* and *méng* to await *fù*.
The *Kuìzhōngshū* concurs.
The Tao edition renders the latter phrase as "*zhūn méng* alone," its meaning no different from this text.

*Zhūn* and *méng* are images of the myriad things in dark obscurity—one nurtures them only to await their return.
*Zhūn* has inner *zhèn* and outer *kǎn*: movement encountering peril, where kalpic hardships are manifold, thus *zhūn* benefits from abiding in perseverance.
*Méng* has inner *kǎn* and outer *gèn*: *kǎn*’s wisdom and *gèn*’s stillness, where the numinous nature is obstructed and the vital apertures unopened, thus *méng* nurtures correctness.

In the great cycle’s *xū* and *hài*, all things rest; in the small cycle’s *xū* and *hài*, it is likewise vital to rest and nurture primordial *qi*.
Master Lǚ said: "Tracing the cause of this, it all stems from loss of illumination and loss of cultivation"—speaking of the small cycle’s reversibility before its time.

Editor’s note:
The *Book of Changes* states, "The Way of all increase moves in step with the times"; the *Book of Documents* says, "The Dao rises and falls, governance reforms with custom"—this is Confucianism’s view of adversity and prosperity in the great cycle to heal the world.
The *Avataṃsaka Sūtra* says, "Pure radiance illumines the world, with unimpeded vows abiding through all kalpas, ever diligently benefiting all beings"; the *Śūraṅgama Sūtra* says, "Through kalpas as numerous as the Ganges’ sands, the world is wholly pacified"—this is Buddhism’s traversal of measureless cycles to heal the world.
This is the third step in practice.

The *Kuìzhōngshū* includes above this passage the seventeen characters: "Master Lǚ said: Tracing the cause of this, it all stems from loss of illumination and loss of cultivation." Yet in the preceding and following text, no "Master Lǚ said" appears—this must be a later hand recording a query to Master Lǚ, mistakenly inserted into the main text. Here it is incorporated into the prior annotation.

Editor’s further note:
In this text, the first two steps—from crown to chest—speak of the body, not the world.
In the third step’s division of the six hours, function reaches the *wǔ* position as the heart, governing both body and world; from *wèi* onward it pertains to the abdomen, to *Jambudvīpa*.
Worldly affairs differ, and methods of remedy differ accordingly, hence each hour is analyzed to clarify the use appropriate to the cycle.
The application of these six hours is all a matter of learning—one should enrich the Dao and its methods in times of non-use.
*Wǔ*, *wèi*, *shēn*, *yǒu*, *xū*, and *hài* all welcome and align with the *gān*’s infusion.
*Gān* is the ruler.
Only with learning that heals the world in accord with the times can one bear the world’s weight; only by regulating the primordial and aiding transformation can one ascend to rectify the ruler’s heart.
To engage in benefiting the people, one must first take rectifying the ruler as the primary task.

Fourth step: expounding the *Fù* hexagram.

Within, *Zhèn*; without, *Kūn*.
*Zhèn* is cultivation, introspection, and the attainment of fortune; *Kūn* is virtue harmonizing without bound.
The *Tuan* says: “In *Fù*, there is smooth progression. The firm returns in movement and proceeds with compliance—this is beneficial for any course, for the firm is growing.”
Yang returns to its origin and accords with Heaven’s movement; yin complies with it—this is the meeting of clarity and goodness.
Thereupon, the flower blooms to reveal the Buddha. By creating one’s own auspicious convergence, for ten thousand years hence, this is the fourth step in practice.

In *Kuìzhōngshū*, the edition by Tao reads “既乃” instead of “已而,” and adds two lines below: “Apart from wondrous efficacy, nothing lies beyond loyalty and steadfastness.” After “自造庆会,” it includes “得致.”
The flower is the heart-flower Buddha, a metaphor for the ruler.
“Blooming” signifies opening the heart to reveal sincerity—within, there is no rigid self, only guidance in accord with the moment. Rectification is not mere admonition but possesses the divine power of a red furnace melting snow.
“Nothing lies beyond loyalty and steadfastness” means that loyalty and steadfastness unify all in one virtue, with mutual trust between above and below, requiring no words or texts. Thus, it is called “self-created,” for sincerity is universally communicative.
Loyalty ensures inner and outer unity; steadfastness ensures unrelenting diligence day and night. Thereby, one fills the air with solemn harmony.
Ruler and ministers alike exist within this single *qi*—this is the above as virtue; the world likewise exists within this single *qi*—this is the below as the people. The distant shores and common folk unknowingly receive its hidden blessings.
Lǚ Zu said: “Only those who know how to welcome the One and the primordial can achieve this.”

A note on “One” states: The *Book of Documents* says, “Harmonizing yin and yang, reverently illuminating Heaven and Earth”; the *Śūraṅgama Sūtra* says, “In great bodhi, one attains thorough understanding, awakening to the Tathāgata and exhausting the Buddha’s realm”; the *Dhāraṇī of Upholding the World* says, “Benefiting and bringing peace to all sentient beings”—all share this same function.

Fifth step: expounding the *Lín* hexagram.

Inner *duì*, outer *kūn*.
*Duì* as joy, *kūn* as compliance—thus without gap.
*Yuán*, *hēng*, *lì*, *zhēn*.

The *Tuàn* says: “Joyful and compliant, firm in the center and responsive.”
“Joyful and compliant” is the origin of primordial unity;
“firm in the center and responsive” is the wondrously congealed virtue, the great flourishing through rectitude.

At this time, merit reaches seamless continuity—every action and measure aligns without deliberate planning, for the two *qi* have merged as one, will and spirit undivided. This is the wondrously congealed spiritual verification.

This is the fifth step of practice.

The *Kuìzhōngshū* and *Táo* editions concur; the *Wénzhèngzàng* edition differs slightly.

Lǚ Zu said: “Having reached this step, one should all the more forget self and others, allowing this upright *qi* of *qián* and *kūn* to billow and swirl, vast as heaven and earth. Only then does one attain this verification. Should discordant tendencies arise, one must welcome the primordial human to unblock it, double the welcoming of the *qián*-primordial to renew it, the *kūn*-primordial to harmonize it, and the quiescent essence of true oneness to unify it. Naturally, the ruler will be sagely and ministers virtuous, above and below as one *qi*, merit and practice unceasing. The attainment of grand harmony may be expected by the day.”

A note on “this” states: The *Book of Documents* says, “All share one virtue”; the *Vajracchedikā Sūtra* says, “Because it is without merit and virtue, the Tathāgata speaks of great merit and virtue”—all are this Dao.

Sixth step: expounding the *Tài* hexagram.

Within, *qián*; without, *kūn*. The *Tuan* commentary states: “Heaven and earth intermingle, and the myriad things communicate; above and below interpenetrate, and their aspirations unite.” The *Xiang* commentary states: “The lord thereby completes the Dao of heaven and earth, assists the fittingness of heaven and earth, and thereby guides the people.” With yin aiding yang and *kūn* upholding the mandate of *qián*, all undertakings flourish, and the realm enjoys the image of universal peace. At this stage of attainment, the court radiates harmony, all offices fulfill their duties, and the people’s hardships are known to the ruler. Proceeding further, one welcomes the true oneness to illumine all directions below. Then, one welcomes the *kūn*-primordial to nurture and the *qián*-primordial to unify. Products multiply, and the people’s conduct becomes gentle and compliant. This is the sixth step in practice. (*Note: "Compliant" should read "good."*)

The *Kuizhongshu* and *Tao* editions concur; the *Wenzhengzang* edition omits the following lengthy passage.

A note by Yide observes: The *Book of Rites* states, “Virtue is the beginning of one’s nature, reaching to heaven and coiling upon earth, moving through yin and yang and penetrating ghosts and spirits.” At this stage of practice, heaven and earth align, the four seasons proceed fittingly, the *gèn* hexagram embodies virtue, and the five grains thrive. The *Odes* says: “Truly the noble one, in great accomplishment,” uniting the Dao of inner and outer. The *Vajracchedikā Sūtra* states: “The Buddha speaks of the non-body as the great body, containing the great thousand worlds in a single grain.” The *Amitābha Sūtra* states: “In the land of Amitābha Buddha, beings know no suffering but only joy—hence it is called *Ultimate Bliss*.” All exemplify the Dao residing in one body while its effects extend to all beings, the pattern of boundless bestowal. The world-healing Dao of both Confucian and Buddhist traditions is fully encompassed in this text.

Master Lü states: “This is the ultimate work of nurturing the world, the consummate task of the sage—yet it does not depend on anything external. The six directions and nine provinces do not lie beyond the belly of *kūn*; breath can connect them, and all may learn this. The key lies in resolute purpose; guard against acting on private cleverness!” He further says: “Heaven and earth have no mind; they entrust their mind to humans. Humans can thus act, and action must bear fruit.” And again: “Know that the world’s fortunes have upper, middle, and lower phases, just as humans have youth, prime, and old age. No one wishes to remain forever old, so how could heaven and earth not wish to remain in their upper and middle phases? The perfected one embodies this, hence this teaching is left for those of aspiration. Yet there is a principle most profound, never before revealed. I once heard this teaching and secretly awaited its fulfillment; only after attaining the Dao in full did I realize that my former efforts were insufficient. Now I can only transmit this teaching (*‘transmit this’* indicates it is not the original text of the scripture, but the master’s exposition for others) for those who will follow in these steps. You disciples, do not press for exhaustive inquiry (*the meaning suggests this Dao is vast; even immortals cannot fully hear it, so mortals should not demand to probe its secrets. The master’s compassion allows us to hear this transmission—is this not the fortune of three lifetimes?*). For now, I will explain in detail the foundation of what can be achieved.”

He continues: “The *Cantong Qi* and *Wuzhen Pian* suffice to perfect destiny; the *Changdao Zhenyan* suffices to perfect nature; the *Dadong Yujing* suffices to transform the ordinary; the *Sanni Yishi* suffices to verify fruition. Yet in studying the first two texts, one encounters many hidden secrets and risks straying onto wrong paths. The *Dadong Yujing*, though concise in meaning, transforms one’s *qi* and disposition with wondrous efficacy. Combined with the *Changdao Zhenyan* to refine the mind, the Three Treasures become pure. Then, one may study the *Cantong Qi* and *Wuzhen Pian* to perfect destiny, and the *Yishi* to verify fruition. To verify fruition is to verify through practice—what greater practice exists than the *Sanni Yishi*? Alas!”

"A wronged village woman may halt the rains for three years—such is the power of misfortune, and so too is the power of fortune. I have personally printed and disseminated the *Sanni* texts, and all confirm: thus it is, thus it is.

The *Sanni* further states: 'If the cultivation of nature is incomplete, verification lacks purity; if the cultivation of destiny is incomplete, attainment lacks firmness; if *qi* and disposition remain unrefined, efficacy lacks wonder. Only when the Three Treasures are fully perfected and one returns to the primordial can this be realized through human practice.'

This is the most profound of profound principles—something I had never heard before. Now you may awaken to it. Otherwise, how careless are the two great forces in their self-governance! How lax are the myriad sages in their shared reverence! Is this not the greatest enigma since the dawn of existence?

From this moment onward, seize the years, months, and days of this life. Practice diligently without cease, exhaust this karmic form to verify fruition—is this not fitting?

Yet to treat illness, one must know its source. Without knowing the source, how can one begin? The two great forces are without mind or desire. Nevertheless, they favor life, but excess life leads to depletion.

In medicine, there is the method of supplementing the child when the mother is ailing, and supplementing the mother when the child is ailing. To preserve the ultimate and renew the people is one method; to cherish the people and ward off disaster is another. Only in this *Yishi* (healing of the world) does there exist a cyclical remedy, infinitely applicable, costing not a single coin, expending not a thread of effort, achieved through stillness—perfecting merit and ascending on high.

Rather than pursuing the three thousand merits and eight hundred deeds, which rely on human effort, is it not better to act upon a single thought, freely wielding control with a method that is not cumbersome? To instead squander time in emptiness—is this not delusion?

The time is now, the time is now—do not wait!" Thus was revealed in the third year of Daoguang.

Moreover, it is said: "When the two great primals return to their origin, all things flourish and humankind prospers. When humankind prospers, all things flourish; when all things flourish, humankind prospers—is this not an age of great peace? Does this not embody the principle of mutual healing? Why then hesitate?

In ancient times, on Mount Guye (pronounced *Yi*), the divine being surnamed Xu, named Jing, styled Ziyou, pioneered the healing of the two great primals during the reigns of Yao and Shun. As a result, the Great Flood was pacified and the Miao people submitted—is this not clear proof? (This is also recorded in the *Questions and Answers of Ge and Lu*.) Even more renowned is the *Buddha’s Sutra of the Dhāraṇī for Upholding the World*, personally bestowed upon the elder Miaoyue in the kingdom of Jiao Mi. To this day, the Western Regions continue to benefit from its grace, as attested in the Buddhist canon. (Peng Chimu’s *Random Notes on the Buddhist Canon* also cites this.) How immeasurable are its merits and virtue!

Within our lineage, only the Seven Masters of the Northern School have attained immortality through this Dao. Yet all people may study it. In the past, without the august decree of the Jade Pure Divine Mother, it was kept secret and dared not be revealed. Now, however, having received her decree, it has been proclaimed throughout the Three Heavens and universally enjoined across the Three Realms, permitting its transmission without distinction of gender. The Three Heavens and Three Realms patrol day and night, protecting those who sincerely uphold it. Where there is sincerity, there is response; no demonic force may interfere. Truly, this is an encounter unprecedented since the dawn of time—a stroke of fortune for the cosmos and for countless generations to come.

Yet it is essential to lead by example. The remaining secrets take the union with the True One as their foundation, and all efficacy begins with the practice of *taixi* (embryonic breathing). I know this Dao will not remain hidden forever, which is why I once revealed these teachings and preserved them in the Longqiao Mountain Chamber of this mountain. Now, I fully disclose what was previously unspoken. You disciples must reverently adhere to this, taking care not to harbor even the slightest expectation of immediate results. What is unverified will verify itself—such is the principle, such is the Dao."

Thus were the instructions of Ancestor Lü. Those devoted to this Dao, upon reading this book, will surely awaken what was previously unawakened and embody it through diligent practice. May the Three Ni silently witness this.

This compilation gathers the lost teachings of Ancestor Lü, elucidating the original intent of this book. The remainder is largely drawn from the *Inner Collection of the Orthodox Dao of Heavenly Immortals*, compiled and edited by Minister Jiang Yuanting. In his postscript, Minister Jiang wrote: "I have heard that on Wuhua Mountain in Yunnan, there is a *Sutra on Healing the World Spoken by the Ancestral Master*, which seems to align with the profound meanings indicated in the *Inner Collection*. Though I have sought it extensively, I have not yet obtained it. If found, I intend to place it at the forefront of the *Inner Collection*, for it must contain essential mysteries. Its absence from the *Daoist Canon* is a lacuna."

In my humble opinion, what the Minister heard may refer to the version from Mount Jizu, transmitted through hearsay, hence the mention of a "sutra." Upon examining Master Tao’s original preface, however, the secrets are not sutra texts, and calling it *Ancestor Lü’s Healing of the World* is also a misnomer. I note this for future verification.

**A Humble Inquiry into Ancestor Lü’s *Exposition on the Three Ni’s Healing of the World***
*By Min Yide of Mount Jingai*

**I.**
According to the *Exposition on Healing the World*, Ancestor Lü received the teachings from the Three Ni. Master Tao Shian stated that these were the celestial spirits of the Three Sages, expounding the great Dao of "participating in Heaven and Earth, assisting in transformation and nourishment." Ancestor Lü heard and recorded it to transmit to others. Its main purport is nothing other than healing the world through the body—this Dao is not a mere method.

From my humble perspective, it is rooted in the very source of the Three Powers. The scripture on healing the world is a treasure of the Jade Pure Realm. Its profundity rivals the *Scripture of the Jade Chapters of the Great Cavern*, which ordinary people find difficult to comprehend and must not be recklessly transmitted. Thus, the Ancestor did not disclose the original text but merely conveyed its teachings to sincere seekers of the Dao. Fearing that learners might not know where to begin or when the altar would descend, he explained at length: one should first complete destiny through the *Triple Concordance* and *Awakening to Reality*, transform the mortal through the *Jade Scripture of the Great Cavern*, and refine the mind through the *True Words of Chanting the Dao*. Only then, by attaining fruition through the *Three Ni’s Healing of the World*, can the meaning of the healing scripture be inwardly realized, and its practice proceed in proper sequence. By grasping its general principles, earnest scholars may undertake it with reverence, continuing the heart-learning of the Three Ni, accumulating merit through repeated practice—bestowing benefit without expense, grand yet not boastful. This is the ladder to celestial immortality.

I have quietly reflected on this: to heal the body is to heal the world; one must first cultivate the root. When the root is cultivated, merit advances. What is the secret? Empty the self of form, unify the self with qi and spirit, and guard this like an egg. Over time, inner and outer become seamless, spirit complete and qi abundant, transforming essence. When the body’s spirit and qi are vigorous, all undertakings will succeed, with no fear of failure or interruption. With further practice, one becomes free of all attachments, forgetting both body and world, returning to the Great Void. When the work is complete and gathered in, one fully restores the primordial, contracting this body and this world into the ancestral aperture, and serenely ceases. At this moment, both body and world benefit, and thereafter, one’s power steadily increases, naturally progressing from restraint to verification to attainment.

What must be constantly examined is this: the body must be upright, the mind single-pointed, conduct firm and unwavering, and one must place the world’s rise and fall beyond concern.

**II.**
In my past practice, whenever I reached the state of forgetting both body and world, a vision would arise: the upper half was utterly clear, the lower half harmoniously turbid, boundless and empty. Turning inward to observe this body, limbs and organs were entirely void, yet I perceived white as akin to Heaven, black as akin to Earth. There were transformations of stirring the turbid and lifting the clear, flowing between movement and stillness. In stillness, I embodied this: the lower realms unfolded like a chessboard. In deeper stillness, I saw a bustling scene, as if dust motes in a sunlit window.

Having taken these signs of qi-mechanism as evidence and inquired of Ancestor Lü, Ancestor Lü replied: “What first appeared to you was the Supreme Ultimate of the Three Powers in undifferentiated unity; what then manifested in inward illumination was the Supreme Ultimate of the single body. The subsequent profusion of visions, unfolding in succession, were the mysterious reflections of the myriad Supreme Ultimates of worlds and eons contained within the undifferentiated Supreme Ultimate—all gathered and governed within the single heart-mind. Only by embodying without fixation, perceiving without attachment, and practicing the work day and night without interruption can the true unity of the Three Powers be felt and descend to merge below. Then, and only then, may one apply the inner function.

If the true unity has not yet been met, you should follow these signs as verification, further emptying and stilling the heart-mind, placing these primal images of the true origin beyond seeing and hearing, so as not to be obstructed by the primal. In time, the true unity may naturally be attained. I rejoice that you have gained this without recourse to imagination, that the mysterious reflections have imprinted upon the heart-mind without stirring thought, and that you have added stillness to embodiment—this does not betray the recommendation of the Great Void. Strive on!

What you have now obtained, though still a mysterious reflection, will no longer be mere reflection once the true unity is attained. Yet how can this true unity be measured by years and months? Alas! The mysterious reflection has entered the chamber—this is the threshold of progress in practice. Strive on!”

“This pertains to an event in the sixteenth year of the Jiaqing reign. As it marks the essential stage through which all beginners in practice must pass, I record it here to serve as a guide for fellow seekers on the path.

Thirdly, when first embarking on the Dao, one perceives black and white, witnesses ascent and descent—these are the subtle signs, yet the true measure lies in self-realization. If the heart-mind harbors intention, it falls into illusion and delusion; thus, attaining the vision of the True Unity is the ultimate aim. The True Unity cannot be grasped by holding, yet abides when embodied. What was spoken of above is the True Origin. As for the Origin itself: when held by the One, it serves inwardly to govern the body and outwardly to govern the world. Fundamentally, it is a single qi, yet divides into two—light and pure ascends, heavy and turbid descends—this is the natural Dao. The perfected person must investigate its source: by principle, stillness yields clarity, movement yields turbidity, yet this alternation of movement and stillness is not without a spirit that governs it. In humans, this governor is called the heart-mind, the most numinous of entities, which relies on a single thought to settle—this is what is called *zhi* (resolve). The noble person values the establishment of resolve, for the attainment of worthiness and sagehood depends on the steadfast power of this resolve. Knowing this, one possesses a method for governing the heart-mind. The method for governing the heart-mind is encompassed in four words: firmness, vigor, centrality, and uprightness. What is firmness? What is vigor? What is centrality? What is uprightness? Inwardly inquire of the heart-mind, and it will be perfectly clear, for the celestial endowment of *xing* (nature) resides within. Centrality is the substance of *xing*; firmness and vigor are its function. *Xing* is the heart-mind of Heaven. Understanding this, one has a means for preserving and nurturing, and a grasp of the central principle.

If one’s resolve has not yet reached its goal, I have privately heard the master’s teachings, which instruct disciples to follow the *Chantings of the True Dao* for self-purification. Thereby, the substance of the heart-mind becomes greatly illuminated, and one naturally discerns the sequence of qi mechanisms. Obstruction in the qi mechanism stems from the burdens of physical form; reverently upholding the Jade Scripture transmutes the qi and substance of one’s nature. By consulting the *Contemplation* and *Awakening* texts, one avoids being misled by metaphorical language, and the seven emotions all return to the uprightness of the single *xing*, thereby fulfilling one’s endowment. With undivided focus, one may apply this to healing the world—entering and exiting transformation with divine skill. Near at hand, it governs a single household or village; farther afield, a county or prefecture. Pushed to its utmost, the four great continents are all harmonized within this square inch of the heart-mind. Dispelling calamities and pestilence, there will be no floods, fires, warfare, locusts, or plagues. Correcting the direction of human endeavor, customs are universally transformed, people are renewed, the populace is at peace, and all things flourish—radiantly, as if ascending a spring terrace. Small application yields small effects; great application yields great effects. Such is the Dao, yet its application depends on the person. Humans receive the qi of Heaven and Earth, and thus connect with and move the qi of Heaven and Earth. Human qi is the pivot of the two qi of Heaven and Earth. If the work of *xing* and *ming* (nature and life) is not yet complete, the qi lacks numinosity; once the work of *xing* and *ming* is complete and the four great elements are emptied, there is no longer any basis for action. Thus, even the celestial immortals yield their authority to humans. This is why humans are one of the Three Powers.

Fourthly, know that Heaven and Earth are not without heart-mind—they are not merely inert masses. They are spoken of in terms of their natural Dao. When one performs good deeds, a hundred blessings follow; when one performs evil deeds, a hundred misfortunes follow—all is the natural Dao. Yet who holds the handle that brings misfortune or blessing? It is wielded by humans, and Heaven follows. Thus, it is evident that humans possess the power to transform creation. Why is this so? For going against the Dao brings misfortune, while following it brings fortune. Heaven is fundamentally without heart-mind; it is humans who summon their own fate. Indulging desires leads to going against the Dao and misfortune; dispelling perverse qi leads to following the Dao and fortune. The power of transformation lies with humans, and it depends on those who can shift and move it. When the single qi is turned, all human hearts turn with it; when human hearts turn, the heart-mind of Heaven also turns. What is meant by ‘entrusting’ is not an external delegation. The Three Powers and the single qi are originally one entity. In terms of form, there are three, yet qi forms each according to its kind—this is the Great Ultimate. The light and pure naturally return to Heaven; the heavy and turbid naturally return to Earth, each following its kind. That which endlessly generates the clear and turbid is the True Origin; that which subtly refines the clear and turbid is the True Unity. The noble person, knowing this, welcomes and unites them, transforming them to return each to the primordial state—this is the key to attainment.

This True Unity, though dwelling among the multitude, is not different; though standing alone, is not solitary. It is shared yet distinct, distinct yet united. For the Origin and the Unity are one yet not one, two yet not two. Speaking of the True Unity apart from qi, and of the True Origin in conjunction with qi: the qi of the heart-mind of Heaven is called the True Origin; the governor of the True Origin is called the True Unity. The True Unity is the heart-mind of Heaven. The heart-mind of Heaven is formless; when bestowed upon humans, it takes form—this is the True Unity. The True Origin possesses qi; by means of the heart-mind, one welcomes the Unity; by means of the Unity, one commands the Origin. Heaven forges forms with the True Unity and True Origin; we cultivate forms with the True Unity and True Origin, allowing each to dwell in peace—this is called healing the world, the study of *xing* and *ming*. Acting yet not acting means exhausting the heart-mind and *xing* to achieve it. Whether results are obtained or not, one does not seek others’ knowledge. The extent of time and space determines the level of fruition. The noble person preserves the heart-mind, uniting inner and outer to perfect the Dao, without calculating efficacy—how much less the merits of the human world! For this is a matter of one’s inherent nature. If there is any self-interested motive, one cannot speak of the Dao. Scholars are the foremost of the four classes of people because they bear the responsibility of transforming the populace. Having heard of this Dao, can one not strive?

Fifthly, this Dao is to be sought in the midst of settled stillness, silently observing the flow and obstruction of the qi mechanism. Once it is fully harmonized, guard the clarity and brightness within the body.”

There exists a principle of harmonizing cultivation of nature and life, within which the art of governing the world is fully encompassed. Having once studied this, I gained some personal insight.

When the heart-mind is focused upon the crown, extending from the crown to the chest, one upholds the primal head to awaken the heart—this is the image of enlightened ruler and loyal minister. Then, from the chest it extends to the abdomen, upholding the celestial heart to govern the people below—this is the work of peace and salvation. Speaking of the single body, this is the method of unifying the Governing and Conception Vessels.

Proceeding from the lower extremity, it pierces the tailbone, ascends along the spine, penetrates the Jade Pillow, rises to Kunlun, and settles in the Mud Pill. With a single thunderous shock of celestial thunder, sweet dew abundantly descends, and the five viscera become cool and clear. At this moment, the Conception and Governing Vessels have merged; celestial qi descends as earthly qi ascends. Warmth and nurturance give rise to growth, embracing vastness and brilliance. All things flourish, above and below achieve harmony, court and countryside are no longer divided. The people draw close to their superiors, their bellies are filled and wealth is stored among the people. The earth does not withhold its treasures; ascending to the celestial court, rich blessings overflow, returning to the Flowery Pond. Abiding to protect the Crimson Palace, the lower flows upward in communication—this is how great harmony is achieved.

Thereupon, Qian and Kun converge in mutual ascent, continuously illuminating and infusing. Customs are transformed, the people renewed—how splendidly flourishing! Tracing the cause of this attainment, there is a True Unity that governs within. This Dao may be called the precious raft of ascending immortality, or equally the divine work of governing the world. Yet without attaining utmost emptiness and maintaining profound stillness, with strength fully developed, it cannot be practiced.

Master Lü said: “If the crown is not known in storage, storage does not reach fulfillment; if the chest is not known in storage, storage does not reach fulfillment; if the abdomen is not known in storage, storage does not reach fulfillment—these three are not yet open. If the lower extremity is not known in storage, storage does not reach its utmost, and the latter three will not be opened. When the three threes are open, half the work is done. To become an immortal and govern the world, one must attack and re-attack; the latter half of the work lies in closing the Xun wind.”

Note: *Attack* here means focused cultivation. *Xun wind* refers to the breath of the nose. The nose has two nostrils; when fully closed, qi does not leak through the nose but ascends and descends directly along the Yellow Path, rendering the nose as if superfluous—this is called “closing.” This is the verification of utmost emptiness and profound stillness, embodying the meaning of Mencius’ “direct nourishment.”

What is nourished? It is this True Unity—what Mencius called “that which is greatest and most unyielding, filling the space between heaven and earth.” “Had it not been for the man of Song,” one would have attained it.

---

Sixthly

I recall when I first studied this method, not yet fully understanding. I simply crossed my legs, straightened my body, emptied my heart-mind, leveled my qi mechanism, and calmly guarded the lower extremity. Once I felt full harmony, a gradual warmth arose, as if from moxibustion. Maintaining the same calm guard, I sensed this warm qi surging upward behind me. I silently preserved it without aiding it.

After some time, I felt the lower extremity expand broadly, the qi mechanism unobstructed. Knowing it was about to ascend through the barrier, I recognized the tailbone as the gate. Gently applying the method of lifting the lower and raising the upper, I followed the mechanism’s natural flow. Suddenly, my spine was no longer a spine but vast as an open thoroughfare, smoothly ascending for tens of miles.

Exquisite blossoms lined the path. There were pedestrians, riders, sedan-chair bearers, straw-hatted travelers, and those carrying burdens while riding—shoulders and wheels jostled like a bustling metropolis. Among them, officials in ceremonial caps and carriages gathered in clouds, supplies converged like spokes on a wheel. Even those with tattooed foreheads and filed teeth arrived in succession, presenting the spectacle of myriad nations offering tribute to the divine capital.

Suddenly, a white rainbow arose from the Northern Sea, advancing with a solemn sound toward the towering southern peaks. My primordial spirit followed it and saw the mountain’s summit vast and level, with palaces standing at its center—gold and jade gleaming, radiant with brilliant light, a world apart. This is what Daoists call Kunlun and Buddhists call Tusita, the true head of the human body.

I dared not linger there. Soon, a crimson glow illuminated the southern sky, rumbling like thunder. Knowing it was the Celestial Stem, with a resounding crash it struck the white rainbow, merging into one. A long bridge spanned the void, adorned with feathered canopies and banners, bustling with movement.

Then, wind carried resonant music, rich and majestic—celestial melodies, which I dared not fully heed. I saw immortals in starry crowns and feathered robes, divine birds and sacred beasts, encircling in splendid array, resplendent as a circular painting, suffusing the space with radiance.

At that moment, my heart fluttered with excitement. I concentrated my spirit to steady it, and suddenly all vanished into darkness, as if night had fallen. My heart stirred slightly, disturbed by the cries of tigers and apes. After maintaining stillness for a long time, a great sound suddenly arose, swift as thunder. Knowing it was the mechanism of *bo* and *fu*, I calmed my heart and awaited it. A slight sweet dew descended, perfuming my entire body with sandalwood fragrance.

Remaining motionless, light suddenly dawned. I saw a thousand miles of fertile land, cities arrayed in rings, their grandeur magnificent—this was what Buddhist scriptures call the Heaven of the Thirty-Three and Daoist texts call Yintuo. With reverence, I rose, and indeed saw celestial deities in imperial robes descending with solemn escort.

I prostrated myself, welcoming the True Unity to spread protection over the celestial palace. After a while, I suddenly felt my body carried away by clouds, far from the Gate of Heaven. Looking back, the celestial palace dazzled with five colors. Below, the great earth appeared like a chessboard. Gazing far and wide, embroidered lands intertwined, mountains and rivers crisscrossed—this was the world below. Auspicious clouds descended, auspicious light intertwined, covering the great thousand worlds like brocade.

Focusing my spirit to observe carefully, the bustling crowds seemed as numerous as grains of millet or ants. As I drew nearer, they became as clear as if placed in my palm.

At that moment, in my heart and eyes, the multitudes were no longer multitudes but manifestations of my single self. The sorrows, joys, delights, and sorrows of the people were no longer separate but personally experienced by my single self. This is the true realm of merging the myriad into one, where self and other are undivided.

For this true realm embraces all beings, filling heaven and earth with spring—where the qi of the Three Primes wondrously converges and congeals. This body and this world alike dwell within the soaring harmony of Great Peace. Alas, at that time, I had not yet fully embraced the True One, nor had I been refined amidst the teeming multitudes.

In emptiness and stillness, I turned my gaze inward and entered the state of primordial oneness. After a long, long while, my original spirit emerged from samadhi. My body remained cross-legged as before, yet my countenance had suddenly transformed—I had become youthful once more, my beard and hair turning from white to black. This occurred on the Winter Solstice of the eighteenth year of the Jiaqing reign.

My learning is shallow, my cultivation insufficient—how could I dare claim this benefits the world? Humbly, I presented the realm I had experienced to Patriarch Lü, who said, *"You have attained it. If you practice without slackening, there will surely be verification."*

The above-described realm need not be rigidly adhered to, for each person’s spiritual attainment and strength differ—one cannot seek the steed with a painted image.

**Seventh Chapter**
According to this book, withdrawing from the world to cultivate the body can indeed lead to immortality. Yet even within a single body, one may encompass an entire lifetime of healing—both body and world thus bear merit, and fruition is attained. This is truly a case of killing two birds with one stone.

The subtle workings of this path were previously outlined in broad strokes. What must be emptied and purified are mundane emotions, mundane impulses, delusive perceptions, and delusive knowledge. What must be embraced and preserved are the True One within Qian and Kun, the primal elements of heaven and earth.

For Qian without Kun cannot harmonize, and Kun without Qian cannot clarify. To know only how to embrace Qian and Kun, yet not the True One at their center, is like boiling an empty cauldron with fire and water—there is no principle by which the elixir can be obtained or immortality achieved. The reason? There is nothing within the center!

What, then, is this *thing*?

The True One is this. When the True One is attained, there is a master within, and all actions are without bias—this is the guiding principle of *Governing the World through Medicine*. Practice it sincerely, and within the method lies another method, for nothing is beyond the True Self that sustains it. By means of one’s own truth, one resonates with the truth of the Three Powers; reversing the course, one restores the Great Ultimate. Where decadence has caused depletion, one carefully harmonizes and regulates, maintaining balance throughout. One should not count the years, nor measure the effects, but persist until the end of this borrowed body.

Among the ancients whose practice was recorded in the classics, there was Zhang Ya, styled Shanxun, of Wu and Kuaiji during the Zhou dynasty. He secretly applied the Dao of governing the world through medicine to achieve worldly merit, silently assisting the Duke of Zhou and the Duke of Shao during the reign of King Cheng. His Dao harmonized with governance, and his blessings were boundless; thus, he attained the fruition of the Wenchang rank. The events are recorded in the *Precious Record*, and the original preface to the *Wenchang Great Cavern Immortal Scripture* also cites them, said to have been written by the hand of the Perfected Lady Hua Wei.

Once, having received my late teacher’s instruction, I diligently pursued the welcoming of the primal elements but had not yet focused on welcoming the One. This was because my nature was not yet fully illuminated, and I feared the True One might not respond in harmony. Moreover, I had not yet heard the profound principles within, and so I waited in vain, hoping to receive further secret teachings before proceeding. Yet the efficacy of welcoming the primal elements had already manifested in divine signs.

In the region where I long resided, spring flowers bloomed again in autumn—not once or twice, but three, four, or five times. At places such as Yunchao of Jingai, the Dade Nunnery, Lianhua Nunnery, and Baoyuan Charity Hall in Gusu; the Tianzhu Abbey and Banzhi Nunnery in Yuhang; the Jining Pavilion in Wulin; and Xiaopenglai in Shanghai, apricot, peach, magnolia, redbud, yulan, quince, crabapple, and other trees blossomed in autumn, resplendent and fragrant, as lush as the third month of spring. All witnessed this, and poems were composed in celebration. The "Ninetieth-Ninth Peach Blossom" was a verse bestowed by Master Lü, which many scholars echoed. These events occurred in the sixteenth, seventeenth, and eighteenth years of the Jiaqing reign.

At Jingai, the flowering trees were especially abundant, covering the foothills in clusters. During this decade, mulberry trees in the Wu and Shen households bore fruit again in late spring for seven years. At Jingai’s riverside dock, there was an elderly man from Jiaxing named Tong Hongyi, feeble and lame. A divine physiognomist had predicted his lifespan would end in the twelfth lunar month of that year, though he was already seventy. Upon finding winter mulberries ripening on the trees there, he consumed a handful and suddenly regained his strength, discarding his cane to walk into the mountains. He traveled over seven *li* with the lightness of flight, returning with a *dou* of fruit. The deep purple ones he used to prepare pills and wine, which he took regularly; the lesser ones he included in medicinal formulas for distribution. Diseases treated with them were cured instantly. Thereafter, he came each year at the appointed time to gather them, saving countless lives in peril.

His friend Mo Dacheng suffered from a blood tumor on his head, as large as a fist, its skin soft and thin like a ripe persimmon. The elder gave him a cup of mulberry wine to drink; shortly after swallowing it, the itching became unbearable, but the tumor immediately flattened and vanished. Moved, Mo vowed with the elder to raise funds for paving a stone path of over twelve hundred steps into the mountain, constructing two stone bridges and a roadside pavilion. The pavilion was named "Stop," and Master Lü descended to inscribe the plaque. Originally, Song Meizichun had often stayed there, and Zhao Mengfu had named the pavilion "Crane Stop." Now rebuilt, Master Lü wished to teach people the meaning of knowing when to stop, hence the new name. Bao Weiyuan, the prefect of Qiantang, composed the stele inscription, detailing the meritorious deeds of building the bridges and path. Liang Shanzhou, the Academician, wrote the calligraphy.

That spring, red knotweed and willow suddenly sprouted in the courtyard of the mountain abbey. Now the willows have grown into shade, and the red knotweed blooms every year.

The willow leaves could cure malaria, and red knotweed, when added to yeast for brewing wine, could relieve abdominal distension. To this day, those afflicted with illness in Jia, Hu, Hang, and the surrounding prefectures come to gather them, calling the willow "Divine Willow" and the knotweed "Immortal Knotweed." When asked about this, Master Lü replied: "They grew through the transformation of qi, and such things have existed since ancient times. The matter is recorded in the *Annals of Jingshan*, concerning the affair of National Preceptor Yiguo—nothing strange in it. Yet it may serve as one piece of evidence for the advent of the Yuan era. The peach blossoms of the double-nine festival are noted in the *Sequel to the Monthly Commands of Literary Evidence*, recounting the tale of Lin Shichen and the Ling Su of Guangling. I composed a poem on the subject, which is recorded there, and the poem I inscribed today follows the original Guangling rhyme scheme. This is not merely a phenomenon that accompanies the advent of the Yuan; the autumn peaches bloom yearly, flourishing in lush abundance, much like the scenery of old Guangling. Strive on, all of you."

He added: "Do you know why Lin Shichen, though a master of the esoteric *Lingqin Record* and a patriarch of his age, left only scant evidence behind? The reason is twofold: first, he sought to establish a private reputation while propagating the great Dao; second, after answering the imperial summons, he repeatedly displayed his powers through miracles."

Rejecting the true Unity and falsely claiming dependence—this is the third reason. Had he refused the imperial summons and secretly embraced the true Unity to heal the world, petty villains would have vanished in obscurity, and the realm would have known great peace—could his merit then have been measured? Deluded, he failed to follow the ancients. Though I have repeatedly instructed him, his notion of dependence remains unshakable, preventing him from ascending directly to the celestial thoroughfare. What a pity!”

This was recorded on the Winter Solstice of the twenty-first year of Jiaqing.

My learning remains inadequate, yet I have been graciously commended by the ancestral master. The responses manifest in plants and trees are visible to all, so I record this to encourage fellow seekers. As for what lies beyond common knowledge—doing what must be done—I do not wish to speak of it to outsiders.

**Postscript to *Master Lü’s Three Nuns’ Techniques for Healing the World***

The printed edition in my chest originally lacked hexagram diagrams. The manuscript copy I obtained from the Zhu family includes hexagrams preceding each step, leading some to suspect they were added later by Daoist practitioners. I maintain that the manuscript has circulated for generations and should not be altered, so I have annotated the hexagram meanings while preserving them.

Some have questioned: “The world’s afflictions are manifold, and the methods for healing it are equally varied. To avert droughts and floods, dispel pestilence, suppress warfare, eradicate disease, rescue from fires and floods, and defend against great disasters—all require vast spiritual powers and mighty techniques: talismans, mantras, and inexhaustible responses to each crisis. Yet this book proposes a single method to cure all ills—is this not overly simplistic? Or does the full text contain all necessary techniques, which you have not yet seen?”

I replied: “What you describe are *techniques*; this book speaks of the *Dao*. I know it does not discuss techniques. Those who grasp the profound Dao disdain illusions like striking stones to summon chess pieces. Those who wield divine mechanisms scorn tricks like waving fans to reverse winds or pouring wine to summon rain. How could the great Dao of the sages be adulterated with mere arts? It is true I have not seen the complete text; but I do not believe I have missed its techniques. The book’s extant passages differ from its transmitted versions—who is to say some eccentric did not pilfer talismans and incantations from other texts and insert them here? Readers then mistake these additions for the original, spreading errors that reduce it to mere occult arts, deceiving others. Do not be misled or duped—burn such corruptions.”

They asked: “If disasters are manifold, can one doctrine truly address them all? Or must we resign ourselves to inaction?”

I answered: “You speak of techniques without understanding the Dao. Techniques are small; the Dao is vast—beyond your comprehension. All worldly afflictions arise from imbalances in the five phases’ *qi*. Within our bodies resides the upright *qi* of the five phases, corresponding to the five directions. By diagnosing the source of an affliction and attacking its locus, we harmonize the world’s *qi* within ourselves—internally unaware of the self, externally unaware of the world. Excess is reduced, deficiency is supplemented, stagnation is dispersed, rigidity is softened, rebellion is pacified. Diseases are innumerable, and healing arts cannot be exhaustively described; one adjusts to waxing and waning, addressing each condition as it arises. When a person is ill, we regulate their *yin* and *yang* with our own body’s transformations. When the world is ill, we likewise harmonize it through our body’s *yin* and *yang*. Swift without haste—how wondrous! Yet this is not something ordinary people can achieve. It is the primal *qi* of *Qian* and *Kun*, the true Unity. Welcome and preserve it, and responses will be as immediate as an echo. Moreover, when the great Dao prevails, why wait for calamities to act? To remedy imbalances and restore order! Those who grasp this principle will not be misled by talismans, incantations, or numerological arts.”

*Written in the fourth month of the wuyin year of Daoguang by Min Yide, eleventh-generation successor of the Longmen lineage, at Ganlu Garden in Jinling.*

**Master Lü’s *Three Nuns’ Techniques for Healing the World***
*Transmitted by Master Taixu Shen Yibing; re-edited and annotated by disciple Min Yide*

The “Three Nuns” refer to Confucius, Śākyamuni, and the Green Nun. “World” here encompasses both the external realm and the body, meaning healing the world through the self.

Master Lü’s earlier *Exposition on the Three Nuns’ Healing of the World* was printed, and I once annotated it, but the *Techniques* were incomplete. This *Techniques* volume was obtained from Elder Taixu, who said the techniques rely on divine mastery of the *Jade Scripture*, while the secrets begin with the *Mystic Store Mantra*. Later, a friend took it away, and forty years passed before I recovered it. I have now re-edited it, added personal annotations, and appended invocations to clarify its applications. Thus, the techniques and secrets are now complete. Not for private gain, I respectfully share this with fellow students.

**Mystic Store Mantra**
Cloud-seals in the great void, at the dawn of kalpas,
Now distant, now near, now sinking, now floating.
Wandering the five directions, beyond a *zhang*’s reach.

According to the *Techniques*, the master compiled this from the *Mystic Store* to guide students in contemplating the origins of things. Before our forms took shape, we were one with the great void—like cloud-seals in the primordial kalpa, drifting near and far across the five directions, yet never beyond the *zhang*-span of the celestial heart. Upon embodying form, we initially retained our true primordial *qi*, but later, external things entangled us, and the discriminating mind took over. Unaware of returning, we became mired in habitual defilements, leaving us no leisure to seek healing—let alone practice these secrets. Thus, I urge those who aspire to this path to first investigate things and extend knowledge, sincerely cultivating their intent. Only with sincere intent can one study this.

Before reciting the scripture each time, embody and recite this incantation to renew mind and eye, thereby returning to our primal state. Thus, the discriminating spirit finds no foothold, the original destiny is secured, and the heart attains profound tranquility. Once settled and stilled, the primordial *qi* is restored—this is when the cloud-seals at last pervade the great void, a clear sign of movement arising from utter stillness. Yet this movement emerges without intent, drifting near and far, hovering in uncertainty. As a phenomenon, it is supremely void and numinous, now hidden, now manifest. Only when the five directions reveal their first signs and the great void bears the cloud-seals can images unfold into script. Though there may be additions or omissions within, they never exceed the *zhang*-span of the celestial heart—this is the supreme principle of movement that does not stray from the ultimate. It is akin to saying that our heart never departs from the *cun*-square. The *cun*-square is the heart. In humans, it is called the *cun*-square; in heaven, the *zhang*-span.

The Heavenly Perfected One respectfully notes from the Daoist canon: in heaven, he is called the Heavenly Perfected One; in humans, the original destiny and primordial spirit. Taking up the brush, he inscribes to expound the *Dongzhang*—the *Dongzhang* being the Jade Scripture, the text that generates heaven, earth, and all beings. The Perfected One, as the primordial truth, thus embodies and unfolds the scripture. In human terms, he is the awakened spirit. Before signs manifest, the spirit first awakens—this is the true purport of the Jade Scripture, from which scholars must not deviate.

Next, he inscribes the numinous talismans—these are the words of the *Dongzhang*, which the Perfected One dissects and writes, each character becoming a talisman. The Primordial Beginning descends, and the true scripture spreads forth. Respectfully noting: this Primordial Beginning is the spirit of the Primordial Dharma King in heaven, the essence of the Three Powers’ true unity. The following phrase, "true scripture," refers to the sacred teachings born of the Three Powers, the sagely instructions that flow forth in due time—these are the scriptures of the Three Teachings. Luminous in their presence, obscure in their absence, they are all born and transformed by the true unity, manifesting as wondrous being and wondrous non-being, two yet one. Thus, their characters encompass all.

Deep-seated illnesses may heal themselves; the drowning in worldly toil can be rescued. Noting: worldly afflictions arise half from human affairs, half from adverse fate, and thus cannot be cured by medicine alone. Worldly toil stems half from habitual defilement, half from innate *qi*, and thus cannot be sustained by coercion or favor. Only by embracing the One, refining and transforming, can deep-seated illnesses heal themselves and the drowning in toil be rescued. Those who aspire to renew themselves and others must diligently embody sincerity in their practice.

Both the hidden and the manifest depend on this, and thereby one ascends to the Pure Capital. The hidden pertains to the earthly Dao, the obscure; the manifest pertains to heavenly virtue, the luminous. The human body encompasses both—this is the body and heart. Only those who know the white yet guard the black, know the male yet guard the female, can employ them without bias, so that both hidden and manifest are sustained. The Pure Capital is the celestial abode of the Three Pure Ones. "Ascends" means to level. By following the One and drawing the One, refining and transforming, one naturally levels and verifies the Pure Capital. This reveals the wondrous function of the true unity: the character "is" in the preceding line connects directly to the character "is" in this line.

This is the Treasure of Original Destiny, impervious to erosion through endless kalpas. If one constantly recites it, one’s world becomes a companion to heaven. Noting: this "world" refers specifically to the individual. The Treasure of Original Destiny is the single stroke within *kan*, rising from the sea bottom, piercing the *weilü*, threading the spine to reach the brain, transforming into the royal infant suspended at the celestial fontanel. When it circulates to the Central Palace and unites with *qi*, it forms a full moon, and the heart reveals the vermilion-yellow talismanic character *Tiangang*, which is ultimately the congealed *qi* of the central generative force. In heaven, it is the Star of Stability, elevated above the sun and moon, the essence of the earth ascending to form its image. As *qi*, it is supremely centered and upright, at once utterly firm and utterly benevolent. The Daoist canon states: "Where it infuses, transformation occurs; where it stabilizes, rectification follows." Its light revolves with the Dipper, yet its heart does not stray from the ultimate. This means its heart is steadfast, like the pivot of a millstone. Thus, the Central Palace is ever in profound tranquility. In our efforts to heal the world, our intentions align with its stabilizing force, and the *Tiangang* *qi* naturally follows, descending. Therefore, one should hold the physical form upright, like standing atop a mountain peak, gazing into empty vastness. For the stabilizing force is like the sun, high in the celestial expanse, its light illuminating the entire body without reliance on human effort. Only when body and heart are empty and still will one’s countenance surely radiate. If one practices thus, the body becomes like fine silk or grain, transparent within and without—this manifestation arises only when the Central Palace reaches the extreme of emptiness and stillness. Moreover, one must not cling to the luminous while also heeding the obscure. Once the body attains purity and harmony, it seems as if it has always been so, the heart undisturbed—this is the body’s attainment of purity and harmony without attachment to form. If one further attains the state of forgetting even this forgetting, one enters perfect verification. Yet if one forgets even this provisional method, one falls into the external path of spontaneity—either scattered or dull. This is why the ancient sages relied on the Treasure of Original Destiny. For the Treasure of Destiny is the true unity of our body; by using the One to stabilize, the heart attains profound tranquility.

Now, in embodying Lüzu’s use of the Jade Scripture to harmonize the heart, its purport is even more profound, its function even more subtle. My teacher employed it to assist the Treasure of Destiny, ascending to welcome and descending to infuse, the entire being empty and numinous—its efficacy is especially divine. For the Jade Scripture is the essence of the Three Powers’ true unity, and the Treasure of Destiny is the heaven-endowed true unity. When the One draws the One, being and non-being mutually dissolve and transform—how could there be anything it cannot govern? Yet only those of utmost sincerity without ceasing can achieve this. Thus it is said: "If one constantly recites it, one’s world becomes a companion to heaven." Such is the admonition left by the ancient sages.

Though the Jade Scripture is numinous, what matters most is the unceasing recitation of it.

The Jade Scripture:
*Luo san lan bo, dai qia tai li,*
*Tang yun tui ru, lian guang ling du.*
*Yu luo shu miao, yu fu chao san,*
*Zhao sheng tian heng, zhi shi ming qian.*
*Ting pan bao ji, you xuan wo chen,*
*Sha fu yan ming, gui hui he zi.*
*Cun le xian le, bai fen tian hou,*
*Tu cheng yuan ping, mi jie zhang sheng.*
*Zhang jie lu miao, lai meng long deng,*
*Ning xie quan xin, di ni tuo li.*
*Namo jue fa, cheng jin you yan,*
*Sun moon stars Dipper, shine and rest the life-qi.*
*Fang yuan de qiu, longevity true and firm in spirit,*
*Longevity mirroring heaven and earth’s clarity.*

Note: The Jade Scripture’s text concludes at *"shine and rest the life-qi."* The following lines pertain to the shared origins of the Three Teachings—Confucianism, Buddhism, and Daoism—as expounded by later patriarchs, and are not part of the original scripture.

The scripture emerged at the dawn of the kalpa, before heaven, earth, or beings existed. It manifested like clouds and mist, filling the void—this is called the *Mysterious Seal Script.* The Primordial Sovereign arose to embody it, tracing its forms to compile the text, though without punctuation or division, it simply circulated in the world.

By the Middle Antiquity, celestial spirits aided its transmission, rendering it as *Cloud Seal Script* or *Tadpole Script,* assembled into chapters as it flowed. Later, the Divine Mother Shenmu descended to orally transmit it to Patriarch Xu of Jingyang. Not only were its forms more precise, but its phonetics were also meticulously preserved. The Patriarch wished to transcribe it in standard script but feared the foolishness of later generations might lead to errors. Thus, he composed a four-character verse imbued with the meaning of the Elixir Way, ensuring no misinterpretation—though this was not the original intent of the primordial scripture’s meaning.

Therefore, this four-character Jade Scripture is akin to Zhou Xingsi’s *Thousand-Character Classic* or the modern compilation of the *Lanting Calligraphy Model*—its essence lies in embodying the rhythm.

I once lamented the difficulty of comprehension and attempted annotations, only to become entangled in verbal explanations. Fortunately, the phonetics remain largely faithful, save for the two characters *namo,* which are pronounced *nangmo,* and the character *hou* in *bai fen tian hou,* which I render as *hou* with a distinct understanding, though it diverges from this oral tradition.

Upon reviewing the *Medical Salvation Oral Formula,* I found no annotations, only preserved phonetics, with a warning against commentary. It advises that prolonged recitation alone leads to realization. The original transmission’s profound instruction can only be grasped intuitively, not through words.

In the Mystery Gate, it is said: *"Recite with sincerity for one year, and you become an Immortal of Human Rank; for two years, an Immortal of Earthly Rank; for three years, an Immortal of Heavenly Rank.
