The knowing spirit leaps with joy, composing ten thousand words in a day, expounding the Dharma and discoursing on the profound without end—this is the penetration of the mind’s realm. Without leaving one’s hut, one foreknows the future; while inside a room, one sees through walls—this is the penetration of the divine realm. In the midst of sitting upright, one suddenly becomes confused and indistinct, as if in chaos. After a moment, the aperture of the mind opens wide, and heaven, earth, mountains, and rivers appear as if viewed on the palm of the hand—this is the penetration of the celestial eye. One hears the speech of the ten directions as if it were at one’s ear, and recalls past lives as if they were before one’s eyes—this is the penetration of the celestial ear. Whether by day or night, one enters profound concentration, seeing heaven above and hell below, perceiving countless past kalpas and the roots of one’s own past lives—this is the penetration of past-nature. With divine transformations and changes, one moves in and out freely, perceiving the hidden and subtle matters within the minds of all beings, knowing their thoughts before they arise—this is the penetration of others’ minds.”

Why is this so? Zisi said: “The spirit of the mind is called sageliness.” Thus, when the mind is stabilized, it becomes wise; when the mind is still, it becomes responsive; when the mind is quiet, it becomes knowing; when the mind is empty, it becomes numinous; when the mind is sincere, it becomes luminous; when the mind is empty, it becomes awakened. At this stage of practice, one must not cling to any good or evil realms, nor to pavilions, halls, or palaces, nor to buddhas or immortals. One must employ the Dao of emptiness, expanding and filling it, so that the spirit of one’s Celestial Valley ascends into the great void and merges into oneness.

With further diligence, refining the primordial spirit of the Celestial Valley to its utmost subtlety and wonder, one realizes the fruit of the Dao. The Supreme Lord says: “Merge this body, world, body, and mind into the aperture. Externally, blend with the world and harmonize with its radiance, appearing and dwelling in the mundane while moving with the common flow. In action and repose, conceal one’s edges, accumulating hidden merit. Open one’s sincerity to universally ferry others across, cultivating and realizing—this is the wondrous function of simultaneously cultivating nature and life.” In the end, this returns to the mysterious workings of the closing and opening of the Imperial Ultimate.

The *Book of Changes* says: “Being prior to heaven, yet heaven does not oppose it”—this refers to the mechanism issuing from the mind, where the qi-mechanisms of the two great forces converge and act without opposition. This is the principle that humans can magnify the Dao. The method of practice is nothing other than the spirit dwelling in the Celestial Valley, acting in a state of unknowing and unperceiving, profoundly deep and profoundly still, with no leakage of yang-light. Thus, it naturally expands ever further and grows ever more luminous, spontaneously giving rise to divine transformations.

"Life begets life without end; transformation follows transformation without limit."

The Lord of Eastern Florescence said:
*"The Dharmakāya is vast and firm, penetrating heaven and earth;
The mind-nature is perfectly luminous, pervading past and present.
Not recognizing that the Three Powers were originally one,
One vainly makes the mind-nature alone perfectly luminous."*

This speaks of taking universal salvation as one’s task—precisely the meaning of fulfilling three thousand meritorious deeds and perfecting eight hundred virtuous practices.

He further said:
*"In the world there are those who cultivate the primordial,
Their prior and posterior energies congealed like a sacred infant.
If the crown aperture has not yet opened its great eye,
Do not allow the dispersal of shadows or the division of form."*

This refers to admixture with the posterior heaven. The posterior heaven has form, and a single sheet of paper can obstruct it—how much more so flesh and bone? As for the prior heaven, it can penetrate gold and jade; why labor to open the great eye?

Only because of admixture with the posterior heaven does one emerge through the opened aperture. Though capable of limitless transformation, one cannot yet unite in virtue with heaven. Thus, one must add the nine-year effort of "facing the wall," washing away all impurities, to unite with heaven. Naturally, one leaps beyond the Five Phases, returning to the homeland of the Ultimate Nonbeing. One verifies the ever-profound truth of true appearance, attains the perfection of true practice, forms the indestructible vajra-body, and becomes an immortal of ten thousand years. Awakening oneself and awakening others, one perpetuates the lineage of the Dao. With three thousand merits fulfilled, the white crane arrives in welcome; with eight hundred virtues perfected, the cinnabar script issues its summons. One ascends to the Golden Portal, bowing in homage to the Imperial Realm.

*The Zhonghe Collection* states:
*"To accomplish the opening of the crown aperture—
Within it lies another heaven and earth."*
Yet how easily is this crown aperture opened? First, one emits the fire of samādhi to penetrate what is impassable; next, one gathers the fire of the Great Yang to surge upward. The two fires blaze intensely, ceaselessly attacking. In an instant, crimson light fills the world, purple flames suffuse the sky, and with a clap of thunder, the Celestial Gate opens.

Lü Dongbin also said:
*"After nine years of true fire-cultivation,
Suddenly the Celestial Gate bursts open at the crown.
The true person appears with great spiritual powers—
From this, one may be hailed as a celestial immortal."*
This refers to emerging through the broken crown when the posterior heaven is not yet purified.

As for accumulating merit and virtue, it all lies in the time when the spirit dwells in the inner chamber.

I once said:
*"Only when merit is perfected may one ascend to the Jade Capital;
Boundless spiritual powers reside within the physical body.
With practice fulfilled, one attains the method of liberation—
Lightly riding a crane to pay homage to the Three Pure Ones.
Now the Golden Portal urgently needs talent;
Master Qiu’s merit is lofty, for he saves from calamity.
To cease killing—how much better to dissolve the kalpa of slaughter!
In the three thousand worlds, all becomes a spring terrace."*

Master Nanqiao said: *"How vast is the intent of my teacher!"*

Now when people obtain a single formula or method, they conceal it in utmost secrecy, fearing its disclosure. Compared to my teacher, how could they not die of shame?

Alas! To ferry others is to ferry oneself; to accumulate virtuous deeds is to cultivate immortality. For universal salvation is none other than the celestial nature of one’s own being!

Min Xiaogen said: *"According to the manuscript copy, this chapter has undergone extensive revisions, with annotations too numerous to note. Here, I have restored it in accordance with the Mountain Edition. Carefully examining the scripture’s text, it is nothing less than the foundational practice for healing the world. Its principles of perfect realization are fully expounded herein—only the ultimate aim of healing the world remains unstated."*

The Perfected One of the Mud-Pill Palace, Li Zu, declared that this text and the *Golden Flower’s Principle* bestowed by the Mountain Edition were both revealed for the purpose of healing the world, as they necessarily uphold the original decrees of the Primordial Beginning. Yet within this chapter, the discourse does not openly address the karmic turn of the age, instead directly stating that its essence lies in what has been shown by the Most High. When the Perfected One was in the world, he manifested through the Dao, but no record speaks of him advocating the way of healing the world. This scripture, then, appears to be a revelation proclaimed after his ascension and verification—such was the workings of the cosmic tide. Thus, the Perfected One Li Zu composed the gatha *"About to speak, yet not yet spoken—now it shall be spoken,"* which appears in the following chapter of this text.

**Chapter Ten: Refining the Void and Merging with the Dao**

Master Yin the Perfected One said: "Master Shuiqiu states:
*‘Shatter the void to still kalpas without end,
Once the far shore is reached, cast off the boat and oar.
Though you peruse ten thousand scrolls of elixir scriptures,
The final word—none dare to speak.’*

Master Li the Perfected One said:
*‘About to speak, yet not yet spoken—now it shall be spoken,
Neither external nor internal, returning to emptiness and stillness.
The qi-cavern serves as furnace, governed by spontaneity;
When practice is complete and merit perfected, one reverts to the Ultimateless.’*

Master Gao the Perfected One said: ‘This is the secret treasury of the mind-seal, transmitted from Buddha to Buddha, patriarch to patriarch. Yet by the time of the Sixth Patriarch, the robe and bowl ceased to be passed down, and the Buddha’s esoteric treasury fell into silence—until now. In this cosmic epoch, the Woodcutter of Yang has been reborn. The true Dao shall flourish widely. What the world transmits as "refining spirit to return to the void" remains but a secondary teaching, not the supreme and most authentic Dao.’

*(The Woodcutter of Yang was the sobriquet of an ancient Perfected One, surnamed Wang, of unknown era. Wang Kunyang, the Venerable Master of the Vinaya from Luzhou, was said at birth to have been visited by an immortal who declared: "The Woodcutter of Yang is reborn! The Vinaya tradition of the Most High shall flourish anew from this moment." This is recorded in the* Records of the Three Mountains Abbey.*)*

During the reigns of Shunzhi and Kangxi, the Vinaya Patriarch five times convened the Dharma-Bowl Hall to confer the Three Great Precepts of the Most High. Over three thousand disciples received the precept robe and bowl. The *Lüzu’s Teachings on Healing the World* was transmitted to them—more than three thousand copies in all. Could this not be called the flourishing of the true Dao? Moreover, the Patriarch’s precept hall was established at White Cloud Abbey in the capital. At that time, both Buddhist and Daoist lineages required imperial sanction to transmit precepts; none could open a hall privately. What was transmitted included the Vinaya, scriptures, and handscrolls. The scrolls recorded the lineage of successive patriarchs, from the Most High downward, along with the transmitted precept verses—some in five-character, some in seven-character, and some in four-character lines—passed down intact through the generations. Those without proper transmission were deemed impostors, and the Vinaya required their expulsion without exception. The scrolls bore imperial edicts at their head, and the mysteries of the Vinaya were strictly guarded to prevent forgeries.

The transmitted scriptures contained no forbidden doctrines, yet because the precepts were held in solemn reverence—lest they be treated with irreverence—the law against careless disclosure was most severe. Thus, all descendants of the Vinaya lineage preserved them in secret. If a lineage had no one to whom they could be transmitted, the texts were gathered and burned. This was the bane of those who consumed the past without digesting it: after three transmissions from the Patriarch, the Way nearly perished.

By the Jiaqing era, the Dharma-Bowl assemblies had resumed, but the precept manual of Patriarch Qiu was lost. What is now transmitted, gleaned from the *Records of the Pure Brightness Teachings*, differs in minor ways but diverges greatly from what Patriarch Qiu passed down. The elders of this mountain also observed the precept of burning such texts, though fortunately a copy of the scripture survives. The scrolls and Vinaya, however, are gone. When my late master, the Venerable Taixu, spoke of this, he would strike his breast and weep—this was the cause.

This book by the Perfected One aligns directly with the wondrous efficacy of healing the world, forming a single thread of transmission. Following its guidance in cultivation, the Most High’s宗旨 becomes as clear as the palm of one’s hand. To leave it unannotated would be to fail my teacher. To act willfully without correction would be to fail the Perfected One. This humble offering arises from necessity, not from a love of idle words.

Respectfully recorded by Min Yide, a later disciple of the Dragon Gate lineage.

The gateway of Chan is a single aperture—when the heart is stilled to embody it (this phrase being the esoteric secret for opening the Mysterious Aperture), once penetrated, it unlocks the three treasuries of the Three Teachings, dissolves the myriad dharmas and thousand gates, and the supreme principle of Returned Elixir becomes suddenly and thoroughly clear. Thus, the secret treasury of the thousand buddhas is reopened in this world.

For the Buddhists, it is called the *Chan Gate*; for the Daoists, the *Mysterious Aperture*; for the Confucians, the *Yellow Center*. Only by diligently practicing this can one refine emptiness and merge with the Dao, attaining the first truth of the sagely teachings—this is none other than the supreme vehicle of the Buddha-dharma.

This method has no other essence but the repeated refinement of the yang spirit, returning it to the ocean of Vairocana’s nature. Through tempering and refinement, the turbid is exhausted and the pure remains, then conveyed back to the Celestial Valley. Next, the spirit of the Celestial Valley is withdrawn and concealed in secrecy, like a dragon nurturing the pearl beneath its chin or a crane brooding the egg in its nest. Neither internal nor external, neither qi nor mind, it condenses into a single grain. Guarded with utmost care, neither emerging nor entering, the Land of Infinite Life appears before one’s eyes, and the entire trichiliocosm silently receives its benefits.

No sharp edges are revealed; at the extreme of emptiness and quiescence, transformation reaches its utmost. What is called *creation* naturally restores both nature and destiny, and naturally returns to emptiness. At this stage, five transformations have already occurred. Yet transformation is inexhaustible, and change is boundless—this is the most divine of spiritual transformations.

Thus, the spirit is refined a hundred times and grows ever more numinous; gold is refined a hundred times and grows ever more refined. Refined again and again, the furnace flames vanish, and emptiness manifests like motes of dust—each mote containing a world of vast, ice-clear purity. Soon, the spirit-light fills the cavity, and the yang radiance soars into the void, passing from the inner apertures to the outer. The nine great outer apertures correspond to the nine provinces, and within each great aperture, every aperture is filled with great spirit-light. The eighty-four thousand minor apertures correspond to the prefectures and counties, and within each minor aperture, every aperture is filled with great spirit-light—penetrating within and without, from crown to sole, everywhere suffused with great spirit-light.

Where the light shines, its benefits arise; thus, it must illuminate everywhere. The illumination should be thorough, with no trace of contrivance in between—only constancy is sublime. Constancy ensures pervasiveness; perseverance ensures thoroughness. The secret of healing the world is fully contained in this chapter.

For where illumination reaches, light arrives in its primal fullness. Capable of penetrating and fulfilling, how could its bestowal be empty? There is true principle and true verification here. Yet for the practitioner, it costs not a single coin, nor expends the slightest effort. Attained while seated, practiced in spare moments, daily progress may seem slight, but monthly gains accumulate—how much more after three years or nine?

The crucial warning is this: when the light shines, guard against willful interference. As detailed in the *Collected Poems and Prose of the Jade Tube*:

> The White Patriarch was originally the Star Lord Lu Cun of the Northern Dipper in the primordial heavens. During the great drought of Emperor Yao’s reign, the Jade Emperor entrusted him with a bottle of water and a whisk, commanding him to ride the dragon and dispense rain. The decree stated: *“Such-and-such a place shall receive so many drops, no more, no less.”* But upon seeing the barren lands—parched crops, dried streambeds—he disobeyed the decree, pouring out the entire bottle before returning. Thus, nine years of flooding ensued, and the Star Lord was demoted to mortal form.

This illustrates that when heaven’s work is delegated to humans, one must not impose personal intent—lest imbalance result. In the healing of the world, no method surpasses the two words *illumination* and *light* in this text, and both teaching and nurturing are thereby perfected.

For instance, whether to employ clarity or harmony depends on whether one’s nature-cultivation is thorough and one’s understanding of destiny’s principles is precise. If applied improperly, the offense is no small matter. Better to let the light shine universally without imposing intent. Such is my humble opinion, set down here for the consideration of the wise.

Once more, gather and return it to the ancestral aperture, immaculate as though not a speck of dust clings—quiescent and still, still and quiescent. In the depth of this stillness, a crimson radiance like racing clouds or flashing lightning surges from the central aperture, piercing through to the upper aperture, transcending all apertures great and small. The spirit-light stirs and blazes, illuminating the ten directions, heaven above and earth below, all beings in between—nowhere does its brilliance fail to reach.

At this stage in the healing of the world, the benefits extend not only throughout Jambudvīpa to the south and Nālandā, but also to the western Ox Continent, the eastern Victory Continent, the northern lands of the Di, and the central Red Region—all receive its grace. Yet the efficacy lies entirely in remaining immaculate, without imposing any contrivance. All that follows in word and deed adheres to this principle, embodying the meaning of nurturing and transforming through subtle influence, awaiting natural transformation.

Thus, gather and refine it further, dissolving it back into the ancestral aperture—immaculate as though not a speck of dust clings, quiescent and still, still and quiescent. In the depth of this stillness, the six dragons complete their transformations, and the spirit further transmutes into the light of śarīra. Like the blazing solar orb, it wells forth from within the ancestral aperture, bursting into myriad rays of light that ascend straight to the nine heavens, universally illuminating the great trichiliocosm—just as the Great Awakened Chan Master once proclaimed in his gāthā.

Only then does one realize what the Most High meant: "Though heaven and earth may crumble, *this* does not." *This* is the primordial master, *this* the true nature and fundamental substance, *this* the adamantine, unchanging, and immutable perfection of the Dao, *this* the unborn and undying, the non-spiritual from time immemorial. *This* great spiritual power, this great nature-light, awakens and illuminates Jambudvīpa, universally ferrying all beings—truly the immeasurable merit beyond measure, beyond conception, beyond thought.

Thus, the gāthā declares:
*A single śarīra blazes with radiant light,*
*Illumining countless eons without end.*
*The great trichiliocosm wholly returns to refuge,*
*All thirty-three heavens are encompassed within.*

Upon completing this sutra, Min Yide rejoiced with exultation, bowing a hundred times in reverence. He respectfully offered a gāthā in return:
*The supreme and wondrous Dao concealed in the West,*
*Now heard anew in the East, thanks to the Master’s transmission.*
*This is the Scripture of the Imperial Ultimate’s Opening and Closing,*
*Encompassing the profound essence of the Daoist lineage, embracing Confucianism and Buddhism.*
*Cultivation and realization proceed as one, the Dao advancing in tandem,*
*Its efficacy silently expressed in the discourse on healing the world.*
*Forgetting years and months, holding fast with single-minded devotion,*
*Dare one rest, whether the effects manifest or not?*
*From beginningless time until now,*
*Lifetimes upon lifetimes spent in vain exertion.*
*Yet the year, month, day, and hour of this life remain—*
*Every moment of light is to be cherished.*
*One day, when perfection is attained and the Great Luo is returned to,*
*The heaven of Great Luo was established for humanity.*
*Scholars of the great trichiliocosm, do not lose heart—*
*Even the Buddha was once an ordinary being who cultivated to attain it.*
*Thus it is, thus it is—not a fabrication,*
*The august words of this sutra merit repeated study.*

The original *Qingyang Gong* text has undergone repeated transmissions and transcriptions. Daoist peddlers presented it to the Vinaya School, whose masters, alarmed by its reckless disclosure, excised its essential passages. The peddlers then further altered and corrupted it, so that more than half of its authenticity was lost. Li Pengtou of Fengtian, whose Daoist name was Yiqi, once discussed this—explaining how the spurious version came to circulate in this world. Those with deep karmic roots and discerning wisdom perceived its inconsistencies and impurities and entrusted me with its collation. Fortunately, a woodblock edition from Mount Ben preserved in the Kangxi era was available. Comparing and emending the text against it, the work was restored to completeness.

Our school’s alchemical scriptures are all treasures of the world. My late master, Tai Xu, wrote a postscript for this book, which, regrettably, was taken away by a fellow practitioner. Recalling its main points, he affirmed that this sutra upholds the orthodox lineage, embodying the Dao that penetrates heaven and earth—longevity and enduring vision being but secondary matters. He also noted that the Perfected One was born in the Eastern Han, his appearances and disappearances unfathomable. The divine immortal Li of Niwan, who abides in this world, once met him in the Liaoyang Hall of Qingyang Gong, where the Perfected One revealed that he had shed his form in Lingnan. Throughout his life, he had dazzled the world with expedient methods, only to be followed by great tribulations. Thus, he mounted an iron crane to depart the world, expounding the Great Dao of Emptiness and Non-Being to exhort his fellow cultivators. From this, it is clear that the Li poem cited in the *Refining Emptiness and Merging with the Dao* chapter of this sutra undoubtedly refers to our patriarch, the Perfected One of Niwan.

Perfected Master Yin, during the Yuan and Ming dynasties, bore the surname Yin and was known as Yin Pengtou. In the Eastern Han, his surname was Qu, his given name Zhen, and his Daoist name Wuwo. Over more than a thousand years, he repeatedly changed his name to conceal himself in the mundane world. I was born late and am fortunate to dwell on this mountain, to have obtained this book, and now to have corrected its spurious version. The extraordinary karmic connections herein are truly inconceivable, and so I record them with reverence.

A humble disciple of the Longmen lineage, Min Yide, respectfully inscribes this postscript.

---

*The Questions and Answers of Perfected Master Yin at Liaoyang Hall*
*(Six Chapters, Transmitted Manuscript from Qingyang Gong)*
*Collated and Verified by Min Yide of Jingaishan*

**Chapter One (The Ascension to the Seat)**

At that time, Perfected Master Yin was at White Cloud Hall beneath Mount Qingcheng in western Shu. After his disciples had completed their purification rites, a seat was prepared in the eastern corridor of Liaoyang Hall, and the Master was invited to ascend it. The Master then arrived (the wording in the original text differs slightly from the manuscript), and the disciples performed the triple bow of reverence before standing in order.

The Master expounded to them the profound mysteries of the *August Ultimate’s Opening and Closing of Heaven*, the undivided Dharma-gate of purity and liberation. Among the assembly, a disciple named Xuan Zhen stepped forward, approached the Master’s seat, bowed twice in inquiry, and asked:

“May I ask the Perfected One about the principles of life and death, yin and yang?”

The Master replied: “All beings cherish life and fear death, yet none know whence life comes or whither death departs. In life, they scheme and strive endlessly, exhausting themselves. But when death arrives, it is like a live turtle shedding its shell or a living turtle dropped into boiling water—earth, water, fire, and wind scatter apart. The spirit, having left the form, perceives the world as if it were a splash of ink: east and west indistinguishable, above and below unknown. They revolve through the six paths of rebirth, assuming new existences according to their karma. Wherever karmic affinities arise, they perceive it as fire, beholding light and radiant forms, which give rise to the seed of desire. Through contemplation, they enter the womb. After ten months, with a cry at birth, the celestial true primordial qi infuses the ancestral aperture, corresponding to the *Kun* hexagram.

From one to three years of age, it corresponds to the *Fu* hexagram; at five, to *Lin*; at eight, to *Tai*; at ten, to *Dazhuang*; at thirteen, to *Guai*; and at sixteen, to *Qian*. From one yin to six yangs, a male who has not leaked essence is called a *Qian* body. If at this time he encounters an enlightened teacher and receives the oral instructions, his cultivation may be swiftly perfected—such a one is a person of supreme virtue.

Thereafter, with the first stirring of desire, the true primordial qi is lost, and with every eight years, one yang is diminished. From sixteen to twenty-four years, the first yin arises, corresponding to the *Gou* hexagram; at thirty-two, to *Dun*; at forty, to *Pi*; at forty-eight, to *Guan*; at fifty-six, to *Bo*; and at sixty-four, pure yin prevails, returning to *Kun*. Such is the course of human life, never exceeding the number of six yins.

A person’s entire life, with all its myriad actions, is but illusion. What accompanies them unerringly is only the dual karma of good and evil accumulated in life, clinging to the body without the slightest omission.”

The disciple further inquired: “And the Three Fields?”

The master replied: “One cun and two fen behind the navel-wheel, with a forceful exhalation, the true primordial qi descends to this place, called the Celestial Heart. It is also named the Sea of Qi, or the Spirit Furnace, for it is the root of the womb-immortal’s origin—hence also called the Celestial Root. It is the site for refining essence into qi and refining qi to ascend, and so is also named the Kun Furnace. According to alchemical texts, this is the Lower Field.

Above the Lower Field lies the Yellow Court, the very place where the Red Child establishes life. The human blood-heart is called the Crimson Palace, not a site for refinement but one for preservation and nurturance. For here, fluid is stored to become blood, and blood is nurtured to transform into essence—this too is a vital locus.

Behind the heart and slightly below lies the Middle Field, named the Yellow Hall, also called the Earth Cauldron. The *Book of Changes* speaks of the ‘Yellow Center,’ and the Dao calls it the Mysterious Aperture. It is where the immortal embryo is knit and nourished, most forbidden to the leakage of the three postnatal treasures.

At the crown of the head lies the Mud Pill, also called the Celestial Valley or the Inner Court. Here the infant takes form and ascends to dwell—alchemical texts name this the Upper Field.

(Note: The manuscript’s errors and confusions have been meticulously corrected according to the mountain edition.)

The disciple further inquired about the Three Passes of the back.

The master replied: “The human tailbone, located at the third vertebra of the coccyx, is also called Long Strength, the Triple Fork, the River Chariot Path, or the Forbidden Gate. Below it lies the Mysterious Pass, and before it the Sea of Qi. This is the realm of yin-yang transformation, the meeting place of the Ren and Du meridians—alchemical texts name it the Tailbone Pass.

The human spine has twenty-four vertebrae, corresponding to the twenty-four qi. A pass lies between the first and last of these vertebrae, called the Double Pass, piercing straight through to the crown. This is the Spine-Nape Pass.

The bone at the back of the skull is called the Wind Pool. Its aperture is the smallest and most difficult to open. To open it, press the tongue against the upper palate, direct the gaze to the crown, and rely entirely on the Spirit Furnace to gather fire and drive it upward in succession—only then will this pass open. This pass is named the Jade Pillow, also called the Iron Wall.

Such is the method for opening the Three Passes of the back.”
(All corrections follow the mountain edition.)

Further, one asks: Can the primordial qi be generated?

The answer: The primordial qi is generated daily. At the *zi* hour, the qi of the first yang arises in the *Fu* hexagram, reaching the Tailbone Pass—this is the third vertebra from the base of the coccyx. At the *chou* hour, the qi of the second yang arises in the *Lin* hexagram, reaching the Kidney Hall—the seventh vertebra from the base upward. At the *yin* hour, the qi of the third yang arises in the *Tai* hexagram, reaching the Pivot of Origin—the eleventh vertebra from the base upward. At the *mao* hour, the qi of the fourth yang arises in the *Dazhuang* hexagram, reaching the Spine-Nape Pass—the twelfth vertebra from the base upward. At the *chen* hour, the qi of the fifth yang arises in the *Guai* hexagram, reaching the Pottery Path—the twenty-second vertebra from the base upward. At the *si* hour, the qi of the six yangs, pure *Qian*, reaches the Jade Pillow Pass—here, yang is at its utmost, and when yang reaches its extreme, yin arises; this is the inevitable principle.

At the *wu* hour, the qi of the first yin arises in the *Gou* hexagram, reaching the Mud Pill Palace—this is the *Baihui* point. At the *wei* hour, the qi of the second yin arises in the *Dun* hexagram, reaching the Hall of Light—located one *cun* and two *fen* directly above the midpoint between the eyebrows. At the *shen* hour, the qi of the third yin arises in the *Pi* hexagram, reaching the Chest Center—the outer pericardium of the heart. At the *you* hour, the qi of the fourth yin arises in the *Guan* hexagram, reaching the Central Cavity. At the *xu* hour, the qi of the fifth yin arises in the *Bo* hexagram, reaching the Spirit Gate. At the *hai* hour, the qi of the six yins, pure *Kun*, reaches its extreme—here, when yin reaches its extreme, yang arises once more.

From *zi* to *si* are the six yangs, traversing twenty-five degrees of yang. From *wu* to *hai* are the six yins, traversing twenty-five degrees of yin. Day and night, they circulate between the five viscera and six bowels—when qi stagnates, illness arises; when qi ceases, death follows. Those who cultivate and attain longevity in this world do so by securing essence to nourish qi, closing the *Ren* to open the *Du*, ensuring the two meridians circulate without cease.

May I inquire into the principle of the Supreme Ultimate?

The Master said: "The Supreme Ultimate is the celestial mind of humanity. In Buddhism, it is called *Perfect Enlightenment*; in Daoism, the *Golden Elixir*; in Confucianism, the *Supreme Ultimate*. The phrase 'the Ultimateless yet Supreme Ultimate' means that which cannot be ultimate yet is ultimately so. At the very beginning of a person’s life, there is but this single luminous spark—what governs the physical form is precisely this Supreme Ultimate. Before the existence of father and mother, there was a single expanse of the Supreme Ultimate, and what prevents it from being bound to the physical form is called the Ultimateless. To recognize the original true countenance, one must look to the radiant wheel before birth.

The Supreme Ultimate possesses two principles. In terms of its movement, it is called *timeliness*—even heaven and earth are not beyond a single breath. In terms of its coagulation, it is called the *true seed*—even a single grain of millet can contain heaven and earth. When the hibernating creature returns to its root and rests in profound obscurity, this is the Supreme Ultimate of *timeliness*. When conception takes form and the embryo is knit through union, this is the Supreme Ultimate of the *true seed*. If one can preserve these two Ultimates without loss, one may attain longevity and transcend transformation—how could it be merely living out one’s years to the end?"

"May I ask what is meant by *Fire Dragon* and *Water Tiger*?"

The Master replied: "The *Water Tiger* is black lead, the root from which heaven, earth, and the myriad things arise—it possesses substance but no qi, and is true lead. The *Fire Dragon* is red lead, the origin from which heaven, earth, and the myriad things arise—it possesses qi but no substance, and is true mercury.

That which has substance is true lead, the essence of the Great Yin and the moon, the mother of all forms in heaven and earth. That which has no substance is true mercury, the radiance of the Great Yang and the sun, the father of all arising in heaven and earth. The bodies of lead and mercury nurture one another in ceaseless circulation—how could they not be called the ancestral source that gives birth to heaven, earth, and the myriad things?

From ancient times to the present, perfected beings have known that these numinous substances lie concealed here. Following the patterns of the hexagrams, they gather the essence of the Great Yin; setting up the furnace and cauldron, they refine and merge with the qi of the Great Yang. These two are returned to the *spirit chamber*, where they blend in primal chaos, intermingling without cease, nurturing endlessly. Thus, the *hun*-soul is born within wood, the *po*-soul within metal; they congeal and transform into the *yin-e*, coalescing into the hundred treasures, called the *Great Return Elixir of Golden Liquor*."

[This answer encompasses principles most profound, most secret, most wondrous, and most vast, yet also most ordinary, most extraordinary, most simple, and most upright in both essence and function. Yet it does not transcend the two phrases of my teacher, Master Tai Xu: *"Inwardly, emptiness is utterly still; outwardly, one blends with the world and harmonizes its light."*

To apply this, one must take heaven and earth as the medicinal substances and the Great Void as the furnace and cauldron. When employed in the world, it becomes the *Three Nīti* for healing the age; when returned to the *spirit chamber* within the body, it is called the *Great Return Elixir of Golden Liquor*. Practicing thus is said to benefit both the public and the private, the world and the self alike.

The sages of old declared: *"The methods in this text suffice to heal the world—such is their purpose."*]

"May I ask what is meant by the 'Sun Crow and Moon Hare'?"

The answer: "The sun is yang, and within yang resides the image of yin—like cinnabar containing mercury. Without yin, yang cannot shine of itself; its spirit is the feminine fire, for yang harbors yin within. The crow in the sun corresponds to the southern trigram, called the *Li Maiden*, hence it is said: *Though the sun occupies the Li position, it is reversed as female.*

The moon is yin, and within yin resides the image of yang—like lead containing silver. Without yang, yin cannot glow of itself; its essence is named *masculine metal*, for yin harbors yang within. The hare in the moon corresponds to the northern trigram, called the *Kan Male*, hence it is said: *Though Kan matches the Toad Palace, it is indeed male.*

Master Wu Yin said:
*From the hare’s brain take lead’s essence,*
*From the crow’s heart draw mercury’s blood.*
*When these two substances conjoin as elixir,*
*The supreme Dao is not complex—no artifice is needed.*

These two are but one body."

[This passage elucidates the profound principle of the preceding section, refining its essence to utmost subtlety. Applied to healing the world, the principle holds true. Yet its wondrous function lies in nothing more than *clarity* and *harmony*, and its efficacy must emulate the crow and hare—distantly yet steadfastly supporting each other, yielding boundless utility. The sages of old declared: *"In employing the sun, be as spring; in employing the moon, be as autumn."* Is there not reason in this?]

May I inquire about the great and small crucibles and tripods?

The Master said:
"In refining the Golden Liquor of the Great Return Elixir, one must first establish the crucible and erect the tripod. The tripod is neither of metal nor iron; the crucible is neither of jade nor stone. The Yellow Court serves as the tripod, the qi cavern as the crucible. The Yellow Court lies directly above the qi cavern, connected by a single thread—this is where the true person’s blood and pulse converge, where the tripod hexagram declares: *‘In the proper position, life is congealed.’* This is called the small crucible and tripod.

The Qian position serves as the tripod, the Kun position as the crucible. Within the tripod lies the yin of mercury, which is the Fire Dragon; within the crucible resides the yang of the Jade Bud, which is the Water Tiger. The Tiger below acts as the pivot for kindling fire, while the Dragon above stirs the winds and waves of ascending clouds. If the crucible’s ascent of yang and descent of yin proceed without error, then within the tripod, the celestial soul and earthly spirit linger, the Azure Dragon and White Tiger constrain each other, the Jade Hare and Golden Crow embrace—when the firing process is harmonized, the supreme treasure is refined.

Thus, Master Qingxia said:
*‘Tripod after tripod, not of metal,*
*Crucible after crucible, not of jade.*
*Fire arises below the navel,*
*Water seals above the crown.*
*Once the three clans unite,*
*The two substances naturally constrain.*
*Firmly sealed, the embryo does not leak—*
*Transformation occurs in an instant.’*
This is called the great crucible and tripod."

[The ancient sage Jing’an remarked: *"To heal the great thousand worlds, employ the great crucible and tripod; to simmer a small delicacy, use only the small crucible and tripod."* Master Taixu said: *"To heal the world’s fortunes, one must employ the great crucible and tripod; if treating the body and household, where illness lies in the self alone, one need only frequently tend to the small crucible and tripod—then the body will know no disorder, and the household no discord."*]

May I inquire about the essence of inner medicine, outer medicine, and the firing process?

The Master said:
"In all refinement, one first cultivates the outer medicine, then the inner medicine. If one is a person of keen insight, possessing innate spiritual roots, then upon refining the outer medicine, one may immediately refine the inner. The inner medicine is non-action yet nothing it does not accomplish; the outer medicine is action with deliberate purpose. The inner medicine is formless and without substance yet truly exists; the outer medicine has form and function yet is ultimately insubstantial. The outer medicine can cure illness and bestow longevity; the inner medicine can transcend and ascend, entering and exiting the realm of being and non-being. The outer medicine pertains to the external ebb and flow of yin and yang; the inner medicine concerns the internal convergence of Kan and Li.

Regarding the outer medicine: the essence of intercourse must first be retained without leakage; the qi of breath must be ever so subtle; the spirit of thought must rest in tranquility. Regarding the inner medicine: to refine essence is to refine primordial essence, drawing forth the yang within Kan; when primordial essence is firm, the essence of intercourse will naturally not leak. To refine qi is to refine primordial qi, replenishing the primordial yin within Li; when primordial qi abides, the qi of breath will naturally not ebb and flow. To refine spirit is to refine primordial spirit, reuniting Kan and Li to restore Qian’s origin; when primordial spirit congeals, the spirit of thought will naturally attain profound stability. Cultivating both inner and outer, one will surely attain immortality.

Master Ziyang said:
*‘The inner medicine resembles the outer,*
*The inner must flow for the outer to follow.*
*The Elixir Head unites in like kind—*
*Two nurturing methods, distinct in function.*
*Within, the celestial true fire burns ever red in the crucible;*
*Without, the furnace’s increase and decrease demand diligent effort.*
*The wondrous seed knows no bounds—*
*The true essence of human origin, the verdict of the fire tally.’*"

[The boundless true seed originates from the great thousand worlds. With the proper method, one may amass it like grain in a granary. That which fills the heavens and earth without end is expounded in *The Precious Raft of Dual Cultivation*. What is difficult to attain is the emptiness and stillness within.

In this answer, the inner medicine refers to the prior heaven within the body; the outer medicine refers to the posterior heaven within the body. Our late Master, the Venerable Taixu, said: *"As Changchun the True Man stated: ‘In terms of the body, Kan lead is the outer medicine, Li mercury the inner medicine—yet it is merely body and mind. In terms of the world, the qi of Qian and Kun is the outer medicine, the essence of Kan and Li the inner medicine—yet it is merely prior and posterior.’* Thus, in discussing the Dao, the ultimate of Taiji is the outer medicine, while the ultimate of Wuji is the inner medicine.

When heaven and earth are ailing, one employs Taiji to replenish them; if that proves insufficient, one invokes Wuji to regenerate them. Such is the work of the perfected. This is recorded in *The Great Precepts of the Most High*, a transmission of our sect’s patriarchs, passed down generation after generation until it reached Ancestor Wang Kunyang, where it ceased. Though the teachings remain, the transmitted methods merely describe their meaning in empty terms—not because heaven has deprived us, but because the human heart is no longer as it once was.

I learned of this from my revered teacher, the Mud-Pill True Man, who recounted it after traversing the great thousand worlds. Of all the supreme mysteries he witnessed, none surpassed this. Yet he declared that the Dao would not remain forever hidden, citing the words of Changchun the True Man’s foremost disciple, the Venerable Zhao of Xuqing: *‘There are those to whom it has been transmitted.’*"

Our late Master’s discourse is recorded in *The Three-One Yin Talisman Scripture*; moved by it, I append it here to this answer.

Alas! My body, too, is the body of heaven and earth. Through profound return and ultimate restoration, one may deeply penetrate the boundless. Having attained the boundless, one may then breathe through the same nostrils as Wuji—how much more so, for the ancient perfected were not beings with three heads and six arms. As the ancients said: *‘Where there is will, there is accomplishment.’* Whether one succeeds or not is not the question; the matter lies within oneself. One must persist until death itself.]

May I inquire about the essence of *‘Drawing from Kan to fill Li, restoring my robust Qian body’*?

The Master said:
"Lead and mercury are the primordial qi of Taiji’s initial division; primordial qi is the qi of the Dragon and Tiger’s first crescent. The Tiger dwells within the northern Kan Water, its yang line originally emerging from Qian. Before the kalpa’s transition, Qian, in its precipitous decline, mistakenly plunged into Kun. Qian’s central line was thus lost, forming Li, where mercury naturally resides—hence the Yellow Male within Kan is named the Ancestor of Mercury."

The Dragon dwells within the southern Li Fire, and the yin line within Li originally belongs to Kun. After the tumultuous fall of primordial chaos, Kun, through nurturing receptivity, was united with Qian, and Kun’s central line thus became replete, forming Kan. Kan is fundamentally lead metal—hence the Dark Maiden within Li belongs to the Kan household.

Thus, male and female reside in separate chambers, lead and mercury in separate crucibles; yin and yang do not unite, and Heaven and Earth are obstructed. The sage employs intention as the Yellow Dame, guiding the Yellow Male within Kan to unite with the Dark Maiden within Li. Once husband and wife consummate, pure Qian is restored—this is called *‘Drawing from Kan to fill Li, restoring my primordial robust Qian body.’* As Master Ziyang said: *‘Take the solid core within Kan and transmute the emptiness within Li’s palace.’*

[For the method of *Drawing from Kan to fill Li*, none surpasses the practice in *The Principle of Golden Flower’s* chapter on *‘The Union of Kan and Li.’* The Patriarch said: *“All dissipation of essence and spirit, all movement and engagement with phenomena, belong to Li. All gathering and turning inward of spirit and consciousness, all stillness and inner containment, belong to Kan. That which strays outward through the seven orifices is Li; that which returns inward through the seven orifices is Kan. One yin governs the pursuit of forms and sounds, while one yang arises from returning to hearing and gathering sight. Kan and Li are yin and yang; yin and yang are nature and life; nature and life are body and mind; body and mind are spirit and qi. Once one collects the breath and prevents the spirit from flowing astray with external conditions, true union is achieved. And in silent cross-legged sitting, this is all the more so.”* Practicing in accordance with this method, one attains the secret of healing the world without fragmentation.]

"May I ask what is meant by 'subduing the dragon'?"

The Master said: "Li is the sun and becomes mercury; within it lies the earth of the self, forcibly named the dragon. Its form is fierce and malevolent, wielding the power to give life or take it, solely determining the path to immortality or Buddhahood. Its numinous might transforms endlessly, responding and thus penetrating all; its cloud-forms rain down, and the ten thousand things flow forth. In the *Zhouyi*, the nine in the second place of *Qian* states: 'The dragon appears in the field—it is beneficial to see the great person.' Confucius said: 'This is the dragon’s virtue, balanced and upright.'

Yet the world fails to comprehend this dragon’s life-giving power and instead often suffers its harm. If one can know it, revere it, and circumspectly master it, then one may subdue this fierce dragon, and the accumulation of the most refined mercury will not be difficult.

The method of subduing it lies in restraining the true fire within the heart. When the nature of fire does not fly upward, the dragon may be subdued, and the moment for casting lead arrives. Without accumulating mercury, how can one obtain lead? Without subduing the dragon, how can one tame the tiger? Moreover, true lead and true mercury do not easily unite, just as the true dragon and true tiger are difficult to restrain.

If the scholar can fully grasp this character of the dragon, then all else is but secondary."

[The supreme marvel of alchemical refinement lies in subduing the dragon; the foremost method of healing the world is rectifying the human heart. The secret is simply to let go of all things and invoke the Primordial Yang to infuse the world of Jambudvīpa. Morning and evening, persist in this, and the world’s customs will naturally be corrected. Then, draw upon the Qi of Primordial Yin to assist it, employing the preservation of the true wind. The former sage Shi’an once spoke of this principle of resonance, whose efficacy is divine—such is the reality of the Dao’s practical study. This discourse is recorded in Han Jichou’s *Records of the Three Mountains Studio*. Han was a renowned scholar of the Kangxi era, a man of literary and moral cultivation. Shi’an was his relative and friend, and these are no empty words.]

Someone asked, "What is meant by ‘subduing the tiger’?"

The master replied: "The moon in *Kan* is lead, and within it lies *wu*-earth—coercively named the tiger. Its form is wild and unruly; though it may harm and even kill, it harbors the vast qi of the Great Vehicle. Its movements command the wind’s majesty, and when struck, it responds. All-embracing and luminous, it nurtures the myriad things. The *Book of Changes* says, ‘Treading on the tiger’s tail, it does not bite the man—auspicious.’ Confucius says, ‘To walk in plain sincerity is to fulfill one’s solitary vow.’ If one can know it with awe and tame it with discipline, then one can subdue this wild tiger and produce the primordial lead. That subduing the dragon must be followed by subduing the tiger is because subduing the tiger eliminates the danger of being bitten. Thus, the sages of past ages took subduing the dragon as refining the self and subduing the tiger as upholding the heart. As Master Ziyang said, ‘If you wish to complete the nine transformations, you must first refine the self and uphold the heart’—this is the meaning."

[The secret of alchemical refinement is indeed thus. When applied to healing the world, the method lies solely in gathering the *kun*-primordial to pacify it. Why? Because only earth can ensure that those without constant property yet possess a constant heart.]

Someone asked, "What is meant by ‘the mind-seal and the robe-and-bowl’?"

The master answered: "Excellent that you ask this! The Buddha has the *Brahma Net Sutra* and *Dhāraṇī*; Heaven has the *Primordial Precepts* and *Jade Scripture*—these are the true mind-seal, the true robe-and-bowl. Yet their principles run deep, and their scope is boundless, like the sky that covers all and the earth that bears all. Even one as learned as Tripiṭaka Master [Xuanzang] merely translated their words but never embodied the essence of the *Dhāraṇī*. Even one as sagely as the Perfected Lord of Pure Yang merely recounted their teachings but never annotated a single word of the *Jade Scripture*. The Perfected Lord of Eastern Florescence said:
‘The Dharma-body is mighty, pervading heaven and earth;
The mind-nature is luminous, spanning past and present.
Not recognizing the Three Powers as originally one,
In vain does the mind-nature alone shine roundly.’

This speaks of the unity of body and world, world and mind, without inside or outside, without extinction or birth—only those who cultivate and realize this together are bodhisattvas, are celestial immortals. Thus, in our Buddha-Dao, only the Vinaya School truly transmits it. Yet though the robe-and-bowl have been passed down for over a thousand years, none have unveiled their cover to propagate the school’s spirit. It awaits the right person to arise, and the right time for that person to appear. Yet people are not beings from beyond heaven—everyone can learn, everyone can achieve. When the work of nature and life is complete, the meaning of the scriptures becomes clear, and their power illumines the great thousand worlds, pervading heaven and earth while operating within a single heart. This is the mechanism of emptiness and secrecy, the wondrous clarity of purity; the body of preservation and embrace, of awakening and luminous vastness. In smallness, not a speck of dust adheres; in greatness, it encompasses the sands of the world. The buddhas of the ten directions all breathe through this single nostril; the immortals of the three realms establish their lives and settle their bodies here; those who awaken to the Dao and realize the truth break through here; those who become buddhas and patriarchs are nurtured here. The Three Powers and Three Treasures—each treasure, each truth—are neither existent nor nonexistent, yet present within the compass. Its form is like the full moon, its appearance like Penglai. Yet it is neither heart nor kidney, neither viscera nor bowels. When released, it fills the six directions; when gathered, it retreats into secrecy. Demon-kings bow in submission; all sages take refuge. Like the red sun at zenith, yin-demons withdraw their forms; like the bright moon in the sky, its radiance must shine. Its mechanism turns the stars, its qi revolves the cosmos. Ancestors remain silent; masters stick out their tongues—this is the supreme and limitless true essence.

This is the principle of the Non-Ultimate True Emptiness, the teaching transmitted outside the scriptures. It is the undiminished numinous chapter, the esoteric canon never passed down by the myriad sages. Though translated and expounded in words, one must cultivate to see the original face, attain true and thorough awakening, then follow the work of water and fire, the methods of refinement. When the three fields are full and the three realms harmonious, one must further add nine years of nurturing—only then is the cultivation of the pure and vast Dharma-body complete, and all undertakings unfailingly verified.

The transmission of this Dao in our Mystery Gate began with the conferral of the celestial immortal precepts in the Jin dynasty, passed down through the generations and treasured in secrecy. Yet among the three thousand disciples of the Perfected Lord of Everlasting Spring, only eighteen immortals heard the Dao!"

A gāthā says:
Not that the Mystery Gate’s message runs deep—
High mountains and flowing waters find few who know the tune.
If one finds the path of return,
The infant’s heart originally connects to heaven and earth.

[This manuscript chapter differs greatly from the woodblock edition—perhaps later Dharma-heirs, alarmed by the disclosure of secret teachings, excised it, and unscrupulous Daoist peddlers further tampered with it, stripping away all core principles and profound meanings. Here, we restore the text according to the original mountain edition.]

Someone asked: What is meant by "gathering the medicine"?
The answer: The method of gathering the medicine is transmitted heart-to-heart, mouth-to-mouth, never to be lightly disclosed. Yet since you now inquire, are you not wise? At the hour between *hai* and *zi*, when the first yang stirs, in utter emptiness and profound stillness—where heart aligns with heaven and spirit unites with breath—primordial *qi* follows your inhalation into the Yellow Court. When the celestial cycle is complete and the cinnabar field seethes like boiling water, this is the true verification. When the hundred vessels feel like crawling insects and the four limbs blaze like fire, this is the secret of gathering the medicine and returning it to the crucible.

Someone asked: How does one "transform consciousness into wisdom" and "change the nature of qi-quality into Buddha-nature"?
The answer: The original celestial and true nature is inherently free from dust and defilement, unattached to any thing—this is the nature of the Great Perfect Mirror Wisdom. Yet when a single thought arises and merges with the mortal frame, it is led astray by acquired knowledge, thus turning into consciousness. To return to the root and restore the original state, at any time each day, concentrate the spirit and stabilize the breath, so that spirit and breath depend on one another, embracing the One without separation. At times, use virtuous methods to support your own heart; at times, use the Crimson Waters to moisten your own heart; at times, use circumstances to purify your own heart; at times, use forbearance to open your own heart; at times, use the insight of immortals and buddhas to awaken your own heart; at times, use the impartiality of immortals and buddhas to expand your own heart. Face the Dharma-eye of right vision and contemplate the wondrous heart of *nirvana*. With prolonged practice, the roots of dust are swept away, the six consciousnesses find no support, and your original face shines like the sun at midday. You recover your primal essence and restore the boundless creation—thus transforming consciousness into wisdom and changing the nature of qi-quality into Buddha-nature, truly with good reason.

Someone asked: If all sentient beings diligently cultivate the Dao, will they have protection? If they cannot practice but instead reverently uphold and make offerings to this scripture, will they gain merit?
The answer: If all sentient beings practice with sincere devotion, this is amassing vast hidden virtue. [When the physical body attains even a moment of harmony, the neighborhood immediately receives a moment’s benefit—how much more so if one maintains this all day and all month! The late Master Tai Xu said: “Master Ni Wan once said, ‘Practicing in three periods each day, within three months one will surely see verification.’ We wandering mendicants, without rank or wealth, when will we complete the three thousand merits and eight hundred deeds? The Most High, moved by compassion, thus bestowed this canon. Yet alas, the world lacks constancy—if the heart is not constant, how can one speak of practice? With unbroken practice, after three years the embryo is complete; this embryo is called the Embryo of Immeasurable Merit and Virtue. The guardian deities of the Dao patrol day and night, protecting it as the eyelid guards the eye—how could one’s practice fail to be perfected? However, the precepts have their substitutes: to know and not act is a sin without pardon! A single day brings one great transgression—how can one not fear? Our lineage’s Dharma-heirs endure many trials, perhaps because they neglect this. If one maintains daily practice, even for a quarter-hour, after nine years the Dao will surely be accomplished. If there are interruptions, they must be accounted for—this is overseen by the Three Primordials’ Merit-Examining Bureau. On the five *la* days of each year, during the Upper Primordial, reports are submitted to the Jade Palace—this is the regular procedure. When the neighborhood makes prayers and supplications, or when Buddhist and Daoist scriptures are recited, these also fall under the precepts of healing the world—something the world has yet to hear.”]

Thus spoke the late master; I dare not keep it secret and now respectfully share it with my fellow practitioners. The following text also conveys this meaning and is not mere mystical exaggeration. Whether explaining, transcribing, or making offerings, all fall under the same principle as prayer, supplication, and recitation—those who follow this will surely see verification. This is the compassionate concern of the Perfected, an expedient means to save those who have lost their way. Yet the great vow lies in practice.

The Jade Emperor decrees that the ten directions’ celestial immortals and flying heavenly divine kings attend to his left and right, guarding the true Dao as they guard the Jade Emperor. All demonic forces dare not encroach, and those who cultivate the truth shall see their nine ancestral lineages and seven generations ascend to the immortal realms. Should one be entangled by worldly ties and unable to cultivate, yet expound this true scripture for others or teach them to practice, the merit thus accrued shall be beyond conception.

If all sentient beings transcribe this true scripture with reverent purity, compiling its upper, middle, and lower scrolls into a complete volume, and enshrine it in a purified chamber with incense and lamps tended morning and evening without fail, then auspicious stars shall shine upon them, their dwellings shall radiate light, all buddhas shall surround and protect them, and the ten thousand sages shall bestow blessings. Disasters and illnesses shall be averted, and all prayers shall be answered. Even those afflicted with blindness, deafness, muteness, or dumbness—should they sincerely make offerings, prostrate before this true scripture, and persist in practice—shall surely awaken their spiritual nature and undergo a sudden transformation of their qi and disposition.

At that moment, the exchange concluded, an extraordinary fragrance filled the hall, and all present in the assembly gained clarity of their nature and destiny, suddenly awakening to enlightenment.

Then, from beneath the seat of the Master of Wisdom Hermitage, a disciple named Tranquil Extremity rose, approached the perfected one’s seat, bowed deeply, and knelt in reverence, extolling:

Great indeed is the supreme Dao, most exalted and honored!
It established heaven and founded the ultimate axis,
dispersing divine immortals across the cosmos.
Ancestor of heaven and earth,
root of the ten thousand things.
From primordial chaos and boundless void,
dim and obscure,
heaven quaked and earth split—
the Primordial One was born.
Opening and closing, the divine surge through the six gates.
Neither born nor extinguished,
scentless and soundless.
Luminous and unwavering,
eternal since ancient times.
Above, it pierces the clarity of heaven;
below, it illumines the tranquility of earth.
At the center, it establishes the imperial pole—
the Primordial One, most supreme.
The Three Sovereigns assist,
summoning and gathering the ten thousand spirits.
It governs the five qi,
uniting the hundred deities.
The stem of nature and destiny,
the balance of opening and closing.
The ten thousand spirits attend in guard,
demon kings offer protection.
Those with karmic affinity who encounter this scripture
can sever desire and extinguish the seven emotions.
Cultivating in accord with this scripture,
they restore their destiny to its root.
Firmly rooted, their spirit guards the court of destiny.
The three treasures of the cinnabar field are forged and refined,
solid and unyielding.
Spiritual power operates within,
revolving heaven and overturning earth.
Neither internal nor external,
all converges in the heart of Dao.
Heaven, earth, and humanity—
the six harmonies vast and level.
The infant ascends to verification,
styled a perfected one.
Propagating the true teaching,
universally ferrying across the sea of delusion.
Disseminating ten thousand scrolls,
repaying the celestial immortals above.
The orthodox lineage of Eastern Florescence,
the true scripture of the imperial pole.
Our master’s awakened transmission
guides later generations.
Upon attaining the Dao and ascending,
nine generations of ancestors ascend together.
Treasure and conceal it—
all sages revere it.

When the disciple Tranquil Extremity finished his recitation, the entire assembly leapt with joy, their faith deepened, and they bowed in reverence before departing.

---

**The Second Scroll (On Absorption and Elevation)**

Perfected Master Yin said: “One inhalation elevates—qi after qi returns to the navel. One elevation swallows—fire after fire meets.” These sixteen characters are the immortal’s life-preserving formula, so precious they are called the Sixteen Gold Ingots. They describe how each inhalation and exhalation traverses the Conception and Governor Vessels to return to the navel.

The human body embraces yang while holding yin: the Governor Vessel on the back pertains to yang, the Conception Vessel on the chest pertains to yin. The Governor Vessel has three barriers: the Tailbone Gate, the Spine Gate, and the Mud Pill Palace. The Conception Vessel has two segments: the lower from the root of yin to the navel, and the upper from the crown down to the navel.

Human breathing occurs naturally, but the entire practice hinges on the two “elevation” characters. In stillness, one subtly employs intention and the power of the eyes to elevate. Yet excessive effort will harm rather than help.

With one inhalation into the abdomen, subtly employ intention and the power of the eyes to elevate from the root of yin, drawing it into the navel. “Elevate” means lifting the qi of one inhalation through the lower segment of the Conception Vessel to the navel—this is what is meant by “one inhalation elevates, qi after qi returns to the navel.”

One elevation is one exhalation. During exhalation, subtly employ intention and the power of the eyes to draw the qi into the Governor Vessel, traversing the spine from the Tailbone Gate to the crown. Ordinary people do not circulate the Governor Vessel, so the Tailbone Gate is also called a barrier. When qi is elevated into the Governor Vessel, the Tailbone Gate opens through the waist. The Spine Gate is another barrier; both the Tailbone and Spine Gates are easily opened, but the crown barrier is most difficult to pass—hence called the Mud Pill Palace. With prolonged practice, the Mud Pill Palace will naturally open. When it does, the joy is indescribable—ancients likened it to celestial ambrosia or to the bliss of union.

Once the Mud Pill Palace opens, the qi is swallowed into the upper segment of the Conception Vessel and returned to the navel. This “swallowing” is neither swallowing essence nor swallowing qi. When qi descends from the crown through the throat, a slight intake returns it to the navel. Before the Mud Pill Palace opens, the entire practice lies in the two “elevation” characters. Swallowing pertains to matters after the barriers are opened.

The Dao is spoken of as the interplay of yin and yang; breathing is spoken of as the interplay of exhalation and inhalation. When both inhalation and exhalation return to the navel, yin and yang are firmly conjoined—this is what is meant by “water and fire meeting.” One *cun* and three *fen* within the navel lies the cinnabar field. Returning to the navel means returning to the cinnabar field. Before birth, fetal breathing occurs here; immortals refine the elixir here—it is truly the bellows of qi and the body’s Supreme Ultimate.

When the Conception and Governor Vessels circulate and water and fire conjoin, each breath irrigates the entire body. How then could illness arise?

Herein lies a swift method for nurturing life: releasing all entanglements to nourish yin, and gathering fire to open the barriers to assist yang. The technique is this—with each inhalation, draw upward from the *weilu*; with each exhalation, send downward from the *niwan*. As the breath ascends, it unifies the inner and outer of the back, and yang qi rises abundantly and universally. As the breath descends, it unifies the forehead and the inner and outer of the chest, flowing smoothly downward through the chest, abdomen, and waist, and within to the five viscera and six bowels, unimpeded and at ease. Gradually gather with intention, directing all to the lower extremity, and focus the spirit for twenty-four breaths, until one reaches a state of near-forgetfulness, then cease effortlessly. Practicing thus daily without interruption not only averts illness but may also prolong life.

This annotation was originally composed by my ninth-generation ancestor, Master Xuesuo, and later revised and supplemented by the disciple Min Yide.

---

**Third Section (On the Foundation)**

Master Yin the Perfected One states: The foundation of Dao cultivation lies in seeing one’s nature.

Man’s nature resides in the two eyes by day, stored in the *niwan*; by night, it resides in the two kidneys, stored in the cinnabar field. The ancient worthies said: “The heart is the trigger, the eyes are thieves. To restrain the heart, first restrain the eyes.” For just as the crossbow’s release depends on the trigger, the heart’s distractions arise from the eyes. If the trigger does not move, the crossbow remains still; if the eyes do not move, the heart remains still. The *Yinfu Jing* says, “The trigger lies in the eyes,” and the *Daode Jing* says, “Not seeing what is desirable keeps the heart from disorder.” Laozi said, “Abide in non-desire to observe its mystery; abide in desire to observe its manifestations”—this is what he meant. The Yellow Emperor’s three months of inner observation refer to this. Thus, observing the heart leads to attaining the Dao, naturally stilling thoughts and dissolving delusion. Longevity and enduring vision, the interdependence of heart and breath—all depend on the eyes. Where the eyes go, the heart follows; where the heart goes, qi follows.

Now, the lower cinnabar field is the root of life, and the upper cinnabar field is the origin of nature. Proceeding from below to reach above is the gradual method; beginning above while encompassing the middle and lower is the sudden method. The *Huangting Jing* states: “Within the Jade Chamber lies the Gate of Spirit. If you wish not to die, refine the Kunlun.”

Before this body existed, breath already did. At the moment of conception, one’s breath followed the mother’s inhalation and exhalation. This thread connected to the mother—forward to the navel, backward to the kidneys, upward through the spine to the *niwan*, reaching the *shangen* to form the two nostrils—this is called the “ancestral nose.” At that time, one’s qi communicated with the mother’s qi, and the mother’s qi communicated with the qi of heaven and earth. When the placenta ruptured at birth, a spark of original yang descended to the place where life is established. Thereafter, postnatal qi governed, and though breath continued to come and go, it could no longer connect with the primordial ancestral qi—merely because the old path from the time of arrival could not be found.

The Most High established the method of cultivating immortality to seize the upright qi of heaven and earth precisely because of these two apertures of breath. Yet today’s practices of regulating breath, counting breaths, or restraining breath all fail to reach the primordial gate. This is entirely because they do not find the proper entrance.

When a person is born, the first aperture congeals, giving rise to the two kidneys. Next, the heart is formed. The heart and kidneys are separated by eight *cun* and four *fen*, with a remaining space of one *cun* and two *fen*—this is the path of communication between heart and kidneys, the realm where water and fire meet. To open this aperture, one must focus intention on the *shangen*, so that the breath’s qi flows directly into the *mingtang*. Then, all nine apertures, eight vessels, twelve meridians, and fifteen collaterals of the body circulate and connect without obstruction. It is like grasping the net’s headrope or the stars revolving around the pole—how could the myriad streams not converge toward the source, achieving a single attainment that endures forever? The subtlety of the elixir path begins here.

---

**Fourth Section (On the Chamber of Spirit)**

Master Yin the Perfected One states: The foundation is called “ascending the hall.” Let us now elaborate on the subtlety of “entering the chamber.”

At that time, a disciple silently inquired: “Is there a difference between original nature and original spirit?”

The Master replied: Original nature is original spirit; there is no difference. Because it is spiritually penetrating and unfathomable, responding wondrously without fixed form, it is called “spirit.” It is termed “original” to distinguish it from postnatal thinking.

“Does the spirit within a person have a dwelling?”

The Master said: I have heard from Master Ziqing the Immortal that a person has three valleys, which are the chambers of the original spirit and the abode of the numinous nature. They are hollow like valleys, hence also called “valley spirit.” When the spirit dwells there, one lives; when it departs, one dies. By day, it engages with the external world; by night, it engages with dreams—thus the spirit does not rest in its dwelling.

The *Lingshu Jing* states: “The Heavenly Valley is the original spirit; guard it to remain true.” Within the human body, the upper is called the Heavenly Valley, which is the *niwan*; the middle is called the Responsive Valley, which is the *jiangong*; the lower is called the Numinous Valley, which is the *guanyuan*. The spirit dwells in these three valleys, which are called the three fields.

Allow me to further expound: The *niwan* is the original palace where the spirit resides; the *jiangong* is the bright hall where governance is enacted...

The Numinous Valley is the secluded chamber for cultivation and refinement. Thus, when the original spirit resides in the *jiangong*, the ears hear, the eyes see, the five senses fulfill their functions, and the hundred parts of the body follow its commands. When the original spirit resides in the Numinous Valley, vision turns inward, hearing withdraws, spirit and *qi* guard each other, and the *hun* and *po* embrace unity.

Yangzi said: “Conceal the heart in the abyss, and the numinous root will flourish.” The abyss is a place of profound obscurity, unfathomable depth—this is the Numinous Valley, the *qi*-cavern. As Liao Chanhui observed: “Before it faces the navel-wheel, behind it faces the kidneys; at its center lies a true golden tripod.” This is precisely the chamber for concealing the spirit. (Here, the text broadly speaks of the original spirit as the original nature, without yet addressing the formation of the embryo, merely indicating the dwelling place of the spirit.)

**Fifth Chapter (On the River Cart)**
Master Yin said: Once the spirit is concealed, it is called “returning to the root.” Returning to the root is called stillness; stillness is called the restoration of life. Then, spirit and *qi* guard each other, embracing unity without separation. When stillness reaches its extreme and movement arises, the spirit, riding the mechanism of *qi*, ascends to the *niwan*, and thus the path of the River Cart begins to open.

Know that the path of the River Cart is none other than the *ren* and *du* meridians before and behind the body. When *qi* first ascends, it wells up gently, steaming between the two kidneys, vast as a rising tide, melting as thawing ice. Overflowing above the five *shu* points, it courses like water spilling beyond its channels. One must swiftly return the spirit to the *weilu*, guiding it to ascend along the *weilu* to the *jiaji* double pass, then up through the *fengfu* to the *niwan*. Where spirit and *qi* meet, their smooth flow and fusion go without saying. After a while, it descends as a fresh and sweet fluid, passing through the *chonglou* down to the *jiangong*, entering the *qi*-cavern, and returning to its concealed abode to rest.

In such circulation and infusion, over time and with mastery, *qi* fills the three fields, and upper and lower harmonize—this is what is meant by “always let *qi* surge through the joints, and naturally essence will fill and the valley spirit will abide.” At this stage, the true realm of internal refinement appears. Yet without profound attainment and ultimate realization, how could one know the validity of my words!

**Sixth Chapter (On Secret Transmission)**
Before sitting, first regulate the mind: empty and still, like silence itself. When matters arise, attend to them; when they depart, forget them. Set aside success and failure, and simply do one’s utmost. Next, regulate *qi* to be full and vast. When it should ascend, let it ascend; when it should descend, let it descend. Set aside effort and simply await the ripening of the mechanism.

For *qi* arises from the mind; when the mind is regulated, *qi* naturally follows. In such practice, unbroken continuity is most excellent. With continuity, body and mind are naturally at peace. Thus, sitting is not confined to the *zi* or *wu* hours—whenever there is leisure, sit. (Here, “leisure” is not written as idle but as *xian*, which holds subtle efficacy.) Nor is cross-legged posture required, but the hands must be held in *wogu* (a hand-seal: press the thumbnail into the crease between the *hai* and *zi* positions, grasp with the four fingers, and use the middle segment of the middle finger to press down on the tip of the thumb. If startled, grip more firmly, and the shock will settle. Hence the name *wogu*—this is an essential technique for calming alarm.)

Once the body is still, stopping thoughts comes first. Moment by moment, turn the gaze inward and illuminate from the empty space before the forehead, visualizing a red-yellow moon suspended at the *shangen*, whether bright or dim, as it may be. From here, let breath and mind depend on each other, with no thoughts beyond this, only the awareness of the three fields as one. All phenomenal forms, the vast emptiness of the mysterious state—none are one’s original nature. Let them appear or vanish as they will, without being swayed by thoughts. This is the central principle, the supreme Way of the *Zhouyi*: “thought does not transgress its proper place.”

Yet the human mind is most subtle, and for beginners, how could it be so effortless? There is a saying: “Fear not the arising of thoughts, only the delay in awareness.” And another: “The arising of thoughts is illness; not continuing them is the medicine.” Thus, there is the principle of “extinguishing the moving mind, not the illuminating mind.” Once body and mind are settled, one must also return illumination to a place (that is, a locus).

This is called “using the one to govern the ten thousand.” Initially, guide the spirit back to its chamber—the chamber of the spirit. In such embodied illumination, one naturally feels this place to be empty, still, and profoundly clear. When one reaches the state of spontaneity, without relying on visualization, this is to perceive the original substance of one’s mind. How could a beginner attain this? Only after long abiding in stillness does this state appear. If one wishes to preserve this and advance further, one must not forget yet seem to forget—then the inner expanse becomes boundless, as clear and still as this.

In such practice, always stop thoughts and return illumination, moment by moment. After seven days of such practice, one may shift the gaze downward from this scene to the interior of the navel, naturally entering the lower field, where warm *qi* follows the gaze downward. Then, rotate the eyes inward: first from center to periphery, gradually widening the rotation, until the lower field feels more spacious. Then reverse the rotation, from periphery to center, gradually deepening it. Within, one naturally feels profound depth, and warm *qi* arises internally, gradually simmering like boiling water. If the mind remains like still water, a cool droplet will emerge in the *jiangong*—this is the true sign of the descending tally.

At this moment, a hot *qi* will rise from the cavity to meet it, reaching the area below the diaphragm, swirling left and right, steaming upward as if awaiting something. One must then focus the mind and gaze to welcome it. In response, after a short while, a cool fluid wells up from behind the heart, meeting the hot *qi* from the kidneys. A scene of indescribable delight unfolds—swallowing and spitting, unceasing and boundlessly refreshing.

Do not cling to this state—immediately withdraw. Gently turn the inner gaze of both eyes toward the profound depth, then guide with the mind’s intent, causing this *qi*-mechanism to revolve within the abdomen. At first, it expands from small to large, then contracts again to small, ultimately guiding the two *qi* to merge as one in the *qihai*. This is the union of *Kan* and *Li*, also called the "Small Celestial Cycle," the true function of the descending tally.
