For this single aperture, the Dao calls it the Mysterious Female; in Confucian terms, it is the boundary between humanity and animality; in Buddhism, it is the divide between Māra and Buddha—all hanging by a thread. Yet this Mysterious Aperture, being left as yang and right as yin, is called the Mysterious Female. How then does it differ from the Confucian “humanity and animality” or the Buddhist “Māra and Buddha”? The reason is that its yang is true yang and its yin is true yin, both belonging to the primordial, and thus it can be universally called the Mysterious Aperture. Master Niwan states: “When the mechanism moves, one enters the Mysterious; when it is still, one enters the Female—this is the ultimate Dao of naturalness.” However, the *Treatise on Dispelling Doubts in Immortal Cultivation* says, “Where the thought moves is the Mysterious Female.” What does this mean? Observing movement from stillness, it is precisely what Confucianism and Buddhism call the boundary between humanity and animality or Māra and Buddha. Yet the *Preface to the Four Hundred Words on the Golden Elixir* states, “Within the human body, seek it not elsewhere,” and its main text says, “This aperture is no ordinary aperture; it is jointly formed by Heaven and Earth.” Master Niwan further says: “This is a provisional method, yet without seeking here, there is no way to enter. Why? This single aperture is so vast that nothing lies beyond it, so small that nothing lies within it. Thus, a millet grain can contain the great thousand worlds and embrace the Three Powers.” The teachings of Master Ziyang are most direct and accessible! Our ancestral master Niwan, in his compassion, revealed this provisional method—how profound, how profound! The Three Powers all reside within the Mysterious Aperture; how could my body lie outside it? If my body is within the aperture, how could my body’s ancestral aperture lie outside the Mysterious Aperture? Therefore, trust and enter directly through the ancestral aperture, following it with thought extinguished and emotions forgotten—then indeed, everything will be naturally free. Not daring to keep this secret, I respectfully share it with fellow cultivators, hoping they will calmly embody it.)*

Within the human body, between the heart below and the kidneys above, lies a space of one inch and two fen—this is the aperture of the primordial, original ancestral qi. Scholars must clearly recognize this path before they can progress in cultivation and enter the Great Dao. They must gather and refine every aspect of the physical form, so that the original spirit may have its proper dwelling. As the ancients said: “There is a precious pearl concealed within the mountain of form.” Little do they know that this pearl resides within the six sense gates, constantly radiating great light—yet most people remain unaware, living and dying in vain. Now, I clearly point out the path. Though the human body has six sense gates, they all originate from one root. The essential mechanism is this: the Three Origins merge into one, the Four Images harmonize, and all return to emptiness and nothingness. Still the body, heart, and intent; gather the acquired spirit and return it to the Central Palace. Constantly maintain awareness, moment by moment align with the center, and practice the work of embracing the primordial and guarding the One. Over time, with mastery, essence, qi, and spirit become complete, the foundation of the Mysterious Female is established, true qi is generated, and true lead is transformed. Only then, by investigating the subsequent methods, will the work bear fruit. This is the wondrous mechanism of celestial immortals’ cultivation and realization. Those who attain it immediately ascend to the realm of sages—how could one without great wisdom ever comprehend these profound mysteries?

*(Min Xiaogen notes: Though this section describes provisional methods, without such practices, learners have no path forward. The Mysterious Pass and its profundities are nearly impossible to open, yet the method of opening lies not in effortful action but in the four characters: emptiness, nothingness, non-movement. The so-called “path” is this single root; the so-called “practice” is the merging into one, the harmonizing, the returning, the gathering, and the refining. Once returned to the palace, one has penetrated the Mysterious Aperture—this is the first step of the provisional method. Constant awareness is the second step’s essential secret; moment-by-moment alignment with the center is the third step’s practice. Following this cultivation, what is held is the primordial, what is guarded is the One. What is the primordial? The original ancestral qi. What is the One? The original nature itself. With long practice, one naturally achieves mastery. Once mastery is attained, the Three Treasures become complete.)*

Yet when it speaks not of "establishing the foundation," this refers only to the initial stage of the Mysterious Female’s inception—where *qi* has not yet transformed into primordial *qi*, and the original mandate remains unrecovered. Only when *qi* returns and transmutes into primordial *qi*, when true lead first arrives, may one proceed with the lower secret. The practitioner must keenly recognize that within this fleeting moment of living midnight, the instant lead arrives and mercury responds, coagulation occurs—all dependent upon the sufficiency of refining the self and laying the foundation.

Master Tai Xu states: “When yang arises, yin responds—this is a principle that arrives unbidden.” Master Ni Wan observes: “Do not fret that true yin will fail to answer; only fear that yang’s arising may not be genuine.” Let the practitioner take heed!

Once prior efforts have ripened, one may then engage in the practice of preserving spirit within the *qi*-cavern. Gather the three—eyes, ears, and nose—turning them inward: the eyes do not gaze outward, the ears do not listen outward, the nose does not smell outward. Thus, the primordial spirit wholly returns to the *qi*-cavern, where breathing naturally becomes harmonized, continuous yet subtle—this is the true oral instruction for nurturing the medicine. Chen Xu Bai says: “Lower the curtains, seal the senses, restrain desire, regulate the breath; detach from form, relinquish intellect—this approaches seated oblivion. I urge you: remain silent all day like a fool, and refine a wish-fulfilling pearl.” Bai Yu Chan declares: “I once received my teacher’s true oral instruction: simply preserve spirit within the *qi*-cavern.” All speak of the oral instructions for laying the foundation.

Of old, Ancestral Master Liu Ming An said: “To begin, establish the elixir’s foundation—examine the midnight and noon. In stillness, at the first movement, this is the moment when *gui* is born.” Such words are addressed to those newly entering the circle. The so-called “establishing the elixir’s foundation” refers only to the work of nurturing the medicine, not to the gathering of the great medicine. “Do not rely on midnight and noon” cautions against confusing this with the inner circulation of *qi* through the midnight-noon cycle, or with the practice of working at the hours of *zi* and *wu*. The phrase “do not rely” serves to clarify the sequence of practice. The “moment” here refers to that spoken of in the *Mirror of Entering the Medicine*: “At any of the twelve hours, wherever intention reaches, that is the moment”—why cling to the *zi* and *wu* hours? “In stillness, at the first movement” denotes the instant when yin reaches its extreme and yang is born, when emptiness attains its utmost and stillness is profound. Thus, this movement is “the moment when *gui* is born.”

The Ancestor exposes the ford of delusion, teaching that upon seeing yang arise, one should immediately gather it—lest one wait until *gui* is full and the opportunity lost, exhausting spirit in vain. If one gathers only when *gui* is full, one obtains merely the yang *qi* that arises in accord with the seasons, not the great medicine. Only by gathering at the first movement in stillness does one obtain the primordial yang of the time before the ten thousand things were born—the divine mother that gives birth to heaven, earth, and all beings, the very primordial unity of *qi*.

Min Xiao Gen remarks: According to careful examination, the arising of yang at the outset, though spontaneous, still belongs to the provisional method. Thus, the yang that is gathered pertains only to the yang of the individual body. Though called “prior to heaven,” it remains within the realm of “after heaven.” Even in the *Mirror of Entering the Medicine*, where yang’s arising is not provisional, it is said to occur “where intention reaches,” still contingent upon intention. What is thus aroused remains “after the prior to heaven”—hence the precise distinction that it is “not the great medicine.” Ni Wan states: “At any of the twelve hours, when the mechanism stirs suddenly, this is the *qi* of the prior to heaven—do not underestimate it. One who gathers it in time obtains the supreme treasure. The ancients who attained it, if their form and spirit were not yet full, used it to adorn and complete the outer enclosure, or to refine the divine chamber and the yellow court.” This teaching, repeatedly affirmed by my disciple Yang Lin, is thoroughly understood. Let all fellow practitioners ponder it.

As for the true arising of the *zi*-yang and the obtaining of the great medicine, this is not a fixed rule. Tai Xu says: “When encounter and response occur amid the body’s utmost emptiness and the time’s profound stillness, what is obtained is immeasurable, and what is born is unfathomable. But if one has not attained emptiness and stillness, or has attained only emptiness without stillness, there is no possibility of obtaining it.” Thus, whenever I speak of the method of observing return, it invariably revolves around the two phrases of the secret: “attain utmost emptiness, preserve profound stillness.” How many truly know this secret?

Now that I am old and soon to return to emptiness, if this secret is not transmitted, it will be like a lion without fur—roaring soundlessly, leaving only regret. Therefore, I have revised and clarified this section on the meaning of “moment,” adding annotations here. May readers treasure and embody it.

The alchemical classics say: “Heaven attains the One and becomes clear; earth attains the One and becomes tranquil; humanity attains the One and achieves longevity.” This primordial unity of *qi* emerges from emptiness and nothingness, yet it is not mere vacuous emptiness. It is the preservation of stillness to the extreme of emptiness. Dwelling within the dim and obscure, in the great settling of chaos, spirit and clarity naturally arrive. The one numinous essence remains ever luminous—this is the true prior to heaven, empty yet not empty.

Min Xiao Gen remarks: This “prior to heaven” is not merely the prior to heaven of the individual body; it is the ancestral *qi* of the Great Ultimate, not the *qi* of dualistic emptiness and fullness. Hence, it is “empty yet not empty.” In my humble opinion, “this prior to heaven” refers to the *qi* of the Great Ultimate, while “yet not” refers to the *qi* flowing through the three powers. In describing the method, it speaks of attaining stillness within emptiness—its meaning is profoundly subtle. Emptiness is the substance, stillness is the practice; without stillness, one cannot obtain it, and without stillness within emptiness, one cannot obtain it fully. I feared that practitioners might suspect this contradicts earlier annotations on the method, so I have taken up my brush to clarify it. As for the ancestral *qi* of the Great Ultimate, when obtained, it serves as the mother; when the *qi* flowing through the Great Ultimate is obtained, it serves as nourishment—both are the great medicine, yet each has its distinction.

For the Great Ultimate arises from the two primal forces, yet this ancestral *qi* in turn precedes the Great Ultimate—when obtained, it forms the embryo, hence it is called the mother. The flowing *qi*, however, is the *qi* emitted by the three powers within the Great Ultimate. In creation, it is prior to heaven; in the Dao, it is posterior to heaven. Within it, purity and turbidity are uneven, and it can only be gathered for nourishment, hence it is said to serve as sustenance.

Those of middling and lesser attainment who obtain this to form an embryo produce but an illusory shadow, not the sacred infant. Thus, the following three sections of practice formulas are provided to distinguish and expound these matters, making clear that human capacity differs and the grades of elixir vary.

Now, *ren* is yang water, the ethereal and pure *qi*; *gui* is yin water, the substance of matured medicine. Alchemists favor yang and disfavor yin—*gui* water is what the Dao of the elixir shuns. For true yang, when born, possesses *qi* but no substance, being the *qi* of pure yang. Delay but slightly, and substance arises! Once substance is born, it becomes *gui* water, a heavy and turbid thing—how could it ascend in reverse flow?

This is why Ancestor Master Ziyang taught the oral formula: *“When lead meets the birth of *gui*, swiftly gather it; when gold reaches its fullness, it is no longer fit to taste.”* Whenever *gui* is said to be born, it is feared that it will arise, not welcomed—do not mistake the birth of *gui* for the birth of yang, for that would be most unwise.

Once yang is born, it must be drawn with true intention into the Central Palace to unite with the true yin within *li*—this is the initial work of dragon-tiger intercourse.

---

Min Xiaogen says: The discourse on the Dao of the elixir favoring yang and shunning *gui* is indeed an immutable principle. Yet if one practices for the sake of nurturing life and the moment has passed, it may still not be discarded. There is another method: after breaking through the summit, simply allow it to disperse throughout the body. Then, forgetting form to cultivate *qi*, a cool delight fills the heart, transforming into true yin. Flowing through the four limbs, returning to the hundred channels, moistening the sinews and joints—this too is a wondrous formula for nourishing the physical form. Only beware of retaining it in the palace, lest it turn into *yin* clouds.

The Elder of Great Emptiness spoke thus for those who take up the Dao in old age, offering this teaching, which resembles the *Returning and Restoring Method* of True Man Shi Xinglin. Those in their prime must not rashly adopt it.

The *Elixir Classics* state: "The dragon emerges from fire," meaning the dragon is born within *li*; and "The tiger is born in water," meaning the tiger is born within *kan*. The method of elixir-making proceeds thus: at the outset, the dragon is summoned by the tiger; thereafter, the tiger responds to the dragon. When emptiness reaches its utmost and stillness its deepest, simply sink the original spirit into the *qi*-cavern, allowing it to inhale and exhale of its own accord. No contrivance may be imposed, nor any intention of seeking achievement entertained. One must remain leisurely and at ease, without attachment, lest disharmony arise—only then does it accord with the spirit’s function. Over time, the breath need not be regulated, for harmony will naturally abound. If one must rise and move, first close the eyes and sit in stillness, allowing it to return to its former cavern, and only arise once absolute quietude is attained. Take heed, take heed! Should one be compelled to rise due to unavoidable circumstances, once the matter is resolved, resume the prior practice—this too is a method of adjustment.

Min Xiaogen notes: The passage beginning "at the outset" corresponds to the *Four Hundred Words on the Golden Elixir*’s "true earth captures true lead"; the subsequent "thereafter" corresponds to "true lead refines true mercury"; the "simply sink" passage corresponds to "lead and mercury return to true earth"; and the "allowing it" passage corresponds to "body and mind remain unmoving in quiescence." The essential principles of elixir-refinement are here fully encompassed! Those who have not yet understood the dragon and tiger must seek a clear-sighted teacher’s guidance to recognize that these are metaphors for the unrefined mind and body. The key oral instructions in this section lie in the two instances of "listening": first, "no contrivance may be imposed," and second, "nor any intention entertained"—these are the utmost cautions. The phrases "one must," "without," "lest," and "only then" convey what earnest admonitions! Fearing that the seeker may be overly eager for results, the text further advises that "over time," harmony will naturally arise. We who study these teachings must aim for clarity—how can we pass over them carelessly? Yet this is the very affliction of learners throughout the world. Thus, I append these few words as a sincere exhortation: may fellow seekers correct their faults if they exist, or redouble their efforts if they do not. As the ancients said: "Reading requires a single eye—nothing more than thorough embodiment."

Beginning forty-nine days before the Winter Solstice, one must first apply effort, so that the solitary yang revives beneath the five yins. With this primordial qi, one transforms the postnatal spirit into a yang spirit—this is a rare method in the world, its subtlety how easily spoken of! Yet in the foundational work of cultivating the medicine and in the practice of gathering the great medicine, each has its distinctions; they must not be conflated in a single, undifferentiated process. Only then may one be called a clear and penetrating adept of our Way.

Min Xiaogen notes: This preliminary effort is precisely the practice of self-mastery. For in cultivating the supreme Dao, one must first open the mysterious aperture; if this aperture remains closed, progress in practice is nearly impossible. Yet it is not through mere circulation that it opens—self-mastery is essential. When one’s thoughts are purified of impurities, the will becomes pure and unified. With will and thought thus mastered and unified, the mysterious aperture will naturally become luminously open. My teacher, Master Taixu, has already expounded this in detail. However, fearing that some may harbor expectations of quick results, I have no choice but to reiterate the forty-nine-day period. Students should examine themselves: if the mind is not yet purified, why not begin at the Summer Solstice? Or even at the Winter Solstice of the previous year? This aligns with the first chapter’s principle of “the longer the accumulation, the better”—it is not a matter of rigidly fixed deadlines.

The distinction between cultivating the medicine and gathering the great medicine has already been clarified above; I shall not repeat it here. Yet there remains a great doubt, seldom addressed in ancient or modern alchemical texts, and even this book does not touch upon it—how many earnest seekers have been misled by it! Having come to understand it, I dare not leave it unexamined.

Take, for example, Ancestor Bai Ziqing’s *On Dispelling Doubts in Immortal Cultivation*, a text recited by every disciple of our lineage as if it were household scripture. Yet most recite it carelessly, glossing over the very crux of the matter. What is this doubt? It is the word *gathering*. Those who do not embody the practice are like riders galloping past flowers—they do not even question the word, let alone discern its meaning. But for those who seek true realization, the misunderstanding leads to forced effort, blind groping, and straying onto side paths, while this treatise is cast aside, a lamentable outcome.

Does the *Treatise* not state: “Take the body as the crucible, the mind as mercury, stillness as water, and wisdom as fire”? And further: “Use essence, spirit, ethereal soul, corporeal soul, and intention as the medicinal ingredients; take movement, stillness, sitting, and lying as the firing times; and employ clarity and naturalness as the method of operation.” As for the refining process, it says: “Take the body as the altar, furnace, tripod, and stove; the mind as the chamber of spirit; seated meditation as the gathering; vigilant attention as the firing; action and cessation as advance and retreat; interruption and distraction as the embankment; operation as withdrawal and replenishment; true qi’s steaming as bathing; cessation of thought as nurturing the fire; subduing body and mind as field combat; concentrating spirit and gathering qi as defending the city; forgetting scheming and severing deliberation as life and death; the movement of thought as the mysterious female; forging into a single mass as union; returning to the root and restoring life as the elixir’s completion; transferring spirit as changing the vessel; having a body outside the body as shedding the husk; returning to the origin and reverting to the source as the true teaching; and shattering emptiness as the ultimate attainment.”

How clear this is! Gathering occurs solely in seated meditation—if this doubt remains unresolved, one may stray in entirely the wrong direction, toiling a lifetime without success, attributing failure to insufficient fortune, a grievous pity. I urge all fellow seekers: first embody the word *cultivate*. Though the medicines may be three, the method of gathering is without duality.

The union of Kan and Li.

For the adept in the cultivation of the Dao, once the foundation is firmly established, one must not grow lax. Continue as before: regulate the breath through the nose, seal the tongue’s qi, concentrate the ears on inner resonance, and close the valley passage. The four images harmonize and return to emptiness and nothingness. Ensure the body and mind remain unmoving, gathering the acquired spirit and returning it to the place of the True Person’s breath. Guard this without losing it, merging with the qi, and naturally attaining the utmost emptiness and profound stillness.

Suddenly, one senses a subtle movement at the sea bottom, and a light shines through—like a crescent moon newly hung in the southwest, akin to the moon of the third day rising in the *geng* direction. This is the initial appearance of the Metal qi. Within *Kan*, a single point of warmth surges upward to the heart’s sovereign. With intention, guide it downward along the Yellow Path: piercing the *Weilü*, passing through the *Jiaji*, penetrating the *Yuzhen*, entering the *Niwan*, and traversing the nine palaces. From the upper palate, it descends in a gentle, warm flow, like dripping water—fragrant as awakening *ghee*, sweet as ambrosia. The eyes send it into emptiness; the mind welcomes it into nothingness. It returns of itself to the cauldron: this is the marvel of the union of *Kan* and *Li*.

Min Xiaogen notes: This is the method of returning and restoration, the initial practice of embryonic breathing. The statement that “after attaining the utmost emptiness and profound stillness, light shines through the curtains, appearing like a crescent moon” follows conventional teachings, though it may not always be so. Sometimes it manifests as a millet grain or a pearl, yet it invariably appears in the abdomen—termed the *Kun* position or *geng* direction—merely to illustrate the initial emergence of the Metal qi. The claim that “a single point of warmth surges to the heart” is not fixed; one must simply guide it downward with intention. As for the original text’s “piercing the *Weilü* by the Yellow Path and passing the *Yuzhen*,” this is a grave error, surely a corruption or omission. Thus, it has been amended to “by the Yellow Path piercing the *Weilü*, then passing through the *Jiaji*, penetrating the *Yuzhen*, and entering the *Niwan*.”

Within the human body, there are three paths: the Black, the Red, and the Yellow. The Yellow Path ascends straight along the central seam before the kidneys and behind the navel; it is the path that runs before the spine and behind the heart, directly piercing the *Niwan*. The Red Path follows the *Ren* channel in reverse, meeting the Black and adhering to the Yellow, ascending to the *Zhen* position, then again meeting the Black and adhering to the Yellow to return to the *Jiang* palace. The Black Path, originating from the sea, meets the Red, adheres to the Yellow, and ascends in reverse, piercing the *Lü* to penetrate the *Zhen*, then from the *Zhen* position, meeting the Red and adhering to the Yellow, descending along the forehead to the *Chi* pool, and returning to the *Jiang* palace to flow back into the sea. Such are the three paths’ courses, and the reasons for their names are little known in the world, though in truth they correspond to the Three Treasures of body, heart, and intention.

The heart pertains to *Qian*, whose original position is in *Li*, its color red—hence the Red Path, which is the *Ren* channel of the body. The nature of the *Ren* tends upward; cultivation must cause it to descend. The body pertains to *Kun*, whose original position is in *Kan*, its color black—hence the Black Path, which is the *Du* channel of the body. The nature of the *Du* tends downward; cultivation must cause it to ascend. This is called inverting yin and yang, for the *Du* is yang while the *Ren* is yin. The terms *Du* and *Ren* derive their meaning from *Qian*’s strength and *Kun*’s compliance. Intention pertains to Earth, its color yellow—hence the Yellow Path.

Conventional teachings thus describe the Red and Black as the Human Path and the Yellow as the Immortal Path. How could one fail to grasp their significance? My disciple Yang Lin’s exegesis of the *Four Hundred Words on the Golden Elixir* is exceedingly clear. His commentary states: “*Kan* is the body, *Li* is the heart, and the foundation of *Kan* and *Li* is intention. In the prior heavens, *Kan* resides in the west as *po*; in the posterior heavens, it resides in the north, where *po* has already flowed into essence. Now, uniting prior and posterior heavens and merging essence and *po* into one is the body. In the prior heavens, *Li* resides in the east as *hun*; in the posterior heavens, it resides in the south, where *hun* has already manifested as spirit. Now, uniting prior and posterior heavens and merging spirit and *hun* into one is the heart. Only Earth, residing at the center and harmonizing the four images, serves as the foundation of *Kan* and *Li* in both prior and posterior heavens, never altering its position—this is intention. The superior Earth is employed to house the body and gather the heart, causing body, heart, and intention to merge into one, unwavering and unceasing, nurturing the true until it flourishes and can generate beings. Is this not the myriad things already complete within me, the three realms returned to a single body?”

Such is his exegesis, which clarifies the three paths as if pointing to the palm of one’s hand. Ancestor Lü said: “To cultivate the Immortal Path, first perfect the Human Path; without cultivating the Human Path, the Immortal Path is distant indeed.” Master Niwan stated: “The Immortal Path and the Human Path are not beyond a single body.” Yet the world misconstrues this, seeking explanations outside the body, unable to find a starting point. They overlook that the Red and Black are the Human Path; only when the human is purified and returns to whiteness can one return to the Yellow. Master Taixu said: “The sagely work of the Elixir Path lies in nothing beyond returning.” To embody the Red and Black is to arise from *Li* and *Kan*; the task of cultivation is to return, necessarily refining *Li* and *Kan* until the posterior is wholly returned to the prior, the ordinary transformed into the sagely.

Yet the common flaw in worldly learning is haste, often skipping stages to advance, leading to the error of “disturbing the Yellow” and arousing doubt. I have elaborated on this in my commentary to *The Heart Transmission of the Heavenly Immortals*. Fellow seekers may consult it to understand that I do not innovate this teaching without cause.

This text contains profound principles and is a rare work among Elixir Path teachings. Unfortunately, through repeated transcription, errors and omissions have arisen. Without correction, the harm of “disturbing the Yellow” and other faults would be no small matter. Though I have amended it here, I have not expounded its profound principles in detail, lest later learners struggle to follow or, worse, hinder their progress. One must not fail to consider this.

I have also changed the word “pass” to “penetrate” regarding the *Yuzhen* gate. This *Yuzhen* barrier is narrow and the bone hard—also called the Iron Wall. If a learner’s posterior has not yet transformed and they forcibly cross it, they will surely suffer the harm of “disturbing the Yellow.” In minor cases, this causes brain swelling; in severe cases, it damages the brain. The consequences are dire—one cannot be unaware.

The passage reading “the eyes send off while the intent welcomes” refers to gathering the heart and eyes together and returning them to emptiness and nothingness. The term “ding” in the following section denotes the correct position for concentrating life-force; one must not hastily mistake the head for the crucible. This is the foundational method for fetal breathing, yet it must not be taken lightly—for without utter emptiness and profound stillness, fetal breathing cannot be attained.

The Minor Celestial Cycle of Ancestor Qiu of Changchun precisely describes this stage, differing only in its emphasis on unchanging constancy and the interdependence of heart and breath.

---

Xiao Gen further states: The above three sections have been revised according to the original text, adhering strictly to its wording, and all remain true transmissions without error. The nine sections that follow—titled *Gathering the Medicine and Returning to the Crucible*, *Fire Phases of the Celestial Cycle*, *Dry Stretching and Intercourse*, *Ten-Month Fetal Nurturance*, *Shifting the Spirit and Changing the Crucible*, *Three Years of Nursing*, *Refining the Spirit and Returning to Emptiness*, and *Awaiting the Imperial Summons for Ascension*—are largely convoluted and fragmented, belonging to the middle and lower grades. They mix in discussions of breath-counting, saliva-swallowing, and hexagram weights, entirely deviating from the superior practice and mismatching this book’s theme. These were clearly interpolated by blind peddlers.

After reading them repeatedly, I could not help but feel my mind and vision shaken, remaining in such a state for three days and nights, nearly forsaking sleep and food. On the fourteenth day of the first month of winter, while seated in meditation at dawn, my heart stirred, and I took up my brush to write directly,不知从何而来的机缘. Following the original titles, I replaced *Three Years of Nursing* with *Cultivating Wisdom in the Mud-Pill Palace* and *Awaiting the Imperial Summons for Ascension* with *Uniting with the Dao in Truth*, completing the nine sections. I swept away all fragmentation and clearly marked the true path—this is precisely the wondrous alignment of “people sharing the same heart” as spoken of by my teacher, the Venerable Tai Xu.

The original nine sections are no longer presented here, lest they obstruct the learner’s mind and vision. May readers understand.

Gathering the Medicinal Essence into the Crucible

Having achieved the union of Kan and Li, with body and mind already merged, one has yet to reach the wondrous fusion and coagulation. At this moment, when the eyes send forth and the intent welcomes—still taking emptiness as the essence and stillness as the practice, without regard for time—one proceeds until emptiness reaches its extreme and stillness becomes profound. Gradually, one returns to the boundless obscurity of primordial chaos, the natural state of deep silence. Suddenly, a thunderous sound arises, as if silk is torn asunder—this is the activation of the Celestial Root’s mechanism.

Instantly, the elixir field grows fiery, and the two kidneys boil like a cauldron. Upon attaining this sign, the entire body is suddenly submerged into the ocean’s depths. The eyes send forth through the turning pivot, the intent welcomes and pierces upward—through the Three Passes, the roaring of dragon and thunder surges like fire, ascending straight to the celestial thoroughfare. Then, one feels a swelling presence gathering in the Mud-Pill Palace—this is the wind stirring in the Moon Grotto.

Thereupon, between the brows, a radiant orb wells up from within. Unconsciously, it descends through the Magpie Bridge and down the Tower of Nine Stories. One tastes a sweetness like borneol’s purity and mint’s coolness, permeating the heart and spleen—this is the moonlight in the Crimson Palace. Then, it is guided back to the Earthen Crucible—this is the return of the gathered medicinal essence.

The term "crucible" is the name of a hexagram in the *Yi*’s imagery, referring to what the ancient elixir formulas call "obtaining the medicine in two of the twelve divisions of an hour." Silently circulating the fire phases of the celestial cycle is called "sealing and consolidating in four divisions." Yet what is obtained here is called the Jade Fluid Returned Elixir—formless yet still possessing a form that can be symbolized.

The Perfected One of Purple Yang said: *"Take the solid center of the Kan position to pierce the yin within the Li’s belly,"* and also: *"One grain after another, from the subtle to the manifest"*—these are the methods for procuring and storing the ingredients.

[Min Xiao-Gen says: This is the method for refining and obtaining the Valley Spirit, that is, "taking from Kan to fill Li," meaning to extract the postnatal Kan to fill the postnatal Li, thereby restoring the original positions of Qian and Kun.]

The Fire Phases of the Celestial Cycle

Master Xue said: *"The moon’s fullness lies in the oral transmission, while the mystery of the midnight hour resides in heart-to-heart instruction."* He also said: *"The breath-count of the celestial cycle is a subtle tally, like the cold dripping of a jade clepsydra’s drops."* These are the very words passed mouth-to-mouth regarding the Fire Phases of the Celestial Cycle.

Thus the Perfected One of Emerald Void remarked: *"When the wind first stirs in ten thousand silences, and the moon stands full above a thousand peaks, swiftly enact the true command—then may you set the Celestial Cycle in motion."* These lines echo the words of Ancestral Master Shi, affirming the oral secrets of Ancestral Master Xue, teaching practitioners to align their practice with the hidden principles of natural resonance.

Master of Hengyang observed: *"In all elixir-refining, one must kindle the fire precisely at the yang-qi’s rise at the true midnight hour—only then is the fire’s power complete; at any other time, it is not so. For at the exact midnight hour, the Great Yang resides in the north, just as the qi within the human body reaches the Gate of the Tailbone. At this moment of kindling, the body’s yin has reached its extreme and yang begins to stir. When the true midnight hour of heaven and earth coincides with the living midnight hour within the body, and both are set in motion together, inner and outer unite—only then is the wondrous mechanism of heaven and human joined in perfect accord, enabling one to fully steal the creative power of heaven and earth to form the elixir."*

His explanation is most lucid and precise. Though not all who attain it may find it entirely so, it nonetheless serves to elucidate the wondrous secrets transmitted in Ancestral Master Xue’s heart-to-heart instruction.

Regarding the tally of the Celestial Cycle, he posited that from the *zi* to *si* yang hours—six positions corresponding to the Qian trigram’s stalks—one arrives at a total of 216 counts. Subtracting the 36 counts of the *mao* yang hour (designated for the bathing rest, where fire is withheld), the actual practice consists of 180 counts. From the *wu* to *hai* yin hours—six positions corresponding to the Kun trigram’s stalks—one arrives at 144 counts. Subtracting the 24 counts of the *you* yin hour (also designated for bathing and halting the tally), the actual practice consists of 120 counts. Together, these make 300 breaths. Including the bathing periods, the total reaches 360 breaths, with an additional 24 counts as intercalary surplus, amounting to 384 breaths. This interpretation of *"the breath-count of the celestial cycle is a subtle tally"* is indeed intimate and detailed. Yet if one were to instruct practitioners to meticulously count these breaths during practice, the advancing fire would become overly vigorous and cumbersome, while the retreating tally would inevitably disrupt the rhythm, leading to disorder—how is this different from entangling silk? Does it not diverge from the teachings of Bai Zi-Qing on the progression and retreat of fire, the withdrawal and addition of qi, and the bathing method?

One must recognize that when Ancestral Master Xue spoke of *"the breath-count of the celestial cycle is a subtle tally,"* he immediately followed with *"like the cold dripping of a jade clepsydra’s drops"*—awakening learners to the foundational technique of practice. His intent was to liken the breath-count to the natural flow of the Celestial Cycle, guided by spirit. This aligns with Bai Zi-Qing’s teaching that *"refinement arises from quiescence and spontaneity."* As Zhang Zi-Yang said: *"The fire phases do not rely on timing; the winter solstice is not confined to *zi*. As for the bathing method, it is likened to the emptiness of *mao* and *you*."*

Thus, all original diagrams and explanations—along with instructions on nasal inhalation, swallowing, palm depressions, and wheel positions—have been entirely excised to avoid obstructing the practitioner’s perception. The learner, upon reaching this stage, need only silently contemplate and circulate the *"subtle, dripping"* pattern. Naturally, the intent will remain unscattered, and one will feel the heart and breath interdependent, the breath harmonized and the heart stilled—this is the moment when the Jade Fluid Returned Elixir is accomplished.

Ancestral Master Xue further said: *"The sages transmitted the medicine but not the fire; the fire phases have ever been known by few. Do not treat the fire phases as child’s play—you must ponder them carefully alongside the immortals."* From this, one may understand that the reason the fire was not transmitted is precisely to prevent learners from misapplying the method and thereby disrupting the fire phases. Hence, he cautioned: *"Do not treat it as child’s play—you must ponder it carefully."*

Learners must recognize that the medicine is the fire, and the fire is the medicine. When the body and heart unite in gathering, it is called the medicine; when body and heart merge wondrously in coagulation, and one diligently preserves the Great Harmony, it is called the fire. How could the fire phases of the Celestial Cycle consist of inhaling celestial winds, swallowing earthly fluids, pressing palm positions, or sequentially circulating through the palaces? Such practices would be akin to counting sand or stirring up true intent—would they not violate the warning against treating the fire phases as child’s play? Our school’s scholars must discern this clearly.

[Min Xiao-Gen says: By the middle ages, bodies untouched by the dissipation of true yang were rare. Thus, the three chapters of practice—*Kan-Li Intercourse, Gathering the Medicine and Returning to the Crucible, and the Fire Phases of the Celestial Cycle*—were established for the Jade Fluid Returned Elixir. These serve only to replenish the postnatal leakage of yang essence, yang qi, and yang spirit, restoring the body to the state of a youth. If one hears the Dao in the prime of life and is willing to begin practice, merely refining the self and laying the foundation allows for the intercourse of Qian and Kun—this is the supreme vehicle, the most exalted and direct elixir method. In an age lacking such individuals, one must insert this middle-grade elixir method into the exalted practice to mend postnatal deficiencies, thereby restoring the body to the state of youthful purity before proceeding to the *Qian-Kun Intercourse* practice below. The original text’s content clearly pertains to a lower-grade elixir method and cannot be the original brush of Master of Hengyang; thus, it has been deleted and is not preserved here.]

*Qian-Kun Intercourse*

Having completed the three preceding methods—where Kan and Li have conjoined to form the medicine, the medicine is gathered into the crucible to circulate the fire, and the fire is conducted through the full cycle of the microcosmic orbit—the positions of the primordial Qian and Kun are now established. From this point onward, one must no longer seek through form or appearance. Instead, one empties the heart to attain the utmost void, fills the abdomen to uphold the deepest stillness, and cultivates sincerity within to inwardly observe one’s return. Naturally, one achieves a profound and unwavering quiescence.

Pure and refined in essence, the mechanism suddenly stirs, and in an instant, the self and the phenomenal world of heaven and earth vanish. One perceives only luminous emptiness, boundless and infinite. At the first glimmer of awareness, swiftly gather and return, instantly entering profound stillness. One merges into the aperture, enveloped in obscurity—unaware, unknowing, soundless, and odorless—thus fully opening the Mysterious Pass and deeply entering the singular aperture. After a time, a single point descends into the Yellow Court, marking the return of the primordial qi, which naturally circulates through the six directions of space. Only then does one realize that this body is originally the altar, crucible, and furnace; the heart is the chamber of spirit, and within it, I reside as nothing but true intention. One feels the qi refreshed, the spirit clear, the body harmonious, and the heart at ease, while heaven, earth, sun, and moon remain soft as silk—this is the Golden Elixir of Returned Fluid.

One perceives only a radiant orb of light, round and resplendent, like an original pearl resting on a crystal plate. In truth, it is formless and imageless—what the sages call “the solitary revelation of numinous emptiness,” and what the former master described as “Qian and Kun merging to complete my Supreme Ultimate.” At this stage, the adept must guard the subtle with utmost care, washing the heart and retiring into secrecy, thoughtless and effortless. Naturally, the void remains unexhausted, and this becomes the ten-month gestation of the embryo.

Bai Ziqing said: “A moment’s coagulation, ten months’ gestation—once the embryo is complete, there are no hexagrams or trigrams, no weight or measure.” The method is simple and easy, yet only the superior adept can practice it; this is why it is so readily accomplished.

**Ten-Month Gestation of the Embryo**
Once the numinous elixir has returned to the chamber of spirit, it is the state of which the ancients spoke: “The elixir crucible and river chariot rest from toil, while the crane’s embryo and tortoise’s breath flow on endlessly.” Wang Chongyang said: “Once the sacred embryo has formed, nurture it with gentle fire, settle the spirit and regulate the breath, allowing all to proceed naturally.” The Elder of Zhengyang said: “No need to tend the fire—within the furnace, warmth arises of itself.” The Patriarch of Apricot Grove said: “Refining qi is labor in vain; preserving spirit is effort wasted. How could one know the marvel of the elixir’s secret? Daylong, one delights in true emptiness.” These are all authentic oral instructions for embryo gestation.

For though one may have obtained the great medicine, with the five colors manifesting, people often mistake this for the formation of the embryo—yet it has not yet undergone transformation. Thus, the immortal master said: “The treasure in the cinnabar field is not the true treasure; only the re-coagulation of the numinous embryo is the sacred embryo.” The moment the elixir is obtained marks the beginning of the ten-month gestation. Thereafter, one must ceaselessly attend to it, moment by moment, like a dragon nurturing its pearl or a hen brooding her egg, ensuring the warmth never ceases, so that the numinous embryo gradually solidifies.

The guiding principle is gentle warmth; thoughts must not arise, for their arising kindles the fire. Intention must not scatter, for its scattering cools the fire. One must avoid excess or deficiency, maintaining only the furnace’s gentle warmth—there is no other method. Any contrivance invites immediate peril. Be cautious! Be cautious!

Throughout these ten months, from beginning to end, one must remain as if it were a single day, perpetually abiding in the state before the seven emotions arise and preserving the body before the eight consciousnesses are defiled. Only thus can one refine and cultivate to achieve the full transformation of the embryo through spirit.

Should the elixir fire grow hot, visualize a black sphere the size of a bowl between the eyebrows, then gather and withdraw it into the chamber of spirit—the heat will subside. This must not be overlooked.

**Moving the Spirit and Changing the Crucible**
Once the ten-month gestation is complete, the qi is full and the spirit whole, and the infant appears in form. Emerging from the womb, one may then move the spirit and change the crucible. The Ancestor Qiu of Everlasting Spring held that this is a direct ascent from the Central Palace to the Upper Yellow; the Upper Yellow is called the Mud Pill, also known as the Heavenly Valley—the purest realm of the human body.

This infant is entirely a coagulation of the primordial, not the ordinary essence, qi, or spirit. It appears and vanishes at will, can penetrate metal and stone, and leaves no trace of its passage—“embryo” and “infant” are but metaphors. Thus, the Patriarch Xue said: “The *Heart Transmission of the Supreme* speaks of preserving as an infant, meaning one must nurture as an infant—this is the compassionate intent of using the tangible to verify the intangible.” Yet Master Duanyang remarked: “Once the Dharma-body has coagulated, the spirit must be further stabilized.” Hence the relocation to the Heavenly Valley is not merely for its purity but follows the natural principle.

The world, failing to grasp this intent, speaks of concealment and manifestation. The adept must remain in quiescent stability, abiding in the proper position within the body, undisturbed by the illusions of the hun and po, so that inner and outer are luminously clear. Xiao Zixu said: “Moving the spirit to the Heavenly Valley is precisely for refining the nature. When the Three Flowers gather at the crown and the Five Qi converge at the origin, there arises a moment of myriad disturbances—yet one who can sit in dignified nonaction, stabilized by wisdom, will experience the verification of spontaneity in stillness.”

However, few among learners maintain this stability, often disturbed by the esoteric teachings of alchemical schools regarding the manifestation of the yang spirit. Thus, the Patriarch Xue said: “The Great Dao is formless—what form or appearance could it have? The Great Dao is nameless—what numinous sage could it possess? All these names and titles, these supreme esoteric teachings, are but means to clarify one thing through another, transforming the illusory into the real through marvelous function. Yet the ultimate spiritual achievement lies in refining during the movement of the spirit to the Heavenly Valley.”

Alas, such profound instructions have long been lost to the world! Those who receive them must not regard the study of nature as mere theory, unrelated to the cultivation of life. They must understand that the body of refined gold is but the manifestation of the singular qi of emptiness and nonbeing—thus it can instantly vanish upon the wish to conceal or instantly appear upon the wish to manifest.

The Patriarch Xuē further stated: “Those who can comprehend the profound meaning within the interplay of great movement and great stillness may grasp it in their hearts—do not mix in conjecture or speculation. Be reverent and cautious.”

**Cultivating Wisdom in the Mud-Pill Palace**
The Mud-Pill Palace is the Heavenly Valley of the body, just as the Dipper has its Northern Apex, the world has its Celestial Pillar, and Heaven has its Jade Purity Heaven. Once the spirit has shifted to the Heavenly Valley, there is no other method—any admixture of contrivance instantly plunges one into illusion and delusion, as the ancient sages have exhaustively explained. The only dharma lies in darkening the mind and settling into quiescence.

For while one still dwells in bodily form in the world, the true self has not yet transformed, the true spirit has not yet become complete, and one cannot yet return like the stars to their fixed pole, nor attain the threefold purity of the celestial realms. One remains ununified with the Celestial Pillar. The Celestial Pillar is without self, yet I still possess a self. The celestial Pole Star is formed of the great mass of true gold—mass yet not mass—thus it can align with the heart of Heaven, transforming as it arises. When we refine the Golden Elixir, we rely entirely on the true dharma-body of our true self and the congealing of the true spirit. Once the great primordial essence is obtained and transformed, ascending to dwell in the Heavenly Valley, one must decisively align with the Celestial Pillar to follow Heaven.

The Pillar universally illuminates the Three Powers; I, too, universally illuminate the Three Powers. Yet I illuminate only the Three Powers of this single body. If one does not inwardly and outwardly dissolve all distinctions, abiding in effortless non-self, how can one penetrate the Three Realms, follow Heaven in every place, maintain unity in movement and stillness, and remain undivided in gathering and dispersion? This is certainly beyond the reach of those lacking spiritual wisdom, and it is also impossible for those who rely solely on spiritual wisdom to preserve forever.

Thus, the Patriarch Xuē said: “When Pure Yang spoke of ‘modeling Heaven and emulating Earth,’ how could it be easy? Without attaining the utmost emptiness and profound stillness, one can hardly dwell in the dust while transcending it. Yet those who achieve this do so precisely through tempering within the dust—what is called ‘cultivating wisdom in stillness and refining wisdom in movement.’”

Master Xìnglín commented: “Only fearing that one cannot see through or let go, hence the need for further refinement.”

In my humble opinion, the method of refinement ultimately comes down to a single word: *sincerity*. Sincerity is not merely perfecting oneself but also perfecting things. Thus, sincerity in stillness brings clarity to the spirit, and sincerity in movement brings transparency to one’s nature. When nature is transparent, the spirit naturally attains great stability, and there are no worldly attachments one cannot relinquish. When the spirit is luminous, nature naturally becomes all-pervading, and there are no principles of things one cannot comprehend. This is truly the state of “things being investigated and knowledge attained, the will being sincere,” where the rectification of the mind and the cultivation of the body follow naturally, as echo answers sound—this is the true secret of cultivating and refining wisdom.

Here, one cannot know through knowledge, cannot comprehend through comprehension, nor can one spiritually grasp through the spirit. Only by stabilizing the non-spiritual aspect of the self does one attain the spiritual—this is the fundamental nature of achieving clarity through sincerity. There is destiny, yet the noble person does not act for nature alone—this is the function of refining the spirit. Advancing toward the return to emptiness is founded upon this!

**Refining the Spirit to Return to Emptiness**
Stillness can generate wisdom, for within its core lies the marvel of quiescence reaching its extreme and then moving—emptiness that does not bend, movement that ever emerges. One may attain great wisdom and possess great spiritual powers, but if one remains constantly in motion without returning, how can wisdom be preserved, and how can the spirit not grow weary? Thus, the ancestral masters also transmitted the secret of refining the spirit to return to emptiness.

This secret lies in holding to the solitary delight of tranquil observation amid all activity. Abiding in this body and world, vast and boundless, the qi-mechanisms within are ever hidden and manifest, all one with myself. Observing ordinary people, they dwell within it like a tiny grain, drifting with the world. I alone embody the true and constant, responding to things as they come, neither resisting nor neglecting them. The subtle stirrings of the seven emotions and eight consciousnesses in ordinary people are nothing but the pervading qi of Brahmā. I alone possess my vast primordial essence, fusing and dissolving until the very emptiness is pulverized.

Yet when one realizes that things and self are one continuum, all riding the Six Qi in ceaseless circulation, and that the sacred and profane share the same Heaven, there is no longer any distinction between form and spirit. Entrusted with the mandate of transforming the earth into Heaven, I do not wield its authority. Allowing the spirit to respond and transform through the qi-mechanisms, I do not seek its effects. Like the sun and moon, which illuminate all within their capacity without intent, they endure through ancient and modern times, unwearied across ten thousand kalpas. This is what is meant by refining and returning—nothing more.

To speak of refining and returning is still to borrow a method. The adept who returns to emptiness is like one who, having caught the fish, forgets the trap—this is permissible.

**Refining Emptiness to Merge with the Dao**
The previous stage of returning to emptiness has reached the state where things and self are undivided, yet the perception of things and self still remains. If this perception is not eradicated, self-mastery is incomplete. One must advance another step at the top of the hundred-foot pole. The ancestral masters further transmitted the secret of refining emptiness to merge with the Dao, only by which can one truly unite with the Dao.

For this world and this body are ultimately illusory shadows, visible and audible. If one does not shatter this emptiness, the deluded view of this as real and that as empty, or this as empty and that as real, will persist. If this view is not eradicated, one can hardly be free from the peril of erosion. Upon encountering worldly conditions that conflict, one will again fall into the turmoil of the dusty realm. With restless comings and goings, following the thoughts of friends and companions, how can one sever attachments and forget emotions?

The only dharma is to forget both the real and the illusory, allowing everything to follow its nature—thus one naturally merges with the Dao. To speak of refining is only to “shatter the emptiness”—in that instant, the Dao merges with the natural. This Dao is like the great thoroughfare of Jambudvīpa, traversed by all things. As it is said, “The royal road is smooth as whetstone, straight as an arrow.” The only obstacles are dim eyes, weak feet, or an unsteady will—how could one fail to reach the ultimate?

Alas, the world has lost the Dao, and people lack the single eye of discernment, further misled by blind guides who falsely point out paths and mistakenly offer staffs for support—some even travel south while intending north. The Most High, moved by compassion, brought forth Master Li of Hengyang to expound the step-by-step practice of the Golden Elixir. Yet even this was distorted by those who peddle the Dao, mixing truth with falsehood to deceive the world for private gain.

Little do they know that this Dao resides in the human heart, transcending the Three Teachings and beyond any sect. All possess an indestructible innate knowing and ability, directly aligned with the Most High’s mind-to-mind transmission. Hengyang traces its lineage to the Southern School yet also inherits from the Northern School, both branches under the tutelage of Patriarch Lü—teacher and disciple as one family, how could their words differ?

Encountering this text, I lament its admixture of truth and counterfeit. Thus, I have mended and compiled it, as if awakening in the same chamber where voices resonate in unison. I intend to bestow it upon later learners, fulfilling the mutual seeking of kindred spirits. May those who come after grasp this mind-to-mind transmission, free from doubts of borrowed names or metaphors, and without the traces of exhausting body and spirit.

With a settled mind, one directly perceives the original nature; with not a single thought arising, the wheel of rebirth ceases. The dust-like evil karma dissolves with each thought, and all beings equally attain the fruit of purity and stillness. How direct! How joyous! What is there to fear that would prevent one from immediately embracing this?

When practice reaches its culmination, one naturally receives and returns in full—like the Yellow Emperor losing and regaining his pearl, or Master Zeng raising his hands and feet, both having completed the work of refining emptiness. Disciples of the Three Teachings should all suddenly comprehend!

**Merging with the True Dao**
When practice advances to refining emptiness and merging with the Dao, no further effort can be applied. Measured by one’s cultivation, this is akin to the sages’ attainment of the Mandate of Heaven. Following its gradations, one refines to perfection in speech and silence, movement and stillness. Then, affairs naturally align with intent, thoughts arise without deliberation, and one abides effortlessly in the central Way. From the world’s perspective, speech becomes hexagrams, silence forms images, movement harmonizes with heaven, and stillness wanders with it.

Naturally, the eight hundred merits are perfected, and the three thousand virtues fulfilled—like Confucius acting from the heart’s desire, Yao and Shun governing by desire, Mencius’ “heavenly citizen,” the Buddha’s “Great Vehicle Golden Immortal,” or our tradition’s “Highest-Grade Heavenly Immortal.” Acting in the world, the nation is ordered and the world at peace. In movement, one becomes the world’s Dao; in conduct, the world’s model; in speech, the world’s standard. From afar, one is revered; up close, never resented.

When spirit merges with the Great Void, there is nothing it does not uphold, nothing it does not shelter. It nurtures the myriad things without harm, circulates through the six directions without dominion, and cycles with heaven and earth in opening and closing—yet remains untouched by their flaws or vicissitudes. As my teacher said, “Galloping alongside Fuxi, shoulder-to-shoulder with the Primordial Beginning,” in truth, one merges with Fuxi and the Primordial Beginning in boundlessness.

Originally, this text was titled *Awaiting the Imperial Summons for Ascension*, suggesting that at this stage, one must accumulate merit and deeds to await the celestial decree, the arrival of phoenix and crane, and the ascent to immortality. This is a narrow view, merely the effect of middle- and lower-grade elixir completion, insufficient to verify the highest-grade elixir method. Thus, I have amended it—may scholars not doubt this.

**Thirteen Subtleties of the Ancient Method of Nourishing Life**

**First: Clenching the Hands Firmly and Closing the Eyes to Still the Mind**
The human body has but one heart, yet it bears three names: the heart in its original position is the *human heart*; its spirit concentrated in the brain is the *heavenly heart*; its spirit concentrated in the abdomen is the *earthly heart*. Its functions are three: the heavenly heart generates essence, the earthly heart generates qi, and the human heart generates blood.

To gather the human heart, one must clench the hands firmly. What is *clenching firmly*? Press the tip of each thumb into the crease between the *hai* and *zi* positions on the opposite hand, then wrap the four fingers around the thumb to form a fist. The heart is a most numinous thing—merely entertaining a thought fixes it there. Moreover, the heart embodies yin and yang, its principle odd yet paired, belonging to the heart in its original position. Examining its lodging place, it resides in the heart of the two hands. Once the *hai-zi* crease is pressed and the hands clenched, the human heart is anchored in its proper place.

With the heart settled in its position, the qi of the entire body naturally gathers and protects it, effortlessly converging around the Crimson Palace above and below, on all four sides. The qi of the postnatal realm is moist and warm; wherever it gathers, it resembles clouds or mist. Yet in its proper place, this cloud-like, mist-like substance first transforms into liquid, dripping down to moisten the heart and becoming blood. This transformation surely does not occur in an instant. Thus, after clenching the hands, one must still the mind.

Stillness must be prolonged—only then is it truly wondrous. Here lies the reason why those who nourish life must clench their hands and still their minds. I speak of this practice requiring prolonged effort: first, because quieting the heart is not easy, and inducing it to settle into stillness is even harder; second, because when the heart is truly still and settled, the qi of the entire body comes to pay homage. Its arrival at the Crimson Palace surely does not instantly transform into liquid. If not gathered long and thoroughly, the cloud-like, mist-like effect will not manifest. Moreover, only when the heart is profoundly still and settled does the gathered qi become perfectly harmonious, allowing the opportunity for transformation to arise. This is an immutable principle—how can one entertain thoughts of instant success?

I have heard my teacher say that the chronic accumulation of phlegm and fluids in the central palace among worldly people stems from nothing else: after eating, when the spleen is fatigued, they either stare blankly or close their eyes to still themselves. The qi around the Crimson Palace above and below, on all four sides, also gathers to protect it, presenting a scene like clouds or mist...

Yet if the liquid fails to arise or, having arisen, one remains ignorant of the inner nurturing secrets and merely settles for a single layer of ease, the droplets that fall will not enter the heart but instead spill beside the central palace, congealing into phlegm. Over time, this accumulation hardens into the chronic phlegm-fluid syndrome. Many among the world’s cultivators suffer from this stagnant-fluid condition—none other than because they neglect to deepen their work in stilling the heart. They may move the incense stick a mere inch or half-inch before shifting to another practice, halting the transformation of numinous liquid into blood.

I have seen this affliction firsthand and thus urge others to devote earnest effort at this stage. I now set forth these details without fear of repetition; may readers not dismiss them as mere commonplace!

Alas! Once the liquid droplets have transformed into blood, if one fails to proceed with the heart-regulating method, yet another alarming illness will arise. This I shall dissect below.

**Second Method: Press the tongue to the upper palate and focus the mind with single intent.**
The entire body is but the heart: the hollow is its essence, the solid its function. This essence and function are spoken of in coarse terms; their subtlety lies in qi and blood, for these are governed by the heart—hence the saying, “The whole body is but the heart.”

Why do the ancient sages teach that after closing the eyes and stilling the heart, one should press the tongue to the upper palate and focus the mind with single intent? The tongue is the heart’s sprout; when it presses the palate, the heart’s spirit naturally ascends. Since spirit commands qi and qi leads blood, this single act allows the spirit to rise and dwell in the primordial origin, already harboring the wondrous function of visualizing the Mud Pill Palace.

This merely entails briefly visualizing the Mud Pill Palace—perhaps perceiving a radiant, luminous presence—then using this bright light to envelop the entire body, front and back. Only then does one proceed to the next step.

By “proceeding,” I mean first regulating the breath, observing how the breath follows this light from the crown to the mouth, from the heart to the abdomen. Next, one empties the head, the heart, and the abdomen—this is the wondrous secret of emptiness. The marvel of this secret lies in maintaining the intention of emptiness, advancing step by step from within to without.

To “regulate” means: where there is non-emptiness, empty it with intention; where there is blockage, unblock it with intention. If one feels as though walls press inward, obstructing outward flow, one should use intention to scatter and relax, allowing the inner landscape to become open and smooth. If something seems to entangle the qi mechanism like a net, one should use intention to release, relax, and free it—letting the heart rest in the realm of nothingness. This depends on the practitioner’s ability to grasp it intuitively.

This is what is meant by “regulating,” by “focusing with single intent.”

I have heard my teacher say that many suffer from coughing up blood, bloody urine, or bloody stool and discharge—conditions often arising from the above-described causes. After eating, when one is fatigued, the blood should be nurtured and transformed! Yet if the transformed blood fails to flow through the channels, store in the liver, or be governed by the spleen, and instead one abruptly rises to engage in activity, the blood courses wildly without return. Accumulating and erupting externally, it gives rise to various alarming symptoms. Many cultivators initially see results, only to suddenly develop such conditions and abandon their practice—this is no coincidence, but rather stems from failing to thoroughly regulate the heart.

I, too, have witnessed these pitfalls and thus expound upon them in detail.

**Third Method: Let the spirit wander in the Water Palace and rub both the waist and kidneys.**
Blood is the root of essence, essence the source of qi. Yet for blood to transform into essence and essence into qi, the spirit must wander in the Water Palace; otherwise, the water remains cold and untransformed. What lingers in the lower region is merely stubborn fluid, not essence.

The ancients said: “When the kidneys are warm, essence is generated; when the heart is cool, blood is generated.” Reflecting on these two phrases, we see that the spirit’s wandering in the Water Palace not only benefits the kidneys but also aids the heart.

What is the method? Direct the gaze inward to guide the heart’s qi, splitting it from behind the heart to flow into both sides of the waist, circling between the left and right kidneys. The blood thus generated descends with the qi, dividing to infuse both kidneys. As the eyes’ spirit continuously directs and revolves, warmth naturally arises, gradually intensifying into a seething, scorching heat. The descending blood instantly transforms into true fluid, pure and white—this is what the world calls “essence.”

Yet without the kidneys becoming searingly hot—boiling and blazing—until both sides grow intensely warm, and this essence ascends to the navel wheel for further refinement by true fire, it merely lingers beside the accumulated fluid near the bladder. At the slightest stirring of ministerial fire, it slips away—this is the root of nocturnal emission and white turbidity.

The secret lies in intensifying the work on both the waist and kidneys, keeping them perpetually scorching hot. Then the navel wheel’s barrier will also grow hot, and essence will naturally transform into qi.

Those afflicted with bloody urine or discharge suffer because the descending heart-blood, reaching the waist, fails to be dried by true fire. Instead, it flows with the qi to lurk in the bladder, stagnating until external pathogens draw it out—men call it bloody urine, women call it bloody discharge.

From this, one may grasp the profound significance of rubbing the kidneys and letting the spirit wander therein!

Yet rather than speak of "spirit abiding," "spirit moving," "spirit rubbing," or "spirit revolving," we call it "rubbing the waist and kidneys"—for beginners, whose spirit is sluggish, whose qi is weak, whose fire is insufficient, and whose meridians and collaterals are half-blocked by accumulated phlegm, cannot easily be guided or led. If forced, results may prove uncertain, and illness may worsen. Thus, we reluctantly teach them to rub with their hands.

Alas! This is the bitter expedient of past masters in saving the world, and so their instructions stop here. Yet some, misunderstanding the reason, dismiss it as mere external work, not true internal cultivation, and abandon it. Aspiring to greatness, they instead invite all manner of illness, ultimately abandoning their practice. What a pity!

I, having deeply grasped its subtleties—and the prevailing errors of the age—do not shrink from detailing it here. May readers not dismiss this as commonplace advice.

When performing this practice, do not rub forcefully. Let the mind follow the turning palms, moving from outside inward, circling endlessly. Do not count the number of rubs; the key is to generate intense heat. Beware of empty ritual, like monks mindlessly reciting the *Sutra of Rebirth*.

Why? When the body’s qi and blood are vigorous, no illness can take hold. The spirit governs qi and blood, yet depends on them for nourishment. Everyone knows qi and blood are the body’s treasures, yet few know how to cultivate them. Thus, they daily decline, and reversal becomes impossible.

If one truly follows the above instructions with sincerity, effort, and unwavering persistence, how could longevity not be attained?

**Fourth:** *Focus the mind on the coccyx, frequently shrugging the shoulders.*
This technique corrects flaws in beginners practicing the above methods and is essential for cultivators. The mind here refers to the spirit. If the prior methods are practiced to their utmost, true qi will naturally pierce the coccyx, warming the spine and rising layer by layer to the crown—no need for deliberate focus or shoulder shrugging.

But beginners, with depleted true qi and feeble spirit, find the coccyx’s gate sealed and impassable. The twenty-four vertebrae of the spine harbor phlegm in each joint. Without this deliberate effort, breaking through the gates would be difficult, and ascending step by step, impossible.

Yet the practice must not stop. If the coccyx remains closed, essence will not stabilize, and descending qi will not settle in the abdomen. It may transform into abdominal distension, rib pain, anal abscesses, or hemorrhoids—or into palpitations, heart tremors, or lesser ailments like toothache, bloodshot eyes, or dizziness. If the qi pierces the spine but stalls midway, it may cause carbuncles on the back, neck, or head.

Thus, the ancients devised this expedient to avert such crises. The method: focus the spirit intently on the coccyx while contracting the anus as if resisting a bowel movement, drawing the qi upward. To proceed, tilt the head slightly forward, then use intent to guide the qi from below upward, shrugging the shoulders. The qi will ascend through the spinal joints; with each joint passed, add another shrug, until the qi reaches the *yuzhen* bone. Then proceed to the next stage.

This technique is what the alchemical classics call "the Yellow River flowing backward." There are three gates: the coccyx, the spine, and the *yuzhen*. Here, only two are passed, so I say further practice is needed to clear the final gate—the *yuzhen*.

**Fifth:** *Gaze at the crown, click the teeth, and swirl the tongue.*
"Gaze" does not mean opening the eyes but closing them, directing the eyes downward to guide the qi upward—as if the spirit, deep in an abyss, focuses intently on rising. This is the proper way to "gaze."

The term "crown" is to help practitioners sense whether the qi has passed the *yuzhen*. Yet there is a profound, essential secret here, long guarded by cultivators. What is it? It lies in the two words "crown gate." "Crown" means the highest point; "gate" is the Celestial Gate. The method: guide the qi straight upward from the *yuzhen*, imagining it piercing into the heavens until one feels a boundless void, with sun, moon, and stars beneath one’s spiritual light. Only then is it complete.

After this, the body’s postnatal turbid qi transforms into prenatal pure qi. Only then should one proceed to clicking the teeth and swirling the tongue, avoiding any sluggishness.

The "Celestial Gate" I speak of is not the gate of heaven above but the crown of the head, the gate connecting to celestial qi. This is where the body’s *tian gang* true qi resides. When this qi descends, all yin is transformed. Passing this gate, the three gates of the body will open effortlessly, like splitting bamboo.

This is the supreme treasure of cultivators. To attain this qi, one must break through the gates, ascend to unite with the celestial *tian gang* above. Otherwise, the qi will congeal at the crown, unusable. Even if one cultivates through other methods, one may ride clouds and command space, but the spirit will still exit through the Celestial Eye.

Yet this remains but one path of the immortals. Only by obtaining this qi and advancing in cultivation can one attain the wondrous achievement of ascending in broad daylight—my master has expounded this in detail. Thus, I have elaborated on this gate at such length. As for clicking the teeth and swirling the tongue, these are but minor practices to gather spirit and draw forth fluids. Yet for those who cultivate longevity, they offer great benefit.

Tao Hongjing’s *True Records* recounts a man who, though untrained in cultivation, lived past a hundred years, and local officials dared not approach his dwelling. Upon investigation, it was found that he suffered from a wind ailment causing his teeth to chatter incessantly. Yet in Daoist practice, when one clicks the teeth, the body’s spirits all gather—this man’s teeth, though chattering from illness, never allowed his spirit to stray. Thus, his gates and orifices were firmly guarded, his body emanating a radiant glow that repelled ghosts. How profound!

As for swirling the tongue: beneath the tongue lie two orifices, one connecting to the heart, the other to the kidneys—what the alchemical classics call the "Flower Pool of Water and Fire." By swirling the tongue, fluids naturally flow forth. Silently guiding the ascending qi to the mouth for swallowing, I say again: this offers great benefit.

Sixth: Quietly circulate the gaze of both eyes and frequently swallow qi. Though this passage speaks to beginners, its hidden meaning is also profound. "Quietly circulate the gaze" serves to gather spirit. Once the ascending qi has passed the Jade Pillow or descended into the mouth, sweet dew will follow—this must be swirled with the tongue and swallowed together. Any remaining qi, lingering in the Mud Pill Palace due to the clicking and swirling, is then directed by the eyes’ movement, producing sensations of warmth, coolness, and moisture. The spirit-light becomes round and white as a pearl, suspended in the space before one.

Yet it speaks of "frequently swallowing qi," not "swallowing fluids"—how profound its intent! For beginners, yin fluids are abundant while yang qi is faint, risking imbalance. Swallowing qi thus aids yang, allowing the lower elixir field to maintain a constant warmth, balancing water and fire within the body. This is the wondrous secret of remedying deficiencies. The alchemical texts confirm this principle is no delusion.

Thus, my master declared that even if one has already transcended the mysterious realm, this practice is not in vain—how much more so for beginners! Why? The Dao of the elixir takes yang as its foundation. To supplement yang is to dispel yin. As the classic states: "If yang is not fully divided, one does not become a ghost; if yin is not fully divided, one does not become an immortal." From this, one may awaken!

I urge those who read this to practice diligently and without doubt.

Yet the qi one swallows must reach the lower elixir field—only then may one cease. The seventh method states: "Calm the spirit and rub the abdomen; grasp both feet with the hands." Though this practice is taught to beginners, it conceals the wondrous principle of fire and earth generating one another, and the three families gathering in union!

It possesses the power to supplement earth and dry dampness, the subtlety of gathering qi and uniting spirit, and the function of the Five Phases converging in their origin. When the spirit is calmed, turbid essence adheres to earth; when the abdomen is rubbed, qi moves and earth is tamed. To grasp the feet, one must bend the body forward, so that the abdomen stores pure qi, which naturally pierces the tailbone and ascends to the mud-pill palace. As both feet bear the grasp, the shins straighten and qi is thrust outward, necessarily emerging through the feet. Once grasped, the yang qi of the soles must rise from the instep, ascend to the tailbone, and follow the qi piercing the abdomen to rise together along the spine.

The wondrous principles within are too numerous to recount. Examining the subsequent text, one will naturally recognize their truth.

Eighth: Bow the body and sound the drum, count the breaths and concentrate the spirit.
To bow the body is to follow the preceding method and add to it the function of non-doing. Since one senses the qi of both feet having ascended from the tailbone, one releases the feet, cups the head with both hands, covers the ears with the palms, and strikes the jade pillow with the fingers—its sound like a drum, hence "sounding the drum." Why sound the drum? To summon the numinous. Bowing the body and sounding the drum calls forth one’s yang spirit, ascending from the back to reach above, a method akin to "riding the raft to the Milky Way." When counting the breaths, one then sits upright. At this moment, the spirit gathers in the mud-pill palace, preparing to bow and attend to governance. Yet why reverse the breath-counting? The mud-pill palace is the court of governance, while restful repose resides in the central yellow; one must know that when counting the breaths, one’s yang spirit has already retired to the earth palace. Counting the breaths serves to advance the yang fire—this is the subtlety of "each breath returning to the navel," the Dao of "remaining at ease without forgetting peril." Thus, the method of breath-counting does not fix the count at the ascent but focuses on the moment of descent, enabling each breath to return to the navel. This is immediately followed by the method of concentrating the spirit, which employs breath-counting as a means to achieve spirit-concentration.

Ninth: Sway the waist and shake the legs, both hands support heaven.
