This segment embodies the wondrous function of stillness reaching its extreme and transforming into movement, a depth beyond the grasp of superficial understanding. After intensifying spirit-concentration, the body’s qi mechanism may become obstructed, so one must first walk slowly—ten or twenty steps—then sit and sway the waist nine, ten, or fifteen times. Rising, one shakes the legs, left and right, matching the count of the waist-swaying. Next, one adds the "supporting heaven" movement, performing it three or five times. The ascent should be slow, and the descent likewise, ensuring the joints remain unobstructed and the qi does not turn coarse.

Tenth: Draw the bow left and right, calm the heart and quiet the qi.
This segment holds no profound meaning; practitioners need only follow the method as prescribed.

Eleventh: Neither self nor other, the heart like still water.
This segment appears to align with nature-cultivation, yet in truth, it is the extraordinary verification of life-cultivation grounded in reality. Without this step in each practice, attainment is impossible. The method resembles the initial practice, but with the resolve to remain unstained by even a speck of dust and to perceive all sounds as empty—thus entering this true and solid state. If one reaches this point and persists over time, the Great Dao is not far off.

Twelfth: The body perpetually warm, harmony filling day and night.
At this stage of practice, one nears immortality. Yet the means to achieve this arise from the preceding methods, not through mere luck.

Thirteenth: Movement and stillness as one, harmonizing light while dwelling in the dust.
At this stage, one has already transcended earthbound immortals, far beyond the realm of water immortals. What remains to be awaited is the Pearl of Munī! This is not something attainable by those whose practice is incomplete or whose merit is insufficient. The above thirteen principles, though merely named, are what all life-nurturing schools revere. Yet practitioners who lack the essential instructions often encounter pitfalls. Now, based on the teachings of my master and verified against the alchemical texts, I have synthesized and expounded them under the title *Elucidating the Subtle*. Though its language may seem plain, its meaning runs deep. It entirely disregards the common talk of dragons and tigers, Kan and Li, trigrams and hexagrams, weights and measures. Those who pursue this Dao will, I know, not dismiss or abandon it in disdain.

Composed on the full moon of the mid-winter month in the wuyin year of the Jiaqing reign by Xiaogen of Jin’gai Mountain at the Lougong workshop.

*Glimpses from a Tube*
Xiaogen says: I have heard from my master that in reading, one must savor the text, and above all, possess the single eye. Now, reflecting on the excerpts from the *Treatise on Dispelling Delusions in Immortal Cultivation*, it states: The Dao of heavenly immortals is most simple and most easy—why then is it said that only superior individuals can learn it? This follows the meaning of Laozi’s words: “The superior individual hears the Dao and diligently practices it.” The so-called superior individual is one whose endowment is pure, whose resolve is single-minded; worldly desires cannot obscure their nature, nor can profit and harm sway their center. They can constantly place their heart in the realm of nothingness and repeatedly gather their body in the state of “though dead, yet living.” Thus, undeterred by setbacks, they uphold their practice of undifferentiated unity—this is why they can learn it. Otherwise, if one takes the body as lead, the heart as mercury, stillness as water, and wisdom as fire, the method is simple and direct—what need is there for trigrams and hexagrams, or weights and measures? Even the clever have no use for their intelligence, so even the most foolish can learn it. Yet this Dao, in its accomplishment, relies solely on the power of wisdom; hence it is said that only superior individuals can learn it.

To take the body as lead and the heart as mercury—how profound is this analogy! When lead unites with mercury, it softens; when mercury unites with lead, it solidifies. Applied to body and heart, their union yields transformative effects. When the body is held by the heart, it becomes warm; when the heart relies on the body, it finds peace. With body warm and heart at peace, cultivation gains a firm grasp, and weariness is unfelt. This is truly the first wondrous step in practice, and the unceasing method that endures from beginning to end. Over time, one attains the marvel of both form and spirit, merging with the true Dao.

As for taking stillness as water and wisdom as fire, these are but two functions, yet water and fire reside within them. Stillness is the state where all sounds are empty, and one abides in profound tranquility. Wisdom is the state where thoughts, once arisen, are immediately dissolved, and nothing escapes its illumination. As for taking the body as the altar, furnace, tripod, and hearth, and the heart as the chamber of the spirit—its purport is profound. If this body is taken as the physical form, where then are the altar, furnace, tripod, and hearth to be placed? If one follows this literally, one either becomes an earthbound immortal or drifts toward the realm of water immortals. If this body is not taken as the physical form, then the altar, furnace, tripod, and hearth must be set externally—following this, one either strays into heterodox paths or becomes mired in mere furnace-fire techniques. Yet the text clearly states “body,” so they cannot be external. The so-called altar, furnace, tripod, and hearth are metaphors—the body they refer to is the Dharma-body. The Dharma-body is the physical body yet not the physical body; not the physical body yet identical to it—visible yet unseen, audible yet unheard. Thus, what can be seen is not the true seeing, what can be heard is not the true hearing. Only by obscuring hearing to hear and obscuring seeing to see does one attain the true Dharma-body.

Then, the heart spoken of here, which can be taken as the chamber of the spirit, is clearly not the heart likened to mercury. What, then, is this heart? It is the Confucian benevolent heart, the Buddhist Buddha-heart, and in our Dao, the Heavenly Heart. One must also obscure seeing and hearing to truly see and hear. Vast without exterior, minute without interior, it is harmonious and silent—never to be parted from in haste, never to be lost in adversity. Hence it is called the essentials of elixir refinement.

Proceeding to savor its words on gathering the ingredients: “sit upright,” “cultivate stillness.” On managing the fire: “maintain,” “observe.” On advancing and retreating: “act,” “cease.” On vigilance: “continuity,” “undivided focus.” On extraction and addition: “circulation.” On circulation: “tranquility and spontaneity.” Regarding the firing times: “moving, stopping, sitting, lying.” Regarding the medicinal materials: “essence, spirit, soul, intent.” Elsewhere, it speaks of steaming with true qi as bathing, quieting thoughts as nurturing the fire, subduing body and heart as field combat, concentrating spirit and gathering qi as defending the city, forgetting schemes and severing concerns as life and death, the arising of thoughts as the Mysterious Female, forging into oneness as union, returning to the root and restoring life as elixir completion, transferring spirit and changing the vessel as “a body beyond the body” and “shedding the husk,” returning to the origin and reverting to the source as true emptiness, and shattering the void as fulfillment.

Such teachings are truly laid bare in full. Yet to encounter them and not practice, or to practice without diligence, is to end as a lowly ghost—what a pity!

Xiaogen says: I have heard from my master that what has been recorded above is indeed laid bare in full. Yet one must carefully savor its essence to not betray the compassionate intent of the sagely teacher’s instruction.

Seated upright in meditation is first to cultivate a reverent heart, as if receiving an honored guest—thus avoiding the state of dull confusion. Within this, the work of regulating the mind and closing the breath must be thorough; once both person and method are forgotten, this is called *ding* (meditative absorption). Should thoughts arise, they are repeatedly released. Thus rising, thus returning—once, twice, thrice—this is called *practicing* *ding*.

As for "grasping and upholding, illuminating and attending," its meaning has four aspects, though its application has but two. What are the four? Grasping corresponds to action, upholding to stillness, illuminating to sitting, and attending to reclining. For people, the mind easily scatters during movement, grows lax in idleness, dulls in quiet sitting, and forgets in weariness—hence the sagely teacher’s comprehensive guidance. What are the two? The work of *grasping and upholding* requires effort, applied when the spirit sinks to its lowest point, seeking support in the middle or upper regions. The work of *illuminating and attending*, however, requires no effort; it is properly employed when the spirit rests at its highest point—this is the correct method.

Regarding advance and retreat, these are called *acting* and *ceasing*. Yet these two terms—*acting* and *ceasing*—must not be understood as starting or stopping practice, but rather as advancing the Yang Fire and retreating the Yin Talisman. *Acting* means advancing the Yang Fire; *ceasing* means halting the retreat of the Yin Talisman. Advancing the Yang Fire does not mean advancing the breath, but rather, after the breath is regulated and the descent of *qi* is prolonged, there arises a state akin to breath-holding. Retreating the Yin Talisman means subtly withdrawing awareness, then immediately engaging in the work of releasing all conditions.

As for *dikes and defenses*, it speaks of *interruption and continuity, lack of focus*. This means that when interrupted, one continues; when unfocused, one concentrates—such is the meaning of *dikes and defenses*. For instance, if practice is interrupted by external affairs, one resumes; if distracted by other practices, one abandons them to return to single-minded focus.

As for *using operation as withdrawal and addition*, this refers to the earlier statement, "tranquility and spontaneity as operation"—when the two are mutually verified, all becomes clear. As for oral instructions such as *bathing* and *nurturing the fire*, one may follow the text directly without further concern, so no redundant annotations are needed.

Only the final phrase, *"no-thought within thought,"* requires careful reflection. It refers to the work of concentrating the spirit and settling into stillness, which relies entirely on *true thought*—that is, the *true thought* of *grasping and upholding, illuminating and attending*.

*Heavenly Immortal Heart Transmission*
Transmitted by Taixu
Compiled by Disciple Min Yide (Xiaogen)

**Author’s Preface**

The turning of the times knows no constancy: whether the world’s fortune flows or stagnates, whether the Dao’s radiance shines or dims—its mechanism lies with humanity, and heaven and earth revolve accordingly. In high antiquity, each person preserved their spirit in full, so the turning of the times never faltered, nor did the Dao ever darken.

In the present age, the world exalts form and sound, striving to sweep away emptiness and stillness. This corruption began with the guiding masters, who first misconstrued subtle teachings, forgetting that purity of emotion (pronounced *zhěng*) leads to downfall, thus erring themselves and leading others astray. Later, those who wielded words for self-gain arose to echo them, luring scholars in droves into their snares—dying unrepentant, utterly blind to the wondrous interplay of *being* and *non-being*, the true and real phases through which the sages merely observed their marvelous subtleties. For its function is thus: whether in passion or dispassion, it remains one, never two.

Modern guiding masters fail to grasp this, nor do scholars awaken to it. Thus, the habit has hardened into custom, descending into the exhaustion of the lower epoch. The fortunes of body, world, and Dao have grown nearly beyond remedy. Though the Creator can do nothing, humanity—being the Creator’s most numinous essence—may yet reverse this turning by first modeling ourselves on the sages of old.

What does it mean to model ourselves on the ancients? In our land, there was Fuxi; in the western regions, the Able One (Neng Ren); in the eastern lands, the Great One (Tai Yi). They enlightened the young and nurtured integrity to refine the human heart, bequeathing subtle teachings to instruct later generations. The scriptures of the Three Teachings remain intact: by purifying the heart and reading them, one naturally understands that world and body are not two, that nature and life are one. Only then does one realize that humanity governs the world, while spirit governs humanity—heaven, earth, and humanity as one continuous thread, its principle thus.

Did not the Great One say: *The human body is the body of a lifetime; the heart is heaven, the body is earth, and thought is humanity. From sincerity and rectitude to cultivation and governance, reaching great peace—no need to parse its workings, only to return from pure thought to sincerity.* The perfected ones of high antiquity governed the world and practiced the Dao without stepping beyond the body’s framework, without relying on external supports—only by fully realizing the self as the work. If each person made self-realization their study, how simple, how profound, how free and unconstrained it would be! That people could be led to learn from themselves stems from valuing emptiness and stillness in aspiration and thought—what is meant by *the root of all under heaven lies in the state, the root of the state lies in the family, the root of the family lies in the self.*

To exhaust this teaching further: the root of the self lies in the heart, the root of the heart lies in spirit. Spirit is not numinous without emptiness, not tranquil without stillness; without numinosity and tranquility, how can spirit attain purity? Thus, study values emptiness and stillness, and the turning of the Dao relies on spirit.

After the Three Dynasties, people competed in achievements, deeming tangible proofs sufficient for trust—yet this opened the door to scheming and deceit. From this, the turning of the Dao dimmed, and the world’s fortune daily declined. The Venerable Lü pitied this and inaugurated the tradition of *healing the world*. Our ancestor, Master Li of the Muddy Pellet (Niyuan), silently aided and abetted. Alas, the world grew ever more dissolute, the masses steeped in filth. Among billions upon billions, only my teacher, the Venerable Taixu, upheld the lineage without fail, guarding emptiness and stillness while embodying the *Doctrine of the Mean*, eschewing merit yet befriending all through the heart.

In the *bingwu* year of the Qianlong reign (1786), I first heard of these matters in the Great Scouring Grotto of the Mysterious Canopy Cave-Heaven, where the divine man Qu Pengtou silently verified and transmitted them to me in a state beyond knowing or awareness. They have long been engraved upon my heart. Now, humbly acknowledging that my learning falls short of my teacher’s, I cannot revive the unspoken resonance of the heart to transmit to scholars. Thus, I have compiled these three volumes in two works, collectively titled *Heavenly Immortal Heart Transmission*. Should later students truly embody and spiritually transform them, they will stand like a pole and cast a shadow without fail.

Its essential holding can be distilled into four words: *emptiness, stillness, constancy, sincerity*. The four take their source from the perfection of spirit, which is the ultimate study of perfecting spirit. Sincerity is nothing more than making spirit the master of body and world.

On the first day of the latter half of the first lunar month in the *jiawu* year of the Daoguang reign (1834), Min Yide of Golden Canopy Mountain respectfully inscribes this preface.

**Author’s Postscript**

The Master transmitted the celestial immortal’s practice to me in the *bingwu* year of the Qianlong reign (1786), which I received by ear in the Grotto-Heaven of Dark Canopy. I have cherished and preserved it in my heart for forty-seven years now. Though I have repeatedly expounded it to others, few have truly partaken of it. Across the ends of the earth, I have worn through iron shoes in search; through ten thousand years and a thousand autumns, I have wearied my spirit in vain. Fearing that the Master’s transmission might be lost to the weeds, I now dare to enshrine these oral instructions in woodblock and pear-wood prints.

Yet for beginning students, some may find their nature and character still impure, their gates and apertures unopened; others may be long entangled in the dust of passions, their obstructions deep. The method requires first a thorough cleansing, followed by *cun* and *si* (cun is visualization, si is concentrated contemplation). Should obstacles arise, though they stem from postnatal obstructions, they ultimately arise from stray thoughts running rampant, causing true *qi* to hide and gates to seal.

For the superior student, there is no need for forced circulation—only the cessation of thoughts is to be revered. Progressing naturally, unwavering from beginning to end, one returns to the prenatal, and the body becomes crystalline. Thus, to return to the prenatal, the method lies solely in perfect emptiness and stillness: within thought, there is no thought. Naturally, postnatal *qi* subsides, the prenatal re-emerges, original *qi* flows again, and the body’s gates and apertures suddenly open wide. One perceives only the five-colored divine light, gathered in countless millions. This is the concrete evidence of the five phases converging. The student must not be alarmed or overjoyed but rely entirely on true oneness, unwavering, to attain profound samadhi. Refined into pure essence, it is nurtured still by true oneness. When the work is complete and the practice fulfilled, the *qi* of Brahma pervades heaven and earth, and the primordial embryo models the ten directions.

Though it appears manifest and expressed in benevolence, how could one know it penetrates the Three Clarities above and below, where the Great Ultimate is fundamentally nonexistent? Though it seems hidden and stored in function, how could one know it rides the six *qi* in ceaseless circulation, utterly empty and ungoverning, seated in the true realm of the Great Void, forever becoming an immortal of the Limitless? This is its ascension to verification. Yet what celestial rank remains to ascend? One no longer knows whether I am the Primordial Jade Clarity or the Primordial Jade Clarity is me.

Alas, the world chases after things, and even when given this simple and direct method, many retreat in confusion and abandon themselves. Their flaw lies in failing to fully set down the phrase *"release the ten thousand conditions."* Without this, they never begin. Even those who do not neglect this phrase but merely sweep away distractions for a moment may deem themselves already empty and still. Clinging to the method of *"facing the celestial stem,"* they rush into the Yellow Center, carrying with them postnatal ordinary spirits and *qi*, blocking the mysterious apertures within the body. How is this different from hauling water and mud to fill the immortal realm of Kongtong? Though they may later exert the strength of five laborers to clear it away, the traces of mud and water remain difficult to wash clean. Even if cleansed thoroughly, time does not pause—sun and moon hasten by. Those who can hold fast to the Dao until the end are already the seeds of our lineage. But if they abandon the path halfway, it is like fearing choking and giving up eating—how pitiful!

Thus, I record the Master’s heart-transmission for the world. Now, as I transcribe these texts, I once more sound the morning bell of *"release the ten thousand conditions"* for students.

**The Ninth Year of Daoguang (1832), on the Intercalary Double Ninth Day, Min Yide of Golden Canopy Mountain records this.**

---

**Inner Chapter (Nine Stanzas)**
The Master said: *"Transform through merging—*
*the celestial immortal’s practice.*
*Release the ten thousand conditions,*
*and the body becomes naturally empty and still.*
*Thereupon, draw in clarity and stillness,*
*uphold constant illumination.*
*Align the center below,*
*without the slightest negligence.*
*Perfect emptiness, perfect stillness,*
*perfect clarity, perfect harmony.*
*What is inside? What is outside?*
*What exists? What is nonexistent?*
*Transformation upon transformation, life upon life,*
*all entrusted to suchness.*
*Returning to wondrous function,*
*thus and only thus.*
*The body within the body—*
*this is called the true I.*
*Honor it as the sovereign,*
*cherish it as your child.*
*Nurture it with warmth and bathing,*
*feed it with your care.*
*When the work is pure and the practice refined,*
*return to the Great Beginning.*
*From end to beginning,*
*few are the admonitions:*
*Rejoice in merging and tranquility,*
*strictly avoid vagueness.*
*Vagueness and merging—*
*how far apart are they?*
*One remains in perfect awakening,*
*the other sinks into confusion.*
*Awakening makes one a sage,*
*confusion makes one a demon.*
*Thus the Master’s teaching—*
*take heed, do not misconstrue."*

**Outer Chapter (Eight Stanzas)**
*The heart-transmission of celestial immortals*
*sees the body as crystalline.*
*Borrowing it to welcome stillness,*
*like standing beneath the sun.*
*Stillness illumines, then life arises;*
*stillness infuses, then transformation occurs.*
*Transformation upon transformation, life upon life—*
*the work lies in this single method.*
*Heaven is born from the One,*
*Earth is completed by the One.*
*If the body loses the One,*
*how can its crystal clarity endure?*
*The One as the One—*
*thoughtless yet sincere.*
*Neither existence nor nonexistence is established,*
*both self and dharma are extinguished.*
*The spirit of original function*
*interroots with its root.*
*Place the body in the One,*
*place the One in the heart.*
*The great realm of the celestial cycle,*
*subtle as a mote of dust.*
*No form, no dharma—*
*merged transformation, perfect truth.*
*This is the true I,*
*the body beyond the body.*
*Invisible to sight,*
*inaudible to hearing.*
*Supernatural transformations,*
*appearing and vanishing at will.*
*When the work is complete and the practice fulfilled,*
*ascend peacefully to the Jade Clarity."*

These two chapters are what I received by ear from the Master.

**Recorded in the *renchen* year of Daoguang (1832) for the disciples of Golden Canopy. The oral instructions of inner and outer elixir are complete herein, hence the title *Inner and Outer Chapters*.**

**Circular Instructions (Four Stanzas)**
*Above, it reaches the nine heavens;*
*below, it extends to the nine abysses.*
*The three powers guard the egg,*
*the Yellow is the field of fortune.*
*I dwell within it,*
*merged with Earth and Heaven.*
*Knowing return, knowing reversal—*
*nothing later is not earlier.*
*Utterly pure, utterly pure—*
*no place is not heaven.*
*Constantly true, truly constant—*
*profound beyond profundity.*
*Unbroken, seamless—*
*the Dao is nowhere incomplete.*
*When the work reaches its apex,*
*I am Buddha, I am immortal."*

These four stanzas were taught to my disciple Xue Yanggui.

The learning of the celestial immortal’s heart is complete herein, hence the title *Circular Instructions*.

**—Inscribed by Xiao Gen** *(a sobriquet)*

**Continuation (Twelve Stanzas)** *(omitted in translation as the original text cuts off here)*

Alas, steadfast scholars—
where there is will, there is fulfillment.
The Three Nīti heal the world—
why not follow in their steps?

Here too, the principle is merging and transformation,
not clinging to fragmentation.
Borrow emptiness to embrace stillness,
borrow stillness to return to emptiness.
When emptiness reaches its extreme and stillness its sincerity,
the foundation of the supreme Dao is laid.
In three years or five,
body and world dissolve into the subtle and unseen.
Thereafter, nurture and cultivate,
never presuming to be full or false.
Enduring and vast—
how dare the spirit grow lax?

The Bhagavān Emperor,
the Ulugh Ulus monks—
since their virtue spread,
proof has ever renewed.
For two thousand years,
war and plague have not encroached.
Men uphold uprightness,
women, secluded chastity.
Western records recount:
the Buddha, too, was but a man.
The *Sutra of Upholding the World*—
Xuanzang’s translation.

Merit neither increases nor decreases;
merging transformation brings purity.
When the work reaches its apex,
concealment or manifestation follows the heart.
This is the true supreme Dao,
the heart’s words of sage after sage.
Scattered through scriptural passages,
the world, benighted, fails to study them.
Lüzu gathered and revealed them,
only for them to sink again.
Niwan inherited the legacy,
and now the Great Void carries on the proclamation.
This humble one has received it,
though not yet transmitted it.
The solemn, resounding tone—
here, the Great Cleansing is thoroughly explored.

Thus, I compile and expound,
wishing to share it with fellow seekers.
"Emptiness, stillness, constancy, sincerity"—
these four words must be strictly observed.

The following section is titled *Continuation*,
comprising twelve chapters in all,
a sequel to *Transmission of the Celestial Immortal’s Heart*.
Its practice is simple and direct,
neither overgrown nor scattered.
Follow it step by step,
and attain great freedom—
truly corresponding, inside and out,
with the wordless true scripture of the Western Sage.

According to *Records of the Western Regions*,
the land of Ulugh Ulus stretches for tens of thousands of *li*,
its soil fertile and rich.
It governs a thousand dependent cities,
all relying on its yearly aid.
Its customs are the purest,
surpassing even those of Fuxi’s age.

Further consulting Buddhist texts:
before the Bhagavān Emperor arrived,
the Uighurs indulged in extravagance,
their people idle and wandering.
Frequent ocean floods struck,
yet they neglected the dikes,
gradually leading to collapse.
At that time, an elder named Wondrous Moon,
devout in the Buddha’s teachings,
invoked the Bhagavān Emperor,
who came from Central India
with twenty-five hundred disciples,
erecting dikes and embankments.
The elder followed, providing funds
and hiring labor to reinforce the walls.
Soon, the whole nation transformed,
and the dikes were completed.
Thereafter, the sea stilled its waves,
and the Uighurs escaped incessant rain.

The Bhagavān Emperor then expounded
the *Dhāraṇī Sutra of Upholding the World*,
bestowing it upon the elder
before returning to Central India.
(He was none other than Śākyamuni Buddha.)
During our dynasty’s Zhenguan era,
Master Xuanzang returned from the Western Regions
and, by imperial decree, retranslated it.
The emperor’s preface to the sutra
records these events in full.

Compiled by Min Yide.
*Resounding Tone of the Great Cleansing* (eleven sections in all).

Blue-Headed Master Qu said:
Teaching transcends sound and scent,
only awakening resounds in harmony—
not form yet form,
not emptiness yet emptiness.

Master Shen of Great Emptiness replied:
This is called the Dao.

Qu responded again:
Model heaven, embrace earth,
cultivate the body through earth’s pattern.
Utmost sincerity knows no rest—
the Dao is none other than my heart.

Shen said:
Indeed. This is called virtue.

Qu then proclaimed:
Affairs require mutual support to succeed,
things yield to one another to abound.

Great Emptiness continued:
Gain and loss are fundamentally impermanent—
is not calculation the error?

Shen intoned:
Form is precisely emptiness,
emptiness precisely form.

Qu replied:
Unknowing, unperceiving,
accord with the Emperor’s principle.

Shen answered:
Shatter emptiness and nothing remains.

Qu said:
Yes—
turn the body, forget the self, and heaven’s truth appears.
Thus may one know: within non-being, I exist.

Shen then continued:
Only then is the vajra indestructible body.

Shen further proclaimed:
The Great Dao originally has no self—
observe emptiness and abide in emptiness.

Qu responded:
Neither being nor non-being stands—
truth resides within being and non-being.

Shen said:
No attainment, no loss—
together they follow the course of fate.

Qu replied:
This is the true message—
how many are those who understand its tone?

Blue-Headed Master sang:
The utmost Dao nearly perished,
while earthen jars thunder like thunder.

Great Emptiness answered:
Only the Dharma of expedient means remains—
in movement and stillness, heed heaven’s heart.

Shen again intoned:
Clouds part and the sun appears of itself;
the sun appears and clouds vanish.

Blue-Headed Master replied:
Yet one must contend within the heart—
the message itself is impermanent.

Qu spoke again:
Just as in healing the world’s fate,
when fate falters, it rests with man.

Great Emptiness answered:
Grasp this essential teaching,
and I shall first enliven the spirit.

Blue-Headed Master continued:
The spirit governs body and heart—
body and heart are earth and heaven.

Great Emptiness concluded:
The Creator has no fixed intent,
thus man wields the world’s authority.

*Resounding Tone of the Great Cleansing* (eleven sections in all).
The Perfected Qu Blue-Head and Shen Great Emptiness
exchanged these teachings within the Great Cleansing Grotto-Heaven.
I, in my heart, received and cherished them,
at first believing them all to be the echoes of my own heart.

In the first year of the Jiaqing era,
Li Blue-Head of Fengtian arrived at Golden Canopy.
Our meeting was deeply harmonious.
I recalled the *Resounding Tone*,
and Li immediately exclaimed with delight:
“The supreme sound is rare; the spirit-chamber unsettled—
no one sings or responds.”
A title must arise from the immediate context
to accord with the Dao’s intent,
thus it is named *Resounding Tone of the Great Cleansing*.
Now, thirty-seven years have passed.
From afar, I receive the echo transmitted through the empty valley,
and so I record, inscribe, and set it down in writing.
May scholars deeply embody this.

Respectfully noted by Min Yide.

**Self-Admonitions** (Nineteen Chapters in All)

As the kite soars to heaven and the fish leaps in the abyss,
the natural mechanism of qi arises from the field of blessings—
no need for effort in ascent or descent,
for it is thus of itself.
In utmost sincerity without cease,
the great Dao congeals therein.

My body is the earth; my heart, the heavens.
Thought is the division of self and things,
yet self and things are one.
Blended and transformed,
subtly continuous without lapse,
without moment of adhesion.

How easily spoken—yet when thought is cut off, the spirit is clear.
How can thought be cut off?
Neither pursue nor heed it.
Through feigned emptiness and feigned stillness,
by effort one attains purity.
Purity leads to forgetfulness,
and only through unceasing sincerity is this possible.

Let me not falter again:
while the body endures, it must bear the Way.
Once transformed by things,
how can one still claim ability?
My years are advanced; only a single breath remains.
Seize this breath
to uphold the mandate and fulfill its course.

Beneath the vast sky and earth,
few share this aspiration.
Let me not wait in delusion:
if action is needed, act at once.
Before returning to the great Creator,
the spirit must first refine the spirit—
how can one linger in hesitation?
The sun’s whip brooks no delay.

The Venerable Miaoyue was but a common man of Jambudvīpa,
yet through reverence and faith in the Buddha’s teachings,
he moved the Tathāgata to respond.
The scriptures record this—
can the scriptures deceive me?
Sufficient proof, sufficient trust:
I may follow his example.

Moreover, this supreme Dao
depends solely on my own effort—
to attain the center, the upright,
the constant, the harmonious.
Like the mind commanding the fingers,
like water flowing into the vortex,
hold fast without slackening,
be vigilant in solitude without distraction.

How soundly I once slept—
only now, compelled, do I awaken.
If even I am thus,
what can the world recognize?
Though I am of no worth,
how dare I shirk responsibility?

The world mocks again: "If this transmission is true, disciples would flock—why do you alone hear it? The world has long been in decline; why did you not receive it sooner?"

This unworthy one fell silent, unable to answer. Suddenly, the spirit spoke in a great voice: "What can be said is hard to say. Had I waited until the Dao was perfected, the error would have been irretrievable. The Mud-Pill Palace of Pure Yang—ancient sages guarded it thus. Only after enlightenment did they reveal their birthdates. This is Heaven’s mechanism; how dare I fully disclose it?

When the time came in the *gengchen* year, the Divine Mother’s august decree was issued. Holding the world’s mandate, I received and proclaimed it. The law of disclosure and punishment was tempered with mercy. Only when the Great Void bore it did I dare address the world.

What does this decree signify? That learning must be *pure* (as in *zheng*) and *pure* (as in *sheng*), the center free from willfulness and certainty. One must rely on others, yet act as one must—only then can others become true persons.

In the harmony of tranquil reflection, unassailed by others, hold fast to this. Body at peace, the world at peace. If learning is not perfected, it only disturbs the mind. Thus, I have delayed—not out of carelessness, but caution. Now, I only urge myself, not others. Let each examine themselves; let none waver in resolve.

Those of like mind, awaken! Each reflect within. In emptiness, constancy, and sincerity, even those who stumble may yet rise. This is healing for the world—body and world unobstructed. Men must uphold centeredness and uprightness; women, secluded virtue. Nurture and cultivate to the end of this incarnate form. Bathed in the Buddha’s response, what can Jambudvīpa do?

Whether the response comes or not, bear it. Act according to one’s fundamental duty; to fail is to be no true person. May my fellow aspirants walk only in suchness."

The world assented: "You must persevere. Endowments vary in depth; proofs differ in manifestation. Whether in action or concealment, in prominence or obscurity—all is entrusted to suchness."

This piece, nineteen chapters in all, is titled *Self-Admonition*, serving as the binding precept for the entire transmission.

The time was the full moon of the second lunar month in the *jiawu* year of the Daoguang reign. The place was called Jade Altar, within the Hall of Praise and Transformation, the Hall of Preserving the Origin. At its center were enshrined the immortals Lü, Qiu, Bai, Huang, and Shen—a site of accumulated merit and cultivated conduct, initiated by Ren’an, Chunfan, Lanpo, Jingxuan, Nanya, and Xinxiang, and completed by Qingbo, Lanyun, and Zhixiang. Jing Tang, Jia Tang, Bu Yu, Chun Quan, Mao Tang, Xi Tang, Shi Xiang, Yun Bo, and others of the same learning intended it as a reverent offering to the Golden Canopy Lineage Altar. Yet I deemed it an act of deliberate effort, existing only while people endure, vanishing when they perish.

Thus, it was proclaimed to reveal the sagely work of Patriarch Lü in healing the world, directly pouring forth the heart-transmission. Its aim is to guide and refine the human heart. It serves as the firewood-removing remedy for the world’s fate, the precious raft for cultivating the self. Collectively titled *The Heart-Transmission of the Heavenly Immortals*, it comprises three volumes in two kinds, elucidating the unity of bodily conduct and worldly action.

As my own fate faltered, Jingxuan and Maotang had it printed. I then appended *Self-Admonition* in nineteen chapters as a conclusion—was this not a timely and auspicious convergence? I inscribe these few lines to record my fortune.

Respectfully compiled and postscripted by Min Yide, Layman of the Golden Canopy Mountain, styled Dingfan.

*The Heart-Transmission of the Heavenly Immortals*
Oral transmission by the Elder of the Great Void
Annotated and recorded by Min Yide, the Younger, styled Xiaogen

**Inner Chapter**
The Master said: "Primal Transformation..."

The Master is none other than Patriarch Li of the Mud-Palace. Carefully examining *Primal Transformation*, it is precisely the *Three Nuns’ Medical Salvation Formula* of Patriarch Lü. Its method constructs the body as emptiness and nothingness, draws the celestial pivot downward to illuminate, and purely practices the triadic ovum-guard of the Three Powers, with no other thoughts intruding—nothing more.

The Elder of the Great Void said: "This is the supreme, highest-grade elixir formula, yet it can only be grasped in the mind and cannot be transmitted in words." My master, Patriarch Mud-Palace, transmitted it to me, saying: "This is the true heart-transmission of the Supreme Highest. To begin, one must first halt thoughts; whether premeditating movement or subsequently engaging in visualization, it is especially crucial to clarify the fundamental principle. What is this principle? Simply knowing the return, knowing the reversion. For *return* is the return to the origin, and *reversion* is the reversion to the root. If one is ignorant of the Dao’s root as utter emptiness and the body’s essence as utter nothingness, then the return loses its return, and the reversion loses its reversion. To return and revert in this manner is no different than heading south while driving north. Once the principle is clear, one may proceed with *having-activity* that is *non-activity*, and every step will align with the Dao. The key lies in recognizing the provisional method. What is this provisional method? Either one borrows emptiness to contain fullness, or borrows fullness to refine emptiness. These two approaches are both methods of transforming the illusory into the real. Essentially, they all lead to the ultimate, but clinging to one while holding fast is called attachment. Those who are attached do not comprehend the Dao and virtue. All the elixir texts in the world derive from the Yellow Emperor and Laozi, and none are not precious rafts for attaining the center. Yet each school clings to its own tradition, failing to recognize the branches and leaves, thereby causing misguidance—deviating by a hair’s breadth, yet missing the mark by a thousand miles.

Our lineage traces back to the Qin and Han dynasties, directly inheriting a single transmission. It began with Guan Yin, was carried on by Patriarch Lü, and the principle was revived. Later, it fell into obscurity, until my master, Patriarch Mud-Palace, inherited it. I, Bing (a lineage name of the Great Void), humbly received it, though I am ashamed of my meager virtue. I have merely recorded what was transmitted. Those who study this must cross-reference it with Daoist scriptures and verify it against Buddhist sutras, neither clinging to existence nor non-existence, but wholly following the essence of the Dao. In practice, one must also cultivate both preservation and guidance, ultimately reaching the state of naturalness—only then can one avoid betraying what has been imparted.

**The Work of Heavenly Immortals**
Immortals are of five ranks: Heavenly Immortals, Water Immortals, Earthly Immortals, Divine Immortals, and Ghostly Immortals. Though there are five ranks, those who achieve success are collectively called *Perfected Ones*, for only the Perfected can accomplish this. However, people’s endowments and habits differ, making the practices of cultivation and refinement impossible to unify—hence the five ranks of immortals. Later disciples have described their practices from beginning to end, passing them down through transmission. The elixir texts extant in the world are largely of this nature; without oral transmission, one remains at a loss as to where to begin.

Patriarch Bai, Master Qiongguan, took pity on this and composed the *Treatise on Dispelling Doubts in Immortal Cultivation* to instruct the world. Yet alas, the world lacks those of superior wisdom, and most are of humble self-regard, often setting aside this treatise without reflection. My master, Patriarch Mud-Palace, considering this, held that one could directly inherit Patriarch Lü’s *Three Nuns’ Medical Salvation Formula* as the entry point, thereby benefiting both body and world without needing to pursue the completion of a single school. In essence, its method is none other than *Primal Transformation*. Thus, it is titled *The Work of Heavenly Immortals*, for it is not something Water Immortals or Earthly Immortals can partake in or practice.

**Letting Go of All Karmic Conditions**
What are karmic conditions? They are the dust of emotions and the roots of passions. Whether arising from internal accumulation or external contact, they must be let go for the Heavenly Heart to manifest—this is the very first step. Cultivating inherent nature begins here, and cultivating life also begins here. The subtleties within are for the practitioner to realize; no superfluous explanation is needed. Yet the methods of letting go are manifold. I shall speak only of the most refined, which is free from adverse effects.

Patriarch Mud-Palace said: "When conditions arise, immediately eliminate them—this is one method. When conditions arise like brambles, scorching within like moxibustion, gather them and release them in a burst—this is another method. When conditions arise, regard them with indifference, letting them follow their own course—this is yet another method. Among these three, the last is the immortal’s approach. It is like a cloud touching emptiness—emptiness remains unstained, thus unaffected by gain or loss. Practitioners need only attend to their own vigilance."

The Elder of the Great Void said: "Indeed. The Master did not say *sweep away* but *let go*. For conditions are formed by intention, and intention arises from the heart. When the heart dissolves, intention naturally transforms, and conditions spontaneously uproot—no effort is required." Let the learner embody this.

**The Body Naturally Becomes Still and Empty**
*Body* refers to the body within. *Naturally* means of itself. When qi is tranquil, it is called *still*; when thoughts are absent, it is called *empty*. In this state, the body equals emptiness and nothingness, and one’s radiance will surely shine. This line is the first secret key to entering *Primal Transformation*, and the work begins with visualization.

What is visualization? Initially, one uses the external to verify the internal; next, one uses the internal to verify the external; finally, internal and external become indistinguishable, with no separation. Patriarch Mud-Palace said: "Such verification is not obtained through the eyes—only then is it genuine. Yet this is not something beginners can achieve. Thus, the method of using the external to verify the internal is a way of entering intention through the eyes. The next step, using the internal to verify the external, is a way of entering the eyes through intention. The final stage, indistinguishability, is the verification of neither intention nor eyes. Only when the learner reaches this point can one proceed to draw the celestial pivot, practicing without vain effort. With prolonged, uninterrupted practice, the true heart is constantly present yet seems empty, and true qi is constantly full yet seems absent. This wondrous state manifests without being preserved and is attained without being sought—it accords with naturalness. How easy is it to reach this stage in practice? The key lies solely in *thought within non-thought*."

**Drawing the Celestial Pivot to Progressively Illuminate and Constantly Uphold**
This continues the verification of the previous line’s work. By further employing the provisional method of drawing the celestial pivot, one constructs the wondrous realm of true emptiness and true nothingness. Its progressive illumination naturally has direction (for *Jin* is the hexagram *Advancing*, signifying progress).

Patriarch Mud-Palace said: "*Advancing* and illuminating downward begins at the crown of the head, descends to the front of the forehead, then from the forehead, shines and pours into the root of the nose."

To further advance, one must first employ true intent to ascend directly from the crown of the head, reaching upward to greet the Celestial Pivot Star of the heavens. This naturally draws down the celestial *pivot* (Tian Gang) to align with the bodily *pivot* (Shen Gang), gathering and concentrating at the root of the nose, then illuminating and converging at the *Quepen* (collarbone basin). By cultivating emptiness to its utmost and stillness to its deepest, one naturally penetrates the mysterious aperture. Once the aperture is felt to open, further nurture naturalness and steadfastly uphold the single key of *non-thought*—thus the true verification of fetal breathing is attained. Yet without constant practice, this cannot be achieved. Know that this method sustains the entire process from beginning to end. Only when one has transformed the mortal to become a sage, leaving not a single trace of the unrefined, may one cease. Between heaven and the abyss, there is no moment’s interruption.

*Heaven* refers to the cranial bone at the crown, while *the abyss* is the *Yongquan* (Bubbling Spring) point at the sole of the foot. The Celestial Pivot Star resides at the center of the heavens, higher than the sun, moon, and stars, formed by the ascent of the earth’s essential *qi*—it is the master of the Dipper’s mouth and the celestial *pivot*. It is also the central star among the Five Stars, illuminating the five directions while maintaining its constant course. Below it lies the Northern Star (the Celestial Pivot, or *Tianshu*), governing the myriad phenomena. In the human body, this corresponds to the cranial bone at the fontanel, formed by the body’s generative *qi* after birth and connected upward to the Celestial Pivot Star. Thus, to draw the celestial *pivot*, one must first greet the Pivot Star. Once the Pivot Star is engaged, the celestial *pivot* naturally descends. From this point onward, its illumination persists day and night, like a vessel raised to receive the sun’s rays—inner and outer become luminous, upper and lower fully permeated. Only then is the postcelestial fully transformed.

This step is precisely the essential method of returning to the origin. The key is called *Returning to the Yellow*, wherein the breath halts, and *qi* penetrates through the front of the spine, ascending directly along the central path to the cranial bone—appearing neither to rise nor fall. This is because the precosmic *qi* is pure and without substance, thus imperceptible. The ancients followed this, stating that only when practiced in a state of singular, unadulterated thought does the ascent and descent belong entirely to the precosmic, free from flaws, and the verification becomes supremely wondrous. If emptiness and stillness have not yet attained naturalness, allow the ascent to proceed as it will, but at the moment of descent, do not forget the key of *directing to the sea*. Such was the oral transmission of Master Tai Xu. For beginners who rashly attempt *Returning to the Yellow*, they will inevitably encounter the postmortal following the ascent. Should one remain ignorant of this, the harm will be no small matter.

**Perfect Emptiness, Perfect Stillness—Perfect Clarity, Perfect Harmony**
The method is universally exalted, yet it must be perfectly rounded, without flaw. The marvel lies in allowing not a trace of the postcelestial to mingle within. Master Tai Xu said: "Emptiness and stillness are the essence; clarity and harmony are the verification. When the practice attains perfect roundness, no flaws arise." This is far removed from the initial stages where beginners circulate *qi* through forced movement or achieve pervasiveness through visualization. Even after attaining full circulation and pervasiveness, one must still purely practice *non-thought*, naturally returning. All methods at this stage are called *blended transformation*, thus one must employ *clarity and stillness* as the means of operation. Otherwise, the errors of *disrupting the Yellow* or *rushing the Yellow* will arise. What is internal? What is external? What exists? What does not? In the ceaseless transformations of generation, all is entrusted to *thusness*.

When one speaks of *thusness*, one has delved deeper into naturalness. Master Tai Xu said: "The internal refers to what lies within the physical body—viscera and the like. The external refers to the physical body itself—skin, flesh, sinews, and bones." Yet Master Mud-Palace spoke of the internal as the physical body and the external as the Dharma-body. This aligns with the *Three Nuns’ Salvific Method* of Lü Dongbin. Proceeding accordingly is akin to crafting immortal flesh: using heaven and earth as the cauldron and stove, *Yin* and *E* as the clay pot, the illusory physical body as the "meat," and concentration and wisdom as the support. The method is exceedingly simple and easy—merely close the six gates to prevent *qi* leakage, and this is the practice of fetal breathing.

What I now present is tailored for learners whose bodies and minds are not yet settled, whose apertures are not yet open. One must begin with physical movement and visualization, progressing until all apertures are fully open and visualization is free from delusion. Only then may one follow the profound instructions of the master, practicing without interruption at any moment, thus avoiding self-deception. Learners, take heed—do not skip stages.

**The Wondrous Function of Returning—Thus, Thus**
*Returning* is returning to the origin; *reverting* is reverting to the root. Master Tai Xu said: "Know that the root is utterly empty, the essence utterly nonexistent." Those who are ignorant of this principle often lose the *return* in their attempt to return, and lose the *reversion* in their attempt to revert. The term *wondrous function* encompasses methods such as *borrowing emptiness to contain the real* and *forging the real to refine emptiness*. Learners, examine this carefully—do not become attached to emptiness or reality. Hence it is said: *Thus, thus.*

**Forming the Inner Body—This is Called the True Self**
This corresponds to the *True Person* in alchemical texts, yet the method here is far simpler and easier. Beware of inconsistency—neither acting nor withdrawing, nor drifting into laxity or dullness. The method employs the Great Void as the crucible, the physical and Dharma bodies as the medicinal substances, concentration and wisdom as water and fire, and *uninterrupted practice* as the firing process. When the firing process is complete, the True Self manifests—no need to break through the crown and ascend afar. Its appearance and concealment follow the mind, unbound by location or distance, perceived only in movement and stillness.

**Honor It as the Sovereign, Cherish It as a Child**
The methods described in alchemical texts are all provisional. Without grasping their meaning, one risks grave error.

**Nurturing, Bathing, Nursing—These Are Your Responsibilities**
Master Tai Xu said: "Though *nurturing, bathing, and nursing* have established teachings recorded in alchemical texts, there is a living method—like Yu dredging the nine rivers, following the natural flow and guiding with one’s mind. This naturally aligns with the heart’s intent, aiming only for the mean and harmony." When the practice is pure and refined, one returns to the Great Beginning.

*The practice* is inner cultivation; *the conduct* is inner refinement. *Returning to me* means reclaiming what I originally possessed.

**The Great Beginning** is the primordial origin, the root of the Limitless, the True One. Tracing back from end to beginning, the teachings are few—only delight in its profound serenity, strictly guard against vagueness. Vagueness and serenity, how far apart are they? One remains in perfect awakening, the other descends into confusion. Awakening makes one a sage; ignorance makes one a demon. Such is the master’s teaching—take heed, lest you err in practice.

These twelve phrases are also the teachings of Master Tai Xu.

---

**Outer Chapter**

**The Heart-Transmission of Heavenly Immortals: Seeing the Body as Crystal-Clear**
*Seeing* is inner vision, the mind’s gaze. *The body* is the physical form, the mortal frame. *Crystal* is like clear quartz, a metaphor for luminous transparency. This stage of practice begins only when all entanglements are released. One must attain the subtle state of "as if present, as if forgotten," lest one fall into illusion. Thus it is called "crystal-clear," the meaning of perfect awakening.

**Borrowing the Dipper’s Light, Like Receiving the Sun Below**
The method is detailed in the *Medical Salvation Formula*. It is like holding a crystal vessel beneath the sun, where light naturally pours in, illuminating within and without. When the Dipper shines, life arises; when it pours, transformation occurs. Transformation gives rise to life, and life to transformation—yet the practice is but one method. *Shining* is universal illumination; *pouring* is concentrated infusion. *Life* arises spontaneously; *transformation* is alchemical change. Though the methods differ, they all rely on the True One. Thus it is said: the practice is but one method. *Method* is the principle; *practice* is its application, governed by this principle—for the true self resides therein.

**Heaven Is Born from the One; Earth Is Completed by the One**
The wondrous work of Heavenly Immortals lies solely in generation and completion. Even Heaven and Earth bear witness to this—only through generation and completion. Yet their profound meaning depends on the One. If one seeks immortality, how can the One be abandoned?

**When the Body Loses the One, How Can It Attain Nobility?**
The body is originally born from the One. When the body becomes crystal-clear, purity is achieved through the One. How can the One be made pure? Through knowing how to return, through thoughtless sincerity. Thus Master Tai Xu orally transmitted.

**The One as the One: Thoughtless Sincerity**
Thoughtless yet sincere, neither existence nor nonexistence is established, both self and dharma are dissolved. *Thoughtless* means no thought within thought. *Sincerity* is the sincerity of "without sincerity, there is nothing"—this is the True One. *Existence* is what is heard and seen. *Nonexistence* is absence of movement or change. *Not established* means allowing concealment and manifestation. *Self* refers to human emotions; *dharma* to principles. *Dissolved* means dissolving all scrutiny. When practice reaches this, thoughts naturally become still, and the heart regains perfect tranquility. This is what must be sincerely upheld from beginning to end.

If one sincerely upholds this, emptiness can be perfected, stillness can be deepened, fetal breathing can be achieved, the Mysterious Pass can open, breath can cease, true *qi* can circulate without obstruction, and what manifests will be nothing but the true state. Yet all must be observed with detached clarity to avoid deviation.

**Tracing the Spirit to Its Root, Interweaving the Root**
Place the body in the One, place the One in the heart. The great cosmic realm enters the tiniest speck of dust, without form or dharma, merging and transforming into perfect reality. *Tracing* means retracing from end to beginning. *Interweaving* means mutual exchange, like circulation. *Root* is the source. *Its* refers to the True One. *Placing* means settling. *Body* is the physical form; *One* is the True One; *heart* is the conscious mind. *Cosmic realm* refers to the body; *speck of dust* to the nature. *Form* refers to the physical body; *dharma* to the dharma-body. Carefully note: *merging and transforming* means uniting the physical and dharma bodies, placing them in the celestial heart to undergo refinement. Though the physical body is impure, the True One resides within it. Though the dharma-body is pure, it is tainted by mortal traces. They must be layered, refined, and fused—only then can the true essence emerge and become complete. The marvel of the method lies in the phrase "interweaving the root." The subsequent "placing the body" and "placing the One" already encompass the subtle application of the great cosmic and the infinitesimal. The reason this can be spiritually efficacious is that the heart arises without attachment. Thus it is said: without form or dharma, merging and transforming into perfect reality. The subtleties within cannot be fully expressed in words.

**This Is the True Self, the Body Beyond the Body**
Invisible when seen, inaudible when heard, with spiritual transformations and manifestations following the heart’s intent. When practice is complete and conduct perfected, one ascends peacefully to the Jade Purity Heaven. *True self* is the true person. *Body beyond the body* compares it to the physical form, for it can depart from the physical body, existing and acting as one. The next two lines quote scripture to affirm that the true self is the Dao-body, striking a warning to worldly delusions—lest one remain confined by conventional teachings and fall into illusion without awakening.

The final four lines reveal that true emptiness is not empty, true nonexistence is not nonexistent. Fools do not recognize that Heaven, Earth, and the Three Powers are but one. They admire the manifestations of perfected beings but do not understand the cause of their manifestation and concealment—it all depends on the One Heart. When it manifests, it manifests; when it conceals, it conceals. The heart of the perfected being is already undivided and unceasing with Heaven and Earth, thus capable of endless manifestation and unfathomable spiritual power.

At first, the physical body has not yet attained pure dharma, so there is the practice of merging and transforming. Once pure dharma is attained but naturalness is not yet achieved, one cannot yet ascend peacefully to the Jade Purity Heaven. There remains a state of "merging with merging, merging without merging, merging transformation, merging perfection," where one lingers in the world to refine it. Only when practice is complete and conduct perfected does one ascend to the Jade Purity Heaven. *Peaceful ascent* means no need to break through the crown to ascend afar. For the Six Directions and Three Continents are all within the One Heart—without location, how can there be high or low, near or far? Why labor over entry and exit, ascent and descent? All this arises from merging and transforming into the One, the spiritual work of the great cosmic entering the infinitesimal, attaining union with Heaven and Earth in virtue. It is not like the various immortals of earth, water, spirits, and ghosts, who are still far from Heaven and must ascend further to reach the Jade Purity Heaven.

Thus it is called the work of celestial immortals.

**The Perfect Formula:**
Above, it exhausts the Nine Heavens; below, it reaches the Nine Abysses.
The Nine Heavens refer to the head and brain—namely, the Mud Pill Palace.
The Nine Abysses refer to the Bubbling Spring, the center beneath the feet.
This treats the human body as a small heaven and earth, hence the ancient teachings speak thus.
*Exhaust* means to fathom fully; *reach* means to attain the utmost.
It contains the method of tracing back and following in unbroken continuity, acting without pause in heaven or abyss.

**The Three Powers Guard the Egg—Yellow is the Field of Blessing.**
The *egg* is the chicken’s egg, its metaphor drawn from Buddhist scriptures.
*Yellow* is the yolk of the egg, symbolizing the human world.
*Guard* means that one takes the Great Void as the crucible and the Three Powers as the elixir ingredients—such is the general formula of merging transformation.
I dwell within it, merging Qian and Kun.
*I* is the true self; *dwell* is abiding; *within* is the Yellow Center.
*Its* refers to what the true self accomplishes of itself, hence the use of *its*.

Carefully examining the method: one merges body and world within the Yellow Center, simply following the substance of the Dao.
A single thought is emptiness and stillness; stillness is emptiness.
Not clinging to any location, not mingling with discursive knowledge,
naturally the celestial qi descends, the earthly qi ascends, transforming blockage into harmony.
Such is the initial verification of merging transformation—thus it is called *merging Qian and Kun*.

**Knowing Return, Knowing Reversion—Nothing Posterior Precedes the Prior.**
*Return* is returning to the origin; *reversion* is reverting to the root.
*Posterior* is the postnatal; *prior* is the prenatal.
*Knowing* is awareness, like clarity.
Only with clarity can one attain sincerity; with sincerity, nothing fails to return; with sincerity, nothing fails to revert.
In this reversion and return, there is naturally no posterior that is not prior.
This is the natural spiritual verification.
Speaking in terms of essence, qi, and spirit, it still pertains to the inner workings.

**Able to Unify, Able to Integrate—Nowhere is Not Heaven.**
*Able* is capability; *unify* is single-mindedness—this refers to application.
*Integrate* is wholeness—this refers to verification.
The Dao of Earth is even; the Dao of Heaven is odd.
Odd is yang; even is yin.
When merging transformation reaches this point, it becomes pure yang, with no trace of yin remaining—thus it is said, *nowhere is not heaven*.
This is the verification of the outer workings—how easily can one attain it?

**Eternally Real, Truly Constant—Mysterious and Again Mysterious.**
Carefully noting: *eternal* means enduring; *real* means uncontrived.
It speaks of what one practices and accomplishes as both enduring and actual, actual and enduring.
When practice reaches its utmost, verification naturally becomes real.
Thus it is said, *mysterious and again mysterious*—it has reached the limitless and yet the limit.
Tracing its beginning and end, it does not exceed the two words *return* and *reversion*.
Pursuing its utmost, one returns to the substance of the Dao.

**Unbroken and Dense—The Dao is Nowhere Unrounded.**
Carefully noting: *unbroken* means constant reality; *dense* means real constancy.
*Dense and unbroken* is attaining utmost sincerity without cease—what Dao would not be rounded?
Therefore, the master conclusively states: *The Dao is nowhere unrounded.*

**When Practice Surpasses Its Utmost—I Am Buddha and Immortal.**
*Practice* is the practice of return and reversion; *surpasses* is transcending.
*Its* refers to the Dao; *utmost* is the limit of the limitless.
*I* is the true self.
This is precisely the *body beyond the body* spoken of in the outer workings—formless yet possessing form,
just as the Buddha’s body of purple-gold or the seed of true constancy in the Mystery School.
Thus it is said, *I am Buddha and Immortal.*

**Racing alongside Fuxi, Shoulder to Shoulder with the Primordial Beginning.**
*Fuxi* is the Heavenly Sovereign Fuxi.

**Racing alongside** means driving abreast. **Primordial Beginning** is the title of the ancestor of all existence and non-existence. **Shoulder to shoulder** signifies standing side by side. This completes the metaphor above. Let the scholar take heed: do not cling to appearances. As the saying goes, *What was Shun but a man? What am I but a man?*

**Heavenly Immortal’s Heart-Transmission: Esoteric Rites for Healing the World**

**Setting Up the Altar**
Prepare a single chamber, a *dou*-room. Within, place one pure table and one low table—one before the sacred image, the other to the east of the room. The chamber need not be large, but it must be pure and bright. Seal the doors and windows tightly to ward off wind.

Place two rush cushions—one before the sacred image, the other to the east. Lay out one palm-fiber mat, one tablecloth, and a set of three ritual implements. At the center, offer a plate of white rice; above it, a cup of pure water, one bright lamp, a pair of candles, and three sticks of fine incense. Prepare one set of pure robes and one pair of pure shoes. Nothing else is to be placed within.

**Entering the Altar**
Enter only with utmost reverence, as if deep in thought. Once inside, hold the body upright, empty the mind, and unify the thought. After stilling sight and hearing, perform the three prostrations toward the honored one. Then step aside, face west, and sit upright before the low table, upon which the esoteric rites are placed, with a rush cushion beneath.

The adept sits in dignity, waiting until the qi settles. Only then are the rites unfolded. Silently recite the syllables *Om Lam*, either three, five, or seven times, to purify body, heart, and intent. While reciting *Om*, one must hold the mind utterly free of thought, visualizing the creation of a single, clear, and empty qi—like water, like the sky—before uttering *Lam*. In the Western method, a prolonged breath is drawn beneath *Om*. If following this principle, simply extend the *Om* sound.

When performed with sincerity, visualization, and devotion, three recitations suffice. Upon completion, proceed to the ritual invocations. The specific forms are not recorded here, for the rites employ *spirit-prostration*. If wishing to withdraw, one must rise, approach the sacred image, and perform the three reverences as before, then depart.

According to the *spirit-prostration*, the spirit bows toward the clear emptiness while the physical body remains still and unmoving.

**Retiring from the Altar**
As the body withdraws, the spirit turns inward to congeal. Not only must one refrain from speaking, seeing, or hearing—within, one must guard and preserve the scene of clarity and harmony. When matters arise, respond; once done, immediately release. Do not chase after emotions, lest the focus of preservation be lost. If lost, immediately re-congeal; once congealed, release as before. Then the spirit will remain perpetually clear, and the qi perpetually still.

If re-entering, follow the initial rites. Once the daily practice is complete, retire to solitude, taking the severance of thought and forgetting of emotion as the fundamental principle. At first, effort is required; in the end, it becomes natural. Do not fear difficulty, nor seek ease.

**Completion of the Rites**
One must possess constancy and sincerity, and make a great vow. There is a gatha to be recited in reverence:

*By the transmission of my master’s teaching,*
*I borrow emptiness to embrace stillness,*
*I borrow stillness to return to emptiness.*
*Emptiness reaches its limit, stillness becomes profound.*
*The Three Origins harmonize with the mechanism,*
*Mutually healing the world.*
*Manifesting wondrous signs (pronounced "ji"),*
*At this very moment,*
*Without the slightest lapse,*
*With earnest heart, I pray:*
*May I attain the Inaudible and Invisible.*

After reciting, perform three prostrations. Rise, approach the sacred image, and perform the three reverences as before, then depart.

The above rites comprise four essentials, handed down by past sages. Though exceedingly simple, they serve as the entryway’s rules and thus include procedures for entering and retiring. The determined adept practices them, for all depends on the self.

*The Discourse on Cultivating Immortality and Dispelling Delusion* states: *Take the body as the altar, furnace, tripod, and stove; take the heart as the chamber of the spirit.* Here, the heart is taken as Heaven, the body as Earth, and thought as Man. Therein, one attains emptiness, stillness, centrality, harmony, roundness, and the ultimate. Body and world naturally transform.

At this time, the form-body and the Dharma-body will either unite or not, yet without any obscurity—this is called *merging*, called *transformation*. Thus did Patriarch Lü establish the esoteric rites of the heart. If one clings to forms or environments, one strays far from the esoteric teaching.

**Esoteric Rites: Original Text with Annotations**

**Opening Gatha**
Embrace emptiness to realize reality,
Return reality to emptiness.
Reality and emptiness fuse as one—
Body and world may be healed.
The method of practice follows.

**The Unifying Mantra**

**The Unifying Mantra**

Chant *Oṃ* (drawn out), without counting repetitions, to create a realm of pure emptiness and singular *qi*. Here, neither world nor self exists; sound and scent dissolve—this is called *unification*.

The efficacy lies in the syllable *Oṃ*, hence its tone is prolonged. It encompasses the essence of the *kāraṇa* (seed-syllable) within its resonance. Yet according to the inner scriptures, this is called the *Pure Realm*, not *unification*.

**Sacred Proclamation**
Heavenly Treasure, Numinous Treasure, Divine Treasure—
Jade Purity, Supreme Purity, Great Purity—
one *qi* flows and pervades, the Three Purities evolve and transform.
Radiant yet silent, they govern the four seasons without speech;
in perfect emptiness, they nurture the Three Realms without action.
In the Great Brahma Heaven, within the Golden Palace,
from primordial void and spontaneity,
the Three Purities, Three Realms, and Three Treasures of the Heavenly Worthies emerge.

This is the *Jade Purity Divine Mother’s Proclamation*, bestowed by the Primordial One at the dawn of time. The world has long called it the *Comprehensive Proclamation of the Three Purities*. Master Niwan states: "When reciting this proclamation, avoid杂念 (distracting thoughts). The essence lies in boundless emptiness, where sound and scent dissolve."

I observe that the text directly describes the *Dao-body*. If not the Divine Mother, none could embody it; if not the Primordial One, none could transcribe it. Those cultivating the supreme Dao should hold it inwardly. Though the world misinterprets it, the full meaning of the Three Purities remains intact—calling it the *Comprehensive Proclamation* is not inappropriate.

**Petition**
At this time of the Lower Kalpa’s turning, only the singular endures. I humbly receive the profound mandate to gather the world and return it to the heart. Revering benevolence and harmony, may all beings renew their *qi*. I beseech boundless compassion to universally bestow illumination.

Heaven’s *qi* descends as benevolence; Earth’s *qi* ascends as harmony. In each inhalation and exhalation, these two virtues cycle naturally. Initially, one cultivates this circulation; in purity, it arises spontaneously. The subtlety lies in neither attachment nor fixation.

**Mantra of Repentance and Liberation**
According to the inner scriptures, this is the *Great Bright Mantra*, the heart-sound of the *Īśvara* Bodhisattva. When sincerely recited, the world responds and beings transform; the body aligns with the *qi*, awakening the supreme bodhi-mind. Thus, karmic obstructions dissolve.

Yet in practice, utmost precision is required. Master Niwan states: "Lüzu adopted this method. The calamities of the Lower Kalpa arise from human actions. The workings of creation unfold accordingly—if karmic obstructions remain, the world’s fortune cannot flourish."

*Oṃ maṇi padme hūṃ* (pronounced *hǒu*)

The practice begins with self-observation of emptiness. One must observe until body and mind are forgotten, and world and self become one. When one perceives a millet-like grain within, moving freely, and the surroundings appear black as lacquer, this is the Lower Kalpa’s world and self—blackness caused by habitual defilements.

At this moment, recall the mantra with spiritual remembrance. Whether holding or not holding the recitation, one attains the resonance of sound entering the heart. Beware of conceptual thought—this leads to the *soundless sound*, resounding through the ten directions, its origin unknowable. This arises from utmost sincerity in cultivation, achieving the state of *non-holding within holding*—akin to reciting in a dream.

Only after mastering this can one elicit worldly responses and transform beings, aligning the body with congealed *qi*. Such is Lüzu’s sacred healing method. How could mere vocal recitation attain this? Yet the Dao does not depart from the world; to ascend to sagehood, one begins with the throat and tongue. Practitioners must awaken to this.

**Cloud Script**
This *cloud script*, as stated by the Primordial One, is called *Mysterious Accumulation*. It embodies the congealed *qi* of the primordial, the heart-flower of the Divine Mother, each stroke containing mountains, rivers, and the cosmos.

The scriptures of the Three Teachings reveal its essence, yet its applications are inexhaustible. Elder Guo later compiled it into the *Mysterious Accumulation Mantra* for transmission. The world mistakenly uses it as an opening gatha, unaware that it is specifically tied to the cloud script.

Its essence is investigable—it is the *primordial mandate*, hence its use in healing the world’s fortunes. Through recitation and practice, both merit and worldly benefits are perfected. This script embodies the *Dao-body*; its essence being utterly real, its function is naturally numinous. Yet it cannot be fathomed by private intellect—hence its applications are inexhaustible. The explanations in the *Mysterious Accumulation Gatha* are not empty words.

**Eighty-Four Scripts**
The Divine Mother disseminated them; the August One copied them; Mother Shen verified them; Zhengyang compiled them; Elder Guo expounded them; Pure Yang employed them; Niwan inherited them; and Bing Cheng transmitted them.

My teacher, Master Niwan, said: "The *Primordial Purity Cloud Script* pervades the great void—a karmic excellence of the era. The August One, a celestial immortal, saw and copied them, storing them in the heavenly treasury and transmitting them to earthly immortals. Like a *kumbha* of pearls scattered into the world, they lacked punctuation or phonetic guidance. Zhengyang, upon obtaining them, lamented: 'Dispersed longevity has no measure; longevity is difficult to perfect.' Moreover, the script’s forms were extraordinary, making replication arduous. Mother Shen, moved by this, descended to bestow phonetic guidance, enabling recitation. Zhengyang received this, transcribing them into standard script and compiling them into a text, hence the name *Great Cavern Jade Scripture*. Yet it was not included in the canon until the Liu-Song dynasty, when Lu Jingxiu of Wucheng was ordered to compile it.

I observe its applications: there are *yong*-for-use, *yong*-for-origin, *yong*-for-play, *yong*-for-dryness, and *yong*-for-spirits. When transcribing the standard script, each stroke within the hooks contains profound meanings.

Lüzu’s healing method uniquely employs the *play* and *origin* aspects, tracing back to the *Primordial Jade Method of Yuanshi*. This aligns with the cloud script’s compilation of the phrase *Namo Jué Fǎ*. My teacher further said: "All things arise from their own source. The cloud script’s origin lies in the *Golden Book*; the *Golden Book*’s manifestation arises from Wang Ni. Who is Wang Ni? The *primordial mandate*."

To study is to delve into the essence—this is called plumbing the source. Knowing and applying with reverence, transformation upon transformation, life upon life, without departing from the body of the Dao. To know the Dao: its root is Great Emptiness, its essence is Utmost Nonbeing. Once this meaning is illuminated, the two words *emptiness* and *nonbeing* are themselves what Wang Ni emerges from. This is called *penetration*; scholars must embody it with solemn care and never neglect it.

The following twelve seal-scripts were appended by Lüzu, yet their profound meanings may be inferred and fathomed:

1. Refers to the Dao inherited by the Confucian lineage.
2. Refers to the Dao inherited by the Daoist lineage.
3. Refers to the Dao inherited by the Buddhist lineage.

The twenty-four seal-scripts to the right were appended by Master Niwan, which serve as invocatory words. The *Niwan Proclamation* states:

This lineage is the utmost Dao,
The cloud-script is the true text.
A single seal moves from the heart,
The Three Powers gaze in reverence.
All that is sought comes to pass,
All wishes naturally fulfill.
When the full seal is set in motion,
Each motion issues from the heart of Heaven.
Unbound by the realms of being and nonbeing,
Its efficacy is manifest.
As recorded by Dipamkara:
Hidden or revealed, it follows the mind.

Niwan further said: There is a transmitted method for its practice, yet without affinity, it remains unseen and unheard. What is this transmitted method? The Perfected Pure Yang said: When scholars practice this method, they simply arrange the cloud-scripts in sequence, storing them either in the navel or the brain, following a prescribed order. In practice, one first moves Wang Ni, then the *Golden Book*, and finally the seals—this sequence must not be reversed.

What is Wang Ni? It is this: ○.
What is the *Golden Book*? It is this: ○.

Niwan also said: When Lüzu moves Wang Ni and the *Golden Book*, he employs the *Heavenly Eye*. For the oral practice, he relies solely on the two syllables *Om* and *Lan*, using them as one would polish a mirror—this is the correct method of applying spirit in practice. Thus, when moving the seals, he shifts to the *Heavenly Eye* and directs them into the void. Once the seal is formed, it is gathered and stored in the navel or the brain, wherein lies the most subtle and profound meaning.

Though the seals are moved beginning with the *Golden Book*, this Wang Ni is the *primordial mandate* of the Three Powers, the very source from which all transformations and lives emerge. In terms of the body: before leaving the womb, its proper place is in the brain; after birth, it descends to the *qi*-sea.

Furthermore, the *Golden Book* embodies the *primordial nature* of the Three Powers, the hidden and manifest source upon which all things rely. In terms of the body: before responding to stimuli, its proper place is in *Li*; once stimulated, it arrives at the *Heavenly Valley*. Thus, when seals are moved in accord with the *Golden Book*, they descend from the *Heavenly Valley*, and clarity upon descent is most excellent. When seals are moved in accord with Wang Ni, they ascend from the *qi*-sea, and harmony upon ascent is most excellent.

Practicing in this manner—storing in the brain and the navel—embodies the meaning of ascent and descent, and the method is well-ordered. It is said that one seal ascends while another descends, and each seal must silently hold the full cycle of the entire script. This is how imbalance is avoided. Practicing thus, ascent and descent are balanced, yin and yang are harmonized, breath is even, and advance and retreat are orderly.

It is said that one must hold as if not holding, move as if not moving—this is how naturalness is attained. By attaining naturalness, the mechanisms of the Three Origins and *qi* return to the prenatal state. Once the primordial is restored, body and world are ceaselessly governed.

Practicing thus, without pause, for three to five years, nurturing and refining, how could the world not be transformed, the practice not flourish, Heaven not be Heaven, Earth not be Earth? Know that frequent calamities are all wrought by human action.
