With intention, gather and retain this qi in the Crimson Palace (that is, concentrating this misty qi). The technique lies in a state of "as if present, as if forgotten" (when practicing this, one will inevitably feel the chest grow stiff or restless with heat, nearly unbearable—this is the misty qi, warmed by the heart’s fire, on the verge of transforming into blood. Only then should the following method be applied, so the blood may return to the kidneys).

With eyes inwardly gazing, perceive the space between chest, back, and bedding as bottomless (thus, the heated blood flows from behind the heart and before the spine, dividing into two paths along the left and right to infuse the waist and kidneys, where blood is refined into essence). Yet do not exert too much effort—merely relax and "attend" (this "attending" is the same *gu* as in *Xiuxian Bianhuo Lun*, meaning the vigilant care of cultivation).

The subtleties within hold boundless wonders (akin to those expounded in my annotations). Its cardinal principles lie in eight methods for generating blood and two for transforming essence. As for the nine secrets of sleeping alongside another—lest they mislead later learners into heterodox paths—I dare not expound them here.

On the first day of the tenth month in the *bingwu* year of the *Chu* reign, Lazy Cloud, attending the presence of Master Tai Xu, recounted the *Precious Rules of the Celestial Immortal’s Path* and *Essential Prohibitions of the Celestial Immortal’s Path* as transmitted by Master Ni Wan. Upon reaching the passage concerning the intervals of movement and stillness, Lazy Cloud’s heart stirred. Master Tai Xu was a divine being, an emanation of Southern Mountain’s spirit, his left palm bearing the inscription *Sovereign of the Great Void* (the script resembled seal characters yet teemed with vitality, its strokes coiled and soaring like flying serpents, its hue a pure vermilion—visible only when washed at the moment of his passing). Hence his name, Tai Xu.

Lazy Cloud, with earnest intent, entreated to commit the teachings to writing, that they might be transmitted to those of karmic affinity. Master Tai Xu replied: “Very well. With you to inscribe them, why should I withhold? They shall spread far and wide across the lands north and south of the great river. Yet the time is not yet ripe.” Then he rose and intoned:

*“In the imperial era of three sixes,
Five more years shall pass.
North of the Divine River’s shore,
South of the Weaver’s Lodge.
A humble rustic,
A barefoot disciple.”*

Thus began the transmission, and the secrets first spread forth.

When the chant ended, he continued: “To obtain these teachings is not difficult, and many have heard them. Yet each must gauge their own nature and capacity, for their cultivation will differ, and so too their realization. All who read this book are of my fellowship—take care not to abandon yourselves.”

After a pause, he added: “My master arrived yesterday and told me I shall soon answer the imperial summons; my departure is near.” Then he rose and chanted:

*“Seventy-nine years in this world,
Time not to be idly spent.
Glad to preserve my true countenance,
Spiritually attaining the Heaven of Great Void.”*

When the chant ended, he took up brush and paper, saying: “Record!” Beginning with *The Precious Principles of the Daoist Path*, he wrote in orderly sequence. By the time he reached the section on “Movement and Stillness in Intervals,” it was already the full moon.

Master Tai Xu said: “Should we not compile the verses chanted on the new moon into a complete text and append them to this record, as a karmic testament for the first disciples to come?” Lazy Cloud rose and compiled them, then presented the work. Tai Xu nodded: “Well done.”

He continued: “Write further for me.” The addition read: “What I have set forth is not fully recorded in other texts. Those who receive it must not treat it lightly. To receive and not practice, to practice without diligence, to be diligent without constancy—all these are forms of disdain. If one fails in these, the Dao will not be attained in this lifetime. Recorded on the full moon of the tenth month, Bingwu year of the Qianlong reign (original text). Inscribed by the Master of Indifference (Indifference being the name of his studio, the Indifferent Realm of Kaihua Monastery in She Village, Gui’an County, where Master Tai Xu ascended). Tai Xu’s final instruction; recorded by Lazy Cloud.”

Alas! Eleven days later, Master Tai Xu indeed departed this world.

In the current year of Wuyin, Lazy Cloud, sojourning near the Weaver’s Lodge, awakened and transcribed these teachings to bestow upon those of karmic affinity. He appended a few more words at the end of this passage.

**Chapter Ten: Essential Prohibitions and Cautions**
**Do Not Act Against Human Norms**

The Master of the Mud-Pill Palace said: “Those who ‘do not act by human norms’ are not steadfast scholars of proper conduct, but seekers of novelty and eccentricity. They may escape human retribution by chance, but Heaven’s law will not tolerate them. The statutes decree that even a single transgression incurs a three-year penalty, for their nature delights in seclusion and deviation from the central path. The harm they bring is severe, so the punishment is heavy and unrelenting. How can one not be warned?”

Master Tai Xu said: “My master’s words are true and unerring. The recluses of antiquity lived in the world yet forgot the years; their names are recorded in the annals, shining brightly for over a thousand to be verified. Today, some mingle with the dust of the world, becoming monks fed by desolate temples or associating with ragged beggars. The most refined hide on Mount Emei, or in the remote peaks of Jizu, Taihua, or Laoye, keeping company with wolves and jackals. They sit in meditation for hundreds of springs and autumns, their bodies buried beneath fallen leaves, thorny vines blocking the paths, fearing only that others might discover them. These are the great adepts of the Han, Wei, Six Dynasties, Tang, Song, Yuan, and Ming.”

“Those who once displayed many wondrous signs have suffered prolonged penalties. I know this truly; I have seen it with my own eyes. Yet I refrain from revealing their names.”

I fear that those in the world with aspirations may become deluded and misuse these arts, bringing no small harm upon themselves—thus I do not hesitate to speak at length for their sake. Let those with resolve take heed: be cautious, and never act against the natural course of things.

At that moment, the Sea-Retaining Elder interjected: “Divine powers and magical arts are what true adepts of this world rely upon to accumulate merit and cultivate conduct—this is recorded in detail in the annals. Master, do you caution against them because the written records are not entirely trustworthy, or is there a deeper meaning in your extreme admonition?”

The Great Void Elder replied: “Your confusion makes you unfit to discuss this. Yet if I do not explain it to you, I risk misleading later generations. Have you seen an egg hatch into a chick?”

“Yes,” he answered.

“Have you ever seen one attempt to break its shell before its form was complete?”

“No, I have not.”

“The transformation of an egg follows its own Dao; the completion of its form follows its own principle; and the breaking of its shell comes in its own time. Before the time is ripe, no transformation can occur; before transformation is complete, no form can take shape. If one forces a premature hatching—before the transformation is done, the unformed will die; if the form is incomplete, it will wither; if the form is hardened but the time is not yet come, it will fall ill. What I spoke of earlier concerns those who have already taken form and hardened, yet whose time has not yet arrived—thus their suffering is no more than this. Yet even so, their affliction is grave indeed!

Alas!”

The chick, like all things, is but a common entity—from non-being it transforms into being, nurtured to completion, its task fulfilled. Yet whether broken by Heaven or by man, the harm or benefit remains as we have seen.

Now, our Dao is the Dao of immortality. From being it refines into non-being, forging the solid back into the void, dispelling delusion to return to truth, gathering emotions to restore nature, transmuting yin into yang. Through myriad practices and secrets, one neither abandons nor clings to the physical form—living yet unbound, serene yet luminous, neither fully present nor absent, utterly pure and refined. The five viscera and six bowels are no longer mere viscera and bowels; the four limbs and hundred bones are no longer mere limbs and bones. One perceives only a radiant, perfect sphere, gleaming and resplendent. First, the realm of the water-moon is attained; next, the world of golden sands; finally, the realm of crimson and violet purity. Suddenly, the manifested realm contracts, shrinking to the size of a grain of rice or millet. Then, with true intent, I draw it into the Mysterious Pass, as a magnet draws iron, penetrating the Mysterious Womb—this is the wondrous function of settling the spirit and entering sagehood. No trace of external, impure qi is borrowed; not a thread of unrefined mundane essence, mundane qi, or mundane spirit from within my body is allowed to mingle.

When the Mysterious Pass first opens, and a single impure practice reveals its extraordinary and esoteric arts, my immortal embryo has yet to form, true qi is still faint, and though the true spirit is complete, the defilements of the dust remain stubborn. With little radiance to speak of, these extraordinary and esoteric arts arise as the true spirit commands the consciousness, marshaling my mundane qi to act in concert with the celestial and terrestrial *qi* of the Big Dipper’s killing and life-giving forces. Their numinous efficacy lies in borrowing the authority of the Celestial Emperor, so that the *qi* of Heaven and Earth cannot but converge. Yet those who come to converge are none other than the Six Heavenly Demon Kings, who, obeying the Emperor’s decree, dispatch their demonic *qi* to gather. Among them are many spirits who feign obedience while fearing righteousness, their hearts not yet rectified. Though they heed the summons and arrive, they must act as commanded—thus their actions are invariably efficacious and verified.

One must understand: those who practice such arts have not yet refined their cultivation, their true qi is insufficient, their true spirit still faint, their heart and nature not yet perfected, and their deluded thoughts still ablaze. Thus, this reckless refinement arises from nothing more than vain desires for superiority, fame, marvels, and wonders, or the foolish impatience to test and taste. These demonic spirits know them well and, seizing the opportunity, entice their inner demons to collude, usurping their bodies. The practitioners, unaware, find their hearts already possessed. From then on, they act without restraint, and their arts grow ever more wondrous and efficacious. They claim their past cultivation was all mistaken, thus misleading both themselves and others—an inevitable outcome.

If, however, their Dao-root is deep and profound, and they encounter a perfected being who awakens them with a shout, returning them to the true Dao, they may yet cultivate with vigor and achieve the formation and emergence of the immortal embryo. Yet in the final step of pulverizing and completing the work, even after hundreds or thousands of years, there are those who cannot proceed. Why is this so?

The delusions of past misdeeds accumulate like mountains and seas; only when karma dissolves and sins are absolved does the celestial decree descend. This barrier is thus broken—how can one not take heed!

Hai Liu says: Know that when inner cultivation reaches completion, merit and conduct naturally suffice. In harmony with the Creator, sharing the same breath, thought stirs and the spirit responds. The spirit congeals and qi guards, as the mind commands the fingers—every gesture answers without fail. Can one then claim that spiritual powers are not vast? What need is there for methods? What need for techniques?

Those who are obscured and do not attain the spirit’s obscurity, obscured and do not attain its penetration—these are but the sentiments and thoughts of the mundane! Purify these mundane sentiments and thoughts, and with a single spur, return to the true. Then spiritual powers arise of themselves.

Hai Liu Weng rejoiced, and Lan Yun Shi thereupon inscribed these words.

**Cautionary Admonitions, Eleventh: Indulgence in Idleness**

Ni Wan Shi says: Those who indulge in idleness are no true aspirants, nor can they be compared to those who seek self-liberation. How lamentable! Even if a sage were to rise again, it would be difficult to spur them toward the Dao. Their bodies are purely yin, for their refinement cannot overcome their indolence. Alas, what more can I say?

Tai Xu Weng says: How compassionate! That my master disdains to instruct them is precisely his profound teaching. Those of a tranquil nature suffer from laziness—seemingly enlightened yet unenlightened, seemingly content yet discontent. They are of limited capacity, mingling among the gates of the mysterious, their efforts truly pitiable. My master pities them deeply, hence his blows and shouts.

In this world, those who seclude themselves in withered trees and empty halls are legion. I say such people merely fail to grasp the secrets of cultivation! To knowingly place oneself amid the realm of afflictions while clinging to idle ease, and moreover to meticulously examine gains and losses—this is the mark of a great spiritual friend. Over time, as others come to recognize their cultivation, they may yet be moved to a place of ignorance. In weighing the merits of this ease, they inwardly nurture themselves, finding solace and encouragement in the intervals. Who would deny that this is the grand path to celestial immortality?

Why is this so? Having entered the gates of the mysterious, beware of squandering time in vain. If one wishes to spend one’s years in tranquil repose, my method ensures this will persist for a hundred thousand lifetimes. Yet this idle ease is never assured—this is precisely the intent behind my master’s blows and shouts.

Alas! Lacking both talent and strength, if one forces diligence, illness will surely follow. Better to adapt to one’s capacity and guide it toward its destined path. Just as birds and swans differ in nature, each harbors its own secret of refinement. No one is born in vain—all may attain the Dao. Take care not to abandon or confine yourself.

**Cautionary Admonitions, Twelfth: Setting Deadlines for Achievement**

Ni Wan Shi says: To claim that achievement can be fixed to a deadline is the view of one person, not a universal principle. For endowments vary, and the foolish differ from the wise. To set deadlines for achievement invites nothing but harm.

Tai Xu Weng says: Indeed. The master’s words strike the mark. Whether one drinks water or broth, the cold or warmth is felt for oneself. The master cannot dictate it to the disciple, nor the father to the son—endowments differ, and the wise are not the same as the foolish. Proceed as is fitting; sufficiency lies in not falling short of the proper time. If the timing is amiss, even if the deadline passes, the practice must not cease.

The terms "seven" and "nine" are but labels for the young and old, not deadlines for achievement. "A hundred days," "ten months," "three years"—these signify enduring constancy. Thirty-six turns to the left, thirty-six to the right—this is like the saying of "half a catty, eight taels." By such analogies, one may infer that rigidity is unnecessary.

Consider the example of traveling a road: measuring bows, steps, and paces to determine distance is the established method. For those who take this path, the journey is all that matters—arrival is the ultimate aim. Why must one cling to passersby to count their steps? Steps vary in size, and their numbers differ. To calculate distance by counting steps—is this not delusion?

The path of celestial immortality is lively and free—it cannot be discussed by those who cling to rigid forms and adhere to texts.

**Cautionary Admonitions, Thirteenth: Self-Imposed Purity and Defilement**

Ni Wan Shi says: Purity and defilement reside in the mind; circumstances have no part in it. Yet those among the world’s aspirants who are deluded and hindered in their practice are legion. How laughable!

Tai Xu Weng says: How profound these words! Purity and defilement reside in the mind; circumstances have no part in it—this is an unchanging truth. To be bound by circumstances is the fault of clinging to the past without digestion.

Know that the various acts of purifying and repelling defilement are akin to washing the face while cleansing the heart, or burning incense to refine one’s nature. Yet how is it that some abandon rites of mourning and avoid graves, believing that scriptures warn that seeing a corpse for forty-nine days bars one from attaining the Dao? They do not realize this teaching arises from the tradition of ritual recitation, subtly admonishing those who deal in yin and yang, whose livelihoods depend on funerals and burials. Such people dream, eat, and sleep amid death, their entire lives—inner and outer—steeped in its qi. Truly, they have no capacity for Daoist attainment.

Yet if those of the yin-yang school could sincerely recite the *Great Mystery Jade Classic*, and moreover daily reflect inwardly, not only would their bodies become pure, but those they encounter would be transformed, and what they preserve would become spirit. In accumulating merit and deeds, what could surpass this? This is what is meant by "forming ghostly affinities"—it too is an aid to attaining the Dao.

Moreover, the mind knows no cycle of birth and death! If even birth and death are absent, what place is there for purity or defilement?

As for the tradition of ritual recitation, it is fitting to maintain inner and outer purity. Any laxity would fail to express proper reverence, hence the rites of burning incense and making offerings, of bathing and changing clothes. But for those who cultivate the solitary path of celestial immortality, dwelling in vast emptiness without trace, there is no fear of encountering inauspicious defilement—what need is there for taboos?

Yet if one lacks the Dao but the heart is moved by resonance, then one may retreat to hold the *Tai Xuan Yu Jing*, preserving and emitting compassionate radiance—like moon, like sun—illuminating the Golden Court. Though touched by resonance, no harm shall arise.

Never should one, without cause, restrain oneself, waiting for seven cycles to pass before offering condolences, thus neglecting the great rites. This would be to obstruct the progress of all things that naturally advance through interaction. Herein lies the merciful intent my master revealed in this teaching.

**Fourteenth Admonition: Clinging to the Past, Binding the Present**
Master Niwan states: As times change and the world transforms, the flow of *qi* and destiny shifts accordingly. Those who cling to the past and bind the present merely cherish antiquity without digesting its essence—they must be cautioned.

Master Taixu responds: Indeed. Ancient methods have long ceased to function in the world. Take, for instance, the transmission of the Dao: circumstances often render adherence to old forms impossible, yet few recognize this. Once, in a certain place, someone transmitted a certain Dao to another, with neither rites nor ceremonies fully observed, yet the transmission was completed. Another arose to reproach them, saying: "This Dao was passed down from such-and-such an ancestor, received from such-and-such a master, with rites like this and ceremonies like that—how weighty it was! Now this transmission is so simple, so careless. Is this permissible?" The accused wished to defend themselves but could not, and to this day, the matter remains a subject of ridicule.

Alas, the reproach was not without reason. Yet how could the critic understand the difference between past and present circumstances? The *Classic* says: "Rites, rites—are they merely about jade and silk?" The ancients valued ceremonial forms precisely to gauge the sincerity of the recipient. Today, however, it is otherwise: if one calculates rites before transmission, one may attract the insincere, who will gather in cold indifference—or worse, slander the Dao on account of the rites.

Alas! One must recognize that the disregard for ceremony in that transmission was an act of reverence for the Dao, not disrespect. Applying this principle to those who cling to the past and bind the present, there is indeed cause for caution.

Oh! In this deluge of the world, even those who cling to antiquity do not truly grasp it. Examining closely, most merely use the past to constrain the present—their hearts and conduct are even more unworthy of inquiry.

**Fifteenth Admonition: Surrender of Body, Heart, and Intent**
Master Niwan states: Those who master the three through reversal attain immortality; those who surrender the three through compliance remain bound to the human realm. Thus, the surrender of body, heart, and intent must be cautioned against.

Master Taixu responds: Profound are the master’s words! Body, heart, and intent may be called *qi*, spirit, and essence—or Heaven, Earth, and Water—for within them lies this principle. Essence arises from the heart, spirit belongs to intent, and *qi* is borne by the body, yet all are governed by the heart alone.

Those who master the three through reversal can use the heart to restrain intent, intent to govern the body, the body to stabilize resolve, resolve to settle spirit, and spirit to harmonize *qi*. Through mutual restraint and stabilization, desires are purified, principles are refined, and unity is achieved—this is the Dao of immortality.

Those who surrender the three through compliance merely follow the heart with intent, the body with intent, and intent with the heart. Through mutual surrender and compliance, desires flare while principles perish, giving rise to a thousand postures and ten thousand forms—this is the way of humanity.

Alas! One must understand that the Dao of celestial immortality employs reversal as its function, just as Heaven and Earth are fixed in their positions, and Earth and Heaven achieve harmony. Even Water and Fire, Metal and Wood possess the marvel of mutual union, while Water and Earth share the power of harmonious blending. Extending this principle, all things employ reversal as their function—surely this is why my master so earnestly admonishes us.

**Sixteenth Admonition: Neglect of Ritual and Etiquette**
Master Niwan states: This can be seen outwardly as proof of inner cultivation—it is precisely the manifestation of reverence and sincerity in both inner and outer conduct. How can it be neglected? Those of resolve who transgress this will surely fall into demonic paths. Must they not be cautioned? This is to misunderstand the true meaning of "measured reverence."

Master Taixu responds: Those who violate this precept are mostly of the "seemingly enlightened but not truly so" sort. Such individuals, lacking merit from past cultivation yet possessing slight talent, drift through life unrecognized. When they offer reverence and respect, others do not respond—instead, some even mock them. Gradually, they reverse their conduct entirely. Then, meddlesome admirers praise them, saying: "So-and-so is talented, surpassing even the ancient recluses and purists." The ignorant follow suit, extolling them as "liberated," "serene," or "aloof," mutually reinforcing one another. Word of this reaches the ears of unworldly scholars, who then emulate them from afar.

This is how, in this degenerate age, the neglect of ritual and etiquette becomes mistaken for preserving one’s true nature. Truly, cultivators must beware! Otherwise, they will inevitably fall into the demonic path of self-importance—must they not be cautioned?

One must maintain consistency between inner and outer, yet also observe proper measure. Thus, when occupying a position of honor, one should uphold the rites of forgetting rank; when in a humble or junior role, one should fulfill the duties of a disciple. In interactions with peers, one need only ensure that ritual forms are not lacking.

Our Dao is the great Dao of celestial immortality—neither shunning others nor fleeing the world. Social exchanges cannot be neglected. The sound of bells in the palace is heard without; take care that the noble gentlemen of the four directions, upon hearing and seeing, do not depart with misgivings.

Moreover, the celestial immortals’ school embeds the fire-phase within conduct, whether moving, stopping, sitting, or lying down—how can one be careless? When one should sit while conversing, there are methods for "conversing while sitting." When walking while conversing, there are methods for "conversing while walking." When standing while conversing, there are methods for "conversing while standing." When others sit, sit; when they rise, rise; when they stand, stand; when they walk, walk.

Every gesture of social courtesy and bowing ritual contains within it subtle and wondrous secrets. One may practice one’s functional techniques and refine one’s qi and essence at any place and time, while also carefully assessing whether one’s practice is relaxed or strained. How could one carelessly perform the external forms of social exchange without the inner cultivation of spiritual mastery? Thus, the single precept of celestial immortality encompasses as many as three thousand eight hundred fine and detailed injunctions. For the more serene the mind, the more perfectly it aligns with the Dao—without need for deliberate focus, it naturally conforms to every rule and measure. Yet one must, in ordinary times, minutely observe and embody these principles, so that when the moment of social engagement arrives, one does not chafe at the complexity of ritual forms.

Thus, the resolute scholars of old never neglected, even in the household, the proper forms of rising, standing, sitting, and walking at every moment and in every place. Their very purpose was to refine the functional techniques of rising, sitting, walking, and standing. When the time came to emerge into the world—whether serving superiors, engaging peers, or facing subordinates—their demeanor and conduct naturally achieved completeness and accorded with both propriety and technique.

This is what is meant by “the great hermit dwells in the marketplace.” Today, however, it is otherwise: people assume that the household has no fixed rituals and thus allow their limbs and body to grow indolent. They do not understand that the saying “the household has no constant form” does not refer merely to morning and evening duties. Rather, all rituals, great and small, must be observed in these moments, so that one may realize how inner and outer become one, and ritual is no longer mere ritual. Each must ensure that inner and outer are unified, without the flaw of imbalance—hence the saying “no constant ritual.”

When Confucius was at ease in his private chambers, his bearing was composed and joyful—this was precisely the subtle application of embodied realization in moments of leisure. It can be grasped in the mind but not conveyed in words. Take care not to mistake leisure for an occasion to grow negligent. The practice of natural reverence and attentiveness is essential.

As the saying goes: “In advancement, think of giving one’s utmost loyalty; in retreat, think of correcting one’s faults.” This does not apply solely to matters of governance. One must understand that the success or failure of governance arises from the single mind. In all actions—moving, stopping, sitting, rising—if one knows the technique to settle and anchor the spirit, then the spirit remains within the body and does not wander elsewhere.

When one emerges to serve in the court, affairs are naturally clarified, decisions are naturally sound, responses are naturally harmonious, and conduct is naturally upright. In all social exchanges and interactions, modesty is fittingly restrained, reverence is fittingly composed, deference is fittingly appropriate, eloquence is fittingly articulate, discourse is fittingly fluent, conduct is fittingly upright, and integrity is fittingly genuine.

For the Way of celestial immortality: in obscurity, one perfects oneself; in prominence, one benefits the world. In stillness, one becomes a sage; in transformation, one becomes a Buddha or immortal. All begins and ends in the single practice of harmonizing the mind. To achieve great transformation without self-attachment—this is the study of celestial immortality. Who would dare treat ritual propriety with negligence?

Those who regard ritual as mere ritual reduce it to empty form. Outwardly respectful but inwardly negligent—this is still negligence, and it must be taken as a solemn warning. Let my disciples take heed.

*Preface to "Idle Words of a Lazy Mind"*

These two individuals remain of unknown origin, their surnames and given names likewise undocumented. Reading their *Heart Talks*, they appear to be practitioners of the art of nourishing life, poised to embark upon the Southern Palace. I chanced upon their writings and transcribed them, delighted by their words—shallow yet profound, coarse yet refined—wherein their intent seems directed toward a purpose, far removed from the obstinate recluses of this world. Their inclinations align with my own. Thus, I have excised the unorthodox and retained the perennial teachings, naming this collection *Idle Words of Two Lazy Minds*. One styles himself Lazy Old Man, the other Great Lazy One. Regarding their "lazy" appellation: it derives from the heart, not from indolence, for it carries the meaning of relying on the heart to pursue learning—akin to the lineage of Su the Lazy Old Man, those who engage with both the celestial heart and the heart of the Dao.

In the eleventh month of the *wuyin* year of the Jiaqing reign, on the full moon day, recorded and inscribed by Xiao Gen.

---

You, sir, drift like duckweed from the southern skies, while I am rooted in the northern earth. This autumn, we met by chance, our joy as if we had known each other for lifetimes. What a felicitous encounter! Your master is Li the Barefoot, while mine is the Venerable Tai Xu. Though seemingly without cause, our bond was silently forged by our two teachers. Recently, you have associated with the Northern City Master, who is a disciple of the Stone Mirror Mountain Man, a transmitter of the Dao—something you were unaware of. His grandmaster, Jin Huaihuai, bore the surname Wang and was known as Qingchu. He is also your grandmaster, making your master, the Barefoot Venerable, a fellow student of my Stone Mirror Mountain Man. I once studied under Jin Huaihuai, having become his disciple through the Venerable Tai Xu. Thus, you and I are as brothers bound by the same lineage. At first meeting, we blended like water and milk, our sects one and our practices unified—our inclinations naturally harmonious.

What teachings did the Northern City Master impart to you? You replied: "What I have heard concerns only the recognition of the Mysterious Pass and the union of heart and kidney." I asked: "Is the Mysterious Pass open? If so, recognizing it is not difficult. But if this pass remains unopened, how do you propose to unite them?" You said: "I wish to receive your instruction." I replied: "We are of the same family—how could I regard you with indifference? For now, our meeting is but a fleeting encounter, but one day we may together unravel these profound mysteries."

---

**A Good Question**
One day, we met again at an ancient temple. Great Lazy One said: "The ancients say the mechanism lies in the eyes. I wish to explore its subtleties." Lazy Old Man rose solemnly and replied: "An excellent question. The human body is entirely yin, and what transforms yin back into yang are the two eyes. This is the first oral instruction for entering the Dao. Since you already know this, henceforth use it for inner illumination, and every aspect will become the Dao—you may then hope to open the Mysterious Pass."

You asked: "Where does one begin with inner illumination?"
I said: "Close your eyes and regulate your breath for a time. Once your breath is settled, concentrate your spirit in the brain, and with your gaze, direct a faint light toward the crown of your head. You will perceive a dim brightness, like moonlight in the dark night. Then, with intention, guide this light to illuminate the *Niwan* palace. When the brain is filled with light and your head feels as clear as crystal (this is the *Marrow-Washing Method*), over time, lead this brightness down the *Chonglou* to the *Jianggong* palace. Hold it there for a moment, and you will feel your *Jianggong* pure and white (this is the *Heart-Washing Method*). Then, with intention, guide it to the *Zhonghuang*. Again, hold it there as before, and you will feel your *Zhonghuang* pure and white (this is the *Pure Land Method*). The radiance will naturally descend with the qi, and you will gradually perceive your lower field expanding, becoming ever more serene and profound (this is the *Pacifying the Sea Method*).

With inner illumination prolonged, the brightness grows clearer, the space wider and more vast. After a long while, you will sense qi stirring within (this is the *Dragon Emerging from the Sea Bottom*). At this moment, maintain a state of pure emptiness, and with subtle intention, guide your gaze to illuminate from the sea bottom backward. Soon, you will feel this light penetrating the *Weilu* (this is the *Tiger Turning from the Water Bottom*). Gradually, a light will ascend from below (this is the *Yellow River Flowing Backward*), ultimately reaching the crown (this is the *Returning Essence to Nourish the Brain Method*).

At this time, employ the *Head-to-Tail Illumination Method*. What is this method? Let the light of your two eyes rest in the mid-heaven, like the sun and moon shining down upon the crown, penetrating the Three Passes straight to the deepest sea bottom (this is the *Sacred Sun and Sacred Moon Illuminating the Golden Court*). It will seem as if a moon’s reflection appears at the sea bottom, mirroring the moon above in the mid-heaven (this is the *Water in the Long River, Moon in the Sky* formula). At this juncture, all sounds fade into emptiness. Use only one intention, simultaneously ascending and penetrating without conflict. With prolonged practice, you will feel this pure light piercing the nine heavens above and shattering the nine abysses below. At this moment, you will no longer be aware of your body.

This is how one begins inner illumination. Alas! It is easy to speak of, but difficult to practice."

You said: "Though I am not quick-witted, I shall take these words as my guide."

---

**A Good Doubt**
One day, we gathered and, after parting, you returned. You said: "After practicing inner illumination and proceeding to the formless, my mind soon became clear and bright. Gradually, I felt as though my lower region had vanished, boundless and unfathomably deep. This occurred after prolonged inner cultivation, with my thoughts stilled to utter sincerity, revealing this scene. I felt my entire body suffused with harmonious qi. Eventually, even this scene faded from my awareness, and I perceived no breath—only a surging heat in my lower region. Suddenly, amid this intense heat, a few strands of cool qi appeared, descending either from the chest and abdomen or flowing down the spine from behind, meandering around the male organ, as if on the verge of leakage. I feared this was not an auspicious sign (though it is precisely the auspicious sign) and halted midway (if one stops without adding fire to refine, there will be harm)."

Upon emerging, you respectfully sought my counsel. Lazy Old Man said: "An excellent doubt."

This lower yin essence, when encountering qi, undergoes transformation (this yin essence is precisely the few strands of cool qi flowing downward on all sides as mentioned above). If the true qi is too weak to refine it (inability to generate intense heat stems from the weakness of true qi, and true qi is true fire), it will merge with ordinary qi (ordinary qi is ordinary fire; at this juncture, ordinary fire is ministerial fire), forming the essence of sexual arousal. Without advancing the yang fire (holding the breath and concentrating the mind is called advancing the yang fire), this substance will inevitably break through the barrier and escape.

The method lies solely in gathering the spirit and concentrating qi at the sea bottom, then propelling it with the light of both eyes, as if turning a millstone. At this moment, the more serene my mind becomes, the more my breath halts, allowing true qi to flow and remain in the lower region (this is the great secret of advancing the yang fire). The lower region then grows as hot as a boiling cauldron (the appearance of boiling water over fire), and the yin essence transforms into qi, following the qi’s ascent. It pierces the tailbone, rises to the mud pill, and becomes true fluid (this is the concrete evidence of returning essence to replenish the brain). Descending through the heavy tower, it moistens the crimson palace (this is called the post-heavenly sweet dew, a substance that transforms into blood), then divides from behind the heart and before the spine to reach both kidneys (at this point, the sweet dew has turned red and become blood).

I then guide the light of both eyes downward to the kidneys, rotating it left and right. The faster the rotation, the hotter it becomes (this is the method for refining blood into essence). The heat spreads from both kidneys to the navel wheel (this is the secret of refining the ordinary to return to the true, and refining qi to return to primordial qi). This heat must be several times more intense than before, so that this substance, transformed from true essence, becomes qi.

From this point, one must not cease (not even for a moment). The heat descends once more to the sea bottom, and the work of concentration and infusion continues as before (this is a crucial instruction). Then, as previously described, the yin essence (which will inevitably appear and in greater quantity—only after refining the entire body to pure yang will it cease) transforms into qi and ascends again. The method for refining yin to return to yang is nothing beyond this. Its effects can be observed at times (interruptions make it difficult to see, hence the warning against them), but the subtlety lies in perseverance (a vital reminder, indeed).

Thus, by circulating without interruption and practicing at set times daily (only thus, only thus is it correct), why doubt that one cannot achieve in months what the ancient worthies promised? (This is certain, without a shred of doubt!)

The Great Lazy One said: "Your words are correct. I shall follow this practice. Yet I have heard that the method of 'dividing from behind the heart to descend to both kidneys' applies to women’s cultivation. Since women are rooted in blood, their mysterious pass opens at the crimson palace. Their method involves massaging the area between the breasts, called the breast stream, rubbing it hundreds or thousands of times until the chest grows fiery hot, causing a sensation of oppression and a wooden, board-like appearance. Only then does their blood begin to flourish. The method requires guiding the intention to retreat behind the heart and before the spine, then dividing it to infuse both kidneys. If, like men, one were to descend straight from the heart to the abdomen, there would be a risk of blood collapse. (This question arises from the Great Lazy One’s mother, who is currently engaged in inner cultivation. Lazy Old Man had explained this to her in the past, hence the inquiry. This is the essential method for women’s elixir refinement.) Thus, their practice truly aligns with your description.

Now, what you describe pertains to qi. Qi ascends to the brain and reverts to fluid—this is already extraordinary. Once transformed into fluid, why must it descend directly to the lower field? Why, like women, must it first descend to the crimson palace, retreat, then reach the kidneys before rising to the navel wheel to transform into qi? This principle is unclear. Moreover, qi and breath are of the same substance, both inherently fiery, differing only in being pre-heavenly or post-heavenly. After hearing your explanation, my doubts multiply, and I cannot resolve them myself. I humbly request your guidance."

Lazy Old Man said: "Excellent question! You truly deserve to be called one who doubts well. What I have shared comes half from my teachers and half from books. Now, let me briefly outline the essentials.

He replied: 'I am eager to hear the profound teachings.'"

The disciple said: "In men, yang resides in the abdomen; in women, yang resides in the back—this is the unchanging principle of Heaven and Earth. What I call 'yin essence' appears like essence but is not true essence; it is the fluid transformed from food and drink, not yet refined into blood, stagnating within the hundred meridians to become phlegm-like. When it lingers in the middle burner, it forms 'retained fluid' syndrome; when it flows into the bladder, it becomes slippery discharge. Within the three hundred joints and eighty-four thousand pores of my body, this substance abounds, lurking in their depths. External pathogens seize the opportunity to ally with it, causing no small harm.

Now, when my true qi circulates and warms it, this substance melts and becomes mobile, flowing with the qi to protect it as it descends to the lower field. Being yin and cold by nature, its movement seeks only coolness. Yet if it accumulates without transformation, it must eventually turn to fire and emerge—what the world calls 'flowing fire syndrome' is precisely this substance.

Thus, whenever I sit in meditation and true qi flows, I feel a cool, rustling breeze rising from within—this is the effect of this substance being transformed and released. Therefore, when this substance flows toward the lower field, I must apply great true fire to refine it (this is a crucial oral transmission). Then, like mist or cloud, it rises with the true qi along the spine to the crown of the head. There, it gathers and condenses into true fluid, like rain or dew, dripping from the nostrils into the mouth (this is the sweet dew). It moistens the crimson palace (here, one must retain it as long as possible), and when warmed by the heart’s fire, it transforms into blood.

Thus, it must descend from behind the heart and before the spine, dividing to reach both kidneys. Once refined, it flows with the qi to the navel, and after further refinement, it becomes qi. This is the fixed process of qi transformation, the same for men and women.

Who does not consume food and drink? The fluids derived from them are produced daily. If one remains ignorant of the method of refining them with the heart’s fire, few will avoid illness—hence nine out of ten people suffer from phlegm. Those who cultivate the Dao often struggle with seminal emission. The world fails to understand, attributing it to lustful thoughts, or to a lack of harmony between heart and kidneys, or to poor digestion—all are mistaken. It is because they do not know how to retain qi with the heart’s focus, allowing their fluids to overflow, accumulate, and transform into phlegm, which then flows downward and leaks out.

If one forcibly restrains it, external symptoms arise, manifesting as abscesses and toxins—this is its transformation into fire. The harms it causes are too numerous to count, so I have explained it in detail.

As for true essence, it exists when observed as a whole but vanishes when grasped. Even the essence produced during intercourse is a product of qi transformation, hence it has form and color. Since it originates internally, it can give life. But this fluid from food and drink comes from without, unrefined by the heart’s fire, not yet transformed into blood—it merely resembles essence. How can it give life? It is not the supreme treasure; even if it leaks occasionally, why regret it? To fret and grow agitated over it is truly deluded!

Rather than taking medicine to restrain it, it is better to refine it as I have described—this is 'removing the firewood from under the cauldron.' I speak of this matter at length because, though this substance is mundane, when refined properly, it becomes yin qi. When it reaches the brain and descends to the heart, it can transform into blood, becoming a treasure. When it further descends to the kidneys and rises to be refined at the navel, harmonized with earth, it becomes indistinguishable from true qi—truly the supreme treasure.

Great Lazy One, the pre-heavenly is yang, the post-heavenly is yin. Our cultivation is nothing but the path of refining yin to return to yang. The method is simply to forget the body to nourish qi, forget qi to nourish spirit, and forget spirit to nourish emptiness. The reason one must reach the state of 'forgetting' is that only when the gathered essence, qi, and spirit all belong to the pre-heavenly can they be free from harm.

Moreover, what matters is that the body constantly undergoes refinement, and the agent of this is fire. When fire is sufficient, one thrives; when fire declines, one fails. Without forgetting, there is no gathering; only by forgetting can fire become sufficient. This is the most essential secret of Daoist cultivation."

Great Lazy One noted this and said: "I dare not but follow your instructions."

Afterward, Great Lazy One asked again: "I have heard that the heart has three aspects. What does this mean?"

The master replied: "Indeed. They are called the Heavenly Heart, the Earthly Heart, and the Human Heart—yet in truth, they are one. As the classics say, 'The heart is the palace of spirit and brightness; the Dao of transformation arises from it.' The entire body moves or rests by the heart’s qi, like a fish in water.

The ancients said: 'The solid parts of the body are Earth; the hollow parts are Heaven. Bending and stretching, speaking and listening—these are Man.' They also said: 'The Heavenly Heart resides in the brain, the Earthly Heart resides in the abdomen, and the Human Heart resides in the crimson palace.' The heart in the crimson palace is substantial yet empty and luminous, containing all three within one.

The hearts in the brain and abdomen are formless and insubstantial—they are the spirit and qi of the substantial heart in the center, shaped like an inverted lotus, ascending and descending in truth. Thus, I say they are ultimately one."

Lazy Old Man said: "Great Lazy One, take note. Intention is what the heart emits. The heart has no sound or scent; when thought stirs and is expressed, it is called intention. Thought is the present mind—it is the heart itself. Intention is the resonance of the heart, meaning the thought has already been activated.

The Buddhist epithet 'Guanshiyin' (Avalokiteśvara) is a great secret for governing the body and mind—ponder it deeply."

"According to Buddhist scriptures, the character *shi* (世, 'world') is interpreted as *shen* (身, 'body'), meaning to carefully examine the movements and stillness of the qi mechanisms within one’s own body, lest they fall into deviance.

Lü Zu said: 'The Great Dao teaches people first to still their thoughts—if thoughts do not cease, all effort is in vain.' He also said: 'Fear not the arising of thoughts; fear only delayed awareness.' Qingyun Zi said: 'When thoughts have not yet left the cavity of the body, they are easily removed; once released outward, their removal becomes more difficult.' Thus, the ancients said: 'Eradicate thoughts the moment they arise, and immortals will acknowledge you.'

Great Lazy One took note. Smiling, he asked: 'Is the secret of immortal cultivation truly found in this alone?' I have heard it said: 'To cultivate life without cultivating nature is the foremost flaw in practice,' and also: 'To cultivate nature without cultivating life makes it difficult for the shadowy spirit to attain sagehood even after ten thousand kalpas.' What does this mean?'

Lazy Old Man sighed: 'Ah! Without nature, life lacks spirit; without life, nature cannot manifest. This means one must cultivate both nature and life together. In my view, cultivating one part of nature preserves one part of life—nature and life are inseparable. At times, one may lean toward nature while life is contained within it, or lean toward life while nature is contained within it. They are like form and shadow—can they truly be divided? In cultivating the Dao, one must first unify the will; this is the foundation of nature cultivation. Cherishing the body as jade is the foundation of life cultivation. Proceeding from this, stilling thoughts and eliminating delusions pertains to nature cultivation; regulating and guiding the breath, circulating and ascending-descending, pertains to life cultivation. Reflecting on this, if thoughts are not stilled, breath not regulated, and delusions not eliminated, progress halts. The common practitioner’s work of stabilizing, guiding, circulating, ascending, and descending, as well as the merging and conjoining of functions, all culminate in the state of no-thought and no-anxiety, flourishing in the moment when all sounds are void and not a speck of dust lingers. Thus, I say: "Cultivate one part of nature, preserve one part of life." Great Lazy One, do you agree?'

'Yes,' he replied.

'You have tested this yourself. Now, in the alchemical tradition, the body is said to contain four seas: the heart is the Sea of Blood, the stomach the Sea of Grain, the kidneys the Sea of Qi, and the brain the Sea of Marrow. Their subtleties are not yet fully grasped—pray, elucidate them.'

'Excellent question. The entire human body relies on the natural qi of life to generate and complete itself. Only the Sea of Grain (the stomach) depends on postnatal external food and drink to digest and transform, replenishing any deficiencies in the body’s generative qi—this is common knowledge, requiring no further elaboration.

Great Lazy One, you understand that those who teach nourishing life often begin with the layer of *mingxin* (obscuring the heart). Why is this? Truly, the heart is the Sea of Blood: when the heart is cool, blood is generated; when the heart is obscured, it becomes cool. The method of obscuring the heart involves subtly guiding the heart’s qi with intention, withdrawing it to the front of the *jiājí* (spine), sensing the warm qi of the entire body suffusing and gathering to protect the front, back, left, right, above, below, and center of the Crimson Palace. In this way, all the gentle generative qi, upon nearing the Crimson Palace, naturally transforms into blood, which then suffuses through the meridians and collaterals. The most refined essence retreats and descends to the two kidneys, where the crimson, radiant essence transmutes into the pure, primordial qi of the Heavenly One.

Great Lazy One, do those who teach nourishing life close their eyes before obscuring the heart?'

Ah! Its meaning is profound, its purport refined."

The spirit of the heart manifests its aperture in the eyes—this is the first point. The two eyes also store the essence-qi of the liver’s *hun*, the lungs’ *po*, the spleen’s spirit, and the kidneys’ essence—this is the second. When the heart is obscured and the eyes close in advance, the generative qi of the viscera, limbs, interior, and exterior naturally come to assemble at the Crimson Palace—this is the third. Moreover, as they assemble, the generative qi is spontaneously obtained, transforming of itself into pure blood without deliberate effort, and this wondrous function also lies in the two eyes—this is the fourth. Furthermore, the ability to guide this pure blood, each following its qi to distribute and moisten the meridians, collaterals, and interstices of the flesh, arises entirely from the two eyes, suspended like the sun and moon, illuminating all within and without, high and low, far and near—now as if intentional, now as if unintentional, seemingly guiding yet not guiding—this is the fifth. You once said its mechanism lies in the eyes; this confirms that the ancients’ words do not deceive me.

Lazy Weng says: The kidneys are the water viscera. You question calling them the "Sea of Qi"—your doubt is well-founded. Nevertheless, know that the kidneys being a water viscera does not refer to the bladder storing turbid water, but rather that the qi of our body’s breathing converges there. Though it is wholly of the posterior heaven, it yet has yin and yang distinctions. Yang is called *qi*, yin is called *fluid*—these two kinds. Without the refining action of the body’s Great Yang person, these two substances stagnate and fail to transform, causing no small harm. Their mutations into disease are too numerous to name. What is the method of refining them? It lies entirely in using the two eyes to guide that true yang and store it in the Sea-Bottom. With a mind undistracted, the qi mechanism flows unimpeded, neither within nor without, unaware of the five viscera, six bowels, four limbs, earth, or heaven. Only then does one inwardly reflect upon the Sea-Bottom, sinking a red sun there (this is the crucial method). If awareness is lost, one must promptly restore it; when restored, the act is forgotten (wondrous is such practice). If lost, one awakens to its presence, cycling through the process (this is the essential instruction). Thus, this one sea becomes perfectly settled, free from harm.

Great Lazy One, those who cultivate the Dao are as numerous as ox hairs, but those who attain it are as rare as rabbit horns—why? They falter at this single barrier of the sea, a common failing everywhere. If you are truly determined, persist in this. To persist without firmness, or to be firm without constancy, is of no benefit (take heed, take heed). Strive on!

Lazy Weng says: Great Lazy One, take note. Though the above speaks of refining the single barrier of the Sea of Qi, the phenomena therein are manifold and cannot all be described. In a thousand words or ten thousand, across the Three Teachings’ scriptures, the Hundred Schools’ works—though they fill ox-carts—none depart from the single method of governing the heart. Great Lazy One, remember this. Do not rejoice in what seems good, nor grieve over what seems bad. All such favorable or unfavorable phenomena, though appearing real, are entirely illusory. The heart must not be moved by them, thoughts must not be swayed, and conduct must not be hindered. The visions that appear are never beyond two kinds: shock and joy. Yet within them, transformations and illusions often exceed all expectations. The fundamental principle is to remain unmoved. One must recognize that all are demonic illusions or tests sent by the Perfected. Only by not being moved by demons does one reveal the true visage of a great person. Thus, when demonic disturbances arise, one should become all the more resolute and all the more courageous.

Great Lazy One, Great Lazy One, I cry out loudly because the paths of orthodoxy and heterodoxy do not coexist, yet demonic and Daoist ways often arise together. Why? Without demons, the Dao cannot be revealed; only by overcoming demons does the Dao become complete. Great Lazy One, strive on!

Lazy Weng says: The brain is called the Sea of Marrow; its principle is evident and requires no tedious explanation. Yet the practices associated with this sea, as commonly described, are many! Most belong to the methods of earthly immortals and ghostly immortals—these are not the supreme Dao and must not be followed. What you and I pursue is the tradition of heavenly immortals, refining to purely return to the prior heaven for proper attainment. Thus, one must be cautious in what one refines.

Great Lazy One, to understand the ultimate truth of heavenly immortals and the pure subtlety of the prior-heaven qi, know that its essence is utterly clear and soft, yet utterly firm and sharp—neither gold nor iron can obstruct it. What it passes through is transformed; what it abides in becomes spirit. It pervades the great cosmos, yet enters the tiniest dust mote. When expanded, it can encompass the three thousand great thousandfold worlds of the Ganges’ sands; when refined, it can coalesce into countless beings, mountains, waters, palaces, halls, and temples (such realms are not difficult to attain; the difficulty lies in becoming attached to them. Why? Once a thought stirs, these realms manifest endlessly, growing ever more wondrous. Once attached to form, one enters the demonic path—at best becoming a demon, at worst dying instantly. Among those who cultivate the Dao, many have perished thus. Not only do they themselves remain unaware, but even their families and fellow cultivators believe they have attained the Dao and departed—such is the magnitude of their error).

Therefore, those who pursue the way of heavenly immortals do not regard such phenomena as proof of attainment; rather, they uniformly consider them demonic disturbances. If such visions arise while seated, one must not intentionally dispel them. To do so would only transform them into combative realms, with unpredictable and uncontrollable manifestations, leading to madness and death. One might even be seized by demons and die, or fall into their snare, emerging victorious in battle, gaining spiritual powers and abilities without cultivation. Deluded, one would take this as proof of attaining the Dao, never realizing it is a demonic lure into their trap. At life’s end, one merely becomes a member of the asura retinue. Or, if defeated in battle, the entire spirit departs the body, which is then occupied by demons.

Those beyond the circle cannot perceive this truth, mistakenly believing such persons to have attained the Dao, testing their spiritual powers and abilities as if they were no different from the ancient immortals. Yet the demon, having taken residence, proceeds to enact its demonic way, gathering followers like clouds. In their discourses, they claim that lust, wrath, greed, and deceit pose no hindrance to the true Dao, and all who follow them enter demonic realms, becoming members of the demonic retinue. The founders of heterodox sects past and present—such as the self-proclaimed Lotus teachings—often began as deluded practitioners whose bodies were usurped by demons, thus giving rise to such perverse doctrines. This must not be overlooked. Therefore, for all who cultivate the Dao, the great secret to subduing demons lies in *seeing yet not seeing, hearing yet not hearing*—what is called, "Though winds and waves arise, I do not set sail." This reveals the essential secret of *not moving the mind*. Those who refine the marrow-sea must take heed.

When gathered, it takes form; when scattered, it becomes qi. Merging the Three Pure Ones without duality, uniting the Three Teachings as one—this refers to abiding in the clarity of emptiness, unattached, allowing all phenomena—being and non-being, green and yellow, red and white—to arise and pass as they will. Scholars must take care not to cling to notions of gathering or scattering, merging or uniting, form or color. This is the ultimate attainment of heavenly immortals, the wondrous function of the primordial qi. Those of us with aspiration can surely reach it—this is no delusion, for such is the nature of resolve. As the ancient immortals said: *To learn immortality, one must learn to become a heavenly immortal; only the golden elixir is the true path.* Thus, resolve must be firmly established.

What is the secret to refining this marrow-sea? Above, it communicates with heaven; below, it penetrates the earth’s bounds. In the four directions and four cardinal points, boundless and without limit, the qi appears serene and still. Mountains, rivers, cities, and towns vanish, leaving only a vast golden world, radiant and bright, with a luminous moon hanging in the sky—this is the secret to beginning the practice. Should visions of jade terraces, jeweled chambers, the Ten Continents, or the Three Isles appear, do not regard them (this is the secret of *superior virtue’s non-doing, having yet not possessing*). Even the iron encirclements, the uncrossable voids, the mountains of blades, the forests of swords, the flaming plains, and the boiling pools—do not examine them (this is the secret of *not seeking through scrutiny*). Only maintain the single, ungraspable right mindfulness, thereby eliminating the moving mind. This is the essential secret to mastering the marrow-sea barrier.

As for the valley-sea barrier, its refinement relies solely on rubbing the abdomen with the hand to assist the yang qi in dissolving and transforming. Thus, the ancients, after eating, would first place one hand on the central stomach and rub downward to the abdomen, then walk slowly for about a hundred steps. Next, they would place their hand on the abdomen and rub in circles, as if polishing a mirror, moving from within outward for about three hundred steps. If the left hand grew weary, they would switch to the right. Then, they would quietly observe the qi’s movement until it flowed smoothly before stopping. When finding leisure to sit, they would continue by closing their eyes, calming the mind, and visualizing the spirit in the Crimson Palace, allowing the valley qi of the central palace to transform into blood and reach the kidneys. Those who practice this method will never suffer from the harm of fluids congealing into phlegm or essence transforming into yin. Though it appears as an active practice, it is in truth an aid to non-doing (this is the method of *inferior virtue’s activity, whose function never ceases*). The Great Lazy One, take note! Do not dismiss this as a minor practice, for it is precisely the secret path by which my master preemptively governs yin essence. The practice is exceedingly simple.

The Great Lazy One rose and bowed, saying: "Understood! I humbly receive your teachings."

Thereafter, the Great Lazy One straightened his robes and cap, and with utmost sincerity addressed him, saying: "I have heard that if the Mysterious Pass does not open, the Sacred Embryo will not form; if nursing and nurturing are improper, the Sacred Infant will suffer internal illness; if the transference is not in accord with the Dao, the True Person will meet an untimely end. I fear these things, and humbly beg your instruction: for one such as I, may the Mysterious Pass fortunately open? May the Sacred Embryo fortunately form?"

Lazy Weng, upon hearing this, smiled cheerfully and said: "You are mistaken—or is this your own account? Your Mysterious Pass has already opened on the previous night. All those words about the lower region were but clear signs of your having opened the Pass. As for whether the Embryo has formed, you must ask yourself: Do you feel unobstructed throughout your body? Do you experience the mists and vapors of qi? Have you attained the state where self and other are forgotten?" (These are all essential practices; only through diligence can they be achieved.)

The Great Lazy One replied: "I have encountered all of these, and at times they occur." (To experience them often is wondrous.)

Lazy Weng asked: "Have you reached the state where all sounds are empty and the solitary spirit alone shines forth?"

He answered: "I have glimpsed such states, but regret that I have not sustained them for long." (If one could sustain them, the formation of the Embryo would be near.)

Lazy Weng then asked: "What signs manifest in your Kun abdomen?"

He replied: "Whenever I sit, I feel true qi threading downward from the heart. Soon after, I sense an inner opening, vast without boundary, minute without interior, where various true qi mingle and pour inward. I feel as though this space has no bottom, only a gentle warmth. At times, it seems as if there is fire, yet also as if there is none—only a kind of warm qi, drifting and rising, ascending from the lower region in all directions. It surges upward along the back, thickly reaching the spine and crown of the head. Then, it seems to descend in a flush, flowing down the face and throat, until it reaches the Crimson Palace, where it suddenly transforms into cool droplets. Passing the heart’s threshold, it abruptly turns into scalding liquid rushing downward, filling the abdomen with fiery heat, and I feel my entire body unobstructed."

Lazy Weng said: "Truly so, and the formation of the Embryo is not far off."

Lazy Weng continued: "Great Lazy One, you must understand that the formation of the Embryo in the Heavenly Immortal differs from what is commonly transmitted. You must carefully study the *Treatise on Dispelling Doubts in Immortal Cultivation*—how to refine, how to form, how to gather, how to tend the fire, how to guard, how to nurture, how to bathe, how to apply, how to subdue, how to transfer the spirit and change the cauldron, and how to complete the liberation of the Embryo. All these are thoroughly explained within. The most crucial secret lies in thought within no-thought, like a hen brooding her eggs. Sitting upright in meditation is the method of gathering; unbroken continuity is the guard; movement, stillness, sitting, and lying are the fire-tending."

He further said: "Diligent yet unmet, one must meet a perfected being; met yet indolent, one will end as a lowly ghost. Remember these four lines and reflect on them constantly."

The Great Lazy One asked: "Apart from the *Treatise on Dispelling Doubts in Immortal Cultivation*, which texts should I study?"

Lazy Weng replied: "*Inquiry on the Dao in Crane Forest*, *Revealing the Secrets of the Mysterious Pass*, *On Nature and Life*—beyond these, *The Ancestral Teachings of the Golden Flower*, *The Unity of Immortals and Buddhas*, *The True Principle of Heavenly Immortals*, and *The Torch of Doubt*. Further still, the *Cantong Qi* and *Awakening to Reality*; broadly speaking, the Bai’s commentary on the *Daodejing*, and the *Vajracchedikā*, *Śūraṅgama*, and *Yuanjue* sutras."

Alas! As Ancestor Bai said:
*"A single word or half a phrase may reveal the profound—*
*Why need a thousand scrolls of alchemical texts?*
*If one is not burdened by form,*
*The world before your eyes is the Great Penglai!"*

*Rain and Fragrance: Heavenly Scripture and Dhāraṇī Commentaries*
*Compiled by Min Yide of Golden Canopy Mountain, Wuxing*
*Preface*

All sounds arise from the human heart. Thus Yangzi said: "Speech is the voice of the heart; writing, the brushstroke of the heart." Though human hearts are fundamentally the same, their qi and temperament differ—north and south, east and west, hard and soft, strong and weak. These variations in qi and temperament, shaped by water and earth, manifest in speech through differences in the throat, tongue, lips, and teeth, producing tones that rise and fall, heavy and light. Not only do those born in the same era adapt their speech to their region, but over time, the original sounds have become distorted through transmission, shifting with the ages. Thus, ancient rhymes often clash with modern ones. Even within the Middle Kingdom, writing has undergone repeated changes, and the drift of cultural currents has rendered them nearly incomparable.

Yet if we trace their source, all sounds emerge from what is common to the human heart. When hearts connect, voices connect. One hears the sound of a chime and knows sorrow; one hears the sound of a zither and knows violence—this is the heart’s resonance with sound. I have traveled widely, and even in places where language is unintelligible, in moments of stillness, I have occasionally heard speech and understood its meaning. But when my heart stirs and I listen closely, the words become incomprehensible. This is because qi and temperament constrain us; when we cling to form, understanding is lost.

The *Daoist Canon* contains scriptures and dhāraṇīs, such as the *Shangqing Registers of Ritual Methods*, which are not written in the language of this world. Yet their sounds resonate with the hearts of those below. As the *He Guanzi* states: "Only the sage can correct the tone and harmonize the voice, so that their virtue reaches the Great Clarity." The Great Clarity is heaven—meaning the profound sounds of the human realm ascend to heaven.

The *Buddhist Canon* preserves many dhāraṇīs in the Sanskrit of the Western Regions, not in the written language of the Eastern Lands. Yet their sounds resonate with the hearts of those in the East. In the *Spring and Autumn Annals of the Sixteen Kingdoms*, Kumārajīva and Fotucheng were both able to translate them into Chinese, for the *Avataṃsaka* alphabet truly connects with the Chinese language. For years, I have studied scriptures and dhāraṇīs, often gaining insight in moments of profound stillness. Where I encountered obstacles and could not resolve them, I suddenly heard a divine voice say: "Without a mouth, follow the meaning; with a mouth, grasp the sound. Reveal and transmit it, lest you fail the intent of the gods and buddhas to enlighten the people."

Thereupon, I joyfully understood and began to analyze and annotate them. Yet I dared not trust my own judgment. For the annotations of Daoist scriptures and dhāraṇīs, I submitted them to my late teacher, Master Taixu, who deemed them not far from profound understanding. For the annotations of Buddhist dhāraṇīs, they were reviewed by the Daoist of Jizu Mountain, the Perfected Huang. The Perfected was originally from Yuezhi, and I was fortunate to have his guidance, sparing me the reproach of arbitrary interpretation.

Some may ask: "Many previous worthies have already commented on scriptures and dhāraṇīs—why expend further effort?" I reply: The depths of sacred texts are inexhaustible, open to all who seek to unravel them. The benevolent see benevolence; the wise see wisdom. Just as the Five Classics are taught in the imperial academy with official annotations, yet Confucian scholars continue to offer new interpretations—especially of the *Book of Changes*—so too does the meaning of scriptures shine like the sun and moon traversing the sky. Those who see the whole are correct, and those who glimpse a ray of light are also correct. Though our understanding may be partial, like peering through a tube or measuring the sea with a gourd, scholars should be free to express their insights. This is not forbidden by any decree, and such efforts may yield new revelations.

Yet my learning is shallow, and I dare not claim that my limited understanding should eclipse the wisdom of the world. If my humble words inspire others to expand upon them, leading to deeper insights, illuminating the sublime truth, awakening the great thousandfold world, widely propagating the mind-seal, and collectively attaining bodhi—to benefit all sentient beings—then my hopes will be amply fulfilled.

*Preface by Min Yide of Golden Canopy Mountain, Wuxing*

**Postscript:**
Daoism has its esoteric and exoteric teachings, just as Buddhism has its exoteric and esoteric traditions. Both are transmitted through oral instruction, requiring personal realization rather than rigid adherence to fixed views, which would obstruct the eye of the Dao. The ancient sages sternly warned against idle chatter and empty discourse. At first, I did not grasp this principle and ventured to annotate profound Daoist texts—scriptures like the *Great Cavern Jade Scripture* and dhāraṇīs like the *True Words of Wisdom*—but dared not comment on the esoteric teachings of Buddhism, as they were not in Chinese and thus beyond my comprehension.

At the time, I was residing at Lotus Convent in Gusu. My disciples, including Xinxiang of Hidden Hermitage, requested that I annotate the *Great Compassion Dhāraṇī*. I replied: "I am Chinese—how could I understand the Sanskrit of the Western Regions?" Before I finished speaking, a voice from the void rebuked me: "No! Did the Buddha not communicate in Chinese when he taught? Examine the meaning of the words—it lies in whether they are spoken or unspoken. For this Sanskrit has sound but no fixed script; those who receive and transcribe it are the true spiritual guides of the world. When they record it, if the rhyme aligns but the meaning differs, they add a mouth radical to distinguish it. You understand the Buddha’s meaning—use it to infer and connect, and you can annotate it yourself."

Thereupon, I took up the task and discerned that *nammo* is *namo*, *hara* is *hera*, *ta* is the sun of nature, *na* is "that," indicating a pointing of breath, and *ra* is an auxiliary particle. This phrase means: when the heart is empty, nature manifests, radiant as the sun—teaching that the essence is to illuminate the mind and see one’s nature. Thus, the following text repeatedly expounds the meaning of *ta*. However, the ancient masters of the West interpreted it as "one phrase, one buddha-name," instructing later disciples to follow the meaning of each phrase in their practice. For Chinese practitioners, it suffices to understand it as "illuminating the mind and seeing nature," without needing to verify it as a buddha-name. This is seen in the *Yunmen Record*, which states that the Dharma is taught according to the region. To cling to one and reject the other, or vice versa, is to lack perfect harmony—such a person is not a true spiritual guide.

Moreover, the Buddha revealed these true words, and the guiding masters adopted them to instruct later generations, aiming to curb deluded thoughts and lead practitioners to begin with an empty heart and a pure realm.

Should we, then, fail to embody this and instead engage in endless disputes? Even in this explication, it remains but a matter of "the benevolent see benevolence, the wise see wisdom." Can it be said to exhaust the profound meaning of these true words? It cannot. These few lines are set forth merely for my own delight—dare I call them a preface?

*Inscribed with reverence by the monk Jilian of West Lake on the first day of the fourth lunar month in the jiawu year of the Daoguang reign.*

---

**On the Textual Forms of the *Yuxiang Tianjing***

This scripture was orally transmitted by the Divine Mother of Jade Purity to the Primordial Dharma King, passed down through successive sages, and only later committed to writing. Yet originally, it bore no sentences to be read or recited. As later transmissions diverged, so too did their applications, giving rise to versions in four-character, three-character, five-character, and seven-character lines—each a distinct school’s creation, devised to manifest its wondrous efficacy. However, the earliest transmission consisted solely of characters arranged in sequence, all in cloud-seal script, collected like scattered pearls in a casket.

The Patriarch Xu of Jingyang, finding it difficult to memorize, entreated the Divine Mother Shen to descend and orally impart its esoteric meanings. Xu then rendered these into standard script, compiling them into four-character verses. Each character was inscribed within the *wan* (玩) radical to facilitate transmission, and the text was titled the *Yuzhang Jing*. The five-character ancient version, though claimed to date to the Spring and Autumn period, was in fact composed by the court-attendant immortal Lin Lingsu during the Song dynasty. The five-character Su version is variously attributed to Li Huanyang, the Lord of Zitong, or Xu Yuanyou. The three-character version originated in the West and was compiled by the Bodhisattva of the Boyi people. The seven-character version was edited by Gong Wushang of Luoyang and transmitted to the Liao minister Liu Cao during the Southern Song.

Now, returning to the earliest transmission, which had no sentence structure, we list each character at the beginning to restore its original form. As this text is deemed the esoteric cipher of the heavens, one must not presumptuously impose personal interpretations. Instead, we merely analyze the differences in usage among the various transmitted versions, annotating beneath each character the variations in their forms, so that practitioners may trust the present without losing sight of the ancient.

---

**On the Origins of the Various Transmitted Versions**

**Four-character version:** Each *wan* (玩) radical is topped with *yu* (雨), and the jade-seal characters are generally enclosed within the *yi* (乚) radical, as the original text was in cloud-seal script. The rest follow this pattern. Those with the *wan* radical on the left derive from the Primordial Jade Script, as transmitted by Perfected Lord Xu, and are employed in our school’s *Yishi Xuanke*.

**Three-character version:** Each character is prefixed with *gan* (干), signifying the triumph of the Lord of the Stem, as transmitted by the Bodhisattva of the Boyi people.

**Five-character ancient version:** Each character is prefixed with *wan* (玩), as it is said to derive from Wang Wu.

**Five-character Su version:** Originally, each character was prefixed with *wan* (玩), identical to the four-character version. Here, we revise it to prefix *yuan* (元), following the *Bilu Ke* version, which claims transmission from the Primordial Sovereign Dao Lord. The original *wan* prefix may also reflect the intent of transmission from the Primordial Dharma King.

**Seven-character version:** Transmitted as-is, with no additional radicals, originating from Gong Wushang. However, in the ritual manuals of the esoteric schools, some characters are prefixed with *ni* (霓), with the first character *luo* (罗) inscribed within the *er* (儿) radical of *yi* (乚), and subsequent characters filled in sequentially. Once completed, they are overlaid with gold script and sealed with cinnabar. These are used in talismanic writing, with distinct forms for upper, middle, and lower registers—no arbitrary alterations are permitted. Their verses also vary in length, including three-character, four-character, five-character, and seven-character lines. While all versions are annotated here, the ritual manuals are omitted due to their esoteric nature and excessive complexity, making exhaustive annotation impractical. As for the *Yishi Xuanke*, it embodies the supreme Dao, and to annotate it would risk entanglement in verbal explication—thus, it is left unannotated.

The above text continues to examine the original transmitted scripture, distinguishing the textual variations among different versions. According to the four-character ancient version, the following is appended:

*Fang yuan de qiu, shou zhen gu ling, shou tian di jing* (防元德丘，寿贞固灵，寿天地晶) (these three lines of twelve characters were added by the Patriarch. Some recite only the first line, some only the second, and some only the last. The three lines may be used as needed; though their usage differs, they are collectively called *The Hundred-Character True Mantra of the Supreme Mystery Jade Scripture*. Some use the first and second lines, some the first and last, some the second and last, and some recite all three. The scripture then continues with:) *"I now hold and recite, only wishing..."* (this is the prayer, concluding the scripture’s intent).

The above distinguishes the concluding text of the four-character ancient version.
