According to the three-character ancient version, the following is appended:

*Shou zhen gu, tian di zhong, xuannu liao, mie xie jing, fang yuan de, qiu ling jing* (寿贞固，天地众，晅朒炓，灭邪精，防元德，丘灵晶) (these six lines of eighteen characters were added by the Venerable One, also called scripture, and must be recited in full. The following is then appended:) *"Green urn’s domain, another spring"* (two-line prayer), *"Om hum hum, hum hum da, svāhā"* (三句敕词) (three-line incantation; together with the above, five lines in total, transmitted by the great *Boyi* chieftain to conclude the scripture’s intent).

The above distinguishes the concluding text of the three-character ancient version.

According to the five-character ancient version, the *qi* character above is connected to form a line, reading:

*Qi fang yuan de qiu, qi shou zhen gu ling, qi shou tian di jing* (炁防元德丘，炁寿贞固灵，炁寿天地晶) (these three lines were compiled by the Patriarch, also called scripture, and must be recited in full. The following is then appended:) *"I now uphold the teaching, to deliver all spirits; may the jade scripture’s power fulfill my wishes."* (this four-line prayer was also transmitted by the Patriarch to conclude the scripture’s intent).

Furthermore, this version was originally transmitted in the *Jilian* ritual manual, and was also revered as a *Bilu* manual. However, its concluding text omits the six lines beginning with *qi shou gu ling*, and instead appends: *"From the lineage of the Three Sovereigns and Five Emperors, the Five Classics and Four Books, the teachings of Confucius and Mencius transcend all categories."* Though this version is said to have been transmitted by Master Lu, upon examination, Master Lu was never titled a *Bilu* Patriarch. Even in the manual compiled by Perfected Lin Lingsu, not a single word pertains to *Bilu*. Judging by its appended characters, it does not conform to the standard *Bilu* format. The doubts are manifold, and no resolution has been reached for some time.

Now, comparing the five-character Su version, its text appends the character *wan* (玩), identical to the four-character ancient version’s additions, yet the lines form rhymed verse, with meanings drawn from governance and scripture, making it particularly suitable as a *Bilu* manual. However, its final line, *qi shou zhen gu nai* (炁受真固奈) and below, lacks concluding text, suggesting incompleteness. Considering the Su version was obtained from a ritual lineage, further inquiry was made. They stated that the manual indeed ends here, but during transmission, a few oral incantations were taught, to be appended as needed, and were not to be recklessly disclosed. Upon this insight, the four lines previously used in the five-character ancient version’s *Bilu* conclusion (*qi fang yuan de qiu*, *From the lineage of the Three Sovereigns and Five Emperors*, *the Five Classics and Four Books*, *the teachings of Confucius and Mencius transcend all categories*) were appended to the Su version. The meaning flows smoothly, the text connects seamlessly, and the rhymes align. Thus, the Su version was finalized as such, and the ancient version as such.

Reflecting on the appended *wan* character, why does it match the four-character version? If this manual were truly for *Bilu* use, why does it not resemble the *Bilu* manual’s appended characters? Moreover, why do ritualists who uphold this manual for various practices find all methods efficacious? The appended *wan* character fundamentally embodies the original intent of the *Primordial Jade Scripture*, making efficacy in all practices naturally fitting. The "few oral incantations" mentioned, adaptable to each method, must refer to specific oral formulas for each ritual. This transmitted manual is undoubtedly the *Dharani* for all methods. Yet, as a *Dharani*, once its essence is grasped, it may be specialized for *Bilu*. For a *Dharani*, appending *wan* is essential; for a specialized *Bilu* manual, appending *yuan* (元) to conform to the standard is also fitting. Thus, the decision was made to use *yuan* instead of *wan*. After revision and presentation to the ritualists, they were initially startled. Upon explaining the reasoning, they warmly approved.

Moreover, it is said: "Originally, the predecessors returned from Ba, and this method has been transmitted through the ages to aid the world. The method, when applied, weaves scriptural phrases together—yet methods are not one single method. For *Bilu* use, this script of characters, this concluding formula, aligns perfectly with the talismanic wall."

He further requested that the two five-character drafts I had settled upon be preserved. Now, among ritualists, it is fitting to revere and guard secret manuals; for me, having gained insight, it is my wish to share it with fellow practitioners. Moreover, having annotated the text, if one does not know, it is acceptable to leave doubts unresolved. But if one knows yet does not clarify and establish it, how then shall I employ my knowledge? Thus, this manual was ultimately revised into the *Orthodox Manual for Sacrificial Refinement*, and the concluding scriptural phrases were recorded separately as follows, no longer appending the lines on the lineages of the Three Sovereigns and Five Emperors at the end of the scripture. This collation is respectfully presented for the scrutiny of those learned in the classics.

**Right: Examination of the Five-Character Ancient Version’s Concluding Scripture**

According to the five-character Suzhou version, the *qi* character from the main text above is connected downward to form a sentence, which reads:
*Qi* receives true solidity—what then? (This line, following the original master’s continuation to complete the text, appears thus in the transcribed copy. The four lines below, present in the five-character ancient version, along with the seven lines such as *Qi* guards the primal virtue mound, *Qi* longevity steadfast and numinous, were all appended at the end of the scripture. Upon reading this version, I suspected it was incomplete and consulted ritualists, who confirmed that these four lines were originally oral transmissions from the master, not written down. Their content matched the appended text in my ancient version. Thus, I continued and revised them to conclude the scripture’s intent. The text reads:)
*Qi* guards the primal virtue mound (alternately written with "mound" as 丘),
Lineage of the Three Sovereigns and Five Emperors,
The Five Classics and Four Masters’ books,
Confucius and Mencius’ (alternately "Cheng Da’s") teachings without distinction.
(These are the words continued by the master and may also be called scriptural text. The last two lines resemble an incantation, as the *Bilu* manual’s commentary also notes.)

**Right: Examination of the Five-Character Suzhou Version’s Concluding Scripture**

According to the seven-character ancient version, the five characters *dou ya xi ming qi* from the main text above are connected downward with *fang yuan* to form a line. The text reads:
*Dou* and constellations still the life-*qi* guard the primal,
Virtue mound, longevity steadfast, numinous longevity,
This is called the *Jade Scripture*—may it be studied with precision.
(These sixteen characters were also compiled by the master. The final line has been seen in the transmitted text of the *Huangting Jing*, and thus may generally be called scriptural text, concluding the scripture with an incantation.)

**Right: Examination of the Four-Character Ancient Version of the *Great Cavern Jade Chapter Scripture***

The four-character recitation method traces back to the Jade Pure Divine Mother, a tradition of great antiquity. During the Jin dynasty, Xu Xun, the magistrate of Jingyang (whose taboo name was Son), received it from the Divine Mother Shen and thereby ascended to become Remonstrating Grand Master, long cherished as a secret treasure in the Daoist tradition. I received it from Master Taixu, who said: "Study it deeply, and you will naturally comprehend." Having held it for over thirty years, I suddenly felt a dawning awareness. Upon careful investigation, enlightenment struck like a flash, and I proceeded to annotate it according to my understanding. I dare not claim this as the definitive interpretation but merely append it to the ranks of those with insight and benevolent understanding.

**Luo san lan bo, dai qia tai li**
These two lines trace back to the primordial realm of the Dragon Han era.
*Luo* (羅) means "to spread out"; the inclusion of *wan* (玩) signifies the true script of the Jade Pure Primordial Beginning and the esoteric meanings of the heavens. This scripture is also called the *Great Mystery Jade Scripture*, totaling ninety-six characters, each adorned with *wan*. For simplicity, the present version adds it only to the first character, preserving the ancient form.
*San* (三) refers to the Three Realms.
*Lan* (蓝) is the color of heaven.
*Bo* (波) is the pattern of water, implying the encompassing of the Three Realms by heaven and water.
*Dai* (逮) means "to reach."
*Qia* (洽) means "to congeal."

"Tai" means "elevated"; "li" means "radiant" and "empty." This is to say: when the turbid yin congeals below, the earth emerges as that which is elevated and radiantly transparent upon the surface of true water. Such a vision does not manifest except in moments of utmost emptiness and profound stillness.

**Tang yun tui ru, lian guang ling du**
These two lines illustrate the method of internal circulation as the starting point.
*Tang* refers to the *yun tang* (運堂), the Celestial Eye.
*Yun* means "to revolve," as in the method of polishing a mirror.
*Tui* means "to push back"—pushing aside the clouds and mist so that the *tang* shines as brightly as the moon. The method requires closing the eyes and revolving the light of one’s gaze until the mists disperse of themselves.
*Ru* means "to revolve inward," the method of directing circulation inward from the Celestial Eye—this is the initial step of internal observation.
*Lian* means "unbroken."
*Guang* means "vast and towering."
*Ling* refers to the *ling tai* (靈臺), the numinous terrace.
*Du* means "metropolis," referring to the Three Fields and Nine Palaces.

An alternate interpretation takes the initial *tang* (堂) as "to apply intent," drawing from the sense of "adding earth to make a hall" (*jia tu yue tang* 加土曰堂). Here, *yi* (意, intent) corresponds to earth, so "applying intent" is akin to "adding earth." This form of internal observation must first involve concentrating *qi* to achieve suppleness, releasing all entanglements, and allowing the solitary spirit to emerge. With a subtle stirring of true intent, one applies the secret method of upward circulation—only then may visions appear. Yet one must avoid attachment to phenomena and guard against empty ambition. Emptiness is the very body of the Dao; those who perceive existence while forgetting the meaning of emptiness will inevitably become trapped and fail to break free—hence the warning.

**Yu luo shu miao, yu fu chao san**
*Yu* means "lush and abundant."

"Luó" means "vast and expansive." *Shū* means "not uniform." *Miǎo* means "unfathomable." This describes the breadth of mountains and rivers within, the splendor of palaces, the multitude of beings, the diversity of customs, the differences in temperament and nature—so distant that boats and oars cannot reach, nor thought and contemplation grasp. This depicts the inner realm as mirroring the outer. If one does not settle within, inner obstructions will immediately arise. The method lies in using emptiness to encompass it and spirit to observe it, ensuring no excess or deficiency—this may then be sufficient.

The method comprises four aspects: *yù* (育), *fú* (弗), *chāo* (超), and *sàn* (散).
What is *yù*? It is to nurture and transform.
What is *fú*? It is to brush aside and rectify.
What is *chāo*? It is to lift and assist, like wings.
What is *sàn*? It is to open and release.

Yet one must first know to position oneself, know to eliminate hindrances, know to exert diligence, and know to revive—only then can flaws be avoided. The method begins with regulating the heart; when the heart is regulated, *qi* naturally harmonizes.

**Zhào shēng tiān héng, zhì shǐ míng qiān**
These two lines teach one to be cautious of the first signs, for they determine the boundary between human and beast; to trace back to the origin, for it illuminates the path between clarity and obscurity.
*Zhào* refers to omens. *Shēng* means the arising of thoughts. The Dao of Heaven and Earth is merely vertical and horizontal; the movement of the heart’s mechanism is merely human or beast. Humans walk upright beneath Heaven, while beasts bear the sun and moon on their backs—hence "Heaven’s horizontality." Where omens arise, stagnation begins. All such stagnant states are devoid of light—hence "obscure." *Qiān* means to shift and emerge, containing the meaning of repentance and transformation.

**Tíng pàn bāo jǐ, yóu xuán wò chèn**
These two lines instruct one to take vigilance as the foundation and unwavering grasp as the principle.
*Tíng* is the Heavenly Court. *Pàn* means to gaze, to observe and reflect. *Bāo* means to firmly protect. *Jǐ* refers to the mutable nature of inherent goodness—here, it also implies change. *Yóu* means goodness. *Xuán* is the supreme mystery. *Wò* means to grasp. *Chèn* means to weigh.
*Note: The first line hints at the method of "gathering the Celestial Stem *wù* within *jǐ*," while the second suggests "weighing goodness to align with the mystery."*

**Shā fú yān míng, guì huì hé zǐ**
These two lines present a vision of a scene of great peace.
*Shā* means multitude. *Fú* is Heaven’s blessing—something to be received in life, beyond conjecture. *Yān* is the *qi* of misty fusion. *Míng* is the unending light of Heaven. *Guì* signifies everlasting vitality. *Huì* means the convergence of the Three Flowers atop the head and the Five *Qi* returning to the origin. *Hé* is the marvel of Metal and Wood intermingling, Water and Fire achieving balance, and Qian and Kun merging. *Zǐ* embodies the ceaseless generation of life, like the flourishing of pines and cypresses, where none fail to inherit.

**Cún lè xián lè, bǎi fèn tiān hòu**
These two lines continue the preceding meaning, urging self-examination—echoing the *Ganying Pian*’s teaching: "Those who aspire to cultivate celestial immortality must accumulate 1,300 good deeds; those who seek earthly immortality must accumulate 300."
*Cún* means to preserve the formless while guarding the tangible. *Lè* means delighting in goodness and practicing generosity. *Xián* means esteeming virtue over desire. *Bǎi* is a complete number. *Lè* implies reining in like a horse at a river’s edge. Together, they encompass the virtues of remaining uncorrupted by wealth and honor, unmoved by poverty and low status, and unyielding to power and force—all embodying the meaning of restraint. *Fèn* means to rouse oneself. The phrase *bǎi fèn* simply means to emulate Heaven and Earth.
*Tiān* is the Dao of Heaven. *Hòu* is the Dao of Earth, signifying the harmony of Earth and Heaven.
*Note: In some esoteric medical and cosmic texts, *hòu* is written as *gòu* (垢), with an even more profound implication—worthy of further consideration.*

**Tǔ chéng yuán píng, mí jié zhāng shēng**
These two lines closely follow the preceding, offering a strategy of vigilance.
"Earth formed" means the heart is free of杂念 and intent free of turbid *qi*. "Walls level" implies guarding against the minute and preventing gradual encroachment. "Mí jié" means thorough prevention and tight obstruction. "Zhāng shēng" indicates preparedness.
*Alternate interpretation: *Zhāng* (彰) and *zhàng* (障) were interchangeable in ancient times; here, it should be read as *zhàng* (障), meaning obstruction. This character further elaborates on *yuán* (垣), suggesting the use of barriers to protect life.*
*Tǔ* is the earth of intent. *Chéng* means harmony and leveling—thus, the intent-earth is made level. *Yuán* refers to walls, constructed of earth and stone. *Píng* means level and open. *Mí* means thorough. *Jié* means firm. *Zhāng* (障) is the ancient form of *zhàng*. *Shēng* refers to the generation of essence, *qi*, and spirit—pointing to the protection of the vital gates. This is called "inner defense," hence *yuán* (walls), subtly conveying that when inner thoughts do not arise, outer demons naturally fade.

**Zhāng jié lù miǎo, lái méng lóng dēng**
These two lines teach the way to establish a distant foundation, achieving twice the result with half the effort.

What is the method? Plant camphor trees to protect it. Here, *zhāng* should be interpreted as *zhāng* (樟, camphor), for only thus can one exhaust the distant and boundless to consolidate them all. The so-called three mountains of *Lái*, *Méng*, and *Lóng* are also enclosed within, ensuring safe ascent without peril. The nature of the camphor is cold-resistant and long-lived; whether planted high or low, it thrives everywhere. Within a few years, a natural fortress takes shape—hence the saying, "half the effort, twice the result," forever free from collapse or decay. Even today, this practice persists in the Western Regions. It is an ancient method, metaphorically teaching that one should use *shēng qì* (vital qi) to guard the vital gates.

*Língxiè quán xìn, Dì nǐ tuó lái*
These two lines, closely following the preceding *dēng* (登, ascent), open a new dimension. They suggest: at the top of a hundred-foot pole, one must take another step; the most perilous place is the level plain, and the crushing of emptiness is the Way. Knowing this, there is nowhere one cannot succeed—what need is there to fear *língxiè* or *tuó lái*? It is merely a matter of steadfast *xìn* (信, faith). *Quán* (筌) and *Dì nǐ* (帝聻) refer to established methods. Without bright faith, how could the spirits witness it? Thus, *língxiè quán xìn*. Following this, *Dì nǐ tuó lái* illuminates the power of faith. Great indeed is the function of *xìn*!

*Língxiè* are two mythical beasts capable of discerning worthiness and folly; their nature is fierce and predatory, so Confucian scholars use them as metaphors for officials. *Quán* is the name of a dharma-pillar, one of five, erected to refine temperament and nature. *Xìn* means bright faith. *Dì* is the Supreme Deity. *Nǐ* is a divine title, used by the Purple Tenuity. *Tuó lái* is a divine beast, a dragon’s progeny, employed by the Supreme Deity to guard treasures: *tuó* governs entry, *lái* governs exit, each fulfilling its duty according to its nature. Who commands them? *Xìn*—the true seed, the master within.

*Nǎng mó jué fǎ, chéng jīn yōu yán*
These two lines summarize the essence of the scripture, as if to say: this is the sacred tradition passed down through the ages, bequeathed to enlighten later generations. There is no ford it cannot cross, no darkness it cannot illuminate, no distance it cannot reach, no old it cannot renew—all by riding this Dharma-chariot. Thus, *nǎng mó jué fǎ*, thus *chéng jīn yōu yán*. *Nǎng* means "of old." *Mó* refers to canonical teachings, instructions, and proclamations. *Jué* is a fine jade. *Fǎ* means method or discipline. *Chéng* is the Dharma-chariot, which may be Great, Lesser, Intermediate, or Supreme—various names, all meant to carry one in cultivation and crossing. This is called the *Jué Fǎ* Chariot. Great indeed is the function of the chariot!

*Jīn* is the ford, the crossing-point. *Yōu* means hidden, obscure, or the deep and winding path. *Yán* means long, enduring, eternal—unceasing and unbroken. This scripture is the eternal Dao of all ages. (Note: In *Yīshì xuánkē*, *nǎng mó* is written as *námó*, with an even more profound meaning, worthy of consideration.)

*Rì yuè xīng dǒu, yào xī mìng qì*
These two lines closely follow the meaning of *yán* (延, enduring), as if to say: like the sun, moon, and stars in their splendor, they possess the *mìng qì* (命炁, life qi) bestowed by the primordial. Without the governance of *mìng*, how could they shine and rest in their places? Thus, *rì yuè xīng dǒu, yào xī mìng qì*. This *mìng* (命) is the central theme of the entire scripture—great indeed is the function of *mìng*!

It says *qì* (炁) rather than *qì* (氣) because *qì* (氣) is a postnatal substance, common and mundane. Only when *qì* returns to the prenatal is it called *qì* (炁). *Qì* is the supreme treasure of the prenatal—it is spirit, it is numen, it is the function of the heart. The scripture says: spirit can enter stone, spirit can take flight, spirit can raise the dead, spirit can restore life. As a thing, it is invisible, inaudible, unknowable, yet it follows the decree of the Emperor. Thus, the scripture says: "If one can remain constantly pure and still, heaven and earth all return." What do they return to? *Qì*. Great indeed is the function of *qì*!

The scriptural text ends here; the following was appended by the lineage master.

*Fáng yuán dé qiū, shòu zhēn gù líng, shòu tiān dì jīng*
These three lines are the lineage master’s instructions to those who receive the Jade Scripture from the ancient sages, exhorting later learners. *Fáng* means embankment, vigilance in solitude. *Yuán* is the highest good, the original substance of the heart. *Dé* is the virtue of the heart, what is attained within. *Qiū* is the taboo name of the Most Sage and Ancient Teacher. *Shòu* means imperishable. *Zhēn* means uncorrupted. *Gù* means unbroken. *Líng* is the taboo name of the Most High Lord of the Dao. *Shòu tiān dì* means that as long as heaven and earth do not perish, the Dao will not perish either—though Buddhist scriptures do not interpret it thus. The constant purity of heaven and the constant tranquility of earth depend on this *qì* for their enduring existence; they do not persist by their own power. It is the power of this scripture.

When one embodies the meaning of this scripture and sustains heaven and earth, it is Vairocana Tathāgata. Thus, *shòu tiān dì jīng*. *Jīng* is the taboo name of Vairocana Tathāgata. This means that those who receive this scripture thereby sustain heaven and earth—Vairocana Tathāgata. Thus, we know that Vairocana Tathāgata is not a person but the nature itself. Buddhists revere the nature, hence they honor him as the Tathāgata Buddha. This is the grand praise of the scripture’s great power.

The lineage master’s appended text ends here; the following is the disciples’ prayer, not part of the scripture itself.

*Chén jīn chí sòng, wéi yuàn yún yún*
These two lines are the disciples’ prayer. The prayers vary, as do the wishes—hence *yún yún* (云云, "and so on").

Examining the *Qinglü* and *Chiwen* texts, it is stated that all memorials, petitions, and various prayers must be drawn from the scriptures. Those who fabricate them are subject to disciplinary measures by the precepts. Thus, these prayers should ideally employ established phrases. Upon careful review, the prayer in this scripture is derived from the *Yishi Xuanke*, composed by Li Zu of the Niwan School, and may directly precede the three preceding lines. The late Master Taixu stated that the three lines above originate from Lü Zu, and for later disciples aspiring to continue the sagely lineage, they must uphold the appended text of my master—scholars, take heed.

*The Three-Word Ancient Version of the Great Cavern Jade Chapter*
**Luo San Lan** – *Luo* means to spread or arrange. *San* refers to the Three Realms. *Lan* signifies color, describing its azure hue. This depicts the scene before the division of the Great Ultimate.
**Bo Dai Qia** – *Bo* is the rippling of water. *Dai* means to reach. *Qia* signifies union or coagulation. This depicts the scene as the Great Ultimate is about to divide.
**Tai Li Tang** – *Tai* is the terrace, symbolizing the floating earth. *Li* means to attach or adorn. *Tang* is the Hall of Light, an analogy for true intention, also known as the "moving hall" within humans.
**Yun Tui Ru** – *Yun* denotes the meaning of oscillation or grinding. *Tui* means to push outward. *Ru* means to advance through motion.
**Lian Guang Ling** – *Lian* means to connect, communicate, or continue. *Guang* signifies vastness, greatness, or the broad dwelling. *Ling* refers to the numinous terrace. This describes the scene within the human body.
**Du Yu Luo** – *Du* means beauty. *Yu* signifies lushness. *Luo* denotes pervasiveness.
**Shu Miao Yu** – *Shu* means difference or distance. *Miao* signifies depth or vastness. *Yu* means to generate or nurture.
**Fu Chao San** – *Fu* means to restrain or remove. *Chao* signifies to rise. *San* means to disperse or dissolve. This instructs the principles of regulating the mind and managing *qi*.
**Zhao Sheng Yao** – *Zhao* is the omen, the mechanism of living things, the self-referential master of the heart. *Sheng* means growth. *Yao* means premature death.
**Heng Zhi Dai** – *Heng* signifies adversity. *Zhi* means stagnation. *Dai* means peril. This describes the trials of cultivation.
**Ming Qian Ting** – *Ming* is the Northern Darkness, the mysterious palace. *Qian* means to ascend through promotion. *Ting* is the Celestial Court, referring to the Crimson Palace and the Yellow Court.
**Pan Bao Ji** – *Pan* means the eye illuminating objects. *Bao* signifies protection, firmness, or solidity. *Ji* means to change or act upon intention. This instructs the principles of transforming the mundane into the sagely.
**You Xuan Wo** – *You* means goodness. *Xuan* signifies the ultimate. *Wo* is the tent or canopy, an analogy for nurturing. This instructs the protection of good thoughts and true *qi*.
**Chen Sha Fu** – *Chen* means to correspond or be fitting. *Sha* signifies the multitude. *Fu* is heavenly blessing, the Land of Bliss, or the immortal realm—the effect of the canopy’s protection.
**Yan Ming Gui** – *Yan* is the misty, swirling *qi*. *Ming* is the realm of unending light. *Gui* signifies evergreen, the meaning of eternal vitality.
**Hui He Zi** – *Hui* means the gathering of the Three Flowers at the crown. *He* signifies the harmony of mutual resonance. *Zi* means ceaseless generation.
**Cun Le Xian** – *Cun* means to preserve the formless while guarding the formed. *Le* signifies the joy of nurturing worthy talent. *Xian* means to esteem virtue over desire.
**Le Bai Fen** – *Le* means restraint. *Bai* refers to the state at the peak of a hundred-foot pole. *Fen* signifies vigorous and diligent progress.
**Tian Hou Tu** – *Tian* is the Way of Heaven. *Hou* is the Way of Earth. *Tu* is the Way of Humanity. This extends the meaning of the preceding *fen*.
**Cheng Yuan Ping** – *Cheng* signifies achieving peace. *Yuan* is the city wall, built to repel invaders. *Ping* is the time of great peace without disturbance. This analogy describes the state when merit reaches tranquil stability, the spirit rests in the ancestral cavity, and nothing is unfathomable.
**Mi Jie Zhang** – *Mi* means thoroughness. *Jie* signifies firmness. *Zhang* means manifestation without effort. This extends the meaning of the preceding *yuan*.
**Sheng Zhang Jie** – *Sheng* means to generate, referring to self-generation. *Zhang* is the camphor tree, evergreen throughout the four seasons. In ancient times, people planted such trees to shelter life, calling it the "camphor city." This practice still exists in several Western regions, as recorded in the *Records of the Western Regions*. *Jie* means to bind these trees as a substitute for earth and stone.
**Lu Miao Lan** – *Lu* is the dry land. *Miao* is the watery expanse. *Lan* is the barrier separating inside and outside, akin to the meaning of *yuan* (wall). *Lan* and *lan* (railing) were interchangeable in ancient times, extending the meaning of *yuan*.
**Meng Long Deng** – *Meng* signifies youthful ignorance. *Long* means simplicity and thickness. *Deng* means to be selected or recorded. This refers to the celestial registry of the chosen.
**Ning Xie Quan** – *Ning* and *Xie* are two beasts known for their vicious and greedy natures. *Quan* is the legal pillar, cast in pure gold, used by the Supreme Emperor to restrain the two beasts.
**Xin Di Ni** – *Xin* (pronounced *shen*) means to rely upon. *Di* is the Supreme Emperor, also signifying the stem. It refers to the *qi* cavity located 1.3 *cun* behind the navel, also known as the Mysterious Pass. *Ni* (pronounced *ni*) is the secret name of the Purple Tenuity, used for summoning and punishment.
**Tuo Li Nan** – *Tuo* and *Li* are two divine beasts used by the Supreme Emperor to guard the treasure vault. *Tuo* governs entry, and *Li* governs exit; both are dragon descendants, as recorded in the *Investigation of Birds and Beasts*. *Nan* refers to the Crimson Palace, the Vermilion Numinous Prefecture—the mansion of spiritual refinement.
**Mo Jue Fa** – *Mo* means canonical decree.

Jade denotes *jue*, the finest of stones. *Fa* means principle or method—such is the meaning of the foregoing.

**Cheng Jin You** – *Cheng* signifies the Dharma vehicle. *Jin* is the ford, the crossing. *You* means darkness, seclusion, or depth.

**Yan Ri Yue** – *Yan* means to invoke. *Ri* is the yang *qi*. *Yue* is the yin *qi*. Externally, they are the two eyes; internally, they are the dual *qi* of yin and yang—both are called the sun and moon. Who is it that invokes them? The true seed, the master within.

**Xing Dou Yao** – *Xing* are the celestial stars. *Dou* is the Dipper of the heart. *Yao* means to radiate light. Humans possess eighty-four thousand pore-spirits; heaven has eighty-four thousand constellations. When practice reaches this stage, each pore manifests luminous verification.

**Xi Gai Qi** – *Xi* means ebb and flow. The object of *gai* can open and close, illustrating its function. *Qi* here is the spirit-*qi*. It is not called *qi* but *qi*—the subtlety lies therein. *Qi* belongs to the postnatal, while *qi* belongs to the prenatal. The secret of immortal cultivation lies solely in returning the postnatal to the prenatal, and its method is no more than that of the *gai*.

The scriptural text ends here. What follows are the appended verses composed by the sagely master.

**Shou Zhen Gu** – *Shou* means longevity, the principle of imperishability. *Zhen* means steadfast and true, like gold or jade. *Gu* means firmness, unyielding and unshaken. These all serve to extol the *Jade Scripture*.

**Tian Di Zhong** – *Tian* is the secret name of the Three Heavens. *Di* is the secret name of the Three Earths. *Zhong* is the secret name of the Three Sovereigns. This too is a verse of praise, speaking of the treasured secrets of the Three Heavens, Three Earths, and Three Sovereigns. It does not say "heaven, earth, and man" but "heaven, earth, and multitude"—within this lies its function, for it is the supreme treasure of the Dharma practitioners.

**Xuan Nü Yao** – *Xuan* is the secret name of the sun. *Nü* is the secret name of the moon. *Yao* is the secret name of the Celestial Stem. Together they are called the Three Luminaries’ secret names, treasured by Dharma practitioners—another verse of praise.

**Mie Xie Jing** – This means to reduce the myriad to one. As this transmission pertains to subjugation, this line is added—also a verse of praise.

**Fang Yuan De** – *Fang* means to guard against the subtle and stem the gradual. *Yuan* is the chief of virtues. *De* means attainment—what is gained in the heart and held without loss. This clarifies that the method of cultivation is nothing beyond this principle.

**Qiu Ling Jing** – *Qiu* is the secret name of the Most Sagely First Teacher. *Ling* is the secret name of the Great One Heavenly Worthy. *Jing* is the secret name of Vairocana Tathāgata. This derives from the *Xizhu Xinzong Jiaduo* Dharma Section, added by the practice of Amoghavajra and transmitted by the Great Master of the Bo Yi.

**Lü Weng Yu** – *Lü Weng* is the name of a grotto, located in the territory of Dali Prefecture in Yunnan. During the Tang dynasty, it was the domain of the Zi Zhao kingdom. *Yu* means territory, as recorded in the *Baiguo Zhi*. It was a grotto inhabited by rākṣasas, which the Great Master subdued and confined.

**Bie You Chun** – This is the incantation used by the Great Master to subdue the rākṣasas.

**Om Hum Hum** – *Om* is a word of praise. *Hum Hum* describes the surging of heart-light upward.

**Hum Hum Da** – *Hum Hum Da* means to guide to the other shore—here, it signifies leading the rākṣasas into the grotto.

**Svāhā** – This is a command word, meaning swift subjugation.

---

**The Five-Character Ancient Version of the *Great Grotto Jade Scripture***

The *Great Grotto Jade Scripture* was orally transmitted by the Jade Pure Divine Mother to the Primordial Dharma King. It is a compilation of the hidden names of all heavens, forming a scripture that is the supreme treasure of the Mystery Gate. Its recitation methods vary, including three-character, four-character, five-character, and seven-character forms, each serving distinct purposes.

This section was transmitted by Wang Dai of the Spring and Autumn period. Dai, a native of Lu, is recorded in the *Zhuangzi* as having divided the state of Lu with Confucius. Rejected by the world, his feet were amputated, and he hence styled himself "Wang Wu." The details are found in the Song edition of the *Tai Ji Ji Lian Xuan Ke*.

The section was compiled by the Perfected Lin Lingsu, who referred to Dai as the "Master of Lu," an emanation of the Azure Lad, descended to deliver those condemned to punishment. After his death, he became the marshal of the Great One Compassionate Venerable.

There exists a *Five-Character Tai Yi Mysterious Scripture*, which the lineage masters regularly circulate through the celestial eye. With prolonged practice, the body emanates a compassionate light. When performing seated refinement before departure, this light is released to guide and relieve all suffering souls, shattering every hell without exception.

With prolonged practice, the Dharma practitioner’s body becomes equal to the Dharma-body of the Primordial Dharma King, merging indistinguishably with the Beginningless Dharma King. Ascending to the Great Luo Heavenly Ministers, success is assured without fail. Even the least accomplished attain transcendence through the Nine Mysteries, realizing the rank of true official and achieving liberation through the corpse-transcendence method.

This is the natural true scripture of heaven and earth. A single character possesses boundless marvelous functions and boundless spiritual powers—how much more so when assembled and upheld?

Upon reciting this chapter, the sound issues and the Dharma follows; the ten thousand spirits obey the command. It is the root of all scriptures and the origin of all methods. Its text is not fixed, existing in five-character, three-character, seven-character, and four-character forms. The *One-Character Mysterious Section* interweaves and interlaces, reversing and transforming—its uses are manifold, its secrets innumerable.

Sometimes cloud-heads, ghost-feet, *gan* ornaments, and other techniques are added. For subjugation, one may add cloud-heads with *gan* enclosures, or ghost-embraces with cloud coverings, or follow cloud ornaments—all are permissible, with the master’s title varying accordingly. If mixed indiscriminately, it loses efficacy. Transmission must be oral and not recklessly imparted.

The master of this section is Wang Dai; the marshal is Wang Wu. Though master and marshal share one spirit, their *qi* follows before and after—thus one becomes two.

When adding secrets, one may enclose with cloud-heads and *wu*, or place the character *wang* to the left—both are highly efficacious.

The supreme treasure of the True Mystery Gate, the sleepless pearl of the Mysterious Rites—transmitted but once in eighty thousand kalpas. This teaching is also fully recorded in the ancestral Saṃgha’s ritual refinement section.

*Luo san lan bo dai, qia tai li tang yun*
*Luo* means to spread. *San* refers to the Three Realms. *Luo san* is to encompass these Three Realms. *Lan* is the color of vital *qi*, signifying Heaven. *Bo* is the rippling pattern of waves, signifying Water. *Dai* means to reach or extend. *Qia* describes the merging of Water and Heaven into one. *Tai* are terraces. *Li* means to adorn. *Tang* is the Hall of Light, implying the addition of Earth. This speaks of Earth rising through the surface of waves, like terraces adorning the void—thus, Earth. *Yun* means movement. When illuminated by the eye of wisdom, the Three Realms become as bubbles in an instant, reverting to emptiness in the blink of an eye—what is called "manifesting in accordance with conditions," the meaning of illusion. This is to awaken oneself to the formless nature of phenomena, for all that has form must decay. It is precisely to rouse the stagnant *po* and deluded *hun*, freeing them from karmic obstructions, so that the mind of liberation arises suddenly, and one may attain the luminous realm of *qianfu*.

*Tui ru lian guang ling, du yu luo shu miao*
*Tui* means to dispel杂念. *Ru* means to enter the true realm. Only when杂念 are dispelled can one enter the realm of clarity and emptiness. This is the work of refining the self, the Way of liberating oneself—and also the Way of liberating spirits. As the Great Dao teaches: "First, eliminate念."

*Lian* is the lotus throne, the heart. *Guang* is the vast dwelling, like the great metropolis of the world. *Du* means beauty. *Yu* means lushness. *Luo* means to spread. *Shu* means difference. *Miao* (pronounced *mu*) means secluded and carefree. Within this true realm, within the numinous palace, there exists another heaven and earth.

*Yu fu chao san zhao, sheng yao heng zhi shi*
*Yu* means to nurture. *Fu* means to dispel. *Chao* means to transcend. *San* means liberation. *Zhao* refers to the multitudes. Within this true realm, impure phenomena may arise when the ruler of the multitudes fails in their function, not knowing how to nurture, dispel, transcend, or liberate the masses. This metaphorically refers to the various practices of regulating *qi* and cultivating the mind. To neglect this invites the ills described below.

*Sheng* means to receive life or to bestow life, bearing a dual meaning. *Yao* means premature death. *Heng* means dying unnaturally. *Zhi* means to stagnate in the Nine Dark Realms. *Shi* means the beginning—the very first beginning. It points to the moment of receiving life, when ominous signs may already exist. This extends the meaning of *yu zhao* (nurturing the multitudes) above, illustrating its consequences. The one who presides over this bears the fault, for they hold the power of bestowing life. This warns the practitioner in seated refinement: when refining, if the mind remains unmoving, the light of nature becomes complete; when conducting rituals, if liberation is thorough, karmic obstructions are purified. Those who are moved to receive life thus become true seeds, exhausting this conditioned existence and together realizing the Dao-fruit. For the *qi* of life that humans receive all derives from the seated refiner. Thus, refinement must be complete, and rituals must be thorough. Herein lies the function of the seated refiner. Whether this is achieved or not determines merit or fault.

*Ming qian ting pan bao, yi you xuan wo cheng*
*Ming* is darkness, the realm of the Nine Dark Realms. *Qian* means to ascend and emerge. *Ting* is the Heavenly Court, the realm of light. *Pan* describes a compassionate gaze. *Bao* means dharma protection, like bamboo with its sheath, never separated from its root. *Yi* is the self, the mechanism of the heart, concealed in the mysterious female (*xuan pin*). In Buddhism, it is called *Guanyin*; in Daoism, the *thought*; in Confucianism, the *heart-mind*, the source of sound. *You* means goodness, where words and deeds are all virtuous. *Xuan* is the mysterious and wondrous, boundless and formless, the ultimate of goodness. *Wo* is a canopy used to shield from wind and dust, akin to a tent, symbolizing protection. *Cheng* means appropriateness, without excess or deficiency. This speaks of the ancestral master of seated refinement: breaking through darkness to reach light, gazing with compassion, protecting with dharma, rectifying the world’s sounds, teaching goodness in word and deed, transcending to the utmost mystery, and sheltering with a canopy to prevent contact with wind and dust. This is to forge and temper the nature and heart, making them firm and balanced, without excess or deficiency. This is what is called *ritual* and *refinement*, and only then can it be called *cheng*—fitting the equilibrium of one’s nature and feelings. Only afterward may life-fruits be bestowed, so that wherever one goes, all accords with the Dao. The ancients practiced seated refinement in this way. To do otherwise is empty posturing, betraying the scriptural meaning.

*Sha fu yan ming gui, hui he zi cun le*
*Sha* means the multitude, referring to those who receive liberation. *Fu* means blessed protection, also referring to those who receive liberation. If seated refinement is practiced as above, then the countless spirits, like grains of sand, all receive the blessings of the refining master. This extends the meaning of *wo* (canopy), as if the multitude receives grace.

*Yan* is smoke, which rises and does not fall, symbolizing the liberation of spirits. *Ming* means the union of sun and moon, signifying unwavering clarity. *Gui* is the cassia tree, evergreen in winter and summer, symbolizing unceasing vitality. This speaks of their nature being lofty and luminous, preserving primordial goodness—hence *yan ming gui*. The cassia endures cold and bears fragrant blossoms; smoke is soft yet ascends—thus, it is also called *gao* (lofty).

*Hui* describes convergence. *He* (pronounced *hu*) means resonance, not isolation. *Zi* means succession.

To maintain focus is to hold this ever in mind. To delight is to find joy in this without weariness—both refer to the spirits receiving deliverance, the effect of seated refinement.

The worthy ascend with a hundredfold vigor to the heavens; the earth is transformed into level ground.
"Worthy" is the title of great goodness. "Le" means unyielding, not drifting. This continues the above, speaking of the clarity of spirits: all attain the ascent of smoke, the luminosity of sun and moon—worthy indeed. Able to endure cold like the cassia, they dwell in harmony, advancing day by day without straying from this path, delighting without fatigue. This is to be worthy of worthiness and unyielding in what is unyielding. The seated-refinement master may be called one who well endows their nature and well restrains their emotions—yet how could the Great Dao be limited to this?

What was spoken above pertains only to the karmic rewards of humans and heavens; it cannot yet be called the Great Dao, for the conscious spirit still lingers within. Seated refinement cannot be considered ultimate, nor should the work of ascension be applied prematurely. Its secret essential lies in the master’s ability to arouse great compassion and employ the work of returning to emptiness and shattering the self—this is what is meant below by "a hundredfold vigor."

"A hundred" is a complete number, also signifying the hundred-foot pole. "Vigor" means to rouse, to advance with courage and diligence. "Heaven" is the Way of Heaven: boundless, formless, vast and serene, profound and still, embodying all things without omission. It governs life and death, movement and stillness as one—neither being nor non-being, so great it has no exterior, so small it has no interior. Its color is azure; its form is round. Immortals and buddhas alike attain this body—this is the ultimate, the infinite.

Next is to emulate the earth: it bears Mount Hua without heaviness, contains rivers and seas without leakage. All things rest upon it, hence it is called *hou*. *Hou* means "after this earth." To take "after" as virtue is to say "posterior." "Posterior" means not daring to be first in the world, yielding to the utmost. "Earth" refers to the number eleven: the lesser ten and the greater one, yin supported by yang, arranged in dependence on yang. The true intent of humans possesses such virtue, hence "earth" (*tu*) sounds like "trust" (*du*), meaning fidelity and sincerity.

"To complete" is to achieve peace. Thus, whether emulating heaven or earth, all is accomplished. "Heaven" refers to heavenly immortals; "earth" to earthly immortals. "Level" means impartiality; "flat" means unobtrusiveness, the absence of self and other.

Thus, the worthy ascend with a hundredfold vigor to the heavens; the earth is transformed into level ground. So it is, so it is—yet this is still not enough.

Vast and firm, manifesting vital qi like the camphor; knotted on land, drifting in mist, nurturing orchids and blessings.
"Vast" describes all-pervasiveness. "Firm" means solid and unfeigned. "Manifest" means to flow forth. "Vital" refers to vital qi. The camphor is a tree, cold-resistant and long-lived. In the West, it is the tree that shelters the multitudes—Camphor City. This tree grows easily and remains evergreen, thriving high and low, on land and by water, expanding wherever it takes root. The circulation of true qi in the human body is boundless, like the camphor, never withering. Everywhere it flows, just as the camphor grows everywhere—whether on land or in mist, all may rely on it to protect and nurture orchids and blessings.

Thus it is said: vast and firm, manifesting vital qi like the camphor; knotted on land, drifting in mist, nurturing orchids and blessings. "Land" refers to dry ground, the open plain. "Mist" refers to water’s edge, the marshlands. The orchid is the flower of the noble, the fragrance of kings, a metaphor for the seed. "Blessings" refers to virtuous influence; the *Yi* says, "Blessings nurture the correct—this is the sage’s work." This continues the above, describing the spiritual transformations. At this stage of seated refinement, there arises the function of worldly and transcendent fulfillment at the thought’s arising.

Obscure as chaos, ascending with the ferocity of the *ningxie*; trust in the imperial root, guided by the *ni* and the *tuolai*.
"Obscure" describes primordial chaos, the state of not knowing yet following Heaven’s principle—profound to the utmost. The clarity of spirits, refined and fused, becomes one whole, without self or other, enmity or kinship equal, containing only the vast and serene primordial qi.

At this stage of seated refinement, one may send them with intent to the nine heavens. Those who attain utmost purity, simplicity, emptiness, and oneness transcend the realms of heavenly, earthly, and divine immortals. Others may descend to be reborn in human or heavenly realms, manifesting as officials or lay practitioners, nurturing and sustaining life, establishing merit everywhere. Exhausting this karmic body, they ascend together to the Golden Gates. Still others do not lose their original heavenly nature, free from excessive desires, drawn to the Dao, with aspiration for cultivation. Exhausting this karmic body, they ascend to the mysterious realm, becoming the immortals’ aides—this is the general outline.

This explains the meaning of "ascend." "Ascend" means to rise, containing the sense of sending upward, transcending, and determining rebirth. Even the lowest, whose natures resemble the *ningxie* or the *tuolai*, may be transformed by the *quan* and guided by the *ni*, becoming useful to the heavenly court and the human world. Such is the wonder of seated refinement.

The *ningxie* is a fierce beast, greedy and cunning, prone to devouring. The *quan* is a dharma-pillar, also called a dharma-banner. The Supreme Emperor erects it in the realm to transform the impure; it has five pillars—this is one of them. "Trust" means clear faith. "Imperial" refers to the root. *Ni* is a secret name of the Purple Tenuity, used to suppress malevolence and pacify the impure. The *tuolai* is a divine beast, a dragon’s descendant. The Supreme Emperor employs it to guard treasures. The *tuo* is loyal, hence governs entry; the *lai* is righteous, hence governs exit. This metaphorically refers to human natures that may be partial or stagnant—through refinement and fusion, they too become wondrous material.

The efficacy of sacrificial refinement ends here.

The preceding lines—*"Of ancient counsels, the jade-dharma vehicle, / Crossing dark fordways, enduring as sun and moon"*—summarize the entire text. All that has been shown belongs to the *nangmo*, to the jade-dharma vehicles of transcendence. Riding these, one traverses the profound and extends through time like the sun and moon: these are the constant paths, not partial discourses.

*Nang* means "former times," akin to "ancient." *Mo* signifies "excellent instruction." To speak of *nangmo* is to invoke the oral transmissions of counsel passed down through the ages by sages, immortals, and buddhas.

*Jue* is the name of a fine jade. *Fa* means "dharma-principle" or "method." *Cheng* (vehicle) refers to a chariot, though its sense encompasses both boats and carriages—metaphorically, that which carries one across mountains and seas. Thus, *cheng* may denote the superior, middling, or lesser vehicles, as well as the Great Vehicle, the Lesser Vehicle, and the Supreme Vehicle, all of which are metaphors for the scriptural teachings. Here, *juefa cheng* (jade-dharma vehicle) carries the same meaning, praising the unimpeded flow of the jade scriptures as if borne by a vehicle. Therefore, *"nangmo juefa cheng"* is the highest form of praise.

*Jin* signifies a thoroughfare, a three-forked crossing. *You* means "profound" or "abyssal." *Yan* denotes "enduring," "far-reaching," or "eternal."

The sun and moon embody the meaning of radiance unobscured—here referring to this *juefa cheng*. For where there is sincerity, there is illumination; where there is illumination, there is sincerity: these are two aspects of the same truth.

In my humble opinion, *nangmo* should follow *namo*, for only when thought ceases does true wonder arise.

Stars and constellations shine and extinguish life;
*Qi* guards the primal virtue’s mound.
*Qi* endures, steadfast and numinous;
*Qi* outlives heaven and earth, crystalline.

*Xing* (星) are celestial stars. *Dou* (斗) is the Dipper—here, the heart’s Dipper. Heaven takes the Dipper as its heart; humans take the heart as their Dipper. Heaven possesses eighty-four thousand stellar lodges; humans possess eighty-four thousand fine apertures. Heaven and humanity, though distinct, are one in essence.

*Yao* (曜) means "to shine." *Xi* (息) means "to extinguish." *Ming* (命) is the Mandate of Heaven, shared by all beings. When the stars shine, life arises; when they extinguish, death follows—such power rests with the Dipper, and this is certain. Yet there are exceptions: only the perfected person can transcend this, just as only the utterly deluded hasten their own demise. Thus it is said: the noble one forges destiny, the petty one squanders it, and the mediocre one is bound by it.

*Qi* (炁) is the transformation of *qi* (气), the essence of spirit. Where spirit abides, life persists; where spirit departs, death ensues—*qi* is the very life of a person. One inhales and exhales it, ascends and descends with it: this is postnatal *qi*, insufficient to attain immortality. *Qi*, however, is the supreme treasure of the prenatal realm, resembling *qi* yet fundamentally distinct. The ancients conflated the two, failing to recognize that *qi* is the transformation of *qi*. They did not grasp that *qi* is what spirit commands: when *qi* flourishes, *qi* flows and blood quickens. Consider it as one and the same person—emperor and commoner alike. When the ruler is sagely, the people are at peace; when spirit wanes, *qi* stagnates. To preserve spirit is to preserve *qi*; herein lies the distinction between *qi* and *qi*.

For *qi* is insentient, while *qi* is profoundly numinous. *Qi* is the substance of the heart; *qi* is the function of *qi*. Thus, to say *qi* is like *qi* may be acceptable, but to equate *qi* with *qi* is not. There is a division of purity and turbidity, a hierarchy of nobility and baseness, a distinction between prior and posterior. Discerning *qi* from *qi* enables cultivation and transcendence; conflating the two leads only to a muddled pursuit of longevity.

I have thus expounded upon this to clarify the matter—reading the Jade Scripture will confirm its truth. This single character, *qi*, is the treasured unifier of the Three Teachings. Therefore:
"*Qi* guards primal virtue" refers to Confucius;
"*Qi* endures, steadfast" refers to the Great One;
"*Qi* outlives heaven and earth" refers to the Tathāgata.
The Tathāgata is thusness itself.

What does *fang* (防) mean? It means to guard against the minute and stem the gradual. *Yuan* (元) is the chief of virtues. *De* (德) is the heart’s attainment. *Shou* (寿) means to preserve this *qi*. *Zhen* (贞) means to uphold this *qi*—also a form of guarding. What does *gu* (固) mean? It means to fortify this *qi*. For when *qi* is guarded, its defense is comprehensive, primal goodness is preserved, and the heart’s virtue is complete. When *qi* endures, the heart endures; when *qi* is steadfast, the heart’s substance is firm, and external demons cannot enter. This is the continuation of the text by the patriarchs of the Confucian and Daoist traditions.

The following line is continued by the patriarchs of the Buddhist tradition: "I, the Tathāgata, extend this *qi* to outlive heaven and earth—how then can there be tranquility, how can my multitudes be at peace?" Thus, the Tathāgata is also honored with the title Vairocana Tathāgata Buddha.

All this is but praise for the scripture. The scripture’s text comprises ninety-six characters, concluding with *qi*.

These five-character verses are employed by the patriarchs to universally deliver the numinous spirits of the Three Teachings. To perform the esoteric rites of *xilian* (祭炼), one must use these five-character ancient verses. The following four lines are recited when commencing seated refinement as an invocation:
*"I now uphold the teaching,
Delivering all numinous spirits.
May the power of the Jade Scripture assist me,
Fulfilling my vow."*

**Five-Character Suzhou Edition of the Great Cavern Jade Chapter Scripture**
The original text of this edition was only one hundred characters; it has now been revised to one hundred twenty, with its meanings elaborated in the *Distinguishing the Text*. For there is no fixed form to the text—even among the four versions I previously obtained (four-, three-, five-, and seven-character lines), each differs. In the *dingchou* year, I acquired this edition in Suzhou from a ritual master. Its characters and phrases diverge significantly from others. I heard it was first transmitted from Ba and Shu, widely circulated among the disciples of Shi Tiezhu, and renowned for its numinous efficacy.

I have annotated the variant characters while omitting those that are identical. The original text marked characters on the left with *wan* (玩); I have revised them to follow *yuan* (元), with the reasoning detailed in the *Distinguishing the Text*.

*Luo can lan bo dai, qia tai li tang hui*
*Can* (参), pronounced *chuan*, represents the Three Powers. It signifies that *luo* (罗) encompasses the Three Powers, embodies the Three Bonds, unfolds the Three Realms, and possesses the Three Lights. Its most prominent manifestations are *lan bo tai* (蓝波台). *Tai* (台) is the numinous terrace, the sovereign’s abode. *Tang* (堂) is the Hall of Light, the place of audience. *Hui* (会) means assembly, the gathering of ministers.

*Tui ru lian guang ling, du yu luo shu mai*
*Mai* (迈) means "distant." It describes the flourishing governance that spreads widely, its luxuriant influence flowing abundantly.

*Yu fu chao san zhao, sheng yao heng zhi dai*
*Dai* (殆) means "peril," referring to the transformations following *zhao* (兆). It depends on those above to cultivate *yu fu chao san* (育弗超散), thereby giving life to those who suffer premature death or stagnation.

*Ming qian ting pan bao, yi you xuan wu kuai*
*Ting* (廷) is the court. *Wu* (幄) means "to cover." *Kuai* (快) means "swift" or "satisfied." It speaks of elevating and manifesting in the bright court, covering the transformed with a canopy, so that the ruler’s heart finds satisfaction in their goodness.

*Sha fu yan ming gui, hui he zi cun lai*
*Lai* (赖) means "to rely upon," continuing the meaning of *kuai* (快). It describes this grand convergence of good fortune, relying on the ruler’s consistent fulfillment from beginning to end.

*Xian le bai fen tian, hou tu cheng yuan bai*
*Bai* (败) means "ruin" or "collapse." It warns that when the teaching’s principles are upheld for protection and defense, relying solely on fortifications will inevitably lead to defeat.

The ever-providing *zhang* gives birth to the *zhang*-beast,
Weaving the land into boundless enclosures of ease.

*Zhang* (章) and *zhang* (障) were interchangeable in ancient times, continuing the meaning of *yuan* (垣, "wall"). The *zhang* (獐) is a divine beast, by nature fond of devouring venomous snakes yet subsisting on plain fare. The ancients forbade its hunting, preserving it to shield mountain-dwelling folk—a measure of benevolent governance. *Lan* (阑) and *lan* (栏, "railing") were also interchangeable, extending the sense of *zhang* (章). *Xie* (懈) here suggests that with such benevolent governance—whether as railing, barrier, or wall—one need hardly rely on railings at all, hence "ease." It is as if to say, "no cause for concern."

The dragon ascends, the fierce *xie*-beast is whole,
Trust in the Emperor’s *ni* obstructs not.

*Whole* (全) signifies the wholeness of the ruler’s virtue. *Obstructs* (碍) refers to hindrances to the ruler’s virtuous governance. It speaks of a court with upright ministers, where flattery is purged and the ruler attains sagacity. Yet to hoard wealth without relief is to obstruct virtue.

The ancient *yu* laws ride the ford of darkness, extending the sun’s presence.

*Sun* (日) here is the sun of wisdom, referring to the mind. *Presence* (在) denotes self-so-ness, that which abides eternally across past and present. This summarizes the scripture’s teaching: the laws are set forth in the *Jade Classic* yet operate within the mind. It is like traveling a path—no fixed route to follow, only forks where, without guidance, the obscure stretches endlessly, and deep entry remains impossible. Thus, the sun of wisdom must not be lost. Yet know this: the sun of wisdom is innate in all, each possessing it fully, never parted even in moments of upheaval. It does not come from without but shines eternally across past and present. In heaven, it is the sun; in man, it is the mind—neither inner nor outer, neither self nor other. It responds to stimuli with illumination, abiding silently without thought—this is called the sun of wisdom. As it does not come from without nor ever fade, it is said to *be present*. The lesson for those above is to first clarify their own sun of wisdom, that the state may be governed rightly.

The stars and Dipper shine, life’s mandate rests;
Qi receives the true, yet how to hold fast?

*Stars* (星) symbolize the ministers and people. The *Dipper* (斗) symbolizes the ruler. *Mandate* (命) refers to imperial decrees. *Qi* (炁) is the heart’s qi, symbolizing the ruler. *Receives* (受) means to accept willingly. *True* (真) means sincerity. *Hold fast* (固) implies rigidity. *How* (奈) expresses helplessness. It warns that the ruler’s decrees must be issued with care, for they determine rise or fall. If commands go unheeded and teachings remain incomplete, one must not abandon them as intractable. Only with proclamations like Pan Geng’s call to relocate or the Duke of Zhou’s governance of Luoyang can this be deemed proper. Here, the original scripture ends.

Guard qi, nurture primal virtue’s mound;
The Three Sovereigns and Five Emperors branch forth.

*Pristine* (元) is primal qi, referring to cultivation from below. *Virtue* (德) is the heart’s virtue, referring to those above. *Mound* (邱) is a hill, signifying elevation. *Branch* (派) means tributary, implying an unbroken transmission. These two lines and the following two were absent in the original but are drawn from a five-character ancient version to conclude this section of the scripture.

The Five Classics and Four Books,
Confucius and Mencius teach without distinction.

This appears to be an invocation. Note: "Confucius and Mencius" in another version reads "cheng da" (成达), meaning "to perfect virtue and attain talent."

*The Great Cavern Jade Chapter Scripture* in seven-character ancient verse.

This section lacks a specified purpose but seems to be treasured and kept secret by those of the *Fengzhen* tradition.

Enveloping the three *lan*, waves reach the harmonious terrace—
This line illustrates entering observation from the external realm, unbound by any single corner; its subtlety lies in the word *envelop* (罗).

From the hall’s movement, push into boundless connection—
This line illustrates beginning with internal movement; its subtlety lies in the word *movement* (运).

The numinous capital, lush and vast, nurtures the distant—
This line presents a vision of the numinous capital’s sublime realm; its subtlety lies in the word *nurture* (育).

Lest the scattered omens bring premature death or calamity—
The crux of this line lies in the word *birth* (生), revealing a means to reverse fate.

Stagnation at the outset, darkness soars in the court’s gaze—
The crux of this line lies in the word *gaze* (盼), expressing a vast vow to save from suffering.

The profound bounty is called "sand-fortune"—
The crux of this line lies in the word *called* (称), embodying the Purple Tenuity’s scales of judgment.

The radiant osmanthus gathers harmonious offspring—
The crux of this line lies in the word *harmony* (和), signifying flourishing vitality.

Rejoicing in the worthy, urging the hundred to strive heavenward—
The crux of this line lies in the word *strive* (奋), suggesting ascent to a higher plane.

Earth forms walls, the far-reaching weaves the *zhang*—
The crux of this line lies in the word *far-reaching* (弥), implying boundless reach.

The *zhang* grows, the land’s expanse veils in mist—
The crux of this line lies in the word *veil* (蒙), evoking the work of nurturing correctness through obscurity.

The Emperor’s *mang* ascends, the fierce *xie*-beast trusts the Emperor—
The crux of this line lies in the word *trust* (信), signifying luminous fidelity.

The *ni* rides the *tuo*, the *yu* laws follow the jade—
The crux of this line lies in the word *follow* (谟), implying adherence to established principles.

Riding the ford of darkness, the sun, moon, and stars extend—
The crux of this line lies in the word *ride* (乘), denoting unfailing precision.

The Dipper shines, life’s mandate guards the primal—
The crux of this line lies in the word *Dipper* (斗), embodying the principle that all is mind.

Virtue’s mound, enduring life, firmly abides—
The crux of this line lies in the word *firm* (固), signifying indestructibility.

This is called the *Jade Book*, worthy of profound study—
This line is drawn from the *Yellow Court Scripture* to conclude this scripture’s meaning.

Note: The scripture comprises ninety-six characters, with an additional sixteen appended by the lineage master Gong Wushang to guide later generations.

*Postscript to the Rain Fragrance Heavenly Scripture and Dhāraṇī Commentary*
Humbly recorded by Min Zhenxian, one hundred and first-generation descendant of the Mind School of Western India.

A modest explication of esoteric verses:
This is no presumptuous interpretation but has its origins. Formerly, my master, Yedapo She, transmitted the *Gāthā Radish Heart Chapter*, saying: "According to our school’s scriptures, the texts are all in Sanskrit, the sounds all in Sanskrit. The Bhagavān, pitying the manifold sufferings of the world and the diversity of customs, found universal proclamation difficult—teaching as if not teaching—thus permitting translation adapted to local conditions."

Within this single principle of adaptation, there are instances where both script and sound are translated—such as the Tripiṭaka scriptures of the world; where neither script nor sound is translated—such as the *Zang Fan Ce*; or where sound is translated but script is not—such as the *Zang* 卍 and the like. There are also cases where, through inference, both script and meaning are harmonized and unified. For script is the written expression of the heart, and sound is its resonance; within this profound subtlety, the universal can be intuitively grasped—this is the essence of the Tathāgata’s teaching. Having privately embodied this, I transmitted it in its entirety to Min Zhenxian of the land of Zhen Dan, bestowing upon him the name *True Immortal* to carry on the Mind School as the next generation of its lineage. With reverence, I presented this to the Tathāgata, humbly beseeching that the original vow be upheld and that protection and mindfulness be extended from beginning to end.

True Immortal received this transmission and once translated the *Dhāraṇī of Wisdom*, the *Esoteric Mantra of the Divine Attendants*, the *Two Sūtras of the Great Compassionate One Upholding the World*, and various *Dhāraṇīs*. Knowing my own mediocre capacity in receiving and transmitting, how dare I claim falsehood as truth? What I have explicated in the past is merely for the benevolent to perceive as they may. Now, as disciples have taken it upon themselves to preserve this in print, I set forth this brief account to the right. May readers show forbearance—True Immortal would be most fortunate.

*Respectfully inscribed on the full moon of the mid-winter month of Jiawu in the Daoguang reign.*

---

**Commentary on the Dhāraṇī of Wisdom**
*By Min Yide of Jingaishan, styled Shaofu*

This *Dhāraṇī* was transmitted by the Divine Mother Chen and treasured in secret by Patriarch Xu of Jingyang. No commentary existed before; having long held it, I suddenly gained some insight and thus offer this explication, hoping to illuminate the minds of fellow seekers.

**Oṃ** – Pronounced *ān*, an exclamation of praise.
**Pāla** – *Pā* (波) is pronounced *bō*; *la* (啰) is pronounced *lā*.
*Pā* signifies a golden vessel, resembling a bowl but with a slightly constricted mouth, round and hollow—from which the Great Ultimate emerges. Its radiance is dazzling, much like the luminous pearl of human nature. This is the meaning of *pāla*.
*La* is an auxiliary particle, akin to "thus" or "so."
*Pāla* – Repeated for emphasis, as in "radiant, ever radiant."
**Oṃ sā pāla** – *Sā* (口三) is pronounced *shā*, denoting plurality.
*Oṃ sā pāla* describes the manifold manifestations of the principle of nature, the meaning of ten thousand distinctions.
*Oṃ sā pāla* – Repeated to signify the inexhaustible layering of the principle of nature, as if countless golden vessels were appearing endlessly.
**Indranīlaśaya** – *Indra* (印) means "to verify" or "to correspond."
*Nīla* (尼) refers to the Three Sages: the Most Holy (Śākyamuni), the Supreme (Laozi), and Confucius. It speaks of the clarity of the celestial nature, its radiance vast and luminous, perfectly aligned with Confucius, Śākyamuni, and the Azure Sage as if matching tally tokens.
*Śaya* (隶野) – *Śa* (隶) means "to belong"; *ya* (野) refers to the "uncultivated person," the noble man of antiquity. It declares that the boundless brilliance of one’s nature, having corresponded with the Three Sages, now belongs to the ranks of the ancient worthies.
**Mīlātanī** – *Mī* (弥) signifies "immeasurably vast."
*Lā* (轮) describes the unobstructed circulation of the Wheel.
It speaks of the boundless, all-pervading radiance of the nature-light, without the slightest hindrance.
*Ta* (陀) conveys the sense of perfect roundness and dazzling brilliance.
*Nī* (尼) is a veiled term for the sun; in celestial speech, the sun is called *nī*, and in the Sanskrit of the Western regions, it is likewise called *muni*. It declares that the form and function of the nature-light not only align with the virtue of the Three Sages but are indeed like the sun itself.
**Halu halu** – *Ha* (含) means "to conceal"; *lu* (鲁) means "dull."
*Halu* suggests that great wisdom is deeply hidden, appearing as if clumsy—concealment in its utmost.
Repeated to introduce the meaning of the following phrase.
**Jñāli yu** – Continuing from above, it states that what the ancient sages delighted in bestowing was the ultimate Dao, precisely because the great wisdom of the scholar appears foolish.
*Jñā* (哲) refers to the ancient sages.
*Yu* (予) is pronounced *yǔ*, meaning "to grant" or "to bestow."
*Jñāli yu* – The ancient sages must have delighted in bestowing the ultimate Dao.
*Jñāli yu* – Repeated thrice to introduce the following, as if to say, "Not only do they delight in bestowing the Dao..."
**Svāhā** – *Svā* (娑) in celestial speech means "swift"; *hā* (诃), pronounced *huò*, also in celestial speech, signifies the utmost speed, as if with a single sound like *huò*.
Continuing from above, it declares that not only is the Dao bestowed, but it is bestowed swiftly. For wisdom is not the ultimate Dao, and the ultimate Dao cannot be attained without great wisdom—hence the deep cherishing of the ancient sages.
The ancient sages refer to the Primordial Sovereign of the Origin.

**Oṃ** – Pronounced *ān*, an exclamation of praise.
**Pā** – Pronounced *bō*, a vessel resembling a bowl with a slightly constricted mouth, round and unbroken, its form like the Infinite, yet radiant and dazzling. The nature-light of humanity truly resembles it, hence the metaphor.
*Pāla* – Repeated to clarify, as in "thus, thus."
**Oṃ sā** – *Sā* (口三), originally pronounced *shā*, denotes the appearance of iteration, also the meaning of *shā*.
*Oṃ sā pāla* – It speaks of many nature-pearls, like vessels, sequentially manifesting the nature-light as *pāla*.
*Oṃ sā pāla* – Also repeated for emphasis.
**Indra** – Means "to correspond" or "to tally," as in "to align."
**Nīla** – The sun; in the divine language of the nine heavens, the sun is called *nī*, and in the Buddhist lands of the West, it is called *muni*. It declares that the *pāla*-like nature-pearls, innumerable in their emanation, align with the sun above. It speaks of their vast luminosity, indeed like the sun, hence *Indranīla*.
**Śaya** – *Śa* (隶) means "to belong"; *ya* (野) is a term for the noble man of antiquity, as in "uncultivated person." It declares that having attained the nature-light and aligned with the celestial sun, one’s status now belongs to the ranks of the ancient noble ones, hence *Indranīlaśaya*.

**Mí** – The appearance of being all-pervading and without lack.
**Lún** – The appearance of revolving without obstruction.
**Tuó** – The appearance of perfect roundness and vastness.
**Ní** – The sun.
**Hán** – To contain, to conceal.
**Lǔ** – Dullness, substance, or inherent quality.
**Zhé** – The ancient sages.
**Lì** – Joy.
**Yǔ** – Pronounced *yǔ*, meaning to give, to bestow, or to grant.

It speaks of this all-pervading, unobstructed, perfectly round, and vast nature-pearl, like the sun, which is ever contained within those of dull substance. Those in whom it is contained are the very ones cherished by the ancient sages—this reiterates the meaning of *hánlǔ*.

Thus, the following text directly states *zhélìyǔ* three times, and then directly says *suōhē*. For **suō** means "swift," and **hē** (alternatively written as *hè*, pronounced *huò*) describes the meaning of "swift," as if to say *huò* in a single breath.

**Zhé** – The ancient sages, the supreme and most authentic ones.
**Lì** – The meaning of joyful bestowal.
**Yǔ** – To give.

The first phrase follows from *hánlǔ*, as if to say, "This is a certain principle." The second phrase affirms it as an unshakable truth. The third phrase introduces the meaning of *suōhē* below, as if to say, "Not only is it joyfully bestowed, but it is swiftly granted," hence it directly states *suōhē*.

Regarding *ní* in *Yìndùníxīyà*, it is best not to interpret it as three separate *ní*.

---

**A Single-Eyed Mantra**
Annotated by Mǐn Tiáofū of Jīngài Mountain, Wúxīng

This mantra is said to have been transmitted by the Filial and Fraternal King of the Dipper and has long been treasured in the ritual manuals of the Dipper. A precious mirror is placed before the meditation cushion, and with each recitation, one bows, touching the mirror’s surface, without counting the number of prostrations. Its origin traces back to Guō Fényáng, who recorded the ritual for seeking wisdom, placing it at the head of *The Mantra of Wisdom*. The explanation is both coherent and profoundly esoteric. Since the method derives from the Dipper and has no prior commentary, and as we who study the Dao rely entirely on wisdom to seek it, there is no reason it cannot be used. Thus, I have added annotations to facilitate recitation and embodiment. I dare not keep this for myself and respectfully print it to share with like-minded practitioners.

---

**Suōhē Yīmù Húnbān** (*Suōhē* is also written as *suōhā* in prayer rituals)
**Suō** – The meaning of a thousand principles and ten thousand truths.
**Hē** – Pronounced *huò*, meaning "to unite."
**Mù** – Item, principle.
**Hún** – The undifferentiated principle of Heaven, with not a trace of human intention mingled within.
**Bān** – Pronounced *bō*, a Sanskrit term meaning the great light of wisdom, similar yet distinct from *pāla*. For *pāla* has a form that can be likened, whereas *bān* is utterly luminous and boundless.

*Suōhē* signifies the power to gather the myriad into one. *Yīmùhún* signifies the meaning of refining it into the profound. Human nature is fundamentally good, yet it becomes deluded through habitual defilements. To return to the original endowment of wisdom-light, one must unify all principles into a single item and refine them into undifferentiated wholeness—only then is true wisdom restored. This is what is meant by *bān*.

*Bān* manifests as a radiant, flower-adorned realm of boundless light—vast beyond measure, possessing a wonder that can be imagined yet not described. The meaning of *bān* is indeed profound! Its ultimate significance is as expressed in the following passage.

---

**Suōhē Dìdì Xīnbān** (*Suōhē* is written as *suōhā* in prayer rituals)
This continues the meaning of *bān* from above. When all principles unite, the light of nature is restored like the dawn. Yet one fears that this momentary union may not be deeply rooted, and thus what has united may scatter, and what has merged may again become confused. The wisdom-light thus obtained would remain precarious and insubstantial. It is necessary for the ten thousand things to return each to its root.

The earlier phrase *suōhē yīmù hún* carries the sense of "not knowing, not perceiving." Here, *suōhē* carries the meaning of following the principle of the *Dì*. **Dì** means "root." *Dìdì* means the root of roots. The first *Dì* in *Shàngdì* (Supreme Deity) signifies following the principle of the *Dì*, while the second *Dì* signifies adhering to that principle.

**Xīn** means to transform the old. It speaks of the thousand principles and ten thousand truths having converged into the undifferentiated whole, restoring the original true wisdom. One must then delve into each of the thousand principles and ten thousand truths to explore their root connections, and further probe the roots of those roots. Thus, the ten thousand things each return to their source, converging at their ultimate origin—this is the meaning of *dìdì*. The old defilements and impurities are all renewed, and the originally complete wisdom-light shines again like an ancient mirror polished anew. Through this, the efficacy of *yīmùhún* can endure forever without flaw.

This elaborates on the preceding phrase, exhausting its fundamental source. It demonstrates that a learning grounded in roots is like a spring flowing inexhaustibly. This mantra was transmitted by the highest immortals for scholars to carry with them, that they might attain their own wisdom.

The first *suōhē* carries the meaning of extensive learning returning to simplicity, enabling self-attainment and abiding in ease. The second *suōhē* carries the meaning of abiding in ease while deepening one’s resources. The third *suōhē* carries the meaning of profound bestowal, enabling one to encounter the source at every turn.

---

**Suōhē Bōluō Bōluō** (*Suōhē* is written as *suōhā*, *bōluō* as *bōluó* in prayer rituals. **Luō** means "to spread" or "to pervade." **Bō** means "moisture" or "abundance.")

This continues the above, stating that when all principles have united in the *Dì* of *Dì*, it is like great waters pooling in the Starry Lake of Heaven, fermenting yet not yet released—this is the meaning of *suōhē* here.

**Bō** – The image of the vast, boundless ocean of nature, flowing far and wide.
**Luō** – A grammatical particle.

*Bōluō bōluō* describes the activation of *bān*, like waves rising one after another without end.

The organization of this process is spontaneous, manifesting in intertwining patterns without end or fixed form. Here it clarifies how the new *bān* of *Dì-Dì* unfolds and releases in such a manner.

**Guān bān guān bān**
This continues the meaning of *bōluō bōluō* above, revealing the principle of observing the self.
The first *guān* is read in its usual sense, meaning "to examine closely."
The second *guān* is pronounced *guàn*, signifying thorough illumination without omission.
It speaks of how, when the principles of nature overflow and spread in all directions, their vast clarity manifests the same *bōluō bōluō* scenery—no less than the highest good resembling water. Yet one fears the human heart’s tendency to shift, just as water is prone to excess.
When water encounters obstruction, it spills; when it spills, it overflows; when it overflows, it floods; and when it floods, it breaches embankments, its force no longer containable.
Only by following its nature to guide it does it flow smoothly without stagnation, for the method lies in acting as if doing nothing.
The wise possess an inherently good heavenly nature, yet one fears it may be swayed by desire; once swayed, it is seized; once seized, its heaven is depleted, and the heart and nature become scattered.
This is the perilous and subtle juncture between heaven and humanity, where close examination must be precise.
Only by cultivating it according to one’s original nature at the moment before it arises does the subtle have its own regulator, and the method likewise proceeds as if doing nothing—this is the meaning of *guān*.
*Guān bān* means using the light of original great wisdom to illuminate the myriad principles, nurturing them directly without harm, embodying the image of clear vision and keen hearing, governing without action.
This is what the *Book of Yu* calls "attending to Heaven’s mandate, ever mindful of the subtle."
The second *bān* refers to what the *Zhou Odes* calls "Heaven’s mandate, profound and unceasing"—this teaches people the method of *guān*.
This is the essential meaning of *guān bān guān bān*, the true principle of *bān*.
Those who seek abundant blessings will have something to rely upon.

**Yīn bān Dì**
*Yīn* means "to depend upon." The meaning of *yīn* follows from the previous *guān*.
