Should one become emotionally attached, they will be detained and unable to transcend, delaying their ascent to realization. At best, their spirit will stagnate in the *niwan* palace, and the hope of rebirth will vanish. Worse still, they may be seized by demonic forces, and their spirit devoured—all due to ignorance of the living *wu* practice.

The Great Void Elder further said: When practice reaches the stage where true and illusory are indistinguishable, even if it is not yet the exact *wu* hour, if one can direct their qi and will, applying effort to concentrate and stabilize, within half an hour, they may return to the true *wu*, where a golden world appears, illuminating the heart and eyes. This is the method of Li Shaojun, who at the setting sun returned to the zenith—his medicine most potent, gathered by intent, transforming into true qi. Then, concentrating with intent, he drew it into the ancestral aperture, calling this *"obtaining the medicine."* The patriarchs of the Southern Lineage, from whom great accomplishments arose—Huainan Wang, Wei Boyang, and the two perfected ones Ge and Xu—added practices like *"embracing and lifting,"* ascending bodily into the heavens.

My teacher, the Mud-Pill Elder, practiced without attachment, and I too have personally experienced the verification of the six celestial tremors. My teacher ceased further transmission, but you should treasure and guard this secret, awaiting the right person to whom it may be passed.

As for visions of crumbling walls and ruined houses, these are signs of the practitioner’s yang declining and yin diminishing. The method here is to constantly revere the true, aligning every action with proper measure, while guarding the *mingmen*, emptying the heart, and filling the abdomen. Above all, avoid the arising of anxious or malevolent thoughts—this too is an oral secret of the ancient sages for entering practice through the living *wu*.

The Elder further said: In our practice, we must follow the ancient sages and buddhas, cultivating nature in activity and life in stillness. Do not be like the scholars of the world, who only apply their methods during seated meditation. That is why ten out of ten of them fail. The ancient sages were not like this, and so they succeeded a hundred times out of a hundred.

I urge scholars to begin by equating the body with emptiness, taking the emptiness of heaven and earth as the dharma-body, this physical form as the divine chamber of the celestial heart, and this fleshly heart as the ruler of the celestial heart. Let there be no preferences, aversions, pursuits, or avoidances—no clinging, no wandering thoughts whatsoever.

Only maintain one vast, empty void—neither bright nor dark—what is called the boundless expanse, neither partial nor biased. Upright in form, hollow in heart, true in thought: only thus does one not squander this precious opportunity. When practice reaches *huozi*, do not neglect its nurturance; when it reaches *huowu*, gather and enclose the essential method.

Alas! If this body is not liberated in this lifetime, in which lifetime shall it be liberated?

The ancient sages said: "When the front gate is closed and the heart’s *qi* is subdued, practice from summer to autumn will succeed." They also said: "When the rear gate is opened, half the work is done—contracting *gen* and opening *qian* is the true practice."

Know that *qi* fails to ascend posteriorly because congealed essence blocks the channels and apertures. The method lies only in directing spirit to the *kun*-abdomen and returning *qi* to the Gate of Life. When fire flourishes, *qi* warms; congealed essence, meeting warmth, melts like water. The channels and apertures are no longer obstructed, and the *qi* naturally penetrates posteriorly.

Now, *qi* circulates through the channels; if the channels are blocked, *qi* stagnates. Know that what obstructs the channels is the very essence once carried by *qi*. Thus, *qi* fails to ascend because of stagnation within essence; essence stagnates because *qi* is not warm; *qi* is not warm because the Gate of Life is weak; the fire of the Gate of Life is weak because spirit is not guarded. For essence moves by means of *qi*, and *qi* is warmed by means of spirit. When spirit flourishes, *qi* is warm; when spirit wanes, *qi* cools. Cool *qi* causes essence to congeal and fail to transform, turning internally into phlegm, which fills the meridians and obstructs the apertures. The consequences are not only that the great Dao is difficult to practice, but even life itself is hard to preserve for long. The method lies only in heating the *kun*-abdomen intensely to draw it back.

Know that essence, as a substance, when governed by flourishing *qi*, is like clouds borne by dry wind—ascending, it becomes rosy dawn; descending, it becomes dew. When governed by weak *qi*, it is like mist borne by damp wind—ascending, it forms stagnant clouds; descending, it turns into rain. Moreover, this yin-essence, descending and lingering in the bladder, when occasionally scorched by ministerial fire, oozes outward—this is the great harm of stagnation below. If governed by *qi* and dispersed throughout the hundred channels, when dried by wind and fire, it transforms into abscesses, paralysis, or even long-term accumulation that turns to fire, resulting in bone steaming. The consumptive illnesses of the world are all brewed from this substance. The ancient sages, fearing this, thus taught the method of nurturing fire.

The method of nurturing fire lies only in focusing intention on the *kun*-abdomen and returning *qi* to the Gate of Life. The fire of the Gate of Life is invisible to the eye but perceptible in experience. The root of spirit-fire lies in the flourishing fire of the Gate of Life; the essence of food can then be transformed into *qi*. Further, by directing intention to the *kun*-abdomen, dryness is nurtured into true earth, and moisture nourishes the hundred bones, invigorating the *qi*-mechanism to contain thunderous yang. The function of true fire is vast indeed!

In our daily transformation of food and drink, we have long been ignorant of the method of nurturing fire. Thus, among the hundred channels, few escape harm, and in the bladder, this substance accumulates in abundance. Yin fails to transform into yang, and the consequences inevitably unfold as described above—how can one not apply focused attention?

If *qi* does not ascend posteriorly, one is not far from this disaster. Moreover, if *qi* does not ascend posteriorly, it must ascend anteriorly. If *qi* penetrates anteriorly, the harm is even greater (minor cases manifest as liver *qi* surges, major cases as leg *qi* attacks). The illness will erupt in spring; if it erupts in spring, it is still manageable, but if it erupts in summer, it is severe.

For this congealed essence, turned to phlegm, first obstructs the central palace, blocking *qi* from descending. Occasionally, some follows *qi* downward, but with the fire of the Gate of Life weak, the descending substance congeals and obstructs below. When the *weilü* cavity is blocked, the *jiaji*, crown, and occiput must also be obstructed—thus both the *ren* and *du* meridians are closed. How can the disaster be measured?

To preemptively remedy this, the method combines the contraction of *gen* with the gathering of subjects to assist and nurture. When the true fire of the Gate of Life flourishes, it can be used to warm and steam the middle and lower regions. Yin-essence will daily melt away, and true *qi* will grow in power, breaking through barriers and opening channels. Practicing thus for one seven-day period, then two, up to seven seven-day periods without interruption, the stagnant substances before and behind will transform, and the *ren* and *du* meridians will open. Not only will illness be cured, but—

If one merely seeks to open the channels without nurturing and assisting, the old stagnant mud will remain in the channels and apertures. Though there may be momentary relief, the root cause remains. The aim is merely temporary peace, for in truth, yang is weak, *qi* is feeble, and the effort to rouse oneself is difficult. Long-ingrained habits are hard to reverse, and thus we arrive at this lamentable state! We, as aspiring scholars, must take strict heed.

Once the *qi*-mechanism is unblocked, yin-essence is transformed, and long-standing illnesses are eliminated, one may proceed to the three methods of cultivation. Among them, there are further essential techniques:

From *zi* to *si*, the practice should involve raising the buttocks, bowing the body, straightening the neck, and contracting *gen* for twenty-four breaths; drawing upward to *qian*, storing spirit in the mud-pill palace for sixteen breaths; then straightening the body, relaxing the abdomen, and sitting for another sixteen breaths—altogether thirty-six breaths, repeated in six cycles.

From *wu* to *hai*, the practice should involve stroking the abdomen, straightening the waist, lifting the neck, and emptying the heart for sixteen breaths; storing spirit in the *kun*-abdomen for fourteen breaths; then, as before, straightening the body and breathing to return *qi* to the navel for fourteen breaths—altogether twenty-four breaths, repeated in six cycles.

The ancient sages said: "From *zi* to *si*, one should advance the yang fire; when yang flourishes, it ascends, and when it ascends, the mechanism is lively. From *wu* to *hai*, one should retreat the yin tally; when yin melts, it descends, and when it descends, stagnation is resolved."

They also said: "The head is the *qian* cauldron, the heart is the chamber of spirit, and the abdomen is the *kun* furnace. The heart is the palace that stores *qi*, the abdomen is the palace where nature and life converge, the place where the elixir is born. The heart should be empty, the abdomen should be full. If the heart is not empty, thoughts are scattered and *qi* is chaotic; long-standing accumulations fail to transform below and brew into phlegm-rheum. If the abdomen is not full, *qi* is deficient and stagnant; fluids and essence fail to melt and transform, brewing into seminal leakage."

Scholars, take heed. How does one align the body upright? It is essential to understand the *Ren* and *Du* meridians. If the body is not upright, the *qi* mechanism becomes obstructed; once the body is aligned, the *qi* mechanism flows without hindrance, and the hundred channels circulate smoothly—a matter of no small consequence. However, when first practicing this method, *qi* does not easily descend, and one may experience *qi* surging upward in reversal, or sensations of distension, stagnation, and soreness along the front and back of the body. This is because the channels contain residual turbidity that has yet to dissolve; when the meridian *qi* penetrates and surges, such discomfort arises—precisely a sign of unblocking. One must promptly apply techniques such as lifting the buttocks to press the *Du* meridian, and emptying the heart while filling the abdomen to press the *Ren* meridian. Once the *Ren* and *Du* are fully open, previous afflictions will naturally resolve.

After the *Ren* and *Du* are unblocked, aside from the major method of circulating and gathering during the *wu* and *zi* hours, one must, upon obtaining the medicine, continue practicing techniques such as lifting the buttocks and emptying the heart, and add the method of maintaining an upright posture to refine and nurture. With three years of practice, success will be achieved.

How does one make the heart empty and vast? If the heart is not empty and vast, *qi* and spirit scatter with thoughts, losing their proper governance and order, making the work difficult to accomplish. Once the heart is empty and vast, *qi* unifies, and even if there are obstructions, they dissolve as soon as *qi* arrives, making the work easily effective. Moreover, there lies a wondrous function within. When practicing the method of unblocking the *Ren* meridian, upon completion, one must perform the technique of sinking the abdomen and settling the spirit. Without this technique, there arises the phenomenon of *kan* yang sinking into yin, easily leading to dullness and torpor. With this technique, *qi* is tranquil and spirit is clear; at this moment, one must attain the state of a single, exposed spirit. When practicing the method of unblocking the *Du* meridian, upon completion, one must perform the technique of storing *qian* and purifying the marrow. Without this technique, ascent becomes mixed with turbidity, often causing brain distension, red eyes, agitation, and the arousal of thunderous yang, leading to the peril of "thunderclap spirit flight." With this technique, all such afflictions are averted; even if distension or dizziness occurs, applying techniques such as emptiness, relaxation, and retreat will immediately resolve the issue. The wondrous function of this phrase is beyond description!

Master Taixu further said: "After eating one's fill, one must strictly avoid abruptly practicing the sinking abdomen technique. The method lies in emptying the heart; once the food has slightly settled, one should merely maintain spirit within the heart and abdomen, avoiding vigorous practice, and only apply the technique of slow walking while gently stroking the abdomen. Only after the food has fully descended can one engage in vigorous practice. Ancient sages said: 'After eating, practice gently,' and also: 'After eating, add the empty heart method; with an empty heart, food digests easily.' For humans, food is paramount, yet the root of illness lies in food stagnating in the middle palace, transforming into phlegm-rheum and giving rise to conditions such as regurgitation. Practicing vigorously after eating causes grain to follow *qi* downward, stagnating at the lower extreme, leading to anal abscesses and hemorrhoids; turbid *qi* stagnating in the channels gives rise to paralysis and other ailments. When this substance adheres to the joints and bones over time, it transforms into fire, resulting in consumptive diseases, steaming bones, and other conditions. What the ancient sages called 'gentle' refers to maintaining spirit at the central pole and directing intention to the *Mingmen*. If one adds sinking, the practice becomes vigorous, which only induces illness—hence the prohibition. What is the method of emptying the heart? It is merely to relax the *qi* mechanism. The instruction to walk slowly contains the function of aiding the spleen in digestion; stroking the abdomen contains the meaning of gathering and returning grain *qi*, guiding it to be transformed by fire into *qi*. Once the food has digested, one must add the technique of contracting *Gen*. What is the method of contracting *Gen*? It is like restraining the urge to defecate or urinate, preventing grain *qi* from leaking outward and ensuring it does not stagnate below. For this substance, the pure aspect follows *qi* upward to transform into blood, dispersing and filling the hundred channels; the turbid aspect follows *qi* downward to moisten the intestines and stomach. If spirit is not properly focused, it becomes yin fluid, bringing calamity to the entire body. Thus, the ancient sages paid particular attention to this thrice.

When one maintains spirit in the central palace and senses fullness and distension in the chest, one should respectfully guide it with intention, descending from the right side of the chest, circling around the navel, rising from the left to encircle it, then descending to the right—this is the method of retreating the yin tally. Since grain *qi* is too abundant, one must apply the retreating method. Upon slight relaxation, cease the practice and merely perform the empty heart method, naturally attaining a sense of ease and release. Gradually, one perceives a misty *qi* phenomenon appearing before the eyes and heart—this is the initial effect of grain *qi* steaming and ascending. Next, one feels this scene pervading the entire body—this is the effect of grain *qi* riding one’s central *qi* to circulate throughout the body. Eventually, the chest and diaphragm feel clear, while the abdomen remains full. At this time, the food has descended, and one may add techniques such as left, center, and right circulation.

Carefully follow this method, aligning the body with nasal breathing: when breathing to the left, circulate left; when breathing to the center, circulate center; when breathing to the right, circulate right. The principle is subtle and wondrous, yet the method remains gentle. Ancient sages did not explicitly explain this, merely stating to follow the method of circulation (ancient methods relied on the *qi* of nasal breathing, exiting left or right to circulate. However, the nose has only two nostrils, exhaling only left or right—how can there be a center *qi*? The so-called center refers to when both nostrils exhale simultaneously, which is the central *qi*). Human nasal breathing aligns with celestial timing, a long-verified truth. The ancient methods do not deceive: the exhalation and inhalation of breath correspond precisely to the hours—*zi* left, *chou* right, *yin* left, *mao* right—alternating without fail. At the transition between two hours, both nostrils exhale simultaneously. The number of exhalations increases slightly at *zi* and *wu*, while other times are roughly similar.

In the circulation method, when *qi* exits from the left, descend from the left side of the chest, circle the abdomen to the right, then turn upward to about two inches above the navel, push inward to directly attach to the *Mingmen*—this is called advancing the yang fire. For those deficient in yang, often circulate up to thirty-six turns and stop. When *qi* exits from the right, descend from the right side of the chest, circle the abdomen to the left, then turn upward to about two inches above the navel, push inward directly to the lower *Dantian* without attaching to the *Mingmen*—this is called retreating the yin tally."

For those deficient in yin, often circulate up to twenty-four turns and stop. When both nostrils exhale simultaneously as the central *qi*, proceed directly from the *Jiangque* to the *Zhonghuang*, circling thirty-six times to the left around the navel-wheel and twenty-four times to the right. Then, at about two inches above the navel, push inward to enter the mysterious aperture, abiding without thought or concern for a brief moment—this is called *sealing the furnace*.

Those who can practice this method uninterrupted through the twelve hours possess a great secret technique. Should one suddenly enter the *qi*-realm of *tun* and *meng*, this is the sign of spirit wandering in the Water Palace. At this juncture, the practitioner must swiftly apply the *Qingkong* technique, turning attention to the *Kun*-abdomen while contracting the *Gen* position, thereby igniting the fire of the lower *Dantian*. When the upper and middle *qi* respond, strictly avoid premature ascent. The work lies solely in descending; one must assist the *qi* in pressing forward. Once the barrier is broken and transcended, the *qi* surges upward through the spine, pierces the pillow, and ascends. After lingering for half a breath, it naturally descends to the *Huachi*. At this moment, redouble mindfulness, and one will surely receive the sweet dew in abundance, filling the mouth to be swallowed in portions. The *Jiangque* will be felt, with true *qi* congealing within. Then, proceed to forget the technique, attaining the wondrous state of having a body yet being without one.

Suddenly, one may feel a drop descending from emptiness, falling straight into the heart, bringing an immense coolness. Then, it descends further into the *Zhonghuang*, producing extreme warmth and moisture, with the body suffused in spring-like vitality—this is the grain-*qi* transformed into the supreme treasure. At this time, the method lies in silently awaiting the state of "not knowing, not perceiving," which is called *receiving the treasure and returning to the furnace*. In alchemical texts, this is termed *the treasure returning to primal chaos*.

For practitioners who have not yet reached the stage of *bigu*, how can this segment of practice be neglected? Indeed, success lies here, and so too does peril. Why must the initial step of Dao cultivation begin with the technique of *making the self equal to emptiness*? This emptiness is the original substance of Heaven and Earth, the ultimate truth of one’s body. By employing this true image as the starting point, subsequent techniques will all accord with the Dao.

In practicing this method, one invariably takes Heaven and Earth as the Dharmakāya. The essence of the technique lies in broadening the *qi*-mechanism. Only when the *qi*-mechanism is broadened can there be no stagnation within, enabling the body to serve as lead, the heart as mercury, stillness as water, and wisdom as fire—without the slightest difficulty.

Moreover, the void within the body is Heaven, and its solidity is Earth. The heart, liver, spleen, lungs, and kidneys correspond to spirit, essence, soul, *po*, and intent, which in Heaven and Earth are metal, wood, water, fire, and earth. In the Dao, they are benevolence, righteousness, propriety, wisdom, and trust. Their functions are nothing but correcting imbalances and remedying deficiencies, ultimately subsumed under the two principles of stillness and wisdom.

Some say stillness is the substance of the Dao, while wisdom is its function—this appears correct but is not. Stillness is contrasted with restlessness, and wisdom with ignorance. In their profound meaning, both stillness and wisdom belong to the function of the Dao. The Dao as Dao is naturally pure and unified, yet encompasses the ten thousand things, embracing past and present, appearing as quiescence yet resembling the Supreme Ultimate. Responding to things as they come is the meaning of wisdom; not following things as they depart is the meaning of stillness—only the sage can achieve this. In our cultivation, we strive to approximate it: difficult at first, then attainable, and finally, naturally so.

The method of practice is nothing other than self-mastery. The method of self-mastery lies in purifying the constant in times of no event and purifying the changing in times of event. My teacher, Master Taixu, said: "If one takes emptiness as the Dharmakāya but does not regard the physical body as the divine chamber of the Heavenly Heart, one falls into the void of reckless abandon, lacking a central master—this is heterodoxy. Thus, the ancients necessarily followed this technique with another, fearing entry into the heartless heterodoxy of emotionlessness, and further took the fleshly heart as the heart of the Heavenly Heart.

For the Heavenly Heart is never obscured, being perfectly pure and perfectly awakened, thus able to respond without bias yet naturally, with the *qi*-mechanism fully replenished. Proceeding thus with the body’s lead and heart’s mercury, stillness as water and wisdom as fire, no thought arises beyond this single thought—this is what is meant by *no-thought within thought*. If one were to eliminate even this thought, it would be like boiling an empty pot with water and fire—this is the heartless heterodoxy. Those who aspire to the state of heavenly immortality must jointly investigate this.

The ancients began with *wuwang* (non-delusion). In our practice, we provisionally distinguish stillness and wisdom for separate cultivation. The method also begins with *wuwang*: taking *wuwang* as stillness and eliminating arising delusions as wisdom. The sequence is: first eliminate coarse delusions, then subtle delusions, and finally the delusion of *wuwang* itself, reaching the state of natural purity and perfection.

First establish this true thought as the seed of one’s Heavenly Heart—this is called *directly refining the upper barrier*. For now, set aside questions of *conceiving the embryo, nourishing the embryo, and shedding the embryo*, for these terms used by the ancients contain profound meanings, intended merely to detail the stages and prevent the error of hasty advancement. Ultimately, the direction is nothing other than eliminating delusion and preserving the true. The technique of practice is simply using one to eliminate ten thousand."

Pushing further into the method of practice, it proceeds from the shallow to the profound, demanding substance in accordance with names, refining ever more finely and verifying the wondrous with the wondrous. Traced to its ultimate operation, it culminates in *non-abiding*. Yet this single principle of *non-abiding* is in truth what sustains the practitioner from beginning to end. The true seed within the bow’s draw takes *nature* as its essence and *life* as its function; congealing and preserving it, smelting it into oneness, refining it with spirit, and then advancing ever deeper—until it merges with the unmanifest prior to all signs, where there is no duality.

In possessing this Dao-body, its function becomes numinous of itself. Yet how could this not begin and end with *wuwang*? Such was the earnest intent of the ancients in establishing names and designations. Alas, later students failed to awaken, instead clinging to delusion, giving rise to manifold heterodox views and leading themselves astray. Only those who grasp this essential point may turn to the alchemical texts for confirmation and verification; otherwise, it is better to leave them untouched upon the high shelf.

*Preface to the Complete Collection of Profound Discourses by Master Sanfeng*
From my youth, I was ardently devoted to the furnace and fire, yet achieved nothing. (This refers to the worldly transmission of furnace and tripod, as in the common accounts of *huangbai*—the transmutation of base metals into gold through elixir drugs, which is indeed verifiable. However, the drugs are concealed under cryptic names, and without guidance, they cannot be obtained. The *Baopuzi* records this. What the Master speaks of here refers precisely to this.)

Yet I have heard that what Master Sanfeng practiced in his early years was transmitted from Patriarch Xu of Jingyang. His method employed medicinal substances as catalysts to attract the qi of Qian and the qi of Kun, thereby achieving the transmutation of base metals into gold. Thus, his furnace was no ordinary furnace, nor his tripod a mere tripod. The very ground where he stood became the site of his practice, leaving no visible trace of furnace or tripod. The adepts of Mount Guye all mastered this art. When the qi arrived, it was as if lightning flashed and thunder roared; once the process was complete, these common clay dishes would instantly turn to gold or silver. The gold thus produced could endure for ten thousand years without the slightest alteration. My own ancestor, Master Chunmei of Mount Wanshou, also pursued this practice during the reigns of Emperor Huizong and Emperor Qinzong of the Northern Song. The record of this is found in *The Three Mountains Studio Records* by Han Jichou.

This is the Dao, not mere technique. My teacher, Master Taixu, received it from Patriarch Li of Nidan, yet he feared its improper use. To employ it recklessly would invite celestial censure, as the cautionary example of Jingyang’s disciples shows. As for the methods described in the *Baopuzi*, they pertain to medicinal alchemy and have misled people for five hundred years. Those of noble aspiration should take heed. Even Patriarch Lü did not practice it, and my teacher, compelled by wisdom, destroyed what he had received. How compassionate! How compassionate!

Nevertheless, I have witnessed even more with my own eyes and ears. To remain silent would be to betray my good friend, Feng Jun Yunbiao. Feng, a native of Panyu, observed my extravagant nature and said: “With your profligate spending, your family will surely decline, yet your reckless temperament will remain unchanged. You will inevitably fall into the snares of Daoist trickery and never repent.” I pressed him earnestly, and at last, he sighed and said: “There exists a method for transmuting base metals into gold—do you know of it?” I replied: “It is the supreme Dao, not mere technique, though it is beyond the capacity of ordinary men.” He said: “What I know is a medicinal method, though not the one practiced in China. It was transmitted from the Eastern and Western Oceans, and many Daoist adepts in Fujian and Guangdong are familiar with it. I learned it from a Daoist and later verified it with the Dutch tribute envoy. It works unfailingly: one can carry a hundredweight of gold or silver and travel alone for thousands of miles—it is a matter of extracting the *hun* while discarding the *po*. Its origin lies with divine beings who practiced it to aid those in distress, but now it has been perverted by wicked men to amass wealth.

Now, there are five metals, each possessing *hun* and *po*. With eight ounces of the elixir, one can extract roughly two ounces of the golden *hun*. The difficulty of extraction varies: gold is harder than silver, silver harder than copper, copper harder than iron, and iron harder than lead. The method for iron is not practiced in China, so the metals I currently work with are only gold and silver. Then he had me take ten ounces of silver and place them in a Guangzhou crucible to be melted. He covered it with pine resin, and once the flames subsided and it cooled, the metal appeared dull and white. When broken, it was extremely brittle and light. He said: ‘This is the remaining *po*.’ He then placed it back in the crucible and fired it intensely, but it would not melt. He covered it again with pine resin, added saltpeter and sulfur, and a sound like distant thunder arose. He said: ‘It is ready.’ When cooled and examined, it gleamed brilliantly. We weighed it and found it had transmuted into gold, equal in weight to the original silver. He lamented: ‘What a pity! Had we added the *po* of lead, it could have gained another two ounces in weight.’ He then returned it to the crucible, covered it as before, and once the flames died, it reverted to a white substance, its weight unchanged. Laughing heartily, he said: ‘How is it now? Behold the marvel of this medicinal method! All those flying tripods and exploding furnaces are merely extracting the *hun*. From this day forth, Master, you need not fall prey to such techniques.’

Having witnessed this, I recorded it carefully in my heart. Now that Master Sanfeng has mentioned such matters, I set it down here to share with my fellow practitioners.

[Another account states: The Yellow Emperor cast nine tripods and thereby attained the Dao. Some claim that nine men are required to operate the tripod. I myself have attempted this with five or seven tripods, yet achieved nothing. Moreover, the moment a thought arises in the mind, primordial purity scatters. Once the primordial is lost, even if the acquired remains, what benefit is there to body and mind? It merely strengthens the four great elements. Such ignorant fools know nothing of the marvel that heaven, though silent, brings forth the four seasons and all things. The workings of the human body mirror those of heaven and earth, yet men do not understand the clarity of heaven or the tranquility of earth. How can they not know what governs creation? If one can take clarity and stillness as the essence, stability as the foundation, the celestial mind as the master, and the primordial spirit as the function, harmonizing the three *thieves*, returning to celestial truth, restoring life, and returning to the root—what hinders one from attaining the state of the sages?

[Note: The character *thief* here should be interpreted according to the *Three August Ones’ Character-Splitting Formula*. *Thief* (盗) is composed of *object* (物) next to *vessel* (皿), signifying the act of concealing and guarding.]

As for the matter of the *ding*-vessel, even if one gains something from it, it amounts to nothing more than curing illness and prolonging life. Otherwise, it brings harm without benefit. The practices of immortals and buddhas are never, never like this—there is absolutely no such principle. Why? Because it loses the formless and scatters the bodiless, thus failing to transcend the realm of the myriad things’ tangible forms.

Nowadays, many speak of "the paired sevens of the White Tiger," using fourteen *ding*-vessels. Alas! Do they not know that the two sevens, when gathered to assist and uphold a person, are the marvel of "treading celestial radiance, breathing to nurture purity," as the classics say? Or that enlightenment comes through flowers and wine? All cling to these as *ding*-vessels. Yet do they not understand the metaphor of the jade bud blooming at the full moon and the golden flower withering at the waning moon? Or the teaching that between *Kun* and *Fu*, one attains the constancy of prior and posterior heaven, ever in a state like drunkenness?

The immortals also say, "Every household possesses it." What is the use of male and female *ding*-vessels? This is to know how to harmonize with the world’s dust while accumulating lead in the marketplace, employing both method and resources, so that the great function may manifest. Without encountering a true teacher, all mistakenly take the union of man and woman as the *ding*-vessel—how lamentable!

Those of karmic affinity who meet a true teacher and quietly gather and refine will obtain the Golden Elixir effortlessly. Fellow seekers should repeatedly ponder this text and not be misled by the blind.

A Postscript to the Portrait of the True Man Zhang Sanfeng

The Master Sanfeng, surnamed Zhang and named Junbao, styled Quanyī, was born with extraordinary qualities. When discussing the Three Teachings and their texts with others, his words flowed like the surging Yangtze and Yellow River. His teachings invariably exhorted the world to loyalty, filial piety, benevolence, and righteousness.

Our Grand Progenitor, the Gao Emperor, dispatched the high Daoist of Sanshan to seek him throughout the realm, yet he never arrived. When the Taizong Emperor ascended the throne, envoys were sent bearing a letter addressed: "To the True Immortal Zhang Sanfeng." Later, the Supervising Secretary of the Ministry of Rites, Hu Fen; the Daoist Registrar, Ren Yiyu; and the Commander of Mangzhou Guard, Yang Yongwang, were all dispatched to search far and wide, but he was never found. A special edict was issued to Zhang Biyun of the Orthodox Unity School, commanding him to build a palace on Mount Wudang to await his coming.

During the Tianshun reign, he was posthumously honored as the True Man of Penetrating Mystery and Manifest Transformation, and a decree of investiture was bestowed. The attendant standing by Cui Lake was none other than the Master’s eminent disciple.

His works include *Records of Extraordinary Communications*, *Annals of the Twin Sophoras*, and other writings. Some have mistakenly written "Sanfeng" as "Sanfeng" (Three Peaks), but this is incorrect. *Three Peaks* is the title of an ancient text, unattributed to any author, and pertains to peripheral arts—how could the Master have deigned to adopt it as his sobriquet?

This postscript appears after the portrait of the True Man in the *Collected Mystical Discourses*. It is unclear who authored it. Here it is recorded to preserve its original form.

The world mistakenly identifies the "Three Peaks" arts of *cai-zhan* (yin-yang cultivation) as the Master’s teachings, unaware that the "Three Peaks" in *cai-zhan* refer to the woman’s mouth, breasts, and yin orifice, whereas the Master’s sobriquet is "Three Abundances" (*Sanfeng*). *Feng* signifies "abundant spirit"; the term *sanfeng* denotes the primordial essence of the Three Powers, where the resonance of yin and yang happens to align. Moreover, the Master lived in the early Ming, yet as early as the *Stone Casket Record* of Zhengyang, there were already expositions on the "Three Peaks" method of controlling women. Daoist immortals like Daoguang, Niwan, and Yuchan had long since repudiated the "Three Peaks" *cai-zhan* arts centuries prior—how could such heterodox practices be attributed to the Master, who had not yet been born? Some claim the Master unfortunately adopted the name "Three Peaks" himself. I contend that the Master would never have deliberately chosen a sobriquet coinciding with the title of a heterodox text. This postscript has already made this clear.

In his self-authored *Direct Pointers to Dispelling Doubts* and his autobiographical account, the Master’s own words should suffice to dispel the misconceptions of worldly transmission. Yet why do people still cling obstinately to their delusions?

*—From the Complete Mystical Discourses, by the True Man Zhang Sanfeng, collated and annotated by Min Yide of Jingaishan*

Zhang Sanfeng said: The Dao resides in the Center—nothing more. Thus, the Confucians speak of "attaining the Center," Daoists of "guarding the Center," and Buddhists of the "emptiness of the Center." As for the "Center" in Internal Alchemy, it is the aperture within the aperture—the true Center. I lament that people fail to recognize the Center: some seek it in the Nine Palaces, calling it *Niwan*, yet do not find it; others seek it an inch and three-tenths below the navel, calling it the *Dantian*, yet do not find it; still others measure eight inches and four-tenths between heart and navel, taking the midpoint of one inch and two-tenths as the Center, or search between the kidneys, opposite the navel wheel, yet do not find it.

Seeking it through form, they cannot grasp it. Then, reversing their approach, they name it the *Mysterious Pass* or the *Mysterious Transformation*, as if it were an empty valley beyond form—yet even this eludes them. Seeking it through formlessness, they still cannot grasp it. Reversing their approach once more, they speak of "non-being yet not clinging to non-being, being yet not clinging to being"—is this not the realm beyond being and non-being, unattached to either? Such wisdom surpasses even Yan [Hui] and Min [Sun], and true attainment defies forced conjecture.

Now I dare to break the taboo and speak of it—not by choice, but of necessity.

Herein lies the reason: in this era, many immortals descend to be born among mortals to save the world. Some take office, others become scholars, farmers, artisans, merchants, Daoists, or Buddhists. Thus, I compose this treatise to summon and guide them, that they may know how to save the world, return to the heavens above, and not fall into the dusty realm—this is my heart’s intent. The illustrations and explanations follow.

The *Outer Landscape* refers to externalizing the body and making it empty and vast, first completing *xing* (nature). As Zhang Sanfeng said: "The Buddhists complete *xing* by maintaining purity, so the Great Void is the self—first empty the body. Once the body is empty, heaven and earth are also empty; when heaven and earth are empty, the Great Void is also empty. When emptiness is emptied of itself, this is true emptiness." He also said: "Non-being beyond non-being emerges from heaven and earth, and one embodies this non-being beyond non-being by externalizing the void."

The *Inner Landscape* refers to internalizing the body and practicing *taixi* (embryonic breathing), first completing *ming* (life). As Zhang Sanfeng said: "The embryo grows through breath, and breath abides through the embryo. The aperture within the aperture is the true place where immortals’ long-abiding breath and embryo reside." Though heaven and earth are vast, they are but one embryo, and the revolutions of the sun and moon, the turning of the Dipper’s handle—these are the true breath. Have you not observed the books of the Three Teachings? The *Book of Changes* says, *"To preserve and sustain one’s nature is the gateway to the Dao and virtue."* The *Daodejing* says, *"Mysterious and again mysterious—this is the gateway to all wonders."* The *Sutra of Bequeathed Teachings* says, *"Control it in one place, and nothing will be left undone."* All these are direct pointers. When I read without obstruction, I know that the sage and the commoner share the same *qi*, and I am not misled by the blind. Sweeping aside side doors, I reorder the mind’s monkey, rekindle my resolve, humble my heart, lower my intentions, endure demons and hardships, seek a radiant teacher with diligence, and exhaustively pursue the origin of receiving *qi*.

This origin is the primordial ancestral *qi* of pre-heaven. This *qi* contains a speck of true yin and true yang, born before heaven and earth, at the inception of the primordial chaos. This luminous, millet-grain pearl of awareness hangs in the midst of utmost emptiness and perfect correctness, radiant and unbounded. Yet those who have not awakened to its meaning resemble the drunk—every step they take away from it leads to side doors. (Master Shen notes: "The millet-grain pearl is *wu* earth. According to the *Luoshu* numbers, metal, wood, water, and fire occupy the eight directions, while only *wu* and *ji* earth reside in the midst of emptiness—hence, the midst of utmost emptiness and correctness.")

This luminous pearl, suspended in emptiness, encompasses all phenomena and gives rise to all things—all are born of this ⊙. In Daoism, this is called true lead and true mercury; once attained, it is attained forever. Do not cling to images of qian and kun, the sun and moon, or male and female. Instead, establish the furnace and tripod within and without the body. Refine the self and uphold the heart; when principle is illuminated and *xing* is seen, gather the fire and ignite it. Within a single *shichen* (two-hour period), a millet-grain of the mysterious pearl appears above the winding river. The moment it enters the mouth of the knife-and-house, in an instant, one aperture opens and a hundred apertures open with it. Fire spreads through the four limbs, and the entire body’s sinews, bones, blood, and flesh transform into *qi*, resembling external mercury. At this stage, a hundred days of firing effort are required to attain numinous subtlety. Once attained, it is attained forever—no regression, abiding in the world while preserving form, refining spirit to return to emptiness, and uniting with the Dao.

In Buddhism, this ⊙ is called true emptiness and true suchness, the awakened nature. If one knows the precise method of application, refining demons to see *xing*, in a moment’s effort, the true fire of *samadhi* arises, returning to the origin and restoring wholeness. All is perceived as one, heaven and earth are emptied, rosy clouds radiate in myriad paths, the five eyes and six penetrations are achieved, and the indestructible vajra body is forged—completing the mechanism even ghosts and spirits cannot fathom.

In Confucianism, this ⊙ is the Supreme Ultimate born of Non-Ultimate. Considering the external heaven and earth: the Non-Ultimate is the encompassing boundary of heaven and earth, before the division of sun and moon, when the four directions and above and below were indistinguishable—a single, murky chaos like yin mist or water. When the time of *qi* arrived and *qi* filled to the point of mutual excitation, the Supreme Ultimate was born. The Supreme Ultimate is the sun and moon; one must model oneself after heaven and earth, not seek to extract the sun and moon of heaven and earth. Once the sun and moon are born, heaven and earth separate. The clear *qi* ascends to become heaven, a vast emptiness where all deities are the luminous radiance of pure *qi*; the turbid *qi* descends to become earth, where mountains, rivers, and people all reside below. The five grains and all myriad things, though born on earth, depend on heaven’s *qi* to come into being. Heaven’s clear *qi* is pure yang; earth’s turbid *qi* is pure yin. Yet dew descends from heaven—yang can generate yin; the myriad things arise from earth—yin can generate yang. Heaven and earth are a vast, boundless, and inexhaustible repository.

The stars and deities of heaven move and turn each in their proper place; the myriad things on earth follow the four seasons and eight solar terms, all arising from emptiness. The sun and moon are the essence of heaven, illuminating the thirty-three heavens above and the nine springs of the Yellow Springs below. They revolve from east to west, ascend and descend, and bring the alternation of cold and warmth. The sun is a body of pure yang, containing a speck of true yin essence—belonging to the Green Dragon, the Maiden, *jia* wood, mercury, the Golden Crow, and the three *hun*. This is the external other. The moon is a body of pure yin, containing a speck of true yang *qi*—belonging to the White Tiger, the Infant, *geng* metal, cinnabar, the Jade Hare, and the seven *po*. This is the internal self.

The creation of the human body mirrors heaven and earth, so the human body also possesses a true sun and moon. The Dao is near at hand, yet people seek it afar. The three *hun* belong to *xing*, and *xing* resides at the edge of heaven; the seven *po* belong to *ming*, and *ming* lies at the bottom of the sea.

When inner and outer communicate, the two words "nature" and "destiny" suffice to resolve the myriad volumes. Nature belongs to spirit and is yin; destiny belongs to *qi* and is yang—thus it is said, "One yin, one yang: this is called the Dao." Yet if one does not recognize that true yin, how can one know this speck of true yang *qi*? Scholars today not only fail to know true yang but also remain ignorant of true yin. If one knew true yin, true yang would naturally be known as well. Without encountering a true teacher, one wastes effort in conjecture—even if the Dao abides in heaven and earth, heaven and earth themselves do not know it.

Scholars must delve into the wondrous apertures of the three powers—heaven, earth, and humanity—within the body, and the true workings of yin and yang within and without. If the essential point is not grasped, upon seeing the varied names in books, one will lack certainty, cling to side doors, and be unable to discern the principle. Failing to fathom the principle, the heart remains unillumined; with the heart unillumined, the celestial nature cannot shine like the bright moon. If one cannot see nature, how can one know destiny?

Alas! The alchemical classics lack oral transmission—where then can one conceive the numinous embryo?

**External.**
*Primordial true yang.*
⊙ This diagram depicts the inner and outer workings of the body, called the "aperture that communicates with heaven," the "elixir-smelting furnace," the "path that evades life and death," the "place of birth," the state "before father and mother were born," where the five phases do not reach. That speck of true yang lies hidden in the secret recesses of the four great form-mountains—this subtle workings is profound beyond profundity. This luminous treasure-pearl within the body shares the same substance as the external heaven and earth and the sun and moon; it is the ancestral *qi* of the entire body. Today, the true parents are revealed—tomorrow, one need not fear death or life. This is the compassionate teaching of the Most High, the essence of the *Huangting Jing*'s "Outer Landscape."

**Central.**
*Within the body.*

This diagram reveals the workings that give birth to heaven and earth—here, the sword is forged as yin and yang, the medicine discerned as old or tender. All is complete within it, establishing heaven and earth without departing from this center. The karmic causes of ten thousand kalpas depend on correct transmission, for the celestial *qi* descends without reaching earth, and the terrestrial *qi* ascends without reaching heaven, eternally suspended in emptiness. This principle is most difficult to clarify, hence the saying: *"The aperture between them few know—it must be transmitted directly by a clear teacher."* Yet the union of Qian and Kun, the intercourse of Kan and Li, all occur here.

**Within.**
*Life-Master of the Sea-Bottom.*

This diagram depicts the numinous tortoise of the golden essence at the sea-bottom, the *dui*-metal of the other household within our body, the life-master of *wu*-earth. All the hundred vessels, the five viscera and six bowels, depend entirely on this entity for governance. Moreover, attaining immortality or buddhahood, transcending life and death—all rely on the arrangement of this cavity. Truly, it is the place of life’s firmness, the method of life’s nurturance, where no illness arises. It is the root and stem of the ten thousand *qi*, the Great Ultimate within the body, the essence of the Most High’s compassionate teaching, the *"Inner Landscape"* of the *Huangting Jing*.

The three talents of heaven, earth, and humanity are truly spoken of in terms of one’s own body. Viewed from the posterior heaven, there are images and directions within the body; but when investigated from the prior heaven, it is the thing that generates heaven, earth, humans, and beings—formless and directionless. The immortals say: *"Without the posterior heaven, the prior heaven cannot be gathered; without the prior heaven, the posterior heaven cannot transform."* This is the three true workings of heaven, earth, and humanity within and without the self—three true crucibles and tripods—belonging to the wondrous dharma of the Three Teachings and Three Vehicles. It embodies the three talents of heaven, earth, and humanity beyond the body, and the scriptures of the Three Teachings beyond the world. These five phases within the five phases of the human being all reside in nature and life—how could one seek them elsewhere? As the *Wuzhen Pian* states: *"Three, five, and one—three characters—through the ages, those who truly understand are rare."* What I speak is no boast. Even setting aside the subtle intricacies of fire-times and gathering, merely the three five phases—among a million people, not one knows them. If one understands the mutual "stealing" of the three talents, returning to this root, restoring this origin, transmitting essence and sending spirit, stealing essence and exchanging *qi*, inverting and gathering—if one dares to undertake this, attaining immortality or buddhahood is not difficult.

For all who study cultivation, first thoroughly investigate the true crucibles and tripods within and without the body. If one does not recognize the true crucibles and tripods within and without, there is nowhere to begin. Once the locations of the crucible and tripod within and without are known, along with the principles of yin and yang’s coming and going, then thoroughly investigate the true lead and true mercury, and the times when the inner and outer medicines arise—only then can one proceed with firing and cultivation. If one does not know the medicinal materials within and without one’s body, what is to be smelted in the crucible and tripod?

**Without.**
*True Lead and True Mercury.*

This aperture is the true crucible and tripod within and without the self. Here, the nine-yang tripod is established, the wisdom-sword is forged to determine the timing, the passes are opened to gather the medicine, mercury returns within cinnabar, gathering and bathing are performed, water and fire achieve balance, and emptiness is maintained to nurture the void. All occurs within this aperture, which contains a speck of true cinnabar mercury, clearly present in the neither-inner-nor-outer place within the body—unknown to ten thousand people. Apart from this, all is blind cultivation and reckless refinement. This is the five phases outside the self, the outer crucible and tripod, the outer workings of creation—precisely the nine-yang tripod cast by the Yellow Emperor.

**Center.**
*Cauldron of Kun-Earth.*

This aperture is precisely where gathering coalesces into the embryo, where heaven, earth, beings, wind, clouds, thunder, and rain are born—all within the central palace’s true position. This is the divine chamber and treasure-tripod, producing the inner and outer two medicines, forging the yin and yang two swords, drawing lead and adding mercury, awaiting the moment to transmute the elixir-medicine. Hence, *"The aperture between them few know."*

**Within.**
*Life-Master Below the Navel.*

This aperture is the root of initiating work, the bridge to attaining the Dao. Here, the crucible and tripod are established within, water and fire are refined, method and resources are complete, spirit and *qi* are whole, and the seven upper apertures radiate light—only then is the true time at hand. Only then can one gather the medicine from the outer crucible and tripod of the self to pair with the yin and yang within the body. All depends on this cavity. When spirit is harmonized to perfection, the ten thousand spirits obey, the stars revolve and the Dipper turns—only then can one seize the celestial mechanisms beyond.

The upper aperture is a body of pure yang, containing a speck of true yin essence—this is the other household’s entity within my body, belonging to the external within the internal, the luminous point between the two kidneys that manifests externally, hence the metaphor for "him." The lower aperture is a body of pure yin, concealing a speck of true yang *qi*—this is my household’s entity within my body, belonging to the internal, the entity of the Qian palace leaking into the Kun position, hence the metaphor for "me." Within the upper aperture is the female body, without is the male; within the lower aperture is the male body, without is the female—thus the immortals often use the metaphors of male and female, self and other. Yet the central aperture is the Central Palace, the Yellow Dame’s matchmaking abode. Only by inverting and uniting here can one attain sagehood.

The treasure of life comes from outside one’s own body, yet it is still the entity of one’s own Kun position—existing within my dharma-body and physical body as the other household. Thus the immortals say: *"Gathering does not depart from one’s own original spirit."* Scholars of the world, lacking correct transmission, have nowhere to begin—clinging to the self is wrong, departing from the self is also wrong. Who knows that this speck of original yang, bright and clear, resides in the profound heights within the self, hidden in the secret place neither inner nor outer? Inner and outer are connected by a single *qi*—a thousand-year-old secret never transmitted.

Yet the human body already possesses two true workings, identical in substance to the external heaven, earth, sun, and moon, without the slightest deviation. Heaven and earth are the greatest of the ten thousand things, and humans are the most numinous among them.

Heaven and earth are but a great human, while the human is but a small heaven and earth—thus the workings of the human body mirror those of heaven and earth. Who among us awakens to the fact that every person possesses a celestial aperture, a medicine of immortality, a crucible for refining the elixir, a ladder to ascend to heaven, and a truth they themselves do not recognize? Yet no one believes in the formula for immortality, no one trusts the path of ascending to heaven in broad daylight, and all willingly submit to death—how lamentable, how grievous!

In refining the Great Return Elixir, one must first replenish deficiency. Only when the marrow is full can one proceed to refine the Golden Liquor Great Return Elixir. The initial practice begins by gathering the true yin within the upper aperture’s yang and drawing it into the inner golden crucible of the *qi*-sea, where it unites with the kidney meridian. This true yin within yang is none other than one’s original spirit in its true form, externally corresponding to the three *hun*; the true yang within the lower aperture’s yin is the primordial *qi* of the body, corresponding to the seven *po*. When these two *qi* meet in sequence, Kan and Li naturally merge, *hun* and *po* blend, spirit congeals and *qi* coalesces, and fetal breathing stabilizes. Each day, like the intimacy of husband and wife, the joy is beyond compare—yet one must not force it. When water and fire achieve balance, they circulate through the four limbs like an active external flame. Maintaining equilibrium between water and fire constitutes the minor celestial cycle’s firing process. Through harmonious steaming, the true breath in the throat reverses its flow back to the original sea, and the lower kidney naturally enters within. True fire then surges into the four limbs, leaving the body supple and the bliss boundless. Within the abdomen, it is as if a living dragon coils and ascends, descending in transformations of dozens of kinds. The infant boy and maiden girl naturally unite—this is the stage of gathering yang to supplement yin, laying the foundation and refining the self.

To refine the Golden Liquor Great Return Elixir, one must amass both inner and outer dharmic wealth, abiding in perpetual ease, luminous day and night—this is the Dao of longevity and enduring vision. Ordinary people rely entirely on the five grains to sustain life; if they go without food for several days, their *qi* dissipates and they die. When a person ages, the lower origin becomes deficient, the marrow hollows, and the body can no longer withstand the *qi* of the five grains—thus the five grains both nourish and kill. If one masters the internal balance of water and fire, causing *qi* and blood to flow countercurrent, the five viscera harmonize, the spleen and stomach open freely, and food entering the abdomen transforms into *qi*, generating essence and spirit.

Once the celestial mechanism’s initial practice is grasped, one must wait until the marrow is full, the abdomen and navel swollen like a pregnant woman’s—though this is not the form of a physical fetus, but rather *qi* full, essence full, and spirit full. When all three are complete, true fire forges and refines, regulating spirit and cultivating *qi*. For the great man, this is the time when merit is achieved and fame is secured.

I now urge the world’s people: seek diligently, inquire earnestly, and break through the celestial mechanisms within and without. Begin practice swiftly, refine the self, and await the moment. When the time arrives, choose a secluded place and enter the chamber to refine this Dragon-Tiger Great Elixir. It must be a quiet retreat where no rooster crows nor dog barks, with only like-minded companions present—no idle or unrelated persons may approach, lest the spirit be startled. The immortals speak of harmonizing with the world, yet I speak of seclusion—why? To refine the self amid the mundane and nurture *qi* in the mountains and forests.

The Golden Liquor Return Elixir is the Dao of transcending the ordinary and entering sagehood, incomparable to other pursuits. One must be unstained by a single speck of dust, free from all distractions, cutting all ties as if with a single blade, without the slightest attachment, forever a stranger in this land, never wavering in resolve. Only with such determination is one a true renunciate. Upon entering the chamber, hold emptiness and refine the spirit, guard the void and nurture *qi*, until essence and blood are abundant, sinews and bones supple, the body free of wrinkles like a spider’s, the seven upper apertures radiating light, luminous day and night, and the heart as vast as the great void—only then is the time ripe to seek immortality.

One must concentrate single-mindedly, cultivating the spirit until it is pure and malleable, capable of transformation at will. When the stars revolve and the Dipper turns, one may change form as desired—only then, with *qi* full and spirit complete, dharmic wealth amassed, can one refine the Great Elixir and become a true alchemist. Once the practice is underway, the seven apertures radiate light, the three yang open in harmony, the spirit-sword takes form, and one rides the current, fanning the flames with the wind. When the first yang arises within, one may seize the celestial mechanism without, begin the work of opening the gates, and gather the external golden elixir of the body, marrying the Dragon to the Tiger as husband and wife.

If one succeeds in gathering and assembling, the golden youth from the sea’s depths is drawn up in stillness. Then, opening the spine and penetrating the mud-pill palace, it descends into the crystal palace to unite with the wood-mercury. In less than half a day, the gathering is complete, true fire surges into the four limbs, and the body’s bones and flesh feel as if scorched by fire or sliced by a blade—this is the most difficult to endure. Even the bravest, at this point, lose all composure. One must guard against danger, bathe body and mind, and balance water and fire. In an instant, the entire body crackles like roasting beans, all pores burst open, and the *qi* and blood throughout the body take form and speak, clamoring together upon the flesh.

Beneath the tongue lie two cavities: the left is the Elixir Well, the right the Sweet Spring, known as the Proper Gushing Cavity. When the bone meridians open in unison, the lower kidney’s water surges to the mouth, and one swallows it hastily—its flavor is extraordinary, unlike even the sweetest sugar. After thirty hours—two and a half days—the frenzied water is exhausted, and one awaits the descent of the heavenly water. At this precise moment, a single drop of true lead descends, cool as ice flakes, and a drop of true mercury immediately rises to meet it.

After the gathering and clustering, the entire body becomes serene and resounding, like the thunder of a thousand war drums or the roar of a million thunderclaps—this is the transformation of the *qi* and blood throughout the hundred meridians. Do not be alarmed. Simply tread the Dipper’s steps, wield the sword, and grasp the seal. Here lies the most perilous point: three revolutions and nine turns, summoning the master and invoking the generals. With such vigilance, in the emptiness, one may witness dragons and tigers intertwining, Heaven and Earth in harmony, the sun and moon conjoined in their palaces, and all manner of immortal realms manifesting. Yet one must not mistake these for reality, lest external evil take hold. Only after true lead merges with mercury, three days later, does the Great Medicine arise.

At this moment of the two forces locked in battle, had I not personally revealed this secret, nine out of ten would have been frightened to death. Fear in the heart invites demonic obstructions. Once one refines the primordial *yang* and the physical form dissolves into spirit, if it returns to harm the self, though it takes shape, it is but a yin spirit. Yin spirits are most cunning in transformation, capable of assuming countless forms to wreak havoc, and unwilling to submit to goodness. As the saying goes: *"Only when you master the six penetrations can you speak of life and death; without them, do not dream of subduing spirits."* If one cannot subdue spirits, how can one attain the Dao? If spirits remain unseen, how can they cause harm?

After another thirty hours—two and a half days—*qi* flows unimpeded, filling to its utmost. Suddenly, with vibrant clarity, the radiant pearl of the sun is borne forth, shedding its husk and entering the mouth. A million dragon spirits are struck with awe. This is the primordial seed, the true elixir. Only upon ingestion does one realize: *"My fate is mine to command, not Heaven’s."* The immortals say: *"Only through this great death does one truly live,"* and *"One battle settles all under Heaven."* At this stage, true harmony between Heaven and Earth, the union of sun and moon, is finally achieved.

When the medicine of true *yang* arrives, the fire of the microcosmic orbit ignites in an instant. The skeletal frame melts into a mass of flesh and mud, and the *yang* spirit departs the body, unbound and free. With single-minded focus, one abides in emptiness and guards the void, following the spirit’s transformations. All things under Heaven are born of Heaven and Earth, and thus all spirits pay homage and submit. Weary of dwelling in the dusty world, one roams carefree in Penglai, attended by three thousand jade maidens, feasting daily at the Peach Banquet, drinking immortal wine, wearing immortal flowers, intoxicated in body and soul. The tortoise and serpent at the ocean’s depths naturally coil together—only then is the true method of the Five Dragons’ Great Hibernation achieved.

After a hundred days of refinement, the Mysterious Pass opens of its own accord, the infant appears in form, the tortoise and serpent emerge, and the ten thousand spirits obey command. Only then is the inversion of true lead and true mercury complete. The entire body radiates purple mist and beams of light, auspicious *qi* in a thousand strands, a red glow enveloping the form. At this stage, the adept’s mouth finally obtains the dry mercury.

After six months of refinement, the body resembles silver paste, the blood transforms into white nectar, and the entire being exudes a fragrance that lingers. The breath from the mouth forms clouds. This is the completion of the numinous elixir—ingested, it grants immortality, and can even revive the dead.

After ten months, the *yang* spirit departs the body, and one form can multiply into a hundred thousand. After twelve months, one seizes the full measure of Heaven and Earth, the *yang* spirit is perfected, and the eighty-four thousand yin spirits shed from the body. One walks without casting a shadow in the sun or moon, passes through metal and stone unimpeded, drowns not in water nor burns in fire. Blades find no purchase, spirits cannot fathom one’s designs, and transformations are boundless—one has become a true person.

The *qi* and vitality of the entire body are now true medicine. A chicken that consumes it becomes a phoenix, a horse that eats it becomes a dragon, and a person who ingests it becomes an immortal. This principle is even beyond the comprehension of spirits. Without having witnessed or experienced it, who would believe such words?

The Great Medicine of the golden elixir is a work of creation and transformation, three revolutions and nine turns, with fire timing so subtle. The oral instructions for gathering and clustering lie within the span of five to seven days, overturning Heaven and Earth entirely—all naturally so. Though natural, one must understand the method of embodying Heaven and Earth’s creation to succeed. Yet this does not mean one must rely on Heaven, Earth, sun, or moon to attain the Dao.

The matter of the Great Medicine entering the mouth must be personally practiced, witnessed, and tested to reach the state of spontaneity. Though the work spans a year, the subtle fire timing lies within a hundred days, and the perilous struggles of movement and stillness occur within ninety days. Through internal and external gathering, in an instant one becomes serene, the sacred embryo is completed, and a pearl the size of a millet grain is produced. Swallowed into the abdomen, the fire of the microcosmic orbit ignites, and the bones are transmuted. One need only abide in emptiness and nurture the void, and all will unfold naturally.

If one truly encounters an enlightened teacher who imparts the true transmission, one must first refine the self amidst the mundane, accumulate lead in the marketplace, gather years into months, days into hours, and hours into moments. Within the great stillness, all occurs in a single instant—no more than half an hour—overturning the celestial mechanism entirely. After ten months of firing, embodying the natural method of Heaven and Earth, if one cannot seek life within death, how can one escape the three calamities and eight difficulties?

Scholars of great learning, keen and wise, who hear one thing and understand ten, who can expound and discourse on the Three Teachings and their scriptures, merely clarify the principles of nature and the meanings of words. Yet regarding the creation of the golden elixir, the celestial mechanism of the Great Dao, and the two true secrets of internal and external alchemy—how can they comprehend? If one truly meets a perfected being who transmits the true teaching, one will at once exhaust principle and fulfill nature, awakening like water returning to the sea. All alchemical texts, when examined, reveal the Dao in every line. The alchemical texts of the masters of old were not idly spoken—every word, every character, holds meaning. It is only that people fail to awaken.

For instance, the phrase *"swallowing the golden elixir into the belly"*—those who fail to grasp its essence mistake it as mere talk of the mouth and stomach. How could they fathom the wondrous aperture that draws in the profound mysteries of the Western River? When texts speak of heaven and earth, sun and moon, or male and female, these are but wild guesses and reckless conjectures. Clinging to heterodox sounds and appearances, they repel others from a thousand miles away, refusing to humble themselves before the wise. In the end, they never awaken, instead nitpicking and slandering the enlightened—how could they ever attain the true method? They become objects of universal disdain among heaven and humanity, seeds of hell indeed. How pitiful! I exhort all in the world: when you encounter a perfected being, never cling to your own views. Instead, approach with an empty mind, seek a true teacher with earnest devotion, and you shall not bring ruin upon yourself.

⊙ This is the *Du Mai* (Governor Vessel).
*Du* means "to govern," for it governs the qi channels of the entire body. It is the primordial yang ancestral qi of the pre-cosmic state, existing before heaven and earth divided, before the body was born—eternal across kalpas, enduring from ancient times to the present without decay.

○ This is the *Ren Mai* (Conception Vessel).
*Ren* means "benevolence," the ceaselessly generative primordial qi. Pure and boundless, round and luminous, radiant and resplendent, bright and dazzling, vibrant and alive—this is the substance that precedes the Supreme Emperor, the ancestor of all spirits, containing all phenomena and giving rise to all things. Buddhists call it the *mani pearl*; Daoists, the *millet-like mysterious pearl*; physicians, the *ever-bubbling elixir pill*, the wondrous medicine of true spirit—truly a secret untransmitted for ages. Yet people today do not understand this principle, nor have they received its transmission, nor do they awaken to it. How could they comprehend the subtlety of the terms *"internal"* and *"external"*? The *Ren* and *Du* vessels are indeed the mystery of pre- and post-heaven, yet the common folk use them daily without knowing it.

The aperture of the *Du Mai* ⊙ is the source of the body’s birth. Before this body existed, this aperture was already present—not an ordinary bodily orifice, but the wondrous aperture of the profound mechanism. This secret is the primordial yang qi, the single point existing before one’s parents were born.

The aperture of the *Ren Mai* ○ is the master of the five viscera, governing both internal and external. If one knows how to invert and gather it, this is the root from which the five viscera arise. Before the five viscera existed, this aperture was already present; before this body was born, this aperture came first. This secret is the method of nurturing life, the root and stem of immortality.

These three true secrets—upper, middle, and lower—if received through proper transmission, enable one to return to the root and restore life, guiding the four qi to return to the lower origin, preventing the dispersal of hun and po, achieving the harmony of water and fire. What illness could then arise? Once the primordial yang is clearly transmitted, even if one encounters the net of the law and cannot escape, or fails to attain the Dao, one may, as a last resort, rouse the life-master at the sea-bottom—the root of the four qi—so that the life-master returns to the primordial qi without dissipation. With a single effortless move, one may abandon this secret and still reemerge to cultivate the Dao. This is the unfathomable mystery beyond the ken of gods and spirits.

When the pre-heaven primordial qi, the millet-like mysterious pearl, is truly transmitted and understood, and one diligently practices it, a sudden great awakening arises. Then the scriptures of the Three Teachings become perfectly clear before one’s eyes, requiring no deliberation, naturally comprehended. In broad terms, the entire body—inside and out, blood and qi—is but the turbid yin dregs of post-heaven. Only the single point of primordial yang in the secret place is pure yang. This true form belongs to the heart, and this heart is the heart of true emptiness, not the fleshy heart of blood and flesh. This true heart is unknown to the multitude, yet within it lies another universe.

I shall now describe the three hearts—internal and external:

**External Heart**　**Heavenly Heart**: ○ This heart is the heart of true emptiness, called the *mysterious pass*, the aperture that communicates with heaven—precisely the true crucible and furnace of the internal and external five agents. All techniques of opening the pass, kindling the fire, pacing the stars, wielding the sword, and holding the seal—through which even gods cannot discern the mechanism—depend entirely on this. One must know the proper method.

**Central Heart**　**Human Heart**: ○ This heart is the central aperture, the dwelling of the *Yellow Dame*. The gathering of internal and external, the timing of observation, all rely on the Yellow Dame. Establishing the furnace and setting up the crucible, refining the internal and external medicines, discerning the old from the young, the true from the false—all emerge from this heart.

**Internal Heart**　**Earthly Heart**: ○ This heart is the life-master at the sea-bottom, the stem of all spirits. In cultivating the Great Vehicle, one must first cultivate the Lesser Vehicle: laying the foundation, refining the self, accumulating the dharma-wealth, preserving the mercury-qi—all depend on this point. One must recognize hardness and softness.

These three hearts, within and without the body, are three secrets. If one can invert heaven and earth, unlock the seamless lock, then a single phrase resolves the ancient Amitābha. These three hearts are the untransmitted secret of ages. Beyond the fleshy heart, there are three true hearts, and these three hearts penetrate the true emptiness of the void. If one understands this true heart, then all phenomena of heaven and earth are contained within this empty heart. This empty heart embraces true yin and true yang, yet the secret of true emptiness is the seamless lock, which ultimately cannot be opened. Where then can one escape birth and death?

The immortals say:
*"The golden needle is easy to obtain,
The jade thread is hardest to thread.
To know the path of birth and death,
Is like tossing a mustard seed into a needle’s eye."*

This metaphor speaks of yin and yang—yin and yang are life and destiny. Who truly understands them? Yet when one awakens for three, five, seven, or twenty-one days, and wishes to preserve life without dying, one must seize the undispersed water, fire, and wind, returning the life-master of the other household to one’s own body. Do not stir the heart—this is the method of immortality.

If one is aged and unable to practice the Dao, yet wishes to turn back, it is like a melon ripening—once the stem falls, all depends on these subtle workings. When the time is known, the life-master from the sea-bottom is aroused, returning to the primordial emptiness of the original nature. Naturally, the hun and po do not scatter, and all is subject to oneself, so one does not go astray.

*Song of the True Dao*
I hold a single oral formula,
Yet sigh that none can hear it told.
Sought throughout the world in vain,
Unfit to speak to all and sundry!
To follow the mundane is mortal,
To reverse it is immortal—
This is the true oral formula.
All else is vain striving,
Mere contortion and pretense.
Master the *Awakening to Reality*,
Seek a teacher to discern it well.
Then some small marvel appears,
A mystery divine and unfathomable.
The marrow of heaven and earth fuses,
Timing and intent must be savored.
One must seek the treasure beneath the earth,
And clearly see the moon above the sky.
Observe the ripeness of the old and young,
Distinguish purity from turbid source.
When wild battle arises,
Let neither ape nor horse grow restless.
When the guest arrives, first be host;
When the host arrives, then be guest.
The Yellow Dame mediates the Dark Maiden,
Their union forges the elixir.
Externally black as lacquer,
Internally white as snow,
Within, radiant with yellow and purple,
Flesh like jade, skin like blood.
Once the five-qi elixir is formed,
The three corpses and yin ghosts perish.
The man of clarity and penetration,
Not the dull, deaf, mute, or clumsy.
The heart must cease all thought,
The mouth must have naught to say.
Use civil means, yet also martial,
Gather in accord with the seasons.
Keep the golden crucible ever warm,
Let the jade furnace never grow hot.
Their union occurs in an instant,
Its nurturing spans ten months.
The man gives birth,
Bearing a guest of the Three Isles.
Swallowing a single pill alive,
Heavenly immortals come to welcome him.
After nine years of merit and practice,
He strides surely toward the Golden Gate.

*Again*
The Dao’s feeling is no common feeling—
Once the mystery is known, it must not be taken lightly.

First lay aside all worldly concerns,
Then delve into the wondrous principles to gain clarity.
Before refining the Returned Elixir, first refine your nature;
Before cultivating the Great Medicine, first cultivate the heart.
When the heart is settled, the elixir’s nature naturally arrives;
When the nature is pure, then the medicinal materials arise.
Thunder rumbles faintly, shaking the empty void,
Yellow Court and purple mist shroud a thousand fathoms deep.
Should you reach this point, do not be startled or afraid—
Only guard the Gate of the Grotto with your original spirit.
Guard the Grotto Gate,
As the cat, mouse, or hare meets the hawk.
Ten thousand scenes are not the true reality—
Only a single red light is the utmost truth.
This red light gives birth to strange phenomena,
Within it, like dust in a sunlit window.
It contains a single point of primordial qi,
Distant as a grape, near as gold.
Seize it with utmost care,
For the slightest thought will lose your celestial truth.
Wait until the first yang returns to the Grotto Palace,
And within your body, the four seasons turn to spring.
A patch of white clouds appears in a glance,
Each rain’s passing brings renewal.
All day long, drifting like a drunkard,
Leisurely guarding only the grotto’s spring.
When the body’s yin essence is entirely stripped away,
It transforms into a mass of pure yang gold.
At this moment, breath ceases as in a minor death,
Forged into one piece—wholly true.
When this work is complete,
Return to the dusty world to accumulate merit.
When merit is fulfilled and deeds are done, the heavenly decree arrives,
The yang spirit emerges, revealing the true numen.
These words must not be spoken to the unworthy—
To lightly reveal them invites thunderous celestial retribution.
I charge my immortal friends and Daoist companions:
Do not lightly discuss this with those who do not comprehend.
Each line here connects to the profound mystery—
Beyond this truth, there is no other truth.
