Gather these brocade verses, seal them tightly,
For one day in your practice, they may seal your heart.
Seal your heart—
Fifty-two lines you must heed.
Should there be falsehood, you will suffer a violent death,
And the Spirit Officials will lash your body to pieces.
*Direct Pointers to Resolve Doubts on the Golden Elixir*

In this world, there exists a class of shallow-rooted, blind individuals who, upon hearing the ancient immortals speak of external yin-yang, external crucibles and furnaces, and external medicinal substances, cling to the delusion that women are the crucible. How pitiful indeed! Such ignorant fools—how could they fathom the profound mysteries of the Great Dao of purity and stillness, which encompasses the Three Bodies and Four Wisdoms, the inner and outer crucibles and furnaces, the inner and outer medicinal substances, and the inner and outer firing times? How could they grasp that all things are complete within me, and the transformations of Heaven and Earth are one with my greatness!

If a person of karmic affinity should encounter a true master, they must first practice the inner returning elixir of jade liquid, refining the self to harmonize with the light, holding fast to nurturing and preserving, turning the light inward to reflect—this is the matter of illuminating the mind and seeing the nature. As for the golden liquid returning elixir, it is the return of emotion to nature, reaching the state of true emptiness, where the great function manifests. The Dragon Girl presents a precious pearl, and only upon its revelation is there an attainment that lasts forever.

At the juncture of *hai* and *zi*, between the belly of *kun*, when the first yang stirs and the work begins, one reaches with the hand to the Moon Grotto and treads with the foot upon the Celestial Root. The returning wind merges and harmonizes—only then does the hundred-day verification of spiritual efficacy arise, and the golden liquid returning elixir completes the great affair of the Five Phases.

Apart from this dual cultivation of nature and life in purity and stillness, all else is but peripheral arts and minor techniques. Within my body, both inner and outer, I have mastered the wondrous methods of establishing the furnace and crucible, the oral instructions for gathering the Five Phases, and the subtleties of medicinal substances and firing times. Yet if one does not understand the laws of emptiness and proceeds to enter the chamber, ingesting the external medicine into the abdomen to initiate the great work and commence the firing, when the practice reaches its most secret point, the ten thousand spirits of emptiness will come to pay homage, and celestial music will play above the crown. This matter is too profound even for gods and spirits to comprehend. It is only because one has not refined the self amidst the dust of the world, has not accumulated lead in the marketplace, and the qi and pulse are not yet fully stabilized, with the foundation not yet complete in three aspects, that although the principle is harmonized, the nature is not yet revealed. Thus, the ten thousand spirits manifest, dangers arise on all sides, the heart and spirit become disoriented, and one cannot take control.

Moreover, without knowledgeable companions outside to guard and protect, one may be startled by sounds and sights, scattering the primordial yang, agitating the crucible and scorching the furnace. The Heart Monkey grows restless, the Intent Horse flees, the spirit does not guard its abode, and the qi does not return to the origin—one falls prey to yin demons. What are yin demons? I shall not elaborate, but later learners will not understand. It is all because the true yang scatters, and yin qi takes control. Day and night, the ghosts and spirits within the body wreak havoc. Whether eyes are open or closed, one hears only the clamor of ghosts and spirits. During the day, it may be bearable, but at night, it is most unbearable—one dare not settle into stillness even for a moment. The life master at the Sea Bottom of the other household, the *dui*-metal’s *wu* earth, overturns the five viscera and hundred pulses, causing blood and qi to surge upward. The entire body is lifted, not touching the ground, leading to the destruction of body and life—a ghostly livelihood.

I temporarily abandoned my previous efforts, following my master’s instructions to conceal myself in the marketplace, accumulating lead amidst the dust of the world, gathering emotions to return to nature, and turning the killing mechanism back to the heart. From youth to old age, Heaven, Earth, and all beings have stolen my celestial authenticity. Now, within the dust and colors of emptiness, I must steal it back and return it to my celestial nature. Only then can the primordial essence, primordial qi, and primordial spirit be restored to wholeness. This depends entirely on extreme emptiness and profound stillness, allowing the myriad things to flourish and each return to its root. When the root returns, the principle harmonizes; when the principle harmonizes, the nature is revealed. The body and mind are greatly stabilized, the Five Phases are gathered, and only then can one proceed to the higher work and complete the Dao.

Many worthy sages of past generations abandoned their practice midway, all because they had not refined the self and held the heart, nor had they returned the metal to nature. Thus, when they obtained the medicine in the second phase and proceeded to the firing in the fourth phase, they did not understand the laws of emptiness, acting with carelessness and recklessness. This is why Master Bai lamented, *"Again, I must carve the joints of the pine and bamboo."*

Who knows that the workings of emptiness are most subtle, most minute, most perilous, and most vicious? If one fails to grasp them firmly, they will surely not spare the practitioner. If a learner can understand the two workings—inner and outer—of the body with perfect clarity, and from there hold fast to nurturing and preserving, eliminating selfishness and restoring celestial principle, then the work of the returning elixir becomes most simple and easy. One may spend all day tending to the yellow blossoms outside the body, awaiting the nectar of the prior and posterior heavens—this is precisely the wondrous truth of *"drinking wine, wearing flowers, and awakening to immortality."*

Yet in the matter of primordial chaos, there must be no intent, no certainty, no rigidity, no self. One must be indifferent to life and death, forgetting both self and others. Spending all day wandering through streets and markets, delighting in the scenery and emotions, sitting idly in brothels and taverns, speaking nonsense—how could this not provoke the astonishment, doubt, laughter, and slander of others? To gather the environment and accumulate lead, employing both method and wealth—how could this not invite the deception and harm of vulgar people?

Thus, one must rely on powerful families in great cities as external protection, perceiving the Dao with a glance while concealing one’s light and hiding one’s traces. As the immortals say, *"If you covet the treasure of Heaven, you must use the wealth of the world."* The great treasure of the Nine Yang Crucible within my body—all beings in the universe, male and female, rely on this single point of yang essence to live and not die. How could there be those who learn the Dao, where men must use women and women must use men? This is wealth corrupting the customs of the world—such actions are known only to beasts and birds!

Alas! When words fail to communicate and delusion persists, how can such people be the kin of immortals and buddhas? If a learner can truly hold fast to nurturing and preserving, not losing their center even in moments of haste, turmoil, or displacement, and then seeks the higher work of ingesting the external medicine into the abdomen, in an instant, they will become profoundly serene. The embryo is transformed, the crucible is exchanged, the entire body dissolves into a single stream of golden light. The great earth becomes empty, and outside the body, another body appears. The yang spirit leaves the form, holding emptiness to nurture the void—this is the Great Hibernation of the Five Dragons.

The Immortals say: "Without the inner elixir’s completion, the outer elixir cannot be achieved."

This means that when one receives the true transmission, one must first accumulate essence and amass qi, gathering both inner and outer resources. When qi is full and spirit complete, the golden light appears, shining brightly day and night. At this moment, the inner elixir is formed, and the symbolic manifestation of the outer elixir emerges from one’s own body.

In studying texts, one must not rigidly follow diagrams. Only when the golden light shines ceaselessly day and night, and the sprouts of medicine arise, may one gather the outer medicine from the body and pair it with the inner yin and yang. Once the golden light enters the mouth and the fire of the celestial cycle ignites, in an instant, profound serenity arises—freedom without hindrance. This is the Great Molting of the Golden Cicada.

Before encountering a true master, one should proceed with humility and caution, accumulating merit and virtue. When faced with demons, do not retreat; when slandered, do not grow angry. Value the Dao and despise wealth. Upon meeting a perfected one, devote oneself wholeheartedly to seeking the true secrets hidden within the body’s inner and outer workings. Suddenly awakening to the true destination, one realizes the saying: "My body is a heaven and earth."

Though this true destination is said to exist without reliance on form, how can the aperture within the aperture be without form? Now, I borrow an analogy to clarify: consider a forked mouth—when its center is full, it opens; when empty, it slackens. The aperture’s ability to open and close is just the same.

At the outset, one must first concentrate the spirit, entering the aperture within the aperture. With each breath returning to the root, the center becomes full, and the embryo grows. The spirit, though born within the aperture, resides in the heart’s palace. I have often called it "the thing that was originally mine, now returned to me."

The aperture within the aperture is the spirit’s chamber, the qi cavity, the Central Yellow. Yellow is the true color of earth, the intent of the above. Thus, the earth of Kan (☵) constantly yearns for Li (☲), and the earth of Li constantly yearns for Kan—this is their inherent nature, and they possess a natural affinity. If one can recognize this affinity and guide it with intent, spirit congeals and qi stabilizes, naturally forming a single golden elixir. It is utterly simple and effortless, without forced contrivance.

This is the mother’s qi subduing the child’s qi, where mother and child qi entwine within the aperture. How could the elixir fail to form?

---

Preface:
The Pure Yang Master vowed to ferry all beings across and has already annotated the *Ninefold Emperor’s Elixir Classic* as a bridge for men’s immortal cultivation. Yet he could not bear to see women of innate roots and long-held Daoist aspirations deprived of true transmission, led astray into deviant paths, and sinking into ghostly realms.

Thus, on the first day of the tenth lunar month in the year *jiwei*, at the Radiant Splendor Tower, moved by the Non-Dual Immortal Maiden, he sincerely expounded the oral transmission of the Queen Mother of the West, originally titled *The Great Golden Elixir Formula for Women*, as received by Lady Wei Huacun. This text has been practiced and transmitted through generations by female immortals such as Wei, Jin, He, Ma, and Fan Feng. Over centuries, true teachings became entangled with errors, distortions compounding distortions. I deeply lament this.

Therefore, I commanded the Non-Dual Immortal Maiden to calmly revise and compile it, continuing the lineage of female immortals. The Immortal Maiden purged the accumulated distortions and edited the text for presentation, revealing its origins and principles with clarity. Now, those who study the Dao have a path to follow!

Respectfully compiled, I have appended *Nine Rules for Women’s Cultivation*, still prefaced with the three characters "Queen Mother of the West," and requested the proclamation of *Nine Precepts for Female Immortals* to purify Daoist conduct. Together, they form ten rules, all to be reverently received in accordance with the august decree of the Jade Pure Divine Mother.

When women’s practice is perfected, the myriad transformations arise within the body. Earth’s virtue upholds Heaven’s, and one may greatly assist in healing the world. On the day of accomplishment, both self and world are fulfilled. By imperial edict of the Three Heavenly Sovereigns, all dragon spirits of the three realms are universally commanded to protect and harmonize. What fortune for creation!

This is an unprecedented encounter since the dawn of time. From now on, not only will virtuous women attain realization, and virtuous mothers achieve the Dao, but all under heaven’s cover, earth’s support, the sun and moon’s illumination, and frost and dew’s descent will rest as steadfast as bedrock—yet it is especially precious for those who personally lead the way.

Immortal Maiden, strive on!

The Dao’s application is boundless, yet its foundation begins with these ten rules. Thus, this preface.

---

The Non-Dual Primordial Sovereign Sun Zhenyi states:
Are there no texts on the female immortal’s elixir in the world? Most are muddled with deviant theories, leading deluded practitioners to force interpretations and deceive both themselves and others. Some even guide others into the realm of lost spirits, spreading calamity far and wide. The Dao’s founder, in profound generosity, merely sighs at their descent into ghostly realms.

Yet I consider: women are bound to one husband for life; once their integrity is lost, it cannot be redeemed. Even if they cultivate, how can they avoid misguided falls? This is how humans and beasts are distinguished. I have long grieved over this!

Fortunately, entrusted by the Dao’s founder to revise and compile, I have carefully collated and refined the text. Following the original *Great Golden Elixir Formula for Women* by the Queen Mother of the West, I supplemented it with *The Mysterious Shadow of the Great Dao, Orally Transmitted by the Jade Pure Divine Mother*, compiling nine rules and presenting them for review.

The Dao is not meant to remain forever hidden. With profound gratitude, I have amended and titled it *The Queen Mother of the West’s Correct Path for Women’s Cultivation*, prefacing it with *The Nine Precepts for Female Immortals*, forming ten rules in total. I have also requested the revelation of its profound secrets, so that women cultivating the Dao may understand: though the earth’s path does not achieve completion, it naturally fulfills its role. Originally, there is the great Dao of assisting in transformation and nurturing life, which one may embody and practice with diligence. Reverently receiving this compassionate approval, it is fitting to transmit it.

From now on, the female lineage will not only avoid deviant paths but will easily ascend to the celestial palaces. As the Dao’s destiny is to be revitalized, I joyfully establish this preface at the Radiant Splendor Tower in Wulin, to mark this felicitous occasion.

A Preface by Sun Zhenyi, Orthodox Disciple of the Complete Perfection Tradition, with One Hundred Bows.

*The Correct Path for Women’s Cultivation: Ten Precepts*
Revised and Retitled by Patriarch Lü; Supplemented and Compiled by Perfected Master Sun; Annotated by Disciple Min Yide, Student of the Great Master Shen of the Grand Void

It is said that in women’s cultivation, one must first receive the Nine Precepts.

The precepts state: Unwavering practice yields great benefit; when the fruits of the precepts are perfected, one avoids the sufferings of hell, is reborn into a family of the Ten Virtues, has one’s name inscribed in the Purple Palace, and takes one’s place among the ranks of immortals.

Now, in promulgating *The Correct Path for Women’s Cultivation*, the Nine Precepts shall serve as the first precept.

The text reads:
1. Be filial, respectful, gentle, and harmonious; speak with caution and harbor no jealousy.
2. Maintain chastity and stillness in body; distance yourself from all impure conduct.
3. Cherish all living beings; be compassionate and refrain from killing.
4. Be diligent and reverent in ritual recitation; abstain from meat and wine.
5. Let clothing and possessions be plain and simple; do not indulge in ornate adornment.
6. Regulate and nurture your nature and emotions; do not give rise to afflictions.
7. Do not frequently attend vegetarian feasts.
8. Do not cruelly exploit servants or slaves.
9. Do not conceal goodness or broadcast evil.

Only by observing these Nine Precepts may one receive and uphold the Correct Path.

For what is here promulgated is most precious and noble. To transmit it without precepts is to profane the celestial treasure; both the giver and the receiver shall incur punishment. Be cautious and reverent.

[Note: Throughout the entire text, each precept is prefaced with the words “It is said,” indicating that the text was composed by the recorder to convey the oral transmission of the Golden Mouth of the Queen Mother of the West. This is analogous to the Buddhist sutras’ opening with “Thus have I heard” or the Daoist scriptures’ opening with “The Dao speaks.”

Furthermore, in earlier versions, the Nine Precepts were placed before the first precept, following passages on purifying the body, speech, and altar. It was Patriarch Lü’s revision that expanded and elucidated the precepts, compiling them as the first precept of the main text. From this point forward, the profound meaning of the Dao is no longer lightly transmitted, and the essential teaching is presented at the very outset.]

It is said: The second precept of the correct path for women’s cultivation is titled “Original Destiny.” This speaks of women, who are of yin substance and likened to the moon. At the age of thirteen or fourteen or fifteen, their primordial qi is abundant, their true blood full and overflowing, possessing within yin the one yang—like the moon at its fullest brilliance. Yet when the celestial water descends, the path of primordial qi is broken, and true blood is lost. After marriage and childbirth, whether bearing sons or daughters, primordial qi gradually diminishes, true blood gradually wanes. Though each month the menses return, each month they also bring renewed harm. The difficulty of women’s cultivation lies in this single point. If a woman wishes to preserve her destiny and return to the origin, she must seek the method of cultivation. Having obtained the method and practicing it, her merit will be swiftly accomplished. The title “Original Destiny” signifies that a woman’s destiny yet depends upon the celestial water. If the celestial water is not transformed, how can her destiny be preserved? The return to the origin will never come. Yet the method of cultivation is most precious, and thus the “Nine Precepts” are placed as the first precept, while “Original Destiny” follows as the second—first addressing nature, then destiny. Following this precept, the next is titled “Original Nature,” for the cultivation of nature is precisely for the preservation of destiny.

[It is carefully noted that throughout the entire text, apart from the first precept composed by Patriarch Lü, the second through ninth precepts were originally compiled by the Peerless Primordial Sovereign and later revised by Patriarch Lü, with the intent of clarity. Thus, the wording is made accessible, lest the meaning be obscured by the text and mislead later generations. Readers must not dismiss it as lacking in ancient elegance and doubt its divine authorship. As for the tenth precept, it was entirely composed by Patriarch Lü, being an extension of the teachings after his elucidation of the principles.]

It is said: The third precept of the correct path is titled “Original Nature.”

For women, their nature is like water, their essence like a flower. When they reach the age of youth and their awareness begins to unfold, they should discipline themselves, refrain from frivolous play, and avoid reckless movement. At this time, there naturally exists a drop of initial menses, concealed within the inner gate—like a star, like a pearl—this is the supreme treasure of the prior heavens, stored above the Kun abdomen and situated within the Central Yellow. If a woman at this time maintains purity of nature, avoids lewd plays and licentious words, conducts herself with quiet elegance, moves in accordance with inner principles, and remains tranquil and composed, then this single entity will adhere to the celestial nature, becoming the primordial unity, an unchanging crimson pearl that does not transform into heavenly water. Yet most women, ignorant and restless in their youth, may indulge in play or chase after excitement, causing their qi to stir, their minds to waver, their spirit to become disordered, and their true qi to destabilize. Thus, this celestial treasure, like a star, melts away, its heat like fire, bursting through the gate and breaking forth—what the world calls "heavenly water." From this point onward, even if she guards her chastity and remains unwed, she is still but an ordinary woman. There is no other reason for this than her failure to recognize the "Original Nature." If she aspires to restore what has been lost, cultivation must begin from the foundation.

[It is carefully noted: The inner gate refers to the vaginal opening. Below, there is also the "spring gate," also called the vaginal opening, hence the gate within the Central Yellow is termed the "inner gate." Furthermore, the treasure of initial menses, if unrecognized and uncultivated, may adhere to the celestial nature and transform into primordial unity. Ancient sagely women have practiced this—Lady Tianfei of the Bodhisattvas is a clear example. Though the world is not lacking in wise women, it is lamentable that they lack immortal parents within and sagely teachers without, leading to a thousand wisdoms and a thousand falls.]

The fourth precept of the correct path for women’s cultivation is titled “Cultivating the Menses.”

For women whose heavenly water has already descended, whose true qi has been broken, and whose true blood has been depleted, if they do not cultivate the menses, their true blood will diminish daily, and their true qi will wane. Even with diligent cultivation, what benefit can there be? As the alchemical texts say: *"When bamboo is broken, it must be mended with bamboo."* What is the method? For those who still have monthly courses, first sever the Red Dragon. For those without monthly courses, they must first restore and then sever. In all cases, the initial practice employs the method of *Zhou Tian*. At the hours of *zi* and *wu*, sit astride the crane, release all concerns, and knock the teeth seventy-two times to open the lung and *shu* points. Then, using both nostrils, gently inhale and exhale thirty-six times to circulate the blood and qi throughout the body. At this time, fearing that qi may leak downward, one must sit astride the crane with added vigor, ensuring no slackness. Place both hands below the navel and above the gate, directing the intention backward and upward, performing this for thirty-six breaths. Next, raise both hands as if supporting the heavens, with the intention focused on the *weilu*, guiding the qi to ascend from behind—again for thirty-six breaths. Then perform slow lifts thirty-six times and rapid lifts thirty-six times, until one feels the qi in the *weilu* stirring, with a sense of ascending momentum. After this, lower the hands, place them on the waist, and vigorously raise both shoulders thirty-six times, until one feels the qi surging upward through the double gates of the spine and the lung *shu* points. If there is any blockage, clench the teeth tightly, focus the intention on the back of the neck, and lift upward thirty-six times, until one feels the *yuzhen* and *niwan* fully open. Only then should one cover the upper lip with the lower lip, applying gentle pressure, causing the qi from the *niwan* to descend to the lower part of the nose. At this time, merely rest the tongue on the heavenly bridge without force, focusing the intention on the point where the tongue touches, and the sweet dew will naturally descend. Then, slightly contract the nose, directing the intention to swallow the dew, sending it straight down to the *jiangque*. Retain it there for a moment, then guide it backward, dividing it to the left and right, rotating around the waist thirty-six times each. Next, direct the intention to the navel wheel, rotating left thirty-six times and right thirty-six times, until one feels the entire abdomen unobstructed. At this time, place both hands below the navel and above the gate, directing the intention to lift simultaneously on both sides thirty-six times, until one feels a single point entering the uterus. Then, maintain a state of *ru cun ru wang* for a brief moment. This is the general outline of cultivating the menses. Within it lies an unsurpassed living method, which cannot yet be spoken of—yet it is nothing more than the phrase *"abide in stillness and observe."*

[It is carefully noted: The uterus is the inner gate, equivalent to the *xuanqiao* in men. The alchemical texts say: *"Yang is called xuan, yin is called pin."* Together, they form what Laozi referred to as the *"Gate of the Mysterious Female"* and what the *Huangdi Yin Fu Jing* calls the *"Marvelous Vessel."* Whether termed the marvelous vessel, *xuanqiao*, *pinhu*, or uterus, though the names differ, the cavity is one. This precept speaks of the uterus to illustrate through human affairs, yet it is evident that both sacred and ordinary embryos are conceived here. Furthermore, the phrase *"nothing more than"* implies there is a subtle principle to be embodied, cautioning against carelessness.]

If the uterus feels a swirling heat at this time, the spring gate must be tightly sealed, allowing no slack, to attain a sense of ease. The greatest danger is the arising of thoughts; even a slight attachment to sensation will cause the entire body to become limp and numb. Not only must one swiftly settle the mind—here, the divide between immortality and mortality is determined.

[This warns that the gate must be tightly sealed, with no carelessness. If the gate slackens even slightly, the true qi will leak away.]

Should the subsequent passage unfold, the peril only deepens. For at that moment, an extraordinary tingling tremor must arise within the gate, and upon further refinement through sealing and restraint, this *yin* chamber will attain an unparalleled sense of ease. Without swiftly settling the mind, the entire body will inevitably grow limp and numb, slipping into the sea of desire—by the time one seeks to compose the thoughts, it may already be too late. Thus it is said, *"the divide between immortality and mortality is determined here."*

Master Taixu of the Great Void observed: *"The method lies solely in turning the back to *gen*; only then will the passions settle."* Otherwise, the gate will surely yawn open, and the essence will leak forth like a pouring stream. Alas! Alas!

At this juncture, one must swiftly quiet the heart for an extended time, awaiting stillness in the uterus—this is none other than Wei Yuanjun’s *"treasure returned to the Northern Sea, settled and secure."* Yet even this is but a *"yellow leaf to quiet a child’s cry"*—take care not to mistake it for the congealing of the embryo.

[It is noted: the *"Sea of Awareness"* is the Southern Sea, while this uterus is the Northern Sea, positioned north of the *Central Ultimate* and *Central Yellow*—the very locus of *"the Yellow Center through which the Dao flows"* in the *Book of Changes*. Here, front and back define south and north, not above and below. Moreover, Wei Yuanjun’s verse serves as ample proof; thus, one must await stillness in the uterus before ceasing the practice.

This passage concerns cultivation after the *"Red Dragon"* has arisen, particularly the methods following the *"slaying of the dragon."* Such practice demands utmost tranquility in embodiment—any recklessness will ruin the entire endeavor, hence *"the divide between immortality and mortality is determined here."*

This entire section forms a *"complete circular reflection"*—the return to the origin, the reversion to the root, the attainment of embryo congealment, wherein the *mysterious radiance* is already present. Yet this passage focuses on the *"heaven and earth, the Five Phases"* within the body, refining and returning them to their primordial treasure—a *"lesser return,"* a *"lesser reversion,"* attainable through daily or hourly practice. The *"one grain returning to one grain"* spoken of in the alchemical texts refers precisely to this treasure.

Thus, the analogy of the *"yellow leaf"* is employed here, yet the true art lies in the secrets of gathering, refining, and guiding the essence back to its secure abode—a complete and perfect *"great return of the mysterious reflection."* One must embody and recognize this with care, lest it be carelessly overlooked.]

As for the fifth principle in the *"Proper Path of Female Cultivation,"* it is titled *"Returning and Restoring."* It speaks of women in the world who, though advanced in years, have not yet purified their bodies, or those who, though only forty-five or forty-six, have already severed their *"dragons."* All such women should cultivate to restore their original state, returning to the condition of a maiden. This practice and method are none other than those found in the preceding four principles, with the sole difference that what was previously drawn upward and inward is now directed forward and downward, flowing back into the *"valley sea."*

Gather the sweet nectar, swallowing only to retain it at the threshold, never allowing it to descend. Then, with hands, massage the breast valley: thirty-six rotations to the left, thirty-six to the right, until this threshold valley reveals a flowing, delightful sensation. Next, separately massage both breasts: thirty-six slow strokes, thirty-six rapid strokes, beginning lightly and then heavily, each performed thirty-six times, totaling one hundred forty-four repetitions. Naturally, one will feel the true qi stirring and swelling within both chambers and the valley, as a cool liquid like a spring emerges from the twin passes and surges into the Southern Sea. Calm the mind and await this, never permitting the qi to divert toward the waist afterward. Only allow all concerns to settle within the Central Palace, without employing any guiding techniques or deliberate distribution. Spontaneously, one will feel the entire body profoundly clear and harmonious.

Practicing thus without interruption each day, the weak will gradually grow strong, the frail will gradually become robust, and the aged will gradually return to youth. The face will bloom with color, the breasts will gradually retract like those of a maiden, and within, something will congeal like a peach pit. Within a hundred days, the heavenly water will attain a hue like rouge, and after three days, proceed with the practices of the fourth principle, without the slightest addition or alteration—thus, the Red Dragon will be severed once more. Yet only when the sun and moon appear as twin rings is this truly achieved.

[According to the Daoist canon, there are elderly women who still produce menstrual water, though this is not true menstrual water but rather the essence of food and drink, transformed by the ministerial fire of the phase cycle and failing to return to the liver and spleen. This may turn into intestinal bleeding, red discharge, or inverted menstruation—all manifestations of this substance. Such conditions arise from deficiency. Therefore, those who cease menstruation prematurely must first cultivate restoration to a maiden-like state before attempting to sever the Dragon.

Note also that the character *jian* (见) in "obtain sight" should be read in the *xian* (现) rhyme, as it here signifies "manifestation." Only with a tranquil mind and embodied presence can this be perceived. The *xian* (现) in "appears as" is the immediate experience of that perception. These two characters, though related, carry distinct depths of meaning and must not be carelessly overlooked.]

The Sixth Principle of the Proper Path for Female Cultivation, titled "The Breasts."

Here it speaks of how the breasts connect upward to the fluids of the heart and lungs and channel downward the true essence of the Sea of Blood. When the breasts are refined to resemble those of a maiden or child, this is the female body transformed into the male form. The method of practice does not depart from the Fourth and Fifth Principles.

Women take blood as their foundation, yet the aim of this principle lies in refining the red to return to the white. Given the inherent deficiency of the root, there is the technique of refining fluids to transform blood. To transform fluids into blood, nothing surpasses the method of "dew lingering at the palace gate," where the spirit is directed to the twin passes. The old stagnant mud-like fluids within the passes melt naturally and flow like streams returning to the sea. The generation of blood must flourish, and the essential meaning of this lies within the Fifth Principle.

If one wishes to transform blood back into white, nothing surpasses directing the mind to the breast channels, clenching the teeth tightly, and intensifying the focus on emptiness and tranquility. Qi will naturally gather in the channels and reach the breasts. Then, use both palms to knead the breasts, first slowly, then swiftly; first lightly, then heavily—performing this one hundred and forty-four times. The qi will gather and flourish even more. Afterward, withdraw the focus and direct it to the two flanks. Further, guide the qi to spiral left and right with the gaze, completing seventy-two breaths, until the qi warms as if cauterized. Then, lead the mind to encircle the wheel without counting, until the lower extremity feels as if boiling. Thus, the red transforms into fresh white, which must naturally transmute into qi, piercing the spine, ascending the ridge, crossing the pillow, and penetrating the valley.

At this moment, if the inner vision reveals the Three Mountains and the Mystic Garden in a state less than pristine, one must immediately engage in forgetfulness. Suddenly, darkness may descend like night, yet I remain in tranquil vigil. With time, there will inevitably come flashes like lightning and rumbles like thunder, dew pouring as if in torrents, the Flowery Pond brimming full. One cannot swallow fast enough, as the essence flows smoothly down to the palace gate and reaches the navel, suffusing the entire body with clarity and harmony. I remain in stillness, observing this.

After a hundred days of unbroken practice, if the breasts were once firm, they will become as flat as a boy’s; if they were once hollow, they will fill like walnuts, resembling those of a maiden. Achieving the form of a boy results from the completion of the white-transformation practice; attaining the form of a maiden comes from the completion of the red-transformation practice.

Our tradition has seen no shortage of verified practitioners, among whom Mistress Feng stands out for her poetic records. Her verses may serve as testimony, and they read:

*"Sun to the left, moon to the right—one yin, one yang,
Through the nose the qi circulates, called ‘guiding the Gang.’
Should you wish yin and yang to return to sun and moon,
Grasp the true fire and knead the twin chambers."*

Let the seeker take heed!

[Note: The "twin barriers" lie before the spine and behind the palace, enclosing two cavities where the body’s turbid fluids congeal. The left is called *gao*, the right *huang*—places where medicinal force cannot reach and true qi does not naturally arrive. These turbid fluids, though resembling essence, are in fact transformed from food and drink, akin to bodily fluids. Borne by qi, they spread through the lungs to moisten the meridians. When the body’s true qi is abundant, they are refined and serve boundless functions. When true qi wanes, they remain untransformed, flowing into the organs and meridians without causing harm—until they encounter extreme yin qi, congealing into turbid fluids, neither essence nor waste. These obstruct the qi pathways, pooling most heavily at the twin barriers and the lower extreme, with the twin barriers suffering the worst, as true qi cannot reach them. There they accumulate like the ice of Kunlun’s yin peaks, enduring the triple summer’s heat without melting. Though the heart’s Gang stands guard above, when spirit is strong, all is well; when spirit weakens, peril follows. The ancients knew this and devised the method of "gathering spirit to warm the barriers," though few in the world have heard of it. Only Mistress Feng, who both knew and verified it, left it recorded in verse. Yet even her success relied first on the secret of an empty, tranquil mind. Only by emptying the mind could spirit return and qi flourish, and with the method of channeling streams and kneading the chambers, the turbid fluids melt and surge forth from the barriers, flowing into the ocean to be refined. Thus is achieved the wondrous interplay of presence and absence!

Further note: The left chamber connects to the liver, the right to the lungs; the streams link to the heart, kidneys, and spleen. Vigilance is required at all times, though in daily practice, one may hold the intention without strain. For in women, the root of life lies in the heart, corresponding to the central line of the *Kun* hexagram, which forms *Li* and harbors true fire. Yet blood is born of coolness, and when blood is abundant, spirit rests at ease. Thus, cultivating emptiness and tranquility is paramount—this is the key to healing, nurturing life, and returning to the primordial Dao. The practice of the *Qingjing Jing*’s threefold contemplation is most fitting here.]

This is the seventh principle of the true path for women’s cultivation, titled **"Jade Fluid."**

In men, the practice begins with purity, and when the work reaches the stage of circulating the River Chariot, true essence is preserved in full, never leaving the Mysterious Pass. It flows backward to the crown, where dew showers the Celestial Valley, then descends to the Flowery Pond—this, too, is called Jade Fluid. Yet when the yin spirit emerges, the hun wanders the Jade Palace, the po pays homage to the Imperial True, a halo crowns the head, tides surge in the Mysterious Sea, and echoes resound in the Jade Clarity—this is the true return of the elixir as Jade Fluid, which the ancient perfected called *"amrita pouring on the crown."*

For women, however, Jade Fluid is the transformation of the Red Dragon’s liquid into the White Phoenix’s marrow. Only when this marrow is abundant can one proceed with the backward flow, lest the work be in vain. Though the method does not depart from the four principles previously shown, its subtleties must follow the six. For only thus can its uses be inexhaustible—this is what the earlier worthies meant by *"one grain begets another,"* and how could its supply ever run dry? Once the true seed is obtained, one must press on with diligence. Yet the means to its attainment all stem from mastering the empty, tranquil mind. Let the seeker take heed!

[Note: To elucidate this principle, let us cite the account of the Immortal Emerald Maiden:

*"In my early practice of returning the elixir, I began by forgetting the person, then forgetting the method, acting only when the time was ripe. Thus, I forgot the self and became the work, forgetting today, tomorrow, and even this great matter of returning the elixir. Day by day, time by time, I forgot even the existence of heaven and earth. After a long while, I suddenly awoke as if from a dream, listening and seeing in stillness, yet utterly unaware of what I was doing or what the work entailed. I only felt a burning heat, and then there appeared a substance like fat, like oil (this was the north pole’s rear; the fat-like, oil-like substance was the Red Dragon’s liquid transformed into the White Phoenix’s marrow). Boundless and vast, sometimes with sound, sometimes without, now flowing, now pausing, now gushing, now spraying—at times hanging like a snow-white ribbon, at others clear as an icy lake. The moments and places were ever-changing, yet my eyes were not dazzled, nor my spirit wearied. Suddenly, within this state, sights and sounds arose that could have deluded my nature. I admonished myself: ‘Do not be lured by phenomena.’ Then I felt as if time flowed like a river, and I could command qi with a mere gesture. About to test this, I suddenly realized: ‘Heaven and earth are one with me.’ Turning inward, I saw that my body was no different. If principle was so without, it must be so within—and if so within, then so without. Thus, I turned my gaze inward, dissolving the self. After long stillness, the self reappeared, yet when I sought to delve deeper, there was no gate or opening. Suddenly, as if waking from a dream, I felt the lower extreme of my body burning like moxibustion, sounds like thunder and wind, like tides, rising within. In an instant, the qi pierced the gate, ascended the spine, passed the pillow, and reached the valley—like sweet dew, it fell from the nose."*]

The Celestial Pond brims with water, so abundant that swallowing cannot keep pace—yet in less than half a morning, the fluid surges into the Southern Ocean. Soon it flows to the waist, encircling the navel, refining and smelting. Heaven and earth share one body; what is outwardly so is inwardly so. Truly, it is thus.

At this moment, I merely followed the usual sequence, completing the practice before withdrawing.

...

The immortal’s account is purely alchemical transformation. One imagines that in daily cultivation, they must have first devoted themselves to emptiness and stillness, then advanced to a state of utter forgetfulness.

A certain adept recorded this to verify and seal the method.

---

**Women’s Cultivation: The Orthodox Path, Eighth Principle – "Embryonic Breathing"**

Embryonic breathing is the supreme Dao, the celestial ladder. After a woman completes the Returned Elixir, her essence and qi become abundant, her body one with the male. Without embryonic breathing, she cannot return to the formless in a single day.

This single breath holds boundless efficacy, yet its method is most simple. However, not all who practice achieve the same result—great disparities arise. Is this not governed by the Creator? Yet the Creator, too, shapes things according to their nature.

When one seeks the breath through stillness, the nose is free of thought, free of worry. Morning and night, one day the Ancestral Cavity is touched—suddenly, it opens of itself, neither sought nor rejected. The breath merges with the nose in a vast, boundless expanse, profound and unfathomable. One knows not whether the Ancestor is the self or the self the Ancestor. A single breath through the nose—ancient sages called this embryonic breathing.

Within this cavity, yin and yang, the Five Phases, heaven and earth, all beings—all arise from it. The breath responds to the mechanism of stimulus, naturally forming the six ranks of immortals: celestial, aquatic, terrestrial, human, divine, and spectral.

The method lies solely in extreme emptiness and stillness.
- Cultivating with virtue united with the True One yields a Celestial Immortal.
- Cultivating with virtue united with the Mysterious One yields a Water Immortal.
- Cultivating with virtue united with the Steadfast One yields an Earthly Immortal.
- Cultivating with virtue united with the Refined One yields a Human Immortal.
- The two lesser vehicles, cultivating with virtue united with the Passionate One, yield either a spirit (if yang-predominant) or a ghost (if yin-predominant).

The fruits attained by the virtuous cannot be called true immortals. Such disparities arise from the interplay of stimulus and response. Though called heaven’s endowment, is it not self-acquired? Practitioners, take heed!

[Reflecting on this teaching, embryonic breathing is indeed the supreme Dao, the true celestial ladder. How can one not strive with diligence!]

---

**Women’s Cultivation: The Orthodox Path, Ninth Principle – "Namo"**

In women’s cultivation, nothing surpasses the attainment of the Great Being. Through ascetic practice and devoted cultivation, one realizes the Buddha and Bodhisattva. The key lies in the two syllables *Namo*.

Within these two characters, profound meaning is concealed. Only by embodying the truth that this very body is the Buddha—like a seven-tiered crystal stupa enshrined upon Mount Putuo—can one proceed. Before the stupa stands a Red Child, the leader of the discriminating mind. The Great Being allows him to wander east and south, to inquire and seek—after fifty-three inquiries, he finally meets the Buddha, and the koan is resolved. Then, the Dragon Girl of the Southern Ocean presents the Pearl of Freedom, which is shielded by the Purple Bamboo Grove. The White Parrot is left to fly up and down...

Holding the pure vase, she inserts a willow sprig,
gathering the sweet dew of nature’s own;
steadfast upon Mount Putuo’s rock, she employs the *dhāraṇī* method,
placing the single syllable *Oṃ* upon the ground of true intent,
receiving the supreme treasure and storing it within the fish basket.
Reciting *Garuḍa-vajra*, she encompasses all of *sahā*,
casting it into the Southern Sea—
though waves surge tumultuously within the sea,
she abides in ease, beholding the Self-Existent.

This great Dharma, however, cannot do without the fourth internal practice,
which must moment by moment arise from the preceding principle,
step by step returning to true emptiness and true quiescence.
When merit is perfected and conduct fulfilled,
one may then exchange smiles with the Great Being,
serene and at peace as the moon’s release.

Let the recipient take heed!

---

This tenth principle of the true path for women’s cultivation is titled *"Vigilance at Life’s End."*
For women embody the virtue of *kun*, the Way of Earth—
not achieving for themselves, yet completing what others have begun.
Thus, they ought to assist in nurturing creation beneath the bright sun of civilization.

Yet the practice still begins with emptiness and quiescence,
costing not a penny, expending not a thread of effort,
achieved through sitting, unknown to others,
while virtue merges with the workings of creation—
this is healing the world through one’s very body.

The practice relies solely on harmonizing the heart’s emptiness and stillness.
When the breast is harmonized to purity, the heavens become profoundly at peace;
when the womb’s *kun*-abdomen is harmonized to openness, neighborhoods prosper;
when the four limbs are harmonized to unobstructed flow, the four frontiers are pacified.
Thus, when the body is harmonized, the body is at peace;
when the body is at peace, the world is governed.
The resonance is such that a single moment of clarity and harmony
yields a moment of true virtue—
though no effect is seen, the effect is naturally present.

Yet one must fear that if foundational learning remains shallow
and the Three Fields are not interconnected,
there has never been a person whose own destiny was unfulfilled
who could yet fulfill the world’s destiny.

The secret lies in morning and evening devotion:
when others advance by one, advance by a hundred;
when others advance by ten, advance by a thousand.
Even the dull-witted will surely become enlightened.

Let the recipient take heed!

[This passage, sanctioned by the Western Queen Mother for solemn re-promulgation in its entirety, was compiled by the Peerless Primordial Sovereign in accordance with the oral transmission of the Great Dao of governing the world from the Divine Mother of Jade Clarity. Here, the final precepts of former transmissions are revised and appended as the concluding maxim. Truly, this is an unparalleled canon since the dawn of creation—Lüzu called it the greatest fortune of the cosmos, while the Primordial Sovereign deemed it the moment for the Dao’s resurgence. Such are their profound hopes for later learners. May all who encounter this text exhort one another to diligence.]

**The Precious Raft of Dual Cultivation for the Female Lineage of the Mud-Pill Master**
*Recorded and annotated by the Great Master Tai Xu Weng; revised by disciple Min Yi De*

**Guide to Female Practice, First Precept**

The Mud-Pill Master states: In advancing female practice, first still the thoughts, then harmonize the mind. When thoughts are stilled and the mind harmonized, one may proceed to self-massage.

The method forbids seeking coolness while avoiding warmth. Women, whose root is blood, are inherently yin in nature; yin delights in coolness. Without the subtle activation of qi through massage, they readily sink into pure yin. Yin engenders cold, cold congeals into ice—without movement to stir it, phlegm stagnation and blood stasis arise, and practice becomes arduous. Thus, one must begin with stilling thoughts and harmonizing the mind.

Women belong to *kun* (Earth), yet *kun* conceals true fire. When fire lies dormant, all is auspicious; when it flares, it scorches metal. If left unharmonized and unregulated, metal, pressed by fire, manifests the omen of "the bird’s cry ascending to heaven." Therefore, the secret of female cultivation lies in beginning with stilling thoughts and harmonizing the mind.

In stilling thoughts and harmonizing the mind, the practice is neither begrudged for its abundance nor shunned for its duration, for within stillness there is movement.

[Master Tai Xu states: When thoughts are stilled, qi becomes pure; when the mind is harmonized, qi becomes balanced. Continuing with massage then awakens the mechanism of yang. Yet one must guard against stagnation giving rise to restlessness. Moreover, women naturally prefer coolness and dislike heat. Upon initially achieving stillness of thought and harmony of mind, if stagnation and restlessness arise amid this tranquil state, the impulse to replenish true yin may emerge—this is the origin of pure yin’s turbulent accumulation. For stillness congeals yin, and inactivity stifles yang; beginners invariably encounter this flaw. Unaware of the causes behind restlessness and vexation, they hastily seek momentary coolness—this is a grave error! One must intensify practice, employing methods to circulate qi. When qi flows, restlessness naturally dissolves. Those who fail to grasp this and seek results only compound their afflictions, thereby inviting phlegm stagnation and blood stasis. Hence, the strict admonition. The proper method lies in persisting with massage precisely to preclude such stagnation and congealment.

Furthermore, as human nature delights in progress and craves advancement, overzealous massage may cause the earthly fire to blaze, igniting all other fires and scorching metal—hence the warning of "the bird’s cry ascending to heaven." The *hanyin* (bird of the *you* hour) is a fowl of the west; when pressed to its limit, it takes flight upward. Thus, the text reiterates the marvel of stilling thoughts and harmonizing the mind. This precept serves as the essential key to female practice from beginning to end.]

The Second Precept

Master Niwan states: In women’s refined practice, one begins with the flourishing of yang and concludes with the restraint of yin—this method is most esoteric, and few indeed comprehend it. Those who err follow the male path in their cultivation, while the discerning turn toward Chan, each able to verify a fruit of attainment, achieving effects such as vanishing while standing or transforming while seated. Yet they remain mired in ghostly realms, far from the Dao.

For women, blood is the foundation: when blood is abundant, essence overflows. When the heart is cool, blood is generated. As the ancients said, the refinement of fluid into blood and the transformation of blood into essence depend on the clarity of spirit. Without the transformation of fluid, fluid loses the warming of spirit, congeals into phlegm, flows into the spleen and stomach, steams upward to lodge in the lungs, scatters through the channels and collaterals, giving rise to a hundred diseases, afflicting the five viscera, and bringing calamity to the six bowels. Thus, ancient elixir methods always begin by stilling the heart. When the heart is stilled and breath is settled, the spirit becomes clear, and the heart cools.

Only when the heart has cooled and fluids surge should one direct attention to the breast channels, applying the hands in circular massage to ensure the free flow of qi. Next, raise both hands to rotate around the breasts, waiting until this *yinyun* (interpenetrating warmth) envelops them, and a gentle warmth suffuses the back, with wisps of vapor rising at the double gates. The force presses through the passes, filling them with viscous fluid, which then overflows into the breast channels like a gushing spring.

Thereupon, with true intent, guide it into the Southern Ocean, silently abiding there for approximately thirty-six breaths. Then relax the intent, and sense within a spontaneous descent, dividing to flow into both flanks, spiraling left and right for another thirty-six breaths each. Next, gather it with single-minded focus into the deep center of the navel wheel, rotating slowly forty-nine times, then swiftly forty-nine times. Observe the coccyx: when warm qi pierces through from behind, if the force seems sluggish, employ the method of contracting the two excretory orifices to naturally ascend through the tailbone, up the spine, over Kunlun, and descend into Niwan. There, Niwan feels vast as the sea, allowing the qi to linger and nurture.

Thereafter, it descends into the Crimson Palace and the Flowery Pond, suffusing the great earth with dewdrops. All tasks forgotten, one feels only a hazy vagueness, where breathing, lifting, swallowing—all occur spontaneously. Within this state, the flavor is sweet and fragrant, qi and spirit harmoniously full, the Three Fields unified.

Suddenly, mysterious conditions pervade all directions, and one must swiftly turn inward, releasing all entanglements. The body feels hollow as a valley, the great earth vanishes, and a subtle coolness gently envelops one, with *yinyun* filling all space. Then, as mist scatters and clouds disperse, the Ocean of Nature appears below, its azure waves limpid. I remain unmoved by a single thought, forgetting both state and emotion. Suddenly, myriad golden rays appear, fine rain like pearls descending with the light, spiraling left and right to coalesce into a luminous moon, floating and sinking in a crystalline sea. Abruptly, one awakens as from a dream.

Master Niwan states: At this moment, swiftly introspect this body. The proper attainment is marked by a refreshing qi, a clear spirit, and harmony throughout the body. When achieved, the entire body remains luminously still for a time, with intent directed to the *pin* (feminine gate), sensing within a profound tranquility—this is it.

Then, rub the hands and face, circulate spirit around the abdomen, and raise both shoulders in the windlass motion, each performed for forty-nine breaths. Gently twist the waist, sway the knees and legs, sit and tap the toes—each for twenty-four breaths—then cease.

Practicing this for a hundred days, three times daily without interruption, the foundation for celestial immortality is established.

Master Taixu comments: This precept is but a general outline, known in ancient times as the "Ladder to Heaven." The great Dao’s elixir method lies herein, lacking only the final crucial step. Later scholars must first become thoroughly familiar with it, pondering each word in silent contemplation a hundred times daily. Then, when practicing, they will proceed as if treading a familiar path, undeluded by phenomena. Even if manifestations slightly differ, the sequence remains orderly. Scholars must not treat this as a mere reading of *Journey to the West*.

For men’s elixir texts abound like cattle hairs, but complete women’s elixir texts are rare in the world. To obtain something like the *Eighteen Precepts of Zhihua’s Direct Pointers* is already to possess an esoteric transmission. With this *Guide* to complement it, the secret method for female celestial immortality is complete. If one possesses only the *Direct Pointers*, one may attain earthly or human immortality at best.

The Third Precept

Master Niwan states:
For men, dual cultivation dispenses with the crucible;
Those who rely on crucibles never attain the Dao.
Adding oil is mere technique, not the true formula—
The true formula unites the Three Powers in one body.

For women, dual cultivation is no different:
Without containment, the Three Existences nurture the elixir.
Within, the True One abounds like granary millet,
Nature as furnace—ripe for feasting at will.

He further says:
Know that in the world there are Unobstructed Assemblies,
Where seeds originally pervade the great chiliocosm.
Yet borrowing altars as crucibles,
After Lu’s departure, the true transmission was lost.

He also says:
When I utter this verse,
The Eight Divisions of Devas and Nāgas will surely be alarmed,
Deeming my words garrulous,
Fearing I incur the penalty of the Mysterious.

Yet I speak so freely
Because I bear the august decree of the Jade Purity Divine Mother,
Who, lamenting the Dao’s near extinction,
Commanded the Peerless Holy Maiden to solemnly proclaim it.
She transmitted it to me orally, intending full disclosure,
No longer concealing it under aliases or altered names to mislead posterity.

Her teaching states:
Solitary cultivation is not the supreme Dao;
Of like kind, each requires the other.
Those who attain a body beyond the body
Forget form and suffice for all affairs.

Her formula states:
The Qian Power is received from the crown,
The Kun Power is lost through the female portal.
The Human Power pervades the great chiliocosm—
The Three Powers are mastered by one heart.

Beyond lies neither the stillness of the empty mind
Nor the obstruction of the body.
In movement and quiescence, merge with the True Constant;
I am not, yet the Primordial naturally coalesces.

When the Primordial coalesces, the One also coalesces;
The One Primordial is essence and nature.
Emotion is the source of nature,
Nature is endowed with talent.

Able to transform without Primordial or One,
One transcends the supreme rank.

This is the august decree of the Jade Purity Divine Mother,
The oral transmission of the Peerless Holy Maiden.
Those who are capable, follow it.

Master Taixu states:
The mutual requirement of like kind is the principle of the Supreme Ultimate—
This is precisely the wondrous fusion of the Two and Five Essences.
Within and beyond the *Awakening to Reality*,
The entire *Triple Concordance* speaks of this single principle.
Yet the world misconstrues it,
Giving rise to the filth of the Three Peaks.
Now, with the Master’s instruction,
The oral transmission of a thousand years is finally revealed.
How fortunate am I, Bing, to receive it (Bing is Master Taixu’s lineage name),
And how fortunate the world to attain clarity!
This is the final great stratagem for both male and female lineages.

Without inherent wisdom,
Few can see it through to the end.
I, Bing, have tasted the宗旨:
The method lies solely in selflessness,
Thereby attaining non-attachment to things.
When self and things are both forgotten,
The True One appears.
Once the True One appears,
Follow the One in cultivation.
The One naturally fuses,
Transforming and generating endlessly.

Within this imperial Dao,
Nothing surpasses the Unobstructed Buddhist Assembly—
In the alchemical texts, this is called "living dragons and tigers filling empty space."
I, Bing, have witnessed it in such assemblies.
Yet one must strictly adhere to ancient protocols
To avoid regret or misfortune.

This assembly,
In meaning, is most esoteric,
Yet in manifestation, most evident—
Take care not to misunderstand.

What is called esoteric
Lies hidden in the one heart,
Where gains and losses remain unknown to others.

What is called evident
Is as open as a marketplace,
Every action and pause utterly exposed.

Only by adhering to this method
Can one avoid worldly censure.

Alas!
The heart of the sage is burdened,
The vision of the sage is far-reaching!

The Fourth Precept

Niyuan Shi said: Indeed, the ancient sages declared: "If the gross form remains untransformed, the Dao will never be realized; if merit and practice are not perfected, fruition will never be attained. To advance by skipping stages is only to court delusion; to seek realization without perfection is to attain but a lesser, inferior fruit." Let scholars heed this compassionate instruction and first refine the Dharma-body to firmness, for only then is there a foundation to endure tempering. Without this foundation, one cannot speak of the higher principles.

The higher principles concern purely the work of transformation, yet each step arises from the physical form—this is the function of lodging the empty within the solid and, through the solid, attaining the empty. Such is the method of the Heavenly Immortals.

Taixu Shi said: The Dharma-body is the body beyond the body. This body is not obtained through visualization, nor can it be accomplished through alchemical refinement. Its secret lies in "borrowing the false to cultivate the real," and its cultivation does not extend beyond the physical form. The key is to refine this physical body until, within and without, it is pure and stainless—where it is a body yet not a body, not a body yet a body. This is what is meant by "when the work is active, the body is absent; when the work ceases, the body is present." At the moment of absence, all sensations of cold and warmth are not the self, all sensations of pain and itch are not the self—this is what is meant by "being aware yet not attaching."

How can this be achieved? The method lies in dwelling in emptiness with the spirit, so that the body is no longer the body. One who can do this has already attained it. One who recognizes the True One, seeing all beyond it as illusion, has attained it further. Refining thus until there is no far or near, no inside or outside, one advances still further. Cultivating until there is no going or coming, no entering or exiting, one truly attains the state of no far or near, no inside or outside. If one can further cultivate until there is no arising or ceasing, no movement or stillness, one truly attains the state of no going or coming, no entering or exiting. Thus, one has already possessed the pure realm of the Dharma-body. Yet this is not sought beyond the physical body.

The Fifth Principle

Master Niwan states: What is said of True Yang (True Yang being the honorific bestowed upon Master Tai Xu by Master Niwan) is thus. Through such refined cultivation, the Dharma-body naturally manifests. Persisting without retreat, one attains a body beyond the body.

You must understand that the ancient sages invariably relied upon the final, decisive effort to complete the Way—this is indeed the swiftest path within the completion of the Way! For the true yin and true yang within the body are limited; when refined, they are but mutually tempered in sequence. Though daily practice of this method yields gradual accumulation, the body’s acquired mundane burdens also grow day by day. Even with diligent cultivation, those who encounter great calamities are many across the ages—truly pitiable. There is no other reason: the body’s primordial true essence can be measured, while its later false accretions proliferate without bound. Moreover, if cultivation does not begin in youthful purity, contamination and decay are inescapable for all. In this, you may well fear for the world!

---

Master Tai Xu states: Drinking water or broth, one knows its warmth or coolness for oneself. If the Dharma-body is already manifest, the methods of regulation and protection, the proper timing of gathering and releasing, need not be sought elsewhere—internal verification is sufficient for certainty. Even if the Dharma-body is not yet manifest, the methods of regulation and protection, the timing of releasing and gathering, should still be sought within the body’s own fluctuations, which are nothing other than blockage and flow, ascent and descent, cold and warmth, dryness and moisture. Applying these principles, how could it be otherwise than unblocking what is blocked, warming what is cold, moistening what is dry, and circulating these in perpetual alternation?

The great essence lies in concentration and softness, not being led astray by external things, harmonizing the heart and qi, unifying the qi’s movement, and recognizing this body as a borrowed vessel. The common practices of massage, contraction, and frequent visualization and circulation serve only to enliven the qi’s movement. Once the qi’s movement is already lively and fluid, the method rests solely on concentration and softness: when thoughts arise, dissolve them; when gathering, know when to cease. Beware of seeking the ox while riding it, or gathering without knowing rest—this is like placing a head upon a head. Even when signs such as unobstructed ascent and descent, balanced warmth and coolness, and harmony are achieved, one must avoid clinging—this is akin to the principle of knowing when to cease in gathering. Cultivating and nurturing in accordance with this, there will be no risk of collapse or ruin. The truth is evident as such.

**Sixth Principle**

Niwan Shi says: Indeed, your words are correct. The woman’s spirit takes flight, the man’s essence congeals—both stem from the error of "placing a head upon a head." For the spirit clings to essence: when spirit congeals and essence is balanced, all is at peace; when essence dries and spirit is left solitary, it flees. Those who fail to understand this mistakenly call it transformation—how lamentable!

From this, one may grasp the error of excessive massage and visualization. Why is this so? The woman is inwardly yin and outwardly yang, corresponding to the *Li* trigram; her true yin often leaks away with the monthly flow. Thus, stillness overcoming movement brings fortune, while movement overcoming stillness brings misfortune. The man’s foundation is essence, the woman’s foundation is blood. Essence thrives with warmth, blood arises from coolness. Knowing this, one knows how to nurture.

The woman’s practice does not abandon massage and visualization, for it serves two purposes: first, to unblock the qi’s movement, ensuring the meridians flow freely; second, to refine the fluids, preventing stagnation from turning to phlegm, so that fluids transform into blood.

The ancient sages spoke of stillness and preservation as the core, which also holds two meanings: when the ruler is at peace, the ministers are at ease, and the spirit remains clear, unscattered; moreover, stillness gives rise to wisdom, free from desire’s disturbance, thus preserving life. This is the secret of dual cultivation for the self.

Once the qi’s movement is smooth and the will pure and tranquil, one adds harmony and follows with purity. Daily progress may seem slight, but monthly gains accumulate. Persisting in this, one day attains a body like empty space, the Three Fields unified. Only then does one feel every limb and joint, every aperture, radiant with light. At this stage of cultivation, the body beyond the body is realized.

If one persists without retreat, spirit and qi become full, thoughts do not stray outward, the spirit does not chase after thoughts, blood flourishes, true yin is sufficient, and qi and essence naturally fill heaven and earth. Yet if thoughts soar and scatter, one falls into the Two Vehicles—what the alchemical texts call the "yin spirit leaving the shell." The practitioner must guard against this.

---

Taixu Shi says: I have heard from the Master that the spirit is the heart’s spirit. When guarded and not scattered, it clings to essence. Once essence dries, the spirit flees. Essence here refers to kidney essence; when essence does not congeal, it is governed by the spirit. This congealed essence is not primordial essence but a fluid-like substance, akin to blood not yet formed. Once the true spirit departs, this essence hardens.

The *Book of Changes* says: "The Dao/Way of one yin and one yang." A verse states: "Half a catty and eight taels make the true." And again: "Solitary yin does not grow, solitary yang does not flourish." Qian and Kun, Kan and Li, Zhen and Xun, Dui and Gen—heaven and earth, sun and moon, nature and life, male and female—all follow the cycle of one yin and one yang, ever returning to the beginning. This is the constant Dao/Way. If cultivation leans toward one vehicle or perception tilts to one side, it becomes a flawed practice.

It is also said: In the beginning of cultivation, one seeks harmony within the body, though there is a distinction between prior and posterior. The prior is called the true, the posterior the false. The false is born of the true, yet the true may also be called false; when the false returns to the true, it is called the primordial. If gathering misses the proper time or clings to form, one strays onto side paths, becoming mere illusion—though still remediable. The gravest danger lies in the moment when solitary cultivation reaches fulfillment, perception enters the profound, and a single bias in thought skews understanding. Though one may seek to halt it, it is too late. The woman’s spirit flies, the man’s essence congeals—how can one not be cautious!

Alas! Know that in *Cui Gong’s "Mirror for Taking the Medicine,"* it says: "It is nature and life, not spirit and qi." To speak of spirit and essence is like using yellow leaves to quiet a child’s cry. Without recognizing true gold, how can one distinguish yellow leaves?

Master Zhong said: "The four great elements of the body are all yin; what thing is yang essence? Only when one meets a bright teacher’s guidance does the Daoist immortal’s work become the body’s affair." And again: "The intermingling of being and non-being is the root of the elixir; concealment and revelation supporting each other are water and metal. Do not cling to this body as the Dao/Way—cultivating a single thing is solitary yin."

Combining the Master’s teachings, there must be what is called the "true seed." Yet if it is not sought beyond this body, its meaning is profound.

**Seventh Passage**

Niiwan Shi said: So it is.

The *Daode Jing* states:
*"There is a thing, chaotic yet complete,
born before heaven and earth.
Silent and void,
it stands alone and does not change,
circling endlessly without cease.
It may be called the Mother of all under heaven.
I know not its name—
reluctantly, I call it the Dao/Way."*

And again:
*"Vague and elusive,
yet within it there is form.
Dim and obscure,
yet within it there is essence.
Its essence is most real,
within it there is truth."*

This one thing lies sealed within the mountain of form. The ancients said: *"Seek it not within the body, nor gather it outside the body."* Vague and elusive, it seems to dwell in the void and the obscure, yet it does not lie beyond the single aperture of the Mysterious Pass. This aperture—boundless in its vastness, infinitesimal in its smallness—cannot be grasped by thought nor opened by effort. The method lies only in equating the body with emptiness, releasing all concerns, forgetting even emptiness, forgetting even stillness. Then the spirit enters of itself, and qi emerges from within. When the qi-body intermingles, without head or tail, this is the manifestation of that thing, the first sign of the body beyond the body. If this aperture does not open, even if one severs the dragon and transforms the spirit, it remains but an illusory existence like yellow leaves—how can it be called "conceiving the embryo" or "entering the gate"? What was shown in the previous passage is still but yellow leaves, not true gold.

**Taixu Shi said:**
Massage, though delusive, cannot be discarded, for without it the qi-mechanism does not flow. Visualization, though false, cannot be abandoned, for without it qi and essence are insufficient. Advancing further, even when one cultivates to the point of having a thing and yet no thing, the Master’s intent does not yet deem this ultimate—because it is still but this-side’s affair! Nevertheless, when this-side’s affair is exhausted, that side becomes easily accessible. If that side remains unopened, the mechanism is blocked by layered mountains. When it opens, intention draws it forth—smooth and abundant, the four neighbors arrive of themselves. Thus, though separated by mountains or lakes, the qi-mechanism flows as if face to face. What is the method? The Master said: *"Emit light to draw it, gather the mind to await it."* If the other ascends while I descend, if the other retreats while I return, the meeting is futile. The method lies only in stillness amid motion, in emptiness that is receptive. When the qi-mechanism arrives, one senses a harmonious ease, yet remains still and unmoving, enveloping it with intention, concealing it within inner refinement. From *kun* it reaches *gen*, riding the raft into the Milky Way. One perceives golden lightning flashing, cool qi filling the void, like clouds or mist swirling inside and out. At this moment, guard against stray thoughts—whether desire or doubt—dismiss them the instant they arise. One feels a certain qi-mechanism, smooth and all-pervading, without inside or outside, without boundary or limit. In an instant, transformations unfold endlessly, beyond reckoning, beyond depiction, beyond speech. Yet there are also times of stillness without radiance, pitch-black as night. These are all called *"mysterious shadows"* or *"perfected images of the other shore."* In truth, they are the perfect interpenetration of self and other—what is called the three realms of the *Avataṃsaka*, *Śūraṅgama*, and *Lotus Sūtras*, the wondrous scenes of the Three Mountains and Ten Isles. In essence, they are the qi-mechanism of self-and-other’s transformative work; the other shore is not truly other. Yet the attainment of the other shore does not lie beyond this.

The Master said: *"I once inquired of the Pure and Primordial Sovereign Lady. She replied, ‘So it is, so it is.’ And again, ‘Why should the practice of men be any different?’"*

The Eighth Principle

Niwan Shi states:
There is a gatha that says:
*"Revolving back and forth, the affairs of heaven and earth—*
*the two qi conjoin in essence, merging with the Gen Metal."*

It further says:
*"The hawk seizes the swallow, the falcon strikes the winter crow."*

In the subtlest of the subtle, the wondrous of the wondrous, it does not depart from *"knowing the white yet guarding the black"* or *"knowing the male yet guarding the female."* How could it ever depart from *"preserving the insubstantial while guarding the substantial"*?

Taixu Shi comments:
The *Dao De Jing* and *Nanhua* are not texts women can recite daily. The *Qingjing Jing* alone should be read until familiar. Internally, one must revere it; externally, only the *Kunning* and *Zhenyi* sutras suffice! For without penetrating nature, life cannot be preserved; without strict discipline, merit cannot be steadfast.

The Master’s cited gatha is profoundly recondite—how could it be easily fathomed? Even when bathed in the revelation of the supreme Dharma, ordinary women remain bewildered, gazing in vain. Such is the case everywhere. For it contains the entire *Fire Record* within; only by thoroughly studying the *Huangdi Yinfu Jing* and examining the *Longhu*, *Cantong*, and *Wuzhen* classics can one begin to grasp its meaning.

I shall briefly outline its contours:
*"Revolving back and forth, its affairs cycle endlessly.*
*Discern the one within the one—*
*ever does the one stand before you.*
*All arises from the two qi,*
*their essence conjoined, shadows myriad.*
*When the body is empty of the one, it manifests;*
*it can embrace the great thousand worlds.*
*The great thousand’s radiant shadows—*
*radiant, they are that primordial source.*
*If not led astray by the primordial,*
*the primordial origin is my own origin.*
*Primordial origins are not one,*
*yet each one is wholly complete.*
*Abiding still, never releasing—*
*how could such effort be ordinary?*
*Swallows and sparrows follow their own ways,*
*winter crows endure the cold.*
*When not hungry, they do not come;*
*when the time arrives, they feast at will.*
*This is the wondrous within the wondrous,*
*the mysterious within the mysterious.*
*Knowing the white, thus guarding the black,*
*one attains the great wholeness in profound contemplation.*
*How does it achieve this?*
*The utmost and the limitless are both contained within."*

Such is the essence of the Master’s profound teaching. Yet though *"being and non-being arise mutually,"* one must follow a single path in taking and relinquishing. Without transforming the physical form, nothing can be accomplished.

**Ninth Entry**

The Mud-Pill Master said: Excellent indeed are your words.

There are principles to be observed: If one wishes to transcend the mundane, one must first purify mundane thoughts and subsequently empty the Three Realms. Yet one must not transgress inner propriety—neither flatter ghosts and spirits, nor fail in filial piety, reverence, kindness, and compassion, nor disobey the Master. Be yielding, smooth, advantageous, and steadfast, never deviating from the Way of Earth. In movement, follow principle; in stillness, dissolve into suchness. Encompass the wondrous Dao in wielding the dustpan and broom; awaken to the firing times in tending the stove and cooking.

The poem says:
*Gentle and graceful, like mountains, like rivers—*
*If this child is unworthy, what can be said?*

Such is the admonition—how profound!

---

The Master of Great Emptiness said: The purport of this entry by the Master is subtle indeed. For those in the world who take refuge in the Dao or in the Buddha, few adhere to inner propriety, and rare are those who recognize the nature-essence. Though they may be yielding and compliant in serving their teachers, they often harbor resentment and defy ethical norms. Such disciples and masters bring disgrace upon the teachings of proper conduct—nay, they cast themselves into the Iron Enclosure and Avīci hells. Is this not lamentable?

A Record by Min Yide:
My master, the Venerable Master of Great Emptiness, received the supreme great Dao from his ancestral master, the Mud-Pill Master, in nearly its entirety, as is further evident in this text. Yet this core transmission is not merely a precious raft for the feminine school. Within it, the masculine school’s esoteric secrets are also subtly revealed—more than can be counted.

The original manuscript, having been copied and recopied through transmission, contains many errors and corruptions. I have carefully corrected and collated it.
