Regrettably, *The Precious Raft of Dual Cultivation for the Masculine School* was taken away by Yuan of Changshan. I shall seek it out; it should not be lost.

For within the masculine school’s texts, the feminine school’s precious secrets are also embedded. Yet its transcribed copies contain many omissions. If it can be obtained and corrected, then published together with this work, they will form a complete treasure. The two texts may then be cross-referenced, and their salvific merit shall be no small thing.

I record this to inform the gentlemen who possess the masculine school’s texts: To destroy or discard sacred scriptures is to invite karmic retribution in the unseen realm. As the sutras warn, can one afford not to be cautious?

Respectfully inscribed by Min Yide of Golden Canopy Mountain.
On the full moon of the first autumn month, in the gengyin year of the Daoguang reign (1830).

Here follows the translation of the *Dharani Sutra for Upholding the World* as transmitted in the tradition:

---

**Practice of the Full *Dharani Sutra for Upholding the World* (with Reference Annotations)**
Transmitted by Master Tuoluo of the Western Land’s Mind School, the hundredth-generation disciple;
Compiled by the hundred-and-first-generation Perfected Immortal;
Carved by the hundred-and-second-generation Guardian of Nature, Shouxing.

**Purification Mantras:**
*Mantra for Purifying the Body:* Oṃ (drawn out) kha-laṃ.
*Mantra for Purifying the Mind:* Oṃ (drawn out) maṇi padme (two syllables merged) hūṃ (pronounced "ho").
*Mantra for Purifying the Intent:* Oṃ (drawn out) siddhaṃ padma-dhara.

**Invocation:**
Homage to the Buddhas abiding in the ten directions.
Homage to the Dharmas abiding in the ten directions.
Homage to the Saṅghas abiding in the ten directions.
Homage to Śākyamuni Buddha.
Homage to *Śūraṅgama*, the Crown of Buddha’s Head.
Homage to Avalokiteśvara Bodhisattva of the Southern Heavens.
Homage to Vajragarbha Bodhisattva.
Homage to the Venerable Miaoyue of Infinite Longevity.
Homage to the Venerable Tuoluo, Heir of the Western Transmission to the East.

**Opening Gāthā:**
The wondrous, all-encompassing, immovable honored one,
King of the *Śūraṅgama*, whose body pervades the world.
Able to dissolve inverted thoughts of countless kalpas,
Attaining the Dharma-body without traversing asaṃkhyeya aeons.
Proclaimed by the Bhagavān himself,
This sutra is called *Dharani for Upholding the World*.
Those who receive and uphold it, widely proclaiming its teaching,
Shall, in a snap of the fingers, fulfill their vows, leaving nothing amiss.
In this very life, they shall penetrate the supreme Dao,
Within the boundless, witness the unborn and unceasing.
This is the world-realized dharani,
The adamantine heart of Śakra, unshaken and unturned.
We humbly pray the World-Honored One to silently protect our vows,
That in body and world, governance and peace may become non-dual and one.

**The *Dharani Sutra for Upholding the World* Spoken by the Buddha**

Thus have I heard. At one time, the Bhagavān was in the country of Kauśāmbī (this was the ancient island of Takṣaśilā, now the land of Russia; the *Records of the Western Regions* do not describe it in great detail, but the imperial preface to this sutra provides a thorough account). There, in the Takṣaśilā Grove, he was accompanied by a great assembly of five hundred bhikṣus. Surrounding him were bodhisattvas mahāsattvas beyond reckoning, along with devas, humans, asuras, and other innumerable great beings.

At that time, in that country, there was a elder named Miaoyue. His bearing was refined and gentle, his aspirations serene and far-reaching. He had many sons, daughters, and servants. He held deep reverence for the Buddha, the Dharma, and the Saṅgha. He came to where the Buddha was, prostrated at his feet, circumambulated him a hundred thousand times, then stood to one side, joined his palms in respect, and addressed the Buddha:

“World-Honored One, I wish to inquire about a small matter that troubles the Tathāgata, the Arhat, the Perfectly Enlightened One. I pray that out of great compassion, you will grant me leave to speak.”

Then the World-Honored One, moved by compassion for him, spoke in a voice of tender mercy: “Ask whatever you wish. I shall explain it to you in a way that brings joy to your heart.”

The elder, overjoyed, bowed his head in reverence, joined his palms, and said: “World-Honored One, how may good men and good women—those who are poor and lowly—attain wealth and nobility? How may the sick be cured, the guilty absolved, and the fearful find peace?”

The World-Honored One, though already knowing, asked the elder: “Why do you ask this?”

The elder again addressed the Buddha: “World-Honored One, we householders have many dependents, yet our resources are meager and insufficient to provide for them. We suffer from illnesses, karmic burdens, and fears. Therefore, I beseech the World-Honored One to teach us a skillful means by which the poor and lowly may gain great wealth and status, abundantly support their families, widely practice generosity, and endlessly fill their granaries; by which the sick may harmonize the four great elements, diligently cultivate virtuous deeds, and remain untiring in body and mind; by which the guilty may swiftly have their sins eradicated, and at the end of this life, be reborn in a good destiny; and by which the fearful may find peace in body and mind, draw near to and make offerings to the Three Jewels of Buddha, Dharma, and Saṅgha, and swiftly realize the supreme, perfect enlightenment.”

Then the World-Honored One said to the elder: “Good man, in the past, countless kalpas ago, I encountered the Buddha World-Honored One named *Vajraghoṣa-sāgara-nāda-tathāgata*, the Arhat, the Perfectly Enlightened One, the One of Perfect Clarity and Conduct, the Well-Gone, the Knower of the World, the Unsurpassed Trainer of Men to Be Tamed, the Teacher of Devas and Humans, the Buddha, the Bhagavān. To bring benefit and happiness to all beings, he taught a dharani called *Upholding the World*. When I heard it, I rejoiced and received it, recited it, and widely proclaimed it to others, bringing benefit and happiness to countless beings. Through this cause and condition, my merit and wisdom grew, and I swiftly realized the supreme, perfect enlightenment. Now, for the sake of devas and humans, I expound this subtle and wondrous Dharma. You and all others should listen attentively, receive and uphold it, and widely proclaim it. The spiritual power of this mantra is inconceivable. All beings who encounter it shall attain benefit and happiness.”

**The Dharani:**
Suru-bi, badara-vati, pu-jelī, e-jelī, e-jebo-lī.
Uṃga-jeni, ava-dani, saha-vati, dhāna-vati, dana-vati, śrī-moti, para-vavati.
Yan-molī, vi-molī, ruru-suru, pavi-molī, e-nana-siddhi, vi-dasiddhi, vi-śva-śīśi, yaṃguli, maṃguli.
Vivimi, dudumi, dada-lī, dalo-dalo, va-jelī, va-jelī, kacīlai kacīlai, va-liṣani, ni-seva-dani, va-jelo-dalo.
Sagelo, ni-ju-śaṃ, dahe-gadaṃ, e-nu-samo-lo.
Dahe-gata, sa-dian-samo-lo, dharma-sa-dian-samo-lo, saṃgha-sa-dian-samo-lo, dada dada, pulo-pulo, pulā-pulaya.
Balo-balo-ni, su-pu-jelī, śāṇḍa-moti, pu-jera-vati, su-badalo-vati, a-geca, a-geca, sa-moyaṃ, a-nu-samo-lo svāhā.
A-va-lanaṃ, e-nu-samo-lo svāhā.
Para-vaji (pronounced "śu"), e-nu-samo-lo svāhā.
Dili-caṃ, e-nu-samo-lo svāhā.

---

"Vi-jiē-yán, e-nu-samo-lo svāhā. Sá-fó sá-duǒ, pí-nà-yán, e-nu-samo-lo svāhā."

This dharani possesses great spiritual power. If good men and good women receive and uphold it with sincere hearts, and widely expound it to others, all evil spirits, ghosts, devas, dragons, yakṣas, humans, and non-humans shall be unable to harm them, and all matters of benefit and happiness shall increase day and night. If one can reverently make offerings to the Three Jewels, recite this dharani sutra with utmost sincerity, and do so continuously for seven days and nights without interruption, all devas, dragons, and spirits will rejoice and come of their own accord to secretly bestow the wealth and grain one requires. Famine, epidemics, and pestilence shall all be dispelled, all karmic obstacles shall be eradicated without exception, every danger and fear shall be pacified, merit and wisdom shall gradually increase, and all aspirations shall be fulfilled, swiftly attaining the supreme, right, and equal enlightenment.

At that time, the Buddha addressed Elder Miaoyue: "You should faithfully receive this dharani, remember it, recite it, and widely expound it to others. All that you seek in benefit and happiness shall be perfectly realized." Upon hearing the Buddha’s words, the elder rejoiced and exclaimed, "I shall receive and uphold it, widely expound it to others, and bring benefit and happiness to countless beings. I only pray that the World-Honored One will compassionately protect and remember me." The World-Honored One replied, "So it is, so it is." Then the elder joined his palms respectfully, circumambulated the World-Honored One hundreds of thousands of times to the right, prostrated at the Buddha’s feet, and departed joyfully.

At that time, the World-Honored One told Ānanda: "Elder Miaoyue’s various storehouses of wealth and grain are now all filled to abundance." Ānanda rejoiced and asked the Buddha, "For what reason are Elder Miaoyue’s storehouses suddenly filled to abundance?" The Buddha told Ānanda: "Elder Miaoyue, having heard the great dharani I expounded, deeply believed and rejoiced in it, received and recited it, and vowed to proclaim it for the sake of countless beings. By the power of this merit, his storehouses are now full. You, too, should receive, recite, and widely expound this dharani, so that all beings in this trichiliocosm may attain benefit and happiness. I observe that in this world, even Māra, Brahmā, and others cannot transgress or corrupt the words of this dharani. It is truly indestructible. Therefore, those of meager merit cannot hear it. Why is this so? These verses have been uniformly praised by all buddhas of the three times, and through their inconceivable spiritual power, those who hear and uphold them shall all attain benefit and happiness."

The Venerable Ānanda rejoiced wholeheartedly and praised in exquisite gāthā:
"The inconceivable are the buddhas,
As is the Dharma they expound.
Those who rightly practice it
Shall likewise reap inconceivable fruit.
The King of Dharma, omniscient,
Extinguishes birth, aging, sickness, and death.
Having reached the farthest shore,
I bow to the Great Awakened One."

Then Ānanda, overjoyed, prostrated to the Buddha, joined his palms, and said: "World-Honored One, by what name should this Dharma gate be called? How should we receive and uphold it?" The Buddha told Ānanda: "This may be called *The Questions of Elder Miaoyue*, or *The Dharani That Attracts All Wealth and Status*, or *The Healer of Illness*, or *The Eradicator of Sins*, or *The Remover of All Dangers and Fears*, or *The Dharani Universally Praised by All Buddhas*, or *The Dharani Blessed by the Spiritual Power of All Buddhas*, or *The Dharani Sutra That Upholds the World*. You should uphold and preserve it, never allowing it to be forgotten, so as to bring benefit and happiness to all beings."

When the Bhagavān had finished speaking this sutra, innumerable voice-hearers and bodhisattvas, along with devas, humans, asuras, and all the great assembly, having heard the Buddha’s words, rejoiced greatly, faithfully received, and put them into practice. They took the Three Refuges and departed:
"Taking refuge in the Buddha,
May all beings
Comprehend the great Dao
And arouse the unsurpassed mind."

"Taking refuge in the Dharma,
May all beings
Plunge deep into the treasury of sutras
And let their wisdom become as vast as the sea.

Taking refuge in the Sangha,
May all beings
Guide and harmonize the great assembly
With perfect freedom from obstruction.
Homage to the sacred assembly.

For all who uphold this sutra and mantra, it is customary to establish an altar, with offerings pure and abundant. Let their demeanor be serene and refined, their qi harmonious and peaceful, their chanting measured and balanced—neither too high nor too low, neither scattered nor forced. Let each word and syllable flow from the celestial nature of their own being.

It is especially fitting to contemplate the yet-to-be-realized within the realm of absolute nothingness, where no-thing exists. Thus may the distinction between Buddha and ordinary being dissolve, and the boundaries between world-as-body and body-as-world melt into oneness, thereby realizing the great *dharani* of world-as-body and body-as-world. Only then does one truly uphold—whether one upholds or not, whether one does not uphold yet upholds.

With long and steady practice, this transforms the self, so that the crown of one’s being merges with the primordial Heart-King, which is none other than the Tathagata of Supreme Victory in the Western Buddha’s Crown. This is what is called the strong name of non-duality.

Indeed, when one presses forward in practice, all arises from serenity, refinement, harmony, and balance—attained within the interplay of action and non-action.

My teacher expounded these profound principles to the world in this manner. A true immortal respectfully records them.

*A Brief Preface to the Rules for Practicing the Dharani Sutra That Upholds the World*
By Min Zhenxian

The establishment of altars and all associated regulations are designed for those who seek immediate realization. For monastics and laypersons alike, in their ordinary practice, sincerity alone suffices.

As the *Shurangama Sutra* states: *"Even if there are beings whose minds are scattered and not in samadhi, who merely recall and recite the mantra with their minds and mouths, the Vajra-King will constantly follow such good men. How much more so for those who have aroused the mind of bodhi!"* It further says: *"Even if one does not set up an altar, does not enter a sacred space, and does not perform the ritual, the merit remains undiminished. Even those who merely recite, read, copy, or wear this mantra on their person, or place it in their dwelling, garden, or estate—if they have accumulated karmic obstructions, these will melt away like snow in hot water, and before long, they will awaken to the patience of non-arising."*

In essence, one must align the three mysteries: the mouth reciting the divine mantra, the mind visualizing the Sanskrit characters, and the hands forming the mudras—these are called the three altars. However, this is not easily achieved by beginners. My teacher, Yedanpo She, following the *Three Ni Medical Salvation Practice*, compiled a simplified method to transmit to me. The Buddha’s teaching on the character *shi* (world) unites world-as-body and body-as-world, a principle no different from the宗旨 of medical salvation. The Daoist tradition speaks of: *"The heart is heaven, the body is earth, and thought is humanity."*

Truly, humanity stands between heaven and earth, and just as earth and heaven, without minds of their own, entrust their mind to humanity, so too, when considering world-as-body and body-as-world: the master of the world is humanity, and the master of the body is spirit.

Based on this principle, the ancient sage Pure Yang created the *Egg-Guarding Practice*, wherein world-as-body and body-as-world merge in mutual generation, transformation, coagulation, and differentiation, following a cyclical pattern. Its essence lies in the cultivation of nothingness—even the absence of nothingness—as its foundation. The practice relies on embracing the empty to contain the real, and returning the real to the empty, placing all notions of existence and non-existence, reality and illusion, in a state of non-abiding and non-attachment. Proceeding from awakening without clinging, one delves deeply into forgetfulness, which is also liberation, ultimately achieving the practice’s goal: the mind’s return to purity and oneness.

What is this oneness? It is the continuous flow of thought returning to the celestial nature of the self. Thus, all intonation becomes the music of heaven, and through the resonance of intonation, transformation arises spontaneously. Yet few in the world can receive and uphold this, for most cling to the idea of uninterrupted recitation while failing to grasp the profound meaning of the seven days and seven nights. They claim their nature is not original and their body no longer pristine, their primordial vitality already broken. How could they sustain seven days and seven nights without interruption? Gazing in vain, they sigh in despair.

For this reason, worldly scholars assert that only those born with innate knowledge and heavenly endowment can achieve this. My teacher, however, laments that worldly knowledge is born of a narrow worldview, thus cut off from the world, and fears to arouse compassion. Little do they know that even the five foolish men attained Buddhahood—what is there to fear in learning, and why would one not practice and transmit this?

I, Zhenxian, have kept these teachings in my heart for over forty years. Upon examining my teacher’s instructions and comparing them with Daoist and Buddhist scriptures, I find they all breathe the same essence. Yet without those who receive and transmit these teachings heart-to-heart, it is difficult to avoid misunderstanding. Nevertheless, what matters is the transmission of sincerity—what is called *"exhausting the heart and fulfilling one’s nature."*

Thus, I set these rules to writing under the title *Practice Guidelines*. Whether the world receives them or not, I leave to my disciples.

Min Zhenxian’s retrospective account, written at Chrysanthemum Hermitage by Lake Shun.
On the day after the Winter Solstice in the fourteenth year of the Daoguang era, the year *jiawu*.

*Practice Guidelines* (Four Articles)

**Establishing the Altar**
When establishing an altar, use either three plain rooms or one large room, free of extraneous furnishings. Place a round table in the center, upon which a small wooden stupa is set—either six-sided or eight-sided, with each face carved with the image of a principal Buddha. Before each image, offer incense, flowers, lamps, water, and rice, emphasizing purity over abundance.

Outside the round table, place a small square half-table on each side, used for offering lamps and incense. Beyond the half-tables, arrange indigo mats made of calabash cotton or similar material, about a foot away from the table, for prostration.

Cover the floor with striped felt for seated meditation. The altar room should have side doors in the *qian* (northwest) and *kun* (southwest) positions, while the main door is opened in the *li* (south) position.

The round table’s circumference should be designed like a canopy with a flat top, serving as a tablecloth. The half-tables are pure purple, while the round table is entirely crimson. [Regarding] attire..."

For augmentation, use golden yellow; for reverence and affection, use crimson; for disaster mitigation, use white; for longevity, use blue-green; for subjugation, use black.

For all ordained disciples, wear a robe with an outer surplice; for lay practitioners, a Daoist robe or formal attire will suffice.

**On Holding the Dharma**

"Holding" means *timeliness*. Who can truly grasp the moment of holding? Who attains it through holding? Only the Buddha does. Thus, to hold with timeliness—how could this be merely an exercise in mystery? As this sutra reveals, the words issue from the Buddha’s own mouth, teaching the method of skillful action. Only by concealing the spirit in secrecy can one evoke responses without fail and respond without missing any evocation—like a single fist shattering the roundness of form and function.

Those who wish to practice this must first recognize that within one seven-day period, one must cultivate without the slightest lapse until the body becomes whole. Then, one forgets the seven days and nights, cultivating without pause until reaching the state of forgetting even the act of forgetting. Only then does one’s application become effortlessly spiritual—this is the method of holding this *dhāraṇī*.

**On Recitation**

According to this sutra’s instructions on recitation, its principle is profound, and its application, divine. The practitioner must awaken to its meaning through practice. Recitation is neither mere vocalization nor the recitation of *vajra* mantras, nor is it *yoga*—yet it naturally becomes *samādhi*.

If one holds without truly holding, the five viscera, six bowels, three corpses, and nine worms may hear only the melodious sound but fail to comprehend the meaning of the ocean’s tide or the harmony of bees. Yet when the sound touches and abides, all it touches is transformed, and all that abides becomes spiritual—receiving as if bestowed, bestowing as if received.

As the Buddha teaches in this sutra regarding recitation, the practitioner must embody its meaning. My master often said that in holding a *dhāraṇī*, one must attain the sound of the ocean’s tide—vast and boundless, without arising or ceasing. Moreover, one must forget the count of recitations to enter the *samādhi* of recitation. Next, one attains the sound of ten thousand bees swarming at court—a sublime resonance that arises naturally from the forgetting of form and the stilling of emotion. Only then can its efficacy be pure and unfathomable.

The human body is entirely yin in its constituents, and only sound is yang. The *Taiyi* states: "The yang within yang is the soundless sound," referring to this resonance. It further says: "What is difficult to fathom is the primordial mechanism of pre-heaven"—this is the *Taisu*. In the Dao, this is true intention; in the Buddhist canon, it is "non-thought as thought, thought as non-thought."

**Lineage**

The orthodox lineage of *gāthā* began with the primordial *Bhagavān*, who, responding to the times, transmitted it to the Tathāgata of Vigorous Progress. Through the power of this mantra, he attained Buddhahood as Śākyamuni in the present world. The Buddha, in turn, transmitted it to the Elder Wondrous Moon. The elder, with deep faith, received and upheld it, widely expounding it to benefit and liberate all sentient beings—this is the second generation of the orthodox lineage.

An ancient record states: "You shall transmit it in succession, establishing the *Suzong* to assist the orthodox Dharma." This corresponds to the *Xizhu* Mind School, inherited from the Iron Ox Sage Monk, who transmitted it to the Bodhisattva Wondrous Brahma. This sutra and mantra spread to China, translated by the Tripiṭaka Master Xuanzang at imperial command. By the Yuan dynasty, my master, *Yedapocha*, entered Yunnan from *Yuezhi*, residing in *Nanzu*. Tracing back, he became the hundredth-generation lineage holder of the *Suzong*, awaiting transmission. In the autumn of the *renzi* year of the Qianlong reign, I, a humble disciple, had the unimaginable fortune to attend him and receive the Mind Teachings of the *Suzong*, thereby understanding that the three teachings—Confucianism, Daoism, and Buddhism—share a single origin. The laws of heaven and earth are not beyond body and mind, and the operations of practice return to spontaneity. Any slight deviation leads to heterodoxy.

From the initial steps to ultimate completion, it is nothing other than the purification of thought. My master was the hundredth-generation successor of the *Zhuzong* branch of the *gāthā* auxiliary lineage. I, presumptuously inheriting this, am named *Zhenxian*, the first generation of the *Zhuzong*’s later branch. The weight of a single leaf is as heavy as a thousand *jun*—how perilous is even the slightest error! I only pray that the *Bhagavān* Buddha will protect and bless the lineage ancestors, that the Elder Wondrous Moon will perpetuate his vast virtue, and that the compassionate *Baiye Tudo Zongshi* will fulfill his great vow, graciously sheltering and guarding the faithful in the Eastern Land. How fortunate! How fortunate!

Thus, I respectfully record the lineage as follows.

Respectfully composed by Zhenxian.

**Lineage Continuation Verse:**
True守初元一,
All harmonize nature and destiny in perfection.
Virtue flourishes in emptiness and quiescence,
Ever faithful to the root-source of the Dao.
West’s completion arises from East’s endeavor,
Initiating the later while inheriting the former.
Exoteric and esoteric perpetuate the lineage’s seed,
Awakening lies not in verbal explanation.

In total, forty characters. My master, *Yedapocha*, continued and extended this in Jizu Mountain of southern Yunnan during the mid-autumn of the *renzi* year of the Qianlong reign.

Zhenxian has long revered this in his heart. Now, as *Shunhu* Zhou Shouxing remains unacquainted with the regulations and ignorant of those who continue and initiate the *Tudo* lineage, I hereby recount these details anew.

**Exegesis:**
What is *gāthā*? In Chinese, it means "all-obstruction-free."
What is *dhāraṇī*? In Chinese, it means "the supreme mind-melody."
What is *Yedapocha*? In Chinese, it means "the Dao-seeking adept."
What is *Bhagavān*? In Chinese, it signifies one whose virtue is as vast as heaven and earth—conveying the meanings of transcendence, surpassing, and soaring.

**Transmission by the Preceptor Yedapocha:**
The master was named *Yedapocha*, a native of *Yuezhi* in the Western Regions.

In the early Yuan dynasty, he first entered Mount Jizu and resided at Utpala Lodge. There, he delved deeply into the esoteric teachings of the *Bhagavān*—those transmissions beyond the exoteric canon—becoming the revered founder of the *Miaoyue* lineage and the patriarch of its hundredfold descendants, known as the "Dao-seekers of Jizu."

During the Shunzhi reign, he journeyed to the capital to observe its splendor and perform the *yansuo* ritual. Prince Kunyang, moved by his virtue, bestowed upon him the surname *Huang* and the given name *Shouzhong*. Having long cherished the resolve to safeguard Mount Jizu, the Venerable Master repeatedly conferred upon our lineage the Three Precepts. By this time, he had already mastered the Chinese language. In retreat, he engaged in mutual refinement with fellow adepts: Guan Tianxian, Zhang Pengtou, Wang Jinying, Wang Xiuhu, Li Chijiao, Yun Dabian, Li Pengtou, and Wang Dajiao.

In the summer of the *renzi* year of the Qianlong reign, I first paid him homage and stayed the night. On the first day of the third month thereafter, I took leave to return to Wuhua. En route, I encountered an emissary of Governor-General Fu, returning from Mount Jizu, who reported that the Master had passed away on the full moon day. Delayed until the ninth month of autumn, an official from Shu arrived with news: on the full moon of mid-autumn, he had encountered the Master at Deer Grotto on Mount Emei. There, they shared rest, meals, and discourse as in ordinary times.

The Master’s appearance suggested an age of fifty, his eyes usually lowered. When he briefly opened them, their radiance flashed like lightning, piercing to the very viscera, rendering all speechless. He would eat but once a month, consuming only a handful of acorns, never speaking of satiety.

His voice resonated like a bell, yet also like thunder, so that when reciting and upholding the dhāraṇīs, it rang with the sound of metal and iron, while its rhythm arose from the sea—vast and boundless, without beginning or end, like the surging tide. Many repeatedly studied in vain; the Master, however, attained this through cultivation—how could it be achieved by blind practice?

As for the richness of his inner cultivation and the profundity of his attainment, I regret that my time in attendance was too brief to fathom its depths. Yet what already exceeds all expectation is this: the transmission beyond the teachings, passed down through direct inheritance and broadly expounded. Such is the fortune of this humble disciple—and indeed, the great fortune of all in this land who hold faith.

Composed with reverence by the disciple Min Zhenxian.

---

As the *Shūzhū Lèngyán* states: In translating sūtras and dhāraṇīs, there are four conventional methods.
First, both sound and meaning are translated, as in the scriptural texts.
Second, neither sound nor meaning is translated, as with Sanskrit terms from the West.
Third, the sound is translated but not the script, as with the *svastika* (卐).
Fourth, the script is translated but not the sound, as with dhāraṇīs.

There are also five cases where translation is not permitted:
First, the secret dhāraṇīs.
Second, terms encompassing the six meanings of *bhagavat*.
Third, terms with no equivalent, such as the *jambu* tree.
Fourth, terms following ancient precedent, like *anuttarā-saṃyak-saṃbodhi*.
Fifth, terms that inspire reverence, such as *prajñā*.

The *Zhèngmài* states: Exoteric teachings are like a physician openly prescribing medicine, while esoteric dhāraṇīs are like a physician administering treatment in secret—each unfolds three kinds of power.
First, the power of principle and dharma, where a single syllable contains boundless wondrous truths, as in *yuan heng li zhen*.
Second, the power of awe and virtue.
Third, the power of the sacred names of the Three Jewels.
Great as a king’s ministers, when one invokes the Three Jewels, the vocal power of true words and dhāraṇīs enables transcendence from the mundane to the sacred, like a royal decree ascending to the throne.

Changshui states: Since ancient times, dhāraṇīs have not been translated, and the reasons are roughly five.
First, they are the secret speech of the Buddhas, which even other sages cannot comprehend.
Second, they are the secret seals of the Buddhas, like a king’s imperial seal.
Third, they are the *dhāraṇī* gateways encompassing the six meanings of *bhagavat*.
Fourth, they are the names of *yakṣa* and *deva* kings, invoked to command their protection.
Fifth, they possess inconceivable power, pardoning sins and conferring rank.

Gushan states: Secret dhāraṇīs in the sūtras are never translated, and ancient masters have offered various explanations. Tiantai harmonizes them under the four *siddhānta*:
First, dhāraṇīs are the names of *yakṣa* and *deva* kings; invoking their royal titles and domains commands their reverence, preventing misconduct—this is the benefit of worldly joy.
Second, dhāraṇīs are like secret military codes; when matched, no interference arises, but when unmatched, punishment follows—this is the benefit of generating goodness in people.
Third, dhāraṇīs secretly suppress evil, unknown to others. Like a lowly man fleeing to another land and falsely claiming to be a prince, he marries a princess, but his many faults make matters difficult. When someone comes to expose him, a single verse silences all—this is the benefit of counteracting evil.
Fourth, dhāraṇīs are the secret speech of the Buddhas, known only to the enlightened, like a king seeking *cintāmaṇi* (仙陀婆), which has four names: *siddha*, *amṛta*, *kalaśa*, and *aśva*. His ministers do not understand, but his wise minister does. A single word of the dhāraṇī encompasses all powers—curing illness, eradicating sins, generating goodness, aligning with the Dao, and entering principle. The supreme meaning of dhāraṇīs truly embodies these four benefits.

Hanxi states: The first is the names of *yakṣa* and *deva* kings, such as *piśāca*, *kumbhāṇḍa*, *ketu*, and *raha*, or *bhagavat* and *bhagavati*, which are also the names of Buddhas and bodhisattvas. These invoke their gratitude upon hearing. Others, like *vajra*, *guhyaka*, and *gaurī*, are the names of *vajra*-guardians, invoking their awe—both are benefits of joy.
Whether as secret military commands, silent suppression of evil, or the secret speech of the Buddhas, the purpose is always to bring joy, generate goodness, eradicate evil, and enter principle in those who hear and uphold them. Thus, the exoteric and esoteric teachings share the same meaning and benefit.

Changshui also states: The opening syllables *taṭha* and subsequent dhāraṇī phrases are all invocations of bodhisattvas, noble sages, and the vow for their protection, delivering beings from the sufferings of hungry ghosts, illness, and other calamities. Only after the *oṃ* syllable is the dhāraṇī’s essence expounded. This section is the secret *Śūraṅgama*, untranslated since ancient times.

The *Supplement* states: The secret speech of the sacred realm—how could ordinary beings comprehend it? Even if rendered in Chinese, the meaning would remain obscure.

For instance, when naming things through speech, the things themselves are not different, yet later generations may not understand—just as the great *wu* with soft fur is used to summon cattle and sheep, or clear rinsing and pure libations are used to invoke water and drink, while the common and vulgar fail to grasp what such terms signify. The discourse of exoteric and esoteric teachings is likewise.

The preceding discussions all explain why secret speech is left untranslated. Yet in this school’s exegesis, we find: examining the works of ancient worthies, some did render both sound and meaning. In Dharmarakṣa’s *Saddharma Puṇḍarīka* of the Jin dynasty, the dhāraṇī incantations were translated both in characters and in sound. In the *Dhāraṇī of the Questions of Brahmā the Devout*, the syllables and sounds of the incantations were likewise fully rendered.

There are also the five cases where translation is withheld:
- *Bhagavat* is rendered as "Sacred Honored One,"
- *Jambudvīpa* as "Continent of Winning Gold,"
- *Vajra Anuttarā Samyaksaṃbodhi* as "Unsurpassed Awakening,"
- *Prajñā* as "Wisdom,"
- while *mantra* remains untranslated as "secret speech."

How then could one claim that all secret incantations are untranslatable? In the *Jingangzhi Tripiṭaka*’s *Manual of Recitation*, the master translator Amoghavajra briefly rendered incantations into Chinese. Śubhakarasiṃha’s *Commentary on the *Prajñāpāramitā* and *Principle of the Tathāgata’s Realm***,** and the Song dynasty Tripiṭaka master Gunabhadra’s translation of the *Forty-Eight Divine Incantations*—interpreted by the National Preceptor Huayan—along with Nāgārjuna Bodhisattva’s exegesis of the *Cundī Dhāraṇī* in the *Small Treasury of Brightness*, and the various esoteric utterances for the protection of the realm’s sovereign in the *Dhāraṇī Sūtras*, the *Sūtra of the Great Compassionate Empty Wisdom’s Single Syllable*, and others—all these were personally praised and explained by the Buddha and bodhisattvas, expounding the seed-syllable incantations of *nirvāṇa* and *prajñā*. In the *Avataṃsaka Sūtra*, the Buddha, together with Mahākāśyapa, Subhūti, and the assembly of spiritual friends, elucidated the meanings of the forty-two letters. Thus, it is evident that the true words of all secret teachings may indeed be translated and interpreted according to the esoteric treasury.

The Sanskrit *namo* is rendered as "taking refuge and paying homage"; *Buddha* as "Awakened One," encompassing the three meanings of self-awakening, awakening others, and perfect awakening; *Dharma* signifies "that which can be followed and upheld," referring to the Three Treasuries and the twelve divisions of scripture; *Saṅgha* is translated as "harmonious assembly," possessing two meanings in one principle: harmony in realizing the twofold *nirodha* of the unconditioned, and harmony in shared practice—harmony in precepts, views, benefit, physical dwelling, speech without contention, and mental joy. The Sanskrit *kalpa* is rendered as "time division."

*(The above is excerpted from the *Lengyan Shuzuan* for reference.)*

Tuda states: The incantation *namo* is first translated as "taking refuge," then as *nāmo*; the Song dynasty Tripiṭaka master further rendered it as "emptiness of nature," which is a translation of meaning. Later, it became a transliteration of sound, while the Song master still translated its meaning. Yet upon examination, *namo* can be understood both as character and sound, embodying the principle of the mind’s emptiness and nothingness—what the ancients called "thoroughly penetrating Sanskrit without departing from the mind." For speech is the voice of the mind, and thus one need only follow the characters, discerning whether they include the "mouth" radical to grasp their meaning.

It is also said: *(From the *Lengyan Shuzuan*: This passage may serve as an annotation for the two characters *namo*.)* The *Lengyan Shuzuan* states: The Sanskrit *asaṃkhyeya* is rendered as "innumerable." When the phrase "three asaṃkhyeya kalpas" is used, it refers to the cultivation of causes over countless eons, thereby illustrating the difficulty of attainment and the importance of steadfast sincerity in practice. The *Śūraṅgama* verse declares, *"Dissolving my eons of inverted thoughts, / Without traversing asaṃkhyeyas, I guard the Dharma-body,"* signifying that those who see their nature attain clarity in a single instant, and with that clarity, all is immediately understood—thus obviating the need for three asaṃkhyeyas, for enlightenment may be realized in a single moment.

*(This excerpt is drawn from my teacher’s annotations, preserved here for reference.)*

The *Lengyan Shuzuan* states: In the *Śūraṅgama Dhāraṇī*, only after the syllable *oṃ* does the heart of the incantation begin. Following the translation and commentary of Master Huaixiu of Xunzhou during the Tang dynasty—recorded in the deep-character volume of the *Great Treasury*, and later rendered into accessible language by Ming dynasty master Shiyuan—twenty-four benefits are enumerated:
1. Knowing the names and titles of the Buddhas ensures constant vision of their bodies;
2. Recognizing the Three Jewels as one’s refuge invokes their majestic virtue and protection;

3. Knowing the names of the vajra-generals ensures all demonic forces submit in surrender;
4. Knowing the hosts of ghostly and divine kings invokes their protection, averting misfortune;
5. Knowing the Buddha’s dhāraṇī establishes it as the supreme among the five divisions;
6. Knowing the crown dhāraṇī, when recited, invokes the Buddhas’ empowerment upon the head;
7. The divine dhāraṇī’s numinous efficacy elicits responses beyond thought;
8. The luminous dhāraṇī engenders the great wisdom of radiant light;
9. Knowing the dhāraṇī-king, it reigns as sovereign over all dhāraṇīs;
10. Knowing the heart of the dhāraṇī, recitation reveals the nature and illumines the mind;
11. The dhāraṇī’s seal and mark ensure wealth and nobility without limit;
12. The dhāraṇī’s incantation and transformation render all things unfathomable;
13. The dhāraṇī’s vow and karmic cause fulfill every aspiration;
14. The dhāraṇī’s binding and mutual pledge leave no deviation in fortune or misfortune;
15. The dhāraṇī’s invocation and prayer elicit responses from Buddhas and devas like an echo;
16. The dhāraṇī’s dharma unfolds with eloquence unbound;
17. Knowing the four treasuries as the root of all scripture;
18. Knowing the letters’ exoteric and esoteric forms, from which sages and worthies arise;
19. The meaning of the letters encompasses boundless principles and mysteries;
20. The seed-letters originate as the wisdom-seeds of all Buddhas;
21. The wise intonation of Sanskrit, first transmitted by Buddhas and devas;
22. Knowing the *dhāraṇī* that upholds all, encompassing all dharma and meaning;
23. Knowing the true word as it is—faithful to its utterance, never deceitful;
24. Knowing the secret speech, like a military decree or imperial edict, never to be divulged.

The first four pertain to the five assemblies, while the latter twenty encompass the heart of the dhāraṇī. This synthesis demonstrates the benefits of the dhāraṇī before and after. If one translates the final heart of the dhāraṇī, six further benefits arise:
1. Each syllable contains manifold dharma-meanings;
2. The Sanskrit and Chinese letters attain perfect interpenetration;
3. They manifest the thirty minds of the Three Treasuries;
4. They reveal the wondrous stages of the Three Worthies and beyond;
5. They return to the Thirty-Seven Factors of Enlightenment;
6. They weave all letters into the esoteric scriptures, interspersing the Sanskrit of true words.

How could such inconceivable spiritual efficacy fail to respond? For it is the very heart-essence of all Buddhas, the nature of dharma being thus, each syllable embodying manifold meanings, the bodhisattvas’ vows and practices, and the inconceivable empowering power. These benefits arise from translation, yielding manifold advantages. Thus, one is earnestly exhorted not to speak of it recklessly.

The *Catalogue of Essential Dhāraṇī Sections* in the *Dhāraṇī Gateway* states: The *Yogācāra* assembly expounds five divisions:
1. The Buddha Division, presided over by Vairocana;
2. The Vajra Division, presided over by Akṣobhya;
3. The Jewel Division, presided over by Ratnasambhava;
4. The Lotus Division, presided over by Amitābha;
5. The Karma Division, presided over by Amoghasiddhi.

The *Meaning of Esoteric Practice and Recitation in the Five Divisions* states: The five divisions are the five esoteric *yoga* gateways—namely, the practices of pacification, increase, subjugation, attraction, and love. Here, it pertains to the Buddha Division’s gateway of increasing supramundane dharma.

The *Susiddhikara Sūtra* states: The *Śāntika* practice for pacification, the *Puṣṭika* practice for increase, and the *Ābhicāruka* practice for subjugation. Each of these three divisions possesses three grades of true words:
1. The true words spoken by noble ones—Buddhas, bodhisattvas, pratyekabuddhas, and śrāvakas—are called the true words of noble ones;
2. The true words spoken by devas—from the Pure Abodes to the thirty-two heavens—are called the true words of devas;
3. The true words spoken by earth-dwelling devas—eight classes of divine kings—are called the true words of earth-dwelling devas.

Here, it pertains to the Buddha’s noble division of increasing benefits.

The *Collected Meanings* states: Esoteric divisions comprise three: the Buddha Division, the Bodhisattva Division, and the Ghost and Deva Division. Each discusses three grades of accomplishment for increase: the superior grade for averting disasters, the middle grade for attraction, and the inferior grade for subjugation. The superior grade further divides into three: ritual conduct, meditative visualization, and strict observances—all governed by the unsurpassed bodhicitta. Without a master’s transmission, it is called "stolen dharma"; violating ritual conduct invites karmic retribution; transgressing strict observances and boasting of one’s achievements to others invites extraordinary calamities. All arise from the Buddha’s inconceivable fourfold benefits.

The *Sūtra of the Questions of the Bodhisattva Wonder-Arm* states: If practitioners wish to recite and attain the benefits and accomplishments of *siddhi*, they must not deviate in the slightest from any ritual observance, lest they afford opportunities to demonic obstacles. Thus, practitioners must recite with focused mind, persistently and without interruption, visualizing the seed-letters of the true words with precision, aligning each detail until the *yoga* of effortless wondrous practice is perfected. Moreover, reciters must not allow their minds to wander to other realms, engage in idle chatter, or interrupt their recitation—lest *siddhi* remain unattained. Those who recite without adhering to ritual, upholding precepts, or maintaining purity not only fail to accomplish the dharma but also invite harm. The division’s lord and wisdom-kings are all Buddhas and bodhisattvas, never causing harm. However, their attendants—devas, nāgas, fierce spirits, and ghosts—will inflict harm upon witnessing transgressions.

The *Vajraśekhara Yoga Recitation Sūtra* states: Those who practice *yoga* teachings must possess wisdom, comprehend *samādhi* and true words, abide by the bodhisattva precepts, and arouse bodhicitta. Only with such virtues may one enter the practice.

The *Bodhisattva Good Precepts Sūtra* states: In upholding divine incantations, five prohibitions apply:
1. Do not consume meat;
2. Do not drink alcohol;
3. Do not eat the five pungent roots;
4. Do not engage in sexual misconduct;
5. Do not eat in impure households.

Upholding these five precepts greatly benefits beings and cures afflictions caused by malevolent spirits and poisons.

The *Dharma Garden* states: When monastics and laypeople recite without efficacy, it is due to lack of utmost sincerity, slanderous speech without evidence, textual errors, improper pronunciation, consumption of alcohol or meat, intake of pungent or impure foods, unclean hands, idle chatter, soiled clothing, or unrefined settings. These eight violations of dharma-precepts enable ghosts and spirits to exploit them, inviting misfortune instead. If one wishes to practice, one must bathe, rinse the mouth with fragrant water, cultivate sincere devotion, dedicate merit universally to the six destinies, and maintain unwavering resolve. Only then will the practice yield certain and unmistakable verification.

The *Manifestation of Esoteric and Exoteric Unity* states: The *Vajraśekhara-Susiddhi-Cundī Sūtra* and other scriptures describe how practitioners, through diligent recitation, may dream of buddhas, bodhisattvas, holy monastics, or heavenly generals; or dream of themselves traversing rivers while riding horses through empty space; or encounter various fragrant lights and other extraordinary signs. Upon witnessing such responsive manifestations, one must rouse the three karmic actions, intensify recitation, and refrain from disclosing the visions within the mantra to others. Only when sharing with fellow practitioners—without seeking fame or profit, and with reverence—may one speak of them.

The *Great Compassion Sūtra* states: When one recites with utmost urgency, various demonic obstacles may arise—sudden fear, bodily and mental unease, excessive drowsiness or sleep, difficulty in reciting, visions of strange apparitions, doubts about the mantra, excessive discriminative thoughts, or delusion. To counter these, one should visualize the seed-syllable *lām* (蓝) in Siddham script or the *a* (哑) syllable. Such contemplation naturally dissolves the illusory perceptions, for one should know that all phenomena arise from conditions and are fundamentally empty.

Though the *Five Assemblies of True Words* follow ancient translations, later propagators of the Dharma may adapt the mantras according to their intent, without rigid adherence. To speak when one should not, or to remain silent when one should speak, is to either lose a person or lose one’s words—only the wise avoid both. Thus, Mencius taught five methods of instruction and five refusals to answer, just as the *Śūraṅgama Sūtra* presents four modes of discourse. Esoteric texts remain untranslated to subdue external demonic forces.

The three doctrinal principles elucidated above are critical to the Dharma, particularly in their preface to the mantras. Tuduo said: It lies solely in emptiness, constancy, and sincerity—adhering without fail ensures divine efficacy, with no possibility of error.

The *Commentary on the Five Assemblies of True Words* explains: The five assemblies exist because, as the *Manifestation of Esoteric and Exoteric Unity* states, the sacred mantras in the canon belong to five divisions:
1. The Buddha Division, comprising mantras of all buddhas;
2. The Lotus Division, comprising mantras of all bodhisattvas;
3. The Vajra Division, comprising mantras of all vajra kings;
4. The Jewel Division, comprising mantras of all devas;
5. The Karma Division, comprising mantras of all spirits and ghosts.

In the altar chamber, the five buddhas represent the lords of these five divisions: Vairocana (Buddha Division), Avalokiteśvara (Lotus Division), Vajrapāṇi (Vajra Division), Ratnasambhava (Jewel Division), and Vināyaka (Karma Division). These five assemblies encompass all mantras of the five divisions.

The sixteen offerings of incense, flowers, bowls, and mirrors are also described in the *Vajraśekhara-Yoga Sūtra* as the sixteen great offerings.

The *Commentary on the Single Assembly of True Words* states: In yoga practice, there are four types of recitation:
1. Vocal recitation, reciting aloud;
2. Vajra recitation, silent recitation with closed lips;
3. Samādhi recitation, mental recitation;
4. True-meaning recitation, practicing according to the literal meaning of the syllables.

Alternatively, five types may be distinguished:
1. Breath recitation: Visualizing the mantra syllables, their meaning following the breath—each exhalation emits a syllable, each inhalation draws one in, the syllables luminous like strung pearls, uninterrupted.
2. Yoga recitation: Visualizing the moon disk within the heart, the mantra syllables arranged in sequence, rotating clockwise along the disk’s edge, cycling endlessly.
3. Vajra recitation: Softly reciting the mantra silently.
4. Subdued-voice recitation: Reciting each syllable distinctly, audible only to oneself.
5. Loud recitation: Reciting so others may hear, dispelling evil and generating merit, as detailed in the *Vajraśekhara* and *Five-Syllable Cundī Sūtras*.

In the *Wish-Fulfilling Jewel Sūtra*, the bodhisattva Wonderful Abode asked: Why, when reciting this universal dhāraṇī, does one not see the buddhas of the three times? The Buddha replied: Because one abides in karmic actions, harbors doubts, clings to conditioned thoughts, or lacks skillful means. If one’s mind is free from doubt, resolute, and single-pointed, this is true recitation.

The bodhisattva Wonderful Arm asked: Why do some fail to achieve fruition in mantra recitation? Is it due to the mantra’s inefficacy, untimely practice, unsuitable nature, defective mantra, careless recitation, or incomplete offerings? Vajrapāṇi replied: Those seeking siddhi through mantra practice must abandon all afflictions, arouse deep faith, generate the bodhicitta, revere the Three Jewels (the Saṅgha being the third), shun the ten evil deeds, forsake the web of wrong views, cultivate the ten virtues, rely on a qualified ācārya within the great maṇḍala, resolve with courage, repent past obstacles, seek virtuous companions, make pure offerings, and ensure the mantra is free from errors. If one fails to follow these principles, how can verification arise?

Further, even if one consumes alcohol, pungent foods, or impure substances, wears tattered robes, or lacks an altar, the buddhas and devas will not deem it a transgression. These are expedient teachings of the Tathāgata, adapted to beings’ capacities to grant the four kinds of benefit. One must not cling to doubts, lest one incur loss. This is called the *Vairocana Dharma Assembly*, for all twelve divisions of esoteric teachings flow from the *Dharmakāya* of the true mind of Vairocana (as Master Huai notes, the *Great Vairocana Dharma Assembly*).

**Colophon**
Respectfully examined, this sūtra is called the *Holder of the World*, akin to our tradition’s *Healer of the World*, embodying the meaning of pacifying the world through bodily practice. Its origin traces to the Bhagavān, who expounded the *Dhāraṇī of the Holder of the World* for the world’s sake. Śākyamuni Buddha received it, and the elder Wonderful Moon, along with the four assemblies, propagated it widely. It spread to China beginning in the Zhenguan era of our dynasty. The method of practice is exceedingly simple and easy—only those of meager merit fail to encounter it. Yet even the ignorant, if they possess faith and uphold it, will attain swift verification. Why is this so?

The Great One of the Supreme Unity has said: the mind is Heaven, the body is Earth, and thoughts are humanity. When thus embodied, the Three Powers reside within a single person. In the original human form, above the mind is called Heaven; below the mind are humanity and all things; below the belly are Earth and the seas. Yet the mind encompasses the body, and the body contains thoughts—thus the body is also called the world. World and body, body and world, are neither two nor one. This is to say: that which governs the world is humanity; that which governs the body is thought. Thought is borne by the mind, the mind by Heaven, the body by Earth. Earth and Heaven, being without mind, entrust their mind to humanity—thus humanity becomes the master of creation. Yet humanity belittles its own body and mind.

My master, Yedapoja, has said: "Your ancestor, the Mud-Pill Elder Li, also taught that in the past, the Bhagavān, moved by the world’s drowning in passion, expounded the *Dhāraṇī of the Holder of the World*—nothing more than pacifying the body, pacifying the mind, and pacifying thoughts. For the body is the world, and the world is the body. If one learns to pacify thoughts, the mind becomes clear of itself, and the body cultivates itself—how could the world then remain untamed?"

My master further said: "Did not the Dao Ancestor, Pure Yang, also declare: 'When a common woman harbors grievance, for three years there is no rain'? From this, one may realize that when calamities recur in succession, the Creator is without mind—it merely responds to things as they are. Ah! Body and mind are one. If, like Wonderful Moon, one faithfully upholds and widely propagates this teaching, the world will naturally be transformed. All sentient beings will attain benefit and joy; humans and non-humans alike will rejoice without exception. Without transgression or discord, all will be as they wish—this occurs in but a single instant. For this dhāraṇī flows from the Bhagavān’s heart, its subtle resonance evoking response upon perception. Such is my master’s profound discourse."

On the Winter Solstice of the *jiayin* year of the Daoguang era, the disciple of the lineage Min Zhenxian respectfully inscribed this colophon at Chrysanthemum Hermitage by Lake Shun.

*Notes on the Sūtra of the Dhāraṇī of the Holder of the World Spoken by the Buddha*
Translated by Tripiṭaka Master Xuanzang
Annotated by Fāshēng Jilian

The Great Awakened One states: In the Buddha’s teaching, *shuo* (說) signifies the unfolding of phenomena through discourse; *chi* (持) signifies sheltering through engagement with conditions. To broadly sustain the Three Realms or minutely uphold a single body—all such scriptures are collectively termed *the World*, and their purport is profound.

*Dhāraṇī* is a Sanskrit term. The late master Yedapoja, a native of the Western Regions and a descendant of the Yue and Zhi peoples, once told Jilian: "This world’s Tathāgata’s vast, unobstructed, perfectly complete, and supreme Dharma of the heart—when resolved into three syllables—is perfectly pure and unobstructed. *Da* (陀) encompasses all without concealment; *ra* (羅) embodies boundless wisdom and power; *ni* (尼) embodies the essence of this *Sūtra of the Holder of the World*. The profundity of these three syllables may already be inferred. Their inner function has been revealed eight or nine parts out of ten. If you comprehend the Dao with your body and propagate it with your heart, the resonance of inner and outer will enable you to follow in the footsteps of the Wondrous Moon. What you lack is only the rigorous austerities of past lives."

The sütras of the exoteric canon pertain to the body, while the dhāraṇīs of the esoteric canon rely on the resolve of the heart—thus, there is no hidden mystery concealed within. Such were the words of the late master. Originally, the late master entered China from Yue-zhi and resided on Mount Jizu.

In the thirteenth year of the Shunzhi reign, he received the Dao precepts from the National Preceptor, Master Kunyang Wang, and passed into quiescence in the *renzi* year of the Qianlong era. All his discourses were words that saw the Dao.

I humbly observe: The sütras are but the path shared by sages and commoners alike. Without sincerity, one ought not recite them; yet sincerity does not merely mean fasting and ablutions. If one can emulate the pure conduct of the Elder Wondrous Moon, then even without formal purification, one is purified. Nevertheless, there has never been one who followed the Buddha’s practices while neglecting bodily discipline. What is truly precious is the ability to maintain a universal heart and unify one’s aspirations, setting aside all concern for merit or verification—only then may one approach the Way.

Master Jiti’s teachings emphasized that one should embody the Dao with the body and propagate it with the heart. His discourse was profoundly abstruse yet profoundly apt, for the Three Realms and our bodies are born of the same True One, each possessing its own True One that abides independently. Speaking in terms of the Three Powers, the two great True Ones are wholly entrusted to humanity, and in terms of the body, they reside in the heart. Thus, if one propagates from the heart, the resonance within will not extend beyond itself. Reciting with the mouth while contemplating with the heart accelerates the response. For the Three Realms are but one vast mental realm, and that which connects them is intention—is intention not the voice of the heart?

The exoteric canon teaches recitation to people, yet this is the most profound and secret technique of the esoteric canon. It is only that people diminish their own hearts and bodies. Now, I note that when the Elder Wondrous Moon received the teaching, he joined his palms in reverence and circumambulated the World-Honored One a hundred thousand times to the right, then prostrated at the Buddha’s feet and departed in joy. The Buddha then told Ānanda that all the treasuries of that elder were now filled to abundance, for he was able to arouse the great vow, widely expound the teaching for others, and bring benefit and bliss to sentient beings. Moreover, he knew to seek the Buddha’s protection and mindfulness—this was the result.

Examining his conduct, it is clear he served the Dao with his very body. I, Jilian, have further reflections on this. My late master, the Venerable Taixu, said: The Western teaching, *The Dhāraṇī Sūtra of the Holder of the World*, was spoken by the Bhagavān in accordance with time, place, and person, emerging in the Western Regions. Such accounts are recorded in present-day Urus (note: Urus is the ancient state of *Kao-chang-mi*, now known as *E-lo-ssu* [Russia]). This was the ancient kingdom of Kauśāmbī, where in former times there lived an elder named Wondrous Moon. He invoked the Bhagavān’s personal descent to uphold and sustain him, and thus the kingdom’s name was changed—a record of its good fortune.

The transmission reached China as early as the Tang dynasty’s Zhenguan era, coinciding with the height of the Li-Tang dynasty’s prosperity. The Dharma Master Xuanzang heard of it and translated it, but it was stored in the imperial archives and never widely propagated, failing the Tathāgata’s compassionate intent. This was because it was merely regarded as a means to fill granaries. At that time, the land was prosperous, so it was not considered an urgent matter and was not widely disseminated. My late master often lamented this, and I, Jilian, recalling it, have now annotated it and entrusted it to the printing blocks, that all who share this aspiration may sincerely uphold it.

*Thus have I heard.*
I respectfully note: From this phrase to *"he said to the Buddha,"* all are the recollections of the Venerable Ānanda. The two words *"thus"* (*ru shi*) serve as the general preface to the entire sütra and also as the record of ancient events. Ānanda synthesized and recounted them, hence *"thus."* *"I"* is Ānanda’s self-reference. *"Heard"* encompasses what he saw as well. The opening lines of Buddhist scriptures all follow this form.

*At one time, the Bhagavān...*
I note: *"At one time"* (*yi shi*) signifies that this was not an occasion that could be seen or heard at any time. From the past to the present, the moment when it was seen and heard had already surpassed 120,000 years, embodying the meaning of boundless good fortune and blessing—hence *"at one time."* *"Bho"* (薄) means to transcend; *"ga"* (伽) refers to the Three Realms; *"vān"* (梵) means *qi*. This speaks of the virtue and power of Śākyamuni Tathāgata, who had already transcended the *qi* of the Three Realms, embodying the meaning of seizing the moment to initiate transformation.

*In the kingdom of Kauśāmbī...*
*"In"* refers to the place where he arrived at that time.

The term *"kau"* (憍) signifies extravagance and ostentation; *"śāmbī"* (饷) refers to provisions and expenditures; *"mī"* (弥) means vast and unrestrained. In Sanskrit, *"mī"* (弥) is interchangeable with *"mí"* (糜), denoting the wasteful consumption of provisions. *"Kingdom"* (国) refers to the land. This speaks of the realm where the Buddha arrived—a place where customs were marked by extravagance and ostentation, where expenditures were squandered without limit. The Tathāgata, moved by compassion, descended upon this land with the intent to save it.

*In the Kaṭhaka Grove...*
*"Ka"* (迦) refers to fragrant woods such as camphor and cinnamon, whose branches twist and spread, their leaves evergreen even in winter. *"Ṭhaka"* (磔) describes stones with cracked veins and a solid base, suitable for stacking to form barriers that retain water. The Tathāgata established his resting place in this grove—a land abandoned by the people.

*With a great assembly of five hundred bhikṣus...*
*"Bhikṣu"* (苾刍) is a Sanskrit term meaning *"one of virtue."* These bhikṣus, who could subsist on grass, bark, and tree roots, were on the verge of attaining the fruit of bodhisattvahood—hence they were called *"great bhikṣus."* Three individuals constitute an assembly; here, *"five hundred"* refers to an assembly of five hundred, meaning there were one thousand five hundred bhikṣus—all on the verge of becoming great spiritual guides. The chronicler records them as *"five hundred."*

*All bodhisattva-mahāsattvas...*
This states that the Buddha, together with these great bhikṣus and the assembly of five hundred, were all bodhisattva-mahāsattvas. *"Bodhisattva-mahāsattva"* is a Sanskrit term meaning *"bodhisattvas of true and equal enlightenment,"* vast and incomparable. Only those who are great spiritual guides may be called mahāsattvas. This speaks of the present gathering, where the merit and practice of all those in attendance had attained such a station—a truly extraordinary assembly.

*In the past...*
*"Past"* (过) refers to former lives. The chronicler records that those who followed the Buddha in this life had already attained such realization in the present, which necessarily implied profound past roots. Thus, the text seeks to trace their causes from former lives, as described below.

*Countless kalpas...*
*"Countless"* (俱) means *"all."* They practiced great austerities (苦行) for *"kalpas"* (胝数), indicating this was not the work of a single lifetime or a single practice. *"Kalpa"* (胝) refers to the foot; the labor of counting without lifting it from the ground is evident, yet all was undertaken with the resolve to dedicate themselves to salvation.

*And with immeasurable assemblies of devas, humans, asuras, and others...*
*"And"* (及) means *"together with"* or *"alongside."*

The *deva-humans* (天人) refer to those of noble and exalted status—princes, royal descendants, high ministers, and the like. The *asuras* (阿素洛), though once impoverished, attained immense wealth and became the stewards of worldly riches, akin to the five classes of wealth deities (五路财神). The phrase *"and others, immeasurable"* (等无量) signifies that their blessings of nobility and abundance are equal and boundless.

Tracing the causes of this assembly of the Buddha’s followers, all have gathered here to form this grand and victorious *Dao*-field (道场). The congregation is none other than the Buddha’s original assembly, their past roots (夙因) having brought them together thus. *"Surrounding before and behind"* (前后围绕) describes the initial scale of the *Dao*-field’s formation—solemn and majestic in order, its splendor a visible manifestation, sufficient to magnify the Buddha’s majesty. Hence, the auspicious causes (胜因) below are awakened, and the Buddha’s teachings flourish.

*At that time* (时), in *that land*—the kingdom of Kauśāmbī (憍饷弥国)—there was a *elders* (长者). *"Elders"* here denotes a layperson of compassion and virtue, not necessarily one of advanced age. The phrase *"there was one"* (有一) underscores its rarity. His name was *Wonderful Moon* (妙月), a self-given appellation that reveals the breadth of the elder’s heart. His bearing was refined and luminous—truly that of a bodhisattva. His aspirations were lofty and far-reaching, making him a great spiritual friend (大善知识).

The elder’s household included numerous sons, daughters, servants, and attendants—this alone demonstrates that he was a great household of that kingdom. One can well imagine the vastness of his dependents. Yet within such a family, he maintained a refined and luminous bearing, his aspirations lofty and far-reaching—was this not rare indeed! Only through such lofty aspirations could his luminous refinement arise, for his learning had already transcended the ordinary. He held the Buddha, the Dharma, and the Sangha in profound reverence, a depth attained through the power of his far-reaching aspirations. The perspective of worldly men, by contrast, would find this even more constraining.

He came to the Buddha’s presence—*came* meaning *arrived*, and *presence* referring to the Ghoṣila Grove. He prostrated at the Buddha’s feet, his five limbs touching the ground in full obeisance. In Western rites, there is the custom of clasping the feet to pay respects and seek instruction, a gesture of reverence that juniors must offer to their elders. Here, the elder honored the Buddha as father, teacher, and sovereign. After completing his prostrations, he circumambulated the Buddha hundreds and thousands of times. This was not mere veneration of the Buddha before him but of the Tathāgata himself, whether in spirit or in body. In my humble view, it was indeed a physical circumambulation, for his devotion was so pure that he acted without self-awareness. The Buddha and the assembly, too, remained in serene stillness, as if unaware—only when unawareness becomes awareness does it become a true Buddha-gathering, something to be grasped intuitively rather than expressed in words. The chronicler records what he witnessed, and thus we must read the sutra with intuitive understanding and spiritual insight. The following passage should be approached in the same manner: there is no need to fix one’s gaze or stand in wide-eyed wonder, yet neither is it forbidden. The scholar who embodies this will grasp its essence through intuition.

The elder’s attainment of the Buddha’s favor did not lie in the subsequent dialogue but in this circumambulation and what followed. He then stood to one side—*stood* meaning *halted his circumambulation*, and *circumambulation* implying a full view. Having circled the Buddha hundreds and thousands of times, he now stood as a child paying homage to the Buddha. With palms joined in reverence, he addressed the Buddha. This was not a casual halt after countless circuits; rather, only now did he truly *see* the Buddha. Before, in his hundreds of circumambulations, he had beheld the Buddha’s majestic form but not the perfect mark upon his crown. Only now did he see it fully, enabling him to face the Buddha and speak.

He said, "World-Honored One"—this title did not arise from an ordinary mouth or an ordinary heart but emerged from the elder’s true unity. To ordinary ears, it sounded like any other word, but to the Tathāgata, it pierced the Buddha’s heart—this is what is meant by *resonance*.

"I wish to hear from the Tathāgata, the One Worthy of Offerings, the Rightly Self-Awakened One, regarding a few matters that perplex me." *Tathāgata* here refers to past buddhas, not Śākyamuni. *Buddha* is the title of a sage from the Western lands, a saint of the present age, while those who have transcended are called *Tathāgata*. This is because they are non-dual with the empty and numinous nature, free from birth and death, existence and cessation, coming and going. As the *Vajracchedikā Sūtra* states: "The Tathāgata is one who comes from nowhere and goes nowhere; thus is he called the Tathāgata." *Responsive* refers to the mutual resonance between the devotee and the Tathāgata. *Rightly Self-Awakened* means perfect and equal awakening. What the elder sought from the Tathāgata was a response born of this resonance, subtle and ineffable, beyond the reach of ordinary reason. His phrase *"a few matters that perplex me"* was a humble expression, as if to say, "I dare not ask many questions." For the Tathāgata’s response to resonance is certain yet beyond the grasp of conventional logic. The elder suspected there were profound mysteries here, not to be openly transmitted, hence his inquiry in this manner. The following words were spoken lest the Buddha refuse his question, revealing the elder’s earnest desire to ask—this was the true struggle between faith and doubt within him.

"I only pray that the Great Compassionate One will deign to listen and grant permission." He did not say *Great Loving-Kindness* but *Great Compassion*, for the elder knew well what he was asking. The three teachings all concern the mind, and that which is non-dual with the mind is called *loving-kindness*; that which does not yet satisfy the mind is called *compassion*. The elder, having heard the teachings of old, knew they were not false, yet his inner questioning remained unresolved. He sensed there must be another method to harmonize with the mind, hence his use of *Great Compassion* to convey his earnest plea.

At that time, the World-Honored One, moved by compassion for him, spoke in a voice gentle and kind—these are the chronicler’s words. In truth, the world’s multitudes know not how to protect themselves, and the World-Honored One had long been filled with pity for them. After the elder’s hundreds of circumambulations, his stillness and sincerity in making his request were profound. The World-Honored One, brimming with compassion, responded to the elder’s sincerity. This was a natural outflow of the mind’s truth, not a calculated act. Previous interpretations, which suggest the Buddha spoke gently to avoid discouragement, impose intention where there is none. Such shallow readings fail to grasp the Tathāgata’s depth, as the following text will show.

"Elder"—in addressing him thus, the Buddha’s compassion was complete, and his reverence and esteem were equally profound, flowing naturally from within.

"Ask freely what you will, and I shall explain in a way that brings you joy." This is the power of loving-kindness: its resonance and response. How vast is its function! Here, one sees the Buddha’s warm and compassionate majesty, revered even by heavenly beings.

Then the elder, overjoyed and exultant, bowed his head in homage, joined his palms, and said, "World-Honored One, how may good men and good women—those who are poor and lowly—attain wealth and nobility? How may the sick be cured, the guilty absolved, and the fearful find peace?" These four concerns pertain to good men and women, suggesting past karmic causes at play. Yet the means of transformation are not singular: wealth and nobility may be *attained*, while illness, guilt, and fear may be *cured*, *absolved*, and *pacified*. The Buddha does not speak falsely, for there are subtle causes at work, or perhaps other wondrous methods to resonate with the workings of creation. These are the hidden truths the elder sought to uncover, hence his earnest inquiry.

At that time, the World-Honored One, though knowing, deliberately asked—this "knowing yet asking" signifies that the Buddha, possessed of the six superknowledges, ought to have known all without exception. Yet his intent must have concealed a profound meaning. Jilian perceived this as the ultimate mystery of the Dao, awaiting revelation before transmission. For it was not a matter of mere spontaneous resonance to be secretly imparted. Rather, the Buddha intended to first elicit the elder’s sincerity, that it might rise earnestly to heaven. Only after the three realms had all heard would he proclaim it, for it contained the power to shift stars and alter constellations, to reverse and remake creation, so that heaven and earth, ghosts and spirits, would bear its mandate. Such authority and mastery could be wielded only by the True One. Without Vairocana Tathāgata as its presiding master, nothing would come to fruition.

In the Buddha’s mind, this great matter of cause and condition could be transmitted but once in a hundred and twenty thousand years, and could not be treated lightly. After this transmission, both the affair and the Dao would be recorded in the Great Treasury. How could it be silently intimated without assembling the gods, dragons, spirits, and ghosts of the three realms, along with humans and non-humans, all to bear witness and swear alliance? Yet without memorials, talismans, and registers interposed, from that day forward the rite would be established in the Dhakavana as an altar, where humans and spirits would jointly revolve the workings of creation—all, in the end, not departing from the Buddha’s teaching. At that time, the World-Honored One was expounding for ten thousand generations, embodying the principle that what is not proclaimed cannot be enacted. Hence his question.

Jilian once presented this understanding to his late master, who joyfully rose and stroked his crown three times. This occurred in the autumn of the renzi year of the Qianlong reign, when the master inscribed it by hand in the Longshu Mountain Chamber on Mount Jizu. Now, thirty-seven years have passed since the composition of this sutra. In the autumn of the wuzi year, while annotating it, I recalled and recorded this passage here, mindful of the fault in forgetting what should not be forgotten.

Elder, why do you speak thus?

Savoring the words "elder" as uttered by the Buddha, one finds within them a profound meaning: without the mind and conduct of an elder, such a vast vow could not arise. The phrase "why" further contains a warning. The World-Honored One had received this Dao in a past life, and the Bhagavān, by virtue of his karmic connection, certified the elder’s present vow as the cause for the expedient means he would later request. Jilian suddenly felt as though awakened from a dream, realizing that the words "why" were nothing less than a direct blow to rouse him. The height of fruition was determined thereby.

Then the elder again addressed the Buddha:

Now, the elder no longer bowed in reverence or altered his expression but simply spoke again. This indicated his failure to grasp the Buddha’s immense compassionate hope that he would confess his former oversight. The recorder deeply lamented this in his heart, hence his forthright account. As for the phrase "though knowing, deliberately asked" above, I have discerned its profound mechanism.

The late master said: So it is, so it is.

Thus, from this repeated address, the words "we" were revealed. Though the Buddha already knew, he required the elder to disclose it himself, intending thereby to dispel his self-interested views.

World-Honored One, we householders have many dependents, our resources are meager, and we can scarcely provide for them. Moreover, we suffer from many illnesses, burdens of guilt, and fears. Therefore, we beseech the World-Honored One to teach us expedient means.

Privately considering the elder’s words, his experience was thus. Having heard of expedient dharmas for relief, he had not yet learned them, hence his request for instruction.

The late master said: The elder’s heart is compassionate, his vow vast, his feeling earnest. He speaks of "we," yet encompasses the great trichiliocosm—countless, innumerable beings, truly pitiable. When he vows to entreat on behalf of "as many worlds as the sands of the Ganges," his vast vow equals that of the World-Honored One. Alas, the elder’s aspiration still falls short.

May the poor and lowly attain great wealth and rank, abundantly providing for their kin, widely practicing generosity, and benefiting all, their granaries inexhaustible. May the sick achieve harmony in the four great elements, diligently cultivate good karma, and remain untiring in body and mind. May the guilty swiftly have their offenses eradicated, and at life’s end be reborn in good destinies. May the fearful find peace in body and mind, draw near to and serve the Three Jewels, and swiftly realize supreme, perfect enlightenment.

The four "may"s seem to imply power in our hands, for there must be a Dao or dharma therein. The elder had not yet heard it, hence his wish for instruction.

At that time, the World-Honored One addressed the elder:

The World-Honored One wished to broadly inform all good men, but chose to begin with the elder, hence his words to him.

Good man:

This address by the Buddha was not directed solely at the elder, but encompassed all in the assembly—all beings of good mind and good conduct. For such thoughts and deeds should be cherished and practiced by all, yet only good men can cherish and practice them. Thus, he did not call the elder but addressed "good man," precisely to manifest his original vow of universally delivering sentient beings. Women were not mentioned, for when men are spoken of, women are included—one may observe this in the great bodhisattvas.

The late master of Jizu once spoke thus:

In the past, countless kalpas ago, I encountered a Buddha, the World-Honored One named Vajraghoṣa Tathāgata.

According to the records of the esoteric canon, there was once an ancient Buddha, the World-Honored One named Vajraghoṣa Tathāgata, who first proclaimed the Dhāraṇī of Upholding the World. Its sound penetrated the ocean of essential nature—now known as the Starry Sea—unseen in throat or lips, yet resounding through heaven and earth. In an instant, it shook the world, and for immeasurable kalpas he expounded the Dharma. In Middle India, Śākyamuni Tathāgata, then known as the Venerable Vīryapraṇidhāna, received its transmission. After one hundred and twenty thousand years, Śākyamuni Tathāgata attained the Way and began his teaching. In the country of Kauśāmbī, now Russia, the Tathāgata rested in the Dhakavana. Knowing the time had come, he transmitted it to a good man of that land, the Venerable Candraprabha. Ānanda recorded the event, initially titled *The Questions of the Venerable Candramas*, which entered the Great Treasury. It is now known as *The Sutra of the Dhāraṇī of Upholding the World Spoken by the Buddha*.

Kumārajīva’s secret translation never entered the canon. Only when Master Xuanzang retranslated it did it first enter the land of Zhendan, and our country received its transmission. In truth, this transmission began with the Venerable Candramas, to whom our World-Honored One personally imparted it.

Respectfully examined: The sound that resounds without throat or lips—ancient worthies called it *yogic holding*; my late master, the Jizu Daoist, said: No, it is called *holding of samādhi*. For the sound arises from the nature, the incantation is proclaimed by the heart, and through inner-outer resonance, heaven and humanity unite in verification. Through this, what is attained is no delusion—this is the true, untransmitted secret. Only those in the Western teachings who are ripe for its mechanism know the four characters *Vajra Sea Sound*.
