Gather the ascent and descent of yin and yang within the circle; discern the return of water and fire within the body. Only when one knows stillness can one understand the workings of creation; only with sincere intent can one awaken to the wondrous sound. Guarding the true and embracing the One, one forgets emotion in the face of phenomena. Serene and unstained by the myriad conditions, one naturally achieves sudden penetration—celestial nature becomes radiant and clear, and ultimate reality is realized.

One’s aspirations may hold the bright moon in the breast; one’s sleeves may dance with the pure wind. Some may choose a grotto-heaven to enter seclusion; some may select a blessed land to close the pass. First, befriend cloud companions and rosy-cloud friends as Daoist companions; next, build a thatched hut or grass hermitage as a crucible chamber.

Tune the zither to cultivate nature; wield the flying sword to subdue demons. Driving dragons and taming tigers, one harmonizes wind and cloud; catching hares and seizing crows, one joins lead and mercury. Turning the earth’s axis, one reopens the dry valleys; stirring the celestial gate, one returns *gou* to the *kun* palace. Stirring the *xun* wind to forge and refine, one moves the *li* fire to boil and steam. There are times for increase and decrease, advance and retreat; there must be no error in warming, nourishing, bathing, and washing.

Then, within the vessel of the Great One, one drinks to the full the wine of long life; within the palace of the Yellow Court, one eternally binds the elixir of agelessness. Ceasing effort and ending strife, one blends with the world and harmonizes with its light. Some may hide in the dusty world to accumulate conduct; some may dwell in the bustling market to establish merit. Virtue fills the human realm; one’s name is inscribed in heaven. Quietly awaiting the summons from the Jade Capital, one early attends the honored one of the Golden Portal. Feasting on the peaches of immortality, one is commanded to wander the Penglai gardens. One’s family all transcend to ultimate bliss; one’s immortal friends ascend together to Penglai and Yingzhou.

This is the result of pure cultivation, the standard of great accomplishment. Beyond this, there are those who have just escaped the world’s net and newly entered the mysterious gate, yet have not cleansed past transgressions or hungered for future blessings. Some, dull in root and shallow in wisdom, cannot fathom the wondrous celestial mechanisms. Some, deep in karmic hindrances and thin in virtue, rarely encounter the bright teachers of the sagely Dao. Their natures turn with things; their minds are entangled by emotions. Thus, the single heart is caught in dual thoughts; the three poisons disturb the four wrongs.

Because the five aggregates are not empty, the six thieves are difficult to subdue. The seven emotions stir; the eight consciousnesses divide and attack. The evils of the nine apertures forever invade the true realm; the ten evil deeds spread and flourish in the numinous terrace. Like clouds obscuring the bright moon or mist veiling the blue sky, wisdom’s light does not shine, and sagely insight cannot illumine. The numinous mechanism is thus obstructed; deluded desires thereby multiply. Without the congealing of spirit and qi, how can there be the wondrous return?

This is why, though the body does not toil, the merit is not great, and the celestial spirits are hard to aid; though conduct is not broad, the heart does not die, and the immortals and sages are hard to accommodate. Scholars, do not betray the empty name of purity and stillness; do not cling to the false appearance of non-action. Though one may willingly wear coarse clothes and eat bark and wood, one merely wearies oneself and labors the body in vain.

If one stubbornly sits in meditation, one will surely fall into demonic realms; if one recklessly practices circulation, one will certainly congeal a phantom elixir. One may thereby invite harm from within kindness and have a beginning but rarely an end. Scholars, ponder these subtleties carefully. Do not err in cultivation; one must seek the correct Dao. With courage and vigor, advance—one should honor the nine stages of merit. With diligence and effort, cultivate—gradually progress on the path of the three vehicles.

Unite body and mind in simultaneous refinement; combine internal and external in mutual cultivation. In stillness, investigate principle and exhaust nature; in movement, accumulate conduct and amass merit. One must practice timely expedients and always preserve all forms of compassion. Rescuing the hidden and delivering the deceased, Master Ge thereby attained the Dao; aiding disasters and dispensing medicine, the Bodhisattva Zhen thereby ascended as an immortal. Dispelling harm and sweeping away demons, Xu Zhenyang’s merit was complete, and his household was delivered.

Protecting the people and blessing the nation, Tao Hongjing fulfilled his conduct and ascended in flight. From ancient times to the present, all immortals transcended through bitter practice. Even now, those who have not yet learned—how could they depart from accumulating virtue to achieve perfection?

Diligently remove karmic obstructions, earnestly nurture concentration and wisdom; constantly harbor the silent light, ever preserve the unbroken breath. Then the sprouts of goodness grow in the Three Fields, and the spiritual root is cultivated in the inch of earth. This pertains to the gateway of gradual cultivation, the very steps of the supreme vehicle. Though gradual and sudden may follow two paths, the ultimate Dao originates from one source. All heroic worthies who aspire to the Dao must vow to seek and inquire—let them embody the practices of those who came before, lest they drown in heterodox arts.

Thus, this treatise is set forth to illuminate the benighted, serving as a precious mirror for cultivating perfection and a spiritual ladder for advancing on the Dao. It is both the passport for seeking and inquiring and the travel permit for cloud-wandering. Those who follow my teachings shall hold it as their bond—by it, they may traverse seas and mountains to achieve union.

The celestial admonition states: Even the slightest deviation invites the transgression of darkness; a fleeting moment of perverse speech inevitably breaches the prohibition of emptiness. The ears and eyes of celestial spirits are never far—let this be proclaimed to practitioners, who must remain vigilant. If words and deeds bear no shame, and hidden virtue is fully cultivated, then immortals will naturally become your teachers—what worry remains that you will not transcend?

**Inscription on Abstaining from Food**
When entering the refectory, attire and cap must be solemn and proper. The cloud-kitchen’s simmering grains are no trifling matter. Without distinction of inner or outer, all share the same grain of rice. First learn the discipline of abstemious eating, then learn to become an immortal. Bowls and spoons may be passed, and rice may be refilled. Refrain from loud speech or taboo words; sit upright, not slouching or leaning. Conduct yourself with the qi of the Dao, not fussing over robes. Make no distinction between guest and host—all are at ease. Be meticulous and vigilant, ensuring resolve remains firm. Let the qi of the Dao abide constantly, and perceive all as one. A grain of rice, a stalk of firewood—each requires a year’s effort. If the mind errs, karmic burdens will fill the void, and you shall repay in fur and horns, flesh and bone.

**Purple Clarity Perfected One’s Regulations and Proclamation**
Heaven, earth, spirits, humans, and ghosts—all five immortals follow the compass and square, defining the round and square. To go against them is to invite disorder at every turn; to follow them is to harmonize with nature in every way.

This is the place where sages and worthies lay down their burdens, the pavilion where immortals nurture their purity. Morning and evening, burn incense and bow in prayer, extolling the boundless longevity of the august emperor. At dawn and dusk, proclaim the sacred name, protecting officials, scholars, and commoners to bring them fortune. Thus, the ordinary and sacred dwell together, hidden and manifest beyond measure.

A single sandal and gourd make the livelihood of the pot; solitary clouds and wild cranes become the idle ones beyond the world. Detached and unconstrained, they roam freely and at ease. Awakening from the dream of millet, they rest in the serenity of a single breeze; opening the furnace of gold and mercury, they are unaware of the half-window’s bright moon. When merit is complete and conduct fulfilled, the body becomes wondrous and the spirit numinous—subduing dragons and tigers, they emerge from the dark paths, riding phoenixes and cranes to return to their grotto-heavens.

For those newly departed from the mundane world, just entering the gate of mystery, whose hearts are still deluded and whose nature is not yet clear, they must strictly adhere to the pure regulations and refrain from transgressing in conduct. Serve the master and respect fellow practitioners; contemplate the Dao and reflect on the real. Always focus on the nature and life, never clinging to thoughts of profit or fame. Walk with measured steps, speak in low voices. Do not sing lewd or alluring songs, nor engage in gossip or slander. When leaving for public or private matters, do not return with lamps or fire. In seated meditation, remain silent until the bell tolls to rise. When arriving, clearly hang your robe; when departing, announce it before the assembly. For any violations, the severity will be assessed and penalties imposed. For minor offenses, tea and oil cakes; for grave ones, bamboo rods and expulsion from the mountain. Theft results in caning and banishment, with robes and alms bowl burned. Gambling, meat, and wine are forbidden in the hall or in service. For lewdness, deceit, or fraud, the bones shall be scattered and ashes strewn. Violations will incur double punishment by the assembly.

Let this proclamation be known to all. Cloud-wandering monks from the five lakes gather in one hall. Having assembled as disciples, they must understand the rules. Whether ordinary or sacred, sometimes hidden, sometimes manifest, their transformations are unfixed, but the regulations of the Dao remain constant.

**Perfected One of Eternal Spring’s Regulations and Proclamation**
Those who dwell in the mountains embrace clarity, emptiness, cold purity, and carefree solitude. Cultivating the mind is the essence; nurturing nature is the function. Softness and weakness are the Dao; humility and harmony are virtue. Compassion is the foundation; expedience is the gate. Among the assembly, always remain humble; in seclusion, do not stir mundane emotions. For all worldly toils, act within your capacity—do not overreach. For every garment and meal, do not overindulge. For every calculation of funds and grain, do not hoard excess. In clothing and self-care, do not be greedy. If the monastery’s resources are abundant, aid impoverished wandering scholars passing through. Or use them elsewhere for alms-gathering, or to prepare vegetarian feasts. In all twelve hours, do not cling to the illusory—always seek to illuminate the real.

Sweep away dust and grime, scrub pots, draw water, carry firewood, and cook meals. Eliminate selfish intentions, do not give rise to anger. Each has their own chamber to settle the mind and discern the Dao. Each has their assigned duties, occupying one task, or exchanging roles. In refining the true nature, do not cling to its use, nor engage in mutual criticism. Carefully lower the fire, sweep away self and others, extinguish sound and form, depart from the body and abandon cunning, and abide in desirelessness. When encountering followers of the Three Teachings, treat them equally—do not harbor arrogance or negligence. Do not leave the abode without cause. Morning and evening, tend to the gates and doors.

At the hour of *yin* (3–5 a.m.), sweep and clean the halls and courtyards. Should any offer supplies, receive them with ordinary courtesy; if none are given, do not harbor resentment. For all wandering scholars who arrive, if after three days they prove to be of lofty wisdom, promote them to a higher seat; if they lack aspiration, let them depart elsewhere. Next, examine the registry of visitors, recording and investigating their circumstances in detail. If these are not made clear, there may be those who conceal deceit, and such matters cannot be taken lightly. Guard against a certain class of wild and obstinate Daoists, or cunning impostors, who use words to delude, defile the assembly, damage the abode, and constantly spread slander—such persons must be expelled at once.

Should any seek to enter the abode and leave the household life, do not presume to admit them without due process. First observe their *Dao*-qi, then examine their *Dao*-heart; consider also the virtue or fault of their ancestral lineage and the depth or shallowness of their own conduct. Those of lofty wisdom may be guided; the dull-witted should be restrained. For any tasks to be undertaken within the abode, first consult the abbot, then discuss with the assembled Daoist community. In leaving the household life, whether early or late, do not discriminate by age or youth—only those who comprehend principle and illuminate the mind are fit to be esteemed.

In all matters of teaching and guidance, do not falsely invoke the names of master households. If one uses the pretext of the abode to solicit offerings from benefactors for personal use, this is private deception of the common treasury. Heaven’s surveillance is ever-present, and no transgression will go lightly punished. Thus is this notice posted.

**Notice of Regulations by the Attendants of Master Changchun**

It is ever heard that human life between heaven and earth is like a white colt passing a crack—suddenly, it is gone. Its coming cannot be resisted, its going cannot be halted. When the six and eight transformations perish and the four great elements disperse, the body no longer remains, and life is not one’s own. Observing how this is so, nothing compares to embodying the supreme Dao. Examining how one cultivates, nothing compares to illuminating the original mind.

For the mind is the Dao, and the Dao is the mind. There is no Dao outside the mind, no mind outside the Dao—it rests solely in our own silent realization. Thus, whether one becomes ordinary or sagely, it is all self-made. Whether one awakens to truth or to the Dao, it lies not in others’ conduct. First, one must comprehend; next, one must advance in practice. Carrying water and moving firewood—all is this. Reciting scriptures and performing repentance rites—it is all here.

Let each employ their own discerning eye to observe; do not let this moment slip by unnoticed. From this day forth, when clouds and waters meet, when mist and peaks gather, should one encounter a teacher on the Way and receive the teacher’s transmission of the essential teaching, steadfastly comprehend it, and fully understand the family tradition of transcending the world—then set the resolve to cultivate and uphold it, and one may become a living means to ascend as an immortal. Do not neglect merit and conduct; one must awaken to the original nature.

All the mysterious statutes and pure regulations, along with the duties of all attendants, are set forth below.

1. The **Director of Supervision** oversees the essential principles and supervises all attendants.

1. The **Director of Administration** governs the standards of the Dao and oversees rituals and precepts.
These two roles serve as the eyes and ears of heaven and humanity, the model for immortals and sages.
They must hold the Dao and virtue in their hearts, and act with benevolence to benefit all.
Before the birth of one’s parents, awaken to the original face.
Within the teachings of sages and worthies, illuminate the radiance of the nature-ground.
First harmonize the vital pulse of the center, then observe the wondrous mechanism of the apertures.
Within the furnace of creation, seize the dragon and tame the tiger;
Within the cauldron of heaven and earth, extract Kan to fill Li.
With the essential teaching of ascending the hall and entering the chamber, rouse from within;
Through the practice of illuminating the mind and seeing the nature, comprehend beyond intention.
They guide and cultivate the virtuous, transforming the worthy.
In movement and stillness, they maintain solemn reverence, dignity, and sincerity.
Should there be the slightest error, the penalty shall be doubled before the assembly.

2. The **Left Hall Attendant** supervises the servers.
2. The **Right Hall Attendant** assists in managing the tea office.
These two roles serve as the guiding principles for the assembly and the stepping-stones for later learners.
They turn the Dharma wheel and assist in upholding the standards of the Dao.
In entering and exiting, they patrol with incense, ever maintaining reverence and awe.
In the stillness of rising and retiring, they must ensure purity and harmony.
They correct lapses in decorum from haste or levity, and publicly address violations of principle from negligence.
Their speech is dignified, their demeanor gentle.
Those who violate the monastic regulations shall be penalized with kneeling incense and prostrations.

3. The **Dragon and Tiger Disciples** cultivate the Dao with sincerity.
They resolve to refine their bodies, eliminating desires to observe the mind, quieting thoughts to fulfill their nature.
They harmonize the spirit and embrace stillness, ever nurturing the mysterious work within the cinnabar field.
With each step, they move lightly, ever upholding the precepts within the red cavern.
They must abide by the mysterious statutes and not transgress the pure regulations; violators shall kneel for incense.

4. The **Sun and Moon Disciples**, during scripture recitation and repentance rites,
must maintain reverence and awe, focusing their thoughts on the venerated countenance.
With solemnity and uprightness, they serve the Supreme Emperor,
uniting in voice to praise and worship, single-mindedly taking refuge.
Should there be any lapse in decorum during audience rites or negligence in recitation, they shall be penalized with incense before the assembly.

5. The **Attendant of Incense, Lamps, and Shrine** tends to incense and lamps, arranges offerings,
and maintains sincere purity, ensuring no impurity or defilement offends the sacred altar.
In their duties, they must be meticulous and reverent, joining the Dharma assembly with equal devotion.
Should there be any omission or insufficiency in offerings, they shall kneel for incense.

6. The **Kitchen Manager and Head Cook** serve as the lifeline of the assembly, the foundation of the monastic community.
They prepare superior vegetarian meals with clarity and purity, never negligent or careless,
harmonizing the six flavors and ensuring three daily meals are complete.
They guard against sour or spoiled food and prevent damage or incompleteness in utensils.
Through this, they align with the celestial perfected and receive their enjoyment,
providing for the Dao assembly to sustain life.
Should there be negligence or lack of precision, they shall be penalized with incense.

7. The **Tea and Water Attendants** prepare pure spring water, brew jade-like dew,
offering it to the heavens, serving the sages, welcoming guests, and receiving the perfected.
They must not mix cold or impure water into the tea, nor allow personal bias to contaminate its purity.
Should there be negligence, they shall be penalized with incense.

8. The **Fire Attendant and Silence Keeper** rise first to signal the end of silence in the morning
and retire only after silence is called in the evening.
They tend the kitchen fires and candles with utmost care.
They sweep the courtyards and halls, ensuring thorough cleanliness.
Violators shall kneel for incense.

9. The **Treasurer** manages finances and handles all receipts and disbursements.
Every coin and grain of alms is the essence of collective virtue;
Every morsel of vegetarian food is the lifeblood of all conditions.
They must not deceive or conceal, for such a heart may face the azure heavens.
If they embezzle or misappropriate, they shall ultimately sink into the dark prisons.
They must keep clear records and manage receipts and expenditures appropriately.
Should there be errors, concealment, or other misconduct, the assembly is permitted to speak frankly.
Minor offenses shall be penalized with fasting; serious ones shall result in expulsion.

10. The **Procurement Officer** must act with uprightness and transparency, never deceiving in private.
All supplies—vegetarian provisions, offerings, vegetables, oil, candles, and other items—
must be recorded in the ledger upon entering the storehouse.
Purchased goods must reflect their true value, without skimming or corruption that harms the Dao mind.
Should there be any private concealment or fraud, severe penalties shall apply.

11. The **Alms Collector** guides the worthy and transforms the virtuous.
They seek alms from noble persons and gentlemen, accumulating merit at sacred altars.
They must consider benefiting others and all beings, never acting for personal or private gain.
Should there be concealment, favoritism, or bias, they shall be doubly penalized with vegetarian feasts for the assembly.

12. The **Guest Prefect** serves as the public face of the monastery, first embodying humility, respect, and deference,
and maintaining dignified and solemn decorum.
In welcoming and sending off guests, they must not violate the pure regulations;
In responding, they must align with the original standards.
They receive guests with an open heart and serve the worthy with integrity.
Should they display arrogance or disrespect, severe penalties shall apply.

13. The **Secretary** is an outstanding figure in the monastic community, a scholar surpassing the ordinary.
They carry the order of procedures in their heart, concealing the subtle mechanism within their words.
In submitting memorials and petitions, they must write with precision and sincerity to move the Supreme Emperor;
In responding to letters, they must craft their words with reverence to engage with the worthy.
Amidst bustle, they find stillness to silently cultivate body and mind;
In busyness, they steal moments to delve deeply into the mysterious Dao.
They must strive to realize sagehood and attain perfection, never regressing into the mundane.
Should there be errors in wording or meaning, peers shall correct them face-to-face.
If they stubbornly resist or willfully violate, severe cases shall be penalized with vegetarian feasts, minor ones with kneeling incense.

14. The **Abbot** oversees all major and minor affairs of the monastery,
serving as the model for the monastic community and the leader of the assembly.
They embody the Dao and virtue in their heart and mind, manifesting benevolence and righteousness in their conduct.
Their integrity is as steadfast as the frost-laden pine, their mind as pure as the moon reflected on water.
Within the four deportments, they cultivate solitude with care;
Amidst the ten thousand practices, they nurture forbearance.
They judge others with the same rigor they judge themselves, and forgive others as they would themselves.
They are lenient with the assembly and maintain integrity in their own conduct:
Spreading the true wind across the seas and lands, they propagate the mysterious transformation in all directions.

The one whose name resounds in their time and whose virtue spreads far and wide must not fail in the duties of their station. Should they embellish their conduct with even slight pretense, the penalty shall be doubled in offerings of vegetarian feasts.

The **Deputy Abbot**, too, is a pillar of the monastic community and a guiding principle for the assembly. They must possess complete moral integrity and practice both benevolence and righteousness; their bearing must serve as a model, their demeanor as a standard. In dealing with the assembly, humility is paramount; in receiving guests, propriety is supreme. They revere the divine as though standing in its august presence, and regard generals and commanders as though they were arrayed in the palace halls. Their names are inscribed in the jade registers of the Daoist pantheon, their forebears’ names recorded in the celestial capital. They expound the teachings of the Most High, proclaim the scriptures of the Three Caverns. The villages look up to their virtue, and the multitudes receive its blessings. Should they grow lax even slightly, the penalty shall be doubled in offerings of vegetarian feasts.

The **Director of Meditation** must embody both Dao and virtue, manifesting both benevolence and righteousness. Seated in stillness within the meditation chamber, they cherish essence and cultivate qi. They take purity and tranquility as their foundation, and concentration and wisdom as their guiding principle. They transcend the boundaries of the mundane world, making their life one beyond the ordinary. Morning and evening, they pay homage to the True, praying for the longevity of the sages. Their sole devotion is to transcend the ordinary and enter the realm of the sacred, ever steadfast in stilling the mind and gathering the spirit. They refine the Three Treasures into the Golden Elixir, guarding the One True as the Great Medicine. They turn the mysterious aperture, reversing and cycling yin and yang. They forge the hundred flames within the Nine Cauldrons, gathering the myriad transformations within the single vessel. When three thousand merits are fulfilled, their names join the ranks of the immortals; when eight hundred deeds are perfected, their bodies transcend the dust and kalpas. Thus do they deliver themselves and others, ascending to the celestial realms, hand in hand with the Perfected, shoulder to shoulder with the immortals and sages. Should they harbor attachments to public or private matters, self or others, they shall be subject to the same penalty of offerings for the assembly.

The **Inspector** serves as the monastery’s overseer of discipline, supervising all major and minor officers of the hall. They act as heaven’s emissary to propagate the Dao and as the patriarch’s successor to spread its teachings. They elevate those of lofty attainment to cultivate truth and nurture their nature, and they investigate and discipline Daoist practitioners who violate the rules. Should they fail in their oversight, they shall be publicly penalized.

The **Steward of Provisions** manages the vegetarian meals for the assembly and sustains the monastery’s foundation. Though delicacies and fine flavors may be set aside, plain rice and simple fare cannot be avoided. They must ever hold the mind of Śākyamuni, who fed himself to the tigers, and emulate Mozi, who wore himself thin for the world. They must not shrink from toil nor harbor regret. Should they grow negligent, lose their way, and resort to pretense or obstinacy, they shall be penalized with incense offerings.

The **Garden Master** must diligently and earnestly tend to their duties without negligence. The vegetables of the four seasons must be cultivated in their proper time; the year’s provisions must be sufficient, with surplus to spare. Should there be shortages in what is needed, or should they pilfer and sell privately, they shall be severely penalized.

All civil and martial officers, each possessing their own virtues, must not contend with one another to the detriment of the monastic ethos. Civil officers harmonize governance and uphold discipline, propagating the true Dharma, guiding the deluded, and inspiring the faithful. Martial officers suppress violence and protect the good, dedicating themselves to the defense of the Dao, undeterred by cold or heat, day or night. Both may be called vessels of the Most High’s teachings, and neither should feel unworthy of their ancestral lineage. They ought to reflect one another above and below, harmonize within and without, each sweeping away worldly attachments and together attaining the wondrous fruit. All officers must exert their utmost effort; though they may not yet perceive the Dao, they shall at least draw near to it. Should civil officers rely on their talents to overshadow others and dismiss martial officers as dull-witted, or should martial officers boast of their bravery and deride civil officers as useless, such individuals are not truly wise. Should any, clinging to their abilities, grow arrogant, they must acknowledge their fault and offer an apology.

These several articles demand the attention of all, each reflecting inwardly. Should anyone make excuses or rely on others, the assembly shall render its impartial judgment. The daily practices of the two halls must be upheld, and the recitation of the Five Sacred Scriptures must not be neglected. All worthy individuals from the ten directions who reside here must be treated with reverence; one must not merely cultivate oneself in isolation. Should one appear enlightened outwardly while remaining benighted within, or speak rightly while harboring deceit; should one’s private conduct exceed their public deeds, or act for personal gain while feigning public service—

Should the patrons from the ten directions regard us as greedy, miserly, and mediocre, the Dharma-protecting deities shall mete out clear retribution. Ah! Better that others betray me than I betray others.

Be it known:
*Erected on the __ day of the __ month of the __ year.*
*The Abbot of this abbey respectfully proclaims.*

**Precepts of the Pure Regulations**

The Dao preceded the Lord of Heaven in the household of all things; the myriad distinctions share a single root. After the pristine simplicity of non-action, the Three Teachings flow from one source. To dwell in the dust yet transcend it is no easy task; to abide in desire yet remain desireless is truly difficult.

We often see the benighted sinking ever deeper into the sea of suffering, their days flowing downward into filth. We can only hope that the wise and discerning will take heed and spur themselves on, lest they fall into the snares of delusion.

The Most High opened the non-dual Dharma-gate, with forbearance as foremost. The Patriarchs expounded the teachings of the Alms Bowl Hall, with discipline as the foundation. Heaven does not tolerate discourteous immortals; how then can the world permit rule-breaking Daoist priests?

This is a place for cultivating the mind and refining one’s nature, not for those who live in drunken stupor or dreamlike oblivion. If one indulges in talk of self and others, or debates right and wrong, how can such a mind ever transcend the world?

Here, we dwell together in this blessed land, having established the Sacred Hall. Gathering good friends who have come from a thousand *li* away, and uniting with ten thousand virtuous companions of the Dao, we must mutually admonish one another and together repent our past transgressions. Let no stray deluded thought arise, nor the slightest perverse idea take root. Let our precepts be as stern as frost and ice, and our minds as resolute as the whetstone.

The following Pure Regulations are hereby proclaimed:

1. Those who engage in licentiousness, theft, or sexual misconduct, thereby violating the statutes of the Most High and corrupting the ancestral traditions of the Patriarchs, shall be burned at the stake.
2. Those who abduct, deceive, or swindle others shall have their eyebrows seared and their monastic names stricken from the rolls.
3. Those who disrupt the Pure Regulations or refuse to abide by the monastic laws shall be caned and expelled.
4. Those who gamble or play at dice shall be caned and made to repent under the Pure Regulations.
5. Those who deceive and delude others with talk of alchemical elixirs or mercury refinement shall be caned and driven out.
6. Those who consume alcohol, eat meat, or disturb the peace of the abbey shall be caned and expelled.
7. Those who harm their parents or revile the assembly shall be caned and expelled.
8. Those who refuse to pay respects to their masters or are ignorant of their lineage shall be expelled.
9. Those who, while managing abbey affairs, embezzle from the community for personal gain or deceive the assembly shall be punished with a vegetarian feast of repentance.
10. Those who rely on official power to bully the Daoist community shall be subject to the assembly’s judgment, caned, and expelled.
11. Those who engage in idle chatter, jesting, or fail to conduct themselves in accordance with the rules shall, for minor offenses, kneel before the incense; for serious offenses, be caned and expelled.
12. Those who attend public assemblies in secular clothing or small hats shall kneel before the incense.
13. Those who privately solicit alms without informing the community or contributing to the abbey shall be expelled.
14. Those who envy the worthy, deceive their juniors, or boast with arrogance shall be expelled.
15. Those who, during rituals in the halls or upon the altars, laugh, chatter, stand with their backs turned, call for attendants, cast sidelong glances, spit, or fail to observe proper decorum in bowing and kneeling shall kneel before the incense.
16. Those who, in the various halls and shrines, fail to maintain cleanliness in the morning and evening incense, lamps, offerings, or altars shall kneel before the incense.
17. Those who fail to attend the morning and evening devotions or do not circumambulate the Heavenly Worthy shall kneel before the incense, unless excused by official duties.
18. Those who fail to gather for the monthly and new moon rites to the Sacred One shall kneel before the incense, unless excused by official duties.
19. Those who, in the refectory, speak out of turn, wear improper attire, or cause bowls or chopsticks to clatter shall kneel before the incense.
20. Those who wear pouches or carry tobacco into the refectory, or otherwise violate Daoist regulations, shall kneel before the incense.
21. Those who privately entertain guests with abbey food without reporting to the guest hall shall kneel before the incense.
22. Those who sleep naked, fail to wear undergarments, or do not secure their trouser legs shall kneel before the incense.
23. Those who, in preparing meals, use dirty water, filthy firewood, or engage in frivolous behavior before the stove shall kneel before the incense.
24. Those who burn incense before the stove, enter the halls in undergarments, or appear without proper headwear or sashes shall kneel before the incense.
25. Those who leave the abbey without notification or fail to obtain a pass shall kneel before the incense.
26. Those who eat in private without offering to the community shall be punished with a vegetarian feast of repentance.
27. Those who, during communal labor, act or rest without following the assembly shall kneel before the incense, unless excused by official duties.
28. Those who, on official or private errands involving lamps or fires, fail to return on time shall kneel before the incense, unless excused by official duties.
29. Those who fail to rise at the signal to end meditation shall kneel before the incense.
30. Those who fail to extinguish the lamps or close the doors at the signal to begin meditation shall kneel before the incense.
31. Those who privately consult the scriptures without informing the assembly shall be punished with a vegetarian feast of repentance.
32. Those who, during nighttime rest, speak loudly and disturb others shall kneel before the incense.
33. Those who, in the kitchen, waste rice or damage utensils and tools shall kneel before the incense.
34. Those who fail to assist in major abbey affairs shall be punished with incense offerings.
35. Those who, while inspecting the abbey, knowingly conceal violations of the Pure Regulations shall be punished with a vegetarian feast of repentance upon discovery.
36. Regarding the *wu* prohibitions: except for the spring *wu-yin* and autumn *wu-shen* days, all other *wu* days are forbidden. On these prohibited days, any Daoist or lay ritual master who burns incense, presents memorials, or petitions the celestial bureaus shall be annihilated. Those who knowingly violate this shall bring calamity upon their nine clans. The Wind Blade shall relentlessly pursue them through ten thousand kalpas, and those without registers shall receive a three-degree reduction in punishment. This is decreed by the Scarlet Script of Heavenly Law and the Azure Maiden of Heavenly Law.

These thirty-six articles are hereby announced to the assembly. All must abide by these laws and together uphold the mysterious standards.

Thus, when three walk together, one may be my teacher; how then, when dwelling in one hall, can there be no mutual benefit? Let the assembly remain ever vigilant, lest they err or violate the Pure Regulations. Follow these prohibitions and precepts, and let no reckless or indulgent thoughts arise.

Let all reflect that sustenance from the ten directions is difficult to digest, and thus a single inch of time must be cherished, for it passes all too swiftly. Through constant, vigilant cultivation, one may surely attain the wings of immortality. This notice is hereby posted.

**Notice of Duties**

A great edifice cannot be upheld by a single timber; it requires the support of many materials. How can a monastic community stand alone through one person? It must rely on the division of labor to flourish together. Assign tasks according to ability, maintaining order between high and low; receive one’s provisions and fulfill one’s duties, ensuring no neglect in matters great or small.

We, having been graced by imperial favor, neither weave nor till, yet ever bear the shame of partaking in idle feasting. Thus, we must be diligent and frugal, lest we waste the passing days. That Magistrate Ma moved tiles while reciting sutras was not without reason; that Layman Pang carried firewood and fetched water was not in vain. Therefore, rules and standards are established, beginning with the self. The rotation of duties and division of labor are the hopes placed in all.

**Admonitions of the Perennial Truth Master to Disciples and Posterity**

Hear now, all disciples and followers who have entered the orthodox gate of the Mysterious Dao: you must possess the good roots cultivated in past lives. First, you verify the blessings of this present existence; second, you cultivate to avoid future descent. If you possess a sincere heart turned toward the Dao, you must constantly adhere to the laws and statutes of the Most High.

Yet why do you merely seek to pass your days under the guise of Daoism, while remaining ignorant of its profound precepts and prohibitions? Every grain of rice and every coin bears consequence—they are the marrow of the common people, the blood and sweat of farmers. Without labor, how can they be rightfully consumed? How can one receive them without merit?

You, in your folly and delusion, fail to reflect upon yourselves. Unwilling to cultivate and uphold the teachings, you instead claim that our tradition lacks merit and turn your intentions toward heterodox paths. This leads to deceit, theft, and licentiousness—harming others for personal gain. Some indulge in meat, wine, and gambling, corrupting the teachings and bringing ruin to the lineage. Others burn thatch and refine mercury to deceive and bewilder the people. Some place their faith in peripheral sects, slandering the true teaching. Such shameless conduct—how can it befit those who claim to follow the Dao?

Moreover, do not think that you, as later learners, can escape karmic retribution. Even celestial deities, if they err, are demoted from their positions; earthly spirits, if they transgress, are stripped of their ranks. Immortals who falter fall into the dust, guardians of the underworld who err are reduced in station, malevolent spirits who sin are obliterated, kings who transgress lose their kingdoms, ministers who err face punishment, scholars who falter are disgraced, and commoners who sin forfeit their blessings. Every misdeed has its consequence. How much more so for those among you who commit such sins—can you escape retribution?

Therefore, all disciples and followers of our tradition must reflect deeply: why did you leave the household life? Was it not to see through the suffering of the cycle of rebirth and enter the Dao? How can you instead compound your transgressions and deepen your sins?

The Dao encompasses the Three Vehicles. Follow the teachings of your own lineage, advance according to your capacity, establish your resolve, and uphold it. Engage in ascetic practice—this is the true path of the renunciate.

The **Superior Vehicle** involves refining the true and nurturing one’s nature, enduring hardship to fathom the mysteries, and realizing the wondrous Dao of emptiness. It aligns with the upright *qi* of Heaven and Earth, resolves karmic entanglements of the mundane world, and broadly practices benevolence and righteousness, amassing vast hidden merit. Only when the Three Thousand Merits are complete and the Eight Hundred Deeds are perfected does one transcend the Three Realms and join the ranks of immortals. Some ride cranes to the Golden Gates, others mount phoenixes to the Jasper Pond. Revered by a thousand truths and protected by ten thousand sages, they become one with Heaven and Earth, their radiance equal to the sun and moon. Is this not the path of the great renunciate?

The **Middle Vehicle** involves sincerely propagating the teachings, performing rituals, and reciting scriptures. Chanting the profound precepts of the Most High and invoking the sacred names of the Heavenly Worthy, one offers earnest prayers before the deities, observes fasts with utmost devotion, and purifies body and mind. By propagating the Great Dao with a single-minded, pure heart, one upholds the true Dharma. At the time of passing, one is naturally escorted by virtuous beings—some reborn in the imperial palace, others in official households. Some ascend to the rank of minister, joining the Three Dukes; others become sovereigns, their names inscribed in the Nine-Five. Then, all people revere them, the Four Seas submit, and they attain the most exalted station among mortals. Is this not a noble destiny?

The **Inferior Vehicle** involves constructing temples and monasteries, printing scriptures and crafting images, repairing bridges and mending roads, abstaining from killing and releasing living beings, offering tea and medicine, aiding the destitute and relieving the suffering. Free from stinginess and greed, one transforms and is reborn as a human. Born into a wealthy and noble family, all desires are fulfilled, and one enjoys boundless prosperity throughout life. Is this not joyous?

These are the methods of cultivation for the Three Vehicles, each clearly delineated. If you fail to awaken, if you do not abandon wine, lust, wealth, and arrogance, then it would be better to return to lay life. There, you may mistake bitterness for sweetness, act as you please, and follow your desires—would that not be carefree? Why linger in the gate of the Mysterious Dao, deluded and unrepentant, accumulating boundless sins and inescapable karmic retribution?

Those with sincere resolve should advance with diligence; those without past karmic affinity should swiftly withdraw. Otherwise, your sins will double, and I shall pity you deeply. Thus, I offer this admonition.

If any who see this turn their hearts, if any who hear this change their minds, resolutely renew their determination, and painfully reform their past wrongs, advancing with courage and diligence—then those who hear will awaken, and those who see will be enlightened. Awakening is the heart that reflects inward; enlightenment is the mind that turns back to illuminate. If you do not awaken soon, you will forever lose your true nature. Once you fall into the dark paths, you will sink into the sea of suffering, transformed into other beings. At that time, what use will regret be?

O wise and discerning ones, ponder this carefully. If you miss this opportunity in this life, the Great Dao will be difficult to encounter again.

---

**Postscript**

I, along with Master [Jian], were both favored with the teachings of Master Jianju. Initially, we exchanged literary works but had not yet met the Master in person. The Master did not disdain me and repeatedly admonished me with discourses on the Dao and virtue. At first, I could not comprehend his teachings, neglecting sleep and meals in my confusion. Later, I gradually awakened. Privately, I compared his words with the recorded sayings of past sages, finding not a hair’s breadth of discrepancy. Thus, I grew ever more delighted to hear his teachings.

The Master once said: “The fundamental origin of human life is just this. When Master Lianxi urged people to seek the joy of Confucius and Yan Hui, it was precisely this.” Thereafter, his followers grew in number. The Master revealed the depths of his wisdom, pointing out the methods for cultivating oneself and governing others, the subtleties of substance and function, stillness and responsiveness, and the principles of boundless vastness. Privately, he expounded these profound truths.

With like-minded friends, we gathered in the blossoms of dawn and the moonlight of evening, through wind and rain, darkness and clarity, for decades without interruption. Only then did I privately rejoice that this untransmitted learning had not been lost. Alas, my like-minded friends scattered to the four directions. After several years, the Master ultimately departed from our company and passed away.

His writings include *The Origins and Development of the Sagely Learning*, *Convenience for the Young and Vast as Heaven and Earth*, *Records of Broad Observation*, and *Eight Chapters of Recorded Dialogues and Doubts*.

The various works elucidate the profound meanings of the sages and worthies—rare treasures indeed since the schools of Zhou [Dunyi], Cheng [Hao and Yi], Zhang [Zai], and Zhu [Xi]. My friend Huang Zuochen, upon first encountering them, rejoiced and wished to disseminate them widely. Yet the volumes were too numerous to engrave in haste. Among them, Huang held in particular esteem *Records for Seeking Correction* and *Letter to Lin Fengan*, these two books, and thus had them printed. I therefore take up my brush to compose this preface.

The Master’s learning in life was vast, and when discoursing with others, he would speak through day and night without weariness—far beyond what these two books could contain. Yet the Master often said that in the cosmos of human life, nothing lies beyond the three words *form*, *qi*, and *spirit*. Form, however, is but a perishable thing; when form is exhausted, qi dissipates. What is truly essential to the self depends solely on *spirit*—spirit being the Great Void. The Great Void, though formless, takes shape through things, pervading the Three Powers, encompassing all directions, traversing past and present, and filling the universe. Had the Master’s virtue, literary brilliance, and statesmanship been given full scope—had he held high office—he would surely have achieved great deeds. Had he ranked among the eminent, he would surely have illuminated profound truths. Alas, fate and time were against him. He spent his life as a humble scholar, dying at only fifty-two. That his words alone served as a beacon for our circle—how could this suffice to encompass the Master!

Yet what endures does not depend on worldly success or failure, nor on the brevity or length of years. Many have held high rank, enjoyed great wealth, and lived to a ripe old age. Yet in life, they may have shone brightly for a time, but once their bones grow cold, their names vanish. A hundred or a thousand years later, who will recall some high official or long-lived man, or what fortunes befell him? Such things are of no weight in measuring the Master. Neither wealth nor poverty, neither honor nor lowliness, neither long life nor early death—all depend on this alone. Those who awaken to this truth are complete human beings; those who do not are scarcely human at all. The sages, worthies, and heroes of past and present were simply those who perfected this one truth—not that they were superior to others. This is the great principle underlying the Master’s teachings. Even ten thousand words would but expound this same truth. Those who read these two books well may grasp the Master’s essential meaning.

The Master’s personal name was Shichen, his courtesy name Kuixin, and his sobriquet Yue’an. A scholar of Liuhe County, he resided on Long Mountain in the west of the county. His disciples thus called him Master Longshan. Written in the eleventh month of the *dingchou* year of the Kangxi reign by his fellow student and younger brother, Yuan Diao.

---

**Original Preface**
Yuan Wurou, a heroic scholar from Daming, arrived in Tang County this spring in the third month and lodged at the Zhunti Meditation Lodge. My friend Li Shujing became acquainted with him, and their bond grew deep. One day, he said to me, “There is a certain Yuan—an excellent man from the north. Why not go meet him?” I inquired about his character, and Shujing replied, “He is modest yet amiable, forthright yet resolute, and ever strives to keep his heart unobscured.” I exclaimed with delight, “He is a true scholar!” Thereupon, I accompanied Shujing to meet him and presented my humble insights. To my surprise, he graciously approved. Thereafter, each evening, I would visit to converse with him.

Yuan said, “A true man in this world must possess great learning.” I lamented, “Alas, my present concerns are too trivial to fully seek your instruction. What is to be done?” I pressed him repeatedly for guidance, and Yuan, growing more pleased, replied, “Once I return home and find some respite, I shall attend to these words.” Over ten days passed, and I returned to the mountains for the Dragon Boat Festival, while Yuan, burdened by travel, had no leisure. Thus, we were separated. Just as I longed for his company, Yuan announced his departure the next day to return home. I lingered in sorrow, ashamed to have nothing to offer in parting, and regretting that our shared aspirations had not been fully expressed, nor the principles of life and destiny fully elucidated. I feared I would fail in the duty of a kindred spirit a thousand *li* apart. Therefore, I dare set down my usual observations in rough form, seeking correction from those of the Way.

Written in the fifth month of the *wuwu* year of the Kangxi reign by Lu Shichen of Six Peaks, younger brother in learning.

**Records for Seeking Correction**
By Lu Shichen of Ancient Tang, sobriquet Yue’an.

The Way of learning and inquiry has no other path but to seek one’s lost heart-mind. These two lines are Master Meng’s revelation of the thousand sages’ essential teaching. In our cultivation, we need not seek far—only here may we find the crux. If we cannot apply effort to the heart-mind itself but merely seek among affairs and things, prop ourselves up with vigor, or act through talent and knowledge, we will never become true seed. Thus, Mencius returns everything to the heart-mind, speaking of preserving it and seeking the lost heart-mind: preservation is precisely what prevents its loss. Returning to the heart-mind does not mean abandoning worldly affairs. The work of preserving the heart-mind is precisely carried out within worldly affairs; to abandon them is heterodoxy, not only unworthy of belief but inviting universal condemnation. How could we, in our learning, follow such a path?

To return to the heart-mind means to take it as the master. In every affair, every thing, in all movement and stillness, we must constantly preserve this heart-mind. It is like threading coins on a string—all are held in hand, hence the saying, “unified by the One.”

Since the teaching of the sages declined and the great Dao was obscured, people have taken affairs as the heart-mind. Those of lesser attainment aside, even the more advanced remain bound by rigid patterns, often performing one or two good deeds or virtuous acts and believing they have reached the ultimate. They do not realize that while good deeds and virtuous acts are indeed sagely work, the source of their goodness and virtue must be traced back to the heart-mind. By reflecting and examining where they arise and from what they emerge, one discerns the location of the original heart-mind.

Formerly, Master Xiangshan discussed the original heart-mind with Yang Cihu, who failed to grasp it. One day, upon witnessing Cihu adjudicate a dispute over a broken fan, Xiangshan said to him: “Just now, in judging the broken fan, the one who knew right as right and wrong as wrong—this was Jingzhong’s original heart-mind.” At these words, Cihu attained sudden enlightenment. This shows that without recognizing the original heart-mind, one’s learning is not true learning. The harm of “practice without embodiment, habit without examination” lies precisely here.

Thus, in our learning today, we must first embody and recognize this heart-mind. Only when we see it clearly can we begin our work. Nowadays, everyone claims to have a heart-mind, yet in truth, they know not where it resides. They merely take the restless flux of thoughts as the heart-mind, unaware that these are but all manner of distractions, karmic entanglements, and fleeting intentions. If asked to set these aside and recognize a true heart-mind instead, they would be at a loss.

Now, every name in the world corresponds to a reality. Since this is called the heart-mind, there must be that which makes it the heart-mind. How can one take distractions, entanglements, and intentions as the heart-mind itself? One must experience, investigate, and identify the heart-mind before making any progress.

All things under heaven have form and trace, but the heart-mind cannot be sought through form or trace. Soundless and scentless, empty and vast—where can one begin the search? One must awaken to the underlying principle and nurture the first signs before seeing that there is such a great matter in the human world.

In daily life, all planning and deliberation arise from the heart-mind, yet these are but its functions, not its true substance. Only that single point of numinous clarity is the true heart-mind. This point of numinous clarity is quiescent yet ever-illuminating, illuminating yet ever-quiescent, free from form and sound. Where can one recognize it? Here, words and texts are of no use; conjecture and thought are also of no use. Only silent, personal realization will bring insight.

The method begins in moments of quiet: sit upright, centered and balanced, turn the gaze inward, and fix the mind without distraction. One will feel the heart-mind alert and luminous, utterly empty above, yet as if something enduring remains, impossible to forget—this is the true heart-mind. There is no need to seek further for its location.

The ancients’ phrase “seeking the lost heart-mind” means that what is sought is the heart-mind itself. The moment one seeks, the lost heart-mind is already recovered. This is most penetrating and direct, a key to entry for all ages—do not let it slip by.

During quiet sitting, when the spirit is gathered inward and the gaze turned within, there will inevitably arise a tumult of thoughts, ceaseless intentions. How can these be swept away? Yet one need not attend to them. These thoughts are but habitual falsities of ordinary times; how could they be cleared all at once? As soon as one thought is dispelled, another arises; extinguished in the east, it springs up in the west—when will it ever end? Only by seeing the true heart-mind will the host of illusions naturally subside. It is like a true master in the hall: how dare the arrogant servants and fierce maids act recklessly? If one is truly determined to seek the heart-mind, how could it remain unseen?

During quiet sitting, observe closely: when the preceding thought has passed and the succeeding thought has not yet arisen, this interval is called “no-thought.” Fix your gaze here, never letting go—this is where the true heart-mind resides. To seek is to seek this; to nurture is to nurture this; learning and inquiry are learning and inquiry into this.

Between the past thought and the future thought, where there is neither seeing nor hearing, neither sound nor scent—this is the heart-mind, this is nature, this is destiny, this is what Heaven calls the joy of Confucius and Yan Hui, the unbroken thread of transmission across the ages. But one must not mistake it. In quiet sitting, do not take mere emptiness and vastness as the truth, but rather that which is alert and luminous within this emptiness and vastness.

Thus, the ancients spoke of “neither seeing nor hearing” as the substance and “vigilance and fear” as the work. Wang Yangming said one could also take “vigilance and fear” as the substance and “neither seeing nor hearing” as the work.

How subtle these words are—they may well reveal the essence of the sagely learning. At first, preserving this heart-mind is most difficult; only with utmost care can it be done. The moment one slackens, it scatters away—hence it is said: grasp it and it remains; let go and it is lost. Once we recognize this, we must summon great resolve, piercing through past and future, holding fast to this single thought without a moment’s forgetfulness. The early masters likened it to a dragon nurturing its pearl, a hen brooding her eggs, or carrying an infant through the marketplace—each step taken with watchful care. They also compared it to a cat stalking a mouse, eyes fixed upon it, ears attuned to it—all apt descriptions. If a student can truly practice in this way, there will come moments of breakthrough, regardless of whether their natural endowment is fine or coarse.

At the outset of this work, though one strives with vigilance to guard it, the heart-mind is easily aroused and easily extinguished—here, the key is to maintain unbroken continuity. The instant a thought returns, one must exert intention to sustain it, clenching the teeth, planting the heels firm, allowing not the slightest lapse. Heart-mind following heart-mind, thought linking to thought, ever roused, ever preserved—only then can progress be made.

In the beginning of this effort, one may be able to maintain it in stillness but not in activity; thus, one must employ the method of practice. First, sit in stillness and inwardly observe the heart-mind, holding fast to this point of luminous awareness. Then rise and walk about, yet still holding it fast; let the gaze wander or rest upon objects, yet still holding it fast. The same applies to listening—let the ears, eyes, and limbs function as usual, but never for a moment release the heart-mind. After days of such practice, one realizes that seeing and hearing do not hinder the preservation of the heart-mind, and that preserving the heart-mind truly benefits seeing and hearing.

Yet one may still struggle with thinking—no sooner does thought arise than the heart-mind scatters. Here, too, the method of practice must be applied. Place an essay before oneself, first steady the heart-mind, then read the text. At first, with spirit inwardly gathered, the words may seem difficult to penetrate—pay this no mind. Simply hold fast to the heart-mind, reading and rereading. Better the text remain obscure than a single thought be lost. After days of this, familiarity will grow. At first, one may grasp only a little, then more; at first, only the general meaning, then deeper insights. Even with the mind fully engaged, luminous clarity remains undimmed—this is the method for refining the mind’s operation.

With long practice, the heart’s awakening gradually unfolds. One must test this in solitary sitting: no awareness of heaven above, no awareness of earth below, no perception of things without, no sense of self within. Vast and empty, radiant and luminous—what is this scene, what is this realm? It is the substance of nature, the state of "fasting the heart-mind" and "sitting in forgetfulness." This scene is indeed wondrous, yet one must not cling to it. To cling is to mistake the scene for the true substance, to prefer stillness and shun activity—this, too, is not the Way. One must know that in stillness, the absence of heaven, earth, self, and others is not the point; the point is that single thread of luminous awareness. If within the heart’s clarity one can remain ever awake, ever illumined—unoccupied yet not inert, engaged yet not disturbed, stillness and activity as one, movement and quiescence undivided—then one has attained it. The heart-mind embraces both movement and stillness, uniting inner and outer.

Mencius’ "accumulation of rightness" is truly the foundation for self-cultivation and the cultivation of others through the ages. If we can truly neither forget nor force, accumulating rightness and nurturing qi, then the way to an unshaken heart-mind lies herein. When the heart-mind has been preserved for a long time, one may become overly inward-turned. Yet this inward-turned effort is originally the meaning of "withdrawing and concealing in the hidden." If one clings to it as something fixed, one becomes confined to narrowness, failing to see the vastness of nature’s heaven. Only by recognizing the boundlessness of nature’s heaven can one perceive the full measure of the Dao’s substance.

Thus, Xiangshan said: "The cosmos is my heart-mind; my heart-mind is the cosmos." How vast, how enduring! One must see this clearly to know that within our single point of luminous awareness lies the capacity to position heaven and earth and nurture the myriad things. Then one realizes that we are not such insignificant beings. Ordinary people, bound by the immediate, fail to recognize the height of heaven and the depth of earth—how could they know that heaven, earth, and the myriad things are all oneself? The ancients said: "The Dao extends beyond the forms of heaven and earth." And again: "In the still observation of the myriad things, all are self-possessed." What breadth of mind! What vision! Yet this is not mere grand rhetoric—the substance of the Dao is truly thus. One must attend to this with urgency.

To recognize the vastness of the heart-mind, first observe the vastness of heaven and earth. From one’s own body, extend upward to the zenith of heaven, downward to the depths of earth, eastward to the sunrise, westward to the sunset, and likewise to the south and north. This is the realm within heaven and earth, the domain traversed by the sun, moon, and stars—yet even this has limits, boundaries, and an exterior. Beyond the sun, moon, and stars, though seemingly unknowable, there is still something to be grasped. One need only follow a single principle and extend it endlessly, beyond all limits and boundaries, and then the saying "its greatness admits of no exterior" becomes evident.

Those who hear these words may find them startling, yet without this understanding, the infinite principle of the great void remains unseen, and the teaching of "so great it bears all" remains hidden. The *Doctrine of the Mean* speaks of greatness as "that which bears all" and duration as "without limit"—its words span heaven and earth, enduring through past and present. Later generations, with narrow vision and constricted hearts, no longer know of this learning of vastness and endurance. Yet how could they know that heaven is inherently vast, time inherently enduring, and our heart-mind and the cosmos inherently boundless? There is no increase or decrease—only the failure to contemplate it.

Heaven bestows upon man a body of a hundred years, and with it, a heart-mind that endures through past and present without cease. Those who scheme only for the body fail to preserve this heart-mind, and after a hundred years, all returns to nothingness. Those who scheme for the heart-mind never once neglect the body, yet their spirit abides across the great earth for ten thousand ages. Thus it is said: "Following the greater body, one becomes a great person; following the lesser body, one becomes a petty person." To be a great person is to preserve one’s heart-mind. When a person’s heart-mind is preserved for long, the form and substance gradually align, naturally penetrating heaven and earth without obstruction or hindrance. Only then does one realize that nothing exists outside the radiance of one’s nature. Yet this cannot be grasped through conjecture. With accumulated effort over time, clarity arises of itself.

Shaozi said, "Only when there is no self do the myriad things become oneself"—this is the ultimate truth, the true secret. The *Book of Changes* states: "Tracing things back to their origin and returning to their end, one knows the discourse on life and death." What, then, is the discourse on life and death? When Confucius answered Zilu, he said, "If you do not yet know life, how can you know death?" What, indeed, is life? What, indeed, is death? While in this world, we possess but this single spark of numinous awareness. Without this spark, how do we differ from wood or stone? As the ancients said, we become "corpses with qi."

From this perspective, human life depends entirely on this spark of numinous awareness. With it, one observes heaven and earth, examines the myriad things, fills the space between above and below, and spans past and present. Without it, even one’s liver, gall, hair, skin, bones, flesh, claws, and fingers are no longer one’s own. How, then, does the heart-mind bind a person? Thus, human life arises from the heart-mind’s life, and human death begins with the heart-mind’s death. Only when the numinous departs from the body does the form die. The sages and worthies nurture this heart-mind to remain ever-numinous, unshaken and unmoved. Though the body may die, that which constitutes life does not perish. Hence it is said: "If one hears the Dao in the morning, one may die in the evening."

To grasp this insight, there is a method of awakening. Confucius spoke of "being steadfast in this even in haste, even in peril," and of "sacrificing oneself to perfect humaneness." When he spoke of peril and sacrifice, it might mean death by blade or saw, or by water or fire—none can be foreseen. Imagine placing yourself in such a situation: how would you perfect humaneness? How would you remain steadfast in this? The method requires holding the heart-mind firm and unmoving, stripping away each layer of the circumstance, then surveying the heart-mind in all four directions. Only then will you know that though your body may perish in peril, your true self remains unchanged. Above, the heavens remain as before; below, the earth remains as before; afar, the myriad things remain as before. What is lost are merely your ears, eyes, hands, feet, body, hair, and skin. Yet even without eyes, your vision remains; without ears, your hearing remains; without hands, feet, or body, your heart-mind’s thoughts and functions remain. Thus it is said: "perfecting humaneness." Humaneness is humanity—true humanity.

Penetrating this mystery, one knows that utmost sincerity is without cease, and without cease is the meaning of enduring. The sages and worthies, while alive, order heaven and earth; when they pass, their influence flows through the great void. Thus it is said: "One knows the conditions of ghosts and spirits." Shaozi said, "When a single thought does not arise, even ghosts and spirits do not know." For ghosts and spirits are without form or sound, possessing only this single spark of numinous awareness. We dwell alongside ghosts and spirits, sharing only this spark. If we were without this body, we too would be ghosts and spirits. Thus, the wonder of ghosts and spirits lies entirely in their ability to resonate with people. When a thought arises or an intention stirs, nothing escapes their knowing. Only in the absence of thought is there nothing to know. If a scholar’s learning does not reach this depth of concealment, it remains superficial. If one can cultivate the absence of a single thought, this is called the learning of the prior heaven. Mastering it, one may govern the world; delving deeply, one may perfect oneself alone. Alive, one orders the world through the human Dao; dead, one may remain numinous for ten thousand kalpas.

My late friend, Master Zhang Xingfu, once said: "To penetrate day and night, to transcend life and death, to traverse primordial chaos—it is all this single heart-mind." What I have set forth here is the authentic learning of the sages’ questions and the worthies’ truths, not some lofty exaggeration. Though I may not attain it, my heart secretly aspires to it. Our bodies, existing between heaven and earth, are utterly insignificant. If we follow only the lesser body, busying ourselves through life, how do we differ from dogs or horses? Without this learning, how can we not squander our lives? Thus it is said: "That by which humans differ from birds and beasts is but a hair’s breadth."

For this reason, the sages and worthies of all ages have been reverently diligent. Great Yu treasured every inch of time; King Wen toiled until the sun’s decline—there was indeed good reason. The *Book of Changes* states: "Simplicity and ease grasp the principles of the world, and one establishes one’s position within them." We appear in this world, far removed from the sages and worthies. If we cannot reform and cultivate ourselves, we will ultimately sink into oblivion, and regret will come too late. Pursuing this principle to its ultimate end, it is so vast it cannot be named, yet its entry point lies in nothing more than preserving the heart-mind through simplicity and ease—this is all.

As for preserving the heart-mind, I have already outlined several methods above. Regarding the Dao of cultivating the self and ordering the family, the principles of human relations and daily conduct, one need only not deceive oneself within and not deceive others without, maintaining equilibrium in all circumstances—naturally, wondrous efficacy will arise.

The above ten-odd passages are merely my humble insights. Though their order may be disordered, they all concern the Dao of cultivating the self and the methods of governing the heart-mind, and may serve as resources for those entering the path.

Wu Ruolai, a guest from Liuhe, forgot his noble status as a prince and scion, and deigned to visit this humble scholar in his mean dwelling. Taking my hand, we spoke heart to heart, delighting in our shared commitment to the Dao and virtue.

Yuanzi is truly a man of learning! I, born and raised among the wild grasses, with humble appearance and shallow discourse, am unworthy of his glance—yet Yuanzi’s literary brilliance and scholarly achievements make him a hero of Yan and Ji. Though how could I presume to match his gaze? Still, those who share the Dao conspire together; allow me, then, to offer Yuanzi one final consideration.

All who live between heaven and earth must have their reckonings. Confucius’s threefold reckoning has been transmitted through the ages, yet it remains incomplete. In my humble view, there is the reckoning of a single lifetime, and there is the reckoning of ten thousand generations.

What is the reckoning of a single lifetime? It is to hone one’s literary arts, refine one’s talents and discernment, and plan for one’s place in the world. From the ignorant and lowly to the highest ministers and generals, though their pursuits differ, all seek only to secure peace for this present life. Yet their affairs end with their bodies; though the years after death stretch long, they hold nothing for them. Thus it is called the reckoning of a single lifetime.

What is the reckoning of ten thousand generations? It is to diligently cultivate virtue and temper one’s nature, to delve into the mysteries of heaven and humanity, and earnestly seek the principles inherent in one’s own nature. This is what is meant by the celestial nobility and true worth that reside within us—whether one’s conduct is grand or constrained, it neither adds nor diminishes. The Dao of Yao and Shun endures to this day: is this not the reckoning of ten thousand generations? Moreover, to awaken at dawn and die by dusk without wavering, from this point onward, there is that which even ten thousand generations cannot exhaust. Ah, how vast it is!

Though we live far from antiquity, the innate knowledge within us remains unchanged across ten thousand years, as if but a single day. How can a true man of resolve not make antiquity anew from himself? Yuanzi is a renowned scholar of the North, his natural endowments noble and flourishing, like uncut jade or unrefined gold. At first glance, one knows him to be an instrument of enduring significance—how could he relegate the affairs of sages and worthies to secondary importance?

Gazing up at his noble example, I cannot help but feel my spirit soar. I fear only that his commitment to the Dao may not be single-minded, and so offer these earnest words—not because Yuanzi truly requires them, but because our bond runs deep, our mutual understanding is profound, and my hopes for him are great.

Shichen bows again and records this.

*Letter to Master Lin Fenqian*
By Lu Shichen of Gutang, styled Yue’an

How vast is heaven and earth! How distant is past and present! How boundless are the lives of men! Some are noble as princes, others lowly as servants; some are so rich their wealth rots, others so poor they gird themselves with rope; some live to a ripe old age, others die young in epidemics. The wise and foolish intermingle, the worthy and unworthy are jumbled together. Judged by the fleeting sights and sounds of a single moment, all seems real—yet before long, the years turn, and soon the rivers and mountains change. Look back at those who once bustled and scurried, chasing and striving: they have all vanished without a trace. In one transformation, cities become ruins; in another, mulberry fields turn to seas. Push this to its extreme, and speak of it in wild terms: the fortunes of the world cannot be detained, heaven and earth grow old in an instant, and in the blink of an eye, the great cycle of 129,600 years has passed. Yet even the great earth itself cannot endure forever.

From this, we see that all within the universe is but an illusory scene—empty, fleeting, without a single truth. Since ancient times, emperors, kings, sages, and worthies have regarded all worldly glory, wealth, and honor as spring blossoms glimpsed in passing, as floating clouds drifting across the void, leaving no lingering savor. They meet such things with indifference, seeking only that which heaven has bestowed upon them, and strive to fulfill it. This alone is the most true and real matter, utterly free of illusion. Alas!

Above, the heavens; below, the earth; before, a thousand ages; behind, ten thousand years—east and west, south and north, the boundless expanse of the eight directions and eight limits. I am fortunate to be born within this vastness, to stand as one of the Three Powers, endowed with spirit beyond all creatures. Surely there must be something extraordinary in me—how could I be the same as grasses and trees, birds and beasts, doomed to rot and decay?

Yet the world does not reflect, and no one awakens. All content themselves with empty assent or hollow denial, frittering away their lives. In the end, their forms lodge in hollow trees, their souls return to the yellow springs. They remain utterly ignorant of what heaven has bestowed upon them. Alas! Alas! How greatly they betray the August Heaven and Sacred Earth! And not only do they betray Heaven and Earth—they betray themselves even more.

For the mandate heaven confers upon humanity is of the greatest magnitude and the most enduring span. This greatness is not the commonplace greatness of ordinary measure, for it is greatness without limit. This endurance is not the commonplace endurance of ordinary time, for it is duration without bound. Greatness without limit encompasses east and west, south and north, above and below. Duration without bound unites past ages and future eras. When east and west, south and north, above and below are encompassed, all within the Six Directions and beyond them is gathered in. When past ages and future eras are united, all before the beginning of a kalpa and after its end are threaded through. What thing is not mine? What time is not mine? If nothing and no time are not mine, how can this be called illusory or fleeting? Is it not the most true and real?

What is it that heaven has mandated in me, and what is it that I have received from heaven? It is the heart-mind. What is the heart-mind? It is spirit. What is spirit? It is awareness. This awareness has no form, no image; it can only be grasped through dark enlightenment and silent realization.

Let us turn inward and seek the substance of awareness. This substance is the state before a single thought arises, where past and future are cut off—lucid, alert, as when one is roused from deep sleep yet has not yet formed a thought, or when sitting in silence and hearing a sound before discerning its source. The former scholars spoke of it as "a mute eating bitter melon—clear in the mind yet inexpressible," or "the taste of salt in water—neither existent nor nonexistent." It is like a cat stalking a mouse, one eye fixed upon it, one ear attuned to it. Alas!

Supreme indeed! What makes Heaven Heaven, what makes me myself—all is exhausted in this alone. For this single spark of numinous light illumines heaven and earth, and every person possesses it. To lose it is to descend into the realm of beasts, ghosts, and demons; to attain it is to join the ranks of sages and noble persons. How can we not prize it? How can we not be vigilant?

Mencius said, "That by which humans differ from beasts and birds is but slight." Zengzi and Zisi both taught people to be vigilant in solitude—"solitude" is precisely that "slight difference." What is this slight difference? It is this state of lucid, alert awareness. All people under heaven share the same heart-mind, never having been distinct. Yet their destinations diverge by ten, a hundred, a thousand, ten thousandfold. There is no other reason: it is simply a matter of being aware or unaware. Awareness brings clarity; unawareness brings confusion. Clarity leads one to perceive goodness and act upon it; confusion leads one to rush toward evil and take it as one’s home. Goodness makes one a noble person; evil makes one a petty person. At the extreme of pettiness, one becomes a denizen of the netherworld; at the extreme of nobility, one is called a Yao or Shun. This is the ultimate disparity, and the inevitable consequence of one’s path.

What makes a human human is nothing other than awareness. To be aware is to be awake; to be unaware is to dream. Awakening is the threshold of dreams. To be aware is to live; to be unaware is to die. Life is the threshold of death. To be aware is to be human; to be unaware is to be a beast. Humanity is the threshold of bestiality. These three thresholds all depend on a single awareness to traverse them. How great is the meaning of awareness!

Let us consider waking and sleeping. While asleep, one is utterly without awareness.
