Without awareness, there is no such thing as heaven and earth, sun and moon, no such thing as mountains and rivers, the myriad things, no such thing as cities and palaces, the mingling of people. Not only this—there would be no such thing as parents, spouse, children, halls, or household goods. One would not even have one’s own bed, curtains, quilts, pillows, or clothing. One’s hands and feet would cease to exist, and one’s organs would vanish as well. In that dark, dim state, even the self is no longer one’s own—how much less anything else?

But upon waking, in that fleeting moment, one discerns the existence of the self. Soon after, one discerns the existence of the body. Listening intently, sounds reach the ears. Rubbing the eyes and gazing, light and brightness appear. Throwing on clothes and rising, stepping forth with ease, looking down and up, one perceives that heaven and earth and the myriad things are all orderly arrayed—awareness makes it so. Thus, with awareness, there is heaven and earth and the myriad things; without awareness, there is no heaven and earth and the myriad things. It is not that heaven and earth and the myriad things do not exist; rather, if I do not know them, it is fitting to say there is no heaven and earth and myriad things.

Confucius said, "If one hears the Dao in the morning, one may die in the evening." The Dao is awareness. Why, then, is death acceptable upon attaining it? Because with awareness, one remains eternally awake. The body dies, but one’s nature lives on; things depart, but spirit remains. Heaven and earth, past and present, are all within the realm of a single awareness. Heaven is my heaven, earth is my earth, people are my people, things are my things. Why? Because awareness is that which has no sound or scent, no form to see or hear. Having no sound or scent, no form to see or hear, it is the Limitless. The Limitless has no bounds, no shape or body. Expand it, and the six directions are filled; extend it through time, and it endures for ten thousand ages. Mountains may crumble, but this awareness does not decay; the two great forces may perish, but this awareness knows no end. It will measure itself against the vastness of the Great Void, match the longevity of the Primal Unity, without beginning or end, without above or below, without inside or outside. All the myriad existences and transformations within the cycles of cosmic epochs arise and pass away within its boundless expanse—how then can life and death be worth discussing?

Humans are but things, endowed with heaven’s qi and receiving earth’s form, molded by yin and yang, granted or deprived by the workings of creation—hence they are subject to life and death. Awareness is not a thing; it is not born with birth, nor does it die with death. Thus, the great sages and worthies, though their bodies perish and their qi disperses after death, remain eternally numinous through ten thousand kalpas. This is the Dao: in humans, it is virtue; in heaven, it is the Mandate of Heaven; in the ebb and flow of creation, it is the spirit-like. Heaven, spirits, and humans are one.

Yet this is difficult to speak of. For humans, indulging desires is easy, while following principle is hard. Heavenly principle and human desire cannot coexist—they both emerge from the square inch of the heart-mind. Only when desire is eliminated does principle remain; only when the human is exhausted does Heaven appear. Yet all this is nothing other than awareness. It is fully realized here.

"Hearing the Dao in the morning"—have you truly heard this?

Formerly, when Zilu asked about serving ghosts and spirits and about death, Confucius replied, "If you cannot yet serve people, how can you serve ghosts? If you do not yet understand life, how can you understand death?" The discourse on life and death truly began with our Confucian school, though his words drew near without fully expounding it, giving the impression he had not spoken of it at all.

Thus, I have often said that when we discuss learning, we should calm our hearts, settle our qi, and unhurriedly seek to reach the place of unity. Where unity lies, how can one forcibly deny it? Therefore, that among all things between heaven and earth, humans are most noble—this cannot be denied. That in the vastness of the world, cultivating the self is fundamental—this cannot be denied. Yet the self is essential, but the heart-mind is even more indispensable. The heart-mind is essential, but without numinosity and awareness, what is it? This cannot be denied.

Numinous! Aware! Let every thought be thus, let every moment be unwavering. Uniting activity and stillness, constancy and change without alteration, though the body may be slain by blade or cauldron, the heart-mind cannot be moved. In haste or peril, one must abide in this—such is the person. Can one such as this still be said to die?

Moreover, death is but the transformation of form, the dispersal of qi, the decay and putrefaction of bones, flesh, and limbs. Yet where does that which in life was luminous and numinous, not dependent on form or reliant on qi, go?

Master Su once said: "It does not exist because of birth, nor does it perish with death." This is true principle, this is real matter—seek it and investigate it, and one knows; embody it and verify it, and one sees. This teaching cannot be denied.

Alas! The followers of the sages speak only of this true principle and real matter that cannot be denied. For this is the great root and great source of all people—not calculated for life and death. Those who attain this matter transcend life and death. Vast without bound, enduring without limit, it fills the cosmos. This is what Heaven bestows upon me, and what I receive from Heaven. Thus the sage, with heart-mind stilled, observes transformation, knowing this nature to be supremely great and enduring.

Contemplating the boundlessness of Heaven and Earth, one recognizes the finitude of one’s own life. How vast are the six directions, yet how small this body! How eternal are the seasons, yet how fleeting this life! How numerous are living things, yet how insignificant this self! There is nothing prior to this by which one may contend with the Creator for supremacy. Therefore, one guards it with care, trembling as if standing at the edge of an abyss or treading upon thin ice.

This is what Boyi and Shuqi sought with such earnestness, what Confucius and Yan Hui found so joyous. Through the ages, the sages’ vigilance and diligence never slackened—never slackened in this. What is this? It is awareness. In awareness, there is truth; in truth, there is sincerity.

The *Doctrine of the Mean* says: "Utmost sincerity is ceaseless." Ceaseless, it endures; enduring, it proves true; true, it reaches far; far-reaching, it is vast and deep; vast and deep, it is lofty and luminous. It also says: "Vast and deep, it bears all things; lofty and luminous, it overspreads all things; far-reaching and enduring, it perfects all things." Vast and deep, it matches Earth; lofty and luminous, it matches Heaven; far-reaching and enduring, it is boundless. Such is the way that, though unseen, it is manifest; though unmoving, it transforms; though non-doing, it accomplishes. Does not the virtue of Heaven and the Way of kings reach their fullness in this?

Yet this must await the proper time to be realized; its greatness and renown must first become manifest before this flourishing is seen. In ancient times, one might sing in a humble chamber and suddenly withdraw into the distance, never envying the honor, wealth, and glory of kings and nobles, yet never losing one’s plain integrity. For the truth lay in this, not in that. How could external gains or losses of glory and decay move one’s joy or sorrow? It was only to seek what is called awareness.

What I call awareness is what others do not see. Yet though awareness is unseen by others, Heaven is this very thing, Earth is this very thing, and all that Heaven and Earth encompass and overspread is nothing but this. For if one turns from the external and seeks within: Heaven is Heaven, but who is it that makes Heaven Heaven? Earth is Earth, but who is it that makes Earth Earth? People are people, things are things, but who is it that makes people people and things things? Know that it is not my awareness that makes them so, yet without it, they would not be.

The noble person of old knew that nothing exists that is not illusory, yet this alone is real; nothing exists that is not empty, yet this alone is solid. Only when there is this reality do illusions cease to be illusory; only when there is this solidity does emptiness cease to be empty.

Ah! Heaven and Earth are truly vast, and the ages truly distant. Without this single point of numinous clarity, the cosmos would be nothing. How could one fail to preserve its truth and guard its awareness? The vastness of Heaven and Earth, the remoteness of past and present—all is awareness. Small awareness makes things small; great awareness makes things great.

Once, Master Yangming traveled through the mountains. Someone pointed to a flowering tree in a cliff and asked: "You have said that nothing exists outside the innate knowledge of the good. Is this flowering tree, then, also innate knowledge?" Master Yangming replied: "Before you came to this valley, this knowledge and the flowering tree were both obscure. Now that you stand before it, all at once becomes clear. What is this if not innate knowledge?"

Thus, is there anything in the world outside awareness? It has been said: vast without bound, enduring without limit. But what is the scene of "vast without bound"? What is the form of "enduring without limit"?

Let us speak first of "vast without bound." What the human mind can conceive and measure extends only to what lies within Heaven and Earth. Yet to stop at what lies within Heaven and Earth is to acknowledge a bounded vastness. Now consider the three hundred and sixty-five degrees of the celestial sphere, to which the sun, moon, and stars are fixed—how small is this, that one cannot call it supremely vast! Only by gazing beyond the revolutions of the sun and moon does one know that the void is inexhaustible. Extending this further: one may multiply the size of Heaven and Earth by one, by ten, by a hundred, by a thousand, by ten thousand, by a hundred million. Even if one stops here, there is still an outside. Then let us take the utmost: a hundred million times Heaven and Earth, a trillion times, ten trillion times, a hundred trillion times, a quadrillion times Heaven and Earth—yet it remains inexhaustible, unending. Thus it is called "vast without bound."

Next, let us speak of "enduring without limit." What the human mind can conceive and measure extends only to what lies within the primordial chaos. Yet to stop at what lies within the primordial chaos is to acknowledge a bounded endurance. Now consider the twelve myriads and nine thousand six hundred years of a cosmic cycle, in which years, months, days, and hours accumulate—yet all must come to an end. How can this be called supremely enduring? Only by contemplating the eternal succession of the celestial stems and earthly branches does one know that past and present cannot be limited. Extending this further: one may multiply the span of the primordial chaos by one, by ten, by a hundred, by a thousand, by ten thousand, by a hundred million. Even if one stops here, there is still a limit.

Then let us further speak of the ultimate: one myriad myriad repetitions of primordial chaos, ten myriad myriad repetitions, a hundred myriad myriad repetitions, a thousand myriad myriad repetitions, ten thousand myriad myriad repetitions. Yet even this cannot be exhausted, cannot be fully measured—thus it is called "enduring without limit," the utmost, the complete. Truly enduring, truly great!

Yet without awakening, how could such boundless endurance and greatness exist? Thus, "great without beyond" is precisely the greatness without beyond of awakening; "enduring without limit" is precisely the enduring without limit of awakening. Therefore, it is said: without exhaustion, without form or substance.

The *Yi Jing* states: *"Qian knows the great beginning; Kun brings things to completion. Qian’s ease is knowing; Kun’s simplicity is ability. Ease makes knowing simple; simplicity makes following easy. What is easy to know fosters closeness; what is easy to follow yields achievement. Closeness allows endurance; achievement allows greatness. Endurance is the virtue of the worthy; greatness is their work."*

From this, it is clear: what can be great and enduring is fully encompassed by simplicity and ease. And the Way of simplicity and ease is no other than awakening. In all under heaven, what is more enduring and great than awakening? What is simpler and easier than awakening?

Thus it is said: that by which humans are human is awakening alone. This awakening is the essence of the *jingyi* at the Yu court, the unified transmission of the Confucian school, the tranquility of the Zhou, the reverence of the Cheng brothers, the rectification of mind and sincerity of intention in Zhu Xi, the playful mastery of Shao Yong, the vast attainment of Lu Jiuyuan, the nurturing of incipient signs in Chen Xianzhang, and the innate knowledge of Wang Yangming—all are this.

The *Hetu* diagrams this; the *Luoshu* writes of this; the Six Classics and the Four Masters likewise convey nothing but this.

Hold fast to this awakening in every step, and there will be no danger of stumbling; hold fast to it in every word and breath, and there will be no reproach for restlessness; hold fast to it in the realm of daily life and sustenance, and there will be no regret for commonplace actions.

Apply it to the ruler, and there is loyalty; to friends, and there is trust; to parents, teachers, elders, spouses, and siblings, and there is filial piety, reverence, distinction, and order. Extend it to the family, and the family is well-ordered; to the state, and the state is governed; to all under heaven, and all under heaven is at peace. One does not shame one’s ancestors and may secure one’s descendants.

Alas!

When this awakening reaches its fullness, what was once deemed illusory is no longer illusory, and nothing fails to be real; what was once deemed empty is no longer empty, and nothing fails to be substantial. Otherwise, one drifts through life in vague assent or dissent, passing the years in vain—like plants, like beasts—some utterly devoid of awareness, others half-awake, rotting and decaying. The vast and enduring gift bestowed upon us by Heaven thus remains unseen. How tragic! How truly tragic!

The cosmos knows no bounds, yet our lives are so brief! How then can we partake in the triad of Heaven, Earth, and Humanity? How can we claim the numinous among the myriad things? Mired in mediocrity, tossed between rise and fall, insensible to pain or joy, heedless of life or death, we consume grain and drink water, exhausting days and years—only to find old age upon us in an instant, the great limit at hand, with no hope of delay.

The snail’s fame, the fly’s profit—all vanish like smoke and scatter like ash. Where now are the boasts of talent, the schemes for victory, the long calculations and short plans? What worth is there in being such a hollow person?

Thus it is said: what makes a human human is awakening alone. Awakened, one is great; unawakened, one is small. Awakened, one endures; unawakened, one is fleeting.

Will you be great or small? Will you endure or fade?
Awakened, one is human; unawakened, one is beast. Awakened, one lives; unawakened, one dies.
Will you be human or beast? Will you live or die?
Awakened, one is real; unawakened, one is illusory. Awakened, one is substantial; unawakened, one is empty.
Will you be real or illusory? Substantial or empty?

This is not something that requires a sage to discern.

Alas! The scholars of this world have indeed aspired to learning, yet they drown in literary embellishments, are shackled by commentaries, fettered by hearsay, and entangled in explanations. The lesser among them chase after rank and fame, dream of wealth and nobility, and engage in base, sordid, and ignoble acts—things even the vulgar and foolish of the marketplace would disdain. Alas, how extreme this has become!

This Dao has long been neglected. People cling to their ignorance, rigidly bound to the present, their hearts hardened and unkind, their customs shallow and corrupt. Should someone arise to speak of it, they dismiss it as impractical or delusional. If they call it impractical, I accept it gladly; if they call it delusional, I endure it. Yet what I truly lament is that this Dao cannot gain the trust of others—this is the deepest regret.

In the days when Yao and Shun ruled above, this Dao illuminated all under Heaven like the sun at its zenith, its radiance reaching every corner. During the flourishing of the Three Dynasties, rulers were enlightened and ministers virtuous; families were well-ordered and states well-governed. The customs and hearts of the people returned to purity, rites and music were perfected, benevolence nurtured and righteousness upheld. These virtues permeated to the marrow, lifting the world into a realm of humaneness and longevity—what Confucius called "illuminating the bright virtue throughout the world."

This Dao is the Dao of enduring greatness, the Dao that unites inner and outer. It is rooted in Heavenly virtue and manifests as the Kingly Way. What is the Kingly Way? It is cultivating the self, ordering the family, governing the state, and bringing peace to all under Heaven. What is Heavenly virtue? It is what Heaven bestows upon us and what we receive from Heaven. Because it is truly possessed within oneself, it is called *virtue*.

This virtue is Heaven itself—above, there is nothing higher; below, nothing lower; in the beginning, no origin; in the end, no termination. Extend it to the farthest east, and the east knows no limit; extend it to the farthest west, and the west knows no limit. The same holds true for the farthest south and north. This is not some invented doctrine—Heaven is thus, virtue is thus, the Dao is thus. This teaching cannot be denied.

Yet people today fail to examine it closely. Upon hearing even a mention of *xing* (nature) and *ming* (destiny), they immediately label it as Chan Buddhism. Alas! "What Heaven imparts is called *xing*"—this is the very first line of the *Doctrine of the Mean*. Even village farmers and herding boys have read and heard it. To suddenly regard these two words as the exclusive domain of heterodoxy is the height of confusion.

Master Cheng once laughed upon hearing someone lecture on the *Doctrine of the Mean*, saying, "I fear that from the very first line, they have already spoken wrongly." Reflecting on this now, even speaking wrongly would be preferable—at least they would have spoken. Today, people cannot even recall the first line. Alas! How profound their blindness!

The luminosity of the human heart has remained unchanged through the ages. Should a sage emerge from the Eastern Sea or from the southern, western, or northern seas, this heart and this principle would be no different. Did Master Xiangshan not speak truly?

Thus have I often said that even beggars possess the substance of the Dao. For I have heard in the streets and alleys their brief words and casual remarks—sometimes utterances so near to the Dao, so consonant with principle, that they merit listening. From this I know that the luminosity within their hearts has never been absent.

How could this be true of humans alone? Even birds, beasts, and insects possess it. Observe how they drink and peck at ease, roam and wander freely—thus do we know that Heaven, in giving life to all things, bestows upon each its nature and grants to each its destiny, each in its own way.

Yet how is it that the Confucians of this world, who read books from dawn to dusk and discourse on ornate phrases, never inquire into this? When one speaks to them of "withdrawing and concealing in secrecy," they say, "Is this not too profound?" When one speaks of "having no fixed form or substance," they say, "Is this not too vast?" When one speaks of "nothing so great it cannot contain, nothing so small it can be broken," they call it "absurd and boundless." When one speaks of "compasses, squares, marking lines, and inked cords," they dismiss it as "the pedantry of rigid scholars." When one speaks of "sages, spirit-like persons, and noble gentlemen," they brand it "madness, delirium, and folly."

The young, upon hearing such words, say, "Discourses on life and death are for the elderly to ponder. We in our prime should be vigorous and active—why speak of such inauspicious things?" The old, upon hearing them, say, "Had I heard this a few years earlier, I might still have had the strength to pursue it. Now, in my decline, there is no need to mention it."

Those pressed by poverty often say, "First I must secure wealth and comfort." Yet the wealthy, burdened by many affairs, say, "I shall attend to this once my matters are fewer and my circumstances clearer." In times of peace and routine, they say, "Today I shall wait for tomorrow." When affairs grow tangled and chaotic, they say, "It is not that I do not wish to, but I have no leisure."

Alas! If people speak thus, what then can be done?

The unworthy Chen privately reflects that all this amounts to nothing more than self-abandonment and self-neglect. Given the vastness of the Way, its enduring nature, and the fact that every person is fully endowed with it and capable of attaining it—why then willingly cast oneself aside, content to sink into obscurity and decay, sharing the fate of beasts and ghosts? I cannot fathom the intent behind such a heart.

Though Chen is foolish and unworthy, far removed from the sages and distant from antiquity, born with mediocre endowments and further corrupted by habit, I dare not aspire to sagehood, nor even to worthiness. Yet the Dao is lofty and sublime; even if it seems as unattainable as climbing the heavens, I still strive to approach it day by day. For though the Dao may be difficult to fully attain, there are indeed aspects that can be learned and reached—namely, the cultivation of the heart-mind.

How is it cultivated? By preserving it. How is it preserved? By grasping it. How is it grasped? By seeking it. How is it sought? By awakening to it. Thus, learning is awakening. In our studies, we must guard this heart-mind as a dragon guards its pearl, as a hen broods over its eggs, as one carrying an infant through a marketplace—each step taken with care, ensuring that the senses do not stray into grave error, and that the movements of thought do not lose their innate purity. This is the path to nearness.

What, then, is this awakening? It is what I call the profound, wordless realization that yields understanding. To awaken is to be serene and clear, free from fixed intentions or rigid thoughts, inwardly illuminated and uniquely perceptive.

Yet most people have long remained unawakened, blindly rushing forward in darkness, their actions shrouded in ignorance—this is all too common. It is a pity that such a noble endeavor, so intimately tied to heaven and humanity, is cast aside and neglected. In the end, when all is said and done, they fret over their families, their children, and their possessions, all to no avail. Regret comes too late, and remorse is of no benefit.

Thus, it is wise to prepare before the rain comes, to plan early. Even if one must rush forward with haste, what time remains for other pursuits? To abandon this path for other aims is like nourishing a single finger while neglecting the shoulder and back.

Moreover, this endeavor is not without effect: a single day’s effort yields a day’s result, and a lifetime’s effort yields a lifetime’s result. Even if one does not fully succeed, Chen believes it is still better than doing nothing. Furthermore, the principle of "first difficulty, then reward" is certain. Therefore, for one who would be human, nothing comes before learning, and nothing is more essential than resolve.

Confucius devoted himself to learning until his final days, when he walked with a staff in leisure. Mencius spent his life aspiring to follow Confucius. Today, when we look up to the towering height of Mount Tai or gaze upon the vastness of the sea—so majestic, so boundless—it truly leaves one at a loss for where to begin. Yet with this awakening, there is a path to climb and a vessel to cross.

The former scholars said that learning is to establish the heart-mind for heaven and earth, to secure the destiny of the people, to continue the lost work of the ancient sages, and to open the way to great peace for all generations. I once recited these words, believing that this was the true ambition of a great person. Now, reflecting on them, how can they not be true?

If one can truly set this resolve, pursue this learning, and take the sages and worthies as one’s own responsibility, then the benefits gained will deepen day by day. This spark of numinous clarity will fill heaven and earth, vast and enduring—these are not empty words. One need only firmly grasp this principle, examine it closely, and the intent behind it will become clear.

*Preface to the Plum Blossom Dialogues*

The Dao is one—why then speak of three? The one is Confucianism, which all people require. Yet the Dao transcends even this name—how can it be confined to one? For those of superior understanding, the veils of literary obstructions are swept away, and the ultimate principle stands alone. Such words are true, but for those beginning their studies, where do they turn for guidance? Thus, the Apricot Altar was established, and the bamboo slips of the classics were worn through three times—here we see the tireless and unwearied dedication of our sage.

Now, Master Xinxiang Xue of Wumen, a distinguished disciple of the Gushu Yinlou, possesses profound virtue and vast learning, having uniquely grasped the transmitted heart-mind. He has shown me his *Plum Blossom Dialogues* and asked me to write a preface. Upon reading it, my mind was suddenly unobstructed, as if a deep resonance had been struck. Though I am by nature dull, how dare I presume to speak grandly of such matters? Yet, as a friend, I could not outright refuse.

Upon careful reflection and quiet contemplation, I recognize that Master Xue’s cultivation runs deep, and his discourse is all the more subtle. From the one, he reaches the ten thousand, and from the ten thousand, he returns to the one, harmonizing its principles without lingering in mere conjecture. He distills its essence to the utmost, not only delving into the subtleties of Confucian learning but also revealing the essential points of the Two Teachings (Buddhism and Daoism).

From this, one sees that the effort of learning is easier said than done. Since the Tang and Song dynasties, those who excel in discoursing on principle have invariably rejected the Two Teachings, while followers of the Two Teachings have invariably belittled the Learning of Principle. Those who seek to unify these teachings have found it utterly impossible—this affliction arises from failing to apply them closely to the self and the heart-mind, instead erecting barriers.

The deeper the barriers, the farther one strays from the nature of life. To seek the Dao that nourishes the self becomes even more difficult than counting the years.

This *Dialogues* compilation, however, encompasses both the Way of governance and peace in the external world and the work of self-cultivation and restoration within. It extends to the highest virtue, the congealing of the Dao, and the power of transformation, leaving no detail unaddressed. It can serve as a model for learning and the true aim of self-cultivation and ordering one’s life.

I have long admired the books of the Gushu Yinlou. The *Hidden Books* series comprises dozens of works, all centered on the Dao of rectitude and sincerity. Among them, the *Record of Forgotten Words*, compiled by Chen Yunbo of Qiantang, most closely addresses the self and the heart-mind.

Yet Yunbo once journeyed north to the clouds’ very edge, his literary brush vigorous and free, like ten thousand acres of cloud-waves surging and subsiding without trace, or like a myriad of cloud-borne zithers playing, each melody seeking its own perfection, turning and shifting to captivate—where self and world are forgotten, as if wandering the Isles of the Immortals, with endless wonders to behold. In this, his *Golden Canopy Heart Lamp* has already reached its zenith. His other works, whether retelling the creations of antiquity or unveiling his own singular insights, are like treasures arrayed within a crystal palace: should one but grasp a single gem, it would already surpass all that heaven and earth can offer.

Yet if merely reading his books evokes such wonder, how much more profound must be the subtleties when one receives instruction face-to-face, hearing his voice and witnessing his countenance? In ancient times, Master Guan Yin composed the *Five Thousand Characters on the Dao and Virtue*; though not written in Laozi’s own hand, it truly captured the heart-transmission of Laozi. The works of Master Xue are much the same. As for their benefit to later scholars and their contribution to the principles of fame and reason, all is unified in the One Thread—what cause is there for hesitation?

I now submit this to Master Xue for his judgment: is it fitting or not? Thus concludes this preface.

Written on a spring day in the gengzi year of the Daoguang era, in the Chamber of Everlasting Spring amid the Compassionate Bamboos, by the later student of the ancient tradition, Li Wenyuan, with a bow.

**Author’s Preface**

In learning, nothing is more vital than establishing resolve. Without resolve, no endeavor comes to fruition; with resolve established, one’s work may be accomplished and virtue cultivated. The essence of scholarship lies in reading to illuminate principle. As Master Zhu said: “Reading is simply about grasping this principle. Governing a household has its own principle, serving as an official has its own principle—though their domains differ, it is always the same principle.” He also said: “When reading, one must press the heart against the pages, examining each sentence and character until all have their proper place, only then can there be discussion.”

Without reading, there is no way to advance in learning. The countless words of the Three Teachings’ sages and worthies all serve to elucidate this principle. Yet one must first read the Confucian classics to grasp principle intimately, for only then does learning have a foundation. Thus, the *Four Books* and *Five Classics* are essential reading for all. Those who lack resolve in this regard may as well not read at all. Otherwise, merely understanding principle is not enough—it must be enacted in conduct to reveal its true substance.

As Hu Jingzhai said: “Once the meaning of a book is understood, one must ensure it arises from within oneself. This aligns with Master Cheng’s teaching that ‘the learner must study accordingly,’ and thus may avoid error.” Today’s scholars, however, either focus solely on literary achievement and worldly success or pursue only the abstruse and the void, neglecting the affairs of human relations and the heart-mind. Thus, they ultimately struggle to enter the realm of the sages.

Yet they fail to realize that the most profound matters must begin with the most mundane. Once, someone asked Master Xiangshan where to cultivate effort, and he replied: “In human emotions and worldly affairs.” Similarly, Huang Mianzhai said: “With every thought that arises, examine it carefully: does it accord with the Dao, or depart from it? Is it pure and flawless, or does it contain even the slightest deviation?” Without a single thought that fails to align with principle, without a single principle left unfulfilled to its utmost—only then can one be said to be truly cultivating effort.

If one merely clings to stillness, indulging in the remote and the void, treating the great task of restraining thoughts as trivial and failing to exert oneself in practice, this is truly having “feet ungrounded, abandoning the root to chase the branches”—how can one hope for virtue and work to bear fruit? Thus, Hu Jingzhai said: “Only when a scholar knows how to preserve and examine can virtue advance.”

Therefore, in learning, nothing comes before establishing resolve. Once resolve is set, books may be read, principles understood, virtue cultivated, and work accomplished. The sages, immortals, and buddhas share this same principle—how could there be two Ways?

This was the urgent teaching my late teacher, Master Xiaogen, often imparted to his disciples, regarding it as most essential. Master Xiaogen was a descendant of the former worthy Minister Min Muzhai, and a nephew of the former governor Zhiting. In his youth, he served as an official in southern Yunnan. His filial devotion in the inner chambers and his virtuous governance are recorded in historical annals, and I need not elaborate here.

As for his mastery of Confucian learning and the subtleties of the primordial tradition, he inherited the direct lineage of Zhong, Lü, Wang, and Qiu, and carried forward the transmission of the Tai Xu school. He was, in truth, a Confucian who embodied the Dao. After retiring from office, he secluded himself on Ancient Plum Blossom Isle, the Cave Heaven of Pure Harmony. In leisure, he traveled between the rivers and lakes of Jiangsu, Zhejiang, Fujian, and the northern regions, with Suzhou as his favored retreat.

His work, *The Hidden Books of Gushu Yinlou*, is a revelation of profound truths, directly expressing the wellspring of the heart-mind. Every word flows from the sea of nature, casting aside all alchemical metaphors of lead and mercury to uniquely transmit the master’s hidden teachings, thereby restoring the Supreme’s heart-transmission to the world. This was the master’s苦心 in saving the age, and a great fortune for later scholars.

Yet the master once said: “Many of my writings address specific times and places, offering remedies for imbalances. As for the heart-transmission of Confucian learning, though I have not composed a dedicated work, examining the foundational meaning of my words reveals that all are rooted in illuminating virtue, with self-cultivation as their application, vigilance in solitude as their starting point, and fulfilling nature to reach destiny as their ultimate aim. They embody the investigation of things and the extension of knowledge within the ordinary words and deeds of daily life, thereby attesting to the unchanging principle of non-duality in all things.”

Herein lies the essence: taking "no-thought" as the fundamental principle, and regarding the four characters "emptiness, stillness, constancy, and sincerity" as the vital core from beginning to end. This uniquely elucidates what Confucianism has left unarticulated, revealing the true nature of human nature and destiny. Though the methods and standards may differ, it is indeed the golden needle for saving the world and the distilled marrow of Confucianism and Daoist immortality. In its practice, nothing lies beyond the function of "focusing on the One and eliminating desires," ultimately attaining the state of natural purity and harmony.

Thus, the master’s approach to the Dao never deviated from the宗旨 of the Confucian school; rather, it greatly benefited later generations. The master’s苦心 was profound, and his功 was monumental.

I, Yanggui, am foolish and have never been well-read—how could I fathom the master’s profound奥秘? Yet, by the fortune of standing within his门墙 for nearly thirty years, I have glimpsed faint traces of the至道’s筌蹄 and gleaned fragments of its teachings. Ashamed of my own mediocrity—like a catalpa or a stump unfit for bearing the torch—I have failed to uphold the transmission, deeply betraying my teacher’s恩 and leaving me with no means to repay it.

Now, I have compiled the oral teachings and heart-transmissions I received, distilling their essence into a single work titled *Plum Blossom Dialogues*. Though I fear this may be seen as seeking fame in the world and invite ridicule from the discerning, my aim is self-assurance in learning, not the approval of others; my pursuit is self-knowledge, not recognition from others. Thus, I present this to the enlightened君子 for correction and guidance, hoping it may serve as a key for later scholars who wish to read the master’s works.

Respectfully inscribed on the day before the Winter Solstice in the *jihai* year of the Daoguang reign, by the later disciple of the Dragon Gate lineage, Xue Yanggui of Dongyun.

---

*Plum Blossom Dialogues of the Yanruosi Studio*
Compiled with heartfelt devotion by Xue Yanggui of Wu
Printed by Yu Yangcheng of Cengyun in Guangling
Collated by Lei Tan of Yunchu in Western Shu
Praised by Xie Laiyi of Haiyin in Shanghai

In the autumn of the *xinsi* year, on the fifteenth day of the eighth month, guests Tao Jiruo and Han Dongran, along with the monk Huiche, the Daoist Xu Donglei, five or six young men, and six or seven boys, gathered to admire the osmanthus at the Bamboo Shadow Plum Blossom Pavilion. At that time, paulownia leaves tapped against the window, osmanthus fragrance filled the curtains; some played the qin and roamed freely, others composed poems by the stream. They burned incense, brewed tea, sat in silence, and conversed from the heart—radiant and harmonious, the hall was filled with warmth.

Jiruo sighed and said: “All can become Yao and Shun; with resolve, anything can be accomplished—this saying is true. Yet why are those who cultivate the Dao as numerous as ox hairs, while those who attain it are as rare as qilin horns? Most fail to find the proper gate to enter. Heterodox paths are not worth discussing, but what constitutes the great Dao and the orthodox tradition?”

Dongran replied: “The Dao has never been two, nor have the hearts of sages and ordinary people differed. Though there are three teachings, their practice is one. The Dao is singular—this Dao is the true mechanism of heaven and earth, inherent in all things and manifest in all affairs. People abandon what is near to seek what is distant, either dismissing it as lofty and wondrous or dismissing it as clichéd. Even the few earnest seekers, lacking true transmission, degenerate into eccentricity. Those fortunate enough to meet a renowned teacher remain entangled in desires, procrastinating and neglecting their practice—how can they hope to succeed? Setting others aside for now, let each of us turn inward and examine: can we advance with fierce courage to unite with the Dao? Yanzi said: ‘What sort of man was Shun? What sort of man am I?’ Those who strive should be like this.”

If one can break the cauldrons and sink the boats, devoting three years of bitter effort—what then? As for the lineage’s essence: the elementary may be transmitted through words, but the profound must be realized through the heart’s awakening.

I humbly submit that at the outset of practice, one must first examine principle. The *Great Learning*’s “investigating things to extend knowledge” and the early Confucians’ “exhausting principle and revering seriousness” are indeed the secret keys to the gate.

*In praise:*
Bamboo shadows and plum blossoms,
Lush and radiant in purity.
The arcane essentials of the sages—
Exhausting principle, revering seriousness.
The true lineage of the Great Dao,
This is the correct decree.
Mastering the self, returning to ritual,
Following Confucius and Mencius as teachers.

One asks: “When responding to the arising of all affairs, we discern them by principle. But as for the Way of inner cultivation—how should one proceed? What method serves as the *dhāraṇī*?”

If learning lacks a guiding core, it is like crossing a river without a boat. One must first clarify the guiding core before true learning can begin.”

Dongran replies: “Inner cultivation and external affairs share the same principle. The ancients said: ‘The heart must reside within the breast; thoughts do not stray beyond the gate of *dhāraṇī*.’ The scholar must first awaken to the original heart before possessing a guiding core. Once the guiding core is clear, the *dhāraṇī* is already therein!

Thus, the books of principle all elucidate but two words—*heart* and *nature*—as the gateway to virtue. The *Great Learning* opens by saying, ‘In *illuminating luminous virtue*,’ for once luminous virtue is illuminated, learning has its guiding core.”

*In praise:*
In *illuminating luminous virtue*,
The plumb line of learning.
Virtue is originally ours—
Its illumination demands effort.
Working diligently all day,
One reaches the ultimate.
When illumination can no longer be illuminated,
A single attainment is forever attained.

One asks: “The two words *luminous virtue*—Zhu Xi’s commentary states: ‘Luminous virtue is what humans receive from heaven: empty, numinous, and unfailingly bright, possessing all principles and responding to all affairs.’ Does this refer to the human *heart*? Or to *nature*?”

Dongran replied: “Heart and nature are originally inseparable. Speaking of its governance, we call it *heart*; speaking of its possession of the principle of ceaseless generation, we call it *nature*. Only when the heart is capable of illumination can nature be seen; only through awakening can one speak again of the heart, for nature resides within it. Illuminating the heart allows one to perceive nature; awakening to nature allows one to know the heart. Exhausting the heart allows one to know nature. Yet one must first know how to preserve the heart and nurture nature. Through long preservation and nurturing, one grasps its principle; through careful reflection, one clarifies its essential meaning. Proceeding thus in learning, one may then approximate correctness.”

*In praise:*
Preserve the heart, nurture nature—
The essence of investigating principle.
Reflect and overcome,
Forgetting self and things.
Still and profound,
One awakens to numinous clarity.
When illumination can no longer be attained,
Therein lies utmost sincerity.

One asks: “The Four Masters and Six Classics of the Confucians, along with the recorded sayings of earlier scholars, all concern *nature and principle*. The inner scriptures of Buddhism likewise concern nothing but the *nature school*. Why then does Daoism speak of *dual cultivation of nature and life*? Lü Zu has said: ‘To cultivate life without cultivating nature is the foremost illness in cultivation. If one cultivates nature alone without refining the elixir, the yin spirit of ten thousand kalpas will hardly attain sagehood.’ He also said: ‘Without life, nature cannot stand; without nature, life cannot endure.’ Clearly, nature and life cannot be separated. Why then does Buddhism speak only of the *nature school*, and Confucianism only of *nature and principle*?”

Dongran replied: “Nature and life are originally inseparable. The *nature* of which Buddhism speaks refers to the *original true nature*. This *true* is the root-source of nature and life, the visage before parents were born—what the *Diagram of the Supreme Ultimate* calls the *true of Non-Ultimate*. The *nature* of which people today speak is *qi-quality nature*, the nature formed by the endowment of qi after birth. Thus, wood has the nature of wood, metal the nature of metal, and water, fire, and earth likewise. Humans, as the most numinous of the myriad things, are endowed with nothing beyond the Five Phases. This is what Master Zhu meant by ‘qi forms the shape.’ What Lü Zu called the ‘yin spirit of ten thousand kalpas’ is the *qi-quality nature*, the spirit of discriminating knowledge. When Confucians speak of *nature and principle*, this principle resides within nature, present in all things at all times, as the mechanism of ceaseless generation and transformation, the principle that all things must follow. Principle is nature, and nature is principle. Principle is one, while qi is two; qi has yin and yang, but principle is ever unified. When principle is illuminated, nature is therein!

For heaven bestows a single point ○, descending as the center of harmony, self-possessing the mechanism of ceaseless generation to become the virtues of vigor, compliance, and the Five Constants—this is called *nature*. Each person receives their allotted portion, unified and without duality—this is called *principle*. The *original true nature* originates from the true of Non-Ultimate. Thus, to exhaustively investigate heavenly principle and fulfill one’s nature is to have life within it. To cultivate nature is to cultivate life. As the ancients said: ‘Cultivating one part of nature preserves one part of life.’ The discourse on the workings of life is but the subtle teaching of Daoism.”

*In praise:*
Nature embodies ethical constants,
Life partakes in the transformations of creation.
Cultivating life through nature—
What worry of decline and renewal?
Hold fast with vigilance,
Cease seeking the imperial chariot.
Life cannot be known,
Nature needs no borrowing.

One asks: “All human life is formed by the endowment of qi, what is called ‘qi forms the shape.’ The nature possessed within this form is all *qi-quality nature*. How then can the *original true nature* be clearly discerned? Moreover, the visage before parents were born is but this ○. This is the state before the existence of form. Once born, having received qi and formed shape, how can one recover this ○ nature? Unless this form perishes entirely, returning to utter nothingness, only then can one recover this ○.”

Dongran replied: “All human life is endowed with the nature of the Five Constants, each receiving a portion to become human, hence the differences in strength, weakness, firmness, gentleness, wisdom, foolishness, worthiness, and unworthiness. Yet the five natures of water, fire, wood, metal, and earth all reside within the *true nature*, and the substance of the *original true nature* is pure and refined, empty, luminous, still, and settled. The *qi-quality nature* is merely what is obtained through the formation of shape by qi! After parents give birth, the physical form does not obstruct the empty and luminous—this is what is called ‘empty, numinous, and unfailingly bright.’ Form is form, and the empty and luminous is the empty and luminous.

For the empty and luminous is the numinous awareness within the heart, without visible form or trace, perceived only as luminous clarity within emptiness—what the *Book of Changes* calls ‘still and unmoving, yet responsive and penetrating.’ If one speaks of form, then there is something present. Thus, the substance of the empty and luminous was originally this ○ before parents were born, and remains this ○ after parents give birth. Therefore, form does not obstruct the empty and luminous.

What is called *qi-quality* arises because humans, formed by qi, engage in activity and rest, responding to the myriad changes, none of which is not the work of discriminating knowledge. Once fallen into discriminating knowledge, the luminous substance of nature is obscured, like a mirror covered in dust or a clear spring muddied. Following one mechanism after another, all is but the work of the spirit of knowledge—this is the *true nature* mixed and become *qi-quality*. Hence, it is called *qi-quality nature*.

If one can have nothing in the heart, not a single thought arising, then the substance of nature is profoundly still, silent yet ever luminous, responsive yet ever silent. This substance of nature is called *perfect clarity* in Daoism, *perfect enlightenment* in Buddhism, *luminous virtue* in Confucianism, and also *utmost goodness.*”

When the bodily form perishes after death, the body dies yet the heart does not die; the form perishes yet the spirit does not perish. What is called "returning to utter nothingness" refers only to the physical substance. As for the heart-mind and nature, they are fundamentally without thing. If the heart-mind clings to anything or becomes attached, how can it recover the original substance of emptiness, luminosity, stillness, and quiescence? What is called "cultivation" means that, whether in stillness or activity, one must always maintain awareness of its perfect clarity and steadfast stillness. Only thus can one accord with the Dao at every turn, encounter its source from every side, and thereafter return to life by reverting to the root.

Thus, the original true nature is fundamentally without direction or location, without form or image, without color or appearance, without coming or going, without movement or stillness, without arising or ceasing. Its substance is emptiness and nothingness, and its function is spirit and luminosity. Heaven and earth are but manifestations within this true nature! People, because their hearts are unclear, remain benighted. If one clarifies the heart, one perceives nature; when the heart is clear and nature firm, one then knows that this nature originally has no coming or going—it has always been thus.

This is why a scholar must have a point of awakening, and only thereafter can one personally engage in practice. If one merely seeks words on paper or plucks phrases from speech, I know that in the end, nothing will be attained!

The Eulogy states:
Since there is no coming or going, how can there be birth and death?
Deep as the abyss, clear as still water, ever luminous and bright.
The beginning before all beginnings, the purity of the Great Clarity.
Radiating boundless light—*yuan heng li zhen*.

One asks: "Since nature is said to have *qi*-endowment, the distinction between the original and the acquired is clear! But if the heart does not recognize this, does it too have distinctions? How can one make it luminous?"

Master Dongran replies: "The *Book of Documents* speaks of the *human heart* and the *Dao-heart*. Master Yangming Wang explained them as 'mixed with human effort' and 'unmixed with human effort,' which is most lucid. The heart is not the fleshy organ within the body, but the empty, numinous, and unwavering heart. As the ruler of the entire being, when the Celestial Lord is at peace, the hundred limbs follow its commands!

The human heart is the most numinous and lively thing in a person. Whether one does good or evil, it is this heart; whether one becomes a sage, a worthy, an immortal, or a buddha, it is also this heart. As the ancients said:
*Three dots like stars arrayed,
A slanting hook like the crescent moon.
From this emerge fur and feathers,
And through it, one becomes a buddha.*
This speaks of the heart’s unfathomable constancy and change.

If it suddenly arises, suddenly ceases, suddenly good, suddenly evil—with countless thoughts and deliberations in a single moment, chaotic and scattered—these are the deluded thoughts of the *human heart*. The human heart is human desire, the seed of *samsara*. If, at the moment of arising and ceasing, one can discern good and evil, examine right and wrong, and grasp them amid movement and stillness, distinguishing between righteousness and profit—what pertains to righteousness is *heavenly principle*, and what pertains to profit is *human desire*—then the heavenly principle is the *Dao-heart*. To constantly preserve heavenly principle and eliminate human desire is the work of sages and worthies in restraining the self and returning to propriety.

Furthermore, if the heart becomes empty and vast, unstained by a speck of dust, unattached by a single thread, ever aware and ever luminous—extinguishing only the moving heart while preserving the illuminating heart, maintaining constant vigilance and clarity within—then, with the spirit and *qi* in harmony like a deity, one attains the true reality of cultivating the Dao and may become a sage, a worthy, an immortal, or a buddha.

Yet if one does not examine righteousness and profit, distinguish right and wrong amid affairs, but instead merely empties the heart and stills the nature, one falls into vacuity and quietism, which neither Daoists nor Confucians accept.

There is also what is called the *heavenly heart*, which is the heart of heaven and earth, the root of the human heart and the Dao-heart. The heart is one—how can there be distinctions of heaven, human, and Dao? The thoughts that arise in the minds of common people are nothing but selfish desires for profit, hence called the *human heart*. The thoughts that arise in the minds of worthies and noble persons are entirely upright principles and righteousness, hence called the *Dao-heart*. If one can have no heart of one’s own, no arising of thoughts, but only perceive the flowing of heavenly principle, ever vigilant and ever still, merging into one body with the heart of heaven and earth, taking the heart of heaven, earth, and all things as one’s own heart—this is called the *heavenly heart*.

But the heavenly heart is not visible; it is seen through people. When people are free from the obscuration of selfish desires, their empty and numinous nature remains unwavering. Whatever arises at any time or place is nothing but the heart of heaven and earth. Thus, the *Book of Changes* says: *'Return reveals the heart of heaven and earth.'*

For those who cultivate the Dao, when all obstacles—sounds, colors, wealth, and profit—are swept away and cleared, and this inner state is nurtured to be as empty and vast as a bright mirror, then at the moment when the *yang* *qi* returns and the vital impulse stirs, what moves is the manifestation of the heavenly heart. Only humans, through having a heart, create things and thus experience birth and death; heaven and earth, through having no heart, operate and transform, and thus endure forever. If humans too had no heart, they would likewise know heaven and earth!"

The Eulogy states:
Heaven and humanity unite as one family, boundless as the vast sea.
A lotus in the pond, a rare flower beyond the skies.
Transforming within the formless, wondrously dividing the melon.
Beneath the moon at the third watch, a few plum blossoms.

One asks: "If the learning of nature and principle is thus, what is the purpose of the Buddhists' seated meditation and *huatou* inquiry? In the past, Master Lianchi Yunqi of Cloud Abode widely established the Lotus Society, teaching people solely to recite the Buddha’s name. What is the essential meaning of these two practices?"

Huìchè states: "Chan is concentration. *Huàtóu* inquiry is wisdom. For all people, whether they cultivate or not, wisdom is foremost, knowledge secondary. Knowledge is the function of the discriminating mind; with knowledge but no wisdom, one’s light is like that of a firefly—without the radiance of sun and day, one cannot become a vessel of greatness. Only with wisdom can one engage in Chan inquiry and Dao-learning; all scriptural meanings become instantly clear at a glance. In responding to the myriad affairs and the ten thousand things, one’s true nature flows forth spontaneously, never missing the mark—this is what is meant by possessing a unique eye.

The *huàtóu* is the gateway for beginners entering the Dao. Through a single staff strike, a shout, a word, or a pause, the student is made to awaken instantly in the moment, suddenly enlightened—this is called the Chan mechanism. The *mechanism* is the source from which arising and movement emerge. By using this to inwardly examine oneself, quietly observing the origin of arising and movement, one seals and confirms the source of the mind, making it the stepping stone to entering the Dao. Then the great Dao of majesty is attained without thought, naturally hitting the mark.

This is the sudden method of awakening to one’s nature in the Chan school. For example, when asked, ‘Who is reciting the Buddha’s name?’ or ‘What is your original face?’—such phrases instruct the student to hold fast to this one question and investigate it closely. What is being investigated? Nothing other than breaking through to one’s original face and recognizing one’s true nature.

When the student silently investigates this *huàtóu* and ponders it deeply, thinking to the point where no thoughts remain—where the mind no longer moves, and thought itself ceases—at that moment of not a single thought arising, serene and still, one does not even know it as serenity or stillness. When the true mechanism stirs, there is a sudden awakening. At this moment of awakening, one examines: what is being awakened to? Who is the awakener? Through such examination, one sees the face before one’s birth—originally thus. The ‘who’ is none other than one’s true awareness.

If one penetrates this mechanism, there is immediate awakening—this is called breaking through the root. Only by breaking through the root can one investigate and clarify the nature-body. Once the nature-body is clarified, the path of cultivation begins. As for sitting in meditation to investigate, it is merely a method to settle the mind. In concentration, wisdom naturally arises; in a sudden awakening, one becomes clear. In clarity, one thoroughly illuminates one’s original true nature. This awakening and clarity cannot be attained without wisdom—this is the method of cultivating both concentration and wisdom. Through concentration, wisdom arises; through wisdom, concentration deepens. With long practice, one naturally attains great concentration and great wisdom, suddenly realizing the unborn, never departing from beginning to end—this is the most essential.

As for a single staff strike or shout, though the student may suddenly awaken without thought, one must still sit in meditation and practice over time, gradually attaining mastery before achieving great concentration and great stillness. A single thought lasting ten thousand years—how many in ancient and modern times have truly accomplished this? Today’s practitioners of *zuòxiāng* merely sit rigidly in silence, clinging to Chan concentration as their sole practice, fixating on the word ‘concentration’ to cut off all thoughts—this is worshipping a dead mechanism. As the ancient truth says: ‘Though one passes through countless kalpas, in the end one falls into emptiness and extinction.’ Thus, Nányuè Mǎzǔ mocked such practice with his ‘grinding a brick to make a mirror.’"

The Eulogy states:
Only when one awakens to "who,"
can one truly speak of awakening.

Unattached by a single thread, his dwelling lies in profound obscurity.
Thus it is, thus it is—guard this great simplicity.
Great simplicity is not simplicity: it is the music of the celestial spheres.

One asks: "Then how should the principle of Buddha-recitation be understood? And do the six syllables *Námó Ēmítuó Fó* hold some wondrous meaning?"

Huìchè replies: "The principle of Buddha-recitation is the Buddha’s compassion, a specially opened expedient Dharma-gate to universally gather beings of the three capacities. For those of superior wisdom, one may expound the nature of principle. For those of middling capacity, one imparts the scriptures, enabling them to recite with the mouth and contemplate with the mind, seeking meaning through the text—entering through understanding and awakening, this is called the gradual method. The sudden method can ferry those of superior capacity, but not those below. The gradual method is for those of middling capacity. But what of the utterly dull? How may they be saved? Thus this expedient Dharma-gate was opened. Moreover, those who fear difficulty and seek ease are many, so the teaching is simply to recite the Buddha’s name. As long as one upholds this Buddha-name with single-minded undistraction, at the time of life’s end one will attain rebirth in the Western Land of Ultimate Bliss.

For the most difficult thing to control in a person is the mind. Now, when this single phrase of the Buddha’s name is recited, this thought is held fast—only the thought of Buddha-recitation remains, and all other miscellaneous thoughts find no gap to exploit. Naturally, the spirit-light shines alone, and the true mechanism is revealed. Over time, when not a single thought arises, the numinous clarity shines through alone, and one spontaneously realizes there is no self, no others, no heaven and earth, no myriad things, no sun and moon, no mountains and rivers—only knowing there is awareness, not knowing there is an ‘I.’ Only then may this be called Buddha-recitation. Attaining the samādhi of Buddha-recitation, the Buddha’s light naturally descends and illuminates, making accomplishment easy.

Formerly, Master Lǚ [Dòngbīn] and Shí Tiānjī recited the Buddha, composing a gāthā:
*Reciting the Buddha with sincerity is the elixir,*
*Turning the one hundred and eight beads in a cycle.*
*Recitation opens the wondrous aperture, connecting numinous wisdom;*
*Recitation knots bodhi, transcending sage and mortal.*
*The mind of recitation does not follow flowing waters;*
*The heart of recitation ever abides among white clouds.*
*Recitation’s power transcends life and death—*
*This gāthā I leave for your contemplation.*

Embody this practice, and it is the true essence of Buddha-recitation. If one merely chatters with the mouth while the mind lacks stability, Buddha-thoughts intermingle with deluded thoughts, unable to attain purity and stillness, entangled and confused—ultimately to no avail. Though one may hold the Buddha’s name all day, it is no different from not reciting. To recite yet not recite is worse than not reciting at all.

For this Dharma-gate does not discourse on mind-nature, does not investigate spirit and qi, does not inquire into nature and life—naturally forging them into one piece, congealing the empty and numinous, transforming through passage and preserving the spirit. Swiftly ascending the lotus realm, it is most easy, most simple. Gain an inch, accumulate an inch—there is no fear of not succeeding, only fear of lacking constancy! With constancy and sincerity, with sincerity and single-mindedness, one naturally attains the samādhi of Buddha-recitation.

For ‘Buddha’ means ‘awakening.’ ‘Recitation’ means the act of maintaining thought—it is not merely chanting with the mouth. The Dharma-gate of Buddha-recitation is also called ‘cultivating the Pure Land.’ ‘Pure’ means true purity. ‘Land’ is earth, and earth occupies the center—referring to the central palace of the human body. Generally, all thoughts and considerations arise from this central palace. Once a thought arises, this center is no longer pure! Thus, to recite the Buddha is to purify the mind. The Pure Land is the true purity within. When the mind is without a speck of dust or shadow, the great awakening appears before one, and Buddha and self are of one body.

As for the meaning of the six syllables, it also does not depart from the wondrous metaphor of the original true nature. The term *námó* refers to the south, which in the five phases corresponds to fire and in the human body to the heart. Within the heart there is only spirit-consciousness, so in the south there is no Buddha—this points to the heart’s non-Buddha nature. *Ē* means immeasurable. *Mí* means pervading. *Tuó* means round and radiant—this points to the form and luminosity of the original true nature, the wondrous bright numinous awareness of the self. ‘Recitation’ means to contemplate without forgetfulness—it is to push through and clarify that deluded thoughts are not the Buddha, that one’s numinous awareness is the true nature, immeasurable and boundless, pervading the six directions, its form round and radiant, its light shining brilliantly, vast enough to embrace heaven and earth, its substance entering into emptiness. Buddha is the self, the self is Buddha. In life it is thus ○, in death it is thus ○; in life there is no increase, in death no decrease; in life nothing is brought, in death nothing is taken away—ultimately, there is no birth and death, no coming and going. Thus the *Heart Sutra* says: ‘No birth, no extinction, no defilement, no purity, no increase, no decrease.’ It all hinges on the distinction between awakening and delusion, the two words ‘confusion’ and ‘awakening’! To constantly abide in this great awakening is the Buddha-recitation of those of superior wisdom. If one merely upholds the name without awakening to the great root, it is the practice of the dull—how can they be spoken of in the same breath?

Sitting in meditation and investigating Chan is the sudden teaching, a Dharma-gate of one awakening and a hundred clarities. This was initiated by Bodhidharma because later students in the Middle Land did not understand mind-nature, did not awaken to the Buddha’s intent, clinging to texts and fixating on meanings—ultimately with no hope of thorough awakening. Thus this Dharma-gate was established, not relying on written words, enabling one to see the nature in an instant—an expedient measure of necessity. An ancient worthy said:
*With Chan but no Pure Land, ten out of ten go astray.*
*When karmic visions appear, suddenly one follows them away.*
*With Chan and Pure Land, like a tiger with horns.*
*In this life a teacher of humans, in the future a Buddha and patriarch.*

If practitioners follow this practice, how can they fear the Way will not be accomplished?"

Dòngléi heard this and laughed, saying: "What you have said may be called great thorough awakening! But what is the joy of the Land of Ultimate Bliss?"

"With no need to snap a finger to reach the Western Paradise—where then is the Western Paradise? It is said: *'Born, one is certainly born; going, one truly does not go.'* Can you turn this phrase for me? All that has been spoken belongs to this shore—do you yet know there is that shore? What then is meant by 'the other shore'?

The matters beneath the monastic robe are clear, but what of those beneath the skirt—are they yet resolved? Do you understand *'The crimson sun shines all around, yet beneath the sea no flower blooms'*?"

Huìchè fell silent, staring blankly.

Dòngléi continued: "Long ago, the Venerable Master of Pílíng had awakened to the well-sweep yet still spoke of the discourse of non-birth. Why then did he go forth to seek the Dao, becoming a disciple of the True Man of Apricot Grove, with headscarf and staff of bramble? The Sixth Patriarch Huìnéng, having already declared *'The bodhi is no tree, the bright mirror is no stand,'*—what Dao was transmitted to him at the third watch? Have you not read in the *Platform Sutra*: *'Sentient beings sow the seed, from the ground the fruit arises. The insentient has no seed, no nature and no birth'*?

Your school speaks of non-birth; my school speaks of eternal life. What is that which is neither born nor eternal? The great virtue of Heaven and Earth is called life—yet Heaven and Earth are but one great mass within creation! To stand with Heaven and Earth, to nurture the myriad things—this is the great virtue of the Creator. The great creation, the great transformation, is unceasingly giving birth. It is not that creation gives birth to the myriad things, but that the myriad things give birth to and transform themselves. Within this, there must abide a master of creation!

Your school’s non-birth does not refer solely to the quiescent concentration of stillness. Only through the constant non-being can there be constant life. My school’s eternal life speaks precisely of this constancy. If one can realize the impermanent, then one may ride alongside the master of creation! As you have spoken, this cannot yet be called the ultimate principle.

Though the Śākya school does not speak of *ming* (destiny/lifespan), *ming* is contained within it. Yet even this word *xing* (nature) must not be spoken of, for there is that which transcends both nature and destiny! Birth is no-birth; death is no-death. Upon the lotus throne of Ultimate Bliss—who is it that awakens?"

In praise it is said:
*Born, one is certainly born; going, one truly does not go.*
*Where there is no Buddha, there is birth; who goes where there is nothing above?*
*Since the non-existent is itself non-existent, its wonder is everlasting.*
*Joy without joy—there is the great compassionate vessel.*

"If the teachings of the Nature School have been heard, may I now hear the discourse of the School of Destiny? What then is meant by the 'Golden Elixir'?"

Donglei said: "Tracing back to high antiquity, there were no teachings of dragon and tiger, lead and mercury, or the Golden Elixir. Only after Wei Boyang composed the *Cantong Qi* and Zhang Boduan wrote the *Wuzhen Pian* did the names of dragon and tiger, lead and mercury, and the Golden Elixir begin to flourish in the world. From then on, books on nourishing life through the Golden Elixir multiplied like cattle filling a barn, yet truth and falsehood became indistinguishable, and heterodox doctrines spread.

What is called *ming* (destiny/lifespan) is the root of *qi*. All human life depends on *qi*; with *qi*, one lives; without *qi*, one dies. Thus, death is called 'the severing of *qi*,' for when *qi* is cut off, *ming* is extinguished. Yet the root of human *ming* is the primordial *zuqi* (ancestral *qi*) of the precelestial. After receiving form, one generates the postcelestial breath of exhalation and inhalation. This *zuqi* is the single point bestowed by Heaven at the moment of parents' union—a fusion of the two and five essences, wondrously congealing to form a person. Without this single point, conception cannot occur, for the two and five have not yet united and solidified. This single point is the principle of Heaven bestowed upon life, what Master Zhou called the 'Great Ultimate.' With this point, the embryo establishes its own Great Ultimate, which then divides into yin and yang. Yin and yang generate the Five Phases, self-generating and self-cultivating within the womb, transforming into postcelestial *qi*. At this time, within the mother’s belly, the fetus relies on the mother’s breath for its own, its *qi* entering and exiting through the navel. When the ten months are complete and the child is born, the umbilical cord is cut, and the *qi* can no longer enter and exit there, so it must flow through the mouth and nose—this is the postcelestial *qi*. The precelestial *zuqi* then retreats into the ancestral palace, daily transforming into the postcelestial, hence the distinction between precelestial *qi* and postcelestial *qi*. The precelestial *qi* is hidden in the ancestral palace and invisible, while the postcelestial *qi* is visible as it enters and exits through the mouth and nose. But where is this ancestral palace? It lies below the heart and above the kidneys, before the spine and behind the navel—a suspended cavity in the center. This is the place where all people receive their *ming* from generation to generation, also called the ancestral aperture. This precelestial *qi* is what is meant by *ming*. With this ancestral aperture, there is *ming*; without it, there is no *ming*. Though this ancestral aperture establishes the Great Ultimate within the human body, its *qi* remains connected to Heaven and Earth. If the seven apertures are closed, the connection to Heaven and Earth is severed, and the person dies. Thus, those who cultivate *ming* cultivate this ancestral aperture. Such is the teaching of the School of Destiny.

What is called the Golden Elixir? Gold is gold, cinnabar is cinnabar—their union is what is meant. When the Golden Elixir is accomplished, one returns to the Great Ultimate. For when a person is born, they receive that single point bestowed by Heaven to descend into life, establishing their own Great Ultimate. This is the small Great Ultimate derived from the great Great Ultimate, what is meant by 'each thing possesses a Great Ultimate.' By refining the Golden Elixir, one returns to this great Great Ultimate. Thus, the Great Dao of the Golden Elixir is not something that can be lightly discussed."

In praise it is said:
*One yin, one yang—*
*Matching Heaven, pairing Earth.*
*The Five Phases are not metal;*
*Thus is the returning elixir.*
*Three and two become one;*
*The Great Ultimate has no beginning.*
*If no beginning, then what?*
*Knock and ask Laozi.*

Huiche, hearing this, rose abruptly in astonishment, then fell silent in realization. Bowing twice, he said: "Though this humble monk is dull-witted, may I follow these words?"

Donglei replied: "The Most High saves all beings; the Heavenly Dao cherishes life. This practice is open to all, how much more to you? Even the foolish man or woman who cultivates it may ascend to sagehood in an instant—it depends only on the resolve of their will!"

In praise it is said:
*Village to village, flowers fragrant;*
*Tree to tree, willows weeping.*
*Where is the bright moon?*
*In the green calyx, the Dao’s altar.*
*Unswerving unto death,*
*One roams the imperial realm.*
*The Great One peers down;*
*Nine refinements forge hardness.*

Huiche said: "I wish to hear the details."

Donglei said: "The meaning of the Golden Elixir is also metaphorical. The Perfected One of Purple Yang said: *'The original true nature is the Golden Elixir; the Four Great serve as the furnace, falsely made into a pellet.'* Gold signifies that which is indestructible through ten thousand kalpas. Cinnabar signifies perfection without lack. This gold is not the metal of the fourth earthly phase in the Five Phases, but the water of the first heavenly phase, existing before the Five Phases as the precelestial. The metal of the fourth earthly phase falls within the Five Phases and is postcelestial. This precelestial gold is purely a strand of empty, primordial *qi*, within the Ultimate Nonbeing—it is the circulation of the Great Ultimate. Once the Great Ultimate divides, it generates the water of the first heavenly phase, then the fire of the second earthly phase, next the wood of the third heavenly phase, then the metal of the fourth earthly phase, and finally the earth of the fifth heavenly phase. These 'heaven' and 'earth' are yin and yang. The water of the first heavenly phase resides in the north, its number is one, and in humans it is essence. The fire of the second earthly phase resides in the south, its number is two, and in humans it is spirit. The wood of the third heavenly phase resides in the east, its number is three, and in humans it is the hun-soul. The metal of the fourth earthly phase resides in the west, its number is four, and in humans it is the po-soul. The earth of the fifth heavenly phase resides in the center, its number is five, and in humans it is intent. These are the generating numbers of the *Hetu*. Among the Five Phases, earth is the most noble, which is why in the four seasons—spring, summer, autumn, and winter—earth reigns for eighteen days in each. For water is restrained by earth, fire is quelled by earth, metal is generated by earth, wood is planted by earth, and within water, fire, metal, and wood, earth is present."

Thus, Heaven’s one generates water, and when it attains five, Earth’s six completes it; Earth’s two generates fire, and when it attains five, Heaven’s seven completes it; Heaven’s three generates wood, and when it attains five, Earth’s eight completes it; Earth’s four generates metal, and when it attains five, Heaven’s nine completes it; Heaven’s five generates earth, and when it attains five, Earth’s ten completes it—these are the *Hetu*’s completion numbers. Therefore, one, two, three, four, and five are the generating numbers, while six, seven, eight, nine, and ten are the completion numbers. Heaven’s numbers are five, Earth’s numbers are five, and the five positions interact to form their respective unions. Heaven’s numbers total twenty-five, Earth’s numbers total thirty, and the sum of Heaven and Earth’s numbers is fifty-five. Thus, one and six reside in the north, two and seven in the south, three and eight in the east, four and nine in the west, and five and ten in the center—this is how the *Hetu* constitutes the generating and completion numbers of the Five Phases. Its image is round, its form empty and without substance, and it is of the primordial Heaven. After the Supreme Ultimate divides, it separates into yin and yang, and yin and yang transform to generate the Five Phases. Yin and yang are Heaven and Earth. Heaven generates and Earth completes, each serving as the root of the other, thereby embodying the image of the *Hetu*.

To refine the Golden Elixir, one must gather the primordial *qi* of the One, which serves as the mother of the Golden Elixir. This primordial *qi* of the One is called "metal." Yet the Non-Ultimate and the Supreme Ultimate—every thing contains a Supreme Ultimate—though they bear many names, are in truth one ultimate. For from one root arise the ten thousand differences, and within the ten thousand differences, the one root is contained. The human body is a Heaven and Earth; as Heaven and Earth are, so too is the human body. Human life is received from a single point within the Supreme Ultimate, and now it departs from that same point within the Supreme Ultimate. To cultivate it in reverse is what is called the Way of Return, also known as the Great Golden Elixir of Nine Returns and Seven Reversions. This is the mind-to-mind transmission of the Supreme, the secret essence of the highest vehicle. Here, nature and life are not divided but cultivated as one. For that single point bestowed by Heaven—nature resides in it, and life also resides in it—thus to cultivate nature is to cultivate life, and this is the true learning of fully realizing nature and fulfilling life.

The other three vehicles—upper, middle, and lower—each have their own methods, but they divide nature and life into two, and these are but side paths and winding trails.

In praise it is said: To fully realize nature and fulfill life is the宗 of learning.

Only our Master from Mount Ni, likened to a dragon in his wisdom,
Sleeps alone in a paper tent—yet at night, the Yellow Bell roars.
Clad in rosy silk, he plucks the radiant lotus,
And asks: “The alchemical texts say, ‘In cultivating the Dao, nothing is more precious than essence, qi, and spirit.’
The *Heart Seal Scripture* states, ‘The three supreme medicines are spirit, qi, and essence.’
Now, hearing such teachings, are essence, qi, and spirit to be deemed useless?
Moreover, the original true nature—can even superior scholars fully awaken to it, while those of middling and lesser capacity find it easily comprehensible?
Heaven-bestowed life, once born, retreats into the ancestral palace, daily transforming into the postnatal to sustain human use. If one seeks it now, how can it be attained?”

Donglei replies: “Nature and life are the root of humanity.
Essence, qi, and spirit are humanity’s great functions.
The three treasures of the body—only these are precious, yet they follow an order of priority.
Prenatal essence is the Water born of Heaven’s One, existing in principle but without form, inherent within qi, pervading the entire body. At the cusp of midnight, when the first yang revives, it is called *original essence*. If a single thought stirs, it instantly transforms into postnatal, tangible substance.
Prenatal qi is the ancestral qi of the central palace, called *original qi*. Daily, it transforms into the postnatal, circulating through the meridians—not merely the breath of respiration.
Prenatal spirit is the luminous clarity within the heart, called *original spirit*. Once engaged in discriminating knowledge, it shifts into the postnatal *conscious spirit* of thought and deliberation.
