Thus, in cultivating the Dao, one relies on the postnatal to return to the prenatal, valuing the prenatal and not the postnatal.
The world, unaware of this principle, mistakenly regards postnatal essence and qi as supreme treasures. Day after day, they toil in the arena of fame and profit, with the seven emotions and six desires raging within, and the allure of sounds, colors, wealth, and gain assailing them from without. Their hearts know not a moment’s tranquility.
If the postnatal is scarcely preserved, how can one speak of the prenatal?
As the Perfected One of Purple Yang once said: ‘Though your wisdom surpasses Yan and Min, without a true teacher, do not presume to guess.’
Therefore, scholars must seek the oral instructions of a true teacher before proceeding.
Yet one fears that heterodox teachings will bewilder the world, and scholars, lacking the single eye of discernment, how will they distinguish the true from the false in a teacher?”

In praise it is said:
No thought, no deliberation—
Follow the natural course.

Without reliance on form or appearance,
One discerns the prenatal.
In the quiet of night, the heart is empty,
At such times, the five strings are absent.
Cool as a jade flask,
Upheld by iron shoulders.

One may ask: “Then how must one proceed to find a teacher?
By what means can true and false be distinguished?”

Donglei replied: “To discern a teacher, first observe their conduct—conduct is the substance of affairs. Next, listen to their words—words are the traces of the heart. Often, words exceed conduct, and conduct disregards words. One must carefully examine those whose words and deeds align with sincerity; only then may they be taken as a teacher.

The Master said: ‘Hear their words and observe their conduct.’
He also said: ‘One who tempers the old to know the new may be a teacher!’

Formerly, Master Wang Kunyang said: ‘If a disciple lacks the true mind of transcending the world, their wisdom-nature is obscured. Even if they encounter a true teacher, spirits and gods will prevent them from seeing, veiling their wisdom-nature. Even if they see, they cannot recognize the teacher as true. But if one’s heart is truly earnest and painstaking in seeking a teacher, then Heaven will not fail them—the true teacher will come of their own accord.’”

In praise it is said:
With a true heart, one sees the true;
With a dust-laden heart, one sees only dust.

As one draws a bow, green as spring’s renewal,
Once were reed slips used—Creation’s kin.
Not-seeking in seeking, the seeking becomes numinous.

One asked: “I have heard that in the refinement of the elixir there are three essentials. May I ask what these three are?”
Donglei replied: “The three essentials are the furnace and tripod, the medicinal ingredients, and the firing times.
The *furnace* is the vessel for applying fire.
The *tripod* is the container for holding the medicine.
The *medicinal ingredients* are one’s primordial, true, unified *qi*, augmented by essence, spirit, ethereal soul, corporeal soul, and intent.
The primordial unified *qi* serves as the mother of the golden elixir, enabling it to surge through the Three Passes and circulate throughout the body’s blood vessels.
Daily, one gathers this *qi* as the medicinal ingredient, converging essence, spirit, ethereal soul, corporeal soul, and intent within the Central Palace, returning them to the furnace and tripod to be sealed and secured.
Daily gathering and daily refinement prevent the primordial essence from transforming into postnatal, tangible essence, instead transmuting it into *qi*;
the *qi* within spirit is transmuted into spirit;
the spirit within the heart is transmuted into emptiness—
this is called *steaming and refinement*.
Within this process, the firing times reside!
*Fire* refers to the application of fire.
*Times* refers to the moments.
Consider the cooking of rice: applying fire without regard to timing either leaves it undercooked or burns it to charcoal. Thus, timing is essential—waiting for the precise moment.
These three are the utmost essentials in elixir refinement, hence they are called the Three Essentials.”

In praise it is said:
Postnatal and primordial,
gathering in leftward rotation.

The marvelous cannot be sought—all day one must act with diligence.
Neither exceed nor fall short, thus securing and concentrating.
Like the sun’s ascent, like the moon’s waxing full.

One asks: “What is meant by the so-called Three Treasures?”
Donglei replies: “The Three Treasures have two names, inner and outer.
The inner Three Treasures are essence, *qi*, and spirit.
The outer Three Treasures are the ears, eyes, and mouth.
All who are born rely upon this essence, *qi*, and spirit.
With essence, one can transform *qi*; with *qi*, one can transform spirit.
When spirit flourishes, *qi* flourishes; when *qi* flourishes, essence is full; when essence is full, spirit is even more abundant.
With vitality and spirit, one enjoys health and longevity, and illness finds no entry.
When vitality and spirit wane, one readily succumbs to wind and cold.
If one fails to guard and nurture them, illness soon arrives—hence they are called the inner Three Treasures.
As Ancestor Lü said:
*‘When the cinnabar field holds treasure, cease seeking the Dao;
Before phenomena, with no mind, ask not of Chan.’*
Among these three, preserving essence is foremost.
The *Huangting Jing* states:
*‘Immortals and Daoists possess no divine power—
They accumulate essence and amass qi to attain the real.’*
Thus, when essence is depleted, spirit and *qi* are also depleted.
In youth, though essence may leak, spirit and *qi* remain vigorous, and one does not feel weakness.
But in old age or those with depleted original endowment, after forty or fifty, even slight leakage leaves one feeling spirit-fatigued and *qi*-faint the very next day—this is the proof.
Yet the Three Treasures employed in the mysterious practice are the Three Origins, not the postnatal essence, *qi*, and spirit.
Nevertheless, to seek the primordial, one must search within the postnatal.
If one abandons the postnatal to seek the primordial, where can it be found?

The outer Three Treasures—ears, eyes, and mouth—are where spirit leaks through the eyes, essence through the ears, and *qi* through the mouth.
When the eyes do not see, the *hun*-soul resides in the lungs;
when the nose does not smell, the *po*-soul resides in the liver;
when the ears do not hear, essence resides in the kidneys;
when the four great are unmoved, intent resides in the spleen—
this is called harmonizing the four images.
Long ago, the Jade Maiden of the Nine Heavens appeared in a dream to my friend, saying:
*‘The outer Three Treasures should be inwardly concealed;
the inner Three Treasures should be sparingly guarded—
this is the utmost essential for entering the gate.’*
The *Cantong Qi* states:
*‘The ears, eyes, and mouth—Three Treasures—
close and seal them, let nothing pass.
The true person lurks in the deep abyss,
floating and roaming, abiding within the compass.’*
Thus, these Three Treasures are the utmost essentials in cultivating the Dao.”

In praise it is said:
Inner and outer Three Treasures—
subtly they await exploration.
Guard them within the compass,
harmonize them to nurture the vast.
From the later return to the earlier—
this is the supreme Dao.
A bowl of nectar,
pounded by the frostless hare.

One asks: “The meaning of the furnace and cauldron has already been explained in detail, yet I pray for further clarification of its subtleties.”
Donglei replies: “The furnace and cauldron are none other than the *qi*-cavity of the Yellow Court in the central palace.
Yellow is the true color of the center.
Court refers to the central courtyard of a chamber—within the human body, it is located between the heart below and the kidneys above.
The *qi*-cavity lies within the navel wheel, thus the Yellow Court is the cauldron, and the *qi*-cavity is the furnace.
As Shi Jianwu said:
*‘Before it faces the navel gate, behind it faces the kidneys—
between them lies a true golden cauldron.’*
Probing its subtle meaning, the Yellow Court resides within the *qi*-cavity, not the Yellow Court point below the heart.
For the human body’s mud-pill palace connects directly to the bubbling spring, a hollow passage called the Yellow Path.
Taking above and below as furnace and cauldron is also permissible.
Yet all these are names without substance, not actual locations—merely borrowed imagery to establish discourse.
The furnace is the cauldron, the cauldron is the furnace; the Yellow Court is the *qi*-cavity, the *qi*-cavity is the Yellow Court.
All converge in one place, nothing more than this.
Here one can receive the primordial *qi*, apply the firing times, and transmute the postnatal into the primordial, returning to the root and restoring the source.
The *Zhonghe Ji* takes body and mind as furnace and cauldron; the *Wuzhen Pian* of Master Ziyang takes Qian and Kun as furnace and cauldron—all are boundless, wondrous metaphors.
One must deeply embody them to realize the ancients’ words were not in error.”

In praise it is said:
The place where life gathers—
firmly it holds its direction.

Within and without, the Yellow Court unfolds as a single scroll to ascend the hall.
Yet it has no form, its name but a forced designation.
Once its mystery is grasped, never forget it.

One may ask, “Then what of the principles of medicinal substances and the methods of their gathering?”
Master Donglei replies:
“The medicinal substances are the primordial True Unity *qi* along with essence, spirit, ethereal soul, corporeal soul, and intent.
This primordial True Unity *qi* is received at the moment of one’s birth, bestowed by the Ultimate Non-Being’s utmost truth, arising from the division of the Great Ultimate.
The Heaven-endowed spark descends into the mother’s womb, congealing with the father’s and mother’s yin and yang to form a person.
This Heaven-endowed spark of the life-root is the primordial True Unity *qi*, also called the *qi* of Great Oneness containing truth.
After the embryo coalesces, this spark establishes the Great Ultimate within the womb, and the Great Ultimate transforms into yin and yang, which then generate the Five Phases.
The essence of yin-yang and the Five Phases condenses into essence, *qi*, and spirit—thus the primordial is concealed within the postnatal.
Yet its rooting place lies within the *qi*-cavity of the navel, so the navel’s life-stem is called the ancestral aperture, like the root of a flower or the stem of a fruit.

By fifteen or sixteen, postnatal *qi* is full, passions awaken, and upon seeing beauty, the heart stirs, the root is touched, the spirit sways—and the true origin is broken.
From then on, the primordial *qi* gradually depletes.
Yet each day at the cusp of midnight, the body’s yin and yang *qi* must conjoin; at their union, the True Unity *qi* naturally arises, transforming into postnatal essence, *qi*, and spirit to sustain the person.
Thus the moment of yin-yang union, when true yang spontaneously arises, is called the living midnight hour, and the true yang born then is the primordial Unity *qi*.
Gathering this *qi* at that time, applying the firing times, refining and tempering it—preventing its transformation into the postnatal—one may also merge the body’s *qi*, essence, spirit, ethereal soul, corporeal soul, and intent into one, all transmuted into the primordial, thereby replenishing prior depletion.
Daily gathering and daily replenishing, until fullness is restored, no different from the state before the body was broken—this is called the Returned Elixir, the restoration of one’s original true origin.

When true yang arises at midnight, in Heaven and Earth it is the proper midnight hour; in the person, it is the living midnight hour.
At that time, the external kidneys must stir—this is the arrival of the proper midnight hour.
Yet if human desire stirs, yang must arise; once arisen, it is difficult to restrain and will inevitably dissipate before ceasing.
Even if it does not exit the external aperture, the three fires of sovereign, minister, and people within the body will flare up, instantly transmuting the primordial into the postnatal, rendering it useless.
Thus the Perfected One Ziyang said: ‘When seen, it cannot be used; when used, it cannot be seen.’
Wu Chongxu said: ‘One must discern the clarity or turbidity of the water’s source. The clear may be used; the turbid may not.’
What is clarity? It is when true yang arises without the stirring of thought.
If yang arises after a thought moves, it is called turbid.
Thus clarity and turbidity depend on whether thought moves or not.

For beginners, when first practicing, thought does not move.
Suddenly, true yang arises spontaneously, and the external kidneys must stir.
Yet upon stirring, thought also surges forth, and the true yang just born instantly transforms into the postnatal.
Thus for cultivators, gathering thought is the foremost task.
Therefore, ‘curbing anger and restraining desire’ are the great keys to nature and life.
For those in youth or prime, repair and replenishment are easier; by fifty, it already feels arduous, and for the elderly, more laborious still.
Ancestor Master Zhongli said: ‘Do not wait until old age when lead and mercury are scarce.’ A most profound admonition!

Yet the young have their ease and difficulty in youth, just as the old have their ease and difficulty in old age.
The young find ease in their vigorous spirit, making progress in practice swift; their difficulty lies in the blazing fire of desire, making essence hard to preserve.
The old find ease in their diminished desires, the fire of lust already extinguished; their difficulty lies in their waning vitality, making progress in practice hard.
Those with aspiration for this path should ponder deeply.

As for the so-called gathering, it is gathering without gathering, taking without taking.
The ancient Perfected said: ‘Gather the medicinal substances in the midst of non-movement; apply the firing times within non-doing.’
One need only maintain a single-minded clarity and stillness, abiding in tranquil stability.
In the principle of yin and yang, extreme stillness gives rise to movement, and extreme movement returns to stillness.
Sitting to the point of extreme stillness, true yang will surely arise spontaneously; I stabilize it with stillness.
Once arisen, I continue to abide in concentration, the heart not attaching to any place, reaching emptiness and quiescence.
Day by day thus, it naturally accumulates daily, growing ever fuller.
When *qi* fills the Cinnabar Field, fire blazes at the lower extremity; then, with a subtle intent, push backward to gather it at the coccyx.
If true *qi* is sufficient, it will naturally penetrate the Three Passes, though some may open them gradually.
Only after the Three Passes are open may the firing times be applied.”

In praise it is said:
From non-being, being arises;
extreme stillness gives birth to movement.

At the very inception of life, it congeals of itself, profoundly tranquil.
Pushing past the Three Carts, the primordial *qi* then pervades all.
Only then may the firing times be practiced, with non-doing as their essence.

One asks: “In the alchemical texts, there is mention of ‘gold within water,’ and also of ‘lead from the watery realm.’ What do these mean?”

Master Donglei replies: “‘Gold within water’ is precisely ‘lead from the watery realm,’ for lead is also a metal. Now, the human heart pertains to fire, the kidneys to water. Within the heart dwells spirit, which pertains to fire; within the kidneys dwells essence, which pertains to water. Though the kidneys are the storehouse of essence, they do not originally possess essence. Rather, when a single thought stirs, desire-fire arises, and the sovereign and ministerial fires together blaze, setting the entire body aflame. The steam thus produced condenses into water, gathering in the kidney palace, seizing the Gate of Yang to exit through the lower orifice, transforming into the essence of lustful fluids. If one can keep the thought unmoving and desire-fire unarisen, then when the time comes, the true *qi* that is generated is none other than the primordial, true, unified *qi*—this is what is called ‘gold within water.’ At that moment, it is called the celestial mechanism. It does not arise from the kidneys but comes from the midst of emptiness, emerging through the kidneys. Because it issues from the kidneys, it is called ‘gold within water,’ also named ‘lead from the watery realm.’

Generally, the human heart is outwardly solid yet inwardly hollow, pertaining to fire, and is likened to *li*. *Li* is yang without and yin within. The kidneys are outwardly hollow yet inwardly solid, pertaining to water, and are likened to *kan*. *Kan* is yin without and yang within. Now, *kan* and *li* are the broken forms of *qian* and *kun*. *Qian* consists of three yang lines, *kun* of three yin lines. When the middle line of *qian* moves, it enters *kun*; the central earth line of *kun* enters *qian*. *Qian* thus becomes *li*, and *kun* becomes *kan*!

Therefore, when the alchemist gathers the one *qi* from the kidneys and raises it into the heart, it is like extracting the one yang line from *kan* to fill the *li* palace—this is called ‘taking from *kan* to fill *li*.’ The *qian* trigram pertains to metal, the *kan* trigram to water; the middle line of *kan* is the middle line of *qian*—this is called ‘gold within water.’”

In praise it is said:
Thought is originally no-thought;
only where it arises does arising occur.

Vast and inexhaustible, the essence of Heaven’s Oneness. *Kan* and *li* exchange positions—no scent, no sound. Serene and still, it ascends to the Jade Capital.

One asks: “Having gathered this primordial One *qi* as the elixir, how then is the ‘fire and timing’ to be practiced?”

Master Donglei replies: “The ‘fire and timing’ is also the fire and timing of nature—only slightly adjusted in application. The ancients said: ‘True fire has no fixed timing; the great elixir is not measured in ounces.’ Yet in ancient methods, the *qian* trigram’s tally was thirty-six, and the *kun* trigram’s tally twenty-four. Borrowing breath to count them, this was called ‘refining and smelting.’”

In praise it is said:
What is fire and timing? It passes naturally.
No timing to time, no measure for the elixir.
*Qian* and *kun* have their tallies,
or the steps to practice.
Yet though ancient, this method falls short of perfect harmony.

One asks: “What is the use of tallies? How is breath to be employed?”

Master Donglei replies: “The method of refining and smelting is called ‘fire and timing.’ The ancients treated it with utmost gravity, for it is the most secret of celestial mechanisms. The alchemical classics say: ‘The sage transmits the elixir but not the fire; since ancient times, few have known the timing of fire.’ For when the elixir arises, fire arises; only when the elixir arises may fire be applied. To practice fire and timing without the elixir is like boiling an empty cauldron with water and fire. Fire is the elixir, and the elixir is fire—when fire arises, the elixir arises. The White Patriarch said: ‘Refining the elixir with fire to form the cinnabar is the same as guiding *qi* with spirit to realize the Dao.’

If one applies fire and timing without the elixir having arisen, the fire is not true fire—it is merely laboring the mouth and nose in vain! Now, one exhalation and one inhalation make a single breath. The true *qi* within the body, ascending and descending, is also called a single breath. ‘Breath’ means rest and cessation. In rest there is stillness; in stillness there is nothingness; in nothingness, one returns to the root of ceaseless generation.

The ancients retired at dusk to rest and nurture their vital mechanism. Master Shao said: ‘After the winter solstice comes exhalation; after the summer solstice comes inhalation—this is the breath of a year. The breath of a day is such that after midnight comes exhalation, and after noon comes inhalation. One exhalation and one inhalation make a single breath. Breath means nurturing. As long as breath continues without cease, so too does generation, and transformation is inexhaustible.’

Thus, a person’s every exhalation and inhalation is of no small consequence. With each inhalation, the *qi* of Heaven and Earth returns to me; with each exhalation, my *qi* returns to Heaven and Earth. The *Yinfu Jing* says: ‘Heaven and Earth steal from the myriad things; the myriad things steal from humanity; humanity steals from the myriad things. When these three acts of stealing are in harmony, the Three Powers are at peace.’ These three instances of ‘stealing’ interpenetrate, and their mechanism lies in the mouth and nose. If one grasps this principle, then Heaven, Earth, and the myriad things all become one’s own thieves. If one fails to obtain the secret, then one is stolen away by Heaven, Earth, and the myriad things!

However, practicing fire and timing means following the natural ascent and descent of the true *qi* within the body—it is not the breath of the mouth and nose. One merely borrows this as a trigger. For beginners whose Three Passes are not yet open, there is no choice but to use this as an entry point, and thus one must first regulate the breath. Once the Three Passes are open, there is the natural ascent and descent of celestial mechanism—only then does it truly become ‘fire and timing.’

What is called ‘breath’? With each exhalation, the *qi* of the mouth and nose issues outward, while the true *qi* within the body descends from the chest to the navel. With each inhalation, the *qi* of the mouth and nose enters from without, while the true *qi* within the body ascends from the coccyx along the spine to the crown. One must focus on the body’s interior, not fixate on the mouth and nose. The mind is entrusted to the breath, and the ears listen to its sound.

Master Sima the Perfected said: ‘Exhale only gently, inhale only softly.’ In all cases, regulate the *qi* so that it is neither coarse nor hurried, neither too swift nor too slow, making the breath harmonious and inaudible to the ear. When the mind is still, the breath naturally becomes regulated; when the breath is regulated, the spirit naturally congeals—this is what is meant by ‘mind and breath depending on each other, breath regulated and mind settled.’

When the breath is so regulated that it seems to exist and yet not exist, one subtly directs awareness to the lower *dantian*. Naturally, the spirit congeals and *qi* gathers, suffusing the body with warmth. The White Patriarch said: ‘Once I received the true oral instructions of a sagely teacher—only concentrate the spirit into the *qi*-cavern.’ The alchemical classics also say: ‘To regulate the breath, regulate the true breath; to refine the spirit, refine the spiritless spirit.’ This is what they mean.

Through sincere and prolonged practice, the true *qi* increases daily. When it becomes abundant, it naturally pierces the Three Passes. Once the Three Passes are open, the true *qi* ascends and descends naturally. It is within this ascent and descent that one applies the *qian* trigram’s tally of thirty-six and the *kun* trigram’s tally of twenty-four.

The method of using the tallies involves circling the hand to count the twelve hours. When the time of the first yang’s arising arrives, one presses the hand to the *zi* position and counts the natural breaths of ascent and descent—one ascent and one descent make a single breath. Count thirty-six breaths and stop. Then move to press the *chou* position and again count thirty-six breaths. Move to the *yin* position and count thirty-six breaths. When moving to the *mao* position, do not count the breaths; instead, place the mind in emptiness and stillness, and the mechanism will naturally pause—this is called ‘bathing.’

After a brief pause, the mechanism stirs again. Press the finger to the *chen* position and count thirty-six breaths. Move to the *si* position and count thirty-six breaths—this is called ‘advancing the yang fire.’ What is meant by ‘advancing’? The spirit is stored in the *kun*-abdomen, while awareness is directed to the crown. When reaching the *wu* position, count twenty-four breaths. Move to the *wei* position and count twenty-four breaths. Move to the *shen* position and count twenty-four breaths. When reaching the *you* position, do not count the breaths; again place the mind in emptiness and stillness, and the mechanism will naturally pause—this is called ‘bathing.’”

After a brief pause, the mechanism stirs again. Press the finger to the *xu* position and count twenty-four breaths. Move to the *hai* position and count twenty-four breaths, then proceed with five additional breaths, completing the three hundred sixty-five degrees of the celestial cycle. Counting twenty-four breaths is called ‘retreating the yin tally.’ What is meant by ‘retreating’? Awareness is directed to the *kun*-abdomen, while the spirit is gathered and guarded—this is called the ‘lesser celestial cycle of fire and timing.’

When the celestial cycle’s count is complete, the spirit converges within the qi cavity. Abide in stillness and guard it, attaining emptiness and quiescence. Gradually release the mind into the realm of nothing-whatsoever, naturally ascending to the state of primordial chaos. Then qi transforms into spirit, and spirit transforms into emptiness.

In truth, this is nothing other than condensing one’s original spirit into a unified whole, forging it into an indestructible body, and thereby attaining the dharmakāya. Yet these are the established words of the ancients and should not be taken as an inflexible method. For if the mind clings to numbers, it inevitably involves deliberate effort.

Deliberate effort stokes the fire, disturbing the heart with vexation. Pursuing this path risks the flaw of scorching essence through excessive fire. Far better to rely on the eight characters: *"mind and breath interdependent, quiescent emptiness with concentrated illumination."* This naturally yields spirit-convergence and qi-gathering, suffusing the body with harmonious equilibrium—truly the most secure way.

**In praise:**
Heaven and earth open and close,
their breath thus aligned.
Yet these methods are too cumbersome—
stillness of self is superior.
Mind and breath interdependent,
the wondrous principle of quiescent emptiness.
With unceasing concentrated illumination,
harmonious equilibrium arises of itself.

One asks: *"The alchemical texts say: ‘The moon’s fullness lies in oral transmission; the hour of midnight, in heart-to-heart transmission.’ What does this mean?"*

Donglei replies: *"The moon’s fullness speaks of the fullness of yang qi and the sufficiency of yang radiance. Consider the celestial moon: on the third day, a faint yang emerges from the *geng* direction—this is the birth of the first yang. By the eighth day, yang fills the eastern half, with the *hun* (yang spirit) dominating half the *po* (yin soul)—this is the second yang’s birth, called the ‘upper quarter.’ On the fifteenth day, the third yang is born, yang radiance is complete, and the moon is full. On the sixteenth day, the first yin is born, and the moon gradually wanes. By the twenty-third day, only the western half’s yang radiance remains, with the *po* dominating half the *hun*—this is the second yin’s birth, called the ‘lower quarter.’ By the thirtieth day, the third yin is born, the *hun* is wholly concealed, and the moon is entirely dark.

The moon’s body is inherently yin and lightless; it borrows the sun’s *hun* to generate brightness. The sun is yang spirit; the moon, yin essence. Yang generates brightness, while yin is inherently lightless. Thus, the moon must rely on the sun’s illumination to gain light—this is called ‘the upper quarter’s gold weighing half a catty, the lower quarter’s water weighing eight ounces.’ Within these two quarters’ gold and water lie the medicinal substances and the firing times.

The true essence of the human body pertains to yin, likened to the moon; true spirit pertains to yang, likened to the sun. The term *spirit-essence* is threaded by qi. Thus, refining essence into qi means refining away yin essence to form pure yang qi; refining qi into spirit means transforming qi entirely into spirit; refining spirit to return to emptiness means dissolving even this spirit, merging with the vast emptiness of the Great Void.

Therefore, the initial birth of true yang is likened to the moon emerging from the *geng* direction; qi penetrating the *jiājí* (spine’s midpoint) is likened to the upper quarter; qi reaching the crown of the head is likened to the full moon. When qi arrives at the *níwán* (mud-pill palace), it must descend—comparable to the sixteenth day’s birth of the first yin. Qi descending to the *jiàngōng* (crimson palace) is likened to the lower quarter; descending into the qi cavity is likened to the thirtieth day’s dark moon. At the dark moon, sun and moon conjoin, *hun* and *po* merge.

Thus, the full moon signifies the sufficiency of yang radiance. The moon requires fifteen days to become full, hence the numbers of the *Luoshu*: nine atop, one beneath, three on the left, seven on the right; two and four as shoulders, six and eight as feet. One resides in the north, nine in the south—adding the central five, from due north to due south totals fifteen. Three resides in the east, seven in the west—adding the central five, from due east to due west totals fifteen. Two resides in the southwest, eight in the northeast—adding the central five, from northeast to southwest totals fifteen. Six resides in the northwest, four in the southeast—adding the central five, from northwest to southeast totals fifteen. Excluding the central five, the north’s one, northeast’s eight, and northwest’s six together total fifteen. The south’s nine, southeast’s four, and southwest’s two together total fifteen. The east’s three, combined with the southeast’s four and northeast’s eight, total fifteen. The west’s seven, combined with the southwest’s two and northwest’s six, total fifteen. Interwoven thus, all paths sum to fifteen.

For three is the beginning of generation, five its culmination, and ten the end of completion. The principle of generation and completion arises from three and five yielding fifteen. Ten, a hundred, a thousand, ten thousand—all are but one. The circulation of the single qi inherently contains the numbers of generation and completion. The *Hetu* and *Luoshu* are mutually exterior and interior.

In the *Hetu*, heaven’s one-water combines with heaven’s nine-metal to form ten; heaven’s three-wood combines with heaven’s seven-fire to form ten; earth’s two-fire combines with earth’s eight-wood to form ten; earth’s four-metal combines with earth’s six-water to form ten. The center conceals fifty, with one, three, five, seven, nine as heaven’s numbers, and two, four, six, eight, ten as earth’s numbers. Heaven’s numbers total twenty-five, earth’s thirty—thus, heaven and earth’s numbers total fifty-five, and the *Hetu* already contains the complete numbers of heaven and earth.

The *Hetu*’s sequence—one, six, two, seven, three, eight, four, nine, five, ten—corresponds to the *Luoshu*’s one, nine, two, eight, three, seven, four, six, forming mutual exterior-interior pairs. Thus, within the *Hetu*’s generation and completion lies the *Luoshu*’s correspondence.

The *Qingnang Jing Zhuan* states: *"The *Hetu* and *Luoshu* both establish the pole through this fifteen."* Though the *Hetu* contains the Four Images, in the primordial state yang ascends and yin descends, the upper and lower are only just divided—it cannot yet be called the four directions. Only when the central five establishes the pole do the four poles distinctly assume their positions. With the four directions’ proper positions, the four corners interpose between them, and thus the eight directions are established. This is the natural revelation of heaven and earth’s principle. Therefore, the *Hetu* and *Luoshu* are the origin of principle, qi, image, and number.

One, two, three, four, five form heaven; six, seven, eight, nine, ten form earth. Heaven and earth’s numbers each attain their five, and combining the two fives yields ten—this is the Dao of fifteen."

Should scholars not clearly comprehend the establishment of the central five as the pole? What is called the "Child of the Hour" refers to the living *zi*-hour within the body. The *zi*-hour at midnight is the proper *zi*-hour, while the *zi*-hour unbound by time is called the living *zi*-hour. This living *zi*-hour is known only to oneself and not to others—hence it is said, "The wonder lies in heart-transmission," for the celestial heart is awakened and transmitted through the heart.

*Eulogy:*
Yin and yang ascend and descend, wondrously forming the elixir.
New moon and full moon give rise to one another, with fifteen as the beginning.
Vivid and free, observed solely within the heart.
Heaven and human unite, enduringly coalescing into oneness.

Huìchè said: "Are the Master’s words concerning this-side matters? That-side matters? Or is there yet another profound mystery to that-side matters?"

Dòngléi replied: "What has been spoken pertains to the affairs of returning the elixir, still belonging to this-side matters. Yet if discussed in terms of the Three Vehicles’ teachings, it already pertains to that side. However, our school of Celestial Immortals belongs to the Supreme Vehicle, possessing its own primordial and wondrous celestial mechanism on that side. Unless one is a person of luminous virtue, who has accumulated true effort over time, it cannot be spoken of. To speak lightly and leak such secrets would instead breed doubts. For the heart cannot be lightly emptied, and principle and desire will inevitably contend. Should principle be obscured and desire prevail, one will invariably drift into heterodox teachings. Leading the blind with blindness, thus misleading later generations—how could this be a trivial matter?"

*Eulogy:*
Cultivate nature and preserve life, so principle and desire do not contend.
The essence of Celestial Immortals lies in luminous clarity.
The Dao’s profundity and primordial subtlety naturally attain tranquility.
This side and that side wondrously merge and congeal.

Thereupon, Huìchè bowed in reverence and withdrew, observing the Six Fasts and the Five Precepts. After seventy-five days, on the auspicious dawn of the winter solstice, he swept the courtyard, purified himself, and burned incense. He invited Master Léi to ascend once more to the Hall of *Yi*-Study, conducting the rites with solemnity and cutting his arm to swear an oath to heaven. On that day, auspicious winds fanned widely, and propitious clouds blanketed the sky. Huìchè, assuming the role of disciple, advanced, knelt, and entreated: "Formerly, I awakened to the original nature and resolved to cultivate both samādhi and prajñā, believing the Dao to lie therein. I have reverently heard the principle of returning the elixir, which has suddenly dispelled my obstructions. Yet I have also heard of the Supreme Vehicle’s Celestial Immortal Dao, its profound and wondrous celestial mechanism—unlike that of the Three Vehicles. I beseech the Master’s compassion to bestow deliverance."

Dòngléi exclaimed: "Hmph! To impart the treasure to one unworthy is to forfeit heaven’s gift; to transmit it to one who cannot receive it is to invite karmic retribution. To withhold instruction from one fit to receive it is to fail the person; to instruct one unfit is to waste words. The wise neither fail the person nor waste words—I understand this well! You are teachable. Come! I shall speak to you.

The Golden Elixir and the Returned Elixir are one and the same; none has ever attained the Golden Elixir without first achieving the Returned Elixir. This is the meaning of ascending the heights from the humble, journeying afar from the near. Generally, the methods of the Supreme Vehicle all begin with refining essence to transform it into *qi*, refining *qi* to transform it into spirit, and refining spirit to return to emptiness. Only in the final step are the furnace and crucible reset, *qian* and *kun* re-established, and the single practice of refining nature pursued until emptiness merges with the Dao—this is the method of first cultivating life, then cultivating nature.

Our Celestial Immortal tradition, however, proceeds directly from cultivating nature, for when nature is perfected, life is naturally perfected. This is the study of fulfilling nature to realize destiny, the meaning of refining the upper barrier while encompassing the middle and lower barriers—what Zhuangzi called ‘forgetting spirit and transcending life.’ Its profound subtleties differ entirely from the three methods of the Three Vehicles. Here, the Great Void is the furnace and crucible, the Three Primes are the medicinal substances, the Celestial Heart is the master of transformation, the Mysterious Pass is the gate of total holding, and primordial merging is the non-dual dharma. As the *Treatise on Resolving Delusion* states: ‘Concentrating spirit and gathering *qi* is guarding the city; forgetting scheming and severing thoughts is life and death. Samādhi and prajñā are water and fire; action and cessation are advance and retreat. Pristine stillness and spontaneity are the operation; harmonious *qi* steaming is the bath. Years, months, days, and hours are the firing times; forging into a single mass is the union; pulverizing emptiness is the culmination.’

Master Qióngguǎn said: ‘The Dao of the Celestial Immortal is like a pearl in a crystal dish, rolling freely and vibrantly—how could it be bound by yin-yang within the Five Phases? One must leap beyond heaven and earth to be called a realized adept.’ Its method is simple and direct; transmitted through the heart, it is easily accomplished. Other Supreme Vehicle methods involve hexagrams and lines, weights and measures—complex and difficult. A hair’s breadth of error leads one a thousand miles astray, hence the saying, ‘A hair’s divergence yields no elixir.’ I transmit this to you orally; you must grasp it with your heart."

In praise it is said:
Its wonder transcends all bounds,
Its Dao is effortlessly plain.

Pulverizing emptiness is the ultimate attainment.
Hair-like thusness, reverent and thought-free.
Heart-transmitted, orally conferred—
the most precious, the most secret.

Huìchè asked: “What distinguishes the Supreme Vehicle from the Three Vehicles’ methods?”
Master Léi replied: “The distinction lies in self and other, here and there! Here, essence, qi, and spirit are the Three Origins; there, heaven, earth, and humanity are the Three Origins. The Three Origins of heaven, earth, and humanity encompass all that is vast and penetrate all that is minute. The Three Origins of essence, qi, and spirit pertain solely to the individual body. Now, primordial essence, primordial qi, and primordial spirit are the innate endowments of this body—hence they are called ‘self,’ belonging to ‘here.’ The Celestial Origin, the Terrestrial Origin, and the Human Origin are all possessed by the self—hence they are called ‘other,’ belonging to ‘there.’ Within the Three Vehicles’ methods, nature and life are divided into self and other, or earlier and later are treated as self and other, with the Nature School as ‘here’ and the Life School as ‘there.’ Our Celestial Immortal tradition makes no division between self and other—it lies solely in the penetration of the One Principle!”

In praise it is said:
The Origins of heaven, earth, and humanity—
the gateway to entering the Dao.
No division of self and other,
only this alone is revered.
Penetrating the One Principle,
encompassing Qian and Kun—
wondrous indeed, the Supreme,
the Way abides herein.

Hui Che said, “What is most critical?”
Master Lei replied, “Opening the Mysterious Pass is the foremost critical point. For the Mysterious Pass is the great gate of the body. If the great gate remains shut, how can one ascend the hall and enter the chamber, gathering the Three Origins to serve as the elixir’s ingredients?”

In praise it is said:
Mysterious Pass, oh Mysterious Pass—
the realm of all wonders.
Unfurled or rolled, it is
bestowed by imperial favor.
The fragrance is not fragrance,
the crescent is not a crescent.
To recognize the true face,
return to Mount Lu.

Hui Che said, “In general, when refining the Golden Elixir, opening the Three Passes is considered the primary task. Now you speak of the Mysterious Pass as critical—how does this Mysterious Pass differ from the Three Passes?”
Master Lei replied, “The Three Passes have distinctions of front and back. The three behind: Weilu, Jiaji, and Yuzhen, are called the Front Three Passes. The three in front: Niwan, Jiangong, and the Lower Dantian, are called the Rear Three Passes. The Elixir Classics say: ‘Front three-three, rear three-three, gather them up, and carry them in a day.’ The Front Three Passes lie within the spine, governing the Du Mai; the Rear Three Passes lie in the chest, governing the Ren Mai. When Ren and Du are unobstructed, the hundred vessels of the body all flow freely. When the Front and Rear Three Passes are all opened in a single day, it is as if borne upon the shoulders—hence it is called ‘carrying in a day.’ Yet these Ren and Du are the red and black paths. The Elixir Scriptures say: ‘The human path, like the governance of the center, lies between the navel and the spine, where there is an aperture called Guanyuan.’ This is the path of governing the descent of the lower yellow, ascending through the yellow path, directly piercing the middle yellow and upper yellow. The Elixir Scriptures mark this as the ‘immortal path.’ This is the primordial yellow path through which the Three Treasures together pass—also called the Yellow Center, truly the governing place of the immortal path. Thus the *Book of Changes* says, ‘The Yellow Center penetrates principle, the correct position abides in the body’—this is the root of our life and destiny, communicating as if by a single breath with the Great Simplicity of heaven and earth. Laozi called it the ‘Gate of the Mysterious Female,’ and also said, ‘This is the root of heaven and earth.’ Its gate is called ‘Guanyuan,’ the very portal of yin and yang’s ingress and egress—hence it is also called the ‘Pass.’ It is called ‘mysterious’ because the unfathomable arises from here—this is where the Great Ultimate of the body is established. There is no one who is not born through this; how could one not return through it in cultivation? Thus the superior returning elixir must first gather the primordial One Qi, descending from Guanyuan, ascending counterflow to Kunlun, then descending to Jiangque, settling into the Dantian, entering the qi cavity, where fire and water timings are stored and circulated—this is called ‘cooking’ and ‘refining.’ Therefore, in our Celestial Immortal tradition, from the beginning to the end of practice, nothing lies outside the Mysterious Pass—how could it be merely the first step of cultivation?”

In praise it is said:
The correct position abides in the body,
the Yellow Center penetrates principle.
No end to the end,
no beginning to the beginning.
From the beginning to the end of practice,
nothing lies outside this.
Communing with the Great Simplicity,
befriending the Yellow and Li.

Hui Che said, “If the Mysterious Pass is opened first, must these Three Passes still be opened?”
Master Lei replied, “If the Mysterious Pass is opened first, there is no need to open the Three Passes again! For after the Three Passes are opened and one further practices emptiness and stillness, it is like breaking in from the outside. When the Mysterious Pass opens, it is an emergence from inner emptiness. Breaking in from the outside may be real or false: if real, inner and outer become one; if false, the outside may seem empty while the inside remains solid. To achieve inner emptiness is extremely arduous—one must reach true forgetfulness before it is possible, and only then can there be real benefit. Thus, when the Mysterious Pass opens, the body becomes like a luminous gauze shell, every pore and aperture open, the true mechanism ascending and descending with its own path—there is no need for these Three Passes. If the Three Passes are opened first, the Mysterious Pass must still be opened afterward to gather the Three Origins.”

In praise it is said:
Having attained the mysterious principle,
what need for the Three?
The Three originally have form,
the One Origin is bottomless.
With the formless embracing the formed,
Kunlun transforms into a carp.
Wondrous indeed, the primordial Origin—
opening it is truly sublime.

Hui Che said, “I wish to know the secret essentials of opening the Mysterious Pass.”

Master Lei said, “For beginners, the difficulty lies in the mind’s unsteadiness and the spirit’s restlessness. If one can achieve spirit-concentration and qi-stillness, standing firm at the state prior to the Prior Heaven, then opening the Mysterious Pass becomes an easy matter. As the former master said, ‘Practice begins with non-thought.’

Thus, there are several methods for the practitioner’s initial steps:

First: Let go of all entanglements, and the body naturally becomes quiescent and empty—this is the oral instruction for entering the state of primordial undifferentiation passed down by the former master. Yet people are constantly distracted, their minds never at peace for even a moment, like boiling water in a hundred bubbles. How can emptiness and stillness be attained without a handle to grasp? The practitioner must first inwardly observe the source of the mind. Then the body becomes quiescent and the spirit empty. This ‘source of the mind’ is not the fleshy heart within the body, but that which is quiescent yet spiritually luminous. Employ the ‘neither attached nor detached’ method to guard it, so the mind does not fix upon any location. In unwavering vigilance, one constantly perceives this inner vastness—empty and boundless, unstained by a single thing—only feeling a profound stillness, embracing the spirit in quietude. This is precisely what is meant by ‘the mind having a master and thus remaining unmoved,’ as the *Vajracchedikā Sūtra* says: ‘One should produce that mind which abides nowhere.’

Second: Constantly operate this mind, withdrawing and concealing it within the aperture of the *jiājí* (between the shoulder blades), guarding it without departure. Naturally, wayward thoughts disperse, scattered concerns dissolve, restless impulses settle, and false notions cease. Over time, the true breath appears, and when breath vanishes, the foundation of life is firmly established. This is the excellent method of ‘turning the back’ from the *Book of Changes*.

Third: Visualize the *shāngēn* (mountain root). At the beginning of human life, the nose is formed first, called the ‘ancestral orifice.’ The *shāngēn* is located above the nose, between the eyebrows, and this place connects with the ancestral aperture. The ancestral aperture can seize the creative power of Heaven and Earth. Thus, visualize the *shāngēn* with neither forgetting nor forcing, as if present yet forgotten. Over time, one feels emptiness, stillness, and stability, and the *shāngēn* and ancestral aperture become as one. Continue guarding with quiescence, then with forgetting, and persist in practice. One day, this body and mind will be placed in a realm beyond recognition, and one’s singular spirit will merge into a state of undifferentiated oneness, entering the true境界 of the Mysterious Aperture. At this juncture, everything hinges on a single thought—thinking of immortality leads to immortality, thinking of the mundane leads to the mundane. The principle of resonance is just so.

If, within this undifferentiated state, one suddenly perceives boundlessness—perhaps stars and moon over the sea, the moon’s reflection in the waves, or vast calm waters with lush grasses and trees—various mysterious conditions arise beyond description. This is the opening of the Mysterious Pass! Yet if a thought stirs and attaches, the Mysterious Pass instantly vanishes. Thus, quiescence is maintained through quiescent observation.

Once this pass opens, one breathes in unison with the Great Primal, and the Three Powers and Six Directions, though not containing it, are contained. It is simply the Great Void itself. When the mechanism within this state is activated, the spirit perceives all without fail, and various true and false appearances arise in succession. Thus, one may only be aware of them but must not cling. As the *Four Hundred Words on the Golden Elixir* states: ‘This aperture is no ordinary aperture; it is formed by the union of Heaven and Earth. Called the cavity of spirit and qi, within it lies the essence of Kan and Li.’ This precisely refers to the Mysterious Pass.

The furnace and cauldron are established within it, the medicine and ingredients are gathered within it, the firing times are conducted within it, and even the formation of the embryo and attainment of sagehood occur within it. Whether employing mind and breath in mutual dependence or preserving the spirit in emptiness and stillness, the key lies in ‘as if present yet forgotten, neither attached nor detached.’ Fundamentally, one must let go of body and mind, observe with quiescent thought, and naturally attain spirit-concentration and qi-stabilization.

In all cases, the practitioner must take non-thought as the foundation, be sincere and persistent—what worry is there of not entering?”

In praise it is said:
Body quiescent, spirit empty,
all entanglements released.
Utmost sincerity without cease—
what hears day or night?
Suddenly, as if all opens,
like ten thousand following transformation.
Aware yet still quiescent,
entering the Dao of the infant and maiden.

Hui Che said, “Earlier, you spoke of the Yellow Court’s qi-cavity as the furnace and cauldron, then of body and mind as the furnace and cauldron, and of Heaven and Earth as the furnace and cauldron. Now you speak of the Great Void as the furnace and cauldron. I wish to know the profound and wondrous essence of these teachings.”

Master Lei said, “The two words ‘body’ and ‘mind’ encompass the meaning of ten thousand volumes. The body is not the physical body but the Dharma-body. The mind is not the human mind but the Heavenly mind. The Dharma-body has no body yet possesses body; the Heavenly mind has mind yet is without mind. Without profound understanding of creation and thorough penetration of the mysterious mechanism, this cannot be known.

The Yellow Court lies above the qi-cavity, connected above and below. Within the qi-cavity, there is also the qi-cavity. The qi-cavity is where the postnatal true qi is stored, while the qi-cavity is where the prenatal primordial qi is received—this is precisely the location of the Mysterious Pass. Qian is Heaven, the yang. Kun is Earth, the yin.”

The upper half of the human body pertains to yang, the lower half to yin. As the *Book of Changes* states, “Qian is the head, Kun is the belly.” For the nature resides in the mud-pill palace, while the life-destiny dwells within the navel. Thus, the true nature belongs to Qian, the heavenly mandate to Kun—Qian and Kun together constitute the true nature and life-destiny. Yet Qian and Kun possess the principle of mutual interaction, yin and yang the mechanism of inversion. Within nature lies true life-destiny, and within life-destiny resides true nature, hence the analogy of the Qian-Kun furnace and cauldron. That the Great Void serves as furnace and cauldron is because the Great Void encompasses the six directions, containing within it heaven, earth, and the ten thousand things. My Mysterious Pass is of the same substance as the Great Void, taking heaven and earth as its heart and true emptiness as its function. The Great Void of heaven and earth is the cauldron, while my Great Void is the furnace—thus the Great Void is metaphorically called furnace and cauldron. The cauldron is the vessel for placing things, the furnace the implement for storing fire; both merely denote the objects for containing and harboring the medicine and fire. Why then distinguish between furnace and cauldron?”

*Eulogy:*
The Dharma is non-existent yet existent,
The mind exists yet is non-existent.
Qian and Kun inverted,
Their exchange is mine alone.
Nature and life-destiny interdependent,
The Great Void as furnace and cauldron,
To refine and temper,
To walk with the sages.

Huìchè said, “What is the essential meaning of the medicine and ingredients?”

Master Lei replied, “Regarding the medicine and ingredients: in the lower-grade elixir method, nasal mucus, saliva, semen, sweat, blood, and fluids serve as the medicine; in the middle-grade, essence, qi, and spirit are the medicine; in the upper-grade, spirit, soul, ethereal soul, intent, and the primordial qi of the prior-heaven are the medicine, with the prior-heaven One Qi as the elixir mother—all pertain to the work of returning the elixir, nothing more than this dharma-realm. Only in our heavenly immortal tradition do we take the Supreme Ultimate as the elixir mother and the Three Origins as the medicine. The elixir mother is used to congeal the elixir, while the medicine nourishes it. *Origin* means great. The qi of the Three Powers—pure, true, and unadulterated—is the wondrous mystery of great transformation. These are the Qian Origin, Kun Origin, and Human Origin. Qian is Heaven, also called the Heavenly Origin; Kun is Earth, also called the Earthly Origin. The origins of Heaven, Earth, and Humanity—the Three Powers—are all nurtured within the Great Void, their origin born of the heart. The heart of Heaven lies in Earth, the heart of Earth in Heaven, and the heart of Heaven and Earth resides in humanity. Thus, humanity is the most precious among the Three Powers; without humanity, Heaven and Earth would have no means to manifest as such. The human origin disperses throughout Heaven and Earth, concealed within the Great Void. Therefore, our ancestor, the Venerable Great Void, said: ‘The Human Origin pervades the great thousand worlds, the Three Origins are mastered by one heart.’ Thus, we gather the medicine from within the Great Void and conduct the firing times within the Mysterious Pass. As the Perfected One of Purple Yang said: ‘The Dao arises from emptiness and generates the One Qi, which then produces yin and yang.’ Emptiness is the Non-Ultimate. The Non-Ultimate and the Supreme Ultimate are not two separate things—the extremity of non-being is precisely the Supreme Ultimate. When the Supreme Ultimate divides, it becomes the Two Modes, which is the One Qi transforming into yin and yang. Hence, ‘One yin and one yang is called the Dao; solitary yin or solitary yang is called the isolated.’ Yin and yang are the active manifestations of the Dao. Yin and yang arise from the Dao, and the Dao is constructed through yin and yang. When one awakens to this, all things embody the Dao. The wise who comprehend these words have penetrated the mystery of the Mysterious Pass. The Patriarch Mud-Pill said: ‘The mechanism that stirs spontaneously in the twelve hours is the prior-heaven qi. If one can gather it in time, it is the supreme treasure.’ If scholars can attain the state of utmost emptiness and profound stillness, the prior-heaven One Qi will naturally arise from the formless. My master said: ‘This prior-heaven is not merely the prior-heaven of the individual body but the ancestral qi of the Supreme Ultimate. The qi that flows through the Three Powers serves as nourishment, while the ancestral qi of the Supreme Ultimate can become the elixir mother—both are great medicines. If one does not embody emptiness and quiescence, and sitting does not reach the state of profound obscurity, there is no way to attain the principle.’”

*Eulogy:*
Take the Ultimate as the foundation,
The Origin as nourishment.
Though there are two,
Only humanity excels.
Imprint this in the heart,
Remember within emptiness.
Emptiness is not empty,
Boundless as flower petals in rain.

Huìchè said, “What is meant by ‘gathering’? What is meant by ‘firing times’?”

Master Lei replied, “As for gathering, follow the method of our ancestor Bai: sit upright in meditation to gather. When sitting in meditation reaches the state of profound obscurity and subtle indistinction, the nature-body becomes serene, and the One Real manifests. As the *Wondrous Scripture of Purity* states: ‘If one can constantly abide in purity, Heaven and Earth all return.’ Thus, the method is to attain utmost emptiness and profound stillness, concentrating the spirit in anticipation. Let the central master within remain utterly still, so that when the mechanism stirs, the spirit awakens, allowing it to ascend and descend naturally. Do not impose the slightest intention, for only then does it accord with the spirit’s function. Over time, the spirit and breath will naturally appear, becoming harmoniously full. Should various signs manifest, simply ensure this mind remains unattached. With intent, guard the center, gathering the mind into unified stillness, allowing its natural operation. As for firing times, let it be natural. Refining and tempering are nothing more than qi returning inward, spirit circulating within, and using spirit to guide qi. The elixir classics say: ‘True fire has no fixed time; the great medicine is not measured by weight.’ And again: ‘There is a natural true firing time—simply rest the spirit and breath, letting them be natural.’ The Perfected One of Purple Yang said: ‘The Primordial Celestial Worthy gathers the medicine daily, and the medicine becomes ever more inexhaustible; the Supreme Lord Lao conducts the firing times ceaselessly, and the firing times become ever more endless.’ Thus, Heaven and Earth also gather the medicine daily, while the sun and moon conduct firing times ceaselessly, enduring for billions of kalpas.”

Should even a single moment’s mechanism cease, Heaven and Earth would likewise collapse! Thus, when the firing times are spoken of in terms of years, months, days, and hours, it is precisely to say they are not measured by years, months, days, or hours. Yet before the Mysterious Pass opens and the work reaches true emptiness and true stillness, how can one rashly speak of gathering the medicine? First, the body and mind must be scoured until spotlessly clean, so that the work may more readily attain the state of emptiness and stillness. Even then, within this emptiness and stillness, one must nurture a sense of ease and liveliness.

What is meant by emptiness and stillness? To empty the heart and still the nature. What is meant by ease and liveliness? To cultivate the free and uninhibited movement of qi. This work is not only to be practiced in stillness; even when engaging with affairs and encountering others, one must maintain this mastery until it becomes second nature. Only when one achieves what Master Cheng described as “movement is stillness, stillness is stillness” can movement and stillness become one, and the work naturally reach completion—this is the true ground of great accomplishment.

When the work reaches the point where there is no inside or outside, no boundaries or limits, the Mysterious Pass will have opened, and the medicine will arise of itself. Only then is the medicine truly born; otherwise, what is gathered remains but the illusory and mundane of the posterior heaven—how could it be called medicine? For only when the aperture opens and the time arrives does the medicine come into being, ready to be gathered. By means of the medicine, the mundane is transformed, and only then is the mundane truly transformed.

*Eulogy:*
The Primordial One gathers the medicine,
The Supreme Lord conducts the furnace.
In wondrous natural operation,
Heaven and Earth are one with me.
Movement and stillness begin as one,
The Limitless unfolds its chart.
Attain this supreme mystery,
And the mundane body is transformed.

Huìchè said: “Are concentration and wisdom the water and fire of our tradition? And what is meant by ‘action and cessation’ as advance and retreat?”

Master Léi replied: “Concentration pertains to water, wisdom to fire. Concentration is the settling of the heart; wisdom is the employment of spirit. Within the heart lies spirit, and spirit pertains to fire. When mixed with discursive thought, it is the spirit of consciousness—mundane fire. The spirit untainted by form and appearance is the primordial spirit, true fire, called the radiance of wisdom. The use of concentration and wisdom is but one principle with two applications.

To settle the heart and spirit without attachment to form and appearance is called awakened wisdom. A settled heart with the illumination of wisdom is awareness that is ever-present. Using water to temper fire is illumination that is ever-aware. The difference between Buddhism and Daoism lies merely in whether the movement of qi is easeful and lively or not.

As for ‘action and cessation,’ this refers to the meaning of advancing fire and retreating tally. When practicing at this stage, it is advancing fire; when one reaches the state of complete oblivion, it is retreating tally—not merely the advancing and retreating of firing times in the usual sense. If one can truly attain complete oblivion, the foundation of transformation through merging is laid. In advancing fire and retreating tally, there naturally appear wondrous celestial signs, beyond all conjecture. When the work reaches this point, marvelous awareness arises of itself.”

*Eulogy:*
Concentration and wisdom give rise to each other,
Awareness and illumination ever bright.
Using water to temper fire,
One returns to the Great Clarity.
The foundation of merging,
Naturally upheld.
Beyond all conjecture,
Its wonder defies naming.

Huìchè said: “In ancient elixir classics, there is mention of ‘the union of Kan and Li,’ and also of ‘the union of Qian and Kun.’ Do the heavenly immortals have such circumstances?”

Master Léi replied: “The union of Kan and Li exists in the three vehicles’ teachings, though it is not an absolute doctrine. As for the union of Qian and Kun, my master said: ‘When the scholar empties to the utmost and stills with utmost sincerity, then sincerity within naturally attains profound and great concentration. Suddenly, the mechanism stirs, and one instantly feels empty, numinous, and radiant—boundless and without limit. With a swift recollection, one immediately enters profound quiescence. After a moment, a single point descends into the Yellow Court. Only then is the qi of the prior heaven restored, naturally circulating through the six directions. I abide within it, aware only of a single true intention, feeling qi refreshed and spirit clear, body and mind harmonious and at ease—this is called the Golden Liquor Returning Elixir.’

In truth, it is formless and imageless, the solitary revelation of the numinous. Qian and Kun merge, completing my Supreme Ultimate.”

*Eulogy:*
Qian and Kun unite,
Sincerity is their quest.
Profound and great concentration,
Radiance swiftly gathered.
After a moment, a single point—
Qi restored, circulating all around.
Only true intention remains,
Golden Liquor returns in excellence.

Huìchè said: “In cultivating the Dao, one must have a Dao companion. What does this mean?”

Master Léi replied: “This Dao companion is a teacher and friend. Generally, each practitioner has different endowments of qi, and their progress varies. Thus, one must frequently discuss and inquire, reflecting deeply, so that both parties benefit. If one practices alone without seeking explanation, the ancients called this ‘blind walking’ or ‘blind practice and reckless refinement’—it is difficult to achieve success.

As the work advances, it becomes ever more subtle; the more subtle it becomes, the more essential it is to discuss it. The slightest error leads to a hundred mistakes. At this point, one must have a renowned teacher and beneficial friends to point out and analyze, so that the path is not mistaken and the work progresses daily. Thus, Chan Buddhism has the staff and shout, the Daoist gate relies on enlightenment, and Confucianism especially values mutual observation. The *Book of Changes* says: ‘The noble person discusses and practices with friends.’ The *Book of Rites* says: ‘To study alone without friends is to be isolated and ignorant.’ Even Confucius, the utmost sage, worried about learning that was not discussed. Zixia, a prominent disciple of the Apricot Altar, still lamented that living in isolation prevented him from hearing his faults. How can one do without Dao companions?

Yet if one does not diligently practice but merely gathers with friends, spending days talking of mysteries and discussing the ancient and modern, this is but ‘mouth Chan’—what benefit does it bring to one’s body, mind, and learning? Thus, while cultivating the Dao values companions, it values even more self-discipline. Like attracts like, and groups form by kind—it depends on oneself, not others.”

*Eulogy:*
The stone of other mountains
Can polish jade.
Friends aid each other,
Timely with loyal advice.

As gold in the crucible, entering darkness raises the torch.
Gathering long the stars of virtue, transcending the dust to surpass the common.
Huìchè said: “The ancients spoke of entering the circular chamber for warmth and nurturing, of nine years facing the wall—does such a practice truly exist?”
Master Léi replied: “This pertains to those who first cultivate *ming* (life-destiny) before cultivating *xing* (innate nature), and only then employ such methods. For they fear that if *xing* remains impure, the work of *ming* may still harbor flaws. Master Wùyuán said: ‘Nine years’ refers to the meaning of the nine returns. *Facing the wall* does not mean sitting in fixed meditation, but rather the unbroken focus of intent and the gathering of spirit. The aim is to leave not a speck of dross, as if a sheer cliff stands before one—nothing seen, all dharmas returned to emptiness, quietly nurturing the infant’s transformation in the womb.’ Our late master said: ‘This practice, performed after the return, coagulation, and nurturing are complete, may seem secure, yet how few in ancient times expended great effort without abandoning it midway? Better is the Supreme Heart Teaching of the Most High, which clarifies *xing* to clarify *ming*, clarifying one to concentrate one, accumulating little by little, day after day, month after month, year after year. Step by step, one returns to emptiness, advancing to the natural state—desiring liberation, one is instantly liberated; desiring transformation, one is instantly transformed. Having reached the state where even emptiness is pulverized, one moves or rests at will. Why labor over entering the chamber or facing the wall?’ According to the master’s teaching, this aligns with Ancestor Bái’s saying: ‘Life is up to him, death is up to him’—one need only master oneself. Thus, the work is simply to cultivate utmost sincerity without cease.”

*Eulogy:*
How can there be facing the wall
When one’s nature is already bright?
The Supreme Heart Teaching of the Most High
Establishes *ming* through *xing*.
Step by step, returning to emptiness,
Moment by moment, accumulating through penetration.
Let life and death take their course—
Wondrous is the mastery of the self.

Huìchè said: “The ancients all spoke of success coming when the crown of the head splits open to release the yang spirit. Is this principle correct?”
Master Léi replied: “This refers to guiding and drawing out the primordial yang. The methods of the Three Vehicles all proceed thus, yet one must ensure that the spirit can emerge but does not emerge, then further refine the spirit to return to emptiness, refine emptiness to merge with the Dao, and refine the Dao to unite with the natural. Hence the saying of re-establishing the furnace and cauldron, of re-erecting heaven and earth. Thus, the Perfected One of Purple Yang said: ‘Light at the nape of the neck is still illusion; clouds beneath the feet do not yet make one an immortal.’ One must proceed until emptiness itself is pulverized. This is the great matter of the final step. If one practices thus, one divides *xing* and *ming* into two separate tasks, necessitating this extra effort. In our Heavenly Immortal tradition, we begin directly with the cultivation of *xing*, advancing one step to return one step to emptiness. When emptiness can no longer be returned, refining the Dao to merge with the natural, only then is the work complete—without first coagulating the yang spirit and then pulverizing it. The aim is simply to fill the cosmos with one’s vast and unyielding qi, becoming one with the Great Void, without entry or exit. As it is said: ‘Utmost great, utmost firm, nurtured directly without harm, it fills the space between heaven and earth.’ Thus, the supreme Dharma of the highest vehicle is the refinement of form, which is the refinement of spirit and the cultivation of *xing*, and thereby the cultivation of *ming*. True emptiness and wondrous existence, wondrous existence and true emptiness—thus can one gather to form shape and disperse to become qi, with both form and spirit wondrous, merging with the Dao in truth.”

*Eulogy:*
Cultivating *xing* is cultivating *ming*,
Refining form is refining spirit.
When form and spirit are both wondrous,
*xing* and *ming* are perfectly realized.
Why need fetal nurturing?
Roaming at ease in the Jade Capital.
The supreme and wondrous secret—
Merging with the Dao in truth.

Huìchè said: “This Great Elixir of Golden Cinnabar pertains to matters after the Returned Elixir. Is it necessary first to cultivate the Returned Elixir before proceeding to the Golden Elixir?”
Master Léi replied: “Not so. The so-called Returned Elixir is the restoration of the original elixir we inherently possess. For after the age of fifteen or sixteen, one’s true primordial essence is broken, and one’s spirit and vitality diminish day by day. Thus, one must replenish it to the state before the age of fifteen or sixteen, when the true primordial essence was unbroken, and further restore the countenance of one’s birth. *Return* means to go and then come back, restoring one’s original Great Ultimate—hence it is called the Returned Elixir. The methods of the Three Vehicles all require first cultivating the Returned Elixir before advancing to the Golden Elixir. In the Supreme Heart Transmission of the Most High, one need only open the Mysterious Pass, then daily gather, hourly refine, and moment by moment return to emptiness—thus gradually replenishing. Day by day, one accumulates and replenishes; day by day, one replenishes and fills, until filled and filled again, replete and replete again. The Returned Elixir lies herein, and the Golden Elixir lies herein as well. What is meant by *filled and replete* is not the spirit and vitality of the acquired, but the one qi of primordial harmony. When the primordial is replete, the acquired naturally flourishes day by day; when the acquired flourishes, the primordial becomes even more replete. The single spark of spirit in a person originally receives the central qi of heaven and earth to come into being, enduring through past and present without cease. This central qi is the primordial qi of the Great Ultimate, the ancestor of the generation of heaven, earth, and the myriad things. Yet the Great Ultimate has both the Great Ultimate of the whole and the Great Ultimate of each thing. The Great Ultimate of the whole is the single Great Ultimate of heaven, earth, and the myriad beings; the Great Ultimate of each thing is the Great Ultimate possessed by each individual thing. This Great Ultimate is the blended name of principle and qi. Principle is the pattern of qi, and qi is the vitality of principle. Master Chéng said: ‘To speak of principle without qi is incomplete; to speak of qi without principle is unclear. To separate them is incorrect.’ Master Zhū said: ‘Nature is principle, thus destiny is qi.’ Therefore, the Great Ultimate may be spoken of as principle, or as qi; as *xing*, or as *ming*. From the moment of the parents’ union, a single point descends into the Yellow Court and establishes itself. The Great Ultimate thus divides into yin and yang, and creation begins.”

Yin and yang are the essence and spirit; in heaven, they are the sun and moon. The White Ancestor said: “When sun and moon combine, they form brightness; when sun and moon ascend and descend, they form change; when sun and moon overlap, they form the elixir.” If one can nurture one’s essence and spirit to the point of unity, then *xing* and *ming* naturally endure, and with *xing* and *ming* enduring, the foundation of the elixir is ever firm.

The Returned Elixir is the return to the Great Ultimate possessed by each individual thing, while the Golden Elixir is the return to the Great Ultimate of the whole. For nurturing virtue and nurturing life are but one and the same. To exhaust principle and fulfill *xing* so as to reach *ming* is where the Golden Elixir lies.

In praise it is said:
To nurture virtue and nurture the body—only one matter.
Returned Elixir and Golden Elixir—how could there be two meanings?
The sagely learning and the immortal tradition, from beginning to end, mutually support one another.
To fulfill *xing* and reach *ming*—how could one not observe the *Xici*?

Huìchè said: “May I inquire about the meaning of *hunhua* (blended transformation)? What is its intent?”
Master Léi said: “*Hunhua*—these two characters are the wondrous key to the beginning and the end. The ancients said: ‘Forget form to nurture qi; forget qi to nurture spirit; forget spirit to nurture emptiness.’ Thus, when first beginning, one must let go of all entanglements. When the work reaches the point of release, one gradually enters the stage of ‘forgetting,’ which is the completion of the beginning in *hunhua*. The method is simply to inwardly and outwardly illuminate one’s body, mind, spirit, and qi, gathering them into one. Then, withdraw the mechanism, and naturally one gradually enters the state of transformation. When there arises a lively scene of emptiness and signs of opportunity, the functions within—whether to welcome, to receive, to release, or to gather—must all be discerned in accordance with the moment and follow naturally. With stillness, one sustains it; with oneness, one transforms it. Only when one reaches the point where there is nothing left to forget does the divine subtlety of *hunhua*’s completion manifest. As the Buddhist scriptures say: ‘Only this one is real; the other two are not true.’ Thus, it is called the ‘non-dual Dharma gate.’”

In praise it is said:
The subtlety of *hunhua*—the three forgettings are most essential.
Forgetting where there is nothing left to forget, with oneness and still illumination.
Following naturally, the emptiness of space is thus emulated.
When the work of pulverization is complete, they meet with a smile.

Huìchè said: “I wish to hear more of its wondrous essence!”
Master Léi said: “The宗旨 of *hunhua* is difficult to describe. The *Book of Changes* says: ‘Match your virtue with heaven and earth, your brightness with the sun and moon, your order with the four seasons, and your auspices and inauspices with ghosts and spirits. Be prior to heaven yet not violate it; follow heaven yet accord with its timing.’ One may nearly approach this! My master said: ‘The heart-transmission of the heavenly immortals’ practice begins with letting go of all entanglements, so the body naturally becomes still and empty. In heaven and in the abyss, there is not a moment’s interruption. Perfect emptiness, perfect stillness, perfect clarity, perfect harmony—what is inner, what is outer? What is being, what is non-being? The ceaseless transformations of the celestial mechanism are all entrusted to *ruru* (thusness) alone. The wondrous function of return is just like this, just like this.’

If the work does not begin with letting go of all entanglements, the six dusts will tempt from without, the six roots will stir within, and without arising from inner accumulation, one will be touched from without. How can body, mind, and intent be at peace? If the heart and *xing* are not settled, how can the work enter? Thus, the *Great Learning* says: ‘Only after knowing where to rest does one attain stability.’ To seek stability, one must first clearly know where to rest. To know where to rest, one must clearly know where the utmost good lies, and only then will one know where to rest.

Master Chéng said: ‘When the heart has a master, it can remain unmoved.’ When the heart has a master, the heart is settled and the spirit at peace. The way of learning and inquiry is nothing other than seeking the heart that has been lost. When qi is still and thoughts absent, the body ascends into the imagery of emptiness and non-being, *xing* is still and emotions forgotten, and one’s radiance surely illuminates. Then, in heaven and in the abyss, all is within my single awareness—this is what the *Doctrine of the Mean* calls the time ‘before arousal.’ Yet this state is attained only in stillness; one may lack control when in motion. Thus, one must cultivate both movement and stillness before it is truly possible. Therefore, the master said there is not a moment’s interruption.

The four characters—emptiness, stillness, clarity, and harmony—must manifest this wondrous scene in both movement and stillness before it is true work and real learning. Thus, what is inner, what is outer? What is being, what is non-being? Within it, the celestial mechanism’s ceaseless transformations are all entrusted to *ruru* alone. *Ruru* means no above or below, no movement or stillness, no direction or place, no inner or outer. The wondrous function of the heavenly immortals is nothing more than this!

Observe the *Great Learning*: from ‘illuminating virtue’ to ‘resting in the utmost good,’ from ‘investigation of things’ to ‘bringing peace to the world.’ The *Doctrine of the Mean*: from ‘vigilance and fear’ to ‘heaven and earth established and the myriad beings nurtured,’ concluding with ‘what heaven covers, without sound or scent.’ All these functions unite movement and stillness, embody the original substance, and are the learning of practice.

Later scholars are unwilling to reflect on their own body and mind, merely reading superficially. Even if they can speak and explain, they treat it as literary embellishment or memorized knowledge, entirely unrelated to body and mind. Though they read books, they have not truly read. Moreover, when they encounter books on the learning of the Dao, they often dismiss them as impractical talk. How many are truly earnest about *xing* and *ming*?

If one is truly earnest in applying effort to one’s own body, mind, *xing*, and *ming*, then one will know that the true learning of the sages is precisely the practice of the heavenly immortals. When one thoroughly understands the practice of the heavenly immortals, one will know that it is indeed the learning of the sages, incomparable to the Daoist lead and mercury of midnight and noon.

The Dao calls it the Golden Elixir; the Confucians call it the Great Ultimate. That which enacts creation is the Great Ultimate, and the Great Ultimate is originally the Ultimateless. That which carries out creation is yin and yang, and yin and yang are originally the Great Ultimate.”
