Heaven, Earth, and all things are none other than the products of the Great Ultimate and yin-yang. The Great Ultimate generates Heaven and Earth, and Heaven and Earth move yin and yang. Thus the four seasons proceed, the hundred things are born, and man is but one thing among the myriad. Each of the myriad things establishes its own Great Ultimate, and man likewise establishes his own Great Ultimate—this is what is meant by “each thing possesses a Great Ultimate.” The Great Ultimate and yin-yang are present in every thing. Therefore, within the Six Directions, both inside and out, all is the flowing and circulating of the Great Ultimate and yin-yang. Since man exists within the Six Directions, both inside and outside his body are nothing but yin and yang.

Yet the Great Ultimate is the root of our ceaseless generation, just as it is the root of the ceaseless generation of the ten thousand affairs and things. The Great Ultimate transforms into yin and yang, and yin and yang move the Great Ultimate, cycling without end, transforming without cease. For hundreds of thousands of years it has been thus, unchanging. That it can remain unchanged for hundreds of thousands of years is because there is a master governing it. What is this master? The heavenly heart.

Man receives the qi of Heaven and Earth to form his body, and thus receives the heart of Heaven and Earth as his own heart. Having received the heart of Heaven and Earth as his own heart, he ought to embody the heart of Heaven and Earth and extend it to the ten thousand affairs and things. When my heart fully extends the heart of Heaven and Earth, it too is fully extended. Only then can one stand alongside Heaven and Earth as a third. As the *Doctrine of the Mean* says: “He who can fully realize his own nature can fully realize the nature of others; he who can fully realize the nature of others can fully realize the nature of things; he who can fully realize the nature of things can assist in the transforming and nourishing processes of Heaven and Earth.” Such is the way man seizes the creative power of Heaven and Earth.

Yet creation means ceaseless generation. Generation transforms, and transformation generates, all following the natural principle. I cannot intervene! If one entrusts the totality of generation and transformation to suchness, then Heaven and Earth intermingle in harmony, and the myriad things naturally attain purity. Thus Qupu Bluehead said: “Neither existence nor non-existence is established; the true lies within existence and non-existence.” This is the true learning of fully realizing one’s nature and fulfilling one’s destiny.

My master also said: “From the vastness of the celestial sphere to the minuteness of a mote of dust, place the heart in oneness, and merge into the perfect truth.” Whether vast as the celestial sphere or minute as a mote of dust, all lies within the one heart. Therefore, if one can place this heart in oneness, the work of merging and transforming is complete, and one perfects the truth.

Though Daoists speak of merging and transforming, even the Confucian practice must ultimately attain spiritual transformation. The *Doctrine of the Mean* says: “The lesser virtue flows like a stream; the greater virtue brings profound transformation.” It also says: “Movement leads to change; change leads to transformation. Only the utmost sincerity under Heaven can effect transformation.” Mencius said: “To be great and transform is called sageliness; to be sagely yet unknowable is called spirit.” Both the Confucian and immortal practices must attain spiritual transformation to reach their ultimate state!

In praise it is said:
Wondrous is this supreme principle,
Confucian learning and Daoist arts converge.
Spiritual transformation, perfect merging—
ancient mysteries beyond compare.
Unobstructed in emptiness and fullness,
the supreme Dao embraces all.
Neither partial nor changeable,
we pay reverence to the Sage of Mount Ni.

Huiche said: “According to all that has been said, Confucian learning and the mysterious learning share the same principle. Why then did the former worthies all reject Buddhism and Daoism, claiming they could not be applied to the world and the state? If they could not be applied, why have the Three Teachings stood like a tripod in the world for over a thousand years, and why has not one of them perished?”

Master Lei replied: “Laozi, Śākyamuni, and Confucius were all sages; the teachings of the Three Teachings are all the Dao. The Dao has no dual principles, but the teachings are divided into three. The followers of the Three Teachings are all human. Every person possesses this heart and nature, possesses this heavenly principle. The principle is not two principles, the heart is not two hearts. Confucians speak of preserving the heart and nourishing the nature; Daoists speak of cultivating the heart and refining the nature; Buddhists speak of illuminating the heart and perceiving the nature. The Three Teachings all apply true effort to the heart and nature, each attaining its ultimate. Thus they have stood like a tripod for a thousand years, what is called ‘different paths leading to the same destination.’

In our learning, we must possess a discerning eye and establish a resolute aspiration. We must know what we are studying. Those who pursue Confucian learning must study until they reach the level of Confucius and Yan Hui and then stop. Those who follow Buddhism or Daoism must practice until they reach the level of Laozi and Śākyamuni and then stop. Once this aspiration is firmly established and true effort is applied, one will naturally progress day by day and month by month, able to comprehend intuitively and each attain the wonders of their respective learning.

What must be most avoided is changing course morning and night, being swayed by new ideas, neglecting one’s own garden to weed another’s, and recklessly judging the right and wrong of past and present. For only with a measure of effort does one gain a measure of learning; only with a measure of learning does one gain a measure of insight; only with a measure of insight can one understand a measure of the ancients’ realm. If one’s insight is insufficient and one rashly passes judgment, when one’s learning advances and insight rises to a higher level, one will regret one’s former judgments of right and wrong—but it will be too late.

The statement that ‘Buddhism and Daoism cannot be applied to the world and the state’ can only be made by sages. We must never lightly utter such words. Why? Only those with the true learning of sages, who can truly apply it to the world and the state, are qualified to say that Buddhism and Daoism cannot be applied. As for ordinary, superficial people with shallow knowledge and little experience, who cannot even govern their own bodies and minds, how can they govern the world and the state? If one cannot govern the world and the state, how can one presume to judge whether Buddhism and Daoism can or cannot?

Moreover, that Confucianism can be applied to the world and the state does not mean that all Confucian scholars can apply it to the world and the state. The true learning of Confucianism, from investigating things and extending knowledge to ordering the state and bringing peace to the world, is entirely for the purpose of fully realizing oneself and others. It must reach the point where the world is at peace and not a single thing fails to attain its proper place before it ceases.”

To ensure that not a single thing in the world fails to attain its proper place—what immense power is this? What monumental achievement? How can it be spoken of so lightly? We must first thoroughly comprehend our own mind and nature, constantly verifying this understanding through our interactions with things, and see whether we can truly apply it. Otherwise, even if one wears the robes and cap of a Confucian scholar all one’s life, one may still fail to apply it even among one’s own family—father and son, brothers—let alone extend it to the world.

An ancient saying goes: “Buddhism speaks of compassion, Daoism of resonance, Confucianism of loyalty and forbearance.” The three teachings originally share a single heart. If one understands what the heart truly is, what distinction remains between the three? And what need is there to speak of their unity?

**Eulogy:**
The ultimate principle is one, though its paths are three.
Loyalty and forbearance, compassion,
Resonance interwoven.
Heart mirrors heart,
Each thing bears and contains.
*The Plum Blossom Dialogues*—
A guide to following one’s nature.

**Postscript:**
The essence of reading lies in embodying and practicing what one learns. The subtlety of practice, in turn, lies in profound comprehension—not being hindered by mere words—before true attainment is possible. Only then has one not wasted one’s reading.

Master Shi Zi, having received oral transmission from Master Xiao Gen, distilled the heart-to-heart transmission and composed *The Plum Blossom Dialogues* in one volume, comprising forty chapters. Every word follows nature, every character is the golden elixir. From rectifying sincerity to fulfilling destiny, and from fulfilling destiny to the wondrous application of cyclic discourse—its principles flow freely, universally applicable. This is truly the standard of sagely learning, plumbing the depths of the boundless.

Though it is the natural and true scripture, what could surpass it?

Laiyi, though born most foolish, delights in reading books of past and present, and from his own reflections seeks their essential meaning. In moments of leisure, whenever I received guidance—even during Master Xiao Gen’s leisurely strolls with his staff—I was granted the deepest discourse.

I recall that in the spring of the *bingxu* year, I was first bestowed with couplets inscribed on scrolls at the *Yalu Study*, reading:
*"Only fearing a shallow heart in devotion to the Buddha,
Yet for lack of learning, I vow to seek the immortal’s Way."*
And again:
*"Nurture my vast and unyielding qi,
Never losing the heart of a newborn child."*
Such repeated kindness, like the carving of a master sculptor, has left me indebted beyond measure.

Yet over these ten-odd years, my learning has not advanced by even a hair’s breadth. Turning inward in self-reflection, I can only darken in sorrow, dreading that I have failed to repay this profound grace. In my leisure, I have perused the essentials of the ancient canons, examined the subtleties of the *Qiu* and *Suo*, and surveyed the masters of the Han, Jin, Tang, and Song dynasties. None surpass the thorough study of the Four Books as the standard for cultivating the self. The *Fen* and *Dian* resemble the *Suo* in form but speak from an even more ancient voice—like the *Lian Shan*, which traces the roaming of the spirit before consciousness arises, where within the profound obscurity, nature yet abides. It is said: *"The Great Ultimate is the parent of Heaven and Earth."* And again: *"After the Great Ultimate comes the Great Simplicity, and the number of the Great Simplicity is two."* By this reasoning, it speaks of subtleties beyond even the *Zhouyi*. Yet in its application, it does not transcend the transformation and refinement of the myriad things.

It further states: *"The Master of Chaos dwells in the position where I descend as the dragon, governing the people."* Here, the origin of nature and life, the essentials of the golden elixir, are already revealed with precision. Though the *Qi Xing* and *Er Fen* are incisive, they lean toward governance. It is also said: *"Nature preserves life, life sustains existence, and existence fulfills longevity."* This aligns with the *Zhouyi*’s *"exhausting principle and fulfilling nature to attain destiny."* Yet here, an additional turn is made upon destiny, directly merging with the great Dao of celestial immortality.

The *Dian Mo* distills its essence in *"refining oneness and holding to the center,"* while Zuo Qiuming, though unmatched in literary brilliance and military strategy, never slackened in his pursuit of the supreme Way. Take, for instance, the passage *"Duke Zheng subdues Duan"*—their meeting in the tunnel, joyous and harmonious, seems to subdue the thunderous momentum of *Zhen* and return it to earth. Is this not a revelation of the *"earth-thunder Return, where Return reveals the heart of Heaven"* in its utmost subtlety?

As for the *Classic of Rites*, it originally included the *Doctrine of the Mean* and the *Great Learning*, forming the beginning and end of the Confucian path—akin to the true precepts of celestial immortality. Beyond these, the schools of Zhuangzi and Liezi, though each expounding the wonders of the Dao, give rise to even greater abuses. The learning of the Han was mired in legalism; that of the Jin was obscured by emptiness. By the Six Dynasties, it had skewed toward doctrines of karmic retribution and merit. In the Tang, though some sought to grasp the essentials of the Dao, only Han Yu championed the school of nature and principle, yet he too faced slander and praise, his heart burdened.

Later, in the Song, Neo-Confucianism flourished, with Zhu Xi and Cheng Yi rising in succession, and the sagely learning prospered. Yet each established their own sect, claiming exclusive mastery. Su Shi, however, did not align himself with the school of nature and principle, yet in his prose and poetry, he often revealed glimpses of truth—*"like the passing of time, never ceasing; like the waxing and waning of the moon, never truly increasing or diminishing."* Does this not harmonize with the *"no going, no coming, the wondrous union of thusness"*? He also said: *"My writing flows like a ten-thousand-gallon spring, moving where it must, stopping where it must."* And: *"A true inkstone does not wear out; a true hand endures."* Here, not only is the firing process made clear, but the attainment of true purity is also achieved. Is this not the work of an intentional master?

Take Huang Gongwang, who painted all day, yet suddenly attained the Dao and achieved immortality upon the rocks of Hupao. Without adhering to any sect, he accomplished this—his lifelong effort lay in unwavering balance. Thus, the gentleman applies himself to the utmost in all things, and how great is this principle! The Four Books merely elucidate the principle of this utmost application—what else could there be?

Confucius said: *"Grant me a few more years, and at fifty I will study the *Yi*, that I may have no great faults."* What are these *"great faults"*? What is this *"fifty"*? Even for one as learned as Confucius, why would he seek additional years to study and avoid great faults? Is it not because, in the realm of *"fulfilling nature and attaining destiny,"* there remains a critical point? This is precisely what is meant by *"nature preserves life, life sustains existence, and existence fulfills longevity."*

Nowadays, those who discourse on principle first erect barriers to refute others, while those who delve into the wonders of the Dao dismiss Neo-Confucianism as trivial. Both err and persist in their errors until death. This *Dialogues* is composed out of pity for them, merely to open the essential passages.

As for the *"embodiment that can be perfected"*—the great Dao of the golden elixir—how could its application fail to govern the self, the family, and the world? Its key lies in the most subtle and critical subtleties, comparable to the two volumes of the *Huangting Jing* and the five thousand characters of the *Daode Jing*.

I humbly present this for your esteemed review and further await your teachings.

Your disciple from beyond the seas, Xie Laiyi, bows a hundred times in respect.

**Illuminating the Subtleties of the *Huanyuan Pian***
**Preface to *Immortal Studies of the Huanyuan Pian***

Can immortals be studied? Immortals cannot be studied. For the traces of immortals are like clouds unfurling and rolling—one cannot grasp the void to fix their rank. Clouds act without intention, while immortals leave behind writings—writings are traces.

Yet why can they not be studied? The Lord of Wood and the Queen Mother of Metal existed before Heaven and Earth—their traces are remote. As for the transmission of the Dao and virtue, it divides into Northern and Southern lineages. Only the Southern School has left writings for posterity. Thus, Patriarch Ziyang first composed the *Awakening to Reality*, and Master Qiongguan further enriched its elegance.

In my leisure, I have perused the classics, pondered deeply, and sought those who grasped Master Qiongguan’s heart and traced the Dao of Ziyang. Only Zhu Yuanyang’s *Illuminating the Obscure in Awakening to Reality* fits this criterion.

The Master Zimin, having received the heart-seal of the Perfected One of Great Void, annotated the *Returning to the Source* of the Two Patriarchs of Apricot Grove—nothing was left unelucidated, and all was made perfect, a truly excellent work. Yet I regret that I never entered the inner chamber to receive direct instruction, and thus could not wrest the untransmitted truth from between the lines or beyond the words. Now the Master has already withdrawn into the mountain of the Dao, leaving me with one lifelong regret.

For the art of the Golden Elixir, when speaking of its essence, it is one—yet even the character "one" is superfluous. When speaking of its subtleties, even three thousand three hundred are too few. Layer upon layer, curve upon curve, it cannot be grasped like a model calligraphy to be traced and tested. I recall when my teacher manifested transformation, a spirit came to announce: *"Take clarity, stillness, and naturalness as the method of practice."* These seven characters are the words of Master Qiongguan, and they form the great purport of *Elucidating the Subtle*. He revealed them with utmost sincerity—how truly compassionate my teacher was!

From now on, if I uphold this golden needle, I may perhaps avoid great error. This compilation was completed by my teacher after three years of revision, distilling the profound and extracting the essential, with punctuation meticulously arranged. Unwilling to keep it hidden in a box, he made it public for all. May those of wise hearts in the world and for ten thousand generations, within the Great Void, pluck a single petal from Apricot Grove—not seeking it through traces—thus fulfilling my teacher’s wish.

I have also heard that the original compilation by Great Void included eulogies of the Apricot Grove lineage, which were later carved into stone images as supplements. Here, I have selected biographies from *The Heart Lamp of Golden Canopy*, along with the eulogy of the Great Void image revered by my teacher, and appended them. Without presumption, I have also included the master’s biography written by Master Tang, along with portraits and eulogies, compiling them into *Investigations of the Immortals*. The main text, *Elucidating the Subtle*, entirely follows the style of Zhu Yuanyang’s *Illuminating the Obscure in Awakening to Reality*—I dared not alter it in the slightest, only adding these few pages at the beginning. Thus, those who read this book may first see the person, comforting the high mountain of admiration from all directions. It is not merely an antiquarian’s heart seeking ancient texts, nor speaking of dreams to the blue sky, but rather continuing the midnight lamp of Golden Peak.

Respectfully composed on the third day of the third lunar month in the eighteenth year of the Daoguang reign, by Cai Yangni, attendant of Golden Canopy, after washing hands and offering incense.

---
**Biography of the Perfected One of Apricot Grove**

The Perfected One’s surname was Shi, given name Tai, courtesy name Dezhi, and he was a native of Apricot Grove Post Station in Fufeng County, Fengxiang Prefecture. During the Xining era of the Song, the Perfected One Zhang Pingshu encountered an extraordinary person at Tianhui Temple in Chengdu, who transmitted to him the secrets of the Golden Elixir’s medicinal substances and firing times. He admonished: *"One day, if you meet someone who has escaped the snares of the world, pass this on to them."* Later, due to reckless transmission, Zhang incurred punishment. The prefect of Fengzhou, enraged, sentenced him to penal servitude and facial tattooing.

The exiled Zhang passed through Bin’s territory amid falling snow and drank with his guards at a village tavern. The Perfected One happened by and saw the group merry, though Zhang had yet to take his cup. He invited Zhang to join the table, and as the wine flowed freely, learning of his plight, the Perfected One reflected: *"The governor of Bin is an old friend—he delights in virtue and forgets rank."* Zhang replied: *"If you could deign to visit him, there may be cause to spare me this journey."* He earnestly entreated the guards, who consented. Together they went to Bin, where the Perfected One interceded on his behalf, securing his pardon. Zhang, moved by gratitude, declared: *"To leave such kindness unrepaid would be no man at all! Moreover, I once received a prophecy."* Thereupon he transmitted to him the essential teachings of the elixir’s method, simple yet profound. The Perfected One cultivated accordingly and attained the Dao, composing the *Returning to the Source* which circulated in the world. He came to be known as the Second Patriarch of the Southern Lineage.

**Later Disciple of the Dragon Gate, Shen Yibing, respectfully compiled.**

**Biography of the Master of Supreme Emptiness**

The Master’s surname was Shen, given name Yibing, courtesy name Zhenyang, also styled Guyin, with the sobriquet Light Cloud Daoist, and posthumous name Master of Supreme Emptiness. At birth, he bore a line of script on his palm reading: *"Sovereign of Supreme Emptiness."* Orphaned young and impoverished, he herded sheep while studying. A certain teacher, taking pity, approached him and expounded the passage on the tattered robe. Hearing this, he rejoiced, saying: *"A man of resolve should be thus."*

Again, upon reaching the passage where Yanzi inquired about benevolence, he remarked: *"I too shall follow these Four Abstentions—perhaps the mark of a true gentleman."* At sixteen, he encountered the ancient immortal Li Nianwu at the foot of Jin’gai Mountain. Their discourse extended through the night, after which he withdrew to the Golden Drum Grotto in Wulin, becoming a disciple of Master Dongli under Zigao. His lineage master then bestowed upon him the name Tingyun.

Master Dai, a precept-master, was a brother to Zigao. He transmitted the Three Great Precepts, and the Master sought the Dao on Gaochi and Mount Hua, where the Perfected Bei Changji also imparted to him the essential teachings. The Master’s preferences and aspirations differed from others’, and even his fellow practitioners could not fathom his depths. Yet one saw him seated like a corpse, standing like one in vigil, his presence solemn from afar, warm upon approach. To young and old alike, he showed reverence as to guests. For decades, he never once slackened—such was the *"reverent yet at ease"* demeanor embodied in the Master.

Once, he paid homage at Qufu and obtained a branch from the scholar-tree planted by the Master Kong. He carved it into a cap and wore it. Alas! Truly the orthodox Confucian immortal of the Dragon Gate lineage!

As for praying for rain at Gucheng, beseeching clear skies at the Prefectural Office, summoning snow at Qiantang, capturing foxes at Qingpu, taming tigers on Zhongnan, and domesticating wolves on Taibai—these were all matters the Master undertook out of necessity, not feats to be marveled at as supernatural powers.

Initially, his mother, Madame Qian, had prayed for an heir at Kaihua Monastery in Gui’an, and so in his later years, he repaired and resided there. When he passed away, celestial music sounded softly, heard by all in the neighboring villages. He lived seventy-nine years and was buried at Jinshu Flat on Mount Dadi.

Though I share the same hometown and master, and later became his disciple, I regret that in my middle years, official duties kept me from receiving his direct teachings or glimpsing the profound depths of his wisdom. Yet in dreams, as if from beyond the cooking-pot and wall, he seemed to come and instruct me. Truly, the Master’s depths cannot be fathomed!

In life, he was utterly sincere and unadorned, meticulous and pure, never complacent, and only ceased when he let go entirely—this, then, was how the Master spiritually realized the Great Void!

The Master left no writings. When asked why, he replied: *"Lest I be ridiculed by the wheelwright."* His hand-annotated books have all vanished like stars, save for *The Return to the Source*, to which he prefixed this poem:

*A myriad alchemical classics converge in one nature’s school,*
*Peaceful heart and clear spirit are the primal work.*
*Beware the flames of the elixir furnace,*
*Forced refinement lacks the perfection of the Dao.*

On the last ten days of the tenth lunar month in the bingwu year of the Qianlong reign, his disciple Min Yide, of the same lineage, respectfully composed this.

*(Appendix: The original teaching makes no distinction between men and women—so long as the furnace is complete and the elixir ripe, the Governing and Conception Vessels merge, and within the cinnabar field, a radiant pearl appears as proof. Test this on a dark night: close your eyes, lower the lids, and it will shine like the bright moon. As *The Awakening to Reality* says:
*"To keep the Valley Spirit from ever dying,*
*Root yourself in the Mysterious Female’s gate.*
*When true gold returns to the golden chamber,*
*A single luminous pearl will never depart."*
And again:
*"Lead the White Tiger home to nurture,*
*And bear a bright pearl round as the moon."*
Regardless of gender, all may witness this vision.)*

**The Life of the Hermit of Golden Canopy Mountain**

At the foot of Golden Canopy Mountain in western Zhejiang, there lived a hermit. His speech was halting, his conduct measured, and none could fathom his depths. I heard from Scholar Cai that the hermit hailed from a distinguished family of Wuxing. In his youth, he suffered from an ailment that impaired his movement, but he was cured under the guidance of Master Gao Dongli of Tongbai, and thus received the Dragon Gate name "Yide." Returning to Golden Canopy Mountain, he found the site of his ancestor’s hermitage and restored it as his dwelling. The place was secluded and serene, with bamboo shadows and the murmur of springs, allowing him to cultivate his will in leisure and radiate a luminous spirit.

There was an eccentric named Shen Taixu, also a disciple of the same master, whose cultivation ran even deeper. He wandered to the mountain, and the hermit received his transmission, wishing to follow him as a cloud or flowing water—but family obligations held him back. The hermit was skilled in literature and extraordinary in numerology. After a brief sojourn in southern Yunnan, he returned upon his parents’ passing and devoted himself entirely to the study of nature and destiny, remaining in the mountains for forty years.

Pearlescent radiance and sword-like qi naturally set one apart in taste and inclination. From ancient times to the present, many have stood out among the multitudes—such as Jin Huaihuai, Bai Ma Li, Li Pengtou, Wang Xiuhu, and the Old Man of Chicken Foot Mountain—all Dragon Gate Daoists who gathered in white-robed camaraderie, their gatherings at Golden Peak a splendid sight. The hermit once told Scholar Cai: "These figures are revered across the four seas, yet none can match them. But when their names are mentioned alongside Taixu, they too seem distant and unattainable. Why? Because Taixu embodied the purity of heaven, which cannot be sought in the Red Waters. It is only regrettable that his transmission was not fully realized." He instructed Scholar Cai in the learning of progressing from near to far, his words plain yet profound.

I have always marveled at the hermit’s deep-rooted learning, his measured conduct, and his boundless potential. Yet one day, he passed away suddenly—was this a display of disillusionment, or did he have another purpose? The hermit left behind many writings. Scholar Cai selected his final work, *Returning to the Source*, still bearing the traces of his hand, and wished to place it at the forefront to present to the world. Weeping, he entreated: "Though unworthy, I once received your teachings at Golden Canopy. Now Golden Canopy lies in ruins, and none in the four seas know of it. The hermit had many friends among the clouds and mist. I beg you to compose a text to immortalize his legacy."

I smiled and said: "I, too, am a hermit. To write of a hermit as a hermit should not invite the mockery of the green mountains. Yet as I remain in seclusion, my writing must suffice." I record your words here to briefly convey the hermit’s life.

The hermit’s surname was Min, his given name Tiaofu, his courtesy name Buzhi, and his sobriquet Xiaogen. A native of Wuxing, he lived to eighty-nine and was buried on Golden Canopy Mountain, where his disciples built a shrine in his honor.

Composed with reverence on the fifteenth day of the second month in the eighteenth year of the Daoguang reign by Tang Zhisu, the Daoist of Western Mountain.

**Preface to *Returning to the Source***

From my youth, I admired the true teaching and traversed sacred landscapes, seeking the transmission of the orthodox Dao. My aspiration was to benefit the world, and I focused on preserving the Three Treasures, with particular emphasis on nurturing life. As the ancients said: "Deluded clouds veil the moon of wisdom; karmic winds stir the sea of stillness." This means that attaining immortality is easy, yet people make it difficult; transcending the mundane is not hard, yet people find it so—how lamentable!

Years ago, at a post station, I encountered the Perfected Zhang of Purple Yang. With a single phrase, simple and concise, the effects of verification appeared in an instant. I knew then that immortality could be learned and rejoiced inwardly. When the golden liquid coalesced and the sacred embryo formed, I composed *Returning to the Source* in eighty-one chapters of five-character quatrains to instruct later learners. Awaken early to the true trap, lest in old age, when lead is depleted and mercury scarce, you regret not having acted sooner. Seek a master, inquire into the Dao, refine the golden elixir, ascend the immortal ranks, and attain transformation and flight—this is my sincere hope.

Prefaced by Shi Tai of Apricot Grove.

**Returning to the Source**

Lead and mercury form the true body,
Yin and yang unite in the Great Primal.
Simply know the practice of two eights,
And you may refine the golden elixir.

Mercury is the marrow of the Green Dragon,
Lead is the fat of the White Tiger.
Gather them into the crucible,
Harvesting them at the right time.

The Maiden rides the lead tiger,
The Metal Elder mounts the mercury dragon.
With the clarity of jia and geng’s decree,
Refine them into a furnace of red.

The serpent’s soul captures the dragon’s marrow,
The tortoise’s spirit restrains the tiger’s essence.
Within the divine pool’s sacred water,
A blossom of jade fat emerges.

White snow flies in the jasper garden,
Yellow sprouts bloom in the jade orchard.
As long as you resemble the crescent moon,
Where can you not refine the red lead?

The medicinal ingredients open the primordial chaos,
The fire times temper the vast expanse.
After ten months, the immortal embryo transforms,
And you will know the merit of the nine revolutions.

The dragon guards the pearl’s hiding place,
The rooster broods at the egg’s hour.
Who knows that when lead and mercury merge,
One may drink the elixir’s measure?

Bathing relies on the water of Kun,
Breathing depends on the wind of Xun.
The infant has no concerns,
Dwelling alone in the Palace of Great Tenuity.

Seek the Maiden of Li in the Purple Court,
Pair the Man of Kan with the Crimson Mound.
Where the Yellow Dame mediates,
The Supreme Ultimate naturally embraces the Three.

The Qian horse enters the golden gate,
The Kun ox enters the wooden palace.
Who will lead the Maiden,
To wed the Metal Elder?

The Maiden is just sixteen,
The Metal Elder is precisely twenty-seven.
In the bridal chamber, auspicious qi arises,
Their joyous union produces the first son.

Last night on the western riverbank,
The toad’s light illuminated the azure waves.
Gathered and returned to the jade chamber,
The crucible refines it day and night.

Li and Kan need not copulate,
Qian and Kun naturally give birth.
If one can grasp this principle,
A single point falls into the Yellow Court.

The Elixir Valley generates divine water,
The Yellow Court holds the Great Granary.
Without thoughts of hunger or thirst,
One enters the immortal realm directly.

The horse of intention returns to the spirit chamber,
The monkey of the heart guards the grotto.
Spirit, essence, soul, and intent,
Transform into purple gold frost.

One aperture connects the three passes,
The three passes are the key pathways.
Suddenly, with light movement,
The divine water circulates on its own.

Restraining the po is not by the heart’s restraint,
Binding the hun is not by the will’s binding.
Only retain spirit and qi,
In a moment they coalesce into the Mysterious Pearl.

The oral instructions are few,
The elixir’s refinement lies in a fleeting instant.
Gently conduct the fire times,
In ten months the infant is born.

Husband and wife first unite in joy,
As years deepen, their affection grows more profound.
The bridal chamber generates auspicious qi,
No day without the spring breeze.
Sudden rain, paper butterflies,
Golden furnace, jade peonies.
At midnight the red mouth blazes,
In the sixth month white frost chills.

From the sea’s depths golden fire flies,
At the mountain’s peak earthly springs flow.
In a moment their union is complete,
The jade crucible emits azure smoke.
Breach the Gate of Primordial Mystery,
Break open the Barrier of Chaos.
Simply know how to refine water and fire,
Let the tiger and dragon coil as they will.

The fire within the Sākaṭa’s water,
The waves upon Kunlun’s summit.
Who can comprehend their operation?
The great essence lies with the Yellow Dame.

The medicine is drawn from prenatal qi,
The fire seeks the Taiyi’s essence.
If one knows how to take the medicine and seek the fire,
Within the cauldron the elixir’s completion is seen.

How is primordial qi to be ingested?
True essence need not be moved.
True essence and primordial qi,
These are the foundation of the Great Elixir.

Confucians clarify nature and principle,
Buddhists strike at empty obstinacy.
Unacquainted with the immortal arts,
The golden elixir’s work is momentary.

Mercury in the crescent moon furnace,
Lead within the cinnabar crucible.
The tortoise and serpent are the true unified qi,
Their product lies in the prenatal.

Seek the crescent and dark moon,
Withdraw and add like waxing and waning.
Unknowing of true creation,
What thing is true lead?

Qi is the life within form,
The heart is the spirit within nature.
If one knows the cavity of spirit and qi,
One is already an immortal.

Wood marrow refines the golden crucible,
Spring flows fill the jade furnace.
Who would spend three hundred days,
Idly applying effort?

The jade crucible refines lead’s liquid,
The golden furnace nurtures mercury’s essence.
Nine returns become nine revolutions,
Warm cultivation follows the stars’ cycle.

Jade liquid nourishes the spirit chamber,
The golden embryo forms the qi’s pivot.
Only seek the medicine within the body,
No need to consult elixir texts.

The fire jujube originally has no pit,
The intercourse pear has no dregs.
All day conduct the fire times,
Divine water irrigates the golden flower.

Refining qi is but exerting force,
Preserving spirit is merely applying effort.
How could one know the elixir’s wondrous secret?
All day contemplating true emptiness.

To refine prenatal qi,
First dry the living mercury.
Once the sacred embryo is formed,
Breaking through the crown, thunder is heard.

Qi’s production is not tied to the kidneys,
Spirit’s dwelling is not in the heart.
Qi and spirit are hard to grasp,
Transforming into a mass of gold.

One aperture is called Mysterious Female,
Within it are stored qi and spirit.
Who knows this aperture?
Seek no truth outside.

The spleen and stomach are not the spirit chamber,
The bladder is but the kidneys’ surplus.
I urge you, do not cling to these,
This is not the ladder to the elixir.

A thousand verses of inner visions,
A cup of Central Yellow wine.
Carefree, unburdened by things,
Beyond the body lies heaven and earth.

Sun and moon mutually refine,
Tortoise and serpent naturally entwine.
Transformed into a single elixir grain,
Warmly cultivated into an embryonic immortal.

All things born must die,
The primordial spirit dies and revives.
When spirit returns to the qi’s cavity,
The Dao of the elixir naturally completes.

Where spirit and qi return to their root,
Body and mind restore their mandate.
Such is the true aperture,
Few indeed know it.

Within the body lies the Mysterious Female,
Within the heart no dust or defilement.
Who can comprehend and recognize it?
Within one aperture lies the truth.

Li and Kan are the true dragon and tiger,
Qian and Kun are the proper horse and ox.
Every person possesses them fully,
Yet why do they not know to cultivate?

The hun and po govern the heart,
Spirit and essence are enveloped by intent.
Steadily conduct the fire times,
Silently move the initial line.

Below the heart, above the kidneys,
West of the liver, left of the lungs.
Neither intestines nor stomach,
A single qi flows through on its own.

The wondrous function is not tied to intent,
The true mechanism requires no time.
Who can know this aperture?
Do not idly practice non-action.

There is something, yet not nothing,
Non-action unites with action.
The power of transformation returns to one’s hand,
Sun and moon congeal golden fat.

The tiger roars on the western mountain,
The dragon intones east of the northern sea.
Capture them—wild battle is needed,
Entrust them to the Gen and Kun palaces.

Fu and Gou govern brightness and darkness,
Zhun and Meng align with dawn and dusk.
The elixir furnace congeals white snow,
Nowhere to find the monkey’s heart.

Black mercury sprouts yellow leaves,
Red lead blooms purple flowers.
Further conduct the fire times,
Within the crucible the cinnabar forms.

Guard against the rabbit in wood’s liquid,
The rooster is more to be feared in metal’s essence.
Withdraw and add during bathing,
Precisely when the moon is full.

The myriad pipes stir as the wind rises,
A thousand mountains hold the moon round.
Hasten to issue the correct command,
Then the celestial circuit may be set in motion.

Distinguish the medicine’s age and tenderness,
Apply the fire times with withdrawal and addition.
A single elixir’s light arises,
The cold toad shines upon the jade eaves.

The clam’s belly once split for its pearl,
The hen’s nest is easy to find for its egg.
From nothing something is born,
Spirit and qi naturally intermingle.

Spirit and qi are not mother and child,
Body and mind are not husband and wife.
Simply align with heaven’s mechanism,
Who recognizes where the elixir coalesces?

When the elixir’s head first forms,
As the medicine congeals,
Dragon and tiger battle fiercely,
The Eastern Lord knows nothing of it.

Side doors and minor methods,
Strange arts and idle words—
The golden liquid’s returning elixir secret
Has no second gate.

Noble and base, high and low,
Husbands and wives, brothers—
If one has the destiny to cultivate immortality,
All may study the elixir classics.

A house in disrepair is easily repaired,
When the medicine withers, its growth is not difficult.
Simply know the method of return and revival,
Gold and treasure will accumulate like mountains.

The hun and po form the three natures,
Spirit and essence harmonize the five phases.
Within them the four images are distinguished,
Gathered and clustered to form the embryo’s essence.

Steadfastly seek lead and mercury,
With a calm heart seek earth and metal.
Only then know the true one aperture,
Who comprehends this profound mystery?

Creation has no root or stem,
Yin and yang have their origin.
These true wondrous points,
Not even father and son transmit.

Leave mercury in the golden crucible,
Place lead into the jade pool.
Host and guest have no left or right,
Only recognize the infant.

The Yellow Dame’s twin breasts are fair,
Elder Ding’s heart is compassionate.
Warm cultivation has no other art,
From nothing the child is nurtured.

The phoenix soars through the jade gate,
The jade toad is nurtured in the cinnabar field.
Within the gourd, heaven knows no night,
White snow falls delicately.

---

After the zither and lute harmonize,
The family legacy is fulfilled in its time.
No need to regulate fire and timing,
Lest the infant be harmed.

The eldest son has just entered *duì*,
The youngest daughter then returns to *qián*.
The *xùn* palace and earthly position,
The celestial cycle seals itself.

Between the after-string and before-string,
At the moon’s fullness and waning.
Withdraw and replenish, mirroring punishment and virtue,
Bathe according to waxing and waning.

Old mercury, three catties of white,
True lead, a single point of red.
Seize the marrow of heaven and earth,
In a moment of union.

Where fire and timing penetrate the mystery,
Who through the ages would dare transmit this?
Before knowing how to gather and refine,
Do not ask of the celestial cycle.

Clouds disperse, the crabapple moon,
Spring deepens, the willow wind.
Who understands this meaning?
Raising one’s gaze, one questions the void.

In the human realm, no burdens remain,
In heaven, there are immortal steps.
Already able to ride the clouds,
Together they come with white cranes.

The field of the heart knows no weeds,
The ground of nature is free from dust.
In the quiet of night, beneath the bright moon,
A single spring bird sings.

White metal is refined through the six trigrams,
Black tin passes through the orchid gate.
At midnight’s third watch,
The golden crow enters the vast cold.

The elixir ripens, no dragon or tiger,
Fire concludes, the body is mercury and lead.
Having shed the embryo, already spiritually transformed,
One becomes an immortal of Jade Clarity.

The path to the Yellow Springs is sealed,
The gates of the Purple Palace are breached.
How does Hai Shan’s disciple,
Transform into a crane, emerging from the mud pill?

To which do rivers and seas return?
To whom do mountains and cliffs belong?
Once the golden elixir is ripe,
All becomes treasure within the chamber.

Lü received the oral transmission from Zhong,
Ge passed the heart-to-heart teaching to Zheng.
No idle words remain,
All returns to mercury and lead.

Mercury and lead unite in one crucible,
Sun and moon must share the same furnace.
Advance the fire with caution,
That you may congeal the jade nectar.

Gather the medicine and unite,
Advance the fire and bathe.
When it comes time to shed the embryo,
The yang number of ninety-nine is complete.

**Postscript to the *Returning to the Source***

Those who refine the golden elixir must know:
The winter solstice does not occur at the *zǐ* hour,
Bathing is not confined to *mǎo* and *yǒu*.
Mercury and lead are neither saliva, essence, fluids, nor blood.

Seven returns mean returning to the root,
Nine reversions mean reverting to the source.
When metal essence and wood liquid meet earth, they unite;
Dragon and tiger, horse and ox—all are without form.

The "essential of the golden elixir lies in the divine water of the flower pool,"
As the former master’s *Waking to Reality* states—this refers to lead and mercury.
If one knows the source of lead,
Then one knows where mercury is produced.

Once lead and mercury are known,
Then the divine water of the flower pool is known.
Once the divine water of the flower pool is known,
Then the golden elixir can be refined.

The golden elixir’s work is accomplished in an instant;
Do not cling to the schedule of nine years or three.
Do not rigidly adhere to years, months, days, or hours in practice.
As Zhongli said, "The four great elements of the body are all yin."
Thus, one cannot seek within the body,
But must seek the single yang essence within.

Yet this yang essence resides in one aperture,
Beyond the conjecture of ordinary people.
This aperture is the gate of the mysterious female,
The very divine water of the flower pool.

Knowing this, one can gather and refine,
Then unite, followed by refinement,
Bathing, and finally the separation of the embryo,
Which must then be nurtured.

Once the elixir is complete,
How can one not discern the river’s source,
Know the weight, or recognize the time?

Since receiving the teachings from my master,
I have known this body cannot die,
And that this elixir must be achievable.
Now that the great work is underway,
I proclaim this to future seekers of immortality.

*Written by Shi Tai of Apricot Grove, with this postscript.*

**Preface to the *Elucidation of Returning to the Source***

It has been over forty years since I returned to the mountains.
For the first twenty, I devoted myself to introspection,
Yet dared not commit the great Dao inherited from my former master to writing,
Fearing it might deviate from the true essence.

In the year *jiǎwǔ* of the Jiaqing era, after three years in the alchemical circle,
My learning and cultivation gradually matured,
And I began to grasp the subtle meanings of scriptures and mantras.
Later, by the riverside, I engaged in discussions with fellow practitioners,
Recording our exchanges in a volume.

Since then, seekers of the Dao from near and far,
Some bearing their masters’ teachings, others relying on their own texts,
Have visited me.
In leisure, I corrected their errors on the spot,
And these were later compiled and printed by my disciples,
Mostly tailored to individuals and circumstances,
To clarify their thoughts and dispel their misconceptions.

Only the lineage of the heavenly immortal’s heart transmission
Has broken free from the conventions of alchemical schools.
I have compiled my own verified methods into a volume,
Hoping to enlighten learners.

Yet few practitioners ground themselves in reality,
Or conceal their spirit in secrecy.
Some sigh in despair, others feign satiety with painted cakes.
Even if they grasp the semblance, they still lose the truth—
How lamentable!

The year before last, I meticulously revised
Master Li of Hengyang’s alchemical writings,
To establish the sequence of elixir refinement,
That one may progress step by step,
From action to non-action.

Yet I remained constrained by the original text,
Failing to clearly expound the initial methods,
And my heart was not yet satisfied.

This year, in the summer of *yǐwèi*,
I brought my grandnephew Yanglin
To the home of Qu, the provincial examiner in Jinling,
Where we discussed the learning of body, heart, nature, and destiny from dawn to dusk.
Thus, I dared to presume,
And, drawing from what I had heard from my former master,
Interpreted Shi’s *Returning to the Source*,
Elucidating the origin of human life,
Following the sequence of steps to return and revert,
Taking the transformation of temperament as the initial practice,
And the restoration of life and nature to unity as the ultimate Dao.

I began the lecture by emphasizing the primacy of the correct thought,
And concluded with nurturing the formless as the proper end.
The steps within are precise and detailed,
Slightly illuminating the simple methods of Master Shi.

Yanglin transcribed these into a volume,
Which I titled *Elucidation of Returning to the Source*,
To expound its pure, subtle, and profound teachings.

For this, I extract only the oral formulas of the elixir-method’s sequence, taking merely the four words "clarity and stillness, lead and mercury." Before attainment, take clarity and stillness as the essence and guard lead and mercury as the function. At the moment of practice, gather lead and mercury as the medicinal material and employ clarity and stillness as the firing times. After attainment, hold clarity and stillness as the host with reverence, and treat lead and mercury as the guest with solemnity. Upon full attainment, take the mind of clarity and stillness as the vast vow, and let the qi of lead and mercury rest to ascend the great harmony. Thus and no more.

What Daoists call "clarity and stillness, lead and mercury" is precisely what Confucius termed "purity, stillness, subtlety, and profundity." Therefore, I further interpret this compilation as follows: the unification of the seven apertures is called *clarity*; the return of the seven apertures to unity is called *stillness*; the arising of qi within the body is called *lead*; the coming of essence within the heart is called *mercury*; selflessness and non-action are called *essence*; knowing the future and concealing the past are called *function*; meeting in time and gathering together are called *medicinal material*; withdrawing to refine and smelt is called *firing times*; illuminating the correct mandate is called *host*; nurturing the formless is called *guest*; the vast stabilization of nature’s light is called *mind*; and true emptiness without obstruction is called *qi*.

This is the ultimate achievement of Dao-learning, the consummate skill of former masters—all is exhausted in what lies within oneself. From beginning to end, there is no other artifice. That it becomes spiritually luminous depends upon the person.

At the outset of this volume, I have added annotations and punctuation to serve as evidence for those of like mind. On the fifth day of the fifth month in the year *yǐwèi* of the Daoguang era, Min Yide of the Small-Gen Studio, eleventh-generation successor of the Longmen Orthodox Lineage, respectfully inscribed this at the Hanxu Chamber in Jinling.

*Elucidating the Subtleties of the "Returning to the Source"*
Oral transmission by Min Yide, eleventh-generation successor of the Northern Lineage Longmen, recorded and edited by disciples Min Yanglin and Cai Yangni

The *Eighty-One Chapters of "Returning to the Source"* was composed by Shi Zhenren of Apricot Grove. A disciple of Master Zhang Ziyang, Shi was the second patriarch of the Southern Lineage. Moved by the plight of those who study books in search of the Dao yet fail to awaken to their own essence, he wrote this text to reiterate and clarify the Way of returning to the source.

The method of returning to the source begins with firmly upholding right mindfulness. In the daily practice of ethical relations, one must everywhere restrain anger and curb desires, acting with sincerity and without pretense—this is *refining the self*. Quietly applying effort to purify thoughts and forget emotions, one dredges and opens the Governing, Conception, and third passes, then retreats into solitude through vigilant self-discipline—this is *laying the foundation*. Naturally, a single point of true yang qi emerges within the body, and a single point of true yin essence flows forth from the heart. These intermingle and fuse, congealing into the elixir—this is the *elixir’s beginning*. From this point, the heart naturally preserves sincerity, and qi naturally circulates throughout. With time, the heart is concealed within the heart yet unseen, and qi is stored within qi yet unfathomable. In stillness, there is emptiness; in motion, there is directness—qi is refreshed, and spirit is clear—this is *completing the body*. Only when the three temporal realms are fully penetrated, all conditions are clarified, the six senses are purified, and the square inch of the heart is empty and luminous—only then, after a full month of unwavering practice, do the medicinal substances arrive ceaselessly. Throughout, one employs clarity and naturalness as the means of operation, thereby returning to the source, reverting to the root, and uniting with the Dao in truth—this is *perfecting the real*.

The essentials of the golden elixir are as such, yet the great key lies first in knowing the single aperture within the body before one can begin. This aperture is the window of spirit and brightness, the origin of nature and life. When scattered, it disperses into the seven apertures; when returned to its root, it coalesces into one. Only those who can constantly gather the body with the heart will know how to fathom principles to fulfill their nature. Only those who can constantly conceal the heart within the body will be able to fulfill their nature to realize their life. For the heart and body are the supports of nature and life, while nature and life are the root and stem of the heart and body. Essence and qi are the functions of the heart and body, while the heart and body are the repositories of spirit and qi. Thus, one who can gather the body’s qi with the heart will return spirit to the Celestial Valley, thereby fathoming principles to fulfill their nature. One who can conceal the heart’s spirit within the body will return qi to the Crimson Palace, thereby fulfilling their nature to realize their life. Only when principles are fathomed are desires purified; only when nature is fulfilled are emotions forgotten. With desires purified and emotions forgotten, nothing disturbs the center. I merely rest in the profound secrecy of life’s foundation, and suddenly the single aperture opens wide. Within it, one perceives emptiness without exhaustion, movement without depletion—responding to circumstances with transformation, following nature in all things. This is what the *Book of Documents* calls: “The mind of the Dao is subtle; only through refinement and unity can one truly hold to the center.” This is what the *Dao De Jing* refers to as: “The valley spirit does not die—this is called the mysterious female. The gate of the mysterious female is called the root of heaven and earth.” Having returned to the root, one restores life; restoring life is returning the elixir. Can one not trace the flow to know the source, thereby first returning to the moment of receiving qi at birth? Return to your origin, and the valley spirit will not die. Be vigilant at the beginning to preserve the end, and the golden elixir will surely be achieved.

Having received this text from my late teacher, Master Taixu, along with his guidance on the subtleties of superior-grade lead and mercury, I silently contemplated and dared not rashly interpret. Yet with a single word of enlightenment from my teacher, I suddenly awakened completely. The method of returning to the source, as revealed in the sequence of this text, encompasses all oral instructions—from gathering, conjoining, refining, and bathing to parting the embryo, warming and nurturing, elixir completion, and liberation—all of which repeatedly clarify the Way of returning to the source, exhausting the subtle to reach the vast. One who cultivates accordingly may enter the inner sanctum of sages and worthies, ascending the ladder to immortality and buddhahood. Now that the conditions are ripe, I respectfully honor my teacher’s intent by elucidating the subtleties of this text.

Here the author commands his grandnephew Yanglin to transcribe the following:

Lead and mercury form the true body,
Yin and yang conjoin in the Great Primal.

The teacher said: "Lead refers to the body, mercury to the heart. When they meet the Primal at the proper time, this is the supreme elixir Way."
My humble observation: At the moment of receiving qi before birth, a single aperture first forms within, containing essence, qi, and spirit—these three blend as one, nurturing and growing day and night within. By the tenth month, when the fetus is fully formed, a sudden cry splits the earth, and the Primal Aperture opens, connecting to the seven apertures, thus establishing breath.

Within the body, three valleys then emerge:
Above lies the Celestial Valley, Mud Pill Palace, the abode of spirit;
In the center lies the Responsive Valley, Crimson Palace, the abode of qi;
Below lies the Hollow Valley, Pass of Origin, later to become the abode of essence.
At this time, Primal Essence has already spread throughout the solid regions of the body and circulates; Primal Qi has gathered in the central valley, Crimson Palace, serving as the foundation of life; Primal Spirit then floats upward to the upper valley, Mud Pill Palace, serving as the seat of nature.

Presently, Primal Qi stirs and generates yang, beginning to flow into the lower valley, Pass of Origin, thus becoming essence—hence the lower valley is also called the Sea of Qi. Yet this essence remains Primal Essence, still circulating with qi throughout the body. At moments of extreme stillness, the seven apertures merge into one, and a single point of true yang qi rises within the body, ascending to pay homage to the Primal Spirit. In the elixir Way, this is called true lead, so the teacher identifies the body as lead.

Primal Spirit, in stillness, generates yin and likewise spreads into the central valley, Crimson Palace, becoming qi—hence the central valley is also called the Spirit Chamber. Yet this qi remains Primal Qi, still congealed with spirit, constantly producing fluid to nourish the heart. When yang stirs, the single aperture is about to divide into seven, and a single drop of true yin essence first flows from the heart to meet the yang qi. In the elixir Way, this is called true mercury, so the teacher identifies the heart as mercury.

When lead qi circulates with mercury essence, the physical form matures—thus it is said, "Lead and mercury form the true body."
When yin essence ascends with yang qi, the Primal Spirit congeals—thus it is said, "Yin and yang conjoin in the Great Primal."
In truth, lead refers to the qi within the body, and mercury to the essence within the heart—these are the postnatal manifestations of the prenatal yang spirit and yin essence, symbolizing the hidden Qian and Kun within Kan and Li. Yin refers to the qi within the sea, and yang to the spirit within the chamber—these are the postnatal lead qi and mercury essence returning to the prenatal, symbolizing the postnatal Kan and Li reverting to Qian and Kun.

Simply by inverting Kan and Li, the postnatal returns to the prenatal: spirit then resides in the heart, symbolizing Qian, while qi adheres to the body, symbolizing Kun. Kun provides life, hence it is called "body"; Qian initiates existence, hence it is called "Primal." It is called the "true body" to clarify that the body has not yet leaked, remaining the body of the True One. It is called the "Great Primal" to clarify that the Primal has not yet dissipated, still bearing the Primal of the Supreme Ultimate. All this forms and congeals naturally at birth, requiring no deliberate effort.

This chapter establishes the fundamental principle, explicitly pointing to the origin and showing that the body formed by the congealing of essence and qi serves as the foundation of Primal Life, while the heart formed by the congealing of spirit and qi serves as the seat of Primal Nature. With body and heart attained, nature and life are complete; essence and qi daily flourish, and both medicine and fire are prepared. One need only return to the True One.

Knowing the practice of the two eights, one can refine the golden elixir. This means that when one attains this body, heart, nature, and life, spirit relies on the heart and belongs to Qian, while qi adheres to the body and belongs to Kun. If one can remain perpetually pure and still, the seven apertures long remain as one, like a single formed Supreme Ultimate. Nature and life have not yet leaked, resembling a golden elixir in solid form. One need only return to emptiness and unite with the Dao to merge with the True Primal—why employ deliberate cultivation or trouble with restoring nature and life?

Yet after birth, the seven apertures, already spiritually connected, cannot constantly return to the single aperture. Thus, the primordial chaos is shattered into knowledge, and knowledge in turn becomes consciousness. From this, the heart is stirred by external things, developing likes and dislikes, while the body encounters external things, generating joy and anger. The essence within the heart, drawn by external objects, no longer obeys the governance of Primal Nature, constantly chasing outward and failing to nourish the heart. Primal Nature, having no place to reside, thus sinks. The Primal Spirit, previously symbolizing Qian, now becomes hollow and transforms into Li.

The qi within the body, shaken by yin essence, no longer circulates in accordance with Primal Life, constantly leaking outward and failing to fill the body. Primal Life, lacking sufficient foundation, daily diminishes. The Primal Qi, previously symbolizing Kun, now becomes solid and transforms into Kan. The Primal Spirit was originally solid, but by constantly chasing qi, it daily becomes more hollow. The Primal Qi was originally hollow, but by constantly flowing into essence, it reverses and appears solid. Ultimately, the hollow becomes ever more hollow, and the solid loses its solidity, leading to the miseries of aging, illness, death, and suffering.

This is not due to any flaw in the origin itself, but to the harm of the root chasing the branches and the source becoming the flow. Spirit loses its solidity, so the heart transforms into Li; qi loses its hollowness, so the body transforms into Kan. Thus, the single point of yang within the postnatal Kan body is the Primal Qi of the prenatal, symbolizing fire within water in the trigrams—hence it is called yang qi. The single point of yin within the postnatal Li heart is the Primal Spirit of the prenatal, symbolizing water within fire in the trigrams—hence it is called yin essence.

The "two eights" refer to the symbolic numbers within the trigrams. Kan water is already formed water, numbered six in earth; the fire within water is newly born fire, numbered two in earth. Six and two both belong to earth, forming one eight within earth—this is the Primal Qi of the prenatal emerging from within the body, metaphorically called lead.

Li fire is already formed fire, numbered seven in heaven; the water within fire is newly born water, numbered one in heaven. Seven and one both belong to heaven, forming one eight within heaven—this is the Primal Spirit of the prenatal emerging from within the heart, metaphorically called mercury.

Thus, whenever speaking of medicine or fire, one must refer to them as the "two eights," and no other numbers may be used. To "practice the two eights" is precisely the Dao of "timely meeting the origin" as the master has said, employing only pure stillness and naturalness in its application.

Now, recognizing the abuses of its later developments and desiring to return to the original source, if one refuses to restrain anger and suppress desires, there will be absolutely no way to begin. If one wishes to have desires suppressed and anger restrained, and then practices the union of these two eights, then spirit becomes fire, and qi becomes medicine. When gathering, it is called medicine—still the postnatal yin essence and yang qi; when refining, it is called fire—now belonging to the prenatal, where spirit is yang and qi is again yin.

Simply knowing how to use spirit to guide qi is to use fire to refine medicine, which can then form the Great Return Elixir of Golden Liquor. The term "refining" inherently carries the meaning of guarding against danger and considering risks, and it too relies solely on pure stillness and naturalness in its application.

For the yang qi within our body, now just returning from the borrowed palace of the hollow valley, if not consolidated by spirit, this qi is precisely at risk of scattering. The yin essence within our heart, now just returning from the borrowed palace of the responding valley, if not circulated with qi, this essence remains in danger of being submerged.

Only by constantly establishing the substance of the Dao through tranquility can one obtain true lead and mercury as the functioning of the Dao. When lead and mercury, these two substances, meet the origin and coalesce into a single correct thought, immediately withdrawing and congealing into great stillness—where thought is without thought—then in that brief moment, they can coalesce, returning to the state at the beginning of receiving qi in this life!

Confucius said, "Essence and qi form things," does this not refer to the true body formed by the coagulation of lead and mercury? Laozi said, "There is a thing, undifferentiated and complete," does this not refer to the Great Origin of yin and yang coalesced? Master Zhang Ziyang said, "When the foundations of Kan and Li are grasped, the three realms return to one body," does this not refer to the pivotal method of practicing the two eights to refine the Golden Elixir?

Thus, lead and mercury are yin and yang; the union of yin and yang is the Great Origin; the Great Origin is the true body. The true body and Great Origin are the prenatal "one that is two"; when timely united, they become "two that is one." With this, one can suddenly awaken!

**Chapter One (conclusion)**
This entire passage serves as the guiding principle, revealing that body and heart, nature and life, spirit and qi, medicine and fire are all complete from the very beginning of existence. Thus, without fear of verbosity, it clearly annotates the original source of human life to facilitate the practitioner’s personal realization. The following eighty chapters are all annotations to this passage!

The next seven chapters systematically elucidate the methods of gathering, uniting, and refining. Chapters nine through fifteen teach the secrets of beginning practice. Chapters sixteen through twenty-four expound on the crucial openings, detailing the processes of refining, bathing, guarding against danger, considering risks, as well as embryo division, nurturing, and elixir formation.

Chapters twenty-five through forty-eight re-emphasize the central tenets, unfolding the true mechanism so that upon reading, all doubts dissolve. From chapters forty-nine to seventy-eight, it clearly teaches how postnatal essence and qi return to prenatal spirit and qi to form the Valley Spirit, then how the Valley Spirit is refined into yang spirit, and yang spirit is further refined back into original spirit, ultimately returning to the true state of Wuji to become a true person—this is merging with the Dao in truth.

The Golden Elixir’s completion directly reveals the intent of the ancient sages to thoroughly investigate principle, fully realize nature, and attain destiny, with earnest exhortations and meticulous step-by-step instructions. The final three chapters once again cite the heart-transmission of ancient sages, earnestly urging the necessary unity of spirit and qi, body and heart, nature and life, thereby summarizing the entire text’s meaning.

If scholars have indeed deeply cultivated self-refinement, focused their qi, unified their spirit, and uprightly held the singularly numinous and independent correct thought, then facing this passage, they will naturally find the method exceedingly simple and can immediately sit and advance in the Dao.

**Mercury is the Marrow of the Green Dragon**
The yin essence within the heart originally emerges from the root of nature. Here, calling it the marrow of the Green Dragon, alchemists use the Green Dragon to symbolize the hun-soul, which in the prenatal trigram positions belongs to Li in the east—hence Master Zhang refers to it as "the wood of the eastern hun." The prenatal hun-soul still resides within Qian and does not move; in the postnatal state, Qian’s center becomes hollow as Li, and the Li trigram, located in the south and belonging to fire, Master Zhang thus calls "the fire of the southern spirit."

Though the hun-soul is stored in the liver and still positioned in the east, its trigram has transformed into the moving image of Zhen, prone to anger, and its function relies on the heart to become spirit, for the heart is the abode of spirit. The yin essence now flowing from my heart originally arises from prenatal wood qi to become mercury. The previous chapter metaphorically called it water within fire, but in truth, it is the liquid of wood. Thus, it is called the marrow of the Green Dragon, indicating it requires refinement.

**Lead is the Fat of the White Tiger**
The yang qi within the body originally draws from the stem of life. Here, calling it the fat of the White Tiger, alchemists use the White Tiger to symbolize the po-soul, which in the prenatal trigram positions belongs to Kan in the west—hence Master Zhang refers to it as "the metal of the western po." The prenatal po-soul still lies hidden within Kun and has not yet manifested; in the postnatal state, Kun’s center becomes solid as Kan. The Kan trigram, located in the north and belonging to water, Master Zhang thus calls "the water of the northern essence."

The po-soul resides in the lungs, though its position remains in the west, its trigram has transformed into the joyous image of Dui, gentle and yielding. Its function adheres to the body and becomes essence, for the body is the congealing of essence.

Now, the yang qi that surges within my body, originally the prenatal qi of metal, is lead. The previous chapter metaphorically called it fire within water, but in truth, it is the liquid of metal. Thus, it is called the fat of the White Tiger, indicating it requires smelting.

Gather it into the crucible,
Timing is key when harvesting.
This speaks of the moment when essence and qi arise—precisely the time for gathering. The method lies in freely drawing them together and uniting them within the crucible, where Kan’s center becomes hollow and returns to Kun, and Li’s center becomes solid and reverts to Qian. When essence and qi return to the crucible and merge, Qian and Kun likewise unite to restore the Supreme Ultimate. This is called the *dan* head; Master Zhang refers to it as the true seed.

*Gui* means to store; the crucible is the orthodox transmission of the *Yi* Dao. The alchemists’ watchword has no visible form—it resides in the very center of the six harmonies of my body. As the ancients said, *“Within lies a true golden crucible,”* yet it has no fixed location. The *Yi* states, *“The crucible: the noble person rectifies position and congeals destiny.”*

*Shi* refers to the time of *gui* arising, the half of the living *zi*. If one has not yet awakened, simply sit upright and cultivate stillness as practice. When stillness reaches its extreme and movement begins, this is the time of *gui* arising. Swiftly withdraw the true thought and conceal it in secrecy for gathering—any turning of the mind is not it, and one must not seek it elsewhere.

In sum: the yang qi within Kan is true lead; the yin essence within Li is true mercury. Kan and Li give birth to lead and mercury, while lead and mercury arise from body and mind. The function of body and mind is essence and qi, and the substance of essence and qi is nature and life. Extracting the yang from Kan returns it to Kun; filling the void in Li restores it to Qian. When the two substances merge, qi becomes primordial qi, and essence transforms into spirit. As spirit and qi interact, Kan and Li revert to Kun and Qian. When their wondrous union congeals, Qian and Kun blend into a single Supreme Ultimate. From this, yin and yang, movement and stillness become each other’s root, firmly bound and inseparable, harmonized and indistinguishable, pure and unceasing.

Such is the method of gathering—is it not the simplest and easiest?

**Chapter Two**
This continues the previous chapter, elucidating the origins of lead and mercury and the subtle art of gathering the medicine into the crucible.

The maiden rides the lead tiger,
The golden elder straddles the mercury dragon.
The maiden is true mercury; the golden elder is true lead. Their names and meanings are explained in detail in Chapter Ten. The tiger symbolizes the body; the dragon symbolizes the mind. As Master Zhang said, *“The mind’s wildness is like a dragon; the body’s ferocity is like a tiger.”* The words *rides* and *straddles* describe the image of mutual mastery. When the two medicines are gathered into the crucible, yin essence naturally masters yang qi, just as yang qi governs yin essence, forming an undifferentiated chaos. Yet if at this moment one’s nature and emotions lack tranquility, the spirit scatters outward, and the *dan* head dissolves. One must await the later reunion of lead and mercury, as the following text urgently instructs on rectifying the mandate.

**Clarify the mandate of jia and geng,**
**Refine to a furnace of red.**
*Jia*, belonging to wood, symbolizes nature; *geng*, belonging to metal, symbolizes emotion. *Zheng ling* (rectified mandate) means an impartial, unbiased command. The character *ling* (mandate) is the top of the character *nian* (thought), forming the top of *jin* (now), while the heart has not yet appeared. Swiftly add a vertical stroke to complete *ling*, meaning that when the mechanism first stirs in the present, one must immediately straighten it within to become the mandate. Confucius said, *“Straighten what is correct,”* hence *zheng ling*. Master Bai spoke of *“the moving thought as the mysterious female,”* and the *Wenyan* of *Kun* states, *“The noble person reveres and straightens within.”* My fellow disciple, Qu Zhishan, said that removing the *xin* (heart) from *nian* (thought) implies concealing the heart, meaning that when the thought first stirs, one must immediately take charge as the commander of qi, so the heart naturally retreats and conceals without delusion. This elucidation of the true method is most illuminating.

The character *shi* (scholar) originally revealed the secret of *zheng ling* (rectified mandate) to clarify the subtle connection between heaven and humanity—a direct disclosure of the ancient sages’ heart-transmission, which no other alchemical texts have revealed! To clarify the mandate, one must first understand it in ordinary times. At this moment, merely reaffirm it, and all parts of the body will naturally follow the command.

This speaks of the moment when essence and qi first interact. One must ensure nature is tranquil and emotions are at ease to preserve harmony without dissipation. The method relies on the power of reverence and sincerity cultivated in ordinary times. When the heart has not yet stirred, swiftly clarify the way of direct nurturing and first conceal it in secrecy, naturally achieving thought within thought. Essence congeals with qi to form spirit; emotions return to nature and attain great stillness. Then the *dan* head forms, free from the risk of leakage. Mencius said, *“Nurture it directly without harm.”* *A furnace of red* refers to what alchemists call *“a furnace of flames forging emptiness,”* which is the way of refining. Mencius spoke of *“fulfillment radiating brilliance.”*

**Chapter Three**
This continues the previous chapter, elucidating that the gathering and congealing of the medicine depend entirely on nature and emotions. When correctness is attained, the spirit does not stray from its position, and qi naturally flows.

The serpent’s po seizes the dragon’s marrow,
The tortoise’s hun subdues the tiger’s essence.
The serpent symbolizes emotion, which often responds to gentleness with joy—this is the work of the po, hence *serpent’s po*. *Dragon’s marrow* symbolizes the yin essence within the mind. The tortoise symbolizes nature, which often reacts to shock with anger—this is the work of the hun, hence *tortoise’s hun*.

**Chapter Four**

*Tiger essence* symbolizes the yang qi within the body. This continues the previous chapter. Once the correct decree is made clear, emotions are forgotten and return to their original nature, so the wild and reckless *heart-dragon* is captured and its essence no longer wavers. Nature is settled and the root of emotion severed, so the fierce *body-tiger* is subdued and its qi no longer stagnates. To *capture* and *subdue* is simply to act without contrivance. Is this not what is meant by *“the tiger is tamed, the dragon is brought low, and the macaque no longer peers through the six windows”*?

Within the divine pool’s sacred water,
A single bud of jade fat blooms.

Master Zhang said: *“When lead meets mercury, it is called the Flowery Ground; when mercury enters lead, it is called the Divine Water.”* In my humble understanding, Master Zhang’s meaning is this: lead symbolizes the body, likened to a pool, and when mercury appears, its qi flourishes—hence the name *Flowery Pool*. Mercury symbolizes the heart, called *water*, and when it enters lead, spirit and essence unite—hence the name *Divine Water*. The harmonious fusion of mercury and lead is likened to *Divine Water entering the Flowery Pool*, but in truth, it is merely the spirit returning to the body and qi naturally restored! When lead and mercury have congealed, emotions are forgotten and nature is settled; the spirit’s entry into qi is like water returning to the pool. There is a master ever wakeful, like a flower bud swelling with sap, joyously flourishing; or like jade congealing into fat, dense and solid—this is but a metaphor.

This continues the previous chapter, elucidating that once the two substances have united, nature and emotion are rectified, and their substance is without duality—thus the elixir’s foundation is established!

White snow flies in the jasper garden,
Yellow sprouts emerge in the jade grove.

*White snow* refers to the body, which belongs to *kan* (☵); the single yang within *kan* is *dry metal*, hence its white color. The body’s lead is born from the overflow of metal qi, and when it meets mercury, it transforms into *Divine Water*—luminous, pure, and clear—thus resembling snow. The *jasper garden* is a metaphor for the body. *Yellow sprouts* refer to the heart, which belongs to *li* (☲); the single yin within *li* is *kun earth*, hence its yellow color. The heart’s mercury is born from the fullness of wood fluid, and when it encounters lead, it congeals and enters the *Flowery Pool*, blending and burgeoning—thus resembling sprouts. The *jade grove* is also a metaphor for this body. To *fly* and *emerge* describe how lead, upon meeting mercury, ascends and spreads as if filling the sky, while mercury, upon congealing with lead, descends and flourishes as if covering the earth.

The venerable Master Xue Zixi said: *“Without white snow, without yellow sprouts—white snow is the water of the spirit-chamber, and yellow sprouts are the flowers of the qi-pivot.”* This confirms the truth! Yet one must not seek it with intention.

Only when it resembles the recumbent moon—where then is red lead refined?

The "recumbent moon" is but a transformed image of the original mysterious aperture. Before the elixir is obtained within my body, with inner purity and stillness, the seven apertures merge into one. Within this aperture, emptiness and spirit interpenetrate, round and whole as an egg—for in quiescence, it contracts. Yet when the elixir arises, my true command arrives, and the aperture turns upward like a vessel to receive the medicine—for as it stirs, it also opens. Viewed from the side at that moment, its form resembles the recumbent moon. Once the medicine is received and darkness and oneness merge, it returns to the egg’s guarded state. For the moment a thought moves, it settles again; the mysterious aperture, though about to open, contracts once more.
