If stirred by emotion and the heart moves, the aperture will split into seven, and the medicine scatters. Thus, "resembling the recumbent moon" serves as the sign of receiving the medicine—yet this describes only its likeness, for it arises spontaneously, without form or substance to behold.

"Red lead" refers to what Master Zhang describes as *"true lead born in Kan, whose function lies in the Li palace, transforming from black to red"*—yet it too has no color or appearance. "Where then is it refined?"—for spirit has no fixed form, warning against attachment to deliberate action. This aligns with Mencius’ *"There must be engagement, yet without fixation."*

In essence, once the cinnabar head is established, medicine and ingredients arise at all times. If I can only clarify the true command, no external distractions will intrude. Within this, it naturally receives and bears the medicine. Over time, with qi replete and spirit full, the Valley Spirit becomes naturally abundant.

For the cultivator, the initial struggle lies in not knowing the aperture; once the aperture is understood, vigilance is required to guard against its severance. Withdrawing in advance is essential; purity and spontaneity are wondrous! If one can withdraw in advance, then when the moment arrives, the opportunity will not be lost, and subsequent thoughts will not disturb. Knowing this, the heart may be rectified!

This continues from the preceding chapter, stating that once the cinnabar head is established, the medicine and ingredients arise at every moment, and the more they are gathered, the more inexhaustible they become. One must never turn the mind to measure or calculate, for within this, it naturally receives and bears them—absolutely no contrivance should be employed to force growth. This aligns with Master Zhang’s words: *"One grain returns to one grain, from the subtle to the manifest,"* which merely describes the grandeur of accumulation, without any form or image to liken it to.

The medicinal material opens the primordial chaos; the firing times refine the vast origin. The "medicinal material" refers to what is gathered at the moment of collection; the "firing times" denote the process of refinement—both pointing to this essence and qi. To "open the primordial chaos" and "refine the vast origin" means that this essence and qi emerge naturally in the midst of purity and stillness, where the seven apertures return to one, as if in the unmanifest state of primordial chaos. Refining it with the intent of purity, without dividing inner and outer, is like the formless vast origin, where natural fusion and success occur. This clarifies that the medicine arises from the primordial chaos, and the firing refines it like the vast origin, further illuminating the earlier principles of the true command and the waning moon, teaching one to comprehend it with a mind free of effort rather than through labored thought.

After ten months, the immortal embryo transforms, and only then does one realize the achievement of the ninefold return. "Transformation" refers to what Master Bai described as *"shattering emptiness to reach completion,"* which is the "shedding of the embryo and spiritual transformation" mentioned below. The "nine returns" are the nine restorations. Nine is the completion number of metal, signifying the return of yang qi within the body—it does not mean nine cycles of return. It speaks of the medicine arising from nothingness, requiring refinement like the great creation’s vast origin, without any attempt to measure its appearance. Only after three hundred days, when the embryo is complete, does one recognize the initial work of gathering the body’s primordial yang qi when the elixir was first formed.

This chapter explains that in obtaining the elixir and refining it, one must not cling to forms or seek traces, for in time, its effects will naturally be known. As the *Canticle* states: *"Do not seek through examination."*

Where the dragon rightly conceals its pearl, where the hen just begins to brood her egg—who knows when lead and mercury unite? Then one may truly drink the *daogui*.

The concealment of the pearl and the brooding of the egg illustrate the wondrous inner landscape of the aperture. Once one knows to return to the single aperture, one has grasped the method of profound seclusion—one should merely focus the spirit like the dragon nurturing its pearl or the hen brooding her egg, unwavering in attention. The word "who" carries profound meaning. My teacher, Master Taixu, in his commentary on the *Nine Heavens’ Heart-Seal Repentance Text*, explained: *"Neither self nor other, inexpressible yet forcibly called ‘who.’"* The word "who" appears eleven times in this text, and each instance may be understood in this light. To say *"who knows when lead and mercury unite"* means only to conceal the spirit in seclusion, guarding purity and stillness, without distinguishing what is other or primary, what is self or guest, nor concerning oneself with whether the two substances unite—this is the true wondrous union without separation.

The *daogui* refers to the two earths, *wu* and *ji*, both numbered five. Originally, they shared the same position at the center, but after birth, they were lodged in *kan* (Water) and *li* (Fire). The yang within *kan* is the essence of *wu* earth; the yin within *li* is the refined essence of *ji* earth. The ancients called this the *"principle of the kan-li daogui,"* while earlier scholars referred to it as the *"essence of the two fives."* The character *dao* (刀) is composed of the first stroke of *wu* (戊) and the first stroke of *ji* (己); the character *gui* (圭) is formed by combining the two earths. This composition holds profound meaning, illustrating that *kan-wu* and *li-ji* meet in perfect accord. At that moment, no intervening substance exists, and they unite at the center—hence the term *daogui*. It teaches one to use the initial intent, which is the true command—the primordial truth of the limitless, the essence of the two fives, wondrously conjoined and coagulated, as the earlier sages described.

What Laozi’s *Classic of Constant Purity and Stillness* calls *"formless, passionless, nameless, forcibly named the Dao"* is the true meaning of the word "who" in my teacher’s commentary—a Dao that may be employed when the primal unity is met.

The first and subsequent thoughts, once attached to form, though initially correct, fall into the posterior heaven, instantly turning into deliberation. The two earths are then separated by the nature of wood and the disposition of metal. The qi, being the *wu* earth within *kan*, flows into breathing, and the water palace cannot preserve its source. The essence, being the *ji* earth within *li*, seeps into the bladder, and the spirit chamber cannot secure its dwelling. Thus, water-essence and fire-spirit cannot assist each other, and the four images no longer serve me—how then can lead and mercury unite to coagulate the immortal embryo? Therefore, the cultivator must regard the ability to drink the *daogui* as the correct method for uniting lead and mercury.

To say *"then one may truly drink"* means that at the moment when lead and mercury first arise—when the celestial heart stirs in stillness, issuing the true command—this is precisely when the two substances have coagulated and may be refined. It does not say "use" but "drink," implying the self-awareness of drinking water or broth, hot or cold. Where my intent perceives, it naturally regulates the firing, illustrating the wondrous function of the true command, where correct awareness resides within its use. Yet the work remains solely in purity, stillness, and unbroken continuity.

From this, one may understand that even a brief moment of effort already encompasses the process of refinement. For the union occurs at the stirring of the thought, in an instant; refinement, being subtle and withdrawn, requires a span of time to firmly establish the union, achieving natural coagulation. Thus, before the union, one works within the effortless effort, sitting in meditative stability to gather and collect. When the medicine arises, one practices effortless effort within effort, abiding in great stability, thoughtless and actionless—this is the refinement. This is the subtlety within subtlety, not easily conveyed in words. Yet having spoken of it, the explanation becomes overly verbose.

Let the reader condense and refine it, embodying and illuminating it—this lies with the individual.

**Chapter Seven (concluded above)**

This continues the preceding chapter, elucidating the Dao of refinement: it requires only unbroken continuity, as Master Bai said, "Guarding against discontinuity and distraction is the defense." Bathing relies on the Water of Kun; gentle nurturing depends on the Wind of Xun. At this stage, if thoughts are not closely guarded, the fire scatters, and the body feels a chill. Yet by simply returning to the correct command, the spirit reverts to the center, and qi naturally returns—true qi steams throughout the body as a bath, warming it within. This is called "relying on the Water of Kun" because one’s bodily form has already transformed into the primordial, and the northern position is no longer the postnatal Kan trigram; thus, this natural bathing qi is termed the Water of Kun. If distracting thoughts arise and disrupt the fire, the body feels restless heat. Yet by turning back to the correct thought to quell agitation, the inner stillness remains focused, and true breath gently nurtures, bringing coolness throughout—this is harmony within. This is called "relying on the Wind of Xun" because, once the Kun body has reverted to the primordial, the southwest region is originally the Xun palace of the nose; thus, this natural nurturing breath is termed the Wind of Xun. This is the subtle remedy for balancing cold and warmth—when the spirit returns, qi follows of itself, and one need not seek it in the qi aspect. Master Bai took vigilant awareness as the practice of firing, true qi’s steaming as bathing, and the cessation of thought as nurturing the fire—his method is precise!

The infant has no affairs, dwelling alone in the Palace of Grand Tenuity. The infant refers to the spirit formed when the yin essence of the heart has coalesced with yang qi, returning to reside in the original palace of the Celestial Valley—this is called the Valley Spirit. The ancients likened it to an infant, for at this stage its power is still weak and requires one’s correct thought to constantly maintain vigilant awareness. The Palace of Grand Tenuity, in the heavens, is the Grand Tenuity Enclosure, where the Emperor’s seat resides at the center; in humans, it is the Central Palace among the nine palaces of the head—the Mud Pill Palace, the dwelling where the Valley Spirit nurtures the true. My teacher often said the infant is the true person, who must be nurtured in leisure and idleness, quietly and alone, to cultivate the original spirit. His meaning is profound! This is the light of self-nature. Within the human body, only this is true nurturing. When the true body manifests, it is the Perfected One of the wondrous Dao.

**Chapter Eight (concluded above)**

This continues the preceding chapter, stating that after refinement, one must bathe. If cold and warmth are unbalanced, it is always due to the spirit straying outward and thoughts disturbing within—one must swiftly correct the fault. Tending to the infant, dwelling alone in the Upper Valley, in purity and non-action, allowing qi to circulate naturally—this is the remedy for harmony, without startling the spirit. If the spirit is startled, it clings to phenomena and remains adrift in the cycle of birth and death.

From the preceding chapter to this point, the principles of the elixir foundation, gathering, union, refinement, and bathing have been fully expounded. Yet their essential teaching lies in maintaining thought for gathering, concealing thought for absorption, stillness of spirit for union, extinction of delusion for coagulation, focusing qi for refinement, and absence of delusion for tempering. For when delusion is extinguished, correct thought endures; when correct thought is concealed, delusion does not arise—the method is upright, simple, and unburdensome. The following seven chapters continue from this, elucidating the Dao of gentle nurturing, parting the embryo, and smelting—all is a single flavor of purity, entirely without contrivance, left to the individual’s intuitive grasp and devoted practice. The phrase "focusing qi" comes from the *Daodejing*, meaning one should be as full of qi as an infant, acting as its own master without the heart’s interference.

Seeking the Maiden of Li in the Purple Court,
Matching the Lad of Kan in the Vermilion Mound.
Where the Yellow Dame mediates,
The Supreme Ultimate naturally embraces the Three.

The Purple Court symbolizes my body; the Vermilion Mound, my heart; the Yellow Dame, my intent. My humble observation: the postnatal body resembles the Kan trigram of the north, Kan being water, its color originally black. To revert to the primordial Kun trigram, one must seek the yin within the Li of the south to receive it. Li is fire, its color red; the intermediate hue of red and black is purple, hence "seeking the Maiden of Li in the Purple Court." The maiden is the yin within Li, meaning the postnatal Kan body returns to the primordial Kun body. The postnatal heart resembles the Li trigram of the south; to revert to the primordial Qian trigram, one must seek the yang within the Kan of the north to match it. The Vermilion Mound is the name of a cave in the Southern Marchmount, symbolizing the dwelling of the heart; hence "matching the Lad of Kan in the Vermilion Mound." The lad is the yang within Kan, meaning the postnatal Li heart reverts to the primordial Qian heart. Yellow is the color of earth; "Dame" is an honorific for an elder woman. The Yellow Dame refers to one’s correct thought. At that time, when refining the postnatal heart and body, one first seeks the yin essence within the heart to match the yang qi within the body. When yang qi obtains yin essence, it ascends directly; yin essence relies on yang qi’s refinement to form spirit, which then returns to its original palace in the Celestial Valley. All depends on one’s correct thought, first retreating and concealing to mediate in secret, thus embracing the three families of body, heart, and intent into a single Supreme Ultimate, forming this Valley Spirit. The Valley Spirit arises from the coagulation of essence and qi; correct thought is singular, illuminating its correct command, naturally merging within—without claiming it as an achievement, hence "the Supreme Ultimate naturally embraces the Three."

**Chapter Nine (concluded above)**

This continues the preceding chapter, elucidating that the return of body and heart depends solely on one’s sincere intent to unite them as one aperture. The following chapter will reiterate and clarify this.

The Qian horse drives the Golden Gate...

The Gold symbolizes emotion, for once the Vermilion Mound is paired with the Kan male to form Qian, one may employ the Way of firmness and strength to govern emotion. Thus, the spirit naturally conceals itself in secrecy, ever dwelling in the Celestial Valley to nurture one’s nature. Yet who brings this about?

The Kun ox enters the Wooden Palace.
The Wood symbolizes one’s nature, for once the Purple Palace obtains the Li maiden to form Kun, one may employ the virtue of softness and compliance to guide one’s nature. Thus, qi naturally fills the void, ever attending the Mud Pill to nurture life. Who indeed enables this?

*Who then escorts the Alchemical Maiden,
To wed the Golden Elder?*

The maiden is the yin essence within Li, which enters Kan to become Kun. As it departs from Li to return to Kun, it transforms into qi, resembling a maiden returning to her dwelling—hence the name *Alchemical Maiden*. The Gold is the yang qi within Kan, which enters Li to become Qian. As it departs from Kan to return to Qian, it refines into spirit, resembling a youth maturing into age—hence the name *Golden Elder*. The phrase "to wed" signifies the yin essence’s departure from Li to enter Kan, thereby pairing Kun with Qian, illustrating how the heart becomes the dwelling of the body and the body conceals the heart, evoking the image of a bride following her husband. When the yin essence departs from Li to join Kan, the yang qi’s departure from Kan to enter Li goes without saying!

At that time, had it not been for my correct command—clarifying its virtue and foreseeing the future while concealing the past—how could qi have nurtured form to achieve softness and compliance, or essence have refined into spirit to achieve firmness and strength? Now, with the compliant form paired with the firm spirit, they wondrously coalesce into the profound obscurity of the Supreme Ultimate. Nature and emotion each attain their proper state—whose power is this?

---

**My humble note:** The *Golden Gate* refers to the Dui trigram, which symbolizes the gate of Qian’s metal palace. *The Qian horse drives the Golden Gate* represents the *Ze-Tian Guai* hexagram, a time when yang qi is already abundant. The *original palace* refers to the Gen trigram, which symbolizes the palace formed by Kun earth harnessing Wood. *The Kun ox enters the Wooden Palace* represents the *Shan-Di Bo* hexagram, a time when yin essence is already abundant. The *Alchemical Maiden* refers to the single yin atop the Bo hexagram, returning to her dwelling to form Kun. The *Golden Elder* refers to the Guai hexagram. The line *"Who then escorts the Alchemical Maiden, to wed the Golden Elder?"* corresponds to the alchemical saying, *"Half a catty must pair with eight ounces."* Here, the eight yang lines in the four yang hexagrams are likened to half a catty, while the eight yin lines in the four yin hexagrams are likened to eight ounces. Together, they form the eight trigrams, completing a full catty.

This speaks of the moment when yin and yang are equally robust. If one has not long cultivated reverence and sincerity, forging an unwavering, vigilant, and steadfast correct thought, who could withdraw the heart and conceal it in secrecy, allowing the single yang atop Bo to naturally pair with the single yin atop Guai to form Qian, while the single yin atop Guai returns to Bo to form Kun? Thus, the body fully embodies Kun’s softness and compliance to nurture qi, and the spirit returns to Qian’s firmness and strength to govern form. From this point, one draws upon the origins of beginning and generation, repeatedly cycling through *Gou* and *Fu*, endlessly transforming. This also clarifies the meaning of the *Auspicious Qi in the Bridal Chamber* in the following chapter, offering a more direct explanation.

However, in the highest-grade alchemical Way, past masters framed their teachings within the principles of the *Yijing* without explicitly mentioning hexagrams or lines, instead providing concrete guidance to ensure accessibility for both the refined and the common. When encountering learned scholars, one may observe the images and ponder the words to directly penetrate the profound meaning. When addressing the unlearned, one must avoid language steeped in classical principles, lest it obstruct their perception. Thus, in annotating this text, it is fitting to focus on the tangible elements within the human body, speaking plainly and precisely, so that all may see and understand without needing to seek images or delve into abstractions—thereby upholding our teacher’s compassionate vow of universal deliverance.

This chapter addresses the *Golden Gate* and *Wooden Palace* symbols, which the primary commentary did not clarify, lest their meaning be lost and stray into heterodox paths. Thus, I have drawn upon the *Guai* and *Bo* hexagrams to elucidate their concrete manifestations, revealing how their mutual transformation gives rise to *Gou* and *Fu*, averting the calamity of excess and avoiding the regret of overweening yang. May all reflect upon this.

---

**Chapter Ten (concluded above)**
This further clarifies the preceding chapter’s principle that the return to the primordial depends entirely on the merit of secretly concealing one’s correct thought. For since the initial coagulation of the Elixir’s foundation, spirit and qi have daily grown stronger, gradually enabling the separation of the embryo. One must then redouble efforts to preserve abundance, conceal the spirit, and nurture qi.

*The Alchemical Maiden is but sixteen,
The Golden Elder is precisely nine-three.*

The Alchemical Maiden symbolizes the qi transformed from my yin essence. *Sixteen* represents the number completing a catty, signifying that the weight is now sufficient. The Golden Elder symbolizes the spirit coagulated from my yang qi. *Nine-three* signifies that the inner yang is complete, resembling the lower trigram of Qian reaching its third line.

This speaks of the stage in elixir refinement when the body’s spirit and qi are both robust, poised to separate the embryo. Yet one often becomes restless and unable to remain still. If one indulges in impatience, qi will agitate the heart, and the Valley Spirit will struggle to find tranquility—there has never been abundance without overflow. Thus, the phrase *"but sixteen, precisely nine-three"* precisely marks the firing times, teaching one to remain vigilant according to the season, neither arrogant nor anxious. With inner beauty contained, anger and desire naturally do not arise, and the separation of the embryo proceeds without harm.

*Auspicious qi arises in the Bridal Chamber,
Their joyous union births the First Son.*

The *Bridal Chamber* symbolizes my body, the secret aperture of concealment. The *arising of auspicious qi* refers to the vigorous stirring of yang qi within my body, the sign of the original life’s return and the initial foundation of the yang spirit. *Bearing the First Son* signifies the initial conception of the yang spirit, resembling *Zhen* as the eldest son, which, when added to Qian, forms the *Lei-Tian Da Zhuang* hexagram—a single yang first stirring in the outer trigram.

This speaks of the stage when the body’s qi is robust and the spirit further retreats into concealment. Suddenly, yang qi surges forth, joyously uniting with the spirit. In an instant, the Valley Spirit transforms into the yang spirit.

Just as the First Son is newly born, so too does the original life return—this marks the Valley Spirit’s accomplishment, whereby one may preserve the spirit and attain immortality.

**Chapter Eleven**

This describes the phenomenon of the original life’s return, elucidating the Dao of natural *fen tai* (separation of the embryo). Should one read this and awaken to its meaning, when yang flourishes to the point of excess—corresponding to the *Guai* hexagram—one must swiftly retreat into concealment, whereupon the upper trigram reverts to its initial state. This is what Confucius meant by “knowing the future and concealing the past.” The *Guai* hexagram interchanges with *Gou*, just as *Bo* interchanges with *Fu*, and from this foundation the yang spirit is born. Only then does one comprehend why the “use of nine” and the “use of six” are both auspicious and free from regret.

---

Last night on the western riverbank,
The toad’s glow illuminated the jade-green waves.
Gathered and returned to the Jade Chamber,
Within the crucible, the sun’s refining fire burns.

“Last night” refers to the time of the original life’s return. The *west* is the *Kan* trigram’s primordial position; *Kan* is Water, hence “western river.” The *toad* embodies lunar radiance, and “toad’s glow” symbolizes the upward breakthrough of yang qi. Whenever the text speaks of the yang spirit’s initial foundation, it invariably likens it to the toad, for its three legs and upward-shining light. The “jade-green waves” represent the *Kan* trigram’s postcelestial qi within the body’s form—*Kan* Water is inherently black, but when illuminated by the toad’s glow, it becomes jade-green, hence “jade-green waves.” The *Jade Chamber* symbolizes my body, for once the original life returns, spirit and qi become dense and flawless, thus called the Jade Chamber. The “crucible” refers to the spirit chamber. “Refining fire” alludes to the method of “concentrating qi as the cooking fire, taking non-delusion as the alchemical process.”

This speaks of how, in the past, my original life’s return arose from the postcelestial *Kan* trigram, when the body’s spirit and qi were abundant. Suddenly, yang qi surged forth, breaking through the Celestial Valley to merge with the spirit and transform into the yang spirit. Now, the body has reverted to the primordial, the *Kun* trigram resuming its northern position, while *Kan* retreats to the west. Looking back, it is as if last night, on the western riverbank, I witnessed the toad’s light illuminating the water. I gathered it and returned to the spirit chamber, refining it so that it self-coalesces and simmers, feeling only a gentle warmth without any visible sign of refinement. Thus, it transforms into the yang spirit, and life is restored! This is the Dao of the Jade Talisman preserving the spirit, whereby the Valley Spirit may not die.

**Chapter Twelve**

This continues the previous chapter, stating that once the original life has returned, one must preserve and harmonize the Great Harmony to ensure proper advantage.

---

*Li* and *Kan* do not copulate;
*Qian* and *Kun* spontaneously generate.
Should one comprehend this principle,
A single point descends into the Yellow Court.

This speaks of how, in the past, my postcelestial heart and body united, nominally called “conjunction,” yet like the sun and moon forming a single disk, it was not true copulation. At this moment of life’s return, though called the union of *Qian* and *Kun*, it is in truth only the spirit’s concentration and qi’s gathering, naturally giving birth to a single Taiji. Should one grasp this principle, then when alchemical texts speak of “a single yang within the body, a single yin within the heart, referred to as two things,” they are but different names for the same origin. Their encounter is a wondrous spontaneous harmony, coalescing into a single right thought. When the thought settles and returns to concealment, it descends into the Yellow Court.

The *Yellow Court* refers to a single aperture, the secret place. *Yellow* is the central true color; *Court* signifies emptiness and boundless space, hence the name. Yet one must not seek it through form.

**Chapter Thirteen**

Building upon the preceding chapters, this elucidates the essential principle that the beginning and end of the alchemical Dao are wholly rooted in spontaneity, and that the two must merge into one.

Within the Cinnabar Valley, spirit-water is born;
In the Yellow Court, the Great Granary abides.
No longer thoughts of hunger or thirst arise—
Straightaway one enters the immortal realm.

The *Cinnabar Valley* is another name for the Crimson Palace within the human body; the *Yellow Court* has already been discussed in the previous chapter. Here it is said that the central valley naturally generates qi, which spirals upward from the lower valley to meet the spirit, thereby producing spirit-water that irrigates the entire body. Thus, the Valley Spirit is ever visited by qi, just as the Great Granary ceaselessly stores and then releases spirit-water to fill the body. Within the body, there is a nectar that irrigates without thirst, free from any overflowing appearance; the Valley Spirit possesses a sustenance that satiates without hunger, devoid of any stored form. Knowing this, one need not heed the worldly discourse on nourishment, and the heart is free from any fear of hunger or thirst. If even hunger and thirst are no longer a concern, what other thoughts could arise? One may then settle the mind and withdraw inward, directly reaching the immortal realm—this is the teaching of a single thought unborn, myriad illusions all stilled.

This chapter, continuing from those above, instructs one to uphold the right thought, withdraw into concealment as the work, and never allow the mind to stray into other concerns, lest the great immortal Dao be misled.

The *Intent Steed* returns to the Spirit Chamber—
With single-minded retreat and concealment, the spirit naturally does not scatter; once returned to concealment, it is the Heavenly Heart.

The *Heart Ape* guards the Grotto Chamber—
All conditions are set aside, the heart abides within the body; in this state of non-doing, it too is concealed.

Spirit, essence, ethereal soul, corporeal soul, and intent
Transform into *Purple Gold Frost*.

Essence is stored in the kidneys; when kidney qi is whole, essence rests securely in the kidney viscus, and one attains wisdom.
Spirit is stored in the heart; when heart qi is whole, spirit rests securely in the heart viscus, and one attains propriety.
The ethereal soul is stored in the liver; when liver qi is whole, the ethereal soul rests securely in the liver viscus, and one attains benevolence.
The corporeal soul is stored in the lungs; when lung qi is whole, the corporeal soul rests securely in the lung viscus, and one attains righteousness.
Intent is stored in the spleen; when spleen qi is whole, intent rests securely in the spleen viscus, and one attains trustworthiness.

Thus, each of the five viscera receives a single qi and possesses a single virtue. If one’s intent is sincere and the heart upright, the five qi are all whole and each rests in its proper viscus, and the five virtues are likewise complete. This is the Confucian teaching of “unity running through all” and “withdrawing into concealment,” which is also the alchemical method of gathering the five phases and returning them to a single aperture. When the five qi converge as one, they may congeal into spirit—this spirit is the elixir.

The *elixir* of the Complete Realization school is none other than the *ren* (kernel) of the Confucian school, as in the kernel within a fruit’s pit. It is called *purple* because the initial golden elixir is formed through the union of water and fire—water is black, fire is red, and their intermingling produces purple, hence Master Guan Yin once saw Laozi’s qi as purple. It is not called *elixir* but *frost* lest one cling to the word and mistake it for a tangible pellet, thereby accumulating delusive thoughts and creating qi stagnation in the body, which would be gravely misleading. Thus, it is likened to frost formed from scattered dew, visible in its traces yet ungraspable when gathered, evoking the image of empty space pulverized. This illustrates the wondrous arising of the golden elixir’s real form within the formless, hence it is called *Purple Gold Frost*.

These two chapters further demonstrate that human cultivation and nurturance share the same workings as heaven and earth. How so?

Heaven suspends its images to cover all things, yet it nurtures only the imageless—thus its images grow ever more luminous, perpetually covering the myriad beings without end. Earth solidifies its form to bear all things, yet it nurtures only the formless—thus its form grows ever more vast and deep, perpetually bearing the myriad beings without leakage. Man dwells within form to complete all things, yet if he can nurture the formless, his form will endure ever more enduringly, encompassing the transformations of heaven and earth without transgression, shaping the myriad beings without omission. Thus may he attain longevity and lasting vision, his wisdom pervading all categories, his blessings flowing through eternal ages—standing as the third between heaven and earth.

Hence Master Bai said: *"If man is not burdened by form, the Great Brahma Heaven lies before his eyes."* He also said: *"Forget form to nurture qi, forget qi to nurture spirit, forget spirit to nurture emptiness, forget emptiness to merge with the Dao."* This single word *forgetting* is none other than *no-thing*. *"Originally there was not a single thing—where could dust alight?"* Why then cling to distinctions of what is essence, what is spirit, what is hun or po, what is intent? All returns to the single secret of nurturing the formless, allowing the natural flow of qi-transformation to fulfill the utmost sincerity of one’s inherent nature without cease.

**Chapter Fifteen (conclusion)**
This chapter, building upon the preceding ones, elucidates that the golden elixir has no substance, teaching that the initial work of practice lies solely in sincerity and undividedness—nurturing the formless to merge with the imageless and formless. Then the upright qi will naturally flow through heaven and earth, and the primordial spirit will spontaneously gather within the body, all attained through the wondrousness of natural purity. As Li Ninan said: *"The three-in-one sound-symbol,"* and Master Zhang: *"Grasp the foundation of Kan and Li, and the three realms return to one body."*

From the first chapter to this point, the text forms a comprehensive summation. The following nine chapters expound upon the crucial apertures and the nurturing of the elixir, further clarifying the meanings of the preceding chapters.

*"One aperture, three passes—the three passes are the key pathways.
Suddenly, with light movement, the divine water flows throughout."*

The *one aperture* refers to the single aperture where the seven orifices return to their root. The *three passes* are: refining essence into qi as the lower pass, refining qi into spirit as the middle pass, and refining spirit into emptiness as the upper pass—this is the supreme path of elixir refinement. Some identify the three passes as the postural points of *weilu* (tailbone), *jiaji* (spine), and *yuzhen* (jade pillow) at the back, or the frontal points of *queqiao* (magpie bridge), *jiangong* (crimson palace), and *guanyuan* (pass of origin). Our tradition also adopts this interpretation for the foundational work of dredging the *du* and *ren* meridians, dissolving long-standing illnesses and impurities to facilitate the unimpeded flow of true qi in later stages. Yet this is achieved solely through emptying thoughts and forgetting emotions, without further contrivance. Here, however, the *three passes* need not be confined to such interpretations.

The *aperture* refers precisely to this single opening within the true body—the pivotal pathway where essence accumulates, qi gathers, and spirit congeals. One need only attain emptiness and guard stillness, nurturing to the point of formlessness, until suddenly the lead and mercury respond in unison—essence has transformed into qi, naturally ascending to the valley, becoming the *five qi returning to the origin*. At that moment, spirit and qi interact, qi transforms into spirit, spirit condenses and qi gathers, transmuting into divine water that fills the entire body—this is the *divine water entering the Flower Pool*. Allow it to circulate and move without cease, naturally and spontaneously, beyond the grasp of cognition, while one’s spirit remains abiding in unshakable stillness—thus is the *three flowers gathering at the crown* achieved.

From this, I realized that the transmutation of essence into qi, qi into spirit, and spirit into emptiness to merge with the Dao depends solely on the mutual forgetting of heart and breath within the formless and insubstantial. The method begins with interdependence, gradually withdrawing into concealment. From this interdependence in nothingness, concealment itself dissolves into the inconceivable—this is *mutual forgetting*. Profound and ever-quiescent, this is the transmutation into emptiness; when quiescence reaches its limit, it is the refinement of emptiness to merge with the Dao.

My teacher, Master Taixu, once said: *"The learning of heavenly immortals revolves around the three—essence, qi, and spirit—turning within a single aperture, like a child in the womb, unmeasured and ungrasped, the mother nurturing the pregnancy without attachment, mother and child mutually forgetting yet at peace. It is like a pearl in a crystal dish, rolling freely and vividly, naturally round and luminous, without the slightest residue or obstruction. Unlike other methods of elixir refinement, which rigidly prescribe set durations for refining essence into qi, qi into spirit, and spirit into emptiness—failing to recognize the secret of this single pivotal aperture, they cannot approach such intimate and authentic practice, resorting instead to trivial techniques, empty words, and arbitrary timelines, leading practitioners into confusion and error."*

This is the heart-transmission of our tradition, the supreme method of elixir refinement. For our tradition’s heart-transmission necessarily takes the *concealment of spirit in undifferentiated transformation* as the work of heavenly immortals. Thus, in examining the treasury of our lineage, every detail is clarified with concrete evidence. In guiding practitioners, we first teach them to seek the master within, urging earnest diligence in all matters, fostering simplicity and sincerity in every action. Then, when commencing elixir refinement, subduing the tiger and descending the dragon, refining the hun and restraining the po become effortless. Returning to the secret of the single aperture, one directly reaches the source of the three passes—this is no longer difficult. Thus, the *Great Return Elixir of Golden Liquor* is accomplished in three hundred days.

All fellow practitioners, take heed: do not be misled into mistaking a cavity near the spleen, imagining the ascent and descent of qi, calling it *qi surging*, *essence dripping*, *spirit numinous*, or *emptiness void*—such misconceptions sever the root and obstruct the source, only compounding errors.

As one who hungers and eats salt, only to grow ever thirstier, you shall never attain the day of forging essence into spirit, nor reach the hour of refining emptiness to merge with the Dao. In vain you sit rigid, exhausting qi and straining spirit, unaware that the foundation of the elixir may be laid in an instant, that the workings of creation may be set in motion within a single body—how lamentable indeed.

**Chapter Sixteen (Right)**
This chapter reveals the secret of the single aperture that turns the pivot, and particularly clarifies the principle of blending qi and essence to forge spirit. All is the efficacy of serene quiescence, of nurturing the formless.
*To restrain the po is not the heart’s restraint.*
To nurture the formless is to let the *shen* of consciousness die and the *Valley Spirit* live; when the Valley Spirit lives, emotions fade, and when emotions fade, the po is extinguished. Yet it is only one who first masters the heart who can restrain it—the heart itself is not what restrains the po.
*To constrain the hun is not the mind’s constraint.*
When form is forgotten, the seven apertures merge and the single aperture shines; when the single aperture shines, true nature manifests, and when true nature manifests, the hun is stored. Only one who holds to this can constrain it—how could the mind constrain the hun?
*Only abide in spirit and qi.*
When the hun is stored, spirit is whole; when the po is extinguished, qi is full.
*In a fleeting moment, the Mysterious Pearl is formed.*
As spirit and qi interact, they naturally congeal. "Mysterious" evokes its profound abyss; "Pearl" evokes its luminous purity—hence the *Mysterious Pearl*.

**Chapter Seventeen (Right)**
This continues the preceding chapter, elucidating that by nurturing the formless, qi naturally becomes abundant and spirit naturally finds its refuge.
*The oral instructions are few; the elixir is refined in a moment.*
The oral instructions for refining the elixir are contained in the two lines from the previous chapter: *"Only abide in spirit and qi."* The meaning lies entirely in the phrase *"few in number"* and the *"fleeting moment."* Yet how spirit and qi are to be conjoined and abided in, how they congeal in that moment—there exists a simple and effortless method, namely, the *"not even half a phrase"* referred to in the original preface by Master Shizi. When the practitioner’s effort becomes pure and mature, wisdom arises from stillness, and enlightenment comes naturally, seizing the initiative—this is what is meant by *"attained without the least exertion."*
*Gently tend the fire’s timing; in ten months, the infant is born.*
Do not idly watch the furnace and monitor the fire’s timing; simply settle the spirit and quiet the breath, letting nature take its course. When qi is focused and thought is still, no errors arise. Nurtured for three hundred days, it naturally becomes as lively as an infant emerging from the womb, manifesting the image of *"the dragon seen in the field"*—a metaphorical expression.

**Chapter Eighteen (Right)**
This continues the two preceding chapters, introducing the intent of the following six chapters.

The preceding two chapters speak of gathering and uniting; this chapter highlights the two-character oral formula and instructs that when applying the formula, the fire’s timing must be gently tended. The following six chapters elaborate on bathing, the division of the embryo, gentle nurturing, and the completion of the elixir.

When husband and wife first unite in joy,
Their love deepens with the passing years.
Auspicious qi arises in the bridal chamber,
Where spring’s breeze blows without cease.

Husband and wife symbolize mind and body; the bridal chamber symbolizes the single aperture; the spring breeze symbolizes gentle warmth. This speaks of how mind and body, initially conjoined through the coagulation of essence and qi to form spirit, already feel inseparable in their joyous union. After refining through firing and bathing, accumulated over days and months, their harmonious bond grows even deeper than at first. In their constant union, true qi naturally steams and bathes them, its warmth as gentle as sitting amid spring’s breeze. The reader must take care not to let the words obscure the meaning.

Master Zixian Xue has a song that says:
*"True husband, true wife—
When Kan’s man and Li’s woman unite in resonance,
The sky and earth reveal their dew in dustless emptiness."*
This depicts the luminous scene within the single aperture—how could the slightest dust of delusion remain?

**Chapter Nineteen (Right)**

This continues from the preceding chapter, speaking of how prolonged firing and refining naturally give rise to the bathing of true qi, still measured by its gentle warmth—seemingly no different from the effects of firing and refining. Yet one must not mistake this: when the medicine coalesces within, the initial application of fire must be meticulous, and this is called "firing and refining." Later, as true qi constantly ascends to pay homage, suffusing the entire body, its warmth and moisture are called "bathing." Thus, firing and refining arise from the timing of fire, while bathing is the medicine’s natural power—hence Master Bai’s dictum, *"Take action and cessation as advance and retreat."*

Firing and refining are action; bathing is cessation. Action is advancing the fire, where effort is employed within effortlessness. Cessation is retreating the fire, where effort is applied within effort that seems without effort. This distinction must not be overlooked.

*"Sudden rain on paper butterflies,
Golden furnace with jade peonies.
At midnight, the red sun blazes;
In midsummer, pristine frost chills."*

The first line depicts peril; the second, danger. Midnight signifies cold; midsummer, heat. The red sun dispels cold; pristine frost dissolves heat. In the Dao of the Elixir, when the embryo is growing, the mind often stirs restlessly, unwilling to abide in stillness—yet the firing times demand non-action and non-effort. If the spirit is truly settled and still, with no thought within thought, the work is pure and nothing need be feared. But if one’s prior refinement of the self remains impure, at this stage of non-action, thoughts will inevitably arise, and the spirit will scatter outward. The peril is like paper butterflies in a sudden rain; the body grows cold as midnight. Only the blazing red sun can warm it, drawing the spirit back to the Celestial Valley, where cold instantly retreats and warmth returns. If thoughts grow restless, the spirit turns fiery; the danger is like jade peonies in a golden furnace, the heart burning as in midsummer. Only the chill of pristine frost can cool it, returning qi to the Crimson Palace, where heat naturally subsides and moisture is restored. The key is to maintain no thought within thought, movement as stillness, and always keep warmth and moisture as the measure.

Yet how can midnight yield the sun, or midsummer yield frost? If one seeks remedies at this point, how can they be effective? Little does one realize: midnight is precisely the *zi* hour, and midsummer is when the sun stands at *wu*. Cold is always likened to midnight, heat to midsummer—these vivid warnings of reckless action conceal a hidden opportunity to seize the moment and turn the tide. If one awakens to where the primordial embryo resides, one may then begin to regulate and harmonize. For those who have not yet grasped the method, read the next chapter.

**Chapter Twenty (Right)**
This continues from the preceding chapter, explaining that during the cessation of fire and bathing, all depends on the spirit’s stillness and qi’s movement to achieve fullness and bring about the division of the embryo. Should thoughts stir and qi scatter, peril ensues—hence Master Bai’s warning to *"guard against interruption and lack of focus."* Here, one may awaken to this truth. Those whose prior refinement of the self runs deep will not suffer this affliction. Those with the resolve to cultivate the Elixir—can they not first rouse themselves to vigilance?

*"Golden fire flies from the sea’s depths,
Earthen springs flow from the mountain’s peak.
In a moment, their union is complete—
The Jade Crucible emits blue smoke."*

The sea’s depths signify the *weilu*; the mountain’s peak, the crown of the head. Golden fire is the fire of life; earthen springs, the water of nature. Their union signifies harmony achieved in secrecy; the Jade Crucible, this single aperture of mystery. The rising blue smoke is the sign of warmth and transformation.

This continues from the preceding chapter, addressing how midnight may yield the sun: one must direct the true command to fly the pure yang fire of Kan’s dry metal from the sea’s depths at the *weilu*, ascending to the crown and returning to Qian—like the blazing red sun suffusing the body with harmony. How may midsummer yield frost? By guiding the pure yin spring of Li’s earthly soil from the mountain’s peak downward to the sea, returning to Kun—like pristine frost’s chill restoring warmth and moisture throughout the body. Though divided into two lines, the process is seamless: ascending from below to return to Qian is "flying golden fire," while descending from above to return to Kun is "flowing earthen springs." This is the method of advancing fire and retreating tally found in other alchemical texts. Through such regulation, in but a moment, the entire body becomes warm and harmonious, like the crucible emitting smoke—no further pursuit of qi is needed.

Yet this is ultimately not natural but a last resort for remedy. Otherwise, the treasure of life should not be lightly tampered with—Master Zhang has warned of this in detail.

In sum, the study of human nature and life hinges entirely on guarding the mind like a fortress. Thus, when King Wen expounded the *sixth three* of *Kun* in the *Book of Changes*, he appended the phrase, "containing brilliance, it may be steadfast." This concludes the twenty-first chapter.

This follows the preceding chapter to elucidate the methods of remedy.

**My humble observation:** The nineteenth chapter above expounds the proper way of natural bathing; these two chapters teach the means to remedy deviations. This is why Master Bai spoke of the practices of "operation, withdrawal, and addition."

Break open the Gate of the Mysterious Origin, surge through the Pass of Primal Chaos.
The Gate of the Mysterious Origin refers to the singular aperture of the mysterious image. "Breaking open" signifies that when the seven apertures return to the root—this one aperture—it suddenly opens wide, revealing at once the original True Unity. Rooted before the ten thousand images, it penetrates the inner and outer of the physical form, utterly void and utterly non-existent, utterly wondrous and utterly mysterious. One feels only boundless obscurity beyond measure, vast and unbounded beyond all shores or banks. Immeasurably great, it has no exterior; infinitesimally small, it has no interior. It encompasses heaven and earth, yet enters the tip of a hair. Above, there is no further color; below, there is no further abyss. A single thing, perfectly rounded, manifests through the ages—this is the moment when the seven apertures are unified and the Mysterious Pass stands wide open.

The Pass of Primal Chaos describes the time when qi has flourished, and the yang spirit dwells alone in the Celestial Valley, receiving the homage of qi, yet remaining in a state of undifferentiated chaos, like an egg in its shell. "Surging through" means that at this stage, the medicinal force is sufficient, the fire force complete—so vast and unyielding that it cannot remain hidden. One’s Valley Spirit has already perceived the Mysterious Origin, and the true aperture suddenly bursts open. Thereupon, the Yellow Center connects with principle, and the correct position is assumed within the body. Its qi then pervades heaven and earth, its spirit governs the Dharma-body. Suddenly, one feels thunder roaring and lightning flashing, shaking the cosmos. Immediately, the hundred vessels stand erect, the Three Passes are penetrated, and the entire body becomes pure yang, burning like fire. This is no mere metaphor but the true landscape.

The preceding line dissolves the former hardships of refining thoughts and washing the mind, condensing the six days into one return to the root. The following line directly points to the Great Dao of the Golden Elixir, unifying the seven through the one, nurturing it straight and without harm. As Laozi said, "Returning to the root is called stillness; stillness is called the restoration of life." Only at this point is the original life fully restored.

In short, in the postnatal realm, it pertains to body and mind, and the work must proceed from movement to stillness to return to the prenatal. Once returned to the prenatal, it pertains to nature and life, and the work naturally shifts from extreme stillness to movement, exhibiting the image of "perhaps leaping in the abyss." Without the diligent and secret cultivation of life from day to night, how could one attain this?

Yet know only to refine water and fire, and let the tiger and dragon coil freely.
Refining water and fire is the practice of gentle nurturing, which will be explained in the next chapter. The tiger originally symbolized the body but now represents qi; the dragon originally symbolized the mind but now represents spirit. At this stage, the Mysterious Aperture has been broken open, and there is no need to remain secluded in the physical form for hidden cultivation. However, the original nature has not yet been restored, much like the *nine in the fourth* of the outer hexagram *Qian*, where Confucius said, "Above and below have no constancy; advance and retreat have no regularity." It means one cannot ascend to join heaven, nor descend to unite with earth; one has not yet merged with the Dao in advance, nor secured the body in retreat. This is a time of concentration yet to be settled, when one can only gather the sack inward and nurture the sagely work. Like the spring emerging at the foot of the mountain in *Meng*, the noble one, through resolute action, cultivates virtue, nurturing stability as water. Like the fire kindling at the foot of the mountain in *Bi*, the noble one, through illuminating governance, dares not impose harsh judgments, nurturing wisdom as fire. Such is the refinement, which must be pursued to the end without presuming completion.

Thus, in expounding the perfect formula of *The Heart Transmission of the Heavenly Immortals*, I say: "The Three Powers guard the egg; the Yellow is the field of blessings. I dwell within it, blending Kun and Qian." This still means that spirit and qi congeal in sincerity without duality, while nature and life are concealed within the aperture of emptiness and spontaneity. Let the dragon and tiger coil freely, awaiting the meeting of wind and cloud—only then may one hope for the elixir’s completion.

*(Lin’s respectful note: My teacher once told others, "To seek the essentials of the Golden Elixir, study the *Qian* and *Kun* of the *Book of Changes*, and the Dao will be complete." Lin once read the *sixth six* of *Kun* and the *ninth nine* of *Qian* and awakened to the method of gathering and refining. Reading the *first nine* of *Qian* alongside the *first six* of *Kun*, I understood the method of congealing. Reading the *second nine* alongside the *second six*, I grasped the method of refinement. Reading the *third nine* alongside the *third six*, I knew the method of bathing. Reading the *fourth nine* alongside the *fourth six*, I saw that after the embryo’s division, one must practice gentle nurturing. Reading the *fifth six* alongside the *fifth nine*, I attained the method of elixir completion. Re-reading the *sixth six* and *ninth nine* alongside the *use of nine* and *use of six*, I finally awakened to the method of transcending life and death. Thus, the Duke of Zhou’s appended judgments urge one to contemplate the omens, while Confucius’ *Tuan*, *Xiang*, and *Wenyan* elucidate their subtleties—truly, one may observe the images to know change and contemplate the words to know the omens! The meaning of reading the *Book of Changes* is appended here.)*

This concludes the twenty-second chapter.

This chapter continues from the preceding one, stating that once the bathing is complete, there naturally arises the method of embryo division—precisely what Master Bai referred to as "shifting the spirit to change the cauldron." In truth, there is nothing to divide and nothing to shift; it is merely that one’s knowledge and vision expand until Heaven and humanity are no longer separate, and spirit and qi fill the body until self and other are without boundary. Only through thorough and gentle nurturing does the elixir’s completion become apparent. Yet the work of gentle nurturing may not yield timely results, for this depends on the practitioner’s habitual sincerity in solitude, which determines the speed of attainment.

Within the waters of Śāketa lies fire,
Atop Kunlun’s peak surge waves.
Who can fathom their operation?
The great meaning lies with the Yellow Dame.

Here, "within the waters of Śāketa" refers to the sea’s depths, and "atop Kunlun’s peak" to the mountain’s summit. Though these two lines appear identical to the opening couplet of the twenty-first chapter, the earlier passage used "flying and circulating" as methods to restore the physical form, signifying that at this stage, the spirit has settled into its proper position to secure destiny, and qi has penetrated both internally and externally. One then knows that within the world exists the sea of Śāketa, wherein one’s wisdom-life is concealed, and atop the summit of Kunlun dwells one’s settled nature. There is no east or west, no distance, no ascent or descent of water and fire—only the boundless, upright qi flowing freely, with all things nurtured together in the sacred work of gentle cultivation. Its operation differs greatly from the time before the barrier was opened. One need only maintain a single-minded, steadfast, and reverent focus, avoiding restlessness and impatience to keep the body at ease, harmonizing with the world while remaining untainted—thus may the return of the original nature be hoped for.

Master Xue of Zixian composed a song:
*"Water is true water, fire is true fire,
As before, await the season to circulate the heavens,
Harmonizing and refining to attain the treasure of eternal life."*
This clarifies the method of operation.

This concludes the twenty-third chapter.

This chapter continues from the preceding one, precisely pointing to the method of gentle nurturing to sustain fullness.

The medicine is drawn from the primordial qi,
The fire is sought in the essence of Taiyi.
Knowing how to draw the medicine and seek the fire,
Within stillness, the elixir’s completion is seen.

Here, "medicine" refers to the qi of the five—spirit, essence, soul,魄, and intent—which, when unified and directed toward the origin, coalesce into the nebulous primordial spirit of pure yang qi, known as the primordial qi. "Fire" refers to the essence of the three treasures—essence, qi, and spirit—which, when transformed and gathered at the crown, internally congeal into the true qi of Taiyi, yielding the pure yin essence within the heart, known as the essence of Taiyi.

My fellow disciple, Master Qu, observed: *"In the* Spring and Autumn Unification Diagram*, the five stars of the Northern Dipper reside in the Purple Tenuity Palace, the celestial abode of the Heavenly Emperor, which is the essence of Taiyi. Its position, slightly south of and near the Celestial Unity, corresponds to the crown of the human head, enabling direct resonance with the human heart."* This principle is well-founded, for it is the very origin of the primordial union of yin and yang at the moment of human birth.

I have also verified this with the seventeenth chapter, which describes what is obtained at this stage as the marrow of Heaven and Earth. Heaven and Earth are the Supreme Ultimate, so the essence of Taiyi derives from the Supreme Ultimate—precisely as Master Hequ described: *"In the profound and obscure, the Supreme Ultimate flows its essence."* Yet the Supreme Ultimate is invisible, so it is likened to Taiyi, which governs Heaven. Thus, the essence of Taiyi in the Purple Tenuity Palace is clearly the essence flowing from the Supreme Ultimate, and it is fittingly called the marrow of Heaven and Earth. However, this need not be discussed in detail.

In essence, humanity and Heaven’s qi are originally interconnected. At this stage of cultivation, one constantly unifies the true qi of the five directed toward the origin with the primordial spirit of the three treasures gathered at the crown, preserving it continuously as if in stillness, with the heart like cold ashes and the mind in profound obscurity. Naturally, one’s original nature returns. This is to seek the essence of Taiyi as fire and gather the primordial qi as medicine, using fire to refine the medicine—within stillness, the elixir is completed. As Master Bai said: *"It may be met without intention, but cannot be sought with intention."*

Thus, Master Xue of Zixian composed a song:
*"The medicine is not a thing, the fire is not a season,
Clearly, it is but a single spark of yang,
Refined into boundless longevity for ten thousand kalpas."*
I need only guard it secretly within the formless purity of stillness, and naturally, fire will forge the spirit—this is *"within stillness, the elixir’s completion is seen."* To seek it with knowledge would be like Zhuangzi’s *"Yellow Emperor losing the Dark Pearl, sending Knowledge to seek it in vain."*

This concludes the twenty-fourth chapter.

This chapter synthesizes the preceding twenty-third chapter, elucidating that from gathering to elixir completion, the process does not depart from the simplicity of Qian and Kun—methods that are easy to know and simple to practice. With the right mindfulness, in natural purity and undivided unity, after three hundred days of effort, one may thereafter roam freely beyond the world, playfully traversing the human realm, coming and going without hindrance, in harmony with the Dao.

**My humble note:** From the first chapter to this twenty-fourth, the discourse on the elixir path is now complete. However, regarding the stages of transmutation, gathering, union, refinement, bathing, embryo division, and gentle nurturing, it is necessary to employ metaphors to express the teachings and to make distinctions for clarity. Yet I fear that later practitioners may cling to the words and become mired in the imagery, mistaking them for tangible, deliberate actions and thus failing to awaken suddenly. Even if one grasps the truth, one may still err in believing that both methods must be employed, becoming entangled in the complexities of ascent and descent without realizing their unity. Even if one understands their unity, one may still, after refining the Valley Spirit, retain the duality of inner and outer without awakening. For the true body originally encompasses form and dharma as one, inherently penetrating both internally and externally. Therefore, the following text further clarifies the twenty-fourth chapter to elucidate the central meaning of the preceding discourse. Though it occasionally employs metaphors drawn from things, its purpose is to dispel doubts at every turn, to expound the true teachings in every chapter, and to let the lingering resonance of its song convey meaning beyond words.

The flavor is profound and enduring—one should savor it deeply.

How does one ingest primordial qi?
True essence requires no transference.
True essence and primordial qi—
these are the foundation of the Great Elixir.

The qi produced within my body is formless primordial qi, unlike tangible food that demands a method of ingestion. The essence born of my heart is immaterial true essence, unlike external objects that are dense and heavy—thus, it need not be moved. If one knows how to gather the medicine and kindle the fire, one realizes that medicine is fire, and fire is medicine. True essence and primordial qi are one in two, two in one—clearly the foundation of the Great Elixir.

**Chapter Twenty-Five**
This chapter continues the twenty-fourth, clarifying that the foundation of the Elixir lies solely in the union of these two—essence and qi—with nothing further to seek externally.

Confucians elucidate nature and principle,
Buddhists strike at empty nothingness.
Unacquainted with the immortal’s art,
the Golden Elixir’s work is instantaneous.

This speaks of how, in that era, the sagely Way and Buddhist Dharma both lacked true transmitters. Confucians merely clarified nature and principle without investigating the primordial life that is the root of nature; Buddhists merely struck at empty nothingness without exploring the primordial nature that is the essence of life. Thus, they failed to recognize the immortal’s unified Way. What is called refining the medicine with fire to form the Elixir is simply guiding qi with spirit to attain the Dao—this is exhausting principle, fulfilling nature, and realizing life.

Alas!
The former sages of Confucianism composed the *Zhouyi* and *Zhongyong*,
while the World-Honored One of Buddhism expounded the *Vajra* and *Perfect Enlightenment*.
If one takes and contemplates each of these,
one will see that the immortal’s art of the Golden Elixir is the art of benevolence—
it can establish merit in an instant, transform the entire body,
and fulfill what the early Confucians called “mastering the one, and all things are complete.”
Only then will one know that since ancient times, the world has never had two Ways,
and the sages of the Three Teachings have never had two hearts.

**Chapter Twenty-Six**
This chapter, following the preceding text, laments that people do not know how to unite essence and qi to form the Elixir. With boundless compassion, it admonishes the followers of the Three Teachings, urging them to explore the heart-transmission of the Three Sages, practice the same art, and universally deliver all beings.

Mercury in the crescent-moon furnace,
lead in the cinnabar tripod.
Tortoise and snake—true unified qi,
born in the prior heavens.

The crescent-moon furnace refers to the place within the human body where the furnace for refinement may be established, without being confined to a specific location. Cinnabar symbolizes the heart, and the term *tripod* signifies that the human heart is inherently empty, capable of containing and refining things. The tortoise and snake were mentioned in Chapter Four; here, they further elucidate the meaning of the first chapter, stating that the lead and mercury within body and heart originally derive from the true unity of yin and yang, all born in the prior heavens. One need only attain emptiness and tranquility to observe their return—nothing is to be sought externally.

Thus, the Purple Sage Xue Zixiao sang:
*“Crescent-moon furnace, cinnabar tripod—
know to embrace the One and guard harmony,
heedless of passing through gates or casting into the jade well.”*
Master Xue was a disciple of Master Shi, having received the true transmission of this chapter and composed this song.

**Chapter Twenty-Seven**
This clarifies that the furnace, tripod, medicine, and fire are all present from the beginning of one’s life, lamenting that people remain unaware and do not practice.

New moon, full moon, crescent, and dark—
waxing and waning, drawing and adding.
Unknowing of true creation and transformation,
what thing is true lead?

New moon, full moon, crescent, and dark are images of waxing and waning. *Xun* means to turn, not to seek. *Drawing* means reducing when full, *adding* means supplementing when empty—all occur naturally. *Creation* is the arising of being from non-being; *transformation* is the return of being to non-being—both follow nature. The Way of the Elixir takes nature as its model. The human body naturally has movement and stillness; the qi mechanism naturally has concealment and activation, just as the moon in the sky has its phases of new moon, full moon, crescent, and dark. One draws and adds according to its waxing and waning—there is never a month of unbroken fullness. If one does not recognize waxing and waning as the true mechanism of creation and transformation, then after the first crescent and before the new moon or dark, seeking the moon’s emergence in the west at dusk will be in vain. This illustrates that before obtaining the medicine, the cultivator of the Elixir should embrace stillness as the body and guard true lead as the function. If the initial stirring of *gui* has not yet occurred, it cannot be seen. Even if one searches the entire body, what thing can be true lead? This further elucidates the meaning of Chapter Two: *“To gather, one must know the time.”*

**Chapter Twenty-Eight**
The preceding chapter having clarified the source of the medicine, this chapter points to the time of its arising, hoping that all may know and practice.

Qi is the life within form,
the heart is the spirit within nature.
Knowing the cavity of spirit and qi—
this is attaining the immortal.

Form is the body. The body relies on the stem of life—true qi—to live, so qi is the life within form. The heart is the heaven of nature, the abode of primordial spirit, so the heart is the spirit within nature—meaning the heart is the chamber of spirit. In sum, nature and life are the roots of body and heart; spirit and qi are what body and heart emit. Thus, knowing that body and heart are the support of nature and life, body and heart are the cavity of spirit and qi. The perceptive person who obtains this true cavity, gathers and stores it, has established the profound foundation of life. Without this knowledge, where does one begin the cultivation of the immortal?

**Chapter Twenty-Nine**
This further elucidates the function of body, heart, nature, and life, relying solely on spirit and qi. It hopes that people will suddenly awaken to the method of return and restoration, thereby reverting to the source.

Refining the golden tripod with wood marrow—
wood symbolizes nature. Nature relies on the heart, and the single point of true essence within the heart originally arises from the root of nature—this is one’s primordial essence, like the marrow of wood. Thus, it is called *wood marrow*, clarifying the source of mercury.

**Chapter Thirty**
Gold represents the primordial Qian virtue, for the primordial heart originally belongs to Qian. Thus, the heart is metaphorically called the *golden heart*, upon which nature relies. Nature is inherently without flaw, so it resides in the heart, which possesses all principles to respond to the myriad affairs—just as smelting gold into a tripod allows it to regulate water and fire to refine the five flavors. Hence, it is called the *golden tripod*. The heart is fundamentally pure; when untouched by external things, it remains free from blemish, and its essence and marrow can be refined into spirit. Yet since birth, unrefined by cultivation, it is stirred by sensory desires and scatters outward, laboring the heart and becoming enslaved by form. How then can one refine the elixir and expect it to congeal essence into mercury? Thus, one must first clarify the correct decree, refining the heart with clarity and stillness to restore its original nature and primordial spirit. When lead arises, true mercury is produced, congealing into spirit. Hence the metaphor: *"wood marrow refines the golden tripod."*

The spring flows into the jade furnace—
*"Spring"* refers to water still within the mountain, unemerged, symbolizing one’s life. Life depends on the body, and the single point of true qi within the body originally arises from the root of life—this is one’s primordial qi, like a flowing stream with its source. Thus, it is called *spring flow*, clarifying the source of lead. Jade embodies the primordial Kun substance, for the primordial body originally belongs to Kun. Thus, the body is metaphorically called the *jade body*, upon which life relies. Life is inherently vigorous, so it abides in the body; at midnight, when a single yang stirs, it is like carving jade into a furnace, where warmth and qi grow ever more temperate. Hence, it is called the *jade furnace*. The body is fundamentally still; when untouched by external things, it remains free from illness, nourished by fetal breathing to mature. Yet after engaging with the world, if one does not return to reflection, the qi mechanism stirs, flowing into essence and causing leakage. To refine the elixir, this qi is still too turbid. One must first uphold the correct thought, guiding qi to gather within the body, settling and purifying it. Only then does the primordial qi naturally stir, refining mercury into spirit. Hence the metaphor: *"the spring flows into the jade furnace."*

Who among the bustling world
would ponder life and death,
rectify the root and purify the source of heart and body’s essence and qi,
refine them into gold and jade,
and devote three hundred days of effort,
neither forgetting nor forcing, steadily cultivating?

**Chapter Thirty-One**
The preceding chapter has fully revealed the origins of spirit and qi, seemingly sufficient for sudden awakening and return to the source. Yet for those who remain unenlightened, their long-ingrained habits run deep—spirit dull, qi turbid—obstructing the numinous gateway, preventing thorough realization. Thus, they are taught to rouse the spirit, refine and purify, awaiting the moment to begin the firing process.

The jade tripod refines lead liquid—
The tripod symbolizes the chamber of spirit. When the master within, refined as in the previous chapter, becomes luminous, the spirit is as flawless as jade. Hence, it is called the *jade tripod*. When lead qi arrives, mercury fire is kindled to refine it, forming spirit water. Thus: *"the jade tripod refines lead liquid."*

The golden furnace nurtures mercury essence—
The furnace symbolizes the sea of qi. When the upright qi within, as in the previous chapter, is settled and purified, it naturally congeals like gold. Hence, it is called the *golden furnace*. When qi arises, it must encounter mercury essence, which is then harmoniously nurtured, entering the flowery pond. Thus: *"the golden furnace nurtures mercury essence."*

Nine returns are nine revolutions—
The meaning of *nine returns* as *nine revolutions* was explained in Chapter Six. Properly gathered, it is the way of refining and conjoining. *"Like the revolving stars"* refers to the celestial bodies that govern the four seasons and the fixed times of dawn and dusk, all following the heavens’ ceaseless motion, naturally revolving around the pivot without error. This illustrates the method of bathing and nurturing.

This chapter’s main point clarifies that spirit is fire, qi is the medicine. When fire meets medicine, it fiercely refines; when medicine encounters fire, it firmly congeals, forming the returned elixir. *"Refining"* and *"nurturing"* describe the process from conjoining and refining to the steadfast stillness of the Qian way, nurturing through bathing and embryo division until the elixir is complete.

**Chapter Thirty-Two**
This chapter explains the correct method of conjoining. The fire jujube has no pit; the conjoined pear bears no dregs. All day, tend the fire and timing—spirit water irrigates the golden flower. *"Fire jujube"* symbolizes the true mercury refined from lead into the elixir. *"Conjoined pear"* symbolizes the elixir’s beginning, where mercury and lead merge. *"Spirit water"* was explained in Chapter Four; *"golden flower"* is the flowery pond. Spirit has no pit, qi has no dregs—simply maintain stillness and emptiness all day, nurturing the formless. Naturally, spirit congeals into the qi cavity.

**Chapter Thirty-Three**
Jade liquid nourishes the chamber of spirit; the golden embryo forms the pivot of qi. Seek only the medicine within the body—no need to consult alchemical texts. *"Jade liquid"* refers to heart qi; *"golden embryo"* refers to the leaden heart. When qi is sufficient to become spirit, it can refine the elixir. Thus, one must first cultivate heart qi to nourish the chamber of spirit, so that when lead is encountered, they merge into an embryo. Once the embryo’s qi is formed, the body’s qi mechanism flows like the celestial revolution, following the heavenly pivot without straying. Here, spirit is the pivot of qi. When Kun constantly congeals, qi gathers without fail—all is the medicine within the body, sought only within. Alchemical texts of past ages merely clarify the main principles, teaching inner self-cultivation rather than textual study.

The Way of *"lead and mercury forming the true body"* as spoken in the first chapter is achieved naturally. This is what Laozi meant by *"being brave in non-action to attain life."* Master Zixian Xue composed a song: *"The true交梨, the true fire-jujube—after eating the交梨, the four limbs grow refined; when swallowing the fire-jujube, ten thousand kalpas are sated."* Do you not believe it?

---

This is Chapter Thirty-Three, expounding the correct method of refinement. The next chapter will address the errors of those who practice *"refining qi"* and *"preserving spirit,"* lamenting their failure to grasp the subtlety of the highest-grade true instructions.

Refining qi is but wasted effort;
Preserving spirit is mere labor.
How could they know the marvel of the elixir’s secret?
All day, one delights in the true void.

*"Delights"* is like the roc soaring ninety thousand *li* and resting for six months—never straying beyond the heavens. *"True void"* refers to spirit as real and qi as empty. When I merge spirit into the qi cavern, both the perception of emptiness and the emptied realm are swept away together, and the entire body becomes utterly transparent, inner and outer as one true void. *"Delighting in the true void"* is what Master Haichan meant by *"illuminating the body, longevity abides in the non-empty void; the numinous mirror embraces heaven and contains the ten thousand things."*

Human true qi should only be nurtured, not refined—let it circulate freely, and it will become clear and unobstructed. Yet some refine qi: if not through *"transporting,"* then by *"breath-holding."* They do not realize that breath-holding and transporting are techniques used in talismanic practices, where one temporarily stores qi in an emptied realm to deploy it, creating an illusion of efficacy. This is refining through deliberate effort. If true qi is already circulating naturally and one still refines it, they shackle their qi. Shackled qi becomes stagnant and blocked, inevitably leaking out unconsciously during sleep—wasted effort, laboring in vain. Such methods belong to lesser alchemical traditions, still clinging to the emptied realm, failing to grasp the error of those who do not perceive inner and outer as one.

Moreover, the primordial spirit should only be settled, not preserved through effort. By constantly withdrawing and concealing it in secrecy, it remains real and not empty. Yet some preserve spirit: if not through *"fixed contemplation,"* then by *"silent invocation."* They do not realize that fixed contemplation and silent invocation are practices used in ghostly rituals, where one feigns reverence through the perception of emptiness to achieve resonance. This is preserving through deliberate focus. If the elixir’s spirit is already serene and one still preserves it, they disturb their own spirit. Disturbed spirit becomes restless and unsettled, inevitably drifting into wandering thoughts and delusions—wasted effort, achieving nothing. These are the errors of the Buddhist Two Vehicles, still mired in the perception of emptiness, unable to forget both self and dharma.

Chen Niuwan’s *Cui Xu Yin* enumerates these flaws, all stemming from a failure to comprehend the true one’s correct instructions, leading to futile labor and endless harm. How could they know the marvel of the highest-grade elixir’s secret? It long ago sweeps away both the perception of emptiness and the emptied realm, achieving a true void without obstruction. Spirit naturally conceals itself in secrecy, nurturing the formless; qi naturally fills the void, converging at its ultimate point.

From the moment of the *"living zi hour"* after the correct union until the onset of the next *"living zi hour,"* one remains serene throughout the day, using activity and rest as the fire-timing. Rising with the sun, one acts like the roc in flight; retiring at dusk, one rests like the roc at ease. When hungry, eat; when weary, sleep. Respond to affairs as they come, return to stillness when guests depart. The ten thousand things cannot disturb my non-awareness; heaven and earth cannot enslave my formless being. I let the six qi circulate freely, while I alone contain the myriad existences in sincerity.

This is the marvelous secret of *"all day practicing the fire-timing"* from the previous chapter and *"all day delighting in the true void"* in this one. Why then do those who refine qi and preserve spirit labor in vain?

---

This is Chapter Thirty-Four, continuing from the previous chapter. It speaks of the life-treasure, which should not be lightly tampered with—merely concealing qi within qi without comprehension, concealing spirit within spirit without awareness. Thus, one neither clings to emptiness nor to nothingness, like a fish in water, leisurely and content. When things arise, respond with integrity; when they depart, remain vast and impartial—naturally and solely present.
